title: WASHINGTON TALK/Working Profile: Jamsheed K. A. Marker; Linchpin of U.S.-Pakistan Alliance
description: Take a strategically situated country that receives large amounts of economic and military aid from the United States, that is developing the ingredients for a nuclear bomb and that is next door to a country torn by civil war for the last eight years.

title: Among Fall's Glories, Graceful Vines
description: AMONG the greater pleasures of early September I number the vines that cloak the pergola above our backyard deck. The hardy kiwi vines have yet to produce fruit, even though there's a male planted in a harem of three females to assure this eventual result. But they produce a pleasant afternoon shade.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning 11 A.M. - Guy Forget vs. Stefan Edberg. Second match - Martina Navratilova vs. Elly Hakami.

title: Quiksilver Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
With the Talents of a 'Missionary and a Showman,' He Revived the Library
description: In his seven years as president of the New York Public Library, Vartan Gregorian presided over the physical and financial revival of an institution that had fallen on hard times.

title: KOREANS CRITICIZE INTELLIGENCE UNIT
description: South Korea's powerful army intelligence service, long free from scrutiny and accountability, is facing unusual public criticism after senior intelligence officials ordered the knifing of a journalist who had criticized the military.

title: Argentina Wants Talks
description: Argentina wants to meet foreign bankers next week to start talks on financing part of its $56 billion debt, a senior Argentine official said Tuesday. The Central Bank Director, Daniel Marx, said Argentina had worked out its negotiating stance and wanted to reach a quick but lasting agreement. If accepted by the bank steering committee that negotiates on behalf of Argentina's 480 commercial creditors, next week's talks would concentrate on the nation's financing needs through next year.

title: Power, Lynn to Tigers
description: The Detroit Tigers, trying to hold on to first place in the American League East, obtained a pitcher, Ted Power, from the Kansas City Royals and Fred Lynn, an outfielder, from the Baltimore Orioles yesterday a few hours before the midnight deadline for postseason eligibility. Lynn was acquired for three minor league players to be named. Power was obtained for two players from the Toledo farm team, Rey Palacios, a catcher, and Mark Lee, a left-handed pitcher.

title: Showcase Cosmetics reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: American Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Even in his younger years, Walter Smith was not the best of drivers. But as age began to rob this rural Minnesotan of good vision and hearing, agility and quick reflexes, he became an increasing hazard on the road.

title: Chesterton Aphorisms Found in 2d Writer's Book
description: In 1910, a now-forgotten British writer popular in his time, Holbrook Jackson, wrote: ''In a beautiful city an art gallery would be superfluous. In an ugly one it is a narcotic.''

title: Unemployed Can Be Trained by Repairing a Crumbling New York
description: To the Editor:

title: New Yorkers Roll Up the Welcome Mat
description: ASK a New Yorker, ''My place or yours?'' and the reply often will be an emphatic ''Neither.'' The excuses given for not inviting people home are legion. Lack of space, a reality of New York living, is a principal one. A highly cultivated desire for privacy, for retiring to a hideaway, is another. Logistics - you are in TriBeCa, I am at 96th and Second Avenue - and the lack of time also figure high on the list.

title: U.S. Overpayments To Banks Are Cited In College Program
description: The Education Department may be paying banks and other lenders millions of dollars each year in excess subsidies on student loans, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Somerset Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income of $23,000 for the quarter and a loss of $13,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: Removing Furniture's Top Layers Of Paint
description: LEAD: MANY coats of paint have been cleaned off old furniture in a misguided effort to get down to the original look - a natural, unpainted finish. That practice now seems like reckless destruction, for much of the character of the furniture (to say nothing of the value) is lost in the process. Today the merest suspicion of original paint on an old piece is enough to increase the price.

title: International Yogurt reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Operetta; A Retouching of Herbert's 'Naughty Marietta'
description: Victor Herbert's ''Naughty Marietta'' has been a mainstay of the New York City Opera, but apart from the sets, everything about the run that opened Tuesday night is new. The book and lyrics have been retouched (inoffensively) by Theodore Pappas; as director and choreographer, Mr. Pappas has brought the ensemble to a new level of execution, and all members of the cast are fresh in their roles. There are some things missing, but the company has done well here.

title: Two Other Candidates Widen the Selection; Photo ID for Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Tokyo Stock Prices Plunge With the Dollar Up Sharply
description: Share prices plunged this morning in thin trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, while the dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen.

title: Corporate Prison Term For Allegheny Bottling
description: In an unusual ruling, a Federal district judge has sentenced the Allegheny Bottling Company to three years' imprisonment and a fine of $1 million for a price-fixing scheme involving soft-drink bottling companies between 1982 and 1985.

title: Maxwell Posts 2% Profit Rise
description: The Maxwell Communications Corporation, the publishing group headed by Robert Maxwell, today reported a slight increase in its first-half profits.

description: The Toronto-based real estate concern, Olympia & York Developments Ltd., said it had raised its stake in the Campeau Corporation to 28.4 percent, from 27.3 percent.

description: b-Nete loss

title: Lower Wilson Bid From Doskocil
description: The Doskocil Companies, carrying out a threat made last week, lowered its offer for the Wilson Foods Corporation, valuing the meat packing company at about $124 million, instead of $127 million. Doskocil, which makes pizza toppings, lowered its bid to $12.25 a share, from the original price of $12.50 that was offered in July. Wilson's shares subsequently fell in over-the-counter trading, to $12.375, down 12.5 cents.

title: All Yields Rise Again
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were all up again for the week ended yesterday. In the New York market, yields on liquid savings accounts remain particularly attractive.

title: Nicholas Cortland, Actor, 47
description: Nicholas Cortland, a stage, film and television actor, died of AIDS on Aug. 21 at his home in Manhattan. He was 47 years old.

Stockholder Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Paul Schrader Talks of 'Last Temptation' And His New Film
description: When Paul Schrader was hired in 1981 to write the screenplay for ''The Last Temptation of Christ,'' his contract included a potentially explosive clause. If Martin Scorsese did not direct the film - and for six long years it looked as if the controversial project would never get started -Mr. Schrader must be offered the next shot at it. The author of scripts for two of the best-regarded Scorsese films, ''Taxi Driver'' and ''Raging Bull,'' Mr. Schrader has also directed seven films of his own. His latest, ''Patty Hearst,'' is scheduled to be released Sept. 23.

title: Review/Theater; Life, Death and Gossip
description: Reaching for metaphor, ''Dreamland'' embraces pretension. The play, at Theater for the New City, was written by Bina Sharif, who, as an actress, shares the stage with Cameron Foord. As directed by Rolf Johannsmeier, ''Dreamland'' begins gravely on an earth-filled landscape. Two wraith-like, white-gowned figures writhe on the ground and then rise as if returning from the dead. At first, they talk about turnips. As one says, ''You have traced the root of the turnip.'' Then they forage less deeply into the meaning of life.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Account
description: * The National Ski Areas Association and Ski Industries America to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/Chicago.

title: Beatrice Bond Prices Dip
description: Prices of the Beatrice Company's high-yield bonds dipped 1 to 2 percentage points yesterday in response to a published report that the company might pay its equity investors special dividends totaling as much as $800 million.

title: Santiago Journal; Can Cuba Be Fun Again? Yes, but No Sex Please
description: Out on the Caribbean coast east of here, a new resort is gearing up for its first winter season. In the capital, the old Havana Hilton, now called the Havana Libre, is being remodeled. At the glorious white-sand Varadero Beach a new airport for jumbo jets is nearing completion and several more hotels are going up.

title: Ocilla Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
Varity Discusses Fruehauf Purchase
description: The Varity Corporation, a Toronto-based equipment manufacturer, said it was discussing the possible purchase of the Fruehauf Corporation, the Detroit-based transportation equipment maker. Varity said it would like to retain the Kelsey-Hayes Company, Fruehauf's automobile parts unit, and would consider spinning off Fruehauf's trailer business. No agreement has been reached, the company said.

title: West Bank Drivers: A Good Offense
description: When Israeli schools reopen soon, bus drivers in the West Bank will be armed and ready.

title: Private Brands reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Angola Confirms Pullout by Pretoria's Forces
description: A top Angolan military officer confirmed today that all South African troops had left Angola, as South Africa reported on Tuesday.

title: Gregorian Is Chosen as President of Brown University
description: Vartan Gregorian, the exuberant Armenian immigrant who restored the fading New York Public Library to its place at the heart of American intellectual life, was chosen yesterday as the 16th president of Brown University.

title: U.S. Court Backs Orchestra In Canceling Redgrave Pact
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Boston Symphony Orchestra did not violate the civil rights of Vanessa Redgrave, the actress, when it canceled her performances. The orchestra took the action in 1982 after threats of protest against the actress's support for the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Too Young to Choose Not to Be a Mother
description: To the Editor:

title: Gasoline Chain's Chief Buys Khashoggi Unit
description: John D. Castellucci is a self-made business executive who parlayed a plumbing supply company into a $100 million chain of gas stations in Southern California. Now, he also has something in common with Adnan Khashoggi, who likes to portray himself as the ''richest man in the world.''

title: Ketchum/Hicks Gets Ciba Laxative Account
description: Ketchum/Hicks & Greist, a unit of Ketchum Communications, has been awarded another Ciba consumer pharmaceuticals account. The product, Fiberall laxative, was recently acquired by the Ciba-Geigy unit, based in Edison, N.J., from S. C. Johnson & Son Inc. The budget, expected to be more than $5 million, would be significantly more than S. C. Johnson had spent in the past on the account, which was previously with Grant/ Jacoby, Chicago.

title: Corrections
description: A Finance/New Issues report in Business Day yesterday misstated the name of the issuer for $100 million of mortgage-backed bonds. It was Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan Association of Glendale, Calif., not First Fidelity Bancorporation.

title: Hungary-Rumania Rift Unresolved
description: The Hungarian Communist Party spokesman acknowledged Tuesday night that a meeting last Sunday between the Hungarian and Rumanian party chiefs, the first such encounter in 11 years, had disappointed most Hungarians.

title: Mallard Coach reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are unavailable because the company went public in March 1988.

title: New York Sets Stiff Rules On Waste
description: The State Environmental Commissioner issued the state's first comprehensive set of solid-waste regulations today, calling them the most sweeping and among the toughest in the nation.

title: Reagan Agrees to Pay Raise Of 4.1% for Federal Workers
description: President Reagan agreed today to a pay increase of 4.1 percent for most civilian employees of the Federal Government, double what the Administration had contemplated but in line with an increase endorsed by Congress.

title: Bush the Front Runner
description: Before the conventions, it was generally conceded that George Bush was running substantially behind Michael Dukakis. Today, pollsters, pundits, sages and savants opine in unison that Mr. Bush has caught up and pulled ahead.

title: Iran Is Said to Use 'Pressure' on Iraqi Captives
description: A United Nations report on prisoners in the Persian Gulf war accuses Iran of using ''mental pressure'' to turn Iraqi captives into pro-Khomeini militants who could riot if forced to return home.

title: Postal Account To Rubicam
description: The United States Postal Service has again turned to Young & Rubicam, its agency of 14 years, to handle its advertising. The budget is $40 million, 60 percent of it going to broadcast and print advertising.

title: Waivers for Birdsong Cram Injured Gondrezick Signs
description: The Nets asked waivers yesterday on Otis Birdsong, who has spent 7 of his 11 years in the National Basketball Association with them, and signed Kevin Williams, a former star guard at St. John's, who had been waived by the Miami Heat. ''It was a difficult decision for us to make,'' said Harry Weltman, the Nets' general manager. ''We wish Otis the best of luck, and by making the decision now provide Otis the adequate time to make the best deal for himself with another N.B.A. team.'' Birdsong, who is 6 feet 4 inches, has scored more than 12,000 points in his career, but averaged only 10.9 a game last season. The signing of Williams came only 48 hours after the Nets traded Dallas Comegys to San Antonio to obtain another former St. John's star, Walter Berry. Williams spent the last two seasons with the Seattle SuperSonics, averaging 6.3 points in 80 games last season.(AP)

Coca-Cola Issue Totals $300 Million
description: The Coca-Cola Company offered $300 million worth of money market preferred stock yesterday through a syndicate led by Shearson Lehman Hutton. The offering consisted of 3,000 shares of stock priced at $100,000 per share, and was offered in four tranches of $75 million each.

title: Damon Spurns Bid Worth $225 Million
description: The Damon Corporation, a medical technology company, said it had rejected an offer of $24-a-share, or about $225 million, from the Nomad Acquisition Corporation and had authorized management to explore alternatives.

title: Manufacturer Admits Defects In Pacemakers
description: A Miami company pleaded guilty today to Federal criminal charges that it had sold cardiac pacemakers that could suddenly fail to regulate the proper functioning of the heart.

title: U.N. Chief Tries New Tack in Gulf Talks Impasse
description: The Iran-Iraq peace talks remained deadlocked tonight after Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations submitted a new compromise proposal, United Nations officials said.

title: Home Improvement
description: CARTRIDGE faucets, found in many newer kitchens and bathrooms, are easy to repair. Such faucets are turned on with a single lever or knob. They can be readily distinguished from other single-control faucets: a rotating-ball faucet, for example, has a dome-shaped top; a tipping-valve faucet has a spindle-shaped control handle at the rear; a disk faucet has a short control lever that is part of a stubby, large-diameter cap covering the top of the faucet.

title: Mandela Moved to Private Clinic
description: Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned black nationalist, has been moved from a hospital to a private clinic while he recuperates from tuberculosis, the Government said today.

title: What if the Vincennes Had Been 'Star Wars'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Carlyle Investors Lifts Oakite Stake
description: A unit of the Carlyle Group Inc., a Washington investment firm, has raised its stake in Oakite Products Inc. to 12.2 percent, from 9.9 percent. The unit, Carlyle Investors V L.P., last week sweetened its offer for Oakite to $45.50 a share in cash. The firm's earlier $44-a-share bid had been rejected by the board of the chemical company, based in Berkeley Heights, N.J. The Oakite board is scheduled to consider the new offer next Wednesday.

title: Teamsters and Producers Try to Bar Strike
description: Negotiators for producers and the teamsters union were scheduled to meet Thursday morning in an attempt to avert another entertainment industry strike.

description: Nick Melisse, a customer service representative at Eastern Airlines for 14 years, stood outside the huge reservation center here handling a white carnation that symbolized the end of his career at Eastern.

description: Each American Depositary Share (ADS) represents 10 shares of common stock. US dollar amounts are translated for convenience at the rate of US $1.00 equals 132 yen. Sales represent consolidated sales. The number of consolidated companies was increased, beginning with the current fiscal year ending March 31, 1989. Figures for the first quarter are restated to reflect the expanded consolidation basis. Number of consolidated companies: 165, including 90 manufacturing companies; 60 sales companies; and 15 financial subsidiaries. Number of companies reflected on the equity method is 189. Products are marketed under the National, Panasonic, Quasar and Technics brandnames.

title: Carnival Cruise Lines To Expand
description: Moving to bolster its leading position in the cruise industry, Carnival Cruise Lines Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy 70 percent of Royal Caribbean and Admiral Cruise Lines for $550 million in cash.

description: Macmillan Inc., which previously rejected a $2.1 billion takeover bid from Robert Maxwell, has held discussions with the British publisher on a full or partial takeover of the company, both sides said yesterday.

title: Banter Before Denver Crash
description: Banter between the pilots of a Continental Airlines jet before it crashed on takeoff Nov. 15, killing 28 people, apparently violated Federal regulations, officials say.

title: Homeless Families Won't Be Sent to the Martinique
description: The Martinique - one of the largest and among the most infamous of New York City's welfare hotels - has been selected as the first target in the city's plan to remove homeless families from hotels, city officials said yesterday.

title: End Game for Yonkers
description: The city of Yonkers and four of its councilmen are nearing the end of their Federal court fight over housing discrimination. If the U.S. Supreme Court allows contempt charges and crippling fines to remain in place, the city faces financial ruin and the councilmen face jail.

description: b-Net income and after extraordinary credits of $31,000 for the quarter and $43,000 for the 6 months. The results restated to reflect operations of Harris & Co. and Capital Trust Management Corp., which merged with Lexington units in November 1987 and April 1988, respectively.

title: Building Cranes Are Boffo on Broadway
description: So many office buildings are being constructed or planned for the blocks around the theater district that the once-dormant neighborhood is likely to continue as New York City's hottest area for developers well into the 1990's, a new study says.

title: Ilana S. Shapiro Wed on L.I.
description: Ilana Sara Shapiro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Shapiro of Willowbrook, S.I., and David Robert Hertzberg, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Joshua Hertzberg of Bayside, Queens, were married last evening in Atlantic Beach, L.I. Rabbi Herschel Schachter and Rabbi Jay Marcus officiated at the Sands at Atlantic Beach.

description: As protesters on the opposition benches and in the galleries waved Maple Leaf flags and sang ''O Canada,'' the House of Commons today approved a free-trade agreement with the United States that would end more than a century of economic nationalism in Canada.

description: Don Euwart, a junior center and chemical engineering major at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was in a store recently, wearing a sweatshirt that said M.I.T. Football. ''Some guy pointed to it,'' Euwart remembered, ''and said, 'Is that a joke?' ''

title: More Charges Urged In Policeman's Death
description: A grand jury should consider manslaughter charges against a man accused of bumping an officer's arm during an arrest so that the officer's gun fired and killed the officer's partner, a Brooklyn Criminal Court judge ruled yesterday.

description: New York State's top court refused yesterday to hear an appeal seeking to remove Mario Biaggi's name from the Sept. 15 Democratic primary ballot.

title: To Stop the Killing, Partition Burundi
description: Once again, thousands have been murdered in the small Central African country of Burundi. If these mass tribal killings are ever to end, the country must be partitioned.

title: Mitsui to Quit Iran Project
description: Mitsui, the Tokyo-based conglomerate, said today that it wants to abandon a $4.5 billion Iranian petrochemical complex it had almost completed when the Iran-Iraq war broke out eight years ago.

title: CUC International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Boyd's Season Ends
description: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, a right-handed pitcher for the Boston Red Sox, said yesterday in a television interview that he is finished pitching for the rest of the season. He said the doctors had determined that he has a blood clot in the same spot that knocked him out of the pitching rotation twice and put him on the disabled list from July 29 to Aug. 19. ''We don't have a formal report from the doctor,'' said Lou Gorman, the general manager. ''There's no final result.'' (AP)

title: Tree Cutting Brings Charges
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted a homeowner accused of chopping down trees in a national park to get a better view of the Potomac River, then boasting of the home's ''river view'' in real estate advertisements.

title: Oregon Death Certificates to List Smoking
description: Oregon will add a section to state death certificates next year asking doctors to comment on the role tobacco played in the deaths of their patients.

description: b-Includes a $9,235,000 reduction of deferred tax liability due to change in accounting principle. c-After an extraordinary loss of $6,027,000 on early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Top Rutgers Back To Miss 3 Weeks
description: Henry Henderson, Rutgers' leading rusher last season, has undergone arthroscopic surgery to repair torn cartilage in his left knee and will be sidelined for three to four weeks.

title: Wounded Officer Is Held in Shootout
description: A police officer who was wounded in a shootout with two other officers has been charged with attempted murder, the police said yesterday.

title: IRT Property Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of real estate investments of $533,257 and $7,061,614 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results for 1987 are restated to reflect the acquisition by merger of Harris-Teeter Properties Inc.

title: Times Reaches an Accord With Deliverers
description: The New York Times announced yesterday that it had reached a tentative contract agreement with unionized deliverers.

title: 14 Savings Institutions Rescued
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today announced another giant rescue package for a group of ailing savings and loan associations in the Southwest. The rescue could eventually cost the Government almost $2 billion.

title: Gunther Von Fritsch, Director, Is Dead at 82
description: Gunther Von Fritsch, an original director of ''The March of Time'' newsreels who later directed TV drama including ''The Lawman'' and ''77 Sunset Strip,'' died of a stroke Saturday night. He was 82 years old.

title: OPPOSITION CALLS FOR STABLE CHILE
description: Beginning their campaign to defeat Gen. Augusto Pinochet in a presidential plebiscite, opposition parties promised today not to let Chile fall into a power vacuum or instability if they succeed.

title: Bond and Note Prices Edge Up
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes inched higher in another sluggish trading session yesterday.

title: Top Designs, All Utilitarian, For $5 or Less
description: BACK in 1954, the editors of Industrial Design magazine invited five panelists - the designers Raymond Loewy, Paul Rand, Eliot Noyes, Milton Immermann and the artist Saul Steinberg - to choose the best-designed products costing under $5. Among Mr. Loewy's selections were a whisk broom, a Christmas ornament, two bullets, a ball of twine, the Canada Dry bottle, an American flag and, not immodestly, the Lucky Strike pack he himself had designed in 1940. Mr. Noyes, the architect, praised the golf ball for its ''perfect shape'' and ''beautiful surface,'' and also chose a pair of nylons for their ''astounding structure'': limp when empty but full of form when worn.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies Saturday in Metropolitan News about a derailment Thursday night on the Long Island Rail Road incorrectly described the train in the photograph. It was an electric train that was struck by a diesel train that had derailed.

description: Best Grown, New York Horticultural Society, 128 West 58th Street; 212-757-0915.

title: Offshore Drilling Ban Vetoed by Deukmejian
description: Gov. George Deukmejian has vetoed a bill that would have banned oil and gas leasing on state offshore lands in Mendocino and Humboldt Counties.

title: Preserving Old Stone Facades
description: Owners of brownstones, like owners of automobiles and antiques, need technical knowledge and expertise to maintain their buildings properly.

What if the Vincennes Had Been 'Star Wars'?; Addicted to Gadgetry
description: To the Editor:

title: Canvas of Disney Ducks Is Sold for $75,000
description: An oil painting featuring the Walt Disney characters Donald Duck and Scrooge McDuck has been sold for $75,000, it was announced today.

title: Hawkins Chemical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago figures reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in April 1988.

title: Xylogics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $270,000 and $715,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: U.S. Open; One Down, Six to Go for Graf
description: Steffi Graf's magic number is now six, the number of matches she must win to become the United States Open champion and complete the Grand Slam. For those who are hoping this will provide the Open with two weeks of added excitement, the drama and suspense building, then the opposition will have to be made of sterner stuff than Elizabeth Minter, the personable Australian who was steamrolled by Graf in a first-round match yesterday.

title: Barbara E. Carter, Author, 63
description: Barbara E. Carter, an author, died of complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease, Sunday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. She was 63 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: Thieves Drive Into a Window To Rob a Store
description: Thieves built a plywood ramp up to the window of a fur salon yesterday, rammed a stolen van through the steel security gate and window, and escaped with about 60 coats, the police said.

title: Harman International Indusries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New-Music Series In 5 Cities in New York
description: Philip Glass, the Kronos Quartet, the Double Edge piano duo, the Max Roach Quartet, the Henry Threadgill Sextett and Women of the Calabash are to each give several concerts as part of a 20-concert series, the New York State New Music Network, from Sept. 24 to Oct. 15. The series is to begin in Manhattan with a free preview performance by Mr. Glass and the Roach and Threadgill groups, on Sept. 19 at 7:30 P.M. at the Equitable Center, 787 Seventh Avenue, between 51st and 52d Streets.

title: At Night, Drugs Invade The Projects
description: By day, the scene at the Gov. Alfred E. Smith Houses in lower Manhattan seems pastoral. At the western end of the sprawling public housing project, practically in the shadow of Police Headquarters, small children romp in the grass. Nearby, elderly tenants pass the time on wooden park benches that line the asphalt pathways around Smith's 12 red-brick buildings. Nighttime, however, is another story. ''Tenants here are fearful, desperate, afraid to ride the elevators, afraid to answer their apartment doors because they don't know who's knocking,'' said the building manager, Robert Rosenbaum, a longtime New York City Housing Authority employee who is, in effect, the on-site landlord for Smith's 6,000 residents, most of them the working poor and the elderly.

title: Solzhenitsyn, in Exile, Is Asked to Join Soviet Panel
description: Alexander Solzhenitsyn, the exiled Russian writer, has been invited to join a committee that will supervise the building of a Soviet memorial honoring the victims of Stalin's repression, an organizer of the project said today.

title: Engine Trouble? Crew Error? Investigators of Crash Search for the Answers
description: Was there a malfunction of an engine or other critical mechanism? Could the crew have mishandled what should have been a routine takeoff? Did the crew deliberately put the plane back down on the ground because, for some reason, they thought this a better alternative than trying to complete a difficult takeoff?

title: Market Place; Sun Convinces The Skeptics
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., the manufacturer of computer work stations that has taken the computer industry by storm, now seems to be achieving a similar success on Wall Street. The stock of the Silicon Valley company is attracting new interest from institutional investors, even as many better-known computer stocks lose favor.

title: Borland Sets Restructuring
description: Borland International Inc., a software company based in Scotts Valley, Calif., said today that it was restructuring to improve profitability.

title: Cram Injured
description: Steve Cram, the star British miler, suffered a leg injury in a track meet in Rieti, Italy, and an Italian doctor who treated him said there were serious doubts that Cram could run at the Seoul Olympics. The 27-year-old star walked from the track and said he thought the injury was far less serious than first feared. ''I am sure with a few days of rest I'll be fine,'' he said.(AP)

title: Wyle Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Sai Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Giant Food Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 13
description: The company said share earnings are adjusted for 100 percent stock dividend paid in June 1988.

title: Labor Board to Allow Health Worker Unions
description: The National Labor Relations Board is opening the way for unions to recruit millions of health care workers, telling hospitals they can no longer thwart organizing drives by lumping nurses with physicians or laboratory technicians with janitors.

title: Review/Music; Just the Basics: AC/DC Plays At the Garden
description: A guitar riff, a drumbeat, a howl: that's all AC/DC knows, and all it needs to know. The Australian band brought its blunt, no-frills rock to a sold-out Madison Square Garden on Tuesday, for a gung-ho audience that knew exactly what to expect.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American General Corp., Houston, a financial services holding company, named Nicholas R. Rasmussen vice chairman, financial policy. Austin P. Young will succeed Mr. Rasmussen as chief financial officer.

title: Warehouse Revival
description: ''WE tried to play off the building's Romanesque Revival style,'' said Judith Stockman, of Judith Stockman & Associates, a Manhattan firm, of the challenge of converting a cavernous warehouse on Greenwich Street into a lobby for a 400-unit apartment building. After creating brick arches leading to a skylit courtyard, Ms. Stockman tackled the mailboxes. ''Instead of hiding them away in closet-like spaces, we made them into pavilions topped with intersecting vaults of tubular steel.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: Cimco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $344,000 from an accounting change.

title: Competition Winners On Radio Music Series
description: ''The Winners Circle,'' a series of eight one-hour programs of performances by young winners of recent international music competitions, will be broadcast on WQXR AM (1560) and FM (96.3), starting Tuesday at 7 P.M. Each program will consist of a 15-minute interview conducted by Robert Sherman and a 45-minute performance.

title: Hormel Layoffs
description: Geo. A. Hormel & Company has informed nearly half of the workers at its plant in Fremont, Neb., that they will be laid off in a year. The notices, given 52 weeks before the expected layoffs, are required by the collective bargaining agreement between the meatpacker and Local 22 of the United Food and Commercial Workers union. About 324 employees in slaughtering, cutting and rendering operations have received notices.

title: AIDES TO JACKSON SAY DUKAKIS SEEKS CURB ON HIS ROLE
description: Aides to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis have asked the Rev. Jesse Jackson not to campaign in Mr. Dukakis's behalf in several states where their polling indicated he would alienate more voters than he would attract, advisers to Mr. Jackson said today.

title: 4UNITS AT HONEYWELL TO BE PUT UP FOR SALE
description: Honeywell Inc., the electronics company that has undertaken a major restructuring, said today that it was selling four units in its space and aviation systems division.

title: American Stores Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The company said earnings and sales for the latest quarter and 6-month include the results of operations for Lucky Stores from June 2 to July 30, as well as the additional interest expense and amortization of asset write-ups relating to the Lucky Stores acquisition.

title: Environmental Hazards; After Years of Cleanup, Lead Poisoning Persists As a Threat to Health
description: Despite steady progress in reducing lead hazards, millions of Americans are still absorbing unhealthy amounts of lead from air, dust, water, food and peeling paint found in older buildings, according to a recent authoritative report and experts in the field.

title: Minority Poverty on Rise but White Poor Decline
description: The proportion of white Americans living in poverty declined significantly last year while the proportion of black and Hispanic poor people increased, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Mayor Who Pardoned Drunk Drivers Is Removed
description: The 85-year-old Mayor of Florala, Ala., who had proclaimed a week in July as National Voodoo Week and pardoned dozens of drunken drivers, was impeached by a State Circuit Court jury and removed from office today on charges of neglect of duty and incompetence.

title: When Inspiration Strikes Twice
description: A. Puck table designed by Anna Anselmi for Bieffeplast was introduced in 1986. B. Inlaid table designed by Kevin Walz for Arc International was introduced in 1986.

title: First Federal Bancorp of Michigan reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are unavailable because the company went public in September 1987.

title: U.S. Ends Zimbabwe Aid Freeze
description: The United States ended a two-year freeze on economic aid to Zimbabwe today with the signing of a $17 million grant.

title: Intercim Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Drugs Linked to Stomach Ulcers in Elderly
description: A new study has added to evidence that many pain killing anti-inflammatory drugs, in addition to aspirin, are causing severe, even life-threatening stomach problems in elderly people. A high incidence of abdominal complications from these drugs was found in patients who died of gastric or duodenal ulcers or bleeding from the stomach or upper portion of the intestines.

title: Anthony Holland Tribute
description: A memorial tribute to Anthony Holland, an actor, is to be held on Sept. 26 at 5:30 P.M. at the Public Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival, 425 Lafayette Street. Mr. Holland died on July 10.

title: Environmentalists Say Either Bush Or Dukakis Will Be an Improvement
description: The next President of the United States will be more aggressive in protecting the environment than President Reagan has been, judging by the campaign pledges and positions of both candidates.

title: Nytest Environmental reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Dale Pon Starts Agency With Media Emphasis
description: Dale Pon, 43 years old, has decided to leave his post as executive vice president at Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/ GGK to start his own venture, Dale Pon Advertising, at 1 Fifth Avenue. Mr. Pon, who most recently was president of the entertainment division and a director at the agency, will gear his new shop toward broadcast and cable promotion as well as music and entertainment. His charter client is WQCD, a new jazz radio station owned by Tribune Broadcasting.

title: Unisys at 2: Key Goal Still Elusive
description: Two years ago, W. Michael Blumenthal, chairman and chief executive of the Burroughs Corporation, sent his counterparts at the Sperry Corporation a merger proposal, a plan to build a new computer company with enough muscle to challenge I.B.M., the industry goliath.

title: Ambulance Workers Say E.M.S. Underestimates Response Times
description: New York City's Emergency Medical Services drew sharp criticism at a hearing yesterday from some of its employees, who said the agency consistently underestimates how long it takes ambulances to reach patients.

title: Monitek Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DUKAKIS ATTACKS BUSH'S OIL STANCE
description: Michael S. Dukakis arrived in California tonight and immediately assailed Vice President Bush's environmental record, charging that Mr. Bush had changed his position on offshore oil drilling.

title: Norman's Wrist Healed
description: Greg Norman is left with putting woes as a reminder of an injury that sidelined him for seven weeks this season.

title: Burma Impasse Seems at Turning Point
description: The August uprising that has given the Burmese people control of their streets but not yet of their Government appeared today to have reached a turning point.

title: Two Other Candidates Widen the Selection
description: To the Editor:

title: What if the Vincennes Had Been 'Star Wars'?; Back to the Beginning

title: Delta Airliner Crashes in Texas; 13 Killed but 94 Get Out Alive
description: A Delta Air Lines jet with 107 people aboard crashed and burst into flame shortly after takeoff here this morning, but 94 people got out alive. Many walked away unscratched, with some flying on to their destinations later in the day.

title: Buyers Sue On Options
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange and some of its traders overcharged more than 1,000 investors who lost at least $40 million the day after the stock market collapsed, a lawyer contended today after filing a class action lawsuit.

title: Peoples Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The bank converted to stock ownership in May 1987.

title: TAYLOR SAYS HE MADE A 'BAD DECISION'
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' All-Pro linebacker, yesterday spoke publicly for the first time since he was suspended for 30 days Monday for violating the National Football League's substance-abuse policy.

title: 50% of Colon-Rectal Cancers Tied to Genetic Predisposition
description: An inherited predisposition contributes to more than half of all cases of colon and rectal cancer, a new study has found.

title: Plats des Jours (et Soirs) Without the 'Little Roses'
description: THE factory called Porcelaine du Site Corot is outside Limoges, France, on a stream where the 19th-century artist Corot is thought to have painted his landscapes. Bill Goldsmith, an American, is the concern's design director, making what he described as ''the things I would like to have for myself and that my friends in the design world would like to live with.''

title: Esprit Systems reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $457,000 and $490,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Horse Racing; Gazelle Victor Surprises Foes
description: The differences between Saratoga Race Track, which closed Monday after a 24-day meeting, and Belmont Park, which opened yesterday for a 42-day stand, were never clearer than they were yesterday in the Gazelle Handicap for 3-year-old fillies at Belmont.

title: Drug Did Not Cause Birth Defects, Court Says
description: A Federal appeals court panel has upheld a lower court decision in 1985 that the prescription drug Bendectin did not cause birth defects in children of mothers who used the drug to alleviate nausea.

title: Court Upholds Voiding of Redgrave Pact
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra did not violate the civil rights of actress Vanessa Redgrave when it canceled her performances following threats by protesters, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: Tucker Drilling Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Latest quarter results include a gain of $326,000 on the sale of an oil and gas field and gas plant. The company said this gain was partly offset by the accrual of a deferred retirement benefit of $302,000 for the company's former chairman. Year-ago quarter results include $1,270,000 of oil and gas sales that represent proceeds from the settlement of litigation of a gas sales contract.

title: Olympic Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Choosing the Unknown Over Pinochet
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, Chile's dictator since 1973, now asks voters to extend his term until 1997 by voting ''yes'' in an October plebiscite. He is given a fair chance of winning, in what many opponents expect to be an honest ballot, despite his regime's ugly record of terrorism and abuse of liberties. This record merits his defeat. But democrats need to absorb the lessons of the unexpectedly wide voter appeal he now seems to enjoy.

title: Piniella and Pagliarulo Exchange Barbs
description: The troubled Yankees, whose pennant drive has become a string of frustrating defeats through the West, began to self-destruct from within late Tuesday night.

title: CARNIVAL OF LAVISH PLUMED COSTUMES
description: Already, spies have gone to Morris Stewart's workshop in Brooklyn to see what is new among the mounds of brightly colored plumes, metallic baubles and bolts of shimmering red, gold and silver fabric.

title: OPEC Leader Visits Iraq
description: The Secretary General of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries arrived in Baghdad today after a similar visit to Iran to discuss ways of curbing overproduction by some of the group's member states.

title: Berkshire Gas Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Communication & Cable Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31

title: Rookie and Veteran Help Jets
description: The Jets' newest defensive help - one a seasoned veteran and the other a rookie - showed up here today, glad to be working somewhere in the National Football League.

title: WALESA, MEETING WARSAW LEADERS, URGES STRIKE HALT
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, called today for Polish strikers to return to work. The call was issued after Mr. Walesa met with members of the Polish leadership for the first time since Solidarity was suppressed in 1981.

title: Metro Matters; Stiff Upper Lip: The Lonely Road Of Moynihan Foe
description: ''The moment it's not fun, it's time to do something else,'' Robert R. McMillan, the Republican who hopes to topple Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan in November, said over a roast beef sandwich in a Great Neck diner the other evening. He sounded like he meant it after three grueling months of campaigning that, right now, looks like an exercise in futility.

title: Gondrezick Signs
description: Grant Gondrezick, a guard who was implicated in the drug scandal involving the Phoenix Suns in 1986, signed a one-year contract yesterday to play with the Los Angeles Clippers of the National Basketball Association. Gondrezick played last season with a team in Caen, France. Gondrezick, after being charged in the Phoenix case with three drug counts, pleaded guilty to tampering with a witness and was fined $200 and placed on three years' probation. The drug charges were dismissed. After being cut by the Suns during training camp last season, he said he moved to France ''to go somewhere else and prove myself for a year.''(AP)

title: Intelligent Systems Master LP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Share earnings are in units of the limited partnership.

title: 'Temperate' Furniture And Clothes In London
description: SITUATED on Great Newport Street in London, between the Soho and Covent Garden districts, Davies is a new 3,000-square-foot shop masterminded by David Davies, a 33-year-old English graphic and industrial designer.

title: Koch and Jackson Meet in a Peace Parley Refereed by Cuomo
description: Mayor Koch and the Rev. Jesse Jackson met yesterday and, despite signs of strain, told 200 reporters and photographers that they had pledged to put aside past bitterness in a common effort to elect Michael S. Dukakis. But they made it clear that much still divided them, and they left Mr. Jackson's role in the mayoral election next year unclear.

title: First Olympic Gold May Be NBC's
description: It will be another two weeks before the Olympic Games begin in Seoul, South Korea, but NBC is already counting itself among the winners. The top-rated network has sold 98 percent of the advertising time available on the 179 hours of programming it will broadcast from the Games and expects to meet its goal of $550 million in gross advertising revenue.

title: Taylor Failed Test First Time in '87
description: The Giants acknowledged today that Lawerence Taylor, the All-Pro linebacker, failed his first drug test administered by the National Football League in 1987.

title: AFP Imaging CorpO) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Texaco Pact With Its Unit
description: Texaco said late last night that it had reached an agreement with Texaco Canada on procedures for the sale of the subsidiary, of which Texaco owns 78 percent, to protect the interests of minority shareholders.

title: TV Portrayal Of Girls Cited
description: Television programs do not show teen-age girls taking the steps necessary to achieve productive lives, but show them as obsessed with shopping, grooming and dating, says a report sponsored by a women's advocacy group.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Critic's Notebook yesterday on child prodigies inaccurately described the piano career of Ruth Slenczynska.

title: Berkline Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Books of The Times; Heller Contemplating Rembrandt. . . .
description: Why should Joseph Heller have written a book about the life of Rembrandt and the death of Socrates, the rise of the Netherlands and the fall of Athens? As the narrator shrugs, in one of the many punchlines that keep reminding us of the author's presence, ''Don't ask me.''

title: Dow, on Rising Volume, Drops by 6.58, to 2,031.65
description: Both the Dow Jones industrial average and the broader stock market finished lower yesterday as trading volume increased from the preceding three sessions.

description: b-After gains of $481,027 for the quarter and $1,266,709 for the 6 months, both from the extinguishment of debt.

SCHOOL CENSORSHIP CALLED PERSISTENT
description: Censorship remains a problem for public schools despite court rulings that rejected conservatives' challenges of textbooks, a civil liberties group said today.

title: West Germany Tops Finland, 4-0
description: Rudi Voeller scored two goals and led West Germany to an easy 4-0 victory over Finland in the opening Group 4 World Cup soccer qualifying match tonight. The West Germans led by 2-0 at halftime.

title: Young, Gay - and Afraid
description: LEAD: The anti-gay attack on the Upper West Side of New York City - in which a group of teen-agers surrounded two young men, taunted them with epithets, then beat and stabbed them - is neither surprising nor unusual. What is surprising is the amount of attention the event has received. But attention should also be focused on the factors that contribute to such violence, especially the hostile anti-gay statements of religious and political leaders.

title: Petrolite Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31

Yonkers Feeling Grip of Fiscal Rules
description: Municipal operations are slowing perceptibly, Yonkers officials said today, as restrictions imposed by the state-controlled Emergency Financial Control Board begin to take effect in the struggle over fiscal control.

description: The 79 major league baseball players who filed for free agency in 1986, listed by teams they finished the season with: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Addenda
description: * Premiere, a movie magazine that is owned by Hatchette S.A. of France and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, will raise both its rate base and circulation 50 percent as of January. Circulation will rise to 375,000, from 250,000.

title: Petroleum Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tokyo Bank's Bid Is Backed by Fed
description: The Federal Reserve Board has approved the takeover of the Union Bank of Los Angeles by the Bank of Tokyo Ltd., as a majority of board members overruled objections by Martha R. Seger. The Fed governor said that she had voted against the application because American banks would not be allowed to make a similar acquisition in Japan.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Becton, Dickinson & Co., Franklin Lakes, N.J., said it would sell the industrial-glove business of its Edmont division, Coshocton, Ohio, through the First Boston Corp.

title: Blast at Apartheid Foes' Office
description: The headquarters of the South African Council of Churches and several leading civil rights groups was destroyed in a bombing early today in which 23 people were wounded.

title: Brighter Oriental Rugs
description: ''NEVER, never should anyone send an Oriental rug to a dry cleaner,'' said Elizabeth Nelle, the manager of Doris Leslie Blau, an antique-rug dealer on East 57th Street. Instead, she said, the rugs should be cleaned by a professional rug cleaner. That may be more costly, but it will prolong the life of the rug.

title: Taylor's Paid Vacation?
description: The Giants are not saying whether they will dock Lawrence Taylor for the minimum of four games he will miss at the beginning of the season - that is one-fourth the regular season, and would involve one-fourth, or $250,000, of Taylor's $1 million annual salary.

title: Igene Biotechnology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Puckett's 2 Homers Boost Viola to 20th
description: Frank Viola became the major leagues' first 20-game winner tonight, and Kirby Puckett hit two home runs and drove in five runs as the Minnesota Twins beat the Texas Rangers, 10-1.

title: Can Back Bay Elegance Find Success at 57th and Lex?
description: Not long ago, Murray Pearlstein received a crystal apple from Clifford Grodd, the president of Paul Stuart, the men's clothier. It was Mr. Grodd's sporting way of welcoming Mr. Pearlstein and his clothing store, Louis, Boston, to New York.

title: Gynecology; Allergies in Sex Linked to Some Vaginitis Cases
description: Allergic reactions set off by sexual intercourse may be responsible for a significant number of cases of recurrent vaginitis, including some in which yeast infections are found, recent studies indicate.

title: Korea to Lift Curb on Won
description: South Korea plans to make the won an internationally traded currency in several months by lifting foreign exchange restrictions, a Government economist said today.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The previous owners of my brick ranch house painted it white. I would like to get rid of this see-through paint, but I am concerned about damaging the brick or mortar joints. Is there a safe, inexpensive way to do this, or should I just live with it? A. Removing paint from brick is never inexpensive or easy. The two methods most often used are to have the bricks pressure-washed by a contractor, or to use a chemical paint remover.

title: Boeing-Short Bros.
description: The Boeing Company said it was not interested in buying Short Brothers P.L.C. of Belfast, Northern Ireland. ''We have now completed our evaluation, and we do not have an interest in purchasing all or part of Shorts,'' said Frank A. Shrontz, Boeing's chairman. Shorts is a state-owned manufacturer of aircraft parts, which supplies Boeing with parts for its 737, 747 and 757 aircraft.

title: Frederick Martin, Publishing Executive, 51
description: Frederick Martin, a publishing executive, died of a stroke Friday at St. Francis Hospital in Jersey City. He was 51 years old and lived in Jersey City.

description: b-Includes a gain of $159,943.

title: Baseball Notebook; Remember Sept. 1, Then Bet the House
description: The Mets will play the Los Angeles Dodgers in the National League pennant playoff and the Oakland Athletics will play the Detroit Tigers in the American League playoff. Who, or what, says so? History.

title: Floating Point Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Volek an Islander
description: The Islanders announced yesterday that they had come to contract terms with David Volek, a right wing from Czechoslovakia who defected to the United States on July 25. The 22-year-old Volek, who was drafted four years ago by the Islanders, agreed to a multiyear contract at financial terms that were not announced by Bill Torrey, the Islanders' president and general manager. Torrey said that Volek would report with the Islander rookies on Sept. 8.(AP)

title: Electoral Dynamite
description: The Environment Yesterday in Michigan, George Bush started to talk about something serious. Diversions about the Pledge of Allegiance or Mr. Dukakis's alleged lack of patriotism were laid aside. Mr. Bush addressed the mounting evidence of deterioration in the environment and promised to convene a global conference to discuss remedies. That's a welcome beginning to debate on a strangely neglected issue.

title: Kirov to Dance in New York After 25 Years
description: The Kirov Ballet will perform at the Metropolitan Opera House in July, returning to New York City after an absence of 25 years, The announcement was made by Oleg Vinogradov, director of the Kirov Ballet, during an interview this week in Manhattan in which Mr. Vinogradov talked of changes in the company and in the Soviet Union in recent years, including new dance exchanges with the West.

The company also said the prior year non-operating income included $414,000 from a gain on sale of assets and $594,000 from investment activity.

Iraqis Reported To Mount Drive Against Kurds
description: Iraq has begun a major offensive against Kurdish rebels, a drive that Administration officials and Kurdish leaders are characterizing as an effort by the authorities in Baghdad to crush the 40-year-long insurgency once and for all.

title: Parent & Child
description: ARCHEOLOGISTS have uncovered 6,000-year-old clay tablets from southern Babylonia that describe how the adults of that community found the younger generation to be insolent and disobedient. ''What they recommended on the tablets was a good swat on the behind,'' said Dr. Irwin A. Hyman, a professor of school psychology at Temple University in Philadelphia and the director of the National Center for the Study of Corporal Punishment and Alternatives in the Schools.

title: I.R.A. Syas 3 Slain Were on Mission
description: The Irish Republican Army said today that three men killed by British soldiers in Northern Ireland on Tuesday were I.R.A. members ''on active service.'' The group uses the phrase to refer to a guerrilla mission.

title: Arraignment Held in Hospital In Assault Case
description: A pregnant Queens woman who has accused a police officer of clubbing her during a dispute over a parking ticket Sunday was arraigned on assault charges yesterday in her room at Bellevue Hospital Center.

title: Soviets Confirm Afghan Attacks
description: The Soviet Union confirmed today that it had sent planes from Soviet territory to bomb guerrilla positions around Kunduz, Afghanistan, but it denied American accusations that the combat missions were a violation of the Geneva accords on ending the Afghan war.

title: Killer of Girl Draws Maximum Sentence
description: Raphael Robles, who was convicted of killing a 9-year-old girl, Jessica Febus, and hiding her body in the basement of their apartment building in the East New York section of Brooklyn, received the maximum sentence of 25 years to life in prison yesterday.

title: Chubb's Rain Liabilities
description: A spokeswoman at the Chubb Corporation said yesterday that several weeks would be needed to determine the amount of the company's liability under the controversial rain coverage plan that expires at midnight today.

title: BellSouth Plans to Offer Access to Data Bases
description: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it planned to offer a ''public information gateway'' that would allow computer users to tap into a variety of data bases by dialing one number from a home telephone line.

title: Review/Television; Workers and Players of Atlantic City
description: Few would consider Atlantic City the jewel of the North Atlantic, but the glint from one of its facets has caught the eye of Channel 5, which will show what it saw in an hourlong documentary tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the TV Notes column of Aug. 22 about a documentary on Doris Lessing incorrectly identified the producer of ''The South Bank Show,'' on which she appeared. The producer is London Weekend Television.

title: Democrats Unveil Ads Aimed at Middle-Class Voters
description: The campaign of Michael S. Dukakis today announced the opening themes for its fall offensive, designed to appeal to the economic anxiety of the middle class, raise doubts about the qualifications and judgment of the Republican ticket and, above all, regain the initiative in what was becoming an electoral debate framed by the Republicans.

title: Managua Lifts Wages, Devalues Its Currency
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has announced a currency devaluation and wage increases to shore up an economy he said has been damaged by American support for the contras.

title: John Jeffery Bernd, 35, An Innovator in Dance
description: John Jeffery Bernd, an experimentalist choreographer and dancer and an associate director of Performance Space 122, died of AIDS on Sunday at New York University Hospital. He was 35 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Autoclave Engineers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Dry Sludge Fertilizer
description: To the Editor:

title: Absurd Lengths for a Mob Trial
description: How could the Government spend 21 months trying a case against the Mafia - and then fall flat on its face? That's what happened in the case of 20 alleged members of the Lucchese crime family in New Jersey. A jury found the case so lacking in merit, one juror said, that it acquitted all the defendants without even discussing the evidence.

title: Rockwood Holding Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $556,000 and $1,591,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: A Gallo Suit Ends
description: The E.&J. Gallo Winery said that a Federal district judge in Fresno, Calif., had granted the winery's motion to dismiss a claim by Joseph Gallo, the younger brother of Ernest and Julio Gallo, that he was entitled to one-third ownership of the winery. Joseph Gallo, a cattle rancher in Modesto, Calif., made the claim as part of a countersuit after the brothers filed a lawsuit two years ago to block him from using the Gallo name on the cheese he markets.

title: Triton Energy in Offering Of $275 Million of Notes
description: The Triton Energy Corporation, a Dallas-based oil services concern, is offering $275 million of liquid yield option notes, or ''lyons,'' with a final maturity in 2005 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Capital Associates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter and year include downward revision in estimates of residual value of certain equipment as well as the recognition of excess collections over prior estimates on other equipment.

title: Mets Stumble On Bases In Defeat
description: Sid Fernandez left the game after the first inning with a tender left knee. Gregg Jefferies left two innings later with a badly bruised right ankle. The two injuries turned out to be regrettable, but not really serious. The same could be said of the rest of the Mets' afternoon.

title: 20 Feared Dead in Crash of Mexican Plane
description: A Mexican aircraft crashed in the central state of Michoacan today and all 20 people aboard were feared dead, an airport official said.

title: Atlantic Financial Federal reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $1,577,000 loss from the reversal of a tax loss carryforward for the quarter and a tax credit of $5,703,000 for the 9 months, and gains from the redemption of debt of $1,390,000 and $2,581,000 for the quarter and and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $5,200,000 for the quarter and $15,172,000 for the 9 months. The company said in the latest quarter and 9-month, share earnings are calculated after the payment of dividends on series A preferred and series B preferred, issued to the FSLIC in February 1988; year-ago share earnings are calculated after the payment of series A preferred dividends only.

title: Seitel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $18,109 for the quarter and $9,277 for the 6 months; the 6 months also included a $137,081 gain from the settlement of a lawsuit.

title: Technogenetics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $70,100. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $105,400 and $182,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Pro-Med Capital reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company has no year-ago quarter figures because it started reporting on a quarterly basis in the third quarter of last year.

title: Energy Development Partners Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter and 6-month figures exclude an $8,000,000 extraordinary gain from gas settlement relating to one of Energy Development Partners, Ltd.'s major fields.

title: Rhoden's Victory Completes Yankees' Lost Month
description: In their seventh game on the trip, and on their last try against the last-place Seattle Mariners, the Yankees finally ended their misery.

title: Bridge
description: In the air battles of World War II, the glory usually went to the pilot. Few thought of the perils, discomfort and occasional successes of the rear gunner, the ''Tail-end Charlie.''

title: New Los Angeles Office
description: Campbell-Mithun-Esty, Minneapolis, has opened a Los Angeles office, the agency's fifth full-service office, and appointed James Brady general manager. Initially, the new shop will work exclusively on the $20 million Chrysler Jeep/Eagle account, but has plans to seek new business aggressively, especially marketing aimed at Hispanic audiences.

title: Resource Exploration Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $834,698 on the sale of a pipeline for the latest 9 months; year-ago 9 months include a pretax gain of $72,168.

title: Gannet Rival Joins Foes Of Merger
description: The Arkansas Democrat of Little Rock will today join the battle over the proposed merger of The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News, taking the side of readers and advertisers who oppose the combination.

title: Condominium Owners Grapple With Governing Themselves
description: Out of the sound and occasional fury of neighbor contending against neighbor, a new level of local government, closer to the people than any other, has been created in America.

title: Forsch an Astro
description: The St. Louis Cardinals acquired a utilityman, Denny Walling, for a right-hander, Bob Forsch, in a trade with the Houston Astros, who are trying to stay in the race in the National League West.

title: Partial Accord in Bond-Default Case
description: Less than a week before the opening of the largest securities fraud trial in history, the Washington Public Power Supply System, a significant defendant in the case, said yesterday that it had reached a tentative settlement with representatives of about some 24,000 investors and the trustee for existing bondholders.

title: U.S. TIES ARMS DEAL TO A SOVIET RADAR
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it would complete no new arms control agreements with the Soviet Union until Moscow agreed to dismantle a disputed radar station.

title: Lendl Needs 5 Sets To Stop Mansdorf
description: Struggling at Wimbledon is one thing, but this was not supposed to happen to Ivan Lendl at the United States Open. This is where he enjoys a home-court advantage, where he has been in four consecutive finals, winning the last three years. It is a surprise when Lendl loses even a set at Flushing Meadows.

title: WORKMAN LOST IN BLAST OFF L.I.
description: An explosion last night aboard an oil tanker docked at a loading platform in Long Island Sound off Northport, L.I., knocked several workers into the water and at least one workman was missing early today, the authorities said.

title: Novell Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Micros Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: On Civil Liberty
description: When Franklin Roosevelt nominated Felix Frankfurter to the Supreme Court, in 1939, voices of the extreme right called Professor Frankfurter a Communist. They cited, especially, the fact that he was a member of a national committee of the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Serenading Sculptures
description: THE sounds of summer fill the almost clean air here at the beach in Santa Monica: crashing waves, laughing children, screeching gulls, singing beach chairs. Singing beach chairs? Looking for all the world like a pair of pastel-colored highchairs, the 14-foot-high musical chairs, each backed with five slotted pipes, serenade beachgoers with mournful sounds when the wind blows. The $17,000 chairs were created by Douglas Hollis, a San Francisco artist, to ''expand the awareness of the phenomenon of the ocean and the wind,'' and are part of the Santa Monica Arts Commission's plan to bring art to the beach.

title: Pacific First Bonds
description: The Pacific First Federal Savings Bank, a unit of Pacific First Financial Corporation, is offering $100 million of 9 3/8 percent mortgage-backed bonds due in 1992 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. They are backed by agency paper that includes Federal National Mortgage Association securities. The bonds have a 9 3/8 percent coupon and are offered at a price of 99.654, to yield 9.48 percent, or about 58 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Noncallable, the issue is rated triple-A by Moody's.

title: Cordis Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,851,000 and $3,386,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a charge of $1,021,000 from a credit adjustment for the quarter and a tax credit of $777,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $105,000 for the quarter and $54,342,000 for the year. The company said the latest quarter and year includes losses from a joint venture of $1,255,000 and $3,952,000, respectively, compared with losses for the year-ago quarter and year of $1,438,000 $3,920,000, respectively.

title: Standard Havens Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago 9 months included a non-recurring gain of $1,317,000 on the sale of stock by a subsidiary.

title: Greenspan to Visit Japan
description: The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan, will visit Tokyo in mid-October to hold talks with senior Japanese monetary officials, a Bank of Japan spokesman said today. He declined to comment on the agenda. It will be Mr. Greenspan's first visit to Japan as the Fed's chairman.

title: 3 Palestinians Die Of Gunshot Wounds In Fights With Army >
description: Three Palestinian demonstrators died today as a result of gunshot wounds sustained in clashes with Israeli troops. It was the highest death toll in several weeks.

title: Southwest Realty Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Oshman's Sporting Goods reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''From the moment we left the ground, you know we were going to wreck. I just thank the Lord I'm still here.'' - Michelle Christensen of Dallas. [ A1:4. ]

title: Litton Profits Rise by 23.4%
description: Litton Industries, a maker of electronics gear, ships and automated factory equipment, said today that its profits rose 23.4 percent in the fourth quarter and 20.9 percent in the fiscal year.

title: Arbitrator Finds Baseball Owners In Second Free-Agent Conspiracy
description: For the second time in less than a year, an arbitrator ruled yesterday that major league baseball's club owners were guilty of conspiring against free agents in violation of the sport's collective bargaining agreement.

title: Six-Month Makeover: A House on the Dunes Is Transformed
description: UP on the bluff, a blue and white Sea Spray flag flutters gracefully in the breeze. Two Ferraris dot the circular tan gravel driveway, and towels embroidered with the Sea Spray logo are neatly folded on the roomy chaises that line the pristine swimming pool. The tennis net is exactly on axis to the Tennessee orchard stone steps that lead ceremoniously up to the porte-cochere.

title: Jets Cleared on Powell
description: An arbitrator has found that the Jets were not acting out of ''anti-union animus'' in 1986 when they released and then traded Marvin Powell, who was president of the National Football League Players Association at the time.

title: Singer Agrees to Sell Kearfott Guidance Unit
description: The Singer Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Kearfott Guidance and Navigation Division to the Astronautics Corporation of America for $285 million.

title: U.S. FOREST FIRES WORST SINCE 1919
description: From the porch of the shop where she works, Carol Montana looked out over the Old Faithful geyser and up at a stunning red and orange sunset.

title: Life in the 30's
description: THE first time I ever saw ''All About Eve'' was in a revival house in the East Village, where the seats were abominably uncomfortable and granola was served at the snack bar instead of popcorn. It instantly became one of my favorite movies, and though I had lots of favorite moments in it, there was only one when I lost control. The actress Margo Channing, drunk and disconsolate - but, of course, still mouthy as anything, since she is played by Bette Davis - is talking about her age and her boyfriend. She's just turned 40, she says, although she hasn't made up her mind to admit it. But not the guy she's in love with: ''Bill's 32,'' she says savagely. ''He looks 32. He looked it five years ago; he'll look it 20 years from now. I hate men.''

title: Koch and Jackson Hold Meeting, Gingerly
description: Wary and stone-faced, Mayor Koch and the Rev. Jesse Jackson met for two and a quarter hours in Governor Cuomo's Manhattan office yesterday and agreed to set aside their past bitterness and work to elect Michael S. Dukakis.

title: 44 Wild Horses Killed
description: The Federal Bureau of Land Management said today that as many as 44 wild horses were shot to death in a remote area north of Austin. The state Commission for the Preservation of Wild Horses has offered a reward for information leading to the arrests and convictions of the killers.

title: Review/Music; Bernstein-Gould Tribute
description: To end this summer's Out-of-Doors series, Lincoln Center offered a joint birthday tribute to Leonard Bernstein, who celebrated his 70th last week, and Morton Gould, whose 75th is in December. Having been rained out on Monday, the performance by the Harmonie Ensemble, directed by Steven Richman, took place on Tuesday evening at the Damrosch Park Band Shell. Mr. Gould attended the performance and offered some comments after the intermission.

title: Ananda Journal; Commune Flourishes, As Does Neighborliness
description: The swami drives a Chevy, writes on a computer and wears hiking boots. His disciples sell fancy women's fashions. Pilgrims to the guru's lair drop pennies in an ''Ask the Swami'' napkin holder that dispenses such less-than-mystical advice as ''Don't walk under ladders.''

title: Inamed Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chairs, Count 'Em, 397 in All
description: LATER this month, Harry N. Abrams will publish ''397 Chairs'' ($24.95), reinforcing the seemingly endless fascination with that most ubiquitous of Western pieces of furniture.

title: Deal Sought By Nomura
description: The Nomura Securities Company is negotiating to purchase a large stake in GNP Commodities Inc., GNP's chairman, Brian Monieson, said today, although the deal is not imminent and terms were not disclosed.

title: Rockers for Rights: On the Eve of the Big Tour
description: This Friday, Bruce Springsteen, Peter Gabriel and Sting, along with other leading rock musicians, will perform at Wembley Stadium in London, beginning a six-week concert tour of five continents for Amnesty International, which monitors human rights abuses.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: TV Notes
description: Portrait of Emmigrants

title: No Decisions on Taylor
description: Lawrence Taylor's agent, Gary Kovach, said earlier this week that the Giants' linebacker might undergo drug rehabilitation beginning sometime soon, after it was disclosed Monday that he had failed a drug test. No starting date for treatment has been set, however, and Kovach would not accept telephone calls yesterday.

title: Syntex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $4.8 million and $5.5 million for environmental cleanup costs.

title: To Cuomo, Campaign Is Most 'Superficial'
description: Governor Cuomo of New York said today that the Presidential campaign between Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee, and George Bush, the Republican nominee, was the most ''superficial'' he had ever seen.

title: Mostly Mozart, and Worse
description: At an uptown subway station, commuters wait with special desperation for a light at the end of the tunnel. On the stuffy platform, a man plays an electronically amplified flute, a noise that invades every corner. The music is Mozart; the flautist, first rate. Why is it so offensive? Because it's nine o'clock in the morning - an hour when most recently awakened people prefer to read or have a few moments to themselves before being swept into the business of the day. Subway musicians, who sometimes lighten the steps of homebound commuters, are a nuisance during the morning rush. Rules that permit music-making in the subways need to be revamped.

title: Alexander Gerber, Cardiologist, 76
description: Dr. Alexander Gerber, an internist who specialized in cardiology and who did early work in the use of steroids in chemotherapy and organ transplants, died of a heart attack at Central Vermont Hospital in Berlin, Vt., while on vacation. He was 76 years old and lived in Atlantis, Fla.

title: In Brooklyn, A Restoration Nears an End
description: The end is in sight for the renovation of Brooklyn Borough Hall. And in the end, it will not have taken as long to renew the landmark as it did to build it in the first place; that took 15 years.

title: British Tourism A Record in '87
description: A record 15.4 million foreign tourists visited Britain last year, the British Tourist Authority said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WPP Group Reports A Big Rise in Earnings
description: The WPP Group P.L.C., the British advertising conglomerate, has reported large earnings gains for the six months that ended on June 30, mainly because of new business and operating increases at the J. Walter Thompson Company, which it acquired last year, and at Hill & Knowlton.

title: Car Sales Rise in Japan
description: Sales of vehicles in Japan increased 14.5 percent in August from a year earlier, to 263,629, according to preliminary figures released today by the Japan Automobile Dealers Association. The rise was the 16th straight year-to-year gain. The August figures, which are compiled from vehicle registrations, were much lower than the 485,549 of July, which was 7.7 percent more than a year earlier. The association will release final figures on Monday.

title: On Stage
description: Teasers From a Musical

title: Review/Film; Just a Big Happy Family With an Odd Sense of Fun
description: If the Waltons had money, not to mention show-business connections and a large house in the Hamptons, they might be a lot like the Rockwell family of ''Rocket Gibraltar,'' which opens today at the Regency. It is not without irony that the Rockwells have been named, since their picture-perfect happy family tableau harkens back to a simpler time.

title: Plebiscite in Chile: Opposition Cautiously Hopeful
description: Although Gen. Augusto Pinochet controls one of the strongest military regimes that Latin America has known, his opponents are cautiously confident of their chances to vote him out of power.

title: No Survivors Found in Mexican Plane Crash
description: Rescuers climbed to the wreckage of a commuter plane today and found no survivors among the 20 people who were aboard when it crashed in rugged mountains in the western Sierra Madre, a military official said.

title: A Month Later, Yanks Try to Regroup
description: The month must have seemed like a year, the six days from last Thursday to last Tuesday like a month. When they were done and the streak was over, the sound of the Yankees' collective sigh of relief was very audible.

title: Barrier Science & Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
