description: b-Net income

title: Jackson Disclaims Reports of a Curb
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today publicly disclaimed reports by his advisers that Michael S. Dukakis's campaign officials had asked him not to campaign for the Democratic Presidential ticket in certain states, for fear that he would alienate more potential supporters than he would attract.

title: Prompted by Session With Jackson, The Mayor Tries to Upgrade Image
description: It seems more a tactic than tact, but Mayor Koch has an improbable new style: he is trying to be, well, nice.

title: Homeless Live on Upper East Side Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; The Downturn In Steel Stocks
description: INVESTOR enthusiasm for steel stocks seems to be waning. Armco Inc., at $$11.125 a month ago, closed yesterday at $10. Bethlehem Steel is now at $20.50, down from $25.125 at the end of July. And Inland Steel, which was at $38.25 at that time, is now at $37.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: At the Movies
description: Mahoney's Many Faces

title: A Golden Chance to Reduce Arms in Europe
description: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Soviet leaders have repeatedly called for a ''pan-European'' conference to discuss the reduction of conventional weaponry in Europe. This is just the latest evidence that Moscow is serious about dramatically reducing East-West confrontation in the world's most heavily armed area.

title: Gerald Mast, 48, Dies; Wrote Histories of Film
description: Dr. Gerald Mast, an author, film historian and chairman of the English department at the University of Chicago, died of AIDS yesterday at the Bernard Mitchell Hospital in Chicago. He was 48 years old and lived in Hyde Park, Ill.

title: Petrie Stores Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $48,800,000 and $57,100,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from the exchange of debentures for Toys ''R'' Us Inc. stock. In March and July 1988, substantially all of the company's 7 l/2 percent and 8 percent subordinated exchangeable debentures were exchanged for about 14,200,000 shares of common stock of Toys ''R'' Us owned by the company, resulting in the gains in the latest periods. The latest periods do not include any interest expense on these subordinated exchangeable debentures. The exchange reduced Petrie Stores' Toys ''R'' Us stake to about 14 percent, and as of May 1, the company no longer accounts for its investment in Toys ''R'' Us on the equity method. Equity earnings for the latest quarter include only the company's equity earnings of Paul Harris Stores Inc.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; It's Post Time in Oklahoma
description: There will never be a sloppy track at the new Remington Park in Oklahoma City because there will never be any slop.

title: Rose's Son Signs
description: Pete Rose 2d, the son of Manager Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds, has signed a minor league contract with the Baltimore Orioles, the team announced yesterday. The younger Rose, an 18-year-old third baseman, was the Orioles' 12th-round draft selection in the June draft. He will report to the Orioles' West Palm Beach affiliate in the Florida Instructional League. Players are due to report on Sept. 13. . . . The attorney for a woman who is suing Wade Boggs of the Boston Red Sox said he would not proceed with the $12 million palimony lawsuit against Boggs until after the season. James McGee, the attorney for Margo Adams of Costa Mesa, Calif., said Wednesday that the delay was to prevent any interference with the American League East pennant race. . . . The Cincinnati Reds announced yesterday that Bo Diaz, their 35-year-old catcher, will need surgery tomorrow on his left knee, which has bothered him recently. Diaz had to be dropped from the starting lineup just before the Reds' game Wednesday night against Pittsburgh because his knee was bothering him. The surgery will sideline him for the rest of the season. (AP)

title: Paris Bank Branch Offers 10% Notes
description: The New York branch of Banque Nationale de Paris is offering $200 million of 10 percent notes due in 1998, at a price of par, to yield about three-quarters of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: Computer Concern In 17% Stock Drop
description: Digital Communications Associates Inc. said it expected first-quarter profits to drop sharply because of a 15 to 20 percent decline in sales. The computer company's shares plunged, closing down $4.375, at $21.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. The 17.1 percent decline was the steepest on the Big Board.

title: Weekend Sounds
description: Half Japanese, a rock band, and Walter Salas-Humara, the songwriter from the Silos, will play a double bill tomorrow at 9 P.M. and midnight at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $7.

title: INSIDE
description: Toxic Fire in Canada

title: Review/Film; Going Undercover in 1820's India
description: The intrepid hero of ''The Deceivers'' is played by Pierce Brosnan, who is seen getting the best of a wild tiger during one of the film's early scenes. Obviously, this William Savage - a fictionalized version of one William Sleeman, a British officer living in the India of the 1820's - is quite a fellow. It develops that he is also a hero of the drawing room, sporting the prettily curled coiffure and red-and-gold-braid uniform peculiar to the time and place, or at least to this slightly fussy production.

title: On Piano and Bass
description: The duo of Bill Mays on piano and Red Mitchell on bass will perform tonight and tomorrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Music begins at 9:30 P.M.; there is a $5 cover and an $8 minimum.

title: Teamsters Resume Talks With Hollywood Producers
description: Contract talks between teamsters drivers and Hollywood producers resuumed today, one day after the union overwhelmingly rejected the producers' most recent offer.

title: TV Weekend; Going One on One With America, Soviet Style
description: In case of a shakeup of Soviet journalists, Vladimir Dunayev should be able to get a job as a stand-up comedian on American television. He can be seen in a debut of sorts on Sunday at 10 P.M. on Channel 13, in a half-hour documentary entitled ''Dear Comrades: A Channel 3, Moscow Special.''

title: On Road to Seoul, a Stop in Wardrobe
description: On the long road to Seoul, the final pit stop for United States Olympic team members is a stay here to pick up their official Olympic underwear and a closetful of other garb, receive some basic chopstick instructions and get a sendoff from Mickey Mouse.

title: High Plains Oil Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a $4.6 million gain from the settlement of debt and tax credits. c-Net loss The company announced a change in the accounting treatment previously given $5.6 million in debt forgiveness resulting from its September 1987 restructuring of its debt to its primary lender. The company also said the change, which was made to comply with the applicable accounting regulations, resulted in the $5.6 million amount being reflected as a reduction of furture interest expenses over the 10- year term of the restructured debt as opposed to the previously recognized extraordinary credit to 1988 operations and a corresponding increase in equity.

title: Family Law: Battleground in Social Revolution
description: Family law, long a professional backwater, has become a new constitutional battleground on which the social revolutions in family structure, childbearing and personal relationships are being fought.

title: Peete Leads Southern Cal in 34-7 Rout
description: Rodney Peete opened his Heisman Trophy campaign impressively tonight in leading Southern Cal to an easy victory over Boston College, 34-7, at Alumni Stadium.

title: Pretoria Seen Easing Mandela's Confinement
description: The admission of Nelson Mandela to a private clinic today was widely interpreted here today as a political decision by the South African Government not to return the black nationalist leader to prison.

title: Luis W. Alvarez, Nobel Physicist Who Explored Atom, Dies at 77
description: Luis W. Alvarez, winner of the 1968 Nobel Prize in Physics who was a member of the team that developed the atomic bomb, died yesterday in Berkeley, Calif., after a long bout with cancer. He was 77 years old.

title: New Date for Tyson Bout
description: Mike Tyson's next title defense, against Frank Bruno in London, will take place Oct. 22. That was the determination made yesterday after Tyson's injured right hand was examined by Dr. David Chiu.

title: A Rapid Drop In Soviet Lake Called a Crisis
description: The Soviet Union's Aral Sea, once the fourth-largest lake in the world, is rapidly drying up because nearly all the water in its tributaries is being diverted for irrigation. By the end of the century, an American geographer has concluded, the lake could become lifeless and briny, leading to widespread ecologic and economic blight.

title: CPI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 23
Windshield Extortion
description: The last thing New York City should want is to discourage enterprise, especially among those hard to employ. But Mayor Koch is right about the need to curtail ''squeegee men,'' who wash windshields of stopped cars and then ask for tips.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums TRICKSTER STORIES, a collection of American Indian tales told by Diane Wolkstein, 11 A.M. tomorrow at the Hans Christian Andersen statue, near 72d Street and Fifth Avenue in Central Park. Free. FAMILY NIGHT, a performance by the Marie Brooks Dance Theater, a troupe of youngsters who will present a program of Caribbean and African dance and drumming, tonight at 7 at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue. Suggested contribution: children, $1; adults, $2. Information: (718) 735-4400. NORTH TO THE POLE, a sky show about the area above the Arctic Circle, the land of the midnight sun and views of the aurora borealis at its brightest, 3:30 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays, and 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, in the Henry B. duPont 3d Planetarium, the Museum of Art, Science and Industry, 4450 Park Avenue, Bridgeport, Conn. Free with museum admission: children, students and the elderly, $2; others, $3.50. Information: (203) 372-3521. ''CINDERELLA WORE COMBAT BOOTS,'' a play with a new slant on the legendary character, 5 P.M. Fridays, 1 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, at the Westside Arts Theater, 407 West 43d Street. Tickets: $7. Reservations: 541-8394. ''THE WIZARD OF OZ,'' a show by the Puppetworks Theater, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays at 287 Third Avenue, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Tickets: $3.75. Information: (718) 834-1828. ''THE ROSE THAT REFUSED TO BLOOM,'' a musical with audience participation, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays, and ''The Snow White Show,'' a musical, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at the 13th Street Repertory Company, 50 West 13th Street. Tickets: $4. Information: 675-6677. MYSTIC (CONN.) SEAPORT, a 17-acre outdoor maritime museum with historic ships, exhibition buildings and two restaurants. Open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. Admission: chilren, $5.50, under 4, free; adults, $11. Information: (203) 572-0711. CLINTON HISTORIC MUSEUM VILLAGE, a 10-acre farm with a 1763 mill, blacksmith shop, log cabin and general store, open 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesdays through Sundays, a quarter of a mile off Interstate 78 in Clinton, N.J. Admission: children, $1.50; the elderly, $2; others, $4. Brochure available. Information: (201) 735-4101. BIBLICAL GARDEN at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine with species of trees, plants and flowers grown in biblical times; open daily from 7 A.M. to sunset, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street. Free. Information: 316-7540. VALLEY RAILROAD, with 1910 cars carrying passengers from the old Essex Station in Connecticut to Chester, a 10-mile round trip. Then a one-hour cruise up the Connecticut River may be taken from the Deep River Station; 10:30 and 11:45 A.M., 1:15, 2:45, 4:15 and 5:30 P.M., Saturday and Sunday; no boat trip connecting with the 5:30 train. Train-boat combination: children, $4.95; adults, $9.95; train only: children, $2.95; adults, $6.95; children under 2, free. Brochure and map available. Information: (203) 767-0103. JAPANESE HILL AND POND GARDEN, with exotic fish in the pond, a display of water lilies and other flowers in bloom on the conservatory plaza at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The garden is open Tuesdays through Fridays from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M., and on weekends and holidays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., 1000 Washington Avenue, at Crown Street. Information: (718) 622-4433. BARTLETT ARBORETUM, a 63-acre garden owned by the University of Connecticut, with flowers, trails, a tree walk with labeled trees and a dwarf conifer collection, at 151 Brookdale Road, Stamford, Conn. Information: (203) 322-6971. THEODORE ROOSEVELT SANCTUARY, a preserve of 12 wooded acres, with trees and vines planted to attract birds, and a visitors' center, in Oyster Bay, L.I. Admission: $1.50. Information: (516) 922-3200. NEW CANAAN (CONN.) NATURE CENTER, a 40-acre site, with trails open from sunrise to sunset and exhibition buildings and greenhouses open 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays and 12:30 to 4:30 P.M. Sundays, at 144 Oenoke Ridge Road. Free. Information: (203) 966-9577. FLAT ROCK BROOK NATURE CENTER, a 75-acre preserve with two ponds, a meadow, stream and woodlands, with volunteer guides and two naturalists, open daily from dawn to dusk, with scheduled walks on some Saturdays and Sundays. At 443 Van Nostrand Avenue, Englewood, N.J. Free. Information: (201) 567-1265.

title: Hussein Delivers a Challenge, but Not to P.L.O.
description: To the Editor:

title: Bangladesh Flood Toll Up to 680 in Monsoon
description: Office workers in small boats and banana-plant rafts sailed to work through flooded streets in the capital today as the Burhi Ganga River reached its highest level in 34 years - more than 23 feet.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Labor Day will be observed on Monday. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK

title: Soviets Warn U.S. Against Abandoning ABM Pact
description: A Soviet arms control official asserted today that the Reagan Administration might be seeking a pretext for withdrawing from the Antiballistic Missile Treaty and said that such a move could provoke a crisis in Soviet-American relations.

title: Afghan Guerrillas Fire Rockets at Capital
description: Moslem guerrillas fired rockets at Kabul and its airport today and Afghan warplanes struck deep into Pakistan.

title: Lizzie Borden's Passion
description: ''The Passion of Lizzie Borden,'' a one-act opera by Mira J. Spektor, with a libretto by Ruth Whitman, is to be featured in an hourlong program of opera excerpts and songs presented by the West End Opera Theater at Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center on Sunday at 2 and 3 P.M. Admission is free. Information: 799-0101.

title: Diagnostic Ventures reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said it has changed its name to DVI Financial Corp.

title: Dukakis Camp Warned on Debates' Deadline
description: The chairman of George Bush's campaign today warned Michael S. Dukakis's campaign that he was not going to wait forever to agree on when Presidential debates should be held. He indicated he might start filling Mr. Bush's schedule with other events.

title: Chain Across Hudson Held the British Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Warner Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $500,000 from an accounting change.

title: May Stores Begins Offer for Shares
description: The May Department Stores Company said it had begun a ''Dutch auction'' tender offer for 14.1 million shares of its stock to finance its recently announced shopping-center joint venture with Melvin Simon & Associates and the Prudential Insurance Company of America. The shares sought represent 9.4 percent of May's 150.4 million common shares outstanding.

title: Brazil Votes Limit on Rates
description: Brazil's Congress has voted to fix inflation-adjusted interest rates at 12 percent a year under the country's new constitution, despite protests from bankers and business executives that the measure will not work.

title: Bass Group Gets Extra Day To Reach Savings Unit Deal
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it would extend until Friday its exclusive negotiations with the Robert M. Bass Group of Fort Worth over the purchase of the nation's largest insolvent savings institution, the American Savings and Loan Association of Stockton, Calif.

title: Islanders Sign Top Pick
description: Tom Fitzgerald, the first-round draft pick of the Islanders in the 1986 draft and the second-leading scorer last season at Providence College, agreed to a multiyear contract, the team said yesterday.

title: Gretzky Pact Extended
description: Wayne Gretzky, who was acquired by the Los Angeles Kings from the Edmonton Oilers last month, reached an agreement with the Kings to extend his contract past the four years remaining, the Kings announced yesterday.

title: CONCERN ON MEESE PROMPTS TRIP BAN
description: The Justice Department said today that Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, concerned over a recent trip to Japan by former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and five department officials, would impose a new policy to bar official trips unless they relate directly to an employee's work.

title: Man Held for Not Giving Jury Tompkins Sq. Tape
description: In a swift strike by the Manhattan District Attorney's office, an artist who videotaped police and demonstrators clashing in Tompkins Square Park was arrested yesterday and charged with contempt of court for refusing to turn over the tape.

title: J. Edgar's Building
description: The J. Edgar Hoover Building it is. And, acccording to the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the J. Edgar Hoover Building it should stay.

title: A Multifarious Approach To Sound
description: Clarence (Gatemouth) Brown, who performed at the Lone Star Cafe on Tuesday night, is one of those odd American creations that arrive, style fully formed, completely assured of their relevancy. The 68-year-old Mr. Brown, a guitarist, violinist and harmonica player, was among the first musicians to mix the sound of a roaring big band with a new instrument, the electric guitar, which in his hands took on a lacerating, savage character.

title: Bridge
description: Soon after World War II, two brilliant young Italians devised a bizarre bidding method, far ahead of its time, that they used with success in international championships in the 50's. They were Mario Franco and Michele Giovine, and their system, named from the first halves of their first names, was ''Marmic.''

title: U.N. Offers Gloomy View of Gulf Talks
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations said today that no substantive progress had been possible in the Iran-Iraq peace talks because of the deep mistrust between the two warring neighbors.

title: Alaska Journal; Marketing Glacier Ice Is a Hot New Industry
description: About 100,000 glaciers cover nearly 5 percent of this vast state. It's hard to see the ice cubes for the bergs.

title: Man Is Shot to Death As a Gunman Fires Into a Concert Crowd
description: One man was killed and four people were wounded yesterday, one critically, when a gunman fired into a crowd of 350 outside a memorial rap concert in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Videotape Collection
description: The National Archives, repository of such precious papers as the Constitution and Declaration of Independence, appears to be acutely attentive, as well, to the value of modern documentary resources such as videotape recordings. Recently the Archives signed an agreement with the Cable Satellite Public Affairs Network to deposit 200 cubic feet of videotaped programs from the years 1979 to 1983.

title: Datavision Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter includes an addition of $700,000 to reserves for potentially uncollectable receivables.

title: Correction
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday misidentified a man who appeared at a news conference with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Mayor Koch. Stanley Hill is executive director of District Council 37, the municipal workers' union, not an aide to Mr. Jackson.

title: Ralf Ralf: Gibberish as an Art Art
description: Two men meet in ''The Summit,'' which will be performed by Ralf Ralf at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater this weekend. Dressed in drab business suits, they are participants at an international conference. Representing opposite sides at the conference table, they hector and cajole each other in a stream of political discourse that ends with fleeting moments of closeness before the battle lines are drawn again.

title: Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss and after a $450 million provision for Trans-border losses for both the quarter and 9 months. Year-ago results are restated. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 449 money market mutual funds decreased $2.01 billion, to $267.04 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 126 institutional funds decreased $637.6 million, to $69.04 billion. Assets of the 221 general-purpose funds declined $333.8 million, to $85.04 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds decreased $1.04 billion, to $112.96 billion.

title: On the Jersey Shore, a Summer to Forget
description: For the first time since he bought the Sea Spray Motel 12 years ago, Jeff Konnor will have to advertise this winter. Charles Perkins has canceled plans to expand his real-estate company. Bill and Michele Willem may not be back at all next season. They've put their restaurant up for sale.

title: Economic Scene; How Well Off Are Workers?
description: LABOR DAY 1988 is bound to yield a great deal of partisan oratory on the economic status of American working men and women and how to improve it. The Republicans will focus on the long spell of economic expansion since 1982, the lowest rate of unemployment in 14 years, the increase in the number of workers employed and the huge increase in employment that lies ahead. The Democrats will stress the decline of real wages, the sluggish growth of productivity, the inequality in the distribution of income, the shift of employment from higher-paying manufacturing jobs to lower-paying service jobs and the tougher economic problems confronting young people today than those their parents faced.

title: Liberty Military Sales reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Audiotronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter includes a write-off of about $191,000 on improvements at a former factory the company leases in Minnesota. The company also said the loss for the year reflects the adverse effect of the decline in the dollar's value from last year, significantly raising its costs earlier in the year.

title: Reviews/Art; Old Master Paintings From Behind Closed Doors
description: At a time of widespread interest in Dutch painting, ''Dutch and Flemish Paintings From Private New York Collections,'' at the National Academy of Design, makes sense. Because it has more to do with demonstrating the strength of Old Master collections in New York than with formulating themes and arguments, it is low key. It presents familiar material in a way that allows the public to discover ideas and themes for itself.

title: San Diego Gas Rejects Higher Bid From SCE
description: The San Diego Gas and Electric Company rejected a sweetened takeover bid of $2.35 billion today and vowed to pursue its own merger plans with the Tucson Electric Power Company.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Guilty Plea in Vernon Case
description: The former Dallas real estate consultant Jack D. Franks agreed today to plead guilty to one count of aiding and abetting bank fraud at the Vernon Savings and Loan Association as part of a plea agreement granting him immunity from other criminal charges, Federal investigators said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Publix Super Markets Shifts Account to West
description: Publix Super Markets Inc., Lakeland, Fla., has switched agencies for its $15 million in advertising spending. The account goes from Louis Benito Advertising, Tampa's largest agency, to West & Company in Jacksonville, which already handles marketing for Publix.

title: Panama Paid Quayle Adviser, Campaign Says
description: Stuart Spencer, a longtime political adviser to President Reagan who is now the guiding force of Senator Dan Quayle's Vice-Presidential campaign, was paid for a year and a half as a consultant by the Panamanian Government ''to improve Panama's image worldwide,'' a Quayle campaign spokesman said today.

title: Stewart & Stevenson Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in the latest second quarter.

title: Idetta to Perform
description: Odetta, the folk singer, will perform tonight and tomorrow at Speakeasy, 107 McDougal Street (598-9670). Sets are at 8:30 and 11 P.M., with Peter Spencer opening tonight and Buddy Mondlock tomorrow; admission is $10 with a two-drink minimum.

title: CONSTRUCTION SPENDING UP 1.2% IN JULY
description: Construction spending in July posted its sharpest increase in four months, but only partly recovered from a slump in June.

title: Philippines' Debt Rises
description: The Philippines' foreign debt rose to a record $28.95 billion at the end of April, from the previous high of $28.65 billion at the end of March, Central Bank statistics showed today. No explanation was given for the increase. The debt will reach $34 billion by 1992, said the Economic Planning Minister, Solita Monsod.

title: Man in the News; Tough Polish Negotiator: Czeslaw Kiszczak
description: When Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak was named recently to hold talks with leaders of various social groups to seek ways out of Poland's crisis, many Poles reacted at first with a kind of surprise, and then - after a double-take - with a nod of understanding.

title: Article 965888 -- No Title
description: Easco Hand Tools Inc., Hunt Valley, Md., is offering $100 million of 12 7/8 percent speculative-grade notes due in 1998, at a price of 99.304, to yield 13 percent, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: New York City Plans Special Foster Care For Troubled Youths
description: New York City will create special group homes for troubled foster children and send some to an out-of-state school, under a plan to deal with hundreds of youngsters who have been bouncing from one overnight placement to another.

title: Jewish Settler Shoots Troops By Mistake in Chasing Arab
description: The police detained a Jewish settler in the occupied West Bank after he accidentally shot and wounded two Israeli soldiers while chasing a Palestinian who hurled a firebomb at his car, officials said today.

title: Review/Film; Coming Of Age In Vermont
description: There are enough carefully researched period artifacts to stock a claustrophobically crowded museum. Scene after scene, shot in golden light and crammed with nicely homely faces, looks as if it came straight out of a Norman Rockwell portfolio. But fine performances take hold about a third of the way through ''The Wizard of Loneliness,'' which opens today at the 57th Street Playhouse, and this chronicle of a lonely, bratty young boy adrift in a friendly Vermont village in 1944 becomes genuinely poignant and colorful.

title: Labor Day Revels in Three-State Region
description: LEAD: Long Island

title: Dr. Hans Lewy, 83, Mathematics Profesor
description: Hans Lewy, a professor emeritus of mathematics at the University of California at Berkeley, died of leukemia Aug. 23 in Berkeley, where he lived. He was 83 years old.

title: Two Fire-Ravaged States Shut Forests for Holiday
description: In the midst of the worst fire season in decades, officials in two Western states took measures yesterday to keep hunters, fishers and campers out of forests over the Labor Day weekend.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: John Scofield Trio

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday LIFE CAN BE FUNNY

title: Labor Day Revels in Three-State Region
description: Westchester County

title: Hatch Says Democrats 'Party of Homosexuals'
description: A day after referring to Democrats as ''the party of homosexuals,'' Senator Orrin Hatch said today he never intended to brand all Democrats as such. But Democrats quickly pounced on the Utah Republican's remarks as unbelievable and insulting.

title: Seoul Journal; Tortured Dissenter Lives to See Far Better Days
description: In the hot, bright summer of his first few weeks of freedom, Kim Keun Tae is blinking at the changes in his life and his country.

title: Goodman Fielder Ends Bid for Ranks
description: Australia's largest food company, Goodman Fielder Ltd., dropped its bid to buy Ranks Hovis McDougall P.L.C., one of Britain's biggest bakers. The offer of $:1.7 billion ($2.85 billion) had been under study by Britain's Monopolies and Mergers Commission. Ranks Hovis is one of the two main bakers of bread in Britain, and the Department of Trade and Industry had said it was worried about how the takeover would affect competition. It referred the bid to the commission for study two weeks ago.

title: Labor Day Revels in Three-State Region
description: Hudson Valley

title: Restaurants
description: The Polo is a plush and patrician refuge in the Westbury Hotel on East 69th Street that has gone through dramatic changes in recent years. Long known as a comfortable if undistinguished Continental dining room, it made a serious commitment to fine dining about four years ago when it created a top-notch Provencal-style French menu under the chef Patrice Boely. As is so often the case with big hotel chains, the corporate winds shifted, new management arrived, and the French effort was dismantled. American cuisine was hot, and that's what the new team wanted.

title: Man, Wife and Hat
description: A British film version of ''The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat,'' a chamber opera by Michael Nyman based on a case study and book by Dr. Oliver Sacks, a neurologist, is to be shown at Film Forum 1, 57 Watts Street, today at 4, 4:30, 7, 8:30 and 10 P.M. The 75-minute film was directed by Christopher Rawlence and includes comments by Dr. Sacks intercut with the opera. The singers are Emile Belcourt, a tenor; Frederick Westcott, a baritone, and Patricia Hooper, a soprano. There will also be showings tomorrow, Sunday and Monday at 1, 2:30, 4, 5:30, 7, 8:30 and 10:00 P.M. Tickets are $5. Information: 431-1592.

title: Dow Drops By 29.34, To 2,002.31
description: Stock prices plunged across a broad front yesterday, leaving the Dow Jones industrial average barely above the 2,000 mark.

title: 2 Arrested in Check-Cashing Scheme
description: Two Brooklyn men were arrested Wednesday and charged with stealing more than $500,000 in a fraudulent check-cashing scheme that spread to about 150 bank branches across New York City over a two-year period.

title: Cuomo Signs Bill on AIDS Confidentiality
description: Doctors will soon be able to tell needle-sharing or sexual partners of AIDS-infected people that they are in danger of contracting the fatal disease under provisions of a bill signed into law today by Governor Cuomo.

title: Ex-Firestone President Takes Post at Whirlpool
description: Albert E. Suter, who left the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company this summer after a short stint as its president and chief operating officer, was named to similar posts yesterday at the Whirlpool Corporation.

title: Leader Booed in Mexican Congress
description: Interrupted repeatedly by the jeers and chants of newly strengthened opposition parties, President Miguel de la Madrid delivered his final state-of-the-nation address today. He defended the disputed presidential election in July as totally ''in accordance with the Constitution and the electoral laws of the republic.''

title: Crew Discussed Engine Problem Before Jet Crash
description: The crew of the Delta Air Lines jet that crashed in Texas Wednesday spoke of an engine problem in the seconds after it took off and before it fell back to the ground and skidded to a flaming stop 3,000 feet past the end of the runway, a Government official said yesterday.

title: Audio-Video Affiliates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $609,000 from the sale of the company's stake in Cyclops Corp. for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Let 'Em Eat Swiss Cheese
description: George Bush got a big laugh from the mostly affluent Republicans who heard his acceptance speech when he derided Democratic references to ''a Swiss cheese economy.'' Now the Census Bureau has confirmed that the economy is, indeed, riddled with holes; and that's no laughing matter.

title: SOVIET PLAYER BEATS SHRIVER
description: Conversations revolve around Steffi Graf's bid for the Grand Slam, Martina Navratilova's renewed efforts to stop her, the promise of Gabriela Sabatini and the perseverance of Chris Evert. But for Pam Shriver, this year's United States Open was another wasted opportunity, even briefer than most, the 11th annual chapter in her bid to win a major championship that seems more elusive than ever.

title: Harold S. Mohler Is Dead at 69; Long a Leader in Hershey Foods
description: Harold S. Mohler, former chief executive of the Hershey Foods Corporation, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center in Hershey, Pa. He was 69 years old and lived in Hershey.

title: 'Br'er Rabbit' Musical On a Showboat
description: ''Br'er Rabbit,'' a musical based on the Uncle Remus stories by Joel Chandler Harris, is being featured this weekend at the Driftwood Floating Theater Showboat, docked at Eddyville, N.Y., near Kingston. The original musical is by Richard Smithies and Maura Cavanagh. Performances are at 8 P.M. today and tomorrow; at 2:30 and 8:15 P.M. on Sunday, and at 2:30 P.M. on Monday. Tickets are $5. The theater can be reached from Exit 19 of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewer Thruway. Information: (914) 331-0400.

title: KEY RATES
Engineers Quit Koppers
description: While Brian C. Beazer continues to seek buyers for the chemical operations of his newly acquired Koppers Company, the Pittsburgh concern's engineering department announced Wednesday that it was breaking away to form a consulting firm. The new Chemtech Consultants Inc. will employ about 30 people, 18 of whom will be investors. The firm's specialties will be process controls and electricity generation from waste energy.

title: Olympic Look Head to Toe
description: Among the items the Olympic athletes, coaches and staff receive in the processing center are:

title: World After Reagan
description: For the price of $195 you may be able to skip the entire fall campaign contest between George Bush and Michael S. Dukakis and learn what it is going to be like here after the Reagan Administration. That is the fee for attending a seminar on ''The World After Reagan/The Transition Begins,'' to be held next Wednesday at the Westin Hotel.

title: Hussein Delivers a Challenge, but Not to P.L.O.; Arab Broadcasts
description: To the Editor:

title: Tennis Federation Rejects Tour Plan
description: The International Tennis Federation and the Grand Slam tournaments held a news conference yesterday to reject publicly the proposal by the Association of Tennis Professionals to organize its own international tour in 1990.

title: Banks Urged to Forgive Some Third World Debt
description: A United Nations development organization called on commercial banks today to forgive at least 30 percent of the debt of 15 heavily indebted developing nations.

title: A Baseball Club Tells Truth; Even Accepts Consequences
description: In all honesty, the Detroit Tigers did what they could. But it was the honesty that did them in.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Times Co. Purchases Sailing World Magazine
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had purchased Sailing World, a monthly boating magazine that focuses on racing and high performance, from the North American Publishing Company. The Times Company did not disclose how much it paid for the magazine, whose circulation is 53,000.

title: A 1,200-Page Recipe for Trade Disaster
description: LEAD: When the next President starts wrestling with the hard issues of trade and protection, he will find that Congress has handed him an albatross in the 1,200-page trade bill it passed this summer.

title: Quayle at Ease in the Field on Southern Tour
description: Senator Dan Quayle campaigned across the deep South today, showing new political confidence and vigor as questions about his earlier personal life appeared to be slipping deeper into the background of the 1988 Presidential race.

title: Toon Suffers Injury; May Miss Opener
description: Al Toon, the Jets' most consistent player and Pro Bowl receiver, has suffered a groin injury that will probably keep him out of the season opener against the Patriots Sunday.

title: Pop/Jazz; Music With Distant Roots Takes Hold
description: Some popular music aims to make the whole world dance, and to do so it seeks a national and international common denominator. Other music, however, maintains ties to a local community even when it's heard a long way from home. In the 1980's, many listeners have begun to prize music that refuses to be uprooted -and this weekend, two musicians who can conjure their hometowns with just a few notes are bringing San Antonio and Rio de Janeiro north to New York City.

title: Somebody Else Saw It, Too
description: One of the side benefits of the baseball collusion decisions is that some of us can stop wondering if we're nuts. Nobody likes to be the only person who sees the emperor is not wearing any clothing, or that the baseball owners must be conspiring to not sign free agents.

title: Rock Double Bill
description: Mofungo and Ritual Tension will play an avant-rock double bill tonight at 9 and midnight at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $7.

title: Reeves Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $956,000 and $2,286,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $219,000 and $720,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net loss Latest fourth quarter and year results include the initial syndication sales of the television show, ''Kate & Allie.''

title: Treasuries Flat in Listless Session
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed at the close of a listless trading session yesterday, as the credit market marked time in advance of this morning's August employment report and the start of the long Labor Day weekend.

title: DUKAKIS SCORNS BUSH VOW OF EDUCATION LEADERSHIP
description: Michael S. Dukakis today attacked the Reagan Administration's record on education and charged that Vice President Bush's pledge to be the ''education President'' was the product of ''an election year conversion.''

title: U.S. Won't Recall Samurai
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration denied a request today by the Center for Auto Safety that it recall the Suzuki Samurai utility vehicle, which critics have said is likely to tip over in abrupt maneuvers.

title: Hussein Delivers a Challenge, but Not to P.L.O.; Time to Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: Beaman Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $30,945 for the quarter and $67,597 for the 6 months.

title: Air Shows and Risks: At What Price Valor?
description: Eversince barnstorming daredevils first dazzled groundlings more than 60 years ago by turning audacious loops in their flying machines, the air show has been a fixture of aviation public relations.

title: Becker, McEnroe and Shriver Depart Early in Open
description: Neither may have been favored to win the United States Open, but some of the color and excitement will be missing for the rest of the tournament after John McEnroe and Boris Becker were eliminated yesterday.

title: Library Gets A Big Music Collection
description: One of the world's larger and more wide-ranging private collections of musical manuscripts, letters and documents has been given to the Music Division of the Library of Congress in Washington.

title: LABOR DAY REVELS IN 3 STATES
description: THE summer season traditionally comes to an end with Labor Day, a misnamed holiday distinguished by the decided absence of work and a day that is actually stretched into several days over a weekend that starts today and concludes Monday evening. It is a day so identified with the somewhat saddening exit of summer languor that it is easy to overlook a weekend calendar so filled with activity that little time may remain to mourn the low-key, if humidly deadening, months behind us.

title: Irish Distillers Stake Is Raised
description: Pernod Ricard S.A., a French drinks company, said today that it had increased to 2.8 percent its stake in Irish Distillers Group, the target of a hostile bid by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.

title: Datametrics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $136,000 for the quarter and $571,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $127,000 and $349,500 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: For 11 Tenants, Perseverance Brings a Victory
description: Housing they can afford is so scarce that 11 tenants at 49 Prospect Street clung to their apartments through two winters, even when their ceilings fell on them and pets froze to death and the mailman no longer delivered because of sewage in the mailroom. They felt their new landlord had hired ''goons'' to remove their doors, cut off their heat and water and force them from their $300-a-month rent-controlled apartments. They believed the landlord wanted to empty the 55-unit building and pursue a lucrative condo conversion.

title: New Face: Emmanuelle Chaulet; Learning From Eric Rohmer
description: Spending nights as the sole resident of a huge uncompleted building in a futuristic community miles from a great metropolis seems far beyond the usual requirements of a movie role, but Emmanuelle Chaulet was glad to oblige Eric Rohmer.

title: Review/Art; Nachume Miller's Turbulent, Syncopated Dreams
description: In several works on view at the Museum of Modern Art, Nachume Miller makes a virtue of obsessive drawing. The West German-born artist, now living in New York, nearly overwhelms large wood panels and sheets of paper with dense, complex webs of swirling lines that suggest tumultuous landscapes and unfathomable calamities.

title: Review/Film; A Nation Disillusioned
description: Of course John Sayles begins ''Eight Men Out'' with a little boy, with the kid who is the purest and most hopeful of baseball fans, the one whose subsequent plea, ''Say it ain't so, Joe!'' went down in history. ''Eight Men Out'' is the story of the 1919 World Series-fixing scheme that shattered the faith of this boy and so many others. As such, it's much more than a film about baseball. It's an amazingly full and heartbreaking vision of the dreams, aspirations and disillusionments of a nation, as filtered through its national pastime.

title: F.C.C. Fights Cable Piracy
description: Federal Communications Commission agents have seized illegal satellite unscrambling devices from businesses in four states in a drive to end cable piracy, the F.C.C. said today.

title: A Foreign Policy View That Goes Beyond East vs. West
description: Amid the patriotic oratory, the partisan fighting and the debate over character in the 1988 Presidential campaign, one of the most fundamental issues of the contest so far has been a question of credentials: would Michael S. Dukakis's inexperience in foreign policy keep him from being an effective President?

title: IMT Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said its wholly owned NDI Engineering Co. received a $1.1 million U.S. navy contract for engineering and technical services.

title: Real Computer Glitch Halts A Simulated Shuttle Mission
description: A real computer crash today halted a mock space shuttle mission in its final hours just before the five Discovery astronauts were preparing to simulate landing on a flat tire.

title: Chrysler Names Head Of Technologies Unit
description: The Chrysler Corporation's board yesterday named Paul E. Wright to the new post of chairman of Chrysler Technologies, which encompasses the company's aerospace and military businesses.

title: Japan Traders Get Hedge in Time
description: With Japanese stocks hovering near their all-time highs, one of the biggest gambles for anyone playing in the world's largest stock market is how long to linger. When the opening bells ring Saturday morning on the Tokyo and Osaka stock exchanges, investors will have their first opportunity to protect themselves against the day when the joyride is finally over.

title: Knight-Ridder Deal
description: Knight-Ridder Inc. completed its $353 million purchase of the Lockheed Corporation's Dialog Information Services Inc. on Wednesday. Dialog maintains the world's largest computer-based data bank, with more than 320 data bases serving 92,000 subscribers in 86 countries.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ketchum Buys Health Agency
description: Ketchum Communications Inc., Pittsburgh, has acquired Botto, Roessner, Horne & Messinger, a $22 million health care agency, which will continue to operate under its name and with its current management.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about American demands that the Soviet Union dismantle a disputed radar station misstated the year in which the Antiballistic Missile Treaty came into force. It was 1972.

title: Labor Day Revels in Three-State Region
description: New Jersey

title: Man Dies in Air Show Crash; Germany Puts the Toll at 49
description: A man died early today of burns suffered in the air show disaster here Sunday, and West German officials gave the first breakdown by nationality of the dead and injured.

title: Presidio Oil to Buy Energy Properties
description: The Presidio Oil Company has agreed to buy a group of oil and gas properties from the Standard Oil Production Company of Houston for Presidio common stock and cash estimated at $55 million, the two companies said. The acquisitions include proven reserves of six million barrels of oil and 22 billion cubic feet of natural gas as well as 30,000 acres of non-producing lease acreage. Presidio, based in Englewood, Colo., acquired a substantial portion of the King Ranch's oil and gas properties earlier this year.

title: Airline Sues Over Sales Of Flier Miles
description: American Airlines has filed lawsuits against four ticket brokers, accusing them of buying frequent-flier mileage from American's passengers and reselling it to people who cash it in for airline tickets.

title: U.S. and Soviet Work Out the Basics For Expanding Student Exchanges
description: Federal officials said yesterday that they had completed the framework of a program to permit the Soviet Union and the United States each to exchange up to 1,500 high school students a year by 1991. Until now, such exchanges had been limited to 50 students a year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/A2-12

title: 'Circuit Breaker' Plans Filed
description: The New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday filed proposals with regulatory agencies that would provide for trading to be halted when markets are falling rapidly.

title: REviews/Art; Reading Messages in Conceptualism Exhibition
description: While many might argue that art should be seen, not heard (or read), the loquaciousness of the visual is clearly on the rise. Language has played an important role in much 20th-century art, but never more so than since the late 1960's. At that time, Conceptual art loosened a flood of words - used singly, in provocative phrases and long texts - into what has become, increasingly, the mainstream. Since then, certain strains of art haven't stopped talking and, what's more, their conversations have become more and more accessible.

title: Hussein Delivers a Challenge, but Not to P.L.O.; Israel Pays the Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: EIL Instruments Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,700 for the quarter and $24,400 for the 9 months.

title: Leonor K. Sullivan, 86, Democrat of Missouri
description: Leonor K. Sullivan, a 12-term Democratic member of the House of Representatives, the only woman ever elected to Congress from Missouri, died today of heart failure. She was 86 years old.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A Branch of Docks

title: New Hershey Product
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation today announced a powdered chocolate mix that will be shipped to stores. Earlier this summer, Hershey withdrew its 32-year-old entry in the $200 million a year powdered-chocolate market, Hershey's Instant. The company said it planned a large television and direct mail advertising campaign. Anthony Pingitore, the general manager of Hershey's grocery products group, said the company would be satisfied if the new mix came in second to the industry's leader, Nestle's Quik.

title: F.C.C. Sets Technical Guidelines For High-Definition TV in 1990's
description: The Federal Communications Commission announced technical guidelines today that will bring high-definition television to the American public in the 1990's. The technology is expected to provide television pictures twice as clear as they are now.

title: Labor Day Revels in Three-State Region
description: Connecticut

title: CHILE ENDS EXILE OF ALLENDE FAMILY
description: President Augusto Pinochet today ended the enforced exile of many relatives and close associates of former President Salvador Allende Gossens, the Marxist overthrown by the armed forces 15 years ago.

title: Andersen And Utility In Inquiry
description: The tax and accounting practices of the Oglethorpe Power Corporation, an Atlanta-based electric cooperative, are the focus of a long-running criminal investigation, the Government official leading the inquiry said yesterday.

title: Insituform Gulf South Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Brookhurst Trims Its Stake in Zenith
description: Brookhurst Partners L.P., a partnership controlled by the New York arbitragers Herbert B. Abelow and Nicholas L. Ilasz, has lowered its stake in the Zenith Electronics Corporation to 6.1 percent, from 7.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Brookhurst said that it ''has engaged in discussions on several occasions with a potential acquirer of Zenith's computer products, systems and components group'' but that no agreements had been reached. In an S.E.C. filing in June, Brookhurst said it would try to get Zenith to sell its consumer electronics division.

title: Child World Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-After a gain of $2,853,000 representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Prab Robots reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss Backlog $7,182,000 versus $5,023,000 a year earlier. The company attributed its turnaround to strong demand for robot manufacturing and an increase in robot orders.

title: Curfew On, and Off Again
description: Hours after announcing yesterday that the city would re-impose a late-night curfew in the parks next week, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said he and Mayor Koch had had second thoughts and postponed the action ''until cooler weather.''

title: Saudis to Cut Wheat Aid
description: Saudi Arabia has decided to reduce subsidies for the 1989 wheat crop, an Agriculture Department report said Wednesday. Saudi Arabia has been subsidizing exports of wheat surpluses since 1985-86.

title: Heinz, H J Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
Parkers Are Told Fast-Meter Alibis Won't Work Anymore
description: Anxiety over parking tickets has long provided New York City drivers with a reason to jump out of bed early, speed along avenues in reverse, or plan a midnight drive from one side of the street to the other.

title: US Shoe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes one-time charges of about $3,100,000 from the closing of six front row apparel superstores and the effect of other non-recurring items. c-Net income and for the quarter includes a total non-recurring gain of about $7,300,000 resulting primarily of the sale of the J. Riggings men's wear division and of the men's show manufacturing and wholesale division; the 6 months include a $16,042,000 gain from accounting changes.

title: Knicks Match Offer
description: The Knicks have matched an offer made to Eddie Lee Wilkins by the Washington Bullets, the team announced yesterday.

title: Dollar and Pound Drop; Gold Falls
description: The dollar weakened slightly yesterday, as speculative trading in New York subsided in advance of the Labor Day holiday and today's report on the nation's employment.

title: Louis Effrat, Sportswriter, 78
description: Louis Effrat, a sports reporter for The New York Times for nearly 50 years, died yesterday at the Royal Manor Nursing home near his home in Royal Palm Beach, Fla.. He was 78 years old and had recently suffered a heart attack.

title: I.B.M. Picks Agencies, Replacing Lord, Geller
description: One of the most coveted accounts in advertising changed hands yesterday as the International Business Machines Corporation named Wells, Rich, Greene and Lintas:U.S.A. as its domestic agencies.

title: In Memory of Rooney
description: The Dallas Cowboys will wear the initials of Arthur Rooney Sr. on their helmets Sunday when they play the Steelers in Pittsburgh.

title: Failing Security Tests Costs 32 Airlines Fines
description: The Federal Aviation Administration levied more than $1 million in fines against 32 airlines today for failing security tests at airports.

title: Century Medicorp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a $300,000 tax benefit. c-Net loss The company said the increase in revenue was largely a result of the acquisition of Amerimed in April, a Burbank, Calif.-based health maintenance organization.

title: Silk Greenhouse Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes pre-opening costs of $230,000, compared with $69,000 a year ago.

title: 'La Generala Alegre' At Gremercy Arts
description: ''La Generala Alegre'' (''The General's Merry Wife''), a 1910 Spanish operetta, is to be presented by Repertorio Espanol tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street. The production is to be given in Spanish with an English synopsis; there also are performances scheduled for Sept. 10, 18 and 24.

title: 9 Are Held After Raids on Seafood Houses in South
description: Federal and state agents raided wholesale seafood houses in South Carolina, Florida and Louisiana today in a move to curb interstate selling of oysters and clams from polluted waters.

title:
About Real Estate;
Jersey City Development Emphasizing Old Charm
description: LEAD: The Port Liberte development taking shape along the Jersey City waterfront just south of Liberty State Park is adding an unusual piece of skyline to New York Harbor - one of pastel-colored buildings with gabled and peaked roofs, cupolas and widow's walks.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Hussein Delivers a Challenge, but Not to P.L.O.; The Lesson of Belgium
description: To the Editor:

title: Auctions
description: There were some who looked askance when Sotheby's held its first auction devoted to rock-and-roll memorabilia in December 1981. But rock has always been an enormous money maker, and as collectors have long realized, one doesn't have to be a performer, manager, record executive or merchandiser to reap the profits. One need only have held on long enough to the ephemera generated by the industry and its stars - particularly if it happened to include autographs, unissued recordings, song manuscripts, stage outfits or musical instruments used by rock's heroes.

title: Sale Terms Set On Texaco Unit
description: Texaco Inc. took another step toward selling its 78 percent interest in Texaco Canada by announcing that it had reached an agreement with the subsidiary on procedures that would protect the interests of minority shareholders.

title: United Chemicals
description: Ellis & Everard P.L.C. said it had conditionally agreed to acquire United Chemicals Inc., a wholly owned United States subsidiary of Sanitas Inc., for $36 million. The deal should be completed in mid-October. United is a chemical distributor operating in several states, with revenues of $87.6 million for the latest fiscal year.

title: Mark IV Suggests Higher Armtek Bid
description: Mark IV Industries said it was prepared to increase its tender offer for the Armtek Corporation if the two sides can reach a satisfactory merger agreement. Mark IV, which owns nearly 15 percent of Armtek's outstanding shares, is willing to increase its bid from $44 a share, to $46. With 12.35 million Armtek shares outstanding, the higher offer is worth $568 million, up from $543 million.

title: Jefferies, in a Short Time, Makes a Big Impression
description: Darryl Strawberry tore open his payroll envelope Wednesday and smiled. Check in hand, he suddenly had an idea. Strawberry walked across the clubhouse and handed the check to Gregg Jefferies.

title: Punjab Land Mine Kills 2
description: A land mine exploded under a police jeep on a highway north of Amritsar today, killing two constables and wounding three others, the police said. The explosion was believed to the be work of Sikh militants, an official said. It was the first reported incident of Sikh radicals using land mines in their campaign for an independent homeland in the Punjab.

title: Canadian Open; Alternate Steps In To Trail By Shot
description: Andy Dillard did not expect to play in the 79th Canadian Open this week. As a nonexempt player, he was an alternate.

title: Crazy Eddie Stake
description: The Baupost Group Inc., an investment partnership based in Cambridge, Mass., has acquired the equivalent of a 9.2 percent stake in Crazy Eddie Inc. as part of a refinancing by the troubled chain of electronics stores. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Baupost said it was holding the Crazy Eddie debentures for investment purposes only. On Aug. 24, Baupost acquired $20.5 million worth of Crazy Eddie convertible debentures.

title: Chrysler Venture With Mitsubishi
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation began producing cars in a joint venture that auto analysts say will pull Chrysler even with its United States competitors in the race for Japanese expertise. Chrysler is the last of the Big Three to open a domestic auto plant with a Japanese company.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Capital and Research Corp., Fairfax, Va., a financial holding company that owns professional and technical services companies, named Kenneth T. Nelson treasurer.

title: California Jockey Club reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Role Rehearsal for Law's Women
description: From Spencer Tracy in ''Inherit the Wind'' to Debra Winger in ''Legal Eagles,'' great actors have made great lawyers. But, according to Karen Ludwig, that's only half the story; great lawyers also have to be great actors.

title: Credit Agreement By Cable Operator
description: The Century Communications Corporation, New Canaan, Conn., which owns and operates cable television systems, said yesterday that it had concluded a $600 million long-term credit agreement with about eight banks led by Citibank. The agreement includes a competitive-bid commercial paper facility.

title: Hauserman Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lectec Corp reports earnings for
Bill in Jersey Could Cut Cost Of Car Policies
description: An automobile-insurance bill that its supporters say could reduce average annual premiums by $120 and eliminate the need for future surcharges was passed by the Assembly yesterday and sent to Governor Kean, who has promised to sign it.

title: Reviews/Music; South African Band Blends Two Cultures
description: Johnny Clegg and Savuka, the South African sextet whose two albums have catapulted the group to stardom in Europe, play vibrant, accessible pop music that is calculatedly internationalist in vocabulary and subject matter.

title: Productivity Fell by 1.4% In 2d Quarter
description: The efficiency of nonfarm businesses in producing goods and services dropped at an annual rate of 1.4 percent in the second quarter, an improvement over the 1.7 percent decline originally reported for the quarter. It was the first quarterly decline since 1986.

title: Dukakis and Jackson: Still Apart
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said in Atlanta that he wanted no big job in the Democratic campaign and no title. What he wanted was respect - to be accepted as a man with useful advice and as a politician capable of delivering a constituency. Apparently he's still a long way from achieving these objectives. And this reflects poorly on the sensibilities and political judgment of the Dukakis team.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: (Seedings in parentheses.) STADIUM Morning 11 A.M.: Jimmy Connors (6) vs. Gilad Bloom.

title: Litton Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is an enormous psychological problem and a social problem. The whole population of Quebec feels that it has been contaminated by PCB's.'' - Dr. Stephane Groulx, an environmental health specialist, on hazardous fire near Montreal. [ A8:2. ]

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Policy Shift By Hispanic Broadcasters
description: HARD-LIQUOR advertising, while never seen on the major broadcast networks or on most local stations, has never been totally banned from television. Most broadcasters have long respected a policy of not accepting liquor commercials, although no legal bar exists to showing them.

title: Giants Fighting Distractions
description: The last four days have been unsettling for the Giants, to say the least.

title: BURMA RULES OUT NEW CONCESSIONS
description: Confrontation between the Burmese Government and its people intensified today as huge crowds filled the streets to demand democratic elections and the President responded on radio that no further concessions would be made.

title: Central Sprinkler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. to End Bond Plan
description: The Treasury Department said Wednesday that it would scrap a four-month-old program that offered investors a 24-hour, toll-free telephone number to buy United States Savings Bonds with a credit card. Investors used the program to buy $4.5 million in bonds from its inception on May 3 through mid-August. Jerrold B. Speers, executive director of the Treasury's Savings Bonds division, said the program ''proved not cost-effective'' and would end Sept. 30.

title: Two Fined for Stunt at Falls
description: Two college students who tried to go over the Horseshoe Falls in a makeshift barrel almost two years ago have been fined $4,725 each by the Coast Guard. The two, Harry Kallet of Bridgeport, N.Y., and Michael Viscosi of Schenectady, N.Y., had hoped to be the first two-man team to go over the falls, but they abandoned the effort after their craft sprang a leak. They were rescued with ropes. Mr. Kallet, saying he has already paid $15,000 in fines, legal fees and other costs, remarked: ''I thought this was all over. Can't we ever forget this?''

title: Review/Operetta; Making a Virtue Out of Marietta's Lack of Same
description: A dollop of inconsequential frippery can be a good thing on occasion, particularly in these few weeks between the end of the summer festivals and the start of the regular season. In recent years, the New York City Opera has been doing its share in the light entertainment department by way of its operetta series, and the one currently on display is Victor Herbert's ''Naughty Marietta.'' The company is performing the work through Sept. 11 with two rotating casts, the second of which gave its first performance on Wednesday evening at the New York State Theater.

title: Thrifty Rent-A-Car reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Perestroika's Perilous Spinoffs
description: Passions over empire and nationalism stir in Eastern Europe once again. Twice before in this century, such conflicts plunged the world into total war. Much has changed since 1945. But it would be hazardous to underestimate the significance of the forces now at play. For the most part, they have been unleashed by the positive initiatives of Mikhail Gorbachev.

title: At the Bar
description: ''Freedom of association,'' the right to belong to groups of one's choosing, is nowhere mentioned in the Constitution. It is a concept often read into the First Amendment by lawyers, argued by lawyers, written and refined by lawyers, expanded and expounded by lawyers. But now the principle has been applied to lawyers and the legal profession is aghast.

title: Israeli's Remark That Palestinians Look to P.L.O. Turns Some Heads
description: The director general of Israel's Foreign Ministry has caused political ripples here and in Israel by saying that Palestinians see the Palestine Liberation Organization as their ''national organization'' and that there is no replacement for it. Israel has steadfastly refused to deal with the P.L.O., which it deems a terrorist organization.

title: Cubans Talked Secretly With the Angolan Rebels
description: Cuban officials and American-backed Angolan rebels held secret face-to-face meetings for the first time last weekend, both sides said today, and State Department officials and rebel representatives characterized the encounter as a welcome development in the 13-year-old Angolan conflict.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allis-Chalmers Corp., Milwaukee, said it had received Bankruptcy Court approval for its agreement to sell its worldwide air filter business to Syndergeneral Corp. for about $245 million in cash.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: George Coleman

title: Mitchell Energy & Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax increase of $13.2 million to the provision for litigation exposure. c-Net income

title: Home Buying Costs Increase
description: Americans hoping to buy their first homes face the worst conditions in 10 years, the National Association of Realtors said in a report released Wednesday.

title: Amoco Completes Takeover of Dome
description: A Canadian unit of the Amoco Corporation completed the largest corporate takeover in Canada's history: the acquisition, worth $5.5 billion (Canadian), or about $4.4 billion, of the once-high-flying oil explorer Dome Petroleum Ltd. Amoco will gain the huge Canadian oil and gass assets of Dome, which was brought low by debt and plunging oil prices, but will also take on Dome's debt of $6 billion (Canadian).

title: Westerbeke Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net loss

title: German Copy of 1939 Baltic Protocol Preserved
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire and Toxic Cloud in Canada Cause Alarm and Recrimination
description: Health officials and politicians are debating how to deal with one of Canada's worst environmental disasters, a fire at a Quebec warehouse that released toxic chemicals known as PCB's and forced the evacuation of more than 3,300 people.

title: Congas in the Night
description: A Night of Congas, part of the New York Salsa Festival, will feature Eddie Palmieri and his Latin Jazz Ensemble, Daniel Ponce and Arawe and the guest conga soloist Giovanni Hidalgo. Shows begin tonight at 9:30 and at 12:30 A.M. at the Village Gate, 160 Bleecker Street, at Thompson Street (475-5120). Tickets are $17.50, and there is a two-drink minimum.

title: Bush, in Enemy Waters, Says Rival Hindered Cleanup of Boston Harbor
description: Vice President Bush, saying he was tired of taking verbal ''sludge'' from Gov. Michael S. Dukakis on the environment, took a boat ride across Boston Harbor today and accused his Democratic rival of neglecting its pollution and hindering its cleanup.

title: Dining Out Guide: Near Shopping and Movies
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Alo Alo ** (June 21, 1985), 1030 Third Avenue, at 61st Street (838-4343) - Alo Alo's wraparound glass walls invite people-watching after a day of shopping or an evening at the movies. This is a cheerfully noisy Italian bistro designed in the grand-cafe style. For starters, try the carpaccio of raw, marinated swordfish with vegetable and herb garnish, or the steamed and roasted vegetable plate. Among the crowd-pleasing pastas are the conchiglie alla bolognese, small shells with Bolognese sauce, mushrooms and fresh rosemary, and farfalle primavera. A good seafood choice is poached salmon with tomato coulis. Appetizers are $6 to $11, main courses $11.50 to $22. Open noon to 11:45 P.M. Friday to Sunday. Arizona 206 Cafe Diner's Journal (Dec. 26, 1986), 206 East 60th Street (838-0440) - Aficionados of blazing Southwestern cooking will appreciate the chili-stoked cuisine at this smart-looking annex to the Arizona 206 restaurant. Bleached wood, stucco and fabric-covered banquettes in desert colors provide an evocative setting for the food. The chef has created an all-day tasting menu (different each day) offering appetizer-size portions. There are some standards, however, and these include hacked smoked chicken with vegetable slaw, empanaditas (cornmeal meat pies filled with minced pork, dried apricots and spices in ancho chili sauce), and grilled vegetables with cheese. Grilled fish is also served, and marinated shrimp and chayote squash salad are sometimes on the menu. The tasting menu ranges from $4 to $12. Open noon to midnight Friday and Saturday and (beginning Sept. 11) 5 P.M. to midnight Sunday. Contrapunto * (Nov. 23, 1984), 200 East 60th Street (751-8616) - Pastas are the main attraction at Contrapunto, an informal, glass-walled restaurant a flight above street level. The menu begins with several good salad appetizers: grilled mushroom salad with garlic and olive oil, or a salad of tomato, sweet pepper, fennel and mozzarella in Tuscan olive oil. Twenty pasta dishes follow, with a small selection of seafood specials. Some recommended choices are angel-hair pasta with sun-dried tomatoes, shallots, leeks, basil and clams, and fusilli with bitter greens, Parmesan cheese, tomato, garlic, jalapeno peppers and virgin olive oil. One of the best seafood dishes is brodetto (fish stew), a carefully prepared melange of seafood and shellfish, garlic and herbs, served over angel-hair pasta. Entrees are $11.75 to $18.75. Open noon to midnight Friday to Sunday. Primola ** (Feb. 20, 1987), 1226 Second Avenue, near 65th Street (758-1775) -Primola's spare decor contrasts with the lively crowd it attracts. The extensive menu of fresh and vividly seasoned dishes is enhanced by many specials. Two that excel are the homemade ravioli filled with seasoned ricotta, spinach and herbs, and fettuccine with assorted wild mushrooms and tomato. Among the regular appetizers are sauteed sliced artichokes, and salmon marinated with fennel, red onions and capers. An impressive special entree is roasted whole sea bass for two; other good selections are grilled giant shrimp seasoned with lemon, garlic and oregano, and grilled baby snapper with balsamic vinegar sauce. Grilled quails, another special, are served with polenta. Prices at dinner are $7 to $9 for appetizers, $13 to $22.50 for entrees. Open noon to 2:30 P.M. Friday and 5 P.M. to midnight Friday to Sunday. Yellowfingers di Nuovo Diner's Journal (Sept. 4, 1987), 200 East 60th Street (751-8615) - This updated version of the old Yellowfingers has an exposed kitchen and a terrace behind glass for dining with a view of this neighborhood's busy street life. The rosemary-roasted chicken salad is highly recommended: it has still-warm pieces of white meat on fresh greens with pine nuts and sweet pepper. A special summer appetizer is a salad of fresh figs, prosciutto and Gorgonzola. Small pizzas have many toppings, incluuding tomato, buffalo mozzarella, eggplant, roasted peppers, basil and aioli. The grill turns out an appealing selection that includes swordfish with herb butter, snapper with braised greens, and roasted vegetables dressed with balsamic vinegar and extra-virgin olive oil. Appetizers are $3.50 to $9.75, pizzas $5.75 to $12.50 and grilled items $9.50 to $17.50. Open noon to 1 A.M. Friday and Saturday, noon to midnight Sunday.

title: Correction
description: An article Aug. 25 on the new logotype for Lincoln Center incompletely attributed the design of the NBC symbol. The network's current peacock logo was designed by Chermayeff & Geismar Associates, but the original peacock logo was designed by John J. Graham and Herbert Lubalin.

description: Imperial City New York By Geoffrey Moorhouse 320 pages. Henry Holt. $21.95.

title: High Court Refuses to Halt Fines Against Yonkers in Housing Case
description: The Supreme Court on Thursday night refused to stay a contempt ruling against the City of Yonkers for failing to implement a federally ordered desegregation plan, but stayed a lower court ruling that had upheld contempt citations against four Yonkers Councilmen for blocking the plan, a high court spokeswoman said.

title: Burundi Official in Brussels Seeking Aid From Europeans
description: Foreign Minister Cyprien Mbonimpa of Burundi visited Belgian and European Community officials today seeking aid for his country, which has been torn by tribal bloodshed.

title: One Nation, Divisible, With Liberty for None
description: LEAD: The debate over whether the Pledge of Allegiance should be made compulsory in our schools has thus far been long on rhetoric and short on history.

title: Tylan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,260,000 from non-recurring items for the quarter; the year includes a $476,000 gain on equity in a joint venture and a $2,500,000 gain from several non- recurring items. c-Net loss and the year includes a $5,700,000 loss for non-recurring and unusual items and a$525,000 gain on the sale of a division.

title: Sounds of a Saxophone
description: Sonny Fortune, an alto saxophonist, will lead a quartet tnight and tomorrow at Birdland, 2745 Broadway, at 105th Street (749-2228). Music begins at 9 P.M.; there is a $5 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: APPEAL BY WALESA FAILS TO RESOLVE ALL POLISH STRIKES
description: Striking Polish workers, voicing strong misgivings about the results of talks between the Government and Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, were deeply divided today over whether to heed his appeal that they end their strikes and return to work.

title: Renaissance GRX reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hotel Bomb Kills 2 in Namibia
description: A bomb exploded this evening at a downtown hotel frequented by blacks, killing 2 people and injuring 10, the police said.

title: Red Sox Cut Tigers' Lead to One Game
description: Larry Parrish's two-run home run keyed a four-run sixth inning that lifted the Boston Red Sox to a 4-2 victory over the California Angels tonight.

title: With Words to Music
description: Marion Cowings and Kim Shaw, two singers, will lead their group tonight and tomorrow at the Golden Eagle Pub, 579 Avenue of the Americas, above 16th Street (633-2220). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and at 1 A.M.; there is an $8 cover charge and no minimum.

title: Cadbury Posts Profit Increase
description: The British candy and soft-drink company Cadbury-Schweppes P.L.C. announced today that pretax profits for the first six months of 1988 rose by 28.3 percent. The company's chairman, Sir Adrian Cadbury, said he expected further growth this year.

title: Fur Vault Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: b-Net income c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,318,000 for the quarter and $932,000 for the year.

title: Reebok Executive Settles Insider Case With S.E.C.
description: A vice president of Reebok International Ltd. today settled insider-trading charges that accused him of selling shares of Avia Group International Inc. because he had confidential information that Reebok would merge with its smaller rival.

title: Bolt Technology Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
