title: After Mental Collapse, Officer Sues for Pension
description: On a bright May afternoon at an entrance to Central Park, Paul J. Hipple, an undercover police officer, was on the ground wrestling in a life-and-death struggle with a cocaine dealer.

title: F.D.A. Weighs 'Smokeless' Jurisdiction
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had advised the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company that the agency's review of the company's new ''smokeless'' cigarette had not been completed.

title: BUSH LASHES BACK AT KENNEDY TAUNT
description: Vice President Bush, who has been trailed by the question ''Where was George?'' since Senator Edward M. Kennedy first raised it mockingly at the Democratic convention, struck back today by saying he had been home with his wife.

title: New York Loses a Lion
description: When Dr. Vartan Gregorian takes up residence in Rhode Island as president of Brown University next April, he will leave a void as big as the vast excavations now under way in Bryant Park behind the New York Public Library. In seven years as the library's president, he revived an empire of learning that is more than ever a national treasure. But to dwell only on his fund raising - $162 million since 1981 - slights his gifts as educator, preserver and lover of books, and exuberant impresario.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the physicist Luis W. Alvarez yesterday misidentified the superior who recommended that Dr. Alvarez not testify at a hearing on the loyalty of J. Robert Oppenheimer. He was Dr. Ernest Lawrence. It also gave an incorrect date for the hearing; it was in 1954.

title: FFP Partners L P reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings represent units. The company said there were no comparable year-ago figures because the partnership began operations in May 1987.

title: Texaco Canada
description: A spokesman for Texaco Inc. said that no sale of its 78 percent interest in Texaco Canada was likely ''before the very latter part of this year.'' Texaco put the subsidiary on the market on Aug. 2 and announced late Wednesday that it had agreed with its subsidiary on how to protect the interests of minority shareholders, prompting speculation among analysts that an announcement was imminent. On Thursday a person close to the company said that ''serious talks are being held with three to five potential buyers'' and that an announcement could come by the end of September. In a statement yesterday, Texaco said, ''The company is not negotiating currently with any potential purchasers; however, a number of interested parties are being furnished information.''

title:
CONSUMER'S WORLD;
COPING: With Cellular Phone Service
description: LEAD: If you buy a cellular telephone to use in the car or while walking around, think twice about the service company you choose. You don't have to sign up with the one your phone dealer offers. Other companies may suit your needs better.

title: Hospitals Strained by Rise In Drug Abuse, a Study Says
description: New York City will soon face ''medical gridlock'' unless hospitals in New York City add hundreds of new beds, and outpatient clinics and drug abuse treatment clinics are rapidly expanded - particularly in poor areas, a recent private study says.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Labor Day will be observed on Monday. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Starts at 11 A.M. at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue, travels north to 72d Street, then east to Third Avenue. Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Schools: Public schools closed. Parking: Sunday rules. Sanitation: Monday's collections will be made Tuesday. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Sunday schedule, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedule. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Public schools closed. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Public schools closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule.

title: Fred Meyer Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 13
description: The company said interest expense in the latest periods was up 39.7 percent over a year ago, primarily because of increased borrowings due to an accelerated new-store and remodeling schedule, and to a lesser extent, higher interest rates. uf92A lower tax rate, resulting from the Tax Reform Act of 1986, more than offset the impact of higher interest costs.

title: Reviewing the Summer And Winter Calendar Of the Next Life
description: By Maxine Kumin; Maxine Kumin, poet, novelist and critic, won the 1973 Pulitzer Prize for poetry.

title: CMS Advertising Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Earl Scheib Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Hurricane Debby Hits Mexico
description: Hurricane Debby brought heavy rains and winds of 74 miles per hour to this city on the Gulf of Mexico today, knocking out power and flooding streets. The hurricane, the first of the 1988 season, weakened after hitting the coast and was downgraded to a tropical storm.

title: Review/Film; Mad Motorist And Cars, Cars, Cars
description: The freeway killer is a maniac, a defrocked priest, a marksman and a fan of call-in radio, but he has apparently never had an automobile accident that was not of his own making. To a New Yorker, who lives in a place where highway traffic rarely loosens up enough to enjoy a wild chase, ''Freeway,'' the movie that opened yesterday at the Movieland, is the very stuff that Southern California is made of.

title: Morris Kaplan, Reporter, 79
description: Morris Kaplan, a retired reporter for The New York Times, died of complications resulting from diabetes yesterday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Quayle Pronounced In 'Excellent' Health By a Capitol Doctor
description: The health of Senator Dan Quayle is excellent, according to a doctor's report released by Mr. Quayle's office today. The report said the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee had a slightly high cholesterol level and had minor skin and nasal problems.

title: Miller Cancels Assembly Session, Putting Shoreham Vote in Doubt
description: In a move that made legislative approval of the Shoreham settlement this month appear less likely, the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, announced today that he had changed his mind and would not reconvene the Assembly in late September as planned.

title: Equitable Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $6,450,000 from a change in accounting.

title: A Dual-Deck VCR Stirs a Controversy
description: Go-Video Inc. of Scottsdale, Ariz., received a patent this week on its invention of a dual-deck video cassette recorder.

title: HPSC Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: The company said the share amounts assume the exercise of options and the retirement of debt, in accordance with the modified treasury method of computing earnings per share.

title: Soviet Aide Admits Maps Were Faked for 50 Years
description: The Soviet Union's chief cartographer acknowledged today that for the last 50 years the Soviet Union had deliberately falsified virtually all public maps of the country, misplacing rivers and streets, distorting boundaries and omitting geographical features, on orders of the secret police.

title: Carriage Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
Cuba and Pretoria Said to Add To Forces in Angolan Region
description: State Department officials said today that Cuba had sent substantial amounts of military equipment to Angola in recent weeks, and they estimated that there were more than 50,000 Cuban troops in Angola.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Keeping Children's Records
description: The start of the school year is a good time to establish a system for the records - academic, medical and legal - that will be needed as your child advances.

title: Spain's New Cry: 'Shove Off, Mate'
description: Hardly a week has gone by this summer without the Spanish press featuring articles on young British tourists regarded as troublemakers in resort towns such as this one.

title: Thomas Gallin, Builder, 58
description: Thomas Gallin, president of the John Gallin Construction Company of Manhattan, died at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital on Thursday, after a brief illness. He was 58 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Unemployment: The Biggest States
description: Civilian unemployment. Figures are seasonally adjusted.

title: Walesa Takes to Coal Country To Press for an End to Strikes
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, went to the Silesian coal fields today to try to persuade striking coal miners to follow the lead of Gdansk shipyard workers and return to their jobs.

title: Catalyst Thermal Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIDGE
description: Cover the East-West hands in the diagram and plan your play in one no-trump after the bidding shown and an opening spade lead. This is a gloom-and-doom situation, for you are playing match points and you are likely to go down two tricks for a disastrous 200-point penalty.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Rise Sharply
description: In one of the most exuberant rallies since the stock market crash last October, Treasury bond prices rose as much as 2 5/8 points yesterday.

title: Ducommun Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,334,000 and $3,467,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a gain of $4,888,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Eastern Says Layoff Injunction Is Reversed
description: A Federal appeals court in Washington tonight stayed an injunction that had barred Eastern Airlines from dismissing 4,000 employees, a company spokeswoman said.

title: Plunge in Price of Oil Is Predicted If Gulf Peace Adds to Oversupply
description: A sharp drop in oil prices may be in the offing, industry experts say, as Iran and Iraq move toward peace and full production. World oil stocks remain glutted, and the price of crude oil dropped below $15 a barrel yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Suits Against Maker of Space Rocket Thrown Out
description: An anguished engineer's multibillion-dollar lawsuits against his former company for its role in the space shuttle disaster were dismissed by a Federal judge in Utah this week.

title: American Guaranty Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: COURT REINSTATES BANKRUPTING FINES IN YONKERS CASE
description: Escalating fines that could bankrupt the City of Yonkers by mid-November were reimposed yesterday, after the United States Supreme Court unanimously rejected the city's final appeal to block a court-ordered housing desegregation plan.

title: Amplification: Making It All Clear
description: When audiences recently listened to Jason Robards deliver the miserly father's lines in O'Neill's ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' it was not simply the actor's distinguished voice they heard booming through the Neil Simon Theater. Nor did Derek Jacobi's declamation in Hugh Whitemore's ''Breaking the Code'' earlier this year reach the ears of the audience unassisted. On Broadway today, even the most seasoned and distinctive-sounding performers speak their lines through discreetly placed microphones.

title: Your Money; Financial Plans: Self-Help Method
description: When Harold Moe landed his first flying job with Republic Airlines 20 years ago, he wondered why some senior pilots seemed unable to achieve their financial goals. One pilot bought a new Cadillac every year, dined frequently at his private club and complained that he could not afford to buy a house, Mr. Moe recalled.

title: 3 Water Mains Break, Slowing Morning Traffic
description: Three cast-iron water mains, all at least a century old, broke yesterday in Lower Manhattan near the Holland Tunnel, causing traffic delays, buckled streets and headaches for area delicatessen owners and residents who were without water for most of the day.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15.

title: Review/Jazz; John Scofield Improvises In an Array of Guitar Styles
description: John Scofield opened his set at Sweet Basil on Wednesday night with an untitled original. His guitar rang away with chiming overtones as he chorded an imagined country melody, while Terri Lyne Carrington set her drums percolating as if she were playing with the John Coltrane group of the mid-1960s. Anthony Cox, the bassist, broke into a 4/4 walk and the band was off, like a racehorse pulling away from the gate.

title: Eastwood's Restaurant Is Allowed to Reopen
description: A restaurant owned in part by Clint Eastwood reopened this week, two weeks after it was closed by health officials.

title: Gambino Associate Convicted Of Perjury Before Grand Jury
description: A Long Island man, who was described by Federal authorities as an associate of the Gambino crime family, was convicted yesterday of perjury before a special grand jury investigating the crime family's links to racketeering and other crimes.

title: Taylor Entering Rehabilitation
description: Lawrence Taylor's agent, Gary Kovach, said yesterday that a rehabilitation program for the All-Pro linebacker is scheduled to begin next week. ''I believe he is going to start next Wednesday,'' Kovach said in a telephone interview from Houston.

title: Montclair Savings reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes $249,000 in non-recurring costs related to the thrift's previously announced agreement to affiliate with First Fidelity Bancorp. of New Jersey. No year-ago 9 months share earnings are available because the thrift was not publicly owned through that period.

title: Jersey Abandons Plan For a Troopship Prison
description: Corrections officials in New Jersey have decided to drop plans to convert a World War II troopship into a seven-story floating prison to handle inmate overcrowding, a spokesman for the department said today.

title: Met Rookies Club Dodgers
description: Gregg Jefferies and Kevin Elster, rookies on an accomplished club, are separated in their clubhouse by a lockers and the cool distance of competition. Those combustible circumstances have made for some awkward moments for the two Mets.

title: Acquisition Of Cherokee Group Near
description: The Cherokee Group said today that it had entered into a definitive agreement with the Green Acquisition Company, a unit of Deutschman & Company, under which Green will acquire Cherokee for $168 million.

title: George H. de Mendelssohn-Bartholdy, 75
description: George H. de Mendelssohn-Bartholdy, a founder of Vox Records and a fourth-generation descendant of the composer Felix Mendelssohn, died on Wednesday in Dusseldorf, West Germany. He was 75 years old and had cancer.

title: Consultant in Pentagon Inquiry Says He Bought Information
description: A military consultant involved in the Pentagon fraud investigation acknowledged today that he had paid other consultants for ''technical information'' on contracts. But he denied assertions that he had made payments to Government employees.

title: 'Last Temptation,' Like It or Not, Merits Respect; Faithful to Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Wyatt Cafeterias
description: The board of directors of Wyatt Cafeterias Inc. has rejected an offer by Furr's/Bishop's Cafeterias L.P. of $89 in cash and $2.25 in securities per share, Furr's/ Bishop's said. The offer, which totaled $188 million, was the second by Furr's/Bishop's. Last week the Dallas-based Wyatt rejected the partnership's first offer of $179.3 million, or $87 a share, in favor of a proposed employee stock ownership plan valued at $84 a share. A Wyatt shareholder meeting has been scheduled for Tuesday to consider the employee plan. Furr's/Bishop's, based in Midland, Tex., has threatened to sue the Wyatt board in the event that its offer is not accepted.

title: Arrow Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: b-Net loss

title: Toxic Waste Boomerang: Ciao Italy!
description: A ship that has spent more than a month searching for a site to unload her cargo of toxic waste is continuing to wander the seas after France, Britain, Spain, West Germany and the Netherlands refused to let her land.

title: Here Are the New York Enemies of Clean Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Caroline L. Rhoden Married
description: Caroline Lee Rhoden, a daughter of Mrs. Charles H. Price 2d of London and Kansas City, Mo., and a stepdaughter of Mr. Price, the United States Ambassador to Britain, was married in Kansas City yesterday to John Gregory McCallister, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ben D. McCallister of Mission Hills, Kan. The Rev. Jeffrey Q. Black performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: Caribbean Select Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Failure of Rocket Is Reported In Placing of Secret Payload
description: A secret satellite was fired into space today in an unannounced launch that the Air Force called a success, but a source close to the program said the powerful Titan 34D rocket had failed to put the satellite into a high enough orbit.

title: 3% Cost Cuts Ordered in Connecticut
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today ordered state agencies to cut spending by 3 percent to offset a projected $121 million budget deficit for the current fiscal year.

title: Birth Control Order Is Overturned
description: A judge today reversed her order that a teen-age mother who left her two sons alone in a sweltering apartment for three days, practice birth control throughout her child-bearing years, saying the ruling was unenforceable.

title: Mortgage Rates Mixed
description: The average interest rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage dropped to 10.65 percent for the week ended today, from 10.67 percent the previous week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported today. The average adjustable-rate mortgage rose to 8.16 percent, from 8.06 percent the previous week, it said. Lenders charged an average of 2.4 percent in fees and points on fixed-rate loans, up from 2.2 percent last week. They charged 2.5 percent in fees and points on adjustable-rate mortgages, up from 2.3 percent last week.

title: Virco Manufacturinge Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Jersey Appeals Court Orders Town to Desegregate Schools
description: A state appeals court today ordered education officials in Hillside to desegregate first-grade classes by the beginning of school Tuesday by reassigning 77 students to different schools.

title: Feed the Hungry
description: LEAD: Dazzling advances in research and ever-increasing harvests in many developing countries have not been able to protect the world's poor from malnutrition. But a simple rethinking of the ways governments give food assistance may achieve what high tech has not.

title: 3 Angels Held After a Brawl On 46th Street
description: LEAD: A brawl between Guardian Angels and neighborhood residents on West 46th Street early yesterday injured four Angels and one resident and led to the arrest of three Angels, the police said.

title: In Kabul, Rumors and Rockets Fly
description: At a European embassy here, diplomats sent a terse private cable to their Government the other morning summing up the latest news about Afghanistan's enigmatic leader, President Najibullah.

title: 9 Reportedly Seized as Suspects in Zia Crash
description: Nine people, including a Pakistani Air Force officer, were arrested Thursday in connection with the crash that killed President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, a newspaper said today.

title: Symbolics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pretax charge of $13,226,000 related to restructuring, compared with $575,000 a year ago. c-Includes pretax charges of $24,924,000 and $13,690,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively, related to corporate restructuring; the latest year also includes $1,810,000 related to a buyout of interest in a research-and-development joint venture.

title: High Court Rules, and Yonkers Crisis Intensifies
description: Administration officials here had expected the United States Supreme Court to turn down their appeal for a continued suspension of the contempt fines against Yonkers for the City Council's blocking of a housing-desegregation order. But they had also expected the court to reject a similar request from the four Council members opposing the order.

title: Aileen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net loss

title: New York Jobless Rate Rises
description: Unemployment rates in New York and New Jersey rose slightly last month, reflecting a summer influx of job applicants, but the region's economy remains stable, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: The Insomniac's Dream: All-Night Services Grow
description: Nighttime is the right time to be with the one you love, the song goes. These days it can also be the time to find out if a check has cleared, to do some shopping, even to rent a movie, as long as you are comfortable pushing buttons.

title: Dow Soars 52.28 Points, To 2,054.59
description: Stock prices soared on Wall Street yesterday, catapulted higher by surprisingly weak employment figures for August.

title: 2 Specialists Lose Roles On 4 Stocks
description: Two stock exchange specialists have lost the right to deal in four specific stocks because of poor performance during last October's market crash, the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday.

title: 4 in Polygamy Clan Get Minimum Terms In Fatal Gun Battle
description: A judge today sentenced four members of a polygamist clan to minimum prison terms for their roles in a church bombing and shootout in which a corrections officer was killed.

title: Bombay Palace Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 10
description: b-Net income The company attributed the increase in sales to the inclusion of the sales of Lifestyle Restaurants Inc., acquired in September 1987.

title: Singapore Votes Today In Test for Ruling Party
description: Voters in Singapore are scheduled to elect a new Parliament Saturday in a test of the continuing grip of the ruling party as the properous city-state moves toward a new generation of leadership.

title: Cross & Trecker Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $910,000. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $104,000 and $4,736,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Year-ago results are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Building a High School Across a Highway Is Dangerous Planning
description: To the Editor:

title: 77,000 in London Hear Rock Stars Make Music for Human Rights
description: A cheering crowd, many tossing beach balls and Frisbees, filled Wembley Stadium tonight to watch a lineup of top rock musicians, including Bruce Springsteen, Sting, and Peter Gabriel, sing, dance and strut across the stage during the opening concert of Amnesty International's six-week international tour to promote human rights.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 Oil prices may drop steeply as Iran and Iraq make peace, experts believe. Oil fell below $15 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Increased production and reserves may also drive down prices. The authorities have agreed to release accurate maps. 1 Western cartographers rejoiced that the Soviet Union might give them a more accurate picture of Soviet geography. title: Review/Rock; For Slayer, the Mania Is the Message
description: If Slayer didn't exist, anti-rock forces could have invented the band. Slayer brings the sensational imagery of tabloids and horror movies to pummeling, speed-metal songs whose lyrics revel in death, gore and allusions to Satanism and Nazism.

title: IN SOUTH AFRICA, BLACKS SIGN PACT
description: Rival black political groups signed an accord today to end what has been called the country's worst factional fighting this century, in which more than 600 people have been killed in 20 months.

title: Rhetoric, Reality and Chancellor Green
description: Richard Green took over as New York City's Schools Chancellor six months ago with a record as an accomplished educator. He has articulated laudable goals. But it is still unclear how he means to meet the political and administrative challenge of turning rhetoric into reality. Meanwhile, the schools are a disgrace, and getting worse.

title: Another Australian Makes His Mark
description: These Australians were inspired by heroes like Laver, Newcombe, Rosewall and Cash, not Crocodile Dundee. Australia, tennis fans would agree, was not discovered yesterday, as the tourist industry would have people believe. And now, it appears, Australian tennis is in the midst of a rebirth, making strides toward regaining the prominent status it enjoyed more than 20 years ago.

title: INSIDE
description: Gossip at Its Hottest

title: Dukakis Appears to Lose Ground in Home State, in Part Because of Budget Troubles
description: The campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, on the defensive nationwide, now finds itself squeezed on its home territory.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1988
description: The Economy

title: First Medical Devices Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company made its initial public offering on July 2, 1988.

title: Belvedere Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $47,000 for the quarter and $97,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $223,000 and $719,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: The Wall That Offended George Shultz
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Was Mike?
description: The Dukakis people must have thought they'd won the election the instant George Bush admitted that Senator Dan Quayle was his idea of the man best qualified, after himself of course, to be President of the United States.

title: Cardiac Control Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Top 2 Teams in Rematch
description: The two top teams in the final 1987 college football polls and one of the most discussed subplots of last season will come together Saturday night when the Florida State Seminoles and the Miami Hurricanes begin their seasons (9 P.M., Channel 2).

title: Ravioli Worker Pulled Into a Dough Machine
description: A worker at John's Ravioli Company was injured Thursday when he was pulled into a kneading machine.

title: Dukakis Rehires Aide Who Left After Role in Ending Biden Drive
description: Michael S. Dukakis, trying to energize his campaign for the White House, rehired John Sasso today, saying his former campaign manager had ''paid the price'' for his role in the demise of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s Presidential campaign.

title: Investors Title Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
South Africa Makes a Deal on New Segregation Laws
description: The Government has struck a deal with a mixed-race leader who led a boycott of parliamentary debates on five bills designed to buttress major segregation laws.

title: Navy Officer Acquitted in Recruit's Death
description: A Navy court-martial panel has found the former commander of the Navy Rescue Swimmer School here not guilty on two charges of dereliction of duty in the drowning of a recruit rescue swimmer.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT UP FOR SECOND MONTH, TO 5.5% IN AUGUST
description: The nation's unemployment rate rose in August for the second straight month, to 5.5 percent, as job growth slackened, the Labor Department said today.

title: In Poland, Hope Again
description: It isn't the clear triumph of Aug. 31, 1980, when Lech Walesa announced that Poland's Communist Government had recognized an independent trade union. But the Aug. 31, 1988, meeting between Solidarity's Mr. Walesa and Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, the Interior Minister, was still a major breakthrough. That 1980 announcement was followed, 16 months later, by martial law and the subsequent banning of Solidarity. Now, the prospects are for a more modest, but perhaps longer lasting advance.

title: Distillers and Pernod in Talks
description: Irish Distillers Group P.L.C., which dominates the Irish whisky market, said today that it was discussing the possibility of being taken over by the French liquor company Pernod Ricard. Irish Distillers, which makes

title: Senior Service reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Includes a $59,241 tax credit.

title: Television; A Potpourri of Dances For the Hands Alone
description: In ''Dancing Hands,'' the final program this season of WNET's Alive From Off Center series, the producer-director Skip Blumberg gives eight interesting performers the chance to create a dance for hands alone. The suite of dances, which will be shown on Sunday at 10:30 P.M. on Channel 13, incorporates a wide variety of artistic points of view. The dances are stylishly filmed, with seldom more than the right amount of intrusion by the camera, against backdrops and in settings that are for the most part elegantly bright.

title: Contempt Ruling Against Myerson Investigators Is Overturned
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday overturned a ruling that held New York City's Department of Investigation in contempt of court for refusing to give investigative files to the defense in the Bess Myerson case.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In May, it took us six hours to shut the gates. This time it took us one hour and 15 minutes.

Pep Boys-Manny, Moe & Jack reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,688,000 from an accounting change. Results for the latest 6 months were after a charge of 2 cents a share to consolidate administrative functions.

title: Soviet Human Rights Shift Seen at U.N. Panel Meeting
description: The Soviet Union has shown increased support for human rights at a six-week meeting of a United Nations rights panel that ended today, participants say.

title: Crash Investigators Puzzled Over Position of Wing Flaps
description: Investigators looking into the Delta Air Lines crash that killed 13 people in Texas on Wednesday sought yesterday to reconcile conflicting data on a troubling new issue: whether the wing flaps had been properly extended before takeoff.

title: 'Last Temptation,' Like It or Not, Merits Respect
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Open; Green, Sluman Share 2d-Round Lead
description: Jeff Sluman, who won the PGA Championship three weeks ago and is being called an ''almost Canadian'' by folks here, had a share of the lead today through two rounds of the 79th Canadian Open. If he goes on to win, the Canadians may drop the ''almost'' and make him one of theirs.

title: A Big Step For Rehe
description: It is not uncommon for young players to make good first impressions, then struggle to find their niches on the tour, some surviving, others fading into obscurity. Stephanie Rehe was 13 years and 1 month when she played in her first Virginia Slims event in 1982, young even by tennis standards. And she was just 17 last year when she suffered her first serious injury, putting a promising career on hold. It is surprising how quickly people can forget.

title: Phoenix American Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KEY RATES
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allwaste Inc., Houston, an environmental services concern, said it had acquired two Louisiana air-moving services and tank-trailer cleaning services in North Carolina, South Carolina and Kentucky. Terms were not disclosed.

title: National Lumber & Supply Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and for the 6 months includes a $250,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: John Gains Victory, First Since July 27
description: Tommy John, the Yankees' 45-year-old pitching wonder, moved his rejuvenated team closer to the American League East lead than it has been in two weeks. The left-hander sent the Yankees to a 4-1 victory over the Oakland Athletics tonight to put them four games from first place and three from second.

title: Fall Raking, Without Backache
description: Even now, in the waning days of summer, leaves are beginning to fall. High winds and rain leave their own detritus of twigs and broken branches.

title: Crowds Stayed Away, So Team Goes Away
description: Halfway through the end-of-season doubleheader between the Glens Falls Tigers and the Pittsfield Cubs, the management of the Tigers tried to sell the shirts off the backs of its players.

title: Suzuki Samurai Vehicles Set Record Sales in August
description: Spurred by incentives, sales of Suzuki Samurai utility vehicles reached record levels in August, a company spokesman said today.

title: Remote Call-Forward Devices
description: Two New Jersey companies received patents this week on devices that allow people with call-forwarding telephone service to change the forwarding number from remote sites.

title: Koch Vetoes Bill to Name Bronx Park After Clemente
description: A measure to name a park after the late baseball star Roberto Clemente -an issue that stirred a conflict with racial overtones in the South Bronx -was vetoed yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Physicians Insurance Company of Ohio reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge from the reversal of a tax credit of $134,500.

title: 3-Minute Strike in Sweden Seeks Money for the Arts
description: Luciano Pavarotti stayed off the stage, movies stopped in midreel, concert halls fell silent and actors froze on stage during a three-minute strike Thursday night to protest the Swedish Government's arts policies.

title: Eunice Forester Is Wed To Hal David, Lyricist
description: Eunice Forester, a member of the Los Angeles County Music and Performing Arts Commission, was married yesterday to Hal David, the lyricist and former president of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers. Surrogate Marie M. Lambert officiated in the music room of the Equitable Building in New York.

title: Two Places at Once?
description: Kenny Miller, the basketball player who led the National Collegiate Athletic Association in rebounding last season as a freshman, will apparently not be returning to Loyola of Chicago. On Aug. 15, Miller said he was leaving Loyola after having been declared academically ineligible by the school, but he changed his mind 10 days later, saying he would try to improve his grades. The Chicago Sun-Times reported yesterday that Miller has enrolled at Barton County Community College in Great Bend, Kan., 70 miles northwest of Wichita. ''Kenny Miller is enrolled full time here,'' said Dan McGovern, the Barton County basketball coach. ''He's taking 15 hours, and he will be playing ball here this year.'' (AP)

title: Continental Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6.9 million and $7.2 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $7 million for the quarter and $12.9 million for the 6 months.

title: Equitable of Iowa Companies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After investment losses of $740,000 and $371,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes investment gains of $2,088,000 for the quarter and $4,679,000 for the 6 months.

title: Sports of The Times; Is the New Track the Right Track?
description: When you get right down to it, there are only two fundamental ways to change horse racing: change the horse or change the surface on which it races.

title: Myers Appeal Fails
description: A three-member arbitration panel upheld the removal of Angel Myers from the United States Olympic swimming team for tested positive for steroid use. ''I didn't expect it to turn out this way,'' Myers said later. She said the test mistakenly identified birth-control pills as evidence of steroid use. The arbitrators met in Denver after a lengthy hearing that ended early yesterday morning. The deadline for United States athletes to be certified by the Seoul Olympic Organizing Committee was 11 A.M. Eastern daylight time yesterday. The Olympic swimming coach, Richard Quick, said Jill Sterkel would take Myers's place in the 50-meter freestyle, an event in which Myers set a United States record at the Olympic trials in July. Janel Jorgensen will replace Myers in the 100-meter butterfly, and Dara Torres, who is an Olympic team member, will take her place in the 100-meter freestyle, another event in which Myers set an American record during the trials. ''Most of the people on the team now are my friends,'' Myers said at a news conference. ''I wish them all the best of luck. I wish I could be with them.'' Myers, of Americus, Ga., testified for 10 minutes before the arbitration panel. ''I told them the truth,'' she said. ''To my knowledge, I have not taken anabolic steroids.'' Later yesterday, Myers was greeted by about 30 friends and supporters when she arrived at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport.(AP)

title: New Director Named For Royal Opera House
description: Sir John Tooley, director general of the Royal Opera House for the last 18 years, has retired, it was announced Thursday.

title: Stifel Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Includes a pretax charge of $1 million and $5 million for the quarter and year, respectively, for potentially uncollectable customer accounts. c-Net income

title: A System to Avoid Aircraft Collisions
description: George Litchford, an engineer and the founder of the Litchstreet Company of Northport, L.I., won patent approval this week for an aircraft collision-avoidance system.

title: Sailing to Milan
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Bid to Rejuvenate Leadership
description: The topic is General Motors, and one wonders what Alfred P. Sloan would have said.

title: Vermont Bars Drug Offenders From House Arrests
description: Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin has ordered the exclusion of drug offenders from the program of house arrest that allowed John Zaccaro Jr. to serve his term for cocaine trafficking in a $1,500-a-month luxury apartment.

title: About New York; 'Manly Drivers' Discuss Horses Without Hats
description: The landscape is the cheerless one of midtown Manhattan's far West Side - warehouses, gas stations, factories, trucks unloading, prostitutes beckoning. It is thus more than surprising to see oats scattered on sidewalks and hear the neighing of horses. But here are the barns where most of the nags pulling New York City's 68 carriages live.

title: 6 Die in Helicopter Crash
description: A California Air National Guard helicopter crashed in a Mojave Desert mountain range Thursday, killing all six people aboard, the authorities said. The helicopter from Moffett Naval Air Station went down at 10:55 A.M.

title: Baseball; Red Sox Again Fail To Gain on Tigers
description: Bob Boone hit a two-run single in the seventh inning tonight to boost the California Angels over the Boston Red Sox, 3-2, and frustrate Boston's attempt to grab a share of the American League East lead.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a theft from a Manhattan fur salon misstated the length of the Chevrolet Astro van. The van, which the police said was used to crash through the front window of the store, is 14.7 feet long.

title: Quayle, in South, Accuses Dukakis of Lacking Issues
description: Senator Dan Quayle, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, campaigned in the South today with a series of harsh attacks on Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.

title: Anne Tyler's Couple on a Journey
description: Breathing Lessons By Anne Tyler 327 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Rising Tide, Sinking Boats
description: A new Census Bureau report offers discouraging news: the poverty rate among minorities increased and the already high rate among children did not improve. That far overshadows the slight decline in the number of whites living in poverty.

title: British Petroleum
description: The British Petroleum Company said it planned to move as many as 500 exploration division employees from London to Britoil P.L.C.'s offices in Glasgow. British Petroleum, a leading oil and gas exploration concern that took control of Britoil earlier this year, said in a statement that the transfer would begin later this year and be completed within 12 months.

title: Talks Continue on Sale Of American Savings
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board and the Robert M. Bass Group negotiated through the day on the purchase of the American Savings and Loan Association of Stockton, Calif., the nation's largest insolvent savings and loan association.

title: The Story So Far in Yonkers
description: The History Dec. 1, 1980: Justice Department sues Board of Education, City of Yonkers and Yonkers Community Development Agency, charging that the city racially discriminated in education and public housing. Nov. 20, 1985: Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court rules that Yonkers's housing and schools were intentionally segregated by race. A Housing Remedy Order directs the city to build 200 units of public housing and to plan additional subsidized housing. Jan. 28, 1988: City Council approves consent decree that sets timetable for building 200 units of public housing and commits city to an additional 800 subsidized units. July 26: Court sets Aug. 1 deadline for Council to adopt zoning amendment needed to build the 800 units. Aug. 1: Council rejects amendment in a 4-3 vote. Aug. 2: Judge Sand finds city and the four Council members who voted against the amendment in contempt of court and imposes fines. The city's fines start at $100 and double daily. The Councilmen are fined $500 a day. Aug. 9: Fines are suspended by a Federal appeals panel while the contempt ruling is appealed. Aug. 26: Appeals panel upholds contempt ruling and fines against Councilmen, but caps fines against city at $1 million a day. The fines remain suspended so city can appeal to Supreme Court. Sept. 1: Supreme Court refuses to grant city a further suspension of fines, but does continue stay of fines against Councilmen so they can seek high court's review of their contempt rulings. The Players and Their Positions The defiant Councilmen: Peter Chema, Edward J. Fagan Jr., Nicholas V. Longo, Henry Spallone: Mr. Spallone says he will not accept any new public housing in Yonkers. His three colleagues say the court-ordered housing plan must be changed to reduce its impact on the city's neighborhoods. Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko: The City Council must approve the housing plan. Governor Cuomo: The law must be obeyed and he will act to remove the four Councilmen from office if they run out of appeals but continue their opposition. Judge Leonard B. Sand: The city must approve the housing ordinance that the City Council agreed to in a consent decree or suffer bankrupting fines. Secretary of State Gail S. Shaffer, chairman of the Emergency Financial Control Board : The City Council must stop incurring the contempt fines or be prosecuted for unauthorized spending. The Price Fines levied against the City of Yonkers, which started accumulating Aug. 2, were suspended from Aug. 9 to Sept. 2 while contempt ruling was appealed. $ Day's fine Cumulative total Day 1 $ 100 $ 100 Day 2 200 300 Day 3 400 700 Day 4 800 1,500 Day 5 1,600 3,100 Day 6 3,200 6,300 Day 7 (today) 6,400 12,700 Day 8 12,800 25,500 Day 9 25,600 51,100 Day 10 51,200 102,300 Day 11 102,400 204,700 Day 12 204,800 409,500 Day 13 409,600 819,100 Day 14 819,200 1,638,300 All days thereafter 1,000,000 When the city would run out of cash: About Nov. 13 Total fines paid by that day: $66,638,300 Budget for 1988-89 fiscal year: $337,000,000

title: HARASSMENT SUIT SETTLED BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has settled a lawsuit filed by a former employee who charged that she was the victim of sexual harassment at the agency, according to papers filed with the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: In the West, Map Makers Hail Shift in Soviet Stance
description: American and British cartographers, long aware of the falsification of key features on Soviet maps, rejoiced today at the prospect of getting a more accurate picture of Soviet geography.

title: Penalty Accords in Job Safety Cases Assailed
description: Several companies facing substantial Federal fines for violations of job safety rules later negotiated reduced settlements at only a fraction of the original penalty, according to a report released here today.

title: Transamerica To Acquire Tifco
description: The Transamerica Financial Corporation, the lending subsidiary of the Transamerica Corporation, agreed to acquire Tifco Inc., the insurance-premium-financing subsidiary of Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., for $73.75 million. The transaction is expected to close in late September or early October.

title: Archdiocese to Continue Foster-Care Services
description: New York City and the New York Archdiocese have reached an agreement that will allow the archdiocese to continue foster-care services for 3,000 teen-agers without directly providing access to birth control and abortions.

title: Florida Alligator Hunt Opens With a Splash and a Thump
description: It is pitch dark out on Lake Okeechobee, a lonely void of black water meeting a black sky. But the night has a voice: bugs zinging, frogs moaning, water splashing. And it has eyes, hundreds of them, glowing red ones that stare out from the dark.

title: Rulings on Yonkers and Excerpts From Dissent
description: Following is the decision Thursday by the Supreme Court of the United States on the request to suspend contempt fines against the City of Yonkers and four Councilmen, and excerpts from the dissent written by Justice Thurgood Marshall and joined by Justice William J Brennan Jr.:

title: Burmese Rallies Seek Immediate Democracy
description: Hundreds of thousands of Burmese demonstrated for immediate democracy today, and dissident leaders called for more protests, rejecting the President's pledge of a referendum on one-party rule.

title: 'Last Temptation,' Like It or Not, Merits Respect; Eccentric and Banal
description: To the Editor:

title: News, the Scores - and a Poem
description: LEAD: When I was a young girl growing up in New Bedford, Mass., my father would bring home the daily newspaper in his black briefcase, buried under the order forms for his grocery company. After dinner, I would spread the paper on the floor and thumb excitedly through it.

title: A Trial to Match a Huge Default
description: When two New York lawyers sued over a default of the Washington Public Power Supply System a couple of years ago, they shared a Seattle apartment for more than a year.

title: Bush Classmate Recalls No Flag Pledge
description: A grade school classmate of Vice President Bush said today that the Republican Presidential nominee was not required to recite the Pledge of Allegience when the two attended a private school in Connecticut in the 1930's.

title: Costly Challenge
description: Rich Gossage's altercation earlier this week with the Chicago Cubs' manager, Don Zimmer, has cost the reliever his job as the team's closer. Drew Hall will replace him during late innings for the remainder of this season. Gossage, who challenged Zimmer while being removed from a game Tuesday, met yesterday with the Cubs' general manager, Jim Frey, and said later: ''If I want to get my job back as the closer on this team, it's all up to me.''

title: Records Show Meese Took Friend on Flights at No Cost
description: Justice Department records made public today show that former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d allowed E. Robert Wallach, a close friend who was a central figure in a recent special prosecutor's investigation, to join him on several trips aboard Government planes at no cost.

title: Markets Closed
description: Stock and commodity exchanges and most businesses in the United States and Canada will be closed on Monday in observance of Labor Day. Federal, state and local government offices will also be closed.

title: With an Eye to Past, Fordham Marches to Future
description: The reminders of past glory on the football field refuse to go away at Fordham University.

title: BRAZIL COMPLETE NEW CONSTITUTION
description: Lawmakers finished work early today on a new Brazilian Constitution that replaces the charter drawn up two decades ago by generals.

title: School Lunch Chief Charged In Theft of Food for Nightclub
description: The school lunch director for public schools in Hempstead, L.I., was arrested yesterday on charges of stealing food from the lunch program.

title: Hotels, Like the Airlines, Offer Discounts
description: The hotel industry, inspired by airline pricing, is developing a system for cutting room rates during slack periods.

title: American Bionetics Inc reports earnings for Year to May 31
Chariot Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago figures are restated to retroactively include the results of operations of Republic Metal Products Inc., acquired during 1987.

title: Emcon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Candelaria Pitching To Leave
description: Lou Piniella and John Candelaria met for 35 minutes today in an effort to resolve their apparent cold war. But the Yankee pitcher confirmed that he has told the club he does not want the option year on his contract renewed, even though sources say he has already been informed it will be done.

title: Question Of the Week How Will The Giants And Jets Do in '88?
description: If Mark Gastineau, the most often-quoted spokesman for the Jets, is any indication of what we can expect, jettison the Jets. Bill Parcells is already making excuses for his team, saying they aren't ready. The Meadowlands will produce a crop of thorns in the side of New York fans. JOAN MARY MACEY Binghamton, N.Y.

title: Air Force at Odds With Amputee
description: A cadet who lost part of a leg in an automobile accident faces dismissal from the Air Force Academy here because of a rule prohibiting amputees in the service, officials say.

title:
THEATER;
Sendup to the Stars Goes Legit (Sort Of)
description: LEAD: Satire has been packing houses since the Greeks; ''Forbidden Broadway,'' a mere six years. But the latest chapter in the history of the wicked, affectionate revue that sends up the Great White Way reconfirms the appeal of the genre, summarized for our century by Dorothy Parker: ''If you haven't got anything good to say, come and sit next to me.

title: For Lebanese, New Chaos, Old Fears
description: At the suburban hilltop village of Suk al Gharb, mainly Christian contingents of the Lebanese Army have again been trading artillery and rocket fire with Druse militiamen.

title: The Last Picnic Show
description: IN WINTER, I LIKE TO WALK WITH MY DOG, Frodo, along the beach near my home on the Connecticut shoreline. By the time April comes along, and I have made a few salads of wild dandelion greens, I look ahead to picnics at the beach.

title: Packing Without Angst: Making a Priority List
description: A FRIEND used to suffer from packer's block, which is like writer's block, if less fashionable. An episode usually begins when the suitcase is opened preparatory to travel. The victim abruptly seizes on some other problem, like alphabetizing the medicine cabinet or waxing the kitchen floor. My friend, unable to get the first pair of socks into the valise, would call at bizarre hours on Friday nights to get help. After several episodes, he dropped the long overture and would simply say: ''I'm leaving in the morning. What's the first thing on the list?''

title:
MUSIC;
The D'Oyly Carte, Free From Its Fetters Grim
description: LEAD: LONDON

title: Worldwide Labor Strife Provides a Collector's Topic
description: THE nobility of labor is celebrated on stamps around the world. It is a topic that attracts collectors in large part because there is a wealth of collateral material.

title: Auto Insurance And the Free Market
description: Re: Jim Courter's Opinion page article, ''Auto Insurance: A Better Way,'' on Aug. 14:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Paramount, Calif.;
The French Connection
description: LEAD: THIS largely industrial Los Angeles suburb has begun a residential redevelopment effort with a tract of single-family homes laid out in a pattern first used in France.

title: The Editorial Notebook; At Home With the Homeless
description: The St. Francis Residence in Manhattan's Chelsea section has a steam-cleaned 19th-century brick exterior, lovely oak doors, a spotless hallway and 80 guests. Having a room at this hotel may be the best luck most of them have ever known. If they were not here, they would probably be living on a park bench, over a hot-air grating or in a bus station - the usual haunts of those who are both homeless and mentally ill.

title: The Ordeal of the Credit Fraud Victim
description: IT is a different kind of household theft. The thief might be a nurse's aide or a cleaning person; the loot Social Security numbers, credit card account data and other confidential information. The thief then applies by mail for new credit cards, lines of credit and checking accounts in the name of the victim, giving a mail drop as the current address and the victim's actual address as the former residence. Because the basic information is accurate, the application is approved, and the victim has a new credit card or checking account - one he does not know about and the thief controls.

title: Eclectic Offering At the Paramount
description: ''WORD is getting out about the Paramount Center for the Arts,'' said Robert Engstrom, the executive director of the reconverted movie palace in Peekskill. ''We have the best mix of live entertainment and films in Westchester.''

title: Coma Case Goes To High Court
description: IT will now be up to the Connecticut Supreme Court to decide the fate of Carol McConnell, a 56-year-old head nurse at Danbury Hospital who has been comatose since Jan. 18, 1985.

title: Agatha Christie Drama: Murder Most Public
description: ON the morning of Friday the 13th, the residents of an English country home in the village of Chipping Cleg-horn read the announcement of a forthcoming murder in the personals column of the local weekly gazette.

title: Traveling Children
description: To the Editor: I was quite interested in Betsy Wade's article about children flying alone (Practical Traveler, July 24) - and aghast at the huge number - for I flew alone from San Francisco to Chicago in 1939, at the age of 6. My picture was on the front page of The Chicago Tribune, where it was said I flew ''across the country.''

title: Japanese Women Sound American Notes
description: THE petite, dark-haired women listen intently to their conductor. When he jokes with them, in their native language, they giggle discreetly behind their hands. The women come together every Tuesday for two hours of rigorous practice, followed by socializing. They are the 40 members of Hanamizuki, a chorus composed of Japanese women from around the county.

title: Sanford Weill Goes Back to Wall Street
description: Sanford Weill is getting back in the brokerage business. The founder of the firm that became Shearson Lehman Hutton worked out a $1.65 billion deal under which his Commercial Credit Group will merge with Primerica, the parent of Smith Barney, Harris Upham. Primerica, the former American Can Company, has been transformed into a financial services conglomerate by Gerald Tsai Jr., who made a fortune during the stock market's ''go-go'' years of the 1960's. Mr. Weill began building his Wall Street firm in the 1960's and in 1981 sold Shearson to American Express for $1 billion. In 1986 he bought into Commercial Credit, which provides consumer loans. The new company will be known as Primerica, and Mr. Weill will hold the top offices. The combination will bring together 1,800 branch offices that could offer a wide array of consumer financial services.

title: Family Still Hopes For Etan's Return
description: THERE is nothing new to report in the case of Etan Patz.

title: Yonkers Mayor to Renew Bid to Obey Court Order
description: Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko of Yonkers said yesterday that he would ask the City Council to meet Tuesday in yet another effort to reverse opposition to a court-ordered housing desegregation plan and thus halt fines that could bankrupt the city by mid-November.

title: Ferit Melen, Ex-Turkish Premier And Defense Minister, Dies at 82
description: Ferit Melen, a former Prime Minister and Defense Minister of Turkey, died Saturday of a heart condition, it was reported in Ankara. He was 82 years old.

title: Dr. June Reinisch Wed To Dr. L. A.Rosenblum
description: Dr. June Machover Reinisch, the director of the Kinsey Institute for Research in Sex, Gender and Reproduction at Indiana University at Bloomington, was married last evening to Dr. Leonard A. Rosenblum, a professor in the department of psychiatry at the State University Health Science Center at Brooklyn. Rabbi Robert P. Abelson officiated at Sammy's Famous Rumanian Restaurant in New York.

title: In Oyster Bay, Tennis, Everyone?
description: LEAD: MEASURE out 250 people, a thousand pounds of ice, 60 tennis balls and 64 tennis racquets. Place them all in one Long Island backyard. Add 24 hours of perfect weather, one ice-cream truck and lots of exotic food and drink. Stir gently and you've created the PITT.

title: A Fight to Win The Middle Class
description: PEOPLE could wonder why Michael Dukakis bothers running. Jimmy Carter rode Gerald Ford out of the White House with a severe recession fresh in voters' minds and inflation picking up speed. Ronald Reagan then rode Mr. Carter out, months after another recession and when inflation and interest rates were raging. But this time around, Mr. Reagan's heir apparent, George Bush, presides over an economy that has been free of recessions and soaring prices for the extraordinary stretch of almost six years. Things look downright serene, at least compared to the turbulent 1970's.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Athens
description: There seem to be two sides to everything in the Cradle of Democracy. Athens abounds in history, but suffers from unchecked modern development: On the Acropolis, the 2,500-year-old Parthenon stands above a television antenna-dotted skyline. The city is renowned for openness and hospitality, but the noise and congestion would try the patience of Hercules. A city of brilliant sunshine and vivid colors, it is also often blanketed by hazy brown smog.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE NIGHT WALK: And Other Stories. By Edward Upward. (William Heinemann/David & Charles, $18.95.) Many British writers of the 1930's had an enthusiasm for left-wing politics, but few retained it. A major exception is Edward Upward. In ''The Night Walk: And Other Stories,'' Mr. Upward, who is now in his 80's, offers further explorations of this familiar political territory.

title: How I Learned to Love the Deficit
description: I WISH to argue a case in favor of a Federal deficit as a normal aspect of sound economic policy. This is to enter a plea in the face of overwhelming public opinion as well as against the views of many, although certainly not all, economists. It would therefore seem to be a hopeless case. I hope to show that it is not.

title: Bank Bailouts
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Everybody Is Crying and Sad': Slain Ice Cream Vendor Is Mourned
description: Rosa Vera did not speak much English but the children in her Queens neighborhood only needed to smile to get what they wanted - an ice cream cone from her Mister Softee truck.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: After 30 Years; Mental Institutions May Be as Empty As They'll Ever Be
description: THIS summer the state of Pennsylvania began closing Philadelphia State Hospital, whose nickname - Byberry - had come to symbolize the snakepits that public mental hospitals were and sometimes still are. Where 5,500 patients once slept in filthy hallways and ate wormy food, only about 400 remain.

title: Eastern's Setback
description: 'Massive layoffs are not, and never shall be, business as usual.' - Judge Barrington D. Parker, of Federal District Court in Washington, who ruled that Eastern Airlines could cut service, but could not lay off 4,000 workers without negotiating with their unions.

title: Object of Desire
description: CLAIRE'S KNEE Starring Jean-Claude Brialy, Aurora Cornu, Beatrice Romand, Laurence De Monaghan. Directed by Eric Rohmer. 1971. Media Home Entertainment. 105 minutes. $59.95. Rated PG. In French with English subtitles.

title: Sports of The Times; Jefferies and Hernandez: The Home Boys
description: Their lockers are side by side, no accident. When Gregg Jefferies was taken out of the game after a collision last Wednesday, Keith Hernandez cornered him and said: ''You've got a great opportunity. Don't go out unless you've got a broken leg.'' The restorative power of that somewhat pungent lecture was shown Friday night when Jefferies, bruised foot and all, slashed three more hits. Hernandez loved it. He said, ''What the heck, we're homies. We played for the same coach in the Joe DiMaggio League.''

title: Yvonne Cheng to Wed Christopher J. Dennis
description: The engagement of Yvonne Joyce Cheng to Christopher John Dennis has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Tsung O. Cheng of Bethesda, Md. Mr. Dennis is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Dennis of La Habra, Calif.

title: Improving On Paradise In Hawaii
description: GUESTS at the $360-million Hyatt Waikoloa Beach Resort, which just opened on the Big Island of Hawaii, have a choice of three routes to their rooms: A bullet-nosed rapid-transit tram in the lobby can take them to one of three hotel towers via a monorail. Nearby, a fleet of boats in the lobby can ferry them to their rooms over a mile-long system of canals. (Along the way, they pass a manmade lagoon where guests can swim with porpoises.) Or they can walk to their rooms down a sweeping, columned staircase of Cecil B. De Mille proportions.

title: SECOND THOUGHTS ON ''LAST TEMPTATION'
description: To the Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Canada's Coin Dollar Is Expected to Have a Long Life
description: LEAD: BECAUSE it depicts a loon, Canada's new mini-dollar coin is known as the ''Loonie.'' It has finished its first full year in circulation.

title: INDIA NEWSPAPERS PROTEST NEW BILL
description: A defamation law rushed through the lower house of Parliament last week by the Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has provoked nationwide protests from newspaper editors who say it will severely curtail India's traditional freedom of the press.

title: THE REGION: Back to School; Statistical Snapshot

title: The Audience Takes the Cake
description: THE performance begins on the streets of Greenwich Village, but a Hofstra University dormitory room is where it all started.
