title: Clare Hollensteiner Plans Marriage To Dr. James P. Smyth in February
description: The engagement of Clare L. Hollensteiner to Dr. James P. Smyth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Smyth of Pearl River, N.Y., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hollensteiner of New York, parents of the bride-to-be.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: L.A. IS THE CAPITAL OF KANSAS: Painful Lessons in Post-New York Living. By Richard Meltzer. (Harmony, $16.95.) A native New Yorker who moved to Los Angeles in 1975 at the age of 30, the rock critic Richard Meltzer enterprisingly turned his dissatisfactions with his new home into a series of humorous pieces chronicling his anomalous life as a ''writer in a town where nobody reads.'' This book collects those essays and, in the interest of coherence, unites them by advancing the (not particularly original) thesis that Los Angeles is the purest expression of American culture - thus making the author's loony rants a type of social critique. Taken individually, many of the articles are entertaining enough, and some are simply hilarious. The section titled ''The Everyman Blues,'' which tells of the author's loneliness in Tinseltown and his struggle to make a living as a writer, moves beyond laughs and fashions a powerful blend of edginess and poignancy. Mr. Meltzer's prose style, however, finally emerges as the book's main delight as well as its most serious problem. Racketing and energetic at its best, his writing combines a slouching adolescent casualness with grudging high culture allusions and a use of odd contractions, abbreviations, italics and capitals to dramatize his impatience with ''the cagelike prison geometry of the printed page.'' But over the course of the more than 30 pieces, his ceaseless quest for originality of expression proves just as desperate, confining and dull a prison. L.A. as the capital of Kansas is a clever conceit. But it's not too tough to figure out in which locale twaddle like ''the given sports qua form/fulfillment mind-manifestingly merit, leaving this town an easy 20-30 years behind even . . . Detroit in terms of, y'know, eschatological sportish etc.'' originated.

title: Debra Sue Miller Weds Alan Jay Schefer in L.I.
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Debra Sue Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Miller of Manhasset, L.I., was married last night to Alan Jay Schefer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Schefer of Manhasset Hills, L.I. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony.

title: Red River Redux
description: ''DEAR BULLDOG,'' the letter saluted me. Dear Bulldog? I had to laugh, being long past caring (or pretending to care) how the Bulldogs fared against their rivals. But Altus, home of the Bulldogs, I do care about. Altus, Okla., is the lived longest; the place that in personal mythology stands for home. During my six years there - junior high and high school - I longed to get away, but regularly, in dreams, I go back.

title: Susan Lee Weds K. R. Weisshaar
description: The marriage of Susan Lee to Kenneth R. Weisshaar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Weisshaar of Cincinnati, took place in Milwaukee yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. David Previant, parents of the bride. Judge Myron L. Gordon of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin performed the ceremony.

title: CRISIS IN PANAMA HITS MIDDLE CLASS
description: Unable to pay her utility bill after being laid off, Juana recently had a friend turn off her electricity meter.

title: And the Foot Bones Are Connected to The Funny Bone
description: Charles Moulton and Stephanie Skura are choreographic jesters, and because many of their works concern problems of making and performing dances, they could be called court jesters to the dance community. Both choreographers appeared at the Joyce Theater this past season and, like the best jesters at regal courts, they made audiences think as well as laugh with their antics.

title: Facing Crisis, Connecticut Frees 200 Inmates
description: More than 200 inmates were released from Connecticut jails and prisons this week as officials scrambled to avoid an overcrowding emergency that would have mandated the release of even more criminals.

title: Hungarian Leader Is Assailed on Rumania Talks
description: Karoly Grosz, the Hungarian leader, has angered colleagues in the Communist Party leadership and Government as well as many other Hungarians by his performance in a meeting last Sunday with President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania, Hungarians in contact with party leaders have reported.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. When our house was built in 1959 we had a large walk-in cedar closet built in for clothing storage. Now the smell is gone. Is the wood still a deterrent against moths, and if it isn't can the wood be treated to restore the odor and the mothproof qualities?

title: 'Even the Mad Are Men of Their Times'
description: A SOCIAL HISTORY OF MADNESS The World Through the Eyes of the Insane. By Roy Porter. 261 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $18.95.

title: Program Attacks Drugs and Driving
description: WHEN the Nassau County police officer arrived at the scene of the accident along the Long Island Expressway, he saw that the driver, a 36-year-old man driving a 1981 Chevy Caprice, had slurred speech and glazed and bloodshot eyes and staggered when he tried to walk.

title: And Now, a Message From Your Sponsor
description: THE word is out: music has the ability not only to soothe the savage breast but a child - and parent - as well.

title: Headliners; Back in Trouble
description: Lawrence Taylor, the star linebacker of the Giants, has gone over the edge once again. Taylor flunked a recent National Football League drug test, a league spokesman said last week, and will be suspended for the first four games of the regular season, beginning with the Giants' season opener tomorrow night against the Washington Redskins. The league did say not what drug Taylor was accused of abusing, but it was widely believed to be cocaine. In his 1986 autobiography, ''LT: Living on the Edge,'' Taylor admitted being a cocaine addict, saying he substituted another player's urine for his own to pass drug tests. The latest offense was Taylor's second violation of N.F.L. substance abuse rules. A third infraction would result in permanent suspension.

title: At a WEdding, a Dream of Unity, a Mosaic of Faiths and Colors
description: ANDREW is black. His family comes from Barbados and they are Christian. Rachel is white, Long Island bred andJewish. A while ago they married among their friends and families. I, one of their guests, have spent lots of time thinking of that joyous but perplexing afternoon.

title: Commercial Property: Operating Expenses; Better Management May Slow Rises in Costs
description: Owners of office buildings across the nation are struggling to trim operating expenses as rising property taxes cut into their profit margins and excess vacant space forces them to shift more money into marketing campaigns.

title: The Latest Big Wave of Little Consumers
description: THE prognosticators were wrong. The number of births in the United States would drop in 1987, they predicted. Instead, an estimated 3.8 million births were recorded, 3 percent more than in 1986, according to the Department of Health and Human Services. And the number is expected to increase slightly this year, too.

title: THE REGION: For Parents; Battling Over Rules On Racial Balance
description: FOR more than 12 years, the New York City Board of Education has tried to maintain racial balance in a handful of neighborhood high schools despite the dwindling number of white students. This has been done by closing the door to minority students from outside the neighborhood, if the school's population was less than 50 percent white.

title: Arthur E. Voss, Publisher,94
description: Arthur E. Voss, a publishing executive and former owner of Financial World magazine, died Thursday in Naples, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 94 years old.

title: Fiona K. Biggs Wed in Nevada
description: Fiona Katharine Biggs, a senior securities analyst at the Dreyfus Corporation in New York, and Stanley Freeman Druckenmiller, the chairman and president of the Duquesne Capital Management Corporation in Pittsburgh, were married yesterday. The Rev. Gene Lee, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of Jack Dreyfus, a friend of the couple, in Lake Tahoe, Nev.

title: The Carbonated Rhythm Orchestra Fizzled Out
description: LEAD: SUNBURN LAKE By Tom De Haven. 293 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Fight Is On to Save an Old Indian Fort
description: AFTER centuries of relative obscurity, the site of a 17th-century Indian fort in Cutchogue has suddenly gained attention as a result of a modern-day struggle between forces that want to preserve it as a historical site and those favoring development.

title: THE REGION: For Teachers; Fearing for Safety
description: WHEN new teachers gathered for orientation seminars over the last two weeks, the subject that evoked the greatest concern appeared to be safety in the city's schools. Some of the new and would-be teachers were plainly scared.

title: POSTINGS: Targeting the Bay Ridge Market; Offices in a Family Setting
description: Steve Pappas readily admits that constructing an office building among the two- and three-family homes in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn is a bit unusual. But that singularity, he said, assures a local market. The 58,000-square-foot structure that Mr. Pappas, with Gino Silvestri and Gus Spiropoulos, is raising above 92d Street between Fourth and Fifth Avenues will be marketed mostly to medical, legal and other small space users now shoehorned into neighborhood storefronts. ''There are certain companies that need a presence in Bay Ridge,'' Mr. Pappas said. ''There may not be a tremendous demand, but for what little demand there is, nothing is available.''

title: Doors and Windows: Shelter From the Storm
description: If your home lacks storm doors or storm windows or you wish to replace existing ones, you can save money by installing them yourself. Doing so is usually a simple procedure. The easiest doors and windows to install are pre-hung - that is, mounted in their frames. Pre-hung storm doors and windows are made to fit nearly all standard door and window openings. Custom sizes are also available.

title: For Whale Expert, Each is an Individual
description: HER home is landlocked, but her job is on the sea, studying the whales that are both her career and her passion.

title: 'Paris Trout'
description: To the Editor:

title: Growing Up Is Hard to Do
description: TEEN ANGEL And Other Stories of Young Love. By Marianne Gingher. 209 pp. New York: Atheneum. $17.95.

title: Softball Players Seeking U.S. Title
description: LEAD: IN an era when sports teams from Pop Warner to professional have difficulty repeating as champions, the Pitney Bowes Women's Softball Team rolls along.

title: Correction
description: The Stamps column of Aug. 28 incorrectly stated the date on which India became independent. It was 1947.

title: Colin M. Carter Plans Marriage To Miss Scribner
description: Alexandra Crowell Scribner and Colin Mark Carter plan to be married Oct. 15, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Richard O. Scribner of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Carter is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Shelby H. Carter of Austin, Tex.

title: Taylor Leads Nebraska to a 63-13 Romp
description: Steve Taylor ran for two touchdowns and passed for another today as Nebraska routed Utah State, 63-13, for its second victory of the season.

title: Question Of the Week How Will The Giants And Jets Do in '88?
description: Contrary to popular belief, the Jets do have a chance to succeed this season. The team still has nearly all of the talented offensive players that led them to the playoffs only two years ago.

title: Appeal for African Refugees
description: The Organization of African Unity appealed today for emergency aid to help nearly six million refugees in southern Africa. The O.A.U. said in a statement that not enough aid had been pledged after an appeal by an conference on refugees in southern Africa held in Oslo from Aug. 22 to 24. The Oslo conference said South Africa was at the root of the refugee crisis.

title: Rushing to (Mis)Judgment
description: Five years after a Soviet fighter shot down Korean Air Lines Flight 007, and two months after the U.S.S. Vincennes shot down an Iranian Airbus, America has yet to come to grips with the common elements in these two tragedies. The Reagan Administration rushed to deny that there could be any. Indeed, the incidents were not parallel, but there were important similarities in the way the parties involved responded. And to recall these responses yields useful lessons.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE ACORN PLAN. By Tim McLaurin. (Norton, $16.95.) How can you resist a book that begins, ''Bubble Riley decided to drink all the wine in the world the night Billy cut the soldier's lung in half''? It's a fine and appropriate opening line, for ''The Acorn Plan'' is about excess - too much drinking, fighting, pride, family history - and Tim McLaurin conveys his understanding of such things in a clear Southern voice.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Mohegan Colony is 65
description: LEAD: CAMARADERIE is a word used often by residents of the Mohegan Colony in northern Westchester. The word describes the feelings many of the homeowners say they get from living in their community, which is on about 400 acres in the towns of Cortlandt and Yorktown. This weekend, neighbors, friends and guests are getting together to celebrate the 65th anniversary of the colony.

title: Scientists Listen to Noises of Plants in Drought
description: Drought-stricken plants emit high-pitched noises as their cell structure breaks down, and scientists are trying to determine if the sounds are attracting destructive insects.

title: Chinese Exposition To Open This Week
description: LEAD: EVERY morning, Governor Kean is said to indulge in a cup of the world's best green tea, imported from China's Zhejiang Province.

title: Jets Fans Preparing for Lots of Change and Plenty of Patience
description: It has never been easy to be a Jets fan. The team goes to the American Football Conference championship one season, then dismisses its coach and has a losing record the next. It starts off one season at 10-1, then loses the last five games. It wins the first two games in upsets another season, then is set back by a strike and drops the final four games.

title: Greatest Little Show
description: It is reported to be the largest and longest-running children's circus in the country, and the only one in Westchester. It is also, in the shining eyes of its performers and their families, the greatest show on earth.

title: Nothing Is Disturbing the Peace at the Western White House
description: A LONG, long time ago, in a place far, far from Washington, a new President came to town with his entourage. Politicians and reporters breathlessly watched the comings and goings of Presidential advisers, recording their every utterance and carefully noting their every nuance.

title: Brooklyn Philharmonic Set for Season Opening
description: The flutist James Galway will be the guest soloist for the opening concert of the Brooklyn Philharmonic's 35th-anniversary season, on Sept. 23 at the Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place. Lukas Foss, the orchestra's music director, will conduct works by Bach, Handel, Mercadante and Alessandro Scarlatti. Other season soloists will be the pianists Shura Cherkassky and Cecile Licad and the violinists Gidon Kremer and Dmitry Sitkovetsky.

title: Read My Lips
description: ''CONGRESS WILL push me to raise taxes,'' George Bush told the whooping Republican delegates at the party's convention in New Orleans (pronounced ''N'awlins'' by the natives, and not, as David Brinkley assured Peter Jennings, ''New Or-le-ans''), ''and I'll say no, and they'll push, and I'll say no, and they'll push again, and I'll say to them, 'Read my lips: no new taxes.' ''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Another Side of Scarsdale
description: LEAD: Thomas Oakes Jr., 22 years old, begins work as a professional firefighter with the Scarsdale Fire Department tomorrow. But when Mr. Oakes, who lives with his parents in Scarsdale, first expressed interest in the job, some of his friends were surprised: ''A few people were a little confused,'' he said.

title: Pakistan Detaining 90 in Zia Investigation
description: More than two weeks after the death of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq in an unexplained air crash, some 90 people are being detained for questioning, officials said today.

title:
ART;
Furniture With Harm on Its Mind
description: LEAD: PERHAPS it was the Dada artists - or anti-artists, as they characterized themselves - who first explored the possibilities of ''Dangerous Furniture,'' the theme of the exhibition at Discovery Gallery in Glen Cove.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE 52 ASSOCIATION;
Sports, the Common Denominator
description: LEAD: WHEN Alice Duchinsky goes to the beach, she keeps her blue jeans on. When she goes to the 52 Association Sports Complex off Cedar Lane here, she wears a bikini.

title: A Bond of Braided Histories
description: JACK OF DIAMONDS And Other Stories. By Elizabeth Spencer. 184 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: Arthritis Sufferers Swim for comfort
description: LEAD: THE 18 people who meet at the Jewish Community Center in Stamford to swim together have little in common but their pain.

title: Autumn's Palette May be Muted
description: THIS year's fall foliage will probably start a little earlier and be a little dimmer than in some past years, the state's foresters say. The weather - especially dry weather - may have taken its toll, the foresters say, and sugar maples in particular have had several problems.

title: Bill on Teacher Strikes Provokes Debate
description: LEAD: A BILL that authorizes courts to settle teacher strikes through binding arbitration is the focus of a dispute among state educators and school officials.

title: Protect Your Garbage Cans! Young Bears Are Coming
description: Young black bears from Pennsylvania and New Jersey have invaded southeastern New York State in recent weeks, according to state wildlife experts.

title: POSTING: Duplexes on a Recreation Site; 44 on 3 Acres
description: ''Just about everyone on Long Island knows this site,'' said Robert Krieger, who with his father, Maxwell, and brother, Steven, is building 44 town houses on three acres in Elmont. But not just any three acres. On this lot between Stewart and Franklin Streets on Johnson Avenue was a recreational complex that included a huge, above-ground pool and the Wal-Cliffe Rollerdrome, a roller-skating rink. Built in 1937 and rebuilt in the 1950's following a fire, the once-fashionable complex attracted, said Steven Krieger, such patrons as Clark Gable and Vinnie Testaverde, the Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback and an Elmont native. The complex had closed before the Kriegers bought it in 1986, and they are now demolishing the abandoned structures.

title: ANTI-SEMITIC JOKE ASSAILED IN FRANCE
description: Jean-Marie Le Pen, the defeated presidential candidate of France's extreme right, has been condemned by politicians and leaders of human rights and Jewish groups for a joke about World War II crematoriums.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transcription error, an article on Aug. 28 about Poland misstated the amount of a fine said to have been imposed against a supporter of the outlawed Solidarity trade union. The amount was 50,000 zlotys, which is about $125.

title: Real Estate Boards Are Going on the Offensive
description: When a judge overturned a zoning restriction last month aimed at protecting factory tenants in New York City's garment district, the ruling marked a new sort of victory for the Real Estate Board of New York.

title: Russian Program for Carnegie Opening
description: Riccardo Muti will lead the Philadelphia Orchestra in Shostakovich's Violin Concerto No. 1 and the Prokofiev cantata ''Alexander Nevsky'' to open Carnegie Hall's 1988-89 season, on Sept. 27 at 7:30 P.M. Viktoriya Mullova will be the soloist for the Shostakovich work, which opens the program; the Bulgarian mezzo-soprano Alexandrina Milcheva and the Choral Arts Society of Philadelphia will sing the Prokofiev work after the intermission.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Stadium Beer Bill Is Approved
description: Beer sales in parts of seven New York sports venues will be restricted beginning next year under a bill Governor Cuomo has signed that requires alcohol-free seating areas in many of the state's major arenas and stadiums.

title: Fragile Scraps Of Fabric That Recall an Era
description: Next month marks the 100th anniversary of the first exhibition of the Arts and Crafts Exhibition Society at the New Gallery on Regent Street here. To celebrate the occasion that gave a whole movement its name, the Victoria and Albert Museum has taken the tissue-paper wraps off of hundreds of fragile materials, some of them stored in 15-foot-high cupboards, and placed them on display.

title: A. J. Johnston Marries Miss Boylan, a Student
description: Cynthia Ann Boylan, the daughter of Mrs. J. Richard Boylan of Devon, Pa., and the late Mr. Boylan, was married at the Registry Office in Chelsea, London, yesterday to Andrew James Johnston, a son of Judy Johnston of Crockham Hill, Kent, England, and W. B. Johnston.

title: A Healthier Tone in the Rental Market
description: To Juanita Mouzon it seems a distant age. Yet it was only three years ago that she found a small one-bedroom apartment on Edgecombe Avenue in West Harlem for an affordable rent of $350 a month.

title: Economics '88, And Geography
description: With the economy appearing to be in generally good shape, precedent would say the Republicans should win the election. But polls show that many middle-class people are worried about the future, so both George Bush and Michael S. Dukakis are pressing economic issues in their campaigns.

title: What do Which Women Really Want?
description: ON ACCOUNT OF SEX The Politics of Women's Issues, 1945-1968. By Cynthia Harrison. 337 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $25.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore $472,000 56 West Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 55-year-old Tudor; 1-bedroom guest cottage, 2-car garage, 1.1 acres; taxes $5,600. East Islip $770,000 85 Percy Williams Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old contemporary; 1.6 acre, 160-foot waterfront, 2-car garage; taxes $8,500. Wading River $121,000 180 Cliff Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; basement, 0.5 acre, private beach rights; taxes $1,400. OTHER AREAS Springfield, N.J. $262,500 34 Littlebrook Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, hardwood floors, 2-car garage; taxes $4,078.
