title: Shamir Calls for Removal of an Israeli Official
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today demanded that the Foreign Ministry's director general, Maj. Gen. Avraham Tamir, be dismissed for saying in Washington that the Palestine Liberation Organization represents the Palestinian people.

title: Up Close At the Open
description: It is an intimate setting, the Wrigley Field of tennis courts, with fans sitting almost close enough to touch the players, and close enough to see the expressions of joy or anguish on their faces. The Grandstand court at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows seats 6,000, which, admittedly, can be a problem when 20,000 people decide they would like to watch the match in progress there.

title: Directory is Planned in Spanish
description: DO you speak Spanish? In Hartford, about 250,000 people do, and they represent buying power of roughly $20 million. As a result, a directory called the Hispanic Yellow Pages and aimed at Hispanic people throughout the state will make its debut Jan. 1.

title:
GARDENING;
Tasks to Insure Healthy Spring Plants
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to gardening, fall is second only to spring in the number of tasks to be done, and, as with most anything seasonal, timeliness is important. In the fall the gardener's deadlines are determined by the threat of killing frost and freezing soil. Some tasks must be done before the frost and cold end most activities until late winter or early spring.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: MANHATTAN COUNTRY DOCTOR, by Milton Jonathan Slocum. (Ballantine, $7.95.) From 1934 to 1968 the author practiced medicine in Hell's Kitchen, the seedy area around Manhattan's theater district that these days developers like to call Clinton. ''The doctor has a deadpan humanism that allows the story to tell itself,'' Irvin Faust said here in 1986. ''His style is ideally suited to a man who comes across as tough, clear-eyed, idiosyncratic and fiercely honest.''

title: Headliners; Back to School
description: Vartan Gregorian is about to be checked out of the New York Public Library. Mr. Gregorian, who presided over the revival of the library as president, was appointed last week as the 16th president of Brown University. Mr. Gregorian was an adroit fund-raiser for the library, and such skills are doubtless needed at Brown, whose $360 million endowment is the smallest in the Ivy League. Colleagues of Mr. Gregorian, who came to the library in 1981 after being passed over for the presidency of the University of Pennsylvania, said the academic world would benefit from his return. ''He will in my judgment quickly become one of the most visible and effective spokesmen in the country for higher education,'' said Jonathan Fanton, president of the New School for Social Research, where Mr. Gregorian sometimes lectured.

title: Celebrating the Bland but Influential People of Connecticut
description: BEING from Connecticut is like being from Canada: nobody cares. The very idea of the place leaves people disoriented. Perhaps no other state in the Union is as colorless. Say Maine, and people think of lobsters and fishermen in long yellow slickers. Say California, and they think of giant redwoods and Hollywood. Say New Jersey, they think of toxic waste and eight-lane turnpikes. Say Connecticut, and people think . . . insurance?

title: SEAGRAM'S 'NEGOCIANT': Abdallah Simon; A Superpower in the World of Fine French Wines
description: A READER of the French gastronomic journal Cuisine et Vins de France wrote an angry letter to the editor recently. He had just been to New York, he said, and was dismayed to discover that fine French wines were much cheaper there than in Paris.

title: Florida St. Poll-Axed By Miami
description: The Miami Hurricanes forcefully demonstrated tonight that the method of determining the nation's top college football team at the start of the season is as inaccurate as it may be democratic.

title: 'Year 2000' Update Sees Some Progress Made
description: LEAD: One year after the city-appointed Commission on the Year 2000 issued its report, ''New York Ascendant,'' the commission says the city has made progress in several areas, particularly in reducing the number of students who drop out of school and slowing the increase in the numbers of people who live in homeless shelters.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The nation's economic situation is hard, and strikes do not help. But until now, we have been unable to reach agreement. We did not strike for the fun of it. We struck so that there would be no need to strike tomorrow, or the day after.'' - Lech Walesa. [ 11:1. ]

title: Reagan Says Welfare Legislation Has to Include Work Requirement
description: President Reagan warned Congress today that he would veto any welfare legislation it sent him that did not contain a work requirement.

title: Aloof Museums
description: To the Editor: Michael Brenson's essay was, sad to say, a quite accurate portrayal of the museums of today. As a frequent visitor to museums I've had experiences with loud, inaccurate lecturers, an absence of chairs, and the horrendous crowds of the blockbuster shows.

title: Environmental Law And Order
description: It was reported on July 24 in the New Jersey Weekly it was reported (The Environment, on July 24) that Du Pont, the only company still disposing of industrial waste at a site the 106 miles offshore, site, planned to withdraw its application for a Federal permit to continue.

title: Why the Military Can't Learn to Shop
description: RECENT headlines about high military costs and the inappropriate use of Government procurement information are the latest evidence of long-standing problems in the Pentagon's acquisiton management system. Every few years, Government commissions or blue ribbon panels are appointed to study military procurement problems. Topics for study usually include cost overruns, cost assignment errors, high-priced spare parts, schedule delays and technical performance failures. Time after time, these commissions make their recommendations - with which most Government officials agree - but within a year or two, key military managers change, the recommendations fade and new problems emerge.

title: State Lines and Party Lines Are Coinciding Less
description: FINALLY, everything is for keeps. The 1988 election campaign has been going on for the better part of two years. But during most of that time, most Americans were not paying much attention. ''Nothing matters until Labor Day'' were words heard scores of times from political professionals who were working furiously, as if they didn't believe their own words. Labor Day is upon us.

title: A Movie That Cannily Celebrates The American Businessman As a Hero
description: If you build a better mousetrap than your neighbor, you are quite liable to get your fingers caught in it. In 1946 Preston Tucker set out to produce the car of his dreams, the ''Tucker Torpedo'' - a vehicle that in terms of design, performance and safety was far in advance of its period. By the time he went out of business, in 1948, he had been forced into bankruptcy and put on trial for fraud: he was acquitted, but his great days were over. Francis Ford Coppola has taken the Torpedo episode as the basis for his latest movie, ''Tucker.''A dark enough theme, you might have supposed: a story calculated to prompt sardonic thoughts about the forces by which Tucker was crushed - big business and its political allies - and melancholy reflections about the fate of the pioneer.

title: Shopping Center Rule Looming for Farmhouse
description: RESTORATION and renovation of a 200-year-old Glen Head farmhouse destroyed by fire five years ago are part of a plan to incorporate the historical landmark into a new shopping center.

title: Shop Owner Returns Bassoon
description: A New York City musician whose $12,000 bassoon was stolen at a bus stop was reunited with the instrument yesterday when it was returned by a storekeeper who had bought it from a vagrant for $3 and a pack of cigarettes.

title: Architect Has Blueprint for Success: His Own House
description: LEAD: When an architect is designing a house, he or she usually gets some guidelines from the client.

title: Up in Arms Over Yanks, Their Owner, and Their Attitude; Accentuating The Negative
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: TOUCH WOOD A Girlhood in Occupied France. By Renee Roth-Hano. 297 pp. New York: Four Winds Press. $15.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: Attacks on the 'L-word' Debase Us All
description: LEAD: President Reagan has given a new impetus and his special imprimatur to the present vilification of liberalism. Arriving at the Republican convention in New Orleans, he declared: ''The masquerade is over, it's time to . . . use the dreaded L-word; to say the policies of our opposition . . . are liberal, liberal, liberal.

title: Iraqi Says Kurd Uprising Has Been Defeated
description: Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq said today that Kurdish dissidents had rebelled against the Baghdad Government but were now fleeing from northern Iraq into Turkey and Iran after the rebellion collapsed.

title: A Minimalist Singing A One-Note Tune
description: When does a composer's style turn into a straitjacket? At what point do we say that an artist is no longer extending and developing an idiom, but instead rehashing it - unconsciously, because a way of working has become automatic, or cynically, because he knows it will bring success, or helplessly, because he's trapped and can't find a way out?

title: Banks Faulted for Withholding Tax Payments
description: Liens have been placed on the houses of thousands of homeowners in New York State because their banks or mortgage companies have deliberately delayed forwarding tax payments from their escrow accounts, the State Consumer Protection Board has found.

title: About Chess Moves
description: The New York Times has converted its method of chessboard notation to the algebraic system, in which each square is unambiguously identified by file letter and rank number. Explanations of the system are available from the Chess Column, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Getting Faster by Getting Simpler
description: Historically, the conventional path to more processing power has been through increased complexity. In the last week, though, a flurry of activity has surrounded a countervailing trend - higher performance through simplification. The technology in the news is called RISC, for reduced instruction set computer.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; Woodcliff Lake
description: Though the cornfields and apple and peach orchards are diminishing, crowds still come - especially on autumn weekends - to Chestnut Ridge Road in Woodcliff Lake to visit Tice's or Van Riper's farm stores, on land owned by these families for nearly 200 years.

title: Movie Miscellany
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: CURTAIN GOING UP. By Carolyn R. Scott. (Joan Kahn/St. Martin's, $16.95.) An impecunious writer can empathize with the heroine of Carolyn Scott's first novel. Sheila Devlin is a fortyish divorced novelist struggling to meet the mortgage payments on her modest Westport, Conn., house and her daughter Kerry's tuition at Vassar.

title: Ingenious Tricks in Speakers
description: Like athletes, always try ing to break their own records, loudspeaker designers are forever striving to surpass themselves. At least the good ones, for whom sonic fidelity is a passion as well as a business.

title: Big Apple Nickname Traced Back 70 Years
description: To the Editor:

title: Princess of Wales, Patroness
description: AT the beginning of this century Britain's King Edward VII was a bridge enthusiast and usually played a social game - auction in those days - after dinner. The royal family has been distinctly short of players since then.

title: Nicole Ismen Married To William J. Hughes
description: Nicole Menekse Zeynep Ismen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ergun Ismen of Houston, was married yesterday to William Joseph Hughes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hughes of Marriottsville, Md. The Rev. Franicis X. Moan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Audubon Naturalist Society in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Gamble by Green Earns 2-Shot Lead
description: Ken Green was certain he was going to make a mistake if he hit the driver for his second shot at the par-5 18th hole today. But he had the driver in his hands, 250 yards from the pin, and faced with trying to negotiate the big pond at the front right of the green. He just dared himself to get home in two with the big weapon.

title: Proper Equipment For Those Rainy Days
description: PHOTOGRAPHING in the rain may not be everyone's cup of tea, but occasionally I get an urge to confront inclement elements with my camera. There's only one hitch: keeping the camera dry.

title: Artist Defends Refusal to Give Up Melee Tape
description: When Clayton Patterson, a 40-year-old East Village video artist and hat maker, ventured out shortly before midnight to tape a music act, he had no idea he would end up in the vortex of a storm over police brutality in New York City.

title: The Counter-Gap Play
description: This play, effective for so long for the Redskins, is now being adopted by more N.F.L. teams. 1. Backs take a counter-step in opposite direction of play; three linemen block that way, too. 2. Backs reverse direction; left guard and tackle pull and help tight end clean out right side, as does the H-back. 3. Tailback takes handoff and follows blocking.

title: Another View On the Death Penalty
description: Leigh Bienen's Aug. 7 article on the Opinion page (''No Savings in Lives or Money With Death Penalty'') prompts some thoughts supporting the death penalty.

title: Reagan's Library Is Edging Closer to Reality
description: After years of delay, the way seems to be clear for the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, even though it will not be open by the time President Reagan leaves office, as originally planned.

title: Neighbors, My Lawn Isn't A Recycling Center
description: SOME of my neighbors, and I am certain some of yours, have misunderstood the concept of recycling. Recycling trash does not mean throwing it on my lawn, in my yard, under my bushes, or in front of my house.

title: Thousands Mass in Serbia, Urging a Cohesive Republic
description: Thousands of Yugoslavs massed in this Danube steelmaking town today to demand a reunited Serbian republic, with the Serbian Communist Party chief, Slobodan Milosevic, installed as new leader of Yugoslavia. As many as 70,000 people attended, according to a police estimate.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: A WOMAN who will go only so far as to say she will never see 50 again was sitting on a crowded bus not too long ago when another woman got on and stood in front of her. The first woman, having been nicely raised and taught to get up for older people and the handicapped, promptly arose and offered the standing woman a seat.

title: Question Of the Week How Will The Giants And Jets Do in '88?
description: I am getting bad signals from the Giants. The line still has some unanswered questions (especially William Roberts at his new position). If the line has trouble, the whole offense will be in bad shape with Phil Simms being grounded and Joe Morris pounded. And after watching the Browns game, it's safe to say the wide receivers aren't producing as much as anyone has hoped.

title: Many Lefebvre Priests Going Back to Vatican
description: In the two months since Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre was excommunicated from the Roman Catholic Church, a steadily growing number of priests have defected from his ranks and have offered their loyalty to Pope John Paul II, Vatican officials say.

title: Lifting the Gloom on Downtown Revival
description: LEAD: Four years ago, when Patrick R. Mack bought the Cranford Sports Center in downtown Cranford, N.J., ''summers were dead.'' Few people, he said, came into his athletic equipment store or other downtown retail outlets. ''There was definitely a feeling of doom and gloom among the storeowners,'' he said.

title: Miss Forcione Married To Mark Paul Lubben
description: Eirka Ann Forcione, an associate in the corporate department at the New York law firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed, was married in Argentiere, France, yesterday to Mark Paul Lubben, a vice president in the mergers and acquisitions department at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York. The Rev. Jean Eyherelde performed the ceremony at the Argentiere Roman Catholic Church.

title: Beach Crisis Leads Public to Assist Naturalists
description: LAST summer, algae depleted oxygen in Long Island Sound. Fish and lobster were killed, and black muck covered much of the bottom. This year, many beaches have had to be closed when sewage and other debris washed up.

title: The Ironman
description: I'M SITTING AT THE TABLE HAVING SOME breakfast. Just ran eight miles. And the headache comes on. Boy. Stops me cold.'' The patient, a computer salesman, clasped his hands behind his neck as he recalled what had happened to him, and snapped his head back with a grimace. ''All I could do is lay down with the lights out and not move.''

title: Nancy Swenson Weds
description: Nancy Kay Swenson, the executive director of training for Estee Lauder in New York, and Robert Charles Dalldorf, an investment specialist for New England Securities in New York, were married yesterday at the Waterloo Ridge Lutheran Church in Spring Grove, Minn. The Rev. W. Gordon Smedsrud performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sander J. Swenson of Spring Grove. Her husband is a son of Mrs. Robert H. Dalldorf of East Harwich, Mass., and the late Mr. Dalldorf.

title: Where the Salads Take the Cake
description: A STOREFRONT restaurant called Main Street sounds like a casual salad and sandwich spot. But Port Washington's Main Street Restaurant is much more than that. This snazzy charmer is a serious dinner only establishment with exciting appetite seducers.

title: 'Walk in the Woods' in Westport
description: AFTER attending the illuminating production of ''A Walk in the Woods'' at the Westport Country Playhouse, one could sum up the disparity between the values of regional theater and the Broadway commercial theater.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: STRAW-HAT THEATER

title: Frames to Fit a Fancy
description: NOW that we all know who framed Roger Rabbit, the next question to consider is this: What are the most amusing and unusual frames around? The easy answer is the decoupage series to be found at Stella Flame, 476 Columbus Avenue (83d Street).

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Young Magicians' Mecca ''ABRACADABRA'' didn't open the gates at LaSalle Military Academy in Oakdale. Nor did ''Open Sesame!'' The receptionist wanted to deal with more mundane matters, such as where the visitor was going.

title: Talking; Office Condos: Problems In Running A Complex
description: As the number of office condominiums increases nationwide, so does knowledge about how to run them. More is now known, for example, about operational problems that office condos regularly encounter; the kind of professional managers that serve these condos; how the board meetings operate, and, as they age, the difficulties that often beset such communities.

title: Amid a Strike, Hardships but No Cries of Help
description: WHEN 10,000 people walked off their jobs at Electric Boat in Groton on July 1, a flow of $3 million a week into the economy, from the submarine builder's payroll halted abruptly.

title: Schools Reopen Amid Challenges
description: THE school term is starting quietly for most New Jersey schools this year, but several longstanding issues are coming to a head, threatening fundamental changes to the state's system of public education.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-21

title: Question Of the Week How Will The Giants And Jets Do in '88?
description: Regretfully, the answer can be found in the question above. The '88 Giants and Jets will be 8-8. Parity comes to the Meadowlands. JOHN P. KELLY Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Windows Into a World of Unshakable Faith
description: At the entrance to ''Holy Image, Holy Space: Icons and Frescoes From Greece,'' at the Walters Art Gallery, is a five-foot-tall panel painting from around 1400. It features the bearded Christ known as the Pantocrator that is one of the prototypical images of Byzantine art. He is blessing with His right hand, showing the Gospel with His left. The gold background reflects light; His wine-colored tunic and night-blue mantle absorb it. The image shows us the word and invites us to listen. Although the icon seems simple, even effortless, it is in fact a prodigious balancing act. This part-God, part-man is fleshy, almost fretful, very much in time; yet he is also removed, forbidding, outside time. The way the hair covers His ears both restrains His head, holding it back, and makes the face pop forward, establishing His physical immediacy.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: HISTORIC CAR FESTIVAL

title: Prime Concerns: Pact Disputes and State Aid
description: LEAD: SHOREHAM, asbestos, AIDS and state aid are the major issues as school resumes this week on Long Island for 394,205 students. In each case, governmental involvement has created factors beyond the control of the individual taxpayer.

title: Revere Beach
description: To the Editor: The name of the narrow-gauge railroad mentioned in the article on Revere Beach (Travel, May 15) and by some of your readers was the Boston, Revere Beach & Lynn. As late as the 1920's it was an incredibly busy and well-patronized transportation system. The trains were numerous and fast and ran on frequent schedules. The engines accelerated rapidly and reached high speeds between stations.

title: Dawn Marie Janerich Wed to Mark Werner
description: Dawn Marie Janerich, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dwight T. Janerich of New Haven and Kennebunk Beach, Me., was married yesterday to Mark Black Werner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. Werner of Huntington Bay, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Laman H. Bruner Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Chapel in Kennebunkport, Me.

title: Paris Temple
description: To the Editor: The so-called Roman temple illustrated in Steven Greenhouse's reference to the Parc Monceau (What's Doing in Paris, July 17) is in fact just an assemblage of French Renaissance columns taken from the unfinished tomb of Henry II and recycled in the form of a classical naumachie, a picturesque stage set. Its builder, Philippe Egalite, would have been pleased to hear that we thought it Roman in the 20th century. WILLIAM HOWARD ADAMS Shenandoah Junction, W. Va. The writer is the author of ''The French Garden, 1500-1800,'' published by George Braziller.

title: Judge Restricts County's Use of Inmate Lounges
description: BELEAGURED county officials trying to administer the increasingly overcrowded corrections complex in Valhalla received a double dose of bad news last week. The inmate population reached 1,401 - the highest level in county history - as a Federal judge ordered further restrictions on the use of inmate lounges to house extra prisoners.

title: Suzanne Thomas Wed To Edward L. Abrams
description: Suzanne Marie Thomas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan D. Thomas of Manchester, Conn., was married in Hartford yesterday to Edward Lawrence Abrams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack M. Abrams of Commack, L.I. Rabbi Steven Mason and the Rev. Stephen Jacobson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Hartford Club.

title: School's Latest Course: An Introduction to Men
description: Jon Huberman, his surfboard under an arm, entered Larcom Hall, a three-story red brick dormitory on Wheaton College's picturesque campus here. His father followed, carrying a skateboard and other necessities of college life.

title: Notebook; Players Resent 'Double Standard' on Punishment
description: The players see Pete Rose suspended for pushing an umpire, Billy Hatcher suspended for corking a bat, Kevin Gross and Joe Niekro suspended for having forbidden objects on the mound, Pedro Guerrero suspended for throwing a bat and they wonder. Why are they punished for breaking the rules, but the owners are not? The owners don't even have to admit that they broke the rules after they have been found guilty of breaking the rules.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WOMEN ACTIVISTS: Challenging the Abuse of Power. By Anne Witte Garland. (Feminist Press at the City University of New York, Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $9.95.) In 1977 Cathy Hinds suffered a miscarriage and her family and neighbors became chronically ill, yet authorities dallied when pressed to clean up the toxic waste dump that a health officer in East Gray, Me., said had poisoned the local water supply and was the cause of illness.

title: Networks Are Losing the Edge At the Olympics
description: LEAD: If the Summer Olympics, which are scheduled to begin Sept. 17 in Seoul, South Korea, run according to plan, sighs of relief will be heard throughout the offices and control rooms of NBC Sports. The last time NBC won the rights to carry the Games, a U. S. boycott of the 1980 Moscow competition precluded extensive coverage, costing N

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Moonstruck Starring Cher, Nicolas Cage, Vincent Gardenia, Olympia Dukakis, Danny Aiello, Julie Bovasso, John Mahoney, Louis Guss. Directed by Norman Jewison. 1987. MGM/UA Entertainment. 101 minutes. $89.95. Rated PG. Contains a brief bedroom scene, minimal rude language.

title: The Crayon Was Mightier Than the Sword
description: ART FOR THE MASSES A Radical Magazine and Its Graphics, 1911-1917. By Rebecca Zurier. Illustrated. 216 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. $29.95.

title: Correction
description: A chart accompanying an article last week on the greenhouse effect provided an incorrect scale for the production of carbon dioxide from various fuels. The figures represented pounds of carbon dioxide produced per thousand B. T. U.'s

title: Claramount Captures Boojum
description: Claramount, who began his career in Mexico and was running in California claiming races until someone noticed this spring that he was a New York-bred, won his third stakes race of the summer when he scored a 2 3/4-length victory over Quick Call and High Brite in the $114,000 Boojum Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: THE WORLD: A Sampling of Editorial Opinion; How the World Sees the Bush-Dukakis Race
description: JAPAN

title: NEW CONTENDERS SITTING IN THE WINGS
description: The mark of the National Football League's 69th season, which kicks off this afternoon, is that last year's surprise teams will not be surprises anymore.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: AN EYE FOR AN EYE. By Gerald Seymour. (Morrow, $18.95.) Set amid the violence of the Middle East, ''An Eye for an Eye'' is a timely thriller of terrorism and reprisal. When a British ambassador is assassinated, two men become uneasy comrades on a British-sponsored mission of retribution. One is Peter Holt, a smug young diplomat who deplores killing; the other is Noah Crane, a legendary marksman and manhunter for whom killing is a way of life.

title: Question Of the Week How Will The Giants And Jets Do in '88?
description: The Giants are much like the Mets. They can control their destiny. The only team that can beat the Giants is the Giants (and maybe Washington). I see no other N.F.C. teams getting in the way of the Giants' path back to the Super Bowl.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Airline Service Is Expanding In Hawaii

title:
MUSIC;
Chorale Asks: Where Are All the Men?
description: LEAD: THE Bergen Chorale, now in its second year under the direction of John Bullough, will open its 1988-89 season with auditions and rehearsals beginning this week. The 50-voice amateur chorus will present three major performances this season, opening Dec. 11 with Haydn's ''St. Nicholas Mass'' and seasonal music, in collaboration with the Leonia Chamber Musicians as part of their Second Sunday

title: Police Official Seized As Hostage in Missouri
description: A St. Louis police official was taken hostage today by a former police officer facing a prison term for his part in a pension fund scandal, the police said.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Danvers, Mass.;
An Office Park Keeps Growing
description: LEAD: CHERRY HILL Office Park has just added a 40,000-square-foot office building with health club and cafeteria, and recently filled half of a 33,000-square-foot office and industrial building, to bring to 11 the number of buildings on the park's 225-acre site.

title: Around the World on a Couch
description: LEAD: RETHINKING PSYCHIATRY From Cultural Category to Personal Experience. By Arthur Kleinman. 237 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25.

title: Storms in Mexico Kill 3 and Thousands Flee
description: Heavy rains from two tropical storms caused flash floods and deadly mud slides near coastal regions today, forcing more than 50,000 residents to flee their homes and killing at least three people, officials said.

title: Not on Board
description: The Seattle Seahawk linebacker Fredd Young, absent from virtually all of training camp because he was unhappy with his contract, missed the team's flight from Seattle to Denver yesterday, a club spokesman said. The Seahawks and the Broncos play their National Football League season opener in Denver today.

title: Wantagh Zoning Debated
description: LEAD: LAST fall, the Wantagh Woods Neighborhood Association claimed a small victory when the Town of Hempstead approved a new zoning law that requires larger plots of land for building in the area.

title: Republicans Haven't Put Fetus Before the Mother
description: To the Editor:

title: Was That a Greenhouse Effect? It Depends on Your Theory
description: THE memorably uncomfortable summer of 1988 has left many Americans with a suspicion that nature is at last getting even for mankind's wanton pollution of the atmosphere.

title: Smoothing Over the Jackson-Koch Rift
description: HE stood in the office of a man with whom he has battled - Governor Cuomo -surrounded by men with whom he may battle - Representative Charles B. Rangel and Manhattan Borough President David N. Dinkins - to try to get on speaking terms with the man against whom, last April, he waged one of the most ill-advised battles of his political career - the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: Dr. Janice Perlman Weds F. C. Spreyer
description: The marriage of Dr. Janice Elaine Perlman of New York and Frederick Charles Spreyer of Washington took place in New York yesterday. The Rev. David Ramage, the president of the McCormick Theological Seminary in Chicago and a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

title: Florida County to Vote on Child Welfare Plan
description: Dade County voters will decide Tuesday whether to create an independent authority with its own taxing power to coordinate welfare programs for children.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Deer Park Eyesore's Fate in the Balance
description: LEAD: ITS walls scrawled with graffiti, its floors littered with debris and fallen plaster and its roofs gone except for patches of slate tile that still cling to a network of twisted girders, the former Edgewood State Hospital complex in Deer Park awaits demolition.

title: Eastern Gains Ground in Drive to Lay Off Workers
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that Eastern Airlines may begin dismissing 4,000 workers as soon as the troubled air carrier posts $4.7 million in collateral to assure that laid off employees are compensated in the event the union wins on further appeal.

title: Craftsmen Let There Be Lights for the Purist
description: LEAD: MODERN ways are not always better than the old ways. At least not for five craftsmen around the state who still make light fixtures by hand, the way it was done centuries ago.

title: 'Paris Trout'
description: To the Editor:

title: Cablevision Attains Dominant L.I. Role
description: DONALD REISS of Brightwaters is not sure that he is worth the record price of $2,750 that the Cablevision Systems Corporation will soon be ''paying'' for him.

title: A Brilliant Tactician
description: GARY Kasparov knows what's good for him when he takes his turn with the black pieces - semi-open games. The games not only provide the best situations for a brilliant tactical imagination like Kasparov's, but they demand it. Especially in the set of positions where kings are castled on opposite sides of the board, routine play is fatally slow.

title: Safe Sex on Screen?
description: To the Editor:

title: Illegally Parked Cars Receive a Mark of Shame
description: Using Day-Glo stickers to deter motorists from blocking street-cleaning operations has been so successful that the New York City Department of Sanitation is expanding the 1987 experiment citywide.

title: Up in Arms Over Yanks, Their Owner, and Their Attitude; Steinbrenner Should Bow Out
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Men's Club Is Subject Of California Inquiry
description: The State of California said Friday that it was investigating the all-male Bohemian Club, whose members include President Reagan, for possible sex discrimination.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Elusive Lakefront In Maine

title: Children's Books: Two Paths Taken
description: EVEN as many well-known book-publishing firms grow ever larger, as they acquire smaller houses or merge with other companies, there remains a role for the independent publisher. Two such publishers that have based their operations in Westchester illustrate the different paths that can lead to success in the field of children's books.

title: Sarah MacLeod Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Walker MacLeod of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Walker MacLeod to Richard Stephen Petersen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lawrence Petersen of Easton, Conn.

title: Women Writers: Coming of Age at 50
description: Time and trouble will tame an advanced young woman, but an advanced old woman is uncontrollable by any earthly force. - Dorothy L. Sayers

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
We Have Met the Summer People, and They Are Us
description: LEAD: A QUARTER of a century ago, when I started spending summer weekends in the Hamptons, the local newspaper always ran what I called a ''sigh-of-relief'' editorial the week after Labor Day.

title: Norman J. Pine 2d Wed to Sharon Greelish
description: Sharon Tracy Greelish and Norman James Pine 2d, May graduates of the Dickinson School of Law in Carlisle, Pa., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J. Msgr. Kenneth E. Lasch performed the ceremony.

title: New Homeless Issue Confronts County
description: LEAD: COUNTY officials, facing a loss of $9 million in Federal aid, are hoping for a further postponement of a Federal regulation on reimbursement of homeless costs that is to take effect Oct. 1.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Rural Past Is Present
description: LEAD: Unlike most people involved in agricultural pursuits, Jim Seaboldt is not hoping for rain. ''I want five days of dry weather,'' said Mr. Seaboldt, a Granite Springs resident. ''But I'll take three.''

title: Afghanistan Will Be Free, Perhaps Like Lebanon
description: BUZKASHI, or goat grabbing, is Afghanistan's national sport. A vicious game created by nomadic tribesmen, it is a bloody free-for-all in which a mass of horsemen fight over the carcass of a goat.

title: The CBS Studio
description: To the Editor:

title: The Drive-In, at Twilight
description: When the moon begins to turn orange you realize that summer doesn't last as long as it used to. The pleasures of summer, which stretched on so deliciously when you were young, no longer seem to last forever, and one of the greatest of all summer pleasures, the drive-in movie, is fading away. Even in summer places, out on Long Island and on Cape Cod, the high price of real estate and the advent of multiplex theaters are making the drive-ins uneconomical dinosaurs.

title: The 'Charm City' Of H. L. Mencken
description: PILGRIMS coming to pay homage to the ''Attila of critics,'' H. L. Mencken, in his hometown, may find, as the sage of Baltimore himself did late in life, that many of charm city's old charms have vanished. But there are still a few fragments of that old port on ''the immense protein factory,'' as Mencken called the Chesapeake Bay, to be savored. The scourge of Rotarians and revivalists, chiropractors and Congressmen, God and golfers, Mencken continues to attract and fascinate a new audience more than three decades after his death and half a century since he wrote the etymological milestone ''The American Language.''

title: 4,2>Noise Ban Angers Ice Cream Vendors
description: The unmistakable melody made by the chimes of Mister Softee ice cream trucks will no longer be heard along city streets here after 9:30 P.M.

title: Mortgage Muddle
description: There is a relatively new practice in banking that is startling millions of consumers -the selling of the right to service a home mortgage. Unless Congress establishes minimum standards for the practice, many Americans could be in for a nasty shock.

title: Fire Depts. Sounding Alarm for Volunteers
description: ONCE they relied on word of mouth. But faced with a constant shortage of volunteers, some fire departments are enlisting the help of public relation specialists to attract applicants.

title: Dolls: From Huggable to Profitable
description: LEAD: NINE years ago, a terrible rainstorm whipped through South Jersey, flooding highways and uprooting old trees. Afterward, a Cherry Hill couple went outside to inspect the damage. Their massive oak lay on its side. As they looked closer, they saw a china doll's head caught in the tangle of unearthed roots.

title: INSIDE
description: Satellite in Wrong Orbit

title: Moving and Shaking the Tokyo Way
description: At 11:58 Thursday morning, Tokyo did not crumble and burn. But nine million people here pretended that it did.

title: Ms. Liptscher, Consultant, Married to Steven H. Kram
description: Marilyn Liptscher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Liptscher of Yonkers, and Steven H. Kram, the son of Judge Shirley Wohl Kram of Manhattan, a judge of the United States Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York and the late Bernard Kram, were married last evening at the Stanhope Hotel in New York. Rabbi Solomon Sternstein officiated.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Sports section last Sunday on a rule change in college football did not mention the number of points a defensive team can score on conversion attempts. It is 2 points.

title: DATABANK: September 4, 1988
Doctor Admits That He Sold Corpses' Parts
description: A Philadelphia doctor has pleaded no contest to charges that he sold stolen parts of human bodies to research laboratories.

title: Up in Arms Over Yanks, Their Owner, and Their Attitude; Yanks Missing Fun of Baseball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: It May Be Good But Is It Art?
description: Critics interested in new art are usually wary of relegating the efforts of someone who claims to be an artist to the status of ''not art.'' Consequently, one usually asks the question the other way around. It's art, we tacitly agree, but is it any good? We assume that answering this question will automatically take care of the other, more difficult one: It's good, but is it art?

title: Filming at School No Boon to Students
description: The Aug. 7 article ''State Seeks Bigger Role in Making of Movies'' stressed the benefits but ignored the hardships students went though at Paterson's Eastside High School during the filming of ''Lean on Me.''

title: Buildings on Drawing Boards
description: LEAD: WHILE new dormitories have recently been added at Adelphi, C. W. Post, Hofstra and the New York Institute of Technology's campus in Central Islip, new facilities are also being planned for academic and recreational use at many of Long Island's colleges.

title: Exotic Pet Market Snares Endangered Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: Letting the Record Speak
description: COLLUSION ACROSS THE JORDAN King Abdullah, the Zionist Movement, and the Partition of Palestine. By Avi Shlaim. Maps. 676 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $40. THE BIRTH OF THE PALESTINIAN REFUGEE PROBLEM, 1947-1949 By Benny Morris. Maps. 380 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $39.50.

title: Bush Discounts Rise in Jobless Rate
description: Vice President Bush said today that he did not believe the increase in the unemployment rate threatened to undermine his key campaign theme of economic prosperity.

title: Bangladesh Intensifies Appeal for Flood Aid
description: Bangladesh renewed an appeal for emergency international aid today as the official death tollpassed 500 in monsoon flooding that has made millions homeless.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. When our house was built in 1959 we had a large walk-in cedar closet built in for clothing storage. Now the smell is gone. Is the wood still a deterrent against moths, and if it isn't can the wood be treated to restore the odor and the mothproof qualities?

title: POSTING: Waterfront Contest; Greenwich Affordables
description: Nine acres of the Greenwich, Conn., waterfront assessed at $13 milllion will be the focus of a design contest for affordable housing. Despite its extraordinarily-desirable position at the intersection of Cos Cob Harbor and the Mianus River, the property is to be considered by contestants as typical of sites throughout Fairfield County.

title: Glick in the 60's
description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy Higgins Weds J. J. Hayes 3d
description: At the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Our Lady of the Rosary in Duluth, Minn., Wendy Anne Higgins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond John Higgins of Duluth and Ocean Ridge, Fla., was married yesterday to John Jay Hayes 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Hayes of Teaneck, N.J. The Very Rev. Lawrence M. O'Shea performed the ceremony.

title: SUPPORT FORMULA STYMIED IN ALBANY
description: A New York State bill that would have established formulas for judges to follow in setting child-support awards in custody and paternity cases is not expected to become law this year, partly because of strong opposition by the State Bar Association.

title: Streetscapes: The Central Park Stable; For a Police Station, Restoration of an 1870 Jewel
description: While it is one of Manhattan's great Victorian Gothic buildings, generations of neglect and decay render it nearly invisible to the thousands who pass it every day on the 86th Street transverse in Central Park. But now restoration is planned for the 22d Police Precinct stationhouse, erected in 1870 as the Central Park Stable, and the low brick-and-brownstone gem may finally emerge from its obscurity.

title: Bikes in Lobbies
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicaragua Refuses Visas to Replace U.S. Envoys
description: The Sandinista Government is refusing to grant visas for American Embassy officers to replace those expelled nine weeks ago, according to Nicaraguan and foreign diplomats.

title: Evert Watches Spotlight Shift
description: She remembered being oblivious to her surroundings, focusing on the matches, then being whisked to a retreat in Larchmont, N.Y., an hour's drive from the stately West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, where the United States Open was played in 1971. Chris Evert was the teen-age sensation then, sheltered, shy and admittedly naive.

title: Lisa Ann Bank Is Engaged To Dr. Alexander J. Covey
description: Lisa Ann Bank's engagement to Dr. Alexander Joseph Covey, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alan H. Covey of New York and Center Moriches, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arnold J. Bank of Dresher, Pa., and Margate, N.J.

title: Outdoor Sculpture To Sit On Or Climb
description: A sculpture garden where visitors touch, climb and lie down on statues worth millions of dollars attracts people who rarely visit museums.

title: Report Urges Increase in Treatment of Alcoholism
description: Predicting that there will be 3.6 pecent more problem drinkers in New York State by 1995, a new state report calls for substantial increases in all levels of alcoholism-treatment programs.

title:
GARDENING;
Tasks to Insure Healthy Spring Plants
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to gardening, fall is second only to spring in the number of tasks to be done, and, as with most anything seasonal, timeliness is important. In the fall the gardener's deadlines are determined by the threat of killing frost and freezing soil. Some tasks must be done before the frost and cold end most activities until late winter or early spring.

title: Miss Stauffer Plans to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. John E. Stauffer of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Karen Stauffer to Thomas Sawyer Murphy Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murphy of Rye, N.Y. A Nov. 19 wedding is planned.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Study Finds No Impact From Group Homes
description: LEAD: ARMED with new evidence, a Westchester agency is battling what it says is an old misconception - that group homes for the mentally disabled decrease the value of nearby residential property.

title: Mandela Called a Moderating Influence
description: A prominent South African civil rights advocate said today after a private meeting with Nelson R. Mandela that the imprisoned African National Congress leader would act as a moderating influence if he were freed.

title: POSTING: Solution for a Site; A Mission For 52d St.
description: With the East Side assemblage, said its broker, Chaim Katzap, ''something of a white elephant,'' the People's Republic of Hungary was something of a white knight. After buying nine adjacent town houses on East 52d and 53d Streets in 1985, Peter Sudarsky watched the value of his investment plummet. He had hoped to build a 31-story apartment house on the 18,000-square-foot lot. Then midblock zoning in the area was changed, and the amount of space he could build was cut in half.

title: Focus: Real Estate Boards; Taking the Offensive with City Halls
description: When a judge overturned a zoning restriction last month aimed at protecting factory tenants in New York City's garment district, the ruling marked a new sort of victory for the Real Estate Board of New York.

title: Calendar Sale for Farmers a Fraud, Suit Says
description: A nonprofit corporation that put out a calendar featuring photographs of young, single Dakota farmers and promised to use money from the calendar's sales to help financially distressed farmers squandered the profits on parties, the State Attorney General said Friday.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Freehold Rides Commercial Building Boom
description: LEAD: FREEHOLD TOWNSHIP is four years into a commercial building boom that is dotting its 39 square miles with attractive new office parks, as well as a regional shopping mall. Now, the latest sign of this Monmouth County community's growth is an emerging stock of light industrial space.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: HERETICAL EMPIRICISM. By Pier Paolo Pasolini. Edited by Louise K. Barnett. Translated by Ben Lawton and Louise K. Barnett. (Indiana University, $37.50.) Known in the United States primarily for his films and, to a lesser extent, his novels and poetry, Pier Paolo Pasolini, who died in 1975, was also a prolific critic and political journalist.

title: Toxic Shock: A 'Success Story'
description: DOCTORS began reporting an increasing number of cases in 1977. By 1980, the reported number had peaked at 890. The diagnosis: toxic shock syndrome, a sometimes fatal disease.

title: Rutgers Player Out
description: A top Rutgers University football player who was involved in an auto accident in which one person was killed will sit out the semester and will not play football this season, the university announced Friday.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''COLUMBUS'' by Peter Sammartino (I.A.M. Corporation, 160 Broadway, Suite 1107, New York 10038, $19.40 postpaid) is a most timely publication, if somewhat in advance of 1992, when festivities will be taking place around the world to commemorate the great Italian explorer.

title: Poland's Tired Dreams
description: There is neither euphoria nor despair in the Polish regime's new agreement to negotiate with its people, whom the Government has openly come to call ''the opposition.'' Eight years to the day after signing the agreement recognizing Solidarity in 1980, the independent union's leader, Lech Walesa, wearily sat down again to open talks.

title: Liquid Dancing
description: GISELLE Starring Alicia Alonso (in photo), Azari Plisetski, Mirta Pla and the National Ballet of Cuba. Choreography by Alonso after the original by Jean Coralli and Jules Perrot. Music by Adolphe Adam, performed by the National Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Manuel Duchesne Cuzan. Directed by Enrique Pineda Barnet. Produced by Raul Canosa and the Cuban Institute of the Cinematographic Arts and Industry. 1965. Video Artists International. 99 minutes. $49.95.

title: The Teacher's Nervous, Too
description: PERHAPS preschool anxiety in teachers begins as early as the calendar page of July becomes scratch paper left on the countertop with vestiges of breakfast juice and scribbling of things yet to do, or maybe its beginning dates back to unresolved conflicts of childhood school days. Whatever the origin, preschool anxiety is real and manifests its presence in many different ways.

title: Up in Arms Over Yanks, Their Owner, and Their Attitude; Yanks: Players, Not a Team
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Question Of the Week How Will The Giants And Jets Do in '88?
description: A sore subject, my Jets.

title: Quayle Is Proud, and Others Skeptical, of Job Plan
description: SENATOR DAN QUAYLE, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, has claimed bragging rights for his efforts to enact the 1983 Job Training Partnership Act, the measure that provides Federal funds to train the unemployed poor for jobs. While some supporters give Mr. Quayle credit for promoting an economical replacement for the problem-plagued Comprehensive Education and Training Act, many who have studied the program are disappointed by its results.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Auto Racing Gant Wins 2d in Row: Harry Gant won his second straight Grand National Gatorade 200 race yesterday at Darlington International Raceway in South Carolina and became the 17th different winner on the circuit in 24 races this season.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Video Pirates Roam the Airwaves
description: Scrambling of satellite transmissions to cable services has given rise to a new kind of high-tech racketeering. Increasingly, the FBI and local law-enforcement agencies are apprehending purveyors of illegal decoding devices designed to let viewers receive pay programs free.

title: Campus Radicals Count the Cost of Commitment
description: Something is touchingly wrong and terribly right about the Pope family.

title: Founders Didn't Know the Pledge of Allegiance; The Hovis Witch
description: To the Editor:

title: WORDS AND MUSIC
description: Martin Gottfried criticizes my ''so usually impeccable'' rhyming by citing the rhyme of ''liaisons'' with ''raisins'' in ''A Little Night Music.'' He misses the point. As is clearly indicated by the normal (i.e. Anglicized French) pronunciation of ''liaisons'' throughout the rest of the lyric to which he refers, it is a deliberately false rhyme, meant to express the wry contempt of the character who sings it (meant, too, to get a laugh, which it usually did). It's a useful and, I would have thought, obvious technique -Ogden Nash made a career out of it.

title: In the Fold
description: The Cincinnati Bengals' first-round draft pick, Rickey Dixon, has come to terms with the team, ending a long contract dispute, the club announced yesterday.

title: Looking Ahed to Fall's Concerts
description: WITH the concert season in its end-of-the-summer doldrums, the moment seems right to look ahead to some of the music awaiting us in the fall, remembering that the early concert subscriber not only gets better seats and lower prices, but can also avoid the sold-out signs sure to appear when such stars as James Galway, Dave Brubeck and Canadian Brass come to town. On the orchestral scene, Bridgeport, Greenwich, Hartford, Norwalk, Stamford and Waterbury, will have opening nights in October.

title: Poland
description: To the Editor: The article on Polish crystal (Travel, July 24) brought back memories of my trip to Poland in May 1987.

title: Bolt Supplier Faces Indictment on Fraud In Shuttle Equipment
description: A California supplier of bolts that were to be used in equipment aboard the space shuttle has been indicted on charges of mail fraud and making false statements to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Retiring From All But Self-Indulgence
description: ''YOU certainly are self-indulgent,'' my wife said to me. I had just informed her that I had not swept away the hundreds of messy mimosa blossoms that fall daily on our driveway and walks in July, that I did not intent to do so in the heat of this day, and that I would wait for the comparative coolness of the next morning.

title: U.S. Black Culture Plays Well in Africa
description: In the domestic air terminal here, news vendors recently peddled copies of Ebony and Essence while video monitors showed tapes of Mike Tyson boxing.

title: 'Rocket Gibraltar' Journeys From Launch to Apogee
description: LEAD: When Amos Poe first scribbled the words ''Rocket Gibraltar'' in his notebook eight years ago, the phrase didn't mean a thing. ''I just like the way it sounded,'' Mr. Poe says. ''It had a ring to it. I knew I wanted to use it in a story someday.'' But for years this tiny germ of an idea lay dormant in the young screenwriter's notes.

title: Delay and Conflict Mark Shoreham Denouement
description: This was to have been the month, had everything gone according to schedule, when Governor Cuomo's plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant would have gathered all the necessary approvals and come to fruition.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Converting Wanamaker's
description: LEAD: FOR the first time in its 78 years of existence, the historic John Wanamaker Building - built in phases between 1902 and 1910 - will soon shelter office as well as retail operations. The conversion will be acomplished in a $185 million renovation scheduled for completion in 1990.

title: Arab Envoy for Israelis Bridges Conflict in U.S.
description: Against the hard-edged rivalries of the Middle East, to be described at once as ''a happy Israeli and a proud Arab'' would seem a contradiction. But to many the phrase aptly describes Mohamed Massarwa, Israel's consul general here.

title: Hello, Hello. Who's Calling?
description: The position of the Public Advocate respecting New Jersey Bell Caller ID (''New Jersey Bell Seeks to Add New Services,'' Aug. 14) has no merit for the simple reason that once an individual has invaded the privacy of another by calling him on the telephone, he has given up any claim to anonymity.

title: Stanford Museum Shows Winners and Collectors
description: IT has been 18 years since the Stamford Museum and Nature Center inaugurated its annual competition for Connecticut artists, the winners of which get to show their work as well as receive small cash prizes. This year's competition is an all-woman event. The director of the Mattatuck Museum, Ann Smith, was the judge, and her choices are Shirley Kraus, Susan McCaslin, Deborah Cooper Sidlin and Shaw Stuart. Their work can be seen at the museum under the title ''Four Winners.''

title: Tufts University Receives Grant To Build Foreign Language Center
description: Tufts University has received a $5.57 million grant to build a center for the study of foreign language and culture on the main campus in Medford, 10 miles north of here.

title: Q and A
description: Passed Over for Repairs Question: My prewar co-op building replaced a lot of iron plumbing in 1982 because of rusty pipes and reduced water flow in some apartments. The pipes leading to my bathroom fixtures were not replaced because my problem was not too bad then and the co-op reserve fund was limited. At the time, the co-op paid for all interior repair work except for repainting the walls that had been opened. Now I have minimal water flow in my bathroom and the building has a substantial reserve fund. Am I correct in believing that the co-op must replace the pipes and pay to replace the wall and tile, even if my bathroom will need more extensive work than the other apartments did? . . . . J. Z., Manhattan Answer: Not necessarily. According to Marc Luxemburg, an attorney who is president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, the typical proprietary lease provides that the co-op is responsible for maintaining common facilities including pipes within walls. But when it comes to interior work - including walls and fixtures dismantled during a repair job - what a co-op will replace varies widely.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: LORRAINE M. ARONSON;
'School Districts are Employers'
description: LEAD: LORRAINE M. ARONSON, one of two Deputy Commissioners of the State Department of Education, is responsible for curriculum and staff development, including overseeing a new law that requires minimum competency testing for new teachers.

title: First Boston's Lesson for the Street
description: AT the First Boston Corporation, the relationship with the people in London was getting rocky. The question became: Do we get married or break up?

title: Catherine B. Cox Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Catherine Baum Cox, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Cox of Newport News, Va., to Daniel Jacob Blumenthal, a son of Mrs. Albert H. Blumenthal of Phoenix and the late Mr. Blumenthal, took place yesterday at Alder Manor in Yonkers. The Rev. Robert Harvey, a Baptist minister, and Rabbi Charles Davidson officiated.

title: For Latinos, Immediate Object Is City Council Membership
description: LEAD: DOLORES CRUZ GOMEZ ran a tough campaign in 1983 for a seat on the City Council of Watsonville, a farm community of 28,000 about 80 miles south of here. Like other Hispanic candidates before her, however, she lost the citywide race by a wide margin even though she had the backing of the town's Latino residents, who make up 49 percent of the population.

title: Older Workers: Needed but Not Wanted
description: AFTER being out of the workplace for a few years, she decided to return to part-time work. Why? Probably for the same reasons that many of us work in the first place - to earn money, to meet new people, to develop new interests, to add another dimension of interest to conversations and to use one's skills. What might be surprising, though, is that she had been retired for almost four years and is 66 years old.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. When our house was built in 1959 we had a large walk-in cedar closet built in for clothing storage. Now the smell is gone. Is the wood still a deterrent against moths, and if it isn't can the wood be treated to restore the odor and the mothproof qualities?

title: Time to Relax and Enjoy the Season
description: Time off for the three-day weekend. Books to Read

title: Ireland
description: To the Editor: Christine S. Cozzen's article on Ireland's Achill Island (Travel, June 26) brought to mind two wonderful summer vacations I spent in the village of Curraun on the mainland just across Achill Sound. At the time, Curraun had a rudimentary telephone system. The local operator's intervention was needed to make any call, local or long distance, from our simple black box of a telephone. The operator, a friendly woman who lived down the road, was happy to take messages when we weren't at home.

title: Hot Line on AIDS Is Aimed at the Teen-Ager
description: Teen-agers afraid to ask parents or teachers specific questions about AIDS now have a toll-free alternative, a hot line based here that is run by their peers.

title: A School for Pedal Pushers
description: KNEES flexed, weight slung back, we neophytes poised at the top of the beginners' hill at Mount Snow, Vt., and prepared for our first descent. From the bottom, the slope had looked like a gentle rise. Now from above, it was a different matter entirely. This wasn't a downhill. This was a crater. Waved down by the instructor, we pushed off one by one and soon were fishtailing through the thick grass and rocks, squeezing the bike's hand brakes for dear life.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: South Burlington, Vt.;
Farmland or Development?
description: LEAD: FOR more than 40 years, Homer Du Bois has been farming a ridge of land overlooking the Champlain Valley and the Green Mountains. Now that he is approaching retirement, he wants to get the most value from his land. Instead of hay, 50 houses recently sprouted on part of the field.

title:
DINING OUT;
Quality Seafood in Beach Haven
description: LEAD: SHORE restaurants tend to be predictable. Most are fairly casual and serve large portions of fresh seafood prepared in an unadventurous manner. But Charles' Seafood Garden in Beach Haven is different.

title: 'Libra' and History
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
Choice Dual-Purpose Plants Bear Tasty Fruits
description: LEAD: WHAT could be more rewarding to a gardener than picking and eating fruit from a plant that is also grown for its beauty? Many trees and shrubs earn their keep year round with leaves that blush in fall or branches and bark patterns that liven the winter landscape.

title:
INVESTING;
Taking a Chance on Chemical Stocks
description: LEAD: THE chemical industry has been enjoying record profits because of its strong operations. Yet the chemical stocks have been stuck in a broad trough. At the Dow Chemical Company, for instance, net income is at an all-time high, double last year's showing for the first half, but Dow's shares have been trading around $84, about the same price as in early 1987.

title: At 68, Brooklyn Woman Triumphs Over Illiteracy
description: For most of her life, Odessa Overby has longed to read, write and perhaps tell others about her memories of growing up in the South and caring for a motherless family from the age of 7.

title: Gooden Masters Dodgers
description: The Mets kept blitzing the National League with relentless pitching yesterday. And this time it was Dwight Gooden who did the blitzing as he outpitched John Tudor before 43,896 fans in Shea Stadium and subdued the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2-1.

title: Nirvana Deluxe In Lotus Land
description: THE NAME AND ADDRESS YIELD a delightful polyglot: Hsi Lai Buddhist Temple, Hacienda Heights, Calif. The ''west-coming'' temple, now being constructed by the Fo Kuang Shan Buddhist society, based in Taiwan, consists of 10 buildings on 15 acres in a suburban community 20 miles east of Los Angeles. The complex, which includes shrines, a monastery and a Buddhist museum, constitutes the largest Buddhist temple in North America. It is scheduled to open in mid-November as the site of the 16th General Conference of the World Fellowship of Buddhists, the first such international gathering to be held in the West. Currently, according to the Rev. Shih Yung Kai, two buildings -the Buddhist Scripture Library and Meditation Hall and the Memorial Pagoda, ''used for the remembrance of past relatives'' - remain unfinished.

title: Season to Season, Day to Day
description: ZONE JOURNALS By Charles Wright. 101 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95. THE SQUANICOOK ECLOGUES By Melissa Green. 78 pp. New York: W. W. Norton. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: VOICES AT THE LATE HOUR. By Bo Carpelan. Translated by Irma Margareta Martin. (University of Georgia Press, Cloth, $20; Paper, $9.95.) In the lengthy introduction to ''Voices at the Late Hour,'' we are told that Bo Carpelan belongs to a Swedish-speaking minority within Finland whose literature is based on ''the lyric.

title: Space Shields and Solar Satellites Won't Fly
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
Tasks to Insure Healthy Spring Plants
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to gardening, fall is second only to spring in the number of tasks to be done, and, as with most anything seasonal, timeliness is important. In the fall the gardener's deadlines are determined by the threat of killing frost and freezing soil. Some tasks must be done before the frost and cold end most activities until late winter or early spring.

title: America Was Not His Medium
description: GEORGE GROSZ A Biography. By M. Kay Flavell. Illustrated. 355 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $39.95.

title: Takeovers Are 'Icing on the Cake'
description: EVERY investor would like to spot takeover candidates before the rumors start and the bids are made. One investment service, the Winning Investor System, boasts of finding 26 such stocks this year. But the service, provided by Desktop Broker Inc., of San Francisco, is not looking for speculative investments. It seeks undervalued companies for long-term investments. ''The icing on the cake is the takeovers,'' said C. D. Anderson, president of Desktop. ''We're not saying we can spot takeovers. But it just happens that the attributes we look for are the ones that many suitors look for in a takeover.''

title: Miss Pearson Has Wedding
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Stockbridge, Mass., Adelaide Douglas Pearson, the daughter of Lawrence Pearson of Easton, Conn., and Margaret Parsons Hallett of Hampton, Conn., was married yesterday to Gregory Ted Hulbert, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Ted Hulbert of Rockaway, Ore. The bridegroom's father, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: WHO OWNS THE LAND?
description: LEAD: WE CROSS THE BOUNDARY OF THE White Earth Indian Reservation from the east, the same direction from which disparate bands of Mississippi, Pembina, Pillager, Lake Winnibigoshish and Lake Superior Chippewa arrived in the mid-19th century, pushed to this far edge of Minnesota by the crush of European settlement.

title: Catching Up With NBC
description: Last year NBC had the highest ratings of the three major television networks. This year it begins the fall season with some very strong programming, including the summer Olympics and following with the World Series and the Superbowl. NBC has already sold 98 percent of the advertising time it has available for the Olympics. Can the other networks catch NBC? Paul Schulman President, the Paul Schulman Company, a subsidiary of Advanswers Media Programming Inc.

title: September Song at the Shore
description: LABOR DAY for us natives of the Jersey Shore means a time of serene melancholy. Again, it's the end of something in our lives. Linda Loman has it right when she tells her husband, Willy, ''Life is a casting off.'' We know we are casting off another season, another passage in our lives.

title: THE REGION: For Administrators; Learning the Slow Ways of Albany
description: IT would be difficult to find an issue that attracted more notice during this year's legislative session than New York City's troubled public schools.

title: Merger Focuses Attention On Law Firms
description: LEAD: THE recent merger of two prominent New Jersey law firms is indicative of the heightened competition resulting from the state's economic boom and the increasingly complex legal environment.

title: Tara Purohit and John Wojak Jr., Lawyers, Wed
description: Tara Purohit, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Surendra Nath Purohit of Port Washington, L.I., was married yesterday to John Stanley Wojak Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wojak of Manhasset Hills, L.I. The Rev. David P. Osborn, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Harrison Conference Center in Glen Cove, L.I.

title: Eloise Lipscomb To Marry Oct. 1
description: Mr. and Mrs. John D. Lipscomb of St. Louis have announced the engagement of Mr. Lipscomb's daughter, Eloise Cella Lipscomb, to Kent Kirby Reynolds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark F. Reynolds of Kinderhook, N.Y. The couple plan to marry Oct. 1.

title: Quick Detection of Cancer in Harlem Sought
description: A Harlem food cooperative has begun offering its members free cancer screening and diet information in an attempt to detect and ultimately prevent the disease, which strikes the community more often and causes more deaths than in any other area of the city.

title: U.S. Studying Cairo Links to Smuggling Plot
description: An investigation into possible links between the Egyptian Defense Minister and a reported plot to smuggle missile components to Egypt centers on references to ''the minister'' in wiretapped conversations, Justice and State Department officials say.

title: Turkey Offers Temporary Haven to Top Iraqi Kurd
description: With Iraq locked in a major offensive against dissident Kurds, Turkey has made a conditional offer of sanctuary to one of the rebel leaders, officials and newspapers here reported today.

title: Regan Questions Cost-Effectiveness of Youth Jails
description: New York State spends almost twice as much as five other major states on its residential youth detention centers, but its rate of recidivism is not much lower, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan reported this week.

title: Professor Wages War on 'Doublespeak'
description: LEAD: AN associate professor of English at Rutgers-Camden has emerged as an eloquent spokesman in a nationwide crusade against ''doublespeak'' - a term for confusing or deceptive language.

title: Trees Fall So That Houses May Rise, All in the Name of Progress
description: I first heard about the development from a local priest who called to be sure I would not oppose it. ''Low-income housing for the elderly,'' he said. ''Of course,'' I replied. ''It's a lovely site. What a good idea.'' Several years went by.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Sports section last Sunday on a Costa Rican swimmer misspelled her given name. Her name is Silvia Poll.

title: Reading My Way To Success
description: SHE parked illegally, 10 feet before the stop sign, left the keys in the ignition and ran up the sidewalk to the heavy church doors and pushed them open. The young woman dashed quickly down the stairs to the basement, where the cooperative nursery school held classes.

SHOPPER'S WORLD;
Handcrafted Wares In Nogales, Mexico

title: SECOND THOUGHTS ON ''LAST TEMPTATION'
description: To the Editor:

title: Behavior, Not Cocaine, Is the Problem
description: If I might take the liberty of paraphrasing Shakespeare's Marc Antony: I come not to praise Lawrence Taylor, but neither do I come to bury him. I do wish, however, that he would lend me his ear. In fact, I wish he would come visit me in Miami. I'd like to take him on a trip down Memory Lane.

title: Smaller Teeth, Smaller Troubles
description: Look in a mirror. Say ''cheese.'' What do you see? You see teeth, most of which are probably real and none of which could be called humongous. But they would have been if sometime around the end of the ice age somebody hadn't figured out that the wisest way to eat a flash-frozen mammoth was to thaw it over a fire.

title: Seeing the World Take Shape in Black and White
description: THANKS to two entrepreneurial health-care professionals, more parents are now discovering what vision researchers and infant care workers have known for years: that babies easily see and therefore enjoy the high contrast of black-and-white items.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: JEWISH ARTS FESTIVAL You don't have to be Jewish to attend the Jewish Arts Festival, but it couldn't hurt.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: An Old Ice Warehouse Is Sculpted Into a Museum

title:
RECORDINGS;
Die-Hard Viennese Romantics Rise Again
description: LEAD: So fascinated have we become by the rush of progress in the arts and sciences of early 20th-century Vienna that we tend to forget what a stronghold of conservatism the city was. Arnold Schoenberg and his followers, for instance, were perceived as a serious threat to a culture obsessed with its musical traditions.

title: Something Solid And Beautiful
description: I WAS ONCE DISTURBED by my hunger for working with wood because it stole time from writing, the craft with which I have earned my living for nearly 40 years. Give me the choice between striving to corral thoughts into an essay or building a cabinet, and I will usually head for jointer plane and saw, pushing my writing deadlines to the limit.

title: Wendy Lee Becomes Bride Of Dr. Jonathan E. Alpert
description: Wendy Lee, a daughter of S. Edward Lee of Baldwin, L.I., and the late Mrs. Lee, was married at the George Washington Manor in Roslyn, L.I., yesterday to Dr. Jonathan Edward Alpert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Alpert of Great Neck, L.I. Charles Agin, a justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Redskins Aim to Repeat
description: During the off season, a free-agent linebacker is signed for $6 million, setting off a string of bruised egos and stinging criticism in the locker room during minicamp. The starting quarterback has surgery on his left knee for the fifth time, increasing speculation on whether he is sturdy enough to complete an entire season.

title: Soviet History Books To Fill 'Blank Spots' For the High Schools
description: Soviet high school students will be given supplements to their history books by the start of next year to fill in ''blank spots'' in their knowledge of the country's past, a senior education official said today.

title: In Rhode Island, a Trial In Faith Is Discarded
description: The Genesis Community was an experimental parish where lay Roman Catholics from across the state could play more of a decision-making role than would be possible in traditional parishes.

title: As Summer Wanes, City Picnickers Bloom
description: WITH the Labor Day weekend upon us, it's hardly surprising that New York City has been abloom lately with picnickers. These appear in abundance late every summer and are easily identified. For one thing, they tend to take root in the lushest green parts of parks, often in the shade of large trees. For another, they are rarely seen noshing anything mundane. Peanut butter sandwiches are O.K. for Jones Beach, where sand gets in them anyway, but not for places like Central Park. There, sesame chicken is eaten with chopsticks, champagne is sipped from long-stemmed flutes and candelabra illuminate an alfresco repast. In moments of giddiness, city picnickers have also been known to bring along their own balloons, streamers and party games. Such signs of rampant lightheartedness are typical of this species -unless it rains; then, the picnic simply moves indoors.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. When our house was built in 1959 we had a large walk-in cedar closet built in for clothing storage. Now the smell is gone. Is the wood still a deterrent against moths, and if it isn't can the wood be treated to restore the odor and the mothproof qualities?

title: Aussies Deliver More Upsets
description: At Wimbledon, it is called the Queen's Plate, the tournament for first-round losers in the women's draw. Given what has happened in the first week at Flushing Meadows, the United States Open should give some serious consideration to implementing its own consolation event, perhaps calling it the Achilles' Heel. The men's draw would be especially impressive this year.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE CATHAY STORIES AND OTHER FICTIONS. By MacDonald Harris. (Story Line Press, 325 Ocean View Avenue, Santa Cruz, Calif. 95062, Cloth, $16; Paper, $9.) Those who are drawn to madness, MacDonald Harris would be the first to inform us, make the finest writers. And in this exquisitely wrought collection of oddities, Mr.

title: Seoul Shoes
description: To the Editor: The article ''What's Doing in Seoul'' (Travel, July 24) states that Reebok shoes are available in the Itaewon shopping district in Seoul for $15. This is, unfortunately, a perfect example of the old adage that something that appears to be too good a bargain generally is. All shoes that are available in Itaewon at this price are counterfeit. Only those shoes available at the three authorized Reebok distributor locations, which are clearly identified, are genuine. The shoes sold at these locations, however, are available for prices comparable to those that would be paid for Reebok shoes in the United States.

title: Army's Hold in Guatemala Stirs Fear for Democracy
description: Two and a half years after Guatemalans elected a civilian President in an effort to end decades of military dominance, progress toward democracy is slow, and frustration is increasing. Although trade unionists and other protesters have greater freedom to organize than they did in the past, men in uniform still exercise ultimate political authority.

title: Doctor Knows Best
description: To the Editor:

title: David Sommers Weds Heidi Hild

title: Beach Crisis Brings A Rise in Donations
description: LAST summer, algae depleted oxygen in Long Island Sound. Fish and lobster were killed, and black muck covered much of the bottom. This year, many beaches have had to be closed when sewage and other debris washed up.

title: Allan Kozinn Is Married to Johanna Beale Keller

Kozinn of Yonkers. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. H. Scott Matheney, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Caramoor estate in Katonah, N.Y.

description: LEAD: WHILE boaters are out this Labor Day weekend, at the end of a recreational season that has been mired by pollution, legislative efforts are under way to make them assume more responsibility for keeping Westchester's waterways clean.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Prices just cannot continue at these levels. They just went totally crazy, and it's finally catching up.'' - Michael Sumichrast, a Washington-based economist, on the drop in new-home sales.

title: Departing Director Reflects on her Decade at the Neuberger
description: LEAD: AFTER 10 years as director of the Neuberger Museum at the State University of New York at Purchase, Suzanne Delehanty is leaving at the end of this year to head the Contemporary Arts Museum in Houston. It is a decision that seems to have come as a surprise even to Ms. Delehanty.

title: Delay in Fuel Aid Program
description: The state's fuel assistance program that helps poor families heat their homes will start a month later this year and end a month earlier because of a lack of funds. The program will begin on Nov. 1, instead of Oct. 1, and will distribute money through March instead of April, Susan Merrow-Kehoe, the program director, said. Allotments for the 140,000 Massachusetts families expected to receive grants under the 13-year-old program will also be cut, she said Friday.

title: 'Summer '88' At Sound Shore Features 50 Visions
description: WESTCHESTER has its share of storefront galleries but as in most suburban-cum-rural areas the ones that are privately owned usually augment their incomes by making frames or selling crafts objects. Not so Mary Luxenberg's Sound Shore Gallery here.

title: Jennifer Teplitzky Engaged to Wed James Lichtman
