title: Aiding Parents After Abortion
description: LEAD: IN a conference room at the Child Development and Learning Center at Schneider Children's Hospital in New Hyde Park, a pale young woman shook with emotion as she recalled there was no reason to suspect that anything would go wrong with her first pregnancy.

title: Truth Eludes Fact and Fiction
description: One reason why the feature-length documentary has lately been in decline is that the fiction feature has subsumed its role. We're as apt to get our facts from lightly embroidered versions of real events as from the events themselves. The television movie, which can proudly base itself on a true story and then touch up the story to suit the audience's taste, has paved the way for this development, but television drama in itself is rarely alarming. It doesn't much matter whether a biography of Barbara Hutton starring Farrah Fawcett gets its facts straight - but when the subject is something like white supremacist groups and their murderous activities, that's another story.

title: Seikaly Close to Deal
description: Rony Seikaly, the former Syracuse star who was the first-round pick of the expansion Miami Heat in the National Basketball Association draft, is about to sign a contract worth nearly $4 million over five years, The Miami Herald reported yesterday.

title: DUKAKIS INVOKES PATRIOTIC THEME
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis went to Ellis Island yesterday, retold the immigrant saga of his parents, and staked his claim to the traditional values of flag and country that Vice President Bush has embraced so effectively in recent weeks.

title: Headliners; Back in the U.S.S.R.?
description: The telegram didn't say all was forgiven, but Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn has, in effect, been invited back home - at least for a visit. The Russian writer, who was expelled in 1974 as an enemy of the people and now resides in Vermont, was invited last week to join a Soviet committee supervising the building of a memorial honoring the victims of Stalin-era repression. Aleksandr D. Vaisberg, the chairman of the committee organizing the monument project, said in Moscow that the invitation did not reflect any official change in the Kremlin's attitude toward Mr. Solzhenitsyn, but was based on a public opinion poll. If Mr. Solzhenitsyn accepts - he has made no comment yet - it would present the Russians with an interesting choice. Could he be welcomed, in effect, by the people but rejected by the Government? Stay tuned.

title:
GARDENING;
Tasks to Insure Healthy Spring Plants
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to gardening, fall is second only to spring in the number of tasks to be done, and, as with most anything seasonal, timeliness is important. In the fall the gardener's deadlines are determined by the threat of killing frost and freezing soil. Some tasks must be done before the frost and cold end most activities until late winter or early spring.

title: 3 Palestinians Die in Combat In a Beirut Refugee District
description: Rival Palestinian factions fought with mortars and rocket-propelled grenades in a refugee district on the southern outskirts of Beirut today, and the police reported that three people had been killed and nine wounded.

description: THE children who will enter New York City's public schools as first graders this fall will become the Class of 2000 - that is, those who remain in school that long. If current trends continue, fewer than half will graduate on time; a little under a quarter of them will never graduate.

title: Sports of The Times; Taylor Must Say No to Booze, Too

But early in this year's training camp, the National Football League's most dominating defensive player talked about how he was 'taking everything more seriously.'' Parcells was delighted.

title: Exchange Program Features Services

But Gustavo Fares, a young lawyer from Argentina, says the Suffolk County court system and the Nassau-Suffolk Law Services in Bay Shore, both of which he has recently observed, are ''excellent models'' of responsiveness and flexibility. His experiences in Suffolk this summer will serve him well in Argentina, he said, where Napoleonic and Roman codes form the basis for law and legal services.

title: Museum's Artifacts: Funeral Styles as History
description: Old embalming tools, a 1917 Ford Model T hearse, intricately braided wreaths of human hair and a 1,500-pound glass coffin - these are some of the memorabilia in Fred Hunter's funeral museum.

title: Living the Sweet Life after Fortune Has Smiled
description: IT is called playing a dream.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ALMOST LIKE BEING HERE. By Tom Leopold. (Dutton, $15.95.) It's not a good week for Sandy Bayard, the narrator of Tom Leopold's occasionally diverting first novel. His shrink is getting senile, there's no hot water in his Manhattan apartment and his ex-girlfriend has just killed herself, apparently because of something he did. The play he was in has folded, and now a succession of women keep distracting him while he's trying to have an existential crisis. Sandy's solution is to get drunk and stoned immediately - yet still keep his grip on the old sense of humor. Using this basic scenario, Mr. Leopold has produced a work reminiscent of Jay McInerney's popular novel ''Bright Lights, Big City,'' which portrayed hip, urban youth adrift in the mid-1980's. Mr. Leopold can write entertainingly, and he keeps his narrative moving at a good pace toward an unexpected conclusion as Sandy gravitates between New York and Boston, moving from woman to woman, seeking to acquit himself of blame for his former girlfriend's death. Nonetheless, the reader is tempted to tell Mr. Leopold to relax and not try so hard to be funny or insightful. Another problem is the patronizing tone the book occasionally takes toward women: Sandy, for example, apparently doesn't have his tongue in his cheek when he refers to his current flame as ''a good girl.'' Mr. Leopold, who has written material for a number of well-known comedians, has got thumbs-up dust-jacket quotes from Chevy Chase, Steve Allen and Paul Shaffer. Readers whose tastes are in sync with this crowd may well agree.

title: John David Tulchin Weds Miss Temnick in California
description: Linda Lee Temnick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nick Temnick of McDonald, Ohio, and John David Tulchin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Tulchin of New Rochelle, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Sheraton Hotel in Redondo Beach, Calif. title: THROUGH THE LOOKING GLASS OF MOVIES AND TELEVISION
description: Eddie Murphy has a cuter figure than I do. I know this because I stood in front of a smoky mirror in the new American Museum of the Moving Image in the Astoria section of Queens, pressed a computer button and saw my face reflected over the jeans, T-shirt and jacket Axel Foley wears in ''Beverly Hills Cop.'' I looked terrific.

title: Janet Granger Is Bride of Thomas Sacci
description: Janet Susan Granger, the daughter of Susan S. Granger of Westport, Conn., and the late Dr. Donald P. Granger, was married at her mother's home yesterday to Thomas Edward Sacci, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John B. Sacci of Bedford Hills, N.Y. The Rev. Peter Maffly-Kipp, a Unitarian minister, performed the ecumenical ceremony.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
What Happened to Art Nouveau
description: LEAD: To attempt to produce an encyclopedia of an international movement affecting all the decorative arts between the two world wars in a mere 192 pages (including more than 350 illustrations and an extensive bibliography) is an act of courage. Fortunately, Alastair Duncan, consultant on 19th- and 20th-century decorative arts at Christie's and editor of THE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF ART DECO (Dutton, $29.95), has the breadth of knowledge to highlight the most important innovations while providing a historical perspective that traces their origins.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: KEEPERS OF THE KEYS. John XXIII, Paul VI and John Paul II: Three Who Changed the Church. By Wilton Wynn. (Random House, $18.95.) A Time magazine correspondent at the Vatican for more than 25 years, Wilton Wynn has written a gentle apologia for the recent pontiffs, in whom he sees a common journey of faith. Unfortunately, he offers little analysis of the shifting attitudes among many Roman Catholics that create distance between them and church authorities. Still, the range of anecdotes - from Pope John XXIII's private diplomacy with the Soviets to the rehearsing of ostensibly spontaneous moments on Pope John Paul II's trips - gives these profiles a fine human texture. One wishes ''old'' were used fewer times in reference to John XXIII, but the image of a clever man bypassing the Roman Curia and opening the church to modern winds is vivid. Pope Paul VI emerges as a more compelling, if elusive, figure: a liberal intellect, obsessed with bureaucracy, whose support of liberation theology was greatly overshadowed by Humanae Vitae, his encyclical banning artificial contraception. The section on Paul's Hamlet-like agonizing over the encyclical is rather weak, and Mr. Wynn gives scant coverage to Pope John Paul I, whose brief papacy showed clear signs of reversing the ban. The author quotes eloquent writings by John Paul II about conjugal intimacy, yet fails to consider arguments of dissident theologians against the 1987 papal instruction forbidding artificial insemination. But the church is vast, and the wealth of information and character insights, especially about Curia figures, makes this an irresistible book.

title: Neiman-Marcus Minds the Store
description: PHILIP M. HAWLEY thought he was giving up some sparkling jewels last summer, when Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. spun off its specialty stores into a publicly traded company called the Neiman-Marcus Group Inc.

Our family of four ate quite inexpensively ($3 for a delicious beef stew). We stayed at the Tokyo Hilton International Hotel, and the office buildings were across the street from the hotel.

title: Correction

At a meeting Friday, the judge, Leonard B. Sand, asked city officials to agree to sign a new consent decree that would establish an independent commission to administer the housing plan. The city officials rejected the plan.

Without a trial, without evidence, he is sent to a remote prison camp. There he and thousands of others exist in harsh and humiliating conditions.

title: 3 Die, 10 Injured as Car Rams Van in Jersey
description: A van packed with holiday travelers was hit head-on by a car that ran a stop sign on a rural Atlantic County highway this morning, killing 3 people and injuring 10 others, the authorities said.

title: Diane Hall Plans To Marry Oct. 22
description: The engagement of Diane Elizabeth Hall to Henry Walter Juan 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Juan Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Bennett Hall Jr. of Greenwich, the parents of the bride-to-be.

title: OLYMPIC ATHLETE

I hope this young woman, who is strong of mind as well as body, will achieve all her goals and bring home the Gold for her country and herself. KRISTINE G. SHANNON Upper Saddle River, N.J.

description: The first of two key police witnesses for the prosecution is scheduled to take the stand Tuesday as testimony in the trial of Larry Davis enters its seventh week in the Bronx.

title: Trappings of the Political Process
description: LEAD: THE current show at the Pound Ridge Museum, ''Winners-Keepers, Losers-Weepers,'' celebrates more than 100 years of memorabilia associated with electing an American President - campaign buttons, songs, signs, stickers and assorted novelty items from an Al Smith fireplace flue stop to an Eisenhower beer can.

title: A Choice Encounter
description: IT WAS 1973 and Ansley J. Coale was fed up with academia. So he bought 2,000 acres in Ukiah, Calif., in Mendocino County. It's only two hours north of Berkeley, where he'd been teaching Greek and Roman history, but - emotionally at least - it's about as far from faculty meetings as it's possible to get.

title: The Kindness of StrangersAt an English Hospital
description: TO break an ankle is painful; to break it on an expensive holiday is disheartening; and to break it quite alone, deep in a wood, is a traveler's nightmare. When I managed on a recent trip to England to do all three on the famous battlefield at Hastings, a working vacation I had planned for a year was suddenly in ruins. But even as I tested my ankle and knew something was seriously wrong, I could appreciate a certain cachet in the situation. To have fallen on the battlefield at Hastings has a distinction, after all, that stumbling on a curb in South Kensington lacks. I planned immediately to inflict an embellished version of the experience upon friends. I even envisioned English Heritage erecting a plaque on the battlefield:

title: Prague Waits for a Thaw
description: ESTRAGON: ''I can't go on like this.''

title: This Time It's Clear: TV Has a Message for Us
description: THE announcement last week of an ambitious television campaign against drunken driving showed how the communications industry can use its considerable powers of persuasion for laudable goals. But the plan, to promote the use of ''designated drivers'' by planting favorable dialogue in television scripts, raised questions about something the advertising and entertainment industries are less comfortable with: social engineering.

title: British Sitcoms: Where Nothing Is Sacrosanct
description: Even back in the days when the British had no sense of humor, it was understood by Americans that their distant insular relatives were funny. That is to say, they were quaint, which is also funny, because quaint meant being stuffy, dense and too pompous to appreciate a joke, which meant, of course, an American joke, such as this one:

title: Stella Adler In Her Latest Role: Author
description: To Stella Adler, one word best describes Constantin Stanislavsky: ''God.''

title: A New Real-Life Spy Story Shows The Need for Preventive Security
description: SPENDING money on security procedures in the Government is a bit like preventive maintenance on a car: everyone agrees it is a good idea, but the hand seems to waver when the time comes to pay the bill.

title: After Two Near Misses, the Browns Want It All
description: The following American Conference preview was prepared and written by Gerald Eskenazi. Teams are listed in the predicted order of finish, with the Jets picked to place last in the East. EAST Miami Dolphins

title: DATA UPDATE: September 4, 1988
TIGER SLIDE CONTINUES; BREWERS WIN, 7-3
description: Joey Meyer hit a three-run home run tonight and Jeffrey Leonard added a two-run shot as the Milwaukee Brewers beat slumping Detroit, 7-3, to send the Tigers to their 10th loss in 12 games. The loss cut the Tigers' lead over the Red Sox in the American League East to a half-game. The Red Sox had a later start in Anaheim, Calif, against the Angels.

title: Back to College, as President
description: LEAD: WHEN Claire Lynn Gaudiani began her role as president of Connecticut College in New London last week. she returned to a campus she knew well. Dr. Gaudiani, a member of the class of 1966, is the first graduate to serve as president in the college's 77-year history.

title: Slower Population Growth Reported
description: LEAD: A NEW study shows that Westchester's population is continuing to grow, but county planners say the rate of increase is much slower than they had predicted.

title: WHEN LESS IS MORE
description: S FASHION DESIGNERS CONTINUE to open stores along the world's major shopping streets, a trend has begun to emerge: minimalism in retailing. These shops have a deliberately spare look, not just in their architecture, but in the small amount of merchandise on display. ''There is a direction on the part of retailers to show less but show it better,'' says the London architect David Chipperfield. Chipperfield is talking from experience. His design for the Issey Miyake shop on London's Sloane Street includes only one rack to display clothes. ''It is a far more luxurious attitude than the normal method of retailing,'' Chipperfield says. And one that is thought to boost sales. According to James Wines, a designer who heads SITE, a New York architectural company that just finished transforming an old Fifth Avenue factory building into the new WilliWear shop, the aim among retailers is to create a store identity that is as much a part of the total package as the style of the clothes themselves.

title: 20,000 Flee Fumes in East Los Angeles and 3 Suburbs
description: A cloud of chlorine gas forced the evacuation of an estimated 20,000 people from their homes before dawn today in parts of eastern Los Angeles and three suburban cities.

title: How a Museum Grew in Astoria
description: LEAD: A half-dozen years ago, a pioneer member of the board of what would become the American Museum of the Moving Image resigned, convinced that the project was doomed. The person he deserted was Rochelle Slovin, director, retired Off Off Broadway actress, holder of a master's degree in business administration, an old hand at running municipal cultural programs, a woman who could give perseverance lessons to ant colonies.

title: How Good People Got That Way
description: THE ALTRUISTIC PERSONALITY Rescuers of Jews in Nazi Europe. By Samuel P. Oliner and Pearl M. Oliner. Tables. 419 pp. New York: Free Press. $24.95.

title: Melissa Breitrose to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Mark W. Breitrose of Purchase, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Melissa Sue Breitrose, to Paul Gabriel Kotcher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Kotcher of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. Miss Breitrose, the assistant fashion editor at New York Woman magazine, and her fiance, a sales manager for Tuscan Dairy Farms in Union, N.J., both graduated from Ithaca College. They plan to marry in November.

title: Tanker Tears Its Hull Open, Spilling Oil Into Mississippi
description: A tanker scraped the bottom of the Mississippi River today, rupturing its hull and spilling about one million gallons of thick, heavy oil into the channel, Coast Guard officials said.

title: 'Free' Trade Costs
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
In Paramus, a Painter's Education
description: LEAD: ALICE SCHILLE taught for 44 years at the Columbus Art School in Ohio, and she is little known outside that city. Yet the worldly spin that she gives to the usual notion of the provincial artist may be reason enough to display 75 of her oils and watercolors at the Bergen Museum of Art and Science in

title: 'Revolutionary' Begins Life Term In 1981 Killing of State Trooper
description: An avowed revolutionary convicted of killing a highly decorated New Jersey state trooper has begun serving a life sentence for the crime.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; What Do You Expect To See in the Olympics?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: From Bond Trader to Party Caterer
description: MAUREEN HIGGINS has switched from bonds to basil butter, and she said that she made a good move.

description: Just two weeks remain before the start of the Seoul Olympics, and as the countdown continues, every day seems special in its own right.

title: Daphne Barbour To Marry Oct. 9
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Barbour of McLean, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Daphne Shires Barbour to David Leslie Moses, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Moses, also of McLean. An Oct. 9 wedding is planned.

title: SECOND THOUGHTS ON ''LAST TEMPTATION'
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Memphis; Mud Island Goes Suburban
description: AFTER 79 years as a wilderness inhabited only by tenant farmers, squatters and assorted wildlife, Mud Island, in the Mississippi River off downtown Memphis, is undergoing its first phase of private residential and commercial development.

title: As Europe Unites, Outsiders Line Up to Join the Club
description: AS the European Community pushes to form a barrier-free market by the end of 1992, other countries are crowding to join the 12-nation organization lest they miss out on the economic benefits.

title: Walk in the Woods' Staged in Westport
description: AFTER attending the illuminating production of ''A Walk in the Woods'' at the Westport Country Playhouse, one could sum up the disparity between the values of regional theater and the Broadway commercial theater.

title: Wit can Undermine a Woman's Career
description: HOW I long for a good belly laugh. But I probably won't have one, at least not in public, until I retire. Women in business don't do that sort of thing - just like, at one time, ''nice'' girls did not have sex before marriage or at least they didn't broadcast it.

title: A Ddarien House in the French Tradition
description: FOR Susan Hurwitt, an interior designer from Darien, creating a French country look has gone beyond provincial prints and rustic armoires. She built a French country house.

title: Cemetery Cottage Imperiled
description: LEAD: EFFORTS are under way to rescue a historic caretaker's cottage threatened by new construction on the grounds of Holy Rood Cemetery in Westbury.

title: Challenger Stakes a Claim
description: Michael Fay drove his white Porsche up to the toll booth at the entrance to the San Diego-Coronado Bay Bridge last week. He was about to pass through the gate when the operator asked him for a dollar. Fay looked puzzled, then reminded the worker that cars with two or more passengers are allowed to pass for free.

title: Condominiums Planned for Pure Foods Site
description: FOR almost 100 years, the fragrance of chicken and onion soup wafted over Mamaroneck, emanating from a large white building at 746 Mamaroneck Avenue that housed the Pure Foods company.

title: The Hague
description: To the Editor: Every year tens of thousands of Europeans and many from other continents visit, as respectful pilgrims more than tourists, the Peace Palace at The Hague, where the International Court of Justice, or World Court, sits.

title: Bush and Dukakis Run Even as Race Heats Up
description: Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts enter the decisive stage of the 1988 campaign with Mr. Bush seeking to maintain the offensive and Mr. Dukakis struggling to regain what was once a formidable lead in the race for the Presidency.

title: Wendy J. Bassett Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Wendy Jane Bassett, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Bassett of New Canaan, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla., to Matthew Scott Patrick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Patrick of Franklin Lakes, N.J., took place yesterday at the Wilton (Conn.) Congregational Church. The Rev. Dr. Zdenek Bednar performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. J. Peter Cullen, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: The Right Medicine for the Teamsters
description: Despite much huffing and puffing, the leaders of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters haven't scared the Government away from its lawsuit charging mob domination of the union. If the Government wins, one outcome could be a new leadership chosen by fair elections. What better cure could there be for the teamsters' chronic and manifest illness than a stiff dose of democracy?

title: Taylor Stops McGirt in 12th For I.B.F. Title
description: Meldrick Taylor, a 1984 Olympic gold medalist, won the International Boxing Federation junior welterweight title today when he stopped the champion, Buddy McGirt, at 2:00 of the final round of a 12-round bout.

title: Making Sure the Lights Go On
description: WILLIAM J. VIERBUCHEN JR. and the Jersey Central Power and Light Company have had a very demanding summer.

title: Bell Canada Strike Accord
description: Bell Canada said today that it reached a tentative agreement to end a 10-week strike by telephone operators and technicians. The accord is subject to a vote by the striking workers.

title: Yankee Bullpen Fails Again
description: The brawl that broke out today on the infield grass at the Oakland Coliseum was little more than a fresh scene in an old script. Everything else was painfully familiar to the Yankees.

title: The Soviets Have Ample Competition in the Mediterranean
description: AMERICAN officials say the expansion of a Soviet installation on the coast of Syria will permit the Soviet Navy to increase its presence in the eastern Mediterranean. But the United States and its allies also have significant numbers of ships and bases in the Mediterranean, and, by most accounts, they would still be a match for the Soviet Navy in that region.

title: State To Buy Orient Wetlands
description: LEAD: THE State Department of Environmental Conservation has formally proposed buying 450 acres, part of it fragile wetlands, from 20 landowners on the North Fork, assuring them that they would be offered a fair market price.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: The Tired Readers Though she saw all readers as tired a priori - tired by both life and literature - Flannery O'Connor thought that a good story ought to be able to overcome their inertia. This is from her ''Collected Works'' (Library of America).

title: N.F.L. '88
description: The National Football League season starts today. A special preview in the Sports section reports on teams and trends for the coming season: * Some of the surprise teams of last year are the teams to beat this year. * Trouble has prevented recent Super Bowl winners from repeating as champion. The Washington Redskins had disruptions during the preseason, but think they can overcome them and win again. * The Giants try to put their preseason problems behind them. The Jets still have a lot of problems. * While National Conference teams wait for the Redskins to collapse, the Browns want to take charge of the American Conference. Team-by-team outlooks for each conference. * Complete schedules.

title: Baseball's Renaissance Man: Bart Giamatti
description: IT'S A HOT SUMMER'S AFTERNOON at Shea Stadium, the Mets are playing the Chicago Cubs, and Bart Giamatti, president of the National League, has come out to see a ball game. Wearing a smart blue suit in the disheveled manner of a distracted man, he has just completed his ballpark-visit ritual, stopping off first at the umpires' room, and then at each clubhouse to say hello to the team managers, and now settles into his seat in the box occupied by his friend Frank Cashen, the Mets general manager.

title:
Maplewood Journal;
A Movie Theater's Bit of Drama
description: LEAD: THIS old-fashioned community is breathing a collective sigh of relief now that the longest-running dispute of the summer is over. And it wasn't about garbage costs, or budget problems or even party politics. It was a confrontation between old and new values tied up with the fate of the local movie house.

title: Marion Hardie and John Roy Price Jr., New York Bankers, to Wed in October
description: Eben Hardie Jr. of New Orleans and Mrs. Lane N. Meltzer of New Orleans and Aspen, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marion Cobb Hardie, to John Roy Price Jr., the son of Mrs. Price of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Mr. Price. The couple plan to marry next month.

title: Jane Austen
description: To the Editor: Readers of ''At Home with Jane Austen'' (Travel, Aug. 7) will be interested to know that there is an active New York chapter of the Jane Austen Society of North America. The national organization will hold its 10th annual meeting Oct. 14 to 16 in Chicago. Information about the New York chapter is available from its president, Elsa Solender (212-737-5531). ANNA QUILLEN New York, N.Y.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Invisible Campuses: Ignoring Housing Needs of Universities
description: LEAD: IN a country that worships youthfulness, spends billions of dollars to stay young, promotes youthful values and enjoys youth culture, suburban Long Island, Nassau County in particular, must be an exception. Not that we are any different from the rest of the country, but some of our actions, most of which we are unaware of, are creating such a situation.

title: Altar or Not?

title: Investigators Find Sweatshops Are in Resurgence
description: Sweatshops, once associated mainly with the garment industry in big cities, are resurging and spreading into the restaurant and meat processing industries in other parts of the country, according to an analysis by the General Accounting Office.

title: Critic to Get Money, but Not Job, From U.S.
description: The Federal Government has agreed to pay $560,000 to settle its dispute with a senior employee who was dismissed five years ago after warning of hazardous conditions in major Government buildings, his attorney said Friday.

title: Simple Ways to Make the Most of Fresh Summer Vegetables
description: OUR local organic produce stand has the same small display of summer vegetables every day now: tomatoes, summer squash, green beans and basil. The stand works on the honor system: the prices are posted on a piece of brown paper and you put your money in an old coffee can.

description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that discussions were continuing with the Robert M. Bass Group over its proposal to acquire the American Savings and Loan Association of Stockton, Calif., the nation's largest insolvent thrift.

description: A secret new spy satellite circled the globe in a nearly useless orbit today, leaving the United States to continue relying on aging systems for eavesdropping and warning of missile attacks.

description: A fragile labor peace settled over Poland today for the first time in 20 days after striking coal miners in the south of the country and dock workers and bus drivers in the north agreed to return to work.

description: They are young, eager and enthusiastic. If those qualities mean anything in the world of the National Football League, then the Jets open their season today with at least a fighting chance against the experienced New England Patriots.

title: Study Faults Foster-Care Conditions
description: A court-ordered study describes in vivid detail the ways in which New York City's deeply troubled foster-care system has temporarily kept hundreds of children in violence-plagued, cramped and poorly equipped field offices.

description: Annamaria Rago, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Rago of Grand Junction, Colo., and Jeffrey Alan Volk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen R. Volk of New York, were married yesterday in Boulder, Colo. Bruno Jambor, a Roman Catholic deacon, officiated at the Flagstaff Mountain Amphitheater.

title: Eva Colin and John Usdan Plan an October Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Colin of Roslyn Estates, L.I., have announced the engagment of their daughter Eva Sambi Colin to John Lemberg Usdan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel H. Usdan of New York and Greens Farms, Conn. The wedding is planned for Oct. 9.

title: 2,380 Dogs Are on Their Way
description: ONCE a year the eyes of the dog-show world turn to Westchester. This year that occasion takes place next Sunday, when the gates of Lyndhurst, the historic Tarrytown estate, open for the Westchester Kennel Club's 71st annual extravaganza.

title: Review/Pop; Earth, Wind and Fire at the Garden
description: If Keith Sweat, who opened what was supposed to be a triple bill at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, were being payed by the hip gyration, he'd be a rich man. Teena Marie, who was supposed to perform along with Mr. Sweat and Earth, Wind and Fire, canceled, so Mr. Sweat, who has had a huge hit with his recent debut album, opened the show and sang for nearly an hour.

description: IN ''Fault Line,'' which ends the Independence Theater Company's first season next Sunday, the scene is a mountaintop in the Sierra Nevada during an earthquake watch, but what theatergoers had better watch out for is a toppling play.

title: A Foe of Gandhi Is Arrested In Killing of Badminton Star
description: A political opponent of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi was arrested today in connection with the killing of India's top badminton player. The arrest came after newspapers asserted that the opposition politician was having an affair with the slain athlete's wife.

title: Robert Watts, Artist And 'Fluxus' Figure, Dies of Cancer at 65
description: Robert Watts, a conceptual artist and designer who helped start the whimsical anti-Establishment Fluxus movement in art, died Friday of lung cancer at his farm in Martins Creek, Pa. He was 65 years old.

title: Founders Didn't Know the Pledge of Allegiance
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ONE SIZE DOESN'T FIT ALL. By John Madden with Dave Anderson. (Villard, $16.95.) The main character in ''One Size Doesn't Fit All'' -the third book written by John Madden with the New York Times sports columnist Dave Anderson - is the Maddencruiser, a deluxe, oversize bus designed for the television broadcaster and former football coach by Greyhound as a publicity gimmick. (He has refused to fly since retiring as coach of the Oakland Raiders.) Long rides on the Maddencruiser allow plenty of time for reflection, and Mr. Madden guides us on a lighthearted cross-country tour as he muses on ''pets and golf and broadcasting and having kids.'' He comes across much as he does on television, as an emphatic, unpretentious, slightly goofy sports enthusiast who also loves to eat. Mr. Madden's homespun charm can be delightful. The maxims he lives by, he tells us, include ''Never go to a restaurant where you need a reservation'' and ''Never go to a golf course where you need a tee time.'' But there are times when he lets his whimsy ramble too far. He devotes a whole chapter, for instance, to football players' uniform numbers and the hypothetical numbers he would assign dozens of celebrities. To this fan's taste, Mr. Madden is at his best when he sticks to football. It is in his discussions of why Super Bowl champions are unable to win in successive years, why Astroturf is a player's worst enemy or how to avoid athletic scandals at academic institutions that we see not John Madden the celebrity, but John Madden the shrewd sports analyst.

title: Elin Elisofon Is Married to David Fogg
description: Elin Elisofon, a daughter of Joan Baker Tower of Vinalhaven, Me., and Aiken, S.C., and the late Eliot Elisofon, was married in Vinalhaven yesterday to David Cushing Fogg, a son of Mrs. George P. Fogg Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Coconut Grove, Fla., and the late Mr. Fogg. Elder Robert E. Candage of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints performed the ceremony at the bride's family's summer home.

title: Country Boys Plow the Past for Songs
description: When Randy Travis and Dwight Yoakam helped pull country music out of its 1980's commercial tailspin, they brought country's long-running identity crisis a new twist by making anti-pop country a resounding popular success. The paradox deepens on their new albums, Mr. Travis's ''Old 8 x 10'' (Warner Brothers 25738, LP, cassette and CD) and Mr. Yoakam's ''Buenas Noches From a Lonely Room'' (Reprise 25749, all three formats).

title: The Small Inns And Hotels Of the Big Island
description: BEFORE statehood, jet planes and resort complexes, family-operated lodging houses catered to traveling salesmen who brought their wares and order forms into the rural towns of the Big Island of Hawaii. Most of these small hotels are gone now, except in scattered country villages. The tariffs are low, the rooms basic and clean, and the old-time island atmosphere is kamaaina (relaxed and friendly).

title: For Some in East Hampton, Cable Cost Is High
description: LEAD: AFTER Cablevision took over the cable television franchise in the Town of East Hampton 10 months ago, those who live on large lots thought they would finally be able to get service.

title: CATALOGUE CHIC
description: STROLLING DOWN A RURAL LANE OR LEANING AGAINST a barn door, the models exude a Huck Finn charm as artless as the clothes they wear. Barn door, freckled boys, gently weathered fashions - together they constitute mail order's new wave.

title: QUAYLE IS CRITICAL OF THE STATE DEPT.
description: Senator Dan Quayle, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, accused the State Department today of failing to help United States exporters, particularly farmers, to win foreign markets for their products.

description: Given the events of the last week, calculating the Giants' chances for success this season is not easy.

title: ELECTION PLACING FOCUS ON THE ISSUE OF JOBS VS. WAGES
description: The Presidential election campaign is focusing attention on two trends that many economists have trouble reconciling: While the nation's economy has demonstrated a spectacular ability to create plenty of jobs, wages generally have not kept up with inflation.

title: Movie Miscellany
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
Southern Cooking in in Tuckahoe
description: LEAD: FOR those who miss Manhattan dining, a visit to Coastal North should help satisfy the longing. This spinoff from the owners' three city restaurants is not only big, slick and glitzy but also jammed with tables spaced too closely together, particularly those for two. While the menu is trendy, dishes are turned out with some thought; apparently the kitchen of this mainly fish house has taken the trouble to time the delicate creatures carefully, and we found them not only pristinely fresh but cooked properly.

title: Colleges See New Emphasis in Enrollments
description: LEAD: UNDERGRADUATE enrollment for the new semester is expected to remain at the same levels as last year at most of Long Island's major colleges and universities.

description: Labor Day will be observed tomorrow. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK

description: Utility crews failed tonight in an attempt to restore service partially to a 50-block downtown section that has been without electricity since Wednesday.

title: UNUSUAL DEAL BURDENS ABC IN SELLING 'WAR' MINI-SERIES

It also got what some Capital Cities executives would come to regard as one of the most questionable business arrangements ever made by a network for a piece of television programming, the deal behind the mini-series ''War and Remembrance.''

title: Rina Beder Weds
description: At Temple Beth-El in Cedarhurst, L.I., Rina Laurie Beder and Irving Cohen, both graduates of Brandeis University and the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University, were married yesterday. Rabbi Dov Schwartz, assisted by Cantor Ben Belfer, performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Abner M. Beder of Rockville Centre, L.I., and Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Cohen of Hewlett, L.I. Mrs. Beder-Cohen, as the bride will be known, is to join the law firm of Kimmelman, Wolff & Samson in Roseland, N.J. Mr. Cohen is an associate at the Brooklyn law firm of Forman & Ziff.

title: Review/Music; The Ways of the Samba
description: In Brazil, the samba can be private or public, jazzy or blunt, a rumination or a pop song or a carnival parade. Martinho da Vila, a leading samba traditionalist, mapped out samba's possibilities in his first set on Friday at Sounds of Brazil, opening a three-night engagement. His music is light and lilting as his smoky baritone wafts through pattering percussion and plinking cavaquinho (a mandolin-size guitar); his lyrics, according to Portuguese speakers, are about Brazilian culture and history as well as love.

title: Plane Crash Kills 4 in Arizona
description: A single-engine plane that had aborted one takeoff because it was too heavy with fuel crashed on its next attempt, killing all four men aboard, the authorities said. The Cessna 172 crashed Saturday about 100 yards north of the runway of Grand Canyon Airport, 10 miles south of the canyon, said Ron Warren, a spokesman for Grand Canyon Airlines.

title: An Ex-Police Officer Surrenders Hostage And Later Gives Up
description: A former police officer convicted in a pension fund scandal surrendered today, 25 hours after taking as hostage the man who had exposed the scandal, police said.

title: Burlington Motor Chief Calls Its Spinoff a Gain
description: Richard Rogan lists a number of reasons why Burlington Northern Motor Carriers Inc. will be better off out from under the wing of its parent, Burlington Northern Inc.

title: Lahore Journal; Pride of the Moguls and the Pride of Punjabis Still
description: There are two Punjabs now, one on each side of the India-Pakistan frontier. But there is only one Punjabi city with the power to fire the Punjabi intellect and enslave a Punjabi heart. That city is Lahore.

title: Books of The Times; A TRULY TANGLED WEB
description: The Pizza Connection Lawyers, Drugs and the Mafia By Shana Alexander 352 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $19.95.

title: Iran Awaits U.N. Verdict Apprehensively; U.S. Dispute Formula
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks' Trip Ends in 11-2 Loss
description: The trip was over. Lou Piniella kicked his feet up on the desk inside his office, sent a billow of smoke into the air from his cigarette and reached for a silver lining.

title: Miami Thwarts Poll and Florida State
description: A week earlier, callers to radio stations in Tallahassee were clamoring to hear the ''Seminole Rap,'' the self-congratulatory recording that made Bobby Bowden, the football coach at Florida State University, swallow hard and wonder about its timing.

title: Gregory Markow Wed to Ms. Muss
description: The marriage of Julianne Louise Muss, the daughter of Mrs. Milton Ratner of Chicago and New York and Joshua A. Muss of Washington and Middleburg, Va., to Gregory Starr Markow, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen Markow of Brooklyn Heights, took place yesterday. Rabbi Joseph Tabachnik performed the ceremony at the Standard Club in Chicago.

title: Requiem for a Steel Town
description: For some years, a man in this town earned his living by transporting an orange material left over from steelmaking at the Homestead Works to a dumping site in the countryside. The man would clatter through town several times a day, his truck piled high with the material, the material sometimes billowing in the air above and behind him.

title: Catlin and Durand Art Must Not Be Sold Off
description: To the Editor:

title: American Libraries Are in Crisis Over the Cost of Scholarly Journals
description: ''I'm sitting here right now with a stack of invoices trying to decide which subscriptions to cancel,'' said Keith McKinney, the chief of periodicals at the New York Public Library.

title: Water Testing to Use Minnows and Fleas
description: Like coal miners who carried canaries down shafts knowing the birds would die when the air turned bad, the state's environmental officials will soon be testing water-pollution levels with water fleas and fathead minnows.

title: Japanese Begin Trading In Stock Index Futures
description: Japanese investors began trading stock index futures Saturday, and brokers said the activity was heavier than expected because of Wall Street's strong performance the day before.

title: Laurie Ellen Strauch Weds Wayne Gardner Dix
description: Laurie Ellen Strauch, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Berish Strauch of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married last evening to Wayne Gardner Dix, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Dix of Manchester, Mass. Cantor Raymond Smolover performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: Rain Is Soothing for Dodgers
description: Mickey Hatcher, the Los Angeles Dodgers' resident wit, noted the steady rain that was drenching Shea Stadium and said, ''I told you our luck would change.''

title: Giants Starting Off in Uncertain Stance
description: On Saturday, shortly after the Giants completed their final full-gear workout for the game against the Redskins Monday night, Phil Simms, the Giants' veteran quarterback, was asked to assess the importance of the showdown with Washington. Simms shrugged. But while he tried to minimize the long-range significance of the game Monday night, the quarterback conceded that the short-range effects could be substantial.

title: The Laborers Left Behind
description: In the spring of 1882, when Chester A. Arthur occupied the White House, the 12-hour day and the 7-day workweek were commonplace, along with the admonition ''If you don't come in on Sunday, don't come in on Monday.'' Suitably aroused, Peter J. McGuire of the Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners suggested ''a general holiday for workingmen.'' A modest parade was duly held on Sept. 5 in New York City, and Labor Day was unofficially born.

title: India Delays Defamation Bill
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, faced with protests from the press, the legal profession and members of his own party over a new defamation law, said today that the bill would not be put before the upper house of Parliament on Monday as planned. The proposed law, which editors say would curtail investigative reporting and endanger the traditional independence of Indian publications, was passed by the lower house of Parliament last week.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Sterling Chemicals Sees Rise in Profits and Sales
description: LEAD: Sterling Chemicals Inc., which announced last week that it was going public, excepts its profits and sales to increase in the fiscal year that ends on Sept. 30.

title: INJURY SIDELINES WHITAKER
description: Lou Whitaker, Detroit's second baseman, has danced his way out of the Tigers' lineup.

title: New Charges for the Call of the Wild
description: Great egrets glide over the peaceful Suisun Marsh and antlered tule elks trumpet for their mates in these warm final days of summer, oblivious that something of a revolution in wildlife management has begun around them.

title: A Slick Innovation
description: Synthetic fabrics are changing the face of competitive sports, most recently for female swimmers preparing for the Olympics. Companies are offering bathing suits to members of the United States team that they claim will significantly trim lap times. The suits have been approved by U.S. Swimming, the sport's national authority.

title: RACE OFFERS LABOR STARK CONTRASTS
description: For organized labor, the Reagan era has been a long and painful period of retreat: membership declined, union wages stagnated and Federal officials have often been passive in enforcing the thousands of Government rules that labor leaders see as essential to protecting workers' health and safety.

title: Preparing for Marathon: Be Cool
description: It's New York City Marathon time again, at least for those planning to run in it. This year's event, on Nov. 6, is only two months away, and if you're running it you should now be in the midst of your most important training. For the benefit of first-time marathoners and veterans with short memories (all marathoners have short memories ), here's a training guide that should put you in good stead for the big day.

title: VOLVO BROADENS A SPORTS MARKETING STRATEGY
description: When the National Football League played its first exhibition game in continental Europe last month, it came to Goteborg, Sweden's leading industrial center and the headquarters town of A.B. Volvo, the game's sponsor.

title: Gulf Canada's Arctic Rite of Passage
description: By early September the Arctic winter is closing in on this 32,000-ton exploratory oil rig, with plunging temperatures bringing a rapid freeze-up to the surrounding sea. Then, as the polar region moves into the 24-hour winter night, heaves in the icepack thicken to as much as 13 feet, pressing the rig's huge steel skirt with forces that have crushed dozens of ships.

title: Layoffs Due Saturday At Eastern
description: Armed with a legal victory over three of its unions, Eastern Airlines announced yesterday that it would begin dimissing as many as 4,000 workers this Saturday.

title: Jennifer Altshuler Weds Barry Green
description: Jennifer Lee Altshuler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan A. Altshuler of Belmont, Mass., and Barry D. Green, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Green of Maplewood, N.J., were married yesterday at the Harrison Inn in Southbury, Conn., by Rabbi Robert Levine.

title: Political Memo; The Art of Creating Reality Out of Campaign Symbolism
description: These days, most of the things Michael S. Dukakis and George Bush do on the stump are carefully staged media events.

title: Countdown to the Marathon: A Training Guide
description: Week of Sept. 12 Do your first 20 miler at the end of the week. Cut mid-week mileage to be rested. A strong ''20'' will mean more than meeting any strict mileage quota. Week of Sept. 19 Train ''through'' a weekend race, preferably a five miler or 10k. If you feel adventurous, try the 25k marathon tune-up in Central Park (Sept. 25), but a more speed-oriented race will be beneficial. Week of Sept. 26 Do your second 20 miler, but on a different course than the first. If it wipes you out, you're not getting enough rest. Week of Oct. 3 Psyched from watching the Olympic Marathons on TV, find a half-marathon and use it as your key month before fitness assessment. The Staten Island Half Marathon Oct. 9 would seem ideal. Week of Oct. 10 With two races and a pair of 20 milers behind you, this is a good week to do some cross-training - cycling, swimming, weight work - to enlist different muscle groups, and forestall training blahs and weakened resistance to colds. Week of Oct. 17 Revitalize, make this your biggest training week, ending with your final 20 miler. If you can get to this point in one piece, you're home free. Week of Oct. 24 Begin tapering off with 10 days to go. Treat yourself to a sports massage. Now the goal is ''defensive'' running - guarding against anything that could undermine your readiness. Week of Oct. 31 Taper, eat pasta,sleep, take a day or two off from running. Relax and focus. Feel confident. Review race plans for Nov. 6. Good luck.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5 Lech Walesa rebuked critics within Solidarity over accusations that he had surrendered to Poland's Communist leaders. In a speech in Gdansk, he told followers that ''Poland does not need strikes.'' Page 1

title: FRANCE DECREASING FLEET IN GULF AREA
description: France announced today that it had ordered four naval vessels in the northern Indian Ocean, including the aircraft carrier Clemenceau, to return home. The move reduces the French naval force in the Persian Gulf region to seven ships.

title: New Setbacks for the I.R.A. But Still the Group Endures
description: The Irish Republican Army routinely advises its new recruits that service in the guerrilla organization will most likely lead them to one of two destinations: a prison cell or a cemetery plot.

title: J. R. Taylor, an Editor, Is Wed to Dr. Solomon
description: The marriage of Dr. Amy Solomon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seth J. Solomon of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Jonathan R. Taylor, a son of Marjorie A. Taylor of Los Angeles and the late Burton L. Taylor, took place yesterday. Rabbi Sanford Ragins performed the ceremony at the Ermitage Hotel in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Yachting Terms
description: Nautical mile: International unit of measurement for air and sea navigation; equal to 6076.12 feet or 1.15 miles. Knot: Unit of speed of one nautical mile an hour. Upwind: Sailing toward the direction of the wind. Tack: Direction in which a boat is moving in relation to the position of the sails. Reach: A tack in which the wind crosses the side of the boat. Run: A tack in which the wind crosses the stern of the boat. Mainsail: Principal sail. Headsail: Smaller sail rigged forward of the mast. Jib: Headsail usually attached in front of the mast and to the fastened to the foredeck. Spinnaker: A triangular, baggy headsail used during a run. Gennaker: An oversized headsail drawn from the bow to a block well behind the mast. Used primarily when reaching. Sheet: Line used to control sails. Halyard: Line used to raise or lower sails. The rigid sail on Stars & Stripes has no halyard. Boom: Spar extending from mast that holds botttom of sail outstretched. Traveler: A mechanism that slides along a metal track across the deck to control the mainsail boom. The rig on Stars & Stripes controls the boom with a mainsheet traveler. Helmsman: Steers the boat, Not necessarily the skipper. Tactician: Plans strategy. Navigator: Calculates the position of the yacht in relation to its opponent and marks on the course. Afterguard: Main crew positions. Includes skipper, navigator and tactician. Bowman: Handles deck work at the bow, such as setting the spinnaker pole. Tailer: Controls sail shape. Trimmer: Controls sail shape. Grinder: Turns handles on winches, the drum-like hardware that aids the crew in hauling in lines or raising halyards. Winches have several gears to ease the job as load increases. Mainsail fullness controller: On Stars & Stripes, adjusts the fullness of the rigid sail with a line at the base of the mast. Main twist controller: On Stars & Stripes, adjusts rigid sail's twist from base of the mast. Twist mechanism allows crew to spill air from top of the sail to reduce power. Pit boss: On New Zealand, heads team below deck.

title: Computer Scientist Forming a Foundation
description: Douglas C. Engelbart, a computer scientist who invented the pointing device used with computers that is known as a mouse and who is credited with work that led to several other important developments in the personal computer industry, plans to leave his position as a researcher at the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and set up a nonprofit foundation called the Bootstrap Institute.

title: Tradition Makes Way For an Unorthodox Series
description: Crewmen from New Zealand's America's Cup team used to play a computer game as captivating as any in a video arcade.

title: Rain Shrinks Protest On Sea Pollution
description: About 250 people joined hands by the shore in heavy rain yesterday to call for the cleanup of the seas.

title: Appointments at Avon
description: James E. Preston, president of Avon Products Inc., has been named to the additional post of chief executive. Mr. Preston, 55 years old, was named president in May, becoming the heir apparent to Hicks B. Waldron, 64, the chairman and chief executive, who plans to retire at the end of the year. As president, Mr. Preston succeeded John S. Chamberlin, who had been regarded by analysts as Mr. Waldron's probable successor. Mr. Preston joined Avon in 1964 and has been a corporate officer since 1971. Avon also said that Robert W. Pratt Jr. was promoted to senior vice president of planning and information.

title: Dr. Audrey Estelle Mars Is Bride of Mike Sherman
description: At Congregation Beth Sholom in Brooklyn, Dr. Audrey Estelle Mars, a resident in pediatrics at the New York University Medical Center, was married to Mike Sherman, an associate at McKinsey & Company, management consultants in New York. Rabbi Mark Kunis officiated. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mars of Brooklyn, received a B.S. degree in nursing from the State University Downstate Medical Center and an M.D. degree from the Sackler School of Medicine of Tel Aviv University. Mr. Sherman, a son of Lionel Sherman of Roseville, Calif., and Margery Levy of Daly City, Calif., received bachelor's degrees from the University of Pennsylvania and its Wharton School and an M.B.A. from Harvard Universitty.

title: Leslye Sussman Wed To Richard Radutzky
description: Leslye Fran Sussman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sussman of Hewlett, L.I., and Alford, Mass., and Richard Radutzky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Radutzky of Old Westbury, L.I., were married yesterday. Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein officiated at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: German Savers Join Mark Exodus
description: Worried about having interest on their savings taxed at the source, West Germans have joined foreign investors in a significant exodus out of mark deposits.

title: Fleeing Assault by Iraqis, Kurds Tell of Poison Gas and Lives Lost
description: They were, they said, the fortunate ones, who had come from a land at war and survived. And their path, in flight from Iraq's elite forces, had brought them here, to a broad valley clustered with rocks and people and small cooking-fires - and a sense that, once more at history's turning, a Kurdish minority had been crushed by a hated foe.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Rowing to South Korea

title: Woman Is Charged In Attacks on Elderly
description: A 33-year-old Brooklyn woman has been charged in a series of push-in robberies of elderly people in the Bronx, the police said yesterday.

title: Opposition in Chile Holds a Huge Rally
description: In the first major test of the degree of campaign freedom to be allowed opponents of President Augusto Pinochet, more than 100,000 people rallied today and called for his defeat in the coming plebiscite.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1988
description: Companies

title: WALESA PLEDGES HE WILL SUPPRESS WILDCAT STRIKES
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, took the offensive today against critics within his own ranks, rebuking them for accusations of softness toward Poland's Communist leaders and pledging to snuff out future wildcat strikes.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Peru's economy minister resigned Friday, three months after taking office, after a Government report showed that inflation had soared a record 243 percent in the first eight months of the year. President Alan Garcia Perez immediately appointed a new economy minister, Abel Salinas, to fill the post vacated by Cesar Robles, according to the official newspaper, El Peruano. Mr. Robles' resignation had been expected after disagreements arose in the Cabinet over economic policy.

title: Review/Dance; Into Kaja Gam's World Of Eskimo Memories
description: Kaja Gam's new ''Translocation 9:16,'' presented by Ms. Gam and her Awkward Dance company on Saturday night at Theater for the New City, is an ambitious excursion into a world of emotions created by the difficulties of immigration. Her subjects are Minik, an Eskimo who in 1897, at the age of 5, left Greenland for New York City with Admiral Peary, and Spaet Gam, the choreographer's mother, a young Danish Greenlander who is transplanted to Denmark and trapped there during the German occupation in World War II.

title: Miserable Week For the Yankees
description: They were flying south the other night, from Seattle back to California, and they were fighting the temptation to look backward rather than into their future. Neither prospect seemed appealing.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; A Village Club's Long Lease on Success
description: In 1955, Art D'Lugoff produced a series of midnight folk music concerts and had to turn away 5,000 people clamoring to hear Pete Seeger and Sonny Terry.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In his career, how many singles, doubles, triples and home runs did Pete Rose have?

title: On Great Lakes, a Greater Coastline
description: While farmers and ranchers are still cursing this summer's drought, beachgoers in Chicago and all around the Great Lakes are reveling in the hot, dry weather at beaches that were under water only a few months ago.

title: Julia Martin Married To Gregory J. Langan
description: At St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in St. George, S.I., Julia Martin, a daughter of Paul Ross Martin of Stapleton, S.I., and Julia Ibbotson Martin of St. George, was married yesterday to Gregory John Langan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Langan of Great Kills, S.I. The Rev. James Dorney, assisted by the Rev. Ramon Salomone, performed the ceremony.

title: The Art of Survival
description: When the Freer Gallery of Art closes tomorrow for renovations, its colony of turtles will be boarded out among employees of the Smithsonian Institution, of which the gallery is a part. Because turtles normally are not among the items displayed at an art museum, one might wonder how they got there.

title: 8,000 Said to Starve In the Southern Sudan
description: Fighting and seasonal flooding are blocking Western relief efforts in the southern Sudan, where local reports indicate that 8,000 people have starved to death in recent weeks, the authorities say.

title: Slip of the Tongue
description: Lewis F. Powell Jr., who retired in 1987 as a Supreme Court Justice, reveals some Court secrets in a taped interview being broadcast today on the C-Span cable television network, including the possibility - with tongue planted firmly in cheek - that he was not legally sworn in on Jan. 7, 1972.

title: Iran Awaits U.N. Verdict Apprehensively
description: To the Editor:

title: On L.I., Bias Case Looks At Zoning and the Poor
description: As a major housing-desegregation case in Huntington, L.I., winds down and another in Yonkers continues to receive widespread attention, a third case is just beginning here in the Town of Brookhaven.

title: Fraud Case Suspect Was A Gambler, F.B.I. Says
description: While at least 50 South Florida physicians believed that Henry Gherman had invested their retirement money in Government-insured certificates of deposit, the 52-year-old financial adviser was using the money instead to live lavishly and gamble compulsively at some of the world's swankiest casinos, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has charged.

title: Olympic Notebook; Soviet Yacht Team Arrives for Games
description: The first group of Soviet athletes participating in the Seoul Olympics arrived over the weekend by ship from Vladivostok. The 27 members of the yachting team, sailors and officials, disembarked 300 miles south of here in Pusan, South Korea's second-largest city, where the yachting events will be held.

title: Quayle, Ending Trip South, Continues Attack on Dukakis
description: Senator Dan Quayle, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, ended a five-day swing through the South today with a continuation of the strong attacks on Mr. Dukakis that he began last week.

title: GROWTH OF LOCAL-NEWS STATION IS WATCHED BY CABLE INDUSTRY
description: Every day, 24 hours a day, the news of Long Island flows from a small cable television studio here to more than 540,000 homes in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: SCENES FORM THE LIFE OF AN AMERICAN SCULPTOR
description: ''Saint-Gaudens: Masque of the Golden Bowl,'' a film about the 19th-century American sculptor Augustus Saint-Gaudens, is a mild and at times schizophrenic docudrama. Made in 1985, the film was written by Will N. Goetzmann and directed and produced by T. W. Timreck. It will be shown on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: Newspaper Guild Grows Stronger Despite Antiunion Climate
description: To the Editor:

title: Unisex Insurance Rules Are Upheld
description: Massachusetts last week joined Montana as the only states that prohibit life insurance companies from charging men higher rates than women - a common practice.

title: Stop the Iraqi Murder of the Kurds
description: On the day the cease-fire began in the Iran-Iraq war, Saddam Hussein, dictator of Iraq, launched a new military offensive. This was for vengeance - to punish the Kurdish people living in northern Iraq who had dared to pursue their long struggle for autonomy during the dictator's war against Iran.

title: Richard Tannenbaum Weds Ellen Distelheim
description: Ellen F. Distelheim, an associate at the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, was married yesterday to Richard Tannenbaum, a manager with the Roulac Real Estate Consulting Group of Deloitte, Haskins & Sells in New York. Rabbi Alan D. Bregman, assisted by Cantor Jerome J. Frazes, performed the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Chicago.

title: 'Trial of an Era' Is Opening in Moscow Today
description: Officially, it is to be the corruption and bribery trial of nine men, including the son-in-law of Leonid I. Brezhnev, that opens Monday.

title: Heavy Workouts Can Be Damaging
description: One of the nagging doubts created by the exercise boom is the possibility that all this rushing about in the name of fitness might turn out to be harmful many years from now. That might seem unlikely, given the care with which most modern medical research is conducted. After all, the evidence seems persuasive that becoming aerobically fit has a number of positive health benefits, particularly in staving off heart disease.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The authorities spat on me, but now I am extending my hand because we have a chance to let Poland be Poland.'' - Lech Walesa. [ 1:6. ]

title: Red Sox Tie for First on Parrish Homer
description: Boston moved into a tie with Detroit for first place in the American League East today as Larry Parrish's leadoff homer in the 10th inning gave the Red Sox a 6-5 victory over the California Angels.

title: Jets Need Dominant Decision-Maker
description: In a steady rain, the Jets' inexperience melted into ineptness. They lost to the New England Patriots, 28-3, a sorry start for Leon Hess's great experiment: reconstructing a National Football League team without a dominant decision-maker in the front office, alias a general manager.

title: Labor Day
description: NEW YORK Parade: Starts at 11 A.M. at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue, travels north to 72d Street, then east to Third Avenue. Government offices: Closed.

title: Meadowlands Recycling Plan
description: State officials hoped to include thousands of football fans in a new recycling campaign at Monday night's season opener at the Meadowlands between the Washington Redskins and New York Giants. To help comply with a 1987 state law that calls for a 25-percent reduction in the state's waste flow, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority has set up 60 recycling bins for glass bottles and cans at the parking lot of Giants Stadium. They will be in the parking lot for all events at the stadium.

title: Israeli Chief Is Said to Plan a Low-Key Visit to Hungary This Month
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel will visit Hungary later this month, Hungarians and foreign diplomats say.

title: Free Juilliard Recital
description: A free, joint recital by the winners of this year's Gina Bachauer Piano Scholarship Competition is to open the 1988-89 performance season at the Juilliard School on Sept. 14. The three pianists, Yu-Chia Hu, Ory Shihor and Jeannie Yu, are to play in the C. Michael Paul Recital Hall, 144 West 66th Street, starting at 9 P.M. WQXR-FM (96.3) is to broadcast the concert live. On the program are works by Scriabin, Chopin, Debussy, Bach and Schumann. Information: 799-5000.

title: Ruth Kugelmass Weds David Gold
description: Ruth Leah Kugelmass, the daughter of Dr. Norman Kugelmass of Storrs, Conn., and the late Marion Herzl Kugelmass, was married yesterday to David Adam Gold, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard L. Gold of Suffern, N.Y. Rabbi David H. Chanofsky officiated at Estherwood, a mansion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Hasidic Group Expands Amid Debate on Future
description: Surrounded by several thousand followers, the 86-year-old Grand Rabbi of Lubavitch put a shovel in the earth and broke ground last week for a new $23 million headquarters for the Hasidic group he heads.

title: Police Store 'One of Everything Ever Made' (Well, Nearly)
description: They have rooms full of television sets, acres of automobiles and mountains of illegal drugs. There are also boxes of Pampers, an artificial Christmas tree, Petula Clark eight-track tapes, a Frederic Remington bronze, a can or two rattling with cremated human remains, tens of thousands of handguns and a hoe.

title: Oilers Top Colts In Overtime, 17-14
description: Tony Zendejas kicked a 35-yard field goal 3 minutes 51 seconds into overtime today to give the Houston Oilers a 17-14 victory over the Indianapolis Colts.

title: Lynda Bolnick Married
description: Lynda Susan Bolnick, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lewis Bolnick of Millville, N.J., was married yesterday to Neal Martin Eiseman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Eiseman of Little Silver, N.J. Rabbi Charles Gelernter performed the ceremony at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club. The bride graduated from Georgetown University. The bridegroom, a partner in the New York law firm of Goetz, Fitzpatrick & Flynn, graduated from George Washington University and the St. John's University School of Law.

title: Patriots Overwhelm Jets
description: In the rain and gloom of opening day, the Jets' offense slipped, and the surprising New York defense finally gave way today to older, cooler New England players as the Patriots produced a 28-3 victory.

title: BIG SPENDERS MARK FLORIDA PRIMARIES
description: Florida Republicans, out to gain the seat being vacated by Senator Lawton Chiles, a Democrat, will choose Tuesday between the grandson of a baseball legend and the prosecutor who convicted a man accused of being a Colombian drug lord.

title: A Queens Teen-Ager Is Charged In Killing of Mister Softee Driver
description: A Queens teen-ager has been charged in the slaying of a mother of five who was shot to death in her Mister Softee truck during a robbery attempt.

title: Catlin and Durand Art Must Not Be Sold Off
description: To the Editor:

title: At Least 520 Are Dead In Bangladesh Floods
description: The official death toll in devastating monsoon floods in Bangladesh reached at least 520 today as the stranded and homeless awaited emergency aid. Officials warned that thousands could die before help arrived.

title: 49ers Edge Saints, 34-33; Montana Hurt
description: Joe Montana threw three touchdown passes in the third quarter today, and Mike Cofer kicked a 32-yard field goal with 1 minute 40 seconds left in the game as the San Francisco 49ers beat the New Orleans Saints, 34-33. The game opened the National Football League season for both clubs.

title: Metro Matters; Political Fallout: Ties to Jackson Could Also Bind
description: Mayor Koch had to eat crow last week when he met with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and other blacks to apologize for his strident criticism of Mr. Jackson during the Democratic primary last April.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BellSouth Enterprises, a subsidiary of the BellSouth Corp., Atlanta, named Earle Mauldin 3d group president, mobile systems, effective Sept. 15. It also appointed Roger W. Hale executive vice president, marketing and business development.

title: Dr. Contreras Weds Dr. C. M. Kramer
description: Dr. Catherine Lynn Contreras, the daughter of Mildred Joyce Contreras and Anthony Cortez Contreras, both of Woodland, Calif., was married in Rye, N.Y., yesterday to Dr. Christopher Milton Kramer, a son of Debora Dammann Kramer of Washington and John Robert Kramer of New Orleans. Judge Joan Lefkowitz of the New Rochelle (N.Y.) Family Court performed the ceremony in the garden at the home of Richard W. Dammann, the bridegroom's grandfather.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf King Leads Rail Classic: Betsy King shot a four-under-par 68 to take a two-stroke lead yesterday after the second round of the $250,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Rail Classic. King was at 136 going into today's final round at the Rail Golf Club in Springfield, Ill. King started the day two shots off the lead after a first round of 68. She pulled into a tie for the lead with two birdies on the front nine and took over first place with a third after pitching to within a foot of the pin on the ninth hole. Margaret Ward, who matched King's 68, was tied for second with Susan Sanders and Nancy Brown.(AP) Auto Racing Elliott First at Darlington: Bill Elliott, the Winston Cup points leader, held off Rusty Wallace over the final 32 laps yesterday to win the Southern 500 race at Darlington International Raceway. Elliott passed Mike Alexander on lap 331 after the event's final caution period, then stayed just ahead of Wallace to win his fifth race of the year, the most of any driver on the circuit. Elliott, who won $75,800, won the pole in record time. But after a lengthy pit stop, he had to come from 13th to win the 500-mile race at the 1.366-mile egg-shaped superspeedway.(AP) Fittipaldi Edges Andretti: Emerson Fittipaldi dominated in the wet and the dry to win the Escort 200 Indy-car race at Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course in Lexington, Ohio. Fittipaldi, who lost the lead to Mario Andretti when the latter took advantage of the only full-course caution flag in the 84-lap, 200.5-mile race, moved past Andretti 24 laps from the end and easily won the battle of former Formula One champions.(AP) Dog Show Bernese Is Best: Ch. Bornedale Puffin V Ledgewood, a Bernese mountain dog, was named best of 1,522 dogs yesterday at the Sussex Hills Kennel Club Show in Florham Park, N.J. Puffin, owned by Leon Kuzikowski and Kim Behrens and handled by Sal Vendrillo, made history as the first Bernese bitch to capture a top award. She won her 22d working group. Cross-Country Rainy-Day Run: Doug Hegley of the Reebok Track Clubwon the 25th Henry Isola Memorial 4-mile cross-country run, the opening meet of the season, in 21 minutes 28 seconds in the rain and mud at Van Cortlandt Park. Belinda Saunders of the Van Cortlandt T.C., was the women's winner in 26:42.

title: How to Create 30 Million Jobs in Eight Years
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Create 30 Million Jobs in Eight Years; Poverty's Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: Outdoors: Surf Fishing in Fall?
description: If you live in the Northeast and have been toying with the notion of becoming a surf fisherman, now is the time to begin.

title: Stephanie L. Gosler Wed To Alan H. Freudenstein
description: Stephanie Lynn Gosler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Gosler of Jersey City, was married yesterday to Alan Howard Freudenstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Freudenstein of Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi Victor Mirelman, assisted by Cantor Joseph Ness, performed the ceremony at the Tavern on the Green in New York.

title: Investigator Mistakes Spoon For Gun and Kills Jersey Man
description: A police investigator who believed a large metal spoon was a pistol fatally shot a man during a drug raid, an Essex County prosecutor said.

title: 9 Sri Lankan Soldiers Killed
description: A military vehicle was blown up in northern Sri Lanka today, killing nine Government soldiers and wounding three others, military officials said. The officials said Tamil separatist rebels were suspected in the attack, which took place near Vavuniya.

title: Air Show Toll Rises to 52
description: Another victim of the crash last Sunday at an air show in Ramstein died today, bringing the toll to 52, officials said. The officials said some of the 164 people still hospitalized with injuries received in the disaster remained in critical condition.

title: Restaurant Chain Settles Suit
description: A restaurant chain will pay $15,000 each to 23 people who sued, alleging they were denied service because of their race or ethnicity.

title: Early Education of Green: Ethnic Wars of New York
description: Shortly after he arrived to become New York City's Schools Chancellor last March, Dr. Richard R. Green accepted an invitation to what he thought was a cocktail party to meet some of the leaders of the city's Hispanic advocacy groups.

title: Reorganization At Polaroid
description: The Polaroid Corporation, which is fighting a takeover offer from Roy Disney's Shamrock Holdings Inc., said Friday that it had reorganized its senior management.

title: Vice-Presidential Candidates Differ on Speaking Fees and Free Trips
description: The Vice-Presidential candidates differ significantly when it comes to speaking fees and free trips, two of the more valuable Congressional fringe benefits.

title: Wine Plans Of Japanese Upset French
description: Franco-Japanese relations stumbled during the past few days when France's Minister of Agriculture said Japan's Takashimaya department store chain should not be allowed to buy the most prestigious Burgundy vineyard because France's cultural heritage should not be sold.

title: Supply and Demand
description: The Japanese have been visiting Washington for the last eight decades - since the first pink Japanese cherry trees were planted around the Tidal Basin near the Jefferson Memorial. But now they are coming to the capital at the rate of 200,000 a year.

title: Wagner Lectures Planned
description: Dale Harris, a writer, critic and professor at Sarah Lawrence College, the Cooper Union and the New School for Social Research, is to present a series of lectures on Wagner and his world, at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The talks are to be given on 10 consecutive Wednesdays at 6 P.M., starting Oct. 12. Admission to the series is $75. Information: 570-3949.

title: ARMENIAN CAPITAL IS ROUSED BY CALLS FOR NEW FREEDOMS
description: Two nights ago, more than 100,000 Armenians, defying an official ban and a heavy police cordon, streamed into the square in front of this city's imposing stone opera house for a town meeting.

title: Hammond Journal; Earthen Barrier Serves as Both Dam and Symbol
description: The two-lane road angles through Hammond, past schools and churches and rows of small, tidy frame houses, heading east into Gary. But in seven years now, no one traveling this way has ever made it as far as the next town.

title: Glenn P. Tobin Weds Nancy Beer in Boston
description: Nancy Beer and Glenn Patrick Tobin, who both received master's degrees in public policy from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, were married at Old City Hall in Boston yesterday. Rabbi Benjamin Rudofsky and the Rev. Dan Graham, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Where Students Are Living Language
description: The youngsters at Waldsee play soccer just as other American campers do, but the words echoing off the tall pines and birches that embrace the playing field are German.

title: Rescue Move in Kansas
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board Friday placed the troubled Valley Federal Savings and Loan Association of Hutchinson, Kan., in conservatorship. Valley Federal, under the appointed conservator, will conduct business as usual, maintaining its name and normal operating hours. Valley Federal has $238.7 million in assets and $252.2 million in liabilities, giving it a negative net worth of $13.5 million, the bank board said.

title: Outbreak Sickens Hundreds At a Base for Navy Recruits
description: Hundreds of Navy recruits were evacuated from their barracks and 119 were hospitalized after complaining of vomiting, dizziness and breathing problems, the Navy said today.

title: Murder Within Sovereign Borders
description: Not just a whiff but the stench of genocide drifts from the Kurdish areas of Iraq and the green hills of Burundi, homeland of the Hutu tribe. Those who commit such acts should know the world watches, that sovereignty cannot legitimize genocide.

title: Menus' Hot Item: Home Delivery
description: Seeing an enormous opportunity in all the Americans who are dollar rich and too time poor to go out to eat, a rapidly growing number of restaurants and food service companies are beginning to deliver prepared food.

title: 10 Utilities in Inquiry Named
description: The Government Friday identified 10 electric cooperatives with ties to the Chicago accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company that are being studied by the Internal Revenue Service and the Rural Electrification Administration.
