title: Jersey Boy, 7, Shot On Lower East Side
description: A 7-year-old New Jersey boy was shot and seriously wounded Saturday night as he stood with his father on a street corner on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, the police said.

title: NEW TABLOID TAKES ON JERUSALEM POST
description: A new English-language newspaper began here Friday, published by American investors who think native English speakers form Israel's most affluent and educated community.

title: Tutu Calls for Boycott Of Local Council Vote
description: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu called on the country's 1.8 million Anglicans today to boycott segregated nationwide local council elections scheduled for Oct. 26.

title: Politics of Child Care
description: While both major Presidential candidates are embracing family issues, a battle is continuing in Congress over a bill requiring certain employers to provide workers with unpaid leave to care for sick or newborn children. With a vote on both the Senate and House versions of the legislation possible this month, a variety of groups are scrambling to be heard.

title: Underdogs Have Their Day as Top Players Fall
description: Eight of the 16 seeded players in the men's draw and six of the seeded women were eliminated in the first week of the United States Open, and the men's third round has not yet been completed. Thus, the rainy-day question yesterday was whether that was good or bad news for tennis. Critics often complain that the game is dominated by a handful of players, which can make the weekly results repetitive. At the same time, people buy tickets in anticipation of climatic showdowns among that handful in the later rounds.

title: More Job Cuts Seen for Wall Street
description: Before year-end Wall Street will cut as many as 5,000 more jobs, analysts predict, as last October's stock market collapse continues to be felt throughout the financial markets. Brokerage firms have already reduced their payrolls by 15,000 since the market peaked a year ago.

title: Rain and Mud Delay Canadian Open
description: Ken Green was leading by three strokes with seven holes to play in the final round of the 79th Canadian Open today when thunder, lightning and heavy rain forced the Royal Canadian Golf Association to postpone completion of the tournament until Monday morning.

title: Political Scientists Trade Opinions on U.S. Leaders
description: He wasn't chosen by his party as its candidate for President, but Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, is the Senator most respected by top Senate aides, while Chic Hecht, Republican of Nevada, ranks last.

title: Officials Debate How to Get Homeless Out of the Subways
description: The Transit Authority, facing an increasing concentration of homeless people living in open squalor in subway stations and on the trains, is in midst of an anguished internal policy debate over how to resolve a problem that officials believe has implications for ridership levels, revenues and public image.

title: Cuomo to Decide Fate of Milk Bill That Could Restore a Cartel
description: Governor Cuomo must decide by Wednesday whether to sign or veto a bill that opponents say would re-establish a cartel controlling the price of milk in New York State and cripple the maverick New Jersey dairy that forced down milk prices last year.

title: Foundations Expand Family Planning Aid Abroad
description: Two of the wealthiest foundations in the United States are starting multimillion-dollar programs to curb unwanted population growth in Asia, Africa and Latin America.

title: Seattle Power Back; Users Asked to Conserve
description: Electricity flowed downtown again today after a three-day blackout that halted elevators in high-rise buildings, thawed frozen food and shut down air-conditioners.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a Geneva conference to review compliance with the Antiballistic Missile Treaty misstated the American position on a disputed Soviet radar. The United States said it would consider declaring the Soviet Union in ''material breach'' of the treaty if it did not dismantle the radar; it was not the first such warning, and the United States did not say it would necessarily take the action.

title: TV Notes
description: Oedipus Dramas

title: Larry Woiwode's Life and Work in Words
description: The main character in Larry Woiwode's new novel, ''Born Brothers,'' is born and spends his early years in North Dakota as a member of a highly religious Catholic family, has a slightly older brother, moves to Illinois, wants to become a physician, attends the University of Illinois -where he writes stories and acts in Shakespeare and Beckett - leaves school, works for a television station and then lives in New York.

title: Dukakis Aide's Return Is Seen as a Critical Lift
description: John Sasso was back at work for Michael S. Dukakis this weekend, with a job that is largely undefined but also, in the view of some Dukakis aides, a set of strengths that could prove critical in the last nine weeks of the Presidential campaign.

title: James N. Black, Jazz Drummer, Dies at 48
description: James N. Black, a jazz drummer who played with such musicians as Lionel Hampton, Cannonball Adderley, John Coltrane and Dr. John, died Tuesday. He was 48 years old. The cause of death was not announced, pending the result of an autopsy.

title: Milesius Splashes To Muddy Victory
description: Milesius stormed from last place to win the Manhattan Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park after heavy rain changed it from an important 12-horse grass race to an insignificant five-horse slog through the slop.

title: Retired Officer Kills Himself After a Spree
description: LEAD: A retired police officer killed himself yesterday after a nightlong spree in which he shot out several street lamps in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx, ending an evening of drinking and driving with an off-duty police officer, the police said.

title: Bridge
description: It will not be surprising if the World Team Olympiad, scheduled to begin in Venice on Oct. 8, proves disappointing for the favorites. Some of the countries that have won in the past, like France, are not at full strength. And many countries that have never won have closed the gap by developing new talent.

title: Workers Playing for Funds
description: It does not faze Sister Joanne Schuster to know that as a 5-foot-2-inch volleyball player, she will face a great task competing Friday in the Franciscan Health Care Games at Felt Forum. As President of the Franciscan Sisters of the Poor Health Care System, and organizer of the games as well, she is used to handling greater tasks.

title: With Vote Secure, Singapore Now Plots a Younger Future
description: The transition to a younger generation in Singapore's leadership may not be complete, as Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew asserted early this morning, but it is well under way.

title: Ms. Dystel, Literary Agent, Marries Steven Schwinder
description: Jane D. Dystel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Dystel of Purchase, N.Y., was married at her home in New York yesterday to Steven Gary Schwinder, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Schwinder of Miami Beach, Fla. Rabbi Gary Bretton-Granatoor officiated.

title: Seven House Primaries Among Most Visible Races in New York Region
description: 11TH DISTRICT Representative Edolphus Towns, 54. Seeking fourth term. Second black Congressman from Brooklyn. Graduated from North Carolina A & T and holds a master's in social welfare from Adelphi University. Deputy borough president under Howard Golden for six years before his election to the House in 1982. Won general election by a 9-to-1 margin in 1986. Married. Raz B. Hussain, 39. Born in Pakistan. Studied pharmacy at Punjab University, Pakistan. Worked in Harlem Hospital pharmacy after coming here in 1973. Established chain of drugstores. Chief executive officer of Sursale Wholesale Inc., a pharmaceutical distributor he founded in 1981. Became United States citizen in 1980. Wife, five children. First race for public office. The district: Overwhelmingly Democratic; includes downtown Brooklyn, Greenpoint, Williamsburg, Bushwick and South Brooklyn areas. At least 75 percent black and Hispanic. 15TH DISTRICT Peter G. Doukas, 35. Born in Brooklyn and graduated from Baruch College. Certified public accountant in private practice, specializing in international finance. Member of Community Board 6 and former president of Mid-Mnhattan New Democratic Club. Field director for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's Presidential primary in New York. First race for public office. Single. John B. Levitt, 29. Born in Las Vegas, Nev., and grew up in Gramercy Park section of Manhattan. Graduate of Cornell University School of Industrial and Labor Relations and Harvard Law School. While in law school, was an intern for Representative Claude Pepper of Florida. Democratic district leader. Member of Community Board 5. First race for public office. Single. George T. McDonald, 44. Born in Spring Lake, N.J. Executive of textile company before becoming a full-time advocate for the homeless in 1980. Founded Doe Fund Inc. to provide funds or homeless. State director of volunteers for Senator Edward M. Kennedy's Presidential bid in 1980. Ran for Congress in the district in 1980, 1982 and 1984. Married, four children. Paul P. Rao Jr., 56. Born in Manhattan. Son of longtime judge of Court of International Trade. Brooklyn Law School graduate. Assistant district attorney, 1955-56. Two years' Army service as staff member of Senate Investigations Committee. Member of City Tax Commission, 1962-66. Unsuccessful candidate for Democratic Congressional nomination in 1968 and 1970, opposing Edward I. Koch. Now in private law practice. Married, four children. The district: Extraordinarily diverse. Runs from the poor Lower East Side to the wealthy Upper East Side and includes Times Square and the heart of midtown. Democrats outnumber Republicans by nearly 23 to 1. Incumbent is a Republican, Bill Green. 17TH DISTRICT Representative Ted Weiss, 60. Seeking seventh term. One of most liberal members of House. Member of Foreign Affairs Committee. Born in Hungary. Graduate of Syracuse University and Law School. Former assistant district attorney. City Councilman from 1961-1977. Has had no more than token opposition in past primary and general elections for Congress. Married, two children. Harry Fotopoulos, 59. A wealthy executive in the insurance and real-estate businesses. Unsuccessful candidate for State Senate and City Council in a series of ideological challenges of liberal Democrats on the West Side. Married, six children. Has homes in Washington Heights neighborhood and Tappan in Rockland County. The district: Snaking along Hudson River from Battery to Riverdale and includes northern Bronx. Very liberal. Overwhelmingly Democratic. 18TH DISTRICT Representative Robert Garcia, 55. First elected in 1978. Sole Hispanic-American in State Congressional delegation. State Assemblyman from 1965-67 and State Senator from 1967-78. Re-elected to Congress with 94 percent of vote in 1986. For the last 18 months, he and his wife, Jane, have been under investigation in the Wedtech scandal. They have not been indicted. Ismael Betancourt Jr., 50. Graduate of Columbia College and Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration. Held posts at three city agencies from 1968-1972, including vice presidency of Offtrack Betting Corporation. Senior vice president of New York Urban Coalition, 1972-75. Owner of food-processing company, 1976-1982; president of management consultant since 1983. Unsuccessful candidate for Bronx Borough President in 1981 and 1985 and Assembly in 1983. In 1982, lost Congressional primary to Mr. Garcia. Married, two children. Pedro Espada Jr., 34. Born in Puerto Rico and raised in a family on welfare. Fordham University graduate. From 1975-79, worked as teacher and community organizer in South Bronx and Harlem and on the Lower East Side. Founder and president of the Comprehensive Community Development Corporation and executive director of Soundview Health Center. Married, three children. The district: Heart of the South Bronx, leading symbol of urban decay. At least 80 percent Hispanic and black. 19TH DISTRICT Mario Biaggi, 70. Born in New York. Graduate of New York Law School. First elected to the House 20 years ago. Former police officer. Convicted twice in last 18 months of Federal crimes, including accepting illegal gratuities, racketeering and extortion. Sentenced to 30 months in prison; additional sentencing in November. Resigned present term under threat of ouster. Unable to remove himself from ballot, where he is also Republican candidate. Won with 90 percent of vote in 1986. Eliot L. Engel, 41. Born in the Bronx. Graduate of Hunter-Lehman College. Master's degree in guidance and counseling from City University and law degree from New York Law School. Public school teacher and guidance counselor until winning Assembly seat in 1977 special election. Has given up renomination to run for Congress. Married, two children. Vincent A. Marchiselli, 60. Born in the Bronx. Graduate of Iona College and New York University School of Education. Assemblyman from 1974 to 1984, when he was defeated for re-election. Defeated again in 1986 comeback attempt. Operates funeral parlor. Married. Longtime opponent of the leadership of the Bronx Democratic organization. The district: Overwhelmingly Democratic. Eastern and northern Bronx and Yonkers. 20TH DISTRICT Hamilton Fish 3d, 37. Member of New York family that dates from the Revolutionary War. Son and grandson of New York Republican Congressmen and great-grandson of a New York Governor. Father represents adjacent Congressional district. Alumnus of Harvard College. Publisher of The Nation from 1977-1987. Co-producer of two films and Broadway play. Nita Lowey, 52. Born in the Bronx. Mount Holyoke College alumna. Served on Hubert H. Humphrey's Senate staff. Assistant New York Secretary of State from 1974 to this year. Married, three children. Headed Women's Network of the Y.W.C.A. and director of National Women's Political Caucus in Westchester and of Westchester Jewish Community Services. Dennis Mehiel, 46. Born in Manhattan. Founder and owner of Four M Corporation of Thornwood, N.Y., which manufactures cardboard inserts. Democratic district leader. Former adviser to Alfred B. DelBello, former lieutenant governor and County Executive in Westchester. First campaign for public office. Married, five children. The district: Eastern Westchester from the Bronx to Connecticut line and to North Castle. Includes Mount Pleasant, Briarcliff Manor, New Castle and Ossining. Slight Democratic edge, but incumbent is a Republican, Joseph J. DioGuardi. 22D DISTRICT Eleanor Burlingham, 75. Born in Boston and lives in Ramapo. Graduate of Bryn Mawr College and University of Buffalo Law School. President of Rockland County Conservation Association from 1953-1976. Chairman of Rockland County Environmental Management Council. Ran for Congress in 1986, winning the primary but losing the election. Widow, five children. Michael T. Delia, 43. Born in Manhattan and lives in South Nyack. Graduate of Cooper Union. Former professional drummer. Owned and operated family scrap-metal business, metal and plastics recycling plant, construction company and, until recently, Space Age Aviation of West Nyack, which buys and sells jet engines. First race for office. Married, three children. The district: Northern Westchester, Rockland, Orange and Sullivan Counties. Predominantly Republican. The incumbent is Benjamin A. Gilman, Republican.

title: Chess
description: Following Viktor Korchnoi's success in the Royan International Tournament in France, the former challenger for the world title continued his climb out of the doldrums by taking another first prize, this time in a much stronger event, the O.H.R.A. Crown Group International Tournament in Amsterdam.

title: Lessons of a Peace Epidemic
description: LEAD: Wars that have raged for years are ending. The Reagan Administration has been quick to argue that this results from its policy of strength. Actually, the peace epidemic tells a great deal about the sharp limits the international system puts on the successful use of force.

title: In San Diego, the Developers Profit As Homeless Get Low-Cost Housing
description: This city has confirmed the old capitalist adage that there's money to be made on poverty, and in the process, it has become a pioneer in providing attractive low-cost housing for the homeless and the working poor.

title: At Moscow Trial, Some Unlikely Court Theatrics
description: The trial of Yuri M. Churbanov, son in-law of the late Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, began here today with court officers offering a lengthy reading of bribery and corruption charges and a defense attorney venting indignation over sensational pretrial publicity, in a display worthy of an American trial lawyer.

title: Price of Illiteracy Translates Into Poverty and Humiliation
description: Iva Mack nearly always orders a hamburger when she eats in a coffee shop. She is not especially fond of hamburgers. But she cannot read a menu and is fairly sure a coffee shop will have a hamburger.

title: Houston Journal; Mission Accomplished For a Veteran Crusader
description: Marvin Zindler, the man who closed the real-life ''Best Little Whorehouse in Texas,'' has succeeded in a new mission. He has gone to Hanoi, the capital of Vietnam, and rescued ''two brave children who were trapped there after the war.''

title: Kindness Is a Closed Subject As Campaign Officially Opens
description: From coast to coast, Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis attacked each other yesterday as they observed the traditional Labor Day opening of a Presidential campaign that has hardly paused for a kind word in weeks.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ex-Official of Diasonics Pursues Buyout Effort
description: LEAD: Albert S. Waxman, one of Silicon Valley's most successful businessmen, has become the focus of a bitter legal battle as a result of his efforts to take over Diasonics Inc., of Milpitas, Calif., a high-technology medical equipment concern that he founded in the 1970's.

title: Besieged Elephants Find Ally
description: This is George Adamson country, five miles south of the Equator, a harsh region blanketed with sandy soil and prickly gray thorn bushes and populated by wild game and Somali nomads.

title: Estrogen Reduces Risk of Stroke After Menopause
description: WOMEN taking estrogen after menopause were half as likely to die from a stroke as women who had not taken the female hormone, according to a new study in the British Medical Journal.

title: Careers; Engineers Take Classes By Satellite
description: THREE years ago Senator John Glenn, the former astronaut, gave the first commencement address at a most unusual graduation ceremony: for one student who received a master's degree from the newly formed National Technological University.

title: Lightning Is Underreported, Researcher Says
description: Bolts of lightning strike far more often than weather records indicate, making electrical storms more dangerous than previously believed, according to a weather researcher.

title: Q&A
description: Q. If osteoporosis occurs more often in postmenopausal women because of estrogen deficiency, why don't men get it even more often, and at younger ages? A. It is true that men don't have as much of the hormone estrogen as women, but ''the male hormone androgen, which normal men have in considerably supply, appears to exert similar protective effects on the skeleton,'' said Dr. William Peck, president of the National Osteoporosis Foundation and physician in chief of the Jewish Hospital of St. Louis.

title: Purchasers Find Drop In Growth
description: The economy's robust growth rate slowed in August, but healthy gains are expected in the third quarter, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report, scheduled to be released today.

title: A Blockbuster Summer of Blockbusters
description: The Hollywood summer of 1988, which ends this week, has been as big a blockbuster as its major movies - ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit,'' ''Coming to America,'' ''Crocodile Dundee II'' and ''Big.''

title: Southmark Expects Loss
description: The Southmark Corporation said it expects to report a sizable loss for the year ended June 30 because of higher reserves against deterioration in the real estate and securities markets.

title: Bloodless Bullfights Are Raising Some Dust in Chicago
description: An official is promising to close a legal loophole that allowed bullfights to be held here over the weekend, but Hispanic residents argue that a ban would strip them of their culture and heritage.

title: Soviet Olympic Payoff
description: Soviet athletes who win medals at the Seoul Olympics will be paid the equivalent of up to $19,000 for their winning performances.

title: Who Raises Taxes, Republicans or Democrats?
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times
description: There is a word for people like Bill Lajoie. It's ''class,'' and there are too few occasions to use it.

title: Critic's Notebook; 'Cymbeline' Forgotten, Or a Silence Not Golden
description: For each of the three plays in Sir Peter Hall's cycle of late Shakespeare at the National Theater - ''Cymbeline,'' ''The Winter's Tale'' and ''The Tempest''- there was a note inserted in the program informing us that ''owing to the indisposition of John Bluthal,'' certain roles would be played by other actors. Mr. Bluthal had been engaged to play a number of minor characters in each production, and in his first nonappearance it seemed that he was indispensable.

title: Ann G. Schaumberger Weds Steven Nicokiris
description: The marriage of Ann Gail Schaumberger, an associate at the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, to Steven Nicokiris, a manager with the accounting firm of Mahoney, Cohen & Company in New York, took place yesterday at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club. Rabbi Ronald Millstein performed the ceremony.

title: People
description: * Seymour L. Leikind has been appointed publisher of Jobson's Beverage Alcohol Group publications.

title: MILITARY LAUNCHES ITS LATEST ROCKET FOR ORBITAL LOADS
description: A Titan 2, the first of a new generation of American rockets intended to diminish the military's reliance on the troubled space shuttle, successfully carried a secret payload into orbit yesterday.

title: Strawberry Board Gives Account to Ketchum
description: After a two-month review, the Strawberry Advisory Board has picked Ketchum Advertising/San Francisco to represent its product, a member of the genus Fragaria that is commonly known as the strawberry. The budget is between $1 million and $2 million.

title: Cocoa Group Begins Talks
description: The 37-nation International Cocoa Organization began discussions here today to resolve their differences regarding price supports for cocoa.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Tuesday New-Car Sales August Wednesday None Thursday Consumer Credit July Friday Producer Prices August

title: Parking Near the Theater? Watch Out for Hydrants
description: Parking next to a fire hydrant in Manhattan's theater district is, for many visitors, as much a part of a night out as a drink at intermission.

title: NASA to Probe Heavens for Clues to Life's Origins on Earth
description: A MAJOR new round of probes to the inner and outer reaches of the solar system could yield important clues about how life began on Earth, say scientists who study the mystery of life's origins.

title: On Horse Racing; Tracks Get Set for Fall Lineup
description: The calendar says that autumn does not begin until the equinox on Sept. 22, but as everyone who goes back to work the day after Labor Day can tell you, it feels as though it starts today. The same is true for thoroughbred racing's best season.

title: Oil Output Off California
description: Oil production from Federal waters off California should double by 1992, according to an Interior Department official. William Bettenberg, director of the department's Minerals Management Service, said last week that production from platforms for which permits already had been granted should bring the total to 200,000 to 225,000 barrels a day.

title: Canada to Give Indigenous People An Arctic Area the Size of Texas
description: Canada passed a major milestone today on the way to a long-delayed land settlement with its indigenous people. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney signed an agreement that will give 39,000 Indians, Eskimos and people of mixed ancestry living along the boundaries of the Arctic Ocean ownership of an area the size of Texas.

title: Guide Is Key to Writers' Software
description: THE proliferation of word-processing programs, all accomplishing pretty much the same basic tasks and each requiring a largely different set of commands to do so, can present a serious problem for many users.

title: Treasury's Offerings Are Limited to Bills
description: Treasury financings for the holiday-shortened week are confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills.

title: Fireworks Kill Man in Illinois
description: An explosion in a fireworks display marking Labor Day weekend killed a 28-year-old man in his hometown, officials said today. The victim, Scott F. Broster, who returned to practice law in this southern Illinois town of 2,300 people about a year ago, was helping set off the fireworks when the accident happened Sunday night, Mayor Jack Hagedorn said. Mr. Broster was flown by helicopter to Welborn Baptist Hospital in Evansville, Ind., where he was dead on arrival, a nursing supervisor said.

title: Patterns
description: Whither Frye Boots?

title: Michael Swidler Wed To Julie Greifer on L.I.
description: At the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I., Julie Greifer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ira Greifer of Manhasset Hills, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Swidler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Swidler of East Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony.

title: Misery Rises With Rivers In Bangladesh
description: Wad-ing through waist-deep water late last week in the Muhammadpur residential district of the capital, Iqbal Ahmed, his few belongings on his shoulder, headed for the school on the Mirpur Road, which was still unaffected by the devastating floods.

title: Presidential Mementos
description: It is a bit of a journey from the capital to West Branch, Iowa, but for connoisseurs of Presidential trivia, it might be worth the trip to view the Herbert Hoover Library's exhibition of artifacts relating to 39 Presidents.

title: Pernod in Friendly Offer for Irish Distillers
description: Pernod-Ricard S.A., France's largest wine and spirits company, today announced a friendly takeover offer for Irish Distillers Group P.L.C. and said it already owned or had been promised 51.8 percent of the shares of Ireland's leading whisky maker.

title: Drexel Official to Focus On Overseas Research
description: ''I've been accumulating stress points,'' said Alan Benasuli, a securities analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert. ''I've got a new job, I'm moving to a new town, and I just got married.''

title: Bridge
description: The Epson Worldwide Pairs, played early in June, was a popular success with an underlying political problem. Should South Africa be included?

title: Robert Bass's Year of Major Deals
description: From all appearances, Robert M. Bass is having an active year as a deal maker.

title: Accord With One Defendant In Big Power Agency Case
description: Lawyers representing investors in the Washington Public Power Supply System said yesterday that they had reached a $20 million settlement with one of the defendants in a huge securities fraud trial scheduled to begin this week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The most expensive rescue of a single savings association was announced. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board agreed to the sale of the largest insolvent institution, the $30 billion American Savings and Loan Association of California, to the Robert M. Bass Group. The Fort Worth-based investor group will inject $550 million into American. The Federal agency will spend $2 billion in the transaction, and it will own 30 percent of American. [ Page A1. ] Robert Bass has chalked up a series of big, attention-getting deals this year, including the sale of the Plaza Hotel and the buyout of Bell & Howell. He is also making overtures to Macmillan. [ D5. ] The economy grew at a slower rate in August, according to a survey of the nation's purchasing managers. Sharp declines were reported in the growth of export orders and in inventories, but the monthly report predicted strong gains in the third quarter. [ D1. ] The U.S. market has not been completely open to foreign makers of computer chips. Numerous distributors say the leading American semiconductor companies have long had a policy that prevents their distributors from selling products made by Japanese and South Korean competitors. [ D1. ] A consulting engineering firm will pay $20 million to be excused from a securities fraud suit stemming from the default on $2.25 billion in bonds by the Washington Public Power Supply System. A trial of the remaining defendants is set to begin Wednesday. [ D9. ] Stock prices closed 1 percent higher yesterday in London. In Tokyo, the Nikkei average lost 0.53 percent. Trading was light in both markets. [ D6. ] The dollar edged higher in Europe. [ D6. ] COMPANIES Pernod-Ricard announced a friendly offer for Irish Distillers. The wine and spirits company, France's largest, said it owned or had been promised 51.8 percent of Irish Distillers' shares. The offer came after a hostile bidder, Grand Metropolitan, increased its bid to about $480 million, from $366 million. Irish Distillers makes Jameson, Bushmills and Power's Irish whiskies. [ D1. ] France ruffled feathers by opposing auto-emissions standards for Europe. The opposition was led by Peugeot, which apparently feared that the proposed accord could reduce its share of the small-car market. In response, European environmentalists have suggested a boycott of Peugeot products. [ D1. ] Barneys New York opens its first satellite store today, shrugging off Wall Street layoffs and a grim retail outlook. The new store, devoted exclusively to men's clothes, is in the World Financial Center, part of Battery Park City in lower Manhattan. [ D1. ] Dow agreed to acquire Essex Chemical for about $366 million, rescuing the chemicals and drug maker from a hostile bid by Gurit-Heberlein. The price of $36 a share exceeded by $2.25 the closing stock price of Essex last week. Gurit-Heberlein's last offer was said to be between $32 and $36 a share. [ D2. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS More men are drinking diet soft drinks, and the companies that make them are putting more men in their commercials. The advertisements, which once featured slender women on the beach, now show professional football players at practice. Advertising. [ D11. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS There is less pressure to raise short-term interest rates in light of weaker-than-expected jobs data for August. The report suggested that other statistics would show that economic activity has fallen from its blistering pace earlier this year. Credit Markets. [ D7. ] Significant changes may be near for H.M.O.'s. Congress is putting the final touches on legislation that may make the health maintenance organizations more attractive to employers while potentially sapping the profitability of the health-care providers. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Anheuser-Busch is test-marketing a new dry beer, similar to one that has been successful in Japan. It is another move aimed at increasing the already commanding market share of the company, the world's largest brewer. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Bush Cuts Fish and Baits His Opponent
description: Vice President Bush began his final push for the Presidency today, extolling American patriotism, slashing his Democratic opponent and, with equal enthusiasm and less precision, taking a knife to an inert but telegenic white sea bass.

title: U.S. Pledges $2 Billion in Rescue Of Biggest Insolvent Savings Unit
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today announced the most expensive rescue of a single savings and loan association on record in a transaction that will cost the agency $2 billion.

title: Blues Trade Gilmour
description: Doug Gilmour, the center who is the target of a lawsuit alleging sexual misconduct with a minor, was traded by the St. Louis Blues yesterday to the Calgary Flames along with the right wing Mark Hunter and two other players. In return, St. Louis received the forward Mike Bullard, the defenseman Craig Coxe and the rights to the defenseman Tim Corkery.

title: Dukakis Seeks to Rally Middle Class
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis set out on the final stretch of his Presidential campaign today with a rallying cry for the middle class, asserting that average families could not afford four more years of Republican rule and promising to ''bring prosperity home.''

title: Who Needs Debates?
description: Roger Ailes, media consultant to George Bush, calls it ''baloney'' that a series of Bush-Dukakis debates would be good for the country. Voters would watch only one or two of them, he told a recent interviewer, and besides, ''I don't think you learn anything about the issues'' from Presidential debates.

title: Jets' Learning Process Begins
description: The Jets' long season is under way. The players had an unscheduled practice today to go over mistakes in Sunday's 28-3 loss to the Patriots, and Coach Joe Walton spoke of having patience ''up to a point.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: Beber Silverstein Forms LaDonne & Wilner Unit
description: Beber Silverstein & Partners, Miami, has set up a theatrical advertising unit in its New York office with the help of Peter LaDonne and Jon Wilner. They previously ran Fisher/ LaDonne/Wilner Entertainment, which totaled more than $10 million in billings last year from creating ads for Broadway hits like ''La Cage Aux Folles'' and ''Into the Woods.''

title: Tribute to Don Erickson
description: A memorial tribute to Don Erickson, an editor on the staff of The New York Times Magazine, who died on Aug. 2, will be held on Wednesday, Sept. 14, at noon in the second-floor auditorium of the McGraw-Hill Building at the Avenue of the Americas and 49th Street.

title: U.S. Open; Krickstein Upsets Edberg in Five Sets
description: Aaron Krickstein was supposed to be the next dominant American player, a role that was unclaimed until the emergence of Andre Agassi this year. He was only 16 years old when he made headlines at the 1983 United States Open, becoming the youngest player ever to reach the round of 16 in the men's draw. Among the players he beat was Stefan Edberg, a promising young Swede, destined to be a Wimbledon champion.

title: Japan and the World: Applying Assertiveness Training to a Foreign Policy
description: Japan is struggling, sometimes against its own instincts, to break away from its follow-the-leader foreign policy and take more initiatives on its own.

title: U.S. HALTS TALKS ON BASES IN GREECE
description: Talks on the future of American military bases were indefinitely postponed today after the Greek Government notified United States negotiators that it would close one of the bases.

title: New Look at the F.T.C.
description: It will be a case of the former regulators assessing the current regulators.

title: Simms And The Big Risk
description: IN the first half, the Redskins' defense was jumping around and confusing the Giants' offensive line as Phil Simms called signals.

title: Charge in Fatal Crash Is Drunken Driving
description: A Westchester County man was arrested on drunken-driving charges after his car slammed into a telephone pole, killing one passenger and critically injuring another, the Southampton police said yesterday.

title: Nothing New Under the Cubs' Lights
description: LEAD: Angry residents of the area surrounding Chicago's Wrigley Field say they are planning to sue to stop the playing of night baseball. Calling themselves CUBS - Citizens United for Baseball and Sunshine - they complain that their neighborhood's nocturnal peace is being shattered by crowds streaming in and out of the ballpark.

title: Brother of Seoul's Ex-Leader Is Found Guilty of Corruption
description: Chun Kyung Hwan, younger brother of South Korea's former President, was found guilty today of embezzlement and bribe-taking in a corruption case that has become a lightning rod for public anger at the abuses of his brother's Government.

title: Farm Conservation Reserve Has Drought Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Scuffle Ends Food Handouts
description: Fifty people were arrested today when a group trying to distribute free food and leaflets scuffled with the police, who had previously warned the group to get a permit or move.

title: 3 Guards Hurt in Prison Fight
description: Three prison guards were injured, none seriously, when about 100 inmates surrounded the officers during a recreation period at the Elmira Correctional Facility, a union official said. The officers were injured Sunday night after they tried to break up a fight between two inmates, one of whom was stabbed, said Dennis Middaugh, president of Local 1240 of the municipal employee union. The guards were punched and one was slashed, he said.

title: Group Plans TV Station For Jewish Audience
description: A group wants to start what it believes would be the first television station in the country that offers a full slate of programming aimed at a Jewish audience.

title: Topics of The Times; Mr. Quayle's 'Pretty Face'
description: If George Bush wanted Dan Quayle on his ticket partly to close the gender gap, the choice has already produced one advance for women.

title: Labor Day '88: A Time to Play and Parade
description: Encouraged by sunny skies and enabled by an extra day off, New Yorkers thronged city streets yesterday for a pair of outdoor events - one featuring the Caribbean, the other organized labor, but both tinged with the political striving that Labor Day, as the unofficial end of summer, traditionally begins.

title: Navy Recruit Held In Killing of Brother
description: A 22-year-old Navy recruit was arraigned on a murder charge yesterday in the fatal shooting of his older brother.

title: Political Marketing; For TV, Candidates Stage an Opening Day for a Campaign in Full Swing
description: The traditional Labor Day opening of a Presidential campaign that has really been under way for weeks was observed yesterday by thousands of Americans who spent part of their holiday in the company of the candidates and millions more who watched them attack each other on television.

title: Amnesty Rock Tour Performs Twice in Paris
description: Bruce Springsteen, Sting, Peter Gabriel, Tracy Chapman, Youssou N'Dour and other performers in Amnesty International's rock concert tour made the French capital their second stop, with concerts yesterday and today.

title: Iraq Asserts Its Authority in a Kurdish Stronghold
description: Iraqi troops pursuing rebellious Kurdish guerrillas dug in today at their border with Turkey, hoisting aloft their banners to assert authority over an area the rebels had long claimed to control themselves.

title: Israeli Labor Party Opens Campaign; Asks Halt in Rule Over Arabs
description: The Israeli Labor Party opened its campaign for the Nov. 1 parliamentary elections today, vowing to ''terminate Israeli rule over 1.5 million Palestinian Arabs who are inhabitants'' of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Week in Review Sunday inaccurately characterized the electoral outlook in Indiana. That state appears to be strongly Republican.

title: One Killed and Nine Injured In Crash of Plane in Alaska
description: One person was killed and nine others aboard a commercial aircraft were injured today when the plane crashed near a lake shortly after taking off from Sitka, the Coast Guard said.

title: Where's the Budget Deficit Issue?
description: Does the budget deficit really matter? The Presidential candidates have certainly been told by their advisers that a failure to bring down the deficit will make it far more difficult to steer a safe course between inflation and recession in coming years. But neither George Bush nor Michael Dukakis seems to see political advantage in advancing a realistic proposal for deficit reduction.

title: 2 Publications Starting For Specific Audiences
description: Hot off the press is the premier issue of Corporate Video Decisions, issued by Act III Publishing. With a controlled circulation, the new publication is intended for some 40,000 decision makers in the corporate video market. Joseph J. Allen is the publisher, and James Kaminsky is the editor. The cover price is $5.

title: Surging Mets Stretch Lead to 10 Games
description: Eleven victories over the Pittsburgh Pirates in 15 games played. And now, 10 games in front with 25 to go.

title: Non-Cubans on the Rise in Hispanic Florida
description: South and Central Americans, overshadowed for years by the Cubans in the large Hispanic community here, are making significant demographic and economic gains, Latin leaders and other experts say.

title: INSIDE
description: Space Clues to Life on Earth Space probes are seeking evidence to support the theory that the universe is awash with the chemical precursors of life. Science Times, page C1. Japan's Foreign Policy Shedding a shyness born of its defeat in World War II, Japan is beginning to assert itself on the diplomatic stage.

title: Two Reagan Speeches Today
description: President Reagan spent the last day of a three-week stay at his mountaintop ranch horseback-riding with his wife, Nancy, and attending to ranch chores, the White House said. On his way back to Washington on Tuesday, Mr. Reagan is to stop in Hastings, Neb., for a dedication ceremony at Hastings College, and in Louisville, Ky., where he is to address the annual American Legion convention on ''defense and security issues,'' a White House spokesman said.

title: Wide Diversity Seen on Spending to Defend Poor
description: The 50 states and the District of Columbia spend widely differing amounts to represent criminal defendants who cannot afford a lawyer, the Justice Department reported today.

title: Sabatini Displays Her New Resolve
description: The congestion around Court 16 made it nearly impossible to move, people milling, shoving, blustering their way toward the small grandstand already filled above capacity. On the court, Stephanie Rehe said, she could almost feel the crowd, the noise and commotion a constant distraction. It was just the kind of scene Gabriela Sabatini might have found unnerving in the past, creating a mood for an upset.

title: Less Pressure on Fed to Lift Rates
description: Pressure on the Federal Reserve Board to push up short-term interest rates again soon has eased somewhat, credit market analysts say, as the Government's first report for August activity showed signs that an economic slowdown may have begun.

title: Investor Buys Donnay Stake
description: A tentative deal was reached Friday for the French business executive Bernard Tapie to take a majority share in Donnay S.A., the Belgian sporting goods maker that went bankrupt last month, officials said.

title: Suit Opposes Lucky's Deal
description: The Attorney General of California, John Van de Kamp, has filed suit to challenge the American Stores Company's acquisition of Lucky Stores Inc., contending the merger was anti-competitive.

title: Stocks Up in London, Off in Tokyo
description: Share prices closed higher in London today, helped by bullish sentiment from United States employment figures released on Friday.

title: Peary and Cook, Two Names Writ in Ice
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Comdisco Disaster Recovery Services Inc., Rosemont, Ill., a subsidiary of Comdisco Inc. that provides computer disaster-recovery services, named John A. Jackson executive vice president.

title: Giants' Defense Makes Its Points
description: It is one thing for a defense to force turnovers. It is quite another for a defense to score off them.

title: Sharing the Defense Burden: Allies Are Listening
description: For the last 20 years, a specter has periodically haunted the closets of capitals in the Western alliance: fear of a major reduction in the number of American troops stationed in Europe and Asia.

title: Barnard's First 100 Years
description: Most American colleges had modest beginnings, and Barnard, about to embark on its yearlong centennial celebration, was no exception. It started out with several rooms in a Madison Avenue brownstone, a handful of students, a few teachers and some chairs with writing arms.

title: Gert Frobe, an Actor, Dies at 75
description: Gert Frobe, the German actor who starred as Goldfinger in the James Bond film of that name, died of a heart attack today in a Munich hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: Dollar Edges Up in Europe
description: The dollar edged higher in Europe today, but trading was quiet as dealers waited for the United States market, closed for the Labor Day holiday, to set the direction on Tuesday.

title: Like Autumn's Air, Sales Are a Bit Cool
description: The snap in the air that signals the onset of autumn also prompts clothes-minded shoppers to seek out the newest styles. At least this is the hope of retail executives. Still reeling from months of flat sales, they are facing the season with a mixture of cautious optimism, carefully planned strategies for recovery and an urgent need for a look that will lead the way.

title: Big Chill on Asian Chips in U.S.
description: Samsung Semiconductor, a South Korean company trying to increase sales of its computer chips in the United States, achieved a major breakthrough in July. Arrow Electronics Inc., the nation's second-largest distributor of semiconductors, agreed to sell its products.

title: Ads for Diet Soft Drinks Look New
description: REMEMBER when diet soft drinks were promoted on television only by curvaceous women in bikinis?

title: France Balks At Pact to Cut Car Pollution
description: Pushed by Peugeot, France is battling other European nations over proposals to tighten automobile emissions standards, and some environmental groups are now threatening to boycott the auto maker for its role in scuttling an agreement to reduce standards for small cars.

title: 'Model' for U.S. Schools
description: IN his final address last week, Secretary of Education William J. Bennett praised seven schools as models for excellence in elementary education. One of them was School No. 59, Science Magnet, in Buffalo.

title: Back to Classes in Jersey: Concern Over the City-Suburb Gap
description: The painting, cleaning and waxing are done, the desks arranged and the supplies and class lists checked in New Jersey's 2,247 public schools. But this year, as more than a million students return to class, there are new concerns about the quality of education in poor urban districts.

title: Top Law Firms Give Free Services to the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Says Younger Families Miss Benefits Of Prosperity
description: The benefits of an improved economy have bypassed young American families, who face an era of vanishing dreams, according to a new study by the Children's Defense Fund.

title: Evening Kris Wins Jerome
description: An old master and his protege scored with 3-year-old colts on different fronts yesterday as Woody Stephens sent out Posen to win the $147,500 Rutgers Handicap at The Meadowlands and Phil Gleaves, his former assistant, saddled Evening Kris to win the $294,000 Jerome Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: 2 Teams Find Huge Bones in West
description: A MID growing suspense and excitement, two separate teams of paleontologists in the West are slowly extracting from the ground enormous fossil bones. One of the groups may soon be able to claim the discovery of the longest dinosaur ever known.

title: Green Holds On In Canadian Open
description: Cold, strong winds put a touch of fear into Ken Green this morning even though he held a three-stroke lead with seven holes to play in the 79th Canadian Open.

title: A Lifeguard Helps Rescue Boat Off L.I.
description: A man on a disabled boat was rescued when a lifeguard swam to it through fog and a heavy sea and used his orange surfboard to attract a Coast Guard searchlight, the police said yesterday.

title: E.P.A. Forms Unit to Study Medical Trash
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has formed a new task force to coordinate its responses to the threat of pollution by medical wastes.

title: Rumanian Defects
description: Daniela Costain of Rumania, who had the longest discus throw of the year at one point and was considered a medal contender for the Olympics, has been granted asylum in Turkey and is seeking to immigrate to Australia. A spokesman for the Australian immigration department said the request was being considered and that Costain could be allowed to enter the country under a special category for ''people with something to offer.''

title: N.F.L. Notebook; A Tough Week For Quarterbacks
description: The season's first week reminded several teams of an ugly lesson already learned: no matter how much preparation goes into preseason, no method prevents the havoc injury can bring. Especially at quarterback. Ask Joe Montana, the San Francisco 49er quarterback. Montana threw three third-quarter touchdown passes against the New Orleans Saints and then had to leave the game due to a bruised elbow on his right, or throwing, arm. San Francisco won, 34-33, but Montana is listed as probable this Sunday when the 49ers play the Giants at the Meadowlands.

title: Revo Chooses Tarlow
description: Revo Inc. of San Jose, Calif., has awarded its sunglasses business to Tarlow Advertising, which opened in January. The current budget of $2 million is expected to rise significantly. Advertising will be print, mainly in magazines. The former agency was Della Femina, Travisano & Partners in Los Angeles.

title: New Barneys Store Aims At Men in Wall Street Area
description: Barneys New York, which started out six decades ago as a clothing discounter and evolved into a major retailer of international men's wear, opens its first satellite store this morning in the World Financial Center, right on the edge of Manhattan's financial district.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Activated Rick Bryan, defensive end; Scott Case, cornerback; John Rade, linebacker, and Rick Donnelly, punter. Placed Tim Green, linebacker, and James Milling, wide receiver, on injured reserve. Released Lewis Colbert, punter, and Tom Strauthers, defensive end. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Re-signed Darrell Colbert, wide receiver. Released J.R. Ambrose, wide receiver. MINNESOTA (NFC) - Activated Darrin Nelson, running back, and Gary Zimmerman, tackle. Waived Mark MacDonald, guard. Placed Brian Habib, defensive tackle, on injured reserve. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Announced that Kenneth Sims, defensive end, will miss the remainder of the season with a reptured Achilles' tendon. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Placed Steve Trapilo, guard, on injured reserve. Signed Mark MacDonald, guard. GIANTS (NFC) - Activated Carl Banks, linebacker. Placed John Carter, defensive lineman, on injured reserve. PHOENIX (NFC) - Placed Tony Jeffery, running back, and Andy Schillinger, wide receiver, on the two-man inactive list. SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Waived Max Runager, punter. Re-signed Barry Helton, punter. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Traded Jay Schroeder, quarterback, to the Los Angeles Raiders for Jim Lachey, offensive lineman, and several conditional draft choices. Activated Mike Scully, center. Placed Stan Humphries, quarterback, on the non-football-injury list.

title: Essex Chemical Agrees To $366 Million Dow Bid
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it had agreed to act as a ''white knight'' and acquire the Essex Chemical Corporation for $36 a share, or about $366 million. The offer was $2.25 more than the Friday closing price of Essex's stock on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Johnson for Bronx District Attorney
description: The sudden death last year of Mario Merola, who had served with distinction for 14 years as District Attorney of the Bronx, left a sizable gap in New York City's criminal justice hierarchy. In a race that may be the most important in New York's Sept. 15 Democratic primary, four men seek to replace him. The best is Robert Johnson, an experienced prosecutor who has also served as a defense lawyer and judge.

title: Manila Is Said to Reject U.S. Proposal on Bases
description: The United States has offered to more than double its aid commitment to the Philippines in exchange for guarantees on the use of American military bases there for the next two years, a State Department official said today. But the official said the Government in Manila had rejected the offer, which amounted to about $360 million a year, and was seeking an annual aid package of $1.2 billion.

title:
Market Place;
Busch Is the First To Test Dry Beer
description: LEAD: ARE American beer drinkers, who already have a dizzying choice of premium, foreign, light, low-alcohol and draft beers, not to mention ales and malt liquors, thirsty for yet another kind of beer?

title: Remembering Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: Lendl Bid Denied
description: A Congressional bid to grant Ivan Lendl immediate American citizenship so he can play on the United States Olympic tennis team has failed because Czechoslovak officials refused to provide the necessary waivers, lawmakers said.

title: Our Towns; Summer Combat: Beach-Seat War Amid the Dunes
description: The Town of Hempstead started its crackdown on June 25. There were reports that a man was bringing his own chair to the town beach at Atlantic Beach Estates, a clear-cut violation of 78-41! Town law requires that anyone at that beach who wants a chair must rent said chair from the concessionaire. Or else!

title: Primaries for House Combine Issues and Infighting
description: Drug abuse is an issue that is cutting across the lines of Congressional Districts and urban, suburban and even rural constituencies in seven primary contests for Democratic Congressional nominations, from poor areas of Brooklyn to middle-class and affluent Hudson Valley towns and counties.

title: Giants' Rally Beats Redskins
description: After a week of controversy and uncertainty, the Giants opened their season this evening by edging the Washington Redskins, 27-20.

title: Computers Create Electronic 'Cadavers' For Anatomy Lessons
description: IN a novel approach to teaching the intricate details of human anatomy, some medical schools are experimenting with advanced computer-imaging techniques to create electronic ''cadavers.'' Systems are being designed so that young medical students can ''dissect'' electronic images, rather than using real cadavers for their initial lessons.

title: Business and Health; Changes Near In H.M.O. Law
description: AFTER more than a year of haggling in Congress, significant revisions to the 15-year-old law that gave health maintenance organizations entree into American health care are close to being enacted. By eliminating some protections and restrictions for health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s, the legislation could make them more attractive to employers. At the same time, it could hurt the profitability of some of these companies, which provide health care at a prepaid price.

title: Who Raises Taxes, Republicans or Democrats?; Carter Presaged Reagan
description: To the Editor:

title: Baku Journal; Citadel of Privilege, Where Now the Masses Marry
description: Geidar A. Aliyev, the former party leader of the Azerbaijani Republic, is recalled by his admirers as a gracious host and by his detractors, including the Soviet press, as a notorious toady.

title: Of Face Lifts And Feminism
description: LEAD: ''You have to suffer to be beautiful,'' my mother used to say, tugging at her girdle. Beauty, or the quest for it - like childbearing - was woman's burden, proudly borne. My mother dressed painfully, enduring high heels and a cinched waist, just as she endured her pregnancies.

title: By Design; The Lowdown on Heels
description: Something is afoot in shoes, and it's a boon for women who walk a lot. Those towering heels that have been de rigueur for dress-up occasions in recent seasons are inching downward.

title: King of Elms Stricken With a Fatal Disease
description: THE reigning king of American elms, a 125-foot behemoth on a farm in Southeast Virginia, is stricken with Dutch elm disease and has only a year to live, according to experts in arboreal medicine.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Lightning apparently does not command the respect it deserves as a dangerous killer.'' - E. W. Friday, director of the National Weather Service, commenting about a rise in lightning-related injuries last year. [ C7:6. ]

title: A Good View of Mars
description: Mars will move to within about 36 million miles of Earth this month, the closest it has been in 17 years.

title: Helping Detroit Take Care of Niches
description: A new Ford Mustang convertible rolls off the assembly line here every few minutes, ready to be shipped to a Ford dealer for sale to someone who thinks the sunshine and wind in their hair is worth an extra $4,000.

title: Dissident Group Says It Shot Eldest Son of Iraqi President
description: An Iraqi opposition group backed by Iran said today that its agents in Baghdad had shot and seriously wounded the eldest son of President Saddam Hussein.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: NATO Spying Debacle: Bonanza for Soviet Bloc
description: The loss of war plans for the defense of the American-controlled sector of the NATO front could be the most serious aspect of the espionage operation uncovered in West Germany last month. Western officials say

title: 2 Film Archives to Preserve the Eastwood Oeuvre
description: The Man With No Name is joining the movies' great names - the Capras, the Welleses, the Hitchcocks, the Walshes, the Bergmans (Ingrid and Ingmar) and all the others whose life and work have become the subject of serious film study.

title: Cocaine: Litany of Fetal Risks Grows
description: THE first detailed studies of babies exposed to cocaine before birth suggest that this widely used drug is causing an epidemic of damaged infants, some of whom may be impaired for life because their mothers used cocaine even briefly during pregnancy.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, some copies of the Times were incorrectly assembled yesterday. No pages were missing, but page 23 should have been the start of the second section.

title: 3 Governors Visit Japan
description: Three United States Governors met with Japanese officials today and appealed for more investment in their states. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Buddy Roemer of Louisiana and Ray Mabus of Mississippi said their states' economies have been damaged by declines in manufacturing and the oil industry. But they emphasized that the region is rich in assets Japan needs. The three Democrats urged

title: North Korean Pledge
description: North Korea pledged today that it would not disrupt the Olympic Games in South Korea and charged that any incident marring the Games would be an American-South Korean plot to create an excuse to invade the North.

title: 2 Space Shuttle Missions in 1989 to Be Postponed
description: In a blow to space scientists, two of the nine space shuttle flights planned for next year are to be delayed, and with them key astronomical missions, according to a new shuttle-launching schedule made public last week by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Television Ads Show 7.9% Rise
description: Commercial television advertising grew 7.9 percent, to $11.83 billion, in the first half of 1988, from $10.96 billion a year earlier, according to the Television Bureau of Advertising.

title: Thompson Beats Rivals For Software Account
description: J. Walter Thompson/USA has won the Computer Associates account over Della Femina, McNamee WCRS and Campbell-Mithun-Esty. The budget is $7 million.

title: No Escape of Radiation Seen In Fire at a Lithuanian Plant
description: A nuclear power plant caught fire in Lithuania today, but automatic safety systems put out the flames before radiation was released, the official Tass press agency reported. Tass said no one was injured in the blaze, which began at 12:50 A.M. in a control cable of the second reactor at the Ignalina nuclear power plant, about 60 miles northeast of Vilnius, the capital of the Lithuanian Republic.

title: Red Sox Alone In First Place
description: Larry Parrish hit his fourth home run in five games and Mike Smithson earned his first victory since July 23 as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 4-1, tonight and took sole possession of first place in the American League East.

title: Gold as Radiation Shield
description: GOLD, one of the heaviest chemical elements, is the basis of a new lightweight plastic foam under development as a radiation shield.

title: Workers Repair Final Cable, Ending Seattle's Power Loss
description: Utility crews completed repairs today on the last of six electricity cables damaged in a fire that caused a loss of power in 50 blocks of downtown Seattle for nearly four days.

title: Review/Television; 150 Years of Surgery In 'The Brutal Craft'
description: ''The Brutal Craft'' takes us back 150 years, to an era when limbs were sawed off without benefit of anesthesia, cleanliness was of little matter to surgeons and blood transfusions were unknown. This first installment of a new four-part series on ''Nova'' called ''Pioneers of Surgery'' will be shown tonight at 8 on Channel 21 and at 9 on Channel 13.

title: Labor Movement in Britain Ousts a Major Union
description: The 330,000-member electricians' union was expelled from the Trades Union Congress today, causing the most serious split in decades in the once all-powerful British union movement.

title: A Pizza Hut For Beijing
description: Pizza Hut will soon join Kentucky Fried Chicken in bringing American fast food to China's capital.

title: As Drought Wanes, Shippers Look to Future
description: Shipping companies, the Coast Guard and the Army Corps of Engineers are joining in an effort to make sure the bottlenecks that idled Mississippi River traffic during this summer's drought will not recur, a shipping executive says.

title: Penguins Are Off Limits For Tots in Strollers
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran's Prime Minister Reported to Quit Post
description: Prime Minister Mir Hussein Moussavi resigned Monday after seven years in office, but will remain as a caretaker premier until a successor is named, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported today.

title: Alexander & Baldwin Plans to Select a Chief
description: Alexander & Baldwin Inc., founded in 1880 by two Hawaiian missionaries, is making plans to select its 14th chief executive. The preparations for the management shift that is not expected before April 1991 are as gradual and deliberate as the company's style.

title: Southern Papers Move Up Front in National Political Coverage
description: A generation after the civil rights movement began on their hometown streets, Southern newspapers have emerged as a major voice in the coverage of national politics.
