description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 4,1988: TUESDAY Chyron Corp Cincinnati Bell WEDNESDAY Ames Dept Stores Portland Gen Co Browning-Ferris Ind Premier Industrial Handleman Co Stanhome Inc Louisville G & E LS Starrett Co Penwalt Corp Witco Corp Phillips-Van Heusen THURSDAY Allegheny Power Hancock Fabric Brown Group Idaho Power Engelhard Corp Rykoff-Sexton Inc General Host SPS Technologies Green Mountain Power Trinity Indus FRIDAY Aluminum Co America Mercantile Stores DeSoto Inc Nerco Inc Helmerich & Payne

title: Books of The Times
description: Clara Bow Runnin' Wild By David Stenn 338 pages. Illustrated. Doubleday. $18.95.

title: Quayle Embraces Patriotic Themes and Attacks Dukakis on Pledge
description: At a Labor Day rally at the base of the Statue of Liberty, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, Dan Quayle, began a new attack on Michael S. Dukakis for the Democrat's opposition to making the Pledge of Allegiance a mandatory start of the school day.

title: Gene Studies Emerging As Key Engine of Science
description: THE science of genetics is fast becoming what geneticists always knew it was: the central and most provocative science of life.

title: Celebrity Promotion
description: People old enough to remember Kate Smith or Bugs Bunny singing ''Buy a Bond Today'' on behalf of the United States Treasury in World War II may think that kind of promotional effort is a thing of the past.

title: Kelly's Savvy Sparks Rally
description: When the season began, Roberto Kelly was the Yankees' center fielder. Five months later, he shares a clubhouse locker with Randy Velarde.

title: Compromise to Halt Fines Eludes Yonkers Mayor and City Council
description: With $192,000 in contempt-of-court fines due today, the Mayor and the City Council of Yonkers struggled again yesterday for a compromise to carry out a court-ordered housing desegregation plan and resolve the political turmoil that has threatened the city with bankruptcy.

title: A Holiday Tries to Cling To Its Origins
description: To many of the people marching in the parade up Fifth Avenue yesterday, the point of having a Labor Day holiday was clear.

title: Newly Discovered Fish
description: While exploring inland waterways in one of the last tracts of rain forest left on the island of Madagascar, scientists from the American Museum of Natural History recently identified a previously unknown species of fish.

title: Laurie Nell Mayers Weds Michael G. Rosenberg
description: Laurie Nell Mayers, a daughter of Audrey Poole of Bedford, N.Y., and Lawrence S. Mayers of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Gaston Rosenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Rosenberg of Weston, Conn. Rabbi Stephen Pearce performed the ceremony at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Markets Closed
description: Federal, state and local government offices were closed yesterday because of the Labor Day holiday. The stock and commodity markets, banks and many businesses were also closed.

title: Taiwan to Buy 4 U.S. Jets
description: Taiwan said today that it would buy four passenger airlines from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to help lower Taiwan's trade surplus with the United States. A spokesman for the Civil Aeronautics Administration said the Government would sign a contract on Tuesday with the St. Louis-based company for four MD-11 aircraft worth $450 million. ''This will be the second-largest order we've offered to the U.S. aircraft company,'' the spokesman said. Last February, Taiwan signed a $774 million agreement to buy five passenger planes and a cargo jet from the Boeing Company.

title: Africa Prepares Biological Assault On Scourge of Its Chief Food Crop
description: A RESEARCH institute here is abuzz with biological ammunition for a war to save Africa's largest food crop.

title: From Philip Roth, 'The Facts' as He Remembers Them
description: Q. Now vee may perhaps to begin. You were born in Newark, on March 19, 1933. Your parents, Herman and Bess Roth, named you Philip. You are a writer, primarily a novelist. But now, seated in your publisher's office at Farrar, Straus & Giroux, you say that you have written an autobiography, entitled ''The Facts.'' Why an autobiography?

title: U.S. Bomb Squad Is Growing
description: The military's bomb squad is nearly doubling as the United States tries to respond to world terrorism, a Navy officer says.

title: Theater Is Vandalized In 'Temptation' Protest
description: Vandals slashed seats at the Cineplex Odeon Showcase Theater and spray-painted threats against a studio executive early today in an apparent protest against the film ''The Last Temptation of Christ,'' the police said.

title: More Medical Tests for Tyson
description: Mike Tyson remained in stable condition yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after an automobile accident Sunday in Catskill, N.Y.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Bangladesh is one vast swamp and what you're confronted with is rebuilding a country. I hate to sound hyperbolic, but this could be one of the largest natural disasters of the century.'' - Thomas Drahman, Asia regional manager of CARE. [ A1:6. ]

title: The Editorial Notebook; Like the Brain of a Bee
description: An intriguing computing structure known as a neural network is attracting a growing circle of fans. Darpa, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, is the latest recruit and plans a large investment in the field. The prize is better understanding of the human brain, and devices better able to mimic certain of its functions.

title: Regis Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $1.6 million for salon restructuring.

title: Auto Sales in Late August Called Brisk Despite Drop
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks remained brisk in late August, industry analysts said, although the auto makers reported an estimated 2.1 percent decline from the comparable period last year.

title: High Ground Is a Stranger In Bangladesh
description: Bangladesh is a nation seemingly founded on unstable footing.

title: Bonn Reports Growth Rate At High 3.9%
description: West Germany today reported a lively growth in its gross national product for the first half of 1988, at an annualized rate of 3.9 percent. That offered strong support for the latest Government predictions that the economy would grow by at least 3 percent this year.

title: Washington Talk: The Cabinet; As Reagan Clock Ticks, Thornburgh's Pounds
description: For an Attorney General of the United States, Dick Thornburgh may have the ideal resume: lawyer, former United States Attorney, former head of the Justice Department's criminal division, former Governor, Ivy League academic.

title: S O S For The U.N.
description: The United Nations has long been lurching into disrepair, ineptitude and impotence. The main thing done about it was to ignore the world organization. But since the Soviet Union unexpectedly changed its position, chances are starting to improve for making it work.

title: A.T.&T. Raises Holdings in Sun
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has raised its stake in Sun Microsystems Inc. to 9.7 percent, or 3.5 million shares, from 7.1 percent.

title: Suit Is Filed By Motorola
description: Motorola Inc. has sued a Silicon Valley competitor, the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation, and five former Motorola employees, accusing them of taking part in a conspiracy to steal trade secrets.

title: Economic Scene; Government Aid And Child Care
description: Does Uncle Sam belong in the day care business? How far in?

title: Sports People; Boy, 11, Swims Channel
description: An 11-year-old English boy crawled ashore in Dover yesterday after setting a record as the youngest person to swim the English Channel, the Channel Swimming Association said. Thomas Gregory, age 11 years and 333 days, broke the record set in 1979 when Marcus Hooper made the 21-mile crossing from France at age 12 years 53 days. Gregory's time was 11 hours 45 minutes. Hooper's was 14 hours 37 minutes.(AP)

title: American Software Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a gain of $713,000 from an accounting change.

title: Wardair Buys Fokkers
description: Wardair Canada will purchase 24 Fokker 100 jet aircraft from N. V. Fokker, the Dutch manufacturer, it was announced today. Financial details were not disclosed. The aircraft, powered by twin Rolls-Royce engines, seats 84 to 107 passengers. It entered service with Swissair in April. Wardair's purchase brings to 110 the number of Fokker 100's sold.

title: U.S. Issues Hold Friday's Gains
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in fairly slow trading yesterday as market participants paused to reassess conditions after Friday's enormous rally.

title: I Resent This
description: LEAD: Having spent most of my working life in the newspaper business, I thought I knew something about journalism. Being on the receiving end of a media blitzkrieg, however, gives you a different perspective on the matter -fast.

title: Suspect Admits Guilt In Wells Fargo Case
description: A defendant in the $7 million Wells Fargo robbery case pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring to transport several thousand dollars in stolen money to Hartford to pay for a toy giveway for Puerto Rican children in 1985.

title: Sports People; Revision Hurts Graf
description: Peter Graf, father of Steffi, said he thought it was a conspiracy. Merrett Stierheim, executive director of the Women's International Tennis Association, called it a long overdue restructuring of the computer point system. Either way, the result will be the same: Steffi Graf, the No. 1 player in the world, will be unable to dominate the women's tour in the future the way she has the past two years. This has incensed her father, who said that Steffi may not meet her commitment of playing in 11 Virginia Slims series events in 1989, exclusive of the four Grand Slam tournaments. If that occurs, then Graf will be ineligible for the bonus pool awarded at the Virginia Slims championships in November, although she can enter any of the tournaments on the calendar. If she plays only sparingly, it could also endanger her No. 1 ranking. The ranking system is cumulative, each year carrying over from the previous one. Points are distributed on the basis of the importance of a tournament. In the past, a top player who participated in a lesser tournament to help that tournament's gate and the W.I.T.A. meet its contractual obligations was not penalized. Her overall point average was adjusted so that the event would carry the weight of a bigger tournament. On Sunday, however, in a W.I.T.A. meeting attended by 111 players, the membership voted to abolish the ''play down'' or adjustment rule. Thus, Graf, who has won 18 tournaments during the past two years, will be penalized the most, her average dropping no matter what she does next year.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: ONE of the nicest attributes of a microwave oven is the way it can make everyday fare of the grains and cereals that normally take a long time to cook and that must usually be stirred with jealous attention.

title: Sports People; Nets Re-Sign Bagley
description: John Bagley, the 6-foot point guard who was the only Net to appear in all 82 games last season, has been re-signed to a multiyear contract. Terms were not announced. The 28-year-old Bagley will be playing his second season with the Nets since joining the team with Keith Lee from the Cleveland Cavaliers in the eight-player three-team deal that sent Darryl Dawkins and James Bailey to the Utah Jazz and Cavaliers, respectively.

title: Deputy Is Assigned to Kings
description: A deputy has been assigned to provide security for the family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. for the past five months.

title: State Aides Issue Warning On Bogus Gold Investments
description: State securities regulators warned today that investors could lose an estimated $250 million this year to telephone sales pitches for investments in bogus gold mines.

title: EMC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. Hispanic Population Is Up 34% Since 1980
description: The Hispanic population of the United States has increased by more than one-third since th 1980 census, growing nearly five times faster than the rest of the population, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Dukakis Speech Marred by Clash Over Abortion
description: A speech by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis turned into an angry confrontation between anti-abortion protesters and members of the audience today, with bitter chants and counter-chants and repeated outbreaks of shoving and scuffling.

title: Government Buildings Are Looted in Burma
description: Looters plundered Government buildings and factories today, and troops newly deployed in the capital made no attempt to stop the destruction.

title: Indian Papers Close in Protest
description: Thousands of Indian journalists held a one-day strike across India today to protest Government legislation that they say will curb press freedom.

title: Education; On Homework, More May Be Less
description: More may be less when it comes to homework, the findings of a study of elementary school teachers, students and parents show.

title: Man Jailed for Refusing To Give Up Melee Tape
description: Defying a court order and disdaining professional legal help, a Manhattan artist refused again yesterday to surrender his videotape of police officers and demonstrators clashing in Tompkins Square Park and was jailed for contempt.

title: Janice Groman, 51, Dancer Who Began A Chamber Troupe
description: Janice Groman, a former member of the New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater who later founded a chamber dance company, died at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx on Friday after a long illness. She was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BANGLADESH GETS PLEDGE OF MILLIONS FOR FLOOD RELIEF
description: Donor nations have pledged millions of dollars in aid to Bangladesh, where the worst flooding in 70 years has left much of the country under water and as many as 28 million people homeless or stranded.

title: Man Charged in the Slaying of a Referee
description: A 24-year-old Queens man who was being sought for fatally beating a referee who made a disputed call during a housing project basketball game, surrendered to the police yesterday afternoon, officials said.

title: America's Cup; After Turbulence on Land, the Sparring Takes to the Water; As the Races Start, Odds Are on Conner
description: Dennis Conner plans to wear a good luck charm from New Zealand. By most predictions - not including Conner's own - he won't need it.

title: Fed Finds Continuation Of Inflation Pressures
description: Inflation pressures continue to build despite reduced optimism about the course of the economy, a new Federal Reserve survey showed today.

title: Ramona, Okla.
description: DORIS BANKES sometimes receives mail addressed simply to ''The Herb Lady in Ramona, Okla.'' What she and her husband, Virgil, started as a hobby in the greenhouse of their Tulsa home became a thriving business, the Growin Things Herb Farm, by 1983, just two years after they started. To meet the demand for fresh herbs, they moved to a farm near Ramona, in northeastern Oklahoma, in 1984. But this is oil country, and times have not been good in the last two years.

title: Panda Seems Homesick, So Zoo Closes Its Exhibit
description: The Cincinnati Zoo has closed its special exhibit of the giant panda Chia Chia for at least five days because the visiting panda is apparently homesick.

title: Different Perestroikas for Different Folks
description: LEAD: Once almost unanimous in their support of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to restructure Soviet society, Soviet intellectuals are increasingly divided in their assessment of his goals. While the right-wing Stalinist opposition to reform has attracted greater attention, the split within the left has become deeper as Mr.

title: Presidential Rivals Step Up Image Making on TV
description: Both Presidential contenders are going on the air with paid television commercials just as they were being reminded anew tonight of the perils of getting their message across through television news.

title: Likud Party Opens Its Campaign With Warnings
description: Standing on a bluff here on the edge of the West Bank, his back to Tel Aviv and Israel's coastal plain just a few miles to the west, Roni Milo, a Likud official, shook his fist today as he warned:

title: Real Estate; Showrooms In Queens Get Office Tenant
description: AFTER more than four years of coaxing furniture and fixture manufacturers across the East River to showroom space carved out of old factory buildings in Long Island City, the developers of the huge design center there expect to sign a lease soon that will bring the first office tenant to the complex.

description: Michael S. Dukakis's campaign gave ground today in the debate over debates, grudgingly agreeing that there might be only two debates between the Presidential candidates, instead of three or four.

title: Taiwan and Italy Order U.S. Aircraft
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it had won two major aircraft orders totaling about $1.2 billion.

title: BEI Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $2,351,928 for the quarter and $2,390,928 for the 9 months; the quarter results also included a provision of $1 million to reflect a modification of the development plan of the company's Colorado real estate holdings. c-After extraordinary credits of $1,042,500 for the quarter and $2,591,500 for the 9 months.

title: Seeking to Prevent Another Summer of Beach Closings
description: After a summer in which sewage and medical waste fouled beaches in the New York metropolitan region, political, business and environmental leaders met here today to exchange strategies to avoid a repeat of the problem next summer.

title: Latest in 'Chat Lines:' Hookups by Computer
description: With so-called chat lines, the faddish party-line hookups that allow socializing by telephone, declining in popularity nationally, a French company has added a high-technology wrinkle, computer party lines whose users are billed by the telephone company.

title: Whose Election Is It, Anyway?
description: A compromise has now been struck: George Bush and Michael Dukakis will square off in two televised debates later in the campaign. Two is better than none, but this is still a disappointing conclusion that cheats voters and leaves the campaign too much in the hands of the image-makers.

title: Minnesota Mining To Buy Spontex
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company agreed to buy Spontex, a Paris-based supplier of household and commercial cleaning products, for about $182 million in cash. ''It's part of our strategy to expand in Europe by acquisition by 1992,'' a 3M spokesman said, referring to the European Community's plan to remove all trade barriers by 1992. 3M said it would buy Spontex from Chargeurs S.A., a diversified French industrial holding company involved in air transportation, textile manufacturing and communications. Spontex makes and sells textile, sponge and other synthetic wiping products to household and building service markets.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Durham, N.C.
description: LEAD: THE points of North Carolina's Research Triangle are Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill. Within the triangle are restaurants of many tastes and aspirations. A particularly noteworthy juxtaposition occurs in Durham, where the Top Hat saloon and the Magnolia Grill are only blocks apart geographically, but galaxies apart in style.

title: Ford Stops Production For Videos
description: The Ford Motor Company has taken the unusual step of stopping work on its assembly lines for two hours to show workers a videotape about raising quality standards.

title: Squeeze on U.S. Agency Seen As Result of Savings Rescues
description: The flurry of rescues of savings institutions in the last three weeks may have left the insurance fund of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in a troubling cash squeeze.

title: Autoinfo Inc reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-After a loss of $552,000 from discontinued operations and a provision of $419,000 for discontinuance of operations. c-After a loss of $452,000 from discontinued operations.

description: b-Net loss

description: BASEBALL

description: A favorite indoor sport among educational pundits in recent years has been to predict how many private colleges will be folding because of the declining number of 18-year-olds in the population.

description: They call the gray stucco apartment block the bullpen. Officially, it is a workers' hotel; actually, it is more like a cage for young men.

title: Cyclops Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company began operations in July 1987.

title: U.S. Open; Back Up on the Next Wave
description: It has been five years since Aaron Krickstein first poked his head through the open door of professional tennis, a painfully shy 16-year-old phenomenon who was going to be the successor to John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors. In 1983, Krickstein was the youngest male ever to reach the round of 16 in the United States Open. In Israel that fall, he became the youngest player to win a Grand Prix event.

title: Bridge
description: Some of the rare specimens of the zoological world are never imported into North America, and the same is true of the bridge world. Bizarre bidding ideas originate on other continents but are barred from these shores by the vigilant officials of the American Contract Bridge League.

title: Price of Oil Tumbles on Output Fear
description: Oil prices fell 55 cents a barrel, or nearly 4 percent, in futures trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, as dealers grew increasingly apprehensive about the rise in oil output made possible by the end of the Iran-Iraq war.

title: Senator Draws Boos at Debate
description: In a candidates debate at the State Fair here, Senator David Karnes drew boos from the crowd and criticism from his opponent when he said, ''We need fewer farmers at this point in time.''

title: Courier Dispatch Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Giants' Victory Not Flawless
description: Coach Bill Parcells was still savoring the Giants' 27-20 victory over Washington this morning as he emerged from a meeting with his coaching staff.

title: Amplicon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $1,350,000, or 20 cents a share, from a change in accounting for deferred taxes.

title: Bush Gets Harsh Reception at Shipyard in Oregon
description: Vice President Bush got far more than he gave today as his message of economic prosperity was engulfed by a wave of boos and obscenities from rank-and-file union members at a shipyard here.

title: Sumitomo Sale Of 9.40% Notes
description: The New York branch of Sumitomo Bank Ltd. is offering $100 million of 9.40 percent notes due in 1993 at par through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Sports People; Ranger Camp to Open
description: Twenty-three of the 65 players who attended the Rangers' rookie and free-agent camp, which ended yesterday, will join 45 others Saturday when the team opens its regular camp at Three Rivers, Quebec. Jim Latos, a free-agent right wing, will not attend. He underwent surgery on the right shoulder injured in an intrasquad scrimmage. . . . Pat Verbeek, who helped lead the Devils to the Stanley Cup semifinals last season, has threatened not to report with the other veterans when the West Orange, N.J., camp opens tomorrow unless he is signed to a new contract. Kirk Muller, the captain in the option year of his contract, said yesterday that he would report even if not signed by tomorrow.

title: Dimensional Medicine reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Wall St. Firms Subpoenaed On Contributions to Regan
description: The United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani, has subpoenaed State Comptroller Edward V. Regan and at least five Wall Street brokerage houses in connection with contributions they made to Mr. Regan's re-election campaigns.

title:
Education;
For Those at Risk of Dropping Out, An Enduring Program That Works
description: LEAD: As educators and policy makers continue their quest for new ways to give more help to students at risk of dropping out of high school, a 24-year-old Federal program continues to work by sticking with an old but successful formula.

title: A New Approach to Programming
description: In the early 1970's the Xerox Corporation's Palo Alto Research Center developed a computer language for children that sought to bypass the abstract thinking often necessary in computer programming. The idea was that children would write programs by stringing together individual pieces of software, each of which did a specific, easily understandable task.

title: Concerns About AIDS and Crime Spurring Push to Expand Drug Treatment Programs
description: As the nation gropes for weapons to fight the interconnected problems of AIDS, drug abuse and crime, medical experts and many in Congress are pushing for a broad expansion of programs to treat drug addicts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the opening of the new Barneys New York store misstated the location of the new Manhattan store of Louis, Boston. It is at 57th Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: U.S. and Soviet Space Efforts Are Sprinkled With Disasters
description: The crisis of the Soyuz TM-5 is only the latest in the history of space flight. Other emergencies, swift and deadly, have led to both Soviet and American deaths, but the close calls have sometimes lasted through days of increasing tension.

title: On Disarming, France Opens a Door
description: In a major policy shift, President Francois Mitterrand has decided to encourage a common NATO position on conventional disarmament and soften what many allied diplomats see as an attempt to delay an agreement on new negotiations involving the Warsaw Pact.

title: Biomass Advance: Making a Silk Purse . . .
description: Many agricultural and forestry processes generate large volumes of biomass, such things as sawdust, wood chips, straw, nut shells, corn husks and sugar cane bagasse. They are usually discarded or burned.

title: Tokyo Journal; A Real Estate Market No One Can Afford Anymore
description: The real estate boom here has been long been out of control, but many people were still shocked when a Government-affiliated research group calculated a few months ago that the book value of all the land in Japan - $13.47 trillion and change at current exchange rates -easily exceeded the value of all the land in the United States.

title: West Yellowstone Journal; Burning Forests, a New Attraction
description: In the land of the grizzly, Old Faithful and the moose, the newest tourist attraction these days is the sight of flames sweeping unchecked across the mountains.

title: JLG Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A Capitalist in Soviet Clothing
description: ANDREI FYODOROV, the director of a cooperative restaurant in Moscow, thinks the service in New York City is splendid.

title: Enserch to Sell Its Pool Unit
description: The Enserch Corporation, a diversified energy company, said today that it had decided to dispose of its flagging oilfield service subsidiary, the Houston-based Pool Company, and would take an after-tax write-down of $220 million in the third quarter. Pool, which has more than 4,000 employees worldwide, carried assets valued between $300 million and $350 million, the company said.

title: Convergent Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $208,000 from discontinued operations.

title: 2 U.S. Court Rulings Favor Lilco on Shoreham Actions
description: Two Federal court rulings today significantly improved the chances that the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station will obtain a commercial operating license if a proposed settlement to close it collapses.

title: Greece Expects Talks On Bases to Continue
description: A spokesman for the Greek Government said today that Athens expected talks on the future of the American military bases here to be continued in October. United States negotiators suspended the talks on Monday after Greece said it had decided to close one of the bases.

title: Wayne Phillips, 63, Journalist and U.S. Official
description: Wayne Phillips, a former chief of public affairs in the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development and a former reporter for The New York Times, died of a degenerative disorder of the nervous system Monday at the Tower Nursing Home, Charlottesville, Va. He was 63 years old and lived in Reston, Va.

title: Frogs' Legs, Hunt to Table
description: LEAD: MIDNIGHT, a canal near Alligator Alley in the preserve adjacent to Everglades National Park in southern Florida. The chairman of the Tribal Council of the Seminoles, James E. Billie, perched high above the hull at the controls of the airboat, touched a switch and a beam of light sprang from the band encircling his wide brow.

title: U.S. Drug Agent Shot; He Is Listed as Critical
description: A Federal drug enforcement agent was shot and critically wounded in a raid on an apartment in Harlem last night, officials said.

title: Just Walk In and Buy a Gun
description: How can you attack Michael Dukakis as soft on crime, Dan Quayle's news conference questioner wanted to know, when you oppose Federal laws to prevent a convict from walking into a store and buying a gun?

title: For a Child of Argentina's Battles, a New Tug-of-War
description: For most of her 10 years, Juliana Ines Trevino has known that she was adopted, but loving parents never told her about the shadow that hung over her country, Argentina, at the time of her birth.

title: Vacation's Over, but the Mind Still Wanders
description: VACATION lag occurs when you return home and part of your brain is still on vacation. It occurs most often after a refreshing, happy holiday, and the consensus is that the sensation may be pleasant, curious or hellish, depending on your perspective.

title: Boxing Notebook; Promoter's Decision Pays Off
description: In 1982, Dan Goossen was an office supplies salesman who had managed the career of Mr. T, the actor.

description: THE smart money on Wall Street is increasingly beginning to feel that the outcome of Roy E. Disney's slowly simmering takeover battle for the Polaroid Corporation depends more on the Eastman Kodak Company than on Mr. Disney.

description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Giving Foreigners Bigger Bond Role
description: The Japanese Finance Ministry yesterday announced major changes in Japan's government bond market that greatly increase the role of American and other foreign firms in underwriting new issues.

title: Federal Express
description: The British-Dutch giant Unilever N.V. said that the Federal Express Corporation would acquire its West German Elbe Transport Group and its Dutch Binfuerst Autotransport and Algemeen Vrachtkantoor B.V. transport operations. Unilever did not disclose the terms of the transaction. Federal Express, a major package delivery company, is based in Memphis. Both the Dutch and West German companies engage in freight forwarding, inland shipping and road haulage.

title: Illicit Crop Almost Saved Farm; Town Now Split
description: Faced with the prospect of losing the grain farm that has been in their family for most of this century, seven members of the Richard Kurth family turned to a new cash crop: marijuana.

title: Actors Reach Accord With Regional Theaters
description: Actors' Equity Association and the League of Resident Theaters reached tentative agreement over the weekend on a new three-year contract. The agreement, which would replace a contract that expired Sunday, requires approval by both organizations.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning

title: First Boston Wins Hertz Note Issue
description: In competititve bidding yesterday, the First Boston Corporation led a group of underwriters that won $75 million of Hertz Corporation notes.

title: Education; Some Miss Out on Benefit of Computers
description: Computers are moving rapidly into American classrooms, but too many minority students are not reaping the benefits of the new educational technology, an advisory group said today in a report.

title: Action Auto Stores reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income A gain of $334,000, or 11 cents a share, is included in 1988 from an accounting change.

Battle Ends In Belgium
description: The rivals for control of Belgium's largest company, Societe Generale de Belgique, accepted a power-sharing agreement today.

title: Butter as Medium

title: Grow Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net of $3.5 million from discontinued operations for the quarter and income from discontinued operations, which included a gain on the sale of Perrigo Co. of $3.5 million and operationg results of $2,789,000 to yield a total of $6,289,000, and a $568,000 gain from an accounting change, all for the year. c-After net of $859,000 for the quarter and a loss of $1,630,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: Tyson-Bruno Fight Is Off Again
description: Mike Tyson's heavyweight title defense against Frank Bruno, scheduled for Oct. 22 in London, has been postponed again on the advice of the physicians who have monitored Tyson since he was hospitalized following an automobile accident in Catskill, N.Y., Sunday morning.

title: Prime-Time Move at FNN
description: The Financial News Network, the cable television network that provides 14 hours of business news daily, said yesterday that it would expand its programming to prime time, beginning Oct. 31.

title: Yanks Are Victims of Swindell's 3-Hitter
description: The Yankees are as low in the standings now as they were the day before they opened the season.

title: Polls Tell Us No More Than Where We Are
description: To the Editor:

title: Accused Drug Lord Denies U.S. Charges
description: Lorenzo (Fat Cat) Nichols, who has been described by the authorities as a drug lord, pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal charges that he operated a large-scale cocaine and heroin ring in Queens.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Wis Services Inc., Appleton, Wis., said it had rebuffed a second request by its largest shareholder to discuss an acquisition proposal, repeating that the company is not for sale.

title: President of Invitron Proud of New Links
description: Charles V. Benton is a scientist by training who has done well on the management side at the helm of the Invitron Corporation, a small biotechnology company that has developed a better way to manufacture cell cultures.

title: Reagan Asserts Democrats Would Hinder U.S. Defense
description: President Reagan told the American Legion today that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and other Democrats would jeopardize national security with a ''Disneyland defense policy'' that he likened to the programs of President Carter.

title: Stocks Continue to Gain as Dow Adds 10.67
description: LEAD: The stock market moved higher yesterday, building upon last Friday's strong rally. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.67 points to close at 2,065.26.

title: EVACUATIONS RULE OF N.R.C. IS UPHELD
description: Rejecting the latest challenge to the Seabrook nuclear plant, a Federal appeals court ruled today that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission may accept emergency evacuation plans developed by utilities when state and local governments refuse to submit them.

title: Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Polls Tell Us No More Than Where We Are; End Taxpayer Funding
description: To the Editor:

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: LETTER from our friend, the party-going deli-lover:

title: INSIDE
description: Concern at the First Bell

title: Schools Open With Focus On Chancellor
description: Students begin returning to New York City's public schools today in an atmosphere of intense public concern over whether the school system will improve or whether that is even possible.

title: New Law Requires Insurers To Pay Mammogram Costs
description: The cost of mammograms, the screenings to detect breast cancer, will be covered under health insurance plans for New York women age 49 and older under legislation signed into law today by Governor Cuomo.

title: Israel Stunned by Bribery Plot To Dodge Service in Military
description: The Israeli Army says it has arrested dozens of people in connection with bribes paid to avoid compulsory military service.

title: Branch Jabs Reagan at Work
description: President Reagan was sporting a small adhesive bandage on his right arm today, the result of a minor accident while doing chores on his California ranch.

title: Wyatt Clears Buyout Plan
description: The board of Wyatt Cafeterias Inc. said today that it and the company's shareholders had approved an employee stock ownership buyout plan worth $173 million, or $84 a share in cash, of which a portion will remain in escrow.

title: Using Abracadabra To Conjure a Wave
description: LEAD: THE sun is setting on summer: back-to-school sales are beginning to outnumber good surfing waves. But surfers aren't taking it lying down.

title: Fire Threatens 2 Towns Near Park
description: The authorities today ordered the evacuation of all 150 residents of two small canyon communities bordering Yellowstone National Park after wind threatened to drive a wall of flame through the towns.

title: An East-West Marriage of Flavors
description: THOSE old enough to remember the La Choy commercial that implored consumers to put soy sauce on everything so that it would ''sing American'' may also recall their first visit to a Chinese restaurant. The most exotic item on the menu in the 1940's and early 50's was sub gum chow mein; the most popular was chop suey.

title: Comptek Research Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-After a credit of $125,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: U.S. Parts, Japanese Computer
description: For the first 98 years of its history, Kubota Ltd., Japan's largest manufacturer of agricultural machinery, never made anything more technologically sophisticated than a tractor. Then last month, from a gleaming new plant north of Tokyo, Kubota shipped its first mini-supercomputer, one of the most advanced of its kind.

title: China Takes Harsh Population Measures
description: To the Editor:

title: Savings Unit To Get a Buyer
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it would provide $19.6 million to allow a private group to buy the insolvent First Federal Savings Bank of Roger, Ark.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions of Business Day on Friday, about the awarding by the International Business Machines Corporation of its advertising account, incompletely described the status of Charles Moss, the former chief creative officer of Wells, Rich, Greene. He is now the agency's corporate creative director.

title: The Pop Life
description: Yoakam the Purist

title: Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: American Jewish World Service, 729 Boylson Street, Boston, Mass. 02116. American National Red Cross, Bangladesh Relief, P.O. Box 37243, Washington, D.C. 20013. CARE, Bangladesh Flood Relief, 660 First Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017. Operation California, 7615 1/2 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles, Calif. 90046. Save the Children, 54 Wilton Road, Westport, Conn. 06880. United Nations for Bangladesh, 821 United Nations Plaza, eighth floor, New York, N.Y. 10017. World Vision Relief Organization. 919 West Huntington Drive, Monrovia, Calif. 91016.

title: KEY RATES
Let's Have a Polling Frenzy
description: Newspapers and television overdid the Dan Quayle story. The result was the infamous feeding frenzy. The public was revolted, especially at breakfast time. It was bad for the image of the press. It was bad for the image of television. And justly so. In the old days, there were certain stories, certain pictures that were not used in newspapers meant for the breakfast table. Dan Quayle being subjected to a feeding frenzy was such a story.

title: Ainslee Cox, 52, A Longtime Leader Of Goldman Band
description: Ainslee Cox, the longtime conductor of the Goldman Concert Band, died of complications arising from Hodgkins disease on Monday afternoon at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 52 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Kosher Goes Mainstream
description: WHEN Sue Greenberg of Washington started keeping kosher 26 years ago, she said goodbye - forever, she thought - to crab meat, Italian sausages and meat tortellini with cheese. Today, however, Mrs. Greenberg, a 47-year-old graduate student in business administration, eats kosher sausages, a crab meat look-alike and taste-alike, and meatless tortellini made from tofu sprinkled with cheese. ''And even though I like to serve traditional foods for Rosh ha-Shanah,'' Mrs. Greenberg said, ''I can vary my menus and add special touches, where I couldn't before those foods were available.''

title: Continental General Insurance Company reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $91,039 for the quarter and $55,093 for the 6 months. c-After realized investment gains of $369,190 for the quarter and $644,854 for the 6 months.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Change in Assignments
description: Where have all the Treasury Department people gone? To Vice President Bush and Senator Dan Quayle. A lot of former Treasury employees are tripping over themselves these days in the campaign's rabbit warren of a headquarters on the eighth floor of a musty office building just a block and a half up 15th Street from the Treasury.

title: Woman Drowns in Cave Dive
description: A 21-year-old woman drowned Sunday while diving in a water-filled cave when her air tanks ran out after she panicked and swam in the wrong direction, the police said. Her body was found Monday in a dead-end corridor in a cave at Orange Grove Sink. The police said that the woman and a partner had been following a marked course but lost sight of the line and drifted apart. The woman's partner lost her but found his way safely out of the cave.

title: EX-MINISTRY HEAD GETS CREDIT LIFT
description: Jim Bakker, the former leader of the PTL television ministry, who is offering a $172 million plan to regain control of the ministry and its religious theme park. received a two-day extension today to produce a $3 million line of credit supporting his bid.

title: About New York; On Top Where King Kong Once Romped
description: At the age of 18, Laura Fries landed her first job as a secretary in a hosiery company in the Empire State Building. She worked there for four years, but never deigned to visit the top of what was then the planet's tallest building. ''I was a New Yorker,'' she explained. ''I knew New Yorkers don't do touristy things.''

title: Concorde Career Colleges reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Concorde was spun off from Cencor Inc. on June 30.

title: Rock Fans Fighting Hearing Loss Insist: Not So Loud, Please!
description: In Haight-Ashbury, where loud live rock became an essential part of the youth culture during the 1960's, a new movement is seeking to warn about the dangers of such music.

title: Seattle Checking Wiring for More Problems
description: With power restored in a 50-block downtown area after a four-day blackout, the city-owned utility plans to check wiring similar to the kind that contributed to its worst outage.

title: Eastern Job Hearings Set
description: Attorneys for Eastern Airlines' unions learned today that they will return to Federal court later this month to argue their case against the elimination of 4,000 jobs.

title: PPG Drops Offer To Acquire Grow
description: PPG Industries terminated its plans to acquire Grow Group Inc., a manufacturer of paint and chemical coatings based in New York, for $300 million, sending the stock tumbling on Wall Street. PPG gave no reason for the surprise decision.

title: Plea-Bargain Talks Seen
description: Stephen Sui-Kuan Wang, a young financial analyst from Morgan Stanley & Company who was implicated in a major insider trading scheme, has been negotiating a plea bargain agreement with officials at the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan, individuals familiar with the talks said.

title: High Tea: With Meat
description: To The Living Section:

title: Bahrain Airline's Plans
description: Gulf Air, a Bahrain-based regional airline, reportedly plans to more than double its fleet, to 42 planes from 20, in five years. Bahrain's daily newspaper, Akhbar Al Khaleej, quoted the island's industry minister, Youssef Shirawi, in Monday's issue as saying the company would also gradually replace its old planes.

title: A Summer Cook Who Lingers In Memory
description: LEAD: THE late James Beard said American cuisine is your mother's cooking, but I like to think of it as Esther's. Each summer Esther Grimes would take the long bus ride north, far across the Mason-Dixon line, to the New Hampshire lakeside camp whose kitchen she inhabited. There she presided, amid rustic wooden counter tops worn with 50 years' use, iron skillets so large they required both hands to lift and an electric refrigerator that had only recently replaced the old icehouse.

title: Sports of The Times; Karl Nelson's Tightrope
description: EVEN before Karl Nelson was introduced Monday night, the fans in Giants Stadium were on their feet, waiting to welcome the 6-foot-6-inch, 285-pound offensive right tackle. Karl Nelson was playing football again after having endured treatment for Hodgkin's disease as well as serious surgery on his left shoulder. Moments later his name was called over the public-address system and he hurried onto the field. But even after he arrived at the Giants' sideline, the cheers continued.

title: Sales Executive Leaving Lotus
description: Vincent G. Kelly, vice president of North American sales at the Lotus Development Corporation, said yesterday that he was resigning to take a position as vice president at Corporate Software Inc., a Westwood, Mass., reseller of software and hardware that had revenues of $60 million in 1987.

title: California Savings Rescue Begun by Federal Agency
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today placed the American Savings and Loan Association of Stockton, Calif., in receivership and injected $250 million in cash to return it to solvency.

title: Leo H. Rosenberg, Advertising Executive, 92
description: Leo Henry Rosenberg, a retired advertising executive who was one of radio's first announcers, died in his sleep Monday at a nursing home in Dunn Loring, Va. He was 92 years old.

title: Sallie Mae Selling Short-Term Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $350 million of floating-rate notes due March 9, 1989, at par through various securities dealers.

title: Air Show Toll Reaches 53
description: The toll in the Ramstein air show disaster Aug. 28 rose to 53 with the death of a West German man, officials said today. Jurgen Dietzen, a spokesman for Rhineland-Palatinate state, where the United States Air Force's Ramstein Air Base is located, identified the victim as a 53-year-old man from Baden-Wurttemberg.

title: For Bruised Spirits, Bitter Medicine
description: ''HI. I'm Dr. Toni Grant. You're on KFI. How may I help you?'' The caller began his story. The woman he had lived with and loved for three years had moved out, breaking not only his heart but also those of his parents, who adored her. What had happened? What should he do? His voice quavered as it came out over the car radio.

title: CMI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $675,000 for the quarter and $5,750,000 for the 6 months; the 6 months' net from operations included an after-tax gain of $3,912,000 from the sale of certain products and designs. c-Net loss

title: Sports People; Esiason Withdraws
description: ''I'm done,'' said Boomer Esiason, the Cincinnati Bengal quarterback, announcing that he would step down as player representative next week when most National Football League teams conduct their union elections. ''I did my two years' service. Now it's up to the 44 or 45 other guys to figure out who they want to represent them. I still believe in the concepts, but you can only make so many sacrifices.'' Esiason, in his fifth professional season, irked management last season when he took a strong pro-union stance during the strike by the National Football League Players' Association. He said none of the players wanted to succeed him because they were afraid of losing their jobs.(AP)

title: Diversified Energies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mother on Trial in 2 Deaths Had Postpartum Psychosis, Lawyer Says
description: A former pediatric nurse charged with smothering two of her children and trying to kill the third was not responsible for her actions because she suffered from a severe postpartum psychosis, her lawyer said yesterday.

title: WINE TALK
description: HERE is a suggestion for a wine lover who has nothing to do this month or next: come to France for the Ledoyen wine auction. Ledoyen, a Paris landmark, closed a year ago this month. It had been a restaurant since Antoine-Nicolas Doyen opened it in 1792, in almost the same location in the flower-filled gardens at the foot of the Champs-Elysees.

title: New Colombian Paper Opens (It's an Old Political Game)
description: In a country where most newspapers, magazines and television news stations are owned by the same families as exercise political power, the appearance of a new daily here in August was predictably more of a political than a journalistic event.

title: Esterline Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $236,000 for the quarter and $951,000 for the 9 months.

title: A $200 Million Offering Of Chrysler Extension Notes
description: The Chrysler Financial Corporation, a unit of the Chrysler Corporation, is offering $200 million of 9 5/8 percent extension notes with final maturity in 2008. Morgan Stanley & Company heads the underwriters.

title: Agriculture Still Another Casualty of Afghan War
description: A series of reports circulating in Western embassies here offers a brutal portrait of the effects of the war in Afghanistan and of what is termed the ''systematic destruction'' of livestock, irrigation systems and farms.

title: 7-Story Village Mural of Stars of the Left
description: An all-star cast of the international left - Karl Marx, Mother Jones, Fidel Castro, Lenin, Malcolm X and other leaders of the working class -is appearing in a new but very old-fashioned political wall painting. The huge work, known as ''The Pathfinder Mural,'' is nearing completion on the side of a building at West and Charles Streets in Greenwich Village, and its creators are braced for controversy.

title: District Attorney Won't Charge Yonkers Councilmen
description: The Westchester District Attorney refused today to prosecute four Yonkers Councilmen whose votes blocking a court-ordered housing desegregation plan have incurred growing contempt fines against the city.

title: Koch Proposes U.S.-Style 'Foreign Legion' for the Nation's Inmates
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed the creation of an American-style French Foreign Legion in which the nation'sprisoners could reduce their sentences by laboring where the country needs them the most.

title: Education; Illiteracy Seen as Threat to U.S. Economic Edge
description: The United States, pressed as never before by competition in world markets, desperately needs workers who can think critically, participate more in company planning and decision making and adapt quickly to change, business leaders say.

title: Persuaders Try to Lead Consumers by the Nose
description: To the Editor:

title: Polls Tell Us No More Than Where We Are; About Vice Presidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Returning Congress Pressured by Clock, Budget and Politics
description: With barely a month remaining to tie up the legislative loose ends of the 100th Congress, lawmakers are returning to Capitol Hill to do battle less with one another than with the clock and budget constraints in the highly partisan atmosphere of the election campaign.

title: Small Hay Crop Is Seen
description: Largely because of widespread drought, the 1988 hay crop is expected to be the smallest in 12 years, and prices are likely to be the highest since the Agriculture Department began keeping annual figures in 1909. Preliminary figures show that hay prices at the farm in August averaged $83.10 a ton, up 35 percent from $61.60 a ton a year ago. Department records show that the highest hay price for an entire season was $75.80 a ton in 1983, another drought year.

title: Morningside Park Is to Be Rehabilitated
description: More than 20 years after Columbia University began building a gymnasium in Morningside Park, a project that was abandoned after student demonstrations in 1968, the foundation hole will become a pond as part of a $12 million city plan to rehabilitate the park over the next 10 years.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Working on Job Figures
description: The Presidential candidates seem to be having difficulties getting their arms around the issue of jobs versus joblessness in America.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Pledges of assistance to Bangladesh have amounted to millions of dollars in money and other assistance, Bangladeshi and international aid officials said. Washington pledged about $3.6 million in food. Page A1

title: Baseball; Greenwell Puts Red Sox 2 Up
description: Mike Greenwell had three hits, including a home run, and drove in three runs, and Wes Gardner pitched a five-hitter as the Boston Red Sox increased their American League East lead by defeating the Baltimore Orioles, 6-1, tonight, With their third consecutive road victory, the Red Sox moved two games in front of the Detroit Tigers, who lost to Toronto.

title: John J. Ryan, Businessman, 83
description: John J. Ryan, who emigrated from Ireland as a penniless 19-year-old and eventually owned several businesses in Queens, died of a stroke Saturday at the Ozanam nursing home in Bayside. He was 83 years old and lived in Astoria, Queens.

title: Wise Bet on Zimbabwe
description: Zimbabwe, self-conscious torchbearer for the nonaligned third world, can be a very prickly friend. Yet it is also a heartening example of racial coexistence and sensible economic management in a troubled region and a victim of the dislocations brought about by the struggle against apartheid in South Africa. Washington has wisely ended a two-year freeze on economic aid.

title: Police Confiscate Tape Of Defiant Tutu Sermon
description: The police today seized a tape of a sermon in which Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu defied the Government and called for a boycott of October elections, a spokesman for the Archbishop said.

title: A Bitter 'Whisky War' in Ireland
description: ''Keep the Spirit Irish'' is the message trumpeted from billboards on street corners. But as the long-running battle for control of the Irish Distillers Group P.L.C. draws to a dramatic finish, the only near-certainty is that soon the Irish whisky industry will be in foreign hands.

title: Herbert W. Dates, Executive, 66
description: Herbert W. Dates, former president and chief operating officer of Szabo Food Services Inc., died of cancer Friday at his home in Florham Park, N.J. He was 66 years old. Mr. Dates was associated with the company, of Oak Brook, Ill., from 1972 to 1979.

title: Sound Advice Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
American Southwest Mortage Investments reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company began operations last August.

title: Telecredit Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NCH Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Slam Stewart Memorial
description: A musical memorial service for the jazz bassist Slam Stewart, who died last Dec. 7, is to be held tonight at 7 P.M. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, at 54th Street. The Rev. John Gensell is to officiate, with music organized by Major Holley, a bassist and associate of Mr. Stewart.

title: America's Cup; After Turbulence on Land, Sparring Takes to the Water; San Diegans' Air Is Clearly Lukewarm
description: Like reluctant but polite hosts forced to throw a party they don't want to give, San Diegans made their final preparations and tried to work up some enthusiasm today for the controversy-plagued America's Cup yachting races that are scheduled to begin Wednesday.

title: Man Slain in Shooting Near Park Boathouse
description: A 33-year-old man was fatally shot while strolling with a friend on the east side of Central Park near 110th Street yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Turning the Tables
description: To The Living Section:

title: California Energy Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Sports People; Average Pay: $433,000
description: The average salary of major league baseball players this year will reach a record $433,000, according to the Player Relations Committee's executive director, Barry Rona. The figure represents an increase of $31,000 over the 1987 average. The official average is computed from the Aug. 31 roster. The Major League Baseball Players Association will issue its report of average salary later in the year.

title: Lack of Offense Foils Ojeda
description: The Mets, who stop hitting when Bob Ojeda starts pitching, stopped hitting again tonight. They scored two runs for Ojeda, as they have done in 16 of the 27 games he has started this year. And Ojeda suffered the predictable result: a 3-2 loss to the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Fay's Drug Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend distributed on June 28.

title: EATING WELL
description: LEAD: MODIFYING the diet is difficult under any circumstance. Adding fiber may be the most unsettling modification of all. Lowering sodium intake generally requires stilling the saltcellar. To reduce fat intake, people avoid the obvious fat-dense foods (cheeses, some meats, snack foods). They cook with less butter or oil, use nonstick pans, and select foods richer in carbohydrates to crowd fat out of their diet.

title: Soviet Crew Lands Safely After Crisis in Space
description: A series of systems failures stranded a Soviet astronaut and his Afghan crewmate in Earth orbit with limited air supplies for 25 tense hours before the crew landed successfully in the Soviet Union early this morning.

title: Wheelchair Users Arrested In Protests at Bus Stations
description: The police in several cities arrested demonstrators in wheelchairs who blocked crowded Greyhound terminals on Monday. The demonstrators contended that the buses were inaccessible to disabled riders.

title: Jet Lands After Malfunction
description: A jetliner carrying 283 people on a flight from Houston made an emergency landing at Los Angeles International Airport after the crew manually lowered the landing gear, the authorities said today. Continental Airlines Flight 475, an Airbus A-300, landed safely at 8:46 p.m. Monday, said Fred O'Donnell, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: U.S. SEES INCREASE IN AFGHAN OPIUM
description: The State Department said today that it expected an increase in the illegal cultivation of opium in Afghanistan after Soviet troops completed their withdrawal from that country.

title: Andrew Ragona, 79, Ex-Director Of Ad Production at Times, Dies
description: Andrew Ragona, director of advertising production and publication for The New York Times for two decades until his retirement in 1974, died of liver cancer yesterday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 79 years old and lived in Valley Stream, L.I.

title: Khomeini Bars Official's Quitting
description: Iran's leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, today rebuked Prime Minister Mir Hussein Moussavi for offering to resign, saying he should get on with his job.

title: Iraqi Drive, Tied to Gulf Truce, Compounds Guerrillas' Disunity and Setbacks in Turkey
description: Iraq's newest offensive against the guerrillas among its three million Kurds seems to have left the rebel forces in disarray.

title: Vacations to Go reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income and includes a $436 tax credit.

title: Carl Karcher Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 8
description: b-After a tax benefit of $1,466,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Georgia-Pacific's $250 Million Issue
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation entered the debt market yesterday with a $250 million offering of 10 1/4 percent debentures due in 2018 at a price of 99.25 to yield 10.526 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Books of The Times; The Life Behind the Films About the Life
description: The Magic Lantern An Autobiography By Ingmar Bergman Translated from the Swedish by Joan Tate. 308 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: By the River, Refuge but Little Relief
description: Clustered on a riverbank, more than 8,000 residents of this town in Bangladesh, about 100 miles south of Dhaka,were forced today to take shelter any way they could.

title: Father, 2 Children Dead After Shootout
description: A 45-year-old Manhattan man shot 14 policemen from his apartment yesterday during a daylong siege that ended eight and a half hours after it began with the man's 2 young children dead and the gunman mortally wounded by police gunfire.

title: Judge Urges Allowing Medicinal Use of Marijauna
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration's chief administrative law judge today recommended legalizing marijuana as a prescription drug for the treatment of multiple sclerosis and nausea suffered by cancer patients in chemotherapy.

title: Benihana National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 17
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $325,802.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Book Notes
description: Orion Takes Off

title: Pop Ephemera Auction: Elton John's Collection
description: An enthusiastic gathering of bidders, spectators and fans, many suitably dressed for a Wembley Stadium rock concert, filled a London auction house today and paid tribute to the pop singer Elton John, buying everything from his rhinestone-studded spectacles to his diamond-studded earrings.

title: Yale Dean to Stay On
description: Lloyd Richards's term as dean of the Yale School of Drama and artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater has been extended for two years, through the 1990-91 academic year. Mr. Richards's term was to have expired next June. The announcement was made last Thursday by Yale's president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr.

title: Drop in Dollar May Signal An End to Summer Rally
description: The dollar fell against major currencies yesterday, and some traders said they were wondering whether the summer rally was finally over.

title: Surprise Inspection of Plane Cancels Dukakis's Ohio Trip
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis had to cancel an Ohio campaign stop today after the Federal Aviation Administration sprang a surprise inspection of his chartered airplane and found safety problems.

title: Continental Medical Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $151,000 for the quarter and $369,000 for the year.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Shades of Gray
description: Since the early years of the Reagan Administration, the map of the world behind the speakers' dais in the State Department press room showed the continents a pumpkin orange against a midnight blue sea. Print reporters didn't mind, but the orange grated on television producers because it tended to turn the complexions of the State Department press aides into an unhealthy pallor.

title: Bangor, Me.
description: AS far as food is concerned, Maine is best known for its lobsters, blueberries and potatoes. Somehow, bagels never make the list.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE notion of combining fresh orange juice with seafood might sound odd, but if used judiciously, the juice can add a dynamic touch of sweetness to scallops, lobster, shrimp, even tuna and salmon.

title: Dukakis's Ties to Orthodox Church Stay Warm Despite Abortion Stance
description: Four years ago the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, a Roman Catholic, was chastised by several Catholic bishops for favoring abortion rights. This year the Democratic Presidential nominee, who is Greek Orthodox, takes the same position but has encountered only the warm embrace of his church.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Festival of Fish Facts

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Seattle
description: LEAD: MARK MUSICK is a specialty produce buyer for Larry's Markets, a chain of four state-of-the-art supermarkets in the Seattle area, but he is much more an educator than a grocer.

title: Agassi Tops Chang In Straight Sets
description: He batted a tennis ball high into the stands, a practice he began earlier this year. Then Andre Agassi took a spare pair of denim shorts, frayed but clean, he said, and threw them to a cluster of fans maneuvering for position. But when he walked off the Stadium court at Flushing Meadows last night, Agassi was still wearing his baggy white shirt. He has yet to lose that at the United States Open.

title: Review/Pop; Sade's Cool, Adult Short Stories
description: There's a sense in which Sade's mostly brilliant show at Radio City on Monday night was seen more than heard. Her band members, resonating cool, were dressed in suits that would have looked fine for the mid-1950's Miles Davis group. The lighting and backdrops, spare and ascetic and changing for each tune, radiated an Asian formality. An acoustic bass - another reference to jazz style - was placed up front as a prop, and used maybe twice during the show. She opened the show with ''Never as Good as the First Time,'' with choreography taken from one of her videos.

title: Experts Debate Cuomo's Stand In Yonkers Case
description: After the United States Supreme Court suspended contempt fines against four Yonkers City Councilmen last week but reimposed fines on the city, Governor Cuomo said that the court's decision ''raised troublesome legal questions'' about removing the Councilmen from office and that, for the time being at least, he would not act against them.

title: Traffic and Air Will Improve if Fewer Vehicles Enter Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: Olympics; A New Craze in South Korea
description: South of here on Route 1 toward Pusan, the crazy-quilt urban patterns of new office buildings and old kiosks begin to melt away into farm land and rice fields. Along the way, exit signs mark directions to nearby towns and villages, some visible from the highway. But for the most part, the road slices through only a verdant countryside, with mountains off in the distance at either side.

title: Prague Gives Dubcek a Visa For First Time Since Ouster
description: Alexander Dubcek, the former Czechoslovak Communist Party chief who led the short-lived period of liberalization in 1968 known as Prague Spring, is to travel abroad for the first time in two decades to visit Italy, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Review/Television; The Earliest Americans, From 15,000 Years Ago
description: The first immigrants to our hemisphere arrived on foot about 15,000 years ago over a land bridge that then traversed the region between present-day Siberia and Alaska. They walked thousands of miles and hundreds of years, over the generations, to settle the Americas, and it may be something of a commentary in itself to note that we can learn about this migration on television, sitting at home and not moving a muscle more than those needed to flip a dial.

title: BENTSEN SUPPORTS MORE SCHOOL DAYS
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen said that today he believed American public school students should spend more days a year in classthan they do now, so as to assure the nation's economic future and to compete successfully with more disciplined foreign countries.

title: Parsley and Pepper
description: East Meets West Sandwich (Adapted from Ken Hom) Preparation time: 20 minutes Cooking time: 6 minutes 4 4-ounce boneless and skinless salmon fillets 4 tablespoons fresh ginger juice, squeezed from fresh ginger root 1/2 cup sweet sake rice wine 1 or 2 teaspoons kosher salt 2 tablespoons freshly ground mixture of roasted Sichuan peppercorns, black and white peppercorns, pink and green peppercorns and whole allspice 2 tablespoons finely chopped fresh ginger 1/2 cup finely chopped scallions Freshly ground black pepper 6 tablespoons or more of good-quality olive oil 6 tablespoons finely chopped fresh coriander 6 tablespoons finely chopped curly parsley 6 tablespoons finely chopped Italian parsley 4 teaspoons finely chopped garlic 4 very crusty mini baguettes, about 8 inches long and 2 1/2 inches wide 12 washed spinach leaves 8 to 10 opal basil or regular basil leaves 2 tomatoes, thinly sliced

title: Chief Operating Officer Is Appointed by Patten
description: The Patten Corporation, a big developer of rural land, has named Warren Van Genderen as chief operating officer reporting directly to Patten's founder, president and chief executive, Harry S. Patten.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Agency Formed As Caggiano & Siebel
description: John Caggiano, once an executive vice president and creative director of Doyle Dane Bernbach, who has been freelancing since becoming a victim of its merger with Needham Harper Worldwide, has now gone into business with Siebel/Mohr, a 19-year-old sales promotion firm. Each is half owner of Caggiano & Siebel Advertising.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Agency Is Hoping for Lightning to Strike
description: ''THIS is an agency waiting to explode!'' exclaimed the energetic Mel (for Melvin) Ciociola, chief executive and creative director of Ciociola & Company, who is looking hard for the fuse.

title: Utility Seen Yielding on Fine; Guard Slept at Nuclear Plant
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company reportedly has decided not to contest a record $1.25 million fine levied because control room operators slept on duty at the Peach Bottom nuclear plant.

title: Jury Finds Southmark Liable in a Civil Suit
description: A California jury has found the Southmark Corporation liable for more than $130 million in damages in a civil suit brought by a San Diego businessman and his wife, the company said today.

title: Less Optimism as Southern Africa Talks Resume
description: Angola, Cuba and South Africa re-sumed talks here today to set a timetable for the withdrawal of tens of thousands of Cuban troops from Angola.

title: SOLZHENITSYN BARS OFFER BY SOVIETS
description: Alexander Solzhenitsyn, the exiled Russian writer, has declined an invitation to join a Soviet committee responsible for building a memorial to Stalin's victims.

title: Jean P. Baltzell, Lawyer, 71
description: Jean P. Baltzell, a retired New York lawyer who was active in Democratic politics in Manhattan in the 1950's and 60's, died of cancer Saturday in Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 71 years old.

title: McCann-Erickson Gets Promotions Company
description: World Sports Promotions, a four-year-old events marketing company in St. Louis, has been acquired by McCann-Erickson USA, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, for an undisclosed sum.

title: Soviets Buy More Corn
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 300,000 metric tons of United States corn for delivery in the coming year, the Agriculture Department said today. More than two million tons of corn have been sold by private exporters to the Soviets in the last week, according to Agriculture Department announcements. As with the other recent sales, no indication was given whether the new sales of corn would count under the current long-term grain supply agreement, which expires Sept. 30, between the two countries or be carried forward separately in case a new pact is forthcoming.

title: Deadline Missed
description: Ten days from the opening of the Seoul Olympics, only 147 of the 161 nations that accepted invitations to participate have supplied entry lists to the International Olympic Committee, even though the deadline was Sept. 2 for all sports except track and field,which has a Sept. 9 deadline. Michele Verdier, an I.O.C. spokeswoman, said she had no reason to think that any of the 14 nations, which she would not identify, would not participate. But with so little time remaining, she allowed fo

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Coleman Co., Wichita, Kan., a maker of camping and outdoor recreation products, marine sports products and products for the home, named Jeffrey Curtiss chief financial officer, succeeding Richard Curry, who has retired.

title: Ford Decision Due On Nissan Venture
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would decide by the end of the month whether to build a minivan in the United States with the Nissan Motor Company, the Japanese auto maker. Ford and Nissan have been negotiating for more than a year on the production of a front-wheel-drive van.

title: Yield Rises Are Smaller
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were up for the week ended yesterday, but the strength of these increases appears to be easing.

title: Ohio to Back $71 Million In Pollution Control Bonds
description: The Ohio Water Development Authority and the Ohio Air Quality Development Authority are tentatively offering $71 million of pollution control revenue bonds for a Duquesne Light Company project through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have been working so hard. I had so many match points that I felt I deserved to win. I'm surprised that I stayed that calm considering what was happening.'' - Zina Garrison, tennis victor. [ D26:5. ]

title: Concern That Aided Bahamas Has Officials Advising Bush
description: A Washington consulting concern whose principals hold prominent positions in the Bush Presidential campaign was paid $800,000 to improve the image of the Bahamas at a time when the leadership of the island nation was under fire for purported ties to drug traffickers.

title: Pirates Win Behind Drabek
description: Alan Trammell's pinch-hit single in the ninth inning scored Chet Lemon from second base to give the Detroit Tigers a 4-3 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays tonight, Detroit ended a six-game losing streak and stopped a six-game winning streak by Toronto. It was only the third victory in the last 16 games for the Tigers, who had not won since Aug. 31.

title: Daily Car Sales Down 7.2%
description: Sales of domestic cars and light trucks ran at a daily rate of 34,946 units in August, down 7.2 percent from the same month last year, according to final industry reports.

title: Hostage Negotiators Ponder the Deadly Outcome of Siege
description: As far as the commander of New York City's hostage negotiating team was concerned, it was the worst situation in the book: an emotionally disturbed man besieged in a barricaded apartment with a shotgun and two small children.

title: Silvester Mooney, Monk, 102
description: The Rev. Silvester Mooney, who headed Douai Abbey in Britain for 40 years and was believed to be the world's oldest Roman Catholic monk, died Monday night, the abbey said today. He was 102 years old.

title: Dukakis Proposing College Loans To Be Repaid Over Job Lifetime
description: Michael S. Dukakis today proposed a college loan program that would allow students to pay back their loans over a lifetime through payroll withholding of a small fixed percentage of their income. He said the program would ''open wide the door of college opportunity'' to American youths.

title: Trade Data in New Format
description: The Commerce Department said today that it planned to present the nation's trade figures in a new format, which reduces the size of the monthly deficits.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have a screened room on the side of the house that has a vinyl roof. On sunny days this room gets hot and uncomfortable. Would the room be cooler if it had an insulated wood roof, with regular shingles that matched the rest of the house? A. It probably would. However, you may also get a good deal of relief by installing vents or louvers in the existing roof - the kind that will let the hot air escape but will not allow rain to come in. These are sold in home centers. Q. The wood on the front of my nine-year-old condominium has been stained several times and each time the stain peels in three or four months. Also, some of the wood has rotted. What causes this and what can be done to correct it, short of removing the wood and starting over? A. A true stain cannot peel; only paint peels, so you apparently have not been using a stain. Some companies make heavy-bodied finishes they call ''opaque stain'' or ''solid color stain,'' but these are really paints made to look like stain. Take all of it off by sanding or by using a remover, then apply a semi-opaque or transparent single stain.

title: The Tile Roof Leaps Beyond Mission Style
description: FEW features distinguish a house as readily as a tile roof, especially in the United States, where tile roofs have never been common except in the Southwest, California and Florida.

title: U.S. Study Finds It Cheaper to Replace Bugged Moscow Chancery
description: A recently completed study commissioned by the State Department recommends that the United States tear down the heavily bugged new American Embassy chancery in Moscow and build a replacement, Government officials said today.

title: Bush and Dukakis, Addressing Jews, Assail P.L.O.
description: Both Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis appeared today before B'nai B'rith and denounced the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: DOLE IN DUAL ROLE AT QUAYLE EVENT
description: In one room, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas served chocolate brownies and fruit juice to the Republican Vice-Presidential nomineer, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana.

title: Corruption Issue Fuels a Bronx Race
description: Three Democratic candidates with no experience running for elective office and a fourth who has lost three races are seeking the Democratic nomination for Bronx District Attorney, a leading office in the borough that has taken on even more significance because of corruption investigations.

title: Belfast Protestant Killed
description: Gunmen shot and killed a one-time militant from Northern Ireland's largest Protestant paramilitary group near his Belfast home today. The police said Billy Quee, formerly of the Ulster Defense Association, had been shot by men who fled in a waiting car.

title: Savings Unit's Ashes Look Like Gold to Bass
