description: In agreeing to take over the American Savings and Loan Association of Stockton, Calif., the nation's largest insolvent savings unit, the Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass is betting that the resurrected company will be able to make a lot of money by operating the major part of the business as a traditional savings unit - that is, taking deposits from customers and making mortgage loans and other consumer loans.

title: Note and Bond Prices Fall Slightly
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds ended slightly lower after a choppy session yesterday, as market participants took profits and cast an apprehensive eye on the dollar, which came under pressure for the second day.

title: Life in the 30's
description: WHENEVER a young man came to call, Ida would insist that he stay for dinner. She was paid to look after the house, do the laundry and provide meals after my mother died, but one of her most consuming extracurricular interests was seeing that I get married, or, as she so pithily put it, ''snag a man.''

title: 'Waste Is Worse Than Loss'
description: To the Editor:

title: Who'll Pay to Fatten Textile Profits?
description: With textile factories running full tilt and profits booming, it's hard to imagine an industry less able to justify extra protection from foreign competition. But $4 million in campaign contributions seems to be all the justification Congress needs. That's how much the textile and apparel lobbies have contributed in the last two Congressional elections, and the investment is on the verge of paying off - at consumers' expense.

title: Winning Colors Returns
description: Winning Colors, the 3-year-old filly who won the Kentucky Derby May 7, will make her first start in three months when she takes on the undefeated 4-year-old filly Personal Ensign in the Maskette Stakes at Belmont Park on Saturday.

title: Reagan Urges Party Leaders To Work With Bush Camp
description: President Reagan told Republican Congressional leaders today that his Administration's officials will coordinate all major policy decisions with those of the George Bush campaign, officials present at the meeting said.

title: Request for Meese Denied
description: A Federal judge refused today to order former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to answer questions under oath about his decision to allow the partial merger of Detroit's two daily newspapers.

title: Christie's to Auction Works From Two Art Collections
description: Two major art collections - Edith Mayer Goetz's holdings in Impressionist, Post-Impressionist and modern works, and Emily and Burton Tremaine's postwar and modern art - are to be auctioned in November at Christie's.

title: Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: American Jewish World Service, 729 Boylson Street, Boston, Mass. 02116. American National Red Cross, Bangladesh Relief, P.O. Box 37243, Washington, D.C. 20013. CARE, Bangladesh Flood Relief, 660 First Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017. Catholic Relief Services, 1011 First Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10022. Church World Service, Bangladesh Emergency, P.O. Box 968, Elkhart, Ind. 46515. Interaction, 200 Park Avenue South, Suite 1115, New York, N.Y. 10003. MAP International, 2200 Glynco Parkway, Brunswick, Ga. 31520. Operation California, 7615 1/2 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles, Calif. 90046. Oxfam America, 115 Broadway, Boston, Mass. 02116. Salvation Army, National Headquarters, 799 Bloomfield Avenue, Verona, N.J. 07044. Save the Children, 54 Wilton Road, Westport, Conn. 06880. United Nations for Bangladesh, 821 United Nations Plaza, eighth floor, New York, N.Y. 10017. World Relief Corporation, 450 Gunderson Drive, P.O. Box WRC, Carol Stream, Ill. 60188. World Vision Relief Organization. 919 West Huntington Drive, Monrovia, Calif. 91016.

title: Werner Felfe, a Leading Official In East Germany, Is Dead at 60
description: Werner Felfe, a member of East Germany's ruling Politburo and the nation's Agriculture Minister, died after suffering a heart attack today, the state press agency reported. He was 60 years old.

title: Bush, Before the Legion, Vows a Strong Defense
description: Warning that the United States is ''not out of the woods'' in dealing with the Soviet Union, Vice President Bush today urged the continued modernization of American nuclear forces as the only way to achieve further arms reductions.

title: 2 Companies Will Stop Sales Of Pesticide Used on Cotton
description: The two sellers of chlordimeform, a pesticide used on an eighth of the nation's cotton crop, have agreed to quit marketing the product and will recall leftovers from farmers after the current growing season, the Environmental Protection Agency said today. The agency said it would make the distribution or use of the chemical, a suspected cancer agent, illegal after Feb. 19. The product has been used to destroy the eggs and larvae of the tobacco budworm and the cotton bollworm.

title: Tyson Discharged From the Hospital
description: Mike Tyson was discharged late yesterday from Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after undergoing three days of care following an automobile accident Sunday in which he suffered a concussion. His treatment apparently included a psychiatric consultation.

title: Leaders' Pact On Vote Panel Faces a Hurdle
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch have agreed to have a screening panel recommend a new executive director of the New York City Board of Elections - but the Board of Elections has already chosen someone.

title: Regan Bans Staff From Any Fund-Raising Role
description: In his first public appearance since records of his official dealings with campaign contributors were subpoenaed last week, the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, today announced a new policy for employees of his office that would prohibit them from having ''even minimum dealings'' with his fund-raising activities.

title: Parent & Child
description: ''MY nose is too big!'' ''I wish my ears didn't stick out!'' ''I'm too fat!'' Almost all children, at some point, say they don't like something about the way they look. Why does the same nose that a parent finds cute loom so large in a teen-ager's mirror? Why do children choose a particular time to say something about them is wrong and should be fixed?

title: Picking a Hero
description: One way to get attention in Washington is to make heroes of officialdom's adversaries. An outfit here that is proving adept at that is a glossy year-old magazine, The International Economy, published by two sometime political consultants, David Smick, a Republican, and Richard Medley, a Democrat.

title: Who's Running for Bronx District Attorney
description: Salvador Collazo, 40. Born in Puerto Rico. In private practice. Graduate of Fordham College and Seton Hall Law School. Assistant district attorney, 1977-83. President, Puerto Rican Bar Assn. Former regional president, Hispanic National Bar Assn. Member, Mayor's Committee on Judiciary. Counsel to Hispanic Court and Corrections Officers Associations and Police Hispanic Society. Married, one child. Philip F. Foglia, 37. Bronx born. Graduate of Lehman College, Pace Law School. Staff of Council of Belmont Organizations and Italian American Alliance for Education, 1973-77. Executive director of New York Center for Community Affairs, 1977-80. Assistant district attorney 1980 to earlier this year. Worked with U.S. Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani on Bronx corruption cases. Married, two children. Robert T. Johnson, 40.Bronx born. Graduate of City College and New York University Law School. Lawyer, Legal Aid Society, 1975-78. Assistant district attorney 1978-86, chief of narcotics bureau for two years. Appointed Criminal Court Judge by Mayor Koch, 1986 to last June. Unsuccessfully sought State Supreme Court nomination last year. Has Conservative and Liberal Party endorsements. Separated from his wife. One child. John C. Klotz, 51. Born in Syracuse. Graduate of Syracuse University and Law School. Assistant counsel to Association of the Bar, 1969-71. Private practice since then specializing in Federal litigation and election law. Ran unsuccessfully three times for State Senate in 1969 and 1972 and Civil Court in 1977. Attempted to run for borough president last year but could not qualify for ballot. Longtime opponent of Bronx Democratic leadership. Married, three children.

title: Delegate From Samoa Quits
description: Fofo I. F. Sunia, nonvoting delegate to Congress from American Samoa, officially resigned Tuesday, a month after he pleaded guilty in a payroll padding scheme.

title: 3d Federal Trial Set For Gene Gotti and 2
description: A Federal judge yesterday set Jan. 16 as the start of the third racketeering and drug-trafficking trial of Gene Gotti and two other defendants. Two earlier trials ended in mistrials.

title: Consumer Group Challenges Agency Over Sandbox Safety
description: Children's sandboxes, normally the place of castles, sculptures and imaginary wars, are at the center of an actual battle over what some people charge are dangers lurking in the sand.

title: Judge Prohibits an Abortion For Woman Seeking Divorce
description: A county judge has prohibited a woman from obtaining an abortion during a divorce proceeding, calling her estranged husband's bid to block the abortion a type of custody fight.

title: Auto Projects Offer Sharp Contrasts
description: AS far as introductory automotive advertising goes, yesterday morning provided a vivid study in contrasts. Class and mass. Toys for those who have attained and for those still reaching.

title: Cuomo Vetoes Bill to Curb Dairy Actions
description: Governor Cuomo vetoed a bill tonight that was intended to prohibit ''coercion'' of dairy farmers by dairies seeking to assure their supplies of milk in the state.

title: Illiteracy - Death in Life
description: LEAD: On Nov. 8, millions of Americans will flock to the banner of George Bush, and millions to the banner of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. Not literally, of course: They will be pulling the levers on voting machines.

title: Richard Lapidus, 53, Professor of Physics
description: Richard Lapidus, head of the physics department at the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., died of a heart attack Sunday morning while running in a 2.5-mile road race in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 53 years old and lived in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday on the Education page about the Upward Bound program misidentified the department that finances the program. It is the Department of Education.

title: Metro Matters; Race and Justice: Realm of Reality And Perception
description: Still unresolved almost 10 months after it unfolded, the Tawana Brawley case underscores a fundamental question about the criminal justice system.

title: Landeta Is Sidelined by Back Problems
description: It's almost tempting to feel sorry for Sean Landeta. The Giants' punter missed nearly all of training camp because of a contract dispute before agreeing to a two-year deal worth $445,000. The ink had barely dried before things began to sour.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Campi Bisenzio Journal; A Fairground Full of What's Called Communism
description: As a full moon rose big and yellow over the Tuscan hills, streams of people began making their way from parking lots in bulldozed corn fields to a little city of circus tents where the largest Communist party in the West was celebrating its identity crisis.

title: G.M. to Pay More for Its Steel
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it had reached agreements with the nation's major steelmakers on new purchasing contracts. G.M. would not disclose the terms of the agreements, but steel industry officials said the increases averaged about 3 percent.

title: At Least 1,000 Flee Flooding in Florida; More Rain Forecast
description: Flood waters swept a motorist away in Tampa today, closed schools in several towns and forced the evacuation of at least 1,000 people after three days of heavy rain on Florida's central Gulf Coast.

title: Enron Notes Set To Yield 9.62%
description: The Enron Corporation, a Houston-based diversified energy company, is offering $100 million of 9 1/2 percent notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.531, to yield 9.62 percent, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: For the New York Assembly
description: New Yorkers vote next Thursday in a primary election. Here are The Times's endorsements for State Assembly races, all Democratic, in which primary victory is tantamount to election.

title: Bridge
description: If there had been an award for the best defensive play of this summer's International Team playoffs in Memphis, it would probably have gone to Bob Wolff of Dallas for his effort in the West seat on the diagramed deal, played on June 1.

title: Inflation Plan Set by Peru
description: The Peruvian Economy Minister, Abel Salinas, announced a tough anti-inflation program late Tuesday that doubles basic food prices and devalues the national currency for most Peruvian exports by 47.5 percent against the dollar.

title: Purple-Heart Project Gets Site for Museum
description: The Town Council has voted to donate 14 acres of land and spend $7,000 to help establish the proposed National Purple Heart Museum in Enfield.

title: Browning-Ferris Picks Ruckelshaus as Chief
description: William D. Ruckelshaus, who twice headed the Environmental Protection Agency, was named chairman and chief executive yesterday of one of the nation's largest waste-disposal companies, Browning-Ferris Industries of Houston.

title: Italian Police Report Arrest of 21 in Terror Group
description: The Italian police said today that they had broken up Italy's most violent leftist terrorist group with the arrest of 21 people in raids before dawn in Rome and its suburbs.

title: Immigration Law and the Hispanic Dropout Rate
description: To the Editor:

title: DISORDER IN BURMA LEADS U.S. TO DRAW EVACUATION PLANS
description: Looters raided Government offices and warehouses in Burma today, as the United States and other countries drew up plans to evacuate relatives of diplomats endangered by growing turmoil in Rangoon.

title: Fiat Raises Stake In Ferrari to 90%
description: Fiat S.p.A., Italy's largest private industrial company, said that it had increased its stake in Ferrari to 90 percent after buying the shares of its founder, Enzo Ferrari, who died last month at age 90. Fiat said it had raised its stake by 40 percent, paying about $13.6 million in recent months. A Fiat spokeswoman declined to say when the transaction occurred.

title: 3 in Polygamist Clan Are Charged in Killing
description: Three polygamist clan members were charged today with second-degree murder in the death of a state corrections officer killed in a shootout that ended the clan's 13-day standoff in a rual compound.

title: Reebok Debenture
description: Reebok International Ltd. is offering $100 million of 9 3/4 percent debentures due 1998 at a price of 99.90, to yield 9.766 percent through Kidder, Peabody & Company. Noncallable for seven years, the debentures are priced to yield about eight-tenths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The issue is rated A- by Moody's and BBB by S.& P.

title: Question of Identity
description: Suppose that during Britain's mandate over Palestine, in the years before 1948, British officials had shut down a Federation of Jewish Charities, calling it a front for Zionism. Suppose they had closed the Jewish Press Association, the Federation of Jewish Trade Unions and the professional organizations of Jewish lawyers, doctors and engineers.

title: TURKEY MOVES OUT 2,000 IRAQI KURDS
description: Turkey transferred at least 2,000 Iraqi Kurdish refugees to Iran against their wishes last week, Turkish reporters and witnesses in this mountainous border region say.

title: Retired Police Officer Arraigned in Assault
description: A retired police officer was arraigned Wednesday on a misdemeanor assault charge for an on-duty incident in which the police said he kicked and hit a woman as she watched last year's New York City Marathon in Brooklyn.

title: Utility Aide Put on Leave
description: An accountant for the Georgia Power Company who acted as an Internal Revenue Service informant has been placed on leave, the company said today.

title: Presidential Farewells
description: President Reagan, having polished a farewell routine that has become familiar in recent months, will say goodbye today to T. Kenneth Cribb Jr., his domestic policy adviser, in a private White House ceremony.

title: Market Place; The 'Greenhouse' Impact on Energy
description: IF the ''greenhouse effect'' pushes temperatures up and rainfall down, which way will energy stocks move? Some analysts on Wall Street believe a global rise in temperatures could attract new interest in fuels and energy technologies that produce little of the ''greenhouse gases.''

title: In Today's World of High Technology, a Greater Role for Schools Is Emphasized
description: While American industry undertakes multimillion-dollar programs to improve the reading, writing and mathematical skills of workers beyond what they learned in school, a consensus is emerging that the public schools should bear the major responsibility for raising literacy levels.

title: Homelessness Swelled In the Reagan 80's
description: To the Editor:

title: T.V.A. Nuclear Official Stepping Down
description: The board of the Tennessee Valley Authority announced today that Steven A. White, the man who was hired to restart the agency's troubled and much-criticized nuclear program, would leave the agency in November.

title: Russians Welcomed to Nome
description: The first official delegation of Russians to cross the Bering Strait since it was closed 40 years ago arrived in this historic gold-mining town today, seeking to improve contacts between the superpowers' most remote regions.

title: Schuyler Van Vechten Jr., Advertising Executive, 65
description: Schuyler Van Vechten Jr., an advertising executive, died in his sleep Saturday at his home in Highlands, N.J. He was 65 years old.

title: Agreement Averts Queens Bus Strike
description: The union representing 1,300 Queens bus drivers and mechanics agreed to a contract yesterday with the city. A strike deadline had been set for 12:01 A.M. today. The walkout would have affected 300,000 riders.

title: The Welcome By Nepalese Is More Wary
description: For years, this Himalayan kingdom, renowned for its tough Gurkha soldiers, its Hindu traditions, its spectacular views of the world's highest mountain range and as a trekker's paradise, has lived uneasily with a growing flood of foreign tourists.

title: 6 Oil Ministers to Meet
description: The six oil ministers of the Gulf Cooperation Council will meet Oct. 16 to review ways of stabilizing the world oil market, the Kuwait News Agency said today. Officials of the council acknowledged that the ministers would meet but declined to confirm the date. The council consists of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar, all OPEC members, and Bahrain and Oman, which are not.

title: Crew of Space Shuttle Makes Inspection Visit
description: Five astronauts today made an inspection of the space shuttle Discovery, which they hope to ride into orbit late this month. The commander, Frederick H. Hauck, reported, ''It all looks clean; it all looks good.''

title: An Easy, Glossy Finish For Wood
description: LEAD: PADDING lacquer, not widely known outside the restoration trade, is a simple and reasonable substitute for French polish, which requires much skill and labor to apply.

title: In Park, a Chess Hustler Mixes Patter With Profit
description: Sweet P, whose real name is Bobby Plummer, calls himself a chess hustler, and he is every bit of that. This short man with an engaging grin and a fast patter will take on all comers at the street game on the north side of Bryant Park in mid-Manhattan, playing for $3 or $4, and he does not lose very often.

title: Boesky Figures Prominently In Charges Against Drexel
description: LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and four of its employees are facing civil charges of insider trading, stock manipulation and improper disclosure of stock holdings, as well as charges of fraud.

title: INSIDE
description: Move on Literacy Rates

title: Extension Granted in Bid for Irving
description: The Federal Reserve Board granted the Bank of New York another extension late yesterday to its application to acquire the Irving Bank Corporation. Irving had opposed the extension and had stated in a letter to the Fed last week that if it were granted it would create ''the unavoidable impression that the Bank of New York has been granted special, favored treatment.''

title: TALKS ON MIDEAST CALLED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan has invited the Israeli and Egyptian Foreign Ministers to meet with him in New York to discuss prospects for Middle East peace, American and Israeli officials said today.

title: Ainslee Cox Memorial
description: A memorial service for Ainslee Cox, the conductor, who died Monday, is to be held Sunday at 3 P.M. at Christ Church United Methodist, 520 Park Avenue, at 60th Street.

title: Court Puts Off Hearing On Irish Distillers Fight
description: The long fight for control of the Irish Distillers Group P.L.C. took another surprise turn today in Dublin, where the Irish High Court delayed a hearing on the takeover battle until early October.

title: Talk-Show Hoaxers Face One of Their Victims
description: Two Chicago actors who have admitted misrepresenting themselves in appearances on three nationally syndicated talk shows return to ''Sally Jessy Raphael'' today to confront one of the most outraged victims of their ruse.

title:
Books of The Times;
Sicily in 1943: A Major but Neglected Campaign
description: LEAD: Bitter Victory The Battle for Sicily, 1943 By Carlo D'Este Illustrated. 666 pages. E. P. Dutton. $27.50.

title: U.S. Has a Battle Plan for War on Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air France, Paris, said it would resume flights between Paris and Teheran next month.

title: Prime Minister of Iran Retracts a Resignation
description: Iran's Prime Minister has withdrawn his resignation under orders from Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, official Iranian news outlets said today.

title: China's Boeing Jets
description: The Boeing Company said the Chinese Government had ordered three Boeing 757-200 jets for about $125 million. The twin-engine jets are scheduled to be delivered to the Civil Aviation Administration in China beginning in December 1989. They will be equipped with RB211-535E4 engines made by Rolls-Royce P.L.C. and will carry about 200 passengers. Boeing said it had received a total of 368 orders for 757's from 23 operators worldwide.

title: Champion Reopens Mills
description: The Champion International Corporation reopened five Pacific Northwest mills on Tuesday after workers ratified a three-year contract. The wood products company will bring back its 2,400 union workers on a staggered basis, Dennis Elder, a spokesman for Champion, said. The mills had been idle since the strike began on June 6. Mr. Elder predicted it would be late this week or early next week before all mills were running normally again.

title: U.N. Will Teach Afghan Refugees to Defuse Mines
description: The United Nations official overseeing aid for Afghanistan plans to spend much of this winter on a campaign to teach Afghan refugees how to defuse the hundreds of thousands of mines, booby traps and unexploded munitions that litter their homeland after eight years of civil war.

title: Boston Police Seize 183 Pounds of Heroin
description: The authorities seized 183 pounds of nearly pure heroin with an estimated street value of $1 billion and arrested four people today, Federal and local law enforcement officials said.

title: Ford Truck Move Seen
description: The Ford Motor Company may replace production of its popular Escort car with a truck at its Edison, N.J., plant, the auto industry journal Ward's Automotive Reports said this week. The publication quoted sources who said that Ford might be nearing an announcement that it plans to build Ranger-size trucks at the plant. A Ford spokesman, John Spelich, said today that the company had a policy of not commenting on future manufacturing plans.

title: Seikaly Signs
description: The Miami Heat yesterday signed its top draft pick, Rony Seikaly of Syracuse. The expansion club would not disclose terms of the contract for the 6-foot-11-inch center, but The Miami Herald has reported the deal to be worth $4 million over five years.(AP)

title: 2 Years' Probation For Felling a Tree
description: A man who chopped down a neighbor's 83-year-old oak tree to improve reception on his television satellite dish received two years' probation yesterday in Superior Court and was ordered to stay off the neighbor's land.

title: Review/Television; 'Today,' With a British Accent
description: David Frost is a singularly unflappable fellow. On the ''Today'' show this Monday, the ever buoyant Englishman was introduced as this week's co-host by Jane Pauley, who called him ''Deborah Frost.'' Without missing a beat, Mr. Frost replied, ''Thank you, Jim.''

title: Keep the Open in New York
description: THEY did a terrible thing the other night, stirring up old memories. Tennis magazine held a party at the West Side Tennis Club, right on the gritty green particles at center court.

title: Democrats Criticize Bush's Role As the House Takes Up Drug Bill
description: The House of Representatives today began debating legislation to combat drugs, one of the major issues of the Presidential campaign, with Democrats criticizing Vice President Bush and the Reagan Administration as failing to enforce anti-drug laws.

title: New Name for 50 Plus
description: Some of the elderly may be delighted to learn that the magazine 50 Plus, recently acquired last January by Reader's Digest, will change its name in December to - get this -New Choices (followed in smaller type by For The Best Years). It was announced by Gerald G. Hotchkiss, publisher, who is one of the crowd himself.

title: Krickstein Defeated by Cahill
description: He slowly packed his racquets, knowing it would be for the last time at this year's United States Open. Aaron Krickstein came into the tournament unseeded, but was within one step of the semifinals. It was an opportunity that Krickstein knew might never come again.

title: Review/Television; When the Taught Can't Learn
description: A play that gives a viewer something to chew on is good news for the start of yet another season on the tube. Such a treat is on tap tonight at 9 P.M. on CBS in the shape of ''Open Admissions,'' a powerful and splendidly performed drama about issues that must trouble many thinking people in America these days.

title: Shopping-Center Explosion ills a Black in Johannesburg
description: An explosion in a northern Johannesburg shopping center killed at least one person today, witnesses said.

title: A Christmas Insert By Fortune Magazine
description: As the Christmas holidays approach, Fortune magazine's advertising sales staff always tries to conjure up ways of profiting from the practice of corporate giving, getting ads from the marketers of items suitable for giving.

title: Hunts Sign Penrod Plan
description: The Hunt brothers said today that they had signed a bank-approved reorganization plan for their Penrod Drilling Company, bringing their three trust estates a step closer to emerging from bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Home Improvement
description: WOOD paneling adds warmth and charm to a room. But conventional paneling, consisting of individual boards of the desired wood, is usually expensive and requires much skill and time to install. An alternative is veneer-covered plywood paneling. This is made of ordinary plywood to which a thin layer of desirable wood has been bonded. Because little fine wood is used, plywood paneling is less expensive, and because it is sold in sheets, less skill and time are required to install it.

title: Amnesty Rock Tour Performs in Budapest
description: A capacity crowd of 81,000 that included Prime Minister Karoly Grosz and other Hungarian Communist officials attended an all-star concert Tuesday night at Nep Stadium, the only Eastern European stop on the rock tour organized by Amnesty International to promote human rights.

title: Auto Safety in a Cul-de-Sac
description: Search the speeches of Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael D. Dukakis for evidence that they think safer motor vehicles are a matter of national concern. You'll wind up in a dead-end street. This is astonishing, for injuries related to the use of motor vehicles are the leading cause of death to most age groups - starting with newborns.

title: Union at Bat for Lynn
description: If the Major League Baseball Players Association prevails in its position and the Detroit Tigers cooperate, Fred Lynn will get to play in postseason games after all.

title: 'Waste Is Worse Than Loss'; Reversing the Trend
description: To the Editor:

title: Debate Advice
description: A week ago, I raised an eyebrow at the way the Dukakis crowd had used the job-creating credit of the State of Massachusetts to set up a ''telemarketing'' operation that then was used to raise money for the Dukakis campaign.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday, with an article about an agreement between the Bush and Dukakis campaigns on televised debates, gave an incorrect date for the meeting between the campaign managers shown in the picture; the meeting was Aug. 30. The agreement on the debates was accomplished Tuesday by telephone.

title: Hazen G. Werner, Methodist Bishop, 93
description: Hazen G. Werner, a retired Bishop of the Methodist Church, died of heart failure Monday at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 93 years old.

title: Arrangements That Tease the Viewer
description: THE word scrim mostly has to do with the theater. A scrim is a thin gauze curtain behind which actors and scenery can be seen when lights are on them. But they are seen as if in a mist, which softens their outlines and causes them to lose definition.

title: Surgery for Schmidt
description: Mike Schmidt of the Philadelphia Phillies underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right shoulder yesterday and is expected to be ready for spring training next year. The 45-minute operation to repair a tear in Schmidt's right rotator cuff was performed in Birmingham, Ala., by Dr. Jim Andrews. The 39-year-old Schmidt, who last played Aug. 12, finished with 12 home runs and 62 runs batted in. . . . Tim Raines of the Montreal Expos will be out the rest of the season with a shoulder injury. Raines is to undergo an operation on his left shoulder next week and expects to spend a month recovering. The left fielder suffered the injury in July when he dived to catch a ball in Cincinnati. He aggravated the problem early in August while making a headfirst slide into second base against the Pirates. (AP)

title: Dukakis Campaign Seeking To Resolve Jackson Issues
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's campaign for the Presidency sought to make peace with the Rev. Jesse Jackson today and to get him to shift his fire from the Democratic Presidential nominee to Vice President Bush.

title: For a Few Rock Players, Music Is All In the Family
description: LEAD: ''I GOT Gary Lee his first guitar in 1975 for $10,'' said Cathy Conner, the mother of Gary Lee Conner, the 26-year-old guitarist in the rock band Screaming Trees. ''It was this really neat American-flag guitar - red, white and blue with an amp right in it.'' That same year Mrs. Conner introduced Gary Lee to the rock music of the 1960's by taking him to yard sales, where they would hunt for 60's albums.

title: Consumers Say No To Machines That Talk
description: LOCKED away in a laboratory in Benton Harbor, Mich., far from the ring-around-the-collar crowd, is an ordinary-looking clothes dryer. Its almond-colored enamel finish is as shiny as any other dryer just off the assembly line at the Whirlpool Corporation plant there. It dries clothes as fast as any other dryer: 30 minutes for permanent-press fabrics, 60 minutes for terry-cloth towels.

title: Continental Health Seeks Healthdyne
description: Continental Health Affiliates Inc., a regional home-health-care concern, has offered to purchase the shares of Healthdyne Inc. that it does not own for $6 a share, or about $82 million. Healthdyne, based in Marietta, Ga., provides home-health-care services through its Home Nutritional Support division, based in Pine Brook, N.J.

title: Review/Book; How the Italians Resisted the Occupying Germans
description: The Other Italy The Italian Resistance in World War II By Maria de Blasio Wilhelm 272 pages. Illustrated. W. W. Norton. $18.95.

title: Navratilova Rally Fails as Garrison Wins in 3 Sets
description: Everything she valued in tennis -the No. 1 ranking, the Wimbledon title and now, the championship of the country she chose as her home when she left Czechoslovakia in 1975 - has been stripped like epaulets from her tennis whites. When she reflects on the events of the past 12 months, Martina Navratilova will wonder whether these are temporary setbacks or conclusive evidence that she will never again reign as the dominant player in the game.

title: Headless Body Identified as Officer's Ex-Wife
description: A headless body found in the Hudson River in April has been identified as that of a Bronx woman whose former husband, a police officer, retired after refusing to answer questions about her disappearance, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Baseball Notebook; Slow-Motion Race in East
description: Is this any way to run a pennant race?

title: 'Waste Is Worse Than Loss'; Why the Right Fails To Gain on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Trips In Speech
description: Vice President Bush made a slip of the tongue today when he declared, ''Today is Pearl Harbor Day - 47 years ago from this very day we were hit and hit hard at Pearl Harbor.''

title: Currents; Looking Upon Perfection, They Found It Boring
description: POPULAR literature on American design has largely focused on interior decoration or architecture. In his book ''New American Design: Products and Graphics for a Post-Industrial Age'' (Rizzoli, $35, 1988) the writer Hugh Aldersey-Williams tries to change that.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BASEBALL Cuba 4, United States 2: Lourdes Gurriel hit a game-tying two-run homer in the bottom of the ninth and Lazaro Vargas singled in the winning run as Cuba rallied for a victory over the United States yesterday to win the world championships in Parma, Italy. Cuba, the defending champion, beat the Americans with a ninth-inning rally for the second time in the tournament. The Cubans rallied Sunday for a 10-9 victory. The Americans will go on to the Seoul Olympics, where baseball is a demonstration sport. Cuba is boycotting the Games. In the consolation game, Taiwan beat Japan, 4-2.(AP) HORSE RACING Tinchen's Prince Triumphs: Tinchen's Prince, ridden by Randy Romero, made his move around the final turn, caught front-running Jazzing Around in the stretch and went on to a 2 1/4-length victory yesterday in the $85,950 Hudson Handicap for New York-breds 3 years old and up at Belmont Park. Easy N Dirty outran the rest of the seven-horse field to finish second, 5 1/2 lengths ahead of Jazzing Around. Tinchen's Prince covered the mile and a sixteenth on the fast track in the stakes-record time of 1:41 1/5, bettering the previous established by Fearless Teddy in 1986 by one-fifth of a second.(AP)

title: 2 DEMOCRATS GIRD FOR FLORIDA RACE
description: Two Florida Democrats face three and a half more weeks of campaigning to decide which of them will face a Republican Congressman for a seat in the United States Senate.

title: Events: 17th-Century Riches on Display
description: English Country House, the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street; 212-860-6868.

title: Kimco Buys Campeau's Gold Circle
description: Gold Circle discount stores, one of the nation's biggest discount chains, will soon cease to exist.

title: Currents; A Streamlined Design For City Newsstands
description: THERE are hundreds of newsstands in New York City. Hari Nair does not like many of them.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Mark Jackson Honor
description: Mark Jackson, the Knick guard who was the National Basketball Association's rookie of the year last season, today will be become only the second sports personality to receive a certificate of appreciation from New York City. The certificate will be presented by Mayor Koch at 12:30 P.M. today on the steps of City Hall. Dave Winfield of the Yankees was the other sports personality so honored. Jackson will be cited for ''his contribution to the resurgence of the Knicks, his commitment to community service and his efforts to enhance New York City on and off the court.''

title: Promoting C.D.'s With Politics
description: Trying to harness the excitement over Presidential politics, several savings associations are offering bonuses to depositors who pick the winner of the election.

title: Cowboys Seek Buyer
description: H. R. (Bum) Bright, who has been unsuccessful in his efforts to sell the Dallas Cowboys, has asked the team's general manager, Tex Schramm, to find a buyer. Schramm performed a similar role for the club's original owner, Clint Murchison, when Murchison sold the club to a group headed by Bright in 1984. Schramm has engaged Salomon Brothers, the New York-based investment banking firm, to find a group of investors willing to meet Bright's asking price for the franchise, Texas Stadium and the club's headquarters and practice facilities. Salomon Brothers, which said it began an active search for buyers about two weeks ago, is barred by a confidentiality agreement from publicly discussing financial details.

title: KEY RATES
Expert in Turnarounds Gets the Top Job at York
description: James T. Dresher, who helped pull off a turnabout at the York International Corporation, has been named chairman and chief executive of the air-conditioning manufacturer.

title: New Haven School to Require Uniforms
description: Helene Grant Elementary School here will require its students to wear uniforms, beginning Oct. 3.

title: Griffin Extends Bid For Resorts Stock
description: The entertainer Merv Griffin has extended his $205 million offer to buy the common stock of Resorts International Inc. until Friday because the deal has not been approved by New Jersey gaming authorities. In announcing the extension of the $36-a-share tender offer, the Griffco Acquisition Corporation said the holders of 81 percent of Resorts' class A common stock had offered to sell their shares.

title: Dirndls: What's Old Is New
description: For centuries, from housefrock to wedding gown, German women have worn some variation of the dirndl - a tight-waisted dress with contrasting apron, often with a ruffle of slip peeking from beneath full skirts.

title: Weston Journal; Hardy Survivor in Year of Drought
description: Earl Benner Jr., the owner of the land, and Louis Smither, a neighbor with a crop of his own, looked on with satisfaction as Ronnie Moppin, a sharecropper, led a harvesting crew through a yellowing field of burley tobacco.

title: Currents; Victorian Parlors Re-enacted
description: ONCE household words, the terms lambrequin, hassock and antimacassar have gone the way of the hoop skirt and the bustle. But in 19th-century America, they - rather than the built-in stereo system and the recliner - were the staples of fashionable middle-class interiors.

title: Currents; Art of the Impossible-Made-Probable
description: MUCH of the talk at the recent Worldesign conference in New York of the Industrial Designers Society of America centered on how American business might be made more receptive to good design, particularly in light of foreign competition.

title: Service for Jo Henderson
description: A memorial service for the actress Jo Henderson will be held tomorrow at noon at the Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street. Miss Henderson, who appeared in a number of Broadway and Off Broadway productions over the past 30 years, died in a car accident in Arizona on Aug. 7. Speakers at the service, which is open to the public, will be Lloyd Richards, artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater, and Tanya Berezin, artistic director of the Circle Repertory Company.

title: Suspension at Texas
description: Eric Metcalf, a tailback who is the key to the University of Texas offense, has been declared ineligible for the game at Brigham Young tonight by order of the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Metcalf, a senior who ran for 1,925 all-purpose yards last year, accepted money from the Texas athletic department to pay for summer school this year but failed to attend either of two summer sessions at the school. ''It was a minor mistake and the money was paid back to the university out of his own pocket,'' said DeLoss Dodds, the school's athletic director. ''Still, it is a violation.''(AP)

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly described the ownership of the Adolf Coors Company. The family-operated company's class B common stock is traded over the counter under the symbol ACCOB.

title: PANEL IS TOLD V.A. FACES DEEP CRISIS
description: The Veterans Administration's nationwide hospital network was described at a Congressional hearing today as being in a deep financial crisis that has left it understaffed, poorly maintained and forced to use money meant for medical equipment to pay salaries.

title: Budapest University Will Add Jewish Studies
description: The only university institution for Jewish studies in the Communist world will begin its first year of full operation this fall at Budapest University.

title: Mets Look Bored In Loss
description: Are they bored, jaded or just restless waiting for the playoffs to begin in three weeks? And are they a sure thing or still vulnerable?

title: Church-State Debate Blocks Day Care Bill
description: The effort in Congress to deal with a relatively new problem, the need for day care for millions of young children whose mothers are working outside the home, has become mired in one of the oldest debates in American life: where to set the boundaries between church and state.

title: PENTAGON OFFICIAL PROPOSES COST CUT FOR SPACE WEAPON
description: The director of the nation's anti-missile program has prepared a new proposal that would cut its budget substantially but would preserve the Reagan Administration's goal of deploying the system, including the first weapons in space, in the late 1990's.

title: Harlem Tour Stresses Need for School Repairs
description: Using a rundown school building in Harlem as a backdrop, Governor Cuomo, Mayor Koch and Richard R. Green, the New York City Schools Chancellor, tried yesterday to increase pressure on the State Senate to enact legislation intended to make school construction more efficient in the city.

title: Round 1 to Stars & Stripes
description: Dennis Conner sailed his first race in defense of the America's Cup today like a doctor afraid of a malpractice suit.

title: Board Declines to Urge Clemency for Fugitive
description: The state Pardon Board refused today to recommend freedom for a man who built a new life in Tennessee during more than 17 years as a fugitive from prison.

title: More Businesses and Schools Join To Attack Illiteracy in Workplace
description: The nation's shortage of literate workers has spawned some unconventional partnerships between business and education.

title: Yankees Lose but Stay 5 Back
description: Yankee Stadium is supposed to be the site of a critical pennant-race series beginning tonight, but the only thing that appears to be critical is the Yankees, as in the patient is in critical condition.

title: Oilers' Herzeg Resigns
description: The Houston Oilers' general manager, Ladd Herzeg, who has been embroiled in a paternity suit, resigned yesterday, but the team's owner, Bud Adams, refused to accept the resignation. ''I submitted my resignation from the Houston Oilers as executive vice president and general manager on the basis of a very personal and private matter,'' Herzeg said in a statement read by his attorney, Steve Underwood. Herzeg said he had agreed to report on a day-to-day basis.(AP)

title: Jewish Militants Strike Back, Raid National Front in Paris
description: Jewish militants attacked the Paris offices of the extreme-rightist National Front early today, in reprisal for an anti-Semitic remark by the party's leader, Jean-Marie Le Pen.

title: Taubman Seen Selling Units
description: Taubman Holdings Inc. has appointed Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Morgan Stanley & Company to explore the possibilities of selling the two Taubman store divisions -Woodward & Lothrop in Washington and John Wanamaker in Philadelphia - retail executives said today.

title: Pakistan Says Jets Downed Intruding Afghan Warplane
description: Pakistani jet fighters shot down an intruding Afghan warplane today and Afghan aircraft bombed three Pakistani villages near the Afghan border, Pakistani authorities said.

title: 'Smokeless' Cigarette Evaluated
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company sent an extensive scientific assessment of its new ''smokeless'' cigarettes to members of Congress yesterday.

title: Biden Return Brings Purrs to Senate
description: Smiling, tanned and almost bashful about all the fuss, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. returned to the Senate today, seven months after a brain aneurysm and subsequent complications nearly took his life.

title: Soviet Space Mission Ends in Relief and Criticism
description: A Soviet astronaut and his Afghan crewmate were welcomed with relief at the Baikonur launching center in Kazakhstan today while the ground commanders of their problem-plagued flight tried to explain how a routine re-entry maneuver went awry not once but twice, stranding them in space for 25 tense hours.

title: A Jerseyan's Mission: To Russia With Pizza
description: The New Jersey man who introduced a slice of America to Muscovites with a mobile pizza truck last spring said today that he wants to build the Soviet Union's first full-fledged pizza parlor.

title: Depression In Alcoholics Transitory, Study Finds
description: Doctors should use caution in prescribing antidepressant drugs to alcoholics who are under treatment to stop drinking, a new study suggests, because in many cases the depression will lift without drugs.

title: Computer Chip Talks Are Set
description: Semiconductor consumers and producers will hold an industry meeting Thursday in San Jose, Calif.

title: Scorsese's 'Last Temptation' Creates Furor at Venice Festival
description: It was never intended, of course, to become the Martin Scorsese Film Festival, but that essentially is what Venice has been for the last 10 days.

title: Fertile Carp in Ponds Pose Too Great a Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Bribes Paid By Goodyear To Iraqis
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company paid about $1 million in bribes to officials of the Iraqi Government several years ago in a bid to obtain tire contracts, a company spokesman said today.

title: California Edison Has Debt Offering
description: Among new competitive corporate issues priced yesterday was a $125 million debt offering by the Southern California Edison Company, which was won by a winning bid from an underwriting group led by Shearson Lehman Hutton, a unit of the American Express Company.

title: Women's Groups Begin Push For Parental Leave Measure
description: More than two dozen women's groups today began a campaign for legislation requiring all but the smallest companies to grant unpaid leave to parents of newborn or seriously ill children.

title: Shultz to See Iraqi on Reported Gassing of Kurds
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will register United States concern about charges that Iraq is using chemical weapons against the Kurds when he meets in Washington with a high Iraqi official Thursday, the State Department said today.

title: Rocket Launching
description: The Ariane space rocket is scheduled to launch two American satellites Thursday that will serve clients including the United States Secret Service and the K Mart Corporation. The Ariane 3 rocket will carry two telecommunications satellites that are designed for television, telephone and digital-data transmission. The rocket is scheduled to take off from the European Space Agency's base at Kourou, French Guiana.

title: Fire in Yellowstone Tourist Area Destroys Cabins but Passes Geyser
description: Wind-driven flames feeding on tinder-dry trees and brush swept into the tourist complex near the Old Faithful geyser today, burning a dozen park buildings and forcing some 40 firefighters to flee.

title: Panel Finds U.S. Failing In Safeguarding Health
description: A panel of experts assembled by the National Academy of Sciences today expressed ''great concern and some alarm'' that the nation's public health programs had fallen into disarray.

title: Water Recedes, Spirits Rise in Dhaka
description: The sun was shining in Dhaka today, the water was receding, and for a moment at least, there was a more hopeful air in city neighborhoods.

title: New Jersey Will Let Non-Teachers Be Principals
description: The State Board of Education adopted new standards for school principals today that for the first time will allow people with no teaching experience to manage schools in New Jersey.

title: The Cast of Characters
description: Michael Milken: The 42-year-old head of Drexel Burnham's high-yield bond department. Has almost single-handedly made ''junk bond'' financing one of the principal tools used to finance corporate takeovers. Born in Los Angeles, the son of an accountant. Attended the University of California at Berkeley, where he majored in mathematics. Received M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, Joined Drexel's Philadelphia office in 1969 as a part-time computer analyst while finishing second year of M.B.A. program. Became head of Drexel's emerging bond department in 1971. Described as an exceedingly driven man who puts in 18-hour workdays. Lives in Encino, Calif., with his wife and two children. Personal fortune has been estimated at more than $500 million. Lowell J. Milken: Brother of Michael Milken. An attorney. Works in Los Angeles office of Drexel's high-yield bond department. Cary J. Maultasch: A senior equity trader in New York for Drexel's high-yield bond department. Pamela R. Monzert: A trader based in Los Angeles for Drexel's high-yield bond department. Victor Posner: Miami-based financier. Dropped out of school when he was 13 and worked with his father, a Russian immigrant. Started selling real estate in Baltimore as a teen-ager, and became a millionaire by the time he was 25. Known for collecting companies, often through unfriendly takeovers, the 69-year-old executive now controls some 40 public companies. Personal fortune estimated at $180 million. Pleaded no contest last September to 10 Federal tax-fraud counts for inflating the value of land he donated to a religious school. Steven N. Posner: The 45-year-old son of Victor Posner. Vice chairman and a director of the Pennslyvania Engineering Corporation. Ivan F. Boesky: The 51-year-old one-time king of Wall Street's arbitragers. Son of a Russian immigrant who owned a chain of delicatessens in Detroit. Started earning money when he was 13 by driving an ice cream truck. Completed the Detroit College of Law in 1964. In 1975, began the first of many independent brokerage houses devoted entirely to arbitrage. Personal fortune was estimated at some $200 million at its peak. Agreed to pay $100 million in 1986 to settle civil charges relating to insider trading. Has been serving a three-year prison sentence since March after pleading guilty in the scandal.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Holders Support Plan Taking T.W.A. Private
description: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., won investor support yesterday to convert T.W.A. into a private company.

title: Talking Deals; Gillette Buyback: Playing It Safe
description: WHEN the Gillette Company agreed last month to retire about 15 percent of its 112 million shares to appease its largest and most nettlesome shareholder, Coniston Partners, the Boston-based consumer products giant could have offered to buy the shares in one fell swoop. But such highly publicized partial tenders have put some companies into play inadvertently.

title: F.D.A. Seeks to Destroy 45,000 Flawed Condoms
description: The Federal Government has gone to court to try to confiscate nearly 45,000 condoms that it says are defective.

title: Former Stock Analyst Admits Insider Guilt
description: Stephen Sui-Kuan Wang Jr., a former financial analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company, yesterday pleaded guilty to charges that he had engaged in an illegal insider trading scheme with at least two people.

title: DREXEL BURNHAM CHARGED BY S.E.C. WITH STOCK FRAUD
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged yesterday that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. had engaged in a secret agreement with Ivan F. Boesky to defraud Drexel clients, trade illegally on insider information, manipulate the prices of stocks and violate a host of other securities regulations.

title: All 42 Men Learned to Read
description: No one knows how many Americans are illiterate; many millions, for sure, and the number is increasing even as their opportunities for employment are decreasing. Without a literate work force, the country often described as the first to enter the 20th century will stumble into the 21st.

title: New Groups Aim to Help Parents Face Grief When a Newborn Dies
description: A movement to help parents cope with intense grief after losing a child to miscarriage, stillbirth or infant death is spreading rapidly around the country.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning 11 A.M. - Steffi Graf-Gabriela Sabatini vs. Chris Evert-Wendy Turnbull or Patty Fendick-Jill Heatherington. Second match - Ivan Lendl vs. Derrick Rostagno. Third match - Mixed doubles final. Evening 7:30 P.M. - Andre Agassi vs.

title: Workers in a Greek Shipyard Strike After Explosion Kills 4
description: Shipyard workers staged a 24-hour strike in this industrial port outside Athens today after four maintenance workers were killed when an explosion split a Greek oil tanker in half.

title: L.I. Mother Is Slain And Father Is Hurt; Son, 17, Is Arrested
description: A woman was stabbed to death in her home and her husband, the village constable in this exclusive North Shore community, was critically wounded this morning, and their 17-year-old son was arrested in the attack hours later, the police said.

title: Judge Blocks Lucky Merger
description: A Federal judge today temporarily blocked the $2.5 billion acquisition of Lucky Stores Inc. by the American Stores Company and scheduled further hearings on a preliminary injunction.

title: HDM Reorganization
description: Michael Drazen, the 46-year-old creative director of HDM, the three-nation joint-venture ad agency, will now share his duties with three other men as the result of a reorganization of his department. All senior vice presidents and former associate creative directors, the new creative directors are Frank Fleizach, 41; Mark Hughes, 30, and Ronald Arnold, 35.

title: Orkin Keeps Thompson
description: Orkin Exterminating, an Atlanta-based subsidiary of Rollins Inc. and which had J. Walter Thompson as its agency for 12 years, has spent the last two months searching for a new agency. Yesterday Orkin, which has 330 branches, announced that it had decided to stay with Thompson. The other finalists were Ogilvy & Mather, Atlanta, and Henderson Advertising, Greenville, S.C. They had been picked from a field of 11 agencies.

title: Father Ruled Insane In Daughter's Killing
description: A man from Southington who heard ''a command from God'' to kill his 7-year-old daughter was found not guilty by reason of insanity Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An Executive Changes listing in Business Day on Monday about the new chief executive of Talbots Inc. misstated the apparel chain's ownership. It was sold by General Mills to Jusco of Japan in July.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS Drexel Burnham Lambert was charged with a two-year scheme of illegal insider trading, defrauding clients, stock manipulation and other securities violations. Some of the long-awaited charges by the S.E.C. were more severe than had been anticipated. Four Drexel employees were named, including Michael Milken, the head of its junk-bond department, whose lucrative deals have been responsible for the firm's enormous growth within the last decade. The complaint also accused the Miami industrialist Victor Posner and his son Steven of violating Federal securities laws. [ Page A1. ] In all but two of the 18 instances in which the S.E.C. found fault with Drexel, Ivan F. Boesky, the convicted arbitrager, served as a ''front'' for Drexel, the S.E.C. said. [ D6. ] The U.S. sold $2.93 billion in dollars at the end of June and in July to try to slow the dollar's summer rally, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said. That was the most concerted attack on the dollar since the second half of 1985. [ D1. ] Investors can tie C.D. deposits to the Presidential election, earning bonuses if their candidate wins. Several savings institutions are offering what they call ''Presidential C.D.'s.'' [ D1. ] Yields rose on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds for the week ended yesterday. [ D17. ] French Government bonds will be traded as A.D.R.'s, starting later this month, on the New York Stock Exchange. [ D1. ] Stock prices edged higher as the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.53 points, to close at 2,065.79. It was the third consecutive gain for the Dow. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds ended slightly lower, as market participants cast an apprehensive eye on the dollar. [ D16. ] Coffee futures prices rose sharply for the second day on fears that a dry spell in Brazil could lengthen into a drought. [ D18. ] Stephen Sui-Kuan Wang Jr. pleaded guilty to charges that he engaged in an illegal insider trading scheme. [ D6. ] THE ECONOMY A bill to limit the growth of imports of textiles, clothing and shoes cleared a major hurdle in the Senate, virtually assuring its passage later this week. That would set the stage for another trade confrontation with the Reagan Administration. The Senate voted, 68 to 29, to restrict debate on the measure, which would allow imports of textiles and clothing to increase 1 percent a year, compared with the 16 to 17 percent annual increases of most of this decade. [ A1. ] COMPANIES G.M. reached agreements with the nation's major steelmakers on purchasing contracts. G.M., the nation's largest steel buyer, would not disclose the terms of the agreements, but steel industry officials said the increases averaged about 3 percent. [ D1. ] Gold Circle discount stores will soon cease to exist. Campeau said it had sold its 76 Gold Circle stores to Kimco Development, which in turn will sell most of them to Target and Hills. [ D1. ] R. J. Reynolds sent an extensive scientific assessment of its new ''smokeless'' cigarette to members of Congress. [ D5. ] Ireland's High Court delayed a ruling for at least a month on whether the handshake agreement between Irish Distillers' largest stockholder and one of its suitors is binding. [ D2. ] Goodyear paid $1 million in bribes to Iraqi officials several years ago, a company spokesman said. [ D5. ] Carl C. Icahn won overwhelming investor support to convert T.W.A. into a private company. [ D5. ] Southmark was found liable for more than $130 million in a suit brought by a San Diego businessman whose company Southmark bought. [ D8. ] A Federal judge temporarily blocked the acquisition of Lucky Stores by American Stores. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Gillette carefully plotted its buyback, hoping to minimizing the difficulties of some partial tender offers. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Fearful of the greenhouse effect? Some analysts identify ways to turn that problem into a profit. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Activated Rick Aguilera, pitcher, from the 30-day disabled list. BASKETBALL MIAMI (NBA) - Signed Rony Seikaly, center, to a multiyear contract. FOOTBALL NATIONAL FOOTBALL LEAGUE -Suspended Calvin Thomas, Chicago Bears fullback; Richard Dent, Chicago Bears defensive end, and Charles White, Los Angeles Rams running back, for 30 days for violations of the league's substance-abuse policy. CLEVELAND (AFC) - Waived Darryl Haley, lineman. Re-signed Glen Young, kick returner. GIANTS (NFC) - Signed Maury Buford, punter. Placed Sean Landeta, punter, on injured reserve. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Waived Larry Mason, running back. LOS ANGELES (AFC) - Signed Steve Wright, lineman, and Russell Carter, defensive back. Waived Norwood Vann, linebacker. Placed Vann McElroy, saftey, on injured reserve.

title: Review/Television; An ABC Study of 'The Poisoning of America'
description: ''Burning Questions: The Poisoning of America'' is a straightforward, forceful and only too timely documentary for the torrid, dry and dirty summer of '88. The ABC News special, which can be seen tonight at 10 o'clock on Channel 7, reviews in punchy fashion the assaults on air and water that threaten health and recreation today and that may threaten existence tomorrow. The tone is one of outrage at a dire situation, which the narrator, Hugh Downs, attributes to ''apathy, greed and politics.''

title: Personal Health
description: The advertisements for exercise clothing and fitness classes would have you believe that physical activity is exclusively pursued by people with beautiful bodies for the sole purpose of keeping them that way. For years this image of exercise only for the already trim has kept millions of overweight people off running trails and bicycles and out of sweats and swimsuits.

title: Stocks Edge Higher as Dow Gains 0.53
description: LEAD: Stock prices edged higher yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.53 point to close at 2,065.79.

title: 'Doomsday' Layoff Plan Adopted for Yonkers
description: A New York State board adopted a ''doomsday'' plan today for cutting city services here to provide money to pay contempt fines that will reach $1 million a day by Friday.

title: Lester Lewis, Producer And Agent, Dies at 75
description: Lester Lewis, a radio and television producer and a talent agent, died of cancer Aug. 24 at the Jacob Perlow Hospice of Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chinese Leader Is Rooting for Bush Victory
description: Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, told American officials today that he hoped Vice President Bush would be the next President of the United States.

title: Currents; Sugar and Spice and Blueprints and T Squares
description: ''I CANNOT, in whole conscience, recommend architecture as a profession for girls,'' the architect Pietro Belluschi once wrote. But if one really insisted, he said, he would give her his blessing. ''She could be that exceptional one.''

title: Arab Said to Have Killed Israeli
description: A 25-year-old West Bank Palestinian man has confessed to strangling an Israeli teen-ager to death and then burning her body last month, the police said today.

title: Move to Curtail Textile Imports Gains in Senate
description: A bill to limit the growth of imports of textiles, clothing and shoes cleared a major hurdle in the Senate today, virtually assuring its passage and setting the stage for another election-year trade confrontation between Congress and the Reagan Administration.

title: Barrett Industrial
description: The Nissan Motor Company and the Marubeni Corporation have bought the American folklift-truck maker Barrett Industrial Trucks Inc. for an undisclosed amount. Nissan plans to produce 1,000 engine-driven forklift trucks at the Barrett factory by the end of 1988 and to bring production to 4,000 in the next year, a Nissan spokesman said. The company exported about 4,000 engine-driven folklift trucks to the United States last year. Barrett, based in Marengo, Ill., is a unit of the Chicago Blower Corporation.

title: Victorian Wall Designs
description: ''THE Victorian view of a white wall was diametrically opposed to ours,'' said Bruce Bradbury, whose California company, Bradbury & Bradbury Wallpapers, has been selling reproductions of Victorian wallpaper since 1976. He emphasized his point by quoting Christopher Dresser, an avant-garde 19th-century wallpaper designer: ''A white wall is always appropriate for lavatories and pigsties.''

title: McDonnell to Build A Longer Aircraft
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation plans to introduce a longer version of its wide-body MD-11 aircraft by 1994. The new design, which would seat about 600 people and have a range of more than 8,000 miles, is an attempt to offer an aircraft that would compete with the Boeing Company's 747 model, a McDonnell Douglas spokesman said.

title: A K.G.B. Aide Attacks Secrecy, His Agency's Stock in Trade
description: A K.G.B. official, in an article published this week, says that excessive secrecy in the Soviet Union has produced abuses of power, crippled scholarship and left citizens ignorant of basic information about their own country.

title: Officer Cuomo Leaps Into Hot Pursuit
description: Governor Cuomo, in Harlem yesterday to visit a dilapidated school, jumped out of his car to help the police chase a suspect in a Manhattan subway token theft.

title: New Delhi Imposes Direct Rule in a Turbulent State
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today dismissed a popularly elected state government of former insurgents in the northeastern state of Mizoram and ordered direct rule by New Delhi after more than a week of political instability.

title: Eleanor G. Kubie, Author, 89
description: Eleanor Gottheil Kubie, an author and artist, died of acute leukemia Sunday at her home in Westport, Conn. She was 89 years old.

title: New York Area Sales Languish
description: Sales among several leading New York retailers continued to languish in August, averaging 2.4 percent ahead of August 1987 in the city and seven-tenths of 1 percent behind in the metropolitan area, a spot-check this week found. Sales failed to keep pace with inflation, which has been about 4 percent in the retail sector.

title: Joyce Brown Held in Drug Case; Police Seize Heroin and Needles
description: Joyce Brown, the homeless woman who challenged a Koch administration program to hospitalize mentally ill street people forcibly, was arrested yesterday by the New York City housing police at a Harlem housing project and charged with illegal possession of heroin and hypodermic needles, officials said.

title: TV Notes
description: The Early Numbers

title: Woman, Unsure if She'll Quit Job, Claims $55 Million Lottery Prize
description: A real estate broker who said a middle-class person ''always needs money,'' presented a winning Lotto ticket today to claim a record $55 million prize.

title: The Early Harlem Musical Scene, From a 100-Year-Old's Perspective
description: In 1920, Bessie Benjamin Taliaferro moved into a brownstone at 232 West 138th Street in Harlem with her brother-in-law, William N. Spiller, and her sister, Isabele Taliaferro Spiller. The street soon became a sort of unofficial headquarters for the music that grew out of Harlem in the 1920's and 30's.

title: Democrats Hope to Set Fund-Raising Record
description: Democrats expect to break a record for political fund-raising in New York by collecting more than $5 million at a dinner Thursday at the New York Hilton.

title: Fed Sold $2.93 Billion In Dollars
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday that the United States sold $2.93 billion in dollars at the end of June and in July, in an effort to slow the dollar's summer rally.

title: Owners to Act On Giamatti as Commissioner
description: Major-league baseball club owners stood ready to name A. Bartlett Giamatti commissioner-designate today at their quarterly meetings in Montreal.

title: Her Moment to Remember, Finally
description: As the pace of her match became more dizzying, as the potential match points came and went and the sounds from the crowd at Louis Armstrong Stadium became more and more desperate, something good happened to Zina Garrison yesterday afternoon.

title: French Government Bonds To Be Traded in New York
description: American investors may buy French Government bonds on the New York Stock Exchange later this month after the exchange completes arrangements for listing the bonds as American depository receipts.

title: Bill Communications Is Placed on the Block
description: Bill Communications Inc., one of the oldest and most diversified privately owned publishers of business magazines, has been put up for sale.

title: City Opera Picks Successor to Sills
description: Christopher Keene, a 41-year-old conductor who resigned as music director of the New York City Opera in January 1987, will succeed Beverly Sills as general director of the company, opera officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. Open; A Look at Old and New Times
description: Up on the top tier of the bleachers, the tanning enthusiasts outnumbered the tennis enthusiasts. A steady stream of people swarmed past on their way to watch Ivan Lendl play, ignoring the players who toiled on lesser courts for lower pay, or no pay at all. A few patrons studied today's tennis schedule like a racing form, but most were oblivious to the nonstar matches.

title: National Education Group Backs Dukakis for President
description: The National Education Association today endorsed Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts for President.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 452 money market mutual funds decreased by $239.9 million, to $266.93 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 126 institutional funds decreased by $104 million, to $68.73 billion. Assets of the 223 general-purpose funds were down by $172.2 million, to $84.98 billion. The 103 broker-dealer funds increased by $36.3 million, to $113.22 billion.

title: Conferees on Welfare Bill Report Accord on a Work Requirement
description: Enmeshed in Presidential politics, welfare legislation made some progress today as the chairmen of House and Senate conferees agreed on two key issues.

title: Mike Tyson and the Wall
description: THE people around Mike Tyson can scoff at reports that he aimed his car at a tree last Sunday morning, but there is no denying that for years Tyson has been hurtling his life at a brick wall.

title: Review/Film; 'Running on Empty,' A Family Underground
description: The Pope family knows things that other families don't. For instance, the Popes know how to leave town forever on a moment's notice, abandoning everything, even the family dog. The parents, Arthur (Judd Hirsch) and Annie (Christine Lahti), know how to find new jobs that don't require much experience or attract much attention. The children, Danny (River Phoenix) and Harry (Jonas Abry), know they ought to miss school on the day when class photographs are being taken. All the Popes know how to change the subject smoothly when anyone asks who they are or where they came from.

title: Campbell Soup Company reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $3,700,000 for the quarter and a pre- tax gain of $40.6 million for the year, from plant closings and early retirement; the year also includes a gain of $32,500,000 from an accounting change.

title: Newport Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Avant-Funk Band
description: Curlew, an avant-funk band, is to perform tomorrow at 9 P.M. and midnight at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $8.

title: Barge Spill in Mississippi
description: A barge ran aground and cracked open near Natchez, Miss., early today, spilling about 42,000 gallons of styrene, an flammable liquid, into the Mississippi River, the Coast Guard said. The Coast Guard closed a 50-mile stretch of the river to shipping.

title: Pilot Knew of Plane Trouble Seconds Before Crash
description: The captain of the Delta Air Lines jet that crashed on takeoff in Texas last week declared, ''We're not going to make it'' and then called for ''full power'' on the engines just before impact, according to the cockpit voice recorder recovered from the crash.

title: U.S. Open; Agassi Knocks Out Connors
description: They could have been father and son, two baseliners hammering forehands and two-fisted backhands across the net, trading grunts and clenched fists, one coming of age, the other trying to prove that the old man still had what it would take to put the kid in his place. There was even one time in the second set when Andre Agassi mimicked Jimmy Connors as he toweled off between points, like a boy watching his dad shave.

title: Amre Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The year-ago results are restated to reflect a change in accounting for taxes.

title: Seagram Co Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included dividend income from E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. of $52,004,000 for the quarter and $98,534,000 for the 6 months and equity in unremitted earnings of Du Pont of $90,701,000 and $175,721,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included dividend income from Du Pont of $43,413,000 for the quarter and $86,826,000 for the 6 months and equity in unremitted earnings of $67,104,000 and $108,890,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Court Review of V.A. Claims Backed
description: A bipartisan group on the House Veterans Affairs Committee signaled today that they would support limited access to the courts for appeals of Government decisions on veterans' disability and pension benefits.

title: Martha Bruner, 86, Ex-Foundation Chief
description: Martha Bruner, a philanthropist and former foundation president, died of a stroke on Aug. 28 at Long Island Jewish Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan before moving recently to Tucson, Ariz.

title: Times Raising Price To 35/ on Sept. 19
description: The New York Times will raise the suggested newsstand price of its weekday issues to 35 cents, from 30 cents, within 75 miles of New York City and on all of Long Island starting Monday, Sept. 19.

title: Ward Sending Unit To Tompkins Square To Fight Drug Trade
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that he planned to assign a special group of officers to Tompkins Square Park similar to one that rid Washington Square Park of heavy drug trafficking last year.

title: Pritzkers Make Offer For Ramada
description: The Pritzker family of Chicago has offered $10 a share, or about $368 million, to buy the outstanding common stock of Ramada Inc., the hotel and gambling casino operator.

title: Labatt, John Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Jets Must Face Another Old Pro
description: This is not what the young, vulnerable Jet defensive secondary needs: a second straight week of facing the National Football League's oldest starting quarterback.

title: Reviews/Film; Curious Scenes From a Southern Marriage
description: From the fevered and weirdly musical imagination of Dennis Potter (''Pennies From Heaven,'' ''The Singing Detective'') comes ''Track 29,'' the portrait of a deluded, repressed and neglected Southern housewife married to a nasty, infantile doctor who has trains on the brain. (The title comes from the song ''Chattanooga Choo-Choo''). This story has found its way into the even more fevered hands of Nicolas Roeg, a director who has done brilliant work when the material was right (''Don't Look Now'') and hair-raising work when it wasn't (''Bad Timing: A Sensual Obsession'').

title: Malrite Communications Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $399,000.

title: About Real Estate; Residential Use of Jersey Industrial Land
description: Vacant industrial land may seem an unlikely place for a large low-rise condominium development with a health club, tennis courts and jogging trails. But just such a project, the Hampton Club with 650 units, is under construction in an industrial park in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: TCA Cable TV Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Royal Bank of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss and included an $800,000,000 provision for losses on Third World debt. Figures are in Canadian funds. Year-ago figures are restated for a change in accounting rules for loan losses. The company is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Yonkers Syndrome Permeates Northeast From S.I. to Boston
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cain Chemical Inc., Dallas, a producer of ethylene, ethylene oxide and derivatives, high-density polyethylene and related chemicals, appointed Frank H. Romanelli president of its petrochemical division. Cain is a subsidiary of Occidental Petroleum Corp.

title: Msgr. J.J. Kowsky, 66, Police Dept. Chaplain
description: Msgr. John J. Kowsky, the Roman Catholic chaplain for the New York City Police Department, died, apparently of a heart attack, Wednesday at his brother's home in Queens. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Baseball; Ryan 5-Hitter Puts Astros 5 Games Out
description: Nolan Ryan pitched a five-hitter and Buddy Bell singled home the game-winner in the eighth inning as the Houston Astros edged the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2-1, tonight.

title: Rykoff-Sexton Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The increased number of shares outstanding reflects conversion of convertible subordinated debentures into common stock.

title: Growth in Consumer Credit Slowed in July
description: Americans took out $2.6 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in July, a sharp slowdown from the pace of growth during the first half of the year.

title: Clients Appear to Be Sticking by Drexel, or at Least for Now
description: A spot-check of longtime clients of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. yesterday indicated that, at least for now, clients intend to stick by the firm in spite of allegations made by the Securities and Exchange Commission that Drexel had violated securities laws and may have defrauded clients.

title: The Two Faces of South Korea's Capital City: Rumpled and Olympic-Tidy
description: There are two Seouls - the everyday one that screeches and blares and laughs out loud, and the sanitized one that is being polished and buffed for the world to see.

title: What's Behind The Dollar's Rise?
description: THE great surprise in world financial markets this summer has been the sharp rally of the dollar. Few economists had expected it after private foreign investment dried up last year and the United States had to depend on foreign central banks to finance its external deficit.
