But, after dropping more than 15 percent against a trade-weighted average of other currencies in the latter half of 1987, the dollar stabilized and then took off this summer. It was back to where it was a year ago before starting to slip again in the past week.

title: The Israeli and the Palestinian
description: It's hardly news when the director general of the Israeli Foreign Ministry says he opposes creating a Palestinian state on the occupied West Bank. It was news when he added, as he did in Washington last week, that ''everyone knows'' the Palestinian Liberation Organization is viewed by Palestinians as their ''national organization.'' And it became astonishing when he said: ''There is no replacement for them. So the question is not how to replace the P.L.O., but how to change it.''

title: Protest at the Guggenheim
description: A demonstration billed as a 30th birthday party for the Guggenheim Museum was held yesterday across the street from the museum at 89th Street and Fifth Avenue. Pickets opposing a proposed addition to the museum paraded around a birthday cake made in the shape of the museum.

title: Review/Film; A So-So Actor Gets His Best Role: Impersonating a Dictator
description: Parador, the Caribbean dictatorship where Paul Mazursky's new film takes place, is definitely a nice place to visit. The carnivals are colorful, the music lively, and the natives are friendly - even the bottom-pinching dictator and the diabolical, scheming chief of police.

title: Brady, W H Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Evert to Face Graf Today
description: With Martina Navratilova no longer posing a threat, the popular opinion is that the United States Open championship and Grand Slam will be a formality for Steffi Graf. But any of the three remaining players in the Stop Graf Movement - Chris Evert, Zina Garrison and Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina - are potentially dangerous opponents, not to be taken lightly.

title: Bonneville Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a $131,000 tax benefit.

title: Plea Entered in Cable Killing
description: An 18-year-old transient has pleaded not guilty in the death of a motorcyclist whose throat was slashed by a cable stretched across a bridge. Jason D. Levison entered his plea on Wednesday in Municipal Court.

title: Takeover Stocks And Drexel Woes
description: WHEN clouds appear over Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., stocks involved in hostile takeovers can also face troubles, as speculators wonder if Drexel's problems will interfere with the financing of those deals.

title: Oldsmobile's Goal
description: With a new campaign aimed at younger car buyers, the General Motors Corporation's Oldsmobile division predicted sales would increase 5 to 10 percent in the 1989 model year. G.M. executives also said they planned an aggressive advertising campaign for the model with the theme, ''It's not your father's Oldsmobile,'' aimed at lowering the average age of their buyers, currently about 50 years old. At a news conference marking the introduction of Oldsmobile's 1989 line of autos, Oldsmobile's general manager, William Lane, said he expected sales to increase to 735,000 to 750,000 in 1989, compared with 700,000 in the 1988 model year.

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Spacecraft Adrift

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Pavin and Barr Share Lead: Corey Pavin and Dave Barr shared the lead by a stroke yesterday after the opening round of the $700,000 Greater Milwaukee Open. Pavin, who beat Barr in a four-hole playoff for the 1986 championship, used a string of four birdies on holes 13 through 16 to finish the opening round at six-under-par 66 on the 7,030-yard Tuckaway Country Club course. Ed Fiori and Jim Gallagher were tied at 67. Barr gained the tie when he birdied his final two holes, ending with an 8-iron approach shot that landed four inches short of the cup.(AP) Coody Leads: Charles Coody, seeking his first career title on the Senior PGA Tour, shot a six-under-par 66 to take the lead after one round of the inaugural $350,000 GTE North Classic. At 65 were Dick Rhyan, Dale Douglass and Ken Still after the first round of the 54-hole tournament at Broadmoor Country Club. The best finish for Coody, the 1971 Masters champion, in 22 tournaments this year, was second place at the rain-shortened Newport Cup July 24. (AP) BOXING Santiago Wins: Felix Santiago of Brooklyn beat Sergio Aguirre of Harlingen, Tex., when Aguirre declined to continue after six rounds of a scheduled 10-round bout last night at the Felt Forum. Santiago, a welterweight, avenged the only defeat of his career. Aguirre beat him in a 10-round decision 20 months ago. Santigo's record went to 21-1-1 with 16 knockouts. Aguirre is 31-12 with 19 knockouts. In an earlier bout, Terry Davis, a heavyweight from Vallejo, Calif., knocked out Jack Johnson of Miami in 39 seconds of the first round. Davis is 17-0-1 with 16 knockouts.

title: Alliant Computer Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $295,000 and $1,028,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; the quarter also includes a charge from merger and consolidation costs of $5,473,000. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $616,000 and $1,521,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago results were restated to reflect the acquisition of Raster Technologies, effective June 17, 1988.

title: America's Cup; Teams Agree on '91 Regatta
description: The smoke was still rising out of the New Zealand camp today over the 18-minute defeat Wednesday of its monohull by Dennis Conner's catamaran.

title: A Brawley Adviser Says Family Plans To Leave New York
description: Tawana Brawley and her family are planning to move out of New York State, according to their adviser, the Rev. Al Sharpton.

title: Cuban Jumps Record 7-11 1/2
description: Javier Sotomayor Sanabria of Cuba broke the world record for the men's high jump in a minor track and field meet today.

title: Fretter Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss and after a gain of $630,036 from a change in accounting principle.

title: Credit Accounts at Sears Back $500 Million Offering
description: Sears Credit Account Trust is offering $500 million of credit account pass-through certificates due in 1993. The certificates have an average life of 2.5 years and are rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: 'Are You Ordering Me to Stay?'
description: Mayor Koch was in a courtroom in Brooklyn yesterday to ask for stiff sentences for a group of people accused of stealing from New York City parking meters. After he finished his statement, he asked Justice Ruth E. Moskowitz if he could be excused and the following exchange took place:

title: Dycom Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Diner's Journal
description: Rosa Mexicano

title: Yanks Recover; Mets' Hitters Wake Up; Yankees 7, Tigers 4
description: The fly ball that Gary Ward hit in the 10th inning last night floated toward the wall in left-center and then disappeared quickly behind it. But whether the Yankees ride the shot that won the game is something they still can't answer. Not now.

title: At the Movies
description: Director Dresses Up

title: Cuomo Signs Bill on Dr. King
description: Saying government has a responsiblity to promote nonviolence, Governor Cuomo signed legislation yesterday establishing a state institute that will encourage the study of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s methods and philosophy in New York schools and colleges. He signed the bill in his New York City office at the World Trade Center to create the New York State Martin Luther King Jr. Institute for Nonviolence, a $1.5 million public corporation to be based in Albany with a 13-member board appointed by the Governor.

title: Record Spending Seen By Businesses This Year
description: Despite rising interest rates, the nation's businesses plan to increase their plant and equipment spending to record levels this year as capital investment remains one of the strongest sectors of the economy.

title: Mercury Found In Proposed Site Of Nature Area
description: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service said here today that high levels of mercury, a deadly poison, had been found in a proposed national wildlife refuge within the New Orleans city limits.

title: Corrections
description: The television highlights listing on Wednesday carried an erroneous entry for ''The Big Sleep.'' The film, on Channel 5, was the 1978 television remake of the Raymond Chandler mystery novel, starring Robert Mitchum; it was not the 1946 Howard Hawks film starring Humphrey Bogart.

title: Quayle Discards His Script on Military Issues and Raises Eyebrows
description: Senator Dan Quayle, in a wide-ranging discussion of military issues, today called for upgrading NATO weapons, developing a defense against missiles, support for Israel and greater military expenditures by Japan.

title: In a Flash, Britons Outwit Mail Strike
description: The postal strikes of the last week have paralyzed the Royal Mail, but modern technology and traditional British ingenuity have kept them from paralyzing the national economy or repressing the English epistolary urge.

title: First U.S. Missiles Destroyed as Part of Nuclear Treaty With Soviets
description: Two Pershing missile engines were destroyed at an Army ammunition plant here today in the United States' first elimination of nuclear weapons of short and medium range under the new Soviet-American treaty.

title: Ex-SS Man Loses Citizenship
description: Stefan Reger, a 62-year-old Yardville resident, lost his United States citizenship today after his lawyers, in a telephone conference, did not rebut Federal Justice Department claims that he served as a Nazi death-camp guard during World War II. Federal prosecutors said Mr. Reger, a native of Filipovo, Yugoslavia, has admitted being a member of the SS Death's Head Battalion but denied their contention that he was a guard at the Auschwitz II concentration camp known as Birkenau. Mr. Reger is thought to be in Germany, authorities said.

title: Qantel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Museum of Moving Image Celebrates All Video Forms
description: The American Museum of the Moving Image, which bills itself as the first museum in the United States devoted to chronicling the history of producing, promoting and exhibiting movies, television and video art, opens tomorrow in Astoria, Queens.

title: Chrysler Notes Are Selling Well
description: The Chrysler Financial Corporation's $200 million offering of extension notes, which was priced earlier this week, has met good investor demand, with a broad range of institutions showing interest.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums THE FUNZAPOPPIN MAGIC SHOW, a program of comedy and magic, presented by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Tickets: $4.50. Reservations: 772-9180. PLAYING TOGETHER, program of games and toy demonstrations during which children, parents and grandparents observe Grandparents' Day, 1 to 5 P.M. Sunday; at 2 P.M. a performance of ''Dona Anna, Palo Libre-Recordando Nuestros Juegos,'' a living-history play, will be performed by the residents of the Gaylord White Senior Center, at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. The performances are free with museum admission; suggested contributions: families, $5; children, $1; students and the elderly, $1.50; others, $3. Information: 534-1034. ''THE WAR OF THE WORLDS,'' a film based on H. G. Wells's 1898 novel about Martians who invade the Earth, (85 minutes) 2 P.M. Sunday, the Hudson River Museum, 511 Warburton Avenue, Yonkers. Admission: children and the elderly, $1.50; others, $2. The film is presented in conjunction with the planetarium show ''Mars, the Red Planet,'' which will be shown at 1 and 4 P.M. Sunday. Planetarium admission: children and the elderly, $1.50; others, $3. Information: (914) 963-4550. THE HELLO SHOW, a show of dozens of large, cartoonlike creatures, by the Poko Puppets, 11 A.M. and 2 P.M. Saturday, at the Emelin Theater, Library Lane, Mamaroneck, N.Y. Tickets: $4. Information: (914) 698-0098. A STORY HOUR, with Steven Kellogg, an author and illustrator, noon to 2 P.M. Saturday, at Books of Wonder, 132 Seventh Avenue at 18th Street. Free. 989-3270. ''PINOCCHIO,'' a musical version of the Collodi story, performed by members of the Theater Workshop, 1 and 3:30 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, (Sunday, Sept. 10, 1 P.M. only), at the Fantasy Playhouse, 317 Merrick Road, Lynbrook, L.I. Tickets: $5. Reservations required: (516) 599-1982. ''LITTLE MOUSE'S PAINTING,'' a story written and told by Diane Wolkstein, with music by Shirley Keller, a guitarist, 11 A.M. tomorrow at the Hans Christian Andersen statue, near 72d Street and Fifth Avenue in Central Park. Free. ''CINDERELLA WORE COMBAT BOOTS,'' a play with a new slant on the legendary character, 5 P.M. today, 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Westside Arts Theater, 407 West 43d Street. Tickets: $7. Reservations: 541-8394. ''THE WIZARD OF OZ,'' a show by the Puppetworks Theater, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays at 287 Third Avenue, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Tickets: $3.75. Information: (718) 834-1828. ''THE ROSE THAT REFUSED TO BLOOM,'' a musical with audience participation, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays, and ''The Snow White Show,'' a musical, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at the 13th Street Repertory Company, 50 West 13th Street. Tickets: $4. Information: 675-6677. MYSTIC (CONN.) SEAPORT, a 17-acre outdoor maritime museum with historic ships, exhibition buildings and two restaurants. Open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. Admission: children, $5.50; under 4, free; adults, $11. Information: (203) 572-0711. THE SEAPORT EXPERIENCE, a film spectacle about the South Street Seaport, with 104 projectors and 33 speakers-surround audio and 150 special effects, every hour on the hour, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays; 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays, at the Trans-Lux Seaport Theater, 210 Front Street. Children, $3; others, $4.50. Information: 608-7888. CLINTON HISTORIC MUSEUM VILLAGE, a 10-acre farm with a 1763 mill, blacksmith shop, log cabin and general store, open 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesdays through Sundays, a quarter of a mile off Interstate 78 in Clinton, N.J. Admission: children, $1.50; the elderly, $2; others, $4. Brochure available. Information: (201) 735-4101. VALLEY RAILROAD, with 1910 cars carrying passengers from the old Essex Station in Connecticut to Chester, a 10-mile round trip. Then a one-hour cruise up the Connecticut River may be taken from the Deep River Station. Train times 10:30 and 11:45 A.M., 1:15, 2:45, 4:15 and 5:30 P.M., Saturday and Sunday; no boat trip connecting with the 5:30 train. Train-boat combination: children, $4.95; adults, $9.95; train only: children, $2.95; adults, $6.95; children under 2, free. Brochure and map available. Information: (203) 767-0103.

title: Soviets Buy More Corn
description: United States grain exporters said today that the Soviet Union had bought 250,000 metric tons of American corn in the last 24 hours, bringing its total purchases since last week to 2.25 million tons.

title: How Much Squeezing Can the Hospital Take?
description: Is the Federal Government shortchanging the nation's hospitals? Or has Washington merely tightened its purse strings in an effort to persuade the hospitals to follow suit?

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Week 2 Could Be Surprising
description: Week One in the National Football League unfolded pretty much according to plan. Except for the Buffalo Bills' 13-10 toppling of the Minnesota Vikings and the Seattle Seahawks' 21-14 victory over Denver in Mile High Stadium, where the Broncos seldom wilt, few results were surprises.

title: Auctions
description: Games People Played

title: Giamatti Named Commissioner
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti, former professor of Renaissance literature and president of Yale University, was elected today to succeed Peter Ueberroth as commissioner of baseball.

title: Penn Traffic Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net loss The increase in shares is primarily attributable to a June 16 $24.5 million stock offering and the conversion of Penn Traffic's convertible preferred stock into common stock. Second quarter represents 13 weeks and 6 months represent 26 weeks.

title: Jazz for Dessert In Club-Restaurants Where Music Is on the Menu
description: AS much as New Yorkers take jazz clubs for granted, noticing them only when they close, they are one of the things that make New York distinct among the world's cities. An integral part of the cultural life, the clubs are also one of the city's better faces. So there's good news: New York, in the midst of a miserable year for clubs and restaurants, has seen, in the last six months, a small explosion of new rooms featuring jazz. Four of the best - Birdland, Zanzibar and Grill, B. Smith's and Fortune Garden Pavilion - are in midtown or the Upper West Side, no longer traditional neighborhoods for jazz. And that's an indication of jazz's continued growth.

title: Denver Symphony Asks Pay Cuts
description: Another American orchestra, the Denver Symphony, faces crisis if not disbandment because of economic quarrels between its board of directors and musicians. A week ago, the board estimated a budget shortfall of as much as $744,000 as of June 30, 1989, and asked the musicians to accept cuts of $325,000 in salary and benefits, Josi Callan, the symphony director of development, said yesterday. The board also asked the musicians to agree to reopen negotiations on a three-year contract scheduled to run until Aug. 31, 1990.

title: BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: New Hearing Is Held On Coloring Movies
description: Hollywood returned to Washington today for another round in the continuing drama about coloring old black-and-white films.

title: Doctor Charged With Dumping Waste Illegally
description: A Manhattan dermatologist and instructor at New York University was arrested yesterday and charged with illegally disposing of medical waste that was found on the Madison Avenue Bridge last month.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Power Tools

title: Democrats Set Record At Hotel Fund-Raiser
description: Democrats set a record for New York political fund-raising last night, collecting more than $5 million from several thousand people who gathered to hear their national candidates, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas.

title: Stocks Close Mixed in Moderate Trading
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 2.67 points, to 2,063.12.

title: Israeli Soldiers Kill a Palestinian In a Clash With Arab Protesters
description: Soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian man and critically wounded a second in the West Bank today in what the army described as a clash between a military patrol and a group of masked Arab demonstrators with knives, clubs and stones.

title: Record Bank Profits Seen
description: United States commercial banks are on a pace to post record-high total profits this year, despite profound problems in the energy-centered economies of the Southwest, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said this week.

title: Taubman Plan to Sell 2 Chains Is Confirmed
description: The Taubman Company yesterday confirmed reports that it had put up for sale its two retail chains: Woodward & Lothrop of Washington and John Wanamaker of Philadelphia. The two department store companies are leading retailers that aim at relatively affluent customers in their metropolitan areas.

title: Brezhnev's Son-in-Law Admits Abuses
description: The son-in-law of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the former Soviet leader, pleaded guilty today to abusing his powers when he was First Deputy Soviet Interior Minister, but denied that he had accepted bribes while in office.

title: Home Federal Savings & Loan (Tenn.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes after-tax gain of $402,000, or 9 cents a share, from writeoff of FSLIC secondary reserve.

title: Antidote for Civilization, Fabulous Vietnam
description: LEAD: ''Rumor has it,'' confides the August issue of Vogue magazine ''that . . . Club Med, always in the right place before anyone else, is said to be scouting Vietnam for a future club.'' Odd news to pick up while flipping through a fashion magazine at the hairdresser. Backward reels the mind - and forward.

title: Yonkers Syndrome Permeates Northeast From S.I. to Boston; Accent Is Different
description: To the Editor:

title: Commander of Soviet Space Mission Admits Error
description: The commander of a Soviet space mission that was stranded in orbit for 25 hours admitted today that he erred by improperly restarting a braking rocket in a failed landing manuever.

title: HOUSE VOTES DEATH FOR DRUG MURDERS
description: The House voted today to permit the death penalty for murders related to Federal drug crimes and to deny even casual drug users a wide variety of Federal benefits, such as student loans and occupancy in public housing.

title: Dr. Frank Cifarelli, Surgeon, 70
description: Dr. Frank Cifarelli, a thoracic and vascular surgeon, died of respiratory arrest Tuesday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Queens. He was 70 years old and lived in Floral Park, L.I.

title: An Unpeaceable 'Kingdom' Where Loners Dwell
description: There is a curious morning-after quality about ''Doc's Kingdom,'' the new Robert Kramer movie that opens today at the Public Theater. The night before was 20 years ago, when Doc, the protagonist, was involved in the passionate upheavals of the 1960's that promised, perhaps threatened, to make the world anew.

title: Lloyd's Expects Huge Loss
description: Underwriters at Lloyd's of London will be hit by record losses because of the hurricane that hit England last October and the explosion of an oil rig in the North Sea in July, the group announced today in its annual report.

title: Toro Company reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Reagan Orders Team to Gauge Help on Fires
description: President Reagan today dispatched a Cabinet-level team to the West to see what additional Federal help was needed in fighting forest fires. The White House said that the number of troops on the fire line was likely to be increased.

title: Report About S.E.C. Post
description: Congressional staff members said today that Mary Schapiro, the general counsel of the Futures Industry Association, is the leading contender to fill the vacancy on the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: How Lawyers Took Over for Sailors
description: In a world that reveres tradition, legalities intrude like the clatter of bongo drums on a string quartet.

title: Single Advertiser Set For Times Section
description: The second part of this Sunday's Sports section in The New York Times, covering the opening of the Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, will have a single advertiser: the Nynex Corporation.

title: College Football Notebook; Penn State to Decide Soon on Thomas
description: Penn State will open its 102d season tomorrow night against Virginia in Charlottesville with Tom Bill at quarterback but without Blair Thomas at tailback.

title: M.S. Hooper, 41, Rights Lawyer
description: Michael Stone Hooper, a lawyer and advocate for Haitian refugees, died of skin cancer yesterday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Poufs May Be 'Out,' but Everybody Loves Campeau
description: A black-tie crowd of 250 powerful New Yorkers filed through a receiving line at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night to pump the hand of a powerful Canadian whose name every third one of them seemed to mispronounce. The name was Campeau (pronounced COMP-oh) as in Robert Campeau, the real estate and retailing magnate who came from the north to pull off two of the biggest takeovers in the history of American business - and who has just been rated one of Canada's 10 sexiest men by Chatelaine magazine.

title: Personal-Injury Lawyer: New Era, New Image
description: Something there is that doesn't love a personal injury lawyer. ''Ambulance chaser'' racing after victims, ''parachutist'' leaping into disaster sites; these have long been the legal profession's catcalls to colleagues who seem to prey on misfortunes.

title: Teresa Weldon Is Wed To Nathan A. Chavin
description: Teresa A. Weldon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Joseph Weldon of Great River, L.I., was married in Las Vegas, Nev., yesterday to Nathan A. Chavin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving A. Chavin of Las Vegas. Rabbi Sanford Akselrod officiated at Congregation Ner-Tamid.

title: New Rabbi, New Year: Pulpit Pressure Season
description: Yesterday, the rabbi went into seclusion.

title: 2 Municipal Issuers Raise $300 Million
description: The State of Massachusetts and Dade County, Fla., tapped the municipal bond market for about $300 million in general obligation debt yesterday.

title: Our Towns; East Side Story: The Long Trail Of Housing Bias
description: As the pressure mounts on the four Yonkers Councilmen holding out, hardly a night goes by when they are not seen on TV making the same two points. First, they say, Federal officials have unfairly singled out Yonkers. Second, they say, people on Yonkers's white East Side don't mind living beside middle-class blacks, they just don't want the welfare types who would come in because of the court order to build low-income units.

title: 7,000 Acres of Urban Wilderness
description: There is a 7,000-acre miracle of nature scattered about the concrete platform that is New York City. Parceled out among the five boroughs, these enclaves of untouched wilderness are the unmanicured segments of the 26,000 acres under the domain of the Department of Parks and Recreation.

title: Interactive Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: American Jewish World Service, 729 Boylson Street, Boston, Mass. 02116. American National Red Cross, Bangladesh Relief, P.O. Box 37243, Washington, D.C. 20013. CARE, Bangladesh Flood Relief, 660 First Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017. Catholic Relief Services, 1011 First Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10022. Church World Service, Bangladesh Emergency, P.O. Box 968, Elkhart, Ind. 46515. Interaction, 200 Park Avenue South, Suite 1115, New York, N.Y. 10003. Lutheran World Relief, Bangladesh Emergency Fund, 360 Park Avenue South, 15th Floor, New York, N.Y., 10010. MAP International, 2200 Glynco Parkway, Brunswick, Ga. 31520. Operation California, 7615 1/2 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles, Calif. 90046. Oxfam America, 115 Broadway, Boston, Mass. 02116. Salvation Army, National Headquarters, 799 Bloomfield Avenue, Verona, N.J. 07044. Save the Children, 54 Wilton Road, Westport, Conn. 06880. United Nations for Bangladesh, 821 United Nations Plaza, eighth floor, New York, N.Y. 10017. U.S. Committee for Unicef, 331 East 38th Street, New York, N.Y. 10016. World Relief Corporation, 450 Gunderson Drive, P.O. Box WRC, Carol Stream, Ill. 60188. World Vision Relief Organization. 919 West Huntington Drive, Monrovia, Calif. 91016.

title: Stories of Death Row, Most With Happy Endings
description: In 1972, the 102 men on San Quentin's death row got a new lease on life when a landmark court decision reversed the juries in all their cases and commuted their sentences to life imprisonment. Forty of them have since been paroled, and several of the parolees are the subjects of ''Life After Death Row,'' which will be broadcast tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 7. The documentary, produced by Janice Tomlin, offers sense, sentiment and sensationalism.

title: The Election Board's Arrogance
description: Betty Dolen, executive director of New York City's troubled Board of Elections, doesn't plan to retire until December - ample time for the 10-member Board to conduct a serious national search for her successor. Yet the Board instead moved quietly this week to appoint Mrs. Dolen's deputy, Daniel DeFrancisco, to the $72,000-a-year post.

title: Judge Scolds Koch in Court For Blaming 'Little People'
description: Mayor Koch traveled to a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday, announcing that he would try to persuade a judge to jail a group of former collection agents who stole thousands of dollars from parking meters. Instead, the judge ignored his plea and scolded him for blaming ''little people'' for a city government failure.

title: Daughter of a Slave Seeks Freedom From Illiteracy
description: As a young girl in Virginia, Helen Elmore, the daughter of a slave, took care of people's children; as an adult in New York, she pressed clothes in laundries. Finally, with ''dimes and quarters'' she had so painstakingly saved from her labors, she fulfilled one dream: although she was nearly 70 years old, she bought a house in Jamaica, Queens.

title: San Francisco Journal; An Unbudgeable Whale Creates Big Problems
description: Well, what would you do if an 80-ton blue whale turned up on your front lawn? Officials in San Francisco have been scratching heads all week since the dead leviathan washed up on the beach at Fort Funston last weekend.

title: Lawrence Brown Is Dead at 81; Was Trombonist With Ellington
description: Lawrence Brown, a trombonist with the Duke Ellington orchestra for several decades, died Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81 years old. Mr. Brown had recently had a stroke, his brother, Harold, said.

title: Gains Reported in Angola Talks
description: Cuba, Angola and South Africa reported progress today in their latest round of negotiations towards peace in Angola and Namibia.

title: Chances of New Insider Law Look Better
description: The chances that Congress will pass legislation this year to increase the penalties for violating insider trading laws have improved, now that civil charges have been filed against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., senior Congressional aides said today.

title: American Academy Names a New President
description: Adele Chatfield-Taylor, a national authority on historic preservation and urban design, has been appointed president of the American Academy in Rome, beginning Dec. 1.

title: Treasury Official Appears To Back the Dollar's Drop
description: A top Treasury official said yesterday that the Reagan Administration continued to believe that a ''destabilizing'' rise in the dollar ''could be counterproductive,'' and at the same time, the official noted that the dollar had fallen from the highs it reached in August.

title: Acquisition Set By Ultramar
description: Ultramar P.L.C., a British-based petroleum exploration and development company, said today that it had agreed to buy a California oil refinery owned by the Union Pacific Corporation for $440 million.

title: Griffin Wins Case
description: The plan by the entertainer Merv Griffin to buy Resorts International Inc. moved a step closer to completion. The Delaware Chancery Court found Wednesday that the $36-a-share offer to holders of class A shares ''is both generous and fair and that the settlement must be approved.''

title: Bridge
description: For the layman, the word ''split'' can indicate an ice-cream treat, a parting from home or a resort in Yugoslavia. For the bridge player, it can be the division of a suit in the opposing hands or, more significantly, a second-hand play with touching high cards.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I will note this is the first time the Mayor is in a courtroom.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE - Announced that A. Bartlett Giamatti was named to a five-year term as commissioner, beginning April 1, 1989. DETROIT (AL) - Purchased the contract of Salvatore (Torri) Lovullo, infielder, from Toledo of the International League. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Renewed its player development contract with the Buffalo Bisons of the Class AAA American Association. FOOTBALL LOS ANGELES RAIDERS (AFC) -Placed Vann McElroy, free safety, in injured reserve. PHILADELPHIA (NFC) - Waived Jonathan Dumbauld, defensive end. Signed Donald Evans, defensive end. HOCKEY TORONTO (NHL) - Signed Scott Pearson, left wing, and Jack Capuano, defenseman. COLLEGES CORNELL - Named Lee Talbot assistant basketball coach. KINGS POINT - Announced that Dennis O'Donnell, sports information director, has resigned to accept a similar position at the University of Rochester. WEST VIRGINIA - Announced that Brett Vincent, basketball guard, is transferring to Robert Morris.

title: French Strike Felt Here
description: If you were planning to call or visit any of France's 12 consulates in this country, its embassy in Washington or its mission to the United Nations in New York today, you might do well to pay attention here.

title: September Scenes at N.Y.U.: Picnickers and Picket Lines
description: In a shady glade in Washington Square Park this week, graduate students, clerical workers and homeless men and women shared a serendipitous picnic that never would have happened but for a labor dispute that has disrupted New York University at the start of its fall term.

title: Yanks Recover; Mets' Hitters Wake Up; Mets 13, Cubs 6
description: The Mets, who have pined and whined over their missing bats all season, got them back today with a clatter that produced 13 runs, 20 hits, 4 home runs, the season's best offense and a 13-6 hammering of the Chicago Cubs.

title: Seven-Mile Walk
description: The New York City Stride, a seven-mile noncompetitive walk through lower Manhattan, will take place on Sunday, beginning at 9:30 A.M. at the World Trade Center Plaza. The walk, sponsored by City Sports Magazine, will include turns around Battery Park City, Battery Park and the South Street Seaport, as well as trips to and from Brooklyn, by way of the Brooklyn Bridge. Registration is $17 on Sunday ($15 in advance). Information; 627-7040.

title: Let Congress Do Justice on Military Contractors
description: To the Editor:

title: Tempers Flare at a Hearing On Yonkers Fund Transfers
description: The tension that has been building in City Hall over mounting contempt fines and the layoffs of city workers required to pay them exploded today in the City Council chamber over a seemingly routine transfer of funds.

title: What the Navy's Anti-Gay Prejudice Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: The Deans' Lists
description: Andrew J. Jacovides, the Cypriote Ambassador to the United States, is only 51 years old, but because of his tenure in the post he stands a strong chance of becoming dean of Washington's diplomatic corps next year.

title: Senate Panel Backs Tax Changes
description: The Senate Finance Committee approved a package of tax changes today, including a ''bill of rights'' for taxpayers involved in disputes with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Review/Art; Angular Sculptures With Multiple Meanings
description: Garth Evans is an abstract sculptor from Cheshire, England, who has definitely not been swept along on the current wave of interest in British sculpture. He is 54 years old, a generation younger than Anthony Caro and a generation older than Tony Cragg and Richard Deacon, one of his former students. He has been living in New York for six years and is almost the same age as William Tucker, another British sculptor who found in the United States the independence he needed.

title: Eastern Environmental reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $65,650 from an accounting change.

title: Where to Glide Across Ballrooms To Big-Band Hits
description: THE Roaring Twenties will roar again and the Swing Era will swing again at the Bethesda Terrace in Central Park tonight, as tuxedoed and begowned legions of New Yorkers dance cheek to cheek to the music of Duke Ellington, Irving Berlin, Fats Waller and Cole Porter. This al fresco excursion into the ''Anything Goes'' heyday of ballroom dancing is open to anyone with a taste for romance and a desire to swirl and swoop under a new moon.

title: Ending PC Chaos in the Workplace
description: A new era in corporate computing is emerging, bringing an end to the chaos and tension that have prevailed at companies since personal computers invaded the workplace.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Lupe Aquino, a former World Boxing Council superwelterweight champion, pleaded not guilty yesterday to two counts each of vehicular manslaughter and drunken driving arising from a San Diego Freeway accident Aug. 14 in which two people were killed. A preliminary hearing was set for Oct. 27 in West Los Angeles Municipal Court. . . . Boris Becker has recovered from a foot injury and will compete at the Seoul Olympics, the West German Tennis Federation said.(AP)

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City on Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Review/Art; Retrospective Covers Guston's Two Careers
description: AS an artist, Philip Guston was blessed with two successful careers, two equally defined identities. During the 1950's, he was a prominent Abstract Expressionist, known for paintings in which simple straightforward horizontal and vertical marks - painting at its most basic - accumulated into vibrant light-filled surfaces.

title: Wall St. Unruffled by Drexel Case; Highlights of the Investigation
description: Major developments in insider cases related to the Boesky scandal: May 12, 1986: Securities and Exchange Commission accuses Dennis Levine of Drexel Burnham Lambert of making $12.6 million in illegal trading on inside information. He agrees to surrender the money, plead guilty to criminal charges and aid the inquiry. Nov. 14: The speculator Ivan F. Boesky agrees to pay a record $100 million penalty to settle charges of trading on inside information supplied by Mr. Levine and also agrees to cooperate. Feb. 11-12: Insider trading charges are filed against Richard Wigton, a vice president at Kidder Peabody; Timothy L. Tabor, a former vice president at Kidder and Merrill Lynch, and Robert Freeman, a partner at Goldman Sachs. All plead not guilty. Feb. 13: Martin A. Siegel resigns as a managing director of Drexel and pleads guilty to illegal stock trading and tax evasion. He agrees to cooperate with the Government and surrender $9 million to settle civil charges of insider trading concerning Mr. Boesky. Feb. 20: Mr. Levine is sentenced to two years in prison and is fined $362,000 for securities fraud, tax evasion and perjury. March 19: Boyd L. Jefferies, founder of the Los Angeles securities firm Jefferies & Co., agrees to plead guilty to two securities fraud charges, one of which involves a relationship with Mr. Boesky. Mr. Jefferies resigns as chairman of his company and agrees to stay out of the securities business for five years. April 23: Mr. Boesky pleads guilty to one criminal charge, conspiracy to make false statements to the S.E.C., and is released without bail as he continues to cooperate with investigators. May 19: The Government drops the Wigton, Freeman and Tabor charges, saying it needs more time to prepare its case. Prosectors predict another indictment, but no charges have been brought. June 4: Kidder Peabody agrees to pay $25.29 million to settle civil charges of insider trading and ''stock parking'' with Mr. Boesky. Dec. 18: Mr. Boesky is sentenced to a three-year prison term. Feb. 18, 1988: John A. Mulheren, a prominent Wall Street trader implicated by Mr. Boesky in wrongdoing, is arrested and accused of threatening to kill Mr. Boesky. March 10: Mr. Mulheren is transferred from Federal detention to a psychiatric hospital. Released, he remains under supervision. March 24: Mr. Boesky begins sentence at a minimum-security facility in Lompoc, Calif. July 5: Mr. Levine is released from a Lewisburg, Pa., prison camp to serve the rest of his term at a Manhattan halfway house. July 6: A federal grand jury indicts GAF; its vice chairman, James Sherwin, and two subsidiaries on charges they manipulated the price of Union Carbide stock in 1986 after trying to acquire the company. These are the first formal charges against a U.S. industrial company that stem indirectly from the Boesky scandal. July 14: GAF and Mr. Sherwin plead innocent. Aug. 4: A Federal grand jury indicts five partners of the investment firm Princeton-Newport Partners and a former Drexel official on charges of racketeering, conspiracy and mail and wire fraud. The case, growing out of the Boesky scandal, is the first time officials of a securities firm are accused of violating the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. All deny wrongdoing. Sept. 7: The S.E.C. charges Drexel and its junk bond expert, Michael Milkin, with securities fraud violations. (Source: Associated Press)

title: United Tote Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $207,862 from an accounting change.

title: Aides to Bush and Dukakis Agree to a Sept. 25 Debate
description: The Presidential campaigns of George Bush and Michael S. Dukakis agreed today to hold debates on Sept. 25 and either Oct. 13 or 14, a victory in the Bush camp's efforts to keep the debates confined to a middle period in the fall campaign already crowded with major televised sports events.

title: The Hispanic Factor
description: If either Presidential candidate can carry both California and Texas, with their total of 76 electoral votes, he will just about have wrapped up the election.

title: Energy Efficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: On Stage
description: Making Political Music

title: Newman Photographs
description: Portraits of 20th-century personages and experiments in photographic abstraction are the main parts of a retrospective of 150 works by the photographer Arnold Newman, opening today at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street. The show will run through Oct. 30. Hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays. Admission: $2 for adults, $1.50 for the elderly, and $1 for children under 12. Information: 873-3400.

title: Gulf & Western Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings and the shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 2, 1988. Revenue represents total revenue.

title: Solar Power Plant Planned for California
description: In a landmark in the development of solar power, a company that currently makes patio lights powered by the sun said yesterday that it would build a $125 million plant in the desert near Los Angeles to make large amounts of electricity directly from sunlight.

title: While Europe Unites, U.S. Is Flying Apart
description: To the Editor:

title: Texan Is Jailed In Bank Fraud
description: Edwin L. Cox Jr. has been sentenced to six months in jail and four and a half years of probation after pleading guilty to bank fraud involving $78 million in loans. He was also fined $250,000 Wednesday by Federal District Judge Joe Fish.

title: Angolans Strive for Military Victory
description: Angola's leadership appears determined to press for a military victory in the country's 13-year-old civil war, despite African, American and Soviet appeals for a negotiated settlement.

title: Getty Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Key Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income c-After losses from discontinued operations of $74,000 for the quarter and $247,000 for the 9 months.

title: Allende Widow Plans Return To Chile for Oct. 5 Plebiscite
description: The widow of Salvador Allende Gossens said today she will return to Chile later this month to help defeat the military regime that overthrew her husband's presidency.

title: Service Corp International reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Apple Held Ready To Display Model
description: Apple Computer Inc. is preparing to introduce a more powerful version of its popular Macintosh II Computer on Sept. 19, reports in several industry trade newspapers said. The upgraded Macintosh will be based on Motorola's 68030 microprocessor, a chip that more than doubles the performance of the 68020 microprocessor used in the current Mac II. The new computer will come with four megabytes of memory and an 80-megabyte hard disk, the reports said. The Cupertino, Calif., personal computer maker will also introduce an optional floppy disk drive designed to permit Macintosh computers to read disks from both Macintosh and I.B.M. computers.

title: Film Concern President Defends Color-Imaging
description: Robert L. Glaser says he's seen ''Casablanca'' about 60 times - the last 15 in color. So it is fitting that he has just been named president of a leading company in the relatively new business of coloring black-and-white films, American Film Technologies Inc.

title: Long-Expected Move Barely Affects 'Junk Bonds'
description: For the last two years, many investors had worried that the market in ''junk bonds,'' which was established by Drexel Burnham Lambert's bond wizard, Michael Milken, in the 1970's, would crack if the Government pressed charges of securities law violatons against the firm.

title: Albany Sets New Rules For Pesticides
description: Regulations mandating that the public be informed when pesticides are to be applied have been adopted by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation and will go into force Jan. 1.

title: Bush Panelist Out After Reports of Anti-Jewish Ties
description: The campaign of Vice President Bush dismissed a member of a panel formed to enlist support among ethnically diverse groupings late today amid allegations by Jewish and Nazi-hunting organizations that he was one of three panelists with anti-Semitic involvements or links to fascist groups.

title: Treasuries Up in Sluggish Session
description: The prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched upward in very sluggish trading yesterday, as market participants prepared for an inflation report due out this morning.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Bank Board Vows Limit On Bailouts
description: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board told Congress today that no more than $16 billion in promissory notes would be issued to guarantee the assets of insolvent savings institutions.

title: Reagan's Done Nothing to Stop the Spies
description: On an Army base in West Germany, a small group of counterintelligence specialists is beginning a long and tedious process of assessing the damage from the latest spy scandal. How many - and which - of the thousands of classified documents that passed through the installation in the last decade are now locked in a safe with a Russian nameplate? It is a question that will be answered only in vague and uneasy generalities.

title: At the Bar
description: The lawyer standing at the front of the packed courtroom was at the peak of his profession. He earned $750,000 or so each year at one of Wall Street's best firms, and led its litigation group. He belonged to the American College of Trial Lawyers, the poobahs of the bar. And soon, he would try one of the most glamorous cases of the decade.

title: LOS ANGELES BOARD IS ACCUSED OF BIAS
description: The Justice Department today accused Los Angeles County of diluting the political influence of Hispanic voters.

title: Ryan's Change of Heart
description: Nolan Ryan, who is in the last year of his contract with the Houston Astros, has apparently had a change of heart about staying with the Astros beyond this season and says he may retire. ''I don't know if I'm going to play next year or not,'' Ryan said Wednesday in Los Angeles, where he was scheduled to pitch last night against the Dodgers. ''Situations have arisen that have caused me to have some doubt about it.'' Ryan, 41 years old, said last spring that he fully intended to pitch in 1989 if he was still healthy and pitching effectively. During this season, his health has not been a question and he leads the National League with 204 strikeouts. He also leads his team with 200 innings pitched. He has compiled a 10-11 record and a 3.78 earned run average.(AP)

title: HAILING ARMS PACT, BUSH ATTACKS FOE
description: Vice President Bush mounted a blistering attack on Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's military posture today, saying that his opponent had been a part of unilateral freeze movement that wanted to restrain production of nuclear weapons in the United States but not the Soviet Union.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY ARTS UPON THE WATERS

title: Shevardnadze to Meet With Shultz in 2 Weeks
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will meet in Washington with his Soviet counterpart, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, on Sept. 22 and 23 to review arms control questions, regional disputes and other issues in American-Soviet relations, Administration officials said today.

title: Soviet Mars Craft Failing to Respond
description: An unmanned Soviet spacecraft headed for Mars is apparently wobbling out of control, its power and its ability to receive commands limited because it is having trouble orienting itself with the Sun. But Soviet space officials said yesterday that they should be able to regain control in three to four weeks.

title: Campaign Make-Over For GTE
description: FOR the GTE Corporation, DDB Needham has conscripted the forces of nature to promote the client's technology.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Drexel Case

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an Executive Changes listing in Business Day yesterday misstated the retirement date of James Q. Riordan, vice chairman and chief financial officer of the Mobil Corporation. It is Oct. 1, 1989. But Lucio A. Noto will succeed him this Jan. 1 as chief financial officer.

title: Opposition in Burma Announces Formation of Provisional Regime
description: A Burmese opposition group led by the former Prime Minister, U Nu, has announced the formation of a provisional government and called for new elections, diplomats said today. They said there was no immediate response from the country's beleaguered leadership.

title: People
description: * Doreen Fox, Stephanie Pierson, Michael Lawlor, Howard Benson and Helio Gonzalez have been promoted to group creative directors at Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide. Mr. Benson and Mr. Gonzalez were also promoted to senior vice president; the others already held that title.

title: Varity Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $7,300,000 and $14,400,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and the 6 months included an $8,600,000 writedown. Latest second quarter and 6-month share earnings from operations reflect preferred dividend requirements.

title: Dining Out Guide: Sunday Brunch
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Adrienne

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Certain that Iraq had used poison gas against Kurdish guerrillas, the United States condemned the action as ''abhorrent and unjustifiable,'' but an Iraqi Foreign Ministry official called the U.S. charge ''absolutely baseless.'' Page A1

title: A.T.&T. to Pursue More Cost-Cutting
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is pursuing earnings growth with a new sense of urgency, its chairman, Robert Allen, told the Boston Security Analysts Society. Mr. Allen said that he was ''encouraged but not satisfied'' with A.T.&T.'s financial performance this year and that the New York-based company needed to cut costs further.

title: Live TV Performances From Around the World
description: ''Wrap Around the World,'' a 90-minute live television broadcast featuring performances and other events produced simultaneously from 10 countries in Europe and Asia, will be broadcast tomorrow at 10:30 A.M. on Channel 13.

title: Books of The Times; A Nondescript Victim, and Los Angeles Shames
description: The Veiled One By Ruth Rendell 278 pages. Pantheon Books. $17.95. The Big Nowhere By James Ellroy 406 pages. The Mysterious Press. $17.95.

title: Metro Airlines Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Pentland to Buy Most of Parker Pen
description: Pentland, a British holding company specializing in clothing and footwear, said it would pay up to $:170 million ($289 million) to buy 85 to 90 percent of Parker Pen, a British quality pen company. Parker's management, which led a buyout of the company from its previous American owners in 1986, will keep the remaining 10 to 15 percent stake in the company, Pentland said. It said Parker as a whole was valued at $:193 million ($328 million).

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Co. Seattle, announced that Gulf Air, the multinational Middle East air carrier, had ordered four more 767-300 long-range jetliners.

title: Hawaii's History
description: ''Behold Hawaii,'' 40 minutes of Hawaiian history seen through the eyes of a young man seeking his heritage, will be presented at the Naturemax Theater of the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street, starting today. Sharing the bill will be ''Dance of Life,'' a view of Indonesia's art, religion and mythology. ''Hawaii'' will be shown seven days a week at 10:30 and 11:30 A.M. and 12:30, 1:30, 3:30 and 4:30 P.M.; the double feature will be screened on Fridays and Saturdays at 6 and 7:30 P.M. Admission to the single feature is $3.50 for adults, $2.75 for the elderly and $1.75 for children; to the double feature, $5.50, $4.50 and $3. Information: 769-5650.

title: Wall St. Unruffled by Drexel Case
description: In the wake of the vast securities fraud and insider trading charges filed against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Wall Street investment house was doing all it could yesterday to soften the impact. Thousands of letters professing the firm's innocence went to clients, and there were T-shirts for employees emblazoned with ''When the Going Gets Tough, Drexel Gets Going.''

title: Collusion II Proposal
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association, taking the first step in the remedy phase of Collusion II, submitted a proposal to the Player Relations Committee yesterday dealing with a possible second-chance free agency for players involved in the case. Lauren Rich, an association lawyer, declined to provide details of the plan but said if the owners' lawyers reject the proposal, the union would present it to George Nicolau, the arbitrator, next week. Nicolau ruled last week that the owners were guilty of conspiracy against the 1986 free agents. Last January, seven free agents from Collusion I were given a second chance at free agency and Kirk Gibson of Detroit signed a three-year, $4.5 million contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers. . . . Commissioner Peter Ueberroth said he was studying the Fred Lynn case. Lynn has been considered ineligible for postseason play if the Detroit Tigers go that far because he reached Chicago 10 minutes after the midnight deadline for eligibility. The Players Association has filed a grievance, contending that a player need not report to his team by midnight Aug. 31 to be a member of it and thus eligible for postseason games. Ueberroth could render the matter academic by declaring Lynn eligible.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Filly's Return Will Be Tough
description: It looked as if the only way that Winning Colors could beat Personal Ensign in the Maskette Mile at Belmont tomorrow would be if she stole off to an early, easy lead. Shug McGaughey, Personal Ensign's trainer, took care of that possibility yesterday when he also entered Cadillacing, who will help set an honest pace for her undefeated stablemate.

title: U.S. ASSERTS IRAQ USED POISON GAS AGAINST THE KURDS
description: The United States said today that it was convinced Iraq had used poison gas against Kurdish guerrillas and condemned the action as ''abhorrent and unjustifiable.''

title: General Cinema Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an after-tax gain of $4,855,000 from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,170,000 for the quarter and $3,066,000 for the 9 months. The latest periods' figures included the results of the Neiman-Marcus Group for the period ended April 30, 1988. The year-ago periods were restated to account for Super Video as a discontinued operation and for the 2-for-1 stock split effective Oct. 30, 1987.

title: Restaurants
description: Mondrian

title: Shabby Shield for Airline Unions
description: When workers lose out in a merger or corporate restructuring, what do their employers owe them?

title: Leonard S. Brown, Accountant, 58
description: Leonard S. Brown, an educator and accountant, died of lung cancer Aug. 31 at his home in Wayne, N.J. He was 58 years old.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: The Sound of Sugar

title: Big-Screen Gimmicks
description: Gimmicks that have titillated movie audiences over the last 30 years are the theme of a series starting today at Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street. Fifteen films will be offered through Sept. 22, from ''Third Dimension Murder'' of 1941, Hollywood's earliest 3-D experiment, to ''Wicked, Wicked'' (1973), the only film made in duo-vision - a split screen offering two movies at once. Glasses will be provided for the three-dimensional ''House of Wax,'' and viewers may get a charge from ''The Tingler.'' Tickets are $5, or $3.50 for Film Forum members. Information: 431-1590.

title: Winning Freedom
description: There was good news for the Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism this week when it was learned that a political prisoner in whom the center took a strong interest had been released from a South African jail.

title: National Policy Urged to Combat Adult Illiteracy
description: Describing the inability of millions of Americans to read and write as a ''a root cause of a wide range of social problems,'' a coalition of 11 educational groups today called on the next President to start a systematic national effort to combat adult illiteracy.

title: First Debate Date Set
description: The Bush and Dukakis Presidential campaigns agreed to televised debates on Sept. 25 and on either Oct. 13 or 14, depending on negotiations with the American League and ABC over delaying the starting time of the seventh game of the baseball playoffs, if there is one. The dates represent a victory for the Bush camp, which had sought to keep the debates confined to a period in the fall crowded with televised sports events. Page A14.

title: DUKAKIS TOUGHENS MILITARY STANCE
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, assailed by the Republicans as weak on national security issues, moved to counter the attack today with a patriotic speech, a markedly friendlier tone toward a space-based missile defense and a biting attack on Vice President Bush.

title: Supporter Ousted
description: The Bush campaign dismissed one of three campaign supporters accused of anti-Semitic or fascist involvements. A campaign spokesman said he was dismissed after it was learned he had been active in efforts to defend a man condemned to death over atrocities at the Treblinka death camp. Page A15.

title: Aides at White House Draft Ban on Use of Fetal Tissue
description: Even before a prestigious Government advisory committee can meet next week to review the issue, White House officials have drafted an executive order that would ban the use of human fetal tissue from induced abortions in all federally financed experiments and medical treatments.

title: Warships in Gulf Get New Radios To Guard Against Air Disasters
description: In response to the accidental downing of an Iranian airliner by a warship in the Persian Gulf on July 3, the Navy has issued new radios to ships in the region so that they can monitor transmissions by civilian aircraft and air traffic control towers.

title: U.S. Awards Job To Westinghouse
description: The Department of Energy said it had awarded a contract valued at $6.7 billion to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation to manage and operate the department's Savannah River Plant, near Aiken, S.C. The department said the contract is for an initial period of five and a half years. Westinghouse will replace the Du Pont Company as the contractor. Westinghouse said it had chosen Bechtel Savannah River Inc., a subsidiary of Bechtel Group Inc., as its subcontractor.

title: Dukakis Revealed: Thomas 'Elusive' Dewey
description: LEAD: Will Michael S. Dukakis be the political reincarnation of Thomas E. Dewey? Is he making the same fatal mistakes that Dewey did when he lost to Harry S. Truman 40 years ago in the biggest election upset in history? Political experts are beginning to think so - and they may be right.

title: At Risk: A Treasure Of the Law
description: Over the last 150 years, the City Bar Association has collected more than 120 million pages of legal briefs from appellate cases, preserving the words and evolving ideas of the Cardozos, the Brandeises and the lawyers whose names have been forgotten by history.

title: Ruling Due Next Week On Detroit Papers' Deal
description: Detroit's two daily newspapers won a promise from a Federal judge today that he would decide by next week whether to allow them to merge their business operations. A merger between The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News would put an end to an eight-year battle for dominance in the nation's fourth-largest market.

title: Dukakis Campaign Fights Slump With New Look and Sharper Edge
description: For days senior aides to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis have been meeting from morning to midnight in a struggle to salvage a Presidential campaign that has seen little but trouble for the better part of a month. The Dukakis aides have said they think they have no more than two weeks to get his campaign back on track.

title: Flood-Ravaged Bangladesh Seeks Plan to Control Rivers
description: The Government of Bangladesh, reacting to what may be the worst flood of the country's history, called today for an international panel of experts to devise plans to control the rivers of South Asia.

title: Study Sees Link Between Genital Ulcers and AIDS
description: Male homosexuals who have had genital ulcers from syphilis and herpes are much more likely to become infected with the AIDS virus than men with similar sexual histories who have not had such ulcers, according to a new study.

title: Afghanistan Says Guerrillas Shot Down Plane, Killing 16
description: Moslem guerrillas shot down an Afghan military transport plane on Wednesday, killing all 16 people aboard, including two army generals, Afghanistan's Government radio said today.

title: Nabisco, Zenith Labs Give Jobs to F.D.& M.
description: Without affecting the regular agencies working for the Nabisco Foods Company on individual brands, Franznick, Deutsch & Molligo is going to be doing an advertising campaign for both consumer and trade publications that includes all the company's non-cookie products.

title: Irving Gives Data To Several Banks
description: At a board meeting late Wednesday, the directors of the Irving Bank Corporation unanimously endorsed a plan to ''seek the best possible financial transaction for Irving shareholders.'' Maintaining that it could obtain a better price for shareholders than the Bank of New York has so far offered, Irving said it had provided information to several banks, which it did not name.

title: U.S. Wheat Exports
description: An expected 11 percent drop in wheat exports in 1988-89 will cut into the United States share of the world wheat trade, Agriculture Department analysts said today. ''World market share may fall from 43 percent in 1987-88 to about 40 percent,'' the department's Economic Research Service said.

title: The Man Who Dreamed Benzene Rings
description: To the Editor:

title: Five-Time Olympian
description: He is 35 years old now, but Pietro Mennea of Italy will become the first sprinter to enter five Olympics. That was made certain yesterday when Mennea was surprisingly included on the Italian track team for the Seoul Olympic Games, which open in eight days. Mennea, who holds a world record of 19.72 seconds in the 200 meters, will run at that distance. He was an Olympic champion in the event in the 1980 Moscow Games. Primo Nebiolo, president of the Italian Track and Field Federation, said Mennea was awarded an Olympic chance ''for his past merits.'' The sprinter, faced with a muscular inflammation, had failed to clock qualifying times for the Olympics in recent Italian meets and had pulled out of the national championships in Milan this week.(AP)

title: Kean Signs Bills to Cut Car Insurance Costs
description: Governor Kean today signed two automobile-insurance bills that he called ''a first step'' toward offering motorists relief from high premiums, and the State Assembly passed a new package of bills aimed at making further insurance changes.

title: For State Senate: Candidates, Crimes
description: A startling fact sticks out from the Sept. 15 Democratic primary campaign in New York City. There are four races in which nomination will be tantamount to election. In each, at least one candidate has been charged with or convicted of a crime.

title: Downtown Grazing: A Taste of the Big Apple
description: Hamburger Harry's will serve just what you'd expect - two kinds of burgers, and also a grilled chicken sandwich. Schaller & Weber will bring the bratwurst, and Bahama Mama will be there with conch gazpacho and Jamaican meat patties. Tavern on the Green will be there, too, even though the setting will be Battery Park, not Central Park, and Friendly's will dip into gallon after gallon of ice cream.

title: Threat of Yonkers Layoffs Jolts Foes of Housing Plan
description: As contempt fines against Yonkers passed $1 million and one-fourth of the city work force faced layoffs in two days, even steadfast opponents of a court-ordered housing desegregation plan seemed jolted today, and pressure grew for city officials to resolve the crisis.

title: Most Reagan Officials Back Satellite Exports to China
description: A majority of senior Administration officials have recommended that President Reagan permit the export of American satellites for launching on Chinese rockets, and Mr. Reagan is likely to accept that advice, the officials said today.

title: B.Y.U. Wins, 47-6
description: Sean Covey passed for 323 yards and 2 touchdowns as Brigham Young (1-1) routed Texas (0-1), 47-6, tonight. Texas was without the tailback Eric Metcalf, who sat out a one-game suspension mandated by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Forbes Magazine Appoints Weinberger to Be Publisher
description: Caspar W. Weinberger, the former Defense Secretary, will become the publisher of Forbes magazine, Malcolm S. Forbes, chairman and editor in chief, announced yesterday.

title: In the Twilight of an Era, a Sad Look Backward
description: One by one, members of the last of the generations of Americans who built and ran the Panama Canal here are preparing to leave, steeling themselves against the moment when they will say goodbye to a way of life that once seemed eternal.

title: Foodarama Supermarkets Inc reports earnings for 13wk to July 30
Steinbrenner Group Offers $50 Million For Westbury Track
description: A group of investors organized by George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, offered to buy Roosevelt Raceway today and to continue to operate it as a harness-racing track.

title: KEY RATES

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Lawyer Named Chief Of Control Data Unit
description: LEAD: With yesterday's spinoff of the Control Data Corporation's $1 billion-a-year disk-drive business as a wholly owned subsidiary, Lawrence Perlman, a Harvard-trained lawyer who has run it since 1985, will become chairman and chief executive of the unit.

title: Harold G. Rosson, 93, 'Oz' Cinematographer
description: Harold G. Rosson, the cinematographer who filmed ''The Wizard of Oz'' and ''The Asphalt Jungle'' during a 52-year Hollywood career, died Tuesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 93 years old.

title: Dent to File Suit
description: Richard Dent, a defensive end for the Chicago Bears, yesterday denied that he has a drug problem and his agent, Steve Zucker, went to court to overturn Dent's 30-day suspension for refusing to take a drug test ordered by the National Football League. Dent and Calvin Thomas, a running back who violated the N.F.L.'s substance-abuse policy for the second time, were suspended by the league Wednesday. Thomas has already begun treatment. But in an interview with WLS-TV in Chicago, Dent said he was not a drug user. Zucker asked for an emergency hearing in Cook County Circuit Court on the matter today, seeking to clear the way for Dent to play with the Bears in Indianapolis Sunday. ''They didn't have reasonable cause,'' Zucker said, referring to the N.F.L.'s request for Dent to take the mandatory drug test. ''We are for a good drug policy, a strong drug policy, but it must be based on strong cause.'' The N.F.L. reserves the right to ask for a urine sample any time a player has tested positive in the last two years. If a player declines, the league treats it as a second drug offense and suspends him. ''I haven't seen anything that says he has tested positive in the past,'' Zucker said. The Players Association also backed Dent's position, saying that Commissioner Pete Rozelle had ''gone beyond the parameters set by the 1982 collectively bargained drug program.''(AP)

title: Dairy Mart Convenience Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The year-ago periods included tax credits equivalent to 3 cents a share for the quarter and 6 cents a share for the 6 months.

title: Joseph John Fried, Ophthalmologist, 91
description: Dr. Joseph John Fried, an ophthalmologist, died of complications of pneumonia Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

title: Smaller Airlines Lead On-Time Arrivals List
description: Despite heavy summer travel, major United States airlines reported that better than four of every five flights arrived on time in July, the Transporation Department said today.

title: CITY'S BANKRUPTCY AVERTED
description: The Yonkers City Council voted early today to approve a court-ordered housing desegregation plan, ending a crisis that had threatened to bankrupt the city.

title: Evidence Against Hastings Overwhelming
description: To the Editor:

title: BELLWETHER TREASURY BOND YIELD BELOW 9%
description: Treasury bond yields fell below 9 percent yesterday for the first time since early July as the credit markets shrugged off an increase in August producer prices that was slightly larger than expected.

title: U.S. Adamant in Charge Against Iraq
description: Reagan Administration officials today stood behind their charge that Iraq had used poison gas against the Kurds, relating Kurds' descriptions of seeing small clouds of either white or yellowish gas and adding, ''That's when they began feeling sick.''

title: Senate Clears Import Curbs By 57-32 Vote
description: The Senate today approved, 57 to 32, a bill to limit imports of textile goods, apparel and non-rubber footwear.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 27 about new bus systems that are easing isolation in rural areas misidentified a bus traveling near Norfolk, Neb. It belonged to Arrow Stage Lines, not Greyhound.

title: Discharge Sentences Common in New York
description: In a city like New York, where hundreds of men and women enter an overtaxed criminal-justice system each day, there is a tacit understanding among prosecutors, judges and probation officials that certain offenders are permitted ''a free bite of the apple.'' That is, certain misdeeds will largely be forgiven.

title: Homeless Center Could Destroy an Old-Fashioned Neighborhood
description: To the Editor:

title: Knoll Sells General Felt
description: Marshall Cogan, chairman of Knoll International Holdings Inc., said yesterday that Knoll had sold its General Felt Industries subsidiary to Merrill Lynch Capital Partners Inc. and Rocco A. Barbieri, Knoll's president. The agreement to sell the unit, which makes carpeting and pads was reached last month. No terms were disclosed.

title: Pentagon May Revise Rules On Averting Contract Fraud
description: The Pentagon may revise newly issued regulations that require contractors to certify, upon penalty of forfeiting profits, that they did not improperly obtain information from the Government while competing for military contracts, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Shana Alexander Signed For a Book on Myerson
description: Shana Alexander has been signed by Random House to write a book about the troubles of Bess Myerson, who resigned under fire as New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs.

title: Metro-North Walkout Stalls Commuters
description: A surprise walkout by track workers for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad halted all trains on the system just before the morning rush yesterday, forcing 95,000 daily riders in Connecticut and Westchester to scramble for connections south.

title: Verbeek Agrees to Pact
description: Pat Verbeek, who led the Devils with 46 goals last season, agreed to a multiyear contract yesterday and reported to camp in West Orange, N.J., with the rest of the veterans. The Devils followed the team policy of not revealing details of the contract, but the agreement is believed to be for two years plus an option year. Kirk Muller and Mark Johnson are the two other Devils going into the option year of their contract who remain unsigned.

title: Confusion Causes a Run
description: A case of mistaken identity spurred a $2 million run on a Chinatown savings institution Thursday. Hundreds of customers lined up at the Elmhurst Federal Savings and Loan Association to withdraw money after confusing the association with a financially troubled bank in the suburb of Elmhurst. The assets of that institution, the United Security Bank, were frozen by a judge last week. ''The headline was, 'Elmhurst Bank Fails,' '' said David G. Plummer, president of Elmhurst Federal Savings. ''I think many of our customers don't even know there's a town named Elmhurst.''

title: Vaudeville in the 80's
description: New Vaudeville '88, a two-week festival of performances sponsored by Manhattan Punch Line Theater, continues at the Actors Outlet Theater, 120 West 28th Street. The comedy team of Wallem and Tolan will appear at 8 o'clock tonight and the performance artist Tamara Jenkins will appear at 10 P.M. The festival is among several events sponsored by the Manhattan Punch Line Theater to mark its 10th season. Tickets to each performance are $10. Information: 239-0827.

title: BRITISH UNIT TIED TO 3 I.R.A. DEATHS
description: Gibraltar's police chief confirmed for the first time today that members of Britain's elite Special Air Service killed three unarmed Irish Republican Army guerrillas in the British colony in March.

title: Producer Prices Up By 0.6%
description: Led by a significant upturn for energy, prices of goods ready for the final individual or business user climbed a hefty six-tenths of 1 percent in August, equaling the highest increase so far this year.

title: Elton John Auction Nets $8.2 Million
description: Sotheby's four-day auction of 2,000 items of Elton John's cast-off clothes, jewelry and other artifacts ended today and brought in $8,224,637.

title: Turkey Reports Kurdish Refugees Showed No Signs of Iraqi Gassing
description: The Turkish Government said today that its examinations of recent Kurdish refugees had produced no evidence to support claims that Iraq used chemical weapons against the Kurds.

title: Ambush by Contras Kills 5 As Truce Violations Grow
description: Nearly six months after the Sandinista Government and contra guerrilla leaders agreed on a plan that they hoped would bring peace and full democracy to Nicaragua, death and political imprisonment are still facts of life in the central provinces of Chontales and Boaco.

title: House Acts to Keep Ban On Funds for Abortions
description: The House of Representatives voted today to maintain the law barring the use of Federal funds for almost all abortions.

title: Limos: Now It's Easier to Go in Style
description: A limousine may conjure up the image of corporate or government privilege. But an increasing number of customers for limousine services are individuals who hire cars for personal activities like getting to the airport, spending a night on the town or sightseeing.

title: Bankruptcy Trustee for PTL Extends Deadline for Offers
description: The PTL bankruptcy trustee today extended indefinitely the deadline to accept bids for the ministry and said Jim Bakker had provided no proof he has the money to support his $172 million offer to buy back the television network and religious theme park he founded.

title: Harry I. Rothman, Principal, 82
description: Harry I. Rothman, a principal in the New York City school system for more than 25 years, died of pneumonia Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Minneapolis. He was 82 years old and lived in Minneapolis.

title: Philip Erard, Banker, Marries Sandra Meil
description: Sandra Meil, a vice president of Grace & Andrews, an advertising agency in New York, and Philip Erard, a senior vice president of corporate finance at Wertheim Schroder & Company, investment bankers in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. John Kamas performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: New York and Sears Battle Over Ads
description: Last year, about 400 retailers settled complaints about misleading advertising with the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs. But not Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: Red Sox Hitting Stops Indians, 7-4
description: Mike Greenwell hit a two-run triple in the first inning, and Wade Boggs had a home run and a double tonight as the Boston Red Sox beat the Cleveland Indians, 7-4. The Red Sox took a two-and-a-half-game lead over Detroit in the American League East. The second-place Tigers lost to the Yankees, 3-2.

title: His Honor, Her Honor
description: Mayor Koch was right, and wrong, in his protest to a Brooklyn judge over the sentencing of former collection agents who stole thousands of dollars from New York City parking meters.

title: KEY RATES
Canada Jobless Rate Up
description: Canada's unemployment rate edged up to 8 percent in August from 7.9 percent the previous month, the Government's statistical agency reported today. But Statistics Canada said there was little change on the labor front in August. On a seasonally adjusted basis, about 12,000 were added to the jobless rolls for a total of 1,069,000 unemployed. The number with jobs rose a scant 3,000 from the previous month to 12.4 million.

title: School Chief Holds Luncheon
description: In an atmosphere that was part pep rally and part revival meeting, the New York City Schools Chancellor, Richard R. Green, held a luncheon yesterday to mark the beginning of the school year. He invited teachers, school guards, custodians, principals, students and others who work in the schools.

title: Fons Iannelli, Who Photographed War in the Pacific, Is Dead at 71
