description: Fons Iannelli, a photojournalist who documented naval combat in World War II and later became a leading magazine photographer, died of heart failure Aug. 26 at Jersey City Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived in Jersey City.

title: Bacteria Create Foaming Agents
description: Igene Biotechnology of Columbia, Md., is using bacteria to create foaming agents for shaving cream, shampoo and even food items, like whipped topping.

title: Boeing Jet Orders Rise $421 Million
description: The Boeing Company announced orders for seven 767 passenger jets for at least $421 million. increasing the company's total jetliner orders for the year to more than $21 billion. Statements issued by Boeing said four 767-300 extended-range aircraft had been ordered by Gulf Air, the national carrier of Bahrain, Oman, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, for delivery in April, May and June. Olympic Airways, the Greek national airline, ordered three 767-200's for delivery starting in early 1990 and took options on three others, Boeing stated.

title: About New York; An Endless Job Atop a Mountain Of Urban Trash
description: ''I know that this is not the most glamorous job in the world,'' Joe Lobosco allowed.

title: Jerusalem Book Fair Is Set
description: The Jerusalem International Book Fair, which is held every other year, is scheduled for the week of March 12, 1989, it was announced yesterday by Mayor Teddy Kollek.

title: Dukakis's Pledge Is Not to the Law
description: LEAD: When the bicentennial of the Constititution was celebrated a couple of years ago, it was suggested that as part of the fete school children across the country recite the pledge of allegiance, simultaneously, in a sort of ''Hands Across America'' ceremony. The plan was dropped, however, when it was learned that the typical school child no longer knows the words.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City on Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Tutu Calls for Boycott; Police Raid the Church
description: The police burst into a church service led by Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu today, moments after he renewed an illegal call for a boycott of segregated municipal elections in South Africa next month, witnesses said.

title: Fire Officials And Ward Renew Feud
description: A long-simmering feud between New York City's police and fire officials erupted again yesterday in a flurry of insults, with Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward ridiculing the Fire Department as misguided and underworked and the head of the firefighters' union accusing Mr. Ward of failing to keep the streets safe.

title: Deaths and Illness Rise in Bangladesh
description: Reports of illness and deaths from gastrointestinal diseases began to rise suddenly today, increasing fears of an epidemic even as the waters of this country's devastating flood continue to recede.

title: Roll-Call on Import Curbs
description: Following is the 57-to-32 roll-call vote by which the Senate today approved new curbs on textile, apparel and non-rubber footwear imports. A vote in favor was a vote to impose the import restraints, while a vote against the measure was a vote not to impose them. Voting yes were 40 Democrats and 17 Republicans. Voting no were 9 Democrats and 23 Republicans. xxx denotes senators not voting.

title: Homeless Center Could Destroy an Old-Fashioned Neighborhood; A Negative Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Net Worth of Quayles Put at $859,700 by Firm
description: In an effort to dispel the perception that Senator Dan Quayle is a man of great wealth, his campaign today released an accounting firm's statement that lists his net worth as $859,700.

title: Blackout Tied To Contractor
description: A four-and-a-half-day blackout in the downtown area was caused by a sidewalk contractor who accidentally drove a piling into underground power cables, the city-owned electric company has reported. The contractor had asked for plans showing where cables were, but the Seattle City Light maps did not show the service line that was hit, Gerald Garman, Assistant Superintendent of the utility, said Wednesday. He said the contractor was not at fault and added that the accuracy of other maps was being checked.

title: Across The Years
description: The days may grow short when you reach September, but retailers hope that the days have been long enough to buy something for Grandma and Grandpa. In case you have not heard, tomorrow is Grandparents Day.

title: Car Makers' Research Tie
description: The General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation said today that they would conduct the United States auto industry's first joint research into using plastic composite materials in the structure of cars and trucks.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday about the use of computer networks characterized the figures incorrectly for installed networks. The numbers shown were in the millions.

title: Review/Dance; Douglas Dunn's Parody and Pain
description: Douglas Dunn's solo dance concert got Equinox, the new experimental music and dance series, off to more than a good start Thursday night at the Equitable Center Auditorium.

title: Unfulfilled Dreams for New York
description: The City That Never Was Two Hundred Years of Fantastic and Fascinating Plans That Might Have Changed the Face of New York City By Rebecca Read Shanor Illustrated. 254 pages. Viking. $35.

title: America's Cup; Stars & Stripes Wins; Court Defense Is Next
description: When Dennis Conner stepped aboard Stars & Stripes today, he had the look of a sure winner, with confident smile and purposeful walk. The skipper then did what he had set out to do: defend the America's Cup against the most unorthodox challenge in the 137-year history of the competition.

title: Former Oil Official Was Arrested In Stolen-Data Case Linked to Iran
description: The former chairman of Ashland Oil Inc. was secretly arrested and charged with transporting stolen company documents sought by Iran for its $500 million lawsuit against the company, according to court records, law-enforcement officials and defense attorneys.

title: Coping: With Winter's Approach
description: The bracing breezes of recent days are reminders that it's time to think about making homes snug.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer transmission error, the Economic Scene column in Business Day yesterday misstated Henry Kaufman's view on the dollar's range. He said the range was now 130 to 135 yen.

title: Hostile Offer for Polaroid Begins
description: A group headed by Roy E. Disney today revised its bid for the Polaroid Corporation and began a hostile $2.4 billion tender offer, raising the possibility of a bidding contest.

title: Full Circle: The New Life of Patty Hearst
description: Patricia Hearst Shaw was in a dither, homebound in Connecticut with two small daughters on a busy morning.

title: Technicolor Purchase Is Set By Carlton Communications
description: Carlton Communications P.L.C. said yesterday that it would acquire Technicolor Holdings Inc. from MacAndrews & Forbes Group for about $780 million.

title: Yonkers Legal Battle: How It Unfolded
description: Dec. 1, 1980: Justice Department sues Board of Education, City of Yonkers and Yonkers Community Development Agency, charging that the city racially discriminated in education and public housing.

title: S. Herbert Riesner, Realty Executive, 85
description: S. Herbert Riesner, a real-estate executive and hotel owner, died of heart failure Wednesday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Investigation of Drexel Continuing, S.E.C. Says
description: The enforcment chief of the Securities and Exchange Commission told a Congressional panel today that the S.E.C.'s investigation of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was continuing.

title: DNA Probe Detects Sex of Cattle Embryo
description: For several years, the cattle industry has used embryo-transfer techniques to enhance breeding. Typically, high-quality cows are fertilized through artificial insemination, and the embryos are then transferred to less well-bred surrogate mothers. With this technique, high-quality cows can produce an almost infinite number of offspring without enduring the strain of carrying calves.

title: Ford-Nissan Van Venture Expected
description: The Ford Motor Company and the Japanese auto maker Nissan are expected to announce plans next week for a joint venture that would manufacture mini-vans at a yet-to-be-built Ohio plant. Gov. Richard Celeste of Ohio , who will be in Japan from Sunday through Thursday, has scheduled a news conference with Ford and Nissan officials in Tokyo on Monday to announce the venture, according to an itinerary released by Governor Celeste's office on Thursday. Ford and Nissan officials have yet to confirm plans for the joint venture.

title: Dennis Levine Is Released
description: Dennis B. Levine, the investment banker convicted two years ago of illegal insider trading, was released from a halfway house in Manhattan earlier this week.

title: Sabatini Is Now Graf's Only Obstacle
description: Gabriela Sabatini, the only woman who has defeated Steffi Graf this year, earned the opportunity to spoil Graf's Grand Slam bid with a workmanlike 6-4, 7-5 dismissal of Zina Garrison in the only women's semifinal match played at the United States Open yesterday.

title: Park and Forest Service Chiefs Assailed on Fire Policy
description: Federal park and forest officials are coming under attack for a decade-old policy of letting some forest fires burn without interference as part of the natural ecological process.

title: BLUE-CHIP RALLY RAISES DOW BY 5.69
description: LEAD: The stock market moved higher yesterday as blue-chip issues rallied strongly late in the session. The rally tapered off by the close, but the Dow Jones industrial average finished at 2,068.81, for a gain of 5.69 points.

title: Missouri School Told There Will Be Dances
description: A Federal district judge said Thursday that dancing could begin at Purdy High School.

title: Friendship Dramatized
description: ''The Ringdove,'' a drama with music based on the themes of friendship and survival, will be presented outdoors this weekend by the Mettewee River Theater Company in the garden at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. The piece, directed and designed by Ralph Lee, has music by Judy Kruskal and a script by George Sand. Performances are at 7:30 P.M. today through Sunday. Admission is by donation. Information: 316-5178.

title: Bentsen Faults G.O.P. Farm Policies
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen carried the Democratic national campaign into the farm land of the Middle West today with a strong attack on what he called ''the mistakes, mismanagement and indifference of the Reagan-Bush Administration'' on agricultural policy.

title: London Cool to 'Temptation'
description: The film ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' opened in London today to poor reviews, a small protest outside a theater and a ban on advertising in the London subway system.

title: Ousted Judge Barred From Federal Practice
description: Harry Claiborne, a former Federal district judge, has been barred from practicing law in Federal courts because of his conviction for tax evasion.

title: Preventing Drug Test Cheating
description: For Joel R. L. Ehrenkranz, the war against drugs has taken a new turn. Eighteen months ago, the founder of Franklin Diagnostics Inc. of Morristown, N.J., began selling what he said was a tamper-proof kit for collecting urine specimens used in drug testing.

title: Macmillan Said to Meet With Kohlberg, Kravis
description: Macmillan Inc. and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout firm, have been discussing a possible leveraged buyout of the publishing concern, several people familiar with the situation said yesterday.

title: Ermanno Olmi Wins Prize At Venice Film Festival
description: The Italian director Ermanno Olmi won the Golden Lion award at the Venice Film Festival today for his ''Leggenda del Santo Bevitore'' (''Legend of the Saintly Drinker'').

title: Over 50 Students Are Hurt As Gym Bleachers Collapse
description: Gymnasium bleachers collapsed at a high school this morning in an assembly, injuring as many as 52 students, the authorities said.

title: Lord, Geller Agency Cuts Staff by a Third
description: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, the advertising agency that lost six top executives in March and the International Business Machines Corporation account last week, yesterday announced the dismissal of about 90 people, about one-third of its staff.

title: Washington Blast Beats Tigers in 9th
description: In July or August, they would have been finished. Two weeks ago, they might have quietly come apart, and then they would have trudged back to their clubhouse, dressed and gone home.

title: Your Money; A New Emphasis On Self-Reliance
description: Employees can no longer assume that if they work hard and do a good job, the company will take care of them, warns George E. L. Barbee, executive director of the Consumer Financial Institute, a division of Price Waterhouse, in Waltham, Mass.

title: 11 Companies Back Irving in Court Appeal on 'Poison Pill'
description: Eleven major companies sided with the Irving Bank Corporation yesterday in its appeal of a court ruling that found its ''poison pill'' anti-takeover measure a violation of New York State law.

title: 'Pregaphone,' to Talk To an Unborn Child
description: Janet D. Hodson, a business consultant in Ventura, Calif., received a patent this week for ''Pregaphone,'' a device that purports to let pregnant women talk to their unborn children.

title: For Civil Court in the Bronx
description: In the sole judicial contest in next Thursday's New York primary, two Democratic candidates in the Bronx vie for a countywide seat on New York City's Civil Court.

title: Vietnam Jet Crashes, Killing 75 in Thailand
description: An Air Vietnam passenger plane crashed and exploded in a rice field today on its approach to Bangkok's international airport, and officials said 75 people were killed and the other 6 people aboard were seriously injured.

title: Let's Put Day Care on a Voucher System
description: To the Editor:

title: Retirement Home Planned for Rock-Music Stars
description: LEAD: For the early rock-and-roll stars, who have spent much of the last 30 years shaking, shouting and twisting, it may be time for shuffleboard and bingo. But the rock pioneers' road to fame was rarely paved with gold, and many still have to play to pay the bills.

title: Maneuver Over Flag Pledge Trips Up House Democrats
description: Democrats in the House of Representatives today learned for themselves what their party's Presidential candidate already knew: In the hands of a political enemy, the Pledge of Allegiance can be a powerful weapon.

title: Dent's Suspension Lifted
description: The National Football League today lifted Richard Dent's 30-day suspension for refusing to take a drug test. Dent, a defensive end for the Chicago Bears, was given permission to play Sunday against the Colts.

title: In a Time of Openness, Things Worth Reading Remain Elusive
description: The Soviet reader in the days of glasnost knows the frustration of Tantalus. The rich fruits of Moscow spring hang on the branches, many of them no longer forbidden but just out of reach.

title: Texas A&M Penalized
description: Texas A&M's football program was put on probation today for two years and banned from a bowl appearance this season after the National Collegiate Athletic Association said it found rules violations. The N.C.A.A. order did not prohibit television appearances. Six schools in the nine-member Southwest Conference have been investigated by the N.C.A.A. in recent years. Besides Texas A&M, the others were Southern Methodist, Texas, Houston, Texas Christian and Texas Tech.

title: Soviets See Little Hope of Controlling Spacecraft
description: The proud Soviet space program suffered another public setback today as officials announced that they saw little hope of regaining contact with the Phobos 1 spacecraft, launched toward a Martian moon on July 7.

title: Shopping for Car Loans
description: The generous sales incentives offered by auto manufacturers and new-cr dealers last year and this summer will not be evident when the 1989 models make their debut in the fall. Car inventories are down sharply, making it less likely that dealers will try to stimultae sales through low car-loan rates or large cash rebates. Last year and earlier this year some auto manufacturers offered interset rates as low as 1.9 percent. However, the rate was abailable only for certain models, for a much shorter financing period and with no price negotiation. Consumers will now have to rely on their own shopping skills to find the best auto-loan rate. The most common sources with typical terms are: SOURCE RATE TYPICAL TERMS Banks 11.5% 20% down payment; 48 months Credit unions 10.2% 20% down payments; 48 months Manufacturer 12.3% 6% down payment; 56 months finance companies

title: Chip Makers Will Seek U.S. Aid to Spur Output
description: Top executives of the computer and semiconductor industries have agreed to seek the cooperation of the United States Government and explore ''extraordinary measures'' to increase American production of vital computer memory chips.

title: A Soviet Fox Guards Filmdom's Chicken Coop
description: As a high-ranking Soviet bureaucrat, Andrei Smirnov is a man of surprising contradictions.

title: Mortgage Process Is Eased
description: The country's two largest purchasers of home mortgages announced Thursday that they had reached an agreement on ways to streamline and simplify the time-consuming process of obtaining a home mortgage.

title: No Option for Schmidt
description: Bill Giles, the Philadelphia Phillies' president, has told Mike Schmidt that the team will not pick up the option on the slugger's contract, according to a report in The Philadelphia Inquirer. Schmidt, 39 years old, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right shoulder Wednesday. But even before Schmidt decided to have the operation, Giles told the newspaper that the Phillies would need another third baseman next year, whether or not the team worked out a new contract with Schmidt. Schmidt's contract, which would pay him $2.15 million next season, gives the Phillies the option to renew next season or to allow him to become a free agent.(AP)

title: Young Classic Is Tonight
description: Unless there is a dramatic increase in ticket sales, the football game tonight between Grambling State and Howard University, the first meeting between the schools, could be the only time the Whitney M. Young Jr. Classic will be played in Giants Stadium.

title: Sherry Thornburg Weds Samuel Belk
description: Sherry Ann Thornburg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dale O. Thornburg of Modesto, Calif., and Samuel Ellison Belk 4th, the son of Joanne Belk and Mr. Belk 3d, both of Washington, were married yesterday at El Capitan Meadows in Yosemite National Park in California. The Rev. Kenneth Hoover, a Seventh-day Adventist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: DRUG MAKER TOLD TO PAY $8 MILLION OVER BIRTH DEVICE
description: A Federal jury today found G. D. Searle & Company negligent in the testing and marketing of its Copper-7 birth-control device, and it awarded $8.75 million in damages to the plaintiff in the case.

title: Soviet Historian Faults Stalin About Trotsky
description: A senior Soviet historian asserted today in Pravda that Stalin ordered the 1940 assassination in Mexico of his arch-rival Leon Trotsky.

title: Paradise Now to Be Won
description: Michael Dukakis is President. The competence is intense. Car repairs are done right the first time. Plumbers, painters, electricians and carpenters who say they will be there tomorrow actually arrive tomorrow. Newspapers stop making errors. Because of their overall superiority, Detroit automobiles become the biggest-selling item in Japan since raw fish. Faced with ruin, Japan has to sell huge chunks of America back to Americans at incredible discounts.

title: INSIDE
description: Stars & Stripes Wins

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about a food tasting that continues today and tomorrow in Battery Park misstated ticket availability. American Express cardholders may charge tickets at the site or at restaurants participating in the tasting, but not at American Express offices.

title: At Synagogue, the Topic Is Beggars
description: Dr. Harvey Kranzler was nearing the Lincoln Square Synagogue last week when the woman approached him. ''My husband just left me,'' she said. ''Could you give me some money?'' For Dr. Kranzler, a child psychiatrist who lived on Manhattan's Upper West Side for 13 years before moving recently to New Jersey, it was hardly the first such encounter, maybe more than the thousandth. Familiar questions flashed through his mind: Is she telling the truth? Will my money go for drugs or alcohol?

title: U.S. Decision Puts Shoreham Closer to Licensing
description: The Long Island Lighting Company cleared its largest remaining hurdle to licensing the Shoreham nuclear power plant today when a Federal agency said an emergency plan the utility would use in case of an accident would protect public safety.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14.

title: President Acts to Promote Conservative Issues Being Used by Bush
description: With only four months left in his Administration, President Reagan acted on two fronts today to promote some of his conservative principles and highlight issues that Vice President Bush is using to attack his Democratic opponents.

title: Labor Is Scapegoat of Mismanaged Eastern Airlines
description: To the Editor:

title: Put a Number on My Tombstone
description: ''May I have your name, please?'' asks the nurse behind the sliding glass window.

title: Spanish Film Exhibition At Kennedy Center
description: The Spanish cinema exhibition at the Kennedy Center's American Film Institute Theater, which will run through Dec. 23, is the largest ever assembled.

title: Best Sellers In Tokyo: Book Tapes
description: In Tokyo, where most people spend at least two hours a day on trains, it is not unusual to see well-dressed commuters listening intently to Walkmans. Like New York's headphoned subway riders, many listen to music. But a growing number are listening to the spoken word.

title: Hungarian Refugees From Rumania on Rise
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Approves China Satellite Deal
description: The White House today approved the export of three communications satellites that will be launched by China.

title: College Football; Young Irish Are Thrown to the Wolves
description: Maybe it was that surprising 26-7 victory over Michigan to start the 1987 season that made Notre Dame believe it was really a good football team again. But Notre Dame lost its last three games and the truth emerged. Coach Lou Holtz was certain, as he had insisted all along, that the Irish were not among the nation's best teams.

title: Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, 711 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017.

title: Spyros Theotokis, 80; Greek Rightist Figure
description: Spyros Theotokis, a former Foreign Minister of Greece and the founder of a right-wing party, died of a heart attack here on Tuesday. He was 80 years old.

title: Ailing Evert Unable to Play
description: As talented as she is, Steffi Graf understands that luck can be an important ingredient in achieving success. Her bid to win the United States Open, and to complete the first Grand Slam since Margaret Court's in 1970, was enhanced Wednesday when Martina Navratilova was upset by Zina Garrison. Then yesterday, her semifinal opponent, Chris Evert, was forced to withdraw, suffering from gastroenteritis, a stomach disorder.

title: Man Sets Himself Afire Outside United Nations
description: A 32-year-old Iranian poured gasoline over his clothes and set himself on fire yesterday afternoon across the street from the United Nations, the police said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Two Tied for Lead: Jim Gallagher, who had to win a playoff in the qualifying round to enter the tournament, shot a second straight 67 yesterday to tie Dave Barr of Canada for the lead after two rounds of the $700,000 Greater Milwaukee Open in Franklin, Wis. Gallagher and Barr, who shot a 68, were tied at 10-under-par 134 after two rounds on the 7,030-yard Tuckaway Country Club course. Corey Pavin, who shared the lead with Barr going into the round, slipped to an even-par 72 and dropped four shots back. David Ogrin was third at 136 after shooting a 66. Donnie Hammond, who had a 69; Chip Beck, who shot a 67, Mike Sullivan, who had a 68, and Mike Bender, with a 69, were next at 137. (AP) Walker and Sanders Lead: Colleen Walker and Susan Sanders shot four-under-par 68's to tie for a one-shot lead over Cathy Johnston in the opening round of the $250,000 Cellular One-Ping Championship at Riverside Golf and Country Club in Portland, Ore. Walker, playing in the morning, used an accurate driver and a consistent putter to fashion a round that featured four birdies and no bogeys over the 6,285-yard course. Sanders, who is from Salem, Ore., finished her afternoon round with a flourish, getting birdies on the 16th, 17th and 18th holes. Walker's 68 marked her 27th sub-70 round of the year, tying a Ladies Professional Golf Association record.(AP) Player, Douglass Lead Pack: Gary Player birdied the last two holes to shoot a 65 and tie Dale Douglass for the lead with a nine-under-par 135 for 36 holes in the $350,000 GTE North Classic in Indianapolis. Seven other players headed into the final round today of the senior event at the 6,670-yard, par-72 Broadmoor Country Club within two strokes of the leaders. Miller Barber, Orville Moody, J. C. Goosie and Dick Rhyan are tied at 136. The first-day leader, Charles Coody, who bogeyed his final hole for a 71, was tied with Bob Erickson and Ken Still at 137.(AP)

title: VW Price Rise
description: Volkswagen United States said that the suggested retail prices of its 1989 Jetta, Cabriolet and Vanwagon models, which it is now shipping to dealers, would rise 2.7 percent above the final prices of the 1988 models. The base Jetta is up $285, to $9,690, while the top-of-the-line version is up $440, to $14,770. The Cabriolet and the Vanwagon Camper GL have been increased $445, to $15,195 and $22,235, respectively.

title: Vatican Says the Pope Is Not Shunning Pretoria on His African Trip
description: In what seemed to be a gesture of good will toward South Africa, the Vatican announced today that Pope John Paul II was eager to travel there in the future and that only scheduling problems would keep him away during a coming visit to five of South Africa's neighbors.

title: Becker Withdraws
description: Boris Becker has dropped out of the Olympic tournament because of a foot injury, but will attend the Seoul Games as a guest of the West German Olympic team, Becker's manager, Ion Tiriac, said yesterday in Frankfurt. The German Tennis Federation said Thursday that Becker was leaving for Seoul next week and was expected to compete. But Becker's doctor in West Germany has ordered a six-week break from tennis, according to Tiriac. (AP)

title: U.S. and Soviet Groups Plan Japan Rock Benefit
description: Rock groups from the United States, the Soviet Union and several other countries plan to present a benefit concert next month in Tokyo to promote world peace and fight drug abuse, it was announced at a luncheon here today.

title: Ultrasonic Vibrations For Windshield Wipers
description: The Motoda Electronics Company of Tokyo received a United States patent this week for a bladeless windshield wiper that uses ultrasonic vibrations to clear rain and snow.

title: Builder Will Buy 5 Texas Savings Units
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it had agreed to sell five insolvent savings associations in Texas to one of the nation's largest builders of single-family homes.

title: Rose Isn't Worrying
description: Manager Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds, whose managing contract is in its final year, said he was not going to concern himself now with statements by Marge Schott, the owner of the team, about Rose's chances of keeping his job. Schott told reporters this week that if Rose is to return as manager in 1989, it will be under a one-year contract and for less money. Rose's current three-year contract pays him at least $500,000 a year to manage but ends after this season. ''I'm trying to concentrate on 1988,'' Rose said. ''I'm not worried about 1989. No one in this organization should be worried about 1989, unless they've given up. And I sure haven't given up.''(AP)

title: Debate Over Cost of Space-Based System Goes to Heart of President's Military Policy
description: The growing debate in the capital and on the campaign trail over the cost of President Reagan's anti-missile program is in many ways a debate over whether Mr. Reagan's dream will ever be fulfilled.

title: DEMOCRATS' DRIVE TOPS $30 MILLION
description: The Dukakis campaign's chief fund raiser said yesterday that with more than $5 million raised at a dinner in New York Thursday night, the Democrats were more than halfway to their $50 million goal this fall.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Hurricane Sweeping In, Louisianians Flee North
description: Hurricane Florence raced north over the Gulf of Mexico today, then slowed as it reached the mouth of Mississippi River late tonight and angled toward Mississippi.

title: Confusion Reigns Among Commuters
description: Anthony Cuozzo knew something was awry when he arrived at the Metro-North Commuter Railroad station in Fairfield, 15 miles east of here, and spotted an unusually large crowd of briefcase-toting, New York-bound commuters with befuddled looks on their faces milling about the parking lot.

title: A U.S. Peace Corps Worker Is Shot to Death in Honduras
description: A Peace Corps volunteer was shot to death on Thursday night, apparently by Honduran security guards who mistook him for an intruder, the police here said today.

title: Art As Industry
description: LEAD: Imagine New York City without the arts: no new plays, no concerts in the parks, no independent exhibition spaces for modern painting and sculpture. What would the city be without the excitement of the ''Next Wave'' festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music or the rich diversity provided by hundreds of ambitious community-based arts groups?

title: White House Backs Away From Ban on Fetal Tissue Research
description: The White House today backed away from immediate action on a draft executive order that would ban federally financed research using human fetal tissue obtained from elective abortions. But it left its ultimate goals on such research unclear.

title: Young Traded to Colts
description: Fredd Young, a linebacker who has made the Pro Bowl in each of his four seasons in the National Football League, could not get the Seattle Seahawks to pay him what he thought he was worth. But he did succeed in finding someone who would. Young left the shadows of Brian Bosworth's 10-year, $11 million deal at Seattle with a huge new contract from his new employers, the Indianapolis Colts. He was sent to the Colts Thursday night after sitting out the Seahawks' opener last Sunday. In return, Seattle received the Colts' first-round pick in each of the next two seasons. Young's Los Angeles-based agent, Jeff Dankworth, said the Colts gave the fifth-year pro a five-year contract worth $4.5 million.(AP)

title: Burmese Revolt Seen as Spontaneous
description: Experts on Burma portray the upheaval there as a spontaneous revolution by people craving democracy, and they say the only mystery is why it took the Burmese so long to rise up against an oppressive, authoritarian Government.

title: Israel Says It Seized 200 Arabs in Crackdown
description: The army announced today that in recent weeks it had arrested 200 Palestinians and crushed a network of political committees that had been used to organize the nine-month Arab uprising in the Gaza Strip.

title: DEFECTIONS STRAIN BURMESE MILITARY
description: Hours after a former leader had declared a provisional government in Burma today, at least 200 uniformed Air Force personnel defected to the anti-Government side in a move that diplomats said could signal cracks in military support for the authorities.

title: Los Angeles Picked for Debate
description: Leaders of the campaigns of George Bush and Michael S. Dukakis have agreed on Los Angeles as the site of the second debate between the Republican and Democratic Presidential nominees, the chairman of Mr. Dukakis's campaign, Paul Brountas, said today.

title: REAGAN NOMINEE PRAISES BENNETT
description: Lauro F. Cavazos, President Reagan's nominee to be Secretary of Education, promised today that he would continue the educational changes he said had been started by the departing Secretary, William J. Bennett.

title: Susan Wheaton Huffard Weds George Lester Ball
description: Susan Wheaton Huffard, an interior designer, and George Lester Ball, the chairman and chief executive officer of Prudential-Bache Securities, were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Avery C. Manchester performed the service at the First Church of Round Hill.

title: Taylor Is Reported in Rehabilitation
description: Lawrence Taylor of the Giants has begun a rehabilitation program for substance abuse, a source close to the team said yesterday. The source, who requested anonymity, said the rehabilitation was not taking place in the metropolitan area.

title: BRIDGE
description: The location of the world's fastest bridge game is distinctly debatable. The daily commuter games that terminate abruptly in Grand Central and Penn Stations each morning and resume in the afternoons certainly have a claim, but halfway around the world there is a game that is perhaps even faster.

title: 5 Are Sentenced In Queens Arson Of Baby Shelter
description: Three Queens homeowners were sentenced to prison yesterday and two others were sentenced to community-service work for setting fire to an unoccupied house on their block that New York City had planned to use to shelter foster-care infants.

title: The Roots of the Inquiry
description: The undercover Customs Service investigation that led to the arrest of the former chief executive of Ashland Oil and three other people began more than a year ago after reports that Ashland documents were being offered to Iranian representatives for about $25 million, court records show.

title: Dukakis Likens G.O.P. Attacks To McCarthy's
description: In his sharpest attack yet, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts today compared the Republicans who are ''attacking my patriotism'' to those who cheered the tactics of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and challenged the patriotism of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY SEPTEMBER 10, 1988
description: Companies

title: Hardly a Peep on Poison Gas
description: Credit the State Department at least for condemning Iraq's ''abhorrent and unjustifiable'' use of poison gas. The department has rightly ignored Administration officials who seem to believe that saying anything might complicate the gulf war cease-fire talks. Yet it was left to the Senate to put teeth in the American protest by approving a ban on aid to Iraq so long as it wages chemical war against its Kurdish population.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, some copies of a front-page article yesterday about the Yonkers housing crisis omitted two lines. The passage, beginning with a quotation from a resident of Yonkers, should have read: '' 'Right now, there's no garbage collection on my street. It's time for integration.' With garbage piling up on sidewalks, with three libraries to close and 447 city workers to be laid off this weekend, many residents shifted the focus from their homes, whose values they fear will be harmed by the public housing required in the desegregation plan, to more immediate concerns, like their jobs and city.''

title: Cup Victory Met With Relief
description: The crowd was not as large in the San Diego Yacht Club today as it was on the night last year when Dennis Conner recaptured the America's Cup in Australia. The celebration was not as raucous, the mood not as euphoric.

title: SAVINGS RESCUES UNDER THE SOUTHWEST PLAN
description: Assistance packages worked out by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation this year to save insolvent savings institutions. Total value of cash or equity capital provided by acquiring institutions is about $87 million; the cost to the F.S.L.I.C. is $6 billion to $12.3 billion. May 13: Coastal Banc Savings Association of Houston acquires four insolvent savings institutions. Coastal contributes new capital of $3.5 million; F.S.L.I.C. provides $138.3 million. May 18: Southwest Savings Association, Dallas, acquires four insolvent institutions. Southwest provides $25 million in equity capital; F.S.L.I.C. $2 billion in assistance. May 25: First Savings of Brenham, Tex., acquires Bluebonnet Savings Association of Texas, in Hempstead. First Savings provides $1.8 million; F.S.L.I.C. $9.9 million. June 22: Merabank, a Federal savings bank in Phoenix, acquires two savings institutions. Merabank contributes $8.8 million in new capital; F.S.L.I.C. cost is $83.9 million. On Aug. 26, Merabank acquires a third Texas savings unit for $20 million; F.S.L.I.C. cost $585 million. Aug. 18: An investment group, Gibson Group/LSST Financial Services, headed by a Chicago banker and backed by a Texas steel company, acquires 12 insolvent savings associations. Gibson contributes $48 million in cash; F.S.L.I.C. cost is $1.3 billion. Aug. 19: Eight insolvent Texas savings institutions are consolidated under the F.S.L.I.C. Initial F.S.L.I.C. cost is $2.5 billion; long-term cost could total $5.5 billion. Sept. 9: Pulte Diversified invests $21.7 million to acquire four Texas savings associations; F.S.L.I.C. cost will be $556.9 million. Pulte plans to buy a fifth unit for $23.3 million; F.S.L.I.C. cost undisclosed. (Source: Federal Home Loan Bank Board)

title: Coniston Buys Gillette Options
description: Coniston Partners has purchased 1.51 million Gillette Company put options in open-market transactions at an average price of $10.42, the investment partnership disclosed today in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Robinson to Return
description: Frank Robinson will return as the Baltimore Orioles' manager in 1989, the club announced yesterday. Robinson and the Orioles agreed to a year-to-year rollover manager's contract that will place Robinson in an executive position in the club's front office once he completes his duties as manager. The contract's renewal will be at the club's option. Robinson, 53 years old, replaced Cal Ripken as manager April 12, after the Orioles lost their first six games. After losing the first 15 under Robinson, the Orioles have gone 49-68.(AP)

title: Egypt Seizes an Israel Yacht, Releasing It After Five Hours
description: Egypt seized an Israeli yacht with at least 31 people on board off the Sinai Peninsula coast today but released it five hours later after urgent diplomatic contacts, a senior Israeli official said.

title: A Fair in Brooklyn
description: Food, crafts, rides, merchandise and entertainment will line Eighth Avenue from 45th to 61st Street in Brooklyn from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. today as part of the avenue's annual International Street Fair. A stage at the corner of 55th Street will offer nonstop performances, and a hospital booth at the corner of 60th Street will offer free blood-pressure tests and dispense health information. The rain date is next Saturday. Information: (718) 234-1657.

title: The Quayle Garble Trail
description: Vice President George Bush chose Dan Quayle as his running mate because of the Senator's apparent knowledge of military affairs and his campaigning skills. Neither asset is testing well.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The platform states the position of the platform, but nobody in our party takes a litmus test that says that everybody has to agree on every issue. I expect the Democrats could say the same thing.'' - Vice President Bush. [ 1:5. ]

title: Optimism Is Voiced on Southern Africa Talks
description: Cuban, Angolan and South African negotiators ended three days of talks here today expressing optimism that another meeting could resolve the troublesome issue of a timetable for the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola.

title: IT'S LADIES' DAY AT BELMONT
description: Talk about an equal-opportunity sport: the leading candidate for Horse of the Year meets the winner of the Kentucky Derby today at Belmont Park, and both of them are fillies.

title: In Frozen North, Weather Reports (Especially on TV) Are a Hot Topic
description: The Canadian weather station huddling here beside an Arctic fjord is one of the last outposts of habitation before the North Pole. It is so far north that the northern lights, the multicolored aurora that hangs like a curtain across the Arctic sky, are visible on the southern horizon.

title: U.S. Open; Agassi Riding High
description: The popular opinion was that Andre Agassi was too young and inexperienced to win the United States Open. He has won six tournaments this year, but the highest-ranked player he beat before the Open was Henri Leconte of France, No. 11 in the world. Thus, it figured that Agassi would be like a sneak preview, winning a few rounds at Flushing Meadows, making friends, influencing people, giving fans a glimpse of the future.

title: Post Offices' Window Service To Return to Normal Today
description: Window service at post offices, cut last February to save money, is being restored starting Saturday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amerihost Properties Inc., Des Plaines, Ill., said it had broken ground in Richmond, Ill., for a Days Inn motel, one of three new motels it is building.

title: Give the Smokeless Cigarette A Chance
description: Should the Food and Drug Administration regulate RJR Nabisco's new ''smokeless'' cigarette, scheduled to be test-marketed this month under the name Premier? An impressive list of experts, including the Surgeon General and the American Medical Association, argue that the Premier is a hi-tech device for delivering nicotine, designed for addicts seeking a safer way to take the drug.

title: Javelin Throw Breaks Record
description: Petra Felke of East Germany set a world record in the women's javelin today with a throw of 262 feet 5 inches, improving her own record of 258-10, which she set last year.

title: Stephanie Boyle Wed To Thomas Harrigan
description: The marriage of Stephanie Boyle, a daughter of Beverly Bates Boyle of New York and John G. Boyle of St. Thomas, V.I., to Thomas Aquinas Harrigan, a son of Jacqueline Bose Harrigan and Judge Dennis F. Harrigan, both of Milford, Conn., took place yesterday at the Lapham Estate in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Anne Bogardus Kimball, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Rock; Lynyrd Skynyrd Band Holds On to a Tradition
description: The Lynyrd Skynyrd Tribute Band broke into its arena tour to play the Ritz on Tuesday night. Despite some use of video and slightly updated haircuts, the concert nearly recaptured the rolling, drawling, gut-level impact of a 1970's Lynyrd Skynyrd show.

title: Surprise Tobacco Data: Suits Fall
description: Three months after the first jury verdict ever against a tobacco company for a smoker's death, the flood of lawsuits that antismoking advocates predicted would threaten the cigarette industry's future has not materialized, new statistics show.

title: Mets Continue to Crank It Out
description: The Mets changed stadiums, cities and even countries tonight, but kept blazing away with their bats, hitting three more home runs, knocking out 14 more hits and hammering the Montreal Expos, 7-3.

title: Happy Landing for Tyson
description: Mike Tyson arrived in Moscow this afternoon, affectionately nuzzling his wife, giving a bandaged thumbs-up sign and dismissing as untrue a report that he tried to kill himself last Sunday by driving his car into a tree in Catskill, N.Y.

title: Experts Said to Find Missile Downed Italian Jet in 1980
description: Experts examining the wreckage of an Italian jet that crashed into the sea in 1980, killing all 81 people on board, have concluded it was probably hit by a missile, Italian news reports said today.

title: Quayle Fields Another Question About Admission to Law School
description: Senator Dan Quayle, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, campaigned today in the swing state of Ohio, telling steelworkers that he identified with them, had worked to limit imports and had co-sponsored a bill to retrain the unemployed.

title: For Workers in Yonkers, Fear Set In As Threatened Dismissals Loomed
description: Months ago, Mary Rogers, a single parent and assistant custodian for the Yonkers Public Library, finally wrested herself from four years of dependence on welfare. Friday was to have been her last day of work, not because she gave up or failed at her job, but because the city was to dismiss her, and hundreds of others, to pay its mounting contempt fines.

title: Westinghouse Adds to Holdings
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation acquired National Electric Inc. for undisclosed terms, giving Westinghouse 100 percent ownership of Aptus, an environmental services and hazardous-waste management company based in Lakeville, Pa.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Bush Assails Using Abortion Issue As a 'Litmus Test' for Candidates
description: Vice President Bush said today that attitudes on abortion should not be used as a ''litmus test'' to measure a politician.

title: How Pakistan's Sacred-Law Ordinance Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Chided on Marketing
description: The United States Commerce Secretary, C. William Verity Jr., today called on Japanese business leaders to streamline their distribution system, which he said acted as a barrier to American exports.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5, 28 A papal visit to Africa is not slight to Pretoria, the Vatican said. Pope John Paul II wants to visit South Africa, but cannot on a visit to five neighboring countries because of scheduling problems, the Vatican said. Page 3 Violence in central Nicaragua, in the provinces of Chontales and Boaco, continues despite the cease-fire between contra rebels and the Government. Political killings and imprisonment have not abated. 2 Fears of epidemic in Bangladesh are rising as flood waters recede. Illness and death from gastrointestinal disease have begun to increase; supplies of medicine and water purification tablets are scarce. 4 Members of Burma's air force defected to the opposition, hours after a former leader declared a provisional Goverment. Diplomats said the move could signal a weakening of military support for the Goverment. 3 The political upheval in Burma is a genuine democratic revolution, according to experts on Burma, who wonder why it took the Burmese so long to rise up against the authoritarian Government. 3 Washington stood behind its charge that Iraq had used poison gas against the Kurds. The Iraqis continued to deny the charge. The Senate approved a bill that would ban American commodity credits to Iraq. 4 Turkish examinations of Kurds have turned up no evidence to support claims that Iraq used chemical weapons against the Kurds, Turkey said in a statement that did not directly contradict Washington. 4 Life at a Canadian weather station in Eureka, Northwest Territories, is severe, but the crew is bothered more by the way American television reports the weather than by polar bears or the cold. 4 Times are trying for Soviet readers, who now face limits on subscriptions to some of the most popular and provocative magazines and newspapers. Officials blame a paper shortage; readers are skeptical. 5 Optimism on Africa talks 3 Plane crash in Thailand kills 75 3 Russians pessimistic on errant Mars craft 5 Israel says it seized 200 Arabs 28 National 6-9, 50

title: At Seafood Event, an Undercurrent of Worry
description: The second annual New Jersey Seafood Festival was held at this seaside resort today, and though the seascape was serene, the festival itself was awash with concerns and conflicting views about the danger that pollution poses, or does not pose, to fish and to people who eat fish.

title: Mood of Caution Rules in the Post-Crash Market
description: FIGURING that panic on Wall Street might deflate property prices throughout New York City, Douglas P. Klassen decided to halt his search for an apartment indefinitely when the stock market plummeted last October.

title: Kristin Gerrity and DeWitt Alexandre Jr. Married
description: The wedding of Kristin Kuhns Gerrity, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Kuhns of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif., and Blue Hill, Me., to DeWitt Loomis Alexandre Jr., the son of Mrs. William W. Foshay of Hobe Sound, Fla., and the late Mr. Alexandre, took place yesterday in Arlington, Vt. The Rev. Joan O'Gorman, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Federated Church of Arlington.

title: Administration Faults Dukakis on College Loans
description: Reagan Administration officials in the Department of Education have criticized a new college loan proposal by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis because the loan repayment plan would make graduates in high-paying careers subsidize the loans of those in low-paying ones.

title: Virtually Unbeatable: Stefanie Maria Graf
description: The promising 14-year-old tennis player had torn the tendons in her thumb, falling on the grass courts during practice, forcing her to withdraw from the Australian Open. Her disappointment, however, was lessened when she received a letter of encouragement from Martina Navratilova, then the No. 1 player in the world. Take your time, Navratrilova wrote. Don't rush your career. Stay in school.

title: Talking About Women, Not to Them
description: THERE IS SOMETHING extremely peculiar about the messages women are getting this election year. A rat, presented with the same set of contradictions, would simply keel over in its little maze, toes up, circuits blown. Women are expected to press on and vote.

title: Boats Circle New York Harbor and Sound Off in Protest of Ocean Pollution
description: Scores of boats, from leisure craft to charter fishing rigs and giant tour boats, gathered in New York Harbor off Battery Park yesterday morning to protest ocean pollution.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: WRIGHTSTOWN AIR SHOW The Thunderbirds, the Air Force aerial demonstration team and their F-16 fighters, will be the stars today of McGuire Air Force Base's annual air show, which last year drew 400,000 spectators.

title: TENSE TALK
description: Reading Ben Yagoda's article brought back memories of my medical internship, when I was astounded to discover that even brain surgery is not that difficult. Neurosurgery is more like real estate. There are only three important things to remember in the human brain: location, location, location. Once the skull is open, the tumor is resectable or not; the hematoma can be evacuated or not. It is all a matter of location. JOSEPH J. NEUSCHATZ, M.D. Port Jefferson, L.I.

title: Dean Stockwell, Happy at Last in Hollywood
description: In 1945, a beatific lost boy was befriended by a madcap sailor with a penchant for tap-dancing in the breezy M-G-M musical ''Anchors Aweigh.''

title: A Crossroads for the Free-Spirited Look
description: LATELY it has made news for other reasons, but Tompkins Square Park has long been a place for freewheeling fashion expression. It remains so, in spite of its recent troubles. In Tompkins Square, the dress mode is good-natured anarchy. The exuberant group that troops through the park may be giving a collective nose-thumb to more conventional styles, but it's done with a smile, not a smirk. These clothes are frequently outrageous, and almost always wonderful.

title: Drexel Burnham Fights Back
description: WHEN officials from the Securities and Exchange Commission arrived last Wednesday at the Federal Courthouse in Manhattan to file their civil complaint against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., they got a sample of the tenacious battle they have in store.

title: Still Fighting The Civil War
description: ''OUR point,'' says the president of the Alabama chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, ''is that that flag can be flown at any time in any place except on public property.''

title: Where Are Our Minority Judges?
description: Following are excerpts from a recent statement to the New York State Commission on Judicial Minorities by Thomas F. Liotti, a lawyer in Carle Place:

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: WALKING TOURS

title:
INVESTING;
The Lure of Troubled Savings Units
description: LEAD: THE participation of Robert M. Bass, the Texas billionaire, in last week's Government bailout of the American Savings and Loan Association, the nation's largest insolvent savings unit, demonstrated yet again that some very astute investors see attractive opportunities in the beleaguered savings and loan industry.

title:
GARDENING;
Manipulating Sunlight for Fall Flowers
description: LEAD: THAT sunlight is essential to the growth and development of green plants is a fact, but the quantity of sunlight required by plants varies, a factor that is confusing to many.

title: No Sabotage Clues Seen in Zia Crash
description: Nearly four weeks after Pakistan's President, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, and the United States Ambassador to that country were killed when a Pakistani Air Force plane crashed in eastern Pakistan, Pakistani and American investigators have so far found no conclusive evidence that a missile or a bomb was responsible.

title: Views From Family Tables
description: I USED to be a model tourist: I ordered coffees or Cokes and watched passers-by from sidewalk tables in cafes on Boulevard St.-Germain and Via Veneto; bargained gently for watches and cameras in Hong Kong or rugs and copper pots in North African souks. Then I got better jobs and stayed in hotels that got starrier and starrier till one day I made it to the top of the firmament: a five-star deluxe. I was introduced to fine wines and tasted foie gras from Strasbourg and caviar from Russia and curried bat in the Seychelles.

title: At 10, Merkin Celebrates Its Deep Roots, Swift Growth
description: LEAD: Mighty Carnegie is nearing its centennial, venerable Town Hall and City Center are both past 50, and even the travertine temples of Lincoln Center have mostly reached their quarter-century. But this year's news concerns a smaller venue. Merkin Concert Hall, the cozy auditorium of Abraham Goodman House, is celebrating its 10th anniversary.

title: Graf Attains a Tennis Slam
description: Steffi Graf of West Germany laid claim to the Grand Slam of tennis yesterday as she defeated Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina to win the United States Open women's singles final.

title: Vietnam Aide a Crash Victim
description: Vietnam's Health Minister was among 75 people killed when a Vietnamese airliner crashed while approaching Bangkok through a rainstorm, a Vietnamese diplomat said today. The health official, Dang Hoi Xuan, died when the Soviet-made Air Vietnam Tu-134 airliner slammed into a rice field Friday, a spokesman at the Vietnamese Embassy said. The diplomat also confirmed that Arun Patwardhan, India's Ambassador to Hanoi, his wife and 15-year-old son were among those killed.

title: Outdoors; Finding Exotic Fish in Unusual Settings
description: Marine angling in the New York region in summertime can produce some unusual catches. Every year from June through September the warm waters that bathe New Jersey and Long Island host a varied and interesting array of exotic fishes usually found at lower latitudes.

title: Behind the Fun
description: To the Editor:

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Demonstration Sports - Baseball
description: Will Clark, Mark McGwire and Cory Snyder - three of the best young sluggers in the major leagues today - played for the United States in 1984 when baseball was a demonstration sport in the Olympics. Yet Japan won the gold medal, which raises a question about how good this year's team will have to be to win the gold in Seoul, where baseball will again be a demonstration sport. (It will be a full medal sport in 1992.) In a ranking based on results in amateur world champsionship play from 1976 through 1986, South Korea has been seeded first among the eight teams scheduled to compete in Seoul. The United States, which won the silver medal four years ago, is seeded third and grouped with South Korea, Canada and Australia. The other group has Taiwan, Japan, Puerto Rico and the Netherlands.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Landmark Spot in Ossining
description: LEAD: ON a tree-lined street in the historic section of Sparta in Ossining, Dudley's is practically a landmark among landmarks. The restaurant has been a meeting and eating spot for almost 15 years. Recent visits have found the place as pretty as ever (except for the dated theater-lobby carpeting), and we wished for more mirrors to reflect the glittery candles, graceful sprays of baby's breath and greenery, dramatic against dark pews and wainscoting.

title: Headliners; A Promotion
description: Only in America could a mere Ivy League president and Renaissance scholar become the commissioner of baseball. Last week, A. Bartlett Giamatti, who left as head of Yale two years ago to become president of the National League, was elected to the five-year term by the 26 major league club owners. He will replace Peter Ueberroth April 1. The future commissioner said that while labor relations and financial concerns were necessary duties, his job also involved such ''social justice'' matters as fairness in hiring and drug rehabilitation. Meanwhile, baseball fans may be lining up to ask him a few questions, and not about his book ''Play of Double Senses: Spenser's Faerie Queene.'' Hey, what about that balk rule? . . .

title: Canada Tries to Make Restitution to Its Own
description: POSTERS of the tiny Eskimo settlement of Grise Fiord, the most northerly civilian community in Canada, show what an arresting spot it is in the noontime darkness of the Arctic winter, a string of lighted homes nestling between a towering rockface and a snow-blown shore. There are 85 people living there now, but when Larry Audlaluk's parents were chosen to help establish a community on the fiord in the winter of 1953, they had little inclination to celebrate.

title: Victoria Dietel Is Wed To Jonathan S. Hopps
description: Victoria Moore Dietel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Dietel of Flint Hill, Va., was married yesterday in Saranac Inn, N.Y., to Jonathan Shaw Hopps, a son of Mrs. Robert L. Foster of Christiansted, St. Croix, V.I., and Thomas D. Hopps of Camden, Me. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr., minister of the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn., performed the ceremony at the bride's family's summer home on Deer Island in Upper Saranac Lake.

title: Of Kettles, Age and Hidden Faces
description: To the Editor:

title: Raising the Odds
description: WINNING MONEY, fame and status in Hollywood is never easy. The quickest overnight success usually takes years. But there are always a few actors, directors, producers - and even a few movie executives - who insist on making it harder. They handicap themselves by making unconventional choices. Those who depart from whatever formulas are in fashion may end up with terrible mistakes, but their movies won't be boring.

title: NO PLACE LIKE HOME
description: There are some dishes that - no matter how appealing - will never be served in a restaurant. And vice versa.

title: Notebook; Revived Brewers, Once 11 Games Out, Up With Contenders
description: The Milwaukee Brewers have become believers in life after death because as far as they were concerned, they died six weeks ago and here they are alive again.

title: Question Of the Week; What Do You Expect To See in the Olympics?
description: If the coverage of the Winter Games is any criterion, I expect to see a tremendous number of commercials. Since my patience with commercials wears thin very quickly, I expect to see what is on the other channels or in my bookcase. STEVAN LEVINSON Forest Hills, Queens

title: A National Festival, and a Source of Pride
description: We have put forward slogans like ''harmony and progress of mankind'' and ''staging the best and largest Games in Olympic history'' while we were preparing for the Games. Now we can say that we have lived up to those slogans.

title: SALVADORAN ISSUES A REFUGEE APPEAL
description: A letter from the President of El Salvador has asked the United States to grant temporary refuge to a half-million Salvadorans already in this country, and the letter warned that many of them would support leftist guerrillas if they were forced to return home.

title:
GARDENING;
Manipulating Sunlight for Fall Flowers
description: LEAD: THAT sunlight is essential to the growth and development of green plants is a fact, but the quantity of sunlight required by plants varies, a factor that is confusing to many.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We hope today to alert the public to what is clearly the 'fraud du jour' - the fools' gold rush of 1988.'' - James E. Meyer, president of the North American Securities Administrators Association, on estimates that fraudulent gold-mine schemes will take in $250 million this year.

title: Questions of Image and Perception of the Games
description: The telephone calls began shortly after 7 o'clock Friday morning. Accounts of a student demonstration the day before had reached Europe, and some of Juan Antonio Samaranch's friends and associates were concerned.

title:
ART;
Wood, Cloth and Neon at Wesleyan
description: LEAD: KLAUS OTTMANN, the new Curator of Exhibitions at the Zilka Gallery of Wesleyan University in Middletown, declares that he has positive feelings for the space that is his province.

title: Legislators Adopt Recycling Program
description: LEAD: BY unanimous vote last Wednesday, the County Board of Legislators adopted a modified version of the comprehensive recycling plan that County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke sent it in February.

title: A Different View Of 'Verona'
description: Having seen and thoroughly enjoyed the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's delightful production of ''Two Gentlemen of Verona,'' I was appalled at the half-hearted, ''damning with faint praise'' review by Alvin Klein (Theater: ''Fun and Games in Verona,'' Aug. 14).

title: Pope Backs Sanctions for South Africa
description: At the start of a five-nation tour of Africa, Pope John Paul II today offered his approval of the strict economic sanctions against South Africa now under consideration by the United States Congress. He said such measures are morally acceptable as a last resort in the struggle against apartheid.

title: Mia Lewis Weds William Masters In Massachusetts
description: The marriage of Mia Lewis and William Masters, 1984 graduates of Yale University, took place yesterday in West Tisbury, Mass., at the summer home of the bride's family. The Rev. Linda Strohmeir, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
East End Houses Are Still Selling Well
description: LEAD: LATE summer is traditionally the time when vacationers who have rented houses for the season begin looking for properties to buy, and all signs indicate that demand for houses on the East End is strong, especially in the Hamptons.

title: Survey to Examine Librarian Shortage
description: LEAD: THE Connecticut Library Association intends to canvass libraries statewide in the coming months to see if an apparent shortage of librarians is critical and, if so, what is causing it.

title: 100-METER RIVALRY RUNS ON
description: AS Ben Johnson and Carl Lewis moved into the blocks that afternoon at the world track and field championships last August in Rome, no one could have known the nature of what was to follow. After all, these splendid sprinters had opposed each other at the same, 100-meter distance 13 other times, with neither pushing the other to any historic limits. And, certainly, none of the previous races burned in memory as this one would.

title: Are We Ready to Learn From the Vietnam War?; Soldiers Who Said No
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; The Ray Brown Trio's Jazz
description: Without a wind instrument in sight, the Ray Brown Trio and Ernie Andrews summon the unmistakable sound of big-band brass. Mr. Brown, a bassist, and Mr. Andrews, a singer, have brought the elegant dynamics of the Count Basie Orchestra to their sets at the Blue Note, where their engagement ends tonight.

title: MUSIC: Operas and Organ Recitals
description: When Harvey Lichtenstein opened the refurbished Majestic Theater last fall, two blocks from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it was perceived as a New York home for Peter Brook and other innovative theater directors. But now it is emerging as a concert hall and opera house as well. Pierre Boulez's appearances there in June with the Ensemble Intercontemporain proved the excellence of its acoustics, and now a number of other musical and operatic events are being negotiated, not the least of which are the Metropolitan Opera's Brooklyn experimental seasons, starting in 1991.

title: Morgan Baker, Writer, Weds
description: The marriage of Mary Morgan Baker, a daughter of Mrs. John O. Flender of Cambridge and West Tisbury, Mass., and James B. Baker of New York and New Lebanon, N.Y., to Matthew Dean Burns Brelis, the son of Nancy B. Jay of Cambridge and Dean Brelis of Milbridge, Me., took place yesterday. The Rev. James Martin performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in West Tisbury.

title: Albany's Battle Over Milk Industry Is Not Over Yet
description: GOVERNOR CUOMO put an end last week to yet another battle affecting the state's dairy industry with a veto of one of the most controversial legislative measures of the year. The bill would have imposed heavy penalties on milk dealers who used ''coercion'' to prevent farmers from joining a regional cooperative. But experts on both sides of the issue predicted that with the industry still in turmoil, there will be a fight over milk in the Legislature again before long.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a ceramic tile floor in our bathroom consisting of one-inch square tiles. The floor is even and in good condition, but it is not attractive, and so we would like to put down new ceramic tile. Can we put new tile on top of the existing tile, or must we rip up all the old tile first?

title: Public to Get Radioactive Waste Plan
description: THIS week the state will publicly reveal its plans for establishing a dump for the 22 tons of low-level radioactive waste generated in Connecticut each year.

title: Aircraft's Parts Are Found
description: An 800-pound propeller that dropped from a C-130 aircraft last week in a wooded section of Winhall was found Friday by Air Force officials. The propeller and other parts fell off a transport plane at 7:05 P.M. Sept. 1 as it headed for Loring Air Force Base, Me., from Davis-Monthan Air Force Base at Tucson, Ariz. The plane was landed safely.

title: Stone Sculpture Society Exhibits Work
description: HAVING no place to call home, the Stone Sculpture Society of New York makes itself known by its exhibitions, one of which is now at Blue Hill Plaza here. Carvings by 64 artists, 52 of them dues-paying members, the rest their guests, most of the works are displayed in the gallery that is a part of this corporate settlement in Rockland. The others are to be found in the greenhouse that runs alongside the cafeteria next door to the gallery, as well as in the lobby and on the landscaped grounds.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Chester, Conn. $155,000 Straits Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new Cape Cod; close to town, private setting, 2 acres; taxes not yet available. Essex, Conn. $145,000 53 Pond Meadow 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old ranch; screened porch, custom construction, 0.75 acre; taxes $846. Riverside, Conn. $287,000 12 Amherst Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 26-year-old split-level; pond views, hardwood floors, taxes $2,040. Bedford, N.Y. $395,000 21 Appleby Drive 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 24-year-old ranch; 2 fireplaces, dining room, master bedroom, family room, patio, 2-car garage, 1.1 acres; taxes $4,787. Mount Kisco, N.Y. $1 million Hoyts Lane 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, den, screened porch, tennis court, pool, 2-car garage, 6.9 acres; taxes $12,699. Rye, N.Y. $367,500 63 Florence Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 34-year-old ranch; fireplace, family room, enclosed porch, patio, 1-car garage; taxes $3,440. OTHER AREAS East Northport, L.I. $247,900 5 Kimber Court 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old farm ranch; eat-in kitchen, 2 fireplaces, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,400. East Patchogue, L.I. $119,750 95 Miramar Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 18-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, deck; taxes $2,100. Mountainside, N.J. $327,500 6 Endor Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 36-year-old colonial; deck, new kitchen, skylights; taxes $3,050.

title: Paying Children To Go to School
description: WHEN Red Bank (N.J.) Regional High School began paying potential dropouts $5 a day to attend school regularly, some other students and teachers became upset.

title: Penguin STages 'Middle Ages'
description: ALTHOUGH the enterprising Penguin Repertory goes in for the new and the unfamiliar, it has a certain fondness for the plays of A. R. Gurney Jr., which seem to pop up every couple of seasons. ''The Middle Ages'' is the third of Mr. Gurney's works to be seen here in six years - after ''What I Did Last Summer'' and ''The Dining Room.''

title: Heritage Hills: Another View
description: Your article of Aug. 21 on Heritage Hills [ ''The View From: Heritage Hills'' ] gave an unbalanced description of life in this semiretirement complex. As more and more young people purchase homes here this is a mixture of working and nonworking residents. Certainly there are many here who think they have died and gone to heaven because of the availability of free tennis and swimming and other carefree activities but there are also many who, as volunteers, are giving much time and effort in hospitals, libraries, to people who are homebound, to literacy programs and other selfless activities.

title: Lions Touting End to Loss Streak
description: After Columbia outscored Hofstra, 34-14, in their practice game on Thursday night at Baker Field, the Lions did some roaring in the field house.

title: A New Move Becomes a Powerful Tactic
description: THERE is something unobtrusive about interrupting a natural-looking series of moves by inserting a move that suddenly introduces a new and powerful tactical idea. It may be that such interpolations escape attention just because they are so different from the original idea.

title: Details at Eleven
description: BROADCAST NEWS Starring William Hurt, Holly Hunter (in photo), Albert Brooks, Robert Prosky, Lois Chiles, Joan Cusack, Peter Hackes, Christian Clemenson, Robert Katims. Directed by James L. Brooks. 1987. CBS/Fox Video. 132 minutes. $89.98. Rated R.

title: SEASON PREVIEW: CLASSICAL RECORDS
description: AFTER HALF A DOZEN YEARS IN WHICH THE classical record business took on new life as a result of the boom in compact disks, the competition both in classical sales and in pressing CD's has become fierce.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: GENDER AND THE POLITICS OF HISTORY. By Joan Wallach Scott. (Columbia University, $29.) Many of the fine essays in this collection have been briskly circulating in photocopy form; their revision and publication in a single volume (most have appeared in print elsewhere) is welcome. These lucid studies in historical method and meaning are addressed to professional historians, whose field is in a state of total upheaval and is now being challenged by (among others) feminists who insist that women have to be written into the story.

title: P. A. Parent Weds Miss Trowbridge
description: Kimberly Trowbridge, the daughter of Alexander B. Trowbridge of Washington and Nancy H. Trowbridge of Southport, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Arthur Parent, the son of Renee Parent of Rumson, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Richard performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Nantucket, Mass. He was assisted by the Rev. Philip A. Davignon, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: 'Architectural Investigations' on View
description: THE show's title is ''Presence and Perception, Architectural Investigations,'' and its location is the City Without Walls Gallery, at 1 Gateway Plaza. This, along with the names of the chief organizers, Ron Petersen and Martin Acampora, and the closing date, Thursday, is about it for hard information.

title: 34>A Mother's Lessons Not Fully Learned
description: ''YOU'RE not to do it, understand? I don't want you to go there tonight. It's a dangerous neighborhood. You'll get stuck in traffic, and you'll come home late and I'll worry about you. Don't go!''

title: The Psychology of the Station Wagon
description: I SAW my friend Lenny the other day sitting in his shiny new Pontiac 6000 station wagon. When I stopped to compliment him on his new car, he put up his hands, shrugged and said with a note of embarrassment, ''Well, I had to get a wagon. I need a bigger car now that we have a kid.''

title: Katherine Dillon Becomes a Bride
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington, Katherine Dillon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy V. Dillon of Washington, and Jeffrey Arnold Murphy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel A. Murphy of Morristown, N.J., were married by the Rev. John C. Harper.

title: Ailing Ashe in Hospital
description: This was a special summer for Arthur Ashe. In 1968, when tennis lifted the barriers to professionals, he won the first United States Open, becoming the first black man to win a Grand Slam event. But Ashe hasn't had a chance to celebrate the 20th anniversary. He is in New York Hospital, undergoing tests to determine why his right side became numb last week.

title: FOCUS: Vancouver; Bustling City Is Transforming Its Waterfront
description: BARELY a century old and now Canada's third largest metropolis, this energetic port city of British Columbia is about to embark on a development spree that will dramatically change its look, character and style.

title: SHREWD AND CRUDE
description: THE TEMPLE By Stephen Spender. 210 pp. New York: Grove Press. $15.95.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Demonstration Sports - Taekwondo
description: Taekwondo, a martial art indigenous to Korea, is a demonstration sport selected by the host nation for inclusion in the Olympics this year. Like other demonstration sports, if it proves popular enough, it could be voted onto the permanent Olympic agenda by the International Olympic Committee.

title: Hibiscus Will Bloom Indoors After Frost
description: IT won't be long now. We will awaken on a chilly morning with a blue, cloudless sky. By noon, the wind will die and the air will grow colder and colder. Frost will be coming during the night.

title: Dr. Brown to Wed Rhena Vaughns
description: The engagement of Rhena English Vaughns, a daughter of Dorothy Cook English of Hollis, Queens, and the late Wilford English, to Dr. Howard R. Brown, a son of Muriel V. Brown of Arden Heights, S.I., and the late Isaac L. Brown, has been announced by the future bride's mother.

title:
Piscataway Journal;
Truck Ban Sought for River Road
description: LEAD: ON hot nights, Michael Munk cannot open his windows because of the roar and rattle of trucks whizzing by on River Road. One of several owners of historic homes on the road, Mr. Munk is chairman of the Piscataway Environmental Protection Organization, a group of 300 families who have been fighting for a year to lower the speed limit and ban trucks at night along this route.

title: HISTORY IS A BUST
description: LEAD: PICTURE THIS By Joseph Heller. 352 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title: Another Mosquito To Worry About
description: AS MOSQUITOES go, the Asian tiger is not only exceptionally aggressive, but also a carrier of serious diseases. So it was with an undercurrent of unease that Federal authorities reported in 1985 that the insect had entered this country in Houston aboard used tire casings.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should Drug Violators Be Paid for Time Away?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: BASEBALL: American League; Clemens Fires 1-Hitter as Red Sox Beat Indians
description: Roger Clemens held Cleveland hitless for seven and one-third innings today as the Boston Red Sox beat the Indians, 6-0, for their fifth victory in six games.

title: NEW FACES
description: LINDA HART

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Cincinnati
description: Some 200 years ago, a party of 24 men and nearly a dozen families settled on the banks of the Ohio River in a place called Losantiville. Two years later, in what is now testimony to the ease with which whims could be satisfied on the frontier, Gen. Arthur St. Clair, Governor of the Northwest Territory, decided he didn't like the name. He changed it to Cincinnati.

title: Barbara A. Hopkinson Wed to Kevin L. Kelly
description: The marriage of Barbara Alice Hopkinson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald F. Hopkinson of Smoke Rise, N.J., and Jupiter Island, Fla., to Kevin Lawrence Kelly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Kelly of Auburndale, Mass., and Duxbury, Mass., took place yesterday in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Edward Johnston performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: As Yonkers Averts Bankruptcy, Residents Express Relief and Anger
description: Hours after the Yonkers City Council approved a court-ordered housing desegregation plan early yesterday, many Yonkers residents expressed relief that the crisis that had threatened to bankrupt the city was over. But the relief was tinged with apprehension that the new housing would lead to slums and crime, as some opponents have long feared.

title: For Better or Worse
description: MADE FOR EACH OTHER Starring James Stewart, Carole Lombard, Lucille Watson, Charles Coburn. Directed by John Cromwell. Key Video. 94 minutes. $19.98.

title: For Congress From New York
description: New York City Democrats so outnumber Republicans that a victory in the Democratic primary usually means election. In four races for Congress in Thursday's primary, voters will have even less choice than usual.
