title: Summertime, and Some Livings, Aren't Easy
description: I'VE spoken to quite a few people lately who, like me, spend their days in an office. Even through the heat, they seem to recall fondly the days when employment commitments hinged on the summer season, and no job was too good to quit.

title: Adoption: Gathering A Family
description: IN 1978, when Iris Moore first decided to take in a foster child, she said, she was lonely. She was divorced, and her former husband, a Black Panther Party leader, Richard Moore, was serving 20 years for the attempted murder of two policemen. Her brother, with whom she had put a down payment on a house, had been killed in a car accident.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Canoeing/Kayaking
description: In most Olympics, canoeing has seemed to be an after thought for the United States. Americans have seldom reached finals, let alone won medals. Now the United States has become a factor, not on the level of East Germany, but certainly in the next group, with Hungary, the Soviet Union and New Zealand. In last year's world championships, the best American, Grey Barton, won two gold medals in kayaking.

title: Rockland Comes of Age as a Suburb
description: FOR more than a decade, the 20-story Blue Hill office tower loomed nearly empty over the wooded hills of southern Rockland County, a symbol of a commercial development whose time had not come.

title: Practical Traveler; Cash or Credit? Saving Money On Bills Abroad
description: WHAT'S the most economical way to pay your expenses on an overseas trip? The answer is parallel to the old saw about success in the stock market: Buy low, sell high. That is to say, when considering whether to convert dollars or traveler's checks into the local currency to buy things, or to use a credit card and pay later, your goal should be to pay at the moment when the dollar is worth the most in terms of the currency involved. If the dollar is falling, pay now. If it's rising, pay later.

title: Poised at the Turning Point
description: I don't know what it actually takes to become a star,'' says the choreographer Agnes de Mille, ''but it is a matter of being given the opportunities and of having the tremendous courage to take those opportunities. You have to have enough belief in yourself to do that, otherwise it's just coloring in the black and white.''

title: OLD, OLD SCHOOL BUILDINGS
description: IT was with a mixture of amusement and anger that I read a recent public relations bulletin issued by the Hewlett-Woodmere School Board. It began:

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Albertson $220,000 17 McKinley Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement, 2-car garage, aluminum siding; taxes $2,100. East Northport $247,900 5 Kimber Court 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old farm ranch; eat-in kitchen, 2 fireplaces, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,400. East Patchogue $119,750 95 Miramar Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 18-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, partly finished basement, deck; taxes $2,100. Massapequa $283,000 102 Adams Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; den, fireplace, new kitchen; taxes $4,100. Mineola $225,000 317 Marcellus Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 60-year-old Tudor; dining room, eat-in kitchen, fireplace, finished basement; taxes $1,900. Rocky Point $314,000 55 Westchester Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath new contemporary; c/a, decks, fireplace, 3-car garage; taxes $5,000. OTHER AREAS Chester, Conn. $155,000 Straits Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new Cape Cod; close to town, private setting, 2 acres; taxes not yet available. Rye, N.Y. $367,500 63 Florence Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 34-year-old ranch; fireplace, dining room, family room, enclosed porch, patio, 1-car garage; taxes $3,440. Mountainside, N.J. $327,500 6 Endor Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 36-year-old colonial; deck, new kitchen, skylights; taxes $3,050.

title: Let's Take Action to Reduce The Ozone on Route 1
description: RECENT health reports indicate that ozone levels in New Jersey have risen to unhealthy levels on many summer days. These reports further noted that the very highest ozone levels can be found immediately over Route 1.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Worcester, Mass.;
Providing For the Needy
description: LEAD: IN a city with a rental vacancy rate of no more than 2 percent and with its 160 beds for the homeless constantly occupied, local officials and housing advocacy groups are trying to develop subsidized low-income rental units on smaller, scattered sites.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Aug. 27 MANHATTAN Gramercy Park Area $151,000 33 East 22d Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 560-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; entry foyer, 12-ft. ceilings, arched doorways; maintenance $400, 39% tax-deductible (Broker: Joffee LaSalle) Greenwich Village $1,165,000 25 West 11th Street 2-family, 5-story, town house; 3 bedrooms, 3 baths, 2 fireplaces, 2 terraces in triplex unit; 2 bedrooms, 1 fireplace, 2 baths in duplex; garden, 20- by 103-ft. lot; taxes $8,100 (Broker: Kingman Associates) Greenwich Village $515,000 48 East 13th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 2,180-sq.-ft. loft co-op; large living room and master bedroom, windowed kitchen; maintenance $794, 35% tax-deductible (Broker: Kanelba & Robilotti) SoHo $515,000 16 Crosby Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 2,700-sq.-ft. loft co-op; 400-sq.-ft. art study, 3 exposures, high ceilings, artist in residence; maintenance $610, 55% tax-deductible (Sinvin Realty) Washington Heights $150,000 350 Cabrini Boulevard 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; part-time doorman, dining foyer, breakfast nook; maintenance $495, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Simone Song Properties) West Side $137,000 230 West End Avenue (70th St.) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 600-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, manned elevator, hardwood floors; maintenance $440, 50% tax-deductible (Penthouse Properties) BRONX City Island $325,000 210 Carroll Street (Boatyard) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,600-sq.-ft. condo in a 4-year-old building; dining area, fireplace, deck, boat mooring; common charge $345, taxes $1,500 (Broker: Jacqueline Kyle Kall) Kingsbridge $47,500 511 West 232d Street 350-sq.-ft. prewar studio co-op; wall-to-wall carpet, new kitchen appliances; maintenance $181, 45% tax-deductible (Broker: Susan E. title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Waterborne Radar ''He's going 30 miles per hour. But look, he sees us! Now he's slowing down! Now he's down to about 15!''

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Fencing
description: The chances that the United States will win its first gold medal in fencing are probably better in Seoul than at any other Olympics in decades, given the caliber of the 1988 team. But the likelihood is still considered remote.

title: FULL OF BEENES
description: At a time in fashion when most designers cautiously refrain from making pronouncements on the nature - and the future - of their craft, Geoffrey Beene remains as tartly outspoken as he was 15 years ago. Then, he decreed, silhouette be damned, ''the challenge of any collection is the fabric.''

title: Ms. Woodward Weds Benjamin Strong
description: Christina Melissa Woodward, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Rittenhouse Woodward 3d of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Benjamin Ruggles Woodbridge Strong, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodbridge Strong of Highland Park, N.J., and Lenox, Mass., were married in Lenox yesterday. The Rev. Duncan R. McQueen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Lenox Club.

title: Show by Firefighters To Benefit Burn Unit
description: A group of New York City firefighters and their friends and relatives will perform the musical ''Oklahoma!'' later this month to raise money for the burn unit of New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: Fire in Yellowstone, Hot Air in D.C.
description: A firestorm of political opportunism and incendiary rhetoric is racing through the treetops of Congress. It's scorching good science, laying waste to common sense and leaving nothing in its path but smoke and hot air.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Worcester, Mass.;
Providing For the Needy
description: LEAD: IN a city with a rental vacancy rate of no more than 2 percent and with its 160 beds for the homeless constantly occupied, local officials and housing advocacy groups are trying to develop subsidized low-income rental units on smaller, scattered sites.

title: Artist's Life: The Making of a 'Miracle'
description: Stephen Huneck is a wood-carving artist who could be called an afternoon success. The afternoon was in May 1984, when he quite unwillingly sold his first sculpture.

title: TENSE TALK
description: Ben Yagoda's article ''Tense Talk'' (On Language, Aug. 14) notes the tendency among many professionals to take solace in the fact that what they do is not brain surgery. But when the going gets tough in my job, what do I say? ABBOT J. KRIEGER, M.D. Chief of Neurosurgery New Jersey Medical School Newark

title: Freshman Orient Themselves in Maine's Woods
description: Sitting beside a campfire in the woods of western Maine on a recent chilly evening, Dave Jorgensen was given a simple, but treasured gift: all the information not fit to print in the student handbook for Colby College, the school he would soon enter.

title: CONNECTICUT SEEKS A FISCAL SOLUTION
description: Connecticut is trying to solve a fiscal puzzle. Its economy still seems to be perking briskly, but the flow of tax money to the state has turned sluggish.

title: Question Of the Week; What Do You Expect To See in the Olympics?
description: I expect to see hype, promotion, show business and flackery, and hope that I will dismiss it in the search for the talented, the practiced, the determined and the skilled.

title: Reagan's Social Issues: Gone but Not Forgotten
description: IN the first years of his Presidency, Ronald Reagan's so-called social agenda - including a Federal ban on abortions, the legalization of organized school prayer and an end to court-ordered busing - was pushed by conservatives on Capitol Hill at every opportunity. But no longer.

title: Diluted Satire in 'Middle Ages'
description: ALTHOUGH the enterprising Penguin Repertory goes in for the new and the unfamiliar, it has a certain fondness for the plays of A. R. Gurney Jr., which seem to pop up every couple of seasons. ''The Middle Ages,'' which is playing at the Penguin's Barn Playhouse through Sunday, is the third of Mr. Gurney's works to be seen here in six years - after ''What I Did Last Summer'' and ''The Dining Room.''

title: IN THE NATION: Orlando, Fla.; A Suburban Developer Imposes Preservation Deed Restrictions
description: A SMALL, single-family, detached housing project that is about to begin in a heavily forested suburban area of this fast-growing central Florida city of 155,000 residents will require homeowners to leave 60 percent of their lots in a natural state. The twist is that the developer, not officials of Seminole County who govern the unincorporated site 15 miles northeast of downtown Orlando, imposed the rules.

title: NO MERE BOY, BUT A MIRACLE
description: THE CARETAKERS By Bernard Mathias. Translated by Freeman G. Henry. 221 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: Conservative Judaism Tilts Toward Israeli Left
description: Leaders of Conservative Judaism, the largest of the three main branches of Judaism in the United States, showed a decided tilt toward the Labor Party camp in Israel when they met last week to discuss their movement's growing involvement in Israeli life.

title: BY SPLEEN SUSTAINED
description: LILLY Reminiscences of Lillian Hellman. By Peter Feibleman. Illustrated. 364 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title: Car Companies Must Obey the Law
description: RARELY have so many news reports strengthened the case for strong implementation of the Energy Policy and Conservation Act of 1975, which gave auto companies 10 years to reach an average fleet mileage level of 27.5 miles per gallon.

title: Headliners; A Return
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware returned to tributes in the Senate last week after seven months during which he was operated on twice for brain aneurysms and once for a blood clot in a lung. He said he bore no grudge against the Dukakis camp for the disclosures -principally that he had used the words of a British politician without attribution - that forced his withdrawal a year ago from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination. ''Any personal feelings'' about that, he said, had ''disappeared somewhere between the first aneurysm and the blood clot.'' And he was careful to attribute to a fellow Irish Democrat, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the observation that ''to fail to understand that life is going to knock you down is to fail to understand the Irishness of life.''

title: There Are Redeeming Qualities
description: I HAVE lived on Long Island for most of my adult life, but lately I've been giving serious consideration to moving away.

title: REVISIONS SOUGHT
description: Facing the threat of bankruptcy and the imminent layoff of hundreds of city employees, the Yonkers City Council voted early this morning to approve a court-ordered housing desegregation plan. But it also voted to seek basic changes in where and how the housing is built.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: A.A.A. Cites Mississippi On Enforcement

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Diving
description: Gymnastics can be pretty and figure skating can be elegant, but for many people, no sport matches the esthetic and athletic beauty of diving. A good dive is easy to recognize, and television's slow-motion replays make a good dive even more enjoyable.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Shooting
description: Olympic shooting's two newest events are men's and women's air pistol competitions, bringing the total to 13. Though the various rifle, pistol and shotgun events have a larger following in Europe, Americans have done well over the years.

title: Staying in Stocks, but Cutting the Risk
description: AS the anniversary of Black Monday approaches, investors are reviewing their stock portfolios, assessing the past year's performance and charting a course for the future. But given the uncertain economic outlook and the looming Presidential election, many people want to minimize risk without abandoning the market. Here are some ways to do that:

title: Roberta A. Daly Becomes a Bride In Philadelphia
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, Roberta Abele Daly, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore M. Daly Jr. of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Earl Gilbert Graves Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Graves of Scarsdale, N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Robert Hofmeister performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Suffragan Bishop Henry B. Hucles 3d of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.

title: Prescription Drug Prices Outrun Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NATION: Who Pays?; How the U.S. Finds the Funds To Close Insolvent Thrifts
description: IN the past month, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has committed billions of dollars in its campaign of closing down, merging or rescuing bankrupt savings and loan associations.

title: A Hatful of Dust
description: ON THE RIO GRANDE -The thermometer rises effortlessly to 100 degrees. The only shade is the halftone cast by the lighting crew's silk screen, a kind of trampoline cocked in the air to deaden the glare for the camera. You try to hunker in this half-shade and cannot because the entire shadow is occupied by thorn bushes. Then you walk across the mesquite flat and stumble onto a deer's skull, and you know, quite certainly, that a man also could perish here. That is one of the realities that must be pushed out of sight until the camera needs it.

title: Once More, the Earth Visits Disaster on the Plains of Bangladesh
description: SPRAWLING across a vast delta where three of the world's great rivers meet, Bangladesh is the drainpipe of Central Asia. In bountiful times, the rich alluvial silt that covers most of the country yields as many as three rice crops a year. But when the drainpipe overflows, as it did two weeks ago, Bangladesh becomes a land reminiscent of Bruegel's visions of triumphant death.

title: An Affable Provocateur
description: RICHARD GREENBERG is a nice guy from Long Island who writes funny plays that often provoke what he calls ''strange, hostile questions.'' He is still rattled by one that was thrown at him last year during a post-performance audience discussion of ''The Maderati,'' his brittle sendup of today's young literati that in another day might have sprung from the pen of Dorothy Parker or Clare Boothe Luce. ''Some woman stood up in the back and said, 'Are all your characters so selfish? They're just talking I! I! I! Me! Me! Me! all the time.' ''

title: Children of Flatbush Adjust to Palm Trees and Poi
description: Separated from their birthplace by 4,969 miles, six time zones and a culture gap that can seem as broad as the Pacific Ocean, former Brooklynites who have settled here might be excused if they occasionally long for the shores of Coney Island.

title: A Newcomer for Professionals
description: THE much-anticipated Nikon F4 has finally arrived. Introduced Thursday at a press conference in New York City, the professional-grade, single-lens-reflex camera takes its place at the summit of Nikon models. It features just about every option and convenience a professional picture-taker might want, need or dream of.

title: In the Dakotas, a Bad Year and Worse Memories
description: ''The dawn came, but no day. In the gray sky a red sun appeared, a dim red circle that gave a little light, like dusk; and as the day advanced, the dusk slipped back toward darkness, and the wind cried and whimpered over the fallen corn.'' - John Steinbeck, ''The Grapes of Wrath''

title: A Few Tips for Buyers of Hardy Spring Bulbs
description: HOUSE plants should be moved back indoors; first, check plants for mealybugs, spiders, slugs and other unwanted invaders; second, wash leaves and stems with a forceful spray of water; third, use a stiff brush to scrub pots clean. Christmas cactus and jade plants can remain outdoors until a light frost occurs to induce flowering. Bulb Shopping

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf King Leads by One: Betsy King, winner of last week's Rail Charity Classic, took the second-round lead by one stroke yesterday at the $250,000 Cellular One-Ping Championship in Portland, Ore. King, who started the day at one-under par, shot a two-under 70 for a two-day total of 141 over the 6,285-yard course at Riverside Golf and Country Club. Stephanie Farwig, Sandra Haynie and Penny Hammel were tied for second. King emerged as the leader late in the afternoon as Hammel took a double-bogey and Farwig took a bogey on the 18th hole. King said she did not feel like she had played particularly well and was happy to have the lead after two rounds of the 54-hole tournament. The first-day co-leader, Colleen Walker, missed an 18-inch putt for birdie on the first hole and went on to take bogeys on the third, fourth, fifth, sixth and ninth holes. She shot even par on the back nine to fall to one over for the tournament, four shots off the pace. The other first-day leader, Susan Sanders, was four-over for the day and alone at even par 144 for the tournament. Hammell, who started the day at two under, took the lead briefly on the back nine when she birdied 11, took a par on 12, and sank three consecutive long putts, including a 40-footer on 15, to move to five under headed to the 16th tee. But Hammell, looking for her second title in her fourth year on the tour, bogeyed 16 and took the double-bogey on 18 to slip back to two under. Farwig, looking for her first victory, said her chipping and putting kept her in the tournament. With all her miscues, she said she was surprised to find herself near the top at the 14th hole.(AP) Player Wins by Two: Gary Player, tied for the lead with Dave Hill going into the par-five 17th hole yesterday, knew he would have make something happen if he was going to win the inaugural GTE North Senior Classic in Indianapolis. Player's second shot, which he estimated went almost 230 yards, rolled to within two feet of the hole. When he tapped in for an eagle 3, Player held a two-stroke lead going into the final hole, which he held for the victory in the $350,000 tournament with a 54-hole total of 201, 15 strokes under par. Hill, with a seven-under-par 65 for the final round, finished two strokes back at 203. Player's victory was his fifth on the senior circuit this season. (AP) Course Record for Green: Ken Green shot a course-record 11-under-par 61 to take a two-stroke lead after three rounds of the $700,000 Greater Milwaukee Open tournament in Franklin, Wis. It was the best 18-hole score in a PGA Tour event since David Edwards shot a 61 in last year's Bob Hope Classic. Green, winner of the Canadian Open in a playoff last Monday, birdied eight holes and eagled two to break the previous record of 62 at the 7,030-yard Tuckaway Country Club course. Green's total was 16-under 200 going into today's final round for the $126,000 first prize. Dave Barr, co-leader with Jim Gallagher Jr. at 10-under starting yesterday's round, was at 14-under 202 after shooting a 68. Next at 205 were Donnie Hammond, who had a 68, and Billy Andrade, who shot a 67.(AP) Dog Show Great Pyrenees Is Best: A Great Pyrenees, Ch. Rivergroves Run for the Roses, owned by Jean Boyd and Judith Cooper, was judged best in a field of 2,378 at the 54th Somerset Hills Kennel Club show yesterday on the County Fair Grounds at North Branch, N.J. The big white 126-pounder celebrated his fifth birthday by gaining his 23d top award. The final was exceptionally strong, with all the dogs except one previous best-in-show winners and with a total of 91 awards among them. Soccer Seton Hall Wins in Overtime: Manfred Schellscheidt's debut yesterday as the head coach of Seton Hall was successful in Durham, N.C., where the Pirates defeated North Carolina State, 5-3, in overtime in the opening round of the Metropolitan Life Soccer Classic at Duke. Ian Hennessy, the leading scorer for Seton Hall, last season's Big East champion, scored the tie-breaking goal on a short header 13 minutes 2 seconds into overtime. Peter Matischak, a senior forward, added his second goal of the game five and a half minutes later. John Murphy, a Seton Hall junior midfielder, was ejected in the first half and the Pirates played the last 94 minutes a man short. In today's final, Seton Hall will play Duke, a 2-0 winner from Southern Connecticut.

title: Ibram Lassaw: The Sculptor as Explorer
description: The 60-year survey of the sculpture of Ibram Lassaw currently on view at the Guild Hall Museum sums up a body of work that will never rank very high in the annals of 20th-century art history. At the same time, this show, which is titled ''Ibram Lassaw: Space Explorations,'' presents a long, dedicated career worthy of attention. Mr. Lassaw's work provides an unusually useful lens through which to examine the history of post-World War II American sculpture, and especially the dilemma of Abstract Expressionist sculpture, and the more subtle issue of the difference between potential and breakthrough, prescience and achievement.

title: Emily Ann Egan Wed To Douglas P. Thomas
description: Emily Ann Egan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Egan of Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday to Douglas Pierce Thomas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Thomas of Old Greenwich, Conn. Msgr. Donald W. Kraus performed the ceremony at St. Scholastica Roman Catholic Church.

title: A Chip Off Old Rodgers Block
description: The play seemed hauntingly familiar.

title: Decision on Boyd
description: The Boston pitcher has been responding well to medication, but after suffering two blood clots within five weeks, Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd has been told not to return to the mound this season, even if the Red Sox make the playoffs and the World Series.

title: TENNIS COMPETITORS PROS IN NAME, FACT
description: THERE will be no mistaking who they are and how they came to afford fancy cars and all the modern conveniences. There is no need to hide their net worth in a trust fund. The tennis players who are coming to Seoul, South Korea, are professionals by any definition the International Olympic Committee chooses to use. They are among the rich and famous in the athletic world.

title: Village Awaits Report on Ethics
description: LEAD: THE Port Chester Board of Ethics has completed its investigation of charges that six village officials, including the Mayor and the Village Manager, received favored treatment when buying condominiums last year.

title: A Rematch For Lendl, Wilander In Final
description: Ivan Lendl, who for three years has kept a dual grip on the United States Open and the top ranking in the world, fended off a lopsided attack yesterday from the tournament's most fashionable challenger, Andre Agassi, and advanced to the men's final today.

title: G.O.P. Official Made a Census of Jews at Agency
description: A Republican official selected by Vice President Bush to be deputy of the Republican National Committee said today that in 1971 at the direction of President Nixon he had conducted a census of the political affiliation of senior officials at the Bureau of Labor Statistics and whether they were Jewish.

title: Question Of the Week; What Do You Expect To See in the Olympics?
description: Half-sport, half-politics and half-parties. TONY BALIS Boston

title: NBC TRIES TOPUTITS OWN STAMP ON OLYMPICS
description: OLYMPICS on television? Isn't that what ABC does? ABC - that's the network of Roone and Howad, the network that invented ''Up Close and Personal.''

title: ESCAPE WAS THEIR PASTIME
description: STALAG LUFT III The Secret Story. By Arthur A. Durand. Illustrated. 412 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. $29.95.

title: Cabaret Nights at Carnegie
description: The singer Adelaide Hall will open a four-night cabaret series at Weill Recital Hall on Oct. 12 at 8 P.M. Karen Mason will appear on Oct. 13; Steve Ross will offer songs by Coward and Porter on Oct. 14, and Andrea Marcovicci will sing love songs from the theater on Oct. 15. Tickets -which go on sale at the box office on Wednesday - are $15, or $52 for all four nights. Information: 247-7800.

title: DATABANK: September 11, 1988
Faked Russian Maps Gave the Germans Fits
description: To the Editor:

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Team Handball
description: It's not like one-wall handball in a Brooklyn playground or four-wall handball in an exclusive Manhattan club. The Olympic sport of handball, also known as team handball, is an indoor sport in which the idea is to throw a ball into a net. It has been called hockey without ice or sticks, water polo without water, indoor soccer without kicking. It is a quick-passing game, and easy to understand. It is popular in Europe, and the best players come from eastern Europe. Though the game seems to be built for Americans, few Americans have ever heard of it.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Cycling
description: The 1984 American harvest of nine gold medals, and Greg LeMond's 1986 victory in the Tour de France, have stimulated cycling interest in the United States, among participants and spectators. But this time, the Soviet Union, East German and other Eastern bloc riders will be competing. And LeMond and other male professionals are not eligible for the Olympics. No such distinction is made for women, and so Jeannie Longo of France, the Wayne Gretzky of women's cycling, will compete in the Games, as a heavy favorite.

title: As Dollar Falls, Markets Rise in the East
description: TWO years ago, Curtis Instruments in Mount Kisco began shipping its electronic instruments for forklift trucks to a Japanese customer.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a ceramic tile floor in our bathroom consisting of one-inch square tiles. The floor is even and in good condition, but it is not attractive, and so we would like to put down new ceramic tile. Can we put new tile on top of the existing tile, or must we rip up all the old tile first?

title: A Moble Store for the Elderly
description: LEAD: KARIN BENEDICT of Bethel has taken her business on the road, bringing her traveling store to residents of homes for the elderly throughout Connecticut.

title: The Moscow Circus: Vaudeville That Delivers a Nationalistic Message
description: When the Moscow-circus comes to the Radio City Music Hall Thursday - the first circus ever to do so - horses and bears will thump about on the landmark stage and spangled humans will soar past the Art Deco proscenium into the immensity above the seats. There is nothing incongruous about this: After all, the Music Hall was originally designed for vaudeville.

title: A Sister's Need
description: A COUPLE OF YEARS ago, on a slow afternoon at the magazine where I work, I was chatting with some of the other editors.

title: UPDATED CLASSICS
description: It's puzzling, but as fashion becomes quieter, classic accessories are acquiring a lively, youthful blast of style. Even the ladylike pearls, handbags and jewelry that are the essence of Chanel, Hermes and Tiffany are getting a spin.

title: Sculptor Pursues Two Passions: Art and Psychology
description: RICHARD SALEWS arose early one recent morning and drove from his home in Niantic to a Providence, R.I., plumbing supply store to spy on the owner. Mr. Salews is a sculptor, and he was on the trail of a possible subject.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Boxing
description: At the United States Olympic trials in July, Ed Hopson, a featherweight (125-pound limit) who had endeared himself to the crowds with his perpetual-motion aggression, earned a berth in the Olympic boxoffs the following week. There, he had to win only once against Kelcie Banks, a boxer in the classic style, to make the Olympic team, but on successive days Hopson lost decisions and his spot on the team.

title: Audrey Mathias to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Michael D. Mathias of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Audrey Elise Mathias to Steven Wayne Winter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Winter of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. Miss Mathias, an accountant at Stephen I. Soble & Company, certified public accountants in New York, graduated from Syracuse University. Her fiance, a graduate of Dartmouth College, is a fourth-year student at New York Medical College.

title: Sports of The Times; A Champion For All Seasons
description: She began it in the blazing sunlight of Melbourne in January and continued it in the swirling red dust of Paris in springtime and extended it again in the sweet early summer of Wimbledon.

title: Megan Conklin Wed To Stephen Roschen
description: Megan Allison Conklin, a daughter of Ferris Richardson Conklin of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Elizabeth Susan Conklin, was married yesterday to Stephen Andrew Roschen, a son of Susan Brown Roschen of New York and William Edward Roschen Jr. of North Salem, N.Y. The Rev. William Lyons performed the ceremony at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Winthrop, Mass.

title: A Place that Works at Finding Out Who's Where
description: EVER wonder what the average sale price of a house in New Canaan is? Or how many Asian auto body repairmen there are in Litchfield County? Or what the dollar value is of groceries sold in Hartford?

title: Question Of the Week; What Do You Expect To See in the Olympics?
description: I expect the Olympics to follow the pattern of the past - the usual bad feelings whenever there is physical contact and in all other competition, with suspicion of drug abuse, the prejudiced and incompetent - irrational official and judges decisions - the usual foul claims and disagreements and objections by biased coaches.

title: Ashley King and Preston L. Goddard Are Married
description: St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Ashley Windisch King, a daughter of Charles Hilary King Jr. of Wilton, Conn., and Mrs. Howard Earle Coffin Hall of Greenwich, to Preston Lane Goddard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanhope Scott Goddard Jr. of Greenwich.

title:
IN THE NEW YORK REGION: Long Island;
Restoring Marshes as Quid Pro Quos for Approvals
description: LEAD: THREE barren peninsulas created in the 1950s when canals were cut into a Great South Bay tidal marsh in Oakdale for a development that never took place are now to be the site of a project that will attempt, in a first for Long Island, to repair some of the ecological damage done to the marsh.

title: Moscow Digs Up Its Past And Then Covers It Over
description: A chapter of Russian history was covered up this week, as Soviet officials decided that discoveries of the past had to yield to needs of the present.

title: Arithmetic Lesson
description: To The Editor:

title: Folk-rock, pop-soul and the prince of funk
description: As pop music moves back indoors, arenas in the New York area are offering an unusually inviting array of pop, rock and soul talent. From the freewheeling West Coast folk-rock of the Grateful Dead (beginning Friday) to the glitzy merry-go-round pop of Elton John, due Oct. 17, Madison Square Garden will be a busy musical hub.

title: Hispanic F.B.I. Agents' Suit Reflects a Sense of Betrayal
description: Whatever the outcome of their historic discrimination trial, whatever the judge's final ruling later this month, Hispanic agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation say they know that bigotry has made them second-class citizens in an agency responsible for enforcing the nation's civil rights laws.

title: IN THE WORKS
description: LOUISE BOURGOIS

title: Worldwide Guide to Vacation Home Rentals
description: RENTING a home - an English cottage, Caribbean villa or Parisian apartment - can offer vacationers privacy, flexibility and sometimes even economy. On the other hand, you may or may not have someone coming in to make the bed every day; room service as such is rarely available, and there's no tour desk to arrange your sightseeing.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Track and Field
description: More gold medals, 42, will be awarded in the Olympic track and field meet than in any other sport in the Games. If events of the last 18 months are any indication, many of them will go to new world record-holders.

title: Ruth Sharp Wed To Robert Keilty, Insurance Broker
description: Ruth Sloane Sharp, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Sharp of Katonah, N.Y., and Robert Allan Keilty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Bruce Keilty of Toronto, were married yesterday at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. John Smith, the chaplain of the Groton School, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Dr. William E. Foley, rector of St. Matthew's.

title: A Low-Tech Tool
description: To the Editor:

title: Frankfurt and Tokyo Take Control
description: THE United States has lost control of its financial markets to foreigners and has run out of easy policy options to regain it. The American financial tune is no longer being called in New York, but rather in Tokyo, London and Frankfurt. In fact, this loss of control had a lot to do with the timing of the stock market crash last fall. Foreigners lost confidence in American economic policy and started the selloff. American investors, well aware that foreigners held all the important cards, panicked and joined the rush to sell stocks.

title: New Era in Burma
description: 'There is wall-to-wall support for the establishment of genuine multiparty democracy in Burma. The Government there has completely unraveled. We are at the dawn of a new era, and it is very much in the interest of the United States to make it as clear as possible, as quickly as possible, that we are strongly on the side of democracy rather than dictatorship in Burma.' - Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, after a visit to Burma last weekend.

title: Lessons in perspective, partly in Italian
description: The 1988-89 art season has a rare urgency. There are shows that we need to see, on contemporary artists we can't stop talking about. And there are shows that provide a historical perspective in an unusually provocative way, by charting one of the most irresistible of all national artistic traditions.

title: Review/Music; Eclectix Performs New Works
description: With two brief exceptions, Friday's program by Eclectix at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church offered music about other music. In keeping with its title, this new-composers group takes its styles where it finds them, but it does seem to be looking in a few specific places. Thus most of this repertory grew out of a tonal, melody-accompaniment tradition, and a lot of it by way of American popular culture.

title: ploring What It Means to Be Canadian
description: Earlier this summer when the Edmonton Oilers sold Wayne Gretzky, the hockey virtuoso who is also probably the world's best-known Canadian, to the Los Angeles Kings, many, perhaps most, of his countrymen were hurt and some truly mourned. His departure injured the nation's self-esteem and aroused thoughts of apostasy and betrayal.

title: Shubert Role Expands with Opera
description: WE call it the Shubert, but the theater in New Haven is actually the Shubert Performing Arts Center and it presents its own ballet and theater seasons. Now, it has added opera.

title: Irked by Delays, Commuter Fights Back
description: MARTIN P. HACKER says he has always considered himself a private man of simple tastes, never one to mix in politics, certainly not somebody who would single-handedly do battle with a giant commuter railroad authority.

title: Holy Cross's Streak Ended by Army
description: Army's defense applied sufficient pressure and its attack performed with remarkable precision in the Cadets' opening game today despite the presence of only two starters returning from last year's offense.

title: SONGS OF THE EARTH AND THE SEA
description: THE LOST SALT GIFT OF BLOOD New & Selected Stories. By Alistair MacLeod. 227 pp. New York: Ontario Review Press/George Braziller. Paper, $10.95.

title: A Big Battle Over Computer Buses
description: THE attention of the computer industry is soon to be riveted once again on the Byzantine inner roads of the PC, specifically the internal data path known as the bus. The mind-numbing technical debate over a bus standard warrants study, because it could affect corporate computer buying decisions into the 1990's.

title: A Canadian Park Far From the Crowds
description: DESPITE its proximity to the populous shores of Puget Sound and the Strait of Georgia, the ragged western edge of Canada's Vancouver Island has long been an obscure outback, an almost roadless realm of fjord-dwelling loggers and salmon fishermen. But the obscurity is no longer deserved. During the last decade and a half, an 80-mile sliver of this once daunting hinterland has been transformed into Pacific Rim National Park.

title: New works and old masters
description: Modern dance by old and new trailblazers promises to be a highlight of this dance year. The season gets off to a formal start when the Martha Graham Dance Company opens a three-week engagement at City Center (Oct. 4-23) with a gala featuring guest artists Mikhail Baryshnikov, Maya Plisetskaya and Kathleen Turner. Nearly all the leading modern dance masters will be presenting new work this year, including Miss Graham and Erick Hawkins (Dec. 6-11), Merce Cunningham (Feb. 28-March 12) and Paul Taylor (April 11-May 7). And the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will be celebrating its 30th anniversary (Dec. 7-Jan. 1).

title: Lacey Hall Wed To John Colligan
description: At St. Denis Roman Catholic Church in Hanover, N.H., Ruth Lacey Hall, a daughter of William R. Hall of Bensalem, Pa., and Barbara Bradley Hall of Essex, Conn., was married yesterday to John Patrick Colligan, a son of Mrs. George A. Colligan of Hanover and the late Dr. Colligan. The Rev. Arthur Kelliher performed the ceremony.

title: Behind Barbed Wire
description: Last month, President Reagan signed into law a national act of contrition for a grievous lapse in this country's cherished standards of liberty almost half a century ago: The wartime incarceration of more than 100,000 Japanese-American citizens and Japanese resident aliens in concentration camps. The legislation provided for recompense of $20,000 to each surviving internee, whether citizen or alien, and, more significantly, an unprecedented apology by the United States Government. What follows is an account of how that injustice came about.

title: Witness Tells of Shotgun Carried Before Davis Raid
description: For the first time in the trial of Larry Davis, a key prosecution witness has placed a shotgun in the hands of one of the three detectives who confronted the defendant in a shootout almost two years ago, although the witness said the detective did not have the weapon during the gun battle.

title: Max Eitingon: Further Views
description: To the Editor:

title: College Given Grant For Humanities Center
description: Ursinus College, a small private liberal arts college in Collegeville, Pa., has been awarded a $5.37 million grant to build a humanities center.

title: A New Team Speeds Mamet's 'Plow'
description: From the New York Times, Aug. 8, 1988:

title: Question Of the Week; What Do You Expect To See in the Olympics?
description: Commercials. GIL EHRENKRANZ Staten Island

title: Museum Celebrating Film Opens Its Doors in Queens
description: Even the ribbon-cutting ceremony made it obvious: the debut of the American Museum of the Moving Image yesterday in Astoria, Queens, was not the usual ho-hum occasion marking the day when a cultural institution officially opens its doors.

title: Abundance of Seafood in Sayville
description: LONG ISLAND should have a multitude of restaurants like Stevie Ray's Seafood Restaurant in Sayville. This casual shopping-center spot has a selection of fish that puts some big-city seafood emporiums to shame.

title: Hidden Faces
description: To the Editor:

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Weight Lifting
description: In weight lifting, there are separate competitions in 10 body-weight classes in which competitors weight from 114 pounds to over 242 pounds. Competition in each weight class involves two kinds of lifts: one is the snatch, in which the bar is raised overhead in a single, unbroken motion; the other is the clean and jerk, in which the bar is first raised to chest level and then lifted overhead.

title: On Emergency Care For Injured Pets
description: In the article ''Emergency Pet Care'' [ Aug. 21 ] , it was stated that the County Animal Clinic provided the only 24-hour emergency care in Westchester for injured pets. This statement is far from accurate. Dr. Theodore Hoch and Dr. Arnold Remson provide 24-hour emergency service at the Yorktown Animal Hospital, at 271 Veterans Road in Yorktown Heights. There is a licensed animal-health technician who lives at the hospital and is available to assist the veterinarians. There are other practices that cover emergency calls in the county. It would be nice to have a centrally located emergency clinic in the county so that every pet owner can be served. THEODORE HOCH, D.V.M. Yorktown Animal Hospital

title: IF YOU CAN'T WATCH THAT MUCH, DON'T MISS ...
description: AFTER the athletes march into the stadium for the opening ceremonies and the flame is lighted and anthems are played and endless speeches are delivered and the Games are declared open and the athletes march out, the real Olympics will begin.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Portland, Ore.;
A Tiny Island Thinks Big
description: LEAD: A TINY South Pacific island nation has started work on a $300 million residential subdivision in the forested hills that hug this city's downtown, breathing life into a project that has been planned for 16 years.

title: To Miter Joints, Use a Backsaw
description: FOR molding to present a neat appearance, individual pieces must be joined skillfully. The technique most often used to accomplish this is mitering (cutting the ends of pieces off at an angle and joining them by placing the angled ends together). Creating professional-looking miter joints requires practice; however, by working patiently with appropriate tools, even beginners can produce excellent miter joints after only a few tries.

title: THE FROZEN ROOM
description: I enjoyed John Stone's article ''The Frozen Room'' (Body and Mind: Aug. 7), but I strongly disagree with his statement that autopsies are less needed now that ''more accurate premortem diagnosis is possible.'' The data don't bear that out. It is only through the autopsy that we test the accuracy of our premortem diagnosis, see the additional diagnoses that we didn't think of, and maintain our humility. Above all, patients and their families need to understand that the autopsy is valuable, however painful the subject may be at the time of the death of a loved one. CLIFFORD A. HUDIS, M.D. New York, N.Y.

title: Yanks Beat Tigers For Third in a Row
description: The season has been so riddled with reverses, so twisted with turmoil that the Yankees have really learned just one lesson during it: Nothing is for certain, not leads, not rosters, not the day-to-day hierarchy in the American League East.

title: SIENESE GOLD
description: Siena sprawls across three rolling hills, a sleepy Italian city centuries past its prime. Its Gothic cathedral and medieval town hall rise over the Tuscan countryside; palaces, now museums, house the poetic late medieval paintings and sculptures that distinguish this region's culture.

title: Florida Man Faces Charges Of Fraud for a Lottery Claim
description: A janitor who contended he had won the nation's largest Lotto jackpot has been arrested and charged with two felony fraud counts, the Florida Lottery Department said.

title: Young Man With a Sax
description: AS A FOOTBALL STAR AT Palisades High School in Los Angeles, Forest Whitaker was eagerly recruited by colleges that wanted to armor their defensive lines with his 6-foot, 2-inch, 245-pound body. A gifted tenor, Mr. Whitaker also received a scholarship in music. When a Hollywood agent saw him in a professional production of ''The Beggar's Opera'' and urged him to audition for a movie, the 20-year-old college student promptly got the part. Before long, he had appeared in a number of television and movie roles (among them as Robin Williams's amiable escort and buddy in last year's ''Good Morning, Vietnam''). This year, his first leading performance, as the legendary jazz saxophonist Charlie Parker in the movie ''Bird,'' won him, at the age of 26, the best actor's award at the Cannes Film Festival. That's the way life has been so far for Mr. Whitaker, a succession of opportunities offered and seized.

title: Harvesting A Vacation On the Loir
description: MADAME'S dog has come down the dusty road and over a bed of dahlias to our Loir valley farmhouse for an early morning visit. He crushes underfoot the last of the plums that have fallen from the tree at the corner of the low stone building, and sniffs like a connoisseur at the ruby grapes hanging from vines growing characteristically around our doorways. We open the half doors and lean out into the rising morning mist to greet him, posing for a half-remembered Greuze genre painting. The stone steps are still warm from yesterday's sunshine; the tall grass in the front garden dons a thousand gemstones of dew as this day's sun breaks through.

title: POSTINGS: On a Peninsula; Thinking Big
description: When James B. Harvie laid eyes on 18 acres of Port Chester, N.Y., he saw an old incinerator, oil tanks, a garbage-truck yard and a lot of potential. He asked the village if he could buy the property for $13 million. He and his associates had three competitors, but James Harvie & Partners was chosen as developer, and they are investing $200 million in the site on Fox Island Road. The chief attraction of the blighted little peninsula in the harbor is that it faces the water and Byram Point in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Scarcity and High Cost Of Land Slow Housing
description: BUILDERS across the country contend that the scarcity and high cost of land approved by local governments for new residential construction is the chief obstacle to producing the elusive new single-family house affordable to the younger American household.

title: NONFICTION
description: RESTRUCTURING THE WORLD ECONOMY. By Joyce Kolko. (Pantheon, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $14.95.) For most economists the period from 1974 to the present is filled with inconsistencies, which Joyce Kolko does her best to explain from an orthodox Marxist perspective. Much of the world during the mid-1970's and the first half of the 1980's was in a profound state of economic, financial and even agricultural crisis, as Ms. Kolko terms it, and the third world especially was hard hit by famine and debt. This period, which came on the heels of nearly 30 years of steady global economic growth, was full of some of the strangest bedfellows any economist could imagine. Inflation, which usually accompanies overheated growth, found itself coupled with slow growth and even economic decline - the infamous ''stagflation'' of the Ford and Carter years; some third world countries saw prices for their raw materials skyrocket while they ran up astronomical levels of debt. Many such problems are with us still, but the analysis presented by Ms. Kolko (the author of ''America and the Crisis of World Capitalism'') sheds no new light on the problems or the solutions. Her book, which reads like the United Nations reports from which much of the research was derived, often simply describes the rapid changes that are under way internationally. It rehashes the failings of the world economic system but offers few practical insights into ways to correct them. Yet despite its shortcomings, this book should still be of interest simply because its Marxist point of view is so fundamentally opposed to that of Reaganomics - but so in line with the prevailing thought in much of the third world.

title: In the Heart of Literary London
description: SEEING PEOPLE YOU KNOW OVER AND over again, in different contexts, happens so much in London that it characterizes the city in an essential way. An old English woman once told me, when I asked her if there was anything in London that could be called society, ''No, and it's just as well, don't you think?'' And yet, the fact that you do meet the same people often, at concerts or plays or exhibition openings or even political demonstrations (though these last are rare now), has to mean that a form of London society does exist. Over the years, I'd met Margaret Drabble and

title: Obstacles Litter The P.L.O. Path To a Consensus
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization's tortuous quest to achieve self-determination is meeting obstacles presented not only among Palestinian groups, but also by Syria, Israel and the United States.

title: THE WORLD'S ATHLETES UNITE IN A DIVIDED LAND
description: IN the quiet of his office in Lausanne, Switzerland, not long ago, Juan Antonio Samaranch tried to remember how many countries he had visited in his tenure as president of the International Olympic Committee. The total approached the number of nations invited to the Games of the XXIV Olympiad in Seoul, South Korea, and he seemed slightly embarrassed that he had not yet reached all 167. But there was still time.

title: THE STARS IN A SUITCASE
description: THE PLACE IN FLOWERS WHERE POLLEN RESTS By Paul West. 490 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95By Thomas R. Edwards

title: DATA UPDATE: September 11, 1988
Senate Candidate Is Chosen
description: Samuel S. Beard defeated Delaware's Lieutenant Governor tonight in a Democratic primary election for the right to challenge the Republican incumbent, Senator William V. Roth Jr. Mr. Beard won 53 percent of the vote to Lieutenant Governor S.B. Woo's 47 percent. Mr. Beard runs a nonprofit company that helps attract grants and designs plans to attract economic development. Senator Roth had no opponent in the Republican primary.

title:
RECORDINGS;
Viennese Operettas Waltz Onto CD's
description: LEAD: The charms of Viennese operetta have begun to assert themselves on CD, thanks in large part to RCA's importation of disks of excerpts from 20 Eurodisc classics. Recorded in the 1960's, these versions have remained popular, and for good reason. Persuasively and idomatically sung by such favorites as Rudolf Schock and Margit Schramm, they use original or unobjectionally revised orchestrations, generally feature the Vienna or Berlin Symphony Orchestra magnetically conducted by Robert Stolz and offer material not readily available elsewhere.

title: Laura E. Petrucci Is Married to George W. Carroll
description: At the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., Laura Elizabeth Petrucci, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph V. Petrucci of Lexington, Mass., was married yesterday to George William Carroll, the son of Dr. and Mrs. George W. Carroll of La Jolla, Calif. The Rev. Preston B. Hannibal, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Carroll Gardens
description: ''THIS is a neighborhood,'' said Alexandra Corbin describing Carroll Gardens, ''where an investment banker can move in next to a plumber and a sanitation worker, and everybody becomes friends.''

title: What's a Carpetbagger?
description: Vice President Bush, who calls Texas home, continues to be hounded as a carpetbagger. Polls suggest that more than half the registered voters in Texas don't think he is a ''real Texan.'' Of course, a lot of other people don't see Mr. Bush as a Texan either, since by background he's obviously a Connecticut Yankee. But is it fair for Texans to call him a carpetbagger?

title: Generation Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Kimberley Martin Is Wed
description: Kimberley Ann Martin and Michael J. Lynch, both graduates of the Fordham University School of Law, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J., by Msgr. John Corr. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Martin of Johns Island, S.C., and Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Lynch 3d of New Vernon and Vail, Colo. The bride graduated also from New England College. Mr. Lynch, a graduate also of the University of Notre Dame, is an associate at the New York law firm of Townley & Updike.

title: Where Swiss Carvers Put Life in Wood
description: THE bucolic village of Brienz, often called the gateway to the Bernese Oberland, is also the center of Swiss woodcarving. From here come most of the country's ubiquitous souvenir bears, as well as realistic animals and figures so artfully fashioned that sculpture would be an apt description. Just up from the Hauptstrasse, which is lined with carvers' shops, lies Switzerland's only cantonal woodcarving school.

title: THE FROZEN ROOM
description: A number of recent studies confirm that autopsies still discover unexpected major findings about 10 percent of the time. The reason fewer of these examinations are done is that autopsies are not reimbursed by third-party payers. Second, in these litigious times, when any less- than-perfect result can lead to years of involvement with the medicolegal system, many doctors prefer to bury their mistakes, and who can blame them? DAVID SHNEIDMAN, M.D. Midland, Tex.

title: View of Future in a 20-Room Museum
description: So here I am, one block and maybe a couple of light years away from the apartment where I grew up. The neighborhood was terrible then, but it has been broomed and polished. It has been reclaimed and the floor of this Victorian mansion gleams.

title:
MUSIC;
Rasputin Rises, to Die Again
description: LEAD: It is the first day of staging rehearsals for Jay Reise's new opera ''Rasputin.'' In a New York City Opera basement rehearsal room, Frank Corsaro, the director, finishes blocking the first orgy scene (there are two), minus the chorus and supers who will supply writhing, naked flesh and simulated copulation.

title: Seeking a Job In a Labor Shortage
description: I read the Aug. 14 article ''Labor Shortage Challenges Employers,'' and I for one find it hard to believe there is a labor shortage.

title: Flunking the Motor Vehicle Test
description: Q. WHAT is the rule of thumb for safe following distance on dry pavement? (On the way over here, on Route 4 in Teaneck, the traffic's moving along at 50. You can't leave more than 15 feet between you and the guy ahead before someone cuts in. It's worse up in Paramus.) It's a Friday afternoon in the summer. I've moved back to New Jersey from Connecticut, and need to face up to the ordeal of going to the Motor Vehicle Department.

title: D. G. Houck Weds Miss Hutchinson
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Chatham, N.J., Carolyn Adele Hutchinson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Percy Hutchinson Jr. of Chatham Township, N.J., and Jupiter, Fla., was married yesterday to David Gerald Houck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald W. Houck Jr. of Rockville, Md. The Rev. John H. Branson performed the ceremony.

title: Upgrading of Creeks Planned
description: LEAD: MEADOWBROOK CREEK was once a vital part of the South Shore's wetlands.

title: Free at Last - To Spend More Money
description: BABY boomers have had their day. Now, it is the turn of the ''empty nesters,'' people generally over the age of 50 who find themselves with more money and more time to spend it. Freed from the burdens of raising children, paying college tuition and making mortgage payments, empty nesters have become good business. Whether it is banks or bookstores, businesses are scrambling to reap the fruits of the empty nesters' new-found prosperity and tap their growing ranks.

title: Movies, sports and familiar faces
description: The schedules for the 1988-89 television season announced by the major networks last spring had a heavy dose of the familiar. Television stars like Dick Van Dyke and Mary Tyler Moore, each long since removed from the domestic bliss that they shared as Rob and Laura Petrie from 1961 through 1966, would be returning to CBS; the recent hit films ''Baby Boom''(NBC) and ''Dirty Dancing'' (CBS) would be turned into weekly series, while old weekly series such as ''Get Smart'' (ABC), ''Mission: Impossible'' (ABC) and ''Marcus Welby, M.D.'' (NBC) would be transformed into TV movies. The media would be the focus of four new shows: ''Murphy Brown'' and ''TV 101'' on CBS, ''Midnight Caller'' on NBC and ''A Fine Romance'' on ABC. And, finally, there would be a new Sunday-night Disney show and ''Roots Christmas'' (ABC).

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Modern Pentathalon
description: Baron Pierre de Coubertin, the French nobleman who founded the modern Olympics in 1896, designed the modern pentathlon to give soldiers something better to do than wage war. It didn't work. The sport made its debut at the Stockholm Olympics in 1912, two years before the outbreak of World War I. The competition features five events in five days. On Day 1, competitors ride horses drawn by lot over a 15-obstacle jumping course within 1 minute 43 seconds. Riders start with 1,100 points and lose 30 for each knockdown, 40 for each refusal and a time penalty of 2 points per second.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: POLITICAL THRILLER The first public reading of a new play called ''When the Deal Goes Down'' will be given at 8 P.M. Saturday in the Schoolhouse Theater on Owens Road in Croton Falls. Set in a mountain cabin in an unidentified Latin American country, the four-character work is described as a political thriller involving an American film maker and his idol - a childhood friend who is now a controversial revolutionary leader and the subject of a documentary that the film maker is shooting.

title: Hans K. Maeder, Stockbridge Founder, Dies at 78
description: Hans K. Maeder, a maverick in secondary education who briefly headed the Walden School in New York City before founding his own preparatory school in the Berkshire Hills, died of prostate cancer Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78 years old.

title:
FILM: LIVING THE PART;
Young Woman With a Gun
description: LEAD: SLIDING UP THE RED-carpeted stairs of the Palais du Festival in Cannes last spring, while a band played and guards held back surging crowds, Natasha Richardson unashamedly savored her moment of fan-magazine glamour. Then, after her film had been screened, the 25-year-old actress stood in astonished silence as her director told a reporter that he felt the same ambivalence about the subject of the movie now as he had before he made it.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a ceramic tile floor in our bathroom consisting of one-inch square tiles. The floor is even and in good condition, but it is not attractive, and so we would like to put down new ceramic tile. Can we put new tile on top of the existing tile, or must we rip up all the old tile first?

title: Southern Cal Tops Stanford
description: Rodney Peete threw 10 yards for a touchdown to the flanker John Jackson with 1 minute 19 seconds remaining as Southern Cal rallied for a 24-20 victory over Stanford in a Pacific-10 Conference game today.

title: 'Angel Fire'
description: To the Editor:

title: Pressed at Home, British Unions Are Looking to Europe for Gains
description: The battle lines have shifted in Britain's long internal struggle over its membership in the European Community.

title: Eight Clubs Submit Bids for '91 Sailoff
description: A fresh breeze swept through the America's Cup arena today. With it came hopes for a multinational challenge in 1991 that might erase the bitterness of this year's campaign.

title: The Legacy of a Museum Designer
description: LEAD: WHEN Ethel Scofield of Pound Ridge thinks of Lino S. Lipinsky de Orlov, she sometimes recalls how ''he was such a gentleman'' that he could make a quick supper of sandwiches, grabbed in the rush of setting up that town's museum five years ago, ''seem like a fine European dinner.''

title: WARMING UP TO THE FRIDGE
description: THE PSYCHOLOGY OF EVERYDAY THINGS By Donald A. Norman. Illustrated. 257 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: More on the Olympics
description: A special Olympic preview appears in today's Times. For profiles, sport-by-sport analyses and the complete schedule of events see section 8A.

title: Kate T. Wilkins Is Married to Peter C. McManus
description: Kate Taylor Wilkins, the daughter of Justice and Mrs. Herbert P. Wilkins of Concord and Annisquam, Mass., was married yesterday to Peter Charles McManus, a son of Jay R. McManus of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Frances G. McManus of Hartsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Fayette Severance performed the nondenominational service at the Annisquam Village Church.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Table Tennis
description: Table tennis, the newest Olympic sport, is hardly an obscure game. Ping-Pong, as it is generally called in the United States, is believed to be the second most popular participation sport in the world after soccer, and even in the United States it is the most popular racquet sport, with an estimated 20 million players.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: KHUBILAI KHAN: His Life and Times. By Morris Rossabi. (University of California, $25.) ''Eurasian history begins with the Mongols,'' Morris Rossabi writes in this book, which details the dozens of territorial battles and tactical alliances leading to Mongolian dominance of the two continents in the 13th century.

title: In the Politicians' War on Drugs, The Rhetorical Guns Are Blazing
description: ABOUT three-fourths of the members of the House of Representatives showed last week that when it comes to the issue of illegal drugs they want no enemies to the right of them.

title: Hungary Tries Letting Its Unions Be Unions
description: Three times since the last week in August, the Hungarian press has carried unusual reports of brief strikes in a coal mine, a printing plant and an optical factory. Even more surprisingly, the articles have indicated that the outcomes have favored the strikers.

title: Pepper Johnson Relishing Role as Giants' New Big Play Man
description: Pepper Johnson returned to his New Jersey home late last Monday night and discovered that his telephone answering service had been bombarded with messages.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Marking St. Agnes's
description: LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor will celebrate mass at St. Agnes' Hospital in White Plains Wednesday evening, bless the hospital's new Breast Imaging Center, where mammograms are done, and greet 1,500 invited guests on the receiving line. The occasion: St. Agnes's 80th anniversary.

title: The Joys and Hassles Of Remodeling a Home
description: SOONER or later it seems to happen to most middle-class house owners. The kitchen looks dingy and old-fashioned, the house gets smaller as the kids get bigger, and anyway, a lot of the neighbors seem to be adding new familiy rooms off the living room, sun rooms off the master bedroom and decks off the dining room.

title: Milestone Near for Coach
description: Howard University doesn't even have to match its 9-1 won-lost record of last year for Coach Willie Jeffries to join the ranks of college football coaches with 100 victories this season.

title: Drawings: Reflection of 40's and '50's
description: LEAD: IDEAS have evolved so rapidly in art that Abstract Expressionism, once the cutting edge, is now regarded with the respect and reverent scrutiny accorded historical achievement.

title: Many Need 2 Jobs for One Life's Bills
description: FOR many jobholders, for many reasons, one is not enough. A schoolteacher by day becomes a theater usher by night. A secretary from 8:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. becomes a nurse's aide from 6 P.M. to midnight. A full-time firefighter is also a part-time coffee grinder. And the list goes on. There are thousands of Connecticut residents who moonlight - work a part-time job in addition to a full-time job - in order to make ends meet or maintain their styles of life. Many have second jobs at restaurants, bars, hospitals and malls.

title: Hurricane Lands Gently in Louisiana
description: ''All we lost was a good night's sleep,'' Wade Guice, the Harrison County civil defense director, said this morning of Hurricane Florence, hours after the storm made a quiet landfall.

title: Pledge Dispute Evokes Bitter Memories
description: When Marie Snodgrass and Gatha Edmonds think of the Pledge of Allegiance, what comes to mind is neither a patriotic ritual nor the 1988 Presidential campaign. Instead, it conjures up indelible childhood memories of traumatic times that helped shape American constitutional law.

title: A Sephardic Temple Greets the New Year
description: LEAD: AS the sun sets today Hebrew prayers will float up, as they will from Jewish lips everywhere, at a small temple on the border of New Rochelle and Scarsdale. The sounds will be mirthful and lyrical. They will be filled with piety. To a Jew unaccustomed to hearing them, they will also be mysterious and alluring.

title: DISPATCHES FROM APHRODITE'S WAR
description: BORROWED TIME An AIDS Memoir. By Paul Monette. 342 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $18.95.MORTAL EMBRACE Living With AIDS. By Emmanuel Dreuilhe. Translated by Linda Coverdale. 162 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $15.95.

title: STRENGTH IN NUMBERS
description: The old adage that there is saftey in numbers prompted several of Paris's most prestigious antiques dealers to found the Antiquaires a Paris two decades ago. It was Didier Aaron who initially conceived of the idea of joining forces with his colleagues, all dealers who specialize in French antiques, to both promote and protect their profession. Every few years they elect a new president, and, thoughthe players have changed over the years, today the group consists of many of the best-known names in the business: Aaron, Jacques Perrin, Jean-Marie Rossi, Michel Meyer, Maurice Segoura and Bernard Steinitz. Each operates a prestigious gallery, and some, like Steinitz and Aaron, also have shops in London and New York. ''We've been friends for 30 years,'' says Michel Meyer. ''We're like a syndicate, a gang.''

title: Why Owning a Home Is the American Dream
description: WHEN it comes to owning a home, few people in the world pursue the dream with as much vigor, desire or penny-pinching thrift as Americans.

title: Ms. Mitchell Has Wedding
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Beatrice Hunnewell Mitchell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Lindsay Mitchell of New York, was married yesterday to Paul Scott Sperry, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Sperry of Newtown Square, Pa. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Basketball
description: On defense, they will swarm like bees, pestering opponents in what could be called the attack of the Killer D. On offense, the United States men's Olympic basketball team will run, run and run some more, a frenetic pace designed to compensate for a lack of size and overall talent.

title: Coaxing Older Customers to Deposit Their Cash
description: TEN years ago, executives at Central Fidelity Bank of Richmond, Va. began looking for ways to attract customers. Someone suggested a program of special benefits and services for the elderly. It was a novel idea.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Wrestling
description: There are two kinds of wrestling in the Olympics, Greco-Roman and freestyle, neither of which bears a significant resemblance to the Hulk Hogan variety of choreographed mayhem known as professional wrestling.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: The New Season/Magazine/Part 2 Previews for theater, dance, film, art, music, television and photography. Jerome Robbins returns to Broadway. Siena's golden age at the Met. Gilgamesh comes to BAM. Residential Property/Section 13 The American home nurtures fortunes and families. Joys and hassles of remodeling. Caution in New York City. Apartments by Candela. Olympics Preview/Section 8A A record 161 nations compete in Seoul. Dave Anderson on security. Most anticipated event: Lewis vs. Johnson in the 100 meters. What to watch if you can only watch a little.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Swimming
description: Track and field may have Carl Lewis, Florence Griffith Joyner and Edwin Moses and all those other glamorous athletes. Gymnastics may have all those doll-like successors to Olga and Nadia and Mary Lou. But if you like to see Americans win Olympic medals, swimming will be the sport to watch in Seoul.

title: Bronx Program Creates Teacher From Illiterate
description: Carmen Malpica remembers Jan. 5, 1986, very well. That was the day, as an illiterate, unemployed, single 23-year-old mother of two, she walked into the offices of Bronx Educational Services, a school devoted to teaching adults how to read and write.

title: Look to Morgan For Example
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Dukakis Assails Bush on Advisers' Ties to Bahamian Leaders
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis fired back again at Vice President Bush on the patriotism issue today, citing reports that some top Bush campaign advisers had worked for the Bahamian Government and declaring, ''In a Dukakis White House, the staff will pledge allegiance to only one flag - Old Glory.''

title: CONSUMER RATES
BRAZIL IS LOOKING FOR LUCKY DAY
description: MORE than a year has passed, so Oscar Schmidt can afford to be generous about Brazil's upset victory over the United States in the men's basketball final of the 10th Pan American Games. ''They had the better team,'' he said. ''In the second half, we grabbed our chances.''

title: MILAN TONES DOWN
description: Invention has traditionally been the operative word at the Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the world's most important furniture fair, which is held in Milan each September. It is here that the latest designs from all over the world are previewed. And it is at these fairgrounds and at showrooms in the center of Milan that store buyers and design experts look for the latest trends the market has to offer. At this year's fair, which opens Wednesday and runs through Sept. 19, the usual bravado will be in evidence. But bravado of a more subtle nature. According to experts, designs will be a bit more subdued than in past seasons. ''The era of wild, grabby pie-in-the-sky furniture is over,'' says Sam Friedman, president of I.C.F. ''Now more serious designs are what will make news.''

title: Baseball Movies Turn Men to Mush
description: The less one knows about baseball - and I happen to know less than almost anybody - the more one is apt to notice in movies about the game. It can be wonderfully liberating to have little idea whether the rookie is really any good, whether the aging manager stands a chance of breathing new life into his career or whether the team has any hope of winning the pennant, since the attention is thus freed to concentrate on more pressing matters. The most salient of these, in almost every film about the game, is baseball's uncanny way of turning otherwise strong men into mush.

title: TED KOPPEL'S EDGE
description: Richard N. Kaplan, executive producer of ''Nightline,'' explains the reason for Ted Koppel's practice of not letting those he interviews have eye contact with him: ''To watch yourself talk out of synch is mind-boggling.''

title: Bank Board Solves A Huge Problem
description: Federal rescuers took care of their biggest ailing savings institution, committing $2 billion to a deal in which Robert M. Bass will take over the American Savings and Loan Association of California. Mr. Bass, a 40-year-old billionaire from Fort Worth, will put up $550 million to acquire American's viable parts, like $14 billion in deposits from 1 million depositors, 185 branch offices throughout California and $10 billion of good real-estate loans. About $5 billion of American's bad loans and $13 billion in mortgage-backed securities will be placed in a separate bank for liquidation. One of the deal's more controversial features establishes a merchant banking unit with a $1.5 billion line of credit that presumably will be available to help Mr. Bass with his other deals, like his current $2 billion pursuit of Macmillan Inc. For its $2 billion in assistance with the American deal, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board will get 30 percent ownership in the institution.

title: ONOFICTION
description: SOUL OF THE TIGER: Searching for Nature's Answers in Exotic Southeast Asia. By Jeffrey A. McNeely and Paul Spencer Wachtel. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The rural people of Southeast Asia believe that a close spiritual tie binds wildlife with humans. Though recognizing the many differences between humans and animals, they think they have similar and transferable souls. Most Balinese families, for example, have animal totems, which usually commemorate a deer, bear or other animal that figures in their history and might harbor the soul of a departed ancestor. Tigers, in particular, are assumed to possess the souls of those they devoured. The members of a hill tribe in Vietnam thought a tiger that killed and ate only women was inhabited by the soul of a deceived husband; as a result, marital fidelity swept through their village. In one fascinating account after another in ''Soul of the Tiger,'' Jeffrey A. McNeely, an anthropologist and zoologist, and Paul Spencer Wachtel, a journalist and psychologist, explain the folklore in which animals are an everyday part of community life as mythological symbols or ancestors incarnate, as well as being sources of meat, leather and medicine. The tales are told with humor, but without condescension. The authors, who went to Southeast Asia in the l960's as Peace Corps volunteers and remained until recently as conservationists, look with favor on the harmony of human-wildlife relations they encountered and conclude that these traditional approaches to conservation should be encouraged in a third world that seeks to balance economic growth and environmental preservation. As Mr. McNeely and Mr. Wachtel note, ''The belief in universal souls means that we are all veritable soul brothers.''

title: Old Sewage Plants Proving Ineffective
description: LEAD: A march on Town Hall in mid-summer by 200 Huntington residents to protest sewage washing up on area beaches demonstrated the anger many Long Islanders have felt during a summer in which water-pollution scares have been common.

title: New York State Cancer Project to Focus on Minority Women
description: Eight urban areas in New York will be the focus of a $1 million state program to detect and properly treat breast cancer among black and Hispanic women, the State Health Department announced today.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on page 27 in some copies of the Arts and Leisure section today about the film ''Prince of Pennsylvania'' misidentifies theaters for the opening on Friday. It will be at the 68th Street Playhouse, not neighborhood theaters.

title: RAIL LINE IS FINED OVER TOXIC WASTE
description: New York State's top environmental official fined the Metro-North Commuter Railroad $100,000 today for illegally storing toxic wastes in a pond and in leaky barrels at its maintenance yard bordering the Hudson River at Croton-on-Hudson.

title: POSTINGS: Round the Station; Just the Ticket for Commuters
description: SoNo is neither SoHo nor NoHo, the neighborhoods south and north of Houston Street in Manhattan, nor is it the invention of rampaging neighborhood-namers. SoNo is South Norwalk, a harborside district of Norwalk, Conn., that has what some see as a trackside gold mine.

title: Tamara Peress Is Wed To Bruce W. Watkins
description: Tamara Ellen Peress and Bruce Warren Watkins were married last evening at the Plaza in New York by Rabbi Stanley Davids.

title:
INVESTING;
Industrials Can Also Be Traps
description: LEAD: TROUBLED thrift institutions are not the only reorganizing companies whose shareholders may wind up with very expensive wallpaper.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE NIGHT OF THE WEEPING WOMEN. By Lawrence Naumoff. (Morgan Entrekin/Atlantic Monthly Press, $16.95.) Three families come under surgical scrutiny in this tight, intense first novel, which makes suffocation look like a lot more fun than marriage. Sally and Robert Zilman, the young couple at its center, have left behind the dreary neurotic constraints of their parents for an almost hippie existence in a rundown Victorian house in rural Chatham, N.C., only 20 miles from their collegiate alma mater in Chapel Hill.

title: American accents are back in style
description: The British tidal wave will subside this season. No large musicals are scheduled to sail across the Atlantic, unless one includes ''Legs Diamond,'' a multinational creation, composed by and starring Peter Allen as the title gangster. Maggie Smith is to arrive in Peter Shaffer's ''Lettice and Lovage,'' her West End comedy vehicle, with her London co-star, Margaret Tyzack. In late spring, there will be David Hare's ''Secret Rapture,'' with Blair Brown.

title: Myers's Request
