description: The United States Olympic Committee is considering the possibility of allowing Angel Myers to seek a second opinion regarding the positive drug test that caused her to be removed from the Olympic swimming team. Myers, who qualified for the team in five events, was found to have used a banned substance, believed to be steroids. She claimed the positive test resulted from her use of birth-control medication.

title: CONSULTANT AS BOSS: James B. Farley; Breaking All the Rules
description: CORPORATE chiefs often become consultants at the tail end of their careers. But a consultant becoming a corporate chief?

title: State Offers New Program On Adoption Of Blacks
description: THE State of New Jersey is starting what officials call ''a major marketing campaign'' directed at the black community to find adoptive homes for hard-to-place black children.

title: Are We Ready to Learn From the Vietnam War?; Class Privilege
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Honolulu;
Chinatown Is Blossoming
description: LEAD: CHINATOWN is experiencing a $125 million redevelopment, as the 46-block district near Honolulu Harbor celebrates the bicentennial of the arrival of the first Chinese in Hawaii.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THREE NOVELLAS: ''A Truth Lover,'' ''Pagan's Pilgrimage'' and ''Clapperton.'' By John Herdman. (Polygon Books/Dufour Editions, P.O. Box 449, Chester Springs, Pa. 19425, Paper, $8.95.) The souls of the young men in the Scottish writer John Herdman's novellas mirror the landscape of his homeland: flinty, often desolate, but marked by sudden glimpses of remarkable beauty.

title: For Two Vietnamese Refugees in the U.S., Lost Families Are Found Again
description: Nguyen Anh Tuan and Giui Thi Le could not believe their eyes, but somehow they were back in Southeast Asia.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Finance column on Aug. 21 about tax planning misstated the cutoff point for the exemption to the Alternative Minimum Tax. For a married couple filing a joint return, the exemption is reduced at the rate of 25 cents for each $1 of alternative minimum taxable income above $150,000 ($112,500 for single taxpayers). The exemption is completely lost when income reaches $310,000 for a married couple ($232,500 for single people). The column also misstated the amount of the exemption for single taxpayers. It is $30,000.

title: Too Many Unchallenged Incumbents and Full Campaign Chests
description: To the Editor:

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Volleyball
description: There is little doubt that it will require a huge upset for the United States' men's team to surrender the gold medal it won in 1984 in Los Angeles. The American men had never won a major tournament before, but since Los Angeles it has built itself into something of a dynasty, winning at the World Cup and the world championships and the gold medal at the Pan American Games last summer.

title:
MUSIC;
Shhh! Don't Call His Music 'New Age'
description: LEAD: WILLIAM ACKERMAN, the guitarist generally credited with starting the trend now known as New Age music, deplores the term. ''Now that the major labels are in,'' he said, ''I think it's predetermined that New Age will be a more or less dead issue fairly soon.''

title: Whither Oil Prices?
description: Since the cease-fire between Iran and Iraq, world oil prices have softened, as oil production has risen. In spite of growing overcapacity, a number of OPEC members are pressing for larger production quotas. Some analysts think this will drive prices down sharply, while others believe OPEC will reassert discipline among members at the November meeting. Which way will oil prices go? Lodwrick Cook Chairman and chief executive, the Atlantic Richfield Company.

title: ABOUT MAGGIE, WHO TRIED TOO HARD
description: BREATHING LESSONS By Anne Tyler 327 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: FRINGE FEVER
description: For popular music, this season brings a paradox. Six giant conglomerates have their strongest hold ever on the $5 billion record business, yet those companies are searching frantically outside their own confines for music that draws loyal listeners. They're still grinding out intensively marketed Top 40 fodder, such as forthcoming albums by Tiffany, Bon Jovi, Duran Duran and Patti LaBelle. And there's no shortage of arena-scale acts. But high-profile, down-the-middle, would-be blockbuster pop and rock are by no means the only game in town. As the mainstream splits up, some pop observers see the end of a community and an era; others see opportunities and new musical possibilities in diversity.

title: Plan Stirs Secrecy Debate
description: LEAD: A LAW that would restrict the public from reviewing plans for land containing endangered species or archeological remains has divided members of the Southampton Town Board and drawn criticism from environmentalists and local news organizations.

title: When North Looks Better Than South
description: IF a partnership is unbalanced, with one player clearly a better cardplayer, there is a tendency to maneuver the bidding so that he, or she, can be the declarer. Provided this is not carried too far, the better player will play more than his share with a profitable effect on the score.

title: Living the Life Of a Bostonian On Beacon Hill
description: HENRY JAMES called it the most proper street in Boston, and it rises straight as an ascendant arrow in eastward flight from Storrow Drive and the river embankment. It crosses Charles Street (once a shoreline of the Charles River estuary before history and real estate ambition and landfill turned it into the boundary between Beacon Hill and the Back Bay) and here Mount Vernon Street is deflected ever so slightly toward the southeast. Then it soars on again steeply upward to the archway at the rear of the gold-domed State House on the very crest of Beacon Hill.

title: Rehnquist's Court: Tuning Out the White House
description: CHIEF JUSTICE WILLIAM HUBBS REHNQUIST stared stonily out at the crowd in the marble-columned chamber from the Supreme Court's center chair, the chair in which Ronald Reagan had put him two years before. It was June 29, the last day of the Court's 1987-88 term, and one decision remained to be handed down - the big one.

title: Headliners; A Complaint
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission let the other shoe drop with a vengeance last week on Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Michael Milken, the head of its junk bond department. After a two-year investigation, both Mr. Milken and the firm, one of the fastest growing investment houses on Wall Street, were named in a 184-page civil complaint. It is widely regarded as preview to Federal criminal charges. The S.E.C. allegations included defrauding clients, insider trading, manipulation of the price of stocks and violations of a number of other regulations; in 16 of the 18 situations described, Ivan F. Boesky, the now jailed former arbitrager, is said to have been the crucial witness. Mr. Milken, a driven 42-year-old whose 18-hour days are estimated to have made him a fortune of $500 million, issued a statement predicting full vindication, and so did the firm.

title: Car Rental
description: To the Editor: We recently returned from a trip to California and Yosemite National Park. We had rented a car from General Rent-a-Car in San Francisco and drove to Yosemite. Upon entering the park, the car began to stall when we slowed down. I was able to reach the valley where there are two garages. The mechanics on duty at each wanted $60 just to look at the car.

title: Top Looks
description: ON ground maneuvers all over town this fall, children will be wearing classic bomber jackets. Today's back-to-school bombardiers are snapping up the styles based on the ''Top Gun'' adult looks of last fall, department-store executives say.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: When Minutes Matter; How a Soviet Capsule Became Stuck in Space
description: A Soviet and an Afghan astronaut were stranded in space last week when a malfunctioning navigation system interfered with the split-second calculations required for a successful landing. On the third attempt, the Soyuz TM-5 capsule touched down safely in the Soviet Republic of Kazakhstan, leaving Soviet and American scientists to reconstruct the sequence of errors that led to a harrowing 25 hours. Tuesday. 2:55 A.M. (Moscow time). The capsule leaves the orbiting Mir space station and heads for Earth with enough air to last for 48 hours. 3:35 A.M. As planned, the capsule jettisons the compartment containing radar, latches and other equipment necessary for redocking with Mir. Now there is no way for the capsule to return to the space station. 5:30 A.M. The astronauts try to fire the deceleration engine to slow the craft for the 40-minute maneuver that will lead to a scheduled landing at about 6:10 A.M. For the capsule to touch down in the Soviet Union, it must begin re-entry at a point over the South Atlantic.

title: Warily, Chicago Wages Store Wars
description: From the jewelry aisles of I. Magnin to the gilded elevators of Marshall Field's, the chatter along North Michigan Avenue these days has been of little else but this: The New Yorkers are coming and the name is ''Bloomingdale's.''

title: BACK TO HER AFRICA
description: HONEY FROM THE LION An African Journey. By Wendy Laura Belcher. 188 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton.

title:
GARDENING;
Manipulating Sunlight for Fall Flowers
description: LEAD: THAT sunlight is essential to the growth and development of green plants is a fact, but the quantity of sunlight required by plants varies, a factor that is confusing to many.

title: Tennessee Falls to 0-2 In Upset By Duke
description: Anthony Dilweg passed for 312 yards, including 3 touchdowns to Clarkston Hines, to lead Duke (2-0) to a 31-26 upset of Tennessee (0-2) tonight.

title: Tiny Trees Pose Big Job for Keepers
description: On a quiet wooded hilltop high above the bustle and the politicking, a handful of experts and devoted amateurs toil at an exacting task that began half a world away and many lifetimes ago - nurturing the National Bonsai Collection.

title: J. P. Prout Weds Susannah Dwight
description: The marriage of Susannah Fanshawe Dwight and James Pius Prout took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York. The Rev. Stan Moseley performed the ceremony.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 11, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 6 FALLEN HEARTS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The scandals and horrors of her past return to haunt a bride in a backwoods town. 2 9 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 3 7 HOT FLASHES, by Barbara Raskin. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) At a friend's funeral, three women who had it made in the 60's reflect on their past and future. 4 7 SPHERE, by Michael Crichton. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Four scientists explore an alien spaceship found on the floor of the South Pacific. 5 21 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 6 2 TEAM YANKEE, by Harold Coyle. (Berkley, $4.95.) The exploits of an American tank company in Europe - during World War III. 7 8 SARUM, by Edward Rutherfurd. (Ivy, $5.95.) Ten thousand years of British history, seen through the experiences of five families. 8 10 WEEP NO MORE, MY LADY, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Dell, $4.95.) Love and murder at a swank California health spa. 9 3 NEW MEXICO! by Dana Fuller Ross. (Bantam, $4.50.) The ''Wagons West'' series reaches Old Albuquerque when it is being menaced by a roving band of killers. 10 4 TRIUMPH OF THE DARKSWORD, by Margaret Weis and Tracy Hickman. (Spectra/Bantam, $3.95.) The concluding volume of ''The Darksword Trilogy,'' a fantasy saga. 11 1 THE BLACK UNICORN, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $4.95.) Ben Holiday has new encounters with the wizard Meeks in a sequel to ''Magic Kingdom for Sale - Sold!'' 12 92 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 13 38 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 14 * 1 THE SLIPPER, by Jennifer Wilde. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The glamorous successes and the disillusionments that await three young women. 15 1 FLASHBACK, by Michael Palmer. (Bantam, $4.50.) Terror stalks a New Hampshire hospital. 16 * 1 THE FIVE BELLS AND BLADEBONE, by Martha Grimes. (Dell, $4.50.) Two Scotland Yard men track down a murderer. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 6 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Dell, $4.95.) The autobiography of a former member of the British secret service. 2 13 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) How mythology illuminates life's stages, from birth to coming-of-age to marriage to aging and death. 3 16 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 4 10 SMALL SACRIFICES, by Ann Rule. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) A police-procedural account of a case involving murder and incest in an Oregon town. 5 1 IT'S ALL IN THE PLAYING, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $4.95.) Behind the scenes of the television series ''Out on a Limb.'' 6 255 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 7 1 VEIL, by Bob Woodward. (Pocket, $4.95.) The inside story of William Casey's years at the helm of the C.I.A., 1981 to 1987. 8 * 2 MAN OF THE HOUSE: The Life and Political Memoirs of Speaker Tip O'Neill, with William Novak. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) The former Speaker of the House tells his story. 9 19 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Touchstone/S&S, $7.95.) A critique of American liberal arts education during the past 25 years. 10 9 THE HERO WITH A THOUSAND FACES, by Joseph Campbell. (Princeton University, $9.95.) The human race's struggle for identity, seen through many centuries of mythology. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 7 NIGHT OF THE CRASH-TEST DUMMIES, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $5.95.) The ninth collection of ''Far Side'' cartoons. 2 25 SOMETHING UNDER THE BED IS DROOLING, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $6.95.) New ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 3 * 15 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 4 32 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1988 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. 5 63 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: The Amazon's Kettle of Fish
description: THE vast web of waterways that make up the Amazon - rivers, lakes, swamps, streams, waterfalls, bayous and igapos or flooded forest land - are, as Brazilians put it, peixoso or full of fish. Fish is the principal source of protein for Indians living in the Amazon region as well as for the caboclos, descendants of a mixed population of Europeans and Indians who farm and fish in the more populated and accessible areas near Manaus, the capital city of the state of Amazonas. An astonishing variety of fish -served grilled, fried or poached in sauces -is a staple of the city's restaurants.

title: MANY FLEE BLAZES AT YELLOWSTONE
description: Two Cabinet officials made an inspection tour of this fire ravaged area today as five communities in and around the park, including Mammoth Hot Springs, the National Park Service headquarters here, were being evacuated in the face of wind-whipped wildfires.

title: No More Bandits
description: After four decades, Taiwan has modified the practice of referring to the People's Republic of China as a ''bandit'' regime. Until August, all goods imported from the mainland had to be labeled as ''bandit goods.'' Now, according to the Free China Journal, they will be called ''products from the Chinese mainland'' or ''products from Communist China.''

title: Don't Discard Summer's Bounty Yet
description: EVEN though the orange glow of pumpkins is beginning to dot the fields around some farmstands, and baskets of crisp apples are already on sale, it's too early to discard summer's tastes. The corn, peppers, tomatoes, peaches, eggplants and plums are still abundant.

title:
GARDENING;
Manipulating Sunlight for Fall Flowers
description: LEAD: THAT sunlight is essential to the growth and development of green plants is a fact, but the quantity of sunlight required by plants varies, a factor that is confusing to many.

title: Bruins Trounce Cornhuskers
description: U.C.L.A. gave Nebraska a taste of California flash and a 41-28 trouncing before 84,086 tonight in the Rose Bowl.

title: Just Disdain For Yankees
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Correction
description: A review Aug. 14 misstated the title of an anthology edited by the reviewer. Andrei Codrescu edited ''American Poetry Since 1970: Up Late.''

title: New Rule Helps Redmen
description: College football's new rule regarding blocked conversion attempts helped convert a possible St. John's defeat into victory yesterday over Iona.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Gymnastics
description: Some of the tiniest competitors have made gymnastics one of the biggest sports of the Olympics. Olga Korbut of the Soviet Union in 1972, Nadia Comaneci of Rumnania in 1976 and Mary Lou Retton of the United States in 1984, twisted, turned and bounced their way into Olympic memories and record books. Chelle Stack of Houston could be the latest in the group: she is all of 4 feet 8 and weights less than 75 pounds.

title: Car Stereo Trolls for a Shapely Bass
description: The unconventional Lord Berners (1883-1950) - quite an accomplished English composer - had the cows on his estate painted different colors for different seasons. He also had a harpsichord built into his chauffeured Rolls-Royce, because he liked to have music on his travels. No doubt he would have delighted in a modern car stereo system bringing him highway Haydn or Monteverdi by the mile.

title: Whistle Stops On the Rails To Siberia
description: ''SAY goodbye to Moscow; you're going off to Siberia!'' It wasn't in keeping with glasnost, but with that announcement, our four-night train trip to Irkutsk began. The overtones of ''going off'' started a nervous giggle.

title: CELEBRITYHOOD IS POWERFUL
description: THE SISTERHOOD The True Story of the Women Who Changed the World. By Marcia Cohen. Illustrated. 445 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Managing the Hotel 100 Homeless Families Call Home
description: VISITORS to White Plains in the early part of this century found the Roger Smith, the city's only hotel, an elegant accommodation. The 125-room hotel, later renamed the Coachman, had its share of prominent guests and notable conventions.

title: In Computer Behavior, Elements of Chaos
description: AS computer systems continue to grow more complex, scientists are finding it increasingly difficult to accurately predict their behavior.

title: Rot at the Top
description: THERE'S AN OLD Greek saying,'' said Michael Dukakis, responding to a question about whether President Reagan and Vice President Bush could be held personally accountable for their Administration's ethical lapses, ''a fish rots from the head first. It starts at the top.'' This scrupulously bipartisan column takes no position on the accuracy of any political accusation, but is ready to examine the roots of all colorful adages used in campaigns.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: HERSELF IN LOVE: And Other Stories, by Marianne Wiggins. (Penguin, $6.95.) In this collection's title piece, a man writes to a woman he knew in the third grade, trying to figure out why there is ''a black vacuum at the center of his life.'' ''It remains one of [ Marianne ] Wiggins's most striking achievements that in making us see her characters' humanity, she also compels us to acknowledge our shared yearnings and sense of loss,'' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times last year.

title: Nicholas Nixon Seeks a Path to the Heart
description: There are two apparently polar but equally valid ways of looking at Nicholas Nixon's photographs. His images are remarkable demonstrations of how the traditional (and by now archaic) tools of the medium - a view camera, black-and-white film, contact prints - can be used to venture into uncharted artistic territory. At the same time, they concentrate on subjects - the poor, the elderly, the mortally ill - that align the work with photography's tradition of socially concerned documentation.

title: Changes Sought in Campaign Financing
description: NEW JERSEY'S public financing law for gubernatorial elections, the first in the nation, is in danger of being undermined by the rising cost of campaigning and is badly in need of an overhaul, several people who monitor the elections and distribute the money said.

title: TED KOPPEL'S EDGE
description: I was disappointed to read of the asymmetry Ted Koppel requires to conduct his interviews. But at least I was not surprised to see this entry in the Oxford English Dictionary for nightline: ''a line with baited hooks set to catch fish by night.'' PAUL ASMAN Metuchen, N.J.

title: Wagner Is Routed In Season Opener
description: Chris Warren scored touchdowns on runs of 37, 20 and 5 yards yesterday as Ferrum College routed Wagner, the defending National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III champion, 40-13, at Fischer Field on Staten Island.

title: Children Aloft
description: To the Editor: I read, with great interest, your article on children who fly alone (Practical Traveler, July 24).

title: S. D. Plofker, an Executive, Is Married to Bobbi Brown
description: Bobbi Brown, a daughter of James J. Brown of Lincolnwood, Ill., and Sandra Mann of Northbrook, Ill., was married last evening to Steven D. Plofker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton H. Plofker of Cinnaminson, N.J. Rabbi Lauren Levy officiated at the Woolverton Inn in Stockton, N.J.

title: Its Time for Us to Stop Abusing Our Environment
description: IT used to be that the weather was something to talk about casually, in passing, as a prelude to more important topics like the stock market or Presidential politics. We laughingly complained about the heat or the rain but endured them because, after all, they were natural events over which we had no control. No more. Our recent weather has not been a laughing matter. The summer of '88 will be remembered as the summer the weather, indeed, the whole environment, turned bad.

title: MUSIC: Jazz Menus: Two From Column A
description: Fortune Garden Pavilion, tucked away on 49th Street, is an anomaly of a jazz club. First, it serves Chinese food. Second, it serves good Chinese food. And third, with its glass-enclosed, airy, second-floor dining room, elegant and restrained, it's as far removed from the cliched, smoke-filled jazz dive as possible. It's a place that musicians like to play in - high praise.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: The Wannsee Conference Starring Robert Artzhorn, Friedrich Beckhaus, Jochen Busse, Hans W. Bussinger, Harald Dietl, Peter Fitz, Reinhard Glemnitz, Dieter Groest, Dietrich Mattausch, Martin Luttge, Gerd Bockmann. Directed by Heinz Schirk. 1988. Prism Entertainment. 87 minutes. $79.95. Not rated. In German with English subtitles.

title: INSIDE
description: A Shift in Zia Inquiry

title: Why Not Use Metric System
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Two Jazz Veterans Work With New Recruits
description: ''Master Mind,'' a thunderous piece by the saxophonist Greg Osby on Jack DeJohnette's newest recording, ''Audio-Visualscapes'' (Impulse!, MCA 8029, all three formats), begins and ends with an ominous, machinelike drumbeat. In between, saxophone lines, radically disfigured by electronic instruments that double and triple the sound of the instruments, riff away unmercifully. A bass joins in, and for the next eight space-age minutes, Mr. DeJohnette and his young, brash band work through an updated version of New Orleans polyphony. It's muddy, industrial jazz.

title: Trial for King Papers Ordered
description: A Superior Court judge has ordered a trial to decide whether Boston University must relinquish its collection of the papers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to his widow. The judge has also denied the university's claim to the slain civil rights leader's papers in Atlanta.

title: New York's Deer Population Outpacing Hunters
description: The deer population of New York State has risen to a record 800,000, state game officials estimated this week on the eve of the opening of a new hunting season.

title: Hut to Hut In the White Mountains
description: IN the Pinkham Notch base camp at the foot of Mount Washington, my son and I found we couldn't fit everything into our pack. What to take, what to leave out? It was a moment of reckoning. While some people on vacation would find climbing to 6,000 feet a form of masochism, to us it was a way of determining the essentials, learning to travel light.

title: Ohio St. Ends Syracuse Streak
description: John Cooper's first game as head coach at Ohio State turned out to be perfect today. Before the largest opening-game crowd in Ohio Stadium history, 89,768, the Buckeyes trounced Syracuse, 26-9, and terminated the Orangemen's unbeaten streak at 14 games.

title: Rutgers Upsets Mich. St.
description: Scott Erney passed for 239 yards and 2 touchdowns, and Doug Kokoskie made a key fumble recovery today as Rutgers stunned 15th-ranked Michigan State, 17-13, in the opener for both teams today.

title: Staci M. Berman Weds J. R. Barber
description: Staci M. Berman, a lawyer, and John Robert Barber, a corporate vice president in the syndicate department at Drexel Burnham Lambert, were married last evening at the Harvard Club in New York by Rabbi Gerald Zelizer.

title: Tamara Tunie Is Wed
description: Tamara Renee Tunie, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Tunie of Homestead, Pa., was married in Pittsburgh yesterday to Gregory T. Bouquett, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Gaston Bouquett of Dayton, Ohio. The Rev. Gerald Chapman, a Baptist minister, officiated in the Heinz Memorial Chapel at the University of Pittsburgh. Mrs. Tunie-Bouquett, who graduated from Carnegie Mellon University, is a television and stage actress. Mr. Bouquett, the owner of the Uptown Atlanta Nightclub, graduated from Wright State University.

title: IN THE NATION: Columbus, Ohio; Froth for a Reviving Downtown: Rentals and Condos in Breweries
description: OVER the last decade, residents of this growing capital city have flocked to new housing developments in its surrounding suburbs. Now, one of the largest local suburban developers has turned to the downtown area for a $70 million mixed-use project that includes the renovation of 17 former brewery buildings, the oldest dating to 1858.

title: IN THE NATION: Seattle; A New Community of 660 Homes To Sit Atop an Interstate Highway
description: SINCE Seattle already has built a park and a convention center over a freeway, it seems appropriate that the next big residential project to be developed here will be erected over eight lanes of Interstate 90.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Rowing
description: In rowing, the stereotypical coxwain is the little fellow in the back of the boat exhorting the oarsmen to row harder for God and country. ''But it's not like that at all,'' said Seth Bauer, the cox of the United States' men's eight-oared crew. ''At the Olympic level, motivation is not an issue. I have to have a feel of what's going on in the boat, to know when we're going fast and how to sustain that. I'm a coach and I correct.''

title: Discounts Galore For the 50-Plus Crowd
description: TRAVELERS over 60 years old need not pay full price - not on most airlines, nor in many large hotel chains.

title: Having Won Trust Among Conservatives, The Candidate Is Free to Test the Middle
description: Vice President Bush, once viewed as dangerously ''moderate'' by the political right, has now won substantial credibility among conservatives and thus the leeway he may need to move to the political center to win this fall's Presidential election.

title: Personal Ensign Takes Maskette
description: Two great fillies dueled through the stretch at Belmont Park yesterday, and both were winners in every respect but the parimutuel one.

title: Electrifying L.I.R.R.: Pluses and Minuses
description: MIKE PERDIE, a Long Island Rail Road commuter from Rocky Point, has been driving to Ronkonkoma to catch the train to Manhattan ever since electric service on the Main Line began there early this year.

title:
IN THE NEW YORK REGION: New Jersey;
As Job Base Grows, Morris County Offers A More Varied Menu of Housing Types
description: LEAD: THE development pressures that first visited Morris County two decades ago, starting its passage from farmland to suburbs, continue as new homes spring up in clusters within its 477 square miles.

title: ROAD TO UPHEAVAL IN POLITICS FOR BURMESE
description: Following is a chronology of events leading to the decision today by the Burma Socialist Program Party to end its 26-year monopoly on power:

title: The Real Issues
description: What are the serious problems facing this country? Put that question to Americans, whatever their party or voting inclination, and I think their answers would tend to focus on the same main points.

title: 'The Power of Envy Motivates People'
description: JEALOUSY has an underserved reputation, according to Peter Salovey, a Yale University psychology professor and researcher who has been studying the emotion for five years.

title: Statement by Solidarity Suggests Union Favors Hard Line in Talks
description: Leaders of the Solidarity trade union called today for an ''open and clear expression of the authorities' readiness to create conditions for the legal operation of Solidarity.''

title: Future Bright for Sagamore Hill
description: LEAD: NEARLY two years ahead of schedule, Sagamore Hill in Oyster Bay, the Presidential homesite, will be as brightly lit as Theodore Roosevelt's toothy grin, thanks to a private donation.

title: B. N. Pyne, Jersey Orchestra Official, And Janet Eaton Auchincloss Marry
description: At St. James's Episcopal Church in New York, Janet Eaton Auchincloss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Auchincloss of New York, was married yesterday to Benjamin Nicoll Pyne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy R. Pyne 3d of Far Hills, N.J. The Revs. Brenda Gail Husson and James Hughes Purdy performed the ceremony.

title: Alexandra Smith Wed To Lucius G. Briggs 2d
description: Alexandra Wells Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Howland Smith of Southport, Conn., was married yesterday to Lucius Goffe Briggs 2d, a son of Peter Goffe Briggs of Mystic, Conn., and Cynthia Moore Gallatly of Dallas. The Rev. Thomas Driscoll performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church in Westport, Conn.

title: Breaking Out of the Biotech Pack
description: WHEN kidney dialysis patients taking part in the clinical trials of Amgen Inc.'s erythropoietin talk about the drug's impact on their lives, they tend to use words like ''wonderful'' and ''dramatic,'' with all the restraint of a carnival barker hawking snake oil.

title: Heady Days for Junior Playwrights
description: ''The play has helped me understand who I am in relation to my mom's suicide, and how important that really was to me,'' said Jonathan Marc Sherman, an 18-year-old from Livingston, N.J. ''I've come to terms with a lot of my feelings through writing it, and I think I've realized just how much it's affected my dealings with women. You know, you can rewrite things when you're writing, but you can't when you're living, which is a shame.''

title: Supermarkets: Tales From the Underground
description: RISING rents for ground floors are forcing Manhattan supermarkets underground. Leading the way is a Gristede's that will open in December beneath the Boulevard, a 300-unit condominium that is nearing completion on Broadway at 86th Street.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE MONUMENT. By Erich Loest. Translated by Ian Mitchell. (Secker & Warburg/David & Charles, $19.95.) Alfred Linden wants to blow up the Monument to the Battle of the Nations, a gigantic memorial that commemorates the defeat of Napoleon at Leipzig in 1813. A descendant of stonemasons, the 70-year-old Linden is a demolition expert who is perfectly capable of blasting the thing into smithereens.

title: REACTIONARY MUSICAL MODERNISTS
description: The most fascinating bit of musical journalism in recent weeks is an article by Richard Taruskin in the Sept. 5 New Republic entitled ''The Dark Side of Modern Music.'' Ostensibly a review of Harvey Sachs's book ''Music in Fascist Italy,'' it lays out biographical evidence indicating the Fascist, or at least authoritarian, tendencies of Stravinsky, Schoenberg and Webern.

title: Agreement Ends Croton Point Suit
description: LEAD: THE elimination of a controversial drainage pipe has produced a peaceful settlement of an 18-month lawsuit between the county and the Hudson River Fishermen's Association, a Garrison-based environmental group. The settlement may also lead to the creation of a 150-acre Hudson River Ecological Center at Croton Point Park.

title: Noted Hotel to Begin a New Phase
description: LEAD: WHEN Bonnie Saltzman, production designer for a film shot at the Fairmount Hotel here this summer, surveyed the location before shooting, she discovered quaint relics of an era spanning more than two decades when the building was used as a ''spiritually pure residence'' for Father Divine's Peace Mission Church and Center.

title: As Manila Resists, the U.S. Looks At a Depleted Network of Bases
description: THE difficulty the United States is having in reaching agreement with the Philippines over the American bases there reflects a growing problem for the American military around the world.

title: HUMPHREY LEADS TIDE TO ROUT
description: Bobby Humphrey, the senior tailback, ran for 91 yards and a touchdown as Alabama opened its season with a 37-0 rout of Temple tonight.

title: THE REGION: Looking for $3 Billion; Koch Has Much Advice and Little Cash for Drug Problems
description: HOW much would it cost to treat New York City's drug problem (assuming it is treatable)?

title: Teresa O'Sullivan Wed in Vermont
description: Teresa Ann O'Sullivan and David Allan Martland, associates in the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, were married yesterday at the Peacham (Vt.) Congregational Church by the Rev. Stanford G. Blankin.

title: Maryann Tarzian Wed To Patrick Britt on L.I.
description: At St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, L.I., Maryann Tarzian, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Tarzian of Port Jefferson, L.I., was married yesterday to Patrick Eugene Britt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Britt of Rockville Centre, L.I. The Rev. Untzag Nalbandian performed the Armenian Orthodox ceremony.

title: Megan Flanigan and George Skakel 3d, Head of a Building Concer, Are Wed
description: Megan Adams Flanigan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Flanigan of Purchase, N.Y., was married there yesterday to George Skakel 3d, a son of the late Patricia Skakel and the late George Skakel Jr., both of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Brian E. Frawley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of Manhattanville College.

title: Thomas Loses Bid
description: What worked on Friday for his teammate Richard Dent didn't work yesterday for Calvin Thomas. The Chicago Bears' fullback lost a bid that would have allowed him to play in today's game against the Indianapolis Colts pending a hearing on his appeal of a 30-day suspension by the National Football League for violating the league's drug policy. Dent, who was also given a 30-day suspension, succeeded in having the league suspend his suspension while he pursues appeals within the N.F.L.

title: HIP, TRAGIC AND FUN TO BE WITH
description: LEAD: DREAM TIME Chapters From the Sixties. By Geoffrey O'Brien. 194 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: Buddy movies with a twist - and more
description: There are no superheroes to be found on this season's schedule, and not many small-town schoolteachers, either. Normal behavior - normal by the movies' standards, anyhow -will not be well represented. Jeremy Irons, who will play twin psychotic, drug-addicted gynecologists in ''David Cronenberg's Dead Ringers,'' may have the role (or roles) that best captures the spirit of the season. John Carpenter's new film, ''They Live,'' will suggest that America's mass media are controlled by forces from another planet.

title: Heavy Rains Worsen Flooding in Bangladesh
description: Heavy rains fell again today, officials said, worsening flood conditions that have covered three-quarters of Bangladesh and left a fourth of its 110 million people homeless.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Hazleton, Pa.;
Custom Homes In Resort Setting
description: LEAD: DEVELOPMENT has resumed on a large residential-resort community seven miles west of this northeastern Pennsylvania town, eight years after the high interest rates of the late 70's forced its former owners into foreclosure.

title: Real Mets Fans Know the Score
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Prescription Drug Prices Outrun Inflation; Competing Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: LaPoint Wins 7th Straight as Pirates Beat Phils
description: Dave LaPoint won his seventh straight decision tonight, pitching a six-hitter as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-1.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ABBOTT'S NEW YORK Although Berenice Abbott began her artistic life as a would-be sculptor, it's as a photographer that she will be remembered, particularly as a photographer of New York City.

title: THE WAR WITHIN
description: The essence of Richard N. Goodwin's charge in his article ''The War Within'' (Aug. 21) is that midway in 1965 Lyndon B. Johnson, detached from reality, became a raving paranoid. Mr. Goodwin confirms this indictment by revealing that he consulted medical books to fortify his epiphany. Like some latter-day Clark Kent, he vanished daily into a White House washroom and reappeared as a psychiatrist.

title: Nicaraguans Press for Talks; Contras Oppose Plan
description: Talks between the Sandinista Government and contra guerrilla leaders, which broke down amid mutual accusations three months ago, could resume in the coming weeks, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said Friday night.

title: About Books; Honk if You Love Lighthouses
description: A couple of weeks ago I read in the newspaper that the 11 lighthouses in the United States that are still tended by keepers will be automated by the fall of 1989. Well, I thought, there goes the last symbol. There'll be no more ''To the Lighthouse,'' just as there'll be no more Don Quixote, because the windmills too are gone. No more ''Moby Dick,'' now that the whaling ships are automated. Can someone write a lyrical novel called ''To the Computer''?

title: THE WHITE SILENCE OF THEIR LIVES
description: OUT OF THIS WORLD By Graham Swift. 208 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $16.95.

title: Sarah Bankson Wed in Capital
description: Sarah Danforth Bankson, the daughter of Mrs. Christopher M. Mould of Chicago and John P. Bankson Jr. of Bethesda, Md., was married in Washington yesterday to Jeffrey Thomas Newton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Newton of Holyoke, Mass. Bishop John T. Walker of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington performed the ceremony in the Great Choir of the Washington Cathedral.

title: Instead of a Shoe Box, Utilize the Albums
description: NEW collectors are frequently baffled by the rich variety of albums designed to organize stamps, covers and other material.

title: H. A. Potter Wed To Judy Renacia
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. Luke in the Fields in New York, Judy Yamashita Renacia, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dick Renacia of Las Vegas, Nev., and Howard Alonzo Potter, a son of Ruth D. Willard of Stonington, Conn., and Clarkson N. Potter of Jamestown, R.I., were married yesterday by the Rev. Ledlie I. Laughlin Jr. Carol Robinson Darling was the matron of honor, and Michael Garvey was the best man.

title: Review/Music; Rock, By Tom Tom Club
description: Tom Tom Club has reappeared in a new, compact lineup for its three-week stand at CBGB (315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street). The group started in 1981 as an occasional sideline for Talking Heads' rhythm section - the drummer Chris Frantz and the bassist Tina Weymouth - and assorted friends and relatives, and the group came up with a hit single, ''Genius of Love,'' that led to two albums. Now, with a new album on the way, Tom Tom Club has turned into a crisp four-piece band, with Mark Roule on guitar and Gary Pozner on keyboards.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Master's Return
description: LEAD: The new dean of the Westchester Day School in Mamaroneck needs no introduction to the school. After serving as its headmaster for 34 years, Maurice Plotnick, who retired in 1981, has returned in the newly created position of dean to lead the school and to conduct what he described as a ''global search'' for a headmaster or headmistress.

title: EASTERN AIRLINES STARTS JOB CUTS
description: Eastern Airlines eliminated 4,000 jobs today in a move it says it needs to survive.

title: The Spotlight Shines on Drawings
description: To draw or not to draw has never been the question among artists who have worked and settled on the South Fork over the last four decades. Rather, when to, how to and why draw, and even what is drawing, are questions that have affected and arisen from their pursuit of this flexible art.

title: Review/Dance; Artists Make Waves In New York Harbor
description: Having missed the 5:45 P.M. ferry to Staten Island by two minutes on Friday, your faithful dance critic waited around for the 6:45. Not any ferry would do - only those invaded by the hardy if subsidized band of musicians and dancers who are part of the ''Making Waves'' festival sponsored annually by the Staten Island Council on the Arts.

title: Breathing Lessons
description: Anne Tyler, who is blessedly prolific and graced with an effortless-seeming talent at describing whole rafts of intricately individualized people, might be described as a domestic novelist, one of that great line descending from Jane Austin. She is interested not in divorce or infidelity, but in marriage -- not very much in isolation, estrangement, alienation and other fashionable concerns, but in courtship, child raising and filial responsibility. It's a hectic, clamorous focus for a writer to choose during the 1980's, and a mark of her competence that in this fractionated era she can write so well about blood links and family funerals, old friendships or the dogged pull of thwarted love, of blunted love affairs or marital mismatches that neither mend nor end. Her eye is kindly, wise and versatile (an eye that you would want on your jury if you ever had to stand trial), and after going at each new set of characters with authorial eagerness and an exuberant tumble of details, she tends to arrive at a set of conclusions about them that is a sort of golden mean.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Seeing Stars With Mother

title: The Rediscovery of a Forgotten Park
description: LEAD: JAY BACCA, a Litchfield County environmentalist, stood admiring the view from along a trail he had recently made through a thick forest and overgrown farmland 10 minutes from downtown Torrington. Spread out before him was a panoramic wetland of tawny grass, still, dark water, osprey nests in tall dead trees, and beaver lodges.

title: Q and A
description: Young View

title: POSTINGS: Park Slope Project; Building into a Low-rise Neighborhood
description: In Park Slope, the brownstones are the prime properties; the restorers are busy, and the builders are highly revered and generally dead. Several residential buildings have been started recently on the western and southern fringes of the prosperous Brooklyn neighborhood, but a $9 million condominium, Sterling Court, at 100 Sterling Place between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, will be the first new construction in the core of Park Slope in years. Work on the 38-unit apartment building begins this fall.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Livingston $274,000 17 Mount Haven Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; fireplace, 1-car garage, central air-conditioning; taxes $3,370. Mountainside $327,500 6 Endor Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 36-year-old colonial; deck, new kitchen, skylights; taxes $3,050. New Providence $210,000 87 Passaic Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, century-old colonial; greenhouse, new roof, loft with skylight; taxes $2,177. Peqannock $213,500 40 Poplar Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 7-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, pool, finished basement; taxes $2,865. Short Hills $320,000 332 Taylor Road South 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; sun room, fireplace, den, 2-car garage; taxes $3,967. West Orange $205,000 45 Buckingham Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 31-year-old colonial; patio, central air-conditioning, den, full basement; taxes $3,204. OTHER AREAS East Patchogue, L.I. $119,750 95 Miramar Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 18-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, partly finished basement, deck; taxes $2,100. Chester, Conn. $155,000 Straits Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new Cape Cod; close to town, private setting, 2 acres; taxes not yet available. Rye, N.Y. $367,500 63 Florence Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 34-year-old ranch; fireplace, family room, enclosed porch, patio, 1-car garage; taxes $3,440.

title: The 'Safest' Ship Was the Titanic
description: When people like Ross Fleisig (''Nuclear Phobia Over Shoreham,'' Aug. 21) - citing all manner of safety systems - insist that Chernobyl couldn't happen here, I remind them that the world's safest ship, the Titanic - with all manner of safety systems - was unsinkable. BEN CALDERONE Levittown

title: Elizabeth Glazer, Lawyer, Marries
description: Elizabeth Glazer and William George Montgomery, 1986 graduates of the Columbia University School of Law, were married yesterday in the Central Park Conservatory Garden by Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

title: Stepping Back From Fiscal and Political Crisis: What Is Next for Yonkers?
description: Facing contempt-of-court fines of $1 million a day, drastic employee layoffs and cuts in municipal services, Yonkers yesterday ended its defiance of a court-ordered housing desegregation plan and stepped back from the brink of fiscal and political crisis. Here are some answers to major questions on how Yonkers came to this pass, and where it might go from here:

title: AN EPIC GROWS IN BROOKLYN
description: Imagine an undulating sea monster, a woman walking a pet lobster, slithering animals with daggers in their mouths, a moon crushing a hero's chest and giving birth to a meteor, a naked prostitute seducing a hairy animal-man, a huge metallic room slowly filling with trees, a dragon that swallows a man and an icy field with a consuming fire on the horizon - all accompanied by speech and song and swelling instrumental music that evokes 19th-century Romanticism yet sounds oddly off-center, too, in the best post-modern manner.

title: The Isadorables: Cherishing the Duncan Legacy
description: The tribute to the late Maria-Theresa Duncan that is scheduled for Tuesday at Lincoln Center (featuring the actress Colleen Dewhurst and the dancers Lynn Seymour and Clive Thompson) recalls a sparsely documented but important chapter of Isadora Duncan's legacy.

title: Frances Field and Stephen King Wed
description: At the First Church of Christ in Old Saybrook, Conn., Frances Reed Field, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William W. Field of Fenwick, Conn., and New Haven, was married yesterday to Stephen Bruce King, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. King of Cambridge, Mass.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Judo (Men's)
description: The modern form of judo, consisting of throws, hold-downs, choking techniques and armlocks, was introduced in Japan in 1882 by Jigaro Kano, a student of jujitsu, the martial art that predated judo. In 1964 judo became an Olympic sport in - appropriately - Tokyo. The Japanese have dominated the sport until recently, when several European countries and South Korea began to produce formidable competitors. In 1986 at the Asian Games, South korea took six gold medals to Japan's two. An Italian, Echio Gamba, won a gold and a silver medal in both the Moscow and the Los Angeles Olympics.

title: BRINGING MOTHER INTO MY HOUSE
description: Joan Gould's article ''Bringing My Mother Into My House'' (Hers column, Aug. 14) has made me angry. We have been deluged with articles in the ''coming to terms'' genre, and the Hers column provides a forum for daughters to rationalize acts of omission toward their mothers.

title: The Roots of a Crisis
description: What were the underlying causes of the Yonkers crisis and why did the dispute lead to such a dramatic showdown? Some answers, page 36.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Platinum Bullion Coin Introduced by Australia
description: LEAD: THE bullion-coin menagerie gets a new addition this month. Joining the American eagle, Chinese panda and Singapore rabbit is the Australian koala.

title: Open Victory Gives Graf a Grand Slam
description: It took a 19-year-old West German with a rapier forehand to give the National Tennis Center the tradition it lacked, and perhaps even some needed dignity. With the flags of the four Grand Slam countries fluttering in a strong breeze on the stadium court yesterday, Steffi Graf accepted the accolades and gifts of a tennis world that had just watched her make history in the United States Open.

title: Judge Overturns Ban on Film
description: About 50 people attended the opening of the film ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' here on Friday after a Federal district judge blocked a county ordinance banning theaters from showing it.

title:
DINING OUT;
Imaginative Cuisine in Cape May
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the summer vacation season is officially over, Cape May is one Shore resort that keeps humming off and on right into December with its Victorian Week beginning Oct. 7 and then its Dickensian Christmas festivities.

title: Civil Rights Groups Are Redefining Their Job
description: THE National Association for the Advancement of Colored People still sometimes engages in battles that recall the height of the civil rights era. Last week, for example, its Mississippi branch picketed and boycotted schools in Greenville in protest of policies it believes are racist.

title: A Rally Organized by Leftists Attracts Thousands in Chile
description: Thousands of people jammed a broad avenue today for the first large rally organized by leftist groups since the bloody military coup 15 years ago.

title: BURMA CHIEF VOWS ELECTIONS TO END SINGLE-PARTY RULE
description: In a victory for anti-Government protesters, the Burmese leadership said today that it would end 26 years of one-party rule and hold multiparty general elections.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: POWERBOAT SHOPPING Some 400 exhibitors will display more than 700 boats at the Norwalk International In-Water Powerboat Show, Thursday to next Sunday at Cove Marina in East Norwalk.

title: Those Eyes, That Smile
description: SHE IS KNOWN AS THE ''Mona Lisa of Roman Palestine.'' The portrait is part of a mosaic floor, dating to the third century - nearly 30 feet long and more than 20 feet wide - revealed in an excavation of the ancient city of Sepphoris, once the capital of Galilee, in what is now northern Israel. Discovered in August 1987 by an expedition led by two Duke University professors, Eric and Carol Meyers, and Ehud Netzer, an archaeologist at Hebrew University in Jerusalem, the mosaic was re-interred over the winter while financing was sought for its preservation. This summer, a fund established at Duke by the parents of an interested student has allowed the mosaic, composed of thousands of stone cubes, to be moved to the Israel Museum in Jerusalem, where it is to be exhibited this fall.

title: Kathleen Haggerty Is Married to John T. Collins 3d
description: At St. James Roman Catholic Church in Setauket, L.I., Kathleen Joan Haggerty, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Haggerty of Sound Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to John Timothy Collins 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard William Collins of New York and Millbrook, N.Y. The Rev. Timothy Stephen Collins, a Roman Catholic priest who is an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Saving Trees in Lewisboro
description: LEAD: IT may still be early for autumn leaves, but in Lewisboro, attention has turned to trees.

title: Dr. Forese Marries Dr. Robert Downey
description: The marriage of Dr. Laura Lee Forese, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Forese of Franklin Lakes, N.J., and Osterville, Mass., to Dr. Robert John Downey, a son of Dr. John A. Downey of New York and Sharon, Conn., and Elsie Downey of Closter, N.J., took place yesterday at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in Wyckoff, N.J. The Rev. Timothy O'Leary performed the ceremony.

title: High-Tech Rebel
description: IT IS EARLY MORNING AND most of the top leaders of the nation's personal computer industry are jammed into a hotel banquet hall in Naples, Fla. The annual, late-winter gathering is one that industry insiders can't afford to miss - 72 hours of closed-door deal-making, hushed corridor conversations about technologies gone amiss, and arguments over the future course of America's most visible high-tech industry. This year, marking a decade since personal computers began to revolutionize the working habits of tens of millions of people, there is also a heavy dose of self-congratulation in the air.

title: Questions Lingering Over Swift Iraqi Rout Of Kurdish Minority
description: Iraq's military campaign against its Kurdish minority has ended and its forces control northern regions formerly considered Kurdish rebel bastions, a senior Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Demonstration Sports - Judo (Women's)
description: Women's judo became an Olympic sport largely through the efforts of a Brooklyn woman, Rusty Kanokogi, who, after her marriage to a Japanese judoka - a judo fighter - in 1964, became a crusader for women in the sport. She organized the first world championships for women, a prerequisite for consideration on the Olympic agenda, in 1980 with 149 athletes from 27 countries. The world championships are now held every two years; women's judo is a demonstration sport in Seoul and will be a full medal sport in Barcelona in 1992.

title: PERILS OF DIVERSITY
description: LEAD: THE RADICAL RENEWAL The Politics of Ideas in Modern America. By Norman Birnbaum. 275 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $17.95.

title: Two Foreign Ministers Meet Again in Talks on Gulf Peace
description: The Foreign Ministers of Iran and Iraq met today for their first face-to-face peace talks in more than two weeks.

title: ATOMIC TEST DATA WEAKEN U.S. VIEW
description: Unexpected results from a recent Soviet-American experiment on monitoring nuclear tests have raised questions about the Reagan Administration's stance in negotiations over restrictions on such tests, some geologists say.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Hotels Accompanying Growth in Offices
description: LEAD: FOR most of this decade New Jersey has experienced a surge in commercial construction that blanketed its landscape with not only gleaming new office buildings, but also hotels and conference centers.

title: S. B. Flagler Weds Miss Rosborough
description: At Holy Innocents Episcopal Church on Long Beach Island, N.J., Caroline Reed Rosborough, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce W. Rosborough of Summit, N.J., and Beach Haven, N.J., was married yesterday to Stephen Brodhead Flagler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Flagler, also of Summit and Beach Haven. The Rev. William H. Strain performed the ceremony.

title: Who Are Nonvoters, And Who Needs Them?
description: THE quadrennial hand-wringing over the vast number of Americans who choose not to vote - nearly half the people who are eligible -has several new twists this year.

title: In Stormy Session, Mexicans Certify President-Elect
description: After three days of stormy debate, the Mexican Electoral College formally certified Carlos Salinas de Gortari as the country's President-elect today, bringing to an official end the electoral drama that has gripped Mexico for more than two months.

title: POSTINGS: The New Linden; Commercial Push
description: In a deal that could spur the transformation of Linden, N.J., from an industrial area to a commercial center, Hartz Mountain Industries has bought a 70-acre industrial park on Route 1 there for $30 million. The transaction, completed late in August, is the largest in Union County this year, according to the broker, the Archie Schwartz Company.

title: Surfers Riding the Waves of Protest in Long Beach
description: LEAD: IT may be the tail end of the summer, but Long Island surfers are still looking for the endless wave.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MY FATHER'S VOICE: MacKinlay Kantor Long Remembered. By Tim Kantor. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) Remember MacKinlay Kantor? He ran 44 books through his typewriter to become one of the most popular historical novelists of his time. His reputation rested largely on books dealing with the Civil War: ''Long Remember'' (1934), ''Arouse and Beware'' (1936), the Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Andersonville'' (1955).

title: Political Notes; Judges Court A Lawmaker For His Vote
description: The Democratic headquarters in Manhattan looked like a doctor's waiting room last week as no fewer than 15 judges seeking advancement to the State Supreme Court filed in for half-hour appointments with Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the borough's Democratic leader.

title: Down Memory Lane On the Hutch
description: I grew up in New Rochelle with only a few steps separating my home from the Hutchinson River Parkway. A ribbon of a roadway, ''The Hutch'' wound itself around the greenest hills, the most colossal boulders and the gentlest brooks that I knew of as a child.

title: Miss McGlothlin, Executive, Weds
description: Patricia Anne McGlothlin, a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, and C. Evan Stewart, the general counsel at Nikko Securities Company International in New York, were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church on the Green in Guilford, Conn. The Rev. Donald R. Cutler performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Howard J. Nash, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Sending Your Child to College: Grief or Relief?
description: Last year, when my son went away to college, I cried bittersweet tears. I felt that although this was a happy milestone, it marked the end of our little family as we'd known it for 18 years. First we were four; now, with just our high school-aged daughter at home, we would be three.

title: PERFORMANCE ART: Rooms for Experiment
description: Gusto House is a feisty and atmospheric little club in the great ''Hey, kids, let's put on a show'' tradition of the Lower East Side. It is housed in a loft that serves as home to Andy Kollmorgen, Daniel Cohen and Bill Callihan, writers and performers who founded the Gusto. The first floor is cut away -originally to accommodate the printing presses of The Guardian, a radical newspaper - to reveal a stage below. Up to about 90 people can watch from the balcony, legs dangling from the cutaway floor, or seated on basement chairs. Acts are presented before a giant plaster face called ''God,'' whose mouth yawns open to provide a black backdrop. Wine and beer are served, and there's often dancing after the performances. Gusto does not advertise. People find it chiefly through mailing lists and word of mouth. But acts like Jeffrey Essmann, the comedian, and the performance artists Ethyl Eichelberger, Danny Mydlack and the Alien Comic have played here. And they, and the surprisingly varied audience, have made Gusto one of the top East Village clubs.

title: Chosen and Given
description: I ONCE TUTORED JUNIOR-high geometry, and one of my most difficult pupils would sit at the kitchen table - wild hair flying, bubble gum popping - as she insisted again and again that she didn't understand.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: The credits accompanying Richard N. Goodwin's article on Lyndon B. Johnson on the Aug. 21 issue mistakenly omitted the name of the publisher of Mr. Goodwin's latest book, ''Remembering America: A Voice From the Sixties,'' from which the article. The publisher is Little, Brown.

title: Q and A
description: Rent Overcharge

title: Democrats Dominate Primary Races
description: LEAD: THURSDAY belongs to Westchester's Democrats, who will head to the primary polls and select candidates in three of the county's four Congressional Districts while area Republicans wait to see who will face their unchallenged nominees in the November election.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Water Polo
description: In 1980, when the United States water polo players felt sure they would win the Olympic gold medal, the American boycott kept them home. In 1984, they tied Ygoslavia for first place and lost the gold because of a tie-breaking rule (goal differential) that has since been abolished.

title: Mark Howe Married To Louise Nicholson
description: Louise Ellen Nicholson, a legal-search consultant for the New York law firm of Symthe, Masterson & Judd, and Mark Peter Howe, an associate with the law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft in Washington, were married yesterday at the Holy Redeemer Roman Catholic Church in Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Leo J. O'Donovan performed the ceremony.

title: ANTI-DRUG EFFORTS BY BUSH CRITICIZED
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen accused the Republican Administration today of conducting a ''popgun war on drugs.'' He said that Vice President Bush had been responsible for leading this battle ''and he blew it badly.''

title: Bustling Vancouver Is Transforming Its Waterfront
description: Barely a century old and now Canada's third largest metropolis, this energetic port city of British Columbia is about to embark on a development spree that will dramatically change its look, character and style.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: THIS is the story the ''pig woman'' told the jury: On the night of Sept. 14, 1922, she had ridden her mule down the road from her hardscrabble Somerset County farm, looking for thieves who had been stealing her crops. Hoping to catch the thieves in the act, she tied her mule to a tree and crept through the woods.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Tennis
description: It could easily be just another tournament on the globe-trotting tennis tour, the Korean Open for the men, the Virginia Slims of Seoul for the women. Setting this tournament apart, though, is that it is part of the Olympic spectacle. It is the first time in 64 years that ennis players will compete for a gold medal.

title: The Seoul Olympics; The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Archery
description: Archery has been an exciting sport, at least not since the days of Robin Hood and William Tell. But a new scoring system promises new excitement because the winner will be in doubt until the last round.

title: Quayle Adviser-for-Life Hits the Campaign Trail
description: This fall was to have been the time when Marilyn Quayle finally went back to work.

title: Young Marx and Old Lenin
description: Conversations in Moscow have taken on a startling new tone.

title: Magazines With Older Readers and Eager Advertisers
description: THE advertisements are for Chanel and Chevrolet as well as hearing aids and ''a face lift without surgery, at last!'' Articles chronicle a leisure cruise to the Antarctic and include an interview with Shere Hite, who writes about human relationships.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Telephone Overload; Communications Equipment Must Be Fast and Foolproof
description: ONCE a simple desk accessory, the telephone has evolved into part of the most complex and expensive segment of corporate offices.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Yachting
description: The yachting competition will be held off Pusan, a port city about 200 miles south of Seoul. The conditions are expected to be windy; sailors who gathered there last September for a pre-Olympic regatta encountered breezes that ranged mostly from 15 to 25 knots.

title: Jets' President Is Learning the Playbook
description: Steve Gutman will not be wearing short pants today, not in the visitors' v.i.p. box at Cleveland Stadium, where the Jets face the Browns.

title: Critic of the Sandinistas Quits Business Post
description: After more than five years as the principal spokesman for private business in Nicaragua, Enrique Bolanos Geyer relinquished his post this week but promised to remain in Nicaragua and continue his anti-Sandinista militance.

title: Miss Gowan Has Wedding
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Cynthia Hood Gowan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Gowan of New York, was married yesterday to William Michael Crawford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll E. Crawford of Wayzata, Minn. Msgr. George F. Bardes performed the ceremony.

title: A Return To the Past On Rosh ha-Shanah
description: WHEN people ask me if these are my ''happy holidays'' or my ''sad ones,'' I really don't know where to begin. So much of what makes a holiday happy or sad is often not the liturgical, official content of the day but the familiar context - how the surrounding song and dance make it seem in memory.

title: Cone Fans 10 and Stops Expos on 7 Hits
description: David Cone kept the Mets roaring through the homestretch tonight with more of the classic pitching that has sustained them all season. He mastered the Montreal Expos by 6-0 and won for the 16th time against only three defeats.

title: CHINA PRODUCING NEW WAVES OF YOUNG DIVERS
description: A GENERATION gap has formed in diving; the age of world-class talent has been dropping precipitously, so that suddenly veterans with two decades of training - and the maturity and grace that come with it - are finding themselves upset by tiny acrobats barely half their age.

title: CABARET: Veteran Entertainers and Fresh Voices
description: Three new cabarets have opened in New York in recent months.

title: Message to a Faltering Campaign
description: Labor Day marks the beginning of the Presidential campaign. The conventions are over, the lazy days of August past.

title: Moyers Designs A Talk Show ForThinkers
description: There are those who say that the intellectual guides, the figures of learning and probity who enlightened the public during such times as elections campaigns, are gone, replaced by flashy media pundits better able to make a fetching image on camera than to reflect on the wisdom of the ages. Bill Moyers, a rare television pundit of a less flashy, more probing stripe, agrees that modern times have been hard on what the British used to call pop dons. The television-watching public chews them up for breakfast, looking for new ones to devour at lunch.

title: Douglas J. Bobley Marries Amy Beth Marion, Student
description: The marriage of Amy Beth Marion, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Marion of Jericho, L.I., to Douglas J. Bobley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Bobley of Brookville, L.I., took place last evening at the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria in New York. Rabbi Philip J. Bentley and Cantor Marvin Antosofsky officiated.

title: Even Chicago Is Not Immune To Fashion
description: For more than a decade now this city in which architecture is a subject of everyday conversation has been in a kind of identity crisis. Chicago has always prided itself on being America's great city of modern architecture - the city in which the average person knew who Louis Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright and Mies van der Rohe were and the average real-estate developer was expected as a matter of course to put up first-class modern buildings. No New York flash and glitz for Chicago. But in the mid-1970's the Chicago gospel began to look a bit shaky. Not only was Mies van der Rohe's austere, steel-and-glass modernism less and less the order of the day everywhere, but worse still, a few revisionist scholars were beginning to point out that Chicago's true architectural past was a lot less purely modernist and a lot more eccentric than the history books would have had us believe.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; A New Look for Downtown New Haven
description: WORK is set to begin soon on a $105 million project to create 530 residential units and 125,000 square feet of office and retail space in a five-block area of downtown New Haven.

title: Apartments by Candela: Grandest of the Grand
description: AT no time in New York City's history were grander apartments built than in the late 1920s, and, by near universal agreement, no architect designed them better than Rosario Candela, the immigrant son of a Sicilian plasterer whose elevated concepts of layout, amenities, spaciousness and luxury set a new standard for the way rich people should live in multiple dwellings.

title: CALIFORNIA ABSTRACT
description: Richard Diebenkorn is by general consent a painter much loved and not like any other, but he does not look like most people's idea of an artist. If we were told that he was the head of the department of moral philosophy at an ancient and low-key university, we would have no trouble believing it. He has the large, heavy-framed glasses, the well-cut tweed jackets (neither old nor new), the corduroy pants of standard cut, the capacious and comfortable shoes and a general air of continuous but soundless rumination.

title: SEASON PREVIEW
description: This season, New York will be welcoming its customary assortment of musicians from around the world, and there will also be some interesting home-grown opera productions. The Metropolitan Opera brings us Handel's ''Giulio Cesare'' (opens Sept. 27) and a Bartok-Schonberg double bill pairing ''Bluebeard's Castle'' with Schonberg's eerie monodrama ''Erwartung'' (opens Jan. 16). The Met also finishes its Ring cycle with ''Gotterdammerung'' (opens Oct. 21). The New York City Opera gives us a new American opera, Jay Reise's ''Rasputin'' (opens Sept. 17) and revives an old one, ''The Ballad of Baby Doe'' by Douglas Moore (opens Oct. 2).

title: Robert A. Rizzo Wed To Dawn Elaine Bona
description: At Our Lady of the Magnificat Roman Catholic Church in Kinnelon, N.J., Dawn Elaine Bona, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Bona of Boonton Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Albert Rizzo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Amedeo A. Rizzo of Broomall, Pa. Msgr. John R. Ryan performed the ceremony.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Russian Tea Room; Sweet Deals Fail to Tempt
description: WITH a knife edge of Harry Macklowe's 78-story Metropolitan Tower on one side and the rising superstructure of Carnegie Hall Tower on the other, the Russian Tea Room on West 57th Street east of Seventh Avenue is Manhattan's newest holdout, a five-story, brownstone peanut of a building whose owners have so far resisted temptations to sell out.

title: Title Is Again Up For Grabs
description: When Penn's dynasty collapsed last year, after five championship seasons, the Ivy League crown was out there for anyone to wear.

title: Sales Pitch: Who the Owner Was
description: THE other morning, a pair of secondhand eyeglasses sold for $16,830, and almost no one in the packed auction house here seemed surprised.

title: Work and Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Yarmouth, Me.; Boat Businesses In Sardine Plant
description: A DILAPIDATED sardine packing plant on the Royal River in this Portland suburb has been transformed into 42,500 square feet of space for professional offices, shops and port-related businesses.

title: SEASON PREVIEW: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: The sesquicentennial of photography's birth approaches, a number of individual and group shows will demonstrate that the medium's future is as bright as its past, and every bit as diverse. This is especially true in September, when the season kicks off with images ranging from the picturesque (''Odyssey,'' a survey of 100 years of National Geographic photography) to the socially concerned (''Homeless in America'' and Nicholas Nixon's portraits). Beginning in January, at least a half-dozen major exhibitions are planned to mark the 150 years since Louis Jacques Mande Daguerre announced to the French Academy his method for fixing light and shadow. New Yorkers will have to hold their applause until 1990, however, since that is when the Museum of Modern Art's 150-year survey, entitled ''The History of Photography,'' will appear. A SELECTIVE GUIDE September Arnold Newman: New Collages, New Photographs and Unseen Vintage Prints. Known for his ''environmental portraits'' of artists, Newman also has an experimental side, featured in this show. Sept. 15-Oct. 8, Sidney Janis Gallery, 110 West 57th Street, 586-0110. The exhibition is a companion to his retrospective at the New-York Historical Society. Homeless in America. Five of the most respected photojournalists working today - Mary Ellen Mark, Bill Pierce, Eli Reed, Eugene Richards and Stephen Shames -assay the visual manifestations of homelessness, in a project sponsored by Families for the Homeless and the National Mental Health Association. Sept. 16-Oct. 22, New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue at 42d Street, 869-8089. Nicholas Nixon: Pictures of People. This 120-print, 10-year retrospective will chart the photographer's passage from formally complex pictures of children and family groups to close-to-the-bone portraits of nursing-home residents and people with AIDS. The constant of his career has been the 8-by-10-inch contact print. Sept. 15-Nov. 13, Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, 708-9480. A companion exhibition, focusing on Nixon's most recent work, will be held Sept. 16-Oct. 22 at the Zabriskie Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, 307-7430. Odyssey: The Art of Photography at National Geographic. Part of the National Geographic Society's 1988 centennial celebration, this mammoth survey (more than 250 prints) includes pictures familiar to readers of its magazine as well as images culled from its substantial archive. Sept. 16-Oct. 30, International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street, 860-1777. The Starn Twins. The precocious and ubiquitous brothers receive the imprimatur of Leo Castelli. Sept. 24-Oct. 15, Leo Castelli, 420 West Broadway, 431-5160. October New Photography 4. Once more the Museum of Modern Art sallies forth into the breach of contemporary image making. This year's nominees are Patrick Faigenbaum, Reagan Louie and Michael Schmidt; the pictures were taken in China, Italy and Germany. Oct. 20-Jan. 10, Museum of Modern Art, 708-9480. November Master Photographs from Photography in the Fine Arts, 1959-67. This exhibition reflects upon one of the postwar era's more quixotic artistic efforts, the Photography in the Fine Arts Project. Organized by the photographer Ivan Dmitri, the PFA Project mounted a series of group shows intended to prove, once and for all, that photography was indeed an art. Assembled here are images from the most illustrious of the exhibits, by Ansel Adams, Henri Cartier-Bresson and others. Nov. 8-Jan. 8, International Center of Photography, 860-1777. December Perpetual Motif: The Art of Man Ray. Bringing together the artist's photographs, works on paper and objects, this exhibition promises to be the most penetrating look yet into a career that has been simultaneously influential and perplexing. Dec. 2-Feb. 20, National Museum of American Art, Washington, D.C., 202 357-2700. Robert Mapplethorpe. The second United States exhibition this year devoted to the photographer's career features 170 works and a traveling schedule that will take it to Chicago, Boston and Washington. Dec. 9-Jan. 29, Institute of Contemporary Art, Philadelphia, 215 898-7108. January Experimental Photography: Discovery and Invention. This is the first of five exhibitions the Getty Museum will mount this year surveying the 150-year history of photography. Jan. 17-March 26, J. Paul Getty Museum, Malibu, Calif., 213 458-2003. Walker Evans: American Photographs. It has been 50 years since Evans's classic volume, ''American Photographs,'' was first published, which is occasion enough for presenting the original prints once again. Another reason is that these are probably the most important pictures of the United States taken in this century. Jan. 19-April 11, Museum of Modern Art, 708-9480. February The Art of Photography: 150 Years, 1839-1989. The former New York gallery owner Daniel Wolf has spent the last several years selecting his own history of photography under the auspices of Houston's Museum of Fine Arts and London's Royal Academy of Arts. Here are the fruits of his labors. Feb. 11-April 30, Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, Tex. 713 526-1361. April Minor White.Once virtually the supreme commander of postwar American photography, White (1908-1976) has never had a major retrospective. Peter Bunnell is the guest curator of this long-overdue show. April 27-June 18, Museum of Modern Art, 708-9480. May On the Art of Fixing a Shadow: 150 Years of Photography. A collaboration between the National Gallery and the Art Institute of Chicago, this promises to be the definitive sesquicentennial extravaganza. May 7-July 30, National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., 202 737-4215.

title: THE MOB WITHIN THE MOB
description: THE PIZZA CONNECTION Lawyers, Money, Drugs, Mafia. By Shana Alexander. Illustrated. 442 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $19.95. LAST DAYS OF THE SICILIANS At War With the Mafia: The FBI Assault on the Pizza Connection. By Ralph Blumenthal. Illustrated. 354 pp. New York: Times Books. $18.95.

title: Checking It Out At the Grocery
description: The story entitled ''At the Grocery, I Was the One Checked Out'' (Opinion page, Aug. 14) sounds apocryphal to me. Getting locked up in an office by a giant who spied a card in a pocket? Being looked upon by another shopper as a possible drug dealer? Sure, hyperbole in a humorous piece is a good tool, but it just doesn't wash here.

title: SIX RMS, PLUS GHOST
description: A STRANGER'S HOUSE By Bret Lott. 256 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: MUSIC: Avant-garde to Zydeco, By Way of Texas
description: Nobody thought avant-garde music could pay a club's rent until the Knitting Factory came along.
