A few months after it opened, it had become a center for improvisational music, at the nexus of risky, format-defying new jazz, new rock and the postmodern assemblages of downtown composers - the tumultuous piano solos of Cecil Taylor, the quick-change artistry of John Zorn, the geometrically proportioned slabs of noise composed by Elliott Sharp, the dreamlike performance-rock of Hugo Largo or the skewed, clattery funk of Curlew. Some Knitting Factory regulars, like Mr. Zorn or Mr. Sharp, can also be heard in special events at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, but the Knitting Factory presents them on an intimate scale, with new ideas while they're hot.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Synchronized Swimming
description: The era of synchronized swimming as a frilly exhibition event has ended. Most competitors now spend at least six hours in the pool six days a week. They no longer wear real flowers in their hair; they slick it back with gel to allow for easy head movement. They run and ride bicycles to build lung capacity, since half of the competition is performed completely underwater without any contact with the bottom of the pool. But one thing hasn't changed since the days of the Esther Williams, the Olympic simmer-turned movie star who popularized this as a glamour sport: the paste-on, glossy smiles.

title: TED KOPPEL'S EDGE
description: I have always admired Ted Koppel's ''Nightline'' (''Ted Koppel's Edge,'' by Marshall Blonsky, Aug. 14).

title: D-Day for ABC
description: EVEN IN A NORMAL TELEVISION season, ABC's prime-time rendering of Herman Wouk's World War II novel ''War and Remembrance,'' the longest and most expensive project ever put to television, would demand notice. As it is, with a full mounting of the new season pushed back by the writers' strike, the ABC mini-series is likely to dominate television this fall in the way that, say, an elephant would dominate a canoe.

title: Art and Rock: An 80's Love Affair
description: Keith Haring's cartoonish new mural on East Houston Street on Manhattan's Lower East Side bears watchwords from Public Enemy's latest rap single, ''Don't Believe the Hype.' The artist and video director Robert Longo's yuppies twist and grimace in black and white on MTV's ''art breaks.'' William Wegman's Weimaraner Fay Ray, the art world's top dog, cavorts in the video clip for New Order's ''Blue Monday.'' Murals by Kenny Scharf and the late Jean-Michel Basquiat hang at the Palladium just as Chagalls decorate the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Artists - Arab And Jew - Find The Palestinian Uprising an Uneasy Subject
description: Slowly, tentatively, painfully, the Palestinian uprising is finding its way into art in Israel. Pop singers, painters and craftspeople - both Arabs and Jews - say they simply can't separate their anguish from their work.

title: IN THE WAKE OF BOYCOTTS, SOVIETS PLAN TO WIN
description: WHILE the Los Angeles Olympics were going on four years ago, Vladimir Geskin, the foreign editor of the newspaper Sovietski Sport, was in Tallin, the capital of Estonia.

title: Museum Loans Add Zest To the Antiques Season
description: Esoteric and exotic antiques - American washboards, African ivories, Indonesian artifacts and ancient Greek miniatures - dominate in the exhibitions to be presented at museums and galleries over the next several months.

title:
ART;
Fantasy as Realism
description: LEAD: JUDGING by the evidence presented in ''Contemporary Realism,'' the current exhibition at the Temperance Hall Gallery in Bellport, a traditional definition of realism is no longer applicable to contemporary art. None of the 14 artists is concerned with the objective depiction of outward appearance.

title: On College Costs: A Presidential Idea
description: Voters impatient with junk-food politics and eager for issues are finally being treated to some pure protein. The college loan plan outlined last week by Michael Dukakis promises to relieve the squeeze felt by middle-income families, and without shifting the burden to taxpayers.

title: John Mooney Is Married To Cheryl Lynn Hopper
description: Cheryl Lynn Hopper and John Brooke Mooney were married yesterday in the Gloucester, Mass., home of the bride's sister and her husband, Teresa Hopper and Douglas LaChance. The Rev. Joel Baehr, a Unitarian minister, officiated.

title: THE WORLD: Likud vs. Labor; The West Bank Is A No-Win Debate In Israeli Campaign
description: LEANING back in his chair, Yaacov Esher spoke with a tone so matter-of-fact that he could have been discussing the changing weather.

title: BIGGER STATE ROLE IS URGED ON WASTE
description: The state's Environmental Protection Commissioner has proposed that the state be allowed to override local zoning regulations and place solid-waste disposal plants where it chooses.

title: Lobster in a New Arena
description: ANYONE returning to Pearl of the Atlantic will be surprised to find the space has been occupied for four months by a new restaurant, Harbour Square, in the restored complex of the same name in Stamford.

title: PHILOSOPHER-KING
description: THE BOSS J. Edgar Hoover and the Great American Inquisition. By Athan G. Theoharis and John Stuart Cox. Illustrated. 489 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. $27.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a ceramic tile floor in our bathroom consisting of one-inch square tiles. The floor is even and in good condition, but it is not attractive, and so we would like to put down new ceramic tile. Can we put new tile on top of the existing tile, or must we rip up all the old tile first?

title: NONFICTION
description: TO THE MEMORY OF CHILDHOOD. By Lydia Chukovskaya. Translated by Eliza Kellogg Klose. (Northwestern University, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $9.95.) This memoir by the novelist and dissident Lydia Chukovskaya is a charming and powerful tribute to her father, Kornei Chukovsky, the Russian critic, translator and author. A reminiscence of the years 1910 to 1917, when she was a child and the family lived in Kuokkala on the Gulf of Finland, the book describes a man who was a self-made intellectual, passionate about language and fanatical about poetry. The sense of humor and fun that later made Kornei Chukovsky an extremely popular writer of children's verse (many of his fairy tales are still available in this country) is apparent here. My favorite example is the story about a guard dog that escapes and starts after the terrified children. ''Do exactly as I do!'' Chukovsky shouts, and then drops on all fours to the dust. ''We follow suit right next to him,'' the author says, and the dog immediately backs off, surprised at the sight and sound of the whole family on hands and knees, barking. While Lydia Chukovskaya writes primarily of his role as a father, it is clear that Chukovsky's business was literature. He ate, drank, breathed and - when he could - slept literature. (He was an insomniac who could fall asleep only as young Lydia read to him.) Fortunately for the readers of ''To the Memory of Childhood,'' published here in a graceful translation, Kornei Chukovsky also was a gifted teacher who passed on the love of language to his daughter.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Burlington's Minor Confusion

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE SLEEP CENTER;
It's All in a Good Night's Work
description: LEAD: AROUND 7 o'clock one recent evening, a 44-year-old woman arrived at the sleep center at New York Medical College with a suitcase. In it, she said, were a bath towel, a nightgown you can't see through; high-heel shoes to wear to work the next day, ''rubber between-the-toe slippers for my nocturnal walk to the bathroom,'' toothbrush and toothpaste and a science-fiction magazine.

title: One Foot in Heaven
description: THE FRONTIERS OF PARADISE A Study of Monks and Monasteries. By Peter Levi. 224 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson.

title: Diane McCormack Weds
description: Diane Marie McCormack, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred McCormack of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Gibb Cropper Nemiroff, the son of Catharine Gibb Shaw Lewis Eftimiadi of Greenbackville, Va., and Alfred Nemiroff of Lakeville, Conn. The Rev. Julian Deeken performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church.

title: Miss McGovern Becomes Bride In Connecticut
description: Calvary Episcopal Church in Stonington, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Elizabeth Laird McGovern, the daughter of Mrs. William B. Cutler of Stonington and James W. McGovern of New York, to Philip MacLaren Johnstone, a son of Rodney S. Johnstone of Stonington and Frances D. Johnstone of Worcester, Mass. The Revs. Ellen and John Donnelly performed the ceremony.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION About Maggie, Who Tried Too Hard
description: LEAD: DOGS, DREAMS, AND MEN. By Joan Kaufman. (Norton, $16.95.) Ann is an Upper West-Sider of pre-yuppie persuasion, a plain woman in her early 30's who works as an editor at a Manhattan publishing house. She lives close to Riverside Park with her dog, Emma Bovary. Joan Kaufman's first novel takes us through eight years of their life together.

title: Lilco Pact with Cuomo Faces P.S.C.
description: LEAD: THE State Public Service Commission is expected on Thursday to approve major components of Governor Cuomo's proposed settlement with the Long Island Lighting Company to close the $5.3 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Famed Nightclub
description: To the Editor:

title: Bibiana Hernandez Weds David Nerkle
description: The marriage of Bibiana Hernandez, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Valentin Hernandez of Washington, to David Nerkle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Nerkle of Ocala, Fla., took place yesterday at the Nunciature of the Holy See in Washington. Archbishop Pio Laghi, the Apostolic Pro-Nuncio to the United States, performed the ceremony.

title: Question Of the Week; What Do You Expect To See in the Olympics?
description: I expect some success in track and field for the U.S. team. Carl Lewis should win several medals, some gold included. We have an excellent shot at a gold in the men's marathon, and the diving champion, Greg Louganis, should bring home the gold as well. Gymnastics should be a bit of a problem with stiff competition from the Eastern bloc countries; specifically, the Russian, the Rumanian and the East German teams.

title: ART IN THE AFFIRMATIVE
description: Like many self-taught artists, Perle Hessing didn't begin to paint until she was well into middle age. Her art has served her as a way to reconstruct and preserve the spiritual fabric of her life, which began in a provincial Galician town in 1908. While A MIRROR TO MY LIFE (Holt, $29.95) reproduces in color more than 90 of the paintings Mrs. Hessing has made in the last 30 years, it is as much a memoir and affirmation of her essential humanism as it is an art book. After a brief autobiographical introduction, Mrs. Hessing comments on the paintings, describing the stories they tell, their iconography and how she came to make them. Many paintings re-create well-known stories from the Bible and Jewish folklore; others recall her childhood in Zaleszczyki, where she lived until she was 6. A few pictures relate to the places she has lived since the end of World War II, particularly Israel (briefly) and Australia. Mrs. Hessing's ingenuous style is strikingly reminiscent of Chagall in some particulars. The paintings reveal an exuberant colorist and an intuitively efficient organizer of pictorial space, especially when she chooses to tell a story like that of Abraham and Hagar sequentially on a single panel. The real text of this charming book is subliminal, however; it is a morality tale that preaches faith and optimism in the face of adversity and a resounding belief in the essential goodness of one's fellow man. In transmuting her life into art, Mrs. Hessing has obviously edited out the distressing episodes (only two pictures depict the Holocaust), choosing instead to idealize beauty, the verities of religious and cultural tradition and the wonder of childhood.

title: LEARNING HUMILIATION AT WRITER'S PREP
description: It is to my friend Chris that I owe my experience at Writer's Prep, the now celebrated school for authors, because he wouldn't take no for an answer. A novelist himself as well as an alumnus of the program, he had watched in horror when, several years ago, I went through the nightmare so many writers endure with the publication of a first book. Two years later, when he saw me completing my second book with no apparent memory of the terrors that had attended the first, he phoned Harry Orloff, the director of Writer's Prep, arranged an interview and refused to accept any of the half-dozen excuses I invented for canceling the appointment.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q&A;: JIM BOUTON;
Former Yankee Is Still Pitching
description: LEAD: JIM BOUTON, 49 years old, author of an irreverent book about major league baseball, ''Ball Four,'' began pitching for the New York Yankees in 1962. He won 21 games for them in 1963 and 18 in 1964, when he also won two World Series games. His final retirement from professional baseball was in 1978.

title: Program for 'Dangerous' Homeless to Expand
description: A New York City program under which homeless people who show signs of dangerous mental disturbance can be hospitalized against their will is to be expanded to Brooklyn, city officials say.

title: Tino Juarez, Actor, Wed To Christina Campanaro
description: Christina Campanaro, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Campanaro of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Tino Juarez, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abel Juarez of Los Gatos, Calif. The Rev. Kenneth France-Kelly performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Armenia and Its Neighbors Only Diverge
description: ONE balmy evening several days ago on the plaza outside the city opera house, a group of Armenians were playing Yerevan's favorite guessing game: What if Armenia broke off from the Soviet Union and declared its independence?

title: Are We Ready to Learn From the Vietnam War?
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS. By Thomas Harris. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) Thomas Harris, the author of ''Black Sunday'' and ''Red Dragon,'' has done it again. Good entertainments are rare, and Mr. Harris has now written three in a row. In ''The Silence of the Lambs,'' a serial killer is on the loose, a madman who specializes in murdering large women with clear complexions.

title: Cyclist Disqualified
description: He pedaled his way to a gold medal and a silver at the 1984 Olympics, but Steve Hegg won't be bringing home any cycling honors from Seoul. According to the United States Cycling Federation, the 24-year-old Hegg has been disqualified from the American team after testing positive for caffeine at the Olympic trials in Houston last month.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board last week agreed to sell the nation's largest insolvent thrift association, the American Savings and Loan Association of California, to a group headed by Robert M. Bass of Fort Worth.

title: THE BEST OLYMPICS? OR THE LAST?
description: ''I thank the city of Seoul and the people of Korea who, through their preserverance and their enthusiasm, will surprise the world by accomplishing Olympic Games of union, excellence and peace.'' -Juan antonio Samaranch YES, peace. Ever since Seoul was awarded the Olympics, skeptics have questioned the wisdom of the decision. Not that South Korea couldn't construct the stadiums and other necessary buildings. Not that Seoul couldn't organize thousands of athletes, officials, journalists and spectators. No, the skeptics have wondered if Seoul could keep the peace by keeping the terrorists away.

title: THE WORLD: The Left's Loss; Where Liberation Was a Dream, Other Visions Ascend
description: A QUARTER of a century ago, revolutionary Algeria, having wrenched its independence from France in a bloody armed struggle, was a heroic beacon to those fighting for freedom elsewhere. As colonial empires in Africa and Asia were dismantled, third world leaders, often drawing inspiration from Marx, Lenin and Mao Zedong, vowed to create a New Man out of the cauldrons of national liberation struggles.

title: The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Field Hockey
description: In the United States, field hockey is primarily a women's sport, but is played by both sexes in the rest of the world, especially in the former countries of the British Empire. An Olympic sport for men since 1908, field hockey became one for women in 1980, when the United States boycotted the Games. Surprising many, the American women won the bronze medal in 1984 in Los Angeles; they are seeded fifth in the eight-team Seoul tournament. (The United States did not qualify for the 12-team men's tournament.) The sport is like soccer in strategy - 11 players on a soccer-sized field trying to propel a ball into a goal - and a bit like ice hockey in implements. The stick has a short, blunt head curved on one side, and only the flat side may be used to strike the ball, which is about the size of a baseball and rock-hard. Artificial turf fields, now used in all major tournaments, have made the sport even faster, putting premium on rapid-fire passing, not to mention aerobic conditioning.

title: A RESTLESS SEOUL ENERGIZES FOR GAMES
description: THE clang of construction that forms the background noise of Seoul will fall still this month, as this city of perpetual motion tries to tame itself for the Olympic Games.

title: High Mileage Rules May Stall Detroit
description: ON THE eve of the 1989 model year, we find ourselves handcuffed by the Corporate Average Fuel Economy program - the CAFE rules. This 1970's law was intended to deal with anticpated oil shortages, but now it threatens American jobs, diminishes consumer welfare and gives foreign auto makers an edge in the marketplace. But it does not save gasoline.

During the 1987 holiday season, Amtrak passengers who had paid the full $40-plus fare were forced to take commuter trains; I saw elderly citizens and families with small children endure the five-hour trip sitting on bags in the aisles.

We understand how some - even some at your own university - take some perverse pleasure in the losing. We understand how tired you get of the media poking around your campus, wondering when the streak will end.

title: FICTION
description: ELYSIAN FIELDS. By Sally Savic. (Scribner's, $14.95.) Alice Bettonville, the narrator of this first novel by Sally Savic, is an Ohioan working for a New Orleans newspaper and living in a house she has inherited from her step-grandmother, a family outsider with whom Alice identifies. It seems that the naive Alice has fallen in with some unsavory characters. One of her co-workers is a malicious conniver. Her neighbor's son, Boy, who makes menacing advances to her, stores stolen property in her attic. And she is married to the irresistible but unfaithful Marshall Bettonville, who has abruptly disappeared. Marshall's shrewish mother believes he is dead. The hideously obese Penny Lapere, Alice's neighbor and friend, thinks he has abandoned his wife. Penny's son, the delinquent Boy, tells Alice her husband is on the lam from his creditors. ''Elysian Fields'' is the story of Alice's search for the truth - about Marshall and herself. Part mystery, part psychological study of despair, part caricature, the novel mingles rich, sensuous imagery with descriptions of grotesque characters and seedy places. Taking her title from the legendary New Orleans street named for the Greek paradise, Ms. Savic displays a good ear for dialogue and an eye for authentic local detail. Indeed, in her description of a wide range of New Orleans eccentrics, she echoes John Kennedy Toole's ''Confederacy of Dunces.'' However, where Toole's novel was consistently satiric, Ms. Savic's fluctuates between the farcical and the serious, and her characters are overdrawn. But although the plot in ''Elysian Fields'' is too thin to support such a heavy cast of grotesques, the novel bodes well for Sally Savic's future. She is a promising writer with a rich, atmospheric style.

My children have been taught, not that appearances are important, but rather that if they work hard and try to be good people they have a better chance of achieving their goals and dreams than if they think everything just comes to them on a silver platter.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.

No matter how agreeable you are, no matter how winning or open your smile, no matter how pleasant and sincere your ''Good morning,'' you are met with a stone wall. Well, not really a stone wall, but a stone face. You are a nonperson, a bit of bothersome flotsam on the landscape. The other person looks right through you, silent if there is no necessity to speak and barely civil if a few words, a modicum of information, must be exchanged.

description: Last year, 3,041 United States citizens were arrested abroad. Most such cases are resolved in ''a timely fashion,'' the State Department says: the American is released with a half-hearted apology, fined or deported.

title: FOREST FIRES CAST A PERSISTENT PALL ON MUCH OF WEST
description: The smoke has obscured the sun in Seattle, darkened the skies over Minneapolis, tinted the sunset in Chicago.

title: Cracker Barrel Old Country Store Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Dollar Rises in Tokyo
description: The dollar bounced back in early trading against the Japanese yen today, while stock prices posted moderate gains. The dollar opened at 133.82 yen, up 0.87 from Friday. On the Tokyo stock exchange, the Nikkei stock average of 225 selected issues, which lost 93.01 points Friday, gained 51.83 points, or 0.18 percent, in the first 15 minutes of trading.

title: Topics of The Times; Appliances That Don't Listen
description: People plainly hate talking appliances, as The Times reported the other day. What's not so obvious is why.

title: In Burma, a Civil War Has Gone On for 41 Years
description: To the Editor:

title: Lee McConaughy Becomes a Bride
description: Lee McConaughy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Francis McConaughy of Loudonville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Warren Woodruff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Norman Woodruff Jr. of Birmingham, Mich. The Rev. Lee Van Sickle, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Helen Hughes Memorial Chapel in Silver Bay, N.Y.

title: Gunmen in Haiti Kill 3 In Attack on a Church
description: Gunmen burst into the church of a radical Roman Catholic priest during Mass today, shot and killed at least three parishioners, wounded 60 and and burned the building down, Radio Haiti-Inter reported.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Mitsubishi Bank Ltd.'s New York branch has established a $2 billion medium-term deposit note program. Morgan Stanley, the lead manager, said it was the largest program ever established by an American branch of an overseas bank.

title: Exports of American Steel Surge
description: American steel companies, stepping up exports in anticipation of a continued weakness in the dollar and tighter supplies, will this year have the highest level of shipments to foreign countries since the early 1980's, industry officials said.

title: Crown Books Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
When a Woman Could Be an Oomph Girl
description: To the Editor:

title: Bowne & Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Market Place; Grain and Coal Lift Rail Traffic
description: THE nation's leading freight railroads have been experiencing an excellent year, helped by an unexpected surge in grain exports and surprisingly higher shipments of coal.

title: House of Fabrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Graphic Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings have been restated to give effect to the 3-for-2 stock split on Oct. 28, 1987.

title: Schult Homes reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Net income

title: Candiotti Stops Red Sox, 4-2
description: Tom Candiotti was not the kind of pitcher the Boston manager, Joe Morgan, wanted the Red Sox to face.

title: Tyson Attends Soviet Golf Event
description: The driving range of the first golf course in the Soviet Union was opened today in a ceremony attended by dignitaries ranging from Mike Tyson to a leading Russian Orthodox clergyman.

title: Review/Country; Swagger, Mythic Bravado and a Hat Worn Low
description: Dwight Yoakam cuts the most conspicuously mythical figure among the constellation of young artists who have been lumped together as country music's new traditionalists.

title: College Football; Kicking Saves Notre Dame
description: Reggie Ho, the smallest man in a very big game, settled a duel of kicking games between Notre Dame and Michigan Saturday night when the 5-foot-5-inch, 135-pound junior from Hawaii booted a 26-yard field goal with 73 seconds left in the contest.

title: Campaign Trails; In Political Ambush, Timing Is Everything
description: Politics is, above all, timing. The right moment. And advisers to Vice President Bush are grappling with the question perenially debated within Presidential election campaigns in mid-September: how to escalate the negative campaign against an opponent without sounding, well, too negative.

title: Corporations Criticized On Trading With Japan
description: On what is likely to be the Reagan Administration's last major trade mission to Japan, Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. appeared more critical of marketing efforts by American corporations than of the remaining Japanese barriers to doing business here.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cushman & Wakefield Inc., a real estate subsidiary of the Rockefeller Group Inc., named Stuart L. Phelps senior vice president of the financial services group.

title: College Football; Upset by Rutgers Keeps Coach Busy
description: Maybe Rutgers should schedule games against Big Ten Conference opponents more often. It would certainly keep Coach Dick Anderson on the move.

title: Chile Protesters Stone Pinochet Motorcade
description: Protesters stoned the motorcade of President Augusto Pinochet today during a campaign tour on the 15th anniversary of the military coup that brought him to power.

title: Reviews/Television; Canada: Living in the Eagle's Shadow
description: ''The Relationship'' gives teeth to the popular saw that ''Canada is a swell place to visit, but you wouldn't want to watch a television show about it.'' This is the first of a four-part series, ''Canada: True North,'' about the country's famous identity crisis. The problem, we are told more than once before the first episode gets fairly under way and several times therefter, is that Canada has the misfortune to have as a neighbor the big and powerful United States. As Pierre Elliott Trudeau, a former prime minister, remarks, it is like being in bed with an elephant.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9 Poison gas attacks on Kurds by Iraq were recounted by Kurdish refugees at a camp in Diyarbakir, Turkey. But Turkish Government doctors say the refugees' medical problems were caused by poor nutrition. Page A1

title: COMPANIES
description: Drexel employees are expected to be charged with a broad pattern of criminal activity over at least two years and possibly with racketeering, people close to the investigation said. They said the indictments against the Drexel executives, expected in October, would probably delay the huge civil proceeding initiated against the firm last week by the S.E.C. [ Page D1. ] Citicorp will acquire a Texas credit card unit. The business, for which Citicorp will pay $159 million, was a unit of the former First Republicbank Corporation of Dallas. Citicorp outbid several other banks to win the credit card business from the F.D.I.C. [ D1. ] An investor group has extended its offer for Interco and made a new bid under which stockholders would receive $72 a share if the investors are allowed to review confidential information related to the company's announced recapitalization proposal. Cardinal Acquisition's existing offer of $70 a share now expires Sept. 22. [ D1. ] Steel exports this year will be higher than they have been since the early 1980's, industry officials said. The rise was attributed primarily to companies' taking advantage of the lower dollar. [ D3. ] American Airlines may have lost as much as $50 million because of a computer glitch in its reservations system. The company said its Sabre reservation system had been indicating that flights were sold out when in fact seats were available. [ D3. ] THE ECONOMY American marketing efforts in Japan were criticized by the U.S. Commerce Secretary, who is there on a trade mission. The comments appeared to reflect a growing frustration in the Administration that many U.S. companies have yet to take advantage of the weak dollar or of agreements with Japan to open its markets. [ D2. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Robert Maxwell is prepared to raise his bid for Macmillan to $84 a share, or $2.5 billion, subject to certain conditions. Macmillan's board was scheduled to meet Saturday, but it made no announcement. [ D1. ] Advertisers are retreating from mimicking popular singers in commercials, following an appellate court decision that the pop singer Bette Midler could proceed with a lawsuit against Ford and Young & Rubicam. [ D6. ] Journalists have an unpleasant surprise in the trade agreement between the U.S. and Canada: tougher standards to determine who qualifies for privileged immigration status. [ D6. ] Corporations are waging a costly contest over Olympic tie-ins in Seoul, South Korea. The rivalries seem to be an outgrowth of the commercialization of the Olympic Games in the 1980's. [ D6. ] Jack the Ripper is the subject of a co-production arrangement by CBS, Lorimar Television and Thames Television. [ D6. ] Elkman has become the agency for Friendly Ice Cream, which recently came under new ownership. Advertising. [ D7. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT China is getting a crash course in consumer protection as a delegation of four Chinese officials is visiting consumer organizations, businesses and a government agency in the U.S. [ D1. ] A mood of optimism prevails in Curacao as new enterprises are starting to blossom. [ D8. ] A step toward a successor to the Concorde has been taken by a consortium of nine European aeronautics companies. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Owners of small businesses may achieve significant tax savings if they liquidate and distribute assets by year-end. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] Freight railroads in the U.S. are having an excellent year, helped by a surge in grain and coal shipments. Market Place. [ D4. ] Interest rates are likely to remain near their new lower levels for a while longer, in the view of analysts. Credit Markets. [ D5. ]

title: Yonkers Case Poses Tough Questions
description: The bitter brinksmanship between Yonkers and a Federal judge has brought national attention this summer to that city's housing desegregation case. Despite the drama, though, it remains unclear whether the city's apparent capitulation Saturday morning will produce a significant legal or political precedent.

title: A Burmese Power Shift; Though Government Schedules Election, Decision Rests With People in the Streets
description: The Burmese Government has scheduled general elections, as a leading opposition figure did separately a few days earlier, but it is the people in the streets, where political power now seems to be, who will decide whether the elections can proceed.

title: Pantera's Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: b-Includes a charge from store closings of $2,800,000. c-Net income Figures for 1988 include the results of Pizza Inn Inc., which was acquired in July 1987.

title: Perry Drug Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes losses of about $6,000,000 attributable to a decrease in gross margins, and an additional $4,000,000 reserve for uncollectable receivables from health care providers for the quarter and the 9 months included a loss from discontinued operations of $14,240,000 and a tax credit of $1,800,000. c-Net income

title: Newlywed Magazine To Begin in February
description: There are magazines aplenty for women and quite a few for men. There are magazines for brides and magazines for parents. But what about the just married? Don't they have problems, too? 3/C Publishing in Westport, Conn., believes it can help and in February will begin its Newlywed, to be published three times a year.

title: Burma Fixes Timing of Vote, But Opposition May Resist
description: The Burmese Parliament set a three-month deadline today for multiparty elections that were announced on Saturday, but there were growing signs that the opposition would not accept elections administered by the ruling party.

title: William Carter Memorial
description: A memorial tribute to William Carter, formerly a leading dancer with the New York City Ballet, American Ballet Theater and the Martha Graham Dance Company, is to be held on Sept. 20 at 11 A.M. in the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the Performing Arts Library at Lincoln Center. Mr. Carter died on July 28 at age 56.

title: Rates May Hold Steady for a Bit
description: Interest rates are likely to remain close to their new, lower levels for a while longer, in the view of credit market analysts, buttressed by extremely favorable technical conditions and the likelihood that new economic data will continue to suggest slower growth.

title: Power Demand Requires A Shoreham That Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Lorimar Joins Thames to Unmask 'Jack the Ripper'
description: A co-production arrangement by CBS, Lorimar Television and Great Britain's Thames Television - the first between Thames and a commercial American television producer -will bring an international audience to the latest unmasking of the world's best-known unknown killer, Jack the Ripper.

title: New Offer By Maxwell To Macmillan
description: The British entrepreneur Robert Maxwell said last week that he was prepared to raise his offer for Macmillan Inc. to $84 a share, or $2.5 billion, subject to certain conditions. He had offered $80 a share for the New York-based publishing company, which has also been resisting a takeover attempt by the Robert M. Bass Group Inc.

title: Pope Urges More International Help for Africa
description: On the second day of a visit to the world's poorest continent, Pope John Paul II called today for a redoubling of international efforts against hunger, poverty and disease in Africa.

title: Review/Concert; Dvorak in the Cathedral
description: The Romantic movement was in decline a century ago, but its weight still sits uncomfortably on us all. Living composers seeking their own languages resent, with some justification, its arrogance, its exaggerations, its proselytizing of heroes, its celebrations of selfishness. Most of all, however, they resent their inability to find overshadowing alternatives.

title: Curacao Battles Island Economics
description: A few years ago, when it became clear that Curacao's oil refinery, ship-repair center and its international finance companies were going into a tailspin, the leading business executives on this little Dutch island organized the Curacao Action Group to try to preserve one of the highest living standards in the Caribbean.

title: Imex Medical Systems reports earnings for Year to June 30
Wilson Foods Accepts Offer
description: The Wilson Foods Corporation has agreed to be acquired by a subsidiary of the IFM Group, an international processor of meat and fish.

title: Rally for Biaggi Draws Criticism of Its Timing
description: Fond words and sentimental Irish ballads were typical fare at a rally yesterday in the Bronx honoring Mario Biaggi, who was convicted on felony charges twice in the last year and a half, and last month resigned as New York City's senior Congressman.

title: Lower New York Milk Prices Face New Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Thorn EMI Sets Successor For Its Retiring Chairman
description: Thorn EMI P.L.C., the British electronics conglomerate, has named Colin Southgate chairman, effective next February. He is to succeed Sir Graham Wilkins, chairman since 1985, who will be 65 in January.

title: Hometown Plays Down Graf's Triumph
description: ''We have been spoiled by Steffi's success, so it came as no great surprise'' said Gunther Reffert, the mayor of the little West German town of Bruhl, trying to explain why the 14,000 townspeople didn't give a regal welcome to the homecoming queen of tennis, Steffi Graf.

title: Accounts
description: * Procter & Gamble to Lally, McFarland & Pantello for professional advertising for Richardson Vicks Pediatric Formula 44 and Children's Nyquil.

title: Soviets Buy More Corn
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 350,000 metric tons of United States corn for delivery in the coming year, the Agriculture Department said Friday. The sale brought the total of corn sold to the Soviet Union in the last nine days to more than 2.6 million tons. The corn is for delivery in the 1988-89 year, which started on Sept. 1

title: Vice Chairman Named At Newmont Mining
description: The Newmont Mining Company, having gone through an upheaval as the result of a takeover bid, plans to relocate to Denver from Manhattan as a smaller company, and Richard P. Leather will be making the move as Newmont's new vice chairman.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: If Frank Viola of the Minnesota Twins in the American League and Danny Jackson of the Cincinnati Reds in the National are voted the Cy Young awards in their leagues, will it be the first time left-handers won the pitching honor in the same year?

title: NBC News Dismisses 110 Employees
description: In the final stage of a long-term drive to cut its budget and eliminate jobs, NBC News is giving notice to 110 news employees that their jobs will be terminated by the end of the year.

title: Pittsburgh Recalls A Neglected Title
description: Under a dying summer sky, a band of aging black men stared at their championship pennant flying above Three Rivers Stadium, a fluttering reminder of the last Negro League World Series ever played.

title: EAC Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a gain of $1.1 million from discontinued operations. c-After a gain of $1,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,039,000.

title: 49ers Jolt Giants In Final Seconds
description: With less than a minute and a half left in their game against San Francisco this afternoon, it seemed as if the Giants might escape with a victory, despite a flawed performance.

title: Opera Ball Draws San Francisco's Bejeweled Elite
description: Going to the opera with an armed bodyguard is not the usual thing to do in San Francisco, but that was the social duty carried out by 16 of San Francisco's most prominent women Friday night.

title: Lafleur Scores in Return
description: Guy Lafleur made an impressive debut with the Rangers today. He scored a goal on his first day of training camp in his attempt for a comeback after a four-year absence from the National Hockey League.

title: Marcade Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $306,000 and $1,328,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; $269,000 and $909,000 in preferred dividend payments for the same periods, respectively; and the 6 months include a pretax gain of $1,255,000 from the sale of property. c-Includes a tax credit of $596,000 and $1,380,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; $169,000 and $458,000 in preferred dividend payments for the same periods, respectively; a gain of $598,000 on debt restructuring for both periods; and a pretax gain of $1,565,000 for both periods from the sale of property.

title: Traditional Industries reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split, effected June 29, 1988.

title: Federal Phone Contract
description: The General Services Administration said Friday that it had set a new deadline of Dec. 10 for awarding a much-disputed contract to build a new telecommunications system for the Federal Government. The agency had previously delayed the contract on the FTS-2000 system indefinitely.

title: Software Bug Cost Millions At Airline
description: A computer glitch in American Airlines Inc.'s passenger reservation system may have cost the company as much as $50 million in lost ticket revenue in the second quarter.

title: 'Last Temptation' Stirs Widening Bigotry
description: To the Editor:

title: Citicorp to Buy Texas Credit Card Business
description: Citicorp will acquire the credit card business of the former First Republicbank Corporation from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for $159 million.

title: U.S. Financings Confined to Bill Market
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, starting with today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills.

title: Wilander Outlasts Lendl to Win U.S. Open
description: In retrospect, this was the perfect setting for Mats Wilander to erase any lingering doubts that he lacked the courage or desire expected of the No. 1 player in the world. The United States Open is more than a tennis tournament, it is a survival course, two weeks of constant distractions that test the mental, as well as the physical mettle of the top players in the world. Flushing Meadows is not a place for the faint of heart, Wilander had heard, or for a Swede.

title: Brae Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The latest 6 months' loss included a provision for restructuring of $1,818,000, a provision for inventory obsolescence of $750,000, and charges of about $2,250,000 related to a leased and owned trailer fleet. The latest 6 months also included revenue of $3,035,000 related to the satisfaction of the remaining obligation under an expired option agreement to purchase the company's railcar leasing and management subsidiary. The year-ago 6 months' loss included various unusual charges and included income of $1,175,000 related to the expired option agreement.

title: Fidelity National Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The third-quarter results for 1988 included the operations of Fidelity National Title Insurance Company of California, formerly known as Western Title Insurane Company.

title: Amrep Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,500,000, or 53 cents a share, from an accounting change. Year-ago results are restated for accounting changes.

title: Consumer Protection 101 for Chinese
description: As China moves toward an economy driven more by consumer demand than by central planners, its leaders have begun to recognize that greater consumer choice also requires greater consumer protection.

title: Karastan Bigelow Picks North Carolina Agency
description: Karastan Bigelow, the carpet people who recently moved their headquarters to Greensboro, N.C., from New York, have now moved their advertising account to the South as well.

title: Confusion Causes a Run
description: A case of mistaken identity spurred a $2 million run on a Chinatown savings institution last week. Hundreds of customers lined up Thursday at the Elmhurst Federal Savings and Loan Association to withdraw money after confusing the association with a financially troubled bank in the suburb of Elmhurst. The assets of that institution, the United Security Bank, were recently frozen by a judge. ''The headline was, 'Elmhurst Bank Fails,' '' said David G. Plummer, president of Elmhurst Federal Savings. ''I think many of our customers don't even know there's a town named Elmhurst.''

title: Driving in New York: The Agony of Victory
description: The longer she waited on line at the Department of Motor Vehicles, the more Anne Duke wished she had learned to drive as a teen-ager, as people in other cities do.

title: Volt Information Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Included a $5,355,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change and a loss on the sale of securities of $244,000, compared to a gain on the sale of securities of $1,544,000, or 15 cents a share, in the year-ago 9 months. c-Included a pre-tax profit of $352,000 and $2,734,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, on the settlement of an insurance claim arising from a fire loss in a foreign branch; the 9 months also included a $3,165,000 charge from the redemption of debt.

title: Mini-Computer Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Healthwatch Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
Bell, W & Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 25

title: Planning a Musical Pastiche By a Rarely Heard Master
description: In a certain sense all of Marc Blitzstein's music is ''rarely heard,'' since he is one of those composers whose artistic credo and place in history are far better known than his actual scores. But ''The Harpies'' and ''I've Got the Tune'' are true rarities, even for Blitzstein enthusiasts. They are short dramatic works, composed in 1931 and 1937 respectively; the first is a satirical bit of neo-classicism in what has been described as a ''soft Stravinsky'' idiom, the second a ''radio song-play'' with autobiographical overtones about a composer who finds his purpose in writing labor-union songs.

title: A Campaign That Was Destined for the Gutter
description: LEAD: Is this year's Presidential campaign exceptionally negative?

title: Adviser to Bush Quits G.O.P. Post Amid Anti-Semitism Allegations
description: A high-level adviser to Vice President Bush resigned from a senior position at the Republican National Committee today after acknowledging that he had drawn up a list of important Jewish officials at the Bureau of Labor Statistics at the behest of President Richard M. Nixon in 1971.

title: Doremus to Advertise G.E. Aircraft Engines
description: Next Monday Doremus & Company will break its first advertising campaign for G.E.'s aircraft engines operation, which in 18 years has become one of the major producers of commercial engines. The ad theme is ''Keeping the Promise.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; The First Constitution
description: In the mid-16th century, five northeastern Indian tribes - Mohawk, Seneca, Onondaga, Oneida and Cayugaa - formed the Iroquois Confederacy, joined later by the Tuscarora tribe. They adopted a constitution, reflecting concepts of checks and balances and separation of powers that impressed such later Americans as Washington, Franklin and other Founding Fathers. Indeed, historians maintain that many principles of the Iroquois constitution were woven into the United States Constitution.

title: Correction
description: A subheading with an article in Business Day last Monday about the Village Gate nightclub misstated the club's hours. It is not open all night; it closes at 3 A.M.

title: 2 Recount '48 Killing in Israel
description: Two former guerrillas of an underground Jewish group once led by Yitzhak Shamir have said that they assassinated a United Nations peace envoy 40 years ago.

title: Takeover Battle For Donnay
description: An investor group headed by a French entrepreneur said it would continue to pursue the bankrupt Belgian tennis racquet maker Donnay S.A.

title: Bloomingdale's Airport Plans
description: Bloomingdale's said yesterday that it had agreed with Host International Inc. to expand the number of Bloomies Express shops in airports across the United States.

title: Forstmann & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Net income Forstmann said it increased its LIFO provision by $7 million in the latest second quarter to recognize the impact that higher wool prices had on inventory amounts. The company said it also incurred a one-time expense of $1.1 million in the latest second quarter to account for an early retirement program and increased charges for professional fees, interest anticipation charges, doubtful accounts and sales commissions.

title: Tektronix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 20
description: b-Affected by two unusual charges which reduced income by $6,538,000, or 19 cents a share. Those charges were related to embezzlement and fraud in the company's German subsidiary and to the decision to move some operations from California and Texas to Oregon.

title: Savings Drain Continues
description: Deposits flowed out of the nation's savings institutions for the third consecutive month in July, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said last week.

title: Ambrit Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $299,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $1,016,000 for the quarter and $603,000 for the 6 months. The latest 6 months included a pre- tax gain of $7,055,000 from a settlement of Ambrit's litigation with Kraft Inc.

title: Back to Basics for a Running Shoe
description: A technology race among athletic shoe manufacturers tends to foster an annual array of new versions, especially during an Olympic year.

title: Bridge
description: Bridge has been played in some unusual circumstances, including prisoner-of-war camps and, from this writer's personal experience, a school roof by moonlight. But major matches hardly ever stray from clubs, hotels and convention centers.

title: In Judging Polls, What Counts Is When and How Who Is Asked What
description: The high season for public opinion polls has arrived once again, and with it, quite a bit of public confusion about their meaning. Expectations of a close Presidential contest in 1988, combined with a proliferation of polling organizations in recent years, all but guarantee that each week of the fall campaign will see the release of several new polls, telling somewhat different stories.

title: Upshaw Inquiry Reported
description: The National Football League Players Association is reportedly being investigated by the United States Department of Labor for possible illegal activities, The Boston Sunday Globe said today.

title: Agency Rent-A-Car Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Senate Veep Creep
description: What's the most important qualification for a Vice-Presidential candidate?

title: Bus Crashes After Driver Dies
description: James Maxwell, 60 years old, a Greyhound bus driver, collapsed apparently of a heart attack Friday and died at the wheel, sending his bus crashing into several trees on a freeway median while a passenger tried to bring it under control. Three people were injured. Richard Lee Stallings of Wake Forest, N.C., a passenger, saw Mr. Maxwell collapse, grabbed the steering wheel and was able to keep the bus from veering into oncoming traffic, said Trooper P. E. Israel of the Virginia State Police.

title: Addendum
description: * Family Handyman will increase its circulation 6.5 percent, to 1,275,000, and its ad rate 5 percent with the January issue.

title: Deltak Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Home Federal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Outdoors: Natural Baits
description: ALTHOUGH there are relatively few species of game and food fish that cannot be consistently caught with a lure, there are times, if you are willing to go to the trouble, when the real thing is much more productive.

title: Bottle Law Reduces Litter But Irks Many
description: Five years after New York began requiring a five cent deposit on all beverage bottles and cans sold in the state, experts say the law has had a dramatic impact in reducing litter and waste.

title: Nobody Is Perfect
description: What do you do when the candidate you support takes a position you don't like? Conversely, what do you do when the candidate you oppose takes a stand that you admire?

title: Sri Lanka, Bowing to a Tamil Rebel Demand, Merges 2 Provinces
description: President J. R. Jayewardene has by executive order merged Sri Lanka's Northern and Eastern Provinces, meeting a major demand of ethnic Tamil militants fighting for a homeland.

title: ACC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $50,381 and $165,282 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes net from discontinued operations of $12,256 and $47,032 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Resignation at MGM Pictures
description: The MGM/UA Communications Company said yesterday that Alan Ladd Jr., a director of the company and the chairman and chief executive of MGM Pictures, had resigned.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's like trying to put a line around a hurricane.'' - Arnold Hartigan of the Interagency Fire Center, which is trying to control forest fires in the West. [ A1:6. ]

title: Majority of Challengers Favoring Free Air Time
description: While Congressional candidates have shown little hesitation about buying costly television commercials, a majority of challengers say broadcasters should be required to provide free television time to campaigns. But among incumbents, only a minority agree.

title: BLACK FAMILY UNIT PROMOTED IN DRIVE
description: More than 90,000 people came to the Washington Mall this weekend as the National Council of Negro Women concluded its summer drive for a stronger black family.

title: Six Days and Counting: Excitement Builds in Seoul
description: Almost two years ago, the day after the 1986 Asian Games ended here, big neon signs overlooking the organized mayhem of Seoul's central districts began counting down the days before the start of the XXIV Olympic Games.

title: U.S. to Complete Emergency Radio Network
description: The Air Force has quietly approved the final construction phase for a nuclear ''doomsday'' radio network, concluding that the project can be expanded without harming the environment.

title: Russ Togs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $599,000 and $1,103,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations, and both periods also include a loss of $1,290,000 from disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income d-Included losses of $269,000 and $391,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations.

title: BBDO Names New York Chief
description: Philip B. Dusenberry, 52-year-old chairman and chief creative officer of BBDO, New York, the largest office in the $3 billion-plus ad agency, has been named chief executive.

title: Interco Gets Alternative Bid As Earlier Bid Is Extended
description: An investor group has extended its previously announced tender offer for Interco Inc. and made a new bid under which stockholders would receive $72 a share if the investors are allowed to review confidential information related to the company's announced recapitalization proposal.

title: Reviews/Television; Bill Moyers Examines Public Issues
description: Beginning tonight at 11 P.M., and running every weeknight on Channel 13 for the next couple of months, Bill Moyers will be presiding over ''World of Ideas.'' The series is intended to provide a ''talking heads'' format for people with ideas and vision and insight.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Trade Balance 2d Qtr. Wednesday Merchandise Trade July Thursday Industrial Production August Retail Sales August Friday Capacity Utilization August Inventory-Sales Ratio July

title: 3-Point Competition
description: For set shooters who are a step too slow, gym rats who have worn out basketball nets quicker than socks and playground legends who have startled more than one defender with a 35-foot jump shot, Al Holtje has a tournament for you.

title: Sentimental Journey
description: A small band of people from the Mets took time out from the cares of the pennant race not long ago in Los Angeles and made a kind of pilgrimage back in time and spirit. They drove to Glendale, the suburb where Casey Stengel reigned as the oracle of baseball for 60 years and where he died 13 years ago this month.

title: Newcor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Handicapped by Charges, Ohrenstein Runs
description: In the bright sunshine of a West Side park, Manfred Ohrenstein went from bench to bench defending himself Saturday, but Laura Nathan was having none of it.

title: Marcy Goodwin Is Bride Of Edgar Peters Bowron
description: The marriage of Marcy Goodwin, a museum architectural consultant, to Edgar Peters Bowron, the Elizabeth and John Moors Cabot director of the Harvard University Art Museums, took place yesterday in Beverly Hills, Calif. The Rev. Akira Tairyo Hata, a Buddist priest, performed a nondenominational ceremony at Greystone Park.

title: No. 1 Ranking Gone, Lendl Feels 'Lousy'
description: Almost five hours had elapsed, and still Ivan Lendl, who enjoyed a lead for only 12 minutes of a marathon United States Open final, tried to hold on to what had been his for so long.

title: Racketeer Case Seen For Drexel
description: The criminal indictments that are expected against employees of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in October are likely to describe a broad pattern of criminal activity over at least a two-year period and may include charges of racketeering, people close to the investigation said.

title: Petroleum Helicopters Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CCX Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $383,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes gains from discontinued operations of $3,000,000 and $1,581,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Topics of The Times; San Francisco Revivals
description: New Yorkers accustomed to putting down San Francisco as provincial shouldn't feel so smug. A New York City movie fan reports that San Francisco, with a population of only 750,000, supports eight revival houses - compared with Manhattan's remaining four.

title: Old Dominion Systems reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Hong Kong Journal; Boat People Now Face Tide of Chinese Prejudice
description: The 23 Vietnamese children, neatly dressed in white shirts and blue shorts, the uniform of the old makeshift school in their refugee camp, stood out from the Chinese children who were dressed in the proper orange uniforms of the Cho Yiu Chuen Primary School.

title: PAMELA CLIFTON WEDS RAINER M. MALZBENDER
description: The Princeton University Chapel was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Pamela Marsha Clifton and Rainer Michael Malzbender, both 1979 graduates of Princeton. The Rev. Raymond Kostulias of the United Church of Christ officiated.

title: Review/Dance; A Manning Double Bill
description: David Manning and Suzanne White Manning collaborate on mixed-media theater pieces with a strong dance component. ''Lost,'' which concerns the 16th-century English colony that vanished from Roanoke Island, and ''Old Stones,'' inspired by Romanesque churches in Catalonia, make up the typically original program they will be presenting again Thursday through Saturday.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Turn to the Videotape
description: The Department of the Interior, finding itself in the middle of a dispute over a proposal to erect a sprawling shopping mall next to the Manassas (Bull Run) National Battlefield Park, turned to state of the art technology to make its case: It made a videotape for the press.

title: Cardinals Are Looking to Win Respect in Phoenix Opener
description: Fans knew what to expect. So did the team.

title: Suit Deters Ad Jingles That Mimic Singers
description: Realizing that imitation, however sincere, can be a dangerous form of flattery, commercial music producers are moving away from using the lyrical styles and vocal mannerisms of famous singers without giving credit or compensation.

title: Tax Watch; Small Businesses Face a Deadline
description: OWNERS of certain closely held corporations may achieve significant tax savings if they liquidate and distribute their companies' assets to shareholders or make other basic changes in their companies' structure before the end of the year. Jerry Joszef, tax manager for Laventhol & Horwath in New York, calls this perhaps the single most important tax-planning consideration of 1988 for owners of small businesses.

title: Review/Theater; Soviet Emigre's Parable
description: David Glikin, who was a playwright, actor and director in the Soviet Union before he came to live in New York six years ago, has a message for us in ''The Golden Leg,'' his first play to be done in America, at the Theater Guinevere. Unfortunately, the message, one that tells us about ruthlessness, avidity and anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union, is badly transmitted.

title: Reviews/Television; A Global Hookup on 13
description: The video artist Nam June Paik returned to Channel 13 on Saturday for another of his ambitious exercises in live global hookups. In 1984, Mr. Paik produced ''Good Morning, Mr. Orwell.'' In 1986, it was ''Bye Bye Kipling.'' This time, beginning at 10:30 in the morning, ''Wrap Around the World'' spent 90 minutes hopping among a total of 10 countries, including Ireland, Israel, China and the Soviet Union. As usual, much of the content was given a comic spin. But, as we all know by now, Mr. Paik is silly like a fox.

title: Forum Reinsurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflects a $1,096,363 expense incurred as the result of an unsolicited tender offer on March 16, from Forum Investments Ltd., a subsidiary of Forum Reinsurance Company Ltd. c-Net income

title: We Must Stop Backing Environmental Ruin
description: To the Editor:

title: Thortec International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Editorial; The Naval Gap in the Persian Gulf
description: The Navy played a critical role in ending the Iran-Iraq war. By blocking Iran's move to intimidate Iraq's allies in the Persian Gulf, it reinforced the stalemate that led Iran to the negotiating table. Over all, the Navy performed a difficult mission with distinction. But there are lessons to be learned from the various mishaps.

title: Intertrans Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Cuban Refugees Arrive in Miami To Joyous Welcome by Relatives
description: A total of 671 Cuban refugees who had waited for years in Costa Rica and Panama to join relatives in the United States arrived here today to the tumultuous welcome of their families.

title: Ojeda Keeps Mets on a Roll
description: The Mets kept rolling toward October with virtuoso pitching today when Bob Ojeda stopped the Montreal Expos, 3-0, for his fifth shutout of the season and the Mets' 22d.

title: KURDS' SYMPTOMS: GAS OR POOR DIET?
description: His name was Mehmet and he was 3 years old, a sad-faced, sandy-haired little boy without shoes and in need of a good scrubbing.

title: Cardinal Faults Recent Beatings Of Gay People
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, who is often the target of gay protesters himself, yesterday condemned recent beatings of homosexuals as stupid, ignorant and malicious, saying that those who perpetuate violence against homosexuals ''are doing violence against Christ Himself.''

title: Yanks Defeat Tigers In 18th
description: The game had stretched into its sixth hour, and day had slipped into night. For the Yankees, the wait was agonizing and exasperating. It took just an electric instant for the wait to be worth it as well.

title: Europe Looks Beyond the Concorde
description: A consortium of nine European aeronautics companies has taken a step toward developing a successor to the supersonic Concorde airliner, but the goal of building a much faster version of the sleek plane remains distant and elusive.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF United States Takes Team Event: The United States, led by Carol Thompson and Pearl Sinn, defeated Sweden by one stroke yesterday to win the women's World Amateur Golf Team Championship in Stockholm. The victory was the 10th in 13 championships for the United States, which finished third two years ago in Caracas, Venezuela.(AP) Woosnam Wins European Open: Ian Woosnam of Wales scored won the European Open in Sunningdale, England, yesterday. He broke the course record by six strokes with a 20-under-par 260, closing with a final-round 65 to beat Nick Faldo of Britain by three strokes to win $85,000.(AP) Another Victory for Green: Ken Green swept to a six-stroke victory yesterday in the $700,000 Greater Milwaukee Open. Green, who set a course record with an 11-under-par 61 Saturday at the Tuckaway Country Club in Franklin, Wis., shot a 68 yesterday for a 72-hole score of 20-under 268 that won him the $126,000 first prize.(AP) AUTO RACING Ferrari Stops McLaren-Honda: Gerhard Berger of Austria and Michele Alboreto of Italy scored a 1-2 triumph for the Ferrari team in the Italian Formula One Grand Prix yesterday in Monza, Italy, ending an eight-race winning streak of the powerful McLaren-Honda..(AP) Fittipaldi Wins Again: Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil won a battle of fuel management as well as the CART Road America 200 Indy-car race yesterday at Elkart Lake, Wis., to charge into contention for the season driver's title. Fittipaldi won his second race in eight days and now has 100 points, 28 less than leader Danny Sullivan. Fittipaldi parlayed good fuel mileage with some crafty driving for his sixth career victory. Driving a Chevrolet-powered Lola, he averaged a record 122.215 miles an hour, breaking the mark of 120.155 set by Mario Andretti, last year's winner. Andretti was third, trailing Bobby Rahal.(AP) Allison Takes Miller 400: Davey Allison exceeded $1 million in career winnings with a victory yesterday in the Miller 400, the first Winston Cup event at the new Richmond International Raceway in Virginia. Allison, who started on the pole in his Ford Thunderbird, averaged 95.770 miles an hour. His margin of victory was 3.25 seconds over Dale Earnhardt.(AP) HORSE RACING Blew by Em Wins: Blew by Em scored a two-length victory yesterday in the $121,000 Lawrence Realization for 3-year-olds at Belmont Park. Carrying 114 pounds and ridden by Chris Antley, Blew by Em went a mile and a half on the firm Widener Turf Course in 2:27 1/5 to record his fourth victory in 13 career starts. Colchis Island was second in the field of 10. Blew by Em earned $72,600 for Joseph Singer and returned $10.60 for $2 to win. Ballindaggin Earns $600,000: Ballindaggin, ridden by Jose Santos, held off Regal Classic in a furious stretch drive yesterday to win the first running of the $1 million Molson Export Challenge for 3-year-olds at Woodbine in Toronto. Ballindaggin won by a half-length. Cefis finished third, 1 1/2 lengths behind Regal Classic. Owned by George Layman Jr. of Yakima, Wash., Ballindaggin was sent off at 7-1 and ran the distance in 2:04 3/5. He paid $17.80 for $2 to win. The victory, Ballindaggin's first this year in eight starts, was worth $600,000 and raised his 1988 earnings to $659,218. DOG SHOW Bedlington Terrier Is Best: The top-winning Bedlington terrier in the history of the breed, Ch. Willow Wind Centurion, owned by David Ramsey, Mary Silkworth and Allan Sheimo, was named best of 2,383 dogs yesterday at the 71st Westchester Kennel Club Show at Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, N.Y. It was the 47th major award for the blue dog.

title: Solidarity's Latest Tactic: Legalization Before Talks
description: The national Solidarity leadership, meeting here to plan strategy for talks with the Polish authorities, today accelerated efforts to put pressure on the Government to recognize the outlawed union.

title: INSIDE
description: Hong Kong Ethnic Tension The colony's Chinese population has reacted angrily to the admission of 23 children of Vietnamese refugees to a local school. Page A4. Solidarity Leaders Meet The national leadership of the banned union called for recognition from the Polish Government. Page A3. Concession by Sri Lanka Sri Lanka has merged two provinces, meeting a major demand of Tamil militants seeking autonomy. Page A3. Sucess for Bottle Law In five years, New York's bottle-deposit law has had a dramatic effect on reducing litter and waste. Page. B1. How to Read a Poll It is the high season for public opinion polling. Why do the polls tell different stories? Page A16.

title: A Sunday of Prayer, Hope and Anger
description: A black clergyman and a white City Councilman, calling for racial reconciliation, joined black worshippers today in singing the civil rights anthem ''We Shall Overcome'' at the morning service in the Messiah Baptist Church, in a mood of relief at the easing of the city's desegregation crisis.

title: Edd Bailey Dies at 83; Once Headed Railroad
description: Edd H. Bailey, who worked his way up from a helper in the car repair shop to president of the Union Pacific Railroad, died Sunday in Cheyenne, Wyo. He was 83 years old.

title: Subaru of America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Unusual Swan Song For Retiring Senator
description: Senator Robert T. Stafford, a New Englander of few words, today began an unusual swan song for a retiring member of Congress.

title: Interpharm Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said that during the first half of 1988, sales of Native Beta Interferon, which account for 70 percent of its sales, totaled $6.1 million, 27 percent higher than the comparable period in 1987. The company also said sales of Human Growth Hormone began in the first half of 1988 and amounted to $1.7 million.

title: Sports People; Tests for Ashe
description: Arthur Ashe, the former United States Open and Wimbledon champion, was listed in satisfactory condition at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center yesterday and said he hoped to be released by the end of the week. He was admitted last Thursday after feeling numbness in his hands while attending the United States Open at Flushing Meadows.

title: Ethiopia Says It Halted Eritrean Rebel Drive
description: President Mengistu Haile Mariam said today that Government forces in northern Ethiopia had halted an offensive by separatist guerrillas based in Eritrea Province.

title: India, Breaking Its Silence, Backs Government Opponents in Burma
description: India has thrown its support behind the opposition forces in Burma and broken a monthlong silence on the uprising shaking its eastern neighbor.

title: Indiana Federal Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
description: Seeking to end four months of takeover turmoil, Macmillan Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to a leveraged buyout offer of $85 a share, or more than $2.2 billion, from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: Buyback at Lotus
description: The Lotus Development Corporation said it would repurchase up to 15 percent, or about 6.7 million shares, of its common stock outstanding. The shares of the company, based in Cambridge, rose $1 each today, to $18, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Home Loan Banks To Set Bond Prices
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks plan to price today a total of $3.6 billion in bonds consisting of a one-year floating-rate issue, a one-year fixed-rate issue, a three-year issue and a five-year security that features an optional principal redemption, meaning that it is callable after a specified period of time. In this case, bond holders have the option of redeeming the issue in three years.

title: RESTART APPROVED AT NUCLEAR PLANT
description: Federal regulators have decided that the staff managing the Pilgrim nuclear power plant is ready to handle a restart under intense monitoring, an inspector said today. The Government ordered the plant shut down in 1986.

title: Standard Brands Paint Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $218,000 for the quarter and $585,000 for the 6 months.

title: Japan to Remove Sanctions Against North Korea
description: Just four days before the start of the Olympic Games in Seoul, Japan said today that it would lift a package of sanctions against North Korea. The sanctions were imposed earlier this year after the bombing last November of a South Korean jet in which 115 people died.

title: Games, for Once
description: The summer Olympics have for years been blemished by political posturing and even bloodshed, grievously compromising the innocent ideals of athletic competition. Yet with any luck, the Games of the XXIV Olympiad starting in South Korea this week will be just that: games, in which the only competitors are athletes - not nations, ideologies or causes.

title: Morgan Stanley C.M.O. Offer Has Backing of Fannie Mae
description: Morgan Stanley Mortgage Trust 29 is making a public offering of $498.19 million in collateralized mortgage obligations divided into nine parts. Morgan Stanley & Company is sole manager of the issue. The C.M.O.'s, which are backed by Federal National Mortgage Association certificates having a weighted average coupon of about 10 percent and weighted average to maturity of 29.58 years, carry a triple-A rating by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Trans Leasing International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
George Alpert, 90, Ex-President Of New Haven Line and a Lawyer
description: George Alpert, the former president of the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad Company, which served the northeast corridor until 1969, died of pneumonia Sunday at his home in Cohasset, Mass. He was 90 years old.

title: Comnet Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: The Cleveland Browns, who lost two quarterbacks in the first two weeks of the season have signed Don Strock to a one-year contract according to his agent, Jerry Kapstein. Strock, a veteran of 14 seasons after being drafted in the fifth round by the Miami Dolphins, is believed to have signed for $480,000 plus incentive bonuses and was expected to report last night. The Dolphins relinquished his rights after he didn't sign after training camp. . . . When the 19th New York City Marathon is run through the five boroughs on Nov. 6, Ibrahim Hussein of Kenya will defend his title, according to Fred Lebow, the race director. Hussein, who lives in Albuquerque, N.M., became the first African to win the race when he won the event last year in 2 hours 11 minnutes 1 second.

title: Metro Datelines; Writ Is Left in Place Against Rail Union
description: A Federal judge left a temporary restraining order in place yesterday against Metro-North Commuter Railroad track workers who staged a brief strike last week.

title: Fabricland Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for inventory of $420,000.
