Books of The Times; News, From 'Acta Diurna' to Modern Media
description: A History of News From the Drum to the Satellite By Mitchell Stephens 401 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $24.95.

title: Investors Request Session With Grow
description: A group consisting of the Massachusetts Bank & Trust Company of Brockton, Mass., and the investor Edward S. Buchanan, which holds 7.7 percent of the Grow Group Inc., has asked to meet with management to discuss a possible acquisition after PPG Industries terminated a $300 million offer.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What star or standard is used when rating the apparent brightness of stars? A. Ancient astronomers first relied on their own eyes in comparing the brightness of stars and classified them in six orders of magnitude, each about two and a half times as bright as the next.

title: Akorn Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $26,348 for the quarter; the year includes a gain on the sale of an affiliate of $5,453,788. c-Includes a tax benefit of $37,262 and $132,950 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said its latest year sales and earnings contain 6 months of results from the acquisition of Spectrum Scientific Pharmaceuticals Inc.

title: Brain Transplants
description: Researchers have transplanted sections of embryonic quail brains into the brains of chick embryos; when they hatched, five of the chicks crowed like a quail.

title: Group Is Cleared On Kroger Shares
description: A partnership controlled by the Haft family of Washington has received Federal clearance to buy up to 15 percent of the Kroger Company. The termination of a 30-day waiting period, required by the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act, was confirmed by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Record Sales at Jaguar
description: The luxury car maker Jaguar P.L.C. said today that it had achieved a record monthly sales total in August,with 5,781 cars being sold worldwide. This was nearly 11 percent higher in volume terms than the previous record month, August 1987. A Jaguar spokeswoman said the group's sales in the first eight months climbed 8.4 percent, to 33,631 vehicles, from 31,018 in the 1987 period. American sales fell, however, to 13,081 cars, from 14,148 in the 1987 period.

title: Defeat Has Giants Still Wondering
description: The atmosphere in the Giants' locker room was discernably downbeat this afternoon. Most of the players remained off limits to reporters, either in the lounge area or the training room, while others dressed quietly in front of their stalls.

title: Campaign Trails; Future Reagan Digs An 'Ordinary' Estate
description: Vice President Bush and Michael S. Dukakis are eager to move into 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. And the current occupants - at least Mrs. Reagan - seems just as eager to move out to their new, $2.5 million Bel-Air estate, which is nestled in the shadows of the ''Beverly Hillbillies'' television mansion. For his part, the President has always preferred the ranch near Santa Barbara to the glitz of Hollywood.

title: Sri Lanka Capital Becomes City of Fear
description: A sudden, silent campaign of intimidation and terror closed down this capital city Monday. Residents of Colombo, who have tasted much bitterness and violence in the last few years, say they have never experienced anything like this.

title: System Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 24
description: The company said its latest quarter results were adversely affected by the limited availability of its top-of-the- line 1.1 Gigabyte data storage product.

title: U.S. AND ALLIES ASK U.N. TO SEND TEAM TO KURDISH AREAS
description: The United States and several of its allies asked the Secretary General of the United Nations today to send an investigative team to Iraq to determine whether the armed forces there used poison gas against Kurdish guerrillas, diplomats said.

title: Jury Selection Starts In Trial of Preacher Accused of Murder
description: A minister went on trial today on charges of beheading a handyman and burning down his church in an alleged attempt to assume a new identity and disappear with $50,000 in church money.

title: Metro Datelines; Union Votes to Stay On Strike at N.Y.U.
description: Clerks on strike at New York University voted yesterday to continue their 15-day-old walkout.

title: Monsanto Stock Plunges on Copper-7 Case
description: The price of the Monsanto Company's shares plunged $7.125 today, after a jury decision against the company's G.D. Searle subsidiary over its Copper-7 intrauterine birth-control device.

title: Helms Objects
description: Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who has been at odds with the State Department for years, is raising last-minute obstacles to the legislative confirmation of several nominees for ambassadorships, according to knowledgeable Senate officials.

title: Bush, in Reagan Style, Drops Script and Assails Dukakis's Foreign Policy
description: With a kind of swaggering rhetoric reminiscent of President Reagan, Vice President Bush spent the day trying to show that he would be a more forceful President than Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.

title: Nichols Tries to Put the Fun Back in 'Godot'
description: Mike Nichols is talking about ''Waiting for Godot'':

description: b-Net loss

description: b-Net loss

title: Chaos And Control
description: Two months ago the U.S.S. Vincennes, a cruiser equipped with the technologically advanced Aegis system of radar detection and electronic fire control, mistakenly shot down an Iranian passenger jet in the Persian Gulf, causing the loss of 290 lives.

title: Patterns
description: Fashionable Cashmere

title: Results Plus
description: Horse Racing Las Manitas Triumphs: Las Manitas came from just off the pace entering the stretch to take the lead and went on to a convincing eight-length victory yesterday in the $41,000 Polite Lady purse for fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Belmont Park.

title: Small Agency Helps a Great Power Lighten Human Suffering
description: When the devastation and human misery are so large - 25 million Bangladeshis homeless from floods covering an area almost three times the size of New Jersey - the generous efforts of even the richest friend may seem minuscule.

title: I.B.M. Deal With Steve Jobs Seen
description: Two bitter enemies in the computer industry have reportedly called a truce and are about to embark on an extraordinary joint business venture.

title: Bethlehem Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chileans Will at Last Have a Vote on Pinochet; Prejudiced Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Spaghetti Warehouse reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Xerox Campaign Will Start Saturday
description: Another TV commercial treat scheduled to make its debut Saturday during the NBC coverage of the Olympic Games is the new campaign from Xerox. The intention is to remind the business community that Xerox manufactures a whole line of document-processing equipment in addition to its famous copiers.

title: Voodoo Voters
description: Everybody is being analyzed and criticized in this Presidential election except the voters and the non-voters, who are performing in their usual mysterious ways. Vice President Bush is trying to persuade them by trickery and Governor Dukakis by evasion, and they do so for the simple reason that they think it works.

title: Bold Experiment in Lakes Tracks the Relentless Toll of Acid Rain
description: LEAD: DESPITE its utilitarian name, Lake 302, ringed by bedrock outcrops, by jack pine and spruce, is as beautiful as any of thousands of lakes that dot western Ontario. But no one is flying a floatplane in to fish here or buying waterfront property for a cottage. The lake's water is acidic and its ecosystem is in rapid decline.

title: Willis Grandy Lipscomb, Airline Executive, 87
description: Willis Grandy Lipscomb, a former airline executive, died of cardiac arrest Friday at his home in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 87 years old.

title: Lafleur Dispelling Doubts
description: Guy Lafleur displayed enough glimpses of brilliance in his first two days of his comeback attempt to become a serious candidate for a job with the Rangers.

title: Sports People; In Serious Condition
description: Hospital officials said that Hank Stram was still in serious but stable condition at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis yesterday after experiencing dizziness and being hospitalized on Saturday. The 65-year-old Stram, former coach of the Kansas City Chiefs and the New Orleans Saints, had been scheduled to broadcast the Dallas Cowboys-Phoenix Cardinals game last night on CBS radio, but was replaced as color commentator by Bill Wilkerson, from KMOX in St. Louis. A hospital spokesman said Stram had requested that no further information be released. (AP)

title: Careers; Accounting: A Dull Field? Guess Again
description: TO outsiders, accounting appears to be a quiet profession, seldom changing. But not these days.

title: Burrowing Missile to Be Built
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci has authorized the development of nuclear-tipped missiles with warheads that can burrow into the earth before detonating, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Charlie Palmieri, 60, Salsa Pianist And Leader in Jazz-Latin Fusion
description: Charlie Palmieri, one of the most important pianists in salsa, died of a heart attack yesterday at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx. He was 60 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Despite Scorched Earth and Parched Crops, Pockets of Plenty Can Be Found
description: They aren't easy to find, an agricultural expert was saying the other day. ''But this is a big country,'' he added, ''and if you get in your car and drive far enough you will find them. Most of the time you'll be looking at the scorched earth and parched crops, but if you keep going you'll find somebody who's doing real well.''

title: Cable TV Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $14,000 for the quarter and $18,000 for the 6 months, and tax credits of $42,000 and $110,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Sears-Pirelli Tire
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, said the Pirelli Tire Corporation, the United States subsidiary of Pirelli S.p.A. of Italy, would be the first manufacturer to have its tires sold at the retailer's tire centers. Beginning Oct. 1, more that 400 Sears stores will offer a limited range of Pirelli's radial tires. Pirelli Tire, based in San Jose, Calif., now has about 1.5 percent of the American market for replacement tires. Its president, David James, said the arrangement with the Chicago-based Sears would ''greatly increase Pirelli's distribution network.''

title: Sports of The Times; Graf's Misleading Reaction
description: THERE was a brief expression of joy, but Steffi Graf mostly looked relieved after winning the United States Open on Saturday to complete the Grand Slam. It had been a difficult two weeks, the 19-year-old West German admitted, because she was constantly reminded about the Slam, which many tennis fans and those in the news media said was a foregone conclusion. The irony was that when Graf finally fulfilled those expectations, what should have been a special moment was anticlimactic instead.

title: Robert Bedingfield, 72, Times Reporter, Is Dead
description: Robert E. Bedingfield, a business and financial news reporter and editor with The New York Times for 23 years until his retirement in 1976, died of leukemia Sunday at Addison Gilbert Hospital in Gloucester, Mass. He was 72 years old and lived in Rockport, Mass.

title: John D. J. Moore, an Executive And a Former Envoy, Dies at 77
description: John D. J. Moore, a lawyer and executive and a former United States Ambassador to Ireland, died of bone cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.

title: Metro Datelines; Pirate Radio Station Awaiting Approval
description: Sarah, the freighter that housed a pirate radio station last summer, was back yesterday - anchored off Long Island awaiting court approval to broadcast.

title: Cowboys Spoil Cards' Debut
description: For three quarters tonight, 67,139 fans in Sun Devil Stadium relished the best of their two pro football worlds.

title: Control to Shift At Playboy
description: Hugh M. Hefner, the founder, chairman and chief executive of Playboy Enterprises Inc., announced today that he would not run for re-election to the company's board of directors and would pass full command to his daughter.

title: Falcon Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
U.S. Among the Targets of Third World Bloc
description: The foreign ministers of the 101-nation Nonaligned Movement have ended their four-day annual conference with a statement criticizing the United States, South Africa and Israel and expressing support for Nicaragua.

title: Julian Bream to Open Great Performers Series
description: The new season of Great Performers at Lincoln Center will include excerpts from the opera ''Nixon in China,'' a master guitarist series, a series of song recitals and a concert version of the second act of ''Tristan and Isolde'' with the soprano Hildegard Behrens. The 1988-89 season is to open Oct. 16 with a recital by the guitarist Julian Bream at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Amvestors Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment losses of $273,000 and $24,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes realized investment losses of $218,000 and $105,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: About Chess Moves
description: The New York Times has converted its method of chessboard notation to the algebraic system, in which each square is unambiguously identified by file letter and rank number. Explanations of the system are available from the Chess Column, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: 138 Buildings Destroyed By Blazes in California
description: A wind-whipped fire destroyed 138 homes and other structures today and forced more than 8,000 people living in the Gold Rush country of the Sierra Nevada foothills to evacuate, many for the second time in two days.

title: A New Index Illuminates The Creative Life
description: THE propensity for inventive flair is the subject of new studies by psychologists who are investigating the role of creativity in the everyday lives of ordinary people.

title: Reuters to Cut Work Force To Protect Financial Health
description: The British news and electronic-market data publisher Reuters Holdings P.L.C. announced plans yesterday to reduce its work force in North America as part of an effort to protect the company's financial position in 1989.

title: Seoul's Subways Ready for Games
description: The city's subway system hopes to lure thousands of extra riders during the Olympics with tightened security, spruced up stops and station calls in English.

title: Hospitals Tell Of Big Losses In New York
description: Nine months after the introduction of a new state-mandated hospital reimbursement system in New York, losses at private and not-for-profit hospitals throughout the state are increasing dramatically, according to health-care professionals and hospital administrators.

title: Ronald Sherman, 55, Advertising Executive
description: Ronald K. Sherman, president of the New York City advertising agency of Calet, Hirsch & Spector Inc., died of cancer Saturday at New York University Medical Center. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: American Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months included a non-recurring pre-tax gain of $3,440,000 from unearned income that had been carried on the balance sheet and previously amortized according to the amount of ammonium perchlorate production from the now-destroyed Henderson plant.

title: Yonkers Legacy: 38 Distinct Neighborhoods
description: There is a legend here about a visitor who, standing atop the Palisades, was told he faced the City of Yonkers across the Hudson River. ''What are Yonkers?'' he asked.

title: Hurricane Is Reported to Damage Over 100,000 Homes in Jamaica
description: A devastating hurricane struck Jamaica today with winds of about 140 miles an hour, destroying or damaging more than 100,000 homes, according to one estimate, and wrecking much of the Caribbean nation's banana crop.

title: Chess
description: The Brooklyn grandmaster Dmitry Gurevich triumphed over a strong field to win the United States Open Championship, held in Boston Aug. 7-20 at the Lafayette Swiss Hotel.

title: 32 Seats Open in New York Primary
description: Since many legislative races in New York are decided long before the general election, learning to fend off a primary challenge is one of the first lessons of incumbency. Judging from the ballots for this Thursday's primary race, most incumbents have learned this lesson well; although all 211 state legislators are up for election in November, there are primary contests in only 6 of the state's 61 state senate districts and 26 of its 150 Assembly districts.

title: INSIDE
description: Jamaica Badly Hit by Storm Hurricane Gilbert struck Jamaica with winds up to 115 miles an hour, damaging more than 100,000 homes, according to one estimate. Page A14. Testimony in T.W.A. Trial A Lebanese on trial in West Germany in a 1985 air piracy case was identified as the killer of an American hostage. In Beirut, the hijacker's compatriots freed a West German. Page A7. Acid Rain's Effects In a bold experiment, Canadian scientists have added acid to lakes and measured the decline in wildlife that resulted. Science Times, page C1. Bess Myerson Trial to Begin City Hall will be watching for any damage to Mayor Koch from the conspiracy trial of the former city official, once a close adviser. Page B1.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ammirati & Puris Wins Battle for Aetna Life Job
description: Ammirati & Puris has bested a field of 12 agencies to win the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's account with billings estimated at about $15 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Chevrolet Dealer Group Gives Job to McCaffrey
description: McCaffrey & Ratner is going to be doing advertising for the Four-Star Chevrolet Dealers Association, made up of 14 dealers in the New York boroughs.

title: Xeta Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Equity Finance Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: There were no year-ago sales figures available because the company was in the development stage. The results included those of Compton Press Inc., acquired Oct. 28, 1987. The results for the 9 months ended March 31 reflected 5 months of Equity Finance operations.

title: Dart Group Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a loss on reacquisition of debentures of $108,000 and a tax credit of $2,826,000. c-After losses on reacquisition of debentures of $66,000 for the quarter and $369,000 for the 6 months. The year-ago periods included pre- tax gains of $32 million for the quarter and $92 million for the 6 months on the sale of holdings in Supermarkets General Corp. and Safeway Inc. The latest quarter and 6-month figures include Jumbo Foods Inc. consolidated for the period June 30, 1988 to July 31, 1988.

title: Congressional Aides Say Drexel Committed Added Violations
description: Officials with a Congressional subcommittee have obtained documents that they say show that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. committed violations of Federal securities laws in addition to those mentioned in a civil complaint filed last week by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Pacer Technology & Resources Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
Reviews/Music; The Band Power Tools Blends Sounds of Jazz
description: It's odd how contradictory impulses sometimes find themselves on the same bandstand. Power Tools, a jazz-ish supergroup that includes Bill Frisell on guitar, Melvin Gibbs on bass and Ronald Shannon Jackson on drums, manages to blend the esthetics of jazz fusion with those of free improvisation. The tension between clean predictability and noisy randomness serves as a good symbol of how the group works.

title: Baseball; Hurst Wins 17th As Red Sox Roll
description: Bruce Hurst won his 17th game and Ellis Burks got three hits and scored three runs tonight as the Boston Red Sox beat the Baltimore Orioles by 6-1.

title: Voodoo Bankers
description: LEAD: ''If we can't make money off our friends,'' Michael R. Milken used to say to his partners at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. about the overcharging of their clients, ''who can we make money off of?'' That comment, vintage Milken, takes on new resonance in light of the charges that the Securities and Exchange

title: National Semi Reports a Loss
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation today reported a loss for the quarter ended Aug. 28, reflecting a restructuring charge and a slowdown in sales of its point-of-sale systems and for its mainframe computer business.

title: Students Protest in Panama
description: The riot police fired tear gas at rock-throwing student demonstrators today, and dockworkers went on strike to protest Panama's economic crisis.

title: Dukakis and Jackson Report Improvements in Relationship
description: Jesse Jackson is evaluating advertising scripts for Michael S. Dukakis. He helped him write a speech. He is even advising on how to deflect Vice President Bush's attacks.

title: ABC Creates New Unit For Nonfiction Programs
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. yesterday announced the creation of a new unit within the ABC Television Network Group to produce and distribute nonfiction programs such as nature documentaries.

title: Armtek Takes Mark IV Bid
description: The Armtek Corporation accepted a sweetened $561.2 million buyout offer today from its once-hostile suitor, Mark IV Industries, ending a battle for the automobile parts maker.

title: Land of Lincoln Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Delaware Primary Victor Declared . . . Maybe
description: For a day, Lieut. Gov. S. B. Woo of Delaware thought that he had lost to Samuel Beard, a Wilmington investment banker, by 2,794 votes in Saturday's Democratic primary for the United States Senate.

title: Treatment of Sewage Is Seen as Insufficient To Protect Water Life
description: LEAD: WATER pollution control experts predict that more sophisticated and expensive treatment of municipal sewage soon will be necessary in some areas to save the fish and shellfish in rivers, bays and coastal waters.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Charges that Iraq used poison gas against Kurdish rebels have prompted the United States and several allies to ask Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to send a team to Iraq to investigate. Page A1

title: Our Towns; Hottest Issue? Keeping Golf A Genteel Game
description: This village of 2,500 has its own golf course and its own Golf Grievance Commission, which meets monthly to debate such key issues as ''who gets yellow-flag privileges to drive his cart across the fairways and who has to park and walk across?'' Following are excerpts from minutes of recent public meetings.

title: Yield Set at 9.41% In Masco Offering
description: The Masco Corporation, a manufacturer of building and home improvement products based in Taylor, Mich., is offering $300 million of 9 1/4 percent notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.375 to yield 9.41 percent through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: S.A.T. Guide on Disk
description: I TOOK the S.A.T.'s a weekend ago. It's a good thing I finished my formal education quite a few years ago, because today I might have difficulty getting accepted by Three Stooges University.

title: MAJOR RADON PERIL IS DECLARED BY U.S. IN CALL FOR TESTS
description: Citing new evidence that the threat of cancer-causing radon is more widespread than previously recognized, the Government today issued a national public health advisory urging that most homes be tested for the naturally occurring radioactive gas.

title: Changeable Bacteria Contradict Rules of Genetics
description: BACTERIA may be able to alter their genes in the face of environmental change, according to new research that seems to contradict one of the oldest precepts of genetics.

title: Fluor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $5 million and $19.4 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Study of Atoms to Use Hoover Dam as Shield
description: SCIENTISTS plan to exploit the Hoover Dam as a radiation shield for instruments they will use in measuring a rare type of nuclear disintegration, a process that could shed light on the distant future of the universe.

title: Cisneros Plans to Leave Office
description: Mayor Henry G. Cisneros, a leading Hispanic politician who was considered a potential Democratic Vice Presidential candidate four years ago, said today that he would not seek a fifth term.

title: The Torme Story, as Told by Himself
description: Almost every veteran entertainer can recall a moment when the normally unthinkable notion of quitting show business became an excruciating possibility. For Mel Torme, who has earned belated recognition as one of the country's greatest pop-jazz singers, that moment arrived in 1956 with the advent of rock-and-roll.

title: Verity Cautious On a Japan Pact
description: Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. said today that an American-Japanese free-trade agreement would not be the best way to solve the two countries' trade disputes.

title: Sono-Tek Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Airline Experience A Key for DHL Chief
description: Tapping a veteran of the airline and hotel industries, the DHL Corporation Inc. yesterday named Patrick Foley chairman, president and chief executive officer of DHL and its major subsidiary, DHL Airways. He will also be chief executive for the Western Hemisphere of the DHL Worldwide Express network, effective immediately.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON REVIEW AND APPRAISAL OF U.N. AFRICAN RECOVERY PROGRAM - 10 A.M. and 4 P.M.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Partnership Will Buy Celestial Seasonings
description: LEAD: Celestial Seasonings Inc., the herbal tea company known for its whimsically named products, will regain its independence in a rapidly negotiated sale by Kraft Inc., which bought the company in 1984.

title: Britain's Postal Strike Ends With a Settlement
description: The British post office and the Union of Communication Workers agreed today to settle a strike that has stopped mail deliveries throughout most of the country, but postal officials said it would take a week or two to break up a backlog of 150 million letters and packages.

title: Airline Accused of Hiring Bias
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission asked a Federal court today to hold United Airlines in contempt for failing to hire enough blacks and women as pilots.

title: Istec Industries & Technoloies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: All figures are in U.S. dollars and have used the exchange rate of 1.6228 new Israeli shekels to $1.00 as of June 30, 1988.

title: Lakeland Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Catholic Schools Reach Out To Serve Poor and to Borrow
description: Roman Catholic schools in the inner cities, serving an enrollment that is increasingly poor, black and Protestant, are looking beyond the church to secular foundations and private corporations for financial help to keep their doors open.

title: American Milers Trail in Race for Gold
description: While the mile continues to be the glamour race of many American track and field meets, no American male runner is considered a serious threat to win a medal in the 1,500-meter race at the Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Yonkers Is Still the Governor's Problem
description: A change of two votes in the Yonkers City Council finally brought the city into compliance with a Federal court order for low- and moderate-income housing. That eases the crisis but does not end it: now the housing needs to be built. The duty of Governor Cuomo and other state officials - who have kept a low profile - remains to take an active and public leadership role in carrying out the court's decision and in healing wounds.

title: Talking Business; with Batts of the Trucking Association; Trucking Safety And Deregulation
description: The trucking industry has been adjusting to deregulation since 1980. Truckers are finding it easier to enter the business and they have more pricing flexibility. But rate bureaus, which are legally protected cartels, still exist to set prices. Meanwhile, various state laws often blunt the intent of letting the industry operate more freely.

title: Conservatives Gather
description: Several generations of conservatives are gathering to pay tribute to the memory of one of their heroines, Freda Utley, who died 10 years ago at the age of 80.

title: Certron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $16,000. c-Net income

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I get your meaning, and I know what you're talking about.'' - Mikhail Gorbachev, responding to hecklers' complaints about food shortages and lines. [ A1:3. ]

title: Luanda Journal; A Troop Paper for All Their Men From Havana
description: The newspaper's weekly language lesson teaches Cuban soldiers how to say '''brother'' in the language of the Kuanhama tribe of southern Angola.

title: Chip Industry Orders Dip
description: The semiconductor industry association's leading indicator dipped again in August, as chip makers based in the United States, Europe and Japan reported an increase in shipments, but a decline in orders, a trade group reported today. The Semiconductor Industry

title: Scientists Find Clues To Healing in Humans By Studying the Sponge
description: LEAD: THE humble sponge, one of the oldest and simplest animals, has become a powerful research tool for scientists seeking to unravel the workings of the human immune system.

title: Dow Rises by 3.56 as Stocks Close Mixed
description: Stock prices closed broadly mixed yesterday as many investors remained on the sidelines awaiting two reports on the nation's economy.

title: USA Waste Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Television; Toontown, Behind The Scenes
description: The Roger Rabbit machine remains in high gear. The highly successful film ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit'' is already being translated into lucrative marketing packages of toys, games and clothing logos. Now, tonight at 8, CBS is offering ''Roger Rabbit and the Secrets of Toontown.'' It can be approached as either a behind-the-scenes documentary or an hourlong commercial for Roger and friends. Frank Marshall and Kathleen Kennedy are the executive producers. Mr. Marshall is also one of the producers of ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit''

title: Brandywine Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $93,000 tax credit. The bank went public in June 1987.

title: U.S. Unseals Complaints In Ashland Papers Case
description: The United States Attorney's Office in Manhattan yesterday unsealed complaints charging Orin E. Atkins, the former chairman of the Ashland Oil Inc., and Roy Furmark, a former consultant to Ashland, with the interstate transportation of stolen property.

title: Chileans Will at Last Have a Vote on Pinochet
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Unit Awarded Intelsat Contract
description: The International Telecommunications Satellite Organization, Intelsat, has awarded the Ford Motor Company a $394.3 million contract to produce five Intelsat 7 satellites. The contract was awarded to a Ford subsidiary, the Ford Aerospace and Communications Corporation.

title: Dow Jones Sees Profit Drop
description: Dow Jones & Company, citing declines in advertising revenue, said yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter would be lower than in the comparable period a year ago.

title: Metamorphosis of 'Like' Is, Like, a Long Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 732988 -- No Title
description: A filly by Alydar sold for $390,000 today to top the fourth session of the September Yearling Sale at Keeneland.

title: Polebridge Journal; Those on the Fire Line Come to Revere the Foe
description: Two thousand miles from his wife and baby daughter, Jim Oliver, a 21-year-old unemployed construction worker from Elkins, W.Va., is shivering in the darkness in a tent in the forest here.

title: Irish Seeking Rest Of First Maryland
description: Allied Irish Banks P.L.C., the largest bank in Ireland, said it planned to take control of First Maryland Bancorp, the second-largest bank in Maryland. Allied, which owns 49.7 percent of the company, said it was offering $340 million, or $35.25 a share, for the rest of the Baltimore-based banking group.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Armor All Products Corp., Irvine, Calif., said it had agreed to acquire the car-care unit of Borden Inc. for about $26 million.

title: Soviet Grain Prospects Dip
description: Prospects for this year's grain harvest in the Soviet Union have deteriorated somewhat because of a drop in some yields, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: What Drove the Kurds Out of Iraq?
description: Although questions linger over accusations by Iraqi Kurdish dissidents of chemical-weapons attacks, what is clear after visits to several camps is that something happened inside Iraq that was sufficiently frightening to make the guerrillas and their families take flight.

title: Drug-Related Fire Kills 2 Girls
description: A house fire Sunday that killed an infant girl and her 4-year-old sister and critically injured a third child was caused by a drug-related firebombing, the authorities said today. The attack was directed at a man who lived in the house, a police official said. The dead children were identified as the infant, Erica Butler, 1 year old, and Ashley Evans, 4.

title: Japan Trade Surplus Cut
description: Japan's trade surplus fell 3.9 percent in August from a year ago and 31 percent from the previous month, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: Olympics; Samaranch Calls Drug Users 'The Thieves of Performance'
description: For all the political problems surrounding the Seoul Olympics, the use of banned drugs by athletes remains an issue no less disturbing to the president of the International Olympic Committee.

title: Forest City Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Mexicans Say They Can't Lose No Matter Who Wins the White House
description: With their own presidential election now behind them, Mexicans are avidly following the American race, their interest intensified by the presence on both the Democratic and Republican tickets of candidates with unusually strong personal and business links to this country.

title: Few Patients Need Worry About Magnetic Scans
description: To the Editor:

title: Wiltek Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Approval of Changes in Housing Plan Called Unlikely
description: The major changes proposed for a housing desegregation plan, pivotal in persuading the City Council to approve the plan last weekend, were described today as deeply flawed and unlikely to gain approval.

title: Reviews/Music; 'Lo Schiavo,' a Rarity From Brazil
description: Antonio Carlos Gomes was a Brazilian composer of considerable gifts who patterned his operatic idiom on that of middle-period Verdi and who had great successes in Italy and South America in the last quarter of the 19th century. The Amato Opera Company's revival of ''Lo Schiavo'' (''The Slave''), which opened Saturday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, serves notice that the score well merits circulation.

title: Fordham and Army Joining Colonial
description: The Colonial League, expanding from six members to eight, has added Army and Fordham, and will announce today its intention to become an all-sports conference in 1990 rather than only a football league.

title: Campaign Trails; 'Hooked' on Politics, He Joins New Camp
description: When Thomas E. Donilon was in high school in Providence, R.I., in the 1970's, he read Hunter Thompson's ''Fear and Loathing on the Campaign Trail.'' He grew entranced with the drama of Presidential politics. He was, he confides, hooked.

title: Study Says Banks Did Poorly In London Securities Trades
description: The London securities operations of many United States commercial banks either lost money or were only marginally profitable in the highly volatile years of 1986 and 1987, according to a study released today by the General Accounting Office.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Yankees Rally, But Fall Short
description: Again, the game ended with a swing of Claudell Washington's bat. Only this time, Washington didn't make contact, and the Yankees failed to complete their comeback.

title: Admac Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Spokesman for Meese Quits Justice Dept. Job
description: Patrick Korten, the chief spokesman for the Justice Department in former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's last months in office, said today that he was resigning.

title: Drought Has Eased, U.S. Reports; Small Food Price Rise Seen for '88
description: The worst of the drought is over, the Agriculture Department said today, standing by its prediction that grain production will fall 31 percent this year.

title: Polifly Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company went public in its latest fourth quarter.

title: Ralph M. Houston, Minister, 84
description: The Rev. Ralph M. Houston, who served on the judicial council of the United Methodist Church for two decades, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Mount Tremper, N.Y. He was 84 years old.

title: Apple Raises Prices for Its Macintosh Computer
description: Responding to increased component costs and continued strong demand for its products, Apple Computer Inc. today announced major price increases on several models of the Macintosh personal computer.

title: A Decisive Baker Puts His Mark on Bush Race
description: The speedy departure of Frederic V. Malek illustrates the decisiveness and centralized authority that James A. Baker 3d has brought to the leadership of Vice President Bush's campaign in the month since Mr. Baker has taken charge as chairman.

title: Unitronix Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included an extraordinary loss of $189,735 from the writeoff of a long-term investment.

title: By Design; Women's Clothes, Men's Fabrics
description: A few years ago designers were on an androgynous kick, suggesting that women deck themselves in man-tailored clothes made of men's wear tweeds and flannels. Then they did an about-face to sexy clothes in slinky jerseys, often with a smidgen of spandex to make the fabric cling to the body. Clothes have now loosened up, and fashion appears to be entering a phase of offering feminine clothes in men's wear fabrics.

title: Inmate Numbers at a Record
description: The Federal and state prison population grew by 4 percent in the first six months of 1988 to a record 604,824 inmates, with female prisoners increasing at a far faster rate than males, the Government reports.

title: August Truck Sales Up
description: August retail truck sales by franchised dealers of United States manufacturers rose 4.7 percent, to 375,302, from 358,365 in August 1987, the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association said today.

title: Manufacturers' Profits Drop
description: The after-tax profits of manufacturing companies dropped to an average of 5.8 percent of sales between April and June from 6.3 percent in the first quarter, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Regrouped Jets Are Refreshed
description: All was well with the Jets at their training complex here today in the wake of Sunday's surprising 23-3 victory over the Browns in Cleveland.

title: Campaign Trails; Slips of the Tongue Prove to Be Catching
description: Perhaps it's the pressure. Or the lack of sleep. Or fatigue. But both Presidential candidates seem to be ensnared in malapropisms that enliven a campaign that otherwise seems a bit tepid.

title: Many Partake of Culture but Few Study It
description: A growing number of Americans are buying books, visiting museums and joining cultural groups, but enrollment in college humanities courses has fallen drastically in the past 20 years, a Government report says.

title: Retirement Rock
description: Rock-and-roll began as a defiant, musical shaking of the fist at adult values, the older generation and the very notion of mortality. Now, however, many of the early rock-and-rollers are facing old age and some who were present at the creation worry about retirement.

title: Dukakis Stresses Defense, Ridicules Bush and Quayle
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, striking a tough posture on national security with six uniformed National Guard soldiers standing at his back, took Vice President Bush to task today for what he called a series of foreign policy blunders.

title: Praising a Cheaper Chip
description: IS the 80286, the chip used in AT-class personal computers, dead? Is it a mistake to buy a PC based on the aging chip, now that the more-powerful 80386 chip is widely available and falling in price?

title: Matrix Medica reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $298,000 and a gain from the sale of discontinued operations of $358,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,272,000.

title: Star Classics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Home Federal Savings & Loan (Upper East Tenn) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax of $402,000 FSLIC secondary reserve writeoff for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: U.S. Issues Dip in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell slightly in very light trading yesterday as market participants sold securities after a sharp rally in oil prices.

title: Gold Reaches 17-Month Low Before Recovering Slightly
description: Gold prices ended little changed yesterday after falling during a volatile session to their lowest level in 17 months.

title: New Stadium Recommended
description: The 60-year-old Chicago Stadium, home of the Chicago Blackhawks and the Chicago Bulls, is structurally sound, but it is obsolete because it doesn't have luxury boxes and should be replaced instead of refurbished, a consulting company has reported.

title: Small Injuries Can Cause Lasting Vocal Ills, Doctors Say
description: A RECENT study suggests that minor fractures of the cartilage in the larynx, which are often undetected and usually untended, may cause permanent damage to the voice.

title: Highland Superstores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $5,685,000.

title: Valley Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Valley Federal converted from a federal mutual savings bank to a federal stock savings bank on July 22, 1987.

title: More Oil Rigs in Action
description: The number of drilling rigs actively exploring for oil and natural gas in the United States increased by 5 last week, to 938, after declining for a month, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago the count was 1,108.

title: POPE, IN ZIMBABWE, ASKS TRIBAL AMITY
description: Pope John Paul II preached peace and reconciliation today at an open-air Mass in a province of Zimbabwe where tribal warfare ended only four months ago.

title: Correction
description: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about the appointment of C. David Burgin as vice president and editor in chief of The Houston Post misstated his former position at The Washington Star. He was sports editor of The Star from 1973 to 1977.

title: Radon: Where It Originates and What Can Be Done About It
description: Radon is a colorless, odorless gas produced by the breakdown of uranium in the earth's crust. In some houses, depending on factors such as internal air pressure and ventilation, the radioactive gas can build up, causing a severe long-term health hazard.

title: Garcia Is Battling Energetic Rival in Bronx
description: Robert Garcia faces something of a novel situation in his bid for a sixth term as the South Bronx's Congressman: this year, many people seem to know a bit about his challenger.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: New York State Mortgage Issue
description: The New York State Mortgage Agency is tentatively offering $175 million of homeowner mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: General Mills Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Includes income of $199,100,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $3,700,000 from discontinued operations. The company said that the sale of its Talbots and Eddie Bauer units, completed during the latest first quarter, generated an after-tax profit of $220,600,000. The company also said that the gain was reduced by the establishment of a reserve of $21.5 million for the disposition of its York's cafeteria chain and other minor adjustments to previously discontinued operations.

title: Carter Home Run Gives Mets Edge
description: When the second baseman stepped to the plate in the eighth inning last night, the crowd rose. But Gregg Jefferies, the Mets' rookie, did not notice. He merely lined a pitch into right field, ran to first base and waited.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Big Changes For Knapp's Magazines
description: KNAPP COMMUNICATIONS in Los Angeles has three national magazine titles, Architectural Digest, Bon Appetit and Home, and next month it is inaugurating major changes in the latter two publications. The changes should make the magazines more attractive to a broader universe of advertisers.

title: F.B.I. Word Due on Penalty In Surveillance of Policy Foes
description: William S. Sessions, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, is expected to announce this week whether he will punish agents who were involved in surveillance of opponents of the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America, Government officials said today.

title: European Insurers To Form Alliance
description: Two leading European insurance companies, Union des Assurances de Paris of France and the Sun Life Assurance Society P.L.C. of Britain, plan an alliance to expand their activities. The deal is the latest among European companies leading up to 1992, when the European Community intends to abolish internal trade barriers.

title: Voodoo Stamps
description: LEAD: In its current offering of commemorative stamps, the United States Postal Service includes one for New York State, captioned ''July 26, 1788,'' that presents a view of Wall Street with the spire of Trinity Church soaring prominently in the background.

title: Advances Propel Solar Energy Into Market
description: A CENTURY and a half after the French physicist Edmund Becquerel discovered that light can be transformed directly into electrical energy, the photovoltaic exploitation of sunlight seems finally on the verge of broad commercial use.

title: Intelogic Trace Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,481,000 from the purchase of debentures. c-After an extraordinary charge of $654,000 from the redemption of notes.

title: Bridge
description: Bridge is perhaps the only sport or recreation in which average players have the opportunity to contend head-to-head against experts of world class. On rare occasions the stars may be available as teammates or partners, and during the current American Down Under Tour of Australia, which ends Sept. 19, two happy Australians in the small town of Ettalong near Sydney had two world champions, Chip Martel and Lew Stansby, as their teammates.

title: Jewelmasters Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net loss

title: West German Hostage Is Released in Lebanon
description: A West German hostage who had been held captive for 20 months was released in Moslem-controlled West Beirut on Monday, Lebanese and West German Embassy officials said today.

title: Thor Energy Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
On Eve of Bess Myerson's Trial, Tension at City Hall
description: The mayoral wing of New York's City Hall is approaching the beginning of the Bess Myerson trial this week with a combination of apprehension, fatalism and a bit of confidence that it may not be so damaging to Mayor Koch after all.

title: Malibu Grand Prix Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $311,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After an extraordinary gain on the restructuring of debt of $1,649,000.

title: A First Hurrah in Rhode Island for Young Member of Kennedy Clan
description: Is the world ready for another Kennedy in politics?

title: For an Unpredictable Season, Clothes to Count On
description: This is a between-times season, a period of transition when midsummer clothes are not quite substantial enough and fall clothes are a bit much. What's the answer? Well, the women pictured here have struck just the right note with coolly functional, classic clothing. They've chosen to face the unpredictability of late summer with cardigan sweaters, double-breasted blazers, crisp white shirts (now long-sleeved, not short) and pleated slacks in familiar colors like beige, navy, camel, gray and black. After all, if the weather's going to be capricious, one wants to be able to count on something. Occasionally, there's an added touch to these ensembles: a deep cloche hat pulled firmly down, a bright silk scarf or an oversized leather handbag. But if anything, they just add to the sense of solidity. As for shoes, the open sandal style is still fine, but now the white footwear of summer has given way to darker shades.

title: Holco Mortgage Acceptance reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company was formed in April 1987.

title: Sage Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gorbachev Listens to the People and Gets an Earful
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, reappeared in public today after a six-week absence and ran into the angry distress of the Soviet consumer in an unusual televised encounter with central Siberians.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Futures Aide Picked For S.E.C. Vacancy
description: LEAD: President Reagan is nominating Mary L. Schapiro, the general counsel of the Futures Industry Association, to fill the vacancy on the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Biaggi Is Still a Force in Bronx Race
description: Mario Biaggi, who was one of New York City's most powerful Congressmen before his two convictions on racketeering and other Federal charges, remains an important factor in Thursday's Democratic primary for the House of Representatives seat he resigned in disgrace.

title: Lawrence Orton, 89, New York City Planner
description: Lawrence M. Orton, a planner and former member of the New York City Planning Commission, died of Alzheimer's disease Saturday at the Hartwyck West Nursing Home in Cedar Grove, N.J. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Have Rap Concerts Become Inextricably Linked to Violence?
description: In recent years, concerts of rap music have gained a reputation for violence. A concert Saturday night at Nassau Coliseum on Long Island featuring Eric B. and Rakim, Kool Moe Dee, Doug E. Fresh and other rappers was the scene of robberies, stabbings and a homicide, violence that led to a ban on rap concerts at the coliseum. It is also likely to make concert promoters and hall owners more leery than they already are about staging rap concerts. Even now, attending a rap concert is likely to mean entering by way of a cordon of police, a metal detector and a frisking, with more police and security guards stationed inside the hall.

title: U.S. Would Ease Bone Labeling Rule for Meat
description: The Agriculture Department today proposed allowing hot-dogs, bologna and other prepared meats to contain as much as 10 percent ground bone and other meat remnants from a mechanical process without identifying the ingredients in product labels.

title: Dr. Myrtle B. McGraw, Psychologist, 89, Dies
description: Dr. Myrtle Bryan McGraw, a psychologist and researcher in child development, died of pnuemonia last Tuesday at her home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. She was 89 years old.

title: De Laurentiis Film Partners reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bridgford Foods reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Sports People; Denial From Upshaw
description: ''I'm being tried by the media,'' said Gene Upshaw, the N.F.L. Players Association executive director in response to an article in The Boston Globe on Sunday that quoted unidentified sources as saying Upshaw was being investigated for allegations of misusing union money. The columnist Wil McDonough, quoting ''unidentified Washington sources,'' said Upshaw was reported to have received a salary increase with the knowlege of union board members, without revealing it and without paying taxes on it.

title: Atlantic Federal Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chileans Will at Last Have a Vote on Pinochet; Allende Was Murdered
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Datelines; Shoreham Decision Expected This Week
description: The New York State Public Service Commission may agree as early as Thursday to back Governor Cuomo's deal with the Long Island Lighting Company to close the $5.3 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant, commission officials said yesterday.

title: Trak Auto Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Stewart Sandwiches Inc reports earnings for Year to June 24
description: b-After a $76,788 tax credit. c-Net loss and after a $32,506 tax benefit.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * John W. Bartelme named vice president of marketing of Holly Farms Foods Inc.

title: HIJACKING SUSPECT IS CALLED A KILLER
description: The pilot of a T.W.A. jet hijacked in 1985 testified in a West German court today that it was the defendant at the trial, Mohammed Ali Hamadei, who killed an American hostage and who was the more savage of two men who seized the plane.

title: T Cell Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
2 Networks Vying on Liberace Films
description: ''Liberace lived for the spotlight,'' said Bill Wells, the director of motion pictures for television at CBS. ''I think he would have been excited by the idea of two networks vying to tell his life story.''

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Ford Raises Prices an Average of 2.6% for 1989 Models
description: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would raise prices on 1989 cars by an average of 2.6 percent, which is midway between the increases announced by the other two American-owned car companies. The Chrysler Corporation's prices are to rise by 2.3 percent, and the General Motors Corporation's by 2.9 percent.

title: Designs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net income

title: Market Place; Analysts Bullish On MCI Outlook
description: SHARES of the MCI Communications Corporation rallied last week as investors' concerns eased about an expected ruling by the Federal Communications Commission on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's plan to offer special discount prices to business customers.

title: Now, in Affluent Japan: Big Cars
description: It was bound to happen.

title: Grand Met Files Complaint
description: The European Community Commission will study a complaint by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. about Pernod Ricard S.A.'s bid to win control of Irish Distillers Group P.L.C., an aide to the community's competition commissioner, Peter Sutherland, said today.

title: A Woman, 69, Is Raped on L.I.
description: A 69-year-old woman who had been walking along the beach with her husband was abducted and raped today, the Suffolk County police said.

title: 2 AFRICAN LEADERS VOW COOPERATION
description: President P. W. Botha of South Africa and President Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique met today and vowed to strengthen economic ties and co-operate in curbing the anti-Government rebels Mozambique has accused South Africa of supporting.

title: Financial-Aid Partnership Keeps Higher Education Within Reach
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
When Fred Malek Could Have Said No
description: In 1971, President Nixon became obsessed with the idea that Jewish officials in the Bureau of Labor Statistics were out to hurt him politically. He demanded a list of names, promptly supplied by the White House personnel chief, Frederic V. Malek. Later Mr. Nixon ordered George Shultz, then Secretary of the Treasury, to audit the tax returns of Mr. Nixon's ''enemies.'' Mr. Shultz flatly refused.

title: Bayer USA Plans Merger of 3 Units
description: Bayer USA Inc., a unit of Bayer A.G. of West Germany, said it would merge its subsidiaries - Agfa-Gevaert Inc., the Compugraphic Corporation and the Matrix Corporation -into one corporation at the end of the year. Bayer USA said the new subsidiary, the Agfa Corporation, would be based at Agfa-Gevaert's current headquarters in Ridgefield Park, N.J. Compugraphic is based in Wilmington, Mass., and Matrix has its headquarters in Orangeburg, N.Y.

title: Pinochet Foes Guard Against Fraud
description: Political opponents of President Augusto Pinochet are setting up an extensive vote-counting network of their own that they say will guarantee against fraud in the coming presidential plebiscite.

title: Nassau Coliseum Bans Rap Concerts Till Murder Inquiry Ends
description: The Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum today banned all rap concerts at the arena pending the outcome of an investigation into the fatal stabbing of a 19-year-old Bronx man and other violence at a concert here Saturday night.

title: U S Sprint To Cut Loss In 3d Period
description: In the first clear sign of a turnaround, the U S Sprint Communications Corporation plans to report that its operating losses decreased sharply in the third quarter, its parent company, United Telecommunications Inc., said yesterday.

title: Singapore's Currency
description: Singapore has managed to convince the United States that there is no need for the Singapore dollar to appreciate, its Finance Minister, Richard Hu, said today. ''That pressure is now off of us,'' he said in an interview. ''I think they've accepted our arguments.'' Last year Washington strongly maintained that Singapore, Hong Kong, South Korea and Taiwan were keeping their currencies artificially low to improve their ability to compete.

title: Dramatic Switch At Top of Tennis
description: The United States Open lived up to its reputation as the most cutthroat tournament within the most inhospitable facility in the genteel world of tennis. There were surprises, but most of them proved unpleasant, like the unseemly pair of brawls that broke out in the stands during the one event that ought to have riveted the New York crowd, the men's final.

title: Oil Rises a Bit Amid Unclear OPEC News
description: Oil prices fluctuated widely yesterday before closing modestly higher in New York futures trading. Traders reacted to conflicting news reports about whether officials of key oil-exporting countries would agree on a price meeting this month.

title: Beretta to Modify Pistols For Army Due to Cracking
description: The Army and the Italian gunmaker Beretta have agreed to suspend deliveries of the military's new 9mm pistol for three months to deal with unexpected cracking in the gun's slide mechanism, the service said today.

title: Federal Ethics Office Assails Meese's Actions as Attorney General
description: The Office of Government Ethics said in a report today that former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d used his official position to benefit a close friend and that Mr. Meese showed no ''genuine concern'' for honoring an agreement with the Government over management of his personal finances.

title: New Factor Affecting Climate: The Golf-Course Effect
description: IN a world that is generally getting warmer, the asphalt and concrete of cities absorb and store radiant energy to send temperatures even higher in relation to nearby suburban and rural areas. Cities are thus ''heat islands.'' By contrast, climatologists report, human development may also be responsible for the creation of ''cool islands.'' Scientists discovered one in, of all places, the desert at Palm Springs, Calif. In the last 15 years, the average temperatures there have dropped two to three degrees below that of the surrounding area.

title: Sports People; Rangers Sign Patrick
description: The Rangers announced yesterday that they have signed James Patrick, a defenseman, to a multiyear contract. Details of the contract were not released, but a source close to the Rangers said Patrick was getting a substantial raise. The source, who requested anonymity, said that Lucien DeBlois would be ''signed, sealed and delivered'' today. The signing of DeBlois will leave Kelly Kisio and Norm McIver the only veterans unsigned going into the option year of their contracts. . . . The Devils announced that Gordie Mark, the defenseman, has retired. Mark, 24 years old, played only 19 games for the Devils and 50 in the minor leagues last season. The Devils have plenty of depth on defense this year and Mark's chances of making the team were small.

title: Curtis Industries reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago results are on a pro forma basis. The net income represents operating income.

title: Stage II Apparel Corp reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: The fiscal 1988 results included the apparel division of Sportsotron Inc. since its acquisition effective Aug. 1, 1987.

title: N.F.L. Notebook; Rams' Reserves Keep Team From Running on Empty
description: As the number of players penalized by the league's drug policy reached 16 before last week's games, some teams were scrambling for replacements while others revamped or scrapped their schemes.

title: Low-Profile Designers Reap Benefit From Politics
description: Some designers explode on the fashion scene, their names becoming as familiar as those of movie stars, while others go along quietly year after year, making clothes for women who buy what they like and don't care about the name on the label.

title: A Country That Can't Draw a Straight Line
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Lifecore Biomedical reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-Net loss Fiscal 1987 results are restated to reflect the acquisition of Orthomatrix Inc. in February 1987. Fiscal 1988 includes a charge of $50,000 for estimated expenses related to a lease buyout at an Orthomatrix facility.

title: 50-Off Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-After tax credits of $30,000 for the quarter and $62,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $18,000 for the quarter and $27,000 for the 6 months.

title: Assault Isn't Christian
description: John Cardinal O'Connor did more than clarify church teaching in his condemnation Sunday of ''gay-bashing.'' He also cut the logical ground from beneath those New York state senators blocking passage of a bill to discourage bias-related crimes of violence. They contend that including sexual orientation as grounds for protection might be seen as an endorsement of homosexuality.

title: Campaign Trails; Air Horns Broadcast Wrong Bush Voice
description: Vice President Bush has been doing his best to depict himself as a conservationist, more attuned to environmental concerns than President Reagan.

title: 50 Savings Units Face U.S. Action
description: Federal regulators expect to close or merge 50 more ailing savings and loan associations by the end of the month, M. Danny Wall, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today The action shows that the bank board is moving to deal more quickly with troubled savings institutions. So far this year, 102 institutions have been closed or merged.

title: Ford Will Join Nissan To Build a Mini-Van
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would join with the Nissan Motor Company of Japan to build a mini-van in a Ford plant in this country. The new model will go on sale in the 1992 model year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Commonwealth Savings Association, Houston, said its chairman and chief executive, S. Don Norris, will resign, effective Nov. 15. Mr. Norris will also resign as chairman and chief executive of a subsidiary, Commonwealth Mortgage of America L.P. Mr. Norris said he would leave the company because Commonwealth Savings had failed to reach a definitive agreement to be acquired by NYTX Corp.

title: On Horse Racing; Alysheba Returns to Site of a Big Failure
description: When Alysheba goes to the post in the Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park Saturday, he will be returning to the site of his greatest failure and racing in a state that has brought him nothing but defeat and disrepute.

title: Many in Burma Say Ne Win Continues to Pull the Strings
description: Shortly before the announcement Saturday that free elections would be held in Burma, official cars were seen entering Ady Road, where the country's retired strongman, U Ne Win, maintains a lakeside residence behind heavy military guard.

title: Move to Stop Iraq
description: The deafening silence of governments on Iraq's use of chemical weapons has provoked serious concern among defense experts. A major thesis that emerged from the annual conference of the International Institute for Strategic Studies here last weekend was that wars in the third world are not likely to diminish if the East-West conflict wanes, but increase in scope and intensity as sophisticated weaponry spreads.

title: Emerson Unit Sale
description: The Whirlpool Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the Emerson Electric Company's dishwasher and trash compactor manufacturing business for $17.4 million. Terms include a long-term agreement between Kitchenaid and Emerson for the continued supply of dishwashers to Emerson's In-Sink-Erator division.

title: Bailouts Under Attack; Criticism of Recent Savings Deals Mounts Because Buyers Have Little Money at Risk
description: Despite all the fanfare by Federal regulators over recent bailouts of sick savings institutions, evidence is mounting that the deals are merely papering over the severe problems plaguing the industry.

title: Article 905288 -- No Title
description: The largest selection of major Impressionist, modern and contemporary art to be auctioned in New York in a seven-day period - with a combined total value estimated to be more than $210 million - is to be offered in early November at Sotheby's and Christie's.

title: Where Summer Exits in Glory
description: SOME people choose to call this the end of summer. I prefer to think of it as the moment when summer preens, showing off its finest produce, as at the Union Square Greenmarket.

title: Hinderliter Industries reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $3,079,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after a loss of $1,841,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $1.3 million.

title: Stocks Advance by 10.67 on Rising Volume
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday with much of the activity focusing on takeovers and restructurings.

title: Environmental Systems Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Campaign Trail; Kemp Taking Post With a Foundation
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp, the conservative New York Republican who ran unsuccessfully this year for the Republican Presidential nomination, has decided to join the Heritage Foundation. Mr. Kemp, who announced that he would not seek re-election as a member of Congress, will serve as a ''distinguished fellow'' at the conservative Washington research group and focus on domestic and foreign policy. The job enables Mr. Kemp to remain in Washington, remain in the political spotlight and remain, perhaps, a dominant voice in the party.

title: Manville Settles With an Insurer
description: The Manville Corporation has reached an agreement with the American Centennial Insurance Company to settle insurance disputes stemming from damage claims filed by former asbestos workers. Terms of the agreement provide for three payments by American Centennial, of Wilmington, Del., totaling $3.4 million, and will cover all of Manville's claims against the insurer for policies covering the periods from July 1, 1980, to July 1, 1981, and from July 1982 to July 1983.

title: Inflation Peril In China Seen
description: The American economist Milton Friedman warned China today that soaring inflation could cripple its economy unless steps were taken to speed the conversion of state-run enterprises to private ownership.

title: Delta Captain Gives Version of Dallas Crash
description: The captain of the Delta Air Lines jet that crashed as it took off in Dallas two weeks ago told investigators yesterday that there was no sign of trouble until the airplane left the ground, Federal officials said.

title: Rohr Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
London Expels 2 Cuban Envoys
description: The Cuban Ambassador and a commercial attache were expelled today, less than 24 hours after the junior diplomat pulled a gun in a residential street in London and shot at a group of people, wounding a British Secret Service officer.

title: A Tribute to Al Cohn To Open Jazz Series
description: A musical tribute to the jazz saxophonist and arranger Al Cohn, who died in February at the age of 62, will open the 16th Highlights in Jazz series at the New York University Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place, on Sept. 22 at 8 P.M.

title: Dallas Kicker Is Cut
description: Luis Zendejas, who kicked a 47-yard field goal in a 17-14 National Football League victory over the Phoenix Cardinals Monday night, was released by the Dallas Cowboys and Roger Ruzek was activated. Ruzek made 22 of 25 field goals last season but got into a contract dispute and was held out of the first two weeks of the season. One kick by Zendejas, a free agent, was blocked by the Cardinals and that could have been a deciding factor in his released. ''He kicked it too low,'' said Coach Tom Landry of the Cowboys. (AP)

title: 2 Suspended by N.F.L.
description: Antonio Gibson, a safety with the New Orleans Saints, and Leonard Mitchell, an offensive tackle with the Atlanta Falcons, were suspended yesterday by the National Football League for violating the league's substance-abuse policy. ''They've been placed on their clubs' non-football illness list for 30 days,'' said Joe Browne, a league spokesman. ''They have been instructed to remain out until Oct. 13.'' The suspensions brought to 19 the number of N.F.L. players cited for violating the drug policy. Gibson is in his third year with the Saints. Mitchell is in his second season with the Falcons and eighth in the N.F.L.(AP)

title: Peace Corps Feedback
description: The Peace Corps is about to get some unusual feedback in the form of a symposium that brings together former volunteers and government officials from the countries in which they served.

title: Ex-Queens Homeowner Describes Death Threat
description: A former Queens homeowner who had complained to the police about drug trafficking on his block testified yesterday that a man the authorities say is a drug dealer had threatened him and his family with death if they did not move from their house.

title: Book Notes
description: National Bibliography

title: Don't Rain on the Parade
description: THE gracious welcome that most visitors have felt upon arriving at the 1988 Summer Games was reaffirmed yesterday for the central participants themselves: the athletes.

title: Gold Miner Weighs South Africa Move
description: Consolidated Goldfields P.L.C., a leading world gold producer, has contingency plans to pull out of South Africa, where it earns 15 percent of its profits, its chairman said. ''If the world's governments tell us to depart South Africa, we will do so,'' R. I. J. Agnew said at a news conference. ''We have set up the mechanism.'' Consolidated reduced its stake in Gold Fields of South Africa Ltd. to 38 percent from 48 percent and increased a 26.2 percent stake in the Newmont Mining Corporation of the United States to 49.7 percent. The move foiled a plan by the Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens, who wanted to acquire Newmont. Jack Jones, a mining analyst at Philips & Drew, said Consolidated ''would rather have cash in hand as their corporate strategy is aimed very much toward North America.''

title: A Modern Computer Chip Is Born
description: In the early years, creating an integrated circuit began with a designer guiding a group of draftsmen who painstakingly mapped out a circuit on drafting paper. Today, the draftsmen are gone and circuit designers sit in front of powerful engineering work stations. They lay out and test a new chip design on a computer screen before storing the design on a special tape for transmission to a semiconductor factory.

title: A Young Partnership Completes Second Deal
description: Vestar Capital Partners Inc., led by Daniel S. O'Connell and Arthur J. Nagle, did the second deal of its young life this week, agreeing to acquire Celestial Seasonings Inc., an herbal tea company, from Kraft Inc.

title: Japan to Press 3d World Aid
description: Japan will apparently press ahead with its plan to help debt-ridden third world nations at a series of international monetary meetings in West Berlin later this month, Government sources said today.

title: Two Bond Issues Offered by Ohio
description: The State of Ohio entered the tax-exempt market yesterday with two competitive issues totaling $155 million. Both bond issues were successfully bid by Kidder, Peabody & Company as lead underwriter.

title: Distributed Logic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The company said it had a pre-tax profit of $14,119 in the latest quarter. It also said it is required to make a provision for foreign taxes on its overseas income, which resulted in a consolidated after-tax loss in the latest quarter.

title: Anchorage Steps Up Bid for Winter '94
description: The weather here has been quite warm lately, which makes the smiling men and women in blue, fur-lined parkas look a bit odd.

title: Yanks Get Big Boost From Aguayo; Gooden Loses; Yankees 5, Indians 4
description: More than Mel Hall's safety hung in the balance as the left fielder for the Indians dangled from he outfield wall in the eighth inning tonight. The score and, as it turned out, the game did, too.

title: First Federal Savings & Loan (Georgetown) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company went public last December.

title: Real Estate; A West Side Hotel Seeks A New Niche
description: THE Empire Hotel, a Broadway landmark that enjoyed a vogue after it opened in the 1920's and then gradually inched toward genteel obscurity, is being bought by an unlikely owner, the giant Metromedia Company, as its first venture into the hospitality business.

title: 6 Weeks: Who Changed Sides
Space Shuttle Can Be Safely Launched, Panel Says
description: An independent review board overseeing the redesign of the space shuttle booster rockets said yesterday that it was satisfied that no safety concerns stood in the way of launching the first mission since the Challenger disaster two and a half years ago.

title: Review/Architecture; Chicago Art Institute's Addition Retains Links to the Beaux-Arts
description: As a building, the Art Institute of Chicago has always been an accurate barometer of this city's architectural temperature. In 1893, as Chicago's rising ambitions found expression in the lavish architecture of the Beaux-Arts, the institute opened its main building, an elaborate Renaissance pile by Shepley, Rutan & Coolidge, on Michigan Avenue. In the mid-20th century there were numerous modern additions, culminating in a sprawling section of travertine and glass designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. And this week, at the end of the 1980's, the museum returned to the classical architecture of its beginnings with the opening of a vast addition designed by Thomas Beeby of the Chicago firm of Hammond, Beeby & Babka.

title: July Home Completions Up
description: The completion of new homes in the United States rose by three-tenths of a percent in July, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.51 million units, after a 3.6 percent increase in June, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Kit Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Tomb in Peru Yields Stunning Pre-Inca Trove
description: Archeologists in Peru have uncovered what they describe as the richest cache of pre-Columbian artifacts ever found in the Americas, a burial site containing finely crafted gold jewelry and implements and a wealth of ceramics.

title: Quayle, Using Jokes and Jabs, Assails Dukakis on Military
description: Senator Dan Quayle turned to ridicule and hyperbole today in an effort to counter Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's increasingly insistent assertion that a Dukakis Presidency would strengthen the United States militarily.

title: European Talks On Currency
description: Central bankers in the European Community took the first steps today toward a European monetary union, but some said creation of a common currency or a European central bank remained distant goals.

title: Ralph Henry Schust, Executive, 84
description: Ralph Henry Schust, a retired vice president of Sunshine Biscuits, died of complications from Alzheimer's disease Sept 5 at the Sunnyside Nursing Home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in Sarasota.

title: Denver Symphony Gets Bankruptcy Reprieve
description: The Denver Symphony, faced last Friday with the prospect of bankruptcy proceedings, has announced a 21-day reprieve during which state, city, business and cultural groups will try to meet a projected shortfall of $655,000 in the orchestra's budget.

title: Judy's Inc reports earnings for
description: b-Net income

title: Rates on Mortgages Rise
description: Interest rates on home mortgages rose in August to the highest level since January, pushing a typical 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage to 10.8 percent last month, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Wine Talk
description: JACQUES Borie made his fortune in West Africa, then returned to France and the little commune of Fronsac, a few miles from here, to restore the Chateau La Riviere and its vineyards.

title: Needs Strain Social Services And Budgets
description: From welfare offices to municipal ambulance services, New York City is feeling the pinch of expanding demands and increasingly limited resources.

title: Second Plunge For Monsanto
