description: The price of the Monsanto Company's shares plunged for a second day in response to concerns about its liability for the Copper-7 intrauterine birth-control device, manufactured by its G. D. Searle & Company subsidiary.

title: Educators Assail U.S. Curbs on Access to Data
description: Seven years ago John Wiener, a history professor at the University of California at Irvine, began teaching undergraduate students about the life of John Lennon, the former Beatle.

title: Proler International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
5 Die and 14 Injured As a Boulder Slams Bus in New Mexico
description: A large boulder tumbled onto a roadway after a thunderstorm and sheared off the front of a Greyhound bus late Monday, killing the driver and 4 passengers and injuring 14 other people, the authorities said.

title: 2 More Engineers Sue Shuttle Rocket Maker
description: Two former safety engineers working for Morton Thiokol Inc., maker of the booster rocket whose failure touched off the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, have sued the company, charging that their work had been blocked and that important safety information about the shuttle booster rockets had been kept from the space agency.

title: DUKAKIS SUGGESTS CAUTION ON U.S.S.R.
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, eager to allay doubts about his ability to manage Soviet-American relations, reached for conservative, largely mainstream ground on superpower relations with a speech today that emphasized his reservations about changes in the Kremlin. But he called for America to ''seize the initiative'' from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: Help for the Grieving
description: To The Living Section:

title: Schools Feel Censorship Pressure
description: Schools and libraries face growing pressure to censor the books children read, a report by the American Association of School Administrators says.

title: LESSONS
description: Two years ago the Reagan Administration offered a bold strategy for streamlining the Federal student aid program.

title: Bonn Hails Release of Last Hostage
description: West German leaders today hailed the release of the last German hostage in Beirut as the reward for several years of efforts to build up contacts with Iran.

title: Checking Out
description: After spending his first season in jail and finding himself on the third string at the start of his third season, Barry Word has retired as a running back for the New Orleans Saints. The 24-year-old Word, who won extensive praise from Coach Jim Mora for his work in training camp, said he was disappointed that he had not carried the ball once in the Saints' first two games. He gained 133 yards last season, but this year the running game has been dominated by Dalton Hilliard, Reuben Mayes and the team's No. 1 draft choice, Craig (Ironhead) Heyward. Word was a third-round draft choice in 1986 out of Virginia, but sat out his first season, spending 18 weeks in jail after pleading guilty to conspiracy to distribute cocaine. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: A report in the TV Notes column on Monday about the first broadcast of ''CE Newsmagazine'' gave an incorrect date. The program, which is weekly, will have its New York premiere on Oct. 16 at 6:30 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the ap-pointment of C. David Burgin as editor of The Houston Post and a correction in this space yesterday misstated Mr. Burgin's previous positions at The Washington Star. He was sports editor of The Star from 1971 to 1973, metropolitan editor until 1975 and assistant managing editor for weekends from 1976 to 1977.

title: A Jersey Team Tackles Tragedy
description: Like many communities in northern New Jersey, this small town is alive with activity in the fall. The streets are filled with young people returning from school and homeowners trying to keep their lawns clear of falling leaves.

title: Microdyne Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a gain of $227,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months. The latest periods' losses included a writedown of $648,000 for discontinued products.

title: JG Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net income and included a pre- tax gain of $424,000 from the sale of assets.

title: NBC Plans to Interrupt Olympics for a Debate
description: The likely audience for the first Presidential debate was increased substantially today when NBC, reversing an earlier decision, announced that it would take a 90-minute break from the Olympics on Sept. 25 to broadcast the debate live at 8 P.M. Eastern time.

title: Lancaster Colony Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The shares outstanding and share earnings adjusted for the 10 percent stock dividend in January 1988.

title: U.S. Propaganda Effort on Latin Policy Reported
description: A staff report by the House Foreign Affairs Committee says the White House set up a ''domestic political and propaganda campaign'' that used intelligence agents to promote the Administration's policies in Central America.

title: Books of The Times; First-Person Stories, Tidy and Not
description: Stories in an Almost Classical Mode By Harold Brodkey 596 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies yesterday reversed the identifications of the candidates for the Democratic nomination for Mario Biaggi's Congressional seat in the Bronx. The man with the mustache was Assemblyman Eliot L. Engel; the other was Vincent Marchiselli.

title: Hans W. Frei, 66; Theologian Studied Biblical Narrative
description: Hans Wilhelm Frei, whose studies of narrative in the Bible have had a major impact on recent theological discussion, died of a stroke yesterday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in North Haven, Conn.

title: Rangers Prove a Big Hit in Quebec
description: Although the Rangers have attracted a contingent of about 30 reporters from the United States and Canada, almost all the attention here has been focused on Guy Lafleur, who is trying to return to hockey, and Coach Michel Bergeron, who spent six years here coaching the local junior team.

title: Warsaw and Solidarity Appear Stuck Over Talks
description: Poland's Communist leaders and the outlawed Solidarity union appeared deadlocked today in efforts to revive direct talks, after the Government spokesman accused the union of ''pressure tactics and reluctance to compromise.''

title: In Botswana, Pope Takes Note Of the Faithful a Border Away
description: Walking slowly behind the other prelates in the traveling entourage of Pope John Paul II is a tall, white-haired man whose role in the Pope's African pilgrimage bears a symbol dimension.

title: Major Battles Reported in Salvador's North
description: Heavy fighting was reported today in rebel strongholds in northern areas of El Salvador, a military spokesman said.

title: Muslims Battling a Move to Seize Mosque
description: Seven years ago, 1266 Bedford Avenue was a crumbling one-story building, a haven for drug users that reeked of cooked cocaine.

title: British Gas Buys 1.14% of Lasmo
description: British Gas P.L.C., the British gas supply utility, said it had bought two million shares, or a 1.14 percent stake, in London and Scottish Marine Oil P.L.C., the North Sea oil exploration company more familiarly known as Lasmo. Lasmo said it had been told by British Gas that the utility had instructed its stockbrokers to enter the market to buy a significant Lasmo stake.

title: Bush Campaign Adviser Quits
description: A sixth adviser to the Presidential campaign of Vice President Bush resigned today after allegations were raised about anti-Semitic involvements. The campaign said the official, Radi Slavoff, quit as national co-chairman of Bulgarians for Bush. An article in The Philadelphia Inquirer identified Mr. Slavoff as former chief of a Bulgarian group formed after World War II and consisting of members of the Nazi-aligned Bulgarian Legion. Mr. Slavoff did not return calls today.

title: In Seoul, Let the Eating Begin
description: EVEN as South Korea modernizes and the people adopt Western dining habits - even with Wendy's and Burger Kings dotting Seoul - the native cuisine remains intact. Visitors to the Olympic Games, which open in Seoul Friday, will find that the dishes served in restaurants and homes are based on recipes hundreds of years old, the cuisine of a culture that dates back some 5,000 years.

title: CHILEAN TV BARS OPPOSITION TAPE
description: A television videotape prepared by opponents of Gen. Augusto Pinochet was kept off the air Monday night because it showed a criminal court judge accusing Government intelligence agents of torture.

title: KEY RATES
Salmon Pastrami
description: To The Living Section:

title: Why It's a Hot Dog
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Women Succeed as Producers, But Easy Street Is Down the Road
description: In an industry dominated by men and blockbusters, producing movies has not come easily to Midge Sanford and Sarah Pillsbury.

title: Schools Accused of Cheating on California Tests
description: Education officials in California have uncovered incidents dating to 1985 in which school personnel in 45 public elementary schools changed answers on standardized state tests that measure a school's progress in reading, writing and mathematics. Officials said more schools might be guilty of cheating.

title: Agreement on Remington Auction
description: The Remington Art Museum of Ogdensburg, N. Y., signed an agreement yesterday with the Roman Bronze Works, a Queens foundry, to share in the proceeds of a group of works by Frederic Remington to be auctioned Saturday by Guernsey's at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street.

title: Grand Met's Stake In Irish Distillers
description: The giant hotel and liquor company Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said it had raised its stake in the Irish Distillers Group P.L.C. to 20.1 percent, from 14.6 percent. Grand Met, through its wholly owned subsidiary GC&C Brands Ltd., is making a hostile bid of 332 million Irish pounds, or about $481 million, for Irish Distillers, which dominates the Irish whisky market.

title: My Lai Figure Dies a Drifter In a Shooting
description: Robert W. T'Souvas died homeless at the age of 39 years, shot in the head after reportedly quarreling over a bottle of vodka under a downtown bridge.

title: Centuri Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $3,783,000 and $3,965,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and tax credits of $87,000 for the quarter and $460,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $98,000 for the quarter and $211,000 for the 6 months, and tax credits of $103,000 and $504,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the year-ago second quarter revenue included $3,000,000 received from Eastman Kodak Co. for the transfer of certain Snomax product rights to them. The company did not have any revenue in the latest second quarter.

title: 2d Developer Joins With New York City To Build Apartments
description: The Milstein Organization, one of New York City's largest residential and commercial developers, has agreed to build for very limited profit more than 1,000 apartments in the Clinton section of Manhattan, company representatives and city officials have said.

title: The Hudson Valley: Moving Beyond the Apple
description: NOT long ago, a well-known Chicago chef raved about the variety of foods in his region and said he felt sorry for his counterparts in New York because their state grew nothing but apples.

title: Burger King Hurts Pillsbury
description: Citing sluggish sales at its Burger King subsidiary and a need to invest in that unit, the Pillsbury Company said yesterday that it expected operating results in the first fiscal quarter to be flat compared with the $57 million profit, or 66 cents a share, in the 1987 quarter.

title: General Instrument Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Current-Account Deficit Shrinks 9.8% in Quarter
description: The deficit in the nation's trade balance, as gauged by the broadest measure, shrank sharply in the second quarter, when overseas sales of American merchandise surged to a record high.

title: British Productivity Up
description: Britain increased its manufacturing productivity faster than its rivals did in the mid-1980's but is still trailing West Germany, France, Japan and the United States, the private PA Consulting Group and the Confederation of British Industry reported today.

title: Sun City Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net income

title: Reviews/Music; Loren Schoenberg Plays Catchy Ellington Sound
description: Loren Schoenberg's big-band show at the Cat Club on Sunday night, a joint production of the Duke Ellington Society and the New York Swing Dance Society, should be judged on how well those on the packed dance floor moved. The drummer Mel Lewis - helped along by the sturdy walking lines of Peter Washington on bass - propelled the band, throwing in rhythmic kicks to make things more lively. Dancers were writhing and swinging on the fast tunes, and swaying gracefully on the ballads.

title: People
description: * Robert Hatfield has been appointed executive vice president, deputy director Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Retail Division.

title: Boy, 11, Among 80 Charged In Drug Investigation on L.I.
description: More than 80 people, including an 11-year-old boy, have been charged with selling small amounts of cocaine, ending a four-month undercover operation, the Nassau County District Attorney said today.

title: A Rock Album Aimed at Soviet Youth
description: Twenty-four leading rock musicians and groups, including U2, Terence Trent D'Arby and Sting, are donating some of their biggest hits to a new double albumthat will carry the latest Western rock music to the Soviet Union.

title: Soviet Corn Purchase
description: Moscow maintained its brisk buying pace of United States corn this week, purchasing 350,000 more metric tons of corn for shipment this fall, the United States Agriculture Department reported today. With the latest sale, Soviet purchases in the past two weeks total 2.95 million metric tons.

title: Hippocrates in the Pentagon
description: Recent indications of widespread misconduct by a network of Defense Department employees, consultants and contractors have reinforced popular impressions of serious problems in the Pentagon. These concerns threaten to unleash an avalanche of hastily considered legislative ''reforms'' even before official confirmation of wrongdoing. One proposal, for example, would create an independent, civilian-run agency to develop and procure all major weapons.

title: Rymer Company reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $122,000 and $727,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and included net from discontinued operations of $40,000 and $175,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary gain of $365,000 and $812,000 for the same periods, respectively. After preferred dividend requirements, there were no common share earnings on the year-ago third quarter and 9 months final nets.

title: Passion for Frogs' Legs
description: To The Living Section:

title: Market Place; Analysts Wary On Chip Maker
description: AFTER shocking Wall Street on Monday with a first-quarter loss far bigger than expected, the National Semiconductor Corporation came back yesterday with a broad announcement of new products from its mainframe computer business, National Advanced Systems.

title: Rhode Island Tops List In Mental Health Care
description: Rhode Island has the best state programs to care for the seriously mentally ill while Arizona and Hawaii have the worst, according to a report issued today by two consumer health groups.

title: Envoy Security Bureau Faces a Budget Squeeze
description: For the last two years, according to its critics, the Bureau of Diplomatic Security lived high on the hog while the rest of the State Department had to slash projects to survive what has been called the worst budget crisis in its history.

title: Tons of Toys Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The company became a public company on May 6, 1987, by issuing 1.3 million shares of common stock.

title: Southern Co reports earnings for 12mo July 31
description: Fiscal 1987 period included an after- tax writeoff of about $229 million related to cost excesses at a nuclear power plant and the same period is also restated to reflect an accounting change and the March 3 merger with Savannah Electric & Power Co.

title: Eating Well
description: A CLASSIC school lunch -fried chicken, mashed potatoes with gravy, steamed vegetables, cheese biscuits with butter and a peach half with whipped cream - has about as much to do with healthful eating as does the typical fare at fast-food outlets.

title: E.P.A. Issues New Rules on Underground Tanks
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today issued what it called ''comprehensive and stringent'' rules for protecting water supplies from leaks of petroleum and other toxic substances from underground storage tanks.

title: Campaign Trail; Loaded for Bear And Then Some
description: Forget John Wayne and Clint Eastwood. Forget Rambo. Meet Macho Mike Dukakis.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In terms of gold and larger artifacts, this find isn't as large as Tutankhamen's. But in terms of its importance to archeology in the Americas, it is that significant.'' - Christopher B. Donnan, U.C.L.A. anthropologist, on discovery of 1,500-year-old tomb in Peru. [ A1:4. ]

title: Boxing Notebook; In the Tyson Camp, Truce Is Tenuous
description: Two days before Mike Tyson drove into a tree in Catskill, N.Y., Ruth Roper, the mother of Robin Givens, the heavyweight champion's wife, was talking of a thaw in her relationship with Tyson's manager, Bill Cayton.

title: Wampler-Longacre-Rockingam Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Includes a credit of $1,112,000 representing cumulative effect of an accounting change. Year-earlier figures are pro-forma to reflect the issuance of shares in January 1988 to the former holders of Rockingham Poultry marketing cooperative.

title: Tongass Forest Jobs Are Needed by Alaska
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Fears for Roe Ruling
description: The author of the 15-year-old United States Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion in the case of Roe v. Wade warned Tuesday that the ruling could be overturned in the 1988 term of the court.

title: Petrie Stores Chief Considering Buyout
description: The Petrie Stores Corporation, an operator of women's apparel shops, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive is considering acquiring the remaining shares in the company he does not currently own.

title: Western Publishing Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The company said the record first half results reflect strong overall product line performance in its base consumer business, led by its new game product, Pictionary.

title: Administration Rethinks Policy On Forest Fires
description: President Reagan said today he had questions about the National Park Service's policy of allowing certain forest fires to burn unattended as it became clear that the Administration plans to reassess the policy.

title: About New York; Limousine King Puts Fantasies On Four Wheels
description: The sleek limousine glides to a halt, preferably in a position visible from her window. The chauffeur leaps out carrying a single elegant rose to fetch the young lovely. Waiting patiently is the self-anointed prince of the evening, nonchalantly preparing to uncork the fine champagne.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE term fricassee has become better known in recent years with the popularity of Cajun and Creole cuisines, which feature a variety of dishes under that name. Sometimes cooks erroneously equate fricassee with stew, but the two are fundamentally different.

title: Campaign Trail; Republicans Raising Cash and Eyebrows
description: It is the season of the Jewish New Year. A woman in New York opened her mail the other morning and was startled to receive a New Year's card from George and Barbara Bush.

title: What Is Russian for First Amendment?
description: To the Editor:

title: Perelman Stock Sale Fuels Takeover Talk
description: Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire chairman of Revlon Inc., yesterday sold his 15 percent interest in TW Services Inc., the big food-services company, creating intense Wall Street speculation that he was raising money for a takeover battle.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Recalled Pete Harnisch and Bob Milacki, pitchers; Carl Nichols, catcher; Keith Hughes and Jeff Stone, outfielders, and Craig Worthington, third baseman, from Rochester of the International League. MONTREAL (NL) - Recalled Randy Johnson, pitcher, and Johnny Paredes, second baseman, from Indianapolis of the American Association. Announced that Joe Sparks, Indianapolis manager, would join the team for the remainder of the season as a coach. COLLEGES COLUMBIA - Named Anthony Perrone acting women's track and cross-country coach. MANSFIELD - Named Rich Marshall assistant men's basketball coach. ST. PETER'S - Announced the resignation of Jim Gilrain, football coach. Named Joe Dolinski, Bob Thomas and Ben Scholz interim football coaches. FOOTBALL NATIONAL FOOTBALL LEAGUE -Suspended Antonio Gibson, New Orleans safety, and Leonard Mitchell, Atlanta tackle, for 30 days for violating the league's substance-abuse policy. ATLANTA (NFC) - Signed Lew Barnes, punt returner. DALLAS (NFC) - Released Luis Zendejas, place-kicker. Activated Roger Ruzek, place-kicker. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Placed Phil Epps, wide receiver, and Jerry Boyarsky, nose tackle, on injured reserve. Waived John Corker, linebacker, and Tom Neville, lineman. Signed Darryl Haley, lineman, and Bob Nelson, nose tackle. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Signed Billy (White Shoes) Johnson, wide receiver-punt returner, and Ron Middleton, tight end. Placed Barry Wilburn, cornerback, and Reggie Branch, running back, on injured reserve.

title: Boston Jurors Convict Seven In Police Corruption Inquiry
description: Seven present and former Boston police officers on trial in Federal District Court were found guilty today of extorting thousands of dollars in bribes from restaurant and nightclub owners in the neighborhoods they patrolled.

title: Another Endowment at Yale, but This One's in Football
description: Yale University announced today that it had received a $1 million gift from an alumnus to establish a new endowed position, head football coach.

title: Joseph Ceravolo, 54, A Prize-Winning Poet
description: Joseph Ceravolo, a prize-winning poet who was a professional civil engineer, died of cancer of the bile duct on Sept. 4 at Clara Maas Medical Center in Belleville, N.J. He was 54 years old and lived in Bloomfield, N.J.

title: Olympic Notebook; Plan to Limit Parade Doesn't Last Long
description: For a moment today, the Seoul Olympics were facing the possibility of a labor dispute.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Bush Urges Midwest Voters To Help Avert Fiscal Shift
description: John Blankenburg, a Chicago businessman, did not pay much attention when Vice President Bush took swipes at Michael S. Dukakis and ''Taxachusetts'' and Democratic ''prophets of pessimism'' in an economic speech in Chicago this morning.

title: Old Keynesianism Doesn't Fit Today's Economy; Social Security Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Surgery for Stram
description: His doctors called it strictly routine, but for Hank Stram, the former N.F.L. coach and current broadcast analyst, the four-and-a-half-hour operation at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis could have been a life-saver. During the surgery, doctors replaced Stram's main heart valve with an artificial version. The 65-year-old Stram, who lives in Covington, La., entered the hospital Saturday, complaining of dizziness. He was in Indianapolis preparing for the CBS telecast of the Sunday game between the Colts and the Chicago Bears. Stram is expected to remain in the hospital for 8 to 10 days. (AP)

title: Loss Posted At Federated
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., which has been restructured since being acquired by the Campeau Corporation, today reported a second-quarter loss of $100 million, on sales of $970.5 million.

title: Wrong Radar - and Wrong Remedy
description: The White House is using peculiarly self-defeating tactics in these final months of its strategic arms negotiations with Moscow. It has threatened to declare an illegal Soviet radar to be a ''material breach'' of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, the diplomatic prelude to scrapping the treaty. It has even declared that it will sign no new treaties reducing nuclear arms until the radar is torn down.

title: St. Peter's Coach Out
description: Jim Gilrain resigned yesterday as the football coach at St. Peter's College just three days before the Peacocks' opener against Iona. Gilrain did not give a reason for quitting, said Jim Hague, sports-information director at the school. Three assistant coaches -Joe Dolinski, Bob Thomas and Ben Scholz - will run the team in the interim, Hague said, adding that a new coach will be appointed shortly.

title: Long Way From Home
description: Joseph F. Salgado is being sworn in as Deputy Secretary of Energy today. A ho-hum event, you say? He is taking the oath of office while working in the Soviet Union, monitoring an underground nuclear explosion at Semipalatinsk, the Soviet nuclear testing site. Troy Wade, the acting Assistant Secretary of Energy for Defense Programs, was deputized to perform the swearing in. The Soviet Union scheduled an underground nuclear detonation for this morning, presumably after Mr. Salgado is sworn in.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. said Roger D. Semerad had joined it as senior vice president of policy development.

title: RATING MENTAL HEALTH CARE
description: State-by-state rankings on the level of care provided for the seriously mentally ill as compiled by Health Research Group and the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill.

title: Connaught Biosciences reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After $3,500,000 in costs associated with the recent tender offer by Institu Merieux and Alternative Actions examined by the company to exchange shareholder value for both the quarter and 6 months. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company was formerly known as CDC Life Sciences Inc.

title: Auction Rates At Citicorp Fall
description: Interest rates fell yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: Audi Sees Recovery In American Sales
description: United States car sales of Audi A.G., a subsidiary of Volkswagen A.G., are finally recovering from adverse publicity about reports of safety defects, Ferdinand Piech, its managing board chairman, said. Audi sold about 3,200 cars in the United States in August, twice July's total, he said. ''It looks as if we have reached the end of the tunnel,'' he said.

title: Polaroid Sets Date On Shamrock Bid
description: The Polaroid Corporation, target of an unsolicited $2.4 billion tender offer by the investor Roy E. Disney, said its directors plan to issue a recommendation on the $42-a-share bid by Sept. 22, when the company is obligated by law to respond. Polaroid, based in Cambridge, Mass., also postponed the effective date of an anti-takeover measure until at least then.

title: Cadillac Focus On Large Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation's Cadillac Motor division today introduced its 1989 lineup and acknowledged it was returning to its traditional strategy of big cars for older buyers. But John Grettenberger, Cadillac general manager, said 1989 was likely to be a volatile year in the luxury car market.

title: Reviews/Music; Marilyn Sokol's Comedy
description: Few performers take more delight in sifting through the arcane crannies of show business history than Marilyn Sokol. The comedian and singer, whose new act plays at the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street) through Sept. 24, is steeped in a tradition of music-hall merriment that embraces everyone from Fanny Brice to Bette Midler. To this tradition she adds her own brand of conspiratorial fun, eschewing the role of brassy entertainer to play a precocious child whose mischievous party humor only partly masks an underlying vulnerability.

title: In Paris, a Passion For Faux Chanel
description: IF it has two C's and is counterfeit, you can bet your last franc it's selling here.

title: Some Major Changes For Partners & Shevack
description: Calvillo, Shevack & Partners, the Mickelberry Corporation subsidiary that lost Ricardo C. Calvillo last June, has changed its name to Partners & Shevack and is working on a deal to make a portion of the agency's equity available to its work force.

title: INSIDE
description: 3 Flee to U.S. Consulate

title: The Talk Of Fishers Island; Isle's Summer Gentry Squeezing Out 'Locals'
description: Summer lingers like a long, slow sunset on this island stretch of beaches, bluffs and meadows. Nannies and au pairs still roam the estates. The Big Club, as its members call the exclusive Fishers Island Club, will stay open for another month. The more plebeian Pequot Inn, the island's only hotel, will not close until Thanksgiving.

title: Alfin Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $8,669,000 and $14,618,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Peters, J M Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
How Do You Spell Food? L-a-r-o-u-s-s-e
description: IF there is a culinary bible, it is Larousse Gastronomique. This monumental tome by Prosper Montagne, originally published in France by Librairie Larousse in 1938, is an alphabetical listing of ingredients, dishes, utensils and historical references, with thousands of recipes along the way. It is an extraordinary catalogue.

title: A Clash of Aims Among Shooters
description: LEAD: A photograph, now 12 years old, shows two people sharing the top platform of an Olympic awards platform. On the left is the bespectacled Margaret Murdock, singing the national anthem. On the right is Lanny Bassham, the gold medalist, holding his United States Olympic shooting-team cap over his heart.

title: Intensifying Storm Routs 500,000
description: With squalls still raking Jamaica, Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga estimated today that 500,000 people -almost one-fourth of the population -were left homeless by the hurricane that ripped across the island on Monday.

title: Japanese Offering Totals $150 Million
description: The Japan Finance Corporation is offering in the United States $150 milion of 9 1/4 percent guaranteed notes due in 1998 at a price of 99.36 to yield 9.35 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: U.S. Studies Phone Fraud
description: Americans are losing at least $1 billion a year in fraudulent telephone sales, the Federal Trade Commission told Congress today.

title: San Salvador Journal; Leftists Try Election Path, Sniped at From 2 Sides
description: When word spread recently that leaders of the Salvadoran leftist coalition were planning an election campaign swing into the countryside, the head of a construction union immediately and publicly warned them to stay home.

title: A Law-and-Order Look at Ed Meese
description: Edwin Meese, who resigned as Attorney General in a hail of criticism over his ethics, blamed his troubles on political partisans, disloyal and ambitious underlings and an overzealous special prosecutor who said he probably committed crimes. He took comfort from President Reagan's constant support. Now from a law-and-order appointee of the same President comes yet another condemnation of Mr. Meese's behavior in office.

title: New Yonkers Plan Divides N.A.A.C.P.
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People appeared divided today over changes, negotiated by its lawyer, as a means of obtaining City Council approval for a court-ordered housing desegregation plan.

title: Mideast Oil for Pretoria
description: Seventeen cargoes of crude oil reached South Africa in the first eight months of 1987 from the Middle East despite an embargo by producers in that area, the Shipping Research Bureau, a Dutch private monitoring group, reported today. It said the cargoes, totaling 4.3 million metric tons, represented 45 percent of South Africa's import needs in that period. All 17 tankers sailed directly to South Africa from the Persian Gulf without disclosing the actual destination.

title: Club Doors Are Open, But Women Draw Back
description: FOR years after Muriel Siebert became the first woman to buy a seat on the New York Stock Exchange she could not find one in the dining rooms of many of New York's leading private clubs. Yet Ms. Siebert, who bought her seat in 1967 and who now runs a brokerage, recently turned down an invitation to join the University Club, which voted to admit women in August 1987.

title: A Special Way With Simple Food
description: BOB Marcelli is a brave man.

title: Minnesota Journal; Bilingual Police to Say, 'Aqui Se Habla Espanol'
description: In a lot of small towns in Minnesota, bilingualism means understanding the occasional Norwegian or Swedish oath, usually muttered at safe distance from the Lutheran pastor.

title: Osicom Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
New Publisher For Newsweek
description: Howard G. Smith, 54 years old and a Newsweek man since 1964, has been named publisher of the magazine. He replaces Gerard Smith, an unrelated Smith who has been named vice chairman. Both men have been executive vice presidents of Newsweek and Gerard Smith has been publisher for three years.

title: Ennis Business Forms Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
South Koreans Woo Communists; Move to Full Ties With Hungary
description: South Korea announced today that it would exchange permanent missions with Hungary, the first step toward diplomatic relations with a Soviet bloc country since South Korea became a separate nation 40 years ago.

title: 'A Hard Line'
description: A holdout by Dino Ciccarelli of the Minnesota North Stars became a freeze-out yesterday when the club announced that it had suspended the eight-year right wing who has stayed away from training camp in a contract dispute. ''We've taken a hard line but hopefully it will work out in the long run,'' said a team spokesman, Joanie Prescott, who said the suspension had been made retroactive to last Saturday. Ciccarelli, who made $215,000 last season, has reportedly sought a multiyear deal that would pay him $400,000 a season, or $100,000 more than the North Stars offered. When negotiations stalled, Ciccarelli, the club's career-leading scorer, demanded to be traded. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a workshop on what to tell children about beggars misidentified the vice president of the Lincoln Square Synagogue in Manhattan. He is Perry Davis.

title: U.S. Issues Climb in a Slow Day
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose in very quiet trading yesterday, recapturing virtually all the ground lost in the previous session.

title: Bridge
description: The considerations that should guide a player to save at a high level are quite complex, and misjudgments are frequent. Suppose you are the West player in the deal shown. Would you bid six spades after the auction shown? You are playing match-points, your partner has opened four spades and the opponents have found their way to six clubs.

title: Applied Data Deal
description: Computer Associates International Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Applied Data Research Inc. from the American Information Technologies Corporation for $170 million. Applied Data, which makes software for data base management and application development systems, had revenues of about $170 million in 1987. The company said Ameritech wasselling Applied Data because synergies between software and communications had not developed to the extent that had been expected. The company said completion of the purchase was subject to regulatory clearance.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: National Semiconductor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Net income The latest first quarter loss included a one-time, pre-tax restructuring charge of $16.6 million, and also reflected continued pressures on the information systems group. The year-ago period has been restated to reflect the fiscal 1988 adoption and retroactive application of a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Economic Scene; The Dukakis Plan On College Loans
description: IT is no great surprise that Michael S. Dukakis's college loan plan was dismissed as unfair and unworkable by Bruce Carnes, the Deputy Under Secretary of Education and an adviser to the Bush campaign. But it is ironic that the proposal is taking a beating from Mr. Carnes, who is one of the Reagan Administration's most articulate defenders of the conservative faith.

title: Massachusetts Winery Shuts Doors
description: The days of wine and losses are over for David S. Tower.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 26 about rapids rides at United States amusement parks named the ride builders incompletely. Rapids rides have been built not only by the Swiss concern of Intamin but also by the Barr Engineering Company of Minneapolis and in some instances by park staff workers and local contractors.

title: Herbs Out of Season
description: To The Living Section:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-20

title: Food for Thought
description: To The Living Section:

title: Harvey Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-After tax benefits of $132,000 for the quarter and $296,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax benefits of $5,000 for the quarter and $149,000 for the 6 months.

title: Brady Backs Most Reagan Policies
description: Treasury Secretary-designate Nicholas F. Brady told Congress today that he would urge the continuation of most economic policies of the Reagan Administration in the next administration, including the President's dollar and debtor-country positions and his opposition to raising taxes to reduce the budget deficits.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Kroger is considering a $3.2 billion restructuring plan in order to resist a possible takeover attempt by the Haft family of Maryland. The plan would involve payment of a special $40 dividend for each of Kroger's 78.6 million shares of common stock, at a cost of more than $3.1 billion. Kroger's stock soared $11.75, to $51.25, with more than 7 million shares changing hands. [ Page D1. ] Ronald O. Perelman sold his 15 percent interest in TW Services, the big food-services company, creating intense Wall Street speculation that he was raising money for a takeover battle. [ D1. ] Colgate-Palmolive agreed to a $960 milllion sale of its Kendall hospital-supply and health-care unit. The buyers are Clayton & Dubilier and Kendall management. [ D1. ] A New York law firm has been accused of a conflict of interest in a report by a court-appointed examiner in the A. H. Robins bankruptcy case, lawyers who have seen the document said. [ D1. ] I.B.M. is being challenged by a consortium of computer makers, software companies and manufacturers of accessories, who want to develop a rival standard for personal computers. [ D5. ] A buyout of Petrie Stores is being considered by its chairman and chief executive, who already owns more than 60 percent of the company's stock. [ D5. ] Monsanto's shares fell sharply for the second day, losing $4, to $74.625, in response to concerns over the company's liability for a birth-control device made by its G. D. Searle subsidiary. [ D5. ] THE ECONOMY Nicholas F. Brady said he favored a continuation of Reagan economic policies in the next administration. Mr. Brady testified before a Senate committee, which confirmed his nomination as Treasury Secretary. [ D1. ] The broadest measure of the trade deficit showed a decline in the second quarter, as overseas sales of American merchandise surged to a record high. [ D2. ] An alternate version of banking legislation will be drafted by the House Energy and Commerce Committee. It promises to be more restrictive than the Banking Committee's bill. [ D11. ] TECHNOLOGY Engineers see no end to the progress of the computer chip. For example, chips can now perform an operation in four-billionths of a second. A decade from now, that speed is likely to be 200-trillionths of a second. [ D1. ] MARKETS Defendants in the Drexel case made their first demand for access to evidence against them but did not request testimony from the Government's star witness, Ivan F. Boesky, defense lawyers and S.E.C. officials said. [ D6. ] Stock prices rose moderately with much of the activity focusing on takeovers and restructurings. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.67 points, to 2,083.04. [ D12. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose in quiet trading, recapturing virtually all the ground lost Monday. [ D19. ] Cotton futures soared on fears that Hurricane Gilbert could bring heavy rains to Texas and damage the crop there. [ D20. ] The dollar rose modestly in light trading. On the Comex, gold rose 30 cents, to $421.50 an ounce. [ D20. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The Dukakis college-loan program has conservative roots, but it is still coming under attack from his conservative critics. Peter Passell. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] National Semiconductor has a credibility problem. The company shocked Wall Street with a first-quarter loss far bigger than had been expected. Market Place. [ D12. ]

title: CSC Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter and 6 months results were increased by $3,357,000, or 39 cents a share, and $4,602,000, or 53 cents a share, respectively, because of an accounting change in the method of valuating inventory to FIFO from LIFO. The year-ago quarter and 6 months results were reduced by $161,000 and the 6 months were increased by $5,473,000 both as a result of the accounting change.

title: Housing-Subsidy Increase Ordered in Suffolk
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ordered New York State and Suffolk County to increase the shelter allowance of a Suffolk woman on public assistance so that she and her family can afford a permanent place to live.

title: Food Notes
description: Chicken, Well Done

title: New Faces
description: The high-stakes Skins Game will have two new faces this year. Curtis Strange, the United States Open champion, and Ray Floyd, the captain of the 1989 Ryder Cup team, will join the defending champion, Lee Trevino, and Jack Nicklaus for the sixth annual game to be played at the PGA West course in LaQuinta, Calif., on Nov. 26 and 27.

title: Ethnic Germans in East Bloc Now Flock to West Germany
description: Their eyes ringed with the fatigue of long journeys and difficult farewells, the newcomers swarm through the barracks and yards of the reception camp speaking in a babel of Slavic tongues and archaic German dialects.

title: M.B. McFarland, 83, A Child Psychologist
description: Margaret B. McFarland, a child psychologist who served as a consultant to Fred Rogers, the host of the children's television show ''Mr. Rogers' Neighborhood,'' died Monday after a long illness. She was 83 years old.

title: Crown Resource reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after gains from discontinued operations of $3,100 and $25,320 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The latest quarter and 6 months included a gain of $4,860,728 on the sale of mining interests.

title: Lauris Norstad Dies at 81; Former NATO Commander
description: Gen. Lauris Norstad, who was commander of United States and North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in Europe during the Berlin crisis, died of cardiac arrest Monday at the Tucson (Ariz.) Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived in Tubac, 40 miles south of Tucson.

title: College Football Notebook; St. John's Runs 83 Yards to Controversy
description: Steve Nieves, the sophomore defensive back for St. John's, picked up the loose ball and froze. The Iona players stood around, too, while Nieves's coach, Bob Ricca, was screaming at him from the sidelines, ''Run, run.''

title: Baseball; Red Sox Go 4 1/2 Up On a Slam by Rice
description: Jim Rice hit the eighth grand slam of his career, and the Boston Red Sox beat the Baltimore Orioles by 6-4 tonight for their seventh victory in nine games.

title: John Crystal, 67, a Career Planner Who Urged Unorthodox Methods
description: John C. Crystal, a career planner known for his unorthodox job-seeking methods, died of acute emphysema Saturday at North Shore Community Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhasset.

title: HRE Properties reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After capital gains of $138,000 for the quarter and $401,000 for the 9 months. c-After capital gains of $128,000 for the quarter and $480,000 for the 9 months.

title: Cushman & Wakefield Head To Run New Chubb Unit
description: Stephen B. Siegel, the chairman of Cushman & Wakefield Inc., a major real estate firm, is leaving to head a new real estate subsidiary of the Chubb Corporation, an insurance company.

title: When to Let the Forest Burn
description: The great walls of fire in Western forests, and the blackened expanses in their wake, are a devastating sight. Some four million acres of the West have been ravaged, including 40 percent of Yellowstone National Park.

title: Charter Revision Made Mysterious
description: The November ballot will include 10 amendments to the New York City Charter proposed by a Charter Revision Commission, covering topics as diverse as mayoral disability, maintaining bridges and other infrastructure and campaign finance.

title: Drexel Defendants Seek S.E.C. Data
description: The defendants in the huge fraud lawsuit brought against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. have made their first demand for access to evidence against them but did not request testimony from the Government's star witness, Ivan F. Boesky, defense lawyers and Securities and Exchange Commission officials said yesterday.

title: 'Moon Over Parador' Is No. 1 at Box Office
description: ''Moon Over Parador,'' a Paul Mazursky comedy about an actor drafted to impersonate a Latin American dictator, grossed $3.27 million in its first weekend of release to finish first at the box office.

title: 2d Kroger Reshaping Considered
description: The Kroger Company, the nation's second-largest supermarket chain, said today that it was considering a $3.2 billion plan to restructure the company for the second time in two years in order to resist a possible takeover attempt by the Haft family of Maryland.

title: Study Shows Teachers Still Feel Left Out on Policy
description: Public school teachers say they are substantially involved in choosing textbooks and instructional materials and in shaping the curriculum but are otherwise excluded from most critical decisions on school policy, a new study has found.

title: Former Senator Alan Bible, 78; Nevadan Was Advocate of Parks
description: Former Senator Alan Bible of Nevada, who began his career in Washington as an elevator operator at the Capitol and subsequentlly served 20 years in the United States Senate, died of pneumonia Monday at Auburn Faith Community Hospital in Auburn, Calif. He was 78 years old and lived in Auburn.

title: Campaign Trail; Dukakis Camp Faces A Balancing Act
description: Governor Dukakis is enduring The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner. Though he yearns to campaign with his wife, Kitty, it is politically smarter for both of them to travel the country separately and thereby cover more voters.

title: 3 Opposition Leaders in Burma Reject Election Plan
description: Three prominent figures in the Burmese opposition told the Government today that they rejected its plan for free elections, in a sign of growing unity among the people who have stepped forward to lead the country's broad-based protest movement.

title: Measurex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Digital Outlook
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation expects its computer sales in Europe to continue growing in the fiscal year ending June 1989, surpassing growth in the United States, a company spokesman said. ''We fully anticipate that our European operations will continue to have another excellent financial year,'' Mark Steinkrauss said at Digital's annual product show, ''and we expect European growth to outpace that in the United States.'' He gave no figures. In the year to July 2, 1988, Digital's sales outside of the United Satates rose a record 50 percent, and 80 percent of that was generated in Western Europe. Digital's European sales rose to $4.22 billion, from $3.25 billion, while profits rose to $770 million, from $635 million.

title: An Evolving Burma: Some Major Political Figures
description: U Ne Win: A 77-year-old former general who took power in a military coup in 1962 and instituted one-party military rule. His philosophy, ''the Burmese way to socialism,'' was a blend of Marxism, Buddhism, isolationism and whimsy that led the country to economic ruin. He resigned the Presidency in 1981 and the party chairmanship July 23, but is believed still to be controlling the Government. U Sein Lwin: A 64-year-old former general who has been at Mr. Ne Win's side for four decades.

title: Lloyd M. H. Francke, A Times Executive, 61
description: Lloyd Mortimer Hastings Francke, director of information sales and services at The New York Times, died of cancer of the bladder yesterday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Poll Shows Bush Sets Agenda For Principal Election Issues
description: Vice President Bush has transformed the 1988 Presidential election into a contest about his issues and has sharply diminished Michael S. Dukakis's image as the more competent leader, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: New York City Sludge Should Continue to Be Dumped at Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Rivals Set Challenge To I.B.M.
description: Since its entry into the personal computer market, the International Business Machines Corporation has been the standard setter for design of the internal workings of the desktop computer.

title: House (or Part of It) Opens With the Pledge of Allegiance
description: The House of Representatives opened its session today with a recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance amid circumstances suggesting that it could become an instant tradition.

title: An Overheated Idea
description: LEAD: Perhaps the greatest threat to the American economy at the moment is an idea. It is the notion that economic growth can cause inflation.

title: 2 Out of 3
description: Manfred Worner, the former West German defense minister who 10 weeks ago became Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, gave his first public address in the new job yesterday. Not surprisingly, he called the alliance's policies a resounding success, but he also displayed a flash of Germanic humor.

title: GNI Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $177,000 for the quarter and income of $94,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and the year also includes a gain of $200,000 from a tax loss carryforward. The company said fiscal 1987 operating numbers have been reclassified into discontinued operations because of the sale of the applicable business segment.

title: A Game Of Kings Now Has Spokes
description: THOSE who have always longed to fill an afternoon with a chukker or two but have lacked the necessary stable of polo ponies can now take heart. Polo, the so-called game of kings, has begun galloping - no, make that pedaling - toward the masses.

title: Law Firm Conflict Seen In Report on Robins Case
description: The court-appointed examiner in the A. H. Robins bankruptcy case has filed a confidential report that concludes that a major New York law firm violated conflict-of-interest standards and should be disqualified from representing the Robins trust for victims of a birth control device, lawyers who have seen the report said yesterday.

title: Calls of Concern Deluge Radon Experts
description: Specialists in reducing household radon contamination said yesterday they had been overwhelmed by reaction to the Government's warning about the nationwide health effects of the gas. While radon buildup is a serious health hazard, they said, it is easy to detect with do-it-yourself kits costing as little as $10, and in most cases fairly inexpensive to correct.

title: Judge Releases Video Artist To Discuss Tompkins Sq. Case
description: A Manhattan artist was released from jail temporarily yesterday after he again refused to surrender a videotape of the clash in Tompkins Square Park to a grand jury.

title: Skaggs Sets Retirement
description: L. S. Skaggs, who built the American Stores Company from a regional drugstore chain into a 1,600-store supermarket and drug giant, will retire after a successor is found, the company announced today. Mr. Skaggs, who took over the Salt Lake City-based company in 1950 when his father died, recently reached the mandatory retirement age of 65, but has been asked by the board to remain while a committee seeks a new chairman and chief executive.

title: Old Keynesianism Doesn't Fit Today's Economy; A Shift to Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Escape From Politics'
description: In a few months residents of the Washington area may be confronted with a foamy side effect of the Iran-contra affair: a light beer called Gold Cup and a dark beer called Virginia Native.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Raymond Carver Tribute
description: A number of writers and editors will take part in a memorial tribute to the writer Raymond Carver on Sept. 22 at noon in St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street. Tobias Wolff, Tess Gallagher, Robert Stone, Richard Ford, Donald Hall, William Heyen, Gary Fisketjon and Ted Solotaroff are among those who will participate in the event, which is open to the public. Mr. Carver died in August at age 50.

title: Primary Election Candidates
description: Following are the candidates in the contested races in tomorrow's primary elections for Congress, the State Legislature and district attorney in the New York metropolitan area. Incumbents are marked with asterisks. DEMOCRATS U.S. Representative Brooklyn 11TH DISTRICT Riaz B. Hussain Edolphus Towns* Manhattan 15TH DISTRICT Peter G. Doukas John B. Levitt George T. McDonald Paul P. Rao Jr. 17TH DISTRICT Harry C. Fotopoulos Theodore S. title: Iran-Iraq Parley Suspended But May Resume at the U.N.
description: The Iran-Iraq talks were recessed today without progress, and a United Nations mediator said he invited the foreign ministers of the two countries to New York for talks with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar on Sept. 22.

title: Vice President Dan Reagan?
description: LEAD: Many right wing Republicans are dissatisfied with their party's Presidential nominee, primarily because he is not another Ronald Reagan. Yet, while Mr. Bush will never be another Reagan, he may have discovered one. The similarities between the President and Senator Dan Quayle are becoming ever more apparent.

title: Review/Pop; Debbie Gibson Sings Of Dreams Come True
description: At age 17, Debbie Gibson is a pop professional. The Long Island songwriter opened her sold-out three-night stand at Radio City Music Hall on Friday with a concert that proved she could sing, dance and work a crowd as smoothly as pop singers 10 years her senior.

title: Stuff Yer Face reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Television; A Comic Who Finds Humor in the Everyday
description: Among the guests on tonight's ''Dick Clark Presents,'' being broadcast live at 8 o'clock on CBS, is Louie Anderson. The comedian is part of a lineup that includes an escape artist, an illusionist and the little clay man known as Mr. Bill. Mr. Anderson will no doubt survive. But those who prefer the Anderson act neat, without distractions, have another alternative, at least if they have access to pay-cable's Home Box Office service. At 9 P.M., HBO's ''On Location'' series will present ''The Louie Anderson Show,'' an hourlong special filmed at Chicago's Park West Theater.

title: The Pop Life
description: Sounds of Populism

title: Boy Dies After Piano Pins Him Against Wall
description: A 7-year-old Brooklyn boy died yesterday after a discarded piano tipped over and pinned him by his neck to a wall in the garbage disposal area of a city housing project, the police said.

title: U.S. DELAYS START OF PLANT TO STORE NUCLEAR WASTES
description: The Department of Energy said today that it was indefinitely postponing the opening of the nation's first permanent repository for nuclear wastes, which was scheduled for next month.

title: Yanks Get Big Boost From Aguayo; Gooden Loses; Pirates 1, Mets 0
description: The game was over, so Dwight Gooden simply left. No goodbyes.

title: Federal Express Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a gain of $18.1 million, or 34 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Chevron Canada Resources Ltd., Calgary, a unit of Chevron Corp., said it would purchase the assets of Columbia Gas Development of Canada Ltd.'s Eastern properties for $82.75 million.

title: Blinder International Enterrises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net income

title: Other Surveys Show Bush With an Edge; Dukakis Leads One
description: The New York Times/CBS News Poll was one of several surveys on the Presidential race made public over the last two days. All but one gave Vice President Bush an edge.

title: Chicago Board Contract Set
description: The first new stock index future approved by regulators since the October stock market crash, the CBOE 250 index, will begin trading Nov. 1 at the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the exchange said today.

title: Spotty Turnout Is Expected In New York Primary Voting
description: With primary contests ranging from the hotly fought to exercises in futility, the turnout in New York State tomorrow is expected to be spotty in an election that is most notable for the number of convicted or indicted candidates on the ballot.

title: Arafat Is Vague on P.L.O.'s Next Steps
description: In his first address to members of the European Parliament, Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, gave no hint tonight of the P.L.O.'s future course in the aftermath of King Hussein's decision in July to abandon Jordanian sovereign claims over the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: Kettle Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-Net income

title: The Chip at 30: Potential Still Vast
description: Thirty years after the invention of the computer chip, engineers see no end to the electronic marvels it can generate.

title: REAGAN, IN SWITCH, SAYS U.S. WILL PAY SOME OLD U.N. DUES
description: President Reagan today authorized the immediate release of some overdue payments to the United Nations, in an attempt to end nearly eight years of conflict between his Administration and the international organization.

title: Federal Home Loan Banks Price $3.6 Billion in Bonds
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks priced a total of $3.6 billion in bonds yesterday for offering through various securities dealers.

title: Bethel Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Hallmark Will Review Agency's Work
description: HALLMARK CARDS, the leader in the greeting card field, is going to be reviewing its advertising, which is currently handled by Ogilvy & Mather. The budget is about $35 million.

title: Dukakis Starts New Round Slugging
description: Shortly after 3 P.M. Monday a report from The Associated Press printer was dropped on the desks of most of the top officials in the campaign of Michael S. Dukakis.

title: U.S. Plans Big Rise in Quota for Asian Refugees
description: The Reagan Administration today proposed an increase in the number of refugees who could be admitted to the United States in the coming year and announced plans for a dramatic increase in the number from Indochina, especially Vietnam.

title: Leonard B. Goldman Physician, 81
description: Leonard B. Goldman, former chief of radiology at Queens General Hospital, died of colon cancer Sunday at his home in Queens. He was 81 years old.

title: About Education
description: More than three million children are starting kindergarten this month, and for many it will be the first opportunity to fail. Depending on their district, it is estimated that 10 to 60 percent of those 5-year-olds will not be allowed to enter first grade a year from now. They will remain in kindergarten for a second year.

title: 3 Pretoria Foes Take Refuge At U.S. Site in Johannesburg
description: Three antiapartheid leaders who were being held under emergency detention laws took refuge in the United States Consulate in Johannesburg today after escaping from a hospital where they were undergoing physical therapy.

title: Leaving a Welfare Hotel, Reluctantly
description: New York City's decision to empty a large and notorious welfare hotel has, paradoxically, brought as much fear as joy to the families who live there. No matter how bad the Martinique Hotel is, many are afraid to leave it.

title: Review/Film; A Reluctant Hippie And His Foxy Grandma
description: Dillon (Peter Capaldi) doesn't really know what it's like ''when you're a Pink Frog'' (to quote a big acid-rock hit of the 1960's), but he thinks perhaps he should. Dillon's father was the leader of the Pink Frogs, but he and Dillon's hippie mother died long before their son ever knew them.

title: Colgate Sells Health Unit to Buyout Group
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Kendall hospital-supply and health-care unit and related businesses for $960 million. The buyers are the leveraged-buyout firm of Clayton & Dubilier and Kendall's management.

title: Reagan Signs Bill to Fight Housing Discrimination
description: President Reagan, signing a bill that strengthens enforcement of laws banning housing discrimination, said today that the measure had brought America a ''step closer to realizing Martin Luther King's dream.''

title: Old Keynesianism Doesn't Fit Today's Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Tougher Banking Legislation Emerges in House
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee is preparing its own version of banking legislation that will be more restrictive than the bill drafted by the House Banking Committee, Representative John D. Dingell, chairman of the commerce panel, said today.

title: Bow Hunters Aided By Special Permit
description: DEER hunting with bow and arrow has become increasingly popular throughout the nation, and for many years there have been special seasons for those who choose to get their venison the hard way.

title: Restaurant Management Services reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $426,302 from an accounting change.

title: Senate Gives Up Effort to Expand Federal Payments for Abortions
description: The Senate today gave up on an effort to permit Federal money to pay for abortions for women made pregnant by rape or incest, voting 47 to 43 to accept a decision by the House of Representatives that retains a prohibition on such spending.

title: American Brands Offers 9 5/8% Notes
description: American Brands Inc. is offering $150 million of 9 5/8 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.75 to yield 9.674 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: 9-Day Sales Of Vehicles Down by 9%
description: Early September sales of new American-made cars and light trucks were off 9 percent from the comparable period a year ago, when buyer incentives were far stronger.

title: Solidarity Also a Challenge to Walesa
description: Even as Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, prepares for a second round of talks with Government negotiators Thursday, the two waves of strikes that brought him from the barricades to the negotiating table are sending ripples of unrest through his outlawed union.

title: Paris Journal; For Lovers of Turmoil, Here Comes 1789 Again
description: Jean-Noel Jeanneney sits in a disheveled office with stacks of books piled up on the floor next to unhung framed prints depicting tumultuous scenes from the French Revolution. Although they have had 200 years to prepare, the French are dreadfully behind in organizing the bicentennial of their epic revolutionary upheaval.

title: Lawrence Ornitz, 53, Beachwear Marketer
description: Lawrence D. Ornitz, who developed a worldwide market for California beachwear fashions, died Monday of complications following coronary bypass surgery at Western Medical Center in Santa Ana, Calif. He was 53 years old and a resident of nearby Tustin.

title: Trial in Utility Case Begins
description: The utility companies that contracted with the Washington Public Power Supply System purposely misled bond buyers about the need for two nuclear power plants and never intended to make good on their $2.25 billion bond debts, a lawyer contended today.

title: Korea Police Thwart Student Raid On Runners With Olympic Torch
description: A small band of radical students tried to attack runners carrying the Olympic torch Wednesday but were held back by riot policemen. It was the first time Korean students have directly made a target of any Olympic-related event.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Y.&R. Plans Joint Venture In Moscow
description: YOUNG & RUBICAM, a leading exponent of agency joint ventures and America's largest independent agency, yesterday announced plans to form a joint venture with Vneshtorgreklama, the Soviet state advertising agency.

title: Review/Television; 'Date Rape' Examines Choices
description: ''Date Rape'' is the title of today's ABC ''Afterschool Special,'' at 4 o'clock. It also seems to be this season's priority subject in programming for young people. Next month, CBS's ''Schoolbreak Special'' series will be covering much the same territory in ''No Means No.''

title: Drexel Defense Set to Attack Boesky
description: Court filings this week by defendants in the Drexel Burnham Lambert securities fraud case strongly suggest that their defense will be based on an assault on the credibility of the Government's main witness, Ivan F. Boesky.

title: American Income
description: The American Income Life Insurance Company said its chairman, Bernard Rapoport, was holding discussions with various parties about leading a leveraged buyout at a price of $18 a share. Based on the company's 11.7 million shares outstanding, such an offer would value it at about $210.6 million. A special meeting of the board has been called for Sept. 19.

title: Lynn Ruled Eligible for Postseason Play
description: Fred Lynn, the man whose mad dash in a chartered plane got him to Chicago 10 minutes too late, will be eligible to play postseason games if the Detroit Tigers go that far, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth ruled today.

title: Two Women at Work: Living the Story of Korea's Sorrows and Triumphs
description: They grew up at opposite ends of their nation, a generation apart. But each, in her own way, is a survivor in this nation of survivors.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think God likes humor. I think there's too much of it for it just to be an accident.'' - J. F. Powers, author of ''Wheat That Springeth Green.'' [ C19:1. ]

title: Killed by Quakes, Hurricanes, Inertia
description: LEAD: The news brings us a series of shocks: Hurricane Gilbert, toll as yet unknown; the earthquake in Nepal, maybe a thousand dead. Who knows how many victims in floods of the Sudan and Bangladesh? Natural disasters of this kind have killed nearly three million people in the last 20 years and caused incalculable suffering and untold damage.

title: Sports People; St. Peter's Job Declined
description: Roy Miller, who was offered the position at St. Peter's, declined it after watching the Peacocks practice yesterday. ''I just don't think they can make it through a nine-game season with the numbers that they have,'' said Miller, who coached at Jersey City State for seven years. ''I did not want to coach there and have a kid get hurt in the fourth quarter because he is tired from playing both ways. My advice to them is to get out of football for now.''

title: Baseball Notebook; Vetoing Boddicker Is Costing Yankees
description: Mike Boddicker will not win any awards this season, but he could be viewed as the most valuable player in the American League East. Two teams, in fact, could attest to his value as the pivotal player in the division race.

title: WHAT'S IN A NAME? A BREZHNEV ASKS
description: The grandson of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the former Soviet leader, complained in an article published today that his family name was causing him problems as Mr. Brezhnev comes under increasing attack for years of misrule.

title: Support for Ohrenstein
description: To the Editor:

title: U.P.I. Sees Profit in '89 Period
description: United Press International expects to turn a modest profit in the third quarter of 1989 and has reached an agreement to provide financial information from the Standard & Poor's Corporation to its newspaper clients, U.P.I.'s president, Paul Steinle, said today.

title: Jets Look for a Rough Game
description: The Houston Oilers don't deliver late, illegal hits, said Robin Cole, who has faced them more than any other Jet.

title: Guilty Plea in Actor's Death
description: Douglas Robert Owens, 35 years old, pleaded guilty Tuesday to drunken driving and vehicular manslaughter in the traffic accident on July 30 that killed the actor Trinidad Silva Jr. Mr. Owens was held in lieu of $25,000 bail for sentencing Oct. 4. Mr. Silva's wife, Sofia, 28, and 2-year-old son were injured in the accident, but not seriously.

title: G.E. Deal With New World
description: The General Electric Capital Corporation will get 15 percent of the stock in the New World Entertainment Corporation in return for an $80 million loan aimed at helping the movie and television company service its heavy long-term debt, the companies announced today.

title: Campaign Trail; Generous Praise For THE Governor
description: How quickly they forget.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Ann Hughes has joined Wunderman Worldwide as a senior vice president, management.

title: Marino of L.I. Appears to Win Top Senate Post
description: In a development reflecting the power of Long Island's Republican Party, State Senator Ralph J. Marino of Nassau County appeared yesterday to have captured enough votes to become the next Senate majority leader, one of the three most powerful figures in New York State government.

title: Satellite Rocket Fails in Space
description: An American communications satellite launched last week by Western Europe's Ariane rocket has failed to reach its proper orbit, but flight controllers said Tuesday that there was still hope that small steering rockets might be able to boost it into a working orbit.

title: Health; Automated Defibrillator For Cardiac Arrest Hailed
description: New devices that automatically detect and interpret abnormal heartbeat and deliver electrical jolts to restore the normal rhythm could save many of the 400,000 Americans who die each year of cardiac arrest, according to a new report.

title: Feud at Vuitton Hennessy Sends Shares Soaring
description: Shares of LVMH Louis Vuitton Moet-Hennessy soared to record levels in frenetic trading today as large shareholders of the conglomerate appeared to be jockeying for advantage before an important shareholder meeting next week.

title: Swamped By the Rising Tide
description: The Republican platform says that Reagan-Bush economic policies have created an ''economic wonder,'' an expansion of unprecedented length and strength. True, the aggregate statistics used to measure economic performance indicate that we have recovered from the deep recession caused by the Reagan Administration's ''cold turkey'' remedy for inflation. But that's all we've done -recover.

title: Judge to Consider Changes in Yonkers Housing Plan
description: A Federal judge agreed yesterday to consider changes in his housing desegregation plan for the city of Yonkers, but he set a final deadline of Sept. 30 for any revisions.

title: Arts, Fine and Applied, In Philadelphia Tradition
description: LEAD: The Helen Drutt Gallery of Philadelphia officially opens a New York outpost today, with a show featuring the work of Lenore Tawney and Rudolf Staffel, both fellows of the American Craft Council, and Francesco Pavan, an Italian jeweler.

title: Dawkins's Strategy: Image as World-Class Achiever
description: Peter Miller Dawkins, former Wall Street investment banker, former United States Army brigadier general, former collegiate football hero and now the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from New Jersey, is even more imposing in the flesh than the photographs and posters suggest.

title: Young Defensive About Taylor Loss
description: George Young, the Giants' general manager, bristled at reporters today after persistent questions about published reports pertaining to the rehabilitation of Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' All-Pro linebacker.

title: Myron S. Isaacs, 77, a Civil Rights Lawyer
description: Myron S. Isaacs, a lawyer who campaigned for civil and human rights, died of pneumonia Tuesday at White Plains Hospital Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Dow Pierces 2,100 Level With a 17.60 Gain
description: Stock prices rose yesterday, helped in early trading by a narrower-than-expected trade deficit report and, later in the session, by futures-related buying.

title: Sports People; McKeon Rewarded
description: When the San Diego Padres turned to their general manager, Jack McKeon, and asked him to take over as manager - on a temporary basis - from the dismissed Larry Bowa, they said they would search for a permanent manager. Yesterday, the 57-year-old McKeon accepted a three-year contract as the manager. According to The San Diego Union, his new contract will pay him more than the $300,000 he made as general manager.(AP)

title: Price Trims Offer For A. M. Lewis
description: The Price Company, a chain of 39 membership warehouse stores based in San Diego, decreased its tender offer for Alfred M. Lewis Inc., a wholesale food distributor, by 7.5 percent, to $37 a share, or $48 million.

title: Campaign Trail; Low Profile or Not, Nixon Gives Advice
description: Report from the Battlefront!

title: Talking Deals; Choice to Holders Offered by Avon
description: NO company enjoys seeing its stock price in a free fall. So after years of reassuring investors that its $2 annual dividend was safe, Avon Products Inc. began to search a few months ago for a way to halve its dividend without provoking a selloff by investors.

title: G.A.O. Attacks Airline Systems
description: The five airline-owned computer reservation systems used by travel agents are so dominant that they are stifling competition in the air travel industry, a report by the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Calendar: Garden Classes and a Festival
description: Gardening Lessons, Watson Building, the New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, 212-220-8747.

title: Atlanta Told to Return Files
description: Thousands of documents relating to the slayings of 29 black children in Atlanta must be returned to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a Federal district judge has ruled. The judge, Richard C. Freeman, instructed city officials in an order filed Aug. 31 to return files containing 2,300 documents related to the investigation of the killings from 1979 to 1981. The files were released to the public in 1987. Wayne Williams, a free-lance photographer, was convicted in 1982 of two of the murders and was given a life sentence.

title: Israeli Chief's 'Private Visit' Is a First for Hungary
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel arrived here today on what Hungary described as a ''private visit,'' the first time an Israeli head of government has been invited to a Communist nation that broke off relations in 1967.

title: On Stump, Reagan Makes It Personal
description: President Reagan asserted today that gains made in his years in office ''could be lost faster than you can say the Pledge of Allegiance'' if Democrats recaptured the White House.

title: Texaco Asset Sales To Total $6 Billion
description: Texaco Inc.'s planned sale of assets should yield more than $6 billion, a figure that would exceed the $5.6 billion required by the company's bankruptcy reorganization plan, its chief executive, James Kinnear, told securities analysts here. Previously the company had said the restructuring would be worth more than $5 billion. Texaco's stock rose 75 cents a share today, to $45.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Greenspan Can Accept Bank Curb
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that he would not oppose bills that expand the underwriting powers of banks but prohibit top banks from merging with top brokerage firms.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 2 Brothers Get Life Terms on Drug Charges
description: A Federal judge sentenced two brothers to life in prison on heroin charges yesterday and ordered that $10 million of their confiscated profits be used to pay for drug programs in the South Bronx.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Top Copywriter To WCRS Unit
description: Louise McNamee, president and chief operating officer of the British-owned Della Femina, McNamee, WCRS, announced yesterday that James Durfee, the much-honored copywriter, had joined the agency as vice chairman and director of corporate creative services.

title: In Africa, Debt Relief Is Humanitarian Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Larouche Retires
description: Pierre Larouche, the only player in the National Hockey League to have a 50-goal season with two different teams, has retired. The Rangers announced Larouche's retirement yesterday and said he would remain with the organization as a special assistant. Larouche suffered a back injury in the first month of last season and never recovered, missing the rest of the season. He did not report to training camp this season. Larouche, 32 years old, played 14 seasons and scored 53 goals for Pittsburgh in the 1975-76 season and 50 for Montreal in the 1979-80 season. Larouche scored 48 goals in his first season with the Rangers.

title: Student Slain Fighting Thief For Her Purse
