description: A 24-year-old fine-arts graduate student from Arkansas who had moved to New York City a week ago ''to pursue her dream'' was shot and killed yesterday in a robbery on a Brooklyn sidewalk.

title: Palestinians Slay Arab Man Suspected of Collaboration
description: Palestinians stabbed to death an Arab man suspected of collaborating with the Israelis and dumped his pajama-clad body on a West Bank street today, the police and Arab reports said.

title: Limit on Budget Deficit Threatens Drug Bills
description: Ambitious plans for legislation creating programs to control illegal drugs are running up against harsh dollars-and-cents realities.

title: Review/Theater; Blues Show With a Past
description: ''Blues in the Night,'' the well-traveled revue that reopened at the Minetta Lane Theater yesterday, is a show that carries its own built-in insurance: a trove of more than two dozen enduring pop and blues songs from the 1920's and 30's.

title: College Football; Being No. 1 Now Makes Miami a Target
description: In Coral Gables, Fla., the topic of conversation is known as the P-word. The Miami Hurricanes would prefer not to discuss the news-agency polls, which, depending on one's view, rewarded or targeted them after their shockingly easy 31-0 defeat of Florida State.

title: Northrop Foresees Revenue Decline
description: The Northrop Corporation said that it expected its revenue this year and in 1989 to fall short of the $6 billion it recorded for 1987.

title: Sports People; Surgery for Walton
description: Bill Walton, the often-injured free-agent center, who was hoping to make a comeback with the Boston Celtics after missing all of last season, underwent surgery on his right foot for the second time in 15 months Tuesday at Presbyterian Intercommunity Hospital in Whittier, Calif. Dr. F. William Wagner, who performed the surgery, said yesterday, ''arthritic-type spurs were removed from three joints in the foot and ankle.'' Dr. Wagner, who previously operated on the 6-foot-11-inch center's right foot, said: ''Bill was born with congenital defects in his feet and the surgery was again necessary to relieve the pressure and the loss of motion.''

title: Guardsmen Are Warned After Role at Rally
description: The Pennsylvania National Guard is sending a letter to the state's soldiers and airmen reminding them of regulations prohibiting their participation in partisan political activities, officials said today.

title: Novelist and Sociologist Get Awards
description: The novelist Walker Percy was named the winner yesterday of the T. S. Eliot Award for Creative Writing, while the sociologist Edward Shils was named winner of the Richard M. Weaver Award for Scholarly Letters. Both awards are worth $15,000.

title: Yields Post A Small Rise
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were up again for the week ended yesterday, but the increases were smaller than the gains of a week ago.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bauer Group Offering 2d Women's Magazine
description: The Bauer Group, a publishing company in Hamburg, West Germany, is preparing to bring out its second women's magazine in the United States in January.

title: Chase Weighing Sites for Moving Manhattan Unit
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation has entered final negotiations with New York City over the possibility of moving 4,000 jobs from Manhattan to Brooklyn amid speculation that it is considering sites elsewhere and leaning toward the New Jersey waterfront.

title: Tentative Offering Of M.A.C. Bonds
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York is tentatively offering $396.5 million of bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.698 percent for an issue due in 2008.

title: U.S. Aides Witness Soviet Nuclear Test for First Time
description: With American officials and measuring instruments present for the first time, the Soviet Union today exploded a powerful nuclear device buried beneath the desolate steppes of Central Asia.

title: New York City Primary Choices
description: Here are our endorsements for races in today's Democratic primary in which victory is tantamount to election in November. Polls in New York City are open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. BRONX HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 18th District: Pedro Espada Jr.; 19th: Eliot Engel. ASSEMBLY 74th District: Hector Diaz; 76th: Aurelia Greene; 77th: Sandra Ramos-Alamo; 78th: Gloria Davis; 79th: George Friedman; 81st: Jay Goldman. CIVIL COURT Countywide: Joseph Cohen. DISTRICT ATTORNEY Countywide: Robert Johnson. BROOKLYN HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 11th District: Edolphus Towns. STATE SENATE 20th District: Ada Smith. ASSEMBLY 42d District: Rhoda Jacobs; 43d: Clarence Norman Jr.; 45th: Daniel Feldman; 55th: William Boyland; 57th: Roger Green. MANHATTAN HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 17th District: Ted Weiss. STATE SENATE 27th District: Joseph Rose. QUEENS STATE SENATE 10th District: Edward Lewis. ASSEMBLY 23d District: Audrey Pheffer; 26th: Sandra Delson; 29th: Cynthia Jenkins; 30th: Harvey Katz; 32d: Lawrence Miller.

title: Wright 'Very Happy' After Giving His Account to Ethics Committee
description: The Speaker of the House of Representatives, Jim Wright, testified for more than five hours before the House ethics committee today and said afterward that he had defended himself with ''total, absolute candor'' against charges of ethical misconduct.

title: Review/Dance; New Disciples of Isadora Duncan Pay Tribute to a Predecessor
description: A great dance tradition came alive Tuesday night at the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the Lincoln Center Library in a program honoring Maria-Theresa Duncan. The German-born dancer and teacher, who died last year at the age of 92, was both a pupil and an adopted daughter of Isadora Duncan, the innovative American dancer who, early in this century, virtually invented the form now known as modern dance.

title: A Runner in Search Of Her Own Standard
description: Joan Benoit Samuelson, who flew down from her ''saltwater farm'' on the Maine coast to announce that she will attempt to make her racing comeback in the New York Marathon on Nov. 6, flew right back there yesterday as soon as an obligatory luncheon appearance ended.

title: Review/Concert; The Philharmonic, in a New Season
description: Once more into the breach, O noblest music lovers. The opening volleys of a new music season were fired last evening at Avery Fisher Hall by the New York Philharmonic under the command of Zubin Mehta, to the easily audible delight of a black-tie benefit audience. The orchestra, fresh from what the publicity department inevitably and possibly justly described as ''a triumphal Grand Tour of Europe,'' seemed in a mood to extend that triumph by at least one more night. The program of Schubert, Beethoven and Wagner, at any rate, was played with all stops out, in the manner of a high-fidelity spectacular.

title: Virginia Gunman Holds 11 for Over 4 Hours
description: A man saying he wanted to promote peace in Lebanon held 11 people at gunpoint for more than four hours today at a military recruiting center before surrendering.

title: American General Unit Selling Notes
description: The Credithrift Financial Corporation, a unit of the American General Corporation, the insurance giant, is offering $100 million of 9 percent notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.525 to yield 9.12 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Cal Bio and Pfizer In Research Project
description: California Biotechnology Inc. formed a five-year commercial alliance with Pfizer Inc. and three professors from Harvard Medical School to develop new treatments for diabetes and obesity. Pfizer has committed $30 million in financing for the new venture, which will initially be based at Cal Bio's headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., with additional research conducted at Pfizer and various universities.

title: Exuberant, Energetic Ceramics
description: THE sheer exuberance of the show now on view at the Garth Clark Gallery in Manhattan is as irrepressible as lightning. The latest work of Ken Ferguson, a ceramist, exhales energy -psychic, kinetic, erotic and mythic.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19 The strongest hurricane to hit the Western Hemisphere in the 20th century slammed into Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula with 23-foot waves and wind gusts of up to 218 miles per hour, forcing the evacuation of tens of thousands of people. Page A1

title: Excerpts From Dukakis Speech on Arms
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of a speech on arms policy delivered today by Michael S. Dukakis at Georgetown University here:

title: Treasury Bonds and Notes Gain
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes moved higher in active trading yesterday, as traders sorted through conflicting data on the economy and inflation.

title: House Passes Bill to Raise Insider Fines
description: The House of Representatives today unanimously voted for much stiffer penalties for insider trading. The measure, approved 410 to 0, would affect people and brokerages whose employees violate the law.

title: Group Seeks to Force Vote on Sale of Zenith
description: A partnership led by two arbitragers in New York, Herbert B. Abelow and Nicholas L. Ihasz, said today that it would call a special shareholders' vote on whether the Zenith Electronics Corporation should be sold.

title: Rockwell Projects Reduced Revenue
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said it expects sales for the 1988 fiscal year, ending Sept. 30, will decline to $11 billion or $12 billion, from $12.12 billion the previous year. Since April, when Rockwell delivered the last of its 100 B-1B aircraft ordered in 1982, the company's aircraft sales have fallen off significantly, Rockwell's chairman, Donald Beall, said at a news conference Tuesday.

title: Catholic Author Deeply Fascinated by the Priesthood
description: ''I think God likes humor,'' says J. F. Powers. ''I think there's too much of it for it just to be an accident.''

title: New Cooper-Hewitt Head
description: The Cooper-Hewitt Museum has named Dianne H. Pilgrim, the chairman of the decorative arts department at the Brooklyn Museum, as its new director. Ms. Pilgrim, who organized the Brooklyn Museum's acclaimed 1986 exhibition, ''The Machine Age in America,'' will take up her post on Nov. 1. She succeeds Lisa Taylor, who retired as director in 1987. The Cooper-Hewitt is the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design and is housed in the former Carnegie mansion on Fifth Avenue at 91st Street.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Tai Babilonia, the former Olympic skater, was hospitalized yesterday morning after taking an overdose of pills, authorities said. Paramedics took Babilonia to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, where she was treated and released in good condition, said a hospital spokeswoman, Paula Correia. The kind of pills taken and other details were not disclosed. Babilonia was said to be despondent over recent poor skating performances. . . . Jay Edwards, Indiana's leading scorer and the Big Ten's freshman of the year, has withdrawn from the university to enter a chemical-dependency program, Bob Knight, the basketball coach, said, yesterday. . . . The defensive end Doug Martin ended his 54-day holdout yesterday, signing a series of one-year contracts with the Minnesota Vikings. (AP)

title: Koch Urges Resolution Of a Mosque Dispute
description: Mayor Koch yesterday urged his ad-ministration to find a way to return a storefront mosque to a group of Muslims who lost the property last year in a tangled dispute with the city.

title: Bridge
description: Quick wits in the post-mortem have little impact on the score, but they can help cover up an error. A player who can point out that a different layout would have vindicated his play can defend himself from an attacking partner. But there may be a counterattack.

title: Chemical Bank Names 2
description: Chemical Bank said yesterday that Barbara D. Capsalis and William C. Pierce had been appointed to its management committee. Mrs. Capsalis, who has been senior vice president in charge of the financial services division, was named chief technology officer. Mr. Pierce is the bank's chief credit officer. The management committee of the bank, a unit of the Chemical Banking Corporation, now numbers 15 of Chemical's most senior executives.

title: Campaign Trail; Slip of the Tongue Creates a Sour Note
description: If the Vice President was having his problems in California, Governor Dukakis was doing his turn in Georgetown.

title: Dukakis Barely Leading Bush in New Poll
description: A poll released tonight shows Gov. Michael S. Dukakis barely ahead of Vice President Bush, eliminating the lead Mr. Bush appeared to have as recently as a few days ago.

title: Review/Recital; Judith Farris, a Contralto
description: Judith Farris, a contralto who has been singing opera around the country and who has appeared locally as a soloist with Musica Sacra, made her debut as a recitalist on Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall, with a program that for the most part was well tailored to her abilities.

title: Book Gives Aides' Conflicting Views of President
description: When Howard H. Baker Jr. became White House chief of staff in February 1987, his advisers were so alarmed about the President's depressed mental state that they briefly raised the possibility of relieving him of his power, according to a new book by two Washington authors.

title: Don't Let the Sun Set on Free Speech
description: For more than three decades, the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act allowed Washington to bar controversial foreign visitors. It was an outmoded limit on freedom of speech and inquiry. Then last year Congress passed a new law to redress this abuse of public intellect, but the law expires at the end of this year. It deserves an extension.

title:
CURRENTS;
An Old Avant-Gardist Returns in a New Guise
description: LEAD: TWENTY-odd years ago Peter Cook, a founder of the London-based design group Archigram, stood at architecture's frontier, with a vision of science-fictionlike cities formed with large plug-in, clip-on contraptions. Archigram and its steely creatures seemed to disappear when post-modern architects waved their capitals, columns and cornices.

title: Sports People; Texas Rangers Sold
description: Edward L. Gaylord, an Oklahoma publisher, said yesterday that he had decided to exercise his option to purchase Eddie Chiles's 58 percent interest in the Texas Rangers. Gaylord's Dallas-based Gaylord Broadcasting Company owns about one-third of the club. Gaylord indicated that a major factor in his decision was to insure that the Rangers would remain in the Dallas-Fort Worth area. The price for the Rangers and Arlington Stadium is an estimated $80 million. (AP)

title: In Korea, Baseball Amid Flying Bottles
description: The Haitai Tigers have come to play baseball, and the police are bracing themselves.

title: Scattered Low-Cost Housing Offers Renewed Hope to Poor and Minorities
description: She lives in a beautiful town house in an upper-middle-class neighborhood near here, in affluent Montgomery County just outside Washington, and she has a secret.

title: USING FETAL TISSUE AS A CURE DEBATED
description: A committee of experts today heard scientists describe the potentially enormous benefits of using human fetal tissue to treat incurable diseases, but critics warned that such research could encourage abortion and immoral practices.

title: Washington Talk: Wealth and Influence; Does Texas Billionaire Aim to Be Power Broker?
description: The capital is accustomed to the powerful, but the truly rich can still cause a stir here. The Washington establishment is about to get its first close-up of Robert M. Bass, a low-profile Texas billionaire who has been in the news as a result of his $2 billion deal with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to take over the ailing American Savings and Loan Associaton of California.

title: From a Shulman Fan
description: To The Home Section:

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FLUORESCENT lights are more efficient than incandescent ones, but also more complicated. As a result, simply replacing the bulb - actually a tube - when a fluorescent light develops problems will not always remedy the situation. Fortunately, trouble-shooting fluorescent lights is not too difficult, and repairs are usually easy to make.

title: Threat of Hurricane Forces Delay in Setting Shuttle Date
description: Space agency officials yesterday delayed making a decision on when to schedule the first space shuttle launching since the Challenger disaster because the hurricane threat in Houston was interferring with the work of key engineers on the project.

title: Let's Try Alternatives to Prison Before Shipping Inmates Upstate
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush, in California, Stresses Patriotism
description: Here in the heart of conservative country, where the two revered ''Dukes'' are John Wayne and Gov. George Deukmejian, Vice President Bush renewed his suggestions that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts was less patriotic than he and said the Republican campaign was ''on the American side.''

title: Friedman Answers Charges of Bribery At Citisource Trial
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader who was convicted on Federal racketeering charges in 1986, appeared yesterday before a State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan to answer state bribery charges in an unrelated case.

title: It's Not Pretty, But Yanks Win
description: The mood in the cramped, steamy little clubhouse was one of complete relief. At last, the Yankees could turn their attention to the Red Sox. And most satisfying of all, they could do so without having to look back in anger.

title: Baseball; Red Sox Roll on Rice's Slam
description: Mike Greenwell hit for the cycle and scored three runs tonight as the Boston Red Sox beat the Baltimore Orioles, 4-3, and maintained their lead in the American League East.

title: Health; Personal Health
description: Decades after their recovery from paralytic polio, some people begin to experience new weakness and atrophy in their muscles, especially in those muscles that were severely affected by the original illness.

title: TV Notes
description: Losing Viewers

title: Delaware Contest Unchanged
description: Lieut. Gov. S.B. Woo remained in the lead by a slim margin today as the recount continued of ballots cast in Delaware's Democratic United States Senate primary race. Only results from New Castle County had not been announced, and election officials were expected to give those results Thursday. Earlier certified ballots in Saturday's election gave Mr. Woo an 88-vote lead over Samuel S. Beard.

title: Public Reading to Help AIDS-Afflicted Writers
description: A reading to benefit writers and editors with AIDS is to be held on Sept. 29 at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Names Runneth Over
description: This morning, for the eighth time, the capital's annual three-mile invitational foot race, pitting Federal bureaucrats against runners representating the judiciary branch, Congress and the press, gets under way at East Potomac Park.

title: BALTIMORE MAYOR OUSTS AIDE FOR LIE
description: Mayor Kurt Schmoke removed the president of the Baltimore school board Tuesday after he admitted lying to board members as a way of trying to find out who gave information to the news media.

title: Century's Fiercest Storm Sweeps Yucatan
description: The strongest hurricane to hit the Western Hemisphere in this century slammed into the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico today with 23-foot waves and wind gusts of up to 218 miles an hour, devastating coastal cities and resorts and forcing the evacuation of tens of thousands of people.

title: Placer Dome Chief Quits Over Company Strategy
description: John S. Walton, president and chief executive of Placer Dome Inc., one of the world's major gold-mining companies, has resigned in a difference with the board over the future course of the company.

title: Ground Covers That Won't Become the Pythons of Plantdom
description: IT is a lesson that all gardeners learn quickly from experience, and every year that passes reinforces it. We often wish that we had left undone things we actually did do and that it were possible to turn back the clock and correct them.

title: Lauren Re-invents Country in the City
description: HIGH above Madison Avenue, old-time rocking chairs ($350 to $1,000) hang from pipes on the ceiling, twig brooms ($85) are propped up against barrels filled with rolls of mattress ticking, stone-washed denim and buffalo-check cotton ($35 to $55 a yard). Flannel shirts ($45 to $97) are piled onto rough-hewed wood shelves, and there is country music in the air.

title: U.S. Says It Monitored Iraqi Messages on Gas
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States had intercepted Iraqi military communications indicating that Iraq had used poison gas against Kurdish guerrillas.

title: CONSERVATIONISTS TO BACK DUKAKIS
description: Rejecting Vice President Bush's recent assertion that he is an environmentalist, the political arm of the nation's major conservation groups will endorse the Presidential candidacy of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.

title: BENTSEN PROMISES NO CUTS IN DEFENSE
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen promised today that an Administration headed by Michael S. Dukakis would make ''no cuts in defense - none.''

title: Kroger Weighs Preferred Move
description: The Kroger Company is considering a $250 million redemption of its preferred shares to complement a possible $3.75 billion anti-takeover restructuring. The Cincinnati-based supermarket chain said management would recommend the redemption of all auction preferred shares.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: NEITHER his parents nor his high-school track coach understood what was going on. The boy would do extremely well during practice, often performing at championship levels. The local papers were full of articles about his athletic potential and predictions of his success. Yet he would do very poorly in competition.

title: Elections Board Rebuffs Mayor Over Director
description: The New York City Board of Elections yesterday rebuffed Mayor Koch and rejected an unusual agreement he had made with Governor Cuomo and the Rev. Jesse Jackson to influence the selection of an executive director.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Code-Alarm Inc., Madison Heights, Mich., said it had been selected to supply Ford Motor Co. dealers with an electronic remote keyless lock for Ford's new Probe model.

title: Mrs. Douglas Fairbanks Jr.
description: Mary Lee Fairbanks, a sponsor of charity benefits and the wife of the movie actor Douglas Fairbanks Jr., died of cancer yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 75 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My bathroom ceiling has been dripping water from a leak in the apartment above. Our superintendent says the leak was repaired by replacing the grouting, but the ceiling is leaking again whenever the tenant above takes a shower. In addition I have three growths coming through the cracks in the ceiling. Each has a long, slender stem and a circular flat head pleated like the underside of a mushroom. Can you tell me how this growth developed and what can be done to repair this problem? A.The growth is a type of poisonous fungus that often develops - usually outdoors - where there is constant dampness. It grows in your ceiling because the leak keeps the inside of the ceiling damp. Simply grouting the tile in the floor above is usually not enough to stop such a leak.

title: Red (and White and Blue) In Saks Gala's Spotlight
description: SAKS Fifth Avenue waved the flag for American fashion Tuesday night. In its 10th annual dinner-dance, traditionally a curtain raiser for the fall season, the store focused as usual on six designers and the six charities they chose to sponsor. This year, as usual, the designers featured were Adolfo, Geoffrey Beene, Bill Blass, Carolina Herrera, Mary McFadden and Oscar de la Renta.

title: No Plan Known on How to Meet Debt to U.N.
description: United Nations officials and members of Congress from both parties today hailed the White House announcement that the United States is willing to pay its debts to the United Nations. But they underscored that there was no plan on how to find the money to make the payments.

title: Bradford Smith, 86, A Retired Chairman Of I.N.A., Is Dead
description: Bradford Smith Jr., a retired chairman of the I.N.A. Corporation, one of the nation's largest insurance organizations, died of arteriosclerosis Tuesday at his home in Centerville, Md. He was 86 years old.

title: Sports of The Times; The Gang's All Here
description: IN the Olympic Village, bullets were flying. But nobody looked up. Not even the Korean secruity guard in the green beret at the door.

title: Searle Looks a Lot Riskier Now
description: When the Monsanto Company bought G. D. Searle & Company three years ago, it defended the $2.8 billion purchase, noting that Searle's Nutrasweet division was hugely profitable and maintaining that its lackluster drug operation could be turned around.

title: From Arafat, Wishes for a Happy Jewish New Year
description: Yasir Arafat startled a news conference today by wishing everyone ''Shana Tova, Shana Tova,'' the traditional Hebrew greeting for the Jewish New Year.

title: Polling Hours
description: Today is primary election day in New York State. The polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. in New York City and Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Ulster and Erie Counties and from noon to 9 P.M. in the rest of the state.

title: U.S. Moves In on Fulton Fish Market
description: One day later this month, in the gloomy hours before dawn, a group of investigators will assemble near the Fulton Fish Market in lower Manhattan to carry out a mission against the underworld.

title: F.B.I. Chief Disciplines Six For Surveillance Activities
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, announced today that he had suspended three bureau employees and was censuring three others for their involvement in a domestic surveillance campaign aimed at opponents of the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America.

title: Park Service Plans to Revise Fire Recovery Policy
description: The National Park Service will reverse some of its established practices of letting nature take its course as it seeks to deal with the consequences of the devastating fires in Yellowstone National Park, Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel said today.

title: Ocean Dumping Foes Dangle From Bridge
description: Thirteen members of Greenpeace, the environmental group, swung on ropes from the Triborough Bridge yesterday evening and unfurled a banner saying, ''Stop Ocean Dumping Now.''

title: MAJOR IS CHARGED IN WEAPON THEFT
description: A Federal grand jury in Nashville, Tenn., indicted an Army major today in connection with the theft of 200 weapons while he handled weapon procurement in the early 1980's for a secret Army intelligence unit.

title: Campaign Trail; A Political Drama Lived in Real Life
description: Francis O'Brien insists that he's not a political junkie.

title: Pretoria Sanctions Gain in Senate
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, voting along party lines, approved a bill today that would impose sweeping sanctions against South Africa to protest apartheid.

title: Corrections
description: A list of primary election candidates yesterday for today's voting in the New York metropolitan area omitted the Conservative party race in the 85th Assembly District in Westchester. The candidates are Irving Scharf and the incumbent, Ronald C. Tocci.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Associated Importers, which recently acquired the United States marketing of St. Pauli Girl beer, appointed Leo Beleiter president. He will be based in New York. Associated is the imported beer and specialty beverage division of Hiram Walker-Allied Vintners, Walkerville, Ontario.

title:
CURRENTS;
Offbeat Ideas From Japan
description: LEAD: FEW people need to be reminded that the Japanese have done well in showing Americans what entrepreneurship is all about. But Leonard Koren has produced a book that contains a collection of quirky Japanese business practices and inventions. His choices are not what you might expect to find.

title: Jamaica Counts the Hurricane Toll: 25 Dead and 4 Out of 5 Homes Roofless
description: Reconnaissance flights over remote parts of Jamaica brought back reports today indicating that a hurricane left widespread devastation throughout the country and that 80 percent of the homes on the island had lost their roofs.

title: Bennett to Help Found Group To Teach Western Classics
description: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett and Professor Allan Bloom, two of the most outspoken critics of American higher education, plan to start a foundation to promote study of classic Western thought.

title: David Puttnam in Pact For 6 Feature Films
description: David Puttnam, who resigned last year as chairman of Columbia Pictures, today announced a $50 million joint venture to produce and finance six new feature films over the next four years.

title: Another Tisch at CBS
description: Preston Robert Tisch was named yesterday to the board of CBS Inc., where his brother, Laurence A. Tisch, is chief executive. The appointment increases the broadcasting company's board to 14 members. Preston Tisch, who earlier this year resigned as Postmaster General, is the president and co-chief executive, with his brother, of the Loews Corporation.

title: U.S. Asks End of 3d World Import Curbs
description: The United States today called for an end to the privileges given developing countries through most of the postwar period to restrict imports.

title: Mother Testifies on Murders of Her Children
description: A former pediatric nurse charged with killing two of her children and trying to murder the third described yesterday how she held pillows over their faces to suffocate them but insisted she never meant to harm them.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Honor for Bojangles
description: American popular music has a champion on Capitol Hill in the person of Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, who once played trumpet in an amateur band in Detroit, still noodles on the piano and keeps a double bass in a corner of his office.

title: KEY RATES
Human Immune Defenses Are Transplanted in Mice
description: Scientists have transplanted the major elements of the human immune defense system into living mice, a stunning achievement that should provide a powerful new tool for medical research.

title: Decline in U.S. Trade Deficit Pushes Dollar Up Sharply
description: The dollar rose sharply yesterday on the strength of a larger-than-expected decline in the United States trade deficit. But several traders said they did not think the spurt, following a general decline since the end of August, signaled a new rally.

title: San Francisco Journal; From Off-Beat Rough Toward Chic and Fine
description: Nowhere are the recent changes that have swept San Francisco more apparent than along Folsom Street in this city's gritty warehouse district south of Market Street.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Feb. 29 about El Salvador described an increase in political killings in advance of the next month's legislative and municipal elections. The article cited killings by rightist death squads and by Marxist guerrillas.

title: Health: Birth Control; Despite Widespread Fear, IUD's Are Safe for Many Women
description: Women in monogamous relationships who use an intrauterine device for birth control are at no higher risk of developing pelvic inflammatory disease than women who do not use contraceptives, a new study has found.

title: William L. Mitchell, Auto Executive, 76
description: William L. Mitchell, a former vice president for design at the General Motors Corporation, died of heart failure Monday at William Beaumont Hospital in Royal Oak, Mich. He was 76 years old.

title: True Compatibility
description: To The Home Section:

title: Man, 23, Is Indicted On Reduced Charge In Killing of Officer
description: A 23-year-old Brooklyn man was formally charged yesterday with criminally negligent homicide in the fatal shooting of a police officer by a sergeant last month.

title: The Jersey Village That Fought Radon With Fans and Won
description: The radon scare is old news in this village 15 miles from the Pennsylvania border. With much of the country just being warned about the radioactive gas and the threat of lung cancer it poses, this square-mile community of 2,000 has met and, by all accounts, conquered the worst residential radon hotspot known in the United States.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: JUST eight weeks ago the cat found a dark place and gave birth to her first litter: three pathetic miniatures of herself, their eyes sealed shut, their voices weak falsettos. For two weeks the new mother was manic, moving them from place to place because of imagined dangers. For two weeks more she was solicitous, slipping out for a meal and returning immediately to the writhing pile of fur and blunt faces, grooming them even when they were clean.

title: Hit-Run Driver Kills Woman
description: Barbara Klimek, the 43-year-old niece of New York Yankee broadcaster Phil Rizzuto, was struck and killed in a hit-and-run accident on the Upper West Side of Manhattan early yesterday, the police said.

title: Health; Breast Cancer Drug Therapies Compared
description: For women with breast cancer that has spread to the lymph nodes, prolonged treatment with a combination of drugs is more effective than a short course immediately after surgery, a new study has found.

title: Turkey Opposes an Inquiry Into Poison Gas Issue
description: The Turkish Government said today that a United Nations investigation of accusations that Iraq used poison gas on Kurdish refugees would be unnecessary and unwelcome.

title: Playtex Sets Buyout Pact Of $1.3 Billion
description: In a complex transaction, Playtex Holdings Inc. and its three apparel units will be bought for $1.3 billion by two investor groups, the parties to an agreement said yesterday.

title: Senate Won't Seize Site Near Manassas, Head of Panel Says
description: The Senate will not go along with a plan to seize land adjacent to the Manassas National Battlefield Park in northern Virginia to prevent a shopping center from being built there, the chairman of the committee involved said today.

title: Democrats Never Lost Because of Liberalism; Two Essential Forces
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo and Kean Join in Sludge Plan
description: New York City and other localities that dump sludge in the ocean would be forced to set aside money to look for alternative dumping sites under a proposal announced jointly yesterday by the Governors of New York and New Jersey. The proposal calls for a ban on ocean dumping by 1991.

title: How Do New Gardens Grow? In Green Sand and Fantasy
description: LEAD: THE ride starts with the Garden of Eden. Then come classical gardens: Egyptian, Persian, Roman, Italian Renaissance, 18th-century French and 19th-century Victorian. Next, you travel under the Magic Mountain that separates Occidental from Oriental gardens, and you end up in a basin turnaround with a statue of

title: A Ned Rorem Premiere By Chamber Symphony
description: The world premiere of a composition by Ned Rorem, Leonard Bernstein's one-act opera ''Trouble in Tahiti'' and Aaron Copland's ''Appalachian Spring'' will form the program for the opening concerts of the New York Chamber Symphony's 1988-89 season in the Kaufmann Concert Hall of the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The two performances, under the direction of Gerard Schwarz, are set for Oct. 8 at 8 P.M. and Oct. 9 at 3 P.M.

title: HARVARD TO SEEK RESEARCH PROFITS
description: In an important policy reversal, Harvard University has decided to raise money for investments aimed at bringing faculty members' research to the marketplace and making a profit for the school.

title: Galveston Concedes Storm's Threat
description: In a mood of edgy, awed respect, people along the Gulf Coast from Northern Mexico across Texas to Louisiana began preparing for the potentially devastating assault of Hurricane Gilbert.

title: Flight Canceled, Pope Sees South Africa by Car
description: Pope John Paul II, forced to turn back when a violent storm blocked his attempt to fly to this remote mountain kingdom, today made a long unexpected trek across South Africa, the land of apartheid he had tried to avoid visiting.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Making Old Pictures Look Just Like New
description: ONE woman brought in a photograph of her grandmother that was so mildewed it stuck to the glass in the frame. Someone else wanted a tiny photo from a gold locket reproduced. Another customer despaired because her child had used a crayon to draw all over a photograph of her mother.

title: Overhaul Study Praises Controls In Subway Fleet
description: Three years after the management of the New York City Transit Authority's $2 billion subway-car overhaul program was found in a shambles, the authority has tightened controls and raised performance in the rebuilt fleet, according to a report released yesterday.

title: Senate Backs Brady, 92 to 2
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to confirm Nicholas F. Brady, the investment banker, as Treasury Secretary. Mr. Brady, 58 years old, of

title: Doing Away With the Battlefield
description: ONE of the most common responses parents have to a child who isn't performing up to potential in school is to offer a reward for improved grades.

title: Industrial Output Up Modest 0.2%
description: The nation's industrial production rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the smallest gain in five months, after a much larger gain in July.

title: Historical Society Seeks to Save Neglected but Priceless Library
description: In a library storeroom at the New-York Historical Society, a row of cardboard boxes containing the personal letters of Cass Gilbert, an eminent turn-of-the-century American architect, is dusted with bits of plaster that have fallen from the ceiling.

title:
CURRENTS;
The Old Is Made New Again
description: LEAD: DONALD J. TRUMP'S Trump Parc, a residential renovation of the old Barbizon Plaza Hotel and an adjoining apartment building, receives a lot of promotion. But another smaller Central Park South apartment house is now commanding serious attention.

title: Fernandez Overpowers Cubs
description: The Mets, who seem to have more pitching than they know what to do with, got even more of it last night when Sid Fernandez pitched them to a 3-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs in Shea Stadium.

title: Health; Study Finds Differences In the Cells Of Alcoholics
description: Cells taken from alcoholics appear to be biochemically different from cells of nonalcoholics, researchers have found. The finding fits in with a growing body of data indicating that some people inherit a propensity to abuse alcohol.

title: Metro Matters; Clocks or No, New Chancellor Is Fighting Time
description: Shortly before Dr. Richard R. Green was installed as New York City schools chancellor last March, he outlined his long-range goals for the beleaguered education system. But wasn't there something, Dr. Green was asked, that he might do immediately?

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Court Backs Partial Merger Of Two Detroit Newspapers
description: America's two largest newspaper companies won a Federal judge's approval yesterday to proceed with the partial merger of their Detroit papers, but a group of readers, advertisers and politicians said it would appeal the decision.

title: Fight Radon; Stop Smoking
description: Another alarm: cancer-causing radon gas in the home. It's a serious and widespread hazard, but one that individuals can protect themselves against. Homeowners can quite cheaply prevent the gas seeping into their basements. And smokers, who are at extra risk, have another reason to stop smoking.

title: Ex-Insider in Mexico Is Stinging His Old Party
description: It was one of the more dramatic moments in recent Mexican political history. As President Miguel de la Madrid was delivering his state-of-the-nation address this month, Senator Porfirio Munoz Ledo rose from his seat on the floor of Congress to interrupt the chief executive and challenge the veracity of July's tumultuous presidential election.

title: First Day in First Grade: Tears at P.S. 106
description: Dana Williams, dressed in a bright yellow outfit, waved a cheery goodbye to her father as she began her first day at Public School 106 in the Bronx. But later in the day, as her class was turned over to a lunch aide in the cafeteria, she wept bitterly at being separated from her teacher for a brief time.

title: Dukakis and Bush Agree on the Rules For Debates on TV
description: The campaigns of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and Vice President Bush today reached final agreement today on the ground rules for their two Presidential debates, which both sides acknowledged were critical and outside experts said could decide the election.

title: Meteorologists Say the Hurricane Is Similar to a Monster Tornado
description: Hurricane Gilbert, the mightiest storm to hit the Western Hemisphere in this century, concentrates so much of its destructive energy into a narrow core that meteorologists say the storm resembles a monster tornado.

title: Rat-Tat-Tatting
description: A helmeted Michael Dukakis clambered up on a tank in Michigan, pointed the gun at the clicking cameras, and said ''rat-tat-tat.''

title: Costly Accounting Change Planned
description: The organization that sets the accounting rules for American business is presenting new proposals today that could require the nation's largest companies to add as much as $2 trillion in new obligations to their financial statements.

title: Yanks Think About '78 Again
description: Mike Pagliarulo is looking to sell his house outside of Boston. He is tired of obscenities being scrawled across his driveway and shouted into his phone by disgruntled Red Sox fans. He chuckled, though, when it was suggested there might be one sure way to stimulate interest in helping him get out of town for good.

title: The Unitarian View
description: To The Home Section:

title: Chairman's Successor Is Chosen by Du Pont
description: The Du Pont Company announced yesterday that its board had named Edgar S. Woolard Jr. as the next chairman and chief executive of the giant chemical and energy concern.

title: Fuel Economy Appeal by G.M.
description: Robert C. Stempel, the president of the General Motors Corporation, said today that unless Federal fuel-economy standards were kept from rising as sharply as scheduled, his company might lose sales of large cars and be forced to lay off employees.

title: STRUGGLE IN BURMA FOCUSES ON ARMY
description: As mass demonstrations and attempts at political consolidation by the Burmese opposition reportedly continued today, a struggle was under way for the allegiance of the armed forces, the nation's most powerful institution.

title:
CURRENTS;
A Watch You Can Count On
description: LEAD: DON'T you hate people who are always looking at their watches? Maybe it's not because they're bored, or think such glances make the elevator go faster. They could be simply admiring their latest timepiece.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bell Atlantic Work By Thompson Is Due
description: The first wave of an outpouring of advertising that J. Walter Thompson has created for its new client, Bell Atlantic, will be seen on television in the company's seven-state region tomorrow during the Olympic telecast. It will mark a radical change for the company.

title: Campaign Trail; Alas, This Patriot Was Counted Before
description: And over at the Bush campaign, there were gleeful noises all day -about the polls showing the Vice President ahead, about the Dan Quayle issue abating (for the moment) and about Jaime Escalante.

title: Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: American Red Cross, P.O. Box 4681, New York, N.Y. 10164-0037, Attn: Hurricane Relief. CARE, 660 First Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016. Friends of the Americas, 914 North Foster Drive, Baton Rouge, La. 70806. Operation California, 7615 1/2 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles, Calif. 90046. U.S. Committee for Unicef, 331 East 38th Street, New York, N.Y. 10016.

title: Two Sisters Make Rivalry an Asset
description: Elizabeth Mead Steig, Margaret Mead's sister, was once quoted as saying: ''You can tell your sister to go to hell in 10 different langauges, but if you need a dime she'll give you one.''

title: Sun Exploration Marketing $500 Million Debt in 2 Parts
description: The Sun Exploration and Production Company, a subsidiary of the Sun Company, is offering $500 million of debt in two equal parts through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Health: Vision Care; New Chart Can Detect Damage In the Back Of the Eye
description: Two researchers have developed a new vision chart that for the first time offers a relatively simple and inexpensive way to test the eye's ability to discern faint images.

title: 84-Cent Jump Raises Oil Price to $15.40
description: Oil prices surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday in hectic trading, with crude oil for delivery next month rising by 84 cents, to $15.40 a barrel.

title: NBC's Long Road to the Olympics
description: NBC's Olympic broadcasts, which begin tomorrow, had their origins seven years ago in Baden-Baden, West Germany, when a network vice president spent an evening talking to South Korean officials while his competition was busy courting the Japanese.

title: Olympics; Drug Cheaters May Be Winning The Battle of Wits With Testers
description: Medical experts say that the small number of athletes they expect will test positive for performance-enhancing drugs during the Seoul Games does not reflect the true number of athletes involved with the drugs.

title: Poland Plays With Fire
description: The first hard test of Mikhail Gorbachev's policy of political freedoms and economic reforms may come in Poland rather than the Soviet Union. Poland's Communist leadership now must choose: either it can honor its recent hints of a new, legal role for Solidarity, or it can renege and thereby provoke fresh unrest that will raise the specter of Soviet intervention. Undoubtedly, hard-line apparatchiks in Moscow will read economic and political chaos in Poland as proof that reforms can't work in the Soviet Union either.

title: Dukakis Says There's Good News on Budget
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, seeking to squeeze some good news out of the state's shaky budget situation, said today that Massachusetts had ended its 1988 budget year in better shape than expected.

title: Eastern Union Voting on Wage Cuts
description: The 12,000 members of the machinists' union at Eastern Airlines are voting on a contract offer that calls for cuts of as much as 50 percent in pay and substantial givebacks in benefits.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Lear's magazine will raise its rate base 40 percent, to 350,000 from 250,000, with its January-February issue.

title: 4 Die as South Africans Storm Hijackers in Lesotho
description: A South African anti-terrorist squad stormed a bus in which 69 Roman Catholic pilgrims were being held hostage here tonight, killing three hijackers and a hostage and ending a 26-hour ordeal.

title: The Great Leveler
description: To The Home Section:

title:
CURRENTS;
High-Profile Advocates For the Undecorated
description: LEAD: MARIO BUATTA, a decorator and designer, and Leon Krier, an architect, may not travel in the same professional circles, but they share beliefs about design.

title: Rice Industry Complaint
description: The United States rice industry filed an official trade complaint today with the Government over what it termed Japan's illegal, unjustifiable and unreasonable rice policy.

title: World Economy's Rise Tops I.M.F. Forecasts
description: The world economy is showing much stronger growth and other improvements this year than were generally expected last spring, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

title: Why We See Friends
description: To The Home Section:

title: Jury Selection Begins in the Trial of Myerson, Capasso and a Judge
description: In a small, crowded, fourth-floor courtroom of Federal District Court in Manhattan, jury selection began yesterday in the trial of Bess Myerson, who resigned last year as New York City's Cultural Affairs Commissioner.

title: Democrats Never Lost Because of Liberalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Norway Oil Output Cut
description: Norway's North Sea oil production dropped to 1.06 million barrels a day in August from 1.17 million barrels in July because of maintenance work on a production platform, a survey found. Norway is Western Europe's biggest oil producer after Britain. Although it is not a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Norway has agreed to 7.5 percent cutbacks since February 1987 in support of OPEC's efforts to stabilize prices by limiting supply.

title:
Market Place;
Hurricane Gilbert Buffets Insurers
description: LEAD: HURRICANE GILBERT hit Wall Street yesterday. Insurance company stocks sold off as the fierce storm - considered one of the most dangerous hurricanes ever - threatened the Gulf Coast of the United States after scything through the Caribbean and striking Mexico.

title: Rise in Poverty Is Grim Side of Minneapolis Boom
description: For more than six years the economy of this city has been surging, with 3,000 new jobs a year being created in the downtown area and a surge of suburban growth that has turned the rolling prairies into a tangle of traffic and construction.

title: Sri Lankan Says He Won't Run as President Again
description: President J. R. Jayewardene, who has played a prominent role in Sri Lankan politics since independence in 1948, said in an interview today that he would not be a candidate in the next presidential election.

title: Dorothy S. Gerber, 84; Developed Baby Food
description: Dorothy Scott Gerber, the widow of Daniel F. Gerber, who founded the Gerber Products Company, died in her sleep Sunday at her home in Fremont, Mich., according to a company spokesman. She was 84 years old.

title: Partnership to Sell Pneumo-Abex Unit
description: The partnership that acquired the Pneumo-Abex Corporation for $1.3 billion last month said it planned to sell the company's Jetway Systems division. The unit, which controls 80 percent of the market for aircraft boarding bridges, had annual revenue of $70 million and is expected to sell for at least $150 million. Jetway Systems is based in Ogden, Utah, and has 600 employees.

title: What Is Quayle Hiding?
description: Why is Dan Quayle refusing to let the public know what he did at college and law school? Why won't he allow those schools to state the facts? Why does he fear the truth?

title: Owners of 2 Papers in Stock Swap
description: The owners of two of Europe's leading newspapers, The Financial Times in London and NRC Handelsblad in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, swapped one another's shares today to guard against unwanted takeovers.

title: Books of The Times; Triple Play of Sorts: Roth to Zuckerman to Roth
description: The Facts A Novelist's Autobiography By Philip Roth 195 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: Domestic Oil Output Down
description: Oil production in the United States declined again in August and imports remained strong as uncertainty over prices left little incentive for increasing domestic output, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday.

title: Dr. Aaron Janoff, 58, Research Pathologist
description: Dr. Aaron Janoff, an educator and research pathologist who won awards for his work on emphysema and smoking, died Sunday at his home in Setauket, L.I., after a long illness. He was 58 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: 6 F.B.I. Agents Punished The Director acted against agents who took part in a surveillance of citizens opposed to Administration policy in Central America. Page A20. Americans See Soviet Blast With American officials present for the first time, the Soviet Union exploded a nuclear device under the central Asian steppes. Page A8. Art Student Dies in Robbery A week after she moved to New York City from Arkansas, a 24-year-old woman was shot dead on a Brooklyn Street. Page B1.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT IMPROVES SHARPLY AS IMPORTS PLUNGE
description: In a surprisingly favorable development, the nation's trade deficit plunged to $9.5 billion in July, the lowest monthly level since late 1984.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Clarifying Confusion
description: When it comes to Congress and the courts, the left hand often does not know what the right hand is doing, according to a study of 15 Federal court decisions that found technical problems in various laws. Some of these problems merely involved questions of grammar, such as misplaced commas and ambiguous adjectives. Other laws had technical gaps, such as failing to state which courts had jurisdiction over cases that could be brought under the statutes. In still other cases, the courts explicitly invited Congressional action to clear up ambiguities.

title: Olympic Notebook; Airing a Soccer Grievance
description: The International Olympic Committee's 94th Congress, convening here this week, has had numerous weighty matters on the agenda: selecting the host city for the 1994 Winter Games, revising the I.O.C. charter, electing a new vice president, and so forth.

title: Review/Music; Nigerian Yoruba Drums
description: Many New Yorkers have heard Yoruba ritual drumming and chanting from Caribbean practitioners -either on its own or as the core of salsa music. On Tuesday night, SOB's presented Yoruba music from the old country - Nigeria - by the Muraina Oyelami ensemble, a trio of drummers and a dancer from the town of Erin Osun in the Province of Oyo in southwestern Nigeria.

title: Toyota Planning Debt Sale in U.S.
description: The Toyota Motor Credit Corporation, the American-based company that finances purchases of Toyota vehicles sold in the United States, plans to price $200 million of three-year notes, rated triple-A, for offering today. The underwriters are led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Sept. 5, about Federal scrutiny of electric cooperatives and utilities, included a company erroneously among those that received subpoenas from the Agriculture Department. The Eastern Iowa Light and Power Cooperative of Wilton, Iowa, was not among them.

title: Rocket Maker to Fight Suits
description: Morton Thiokol Inc., maker of the space shuttle's booster rockets, said yesterday that two lawsuits filed by safety engineers who formerly worked for the company were without merit and that it would fight them.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New England Buick Goes to David Deutsch
description: David Deutsch Associates, already the agency for Team Pontiac, the New York and New Jersey dealers association, has just been assigned the New England Buick Dealers Association, Woburn, Mass., made up of 60 dealers in Massachusetts, Rhode Island and New Hampshire who have about $2.5 million for advertising.

title: China Has Humane and Fair Birth Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Balladeer of the Green Berets Badly Wounded in Guatemala
description: Barry Sadler, a songwriter who became prominent in the 1960's with his recording of the ''Ballad of the Green Berets,'' was listed in critical but stable condition in a hospital here today after being shot in the head in Guatemala last week.

title: Sports People; Bullets Sign Price
description: The Washington Bullets signed a Cleveland Cavaliers' guard, Mark Price, and a veteran free-agent forward, Charles Jones. Price was signed to an offer sheet, the terms of which were not disclosed. The Cavaliers have 15 days to match Washington's offer to Price, 24 years old, who was Cleveland's third-leading scorer last season with an average of 16 points a game. If the Cavaliers fail to match Washington's offer, Price is free to join the Bullets, team officials said.(AP)

title: Forest Hills: From Rage to Tranquillity
description: In a quiet corner of Forest Hills that once was as hotly contested as the sites designated for public housing in Yonkers, an old white woman sat on a bench under a willow tree and tried to explain to an old black woman what the early mornings used to feel like in her native Odessa. Nearby, children from a nursery school played, and a mother shouted to her son in Urdu to be careful as he rode his bicycle.

title: Dukakis Outlines Military Policy And Offers a Challenge to Soviets
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis outlined his military policy today in the greatest detail he has yet offered, endorsing three nuclear arms programs and calling for a major buildup of conventional forces. He also went beyond Reagan Administration proposals and challenged the Soviet Union to eliminate its biggest and most deadly nuclear missiles.

title: Democrats Never Lost Because of Liberalism; Language and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; The End of Churchill's Life Story
description: Winston S. Churchill Volume VIII 'Never Despair': 1945-1965 By Martin Gilbert 1,438 pages. Illustrated. Houghton Mifflin. $40.

title: Strike at New Jersey Hospital By 1,165 Employees Is Over
description: A two-day strike over wages by 1,165 unionized workers at the Bergen Pines County Hospital in Paramus, N.J., the largest public hospital in the state, ended last night when both sides agreed to a tentative new contract, officials said.

title: Dukakis Faces Powerful Foe In Camera-Hogging Hurricane
description: As many military commanders have, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis this week found his counterattack on defense and foreign policy battling bad weather, in this case the powerful hurricane that was blowing political coverage off the top of the evening news.

title: Cooper Companies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a one-time restructuring costs of $35.8 million due primarily to severance and facilities closures for both the quarter and 9 months, and net losses on the sale of businesses of $4.4 million for the quarter and $9.7 million for the 9 months, and the 9-month also includes an extraordinary loss of $4.6 million. c-Net income d-Includes a minority interest in Cooper Technicon of $1.5 million for both the quarter and 9 months , and the 9 months also includes a net gain on the sale of businesses of $190.8 million, costs associated with restructuring operations of $11 million, a non- recurring charge of $6 million from the settlement of litigation, an extraordinary charge of $17.9 million related to the repurchase of debentures. The company said its financial results for the third quarters and first nine months of fiscal 1988 and 1987 are not directly comparable because Cooper Technicon's operating results are only included in the last month of the year-ago third quarter; the company's former ophthalmic pharmaceutical business' operating results are only included in the first two months of the year-ago first quarter; and its former non-U.S. solutions and optical retail businesses' operating results are not included in the second and third quarters of fiscal 1988. The company also said Cooper Technican added sales of $109.5 million to its latest third quarter results.

title: Mets Strong-Arm Another Opponent
description: So, how good are they, these fine young pitchers on the Mets as they streak toward October in a blur of shutouts, complete games, low-hit games and no-nonsense games?

title: George Clowes Jr., 73, A Medical Researcher
description: Dr. George H. A. Clowes Jr., a surgeon and researcher who studied activity in human cells that causes tissues to waste away, died of a cerebral hemmorrhage Saturday at his summer home in Woods Hole, Mass. He was 73 years old and lived in Dover, Mass.

title: TCBY Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Ohrenstein, Outspent 3-1, Defeats Primary Opponent
description: Manfred Ohrenstein, the State Senate's Democratic leader who was indicted a year ago, withstood his strongest political challenge in 25 years yesterday, handily defeating his opponent, Joe Rose.

title: Stram Feeling Better
description: Hank Stram, a former coach of the Kansas City Chiefs, was moved yesterday from the cardiovascular critical care unit to a regular room at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis. ''He is up and walking around,'' said Jon White, a hospital spokesman. Stram, 65 years old, underwent open-heart surgery Tuesday to correct a narrowing of the aortic valve. (AP)

title: Right to Bar Treatment by Any With AIDS Virus Weighed
description: Patients at Cook County Hospital would have the right to refuse to be treated by workers who carry the AIDS virus under a proposal that has been criticized by AIDS experts and the American Medical Association as misinformed and unnecessary.

title: Giants Sign Cooks To Help Defense
description: The Giants are beginning to find themselves with more leaks than fingers to plug the holes.

title: 'Rasputin' Premiere
description: The New York City Opera is to give the world premiere of Jay Riese's ''Rasputin'' tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock at the New York State Theater. Christopher Keene will conduct the performance, which is to be sung in English. The cast includes John Cheek in the title role, Margaret Cusack as Alexandra, Jon Garrison as Nicholas and Henry Price as Prince Felix Yusupov. Tickets are $10 to $44. Information: 870-5570.

title: For Walesa and Warsaw, Round 3
description: Lech Walesa and the Polish Interior Minister, Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, held a second round of talks today designed to pave the way for broad round-table discussions on economic and political change in Poland.

title: Americans and Soviets Coordinate Storm Flights
description: American and Soviet tracking aircraft flying inside the vortex of Hurricane Gilbert in recent days have found themselves so close at times that they were forced yesterday to begin coordinating flight paths as they whirled through thestorm.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 452 money market mutual funds decreased by $347.4 million, to $266.58 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 126 institutional funds fell $166.4 million, to $68.56 billion, while the 223 general purpose funds fell $53.5 million, to $84.92 billion, and the 103 broker-dealer funds fell $127.5 billion, to $113.1 billion.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on Wednesday incorrectly characterized the position of the United States Department of Agriculture on the Federal Dietary Guidelines. As stated elsewhere in the column, the Agriculture Department has said school lunches should be consistent with the guidelines while questioning whether those guidelines are appropriate for children.

title: Industrial Operating Rate Increased to 83.7% in August
description: The nation's industrial operating rate rose for the fifth consecutive month in August, but economists played down the inflationary effect of the increase because it was entirely attributable to a temporary summer surge at utilities.

title: Espey Manufacturing & Electronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $102,774 from a change in accounting.

title: Bias Order Is Again Splitting Town in Jersey
description: Nothing raises the ire of Vito Menza, a former school board member here, as much as talking about the whites who left Hillside after the state ordered the desegregation of the public schools in 1983.

title: Reviews/Film; Down on the Farm, And Down and Down
description: The farm of the fictitious Roberts family was once such a shining example of American agricultural expertise that when Nikita Khrushchev visited Iowa, it was the Roberts place that he wanted to see. That remarkable moment is captured in the rapturous slow-motion prologue to ''Miles From Home,'' which views Khrushchev's visit through the proud eyes of the two young Roberts boys (with Brian Dennehy making a fleeting appearance as their father). But today, with Frank Roberts Sr. gone and the farm in the hands of his sons, Frank Jr. (Richard Gere) and Terry (Kevin Anderson), the place is on the verge of bankruptcy. What has gone wrong?

title: Judge Deserves Praise In Long Mob Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Presley Stamp Salutes His Art, Not His Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Prime Is Raised in Canada
description: Five of Canada's largest banks today increased their prime lending rates by half a percentage point, to 11 3/4 percent, as Canada's central bank toughened its anti-inflationary stance.

title: Review/Film; Words Bearing Witness: 'Letters Home From Vietnam'
description: Bill Couturie's ''Dear America: Letters Home From Vietnam'' recalls the Vietnam War in the words of the men and women who fought it, in letters written in haste, without self-consciousness and, mostly, without pretense. These are read on the soundtrack by more than two dozen professional actors, some of whose voices are all too familiar, juxtaposed with Vietnam War film, much of which is new to me and all of which remains sad and harrowing.

title: 'WASP' Stings. It Isn't Amusing.
description: It's past time that the media quit using the jeering word ''WASP'' in their pages. This ethnic epithet is often employed in print (and conversation) with a prejudice that is intended to sting. It's a cudgel, though some people do express with it only a sort of playful irony or sloppy abbreviation without sneering intent, as has been the case with similar sobriquets such as ''Mick,'' ''Wop,'' ''Spick,'' ''Kike'' ''Bohunk,'' etc. The history of ''White Anglo-Saxon Protestants'' in the United States has been different from the histories of these various other groups, as each one's has been different from the rest, and as each group in its turn has offended and taken umbrage at the rest.

title: In Welfare System, Clients Are Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Death Penalty: A Federal Tantrum
description: LEAD: The Senate has passed a bill sponsored by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato that establishes a death penalty for drug-related killings. A slightly different drug death penalty passed the House last week. A conference committee is expected to decide whether a death penalty is an appropriate part of the Federal drug war.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Autumn With Torme

title: Divi Hotels NV reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
N.F.L. Matchups; Schroeder to Take Over Soon
description: The Raiders were stretching before practice today, a line of silver and black, bending knees and backs and chanting cadences between grunts. Three players, all quarterbacks, stood near the front in bright red jerseys. Steve Beuerlein was on the left. Vince Evans was on the right. Jay Schroeder was in the middle. ''I'm right in the middle of all of this now trying to keep everything straight,'' said Schroeder, the former Washington Redskin who lit up the capital and then dimmed the lights in a huff after losing his starting job to Doug Williams. He was traded to the Raiders last week for Jim Lachey, an offensive lineman, and undisclosed draft choices.

title: The Law; At the Bar
description: According to Justice Thurgood Marshall, the annual Second Circuit judicial conferences were no big deal when Learned Hand was running them.

title: Odd Doings As 'Mama Turns 100'
description: ''Mama Turns 100'' was shown as part of the 1980 New Spanish Cinema Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times Jan. 11, 1980. The film, in Spanish with English subtitles, opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema, at La Guardia Place.

title: Former Aide Questions Signing of Reagan's Initials
description: James M. Cannon, who in early 1987 was an adviser to the White House chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., said today that he had seen a ''serious document'' on which President Reagan's initials had been signed by someone else.

title: Bentsen Takes Up the Offensive, Assailing Bush's Choice of Quayle
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen has not devoted much campaign time so far to discussing his Republican opponent, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, but today he began what his aides called a calculated Democratic offensive.

title: Our Towns; Hello? A.C.L.U.? I'm a Republican, But I Need Help!
description: When Michael Dukakis said he was proud to be a card-carrying member of the American Civil Liberties Union, George Bush shot back, ''I am not and never will be,'' and said that was typical of Mr. Dukakis's liberalism.

title: Becker Staying Home
description: Boris Becker will not attend the Olympic Games in South Korea after all, chiefly because some other West German athletes criticized his plans to visit Seoul as a nonparticipant. Becker withdrew as a tennis player earlier on the advice of his doctor, who is treating the two-time Wimbledon champion for foot problems. He was to have gone to Seoul as ''diplomat of German sports'' and stay at the Olympic village. The West German newspaper Bild quoted a West German javelin thrower, Wolfram Gambke as saying: ''Every sports figure who had to stay home would have given their best in Seoul. Boris Becker will certainly do the same: by standing around, greeting people and giving interviews.'' Becker's father said in Frankfurt that his son's decision not to go was for personal reasons.(AP)

title: ILLNESS FROM EGGS BRINGS U.S. ACTION
description: Cases of salmonella food poisoning that are attributed to eating raw or undercooked eggs are appearing in parts of the country other than the Northeast, where they were previously reported, Federal health officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about an American decision to release some overdue payments to the United Nations misidentified the Administration under which Daniel Patrick Moynihan served as American representative at the United Nations. It was the Ford Administration.

title: State by State; In Jersey, Bush's Transformation Impresses a Friend of Both Nominees
description: Few if any professional politicians are as well-positioned to comment on this year's Presidential race as Governor Kean.

title: U.S. Confirms 16% Rise in Cost for Secret Bomber
description: Pentagon officials today confirmed that the price of the secret Stealth bomber had grown 16 percent from previous estimates, but they said the program was now being managed in a way to control the aircraft's costs.

title: Dukakis Gains 614 Votes (on a Greek Isle)
description: The Government today announced the approval of a $700,000 public works project to pave a road on the island of Lesbos leading to the 'hometown' of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, the Democratic candidate for President of the United States.

title: Procurement Complaint Against Goodyear Is Expanded
description: The Federal Government yesterday expanded its complaint that the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company had overcharged the Government on military contracts.

title: The Big Series: Game 1 to Yanks
description: They were also-rans two weeks ago, but tonight the Yankees pulled themselves back into the race. They beat Roger Clemens and the Boston Red Sox, 5-3, at Fenway Park, and when they were done, they spoke only about the next day.

title: King City Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The bank converted from a federal mutual savings and loan association to a federal stock savings bank on Nov. 4, 1986. Therefore, the per share earnings for fiscal 1987 represented a prorating of income for the time period the shares of stock were actually outstanding.

title: 'Sophisticated Ladies' Opening Oct. 1 in Moscow
description: The first Soviet-American co-production of a Broadway musical -Duke Ellington's ''Sophisticated Ladies'' - is to open Oct. 1 in Moscow, the sponsoring organizations have announced.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''THE SECRET OF THE CARDBOARD ROCKET,'' a sky show about the adventures of two youngsters, for children 6 to 9 years old, noon tomorrow, at the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium, Central Park West at 81st Street. Admission: children, $2; adults, $3.75. Information: 769-5900. HARVEST DAY, a program of old-time crafts, farm chores, games for children, gardening talks and folk music, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Sunday, at the Stamford (Conn.) Museum and Nature Center, 39 Scofieldtown Road. Admission: children and the elderly, $2; others, $3. Information: (203) 322-1646. THE FUNZAPOPPIN MAGIC SHOW, a program of comedy and magic, presented by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Tickets: $4.50. Reservations: 772-9180. ''ELSIE PIDDOCK,'' a story written by Eleanor Farjeon, and told by Diane Wolkstein, with music by Shirley Keller, a guitarist, and a skip-rope contest (children are urged to bring their own skip ropes), 11 A.M. tomorrow at the Hans Christian Andersen statue, near 72d Street and Fifth Avenue in Central Park. Free. CHILDREN'S CONCERT, a program for children and their parents, including some sing-along music, 2:30 P.M. tomorrow, at the Heckscher Oval Theater at Lincoln Center. Free ( advance reservations are required). Information: 870-1633. ''THE WIZARD OF OZ,'' a show by the Puppetworks Theater, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays at 287 Third Avenue, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Tickets: $3.75. Information: (718) 834-1828.

title: Presley Stamp Salutes His Art, Not His Life; It's About Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Greek Premier Is Seeking a Divorce
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, apparently embarrassed by his wife's accusations that his mistress had endangered his health, indicated today that he would seek a divorce.

title: Pilot Faulted for Downing Jet
description: A year after a Navy F-14 Tomcat shot down an Air Force reconnaissance jet, the Navy has released an investigative report that attributes the accident to a ''basic error in judgment'' and ''an illogical act'' by the young fighter pilot.

title: A Unit of G.&W. Offers 8 3/4% Notes
description: The Associates Corporation of North America, a unit of Gulf and Western Inc., is offering $150 million of 8 3/4 percent notes due in 1991 at an initial price of 99.60, to yield 8.894 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Blood Products Issued in Error, Red Cross Finds
description: An internal review of the Red Cross blood service regions indicates that more than 2,400 blood products were improperly released over a six-month period, 518 of them without complete testing for deadly diseases.

title: G.A.O. Lifts Bailout Estimates by 25%
description: The General Accounting Office said today that it would cost at least 25 percent more than it had estimated to clean up the nation's savings industry.

title: Mormon Bomber in Hospital
description: Mark Hoffman, convicted of killing two people with pipe bombs and of forging Mormon documents, apparently took an overdose of drugs today and is in critical condition, a spokesman for the Utah Health Sciences Center said. A medical helicopter took the 33-year-old Mr. Hoffman to the hospital from Utah State Prison this afternoon. He is serving five years to life for the fatal bombings Oct. 15, 1985. The authorities said at the time he acted to cover his forgeries.

title: GUN CONTROL PLAN REJECTED IN HOUSE
description: In a blow to advocates of gun control, the House voted today to strike from major drug legislation a measure establishing a seven-day waiting period for gun purchases.

title: Christian Science Group To Begin News Monthly
description: The first issue of World Monitor, a monthly news magazine from The Christian Science Monitor, will be going to newsstands and subscribers early next month.

title: Inacomp Computer Centers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Bridge
description: Years ago, the favorite in a major golf tournament proceeded to win after asking aggressively on the first tee, ''Who's going to be second?''

title: Ex-Judge Wins in the Bronx In Vote for District Attorney
description: Robert T. Johnson, a relatively late entrant to one of the stranger elections in recent memory, won the Democratic nomination for District Attorney in the Bronx last night and was virtually assured of becoming the first black District Attorney in the state.

title: '94 Winter Games Awarded
description: In a mild surprise, the International Olympic Committee voted to award the 1994 Winter Olympic Games to Lillehammer, Norway. Page D19.

title: Reviews/Film; Almodovar's 'Matador,' Surrealist Sex Comedy
description: Diego and Maria have not yet met, but it's clear from the initial sequences of ''Matador,'' Pedro Almodovar's insistently raffish, 1986 Spanish comedy, that they were made for each other. Each equates the act of killing with an act of sex in which death is the ultimate orgasm.

title: Review/Theater; Skewering With a Smile, in 'Forbidden Broadway'
description: The only real worry about ''Forbidden Broadway,'' the long-running Off Broadway revue, has been whether it might outrun Broadway itself. During the leaner theater seasons of the 1980's, this satirical cabaret, now six years old, was scraping around desperately in search of fresh Broadway targets to mock. As a result, reruns set in. So did gallows humor. In one outing, ''Forbidden Broadway'' announced its intention to read the roll call of the New York theater's latest hits, then fell into a minute of dead silence. That was not a joke so much as honest journalism.

title: Global Pop, Done in the Soviet Style
description: The Iron Curtain isn't soundproof. Music makes the East-West or West-East crossing, depending on the vagaries of international diplomacy and commerce, and the not quite untrammeled traffic in culture makes every trip different. While some musicians pick up ideas from the other side, others ignore them.

title: A Booth-by-Booth Guide to the Book Fair
description: This is a booth-by-booth browser's guide to activities at the New York Is Book Country fair. The major displays of each booth are listed. Author appearances are subject to change. 1. Rizzoli Publications: Display based on ''Art of the South African Townships.'' Drawing for pair of tickets to ''Sarafina!'' South African singers. 2. New York Botanical Garden:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Toyota Motor Credit Corporation, the auto maker's financing unit in the United States, yesterday became the first Toyota entity to tap the United States public debt market and the first non-government Japanese company to sell debt here since 1978.

title: Dining Out Guide: Near Lincoln Center
