description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Cameos

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: For Russians, Food Buying Is No Bargain
description: The first aisle of the best grocery store in Klavdiya M. Petrova's neighborhood today offers scrawny chickens, two grades of bony soup beef, some Bulgarian fruit juices, mayonnaise, pickles, cottage cheese, thin yogurt, cherry jam and jars of Rumanian peas. The fresh produce: garlic, celery greens, apples and green peppers.

title: Marshall Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Young Kennedy Gets Support
description: Democratic Party leaders who once dismissed Patrick Kennedy as too young and inexperienced to be a State Representative said today that they were just being loyal to the incumbent he defeated.

title: New Publishers At Conde Nast
description: Conde Nast announced yesterday that Jack Kliger, 41 years old, publisher of GQ magazine for the last three years, had been shifted to the publisher's job at Glamour. Mr. Kliger replaces E. Louis

title: Grateful Dead Plans Benefit for Rain Forests
description: In a rare appeal to their devoted fans, known as Deadheads, leaders of the Grateful Dead rock band announced this week that they were starting a campaign to save the world's tropical rain forests.

title: Cartoon Images Mask Violence in Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Acts to Seize Battle Site
description: A Senate panel voted today to seize a development site adjacent to the Manassas National Battlefield Park in suburban Virginia, rejecting several compromise plans that would have acquired only part of the parcel.

title: Retail Sales Down, but Just a Bit
description: Retail sales dropped two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Many economists said the small decline should not arouse any serious concerns about the economy's health.

title: Lesotho Hostage's Story: 'We Began Praying'
description: Sister Florina Nyokana sat up in her hospital bed and talked about her ordeal as a hostage during the 30-hour hijacking of the bus she and 70 other pilgrims witnessed on Wednesday.

title: Horace Henderson, 83, a Pianist And Arranger for the Jazz Greats
description: Horace Henderson, a pianist, arranger and composer who often collaborated with his brother, Fletcher, died after a short illness on Aug. 29, at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Denver. He was 83 years old and lived in Denver.

title: Biaggi's Law License Is Suspended by Court
description: A state appeals court has suspended Mario Biaggi, the former Bronx Congressman, from practicing law in New York State and begun a process that could lead to disbarment. He has been convicted twice on Federal Corruption charges in the last year.

title: U.S. Bonds Down on Profit Taking
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds slipped in thin trading yesterday as market participants elected to take profits rather than buy more securities after the release of weaker-than-expected economic data.

title: 'Ties' Creator in Pact
description: Gary David Goldberg, the creator of ''Family Ties,'' has signed a contract that will keep him at Paramount for another six years. Mr. Goldberg will branch out into producing and directing movies for the studio as well as continuing to oversee his three television shows -''Family Ties,'' ''Day by Day'' and ''Duet.''

title: Restaurants
description: La Colombe d'Or

title: AEP Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A Revival for the Rear-Wheel-Drive Car
description: After a decade of turbulent change, Detroit is returning to the tried and true. Rear-wheel drive is making a bit of a comeback.

title: Savings Unit Takeover
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had arranged the acquisition of the insolvent Coosa Federal Savings and Loan Association of Gadsden, Ala., by the Birmingham-based Secor Savings Bank. The transaction brought to 103 the number of troubled savings units dealt with this year, 85 of them through federally assisted acquisitions or mergers, the bank board said.

title:
About Real Estate;
'Manhattan Style' Housing Comes to White Plains
description: LEAD: Residential high-rise development in White Plains has tended to follow in the path of that city's older multifamily housing stock, offering traditional architecture and masonry construction.

title: 2 Quit Porsche In Shake-Up
description: Two top executives of Porsche Cars North America Inc. are leaving their jobs in a management shake-up that will abolish an executive-level sales post, the company said today.

title: Panel Asks for Major Expansion of Drug Clinics to Combat AIDS
description: A commission sponsored by 18 foundations yesterday appealed to local officials in New York City and New Jersey to resist neighborhood opposition and help encourage a major expansion of drug clinics to end the backlog of addicts seeking treatment.

title: Nets Sign Romar
description: The Nets have given a multiyear contract to Lorenzo Romar, the free-agent guard who has played the last three years with Athletes in Action. The 6-foot-1-inch Romar played four National Basketball Association seasons with the Golden State Warriors, Milwaukee Bucks and the Detroit Pistons before being waived by Detroit nine games into the 1984-85 season. Romar, a seventh-round draft choice of the Warriors in 1980 out of the University of Washington, had his best season in the N.B.A. when he averaged 7.3 points in 82 games for the Warriors in 1982-83. . . . Gene Banks, formerly with the Chicago Bulls, and Larry Drew, formerly with the Los Angeles Clippers, have signed to play basketball for teams in Italy this season, Banks with Arimo Bologna and Drew with the Italian champion, Scavolini Pesaro. Both players will be paid about $250,000 for one season. (AP)

title: Cut in Staff Is Sought for U.S. Embassy in Panama
description: The American Ambassador to Panama has recommended the elimination of about half of the 160 diplomatic posts at the embassy in Panama City because of concern for their safety, State Department officials said today.

title: American Building Mainteance Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Islander to Retire
description: Todd Okerlund, a right wing who spent most of last season with the United States Olympic team, has decided to retire because of a recurring knee problem, the Islanders announced yeaterday. Okerlund, 24 years old, has had reconstructive surgery on the knee, which he injured in 1986 while playing for the University of Minnesota. Although he passed a team physical, Okerlund experienced pain while skating and left training camp last Friday after being advised by an team orthopedist that he was risking further damage. He scored one goal in three Olympic games and appeared in four games with the Islanders. . . . With Kirk Muller, their captain, reaching an agreement for a three-year contract plus an option year, and Mark Johnson and Jack O'Callahan also signing, the New Jersey Devils have signed all their players.

title: Hurricane Affects Teams
description: The likelihood that Hurricane Gilbert will hit the Texas Gulf Coast and pelt other coastal areas along the Gulf of Mexico with high wind and heavy rain this afternoon has inspired some changes in sports schedules.

title: Again, the N.R.A. Beats the Cops
description: For years the National Rifle Association enjoyed friendly relations with police, but now the cops are estranged - for reasons that became clearer than ever yesterday. The big gun lobby appears bent on giving aid and comfort to criminals.

title: Nu-Med Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $4,241,000 from the purchase of debentures.

title: Academic Research for Financial Gain
description: Scientific research at American universities like Harvard has traditionally had an aura of purity about it. The impression was that it was conducted solely for the pursuit of knowledge and was free of the taint of commercial profit.

title: Rochester Community Savngs Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $3,416,000 for the quarter and $7,964,000 for the 9 months.

title: Contras Agree to Resume Peace Talks
description: Nicaraguan rebel leaders said today that they had decided to resume negotiations with the Government of Nicaragua in an effort to ''resuscitate the hope of peace'' in Central America.

title: Boston Journal; Campus Declares War To Control Dormitories
description: Sometime in the last school year, John R. Silber received a letter from a parent expressing anger that her daughter's roommate had lived for two months with a boyfriend in their dormitory at Boston University.

title: Gencorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a gain from the sale of land of $6 million, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter, and the 9 months includes net from discontinued operations of $4 million and a gain of $3 million from an accounting change. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1 million and $5 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a gain of $214 million from the sale of discontinued operations.

title: Paris Parley On Currency
description: Finance Minister Pierre Beregovoy of France said today that he had met secretly with the head of West Germany's central bank to discuss Europe's nervous currency markets.

title: Tultex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
KEY RATES
EVACUATIONS RISE
description: The outer edges of Hurricane Gilbert began licking the Gulf Coast today as Jamaica and the Yucatan Peninsula picked up the pieces left by one of the fiercest storms in history.

title: Campaign Trail; On With the Image, Off With the Image
description: As Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's chartered plane headed westward yesterday from Boston, the Democratic candidate wandered up the aisle dressed in khaki pants and a red sweater.

title: Textile Bill Is Passed Again
description: The Senate again approved a bill to limit textile imports, voting 59 to 36 today in a procedural step. It approved the same wording last week, 57 to 32.

title: U.S. Jury Charges Ashland In Oil Spill Near Pittsburgh
description: Ashland Oil Inc. has been indicted for violating Federal environmental laws in the collapse of a storage tank last January that spilled more than 500,000 gallons of oil into the Monongahela River near Pittsburgh, the Justice Department announced today.

title: Highlights From Four Decades of Jackie Gleason
description: Jackie Gleason developed his comedy talents on the old Dumont network's ''Cavalcade of Stars.'' Then, wooed with multimillion-dollar contracts, he moved to CBS, where he presided over 10 different shows in 23 years. Mr. Gleason was good for CBS, and the network is acknowledging that fact with an ingratiating two-hour special tomorrow at 8 P.M. It's called ''Jackie Gleason: The Great One,'' and the hosts, sifting through four decades of films, tapes and kinescopes, are Art Carney, John Candy, Jane Curtin, Teri Garr and John Larroquette.

title: Reviews/Film; Russians And Afghans
description: ''The Beast,'' opening today at the Manhattan Twin and other theaters, is a sincere, most peculiar, politically aware action film, a sort of cross between ''The Lost Patrol'' and a liberal-leaning ''Rambo.''

title: Wallace Computer Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Playing the Housing Slump: The Quick and the Indebted
description: Mitch Pow went bargain hunting in this ungainly prairie suburb last April and bagged a whopper: a $110,000 town house, slashed to $77,000 after the owner defaulted on his federally insured mortgage. The Department of Housing and Urban Development, which sold the home to recoup losses, even contributed $3,000 in closing costs.

title: I.B.M. Deal On Graphics Is Expected
description: Silicon Graphics Inc., a manufacturer of powerful computer work stations, is expected to announce an arrangement on Friday under which the International Business Machines Corporation would license its technology for making computers whose strength is graphics.

title: Washington Talk: National Security Affairs; Mentors Help to Shape General Powell's Career
description: There is a familiar pattern in the way some careers are made in the capital; catching the attention of those who travel in Washington's circles of power usually is rewarded and leads to greater things. That pattern seems to work especially in the case of the men who have advised the President on national security affairs.

title: Jamaica Prime Minister Orders Stores Reopened
description: With Jamaica strugglingto recover from an onslaught by Hurricane Gilbert four days ago, Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga today declared a state of ''public emergency'' for the capital and three adjacent districts.

title: Lamenting a Lack of Tourists
description: Two days before the opening of the Olympics, more than a third of the tickets for the Games are unsold and almost a quarter of the rooms in the city's hotels are vacant.

title: Optical Radiation Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AT THE MOVIES
description: Styron Project Revived

title: Carolina Power Bonds Yield 9.03%
description: Among new corporate issues up for competitive bidding, underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company won a $100 million financing by the Carolina Power and Light Company.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Letters From Vietnam
description: John Wheeler, executive director of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund, was among those who attended a Wednesday night filming here of the acclaimed made-for-television documentary, ''Dear America: Letters Home From Vietnam,'' that is to open in movie theaters in 55 cities in the United States and Canada this weekend.

title: Rev. William Edward Cousins, 86, Retired Archbishop of Milwaukee
description: The Rev. William Edward Cousins, the retired Roman Catholic Archbishop of Milwaukee, a central figure in a widely publicized civil rights controversy in the 1960's, died from complications of pneumonia Wednesday at St. Anne's Home for the Elderly in Milwaukee. He was 86 years old and lived in Milwaukee.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Plans Venture With Soviets
description: On the heels of an announcement that Young & Rubicam has signed a joint venture agreement with a Soviet Government ad agency to operate in Moscow, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide has reported that it too has signed a letter of intent for a joint venture in that city.

title: Among South Koreans, Olympics Foster True Believers and Infidels
description: This nation, for centuries a victim of foreign invasions, is pouring all the fury at its past and pride in its present into an Olympics meant to prove Korea's worth to the world.

title: Ashe Improving
description: After being hospitalized for a week, Arthur Ashe was released from New York Hospital yesterday. The former tennis champion underwent tests last week for a condition his agent described as a severe bacterial infection in his head. The infection put pressure on nerves, causing numbness in Ashe's arm, according to Ted Ewanciw, a spokesman for ProServ, Ashe's agent. Ashe underwent antibiotic treatment, which relieved the pressure considerably, Ewanciw said.(AP)

title: Auctioneer Admits Trying to Extort Bribe for Navy Yard Bid
description: LEAD: A businessman admitted in court yesterday that he tried to extort a bribe from a ship-repair company by claiming to be the middleman in a payoff that he said was intended for a Brooklyn Navy Yard official.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Barrick Resources Corp., Toronto, which is engaged in the mining of gold, petroleum and natural gas and coal, appointed Marshall A. Cohen, president of Olympia & York Enterprises Corp., to be a director.

title: Gearhart Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Year-ago figures are restated to exclude results of a Canadian subsidiary sold in fiscal 1988. Also excluded from the year-ago results was a $19.3 million gain on the sale of Gearhart's stake in the subsidiary.

title: Topics of The Times; NBC's $8 Million Contribution
description: It was regrettable that Vice President Bush and Governor Dukakis agreed to only two televised debates. This disappointed voters who hoped that a more expansive schedule would add substance to a campaign trivialized by long-distance mudslinging. Worse, the date for the first debate, Sept. 25, coincides with the Olympics.

title: In U.S., a Difficult Wait for Word From Families
description: A week ago Monday, on the first day of school, Carole Tomlinson talked to her children on the island of Jamaica.

title: 12 Israeli Boxers Are Banned for Life
description: The International Amateur Boxing Federation today suspended 12 Israeli boxers for life and accused that country's boxing federation of gross misconduct for sending a team to compete in South Africa.

title: A Book Fair That Transports Voyagers to Faraway Places
description: ''BOOKS are for traveling,'' proclaims this year's New York Is Book Country fair (to be held this Sunday on Fifth Avenue). Yes indeed. But it isn't necessarily travel books that we want to take on our travels.

title: Mugabe Wins Anti-Hunger Prize
description: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe was named yesterday as the winner of a prize given to African leaders who have worked to increase food production and end hunger.

title: Yankees Handle Erratic Clemens
description: Roger Clemens, who more than a month ago dropped out of the running for his third consecutive Cy Young Award, continued to confound the Boston Red Sox tonight.

title: Boston Celtics LP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest year included a gain of $2,525,774 from the expansion of the National Basketball Association. Comparable prior year net per-unit is not applicable; partnership went public in December 1986. Share earnings are in units.

title: Presley Stamp Salutes His Art, Not His Life; Is a Tow Truck Better?
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Decries the Beating of a Union Leader
description: The family and friends of Dolores Huerta, the co-founder of the United Farm Workers, expressed outrage today over what they said was her severe beating by the police. She suffered broken ribs and the loss of her spleen.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Tommy Flanagan

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY HONG KONG FILMS

title: Review/Film; A Loner Rebels in Coal Country
description: The hero of ''The Prince of Pennsylvania'' is a sullen teen-age boy named Rupert Marshetta (Keanu Reeves), who is locked in battle with his father. Already, there's a problem: the father, a stubborn, difficult, long-suffering coal miner named Gary Marshetta (Fred Ward), is nevertheless a great deal more likable than his loutish and self-involved son. This problem is greatly emphasized when Rupert and an older girlfriend, Carla Headlee (Amy Madigan), decide to kidnap Gary so they can raise enough money to leave their small Pennyslvania town. This scheme will seem both cruel and inefficient to audiences who wish Rupert would get moving in a hurry.

title: Beef From Mr. Dukakis on Defense
description: Michael Dukakis has finally gone beyond campaign oratory on national security issues. Sure, he has to if he's to counter George Bush's campaign to portray him as weak. Sure, some of his offerings are confusing, even questionable. But encouragingly, the Democratic candidate is engaging the subject seriously, and trying to bridge the gap between liberal ends and hard-headed means.

title: INSIDE
description: Contras Agree to Talks Nicaraguan rebel leaders said they had decided to resume negotiations with Managua in an effort to ''resuscitate the hope of peace.'' Page A3. indicted Ashland Oil over the collapse of a storage tank that spilled 500,000 gallons of oil into the Monongahela River on Jan. 2. Page A12. Food Poisoning From Eggs A type of Salmonella food poisoning linked to clean, uncracked Grade A eggs is spreading beyond the Northeast, health officials said. Page A15.

title: Cole Setting Out To Inspire the Jets
description: If a Super Bowl ring, old-fashioned homilies and a dose of carnival pitchman help, then Robin Cole might actually improve the Jets' corps of linebackers.

title: Athletics Need Five to Clinch
description: Dave Parker drove in three runs with two singles as the Oakland Athletics beat the Texas Rangers, 6-2, today and moved another step closer to the American League West title.

title: LTX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $810,000. c-Net loss

title: Bound Girl, 13, Is Found Slain in Her Home
description: A 13-year-old girl who had been bound, gagged and repeatedly stabbed was found dead yesterday in the apartment where she lived with her family in the Parkchester section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: People
description: * Lisa Blumenstein and John Draper have been named senior vice presidents at Sudler & Hennessey Consumer Group.

title: Panel Backs Bill to Expand Veterans' Appeals
description: The House Veterans Affairs Committee today approved a bill that would give veterans a limited opportunity to appeal to the Federal courts over denials of benefits.

title: Andre Watts Receives Avery Fisher Prize
description: The pianist Andre Watts became the ninth recipient of the Avery Fisher Prize - a $25,000 tax-free gift - receiving the prize Wednesday afternoon at a ceremony in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Recount Confirms Loser Won
description: Lieut. Gov. S. B. Woo won a 71-vote victory today in a recount in Delaware's Democratic senatorial primary race, five days after a clerical error left his opponent claiming victory.

title: Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, 711 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017

title: CROWD FOR POPE SPARSE IN LESOTHO
description: About 10,000 worshipers, a tiny crowd by papal standards, gathered around a big altar in this small mountain kingdom today for the religious highpoint of Pope John Paul II's trip through southern Africa, At the solemn Mass, John Paul beatified the Rev. Joseph Gerard, a French missionary who spent 60 years among the Zulu and Basotho people before he died in 1914. The event is a preliminary step to sainthood.

title: Economic Scene; Submerged Issue: The Budget Gap
description: THE Federal budget deficit remains the great submerged issue in the 1988 Presidential campaign. Vice President Bush cannot hit the issue hard without acknowledging the Reagan Administration's role in swelling the deficit to $2.5 trillion from $1 trillion eight years ago. The one Bush phrase that will not die is his 1980 attack on Mr. Reagan's ''voodoo economics.'' Today Mr. Bush presents himself as a hawk on military programs, a protector of Social Security benefits and other social programs, and an ardent opponent of tax increases, and says he expects the nation to ''grow out'' of the budget deficits over the next four or five years.

title: It's Still Bush League
description: Let me repeat what I wrote here on June 24: ''Vice President Bush must have little to say of real national importance if he can think of nothing better than to picture Michael Dukakis as soft on crime and weak on patriotism.''

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Winners Still Have Something to Prove
description: The eight horses who will contest the $831,000 Woodward Handicap at Belmont Park tomorrow are proven stakes winners who have earned more than $12 million in their careers. Their quality is beyond question, yet all of them have a lot to prove tomorrow.

title: Guinness Lifts Earnings 19%
description: Guinness P.L.C. today reported a 19 percent profit increase for the first half, helped by a large reduction in interest costs.

title: 5,000-Cruzado Banknote
description: Brazil's central bank introduced a 5,000-cruzado banknote today in an effort to keep money denominations in line with skyrocketing inflation. The new bill, worth $16 at the official exchange rate, replaces the 1,000-cruzado note as the country's highest-value banknote. Independent economists predict that consumer prices will rise by 800 percent this year. Prices climbed by 300 percent in the first eight months. Consumers need large wads of bills to make even basic grocery purchases.

title: Review/Rock; Prince's New Show Combines Sex and Piety, Mist and Motion
description: Sex and piety, spectacle and showboating, frenzy and repose, glitter and sweat all have a part in Prince's latest arena production, ''Lovesexy Tour '88,'' which had its United States premiere Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Center here in Prince's hometown. His first full-scale American tour since 1984 - a European tour in 1987 was filmed as ''Sign o' the Times'' -charges through a catalogue of songs, styles, attitudes, messages and feats. They don't always add up, but they are dazzling.

title: PHP Healthcare Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Hispanic Gains
description: Not only is the Hispanic population increasing in the United States, but the number of elected Hispanic officials also continues to rise, albeit at a much slower pace. The number of Hispanic people elected to public office increased 1.3 percent from last year to a total of 3,360, the head of the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials reported this week.

title: Schwartz Brothers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a $154,814 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split of class A common stock effective June 23, 1988.

title: Gala Celebreates New Era of Trade With China and Far East
description: To the sound of gongs and the sight of Chinese calligraphy blazing out in neon, Bloomingdale's ushered in ''The Year of the Dragon'' on Wednesday night. The 7-week, 17-store promotion celebrates the 10th anniversary of Bloomingdale's resumption of trade with China and its ongoing trade relations with Hong Kong and Macao.

title: Columbia Turns to Experience in Opener
description: Larry McElreavy, the Columbia coach, who described himself as ''pessimistically optimistic,'' was being careful about the Lions' opening game tomorrow against Harvard in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Jumping-Jacks Shoes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DWG Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $370,000. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,636,000. The company said the latest quarter operating net includes an after-tax gain on the sale of securities of $8.1 million. Year-ago figures have been restated to account for the discontinuation and sale of certain operations and the consolidation of insurance operations.

title: At Hospital Giant, Hint Of a Buyout
description: Senior executives of the Hospital Corporation of America, the nation's largest hospital operator, said yesterday that they might propose a leveraged buyout for $47 a share, or $3.3 billion.

title: Cuomo Selects 8-Member Panel To Help Yonkers With Housing
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday named a special eight-member state panel to help put a court-ordered housing desegregation plan into effect in Yonkers.

title: Topics of The Times; New York's Board of Arrogance
description: What does it take to shame New York City's Board of Elections? The state Board of Elections has faulted its poor management and chronic inefficiencies. Governor Cuomo, Mayor Koch and the Rev. Jesse Jackson wanted it to undertake a national search for a new executive director to replace Betty Dolen, who retires later this year. Yet the city Board of Elections arrogantly refuses to reconsider its abrupt appointment of an insider, Daniel DeFrancisco, to the $72,000-a-year post.

title: Topps Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
A Batus Approval
description: Batus Inc., a unit of Britain's B.A.T. Industries, received approval from the Idaho Insurance Department for its proposed acquisition of Farmers Group Inc. Although Farmers agreed in August to be acquired by Batus for $5.2 billion, the transaction is subject to approval by nine states in which the insurance company operates. Idaho's action means that six states have given some form of approval.

title: Market Place; Milton Petrie's Latest Surprise
description: MILTON PETRIE, the apparel shop entrepreneur, delivered another surprise with his disclosure on Tuesday that he might buy the remaining 39 percent of his company's stock, securities analysts say.

title: Dent and N.F.L. Agree
description: Richard Dent, the Chicago Bears defensive end who has been fighting a 30-day suspension by the National Football League for refusing to submit to a drug test, has reached an agreement with the league, and his suspension has been lifted. Dent will play Sunday against the Minnesota Vikings. He was suspended last week, but was allowed to play in the Bears' 17-13 victory over Indianapolis after Steve Zucker, his attorney, went to court to challenge the suspension. Dent had contended that the N.F.L. had no reasonable cause to ask him for a urine sample. . . . Terry Taylor, the veteran cornerback of the Seattle Seahawks, flew to New York to appeal his 30-day drug suspension. Taylor is disputing the findings of a drug test.(AP)

title: Quayle No Kennedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Renewed its working agreement with the Colorado Springs Sky Sox of the Pacific Coast League for the 1989 season. PHILADELPHIA (NL)- Appointed Lee Thomas vice president and general manager. BASKETBALL NETS (NBA) - Signed Lorenzo Romar, guard, to a multiyear contract. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (AFC) - Signed Paul Oswald, offensive lineman. Placed Elbert Shelly, safety, on injured reserve. DETROIT (NFC) - Signed Curt Singer, offensive tackle. Released Rob Rubick, tight end. GIANTS (NFC) - Claimed Johnie Cooks, linebacker, on waivers from the Indianapolis Colts. Placed Karl Nelson, offensive tackle, on injured reserve. Signed Ron McLean, defensive end. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Signed Ron Pitts, defensive back. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Re-signed Buford Jordan, fullback. HOCKEY RANGERS (NHL) - Released Drago Adam, goaltender; Patrick Dunn, left wing, and Dwight Mullins, right wing. ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Signed Paul Cavallini, Gordie Roberts, Gaston Gingras and Rob Whistle, defensemen, to multiyear contracts.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Keyboard Marathon Sunday at Merkin Hall
description: More than a century of American keyboard music will be compressed into four concerts tomorrow and Sunday at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. This so-called ''Pianorama'' marathon, which opens Merkin's 10th season, will feature 23 pianists performing classical, jazz and popular compositions.

title: Shaky Start for Rocket Business
description: Even before the nation's commercial space-launching industry lofts its first payload into orbit, it faces severe problems from intense foreign competition and weakening demand for its services.

title: Campaign Trail; In Which Hecklers Become the Heckled
description: This has been a good year for campaign hecklers. In a number of instances, most of which have showed up on the evening news to the chagrin of the victims, hecklers have out-thundered candidates, forcing them to cut short their appearances and slink away.

title: Carnegie Altering Acoustics
description: In May 1986, Carnegie Hall closed its doors for a renovation that took 30 weeks and cost $50 million. At the time, musicians and critics admitted to a certain nervousness about whether the hall's acoustics, which were generally agreed to be the most glorious in the city, if not the country, would come through intact.

title: Boat Loans To Back Issue
description: The different types of asset-backed securities brought to market since their inception in 1985 expanded yesterday. Chemical Bank Grantor

title: A Housing Plan Gains Approval In Mt. Vernon
description: Housing for 46 homeless families was approved by the Mount Vernon City Council Wednesday night, encouraging sponsors of a program that has plans to build similar apartments in White Plains and Greenburgh.

title: Dangling From Bridge For a Cause
description: The protest was planned with almost military precision. Just before 6 P.M., 13 experienced mountain climbers, spaced precisely 80 feet apart, vaulted over the side of the Triborough Bridge, plummeted exactly 70 feet to the end of tether lines, and hung above Hell Gate for nearly six hours, nibbling trail mix and waiting for New York City's big sewage sludge barge to try to pass.

title: BIAGGI IS DEFEATED IN CONGRESS RACE BY ASSEMBLYMAN
description: Mario Biaggi's long political success ended yesterday when he was defeated in a Democratic primary for the House of Representatives. The State Senate minority leader, Manfred Ohrenstein of Manhattan, handily won renomination and almost certain re-election for a 15th term, despite being under a state indictment.

title: Suit Accusing Shuberts Of Monopoly Is Voided
description: A suit charging that the Shubert Organization, Broadway's largest theater owner, has had an illegal monopoly on theater-party sales of tickets to the musical ''Phantom of the Opera'' has been dismissed in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Two Share Lead: David Frost and Don Hammond, who together have only one victory in a combined 10 years on the PGA Tour, shot 67's yesterday to share the first-round lead in the $600,000 Bank of Boston Classic in Sutton, Mass. Frost, 14th on this year's money list with $436,140 but seeking his first Tour victory, shot 34,33-67 over the 7,110-yard Pleasant Valley Country Club course. Hammond, who has won only the 1986 Bob Hope Classic in six years on the Tour, shot 35,32-67. Fuzzy Zoeller posted a 68 that included three birdies and four bogeys on the front side before he rallied to birdie three of the last four holes. That tied him with Larry Rinker, Steve Pate and D. A. Weibring.(AP) Sweden Leads Team Play: Fredrik Lindgren shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday and helped Sweden post a 214 for a five-stroke lead over the United States after the opening round in the men's world amateur team championship in Stockholm. Sweden's total is two under par. The three best individual scores each day count toward each team's total. Jay Sigel of Berwyn, Pa., shot a 71 to lead the Americans. Danny Yates of Atlanta had a 72 and Eric Meeks of Walnut, Calif., who beat Yates in the United States amateur final last month, had a 76 for a 219 total. Kevin Johnson of Pembroke, Mass., had a 77.(AP) Ballesteros Ahead in France: Severiano Ballesteros took a commanding four-stroke lead yesterday after the first round of the Lancome Trophy tournament in St. Nom La Breteche, France. The 31-year-old Spaniard, the leading money winner on the European tour, shot a seven-under-par 64 to head the 66-man field. He was trailed by his two playing partners, Craig Parry of Australia and Mark James of Britain. Greg Norman of Australia had an eagle at the first hole and finished with a 71.(AP) Three Women Tied for Lead: Susie Redman, Kathryn Young and Cathy Johnston, all non-winners on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association Tour, shot 69's yesterday to share the first-round lead at the $225,000 Safeco Classic in Kent, Wash. Young, in her 10th year on the Tour, earned her share of the lead with birdies on her last two holes at the 6,222-yard Meridian Valley Country Club. Lynn Adams, Kim Bauer, Jane Crafter, 1986 Safeco winner Judy Dickinson, Anne-Marie Palli, L.P.G.A. Hall of Famer JoAnne Carner and Debbie Massey were all tied at 70. Redman, 22 and in her third year as a pro, lost her Tour card in 1986. She played in Europe last year, then regained her card in the L.P.G.A. qualifying school last fall.(AP) TENNIS Gustafsson Upsets Leconte: Ninth-seeded Magnus Gustafsson of Sweden defeated top-seeded Henri Leconte of France, 6-2, 7-6, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the 36th annual Count of Godo tournament in Barcelona, Spain. Gustafsson will face Thomas Muster of Austria, who advanced by beating Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina, 3-6, 6-4, 6-3. The other semifinal will pit Kent Carlsson of Sweden against Marcelo Filippini of Uruguay. Carlsson beat Jorge Arrese of Spain, 7-5, 6-1, while Filippini eliminated Sergio Casal of Spain, 7-5, 2-6, 6-3.(AP)

title: Norwegian City Wins '94 Games
description: Just seven months after the president of the International Olympic Committee predicted the trend in Olympic Winter Games would be toward staging them in large cities like Calgary, the International Olympic Committee voted tonight to award the 1994 Win=teteGaGames to the smallest ofhehe four cits s that bid for them.

title: Athletes Primed For Big Parade
description: They are coming together, not only in body but also in spirit and emotion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Hospital Corporation of America may receive a buyout offer of $47 a share from its senior executives. The proposal is dependent on the executives' ability to secure financing and would be worth $3.3 billion. The deal, which would be subject to approval by the company's outside directors, reflects the impact of changes in Federal health-care policies on the hospital industry. Hospital Corporation is also considered a possible takeover target. [ Page D1. ] . Zayre will sell its discount department stores to Ames Department Stores, its nearest competitor, for about $800 million. Ames will operate its 348 stores and Zayre's 388 stores using separate names for now. Zayre said it would consider using some proceeds for a buyback or a one-time dividend. [ D1. ] Public Service of New Hampshire's president resigned because of ill health. The management changes comes as the Nuclear Regulatory Commission acts to resolve the last two issues blocking the Seabrook nuclear plant's low-power test license. [ D1. ] The Government expanded its complaint that Goodyear Tire had overcharged on military contracts. The U.S. Attorney in Manhattan filed 35 new charges and said it was seeking at least an additional $91 million. In March, the Government sued Goodyear, seeking $21 million in damages and civil penalties. [ D6. ] Robert Maxwell raised his bid for Macmillan to $86.80 a share in cash, or about $2.4 billion. The offer surpasses the $85-a-share buyout bid from management and Kohlberg, Kravis. [ D17. ] Ashland Oil was indicted for violating environmental laws in the collapse of a storage tank that spilled more than 500,000 gallons of oil into the Monongahela River near Pittsburgh. [ A12. ] About 80 percent of Chevrolet's 5,000 dealers have agreed to market the company's imported cars under the Geo name. [ D5. ] Silicon Graphics is expected to announce a deal with I.B.M. to license its technology for making graphics work stations. [ D4. ] Bernard Arnault said he owned 32 percent of LVMH Louis Vuitton Moet-Hennessy. That will probably enable him to have a veto at next week's shareholder meeting about restructing. [ D4. ] Toyota Motor Credit has become the first non-government Japanese company to sell debt in the U.S. since 1978. [ D15. ] THE ECONOMY Retail sales dropped 0.2 percent in August, the Commerce Department reported. Many economists said the small decline should not arouse any concerns about the economy. [ D1. ] The nation's industrial operating rate rose for the fifth consecutive month in August. But economists said the increase reflected the summer surge at utilities and was not inflationary. [ D4. ] The G.A.O. raised its estimate for cleaning up the savings industry by 25 percent, to at least $45 billion. The agency said the cost of closing insolvent savings associations in the Southwest was greater than anticipated, in part because little outside capital had been attracted. [ D3. ] MARKETS Stock prices fell moderately as the Dow Jones industrial average dropped back below the 2,100 level. The Dow dropped 8.36 points, to 2,092.28, as declines on the Big Board outnumbered advances, 766 to 665. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasuries slipped in thin trading as market participants elected to take profits rather than buy more securities after the release of weaker-than-expected economic data. [ D15. ] The dollar turned mixed against most currencies as dealers continued to assess the U.S. trade situation. Gold fell $2.70 an ounce on the Comex, to $418.60. [ D12. ] Crude oil prices fell 50 cents a barrel after climbing 84 cents on Wednesday as traders took profits or hedged. [ D12. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The Federal budget deficit remains the great submerged issue in the Presidential campaign. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Milton Petrie created a stir with the news that he might buy the remaining 39 percent of Petrie Stores. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Iraq Bars Cut In Oil Output
description: Iraq will not agree to lower its oil output, the country's oil minister said in an interview published today. The minister, Issam Abdul-

title: Group Claims LVMH Edge
description: In the latest development in a feud over control of LVMH Louis Vuitton Moet-Hennessy, Financiere Agache, the retailing and fashion group controlled by Bernard Arnault, announced today that it owned about 32 percent of the shares of the luxury goods conglomerate.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; New Voice on Chekhov
description: By day, Frank Dunai is a radio commentator on labor and economic issues for the Hungarian service of the Voice of America. After hours the 56-year-old is, in his own words, ''an ordinary American playwright with a few peculiarities.''

title: Campaign Trail; Political Home Fires Stoked for Dukakis
description: And speaking of debates . . .

title: Campaign Trail; Waiting in Wings For Role in Debates
description: Who is Bob Barnett and why is he behaving oddly?

title: Fight With Zenith Puts Brookhurst in Limelight
description: Brookhurst Partners, which is seeking shareholder support to oust some of the directors of the Zenith Electronics Corporation and to sell the company, is led by Herbert B. Abelow and Nicholas L. Ihasz, two Wall Street figures who have come into the limelight for the first time with their public fight with Zenith management.

title: Prism Entertainment Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $24,000 and $96,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $94,000 and $106,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Bush Attacks Dukakis's Fiscal Record
description: Vice President Bush battered his opponent with statistics today, trying to show that Massachusetts was far from being ''a miracle'' state but instead ''is approaching a fiscal fiasco that might best be described as a budgetary Three-Mile Island.''

title: Henry C. Wallich, 74, Dies; Served on Federal Reserve
description: Henry C. Wallich, a longtime member of the Federal Reserve Board and its leading authority on international finance, died today at George Washington University Hospital. He was 74 years old and had been in failing health since undergoing surgery for a brain tumor in 1985.

title: C.F.T.C. Deal With British
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today that it had reached agreement to share information with the British Government in an effort to better coordinate the regulation of the futures industry.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Agence Havas, France's largest media group, announced a restructuring this week, including the breakup of a friendly group of institutional shareholders.

title: Carrying the Torch
description: OUTSIDE the huge apartment complex, women are selling fruit and washing down the sidewalks. From an unseen apartment, a Buddhist man is chanting his midday ritual. It appears to be a blessedly mundane day in this giant city that has sprung from rubble.

title: Review/Art; Met Retrospective Explores Boccioni And Futurism
description: IT has been a long time since the Metropolitan Museum presented an exhibition of 20th-century art for which the public can be grateful. Two recent exhibitions are typical. The David Hockney retrospective was a crowd pleaser devoted to an artist whose fluid narratives have more to do with seduction than substance. The recent mini-Klee retrospective was nothing more than a display of the 90 Klees given to the museum by Heinz Berggruen in 1984, and its timing - a year after Paul Klee had been honored in a major retrospective by the Museum of Modern Art - was not ideal.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions in some copies on Monday reversed the identities of two girls injured when they were hit by a police car. The girl at the left, in a white blouse, was Ana Gonzalez; the other was Tabitha Olivera.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Kansas Case Set for Review
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association Infractions Committee will review the case against the Kansas basketball program on Sept. 30, sources said today. Kansas won the national championship in basketball last spring.

title: Ill Health Forces President To Quit at Seabrook Utility
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire, which entered bankruptcy in January because of its inability to get an operating license for the Seabrook nuclear plant, said yesterday that its president had stepped down because of ill health.

title: Coleco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 11
description: b-Net income The latest periods' results included a charge of about $105 million related to restructuring costs and expenses associated with downsizing the business.

title: Dow, With an 8.36 Drop, Falls Below 2,100
description: Stock prices fell moderately in a broad decline yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average back below the 2,100 level.

title: 20% Stake for Sale In Pacific Scientific
description: The New York investment adviser Shufro, Rose & Ehrman disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was seeking to sell its 20.86 percent stake in the Pacific Scientific Company, preferably in a single transaction. A spokesman for Pacific Scientific said the company would have no comment.

title: Why Israelis and Arabs Are Pulling for Bush
description: LEAD: In what seems to be a curious difference of opinion, American Jews favor Gov. Michael S. Dukakis for President while Israeli Jews would prefer Vice President Bush.

title: Appeal Filed in Detroit Deal
description: Opponents of the proposed partial merger of two Detroit newspapers asked an appeals court today to delay the business arrangement until the courts can hold a full hearing on the issue.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chairman Appointed For First Nationwide
description: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company yesterday named Robert E. Lackovic chairman and chief executive of the First Nationwide Financial Corporation. He has had responsibility for the company's operations since February when the top position became vacant.

title: Review/Art; A Penchant for the Past
description: Anyone who spends much time going to galleries finds that exhibitions often group themselves into loosely related clusters. It can't be helped. The show of one artist will make you think of the show of another artist; soon you are putting together one and one, and then two and two -and then taking them apart again to see if they really fit.

title: P.S.C. Endorses Accord to Shut Down Shoreham
description: The State Public Service Commission today grudgingly endorsed Governor Cuomo's plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island.

title: The Law; When Private Life Interferes With Public Duties
description: One hour before the presses of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer started rolling last month with a report about allegations of sexual misconduct by Judge Gary M. Little, the judge put a .38-caliber pistol to his right temple and shot himself dead.

title: The Law; Public Defender Cuts Cases Back
description: The Public Defender's office here has announced that starting Monday it will stop representing poor people accused of misdemeanors and will cut its felony caseload by 20 percent unless its budget is increased to cover an explosion of drug cases.

title: Auctions
description: Plaster Masters

title: Huffman Koos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Recipients Are Named For Playwriting Prizes
description: Diane Ney, author of ''The Jeremiah,'' has been named winner of the $10,000 first prize of the annual Joseph Kesselring Awards for Playwrights. Ms. Ney's play was presented at the Milwaukee Repertory Theater.

title: Cadiz, Not Dundee, To Get Ford Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would build a $68 million electronics plant near Cadiz, Spain, instead of Dundee, Scotland, where labor uproar killed the project. The Spanish Government will subsidize roughly one-third of the cost of the plant, which will employ about 350 people. Construction will begin soon, and production will begin in 1990.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the Kroger Company misstated the timing of the disclosure that the Haft family had been granted permission by the Federal Trade Commission to accumulate Kroger stock. The disclosure was made on Monday before stock market trading ended.

title: Soviet Region Hit by New Ethnic Unrest and Strike
description: After two months of precarious peace, the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh has been hit by a new outbreak of unrest, including a general strike that has closed all industry in the capital city of Stepanakert, residents of the city said today.

title: Hunt Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
'Baby Bell' Curbs Assailed
description: Congress should lift restrictions preventing the seven regional Bell telephone companies from making telecommunications equipment and providing information services, the chairman of Ameritech said today.

title: Hungary Chief Pledges Help on Soviet Jews
description: Ending the first visit by an Israeli Prime Minister to one of the Communist countries that broke relations with Israel in 1967, Yitzhak Shamir said here today that he had obtained the Hungarian leader's promise to ask for better treatment for Soviet Jews.

title: Ames to Buy Discount Unit From Zayre
description: The Zayre Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its Zayre discount department stores to its nearest competitor, Ames Department Stores Inc.

title: Investigators Rule Out Engine Failure in Airliner Crash Fatal to 14
description: Federal investigators today ruled out engine failure as the primary cause of the crash of a Delta Air Lines jetliner last month, saying there was no evidence of a mechanical breakdown before the crash.

title: Crude Oil Prices in Retreat As Traders Watch Storm
description: Crude oil prices, which soared 84 cents a barrel on Wednesday in very heavy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, fell 50 cents yesterday. West Texas Intermediate, the American benchmark crude oil, was trading at $14.90 a barrel for delivery next month.

title: Celebrating the Day the Martians Landed
description: We interrupt our regularly scheduled programming for this special bulletin: Not since the Sunday night in 1938 when Orson Welles told millions of radio listeners that the Martians had landed at this pastoral crossroads has there been so much excitement here.

title: Worthington Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Federal-Mogul
description: Federal-Mogul, a maker of auto parts and machine tools, said it had sold its operations in South Africa, which accounted for about $25 million in sales. Federal-Mogul said that National Bolts Ltd., a subsidiary of the FSI Corporation, had purchased its Femo and Huck South Africa operations. ''It was with considerable reluctance that we decided to withdraw from South Africa rather than risk the loss of our financial investment there,'' said Thomas F. Russell, Federal-Mogul's chairman.

title: Peter D. Kiernan, 65, Head of Fleet/Norstar
description: Peter D. Kiernan, chairman of Fleet/ Norstar Financial Group, a national financial services company, died Wednesday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston from complications following heart surgery. He was 65 years old and lived in Newtonville, N.Y.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Fit for Old Glory
description: Patriotism is in vogue these days, even in Washington's think tanks. A new, outsized American flag is flying from a newly constructed flagpole in front of the Brookings Institution. The flag, which had flown atop the United States Capitol, was a gift from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a New York Democrat, to Stephen Hess, a senior fellow at Brookings who is an old friend of the Senator's.

title: L.I. Speeder Convicted in Newlyweds' Deaths
description: A driver whose speeding car crashed into a wedding party's limousine, killing the bride, groom and best man, was found guilty today of three counts of criminally negligent homicide.

title: Irving Bank Gets Personal In New Way
description: IN the crowded byways of New York one of the more pleasant pastimes is listening in on strangers' conversations.

title: The Day When 5th Ave. Becomes Literary Lane
description: Few books are so successful that they have 10 printings, but New York Is Book Country - the once-a-year, outdoor anthology of fact, fiction and fun attended by a quarter-million strolling book lovers - goes into its 10th edition this weekend.

title: Leon Journal; A Tale of Lust and Death, Undimmed by 50 Years
description: The most sensational criminal case in Nicaraguan history, a tale of high society adultery and murder, has again become a topic of intense controversy more than half a century after it was seemingly resolved.

title: Marilyn Ruben, Interior Designer, 61
description: Marilyn Ruben, an interior designer, died of cancer Tuesday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 61 years old and lived in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Bayly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,414,000.

title: Increase in Drugs Impinges On City Services, Koch Says
description: Despite its escalating war on drugs, New York City has failed to slow the growth of narcotics, and particularly crack, as a major source of crime, Mayor Koch said yesterday as he released his annual management report on the quality of city services.

title: Dukakis Is Briefed About Fire Damage
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts began a campaign swing through the West today with a careful mix of politics and photo opportunities.

title: Maxwell Lifts Macmillan Takeover Bid to $86.80 a Share
description: In a surprise move, Robert Maxwell, the British entrepreneur, raised his takeover bid for Macmillan Inc. yesterday to $86.80 a share in cash, or about $2.4 billion.

title: To Our Readers
description: Starting on Monday, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on weekdays within 75 miles of New York City, and on all of Long Island, will be increased to 35 cents. The change is prompted by rising production costs, including an increase in the price of paper. The newspaper's Sunday price will not change, nor will its weekday price outside the 75-mile area.

title: Chevy Puts Imports Under Geo Name
description: About 80 percent of Chevrolet's 5,000 dealers have agreed to market the company's imported cars under the Geo brand name this fall.

title: American Brands
description: American Brands Inc. said that Brooke Partners L.P., which is controlled by Bennett S. Lebow, had filed for Federal antitrust clearance to purchase up to 50 percent of American Brands' voting stock. The size of Mr. Lebow's holding in American Brands has not been disclosed. He is required to notify the Securities and Exchange Commission if his stake reaches 5 percent. Mr. Lebow, who controls Liggett Group Inc., a maker of generic cigarettes, approached American Brands in July and suggested buying its tobacco operations, which include Lucky Strike, Pall Mall and Carlton. He was turned down.

title: Emanuels Move From Evening to Day
description: With the official start of fall just a few days away, the fashion-social-charity season is building up steam. Five hundred women dressed in their new fall clothes lunched at the Plaza yesterday. Their $150 tickets bought them a look at the first ready-to-wear collection introduced in the United States by David and Elizabeth Emanuel, the young British couple who designed the Princess of Wales's wedding dress in 1981.

title: Review/Art; Malcolm McLaren Show
description: Whether he has been called pop-music Svengali, Britain's Andy Warhol, fashion designer, punk promoter, Conceptual artist or cold-blooded opportunist, Malcolm McLaren has borne the designation with glib pride. Throughout a career encompassing ownership of a London clothing store specializing in fetishistic outfits and management of, among other bands, the Sex Pistols, Mr. McLaren rarely fails to offend a share of his public.

title: Presley Stamp Salutes His Art, Not His Life; Doubt on Eligibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Can the Candidates Make Chili?
description: LEAD: Faced with two less than charismatic Presidential candidates, we need something to keep this campaign from boring us silly. A competency test might do it. Let Bush and Dukakis demonstrate their skills. Let then show competency and experience instead of just talking about it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It sounds facetious, but people can stay as long as we fingerprint them so we can identify them later.'' - Mayor Bob Pinkerton Jr. of South Padre Island, Tex., on the need to flee Hurricane Gilbert. [ A10:5. ]

title: Diner's Journal
description: Mirabeau

title: Protein Design Names Official
description: Protein Design Labs Inc., a closely held biotechnology company based in Palo Alto, Calif., said today that Shirley Lui Clayton would join the company on Oct. 17 as chief financial officer. Ms. Clayton, who is 50 years old , has been vice president and treasurer for Genentech Inc., which she joined in 1981.

title: Dance Awards Presented, One to Their Namesake
description: Dance Theater Workshop presented its fifth annual New York Dance and Performance Awards -known as the Bessies - last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, honoring achievements in choreography, performance, design and music for the 1987-88 season.

title: Don't Confuse Sinn Fein With the I.R.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: On Stage
description: Kanin's New Play(s)

title: Iraq's Right to Chemical Arms Upheld by Official
description: Iraq's Defense Minister suggested strongly today that his country reserved the right to use chemical weapons if it felt that circumstances warranted it.

title: Rates Mark Time in Quiet Trading
description: Interest rates were little changed in very quiet trading yesterday.

title: House Backs State Grants To Curb Drunken Driving
description: The House of Representatives passed three amendments to a major drug bill today, including one that budgets $125 million for grants to states that suspend the drivers' licenses of people arrested on charges of drunken driving after a breath or blood test. The money would be used for programs to curb drunken driving.

title: F.A.A. Tells Airlines to Check Boeing Jets' Takeoff Alarms
description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered airlines today to check takeoff warning alarms on all Boeing 727 jetliners because of questions raised in the investigation of a Delta Air Lines crash last month in Texas.

title: Gorbachev Offers Disputed Radar For Peaceful Exploration of Space
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, offered today to place a disputed radar installation in Siberia under international control for use in the peaceful exploration of space.

title: For U.S. Zoos, No More Pandas From China
description: China has announced that it will no longer lend giant pandas to zoos in the United States.

title: Sir Donald Albery Is Dead at 74; Influential British Stage Director
description: Sir Donald Albery, a London theater manager who encouraged the playwrights Samuel Beckett, John Osborne and Brendan Behan, died Wednesday at his home in Monte Carlo, his family reported. He was 74 years old.

title: College Football; Pitt to Take On Ohio State
description: West Virginia and Pittsburgh have been accorded some recognition as strong football teams this season. Each is ranked among the nation's top 20 in one or both news-agency polls. And maybe they will be that strong when the season ends.

title: Bridge; One of the hallmarks of the best players is their resilience and ability to persevere.
description: Resilience that enables them to brush aside the blows of fate and get on with the next deal is a mark of the world's great players. Consider, for example, the diagram deal from the open Expo pair championship, which ended in Brisbane Sept. 5. Sitting East and West were Jim and Norma Borin of Melbourne who have long been one of the world's best mixed partnerships. They are the only married couple ever to represent a country in the Bermuda Bowl world team championship.

title: Reds' Browning Becomes 14th Pitcher to Be Perfect
description: Tom Browning of the Cincinnati Reds tonight pitched the 14th perfect game in major league history as he defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 1-0.

title: Fiscal Woes Jeopardize New York Bond Rating
description: New York State's bond rating might be lowered unless it reduces a budget gap estimated at $1.2 billion, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Delays Detroit Newspaper Merger
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has ordered The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press to delay their partial merger, which could have begun as early as this weekend, as the judges consider whether the deal should be scrapped altogether.

title: Reagan Right Has Been Heard on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Squeeze on the Middle Class, A Suburb's Young Voters Like Bush
description: Dawn Bethmann sees the cost of day care for her two children as the obstacle to getting back to college for her nursing degree. Lisa Stinson, a neighbor, worries about affording the down payment on a house and about how her husband's job does not provide health insurance.

title: MEN IN THE NEWS: Eliot L. Engel; An Artful Insurgent
description: If part of the art of politics consists of donning the cloak of insurgency while building bridges to the establishment, Eliot L. Engel is something of a master.

title: Tent With View (A Dim One) Of Manhattan
description: Day in and day out, it is the same trying routine for Ali A. Treiki, chief representative to the United Nations from Libya - forever complaining, explaining and dogmatically disdaining everything from the latest accusation of terrorism to American attacks, verbal and otherwise. Moreover, it is 5,000 miles from his dusty home.

title: Leader of U.S. Team Grapples With New-Found Stardom
description: The money she earns would be considered loose change by most of her male counterparts in professional basketball. Although there is fame and adulation in the foreign ports where she plays, Teresa Edwards is virtually unknown in the United States, where she grew up thinking she could be just like Dr. J, only to discover that the women's game was a dead-end street.

title: Man Pleads Guilty on Cable TV Piracy Ring
description: A man whom Federal officials say ran the biggest cable television piracy ring in the nation and defrauded cable companies of almost $5 million in potential fees pleaded guilty today to mail fraud and income tax evasion.

title: Tibetans Don't Oppose Technological Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Hurricane Claims 17 in the Yucatan Peninsula
description: The hurricane that jolted the Mexican coast today for the second time in three days has left a trail of devastation in the Yucatan Peninsula, including the deaths of at least 17 people, the official Government news agency reported.

title: Correction
description: An article in some copies on Thursday about campaign appearances by Vice President Bush, in which he suggested that his campaign was ''on the American side,'' rendered a word incorrectly in his comment about economic recovery. He said: ''We go about it with the three lows - low taxes, low regulation and low spending. And these are the lows that make the highs: high employment, high growth, high expectations.'' He did not say ''unemployment.''

title: Primary Election Results
description: Following are the unofficial results in the contested races in Thursday's primary elections for Congress, the State Legislature and district attorney in the New York metropolitan region. Incumbents are marked with asterisks. DEMOCRATS: U.S. Representative BROOKLYN 11th DISTRICT Edolphus Towns* . . . 13,998 Riaz B. Hussain . . . 4,468 MANHATTAN 15TH DISTRICT Peter G.
