title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/2-4, 28

title: Environment Seen as Key Issue in Swedish Vote
description: On the face of things, the Social Democrats who have run Sweden for all but six of the last 56 years should have little to worry about in Sunday's national elections: Unemployment among the country's 8.4 million people is less than 2 percent, industrial output has risen by 20 percent since they came back into power after a six-year hiatus in 1982, and the standard of living is about the highest in Europe.

title: British Inflation Rises Sharply
description: Britain today announced its highest annual inflation rate in almost three years.

title: The Artificial Heart: Bleeding Us Dry
description: LEAD: The National Institutes of Health decided in July, under pressure from Senators Edward M. Kennedy and Orrin G. Hatch, to again go forward with research on the artificial heart. That is regrettable, for the artificial heart is a device our society does not need - and one that we will not be able sensibly to pay for.

title: Students and Teachers Mourn Pratt Student Slain by Mugger
description: Judith Anne Wrappe, an art student who was slain earlier this week in a robbery, was a stranger to most of those who attended a memorial service for her yesterday at the Pratt Institute where she was enrolled.

title: Dukakis Is Accused of Naming Anti-Israel Members to Party Posts
description: A group of House Republicans charged today that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic Presidential nominee, had appointed three ''anti-Israeli, pro-Palestinian'' members to the party's ruling body and challenged him to dismiss them.

title: Pope Asks Mozambique To Work With Church
description: In an appeal to a one-time foe, Pope John Paul II today urged the Marxist Government here to join forces with the Roman Catholic Church so Mozambique could be saved from the ravages of war and poverty.

title: Duane Jones Memorial
description: A memorial service for the actor and director Duane Jones, who was artistic director of the Richard Allen Center for Culture and Art in Manhattan, will be held on Monday at 7 P.M. at the Church of the Intercession, 550 West 155th Street. Mr. Jones died on July 22 at age 51.

title: All Rookies Face Drug Tests in Camp
description: The National Basketball Association and its players union have agreed to test all rookies for drug use during training camps, which begin on Oct. 7. Under the new agreement, a rookie who tests positive for heroin or cocaine use would be suspended for a year without pay.

title: July Inventory Rise of 0.3% Slowest Rate in 11 Months
description: Business inventories in July rose at the slowest rate in 11 months, suggesting to analysts that underlying economic growth remains strong despite a pause in business sales.

title: The Force of Hurricanes
description: Hurricane Gilbert was at Category 5 when it hit Jamaica and the Yucatan Peninsula but diminished to Category 3 as it approached Texas. Barometric pressure is measured as the height in inches to which the atmosphere will force a column of mercury in an evacuated tube. Category Barometric Wind in Potential damage pressure m.p.h. 1 Over 28.94 inches 74-95 Damage mainly to trees, shrubbery, unanchored mobile homes 2 28.50-28.91 96-110 Some trees blown down; major damage to exposed mobile homes; some damage to roofs 3 27.91-28.47 111-130 Trees stripped of foliage; large trees blown down; mo bile homes destroyed; some structural damage to small buildings. 4 27.17-27.88 131-155 All signs blown down; extensive damage to windows, doors and roofs; flooding inland as far as six miles; major damage to lower floors of structures near shore. 5 Less than 27.17 Greater than 155 Severe damage to windows, doors and roofs; small buildings overturned and blown away; major damage to structures less than 15 feet above sea level within 500 yards of shore. (Source: Pennsylvania State University)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Anthony A. Goodchild, Executive, 60
description: Anthony A. Goodchild, retired chairman of Armatron International Inc., died in an automobile accident near Allentown, Pa., Thursday. He was 60 years old and lived in retirement in Alexandria, N.H.

title: Athletes Are Ready to Start Competing
description: An hour or so after the opening ceremonies end, after the athletes have marched off and the stadium has been cleared, the competition will begin in the Games of the XXIV Olympiad.

title: Hurdles Cleared, the Games Begin
description: After 16 years of political interference, the Olympic Summer Games came together today in glorious splendor with a festive opening ceremony celebrating the theme ''Beyond All Barriers.''

title: Dow Up 5.87 in Busy Session As 'Witching Hour' Passes
description: LEAD: In one of the busiest sessions in weeks, the stock market was pushed higher in heavy futures-related trading yesterday, but the rally was tempered by last-minute profit taking.

title: Sept. 29 Launching Scheduled For Redesigned Space Shuttle
description: The space shuttle Discovery is scheduled for launching at midmorning Sept. 29, the space agency announced today.

title: Immediate Remedies for New York City's Traffic Ills Abound; Noxious Bus Fumes
description: To the Editor:

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 32.

title: Navy to End Convoys in Gulf But It Will Still Protect Ships
description: In a response to the reduction of tensions brought about by the Iran-Iraq cease-fire, the United States Navy plans to relax the protection it provides to merchant ships in the Persian Gulf, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: MEN IN THE NEWS: Robert Thomas Johnson; 'Devastating Adversary'
description: Robert T. Johnson admitted yesterday that, for political purposes, he deliberately failed to tell voters one key fact about himself during the campaign for the Democratic nomination as District Attorney of the Bronx: if a Subway Series ever comes to pass, he'll take the Mets.

title: Books of The Times; Revisionist Perspectives on a Poet
description: Wallace Stevens The Later Years, 1923-1955 By Joan Richardson Illustrated. 462 pages. Beech Tree Books, William Morrow. $27.95.

title: Bush Talks of Lasers and Bombers
description: In the combat of this Presidential campaign, Vice President Bush has a growing fondness for expressing himself in military terms.

title: Correction
description: A brief article yesterday about the winners of the Joseph Kesselring Awards for Playwrights gave an incorrect title for a work by Frank Hogan, who received an honorable mention. It is ''Koozy's Piece.''

title: Suspect in Chase by Cuomo Is Held in Two Repeat Cases
description: A suspected subway-token thief who was arrested last week in Harlem after Governor Cuomo happened by and left his limousine to join in the chase was apparently not impressed.

title: A Test to Identify Problem Drinkers
description: Boris Tabakoff, scientific director at the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism in Bethesda, Md., received a patent this week for a test that identifies people predisposed to alcohol abuse.

title: KEY RATES
Walter Prude Memorial
description: Isaac Stern, Emanuel Ax and Zoe Caldwell will take part in a memorial tribute to Walter Foy Prude on Monday at 12:30 P.M. in the Kaufmann Concert Hall of the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue. Mr. Prude, who was active in concert management for more than 40 years, died on Aug. 29 at the age of 78.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULE
description: All times Eastern daylight. Basketball Men - China vs. Egypt, 5:30 A.M.; Canada vs. Brazil, 7:30 A.M.; United States vs. Spain, 9:45 P.M.; Australia vs. Puerto Rico, 7:45 P.M. Boxing Preliminaries, 5 A.M. and 8 P.M. Cycling Men - 100-kilometer team time trial, 7 P.M. Diving Women - platform, preliminaries, 1 A.M. and 5 A.M.; final, 9 P.M. Field Hockey Men - Soviet Union vs. India, 7 P.M.; Pakistan vs. Poland or Spain, 8:45 P.M.; West Germany vs. Canada, 11:30 P.M.; the Netherlands vs. Argentina, 11:30 P.M. Gymnastics Men - team compulsories, 9 P.M. Modern Pentathlon Riding, 7 P.M. Shooting Women - air rifle, 40 shots, 6 P.M., 10 shots, final, 8:30 P.M. Men -free pistol, 60 shots, 7 P.M., 10 shots, final, 11 P.M. Open - clay target-trap, first round, 75 targets, 7 P.M. Soccer China vs. West Germany, 3 A.M.; Italy vs. Mexico, 3 A.M.; Sweden vs. Tunisia, 5 A.M.; Zambia vs. Iraq, 5 A.M. Swimming Qualifying, 7 P.M. Women - 100 freestyle, 400 individual medley. Men -100 breast stroke, 200 freestyle. Taekwondo Men and women -flyweight and welterweight, preliminaries, 11 A.M., semifinals, 5 A.M., final, 7:20 A.M.; bantamweight and middleweight, preliminaries, 8 P.M. and 11 P.M. Volleyball Men - the Netherlands vs. France, 2:30 A.M.; South Korea vs. Sweden, 6:30 P.M.; Japan vs. United States, 7:45 P.M.; Italy or China vs. Brazil, 10 P.M. Wrestling Greco-Roman, 48-, 62-and 90-kilogram preliminaries, 8 P.M. Television Coverage Today's highlights on NBC. 4-7 P.M. Taped highlights of early-morning events. 7:30 P.M.-Midnight Diving, women's platform final; gymnastics, men's team; basketball, United States vs. Spain; volleyball, women, United States vs. China; swimming and boxing preliminaries. 12:30-2:30 A.M. Gymnastics, men's team.

title: 'The Whole World Is Here'
description: THE world waited long enough, and finally there is a full-scale Summer Games again. They began here Saturday morning with a glorious ceremony of color and motion, ritual and legend, and most of the 160 nations marching in line, except, of course, for your basic American athletes swarming and waving ''Hi Mom'' and ''NBC'' banners.

title: Review/Art; In Speed, Experiment and Crisis, Giacometti's Career Stands Apart
description: The retrospective of the work of the Swiss artist Alberto Giacometti, which opened Thursday at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, is the first to be held in this country in nearly 15 years. The exhibition surveys Giacometti's 40-year career with 51 sculptures, 30 paintings and 24 drawings.

title: HURRICANE ROARS INTO MEXICO AGAIN WITH LESS FORCE
description: Hurricane Gilbert finished its 2,400-mile odyssey from the Caribbean across the Gulf of Mexico by slamming into the Mexican coast about 120 miles south of here. It vented most of its fury in lightly populated areas.

title: Ex-Inspector Sentenced To Jail in Payoff Case
description: A retired New York City health inspector who pleaded guilty to extorting a $500 payoff from a restaurant was sentenced by a Federal judge yesterday to three months in jail and a $1,000 fine.

title: Time's Stock Up on Talk of Realignment
description: Shares of Time Inc. rose $9.375 yesterday amid speculation that it had retained the investment banking firm of Wasserstein, Perella & Company to advise it on a restructuring.

title: Review/Circus; Fresh From Moscow, Daredevil Acts
description: The Moscow Circus, visiting the United States for the first time in 10 years, offers a bravura display of skills, leading to a kind of natural hyperbole in performance. The high wires seem higher, the tiger tamers more death defying, the trapeze artists more daring. The show began its New York engagement Thursday at the Radio City Music Hall.

title: Allies to Ease Curbs On Phone Exporting
description: The agency that controls allied exports to Communist countries has decided to ease restrictions on telecommunications equipment, Commerce Department officials said today.

title: Reviews/Television; Tribute to Woody Guthrie and Leadbelly
description: Frst came ''A Vision Shared: A Tribute to Woody Guthrie and Leadbelly,'' an all-star benefit album from which the performers' royalties will buy Folkways Records for the Smithsonian Institution and maintain the Woody Guthrie Archives. No rock benefit is complete without a video tie-in, and a program that shares the title, but not the same music, will be shown at 10 o'clock tonight on Showtime, with repeats to follow.

title: Zenith to Meet With Dissident
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation today asked for a meeting with its dissident stockholder,Brookhurst Partners, which said Wednesday that it would push for the prompt sale of the company.

title: Oilers' Offense Puts Jets on Defensive
description: Marty Lyons admits it: the fans want to know which Jets team will show up Sunday in its home opener against the Houston Oilers.

title: Wall Disputes G.A.O. on Aid
description: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, M. Danny Wall, today disputed a General Accounting Office report that it would cost $45 billion to $50 billion to resolve the problems of the nation's ailing savngs and loan industry.

title: Going, Going, Not Quite Gone
description: Three times this season Lee Smith had squandered saves by giving up three-run home runs, and in the eighth inning tonight Mike Pagliarulo and just about everbody else on the field and in the stands at Fenway Park thought they were watching No. 4.

title: U.S. Panel Backs Research Use Of Fetal Tissue From Abortions
description: An advisory committee of the National Institutes of Health concluded today that it is morally acceptable to use human fetal tissue obtained from legal abortions for research and therapy.

title: Parade Today
description: The annual Steuben Day parade will begin at noon at Fifth Avenue and 61st Street, moving north to 86th Street, then east to Second Avenue, where it will disband.

title: Iraq Rejects Attempt by the U.N. To See if Gas Was Used on Kurds
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 16 -

title: U.S. Film Industry Assails Seoul's Curbs
description: The American film industry today filed a major trade complaint against South Korea, charging that it is maintaining unfair barriers against American motion picture exports and tolerating piracy of American films in its home video market.

title:
CONSUMER'S WORLD;
COPING: With Buying Firewood
description: LEAD: Now is the time for people with fireplaces to try to remember how many logs make up that obscure measure known as a cord, and all the other facts about firewood that tend to slip away during warm weather.

title: Cold Front in the West Awaited by Firefighters
description: Firefighters battling wildfires contended with higher winds today while awaiting an approaching Canadian cold front that was expected to bring showers and cooler temperatures to burning woodlands this weekend.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 34..

title: Ford Sees Delay On Europe Venture
description: The head of the Ford Motor Company's international operations said that he does not expect Ford and the Nissan Motor Company of Japan to reach agreement on an European joint venture this year. Ford and Nissan, in announcing an agreement to build a mini-van in the United States earlier this week, disclosed they had begun a feasibility study on jointly producing a sport utility vehicle in Europe that would be sold there.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is better than I had expected, but it is difficult to say anything while the cake is still being baked.'' - Andrzej Stelmachowski, adviser to Lech Walesa, on talks with the Government. [ 4:6. ]

title: Doctor Recalls Deaver As 'Alert' in Hospital
description: A doctor who treated Michael K. Deaver for alcoholism in 1985 said that the former aide to President Reagan ''remained quite alert'' in the hospital despite heavy sedation.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Britain-Ireland Grabs Lead: Britain-Ireland, six strokes behind Sweden overnight, moved into a three-shot lead over the United States yesterday at the midway point of the men's world amateur team championship in Stockholm. Peter McEvoy shot one-under-par 71 to lead his team. He had a 72 Thursday and held second in the individual standing. Others contributing for Britain-Ireland were Garth McGimpsey with a 72 and Eoghan O'Connell with a 75 for a 36-hole team total of 438, which is 6 over par. The United States retained second place with 441. Sweden, the European champion, dropped to third at 443.(AP) Two Share Second-Round Lead: Steve Pate and D. A. Weibring shot their second successive 68's yesterday to share the second-round lead at the $600,000 Bank of Boston Classic in Sutton, Mass. Pate and Weibring were at 6-under-par 136 after 36 holes, David Frost, who shot a 70 after an opening-round 67, slipped into a third-place tie at 137 with Fuzzy Zoeller, who had a 69.(AP) Palmer Leads by Two Strokes: Arnold Palmer fired a 7-under-par 65 to take a two-stroke lead after the opening round of the Crestar PGA Seniors Golf Classic. Palmer, 59 years old, had nine birdies yesterday on the 6,644-yard Hermitage Country Club course in Richmond. Tied at 67 were Don Massengale, Gene Littler and Bobby Nichols.(AP) Tennis Carlsson and Muster in Final: Kent Carlsson of Sweden and Thomas Muster of Austria moved into the final of the Count of Godo tournament with semifinal victories yesterday. Carlsson, seeded second, defeated Marcelo Filippini of Uruguay, 6-2, 6-2. Muster, seeded fifth, beat the ninth-seeded Magnus Gustafsson of Sweden, 6-1, 3-6, 6-3.(AP) 184th Title for Cheney: Dorothy (Dodo) Cheney of Santa Monica, Calif., 72 years old, who has won more United States Tennis Association championships than anyone, won the 184th title of her career by defeating Jean Corvino of Boca Raton, Fla., 6-3, 6-1, in the final of the 70-and-over division of the senior women's grass court championship at the Rockaway Hunt Club in Cedarhurst, L.I. High School Football Adams 20, Kennedy 14: John Adams of Queens, the defending Public Schools Athletic League champion, scored a 20-14 victory over John F. Kennedy of the Bronx on the losers' field yesterday. Arthur Dennis scored the three Adams touchdowns, all on 1-yard runs.

title: Petrie's Modernization
description: To the Editor:

title: Horse Racing; Old Rivalries Renewed in the Woodward
description: The $831,000 Woodward Handicap at Belmont Park today features the continuation of at least five old rivalries, but the most intriguing clash is a new one: the annual first meeting between the nation's best 3-year-olds and the top older horses.

title: The Times Appoints 3 Editors
description: Three appointments to senior editing positions at The New York Times were announced yesterday by Max Frankel, executive editor of the newspaper.

title: The F.B.I. Confesses
description: F.B.I. Director William Sessions was following a young but healthy tradition with his remarkable admission of mistakes in probing opponents of Washington's Central America policy. Such a confession was unimaginable in J. Edgar Hoover's time, but successor directors have shown a willingness to acknowledge failure, or at least the failure of predecessors. The confession also ought to remind Congress to take its F.B.I.-monitoring function more seriously.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sept. 9 about a strike by clerical employees of New York University described the strikers' salary figures incompletely. The figure given by the union is $17,400, but the university says the average salary is $19,763.

title: Student Athletes Are Students as Much as Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: Kicker's Big Impression
description: Luis Zendejas, a former Arizona State all-America place-kicker, was cut last Tuesday by Dallas one day after his 49-yard field goal attempt was blocked in the Cowboys' 17-14 victory over the Phoenix Cardinals. But he did kick a 47-yarder and that apparently impressed his opponents enough that Zendejas will be given a free-agent tryout in Phoenix next Tuesday by the Cardinals.

title: So Parents Can't Cheat Their Children
description: The New York State Senate has a wonderful opportunity this fall to help the children of single-parent families and lift a heavy financial burden from the counties. All it has to do is retrieve the child support standards bill from the grave that is the Rules Committee - and, as the Assembly did in July, pass it.

title: Officer in Bronx Is Shot As He Chases a Suspect
description: A 25-year-old police officer was critically wounded in a shootout with a robbery suspect who was being pursued in the Bronx yesterday, the police said.

title: Transit Agency Reports a Rise In Vandalism
description: The number of subway turnstiles being broken into, jammed or vandalized has risen sharply this year and has now become a critical problem for the Transit Authority, with record one-month revenue losses of $150,000 in August alone, the president of the authority said yesterday.

title: Linda Christine Holub Wed to Kent D. Reilly
description: Linda Christine Holub, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roland J. Holub of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Kent Dunphy Reilly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald D. Reilly of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Henry J. Meade performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Darien.

title: Koch Jeered During Speech on Corruption
description: Mayor Koch issued a sharply worded warning yesterday to 3,000 city inspectors, vowing to prosecute corrupt employees. But some members of the audience responded with more jeers than applause.

title: Fast IIc Plus Computer Is Introduced by Apple
description: Apple Computer Inc. today introduced the IIc Plus, a faster and less expensive version of its lowest-priced personal computer.

title: Correction
description: A review of the artist Clemens Weiss in Weekend yesterday mistated his birthplace. It was Germany, not Austria.

title: U.S. Rejects Soviet Offer on Disputed Complex
description: The White House said today that the Soviet Union must tear down the Krasnoyarsk radar and that turning it into an international center on space research would not be good enough.

title: Seabrook Moves Aid Both Sides
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission yesterday removed one major obstacle to giving a test permit to the Seabrook nuclear power plant in New Hampshire, but reluctantly agreed with opponents of the plant on another issue.

title: Americans Get a Taste of Labor Protests in Chile
description: Several dozen European and American labor leaders tasted daily life in Santiago this week when the police attacked them with tear gas, water cannon and riot sticks as they marched to the Supreme Court in support of Chilean labor.

title: Partial Sense Of Touch in Plastic Hand
description: IN recent years, plastic surgeons have developed increasingly lifelike artificial hands, covered with a skin-like material, that can hold and manipulate objects much like real hands.

title: Suffolk Budget Proposal Includes a 15% Tax Rise
description: Most homeowners in Suffolk County would pay 15 percent more in property taxes next year under a $1.2 billion budget County Executive Patrick G. Halpin proposed today.

title: HURRICANE READINESS
description: If your region is vulnerable to hurricanes, review plans to protect yourself and your property. If you live on the shore or in a mobile home, map your escape route and destination. A household inventory, stored away from home, will help in obtaining insurance settlements and tax deductions for losses. In many states you can supplement your insurance coverage with separate protection for wind and water damage. Flood insurance can be obtained from the National Flood Insurance Program. If you plan to wait out the storm at home, lay in some basic supplies and canned food before a hurricane watch is issued, after which certain items might be hard to obtain. Save receipts for materials used for temporary repairs; they may be covered by insurance or be tax deductible. EVENT ITEMS High Winds Tape for small windows; plywood for larger panes. Loss of Power Battery-operated radio; flashlights; extra batteries; candles or lamps; matches in waterproof canisters; supply of gasoline Loss of Water Clean, airtight containers to store enough drinking water for several days (Source: Insurance Information Institute.)

title: Fuzhou Journal; Newest Economics Revives the Oldest Profession
description: In dark hotel bars along China's coast, young women in tight dresses and carefully coiffed hair wiggle their ankles as they linger for hours over a single Coke. Nearby, young men in ostentatious jewelry look for clients to whom they can offer the women's services.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chock Full o'Nuts Corp. said it would acquire Jimbo's Jumbos Inc., a privately held processor and packager of peanuts, for $31.5 million.

title: Student Athletes Are Students as Much as Athletes; Not All Agents
description: To the Editor:

title: How Dukakis Can Overcome Bush's 'Slur du Jour'
description: Michael Dukakis faces a quandary: how to respond to the Bush campaign's Niagara Falls of negative attacks, a ''slur du jour'' since August that pummeled Dukakis's lead. Since John Sasso's return to the campaign, the apparent answer is a mixture of a more positive message but more jabs.

title: Immediate Remedies for New York City's Traffic Ills Abound; Transitway Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: College Football; St. Peter's Drops Football
description: St. Peter's College has dropped its football program for the second time in four years and has forfeited its nine games this season, including the game scheduled against Iona last night.

title: Financial Planners Seek a Clearer Image
description: Financial planners are trying to improve their image.

title: Yeutter Sees Slow Exports
description: The growth in United States exports will probably slow as many industries reach production capacity, Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said today.

title: Burmese Ruling Party Ends Forced Membership Policy
description: The Burmese ruling party, which has controlled most aspects of public life for a quarter of a century, announced today that those serving in the armed forces, civil servants and government employees would no longer be party members.

title: Immediate Remedies for New York City's Traffic Ills Abound
description: To the Editor:

title: Silicon in Deal With I.B.M.
description: Silicon Graphics Inc., a Mountain View, Calif., maker of computer work stations, said that the International Business Machines Corporation had agreed to purchase certain proprietary components and to license its software. Both companies declined to state the monetary value of the arrangement or I.B.M.'s intended use for the parts.

title: Dr. Chin T. Huang, 60, Pulmonary Specialist
description: Dr. Chin Tang Huang, professor of medicine and chief of the division of pulmonary diseases at the Lincoln Hospital Center, died of gastric cancer Thursday at the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan and Sands Point, L.I.

title: Shift Seen For Official Of I.B.M.
description: As part of an effort to stimulate lagging personal computer sales, the International Business Machines Corporation will reportedly put the head of its Asian operation in charge of its Personal Systems Group.

title: Response at Indiana
description: Jay Edwards, voted the basketball player of the year in the Big Ten Conference last season, denied that he was a drug addict, said he never enrolled in a chemical dependency treatment program and that he had not left Indiana University. But all of that is contrary to what his coach said recently.

title: College Football; College Game Is Postponed
description: The football game between Alabama and Texas A&M, scheduled for Saturday afternoon at College Station, Tex., has been postponed because of Hurricane Gilbert.

title: Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, 711 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017. American Red Cross, P.O. Box 4681, New

title: Towering Expo
description: Pittsburgh Pirate batters had to look up to Randy Johnson Thursday night, not only because the Montreal Expo pitcher beat them, 9-4, but also because at 6 feet 10 inches the lefthander became the tallest player to appear in a major league game. He is an inch taller than Johnny Gee, who pitched for the Pirates and New York Giants from 1939 to 1946.

title: House Rejects Bid to Require Disclosure to AIDS Spouses
description: Democrats in the House today rejected a Republican attempt to bring up a measure to require doctors caring for AIDS patients to inform spouses if their partners were infected with the virus.

title: DUKAKIS OUTLINES HIS DRUG PROGRAM
description: Michael S. Dukakis today outlined a battle plan for his war on drugs, saying that as President he would double the number of Federal drug enforcement agents, add 800 Federal prosecutors and send a message to drug kingpins that ''as far as Mike Dukakis is concerned, there's nowhere you can run.''

title: To Our Readers
description: Starting on Monday, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on weekdays within 75 miles of New York City, and on all of Long Island, will be increased to 35 cents. The change is prompted by rising production costs, including an increase in the price of paper. The newspaper's Sunday price will not change, nor will its weekday price outside the 75-mile area.

title: For Tourists in Jamaica, Boats Flew and Fear Grew
description: When the gates for American Airlines flight 2645 to New York opened this afternoon, a cheer went up and scores of sweaty, weary Americans dashed for the jet.

title: Red Sox Rally To Top Yankees
description: They are even now. There will be no sweep in Fenway Park, no charge through Boston, no Red Sox heartbreak. The Yankees, who rushed into town on Thursday, fell back to earth tonight.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football

title: For Columbia Theater, A Festive First Night
description: When Schuyler G. Chapin became dean of the School of the Arts at Columbia University, in 1976, he took a walk through the school's performance hall, McMillin Academic Theater, and was horrified.

title: College Football; Vanderbilt's Jones Gets Star Buildup
description: Eric Jones, the quarterback for Vanderbilt, has his own video and his own full-color poster. Sounds more like a rock star than a football player.

title: Review/Opera; An Omaha Premiere For 'The White Rose'
description: From its strictly amateur status of 30 years ago to purveyor of the new and rare in opera represents a long, gradual stride for Opera/Omaha, which opened its fall season here this past week. Last Saturday offered ''Partenope,'' one of Handel's few attempts at satire. Wednesday night brought the American premiere of Udo Zimmermann's ''White Rose'' together with Janacek's ''Diary of One Who Vanished,'' a song cycle for small vocal ensemble transliterated here for the stage.

title: For Another Kennedy, Another Victory
description: A candidate named Edward J. Kennedy Jr., who did not campaign much and received no endorsements, finished ahead of three opponents in the race for Middlesex County Commissioner in the state Democratic primary Thursday.

title: Too Much for Even the I.O.C.
description: The records set in the Seoul Olympics for the number of athletes participating and for the number of events held are likely to be broken four years from now in Barcelona, Spain, officials of the International Olympic Committee said today. But after that the numbers could be cut back.

title: Quayle Vows G.O.P. Will Make Agriculture Policy Its Top Priority
description: Senator Dan Quayle, boasting that he came from Indiana farm country and therefore understood farmers and their problems, said today that the top agricultural priority of a victorious Republican ticket would be more farm exports, more rural development and an economic summit on agriculture.

title: Coach Calls U.S. a Contender
description: None of the Olympic boxing experts expect the United States team to approach the nine gold medals won by Americans at Los Angeles four years ago. Two or three gold medals here would be a bonanza.

title: For 1989, New Cars And Warranties Come in All Lengths
description: If you plan to shop for a new car when the 1989 models officially go on sale at the beginning of next month, you may feel overwhelmed unless you have been keeping up with the auto market. Not since the industry's infancy has there been such variety.

title: Close-Up: Diving
description: Scoring

title: Article 979588 -- No Title
description: A jury today awarded $1.85 million in general damages to Valerie Harper in her suit against Lorimar Telepictures Corporation over her departure from the ''Valerie'' television series.

title: Take Me to Check-It-Out Street
description: LEAD: A few weeks ago, I changed my address without moving out of my apartment. One night I went to bed living in Jamaica, the next morning I woke up living in a place called Kew Garden Hills.

title: Former Navy Chief Defends Policies
description: Former Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. today called for the mandatory registration of consultants involved in military procurement, but he said the Navy's procurement policies were not to blame for possible fraud in contracting.

title: Review/Television; On Another Plane, Sophocles and Thackeray
description: Going into something other than adolescent sitcoms and tabloid entertainments, television is offering Sophocles and William Makepeace Thackeray this weekend.

title: Endorsing A Check Is Now a Smaller Job
description: Endorsing a check? A new Federal law says you have just 1 1/2 inches in which to do it.

title: Review/Pop; Band Brings Back 60's
description: Carlos Santana's show at Pier 84 on Wednesday night was filled with sounds and ideas that wafted in from the past. Mr. Santana's guitar tone, tightly distorted, soared above the juicy sounds of Gregg Rolie's organ; combined, they make up a classic sound of the 1960's. And Mr. Santana's eclecticism, mixing rock, latin and jazz - and the mainstream popularity to go with it - unfortunately also seemed like something from an earlier, more optimistic age.

title: Keeping Choice Alive on Nicaragua
description: The next President deserves meaningful choices on Nicaragua. To this end, the Reagan Administration has to keep alive Central America's peace plan. And the bargaining process has to have enough momentum to prevent the contras from disintegrating into hit-and-run gangs who can only terrorize, not negotiate.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption yesterday about faculty members at New York University supporting a strike by clerical workers misstated the location. It was the Elmer Holmes Bobst Library; Low Library is at Columbia University.

title: A New Method to Kill Salmonella in Poultry
description: The Monsanto Company received a patent this week for a new approach to killing salmonella bacteria in poultry. Salmonella causes nausea, vomiting and other flu-like symptoms, and more serious illness in people with weakened immune systems.

title: 10 Years After Camp David. Now What?
description: LEAD: The Palestinians' response to the Camp David Accords, signed 10 years ago today, has taken the form of the intifada, or uprising. Their clear message is that the Camp David formula of ''autonomy'' and the idea of having Egypt or Jordan represent Palestinian interests are unacceptable.

title: Power Shifts For Democrats After Primary
description: New York's Democratic politicians yesterday looked beyond their party's primary returns to their impact on next year's mayoral election, power shifts in the Bronx and even a rivalry between the city's most prominent prosecutors, who are not normally involved in political maneuvering.

title: Merger Talk Lifts Tobacco Issues
description: The stocks of American Brands and Liggett Group Inc. jumped yesterday on speculation that either or both of the companies might become takeover targets.

title: Aircraft Leasing and Irish Luck
description: Thirteen years ago, Tony Ryan was a middle-level manager at Aer Lingus, Ireland's state-owned airline. When he left to start his own business, with $5,000 in savings, colleagues thought him foolish for giving up a steady if modest salary and a secure future.

title: Shultz Says U.S. Opposes P.L.O. Statehood Plans
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said tonight that the United States would oppose any ''declaration of independent Palestinian statehood or government in exile'' that might be established for the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: Rowena Kostellow, 88; Taught Design at Pratt
description: Rowena Reed Kostellow, a professor of design at Pratt Institute, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Beekman Hospital. She was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Widow of Slain Judge May Get His Benefits
description: The widow of a Federal judge from Pelham, N.Y., who was slain over a sex-discrimination case he had handled, would become eligible for death benefits under legislation introduced today.

title: INSIDE
description: 'Squeezed Middle Class'

title: Meeting the Need For Health Care
description: THERE is a growing need for long-term health care in America, but all too little provision for it, the experts warn. As a result, many Americans will die destitute unless they put private plans into place during their working years.

title: Samuel Burman, 87, A Former Prosecutor
description: Samuel Seidel Burman, a lawyer and former assistant United States attorney in Manhattan, died of emphysema Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 87 years old. Mr. Burman, who was born in Pinsk, in what is now the Soviet Union, and came to the United States in 1905, received his law degree from New York Law School in 1923. He entered private practice and later served as law secretary to Justice Julius Miller of State Supreme Court.

title: Toughest Part May Be Over for Thompson's Team
description: John Thompson thought it was a normal reaction, something he would expect from 12 players who have not had any time off since the college basketball season began last October. All of them would feel like quitting at one time or another, fed up with the daily grind, listening to his sometimes unflattering critiques.

title: Lieberman and Weicker Start Series of Debates
description: Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman, running a clear second in his campaign for the United States Senate, took the offensive today in his first debate with Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., characterizing the three-term incumbent as a political misfit masquerading as a maverick.

title: You, the Night and the Jackhammers
description: In the glare of Manhattan at midnight, steam rose above hot tar as 700 tons of black muck was pounded and rolled into what would become, sometime before dawn, the outside eastbound lane of Central Park South.

title: Wace to Acquire Techtron in U.S.
description: The British printing and publishing company Wace Group P.L.C. will acquire Techtron Imaging Network of Chicago for about $:33.4 million, or about $55.9 million. Techtron is the largest United States color separation and electronic imaging company, with revenue of $83 million last year.

title: F.B.I. Is Willing To Erase Names From Its Records
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, indicated today that the bureau was willing to expunge the names of people and organizations identified in files of a bureau surveillance campaign aimed at opponents of the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America.

title: Soviet Newspaper Criticizes Warsaw
description: A Soviet newspaper accused the Polish leadership today of mismanaging the economy and said the Government of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski might be forced to resign.

title: Cris Carter Pleads Guilty
description: Cris Carter, a wide receiver with the Philadelphia Eagles, pleaded guilty today to charges of mail fraud and obstruction of justice. He agreed to cooperate with prosecutors investigating improper payments from sports agents to college athletes.

title: A.T.&T. Gets Permission To Discount
description: The Federal Communications Commission said yesterday that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company could temporarily match the special discounts on long-distance rates that its smaller rivals offer to large business customers.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Facing Inevitable as the Storm Nears
description: No one who has lived through a major hurricane could fail to respect their terrifying, awesome force. And even in Texas, Hurricane Gilbert has managed to quell most of the foolishness that sometimes leads island residents to swill tequilla at seaside parties amid killer storms.

title: Gertrude Golden, 75, A Film Publicity Agent
description: Gertrude Golden, a publicity agent for many postwar feature films imported from Italy and France, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 75 years old and also lived in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Europe Missile Job
description: A three-nation West European arms consortium has won contracts worth $:806 million, or about $1.37 billion, to develop antitank systems for the British, French and West German Governments, British Aerospace P.L.C. said. A company statement said the Governments had jointly agreed on two contracts with Euromissile Dynamics Group to develop a portable antitank missile for infantry and a longer-range system for helicopters. Both would be ready by the late 1990's. The other two members of the Euromissile group are Aerospatiale of France and West Germany's Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H.

title: Mechanical CPR Is Said To Improve Blood Flow
description: Dr. Ralph D. Lach, a cardiologist in Columbus, Ohio, has invented a mechanical device that provides cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR, to victims of heart attacks. According to the patent, the device is safer and more effective than conventional CPR, in which a hand is pressed against the victim's chest every few seconds to pump blood through the body.

title: In S.I. Court, Each Is Fined To Fit Means
description: In the first such organized experiment in this country, the Staten Island Criminal Court has begun a yearlong project in which those convicted of misdemeanors and violations are fined according to their ability to pay.

title: Reagan Right Has Been Heard on Campus; The Unopened Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball; Jefferies Delivers; Ojeda Hurt
description: For Gregg Jefferies, who has been feasting on big-league pie for nearly a month, it was one more tasty slice. With two out in the ninth inning last night in Shea Stadium and Keith Miller on second base, he singled to defeat the Montreal Expos, 4-3, and move the Mets one step closer to the National League playoff.

title: CRIME RATES RISE IN NEW YORK CITY
description: The New York City Police Department reported yesterday that murder and manslaughter rose to a near-record level in the first six months of the year.

title: A Chair for the Coach
description: The news that Yale University has received $1 million from an alumnus to endow the position of football coach invites irreverent speculation. What's next, a tenured tuba player? A lifetime annuity for Handsome Dan, the ineffably ugly bulldog who serves as Yale's mascot? And somebody will surely ask whether the money should not be put to uses more obviously consistent with Yale's larger mission of marinating its students in civilization's highest values.

title: Review/Film; Madman's Brand of Justice
description: ''Seven Hours to Judgment,'' directed by and starring Beau Bridges, is a dim suspense drama about a Crazy Eddie-type of Manhattan appliance merchant who goes certifiably crazy when his wife is murdered by a gang of black and Hispanic muggers. To get even, he kidnaps the judge who, for legal reasons, was forced to free the criminals, and the judge's wife.

title: Artist Surrenders Videotape Of Clash in Tompkins Square
description: Ending a 16-day holdout, a Manhattan artist agreed yesterday to turn over a copy of his videotape showing the police and demonstrators clashing in Tompkins Square Park.

title: New Role for Witt
description: A day before the Summer Olympics begin in Seoul, South Korea, one of the heroines from the Winter Games in Calgary, Alberta, re-entered the international arena yesterday at the United Nations. Katarina Witt, the East German figure skater and two-time Olympic gold medalist, was named a sports ambassador for the United Nations Children's Fund.

title: Korean War Memorial Will Rise on the Mall
description: A memorial honoring the 5.7 million Americans who served in the Korean War will be placed on the Mall in Washington, near the Lincoln Memorial and opposite the Vietnam Memorial.

title: Reagan Planning a Cut In Envoys to Panama
description: President Reagan said today that the United States was reducing its diplomatic presence in Panama because of concern for personnel stationed there. He said the move was ''probably temporary'' but officials of the State Department disagreed.

title: U.S. Plans Cuts In Persian Gulf
description: The United States Navy plans to relax the protection it provides to merchant ships in the Persian Gulf, Reagan Administration officials said. It would be the first major reduction of American operations there since a cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq war went into effect on Aug. 20.

title: Kroger Holders File 2 Lawsuits
description: Three shareholders of the Kroger Company have sued to block the company's proposed $3.8 billion restructuring aimed at fending off hostile takeovers of the nation's largest supermarket chain.

title: Offer Extended By Halliburton
description: The Halliburton Company said it had extended its tender offer for all outstanding rights of Gearhart Industries to next Thursday. The offer had been scheduled to expire on Thursday of this week, Halliburton said.

title: Review/Film; On Mormons and Mayhem
description: If ''Messenger of Death,'' the Charles Bronson movie that opened yesterday in neighborhood theaters, were a novel, it could be called a decent page turner, one that holds the eye and makes one wonder whodunit.

title: 41 Homeless to Get $500 Each
description: In a surprise move, the City of Los Angeles has agreed to pay $500 each to 41 homeless people whose belongings were destroyed by the police. Lawyers filed damage claims against the city in June after the police raided an encampment of homeless people near City Hall. The possessions of about 50 residents who were away from the camp were removed and buried in a dump. The city was expected to contest the case, but agreed to a $20,500 settlement Thursday.

title: Mail to Britain Restored
description: Mail service to Britain is being restored today, the United States Postal Service announced. Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank said he had been advised by the British Post Office that the strike there had ended and that the agency was again accepting mail. The United States Postal Service embargoed mail to Britain on Sept. 7, when the authorities reported that they were unable to accept incoming mail because of a strike. Mr. Frank cautioned, however, that there may still be some delays because there is a backlog of mail to be sorted and delivered in Britain.

title: Baseball; Tigers Win by 8-7 On Lynn's Homer
description: Fred Lynn, traded by Baltimore last month, hit a two-run home run in the ninth inning tonight that gave the Detroit Tigers an 8-7 victory over the Orioles and kept their hopes alive in the American League East.

title: SIX GOVERNORS IN SEARCH OF AN ANSWER
description: LABORATORIES OF DEMOCRACY By David Osborne. 380 pp. Boston: Harvard Business School Press. $24.95.

title: Foreigners to Observe the Plebiscite in Chile
description: Over the objections of the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, several hundred prominent political figures and others from Western democracies plan to come to Chile to observe the Oct. 5 presidential plebiscite.

title: Travelers Sells Plaza Property
description: The Travelers Corporation has agreed to sell properties in five states, including Constitution Plaza, to the Colonial Realty Company of West Hartford for nearly $235 million.

title: NONFICTION
description: WILLIAM EVERSON: The Life of Brother Antoninus. By Lee Bartlett. (New Directions, $25.95.) The poet William Everson has had a dramatic life. As a teen-ager in 1930 he started a sexual affair with a girl in his California hometown that lasted eight years before they were married. But then, fearing his Oedipus complex would make him a bad parent, he had a vasectomy. While he spent World War II in a conscientious objectors' camp his wife became the lover of one of his friends. He married again after the war but separated in a year. Then, having been always an agnostic, he was baptized as a Roman Catholic in 1949 at the age of 36 and shortly afterward became director of the new Catholic Worker house in Oakland, Calif. In 1951 he entered the Dominican order as a lay brother, and it was as Brother Antoninus that he gained national attention as a poet - a most conspicuous San Francisco Beat poet. His asceticism was so fierce that even priests protested, but he conceived intense passions for several women, one of them celebrated in the mystical and erotic sequence ''The Rose of Solitude.'' In 1969 he left the Dominicans, married a woman 35 years his junior and became a college teacher. Parkinson's disease ended his career several years ago. Some of his poetry may endure, but it is his printing that should be revered for ages. He taught himself hand printing in his 30's; his ''Psalter'' (1955), although incomplete, is generally acknowledged one of the greatest feats of American printing, and collectors have turned his ''Granite & Cypress'' (1975) into a fantastically expensive rarity. Lee Bartlett, the editor of the journal American Poetry, is not a brilliant writer, and his excuse for mentioning Mr. Everson's second marriage only in a note (''in deference'' to the wife's ''wish for privacy'') is unnerving, but his book outlines an amazing life.

title: Phuket, Thailand's Resort Island
description: DANGLING like an irregularly shaped pearl in the Andaman Sea off Thailand's far southern peninsula, the island of Phuket has been blessed with jungle-topped mountains, planted on their lower slopes with rubber trees and coconut palms, and valleys patterned with lush rice paddies. Its coastline is studded with more than a dozen white sand beaches, each on a self-contained bay formed by rocky outcrops that jut into the translucent sea.

title: Making, and Unmaking, the News in Beijing
description: Last Sunday, People's Daily, the organ of the Chinese Communist Party, reported on its front page that Qi Wenzeng marched into Zhongnanhai, the walled and guarded compound where China's leaders live and work, and proceeded to peddle more than $8,000 worth of stock in his company.

title: Flight of the Osprey, From Extinction to Guarded Health
description: LEAD: A DECADE ago, the sight of an osprey soaring above a bay in search of fish had become all too rare on Long Island. Conservationists feared this proud bird was headed for extinction, a forelorn symbol of the region's dwindling wildlife population.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Local Colleges; Fordham Records Another Shutout
description: Rick Hollawell rushed for touchdowns on carries of 1 yard in the opening period and 7 in the second as Fordham registered its second shutout in two games, 27-0, over Catholic University (1-1) yesterday in Washington.

title: Gas: Problems With Proof
description: Time and distance are enemies of the inquiry into whether mustard gas was used on Kurds in Iraq. The chemical degrades rapidly in tissue samples, and the area of the supposed attacks is off-limits. Page 14.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: FOR almost three decades, the housekeeper addressed Renny Saltzman as ''Mr. S.'' This would not have meant a thing except that ''Mr. S.'' originally referred to Mr. Saltzman's late father-in-law, whose name was Sadowsky and for whom the housekeeper had worked, in the very same apartment, since Mr. Saltzman's wife, Ellin, was an infant.

title:
INVESTING;
Builder's Smart Bank Board Deal
description: LEAD: On Sept. 9, Michigan's PHM Corporation, through its Texas affiliate, Pulte Diversified, agreed to buy five insolvent Texas savings institutions for $45 million in cash from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: Six Times Square Theaters to Go 'Populist'
description: In New York's most ambitious cultural venture since Lincoln Center was built in the 1960's, city and state officials plan to transform six 42d Street theaters into what they call a ''populist'' theater complex for low-priced and widely divergent forms of live entertainment.

title: Missy Kilroy Weds in Ohio
description: The marriage of Mari Angela Kilroy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Kilroy of Shaker Heights, Ohio, to John Upshur Moorhead 2d, the son of Clare Fahnestock Moorhead of Stratton Mountain, Vt., and Cambridge, Mass., and Thomas C. Moorhead of Washington, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Dominic in Shaker Heights. The Rev. Martin J. Amos performed the ceremony.

title: 5 Cities to Get Help With Recycling
description: THE state's five largest cities will be receiving special help to meet recycling requirements that are to go into effect in 1991.

title: Evelyn H. Seeler, Lawyer, Marries
description: At the Church-in-the-Gardens in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, Evelyn Harrison Seeler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard William Seeler of Forest Hills Gardens, was married yesterday to John Francis McKay 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. McKay Jr. of Hempstead, L.I. The Rev. Steven E. Berry, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Kramer Marries in Jersey
description: At the chapel of the Lawrenceville (N.J.) School, Elizabeth Ann Kramer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Kramer of Princeton, N.J., and Greensboro, Vt., was married yesterday to Robert Lawrence Whitney Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitney of Exeter, N.H., and Ipswich, Mass. The Rev. Edward J. Dougherty, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: RIGHTEOUS BUT GOOD
description: PERFECTING THE WORLD The Life and Times of Dr. Thomas Hodgkin 1798-1866. By Amalie M. Kass and Edward H. Kass. Illustrated. 642 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $34.95.

title: Confronting Culture Shock in Princeton
description: WHEN I first moved to Princeton from New York City two years ago, I experienced a certifiable case of culture shock.

title: THE AGGRESSORS
description: Just when so many of us had begun to hope that biological determinism had fallen out of fashion, Melvin Konner informs us in ''The Aggressors'' (Body and Mind, Aug. 14) that biological imperatives compel men to behave more violently than women. It is such a tired argument that one might have assumed it would not be dragged out unless there were new evidence. But Dr. Konner disappoints us. He gives us a simple explanation for an array of complex human behaviors ranging from the rough-and-tumble play of little girls to genocidal holocaust.

title: Bill Forsyth Plots His Latest Caper
description: LEAD: CONFERRING QUIETLY with Burt Reynolds, Bill Forsyth appears oblivious to his crew's panic as they rush to make one last camera setup before dusk turns into night. Despite the luxuriant black hair and beard that frame his pale features, Mr. Forsyth tends to be the least conspicuous figure on the set of ''Breaking In.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
More Space for Y
description: LEAD: ''Lots of glass, lots of light'' is how Judith R. Margulies, president and chairwoman of the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Mid-Westchester, describes the Y's new Enid Ancell building, which is being dedicated today.

title: After Storm, Jamaica's Have-Nots Have Less
description: Beverly Smith looked despairingly at the empty cast-iron cooking pots in the outdoor kitchen that she and her seven children and grandchildren share with the family of nine next door.

title: LEFT BEHIND ON BLUE STAR MOINTAIN
description: FAIR AND TENDER LADIES By Lee Smith. 316 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: Review/Rock; Lonnie Mack in a Melange of Guitar Styles
description: Lonnie Mack, the semi-legendary rock guitarist, brought himself and a three-piece band to the Bottom Line on Thursday night. Mr. Mack plays roadhouse music, rock that easily blends country and blues into a functional style meant to make people have a good time and dance.

title: Priscilla C. Barker Weds D. K. Miller
description: At. St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York, Priscilla Corwith Barker, the daughter of Mrs. John William Veitch of Montreal and the late William Crichlow Lamond Barker, was married yesterday to Donald Keith Miller, a son of Mrs. Clinton R. Miller of Akron, Ohio, and the late Mr. Miller. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony.

title: As Fall Aproaches, an Apple a Day for the Dessert Table
description: APPLES are at their peak in the fall. Fresh and recently ripened, they have much more flavor than those that have been shipped or stored. The best are to be found at roadside stands or farmer's markets, where, with any luck, the apples have been picked ripe.

title: 'I AM ONLY EQUIVOCALLY HAROLD BRODKEY'
description: STORIES IN AN ALMOST CLASSICAL MODE By Harold Brodkey. 596 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: Jessica Herzstein, Physician, Is Wed
description: At the First Unitarian Church in Jamaica Plain, Mass., Dr. Jessica Anne Herzstein, a daughter of Robert E. Herzstein and Priscilla Holmes Herzstein of Washington, and Dr. John Louis Ryan, a son of Mrs. Alfred Toscano of New Haven and the late Philip W. Ryan, were married yesterday by the Rev. Terry Burke.

title: Cairo Advises P.L.O. to Go Slow on a Government
description: Intervening in a critical debate, Egypt has urged the Palestine Liberation Organization to avoid a rapid decision on declaring a government in exile for the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, according to officials and diplomats here.

title: Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, 711 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017. American Red Cross, P.O. Box 4681, New York, N.Y. 10164-0037, Attn: Hurricane Relief. American World Jewish Services, 729 Boylston Street, Boston, Mass. 02116, Attn: Jamaica Recovery Program. Americares, 161 Cherry Street, New Canaan, Conn. 06840. CARE, 660 First Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016. Catholic Medical Mission Board, 10 West 17th Street, New York, N.Y. 10011. Catholic Relief Services. 1011 First Avenue, New York. N.Y. 10022. Church World Service, Hurricane Gilbert Emergency, P.O. Box 968, Elkhart, Ind. 46515. Friends of Mexican Development Foundation, 145 East 74th Street, Suite 1C, New York, N.Y. 10021. Operation California, 7615 1/2 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles, Calif. 90046. Oxfam America, 115 Broadway, Boston, Mass. 02116. Partners of the Americas, 1424 K Street N.W., Washington 20005. Save the Children, Hurricane Reconstruction Fund, 56 Wilton Road, Westport, Conn. 06881. U.S. Committee for Unicef, 331 East 38th Street, New York, N.Y. 10016.

title: Law School v. Reality
description: TO A GREAT EXTENT, law and lawyers are in their heyday in the United States. Lawyers' incomes continue to rise and their prominence in the society at large seems ever-increasing. One of the most popular shows on television at the moment is about daily life in a law firm. As our notions of privacy have changed and as venerable institutions like churches and schools have come to speak with less uniform authority, the courts have emerged as the arena where debate is most often conducted concerning matters - often highly personal ones -about which we find ourselves profoundly in conflict: the right to abortion, the means to accomplish racial and gender equality, the propriety of surrogate motherhood or the appropriate treatment of contagious, life-threatening disease. Perhaps because the law seems to know more of the answers, the legally trained continue to show up in increasing numbers as leaders in areas outside the law. These days, a law degree, for instance, seems to have replaced a cigar as a requirement for Hollywood mogulhood.

title: Political Memo; Race Reflects Voter Concern With Image Over Substance
description: For those who would like the 1988 campaign to be a broad debate between Michael S. Dukakis and George Bush about a wide range of tough issues, such as how they would close the budget deficit or what they would do about Nicaragua, the encounter so far has been a dud.

title: U.S. Envoy Meets Syria Chief
description: Richard W. Murphy, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, today discussed efforts to break the deadlock over Lebanon's election with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, diplomats said. No successor has been found for President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon, whose term ends on Sept. 23.

title: Detainee Is Fatally Stabbed at Rikers Island
description: A 28-year-old detainee was stabbed to death yesterday by another inmate at a city jail on Rikers Island, the authorities said.

title: Discovering Harriet Wilson
description: To the Editor:

title: Drop That Card
description: CREEPY-LOOKING guy sidles up to you and whispers, ''Wanna buy a pornographic record?''

title: Harold E. Davis, 85, Professor and Author
description: Harold Eugene Davis, a Latin American scholar and professor emeritus at American University, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in this Washington suburb. He was 85 years old Mr. Davis served on the American University faculty from 1947 until he retired in 1973. He continued to teach part time until the fall of 1986.

title: The Titanic And Nuclear Power
description: Ben Calderone's letter (The 'Safest' Ship Was the Titanic, Sept. 11) raises two key points in the discussion of public safety. Even though the Titanic sank, a movement to destroy ocean shipping did not result. Since then, means to detect and avoid icebergs have been been improved, leading to safer marine transportation. As this applies to the Shoreham power plant, modern techniques of safety engineering will reduce the possibility of accidents. Shoreham should not be dismembered. ROSS FLEISIG Garden City

title: Poison Gas Attacks: Why a Diagnosis Is So Difficult
description: The reluctance of several European doctors to diagnose chemical warfare poisoning among Kurds who have fled Iraq underscores difficulties a physician has in documenting such poisonings when he is able to examine supposed victims only after they have left the scene of the alleged attacks.

title: Ellen Minsky to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold I. Minsky of Brookville, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ellen Minsky to Richard B. Diamond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Diamond of New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: Miss Willi, Editor, Becomes the Wife Of Wayne Coffey
description: Madeleine Denise Willi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Willi Jr. of West Redding, Conn., was married yesterday to Wayne Ryerson Coffey, a son of Marion R. Coffey of Ridgefield, Conn., and Frank B. Coffey of Palm Springs, Calif. The Rev. Arthur E. Oudemool, a Dutch Reformed minister, performed the ceremony at All Souls Church in Tannersville, N.Y.

title: Hey, Big Spender!
description: When it comes to spending the money, the Americans who win state lotteries are like peas in the pod. If they have children, they put it toward college educations. If they only rent a home, they want to buy one. If they have one car, they buy another. If they've never traveled, they take a trip. Scatter your dollars while you may is, it seems, the American way.

title:
DINING OUT;
Quality Italian Fare in Stirling
description: LEAD: THE dining experience at Primavera, a three-month-old Italian restaurant in Stirling, can be totally different, depending on whether one dines there during the week or on the weekend.

title: Review/Opera; Handel in Light Mood, In Omaha 'Partenope'
description: Two-thirds of Opera/Omaha's season looks like that of any American regional company - a musical comedy to entice the faint of heart and then the Romantic repertory aimed at those for whom ''grand'' remains the important constituent of opera.

title: Greenland
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Explorations in a Land of Glaciers'' (Travel, Aug. 21): We returned to Narssarssuag in a small boat (someone laughingly called it the Titanic), sailing for three hours amid icebergs, alone in the visible world. The emergency radio told of a boat accident and subsequent drownings.

title: Fairfield U. Opens Drive With a $22 Million Start
description: LEAD: FAIRFIELD UNIVERSITY has a head start on a $35 million capital campaign announced last week, the largest in the school's 46-year history. About $22 million has already been raised in what officials called a quiet advance campaign.

title: Columbia Loses; Streak Is Now 42
description: There was a little tease in the Columbia-Harvard game today, a Columbia tease. Solomon Johnson, the Lions' acclaimed sophomore halfback making his varsity debut managed a 61-yard end run that led to a touchdown early in the second period after the Crimson had compiled a 17-0 lead.

title: Baby Boom in Progress
description: CONNECTICUT is experiencing a big increase in the smallest of people. Like the nation as a whole, the state is in the midst of a baby boom, with consequences both present and future.

title: This Company Speaks English - and American
description: IMAGINE A PRODUCTION OF SHAKESPEARE's ''Twelfth Night'' or Ibsen's ''Master Builder'' or a new play by Peter Shaffer or Simon Gray transferring, with its British cast intact, directly to Broadway after a three-month season in the West End. Imagine an all-American revival of O'Neill's ''Mourning Becomes Electra'' or Edward Albee's ''Delicate Balance'' or even Shakespeare's ''Hamlet'' making the reverse trip.

title: Meetings With More Frills - and More Fun
description: Companies may be under pressure to control costs, but the amount they are spending on meetings continues to rise. An estimated $41.2 billion will be spent on corporate and association conferences this year, up 15 percent from 1987, according to Bjorn Hanson, a hotel specialist for the accounting firm of Laventhol & Horwath. This includes spending for lodging, meals and transportation.

title: Margaret Shivers Weds Peter Heyward
description: Margaret Littlehales Shivers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Shivers Jr. of Baltimore, was married yesterday at her parents' home to Peter Eric Heyward, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. J. R. Heyward of Great Neck, L.I., and Paris. The Rev. William R. Mueller, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: A JOB WITH MORE TWIST THAN MOM'S SPAGHETTI
description: BIG CITY D.A. By Mario Merola. With Mary Ann Giordano. 242 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Roundup; U.S. MEN'S VOLLEYBALL TEAM OVERPOWERS JAPAN
description: The United States men's volleyball team kept its unbeaten string intact against Japan today as the Americans opened their quest for a second consecutive Olympic title.

title: John Byington 3d Wed To Grace A. Manning
description: Grace Ann Manning, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Manning of Baldwin, L.I., and John Howard Byington 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Byington Jr. of New York and Shelter Island, L.I., were married yesterday at Our Lady of Isle Roman Catholic Church at Shelter Island. The Rev. John J. Traynor performed the ceremony.

title: A Dream as Bright as Its Chrome
description: The December 1946 issue of the now defunct Science Illustrated magazine carried a dramatic front view of a vehicle with fenders that pivoted with the front wheels and a drawing of an all-hydraulic drive train. This was the Tucker - a new car concept that set the stage for Preston T. Tucker's entrance onto the automotive scene.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: VELAZQUEZ: Painter and Courtier, by Jonathan Brown. (Yale University, $35.) The masterpieces of Velazquez, including his haunting, self-referential ''Las Meninas,'' were completed while he was becoming increasingly consumed by his duties in the court of King Philip IV, where he was finally knighted in 1659. Last year, our reviewer, Lawrence Gowing, said the last chapters of Jonathan Brown's book ''reach a depth that is uncommon even in the finest art criticism.'' The publisher ''has provided Mr. Brown with an edition in every way worthy of his achievement, with plates far better than any others that have been devoted to this extraordinary artist.''

title:
4>MUSIC;
Ensemble Aims at a National Audience
description: LEAD: THE first five years of Solid Brass have been a time of building repertory, setting goals and establishing a style. Some members of the Chatham-based ensemble, which will make its New York debut at Alice Tully Hall this afternoon at 3, readily admit that they wouldn't have considered such a debut any earlier.

title: Hurst Finds a Home at Fenway Park
description: Fenway Park, goes the belief that dies hard, eats left-handed pitchers for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Midnight snacks, too, when the games last that long. Bruce Hurst, though, has given Fenway indigestion.

title: A Milestone for Johnson As Mets Set Back Expos
description: Unchallenged and almost untouched, the Mets continued their countdown to the playoff yesterday when they beat the Montreal Expos, 6-2. And in one afternoon's work, they put the Expos out of the race and put Davey Johnson into the baseball record books.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Centreville, Va.; 9,500 Homes, Pop. 20,000
description: BUILDERS have begun selling some houses for more than $500,000 here in far western Fairfax County, an area that many had considered lower-income. It lies 21 miles west of Washington on Interstate 66.

title: On the Road To Monopoly
description: Alvah H. Chapman Jr., a Southern patrician with deep pockets, does not like to lose. But to win what could be the most dazzling prize of his long career - huge and steady profits from one of his most important markets - he must prove that the biggest newspaper under his control is a failure.

title: The New Gambit Is Finally Revealed
description: IN the fourth game of the world championship match in Seville, Spain, last September, the titleholder, Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union, used a variation of the English Opening that had a bad reputation, but no one could guess why.

title: Reid Norris, Student, Plans Marriage to Charles Buckley
description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. Cowie Jr. of Baltimore have announced the engagement of Mrs. Cowie's daughter, Barbara Reid Norris, to Charles Boyle Buckley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Buckley of Wilmington, Del.

title: Housing Measures on the Road to Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking; Convertibles Keeping Options Open
description: Hundreds of borrowers who took out one of the new convertible type of adjustable-rate mortgages will be receiving a letter from their lenders this fall reminding them of the opportunity to convert to a fixed-rate loan. Some lenders may even follow up the letter with a phone call to help explain the option more fully.

title: Massachusetts Homeless Backed On Right to Attend Local Schools
description: The Massachusetts Department of Education says communities are responsible for the education of children living within their boundaries, even if they live in temporary shelters, state parks or other temporary situations.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Drug Violators Be Paid for Time Away?
description: Drug violators should not be paid for time away. Drugs became a serious problem, and a possible cure is to hit the violator where it hurts the most and that's in the pocket. ALEX TIRSCHWELL Brooklyn

title: PCB Warning on Appliances
description: THE recycling industry on Long Island is refusing to dispose of most refrigerators, dishwashers and other large appliances, following a warning by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency that older models of some of these items may contain unacceptable levels of PCB's.

title: Graduates Need Marketable Skills
description: Fundamentally, what these newly minted liberal arts graduates are suffering from is reality shock [ ''Brand-New Degree and No Place to Go,'' Aug. 28 ] . For the first time in their lives, they have to get real jobs and support themselves, but no one has told them - not parents, friends, or teachers throughout their 16 years of schooling - that without marketable office skills, they are virtually unemployable.

title: Sentimentalizing 60's Radicalism
description: 'RUNNING ON EMPTY'' IS Sidney Lumet's family drama about radicals who, 15 years after blowing up a research laboratory that made napalm, are still on the run. Why is this idea so undeniably compelling? In part it's novelty, since Hollywood has left the radicalism of the 1960's relatively unexplored. And, of course, there's a romantic side to this story of rebels on the run. For baby-boom viewers, the film's ascetic characters and their disdain for materialism - they live in makeshift quarters, throw wonderful birthday parties using paper streamers and tinsel crowns, and get their clothes from lost-and-founds - must seem refreshing, too.

title: Plan to Treat Addicts At Airport Criticized
description: LEAD: TWO county proposals to use vacant military quarters at Suffolk County Airport as an outpatient clinic for heroin addicts and housing for the homeless have angered the airport business tenants and community leaders near the facility.

title: CTW Romps Onto Cable With 'Encyclopedia'
description: SO, YOU THINK YOU'RE WELL-informed? A new weekly television series making its debut tomorrow evening at 7:30 on Home Box Office may test that conviction.

title: Giant Defense Is Struggling
description: In their first two games the Giants have allowed 298 yards rushing, 518 yards in the air and an average of 408 net yards per game. Early last week, Coach Bill Parcells conceded that his defense needed help and that he didn't care where it would come from.

title: Q And A
description: Imbalance in a Co-op

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ERIC ROHMER: Realist and Moralist. By C. G. Crisp. (Indiana University, Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $11.50.) With the recent release of Eric Rohmer's film ''Boyfriends and Girlfriends,'' it seems a good time for the publication of a critical analysis of the writer-director's works. Born in 1920, Mr. Rohmer became associated with New Wave directors like Francois Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard, but unlike them he shunned innovative techniques.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 18, 1988

(Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses ways for companies to survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 15 1 THE PREDATOR'S BALL, by Connie Bruck. (American Lawyer/Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The rise and influence during 1980's of the Wall Street firm Drexel Brunham Lambert 16 * 32 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 17 * 181 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 63 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 4 24 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 3 * 3 155 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $16.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 2 2 ALL YOU CAN DO IS ALL YOU CAN DO, BUT ALL YOU CAN DO IS ENOUGH! by A. L. Williams. (Nelson, $14.95.) The philosophy of a highly successful entrepreneur who deals in life insurance and investments. 5 42 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $18.95.) The heroine of Ms. Tyler's zesty and merciful 11th book is an inveterate nudge and prompter whose plans for other people's lives strain but do not break the affections of a decent enough family trying to hold its rung in the middle class. BORROWED TIME: An AIDS Memoir, by Paul Monette. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $18.95.) Black humor and strategies of denial give place to real tenderness and heroism in Mr. Monette's account of 19 doomed months in the life of his friend and lover. THE PLACE IN FLOWERS WHERE POLLEN RESTS, by Paul West. (Doubleday, $19.95.) Big (490 pages) and ambitious, this highly original novel concerns a young Hopi Indian whose adventures invoke large issues of creativity and universal order. LAST DAYS OF THE SICILIANS. At War With the Mafia: The FBI Assault on the Pizza Connection, by Ralph Blumenthal. (Times Books, $18.95.) A reconstructed narrative, by a Times reporter, that gives texture and dimension to the Government's unraveling of a mob empire great both in scope and in elusiveness. INTERACTIONS: A Journey Through the Mind of a Particle Physicist and the Matter of This World, by Sheldon Glashow with Ben Bova. (Warner, $19.95.) More a guide to how physicists work than to physics, this book tracks its particles chronologically through the life of its author, who won a Nobel Prize in 1979. THE LOST SALT GIFT OF BLOOD: New & Selected Stories, by Alistair MacLeod. (Ontario Review/Braziller, Paper, $10.95.) Stories at once colloquial and literary, memorializing rough destinies and passing ways of life in Nova Scotia. A STRANGER'S HOUSE, by Bret Lott. (Viking, $17.95.) Ominous secrets in an ancient house augment the sorrow and scariness of everyday life for the young folk of Mr. Lott's second novel. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Shadow Cast Over Sports
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A MONUMENT TO HIS EGO
description: LEAD: FIREFLY SUMMER By Maeve Binchy. 601 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $19.95.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBAL: South; Florida St. Tricks Clemson
description: Florida State faked a punt and sent LeRoy Butler on a 78-yard run to set up Richie Andrews's 19-yard field goal with 32 seconds left today to stun Clemson, 24-21.

title: BBottle Law: When Can Becomes Can't
description: ME-VT-CT-MA-NY REFUND 5. When I first encountered this obscure message it did not strike a chill in my heart. There was no foreboding, only a smug sense of participating in a virtuous and civilized system. To be precise, the message did not at that time include NY; perhaps it read only ME-VT-CT, or something of the kind. That is the problem.

title: A New Glass Menagerie, Some of It 3,500 Years Old
description: Animals - a major theme throughout the history of glassmaking - have been rendered wittily, ingeniously and with extraordinary zest by craftsmen in many cultures. Virtually all the techniques known to this craft are seen in the 71 examples assembled in an exhibition at Steuben Glass, 715 Fifth Avenue (at 56th Street) through Oct. 8.

title: Art Show Postponed
