description: ''1962 to 1988: Contemporary Art from the Paine Webber Collection,'' which was to open Friday at the Paine Webber Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, at 51st Street, has been postponed indefinitely.

title: India From a Private Rail Car
description: CHASING after the glittering prize of India more than 400 years ago, Mogul invaders used both military might and statecraft to subdue those who stood in their way. Today the legends surrounding their battles and alliances with the powerful Rajput warlords in north central India are among the most romantic features of the nation's history. For the traveler, dozens of crumbling palaces and forts dotting the wooded hills and rocky desert of Rajasthan and Madhya states offer a glimpse at how the Hindu princes once lived and fought.

title: SUMMER 1988; Loking Ahead, With Anticipation
description: FORGET the weather. Pay no heed to the end-of-season productions and awards ceremonies that were almost as prolific in late August as they were in June. And most certainly ignore the fashion previews of woolens and corduroy that hit the clothing stores just about the time you decided it was time to invest in a new bathing suit.

title: Bush Rings Tiny Liberty Bell As New Citizens Are Sworn In
description: In another patriotic tableau for his campaign of American symbols, Vice President Bush today rang a model of the Liberty Bell along with schoolchildren to commemorate the 201st anniversary of the signing of the Constitution.

title: Putting Price Tags In Art Galleries
description: MANY fine-art galleries in New York City would prefer not to display the price of their works. Price, they say, is a matter of urbane negotiation. It is, as one art dealer put it, ''an agreement reached between two consenting adults.''

title: Mandatory Coverage Means Lost Jobs
description: In July, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts signed into law a bill mandating universal health care for all workers in that state. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, introduced legislation in Congress calling for universal health insurance on a nationwide basis. John J. Motley, director of Federal Government Relations at the National Federation of Independent Businesses, spoke with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about why small businesses are opposed to mandatory health care coverage.

title: Ramon Subejano, 83; Hero of World War II
description: Ramon Simpas Subejano, a native of the Philippines who became a highly decorated United States war veteran, died after a brief illness Friday at a Veterans Administration hospital here. He was 83 years old, said a close friend, Al Livingston.

title: Harry McCabe, 68, Former Chief Of Offtrack Betting in New York
description: Harry McCabe, a former president of New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Randall Manor, S.I. He was 68 years old.

title: Zimbabwe Leader Tells of Food Gains
description: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe sat in his suite at the Helmsley Palace hotel yesterday and described how his nine-year-old nation has confounded the gloomy predictions of old Rhodesia's white rulers by increasing overall agricultural production while leading millions of black peasants from subsistence farming into the commercial food chain.

title: Shoreline Building
description: To the Editor:

title: TESTIFYING TO TORTURE
description: I am writing in response to several aspects of James LeMoyne's article ''Testifying to Torture'' (June 5).

title: Surgical Cinema
description: THE DAY I learned what happened in the operating room while I slept, the season's first snow was falling. As my neurosurgeon set up the videotape player, I could see flakes the size of half dollars tumble by the window. I'd known that at New York University Medical Center, as at all academic hospitals, surgeons videotaped their operations as teaching aids. I'd mentioned to Dr. Eugene S. Flamm that someday I wanted to see the video of my operation. ''Whenever,'' he responded. He was keeping the tape in a safe place. A neurosurgery resident who'd become a friend didn't think I should watch the surgery done in my own head. I suppose he thought that dwelling on my illness might make me worry about my recovery. It didn't matter, I boasted. My fascination was in the technical. My concern was like that of the residents. I was disinterested in the personal aspects of the case. That surgeons could repair an organ as complicated as the brain -that thrilled me. As I took a stool next to Dr. Flamm, in a narrow laboratory, I thought: how unprepared I am for this; I meant the snow.

title: Gilbert Said to Be Most Destructive
description: Hurricane Gilbert has cut a 2,500-mile swath of devastation through the Caribbean and Gulf Coast since it formed a week ago, making the extent of its destruction the worst recorded for an Atlantic storm, the director of the National Hurricane Center said today. At least $10 billion in damage has already been reported in six countries.

title: Weekly Reader, the Paper for the Young, is Going on 60
description: LEAD: WEEKLY READER, the little newspaper with nine million readers in schools across the country, celebrates its 60th birthday on Wednesday.

title: The First 50th Reunion at Mt. Vernon High
description: LEAD: FOR the organizers of the 50th reunion of Mount Vernon's A. B. Davis High School Class of 1938, the hours of planning have been well worth the effort. ''It's been a wonderful experience getting people together; even the phone reunions have been great,'' said Stanley Wolar, the reunion chairman who started working on the event more than a year ago.

title: Pope Preaches Peace on Mozambique Visit
description: Victims of Mozambique's civil war sat in wheelchairs by an altar today as Pope John Paul II preached reconciliation and nonviolence at one of the largest gatherings of his tour of southern Africa.

title: A Guide to Money Matters
description: ONE old Asia hand likes to tell of an encounter at the airport restaurant in Guilin, China. The left side of the menu was printed in English, the right in Chinese. Entrees were identical, prices were not.

title: IMAGE INVENTORS
description: When Jef Blum moved from New York to California 11 years ago, he brought suitcases full of East Coast clothes - not to mention some psychological baggage.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Men's Basketball; Impressive Debut for U.S. Men
description: Perhaps it lacks star quality, a player who has a sneaker named for him or a National Basketball Association team counting the days until he arrives at training camp, but collectively, the 1988 United States Olympic basketball team looked every bit as good as it is always expected to be.

title: THE REGION: Professors at Work; Management 101: Finding Ways To Save Bridges
description: IN the days after the emergency closing of the Williamsburg Bridge last spring, New York City transportation officials pondered how things could have reached such a state. There was talk of a mysterious rapid-corrosion process in the bridge's 85-year-old steel, of the deleterious effects of road salt and of flawed construction.

title:
GARDENING;
For Plants, Look to Test Tubes
description: LEAD: TO meet the increasing demands of home gardeners and commercial landscapers for ornamental plant material, more perennials and shrubs are being propagated in the laboratory by nurserymen. Rather than increase stocks of hostas and dianthus, or mountain laurel and rhododendrons, by division or cuttings, many producers snip a tiny sample of shoot or leaf tissue from a ''parent'' plant, place it on a gel rich in nutrients and hormones and grow it in an aseptic environment under lights.

title: PUSHKIN WAS HER EDITOR
description: THE CAVALRY MAID The Memoirs of a Woman Soldier of 1812. By Nadezhda Durova. Translated by John Mersereau Jr. and David Lapeza. 222 pp. Ann Arbor, Mich.: Ardis Publishers. $20. THE CAVALRY MAIDEN Journals of a Russian Officer in the Napoleonic Wars. By Nadezhda Durova. Translated by Mary Fleming Zirin. Illustrated. 242 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $25.00.

title: Daring Hurricane Trackers Ride Roller Coaster in Sky
description: In the heart of the storm just as the eye of Hurricane Gilbert touched land late this afternoon, a four-engine Lockheed WP-3D Orion dropped to 1,500 feet above the mountainous swell rolling up the Mexican beach.

title: WORKER-CAPITALIST: Donald Liddle; A Union Man Runs Unimar
description: A few days after Donald Liddle took the helm at Unimar International Inc., one of the largest shipbuilders and tugboat companies on the West Coast, he stopped by his old office to see a few of his former work mates.

title: BASEBALL: National League; GIBSON'S HIT IN 9TH DEFEATS REDS, 4-3
description: Kirk Gibson's run-scoring single in the ninth inning tonight gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 4-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. Any combination of Dodger victories and Houston defeats totaling seven will give Los Angeles the National League West title.

title: Rebecca West's Picts
description: To the Editor:

title: Worker Buyouts
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
Bonsai: Some Sources for the Timid
description: LEAD: HORTICULTURE has been described as a blend of art and science, but providing for the needs of plants in a house or garden has become increasingly technical.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-22

title: A Vintage New Zealand, Not Yet Tamed
description: THE romantic yearnings that sent Wordsworth through England's Lake District and Lawrence through the Alps also, in part, impelled the writer Katherine Mansfield to tour her native New Zealand's Urewera country in 1907. Then as now, the Urewera and neighboring towns of Rotorua and Taupo on the North Island lured visitors with a vast variety of topography, flora and wildlife. For modern travelers, the region also affords a glimpse of the country's history as a British colony and dominion. Mansfield found it ''gigantic and tragic - and even in the bright sunlight . . . passionately secret.''

title: POSTINGS: Demolition on Fifth; 'Last Day' at Last
description: Last year a sign in front of the electronics-luggage-carpet store at 565 Fifth Avenue read: ''Going Out of Business - Building Coming Down.'' Much later, the perpetual clearance sale was still on. Then recently, behind rising scaffolding, a new sign was tacked up: ''Last Two Days.'' In two days the store closed. The building is coming down.

title: Bridgeport's Incubator for Business Succeeds
description: LEAD: WHEN Andy Pandiani and two of his classmates in the industrial design program at the University of Bridgeport decided to go into business for themselves after graduation it looked a little like a pipe dream.

title: Wine Makers Are Reporting A Good Crop
description: NEW JERSEY'S September grape harvest is in full swing, and wineries are reporting good crops.

title: Miss Gaynor Wed To John Minden
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Helena Gaynor to John Andrew Caputineanu Minden, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Caputineanu Minden of New York, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Schoonover Gaynor, the bride's parents, in Southport, Conn. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Lesson for Parents: Knowing When to Let Them Go
description: ''YOU can't put your head on your daughter's shoulders!''

title: A Perverse, Witty, Sadomasochistic Universe
description: The paintings of Alan Turner may not seem to be rooted in this postmodern decade but they are. Certainly they have a traditional feel to them. They are very much paintings, attuned to questions of composition, surface and form; they involve the human figure, and they depend upon Abstract Expressionism and Surrealism.

title: POSTINGS: Empty-Nester Condos; No More Mowing
description: For the buyer whose empty nest must still hold a brood of furniture, a Stamford, Conn., project offers condomium houses. A $285-to-$325 monthly common charge replaces weekend weed pulling and gutter cleaning, but, unlike a line of town houses or a stack of apartments, large - 3,000 to 3,400 square feet - single-family homes give this condominium cluster a subdivision look. Its market, said Dennis C. Lyndon, one of the developers, is ''people whose children have gone to college or moved out, but they want to have their family come back.''

title: Albany Notes; Naming of Battery Park City Head Expected
description: After several weeks of pondering, Governor Cuomo is expected this week to name David Emil, a deputy commissioner at the state's Social Services Department, as president of the Battery Park City Authority.

title: Persians and Arabs Divided by Same Waterway for Millenniums
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SPICE ROUTE
description: You are sitting in a taverna surrounded by cobblestone streets, pastel-colored houses and Baroque churches, sipping a copito or two of port or vinho verde. The warm breezes are scented with sweet cinnamon and saffron, turmeric and soy.

title: INSIDE
description: Plane Factory Mystery

title: New York State's Lottery Has Reached the Point of Lunacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Illness at Military Plant: Mystery in Secret Work
description: At least 160 manufacturing workers at a Lockheed Corporation plant here, many of whom are believed to be involved in building a top-secret fighter, have become sick, spawning a whirlwind of questions that begin with the materials used in the plant.

title: Finding The Real Thing In Seoul
description: LEAD: ALONG with Singapore, Taiwan and Thailand, South Korea is one of the four capitalist Asian bastions that have been termed miracle economies. South Korea now plays a central role in Asian commerce as well as culture. It is rich in history, yet increasingly modern, progressive and bustling.

title: Carole Kennedy Weds
description: At St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J., Carole Anne Kennedy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan J. Kennedy of Tenafly and Sea Girt, N.J., was married yesterday to Brian T. Jones, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald T. Jones of New Hyde Park, L.I. The Rev. John Magdziak performed the ceremony. Mrs. Jones is a national sales manager for the Hilton Hotels Corporation in New York. Her husband is the assistant director of sales at the Capital Hilton Hotel in Washington.

title: Men's Fashions Of The Times/Magazine Part 2
description: * Clothes that capture the drama and dash of old Hollywood.

title: Prospects; A Shrinking Trade Gap?
description: When the Commerce Department released the trade figures for July last week, imports showed an unexpectedly large 8.9 percent drop from the previous month. The overall deficit, $9.5 billion, also showed improvement over June's dismal showing of $13.2 billion. Do July's gains signal a closing of the trade gap? Shiniji Sasaki General manager and senior economist, Yamaichi Research Institute, Tokyo.

title:
ART;
Spotlight Falls on Wall
description: LEAD: A SHINGLED exterior wall is a wall is a wall, except when it is covered with a painting by Jimmy Ernst, the noted Abstract artist who died in 1984.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: The Umbrella of Innocence

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They talk about the Pledge of Allegiance in the schools but not about whether kids are really learning to read and write.'' - Frank Kinney, a Hoboken voter. [ 30:3. ]

title: THE GREAT AMERICAN ORIGINALS
description: Fall 1988 marks the coming of age of the American look, an eminently easygoing style whose roots - and influence - stretch across the Atlantic. A timelessness and a graceful nonchalance define this home-grown way of dressing. Western boots, a chambray work shirt or, on a more formal note, a three-button suit worn with cordovan brogues are a few of the badges of Yankee style updated for this season.

title: Richard Pena Charts The Film Festival's Course
description: LEAD: WHEN THE LIGHTS came up after a recent screening of ''Die Hard,'' the extravagantly violent thriller starring Bruce Willis, Richard Pena turned to a companion and remarked, ''It wasn't as bloody as I had expected.''

title: Kurds Can't Go Home Again Because the Homes Are Gone
description: From a low-flying helicopter, the systematic leveling of Kurdish Iraq becomes evident.

title: Time for Golf At A&M
description: University of Alabama officials postponed the game with Texas A&M today because of the threat of Hurricane Gilbert, but golfers nevertheless crowded the Aggies' golf course.

title: Our Perfect Island Is Becoming Less Than It Should Be
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by John O'Brien, chairman of the Grumman Corporation, to the Long Island Association. Awhile ago, someone gave me a book by W. D. Wetherell called ''The Man Who Loved Levittown.'' It's a terrific story. It's fiction. But most of us probably know someone just like the main character. His name is Tommy Dimaria and he's a young man just back from World War II. He lives with his wife and children in his parents' crowded apartment in Brooklyn, and he wants a better life. So he takes his father-in-law's car out from Brooklyn, and by the end of the day he has a job at Grumman and he's given Big Bill Levitt an $83 deposit on a brand new house. He stands in an open field, watching houses go up around him. He has escaped from Brooklyn and found an island of opportunity. There's so much clean air and open space. He swears he can see waves breaking on the rocks at Montauk.

title: POSTINGS: Warehouse Conversion; Bulk With Style
description: A 35-unit condominium nearing completion in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn, is nearly twice as large as zoning allows. But the case will not go to court. The new apartment house, called Gardenia Plaza, is being formed in a 34,600-square-foot warehouse shell at 93 Underhill Avenue and St. Marks Place that was built in 1902 before such a structure would be limited to about 19,000 square feet.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: SUMMERFIELD UNITED METHODIST CHURCH;
Parishoners Return for ''Homecoming''
description: LEAD: EVELYN LEWIS was on the cradle roll at the Summerfield United Methodist Church here. ''That was what they called the beginning of Sunday school - cradle roll,'' she recalled recently. ''I was only 1 year old - didn't attend classes - but my name was on a list.''

title: Radon Alert: The E.P.A. Goes After The Carcinogen That Nature Made
description: WE have met yet another environmental enemy, the Government warned last week, but, for once, he is not us.

title: An Arab Voice in Israel
description: THE NOVELIST IN ISRAEL HAS COME TO ASSUME a large and even crucial role, looked to as chronicler, sage and seer; and as we drove along the highway from Ben-Gurion International Airport to Jerusalem, Anton Shammas was beginning to talk about this - hesitantly, at my prompting, a thought here and there.

title: Court Suit Challenges Plastic Ban
description: LEAD: WHEN the Suffolk County Legislature voted in March to ban the use of certain types of plastic food containers by retail food establishments, supporters called the measure a bold step toward environmental protection.

title: Israelis Said to Kill 2 Arabs In Clashes in Occupied Areas
description: Israeli troops killed two Arabs and wounded dozens more in clashes in the occupied territories today, the sixth anniversary of the killing of several hundred Palestinians in Lebanese refugee districts. At least 40 Palestinians were wounded, most of them in the West Bank, where Israeli forces raided villages and refugee areas and arrested 200 poeple, security officials said.

title: A Low-Income Housing Site, 15 Years Later
description: DESPITE the opposition of 700 irate residents at the first public hearing, 15 years ago Greenburgh changed its zoning and created public housing for low-income families, scattering 100 units on six sites in the town.

title: Witness Rebuts Davis on Drug Deals With Police
description: A convicted felon and former associate of Larry Davis testified for the prosecution at the Davis trial last week that, to his knowledge, the defendant had never dealt in drugs with police officers.

title: Company to Extend Health Coverage to AIDS
description: The Circle K Corporation has canceled a plan to limit medical care coverage for employees who contracted AIDS or suffered from drug or alcohol abuse.

title: AIDS in School: Districts Set Policy
description: RECOGNIZING the public concern over the spread of AIDS, many Long Island school districts have adopted policies to regulate the admission of students and the employment of staff who have AIDS, AIDS-related complex (ARC) or confirmed presence of the HIV (human immuno-deficiency) antibody.

title: Military Programs of Candidates Mean Cuts Despite the Tough Talk
description: While Vice President Bush and Michael S. Dukakis continually argue over just which weapons to add to the nation's arsenal, there has been little direct debate over the cuts in other military programs that would be required under their budgetary promises. Mr. Dukakis usually talks about making some cuts; Mr. Bush hardly ever does.

title: U.S. Off to Moderate Start As 5 Advance but 3 Don't
description: Janet Evans and Matt Biondi swam well and said they felt comfortable. Troy Dalbey did what he had to do. Otherwise, the United States had a shaky day as swimming competition began in the Games of the XXIV Olympiad.

title: Unattractive Traits Overgeneralized
description: Ms. Gass's article made for very interesting reading. While I do believe that some of her feelings are justified, I also feel she has overgeneralized some unattractive traits of an attractive community. Assuming economic levels are relative, does a place exist that is void of the shallow, materialistic individual? Ms. Gass gave the impression that her community doesn't have a sincere, caring, polite or generous person in its population. Fortunately, I know first hand that's not true.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Infant Organ Plan Ends; Brief Lives, Large Questions
description: LAST October, at the Loma Linda University Medical Center in California, Dr. Leonard L. Bailey transplanted the heart of a Canadian infant, known as Baby Gabrielle, into the chest of another Canadian baby. Baby Gabrielle was anencephalic, born without the part of the brain responsible for consciousness, memory and thought, and doomed to a quick death.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
From Olympic Dream to Athletic Afterlife
description: LEAD: Three days after my 16th birthday, I packed my bags and moved from my home in Kentucky to California to pursue a dream of competing in an Olympic Games. The dream was born when I was a young gymnast, intently watching Cathy Rigby in the 1968 Mexico City Games. My gymnastics career ended prematurely at the age 12, but it was soon replaced by diving.

title: WE ARE WHAT WE READ
description: A HISTORY OF NEWS From the Drum to the Satellite. By Mitchell Stephens. Illustrated. 401 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We have the best of both worlds. There is lessened concern that the economy is on the verge of overheating.'' - Gary E. Schlossberg, economist, Wells Fargo Bank, reacting to the trade data.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Newport, R.I.; Sheltering The Homeless
description: A COALITION of church and civic leaders is converting a former Y.M.C.A. in the heart of the tourist district as a shelter for the homeless and other needy people.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: NEW CHAMBER SERIES As far as Bruce Adolphe is concerned, there is never enough chamber music. And since Mr. Adolphe, a composer who teaches at the Juilliard School and New York University, is also the music director of the Unitarian Universalist Church of Central Nassau in Garden City, he has the chance to practice what he preaches.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Men's Basketball; SCHMIDT IN FINE FORM AS BRAZIL BEATS CANADA
description: More than a year has passed, but the repercussions are still being felt. When the United States men's basketball team is not answering questions about the Soviet Union, talk invariably centers on a 6-foot-8-inch Brazilian folk hero who played a major role in leading his team to the second-biggest upset in the history of the amateur game. Sometimes, it seems as if the Olympic basketball competition is being waged among 11 countries and a player known as Oscar.

title:
GARDENING;
Bonsai: Some Sources for the Timid
description: LEAD: HORTICULTURE has been described as a blend of art and science, but providing for the needs of plants in a house or garden has become increasingly technical.

title: FICTION
description: KINGDOM'S END AND OTHER STORIES. By Saadat Hasan Manto. Translated by Khalid Hasan. (Verso/Routledge, $18.95.) Saadat Hasan Manto never lived to see his work translated; given the quality of this English edition, he was probably lucky. Born a Moslem in the Punjab region of India, Manto was forced by the violence that accompanied partition to leave for Pakistan, where he died in 1955 at the age of 43. His fiction, written in Urdu, has since maintained a large following throughout the subcontinent. Most of the stories in this collection protest communal and sectarian hatred. (In ''The Dog of Titwal,'' for example, a stray mutt wanders between warring Pakistani and Indian troops. When each side discovers that the other has been caring for the animal, the dog, like the civilian population, comes under fire from both armies.) In making Manto's work available to English readers for the first time, Khalid Hasan has rendered it into wooden, obscure prose that is studded with anachronisms. But even after this is taken into account, Western readers accustomed to sharply focused plots and economy of literary effect are likely to find Manto's stories amateurish and predictable.

title: Hit the Worst, Yucatan Begins a Long Cleanup
description: Nowhere along Hurricane Gilbert's path of destruction did the storm hit with greater force and fury than here in the Yucatan. When it made its first landfall around dawn on Wednesday, it was with sustained winds of 180 miles an hour as well as gusts of wind measured at 218 miles an hour and waves of 23 feet or more.

title: A Small 'Dreamgirls' On Stage in Elmsford
description: AS much a technological marvel as a theatrical miracle, ''Dreamgirls,'' as conceived by Michael Bennett, can hardly be contained on an ordinary stage.

title: The Joys of the Beach in Autumn
description: RESEARCH on the autumn beach begins for me on Aug. 31 and continues on into October. On a typical day in the fall there might be cirrostratus clouds overhead, all streaked and fine, with lumpy little cumulus clouds clumped on the horizon.

title: GEORGE BERNARD SHAW, CUB REVIEWER
description: The Pall Mall Gazette was the center of what Matthew Arnold called ''the New Journalism.'' It was edited by W. T. Stead, who used the paper to produce an emotional bond between himself and the public. Together with Frank Harris, who edited The Evening News, Stead altered the character of daily journalism in Britain during the mid-1880's. Papers became simpler - as he wished the world to be. He popularized interviews, added illustrations, invented picturesque headlines, pursued virtuous crusades. ''All his indignations did him credit,'' Shaw affirmed; but his ''infatuation with his own emotions'' made him deeply untrustworthy. His emotions were sacred to him. When he was angry it was obvious to him that everyone shared his anger; when he wept, he took it for granted that the world wept with him. People read his paper to find out what on earth he was up to next. One day he would drop in on General Gordon at Southampton and call for him to be sent to Khartoum; next he was warning Gladstone against declaring war on Russia; then, switching his energies elsewhere, he fell strongly behind Mrs. Gordon-Baillie's scheme for establishing fishing settlements in Tasmania for Scottish crofters; and, most extraordinary of all, as part of his campaign against London vice, he had procured five virgins for seduction and landed himself in prison.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: Root of All Evil By Robert Neidhardt Jove Books. 278 Pages. $3.95, paperback.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LAST MAN OUT. By H. Robert Charles. (Eakin Press, $16.95.) In the personal narratives treating World War II, events in Southeast Asia have provoked much less attention than have activities in the European or Mediterranean theaters. This unassuming little memoir by a Michigan journalist who was held prisoner by the Japanese offers a stimulating change of locale.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Emeryville, Calif.;
A Tiny Town Coming of Age
description: LEAD: LAST July this tiny industrial town of 5,000 residents between Oakland and Berkeley, at the eastern approach to the Oakland-San Francisco Bay Bridge, approved plans by the Chiron Corporation, one of the nation's largest biotechnology companies, to build a 247,000-square-foot manufacturing and research plant adjacent to its existing headquarters.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Drug Violators Be Paid for Time Away?
description: ''As ye sow so shall ye reap.''

title: Moscow's Still Holding
description: INSIDE A WINDOWLESS ROOM in the heart of the Pentagon, a set of antiquated encryption/decryption machines suddenly start to percolate. The whir prompts a gray-haired Army colonel to glance up at three oversize digital clocks labeled ''ZULU'' (Greenwich mean time), and, in Russian, ''WASHINGTON'' and ''MOSCOW.'' It's 10:57 A.M., Eastern Standard Time. ''That's Ivan's 'call-up' coming in just before the hour,'' says Col. Donald L. Siebenaler. The hot line - Washington's 24-hour electronic link to Moscow - is being tested, as it has been every hour of every day since it was inaugurated 25 years ago.

title: Wrong Button
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Ivy League; Princeton Stops Cornell by 26-17
description: Greg DiFelice rushed for two touchdowns and Princeton's defense accounted for 9 points this afternoon as the Tigers defeated Cornell, 26-17, in the season opener for both teams.

title: SUMMER 1988; Looking Back, With Some Dismay
description: SUMMER 1988. What a dud. In the county we expected (because of past experiences) no spring - and got none. We did, however, expect a summer - and got Hell instead.

title: Fearless Fighter
description: The way the British boxer, Frank Bruno, now sees it, he no longer has any reason to fear Mike Tyson.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: McKeesport, Pa.;
Big Mill Sites Go Public
description: LEAD: THE nation's largest transfer of industrial property to local government for redevelopment has taken place at two sites on the Monongahela River about 10 miles southeast of Pittsburgh, in the Allegheny County communities of McKeesport and Duquesne.

title: Player Ends Career
description: Before deciding to play football this season, Chris Thorpe checked with three medical specialists. That's because Thorpe, a 21-year-old senior safety for Penn State who had missed the 1986 season with a severe neck injury, wanted to make sure he would be at no special risk this year even though he had played in nine games last season.

title: 'Gone With Wind' And a New Battle
description: MARGARET MITCHELL called it ''the dump'' - a Victorian-style building in Atlanta where she lived in a basement apartment from 1926 to 1932 and wrote ''Gone With the Wind.'' In January, when a developer sought a permit to demolish the building as an eyesore, Mayor Andrew Young declined to approve it.

title: Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: A Voice From Yellowstone; 'Neither Fire Suppression Nor Natural Burn Is A Sound Scientific Option'
description: NOW that cool, damp weather has thankfully come to Yellowstone, the giant fires raging out of control in and around the park during the last several months have finally slowed. And although no one knows when the blazes - which have already consumed 1.5 million acres - will finally be extinguished, the political debate over wildfire policy has already begun.

title: Tax Shortfall Brings Search of U.S. Rules
description: AS Connecticut's state agencies tighten their belts to live within new budget constraints ordered by Governor O'Neill, state fiscal officers are searching the Federal tax code for some possible explanations of why tax revenue is not flowing to Hartford as fast as expected.

title: Town Survives Without a Company
description: Gary Buealmont was a company man in a company town. An eight-year veteran of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plant in this Connecticut River Valley town, he had a good job at good wages. He expected to work there forever.

title: Reclaiming Taiwan
description: TWO PLACES IN TAIPEI lend themselves perfectly to contemplation of the split personality of modern Taiwan: the National Palace Museum and a night market cum red light district known as Snake Alley.

title: Gem Collecting
description: To the Editor: In response to B. R. of Brooklyn (Q & A, July 10) requesting information on tours for gem collecting:

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: East; Pitt Overwhelms Ohio State, 42-10
description: Adam Walker ran for 179 yards and 3 touchdowns, scoring twice in the first six minutes of play following Ohio State mistakes, as Pitt routed the Buckeyes, 42-10, tonight.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Suffolk Weighs Home-Buying Safeguards
description: LEAD: A BILL approved last month by the New York State Legislature, which requires builders to provide a graduated six-year warranty on the structure and mechanical systems of a new house, does not go far enough in protecting home buyers, Suffolk County officials say.

title: Mother-Daughter Time at a Women's Prison
description: Margaret Nathaniel, 10 years old, helped her mother stock their gray tent with sleeping bags, thin mattresses and a cooler. They worked in a steady rain.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BALLADEER OF SENEGAL Much like Europe's medieval troubadors, Djimo Kouyate - a griot, or balladeer, from Senegal - translates the history, foibles, politics and cultural traditions of West Africa into music, dance and storytelling. He will give a free performance at 3 P.M. today in the Yale University Art Gallery as part of the gallery's Celebration of African Art and Culture exhibition.

title: When Reality Begins to Look a Little Unreal
description: NOTHING HAS MORE SIZZLE ON television these days than ''reality.'' Don't bother asking for a coherent definition. Television's reality formats include everything from the nightly news to talk shows to ''based on fact'' movies to the Summer Olympics to Phil, Oprah and Geraldo. The only productions definitely not admitted under the reality umbrella are sitcoms and action-adventures. The studios have to concede that these are generally fictions, requiring scripts and, if the budget and talent allow, skill and imagination. Little wonder that during the long writers' strike earlier this year, network and studio executives were talking more rhapsodically than ever about reality formats in which the role of writers would be relatively insignificant.

title: Susan Etterbeek Weds
description: Susan Beth Etterbeek, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Etterbeek of Midland Park, N.J., and Carl Robert Soderlind, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Karl Soderlind of Duluth, Minn., were married yesterday at the Preakness Reformed Church in Wayne, N.J., by the Rev. Timothy Mulder. Mrs. Soderlind is a purchasing agent and her husband the vice president of corporate communications and investor relations for the Witco Corporation, a chemical and engineering products concern in New York. The bridegroom's previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Remembering the Hurricane of '38
description: THE rain was still pouring down - for the fifth straight day - as I awoke on that morning of Wednesday, Sept. 21, 1938. Soon after reaching my office at the phone company's state headquarters in New Haven, a group of us gathered to consider problems that might lie ahead.

title: Sarah Lindsley and John Mattes Marry
description: The marriage of Sarah Elliott Lindsley, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. James E. Lindsley of Germantown, N.Y., and Castine, Me., to John Baxter Mattes, a son of Mrs. Edward C. Mattes of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and the late Mr. Mattes, took place yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Tivoli, N.Y. The bride's father, the rector of St. Paul's, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Ledlie I. Laughlin Jr. Alice Todd Lindsley was her sister's maid of honor, and Edward Charles Mattes Jr. was his brother's best man.

title: Judge, Under Inquiries, Is to Forgo Renomination
description: Justice Louis Fusco Jr. of State Supreme Court, the subject of investigation by two agencies, will not seek renomination, according to Bronx Democratic leaders.

title: Firehouse At School Protested
description: LEAD: THE petitions have been circulating since mid-August, one manifestation of a growing controvery over a recent proposal by the East Northport Fire Department to build an unmanned fire and ambulance substation on the grounds of the Dickinson Avenue elementary school.

title: HAIR-RAZING
description: IT WAS ONE OF THOSE DAYS - fractious throughout, satisfaction in short supply. If I'd had enough money, a new suit might have mollified the mopes. I didn't, so I shaved off my beard. Less is sometimes more.

title: ADRIFT IN THE GULAG ARCHIPELAGO
description: SEVEN THOUSAND DAYS IN SIBERIA By Karlo Stajner. Translated by Joel Agee. Introduction by Danilo Kis. 400 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: Remedy for a Rigid Rule
description: Sense, not sentiment, moved organized baseball to change the rule that barred Fred Lynn, recently traded to the Detroit Tigers, from postseason play because he joined the team a few minutes past the deadline of midnight Aug. 31.

title: Colleen Campbell Weds
description: At St. Theresa's Roman Catholic Church in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., Colleen Campbell, a daughter of Mrs. Arnold L. Windman of Briarcliff Manor and the late Joseph P. Campbell, was married yesterday to Terrence Peter Yanni, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Yanni of Briarcliff Manor. The Rev. Richard J. Kehoe, an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: BASEBALL: American League; A's Defeat Royals; Magic Number Is 4
description: Terry Steinbach hit a two-run homer and four Oakland pitchers combined on a seven-hitter today as the Athletics defeated the Kansas City Royals, 3-2. Any combination of four Oakland victories and Minnesota losses will clinch the American League West division title for the Athletics, who lead the Twins by 10 1/2 games.

title: Lingering Questions on Iran-Contra May Arise in Court - Or May Not
description: NEARLY two years after a Sandinista missile downed a cargo plane and detonated the Iran-contra affair, doubts continue to linger about whether the full story has emerged.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
>Australian Academe
description: LEAD: Student interest in Australia, partly sparked by Australian films, was among the reasons Marymount College in Tarrytown embarked upon its new Study Abroad Program in Australia.

title: Brian C. Cook Marries Miss Rand on Potomac
description: Felicia Alexandra Thornhill Rand, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford A. Rand of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Brian Corey Cook, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Chester Cook of Vienna, Va. Capt. Clayton Cisar officiated aboard the Cherry Blossom, a Potomac riverboat docked at Alexandria, Va.

title: Linda Tilghman, A Teacher, Wed To Peter Murphy
description: Linda Slocum Tilghman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Tilghman of Fairfield, Conn., and New York, was married yesterday to Peter Emmons Murphy, a son of Dorothy Carr Linicus of Boise, Idaho, and Jonathan F. Murphy of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund, assisted by the bride's uncle, the Rev. Henry A. Tilghman, performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

title: Campaign Focuses on Spano's Record
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH there is an incumbent in office and the candidates expect to spend far less than was spent in the last campaign, the race for State Senate in the 35th District promises to be as hotly contested as it was two years ago.

title: A Duel of Jockeys
description: They could have called it ''Age Against Youth,'' or just maybe, ''Beauty and the Beast,'' but to the officials at Canterbury Downs in Shakopee, Minn., the ''Duel of the Downs,'' match race scheduled for Sunday, Oct. 2, is nothing less than a battle of the sexes.

title: Company Measures World of Options
description: FIFTY-TWO years ago, the Roper Organization, a young and little-known research firm, gained national recognition overnight by accurately forecasting President Franklin D. Roosevelt's victory in the 1936 Presidential election.

title: Changes and Dues
description: 'President Reagan has determined that the United Nations has reformed its operations to the point he can release the United States funding for that institution . . . The U.N. is directly serving important long-term objectives of this Administration to end regional conflicts and advance peace and freedom around the world. The Presidential action makes it clear that the United States is prepared to meet its obligations in support of these peace-keeping efforts. We have seen in the last six months some important reforms in terms of the budget and hiring practices, and so forth, and so that has been a determining factor.' - Marlin Fitzwater, White House spokesman, on President Reagan's decision last week to authorize the release of some overdue United States payments to the United Nations.

title: MR. EURIPIDES GOES TO WASHINGTON
description: People often talk wishfully of establishing a ''national theater'' in the United States, but they aren't always clear what that cultural incantation means. Do they have in mind some grand metropolitan institution, an American counterpart of Britain's National Theater or France's Comedie Francaise or Sweden's Royal Dramatic Theater, rooted at Lincoln Center or even the Kennedy Center? Or could they more subtly and perceptively be thinking of a federation of companies that actually traverse the nation, bringing drama to professors and pig farmers alike? If the latter, then America has already had and lost it. Between 1936 and 1939 some 10,000 people gave more than 60,000 performances of over 1,200 plays, old and new, conventional and experimental, to almost 30 million spectators in 40 states - all under the auspices of the Federal Theater Project. For that brief period there flourished the most authentically national theater the globe has yet seen.

title: New Yorkers Destroy As They 'Discover'
description: A spate of articles and editorials in The New York Times prompts this reply. Recently The Times has editorialized in favor of the Iroquois pipeline project, reported on the zoning confrontation over a cheesemaking operation in the town of Sherman, carried the announcement that Danbury and its surrounding area was deemed the No. 1 area in which to live in the United States, reported on Candlewood Lake and the traffic problem in this area and interviewed the owner of a new gallery in Kent.

title: Correct View On Taylor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FICTION
description: HIS VISION OF HER. By G. D. Dess. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) To the glut of enervated first novels set in downtown Manhattan, G. D. Dess has provided a tonic voice of irony. His hero, Stephen - idiosyncratic, vaguely misanthropic, bisexual - becomes obsessed with Gilberte, a manipulative and ambitious young photographer. But when Stephen secures a position for Gilberte at the SoHo bookstore where he works as manager, she proceeds to have a professionally expedient affair with the shop owner's wife. In compulsive detail, Stephen recounts Gilberte's rise to ingenue art star, deconstructing her every strategy and motive and examining his own role as artistic conscience, lover and collaborator. Through this sardonic and cerebral confession, Mr. Dess considers art and authenticity, love and exploitation, appearance and reality. Ultimately, Stephen comes to believe that both love and art in their purest forms should involve honesty, sacrifice and the gut-wrench of recognition that makes visceral communication possible. If, like his narrator, Mr. Dess harbors such impeccable esthetic ideals, then he has written a novel worthy of his own standards. Like the Picabia painting on its cover, ''His Vision of Her'' is a palimpsest: expressive but tantalizingly elusive. Its characters emerge and retreat, their images distorted by the narrator's edited perspective or their own self-presentations. It is a tribute to Mr. Dess's technical precision and to his compassion that, even through the medium of Stephen's rarified vision of Gilberte, we get an indelible and poignant vision of them both.

title: Card-Carrying Smears
description: Even in a negative campaign for President, one topic that ought to be off-limits is questioning an opponent's loyalty to country. The Bush-Quayle campaign has been operating close to the borderline of decency in its carping about the flag and the American Civil Liberties Union. That such techniques may be working, at least temporarily, does not dignify them.

title: 16 Million Jobs in Eight Years Seems Best We Can Do
description: To the Editor:

title: In Hong Kong, Early Tea And Strategy
description: THERE'S a lot to do in Hong Kong besides eat, but perhaps nothing so worthy of attention, so all-consuming, nothing that offers as great a share of its everyday life. The lure of the five- or six-course lunch, followed after a decent interval by a 10-course banquet in the evening, calls for a breakfast strategy. You might be tempted to have that meal in your hotel. But a breakfast I had at the Peninsula during a recent visit was off-putting: bland porridge, chewy smoked haddock and a heavy brioche.

title: Medical Care Is Poor Public Policy
description: There are 37 million Americans uninsured for health care. Two-thirds of them are working, or are dependents of those who work. About 19 percent of all children under the age of 18 are not covered by health insurance. In addition, an estimated 2 million people suffer from pre-existing or excluded conditions that preclude them from coverage, regardless of their employment or income status. Then there are many millions who are simply underinsured. Our inability to forge a universal system for insurance to manage health care for these millions is bad social and economic policy.

title: CRIME
description: Grace Stark should never have put up the $30,000 bond for that cocaine dealer. What does a 52-year-old suburban housewife from western Massachusetts know about the bail bond business anyway? She's only supposed to be minding the store until her husband, Phil, a professional bondsman who has filed for Chapter 11, can make good on some forfeits and get his license back. Nevertheless, in a rush of rapacity that might better have been directed at improving her mah-jongg game, Grace puts up bond. And wouldn't you know, the deadbeat skips.

title: Lessons the Military Learns, With a Sense of Urgency
description: EARLIER this month the Navy began installing additional radios on ships in the Persian Gulf to enable them to monitor more civilian transmissions in the region. Only one of those radios was on board the American cruiser Vincennes on July 3, and it was not being used to monitor transmissions between an Iranian airliner and its control tower before the crew mistook the passenger plane for an F-14 fighter and shot it down, killing 290 people.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the official certification of Carlos Salinas de Gortari as Mexico's President-elect misidentified a group that jeered President Miguel de la Madrid during his State of the Nation address. The hecklers were from the National Democratic Front, which ran Cuauhtemoc Cardenas for President; they were not from the National Action Party of Manuel Clouthier.

title: In Bangladesh, Too Much Water and Not Enough
description: With two jerrycans in hand, Muklesha Khatun waited impatiently for about four hours for the water trucks to arrive, and finally took home her allotted daily quota, two gallons.

title: Meaning and Entropy To the Editor
description: Reviewing Robert Wright's ''Three Scientists and Their Gods: Looking for Meaning in an Age of Information'' (Aug. 7), George Johnson refers to the information theory of Claude Shannon as an entry into the search for meaning behind the book: '' [ Mr. Shannon's ] suggestion that information is the opposite of entropy - the principle that can explain why there are islands of order in a universe doomed to increasing randomness by the second law of thermodynamics - caught the imagination of theologians and philosophers.''

title: University Chiefs Urge Disarmament Studies
description: Forty-five university presidents from around the world have adopted a resolution to develop common curriculums on disarmament and the theory and practice of international conflict management in their universities.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bluepoint $157,000 373 Second Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 26-year-old Cape Cod; basement, fireplace, patio; taxes $2,400. Kings Park $265,000 4 Mountain Laurel Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; den, basement and a 2-car garage; taxes $5,800. Levittown $145,000 16 Sugar Maple Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 39-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,200. Riverhead $163,000 124 Roanoke Avenue 6-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 60-year-old center-hall colonial; dining room, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,000. Southold $160,000 Waters Edge Way 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old ranch; fireplace, family room, attached 1-car garage; taxes $1,600. Wantagh $150,000 20 Deer Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 37-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, covered patio, carport; taxes $2,300. OTHER AREAS Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $352,500 59 Apple Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old colonial; fireplace, study, walk to transportation and shopping; taxes $5,592. Westport, Conn. $365,000 44 Oak Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old raised ranch; large country kitchen, screened porch, 1/2 acre; taxes $2,337. Springfield, N.J. $439,000 587 Ashwood Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old contemporary; 2-zone heating, deck, central air-conditioning; taxes $5,752.

title: Q and A
description: West Germany

title: Court Orders Trial for Columnist in Shooting of a Teen-Ager
description: A Superior Court judge refused Friday to dismiss weapon charges against the syndicated columnist Carl T. Rowan, ruling that Mr. Rowan was not authorized to own a pistol he used to wound a teen-ager who was trespassing in his backyard.

title: Gary Martin Wed To Miss McIntyre
description: Martha Cheswell McIntyre, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John William McIntyre of Atlanta, was married there yesterday to Gary Bradford Martin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Parker Martin of Winnetka, Ill. The Rev. Thomas Conley performed the ceremony at the Northside Drive Baptist Church.

title: Definitive Post-Mortem
description: SIMPLE suit combinations can generate complex post-mortem discussions. Cover the East-West hands on the diagramed deal and study the heart suit. How do you play, in the abstract, if you can afford one loser? Would you make that play in six hearts after an opening lead of the spade ten?

title: Barbara Johnson Becomes a Bride
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. Andrew in Marblehead, Mass., Barbara Stuart Johnson, a daughter of Mrs. H. Alden Johnson Jr. of Marblehead and the late Mr. Johnson, was married yesterday to Roderick Whipple Fletcher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey Fletcher of Durham, N.C. The Rev. Howard W. Gamble performed the ceremony.

title: Sympathy for O'Malley
description: To the Editor:

title: Alan Vaskas Married To Janet McClendon
description: The marriage of Janet Stewart McClendon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Stewart McClendon of New York and Stonington, Conn., to Alan V. Vaskas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albin Vaskas of Houston, took place yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Revs. Bryant M. Kirkland and Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony.

title: Correction
description: A column entry on Sept. 4 in ''This Week in Connecticut'' gave an incorrect closing date for a show of watercolors by Dennis Hanceri at the Guthman Galleries in Southport. It will continue through Sept. 30.

title: J. D. Eggert Wed To Cornelia Read
description: The wedding of Cornelia Ludlam Fabyan Read, a daughter of Deborah Smith of Centre Island, L.I., and Frederick H. Read of Malibu, Calif., to James Douglas Eggert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Eggert of East Syracuse, N.Y., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. Thurston H. Smith, in Centre Island. The Rev. David A. Owen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article Sept. 4 on the Presidential campaign gave an incorrect affiliation for Professor Samuel Popkin. He is at the University of California at San Diego, not the University of San Diego.

title: New Hand at the Housing Agency Helm
description: When Governor Cuomo announced the departure of his beleagured Housing Commissioner, William B. Eimicke, last month, the resignation was widely expected. Mr. Eimicke had been involved in embarrassing flaps over inflated housing production numbers and the inadequacy of his department's handling of the rent regulation system.

title: THE WORLD: Mexico Divided; Salinas Steps Up With Resolve And Insecurity
description: AFTER a two-month political battle that included violent confrontations in Congress and demonstrations that brought hundreds of thousands of protesters into the streets, Carlos Salinas de Gortari was officially certified as Mexico's President-elect last weekend, assuring his inauguration on Dec. 1. What comes next will only be more difficult.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THERE is a smell that the woods have in late summer. I suppose it's a combination of many different smells, but I can separate only a few. The main ingredient is the hard-baked-earth smell of summer that has supplanted the rich-earth smell of May. It smells like fired clay, like dirt roads polished by too many feet, like parched earth and the despair of plants.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Drug Violators Be Paid for Time Away?
description: You're joking? ROCCO ST. ANN Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Audio Goes By the Numbers
description: AUDIO IS PROBABLY THE only field in which it is always safe to believe what you hear. Playing it by ear, so to speak, is what audio is all about, and casual listeners rarely go beyond that. But those who hope to evaluate sound equipment with real critical discernment need more than ephemeral impressions as a basis for judgment. They find it helpful to have things spelled out in black and white in the form of numbers and graphs.

title: Licensing of Home Repair Contractors Faces Review
description: LEAD: SUPPORTERS of a 17-month-old law that makes it illegal for home-improvement contractors to work in the county without a license say the law has given consumers needed protections but skeptics maintain that it may have caused the opposite result.

title: Sondheim Musical Explores Marriage
description: ''COMPANY,'' the Tony Award-winning musical by Stephen Sondheim and George Furth, is now at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale.

title: The Clumsy Quest for Irving Bank
description: On the evening of May 6, two of Wall Street's leading lights, Eric Gleacher and Martin Lipton, could be found celebrating at a birthday dinner for Mr. Gleacher's wife at Bellini by Cipriani, a fashionable Manhattan restaurant. Festive as the occasion was, the two men found time to do some business. They were on opposite sides of a hostile takeover battle between the Bank of New York Corporation and the Irving Bank Corporation, the first ever to involve two major American banks. Just hours earlier, shareholders had cast their votes for two rival slates of Irving directors, but the results would not be known for several days.

title: PAMPERED IN TOKYO
description: CHILDHOOD YEARS A Memoir. By Junichiro Tanizaki. Translated by Paul McCarthy. Illustrated. 181 pp. New York: Kodansha International. $17.95.

title: Alysheba Wins by a Neck In Duel With Forty Niner
description: Alysheba returned to the scene of his greatest defeat and wore down Forty Niner in a stirring stretch duel yesterday at Belmont Park to win the $831,000 Woodward Handicap by a neck in track-record time.

title: Chain Shows Its Staying Power
description: LEAD: IN the fickle world of fashion, where business can fluctuate with hemlines, Elliot Jaffe's Dress Barns chain has shown its staying power. The chain, which has grown from one store in Connecticut to 354 in 26 states, mostly in the East and Midwest, is celebrating its 26th anniversary this year.

title: Correction
description: An article in The Week in Review on Sept. 4 about mental institutions misidentified the Commissioner of the Texas Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation. He is Dennis R. Jones.

title: Pre-Abstract Expressionist Artist
description: IF Abstract Expressionism was the atom bomb of art, maybe the revival of artists eliminated by the explosion can be likened to the rebirth of the natural environment. In any case, they keep coming, these pre-bomb artists, and, as someone recently remarked to the reviewer, it's as if they, or the historians espousing them, are scurrying to beat the deadline of the century's end.

title: Deborah Morosini and Claudio Lichtenthal Wed
description: Deborah Trenton Morosini, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles J. Morosini of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Jeffersonville, Vt., was married yesterday to Claudio A. Lichtenthal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sigfriedo Lichtenthal of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Alton Wasson performed a Protestant ceremony at the Williams Club in New York.

title: Signs of Slowdown Are Well-Received
description: A slowing of the economic pace seemed to be registered in the week's statistics. Far from being alarmed, most economists welcomed signs that the strong growth of earlier this year, and its potential for inflation, might be easing. The statistics included a two-tenths of 1 percent drop in retail sales in August. Analysts said the August figures were skewed by hot weather that depressed sales of autumn goods and by a 1.8 percent drop in auto sales. They point out that this year Detroit is not offering the generous incentives that caused car sales to surge in previous Augusts . . . Business inventories rose three-tenths of 1 percent in July and business sales were down two-tenths of 1 percent . . . Industrial production was up two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the smallest gain in five months. The capacity utilization rate last month was 83.7 percent, the highest since March 1980, but the gain of one-tenth of 1 percent was attributed to hot-weather output by utilities.

title: POSTINGS: Dissecting a Nassau Mansion; A $10 Million, 10-Year Restoration
description: Hempstead House is falling down. Decay is not visible on the outside, with seemingly immutable granite and limestone walls, or on the inside, with 40 rooms that have served as lavish showcases for prominent designers, but in its crevices, where rain has seeped for 76 years. In summer, water rusted the building's steel frame. In winter, the water froze, expanded and cracked the limestone. Now, Nassau County has begun a 10-year, $10 million restoration, its most ambitious ever, of the Tudor-style mansion in Sands Point.

title: First Liver Transplant in New York Performed
description: The Mount Sinai Medical Center has become the first hospital in New York State to perform a liver transplant. Four other city hospitals are expected to receive state approval soon to perform the operation.

title: Toon Still Jets' Most Valuable Weapon
description: Al Toon spins and leaps, twists and turns in territory where many receivers fear to tread.

title: Renewing the United Nations; A Disposable U.N. Rite
description: For most of this decade, Arab members of the United Nations have made a September ritual of asking the General Assembly to expel Israel. And every year, an increasing U.N. majority disposes of the proposal and hews to the charter's principle of universality. Last year, 80 nations opposed the Arab move, 39 voted aye and 10 abstained.

title: Man Is Charged in the Killing Of Newly Arrived Art Student
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested last night and charged with the murder of a student who was shot to death only days after her arrival at art school in New York City, the police said.

title: THE HAVANA TRAP
description: INSIDER My Hidden Life as a Revolutionary in Cuba. By Jose Luis Llovio-Menendez. Translated by Edith Grossman. Illustrated. 466 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $21.95.

title: Writer Traces Geographic Years
description: CELEBRATING its centennial, the National Geographic Society cooperated with the writer C. D. B. Bryan on a history of the organization and its magazine.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Seven years ago, we built a redwood deck and left it untreated, as we expected it to weather to a uniform gray color. After the first year, the wood darkened with fungus and moss and there was no graying. The deck was scrubbed and a gray deck stain applied, but two years later the wood was again dark with fungus and moss. Is there any way to achieve a stable gray color?

title: Helena Franklin, An Editor, Weds Charles Rozier Jr.
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., Helena Franklin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Franklin of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I., was married yesterday to Charles Preston Rozier Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rozier of Washington. The Rev. William H. Russell performed the ceremony.

title: Victims of Collusion May Get 2d Chance
description: At least some of the 79 players who were free agents after the 1986 season are expected to be granted free agency after the World Series, lawyers familiar with the case said yesterday. An arbitrator has found that the club owners conspired against the 1986 free agents.

title: Lili Ruane Is Married To Michael B. Barrett
description: At the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York, Elizabeth Arnold Ruane, a daughter of William John Ruane of New York and Bethlehem, Conn., and the late Elizabeth A. Ruane, was married yesterday to Michael Briggs Barrett, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman K. Barrett of Berwyn, Pa. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean of the cathedral, performed the ceremony.

title: New Curbs on Check Cashing Urged
description: THE State Commission of Investigation is expected this week to release a report recommending tougher controls over the state's $1 billion a-year check cashing industry.

title: Transient Is Held in Burning of 102 Homes
description: A transient suspected of accidentally igniting a fire that destroyed 102 homes has been charged in the blaze.

title: Suits From Jackets
description: LIZA JERNOW, a 17-year-old high school senior from Armonk, N.Y., spent her summer vacation snipping sharkskin and shantung for her budding clothing line. She is now cutting men's and boy's suit jackets in half to make women's suits: bolero jackets and miniskirts with cummerbunds attached. They are $175 to $275. High-vent dinner-jacket and tulip-hem blazer styles by Ms. Jernow sell to ''ballerinas, actresses and a confident Copacabana crowd,'' said Gina Ghiron, owner of G. Ghiron, a boutique at 102 West 69th Street off Columbus Avenue. A Marine Corps uniform is worn by ''fans of Michael Jackson,'' said Ilene Morgenroth, owner of Infinity, 1116 Madison Avenue at 83d Street. Ms. Jernow's first professional label was sewn onto a lining last fall. But she is no novice. ''My dresses made of Mom's bed sheets were big with my eighth-grade class,'' she said.

title: Teaching the Young About Boating Safety
description: Mothers Against Drunk Driving wishes to commend Assemblywoman Dolores G. Cooper of Atlantic City, who sponsored the new law that requires youths 16 or younger to pass a state-approved boating safety course before they operate motorboats in New Jersey (''New Law Takes Aim at Young Boaters,'' Aug. 21).

title:
The Talk of North Tarrytown;
Historic Village's Business District Seeks a Rebirth
description: LEAD: THIS is a village with a past, and even the young are well-versed in the details. A schoolteacher; a beautiful woman; a jealous suitor, perhaps possessed; a mad midnight chase across a creaky old bridge; and then - nothing but a shattered pumpkin and speculation.

title: Fred D. Thompson Is Dead at 72; Former Ad Executive at The Times
description: Fred D. Thompson, a former vice president of advertising for The New York Times and later the assistant to the president of the Times Company, died of a heart attack yesterday while vacationing in Fort William, Scotland. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Why Olympic Records Fall As Humans Stay the Same
description: THE 1988 Olympic Games began last week with the near certainty that a world record would be broken in at least one event.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Is Gregg Jefferies The Rookie Of the Year?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Rice Grows On the Anacostia

title: Quest for Island-Nation's Judaica
description: LEAD: NOT many people know that Julius Vogel was the first Jewish Prime Minister of New Zealand. Nor is there widespread awareness that the founder of New Zealand's first volunteer fire department was a Jew named Asher Asher.

title: Downward Mobility
description: THE LAST EMPEROR Starring John Lone (in photo), Joan Chen, Peter O'Toole, Ying Ruocheng, Victor Wong, Dennis Dun, Ryuichi Sakamoto, Maggie Han, Lisa Lu, Richard Vuu. Directed by Bernardo Bertolucci. 1987. Nelson Entertainment. 162 minutes. $89.98. Rated PG-13. Some violence, nudity. (Closed captioned.)

title:
ART;
19th-Century Works by America's First Black-American Portraitist
description: LEAD: JOSHUA JOHNSON, a 19th-century black artist, never saw the Mona Lisa, yet the sitters in the 33 portrait paintings by him at the Whitney Museum of American Art's Fairfield County branch in Stamford have her simplicity and her serenity as a rule.

title: Dukakis Asserts Foe Somersaults On Environment
description: Michael S. Dukakis counterattacked today on environmental issues, accusing Vice President Bush of ''more somersaults than an Olympic gymnast'' and of changing his positions as he changes time zones.

title: Sarah Baldwin Marries T. M. Kavanagh
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Nantucket, Mass., Sarah Todd Baldwin, a daughter of Susan E. Baldwin of Watertown, Mass., and Robert H. Baldwin of Andover, Mass., was married yesterday to Terence Michael Kavanagh, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Kavanagh of Halton Hills, Ontario. The Rev. James A. Diamond performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Richard Gross, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Ronald Radosh's Macdonald
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WORLD: Q & A: Izvestia's Legal Expert; A Changing Soviet Approach to Crime and Punishment
description: YURI V. FEOFANOV has written about Soviet legal affairs for Izvestia, the Government newspaper, for 33 years, often criticizing his colleagues in the press for publicly prejudging the outcome of criminal cases. He returned to the theme recently, as Yuri M. Churbanov, the son-in-law of the late Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, went on trial for bribery and corruption days after he had been harshly criticized in an article in Pravda, the Communist Party daily. Mr. Feofanov talked about changes in the Soviet legal system and the press's treatment of trials last week in an interview with Felicity Barringer, who writes for The New York Times from Moscow. Here are excerpts from the interview.

title: Being Exclusive Is Nothing Special
description: I RECENTLY RECEIVED a card from Ireland. It simply said, ''Hello,'' and was not signed. I suspect it was from a man I was once related to by marriage. More than 10 years have passed since my divorce from his cousin. I had met him briefly one night while on a family visit. He wanted me to feel at home in his country. The card was a happy continuation of relations, not all of them fortunate, with people I once viewed with apprehension, even after marriage and a visit among them.

title: Recycling Equipment Is User-Friendly
description: As the manufacturer of the equipment that confronted Charles K. Rockwell on his recycling (mis)adventures a few weeks ago (''Is Modern Recycling Really Progress?'' July 31), I read with interest of his difficulties.

title: The Moscow Blob
description: The State Department's commitment to good architecture for U.S. embassies has raised some beautiful structures in faraway places - they are elegant expressions of America's best. The embassy in New Delhi is the best known, but there are proud examples in Kuala Lumpur, Lisbon and Nicosia, and another is going up right now in Santiago. And then there's Moscow. The bug-ridden new chancery at the embassy in the Soviet capital is not only a security disaster; it's an architectural blob - a block of red brick no grander than New York City's police headquarters, to which it bears striking resemblance. The State Department has not yet decided whether to rip the whole thing down and start again or just rebuild a few floors. Since the cost will run to the tens of millions of dollars either way, why not redo it, and do it right?

title: British Commandos Testify on Gibraltar
description: Hidden behind a brown curtain, a member of Britain's elite Special Air Service regiment, identified only as ''Soldier A,'' testified in clipped tones how he fired five bullets at close range into two Irish Republican Army guerrillas here in March.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Sports of The Times; Up North, a Different Opening Ceremony
description: Across the valley of green rice fields, jarring music clanged from the huge loudspeakers in Kijongdong, the small North Korean village within the DMZ, the demilitarized zone along the 151-mile border. Near the Bridge of No Return on this sunny Saturday morning, Lieut. Jeff Helmick suddenly heard a voice interrupt the music. Quickly, the tall, lean officer from Richmond turned to the South Korean soldier with him.

title: Elise Knight Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Elise Spence Knight, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Townsend Jones Knight of New York and Lloyd Harbor, L.I., to Hugh Campbell Wallace Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace of Greenville, Del., took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: The Hills Are Alive With the Sound of New Music
description: IF NOT EXACTLY TANTAMOUNT to Isaiah's promised reconciliation of wolf and lamb, a concert featuring the Minimalist composer-pianist Philip Glass alongside jazz ensembles like the Max Roach Quartet and the Henry Threadgill Sextet may itself be prophetic.

title: Ode to the Dance
description: NUMBERS 3 and 4, from the Slavonik Dances by Antonin Dvorak.

title: Piggott Avoids Club Suspension
description: Lester Piggott, the jockey jailed for three years last October after a conviction for tax fraud, will not face further penalties from the Jockey Club, the sport's ruling body, the club announced today.

title: FICTION
description: DOCTORS. By Erich Segal. (Bantam, $19.95.) In his literary challenge to television's ''General Hospital,'' Erich (''Love Story'') Segal hits historical high spots from the Spanish Civil War through the women's revolution and throws in every trendy medical issue to make the news since the 1950's. When the story flags, he whips out a last-minute disease to provide a perfunctory climax. And the prose? Some is elaborate. (''While his fellow classmates thought they were in hell, he felt like a purified soul, who in a few brief days would leave this transient purgatory and soar up to be emparadised in Cheryl's arms.'') Some is cliched. (''We're in this together.'') ''Doctors'' is what happens when you fuse a professor of classics and comparative literature with a pop novelist: the idealistic academic prescribes doses of serious issues and major moral dilemmas, while the pragmatic pop novelist wants to get on with it and make this book a hit. The latter hatches characters so fast their faces blur and zips them through multiple adventures, pausing only occasionally to let the former drop in historical and medical nuggets. And the story? Will childhood friends Barney and Laura find love? What about the other members of Harvard Medical School's class of 1962? What will happen to Dr. Perfect, the brilliant black Rhodes scholar with the Holocaust survivor foster-parents? Fortunately, Erich Segal the pop novelist manages to grapple the more ambitious (and somewhat boring) Professor Segal into submission in time for a happy conclusion.

title: ,1>A Pianist Who Has Hit Her Stride
description: LEAD: AT 35 and celebrated as one of the few stride pianists performing these days, Judy Carmichael has never been one to ignore a challenge or dare.

title: Review/Music; Mehta, Webern and Schoenberg
description: It is rough on the symphony orchestras of America that they should play best a repertory for which few of their subscribers want to pay. The presence of Webern's ''Six Pieces for Orchestra'' on the New York Philharmonic's first subscription concert of the season Friday evening no doubt played its part in keeping the hall appreciably less than full. And the warmest applause of the evening certainly went to Schubert's Ninth Symphony. But that should probably be interpreted as an endorsement of the score; Zubin Mehta and the orchestra got much closer to the gist of the Webern than of the Schubert. Schoenberg's Chamber Symphony in E came out somewhere in between.

title: Key Limes
description: To the Editor: As one who shares Margaret Shakespeare's enthusiasm for key limes and recently read her Fare of the Country (Travel, May 22), I was sorry she did not note that all limes found in the Keys are not Key limes. The yellow lime is not a true Key lime.

title: Please Send One Bag of Garbage
description: BY now there are very few people in New Jersey who are not fed up (please excuse the choice of words) with the garbage situation. Single households like mine find the present arrangement particularly burdensome, since there is a flat pickup fee regardless of the amount of garbage generated.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: West/Southwest; Washington Intercepts Army
description: Vince Weathersby ran for two touchdowns and Chico Fraley returned an interception 72 yards for the clinching score with 1 minute 10 seconds left as Washington held off Army for a 31-17 victory today.

title: A Call to Vote, Not to Arms, For Polisario
description: The end to a long war for independence for this sparsely populated, largely desert region now hinges on votes, not bullets.

title: Values and Affluence: Mutually Exclusive?
description: I was somewhat taken aback by the recent opinion expressed by Linda Gass [ ''Full Life, Empty Values,'' Aug. 21 ] regarding the Roslyn community.

title: Senate Passes Coinage Bill; Opposition Likely in House
description: The Senate has approved legislation to modernize the designs of the nation's pocket change and to issue coins commemorating the centennials of six states and the 100th birthday of President Eisenhower.

title: Is a Mother's Life Safe With Abortion Foes?
description: To the Editor:

title: Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
A Long Menu in a Small Space
description: LEAD: IT may not be fair to speak in glowing terms about a restaurant that holds only 19 diners. In fact, it is tempting to keep this one under our hat. Keep in mind that the place obviously cannot accommodate an enthusiastic onslaught; thus readers should pace themselves and remain in good temper if they're turned away.

title: Country Inns Offer Quiet Getaways
description: LEAD: IN Colonial days, when New Jersey was the stagecoach crossroads between New York and Philadelphia, scores of inns were opened to feed and house the travelers. One hundred years or so later, resorts along the Atlantic blossomed and Victorian summer ''cottages'' in towns like Spring Lake and Cape May began taking in guests.

title: Amy B. Avellone Wed To Dr. Jeffrey Viscardi
description: Amy Barrett Avellone, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph C. Avellone of Lakewood, Ohio, and the late Dr. Avellone, was married yesterday to Dr. Jeffrey Joseph Viscardi, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John P. Viscardi Jr. of Plandome, L.I. The Rev. Theodore Marszal performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Cleveland.

title: Lisa Pierson Wed To Andrew Boles
description: The marriage of Lisa Duncan Pierson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Pierson of Morristown and Loveladies, N.J., to Andrew Bowen Boles, a son of Betsy Bowen Boles of Brevard, N.C., and Dr. C. Read Boles of St. Louis, took place yesterday at the Presbyterian Church on the Green in Morristown. The Rev. Thomas C. Sheffield performed the ceremony.

title: Jose Greco Returns, With His Offspring at His Heels
description: TO HAVE POPULARIZED Spanish dance throughout America - if not the world - would seem to be remarkable enough. To have spawned children very likely to carry on this tradition, is, to say the very least, extraordinary. But Jose Greco, the legendary Italian-born, Brooklyn-raised exponent of Spanish dancing, has done just that.

title: HIS OWN BIG PICTURE
description: Stuart Davis (1892-1964) was an artist whose biography is that of American 20th-century art. It is not that Davis was at the center of the mainstream art world. Rather, as we learn in Karen Wilkin's book STUART DAVIS (Abbeville, $85), a lavishly illustrated and handsome coffeetable volume, he was an important and representative figure, one who started in the socially conscious Ashcan School tradition and became an outstanding Cubist. Davis was inspired by technology and city living, and he translated this into work that featured brilliant colors and intriguing spatial relationships. Ms. Wilkin, an art historian and critic, places him in the context of his times. Hers is more a biography of the artist than of the man and that is all to the good, although the Davis we see here is a fascinating personality. He was articulate, even scathing, in speech (and used words as elements in his paintings) and was as intensely political as he was eloquent in his condemnation of the harnessing of art to political ends, either by Stalin or Hitler or by American conformists.
