The pictures, in color and in black and white, are beautifully reproduced. Ms. Wilkin writes interestingly about the developments in American art in the 20th century, and she has provided a valuable summary of events, concepts and techniques that knits together a history too often fragmented by discursions that obscure the big picture. ''Stuart Davis'' puts it all together in a most attractive way.

title: The Asians Have Given In And Still Prevailed on Trade
description: WHEN the Reagan Administration took office in 1981, its message to Asia was clear: It would no longer stand by idly while Japan and a handful of other fast-growing economies flooded the United States with low-priced products and blocked American goods from their own markets. One of the Administration's first international successes, in fact, was strong-arming Japan into imposing ''voluntary'' quotas on automobile exports.

title: Review/Theater; Metaphor and Whimsy in 'A Murder of Crows'
description: As if old age, creeping senility and a battle between a father and his son were not enough to furnish a family play, imagine a case of chemical contamination on Golden Pond and one begins to see the trouble in store in ''A Murder of Crows.'' This new play by Ed Graczyk, author of ''Come Back to the Five and Dime, Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean,'' opened Wednesday night at the South Street Theater, 424 West 42d Street.

title: An 'Applause' With Some Flair
description: ''APPLAUSE'' is the producer Maynard Sloate's 17th ''tab show'' at the Claridge Casino Hotel's Palace Theater. Clearly, the Broadway show, in shortened - or tabloid - form, serves a twofold purpose here. Customers, for whom theatergoing is not priority No. 1 can get on to other diversions in a hurry, and management has the chance to increase grosses by putting on two shows a night.

title: Peking Duck At the Source
description: BEIJING, which in recent decades seemed content to ignore its dynastic past and culture as somehow corrupt, has, even as it rushes toward modernity, taken to collecting accounts of the customs and mores of the past century from its elderly citizenry. A recent collection of these reminiscences, ''Talks on Beijing's Recent Past,'' contains the recollections of one Yin Runsheng, who is otherwise unidentified but who remembered the capital's two great duck houses for nostalgic readers.

title: Bernadette Gallagher Weds Joseph Gaffney
description: Bernadette Patricia Gallagher and Joseph Peter Gaffney, both third-year law students at St. John's University, were married yesterday at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookville, L.I., by the Rev. Mario C. Costa. Barbara Gallagher Erickson was her sister's matron of honor, and Gerardina Vecchio was the maid of honor. Thomas Tomasulo was the best man.

title: Can Arafat Be Ben-Gurion?
description: LEAD: With the Palestinian revolt prompting Jordan to bow out of West Bank politics, Yasir Arafat faces a challenge reminiscent of the one faced by David Ben-Gurion, Israel's founder and first Prime Minister, more than 40 years ago: whether to declare an independent state.

title: Rite of Passage: Dressing Up
description: The celebration of Rosh ha-Shanah last week marked not only the beginning of the Jewish New Year but also, for many children, a rite of passage into a whole new world, that of dressing up.

title: Article 435288 -- No Title
description: GREAT HEART The History of a Labrador Adventure. By James West Davidson and John Rugge. Illustrated. 385 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Renewing the United Nations; Give the U.N. Its Dues - and Its Due
description: The United Nations has lately shown a resolve to tackle its longstanding organizational problems, and has begun playing a more conspicuous and constructive role in resolving regional conflicts. In belated response to these welcome trends, President Reagan last week announced he would stop the U.S. policy of crippling the U.N. financially and start paying U.N. dues. Though hastily conceived, his plan moves in the right direction.

title: More New Models Make Their Debuts
description: IF this column has seemed full of talk about new cameras of late, there's a good reason. Since midsummer, camera makers have been announcing their latest and greatest products with nonstop intensity. The main impetus is an upcoming trade show known as Photokina, which takes place every other fall in Cologne, West Germany.

title: Review/Music; The Herb Roberts Septet Gives a New Sound to Pop
description: Blues, noise, ostinatos and plain funk all vied for attention on Tuesday at the Knitting Factory. Herb Roberts, a cellist, led an acrobatic group through long pieces that exposed section after section of different textures, from compressed noise to fragile melodies carefully presented on just cello and trombone.

title: Joyce Purnick to Marry
description: The engagement of Joyce Purnick, the daughter of Jack Purnick of New York and the late Charlotte Leah Purnick, to Max Frankel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Frankel of New York, has been announced by the future bride's father. Ms. Purnick is the urban affairs correspondent of The New York Times and a former City Hall bureau chief for the paper. Mr. Frankel, a widower, is the executive editor of The Times. The couple plan to marry in December.

title: Nebraska Concern Buys Gallup Organization
description: The Gallup Organization, the public opinion research company that became virtually synonymous with polling, has been acquired for an undisclosed price by Selection Research Inc., a Nebraska-based market research and personnel testing concern.

title: 16 Million Jobs in Eight Years Seems Best We Can Do; Quality, Not Quantity
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big Flat Brook: Fishermen's Haven
description: LEAD: NOT far from Route 206 in Sussex County, a dusty, rough road enters the woods and follows one of New Jersey's best trout streams, the Big Flat Brook.

title: Two Rare Wildflowers Are Found in New York
description: A wildflower never before seen in New York, the Michigan lily, has been discovered growing in a singular prairie in the state northwest of Watertown, not far from Lake Ontario.

title: Jeanne Buckley Marries
description: Jeanne Louise Buckley, an international relocation coordinator for Salomon Brothers, and William Michael Peloso, a specialist clerk for the brokerage house of Wagner, Stott & Company, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y. Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick of Newark, assisted by the Rev. Francis Boyle, performed the ceremony. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Buckley of Pelham Manor, and Mr. and Mrs. William Peloso of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Ship Bottom Journal; A Surf Shop Folds Awning After 30 Years
description: RON JON'S Surf Shop, despite being a popular spot for visitors to Long Beach Island to purchase anything from surfboards to fresh clams, has permanently pulled down the red canvas awnings on its theme-park-like outdoor merchandise display, after 30 years.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: TV Sports; NBC's Coverage Captures the Color, but Not the Fun
description: In its zeal to Get That Story, along with its phobia of seeming like a flag-waver, NBC-TV opened its Olympic coverage by combining the joy of the event with a certain heavy portentousness.

title: Miami Rallies To Win
description: The list of places where the University of Miami has won football games during the past four seasons would trace a roadmap to dominance. The Hurricanes of Jimmy Johnson's brief but stunningly successful era as coach established credibility in Norman and South Bend. They earned hard-fought recruiting prestige with victories in Tallahassee and Gainesville. They won the school's second national championship of the decade.

title: Congress Democrats Aim at G.O.P. By Pushing the Parental Leave Issue
description: In an attempt to embarrass Republicans on an important election issue, Democratic Congressional leaders say they have decided to push forward with legislation that would require companies to grant unpaid leave to parents of new babies or seriously ill children.

title: The Uncommon Art of Caring for the ''Pipes''
description: ALAN D. McNEELY and his colleagues work in places that few people ever see but that many pass regularly. They work on instruments that few play but that many expect to hear. They do work that few understand and that fewer know how to do.

title: You Better Pledge . . . or Else
description: LEAD: To Captain Black, every officer who supported his Glorious Loyalty Oath Crusade was a competitor, and he planned and plotted twenty-four hours a day to keep one step ahead. He would stand second to none in his devotion to country. When other officers had followed his urging and introduced loyalty oaths of their own, he went them one better by making every son of a bitch who came to his intelligence tent sign two loyalty oaths, then three, then four; then he introduced the pledge of allegiance, and after that ''The Star-Spangled

title: Whither City Opera Now?
description: THE NEW YORK CITY OPERA'S ANNOUNCEMENT the other day that Christopher Keene would replace Beverly Sills as general director after this season came as a mild surprise, though hardly a shock. Though some observers had hoped that the board of trustees might choose a career administrator who would share reponsibility with an artistic director, rather in the style of the Metropolitan Opera's team of Bruce Crawford and James Levine, that was not in the cards. Perhaps no qualified opera administrator was available at this time for transfer to New York, or perhaps Mr. Keene had the inside track all the while. We may never know.

title: Magnetic Imaging Approved for County
description: WHAT some call ''the magnificent magnet'' and others consider an expensive alternative to X-rays will soon become standard equipment in three Westchester hospitals, regional health officials said last week.

title: Before It Is Too Late
description: In Jerusalem last June several dozen Israeli and Palestinian writers, artists and academics signed a symbolic peace treaty. It called for peace between Israel and a Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza, each respecting the other's need for security.

title: ALLURING CHOICES
description: MAKEUP: WHITTLING IT DOWN

title: Open Hearths in a Colonial Inn
description: DINNER at Randall's Ordinary in North Stonington is a unique experience, as close to dining in Colonial times as most of us will ever know. The dishes served are from authentic 18th- and 19th-century recipes, and most are cooked in the fireplaces of three small, low ceilinged dining rooms with exposed beams.

title: Quayle on Stump: Ghosts of Academic and Military Past Follow Caravan
description: He was near the end of his fourth swing out on the hustings, a five-day trip covering 5,000 miles, 10 states and 25 airport and civic center rallies, and Senator Dan Quayle, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, thought it was time to sum up progress.

title: Nature as a Passion and a Subject
description: CAMPBELL NORSGAARD has given much to nature through his films, photographs, lectures and other projects. He has even given nature his backyard.

title: Books From The Times
description: LIVING OUT LOUD. By Anna Quindlen. (Random House, $17.95.) When Anna Quindlen was 22 years old and wanted to write a column about her life, her editor at the time said she ''hadn't lived enough to be qualified for 'living out loud.' '' This collection from Life in the 30's, Ms. Quindlen's syndicated New York Times column, is all about ''muddling through the middle,'' her definition of life. A former Times reporter and editor, she writes about herself and those whose lives touch hers - her husband and sons, as well as strangers. Among other themes are ''Gossip'' ''I Am a Catholic,'' ''Feminist,'' ''A Baseball Wimp'' and ''Raised on Rock-and-Roll.''

title: Kathleen Moore Weds
description: At St. Peter the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Amagansett, L.I., Kathleen Anne Moore, a soloist with American Ballet Theater, was married yesterday to Peter Quentin Tovar, an advertising supervisor at Ogilvy & Mather in New York. The Rev. Raymond Rafferty performed the ceremony. The bride, who graduated from the Alabama School of Fine Arts in Birmingham, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Moore of Huntsville, Ala. The bridegroom, a son of Deborah Tovar of Chevy Chase, Md., and B. Hugh Tovar of Washington, graduated cum laude from Harvard University.

title: A Revolutionary Cuba is Portrayed in Show of Posters at Lehman Gallery
description: THE mission of the poster being to persuade, it seems redundant to call a show of them ''Persuasive Images.'' Then again, these particular posters, on display at the Lehman College Art Gallery, are Cuban, so the title may be a kind of caveat emptor aimed at those who are wont to see Castro as a Robin Hood.

title: Miss Demaree, a Teacher, Is Married to Coy Comart
description: Heather Demaree, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan T. Demaree of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Coy Comart, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Comart of Scarsdale and Delray Beach, Fla. George F. Roberts, the town justice of Lewisboro, N.Y., officiated at the Rene Chardain Restaurant in Lewisboro.

title: Curriculum In Navajo Is Planned
description: Martha Jackson remembers her teachers washing her mouth out with soap because she had spoken in her native tongue, Navajo, at a boarding school run by the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

title: Soccer Rules Are Also for U.S.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Sept. 3 MANHATTAN Gramercy Park $995,000 7 Gramercy Park 3-bedroom, 4-bath, 2,200-sq.-ft. condo in a recently renovated building; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, 2 fireplaces, Gramercy Park view, park key; common charge $1,363, taxes $690 (Broker: Baker R.C. Inc.) Greenwich Village $275,000 31 East 12th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 875-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, large dining foyer, windowed kitchen, fireplace; maintenance $500, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Buchbinder & Warren) Upper East Side $880,000 116 East 63d Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,800-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, maid's room, large windowed kitchen, high-beamed ceilings; maintenance $1,500, 43% tax-deductible (Broker: B.J. Gottesman) Upper West Side $565,000 473 West End Avenue (83d St.) 2-bedroom, 3-bath, 1,600-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; manned elevator, dining room, large kitchen, Hudson River view; maintenance $1,222, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Eden Realty) Upper West Side $232,500 176 West 87th Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 800-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, windowed kitchen, high-ceilings, parquet floors; maintenance $403, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate) Washington Heights $82,000 900 West 190th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 600-sq.-ft postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, large, windowed kitchen, Hudson River view; maintenance $390, 48% tax-deductible (Broker: C-Uptown Realty) BRONX Riverdale $85,635 4901 Henry Hudson Parkway (Windsor North) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 630-sq.-ft, postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, terrace, c/a, pool; maintenance $461, includes gas and electricity, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Susan E. Goldy) Wakefield $295,000 2201 Strang Avenue 2-family, detached brick house; 3 bedrooms, 1 bath, dining room, large kitchen in each unit, detached 1-car garage, 30- by 104-ft. lot; taxes $1,800 (Broker: Cancro Realty) BROOKLYN Kensington $68,200 310 Beverly Road 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 750-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining area, remodeled, windowed kitchen; maintenance $396, 48% tax-deductible (Broker: Elise Franco Brown) Prospect Heights $63,000 77 Eastern Parkway 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 600-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar co-op; large kitchen, hardwood floors, Botanic Gardens view; maintenance $335, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Dowling & Peltz) QUEENS Corona $230,000 57-12 Waldron Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, semiattached, brick house; dining room, large kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $900 (Broker: Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) Forest Hills $117,900 72-34 Austin Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 750-sq.-ft. postwar condo; dining area, large kitchen, hardwood floors; common charge $215, taxes $564 (Broker: Century 21/Elms Realty) STATEN ISLAND Castleton Corners $175,500 670 Manor Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, large kitchen, fireplace, full basement, detached, 2-car garage; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Weichert Realtors) Grant City $259,900 324 Stobe Avenue 2-family, detached High-Ranch; 3 bedrooms, 1 1/2 baths, dining room, deck off living room in primary unit; 1 bedroom, 1 bath in other; c/a, full basement, attached 1-car garage, 44- by 100-ft, lot; taxes $1,293 (Broker: Salmon Real Estate)

title: How Different Are the Famous From the Faces In the Crowd?
description: The famous are different from you and me - they receive more attention. Looking at them, we are conscious of how many times they have been looked at before. The images they project are inseparable from our knowledge of what they are; and as their fame grows, their features evolve into something more than faces - into masks, trademarks, icons.

title: Cruise Ships That Cater to the Corporate Market
description: Cruise ships are now being designed with the lucrative corporate market in mind. Introduced in January, the Royal Caribbean Cruise Line's $180 million Sovereign of the Seas, the largest passenger ship in the world, has 11 lounges and movie theaters that can double as corporate meeting rooms. Two Royal Caribbean ships will have break-away walls in public rooms.

title: FOCUS: Columbus, Ohio; After 26 Years, Downtown Renewal
description: A 94-unit residential development under construction here will complete the redevelopment of a 70-acre downtown urban renewal site prepared by the city 26 years ago.

title: Carter Assails Bush For Stance on Pledge
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, taking issue with Republican campaign attacks centered on the Pledge of Allegiance, says he respects the flag but would probably refuse to recite the pledge if ordered to do so by the Government.

title: CLOSE-UP: Rowing
description: The Course

title: Hosital Has Recipes for Success
description: LEAD: HARVEST breakfast from the Cudner-Hyatt House in Scarsdale, ''dining with the general,'' as it was done at the Elijah Miller homestead - George Washington's White Plains headquarters - and ''high tea a la Lyndhurst'' are among the 14 menus suggested by historic sites for the newly published ''Golden Apple Collection: New Traditions in Westchester Cuisine.

title: THE NATION: U.S. Plan on Hold; Suddenly, Nuclear Waste Looks Very Visible Again
description: ALMOST half a mile beneath the desert in southern New Mexico, Federal engineers believe they have found a solution for disposing of nuclear waste that is as eternal, as elemental and as invisible as the atom itself. Since 1983, they have been mining from salt beds the nation's first permanent repository for radioactive garbage, a tomb as vast, splendid and concealed as any ever built.

title: Nudism
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''The Naked and the Dressed in Provence'' by Mickey Friedman (Travel, June 26): Was this mixture of furtive voyeurism and prudish distancing for real (''stunned, shock, widened eyes, shame''), or (now I get it) just a satire of those oh so noncosmopolitan Florida citizens who have not yet become suave New Yorkers? HANS-JAKOB WERLEN Swarthmore, Pa.

title: Pewter of Tin-Rich Malaysia
description: JUST over a century ago, a young pewtersmith named Yong Koon took the tools of his craft and sailed across the South China Sea to join a new settlement of Chinese tin miners at Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. There, Yong Koon used the tin in fashioning traditional pewter items such as teapots, wine cups and incense burners, which he peddled from door to door.

title:
GARDENING;
Bonsai: Some Sources for the Timid
description: LEAD: HORTICULTURE has been described as a blend of art and science, but providing for the needs of plants in a house or garden has become increasingly technical.

title: Alison K. Todd Is Wed To Gregory Cokorinos
description: At the Presbyterian Church at Tenafly, N.J., Alison Keith Todd, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. W. Duane Todd of Tenafly, and Gregory Dennis Cokorinos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dan Cokorinos of Manhasset Hills, L.I., were married yesterday by the Rev. Harry E. Chase. The bride is a costume designer. She graduated from the Emma Willard School and Carnegie-Mellon University and was presented at the Thanksgiving Eve Ball of the Junior League of New York. Her father recently retired as a professor of clinical obstetrics and gynecology at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: Concern Rises as a Pond Grows Shallower
description: ''I REMEMBER one year, I think it was 1980, and all the white houses turned gray from it,'' recalled Dr. Paul Brauer, referring to the hydrogen sulfide that is said to be coming from the deteriorating Sherwood Mill Pond, an estuary along Westport's shore.

title: To Manage Power Use, Stop New Construction
description: A Lilco spokesman is cited [ ''Managing Electric Use: A Strain After Shoreham,'' July 31 ] as saying that the company is operating its plants up to 99 percent of their total capacity during peak periods.

title: China Wins a Gold in Diving
description: Michele Mitchell and Wendy Lian Williams of the United States put off the projected domination of 10-meter platform diving by the Chinese for at least another four years today as they took the Olympic silver and bronze medals behind Xu Yanmei of China, who won the gold.

title: Efforts by 2 Latin Presidents Appear to Break Impasse on Peace
description: Efforts by the Presidents of Guatemala and Costa Rica appear to have broken a three-month stalemate and given a new impetus to the Central American peace process.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsfield, Mass.;
Berkshires Mixed-Income
description: LEAD: Residents have begun moving into the Pines, a 41-unit, mixed-income condominium development on a five-acre site here overlooking Pontoosic Lake, a popular recreation area.

title: Bringing Up Babies to a Broadway Beat
description: WHEN I WAS A SMALL child - I cannot recall exactly how small - my favorite toy was a narrow box full of records. It was the original cast recording of the Broadway musical ''South Pacific.'' I don't know how many were inside, but this was in the days before long-playing records, so I know there were a good many of them. I would listen for hours, learning to mug along with ''Honey Bun,'' mastering the pace of ''There Is Nothing Like a Dame'' and feeling the sort of uncomfortable frisson that no little girl far afield of puberty has any business feeling when Ezio Pinza sang ''Some Enchanted Evening.''

title: Dr. Miller Weds Dr. William E. Hunt
description: Dr. Carole Ann Miller and Dr. William E. Hunt were married yesterday at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., by the Rev. A. Orly Swartzentruber. The bride is a daughter of Elsa Miller of Columbus, Ohio, and the late Clayton B. Miller. Her husband is the son of the late Mrs. Alfred T. Mehle of Pasadena, Calif., and the late William W. Hunt.

title: A Graduate Gives
description: Some people endow university chairs; Joel E. Smilow has endowed a locker room. Yale University announced last week that Mr. Smilow, the president of Playtex Inc., had donated $1 million to endow the position of head football coach. Mr. Smilow, a member of the Yale College class of 1954, said that football was ''an integral part of the very broad objective of attracting, educating and motivating persons with the potential to become tomorrow's leaders.'' The gift, the first of its kind at Yale but not unique in academia, differs from most academic endowments in that it does not guarantee job security; college coaches, like their counterparts in the pros, are paid to win. That has not been a problem for the current Yale coach, Carmen L. Cozza, in whose 24 seasons Yale has won 139 games, lost 70 and tied 4.

title: AN AMERICAN ORIGINAL
description: In the brilliant sunlight of the French Riviera, Steve Martin, the comedian-turned-movie-star, hides under a baseball cap, behind his ''go away'' shades. Although he has been shooting a comedy, ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels,'' along the Mediterranean for six weeks, his complexion has remained trademark pale.

title: CONSUMER RATES
John Adams Starts Off in Winning Style
description: With Arthur Dennis returning for his senior year at John Adams after gaining 1,418 yards as a junior, the Spartans were everyone's pick to repeat as the Public Schools Athletic League champion. They did not disappoint in the first big weekend of football.

title: Newcomers Spark Islanders
description: The Islanders commenced their exhibition season tonight to the syncopated tune of Ron Hextall, the Philadelphia goaltender-percussionist, who pounded his goalposts less merrily as the evening wore on.

title: Using Face Lifts to Solve an Identity Crisis
description: Conference centers are facing an identity crisis. Throughout the early 1980's, their reputation rested on being serious: a campus-like collection of meeting rooms with audio-visual equipment that were dedicated to business use.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Midwest; Notre Dame Takes an Option to a Rout
description: Michael Stonebreaker, a linebacker, returned an interception 39 yards for a touchdown and Tony Rice, the option quarterback, scored on an 8-yard run to lead unbeaten Notre Dame to a 20-3 victory over Michigan State today.

title: As Its Problems Mount, Rio Declares Bankruptcy
description: After quarreling with bankers and creditors for weeks, the Mayor of Rio de Janeiro has publicly declared the city in a state of bankruptcy.

title: Officials Investigating 3 Deaths After Fire
description: Three people were found dead this morning after a fire swept through a house in this Westchester County community, the police said.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Drug Violators Be Paid for Time Away?
description: No, No, No. Would they be paid if they worked in private industry? I doubt it. Moreover, upon first offense, drug violators should be banned for the season; upon second offense, they should be banned for life. Perhaps - then and only then - will athletes keep their noses clean. NICHOLAS D. DeCURTIS New York

title:
DANCE;
Jersey Ballet Prepares For the New Season
description: LEAD: THEMATIC evenings will characterize what Carolyn Clark, the artistic director of the New Jersey Ballet Company, calls ''the most important and exciting season in the history of the New Jersey Ballet.'' While out in the studios the dancers, just back from a layoff, stretched and chatted with each other, Miss Clark and other company administrators squeezed into a tiny office at the company's West Orange home to put the finishing touches on last year's dreams and make them this year's reality.

title: Today's Events
description: All times Eastern daylight. Baseball Australia vs. Canada, 8P.M. Basketball Men - South Korea vs. Central African Republic, 5:30 A.M., Soviet Union vs. Yugoslavia, 7:30 A.M. Women - United States vs. Czechoslovakia, 7:45 P.M.; Soviet Union vs. Bulgaria, 9:45 P.M. Boxing Preliminaries, 5 A.M. and 8 P.M. Diving Men - springboard preliminaries, 8 P.M. Equestrian Three-day event, dressage test, open, 8P.M. Field Hockey Men - Britain vs. South Korea, 1:15 A.M.; Australia vs. Kenya, 1:15A.M. Gymnastics Men - team compulsories, 12:30 A.M. and 6:30 A.M. Women -team compulsories, 9P.M. Modern Pentathlon Riding, midnight; fencing, 7 P.M. Rowing Qualifying, 7 P.M. Women - fours with coxswain; double sculls; pairs without coxswain. Men -fours with coxswain; double sculls; pairs without coxswain; single sculls. Shooting Men - smallbore free rifle (English match), 60 shots, 7 P.M., final, 10 shots, 10:30 P.M. Women - sport pistol-rapid fire, 30 shots, first round, 7 P.M., 30 shots, second round, 9:30 P.M.; Open -clay target-trap, second round, 75 targets, 8 P.M. Soccer South Korea vs. Soviet Union, 3 A.M.; Australia vs. Yugoslavia, 3 A.M.; United States vs. Argentina, 5 A.M.; Brazil vs. Nigeria, 5 A.M. Swimming Finals, 10 P.M. Women -100 freestyle, 400 individual medley. Men -100 breast stroke, 200 freestyle. Taekwondo Men and women -bantamweight and middleweight, semifinals, 1 A.M., final, 3:20 A.M.; finweight and lightweight preliminaries, 8 P.M. and 11 P.M. Volleyball Men - Soviet Union vs. Bulgaria, 4:30 A.M.; Argentina vs. Tunisia, 6:30 A.M.; Netherlands vs. United States, 7:45 P.M.; Sweden vs. Soviet Union, 10 P.M. Weight Lifting 52 kilograms, midnight, 3 A.M. and 7 A.M (final). Wrestling Greco-Roman - 48-, 62- and 90-kilogram preliminaries, 3:30 A.M.; 48-, 52-, 62-, 74-, 90-, and 100-kilogram preliminaries, 8 P.M. TELEVISION COVERAGE Today's highlights on NBC. 8 A.M. to noon Live and taped coverage: Gymnastics, men's compulsories; boxing preliminaries; men's basketball, Soviet Union vs. Yugoslavia and weight lifting, 52 kilogram. 4-7 P.M. Taped highlights of early morning events. 7:30 P.M.-Midnight Swimming finals, men's 100 breast stroke and 200 freestyle, women's 100 freestyle and 400 individual medley; gymnastics, women's team compulsories; men's basketball, United States vs. Czechoslovakia; Diving, men's springboard preliminaries; Men's volleyball, United States vs. the Netherlands, Soviet Union vs. vs. Sweden; boxing preliminaries. 12:30-2:30 A.M. Tennis, first round men's singles.

title: Kelly Kildow Is Wed To Walter Hoffmann
description: Kelly Kildow, a daughter of Alfred G. Kildow of Brookline, Mass., and Fae M. Kildow of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Walter Hoffmann, a son of Bernhard Hoffmann 2d of Warren, Conn., and the late Phoebe L. G. Hoffmann. The Rev. Otis Charles, dean of the Episcopal Divinity School in Cambridge, Mass., performed the ceremony at the Cambridge Boat Club.

title: Reviews/Music; Ancient Music Group At New Miller Theater
description: The McMillin Theater at Columbia University is dead. Long live the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater. Although McMillin, the 64-year-old hall at West 116th Street and Broadway, enjoyed a long and honorable run as a center for campus activities and especially as a home for electronic music and other varieties of contemporary art, it has been in recent decades a depressing place to hear concerts. No matter how potentially attractive the event, a drab, lecture-hall ambiance worked against enjoyment. However, on Friday evening the reborn hall, remodeled at a cost of $3 million and named for a donor who died nine years ago, welcomed the public for the first time with a concert by the Academy of Ancient Music Chamber Ensemble.

title: Dr. Darin C. Schonzeit Weds Steven Sharpe
description: The marriage of Dr. Darin Carla Schonzeit, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Schonzeit of New York, to Steven Alan Sharpe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Sharpe of Northbrook, Ill., took place last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Joel Goor performed the ceremony.

title: A New Zealand Sampler
description: Following is a selective guide to travel in New Zealand. American citizens visiting the country do not need a visa for stays of less than three months. They must, however, show that they have onward or return tickets and sufficient money for their stay. Prices throughout the chart are given in United States dollars, figured at a rate of 2.37 New Zealand dollars to $1. For more information, write or call the New Zealand Tourist and Publicity Office, 630 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10111, 212-698-4680; or, 10960 Wilshire Boulevard, Los Angeles, Calif. 90024; 213-477-8241. CLIMATE

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Sports of The Times; Korea's Home-Grown Sport
description: On the first day of these Summer Games, the old was never very far from the new: a state-of-the-art stadium and men and maidens performing an ancient purification ritual on the lush grass during the opening ceremony.

title: Centers of Learning Offer a Total Harvest
description: ONCE again this season, the wise (and thrifty) music lover would do well to check the performing agendas at the many colleges, conservatories and other centers of learning in the county. The tonal harvest is abundant and the admission charges lower than at most equivalent programs elsewhere in Westchester.

title: More About Eve
description: To the Editor:

title: ,3>A 'War'Of Words In Freeport
description: LEAD: EVERY Saturday morning, on the sidewalk in front of the Freeport post office on Merrick Road, there is a scene that seems to set the calendar back 20 years.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Seven years ago, we built a redwood deck and left it untreated, as we expected it to weather to a uniform gray color. After the first year, the wood darkened with fungus and moss and there was no graying. The deck was scrubbed and a gray deck stain applied, but two years later the wood was again dark with fungus and moss. Is there any way to achieve a stable gray color?

title: For Young Presbyterian Minister, Housing Is His Ministry
description: LEAD: DURING the drought this summer, while many farmers waited for nature to turn kindly, the Rev. Kent Pipes hoisted 50-gallon drums of water onto the bed of his pickup, and drove across town to the family garden. With his children - Kristen, 10 years old, Rebecca, 7, and Kyle, 4 - he emptied the drums' contents on a grateful patch of struggling vegetable plants.

title: Providing Therapy For Wife Batterers
description: The article by Judy Glass [ ''Therapy for Wife Batterers,'' Aug. 14 ] was informative and essentially accurate. Ms. Glass did an excellent job of conveying the flavor of the group experience.

title: Swimmer Outraces His Past
description: At the age of 12, Chris Jacobs of Livingston, N.J., tried cocaine for the first time. At 21, disgusted with the way drinking and drugs had taken over his life, he bought a .357 magnum. Several times, he sat in a closet, put the barrel in his mouth and cocked the hammer.

title: Ngaio Marsh's Scenes Of the Crime
description: MANY Americans have received their most vivid impressions of New Zealand from the descriptions in the mystery novels that the late Ngaio Marsh set in her native country.

title: Karen A. Buynak Marries Charles Fairbank Painter
description: Karen Anne Buynak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Buynak of Bayville, L.I., was married yesterday to Charles Fairbank Painter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitfield Painter of Concord, Mass. The Rev. Nehemiah Boynton performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in South Dartmouth, Mass.

title: Burma Troops Fire on Protesters, Then Surrender
description: Burmese troops fired today on demonstrators who surrounded a Government building the troops were guarding, then surrendered to students and Buddhist monks, witnesses said.

title: Education Head Is Ready to Bow Out
description: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett plans to pay his 107th and last official visit to a school on Tuesday in New Hampshire. Then and there he will bid farewell to his bodyguard, turn over his Government credentials and drive off as a private citizen to write a book, promote reading of the classics by high school students and seek his fortune on the lecture circuit.

title: Fire Destroys Social Center For the Elderly in L.I. Town
description: Fires, possibly set by an arsonist, destroyed the town's social center for the elderly early today and damaged a beauty salon across the street, the authorities said.

title: Book on Massacre of Poles Gets U.S. Funding
description: The National Endowment for Democracy, a private group financed by the Federal Government, has approved a plan to disseminate in Poland a book that accuses the Soviet Union of the massacre of more than 4,000 Polish Army officers at Katyn Forest in World War II.

title: Finding a Flight To China for $900
description: YOU can get an air ticket to China cheaper than you might expect, even as more and more Americans are traveling there. There is a round-trip ticket from New York for $900 or slightly less (not counting customs and landing fees) - and it is on a scheduled airline with a name you have heard of. To get this fare, instead of the usual $1,400 or $1,500 round-trip APEX coach fare, you will need to be prepared to press your travel agent to meet your price, or you will have to use the phone extensively to a no-frills agency or consolidator.

title: Comings and Goings
description: He lost the United States Open and the No. 1 ranking he had held for 156 weeks, but Ivan Lendl, who is now ranked No. 2 behind Mats Willander, cited another ailment in withdrawing from this week's Volvo-Los Angeles tournament: an injury to his right shoulder joint incurred during the Open. Other withdrawals from the tournament include Pat Cash, Aaron Krickstein, John Frawley and Eliot Teltscher. . . Boris Becker, who had to withdraw from the Seoul Olympics because of foot problems, has withdrawn from the Eagle Classic set for Oct. 3 in Scottsdale, Ariz., citing the same ailment. . . . The Cleveland Cavaliers will match the $1.8 million, four-year offer sheet extended to Mark Price, a guard, by the Washington Bullets, according to the Cavaliers' general manager, Wayne Embry.(AP)

title: Islamic Fundamentalist Group Splitting Palestinian Uprising
description: In the first serious split of the nine-month-old Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories, an emerging Islamic fundamentalist organization is challenging the protest's clandestine ''unified leadership.''

title: Perspectives: Land Use; Postal Trucks Find a Home on 11th Ave.
description: There was anguish in Chelsea in the 1960's when the United States Postal Service wanted to build a maintenance center for its trucks on the site of its Morgan annex on Ninth Avenue at 29th Street. Opposition killed the plan. But the need remained, and the Postal Service looked elsewhere. Eventually, more hospitable territory was found to the west. Land was purchased in 1984 on what was once the Baltimore & Ohio railroad yard at the Hudson River and a new building was designed, approved and built.

title: 120 FEARED DEAD ON MEXICAN BUSES FLEEING HURRICANE
description: As many as 120 people fleeing Hurricane Gilbert were feared dead today in the industrial city of Monterrey after four buses overturned in flood waters, trapping most of the passengers inside.

title: Campaign Takes a Turn Onto the Low Road
description: WEEKS before the political conventions, Republican strategists such as Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., the party chairman, and Lee Atwater, Vice President Bush's campaign manager, argued that Michael S. Dukakis was vulnerable to attack. The only question, a Republican official said in July, was ''whether our guy will have the stomach for sticking it to the other guy when the moment comes.''

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $352,500 59 Apple Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old colonial; fireplace, study, walk to transportation and shopping; taxes $5,592. Katonah, N.Y. $286,000 48 Lily Pond Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old split level; master bedroom suite with skylight, family room with wood burning stove; taxes $3,705. title: Taft Home, Rebuilt, Is Opened to Public
description: The boyhood home of President Taft opened to the public today after a 19-year Federal renovation that cost $3 million in public and private money.

title: A Scion Runs
description: Patrick Kennedy evidently figured that at the age of 21 it was high time he entered the family business. Last week the Providence College junior, son Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, won the Democratic nomination for a seat in the Rhode Island State House. He defeated a five-term incumbent, John M. Skeffington

title: New York Farmers to Fight $3 Billion Highway Proposal
description: New York's largest farmers group has voted to oppose a plan for a $3 billion highway bond issue, saying the borrowing would, in effect, mortgage the state's future.

title: Rutgers Outgunned by Vanderbilt
description: Eric Jones was an efficient general on attack and a superb passer today, just as Vanderbilt has said of its senior quarterback and just as Rutgers knew from last year. Jones had to be outstanding because Rutgers countered with a record performance by its quarterback, Scott Erney.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Bridgewater $225,000 672 Thruway Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; in-ground pool, central air-conditioning, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $3,149. Chester $750,000 9 Ryan Court 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; 2-story library, deck, family room, 2-car garage; taxes $1,124. Livingston $410,000 7 Billingsley Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old split-level; central air-conditioning, deck, 2-car attached garage, basement; taxes $4,016. Millburn $268,000 161 Myrtle Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 full bath, 3 half-bath, 32-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,905. Short Hills $361,000 37 Byron Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old split-level; enclosed porch, living room with fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $5,417. Springfield $439,000 587 Ashwood Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old contemporary; 2-zone heating, deck, central air-conditioning; taxes $5,752. OTHER AREAS Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $352,500 59 Apple Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old colonial; fireplace, study, walk to transportation and shopping; taxes $5,592. Westport, Conn. $365,000 44 Oak Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old raised ranch; large country kitchen, screened porch, 1/2 acre; taxes $2,337. Kings Park, L.I. $265,000 4 Mountain Laurel Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; den, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $5,800.

title: Policy and Politics
description: European officials, East as well as West, are unusually relaxed about American elections this year. They don't feel they have a big stake in the outcome, not because U.S. decisions are any less vital to them nowadays but because they don't expect much change whoever wins.

title: Nancy B. Peretsman Weds Robert Scully
description: The marriage of Nancy Beth Peretsman, the daughter of George Peretsman of Brockton, Mass., and Norma O'Haire of Highland Lakes, N.J., to Robert William Scully, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Scully of Short Hills, N.J., took place yesterday at the bridegroom's home in Peapack, N.J. The Rev. M. Bruce McKay, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TOURS OF ESTATES Eleven homes in the Great Estates region of the Hudson Valley, a 20-mile district stretching from Hyde Park north to the town of Hudson, will be opened to the public in a series of tours Thursday through next Sunday. The ones that are still privately owned are being been shown for the first time and each will be open on only two of the four days.

title: Two Philosophies for Uncertain Times
description: Recent signs of a pulse in the stock market have brokers and traders hoping that the retail investors who fled Wall Street this summer may start to trickle back, looking for bargains.

title: Remote Shacks on Cape Are Caught Up in Storm
description: ''Euphoria'' is a shack made of castaway shingles and facing an ocean vista from a dune on the easternmost tip of Cape Cod. It is a spot rarely touched by the noise of modern life.

title: 'The Medical Profession Has Changed'
description: A GENERAL INTERNIST practicing in Lakeville since 1966, Dr. Peter Gott combines medicine and writing. He is the author of the book ''No House Calls,'' published by Simon and Schuster, and his syndicated newspaper column appears daily in 400 newspapers around the country.

title: AMERICAN ACCENTS
description: When the English actor Terence Stamp arrived on the set of the movie ''Wall Street'' wearing a Savile Row suit, the director, Oliver Stone, told him he didn't look British enough. Stone wanted a look that was supremely powerful - and unmistakably English - for the role, which was based on the real corporate raider Sir James M. Goldsmith.

title: Ex-War PrisonersAwarded Medals
description: THE ceremony was short and to the point. And in the space of half an hour, Howard E. Brooks's mind took him back nearly half a century to the day he became a prisoner of war. Tears filled his eyes and words were unattainable. A hug from his wife, Sylvia, steadied his shaking hands.

title: State by State; Voters in Jersey City Don't Know What to Think of Presidential Race
description: There is no real Democratic machine in Hudson County, no proper heir to Frank Hague, the famous boss of the 1930's and 1940's who used to brag, ''I am the law,'' and prove it every day.

title: Greenland
description: To the Editor: Dale Brown's account of a trip to southern Greenland should encourage travel to that interesting island, though he visited only a small part of it.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Newport, R.I.; Sheltering The Homeless
description: A coalition of church and civic leaders is converting a former Y.M.C.A. in the heart of the tourist district as a shelter for the homeless and other needy people.

title: Sacha Jonckheer, An Executive, Becomes Bride
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in New York, Alexandra Louise Jonckheer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willem August Jonckheer Jr. of Larkspur, Calif., was married yesterday to James Herbert MacNaughton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Robert MacNaughton of Bethesda, Md., and Sanibel Island, Fla. The Rev. Hayes H. Rockwell, the rector of the church, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Bishop John H. MacNaughton of the Episcopal Diocese of West Texas, who is an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: THE NATION  Pro & Con: Privacy at the Pharmacy; Civil Liberties and A Bid to Streamline Medicare Files
description: A FEDERAL plan to equip American pharmacies with computers to keep track of medications and spending on them by Medicare's 32 million beneficiaries highlights the conflicting demands of efficiency and protection of individual rights.

title: Fixing Garage Doors
description: BECAUSE of their weight and the fact they have many parts, garage doors need periodic lubrication and adjustment - and sometimes repair - to keep them operating smoothly. The job is usually easy, but some adjustment procedures may require two people.

title: Training a Robot For Hospital Jobs
description: WITH nurses in short supply, Danbury Hospital in Connecticut considered an offbeat aid to make its nursing staff more efficient: Roscoe, a three-foot-tall robot designed to do some of the drudge work.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Bhutan to Raise Tourist Fees In January

title: Films Reflect a Brash New Spain
description: LONG AFTER FRANCO DIED A LINGERING death in 1975, Chevy Chase would routinely end his newscasts on ''Saturday Night Live'' by announcing breathlessly that ''we've just been told that Generalissimo Francisco Franco is still dead.''

title: Wrigley Field: A Baseball Park That Radiates Joy
description: It is not within the power of architecture to guarantee that we have a good time - except, perhaps, at Wrigley Field. For this extraordinary baseball park, this amiable pile of steel and bricks and concrete that despite careful maintenance still shows every one of its 74 years, seems to radiate more joy than all the domed stadiums of the last generation put together. The happiness in this place is palpable -and it comes not merely from home-town loyalty to the Chicago Cubs, potent though that may be. The glow that envelops Wrigley Field each time a game begins is, at bottom, a shared sense that there is some basic rightness to this place, that it is a field full of grass in the middle of a city, one of the only places left in professional sports in which a game can be experienced more or less as it was half a century ago.

title: Lessons Learned In Youth Have
description: FOR A DANCE WRITER, ONE OF the unpredictable pleasures of interviewing is that moment when, without fanfare, words tumble out of a dancer or choreographer that offer a fresh or codifying insight into a body of work, a career or dance itself. Alexander Kolpin, a young principal dancer with the Royal Danish Ballet, Martha Graham and Erick Hawkins are all articulate and, often, poetic. Recent conversations with each yielded three such insights - small truths that lingered long after they were uttered.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CHILDHOOD OF NIVASIO DOLCEMARE. By Alberto Savinio. Translated by Richard Pevear. Introduction by Dore Ashton. (Eridanos Press, Cloth, $21; Paper, $12.) First published in Italian in 1941, this short autobiographical novel deftly combines farce with surrealist imagery in its satire of aristocratic society in turn-of-the-century Athens.

title: Navigating Through a Job Hunt
description: As the autumn winds begin to blow, many executives find themselves with the urge to roam. According to Drake Beam Morin Inc. of New York, the world's largest career counseling and outplacement firm, more executives change jobs in September than in any other month.

title: Seasonal Flower
description: LAST call to dig, divide and replant spring-summer flowering perennials especially phlox, daylily, astilbe, hosta and columbine. Seed or sod new lawns; keep moist to speed germination and rooting. Continue moving house plants indoors; check plants for insects and discard those infested with white flies as these insects are hard to control if taken indoors. Blossoms for Fall

title: NEW YORK EXPANDS AUTO-THEFT PLAN
description: An innovative effort to deter automobile thefts has been so successful in two Queens police precincts that the department has decided to expand it to much of the city.

title: Guernsey Bisects Solved the Supply Problem
description: A simple postcard can lead to some rewarding research.

title: Aquino Says Soviet Base Offer Is Up to U.S.
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that the United States rather than the Philippines must decide whether to accept a Soviet offer and close American bases here in return for a Soviet pullout from a strategic base in Vietnam.

title: Midnight Perfection
description: The only time Tom Browning had to work out of trouble was after it was over. Browning had just retired the last of 27 straight Dodger batters and he remained trapped under a pile of teammates for nearly a minute late Friday night in Cincinnati. At last he emerged, disheveled and a little disbelieving. But the night was as he had left it. Perfect.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 18, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 7 FALLEN HEARTS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The scandals and horrors of her past return to haunt a bride in a backwoods town. 2 10 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 3 3 TEAM YANKEE, by Harold Coyle. (Berkley, $4.95.) The exploits of an American tank company in Europe - during World War III. 4 2 THE FIVE BELLS AND BLADEBONE, by Martha Grimes. (Dell, $4.50.) Two Scotland Yard men track down a murderer. 5 8 HOT FLASHES, by Barbara Raskin. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Coastal Pollution Isn't Just Coastal
description: The thorough piece ''Coastal Pollution: No Quick Remedy'' on Aug. 28 is to be well-pondered.

title: Steinbrenner Treated Unfairly
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Through a Life Darkly
description: THE MAGIC LANTERN An Autobiography. By Ingmar Bergman. Translated by Joan Tate. Illustrated. 308 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Sounds of the Big Bands Still Swing on the Dance Floor
description: ERIC EMORY likes to tell about the time his band played at a dinner-dance for the New York Society for the Deaf. The guests conversed in sign language, he said, so you could really hear the music.

title: No Pay, No Fun, but Fight Is On for U.N. Job
description: The job provides a chauffeur-driven limousine but it does not pay a salary. It means attending innumerable cocktail parties, shaking thousands of hands and sitting for weeks on a podium trying to look bright-eyed and interested as hundreds of orators reel off prepared speeches that more often than not are repetitive and dull.

title: SHADOW OF A STRANGER
description: Wally Lamb writes in ''The Shadow of a Stranger'' (About Men, Aug. 21) that parents must protect their children from strange men. As a woman, though, I am also viewed as a dangerous stranger in many situations.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
A Different Way to Rebuild a Downtown
description: LEAD: THE City of New Rochelle has received quite a gift for its 300th birthday this year. It is a signed contract for the construction of a 31-story, 360-unit condominium complex complete with health club, tennis center and 525-car parking garage in the heart of its central business district.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Back to Colonial Basics FOR some, getting back to the basics in cooking means popping a potato into the wall oven, rather than nuking it in the microwave. For Alice Ross of Smithtown, getting back to the basics means the basics. She spends two to three hours feeding wood into a brick and stone oven before she even begins baking that Long Island potato. Mrs. Ross specializes in Colonial cooking. ''I've always been an adventurous kind of cook,'' she said, ''and for years I collected all these old pots. I figured I might as well start using them.''

title: A Phone Call Ends Custody For a Father
description: In the end, it was an unexpected telephone call that plucked two children from what appeared to be a happy home.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Seven years ago, we built a redwood deck and left it untreated, as we expected it to weather to a uniform gray color. After the first year, the wood darkened with fungus and moss and there was no graying. The deck was scrubbed and a gray deck stain applied, but two years later the wood was again dark with fungus and moss. Is there any way to achieve a stable gray color?

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Scouting Project
description: LEAD: Local Boy Scouts are preparing to rebuild a cabin that was badly damaged last month by a fire termed suspicious in origin.

title:
If You're Thinking of Living in:;
PARAMUS
description: LEAD: To the motorist driving along Route 4 or Route 17 in New Jersey, Paramus looks like nothing more than a jumble of giant malls, retail strips and home furnishing outlets - an image that over the years has led to its being called the shopping center capital of the Northeast.

title: My Birth And the Great Hurricane of '38
description: WITH a mighty and explosive burst, the wind split the giant elm, sending it crashing through the garage; the lights went out, the trolleys stopped and my whole birthday party was forced to sleep over. It was 1945, the night of my seventh birthday. It was a night of cozy excitement and as the wind whistled, my family sat around the candle-lit kitchen table. ''This is how it was the night you were born,'' one aunt told me. ''Only worse,'' piped in another. ''No one will ever forget the night of the Great Hurricane of '38!'' ''The hospital lights were all dim,'' my mother told me. ''But I wasn't at all surprised there was such a storm the night you were born!'' Much laughter. My brother poking me in the ribs. ''Hold it, hold it,'' I cried. ''What's so funny? Wasn't it scary?'' More laughs, my grandmother with the unmistakable gesture of Italian love, tweaking both my cheeks, my mother exchanging the female's knowing looks with her sisters. More rib pokes and tousling of hair. As the 50th anniversary of that great storm arrives along with my halfcentury birthday, I look back to this sequence of memory for the start of my curious and paradoxical bonding to the hurricane of 1938. For the stage was here set for a theme of my life and of the lives of many who have made this trip with me. The mythology of the hurricane was insinuated into my life much like an astrological sign. It was a source of personal identity, individual mystique, and it was a historic connection with the lives of others. From that birthday party, I learned of what a difficult pregnancy I was for my mother, how much I kicked and squirmed and how long was the delivery and recovery. ''Like a storm coming that finally arrived,'' she would say from time to time. To which there was always someone to say (often myself), ''And you've been checking out the damage ever since!'' And what was the damage of this coincidence that impressed itself on my young psyche? I seem always to have known that hundreds of people perished that tempestuous night so that, when the going got tough for the little kid, having survived the birth storm was a source of confidence and optimism. When I was a teen-ager, too freely expressing criticism of my parents, I could not be told, ''An apple falls not far from the tree,'' for I always had the ready response, ''It does in a hurricane!'' I believed it and I lived it. The cosmic connection I bear to hurricanes was reinforced at every turn. With uncanny consistency, a hurricane hit the East Coast of the United States every seven years as I celebrated my birthday for over a quarter-century. Rarely has there not been a stormy landfall for me to receive as nature's birthday gift. When ''camp'' was in, I searched for my personal camp hero. No doubt about it: Richard Widmark, for his otherwise unremarkable performance in ''Slattery's Hurricane.'' I have met dozens of people who witnessed the famous storm and volunteered their stories for my memory. It was natural, for every offhanded reminiscence of that night precipitated a mutual interest. No one who lived through the ''Great Storm'' forgot where he was or what he was doing at that moment. A typical conversation took place at Woods Hole, Mass., when, during a chance encounter with an elderly mason repairing an old stone wall, it was volunteered that he ''first built it 33 years ago, after the storm.'' That would be my invitation to say, ''That was the night I was born.'' His memory was immediately loosened as I learned how this man had spent the better part of that night in 1938 ''rope-tied to that there post,'' as he pointed to it, ''10 feet off the ground and two feet out of the water, fearing for my life up there.'' I have met people who spent the night in Long Island Rail Road cars with their feet wet, who had their front yards end up on their neighbors' backyards, whose boats moored in Southampton Sound traveled overnight to Peconic Bay where there had not previously been a waterway and some who woke up the next morning to find the sand bar of Long Island's South Fork had been moved hundreds of yards east and north. So fearful was the darkness that night that the town fathers of Southampton vowed ''never again'' and invested in their own gas-powered generator. Twenty-seven years later, in October 1965, when the rest of the Eastern United States was plunged into darkness in the ''Great Blackout,'' Southampton's lights merely flickered once. The folklore is endless, and even though I could not possibly have had any of the experience, much of it is collected in my memory. In some part of my identity, I have thought of myself as born as much of storm as of woman. As a professor to the generation of the 1960's when asked that obligatory student question, ''What sign were you born under?'' my unblinking answer was ''Hurricane.'' It was, of course, with great interest that I came upon a book-length account of my stormy day shortly before the crisis of my 40th birthday. I bought it on the spot! I could hardly wait to immerse myself in a subject so intimate to me but still so unstructured in a mosaic of anecdotes. I never got past the first page. The hurricane of 1938, which had played a role of continuity in most of my life, became a symbol, once again, but this time it was of the discontinuity of midlife reconsideration. I thought the author was mistaken when he dated the storm as Sept. 21, 1938. A misprint, I was sure: I was born on Sept. 14! Who at age 55-minus-10 has not felt the famous lack of sufficient substance of those first four decades? Who has not wished to celebrate the truths of his life if only to eclipse the lies, to fete the successes and regret not the untraveled paths? Who has not struggled, at that age, with the downside?

title: Of Trade and War
description: To the Editor:

title: A Beauty Stumbles
description: Judges have played an important role in the life of Bess Myerson. Several made her Miss America. And one may decide whether she goes to jail. Jury selection began last week in the trial of Ms. Myerson, New York City's former Cultural Affairs Commissioner. She is accused of seeking to improperly influence yet another judge, former Supreme Court Justice Hortense W. Gabel, who presided over a divorce case involving Ms. Myerson's companion, Carl A. Capasso. Those two are also on trial. The case forced Ms. Myerson to resign from her post last year and has embarrassed Mayor Koch, a close friend. But the Mayor contends the trial is more of a personal tragedy. ''It's obviously sad,'' he said. ''I'm not anxious about myself. I'm saddened by her state.''

title: Martha Brown to Marry Bruce Scott in November
description: The engagement of Martha Elliott Brown to Bruce William Scott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Cyril Scott of Darien, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Lucy Livingston Brown of New Canaan, Conn., and George Trowbridge Brown of Providence, R.I., and West Falmouth, Mass. A November wedding is planned.

title: Navy Is Waging a Battle For San Francisco Port
description: The old Hunters Point Naval Shipyard, which sent warships into the Pacific in three wars, seems an odd battleground for a fight over this city's future. Today, in the decrepit buildings that the Navy vacated 14 years ago, Tom Lacey harvests 4,000 pounds of mushrooms a day for local markets, Scott Madison makes cheesecake for restaurants and Judith Dunworth paints her abstracts.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE WOMEN IN HER DREAMS. By Candace Denning. (North Point, $16.95.) This striking second novel by the author of ''Adventures With Julia'' is composed of finely observed scenes of a young woman's dance with small-town folly. Sarah Broderhouse is the principal object of scrutiny in a work that unfolds with the bleak inevitability of a brilliant black-and-white film.

title: Junior Hockey Set for Canada
description: Canada has been awarded the 1991 world junior hockey championships. The decision was made at the annual congress of the International Ice Hockey Federation last week on Majorca.

title: Bentsen Plays Up Roots In His Tour of the South
description: Texas Democrats with national political aspirations have often identified themselves as Southwesterners. Lyndon B. Johnson particularly favored this approach after he decided that his party would never nominate a Southerner for President.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Notebook; U.S. Committee Closes Book on Myers
description: As far as the United States Olympic Committee is concerned, the Angel Myers case is closed.

title: Robert James Longood Sr., Speechwriter, 61
description: Robert James Longood Sr., director of speechwriting in the Office of Public Relations at the Department of Health and Human Services, died Sept. 10 in the Washington Home Hospice in Washington. He was 61 years old and lived in Rockville, Md.

title: Carole Kennedy And W. P. Shea Are Wed on L.I.
description: The marriage of Carole Lesley Kennedy, a daughter of Letty L. Linhart of Olvido, Fla., and Dr. Robert S. Kennedy of Cambridge, Mass., to William Peter Shea, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Shea of Brookville, L.I., took place yesterday in Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Mario Costa, assisted by the Rev. Vincent J. Hart, performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Chapel.

title: Two Rock Storytellers Hit Their Stride
description: ROCK LOVES OVERNIGHT SENSATIONS - the singer who swoops out of nowhere and draws a dedicated national following, and preferably a hit single, to reinforce the great American myth of the untutored genius. Second best is a smooth ascent from cult band to theater headliner to arena band; everybody loves a winner.

title: Caroleigh Ritz Marries on L.I.
description: At the Presbyterian Church in Bridgehampton, L.I., Caroleigh Ritz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Ritz of Bridgehampton, was married yesterday to Edwin Denison Morgan Evarts, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jasper M. Evarts of Landgrove, Vt. The Revs. Stephen and Linda Quinlan performed the ceremony.

title: Commercial Property: Energy Subsidies; A Sweetener to Stay in New York Stirs Controversy
description: New York City helps more than 250 companies pay their utility bills and it has promised future subsidies to nearly as many additional ones, from fledgling garment makers to major investment banks.

title: Sony and CBS Records: What a Romance!
description: ON THE MORNING OF last Oct. 20, Laurence A. Tisch, the president and chief executive officer of CBS Inc., sat in his office on the 35th floor of Black Rock thinking pessimistic thoughts. In the background, a single television set was tuned to the Financial News Network, which was airing a Wall Street report. Tisch was meeting with a business associate that morning, and their conversation was the conversation that businessmen across the country were having that day, the day after Black Monday, when the stock market collapsed: What could it mean?

title: WRITERS ARE LIARS, PUBLISHERS ARE WORSE
description: LEAD: GASTON GALLIMARD A Half-Century of French Publishing. By Pierre Assouline. Translated by Harold J. Salemson. Illustrated. 430 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $35.

title: The Worst Beach Pollution Is Routine
description: SYRINGES in the sand and sludge dumped into the sea became symbols this summer for the deterioration of the New York metropolitan region's waters. But, many marine biologists and environmentalists contend, the worst threat to human health in the shore's waters and the main problem that needs to be addressed now is sewage, not sludge or medical waste.

title: Business and Health Mix at Spa Sessions
description: Spas have generally been known for their facials and Jacuzzis and have appealed mainly to women who want to be pampered. Now spas are trying to provide stress reduction and fitness for busy executives who combine corporate conferences and relaxation.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Drug Violators Be Paid for Time Away?
description: Every professional athlete has a moral obligation to honor his contract and do everything possible to perform at his best. Being involved with drugs, in my opinion, is highly irresponsible and illustrates an individual's disregard for his teammates and his fans.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Drug Violators Be Paid for Time Away?
description: The drug violator could draw on his or her sick time, and thus continue to be paid. After that is exhausted, vacation time. If there is no provision for leave time in the professional athlete's contract, or if such leave time has been exhausted, then that person should go on leave without pay. Professional athletes are no different from anyone else; they sign a contract to work and they ought not to be coddled. ROBIN M. ROSENTHAL New York

title: Senate Panel Supports Nominee on Education
description: President Reagan's choice of Lauro F. Cavazos of Texas to become the nation's next Secretary of Education has been approved by a Senate committee, clearing the way for expected easy confirmation by the full Senate.

title: Gene Russell Sower Weds Nina Sloan, Film Producer
description: Nina Savad Sloan, the daughter of Profs. Arthur and Helen Sloan of Lynbrook, L.I., and Gene Russell Sower, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene Sower of Edison, N.J., were married last evening at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden by Rabbi Charles Lippman.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: TRIPLE THREAT

title: HANDS-ON STYLE
description: For many men, a manicure is a supreme but necessary indulgence, even an inexpensive thrill. Some desire short, meticulously groomed nails for professional reasons; others enjoy the soothing qualities of the experience. For instance, Charlie Rosner, creative director for a New York City advertising agency, favors very short nails for drawing, and delights in his periodic pilgrimages to Manhattan's Gio Hair Stylists because the manicurists there, he says, ''are kind enough to give me half an hour of complete silence once every 10 days to two weeks.'' Si E. Knee, a New Jersey leather-goods consultant who is a frequent manicure customer at Joseph Hair Stylists in Manhattan, has been getting his nails done - buff, no polish - for 30 years simply because ''it makes me feel good.''

title: Grumman Chief Offers Gloomy Forecast
description: THE new chairman of the Grumman Corporation, Long Island's largest private employer, has shaken business and political circles on the Island with an unusually blunt and pessimistic assessment of the region's economic future.

title: New Opposition Front in India Stages Lively Rally
description: In an extravagant political rally on a Bay of Bengal beach tonight, a nine-party national opposition front set aside differences and opened a campaign to try to bring down the Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi.

title:
GARDENING;
Bonsai: Some Sources for the Timid
description: LEAD: HORTICULTURE has been described as a blend of art and science, but providing for the needs of plants in a house or garden has become increasingly technical.

title: Amy Cohen Weds
description: Amy Renee Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold T. Cohen of East Meadow, L.I., was married yesterday evening to Dr. Douglas Mitchell Roth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Roth of Monsey, N.Y. Rabbi Maurice Simkus officiated at Temple Israel of South Merrick, in Merrick L.I.

title: DATABANK: September 18, 1988
Athletes Have Right to Privacy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Palmer Leads Seniors: Arnold Palmer, five under par for the day after the first five holes, rolled in a 25-foot birdie putt on the final hole yesterday to salvage a four-under-par 68 for a three-shot lead after two rounds of the $325,000 Crestar PGA Seniors Classic in Richmond. ''I kind of pulled it back together,'' said Palmer, who had a 36-hole total of nine-under-par 133. Bob Nichols had a 69 and a 36-hole total of 136. That tied him for second with Walt Zembriski, whose 66 was the best round of the day in intermittent rain over the 6,644-yard Hermitage Country Club course.(AP) Three-Way Tie in Boston Classic: Larry Rinker shot a six-under-par 65 yesterday to tie Steve Pate and D. A. Weibring for the lead after three rounds of the $600,000 Bank of Boston Classic in Sutton, Mass.

title: New Gear Emphasizes Convenience
description: Next to picture quality, perhaps the most decisive consideration in choosing video equipment is convenience. Two recent innovations, both developed by Panasonic, stand out in this respect - a wobble-free camcorder and a phone-programmable VCR.

title: THE WAR WITHIN
description: I was intrigued and then dismayed by Richard N. Goodwin's article ''The War Within'' (Aug. 21), about Lyndon B. Johnson. From the depth of his analysis, it sounded as though Mr. Goodwin was one of the President's closest advisers. Mr. Goodwin met or talked with the President 127 times in 1964 and 1965, according to my research using the Presidential daily diaries. During that same period, Bill Moyers met or talked with the President more than 2,100 times and has yet to say anything publicly about the President's behavior.

title: Carol Makovich Is Married To James Patrick Grondin
description: Carol Jeanne Makovich, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Makovich of Norwalk, Conn., was married there yesterday to James Patrick Grondin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred L. Grondin of Milford, Mich. The Rev. Mark Grimes performed the ceremony at St. Jerome's Roman Catholic Church.

title: St. Paul's
description: To the Editor: Dean Alan Webster's article, ''St. Paul's Is for Yanks, Too'' (Travel, July 10), brought back memories of how his kindness on Sept. 17, 1978, rescued me from despondency.

title: Fences: Do They Really Block Views?
description: LEAD: OVER the objections of many residents of the Town of Oyster Bay, the town board has amended a zoning regulation so that property owners may erect six-foot-high backyard fences without having to seek a variance from the Zoning Board of Appeals.

title: AMERICAN GLAMOUR
description: In the Hollywood of the 1920's through the 40's, a man's clothes were cut to play up his assets - and play down the rest. And the fashions made popular by the studios' most celebrated leading men conveyed the message that, on celluloid at least, style and substance were synonymous. It wasn't easy, for example, to separate Robert Montgomery's suave authority from the elegant white dinner jackets he wore in his portraits. Increasingly, such stars came to be identified with their costumes: James Cagney, compact and menacing in a striped ''gangster suit''; William Powell, debonair in plaid; Van Johnson, boyishly insouciant in a V-neck pullover . . . the list goes on.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Collection of Territorial Gold Pieces Is Sold
description: LEAD: THE Kagin Collection of United States territorial gold pieces, possibly the finest ever formed, has been sold for $2.3 million. A Philadelphia coin dealership, Tangible Investments of America Inc., purchased the collection in conjunction with Iraj ''Roger'' Sayah, a former Iranian businessman now living in

title: An Old Favorite in New Hands
description: NEW life has been pumped into Ristorante Orlando, an old favorite in Huntington Village. The efforts of the new owners of this 30-year-old standby are dazzling regulars and first-timers alike.

title: Ernest Bloch Begins a Modest Comeback
description: LEAD: YEHUDI MENUHIN, ONE OF the steadfast champions of Ernest Bloch (1880-1959), remembers him as ''a great composer without any narrowing qualifications whatever, and the forerunner of a world of music which has superseded dodecaphony and returned to counterpoint and modal juxtaposition.''

title: A Preview of Classics and Pops at Hartford
description: OFFICIALLY, the Hartford Symphony subscription season will begin Oct. 4 and 5, with the Hartford Pops arriving a month later, but you can get a taste of both series at a special pre-opening concert this Saturday at 8 P.M.

title: For Sale: Farm Where Memories Grow
description: THE county has lost another farm market. A few months ago the Square Deal Farm in Hartsdale announced that it would not open this year. The land is apparently for sale, with the asking price in seven figures.

title: Conferees Say Bill to Revise Welfare Is in Trouble
description: Objections by a group of House liberals have imperiled a welfare bill that is languishing in a House-Senate conference, leaders of House and Senate conferees say.

title: Gay Caroline Vincent, Painter, Is Wed To William Farish Gerry, Stockbroker
description: The marriage of Gay Caroline Vincent, the daughter of Elizabeth von Furstenberg Reynolds of New York and Guy A. Vincent de la Maisoneuve of Sherman Oaks, Calif., to William Farish Gerry, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Harriman Gerry of Mill Neck, L.I., took place yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Robert Farrar Capon performed the ceremony.

title: Luring Apes From Mist To Movies
description: BEFORE SHE WENT OUT TO WORK WITH the gorillas, Sigourney Weaver said, she stopped by the small gorilla cemetery, at the grave of Dian Fossey, the prickly American naturalist who devoted 18 years of her life to befriending, studying and protecting the rare mountain gorilla. Fossey, whose murder in Rwanda in 1985 remains a mystery, is buried near Digit, a favorite ape, whose killing by poachers stirred international concern for the plight of the mountain gorillas.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Seven years ago, we built a redwood deck and left it untreated, as we expected it to weather to a uniform gray color. After the first year, the wood darkened with fungus and moss and there was no graying. The deck was scrubbed and a gray deck stain applied, but two years later the wood was again dark with fungus and moss. Is there any way to achieve a stable gray color?

title: U.S. Fears Japan Aids Libya on Chemical Arms
description: The United States has told Japan that it is concerned that a Japanese company has helped Libya build a metallurgical complex that could be used to help make chemical weapons.

title: Scott Flood Wed To Cecelie Berry
description: Cecelie S. Berry and Scott L. Flood, graduates of the Harvard Law School, were married yesterday at Grace United Methodist Church in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn by the Rev. Ivan Roberts.

title: News at Any Cost?
description: FAIR PLAY CBS, General Westmoreland, and How a Television Documentary Went Wrong. By Burton Benjamin. Illustrated. 218 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/Harper & Row. $17.95

title: What Do I Hear?
description: I AM having a hard time adjusting to the sounds inanimate objects are making. All around me, at home and work, steel and metal are talking to me.

title: Man in Chinatown Dispute Is Shot by Off-Duty Officer
description: An off-duty police officer shot and critically wounded a man who was firing shots at another man in Chinatown early yesterday, the police said.

title:
ART;
Portraits By Early Black Artists
description: LEAD: JOSHUA JOHNSON, a 19th-century black artist, never saw the Mona Lisa, yet the sitters in the 33 portrait paintings by him at the Whitney Museum of American Art's Fairfield County branch in Stamford have her simplicity and her serenity as a rule.

title: Jersey Man Pleads Guilty in Cable TV Fraud
description: A man who Federal officials say ran the biggest cable television piracy ring in the nation and defrauded cable companies of almost $5 million in potential fees pleaded guilty Friday to mail fraud and income tax evasion.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
The Race to Save the State's Farmland
description: LEAD: AS development pressures grow, many farmers are intent on getting the most value from their land, if not by working it then by selling it to builders. How to meet the farmers' concerns while preserving a dwindling supply of farmland is one of the state's biggest challenges.

title: Social Events; New Season's Debut
description: Subject Is Kissing

title: Review/Piano; Neil Rutman In Schubert And Mozart
description: It may be that many who attended Neil Rutman's piano recital at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening came primarily to hear the actor Tony Randall narrate Poulenc's ''Story of Babar the Little Elephant.''
