But by the time Mr. Randall appeared, after intermission, Mr. Rutman had won over the audience for himself with exquisite performances of a Mozart Sonata (K. 311), Schubert's ''Wanderer'' Fantasy, and a new work by Albert Glinsky.

title: Harvard Wins In Soccer, Too
description: Derek Mills headed home the goal with less than six minutes remaining as Harvard defeated Columbia, 1-0, today in the Ivy League men's soccer opener for both teams.

title: THE ANGER IS BILINGUAL
description: LEAD: CONFESSIONS OF A GOOD ARAB By Yoram Kaniuk. Translated by Dalya Bilu. 215 pp. New York: George Braziller. $17.50.

title: Once More, Alger Hiss
description: To the Editor:

title: 1800's Tradition Invoked in Fight Over Wall
description: A gentleman farmer dedicated to keeping his property much as it has been for hundreds of years reached into the 19th century for a solution to his dispute with neighbors who disturbed an old stone wall dividing their property.

title: Faye Zuckerman Becomes a Bride
description: Faye Beth Zuckerman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Zuckerman of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to J. Martin Chitwood, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Chitwood of Jefferson City, Mo. Rhode Island Superior Court Judge Richard Israel performed the ceremony in the arbor at Hammersmith Farm in Newport, R.I.

title: Pressure Builds for an End to Shoreham
description: LEAD: PRESSURE continued to mount last week for acceptance of Governor Cuomo's proposed settlement with the Long Island Lighting Company for closing the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Review/Dance; Choreography From a Vineyard Summer
description: The autumn dance season has surely begun. The Yard offered a program Friday night at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace, and the Yard's annual programs in New York are signs that an old season has ended and a new one is at hand.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: GROWN-UP FAST: A True Story of Teenage Life in Suburban America. By Betsy Israel. (Poseidon, $16.95.) In a manner reminiscent of the 1950's, Betsy Israel tried to hide and deny a pregnancy in 1976, producing a daughter who was spirited away to eager adoptive parents. Ms. Israel sets the stage for her pregnancy with a depiction of teen-age life during the early 70's in suburban Long Island, but ''Grown-Up Fast'' quickly degenerates from lively reporting to a personal confession.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: CHAPIN IN RUTHERFORD Tom Chapin, the folk singer and songwriter, will do two shows Saturday in the partially restored Rivoli Theater at the Williams Center in Rutherford.

title: From the Drought to the 'Kiddie Tax'
description: Below are answers to recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: AN EVENING WITH CLAIRE. By Gaito Gazdanov. Translated by Jodi Daynard. (Ardis, $19.50.) This once celebrated, until now largely forgotten novella by the Russian writer Gaito Gazdanov was first published in France in 1930. It consists entirely of the reminiscences of its hero, Kolya Sosedov, a deeply introspective young Russian emigre living in Paris, whose recollections, prompted by an evening spent with Claire, the great love of his life, reach back to his affluent childhood in prerevolutionary Russia and his youth amid the disorder and violence of the country's civil war.

title: Vane Lucas Wed To Lucy G. Field
description: Lucy Georgina Field, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard D. Field of Manhasset, L.I., and Windham, N.Y., was married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset to Vane Thomas Lucas, the son of Mrs. Vane B. Lucas of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Dr. Lucas. Bishop Robert C. Witcher of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Leslie Hughs. Mrs. Lucas, a manager in the consumer-card division of the American Express Company in New York, graduated from Bowdoin College and received an M.B.A. degree from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. Her father is a dentist. Her mother, Lucy S. Field, is a sales agent with Douglas Van Riper Inc., a real-estate concern in Manhasset.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Drug Violators Be Paid for Time Away?
description: No. But if they remain drug free for the rest of their careers, the money could be added to their pensions. JAMES McCAFFREY Brooklyn

title: Evidence Blocked In Barkley Case
description: A Superior Court judge ruled today to suppress evidence in a gun-possession case against Charles Barkley of the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Julie Breene Married To Townsend Ziebold
description: At the First Congregational Church in Washington, Conn., Julie Brodie Breene, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James K. Breene Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Warren, Conn., was married yesterday to William Townsend Ziebold Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ziebold of Charleston, West Va., and Hot Springs, Va. The Rev. Richard Sears performed the ceremony.

title: Outdoors; Steel Shot Is Replacing Lead
description: With waterfowling seasons beginning next month, hunters should be aware of the increasing number of states or portions of them that have been zoned for steel shot. In some instances, the states have moved ahead of the Federal timetable established several years ago for the switch to steel.

title: Margi Glass Is Bride Of Scott H. Orenstein
description: Margi Elizabeth Georgina Glass, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Kusik of New York and Los Angeles, and Scott Henry Orenstein, a son of Carol Orenstein of New York and Joel C. Orenstein of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Hays H. Rockwell.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Tokyo
description: Perhaps more than ever before, Tokyo these days is about money and power. With Japan's economy in perpetual overdrive, evidence of the city's affluence is everywhere. Tiny apartments are still crammed together, and much of the architecture remains a postwar afterthought, but Tokyo is rebuilding every day. From the old neighborhoods to the center city, new apartments and offices are popping up.

title: A Wing and a Prayer
description: ASKED THE OBVIOUS - WHY? -Greg DeWolf says: ''When I was a kid, my father told me work was something that shouldn't make you smile. I wanted to prove he was wrong.'' DeWolf teaches people more or less how to fly. He's the founder of Fly America, an organization dedicated to popularizing the sport of hang gliding, all four of whose members are now involved in the first cross-country hang-gliding excursion. It began on Memorial Day near Los Angeles, and barring calamitous weather, should conclude sometime next month. That's DeWolf, above, taking his turn in flight near Hawk Springs, Wyo. Final touchdown is planned for Kitty Hawk, N.C., the famous launching pad for Wilbur and Orville Wright and currently the home of Francis Rogallo, who, in 1949, patented the flexible wing that was later adapted for hang gliders.

title: Jazz Moves Fast Forward Into Its Past
description: THEY'RE EVERYWHERE: TRIBUTE CONCERTS, tribute groups, tribute records, repertory groups, floods of reissued records. This year's JVC festival, programmed by George Wein and as good an indication of official jazz culture as can be found, was more than ever laden with homages to past masters, from Mingus to Ellington, from Buddy Rich to Billie Holiday. Lincoln Center, which has started a long overdue jazz series, calls it Classical Jazz, with emphasis on the word classical. Of the eight jazz shows they've produced over the last two years, five have been tributes. The American Jazz Orchestra, a fine repertory group working out of Cooper Union, exists to perform classic big-band jazz in concert.

title: Five Torah Scrolls Burned by Vandals At Brooklyn Temple
description: Vandals broke into a synagogue in the Midwood section of Brooklyn early yesterday and set on fire at least five Torah scrolls, the most sacred objects in Judaism.

title: The Dictionary as a Blockbuster
description: Just about everybody owns one, but nobody ever reads it all the way through. The plot is nonexistent, the ending shamelessly predictable and the style sets the standard for wordiness. There's no chance of it becoming a mini-series.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Frantic Starring Harrison Ford, Betty Buckley, Emmanuelle Seigner, John Mahoney, Gerard Klein. Directed by Roman Polanski. 1987. Warner Home Video. 120 minutes. $89.95. Rated R. Closed captioned.

title: REFLECTIONS OF A BIONIC CRITIC
description: The Kitman Tapes. By Marvin Kitman. 377 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: DATA UPDATE: September 18, 1988
Southampton Strives to Stave Off Pond Pollution
description: LEAD: SHADOWS of concern have fallen over a few lakeside communities in North Sea, Long Island's oldest port, as a result of residents' fears that their bit of paradise is on the edge of ruin.

title: Court Overturns Curb On Taxes in California
description: A state appellate court has overturned a 1986 voter-initiated referendum that would have required voters to approve all taxes imposed by local governments.

title: Point O'Woods: Idyllic Monolith?
description: Your article refers to Point O' Woods, Fire Island as an idyllic community. I gather there are no blacks, there are no jews, there are no gays, there are no hispanics, etc.

title: Battle Over Condo Conversions Heats Up
description: WHILE New Jersey suffers from a severe shortage of low-cost housing, tens of thousands of tenants across the state face eviction because their apartments are being converted to condominiums or cooperatives. Mounting opposition to the evictions has generated fierce legislative and legal debates.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DONALD L. HARRIS;
Helping to Build A New Newark
description: LEAD: DONALD L. HARRIS has built a reputation as a developer with a social conscience.

title: Evans's Homer Sinks Yanks BASEBALL
description: There was something desperate in their voices, something that said the Yankees are running out of time and hope. They were euphoric Thursday night, but today they were glum and uncertain. They knew it as they dressed and left under a darkened sky at Fenway Park.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MEDIEVAL PROSTITUTION. By Jacques Rossiaud. Translated by Lydia G. Cochrane. (Blackwell, $24.95.) Reeling from the Turkish threat, torn by schism and beset by plague, mid-15th-century Christendom entered the era that would become the Renaissance. Popular reactions to death and uncertainty were split between doomsday prophecy of the apocalypse and vigorous promotion of a return to nature.

title: Lessons From Art Rooney
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ON THE WAY UP
description: THE YOUNG MR. LINCOLN Starring Henry Fonda. Directed by John Ford. 1940. Key Video. 100 minutes. $19.98. (Closed Captioned). If Abraham Lincoln were half the man that Henry Fonda makes him in ''The Young Mr. Lincoln,'' he could have settled the Civil War with a jest. John Ford's 1940 movie, about Lincoln's days as a lawyer in Springfield, Ill., in the 1830's, is unabashed hagiography, but its strong feeling for time and place and the careful performance by Fonda, looking more like Lincoln in frock coat and stovepipe hat than Lincoln could have, makes up for some of the hokum.

title: Streetscapes: The 125th Street Station; Metro-North Plans New Makeup, Not Plastic Surgery, for a Beauty
description: It has been so neglected that it has the air of an abandoned building, even though 3,400 passengers use it daily. But now the Metro-North Commuter Railroad has put out to bid plans to renovate its 125th Street station at Park Avenue, which was built in 1897. Sometime next year the exterior will emerge from decades of neglect, but the long-hidden golden oak interior will simply get another coat of paint.

title: Article 429888 -- No Title
description: THE OUTSKIRTS OF TROY By Carl Dennis. 80 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $8.95. THE IMPERFECT PARADISE By Linda Pastan. 80 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $15.95. TANGO By Daniel Halpern. 88 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/ Viking, Cloth, $17.95. Penguin, Paper, $10.95.

title: A Quintessentially American View of the World
description: It would be difficult to overestimate the impact that the National Geographic magazine had on the formative years of someone raised in postwar America. From the perspective of small-town U.S.A., the wild animals, tribal cultures and mountain vistas pictured on its pages seemed utterly foreign and completely fascinating. They were far off but, with the magazine nestled in my lap, they were also tantalizingly near. Together with the then-infant medium of television, the National Geographic made the world shrink before my eyes.

title: National League's Leading Batters Are Far Below Average
description: The honor of the National League is in the hands of Tony Gwynn, Rafael Palmeiro, Gerald Perry, Andres Galarraga, Kirk Gibson and Andre Dawson.

title: FICTION
description: THEN AGAIN. By Sue McCauley. (Hodder & Stoughton/David & Charles, $22.95.) Even when outcasts find each other, that may be all they find: society has usually closed and locked the door. In her very good first novel, ''Other Halves,'' the New Zealand writer Sue McCauley vividly portrayed two of society's rejects struggling to build a life in a highly industrialized country that is secretly sick of itself. Here, condescension if not dislike is the normal approach to ''misfits'': the poor, the Maori minority, single mothers on welfare, homosexuals, the insane. In ''Then Again,'' her second novel, Ms. McCauley approaches the same theme from many directions but is not as successful. In alternating sections she develops the lives of a larger cast of characters who assemble on a bucolic island near Auckland, trying to escape the buttoned-up society that has rejected them. Maureen and her three anxious children are on welfare; Keith, who drinks too much, has quit his reporter's job after siding with a Maori in a labor dispute; beautiful, middle-aged, overweight Josie is afraid after several bad marriages to try again with Geoff, who loves her. Ms. McCauley uses a houseful of militant lesbian feminists to raise some women's issues, but she has a bigger aim in mind: the irony of ''safety'' in a nuclear-free zone. ''Sometimes,'' says one woman to Keith, it ''seems so futile. . . . Yet I can see if we were all . . . determined . . . well then we'd have disarmament tomorrow. So the reason for despair lies in what we are.'' As the characters meet, and as one of them, in despair, chooses violence, the author's preaching clouds the story. Yet her portraits, especially of the women, stand out above the fog.

title: Priests in Baltimore Asked To Urge Gun Control Backing
description: Roman Catholic priests in the Baltimore Archdiocese were urged use their homilies to encourage support for the state's law controlling pistols.

title: 870 Arrested in Effort to Halt Gang Violence in Los Angeles
description: Police officers swept gang territories and arrested more than 870 people to curb violence that caused one death and left at least four people wounded over the weekend, the authorities said today.

title: Oasis on the Mall
description: One of the problems facing the millions of visitors who flock each year to the museums on the Mall is the lack of eating places, a situation alleviated somewhat with the opening last weekend of a huge restaurant at the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum, which hopes to feed 9,000 visitors a day.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 18,1988: MONDAY

title: To Our Readers
description: Starting today, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on weekdays within 75 miles of New York City, and on all of Long Island, is increased to 35 cents. The change is prompted by rising production costs, including an increase in the price of paper. The newspaper's Sunday price is unchanged, as is its weekday price outside the 75-mile area.

title: Pure Knowledge vs. Impure Profit
description: Oscar Wilde could resist everything except temptation. University presidents, it seems, can resist everything except money. Last week came news that Carnegie Mellon University and Stanford University have invested in Next Inc., the computer company founded by Apple's Steven Jobs. Even Harvard, having resisted the apple for eight years, has finally succumbed: it proposes to raise $30 million by joining in a partnership to exploit the ideas of its medical school faculty.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Thursday, with an article about proposed accounting rule changes, misstated the 1987 net income of Bell Atlantic. It was $1.24 billion.

title: A Drifter Called Johnny Is Killed Fleeing Youths
description: Some of the men who lived with Johnny in the hollow core of a walkway support next to the Harlem River Drive were philosophical yesterday about his death.

title: Officer Is Run Down By a Hit-Run Driver
description: A 23-year-old rookie police officer was seriously injured in a hit-and-run accident last night, the police said.

title: Giants Hold Off Cowboys
description: Before today's game with the Dallas Cowboys, a number of Giants players talked about, even dwelled on, the bad luck that seemed to haunt the team whenever it visited Texas Stadium. After the Giants' 12-10 victory, even the most superstitious Giant might believe that fate switched sides. At least for an afternoon.

title: Why Mayor Koch Went to Court in Parking-Meter Theft Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Carol Mann Wed To H. W. Helene
description: Carol Ruth Mann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Mann of Chicago, and Howard Warren Helene, the son of Lillian Kingsley of the Bronx and the late Robert Helene, were married yesterday afternoon at their home in Ghent, N.Y. Rabbi Leslie Freedman performed the ceremony.

title: Congress, Eyes on Elections, Taking Up Minimum Wage
description: The Senate, in the next two weeks, and the House, shortly afterward, will decide how much to increase the minimum wage of millions of American workers at the lowest end of the economic scale.

title: Coast Guard Joins Effort to Save Mexicans Trapped by Hurricane
description: The last traces of Hurricane Gilbert were being felt on both sides of the border today as the United States Coast Guard helped villagers flee treacherous flood waters in northern Mexico and residents in several Texas towns cleaned up debris from tornadoes spawned by the storm.

title: Business and the Law; Target Is Suing Asbestos Lawyers
description: A LEADING manufacturer of asbestos has decided that, when it comes to litigation, a strong offense can be a powerful defense.

title: Prices Worry Coffee Group
description: The world's coffee-producing and consuming nations will begin talks this week in an effort to prevent a price collapse in 1989.

title: Modern Matchmaking: Money's Allure in Marketing Mates and Marriage
description: LEAD: For Stuart Fromm and Suzanne Seid, the road to their November wedding began in a penthouse office at 400 Madison Avenue, where singles employ the matchmaking services of Helena Amram to meet, perchance to marry.

title: Campaign Trail; In Chicago Politics, Never a Dull Moment
description: The Presidential race is downright mellow compared to the one in Chicago.

title: Police Say Three Deaths In Fire Were Homicides
description: Three people whose bodies were found in a fire were determined to be homicide victims, and the police were searching today for clues in the first murders in this town in nearly four decades.

title: Jackson Visits Homeless Jamaicans
description: Seven days ago, the fiercest hurricane of the century swept across the beaches here on the easternmost tip of Jamaica, beginning a wild, thrashing journey that devastated the island.

title: Cocaine Raid in Florida
description: United States Customs agents seized 1,000 pounds of cocaine and arrested eight men in a raid of the sport-fishing boat ''What's Up'' Saturday, the Customs Service reported. A Customs spokesman, Cliff Stallings, said the cocaine was worth about $12 million whosesale. Also seized were the boat and five vehicles. Customs agents, acting on a tip, began surveillance of the 38-foot boat at a Key Largo marina two weeks ago, Mr. Stallings said.

title: Ready To Play Rough
description: Rarely have so many players skirmished so often in a National Football League game as the Jets and the Oilers did today.

title: Waiting, Forever, for Mr. Arafat
description: Is it possible that Yasir Arafat will finally acknowledge Israel's right to exist, and that his Palestine Liberation Organization will renounce terrorism? For months, rumors have swirled and hopes expanded. But at Strasbourg last week, Mr. Arafat only repeated the old, tired formulations. As with Godot in Beckett's play, the ''new'' Arafat seems perpetually around the corner.

title: Redskins Defense Trips Up Eagles
description: The Washington Redskins defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 17-10, today in a battle between two of the four 1-1 teams that were leading the National Football Conference's Eastern Division.

title: Louis Quinn, Character Actor, 73
description: Louis Quinn, a veteran gag writer turned character actor who became known to millions of television viewers as Roscoe the horse player on ''77 Sunset Strip,'' died Wednesday of lung cancer. He was 73 years old.

title: L.I. Lawmaker Shakes Albany In G.O.P. Rise
description: A soft-spoken man with a successful law practice and two flags standing guard over his desk, State Senator Ralph J. Marino hardly seems the sort destined to shake up the establishment.

title: NBC Considers Scrapping Saturday Cartoons
description: Saturday morning has long been the playground of network television, the place where Smurfs, Chipmunks and other cartoon creatures reigned over a time period given over by all three networks to children viewers.

title: 2 Racing Cars Kill Man on a Motorcyle And Leave the Scene
description: A motorcyclist was dragged to his death when caught between two cars racing on the Bruckner Expressway in the South Bronx, the police said.

title: Three Lessons From the U.S. Open
description: SOME of the best tennis lessons you'll ever get about how to play and win matches are those you see during a major championship. Three matches at this year's United States Open were fine examples of, for lack of a more positive phrase, how not to lose a match. In two cases, the student lost, and in one case, the student won. In chronological order, the matches and lessons were:

title: China Has Also Been a Dragon of the Seas
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisbon Journal; A City's Heart in Ruins: Now to Put It Together
description: The fire began in a department store and quickly spread through the historic Chiado district, a neighborhood of steep, narrow streets.

title: Report Cards Can Make Lawmakers Cringe, Too
description: It is report card time again for members of Congress, and some of them are not amused.

title: Entrepreneur Plans to Donate About $25 Million to N.Y.U.
description: Leonard N. Stern, chairman of the Hartz Group, plans to give more than $25 million to New York University this fall to strengthen its schools of business, which would be named after him and consolidated in a large new building on the Washington Square campus.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Iranian Puts War Death Toll At 134,000; 60,000 Missing
description: Iran said today that it lost 123,220 soldiers and 11,000 civilians in the eight-year war with Iraq. The announcement marked the first time that Teheran has reported casualty figures for the war.

title: Never Have So Few Published for So Many
description: RANDOM HOUSE's recent surprise purchase of Crown Publishers and McGraw-Hill's decision to get out of the trade book business are only the latest examples of the book publishing industry's march toward consolidation.

title: Review/Opera; Meyerbeer in San Francisco
description: We are periodically obliged to resurrect the operas of Giacomo Meyerbeer, but one suspects it is more out of a duty to history than flat-out enthusiasm. People wanting to make their way from opera's origins to the present inevitably find him in their path. Meyerbeer was a giant figure and is not to be ignored.

title: Campaign Trail; Words He'll Retract, But Not the Meaning
description: There are words that a Jewish spokesman just doesn't use, like saying someone was ''just following orders.''

title: 'McSleep' Loses to Big Mc
description: Quality Inns International Inc. must stop using the name ''McSleep Inns'' for the economy hotels it plans because the public would believe the hotels were owned by the McDonald's Corporation, a Federal district judge has ruled.

title: Wall Street Rat Race
description: On Thursday night, 2,000 men and women who work in the financial district will end their day by donning their running shoes and entering the Rat Race. In the second Carey Limousine Wall Street Rat Race, which will begin at 6:30 from the World Financial Center at Battery Park City, runners will wear business suits and carry briefcases.

title: Review/Music; Mad Monk Redux in City Opera's New 'Rasputin'
description: The New York City Opera, which has an honored history of taking chances with new works, tossed the dice bravely on Saturday evening with Jay Reise's ''Rasputin.'' Sorry. Snake eyes. The odds against success are always high in such a game, and this time the gamble did not pay off. ''Rasputin,'' which had its world premiere at the New York State Theater, is the 38-year-old composer's first opera and no worse than many a less visible failure. But the spotlight proved pitiless to Mr. Reise's score, which is a characterless melange of 20th-century styles.

title: Horse Racing; Trapp Mountain Takes the Futurity
description: The Futurity Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday had an ugly beginning and a dispiriting finish. A ragged start may have compromised the favorite's chances, and the entire field then staggered home in unimpressive time, looking like a very ordinary bunch of 2-year-olds.

title: The Games at a Glance
description: Swimming

title: Face in Crowd Is Premier's
description: Even after the assassination of Olof Palme two and a half years ago, a Swedish Prime Minister mingles with election crowds here in a way that would be unthinkable for American Presidential candidates.

title: New Esteem and Old Issues To Greet the U.N. Tomorrow
description: The United Nations will gather Tuesday for the 43d General Assembly, closer to agreement than a year ago on many of issues, and with the United Nations itself enjoying new esteem.

title: The Day When the Book Is King
description: New York City reasserted its claim to literary pre-eminence yesterday, as tens of thousands of books and several hundred thousand of their devotees thronged onto a half-mile of Fifth Avenue and adjacent blocks for the 10th annual New York Is Book Country street festival. More than 160 publishers and booksellers displayed and sold their wares on the avenue, from 48th to 57th Streets, and four noted authors spoke at a literary brunch at the Plaza Hotel.

title: A Retail Chain May Be Bought
description: The Service Merchandise Company said yesterday that an investor group that includes members of its senior management might acquire the company through a leveraged buyout. The investors include Raymond Zimmerman, the chairman and chief executive of the Nashville-based catalogue and retail chain.

title: Letter: On Medicaid; Prenatal Care for the Indigent
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Slug Oilers in 45-3 Rout
description: Attention must now be paid to the Jets, who today crushed a playoff team for the second straight week. But this time, in a 45-3 rout of the Houston Oilers, they threw punches as well as footballs.

title: Mozambicans Greet Pope With Frenzy
description: Mothers carrying infants screamed and children cried today when the thousands gathered among the bamboo shacks of a refugee slum surged violently toward a white-robed figure on a little stage. As with the other crowds that have come to see Pope John Paul II across this devastated land, their enthusiasm was born of despair.

title: Paroled Killer Is Arrested In Murder of Pratt Student
description: A 37-year-old crack addict on parole for a manslaughter conviction has been charged in the slaying of an art student who was shot to death in a robbery in Brooklyn not long after she arrived in New York City, the police said.

title: The Day When The Book Is King
description: New York City reasserted its claim to literary pre-eminence yesterday, as tens of thousands of books and several hundred thousand of their devotees thronged onto a half-mile of Fifth Avenue and adjacent blocks for the 10th annual New York Is Book Country street festival. More than 160 publishers and booksellers displayed and sold their wares on the avenue, from 48th to 57th Streets, and four noted authors spoke at a literary brunch at the Plaza Hotel.

title: David Alan Jacobs Is Wed To Robin L. Tannenbaum
description: Robin Lesley Tannenbaum, a daughter of Steven Tannenbaum of Great Neck, L.I., and Arlene Reitman of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married in New York yesterday to David Alan Jacobs, a son of Peter Jacobs of Los Angeles and Marina Engel of New York. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg officiated at the Harmonie Club.

title: Outdoors: Game of Sporting Clays
description: FLYING home after a recent round of sporting clays at the newly established Pawling Mountain Club, I almost persuaded myself that some strange malady had deprived me of hand-eye coordination since last year's upland bird and waterfowl seasons.

title: Soviet Policy Sweetens Farm Living
description: In this village of vineyards, mulberry trees, piglets and geese, cradled between snow-patched ranges of the Caucasus Mountains, one of the largest collective farms in the Georgian republic has experienced profound changes as a result of efforts by the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev to restructure the economy.

title: U.S. Warning Helps Radon-Test Companies
description: Executives of companies that provide radon detection and testing services say their prospects received a lift from a public health advisory issued by the Government last week.

title: Soccer; U.S. Falters, Ties in Opener
description: Rick Davis, who has seen it happen before, said the United States soccer team is still naive about playing with a lead.

title: The Group Run-D.M.C. Defends Rap Music
description: The rap group Run-D.M.C. held a news conference on Friday to defend rap music against criticism that it encourages violence, and the group blamed news organizations for focusing on the negative side of rap.

title: Report Says Debt Crisis Lacks a Quick Solution
description: No acceptable solution to the debt crisis in the third world will be found in the near future unless developing countries pay out less money and achieve faster economic growth, the World Bank said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ammirati Gets Next Inc. Work
description: Ammirati & Puris of New York has become the agency for Steven Jobs's new company, Next Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif., which plans to introduce its first computer on Oct. 12, Edward Vick, the agency president, said.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Finance/New Issues column of Business Day on Friday about a financing backed by boat loans described the underwriting of the issue incorrectly. Chemical Bank Investment Banking was the lead manager; First Boston was co-manager.

title: Reviews/Music; 'Lammermoor' Changes
description: The New York City Opera's solid production of Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' took on a share of magic at the Saturday matinee performance at the New York State Theater when Sheryl Woods joined the cast in the title role. This was the soprano's first Lucia with the company, but there was not the slightest tentativeness in her performance.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets (closing of 42d session) 10 A.M.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Boston Co., Boston, a subsidiary of American Express Co.'s Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., named Josephus Long, senior vice president, to the additional post of deputy group manager for its Corporate Operations Group.

title: Penrod Plan Is Approved
description: A Federal bankrupcty court has approved a plan to convert the Penrod Drilling Company into a corporation that will be 50 percent controlled by the banks that are creditors of the trust estates of the Hunts of Texas.

title: 9 Charged, 4 With Murder, in Robbery Spree at L.I. Rap Concert
description: In a weekend sweep, the Nassau County police arrested and charged nine Brooklyn men, four of them with murder, in a robbery spree at a Uniondale rap concert Sept. 10 that left one man dead and 14 injured.

title: Miami Youth Serves After Johnson Plea
description: Just when the University of Miami seemed certain to lose its top ranking in the national college football polls, when a 33-game regular-season winning streak appeared doomed and the Hurricanes were apparently headed for the third-worst defeat in the Jimmy Johnson era, the coach's pleadings came true.

title: 2 Hopefuls Sharpen Debate Weapons
description: Next Sunday night America will finally tune in to the 1988 Presidential race. Millions of voters will be watching, certainly millions more than will see any other single event of this campaign. Live and on stage, Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis will confront each other, or maybe not, in the first of two televised debates.

title: To Hijack or Fast?
description: ''We could have done other things, maybe hijack an airplane, but we don't think that is nice,'' said Muhyeddin Abdula, a representative of the Kurdistan Democratic Party in the United States and Canada. ''We're trying to do things the nice way, the peace way.''

title: Reviews/Music; 'Pianorama' for a 10th Anniversary
description: Merkin Concert Hall in the Abraham Goodman house on West 67th Street opened its 10th anniversary season Saturday night with an event that was as good a specimen as any of what the hall is about: a ''Pianorama'' of little-heard American music played by four excellent nonstar pianists.

title: Police Search Mexico Bus Wrecks
description: Rescue workers reported finding 90 drowning victims left behind by the floodwaters spawned by Hurricane Gilbert. But they said they may never know how many people were on the buses that washed away in a swollen riverbed Saturday.

title: POISON GAS ISSUE: GULF TALKS SNAG?
description: The international storm over Iraq's supposed use of chemical weapons against its Kurdish minority may create new obstacles for the fledgling peace talks under way between Iraq and Iran, Western diplomats and Iraqi Government officials here say.

title: Terri Ann Sullivan Is Married to Steven E. Moses
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in New Brunswick, N.J., Terri Ann Sullivan, a financial journalist, was married yesterday to Steven Edward Moses, a cinematographer. The Rev. Louis Grenier, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Roy Rosenberg.

title: University to Review Its Policy on Alcohol
description: With increasing reports of some students drinking themselves unconscious and others getting drunk and hurting themselves, a University of Connecticut committee will review the campus alcohol policy and consider possible changes including a ban on alcohol, the school officials said.

title: Virginia Marie Moe Wed To Dennis Floss in Jersey
description: St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Virginia Marie Moe, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Moe of Glen Ridge, N.J., to Dennis Robert Floss, the son of Dale J. Floss of Buffalo, and the late Ross Taylor Floss. Msgr. Franklyn M. Casale performed the ceremony.

title: Reviews/Music; Some Playful Algebra From Anthony Braxton
description: The history of jazz is filled with eccentrics, and the saxophonist Anthony Braxton, who brought a quartet to the Knitting Factory for a rare engagement, qualifies as one of them. Though he represents jazz's pedagogic side - his liner notes are as arcane and indecipherable as the densest semiotic text; he labels his compositions with line drawings that look algebraic - his music is often playful, with lines shooting out from all angles, and tempos picking up only to slow down. Mr. Braxton's created his own musical world, and in his own odd way, he is a virtuoso.

title: Did Mr. Regan 'Give and Get'?
description: Edward Regan, New York State's Comptroller, finds himself embattled over serious allegations that he misused his position as sole trustee of the state's $38 billion pension fund. Whether or not the allegations result in criminal charges, they raise legitimate concerns about Mr. Regan's integrity and judgment. They also send a powerful message to the Legislature about the need for campaign finance and pension management reforms.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Carving a Niche

title: New Unisys Computers Expected
description: The Unisys Corporation is expected to introduce today a powerful line of mainframe computers in an effort to revive its aging Sperry line and slow the defection of customers to competing mainframe computer makers.

title: U.S. Curbs a Program On Wild Horse Control
description: The Federal Bureau of Land Management has ordered an end to free mass adoptions of wild horses, a practice that critics said attracted people who sold the animals for dog food and other commercial purposes.

title: Fitness; Can Athletic Shoes Provide Energy?
description: FOR centuries, mankind has been fascinated with the idea of perpetual motion machines. Obtaining something for nothing is a seductive idea.

title: A Fashion Magazine Tries China
description: Elle magazine has reached the People's Republic of China, where young people appear eager for a peek at the latest in Western fashions. Officials at the magazine say it is the first international fashion and style publication to appear regularly in China.

title: Dukakis Seeks to Recover His Edge
description: Turning a Presidential campaign is like turning a battleship; great exertion is required for small shifts in direction.

title: Retiree Health Plans Need Cost Management; Social Security Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; A Modern Rendering of Ever-Timely Moliere
description: ''Tartuffe'' is unfailingly timely, especially so whenever those who are outwardly sanctimonious are revealed as inwardly impious. With hypocrisy flying high in politics as well as in religion, one should be able to turn to Moliere for comic relief. Unfortunately, R. Jeffrey Cohen's production flattens the play into a one-dimensional cartoon. ''Tartuffe,'' presented by the RAPP Theater Company, is running at St. Clement's in repertory with ''Romeo and Juliet.''

title: Brazil Accord To Be Signed
description: The terms of a financing package for Brazil through 1989 have been reached with 16 commercial banks, and the agreements are scheduled to be signed on Thursday, a representative of the banks said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday from Los Angeles on issues in the 1988 campaign contained misplaced lines and paragraphs in some copies. Readers wishing corrected copies of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street,

title: College Football; Big Ten's Tumble Continues
description: The Big Ten Conference not only took it on the chin again Saturday but its four best teams - Michigan, Iowa, Ohio State and Michigan State - were beaten. Six Big Ten teams lost yesterday and only four won, leaving the conference with a 7-15 record against the outside world.

title: Reed Meeting With Pearson
description: Pearson P.L.C., a London-based publishing, banking and industrial group, said yesterday that it had been approached by Reed International P.L.C., another British publishing company, about a possible takeover.

title: On Not Mistaking the Constitution for a Menu
description: To the Editor:

title: Off-Duty Guard Shot In Car After Dispute
description: An off-duty correction officer was shot and wounded in Brooklyn early yesterday while riding in a car, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the Hospital Corporation of America misattributed the estimate that a proposed buyout deal would require close to $5.4 billion in financing.

title: Reviews/Music; Indian Evening Ragas In a Town Hall Festival
description: Pandit Hariprasad Chaurasia, one of India's top classical flute players, opened the Vedic Heritage Inc.'s two day festival of Indian classical music at Town Hall on Saturday night with a softly bent note. Accompanied by a tambura, a stringed instrument which projects a shimmering, metallic sound, Mr. Chaurasia spent the next 15 minutes exhibiting an extraordinary virtuosity on an evening raga.

title: Campaign Trail; Bush Aides in Race: It's Neck and Neck
description: Bulletin from the Bush campaign! The contest is escalating. Not the Presidential contest - the other one, the tie contest.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Hop a Cloud In a Balloon
description: LEAD: DAYBREAK in an open field. A low roar penetrates the early morning calm. The outline of a small balloon arches slowly across the horizon. A man wearing a backpack strapped to the gently straining balloon stands directly beneath it.

title: Golf; Palmer Triumphs In Crestar Classic
description: Arnold Palmer coasted to a two-under-par 70 today to win his first PGA Senior Tour event since 1985 with a four-stroke victory in the $325,000 Crestar Classic.

title: Review/Rock; Appalachian Echoes: Hornsby and the Range
description: Bruce Hornsby is such an unassuming stage performer that it would be easy to overlook his solid contributions to adult mainstream rock.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Unique Qualifications

title: Sports of The Times; A Natural For the Game
description: HE'S different from all the other 9,626 athletes in these XXIV Olympic Summer Games. But he learned to play baseball the same way just about every kid does: playing catch with his father.

title: Retiree Health Plans Need Cost Management
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 Arrested in Protest Near Soviet Embassy
description: Seven people protesting the denial of a medical visa for a Soviet man were arrested after blocking traffic outside the Soviet Embassy yesterday, the police said.

title: Easy Reading
description: In a booklet that has already become a best seller, cartoons show Superman battering foreign trade barriers and a timebomb labeled Agricultural Subsidies ticking away under a trade negotiating table.

title: States Are Toppling Workplace-Injury Convictions
description: In a series of recent cases, state courts across the country have overturned what had been hailed as trailblazing criminal convictions of companies and their executives for workers' deaths and injuries.

title: Reebok Sees Profit Decline
description: Reebok International Ltd. said Friday that it expects its earnings for the third and fourth quarters to be lower than in the comparable periods last year.

title: A Western Sahara Cease-Fire Fails to Halt Heavy Fighting
description: Morocco and its guerrilla enemies in the Polisario Front have reported a major battle in Western Sahara less than three weeks after conditionally approving a United Nations peace plan that included a cease-fire.

title: Centrists Lack the Guts to Respond to Gorbachev
description: The next President will have a historic opportunity and obligation to end the decades-long cold war. The opportunity awaits him in Moscow - in the anticold war thinking and policies adopted by Mikhail S. Gorbachev since he was chosen leader in 1985. The obligation is dictated by the fact that the cold war, with the arms race as its most characteristic expression, has become the greatest threat to America's national interests.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Wyse Executive
description: Allan D. Gardner, 50 years old, is joining Wyse Advertising of Cleveland and New York as president of the New York office. He is replacing Lois Wyse, who will continue as president of the parent company, of which Marc A. Wyse, her former husband, is chairman. A Brooklyn native and Columbia graduate, Mr. Gardner is coming from Canter Achenbaum Associates, the consulting firm, where he was executive vice president. Wyse bills almost $100 million, of which some $15 million comes from the New York office.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Power in Haiti was assumed by Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril after noncommissioned officers of Haiti's Presidential Guard seized power from Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, who flew to exile in the Dominican Republic. Page A1

title: 10 Years Later, Yankees Flop
description: The calendar is right. This is not 1978.

title: Mischief In Moscow
description: In a column five years ago that deserves a retroactive Pulitzer prize, Rowland Evans and Robert Novak revealed a whopping violation by the Soviets of the ABM treaty: a huge phased-array, battle-management radar complex in Krasnoyarsk.

title: Men's Basketball; Sabonis Ineffective As Russians Fall
description: In moments of frustration, Arvidas Sabonis chose to stare at his sneakers, shaking his head, sometimes bouncing the basketball as if he wanted to punish it for his plight. By the time he left the game with 2 minutes 28 seconds to play, however, even those mild displays of discontent had ended, Sabonis quietly taking his seat at the end of a long line of glum faces.

title: Elliott Triumphs In Delaware 500
description: Bill Elliott held off Dale Earnhardt and Rusty Wallace by a little over a second today to win the Nascar Delaware 500 yesterday at Dover Downs International Speedway.

title: Snowfall Lessens Fire Threat in Yellowstone Park
description: Officials at Yellowstone National Park say several inches of snow blanketed parts of the park over the weekend and may have finally taken the fight out of wildfires there.

title: Division of NL Will Go Public
description: NL Industries announced Friday that it planned to undertake a restructuring in which its petroleum-services division would become a publicly held company.

title:
Market Place;
Underleveraged Food Retailers
description: LEAD: LEVERAGE, in the financial sense, is a word not normally associated with radishes, English muffins, London broils and deli salads. But the way the supermarket industry is going, it probably should be.

title: Shoreham in Flux; In Seesaw Battle Over Nuclear Plant, A Final Deal Is Far From Imminent
description: In the surreal world of nuclear politics, events often mean little. A court decision often results in years of additional judicial appeals. Regulatory actions seem to mean even less. Nothing, it would appear, is concrete.

title: Falcons' Defense Stuns 49ers, 34-17
description: Chris Miller passed for 130 yards and ran for Atlanta's third touchdown today in a 21-point second-period outburst that carried the Falcons to a 34-17 upset victory over the San Francisco 49ers.

title: Artful Career Officer: Prosper Avril
description: While rarely seen in public, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril has wielded power in Haiti for years. Until now he had been content with influencing his poor country from the shadows.

title: California Official Fights Grocery Chains' Merger
description: California's Attorney General, John Van de Kamp, has led inquiries on Asian gangs, drug peddlers and fraudulent AIDS remedies.

title: Gymnastics; Soviet Men Dominate
description: As the first full day of competition in the Olympic Games came to an end, the domination of the men's gymnastics competition by the Soviet Union was even more complete than expected.

title: Newcomer to Politics Wins Hawaii Primary
description: Mary Bitterman, a former director of the Voice of America who is seeking office for the first time, defeaated two other Democrats Saturday in Hawaii's primary election for the urban Honolulu Congressional district and will face Representative Patricia Saiki in November.

title: Baseball; Canseco Hits 40th and A's Can Clinch Title Tonight
description: Dave Henderson drew a bases-loaded walk in the 11th inning and Jose Canseco hit his 40th home run today as the Oakland Athletics defeated the Kansas City Royals, 3-2.

title: Close-Up; Modern Pentathlon
description: Day 1 Riding: Entrants ride 600 meters over a 15-obstacle course on a horse drawn by lot. Riders start with 1,100 points, with deductions for knocking down barriers, falls and balky or slow horses. A clean ride in 1 minute 43 seconds earns the maximum points. Day 2 Fencing: One touch of the epee anywhere on the body decides a match. If there are no touches in the three-minute bout, both fencers lose. Points are based on the number of entrants. Winning 70 percent of his matches earns a competitor 1,000 points. Day 3 Swimming: A 300-meter swim in 3:54 is good for 1,000 points. Each second above or below that time is worht 8 points. A swimmer called for a third false start is penalized 5 seconds. Day 4 Shooting: There are 20 shots from a .22-caliber pistol at a rotating target 25 meters away. Shooters must keep their arms at a 45-degree angle until the target faces them. A score of 194 nets 1,000 points; each target point is worht plus or minus 22 points. Day 5 Running: Competitors run 2 1/2 miles, with a time of 14:15 earning 1,000 points. Runners start based on the standing through four events. For every point a competitor is behind the leader, he starts three seconds after him. Promoting Peace Among Soldiers

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; BBDO Promotions
description: Philip B. Dusenberry, chairman and newly elected chief executive of BBDO New York, has appointed Gary de Paolo, 46, and Joseph Barrett, 53, managing directors, and Ted Sann, 43, and Charles Miesmer, 46, executive creative directors. All are already executive vice presidents and members of the New York board. Mr. de Paolo will direct finance, administration, human resources and media. Mr. Barrett is in charge of account management, research, public relations and new-business development. That leaves Mr. Dusenberry plenty of time for deep thoughts.

title: Barges: Lifeline for the Far North
description: Toward midnight, with the 24-hour sun of the Arctic summer hovering above the horizon, a dilapidated wooden cabin came into sight on the shore of the Mackenzie River. Its roof caving in and walls askew, the cabin is all that remains of a community that took its name from a gunfight between two fur trappers in the 1920's.

title: Walter P. Chrysler Jr., a Collector Of Modern Art and Artifacts, 79
description: Walter P. Chrysler Jr., one of the country's leading art collectors and benefactors whose reputation as a shrewd judge of talent was tainted by suspicions that he knowingly attained forged works, died of cancer Saturday at Sentara Norfolk General Hospital in Norfolk, Va. He was 79 years old.

title: BURMESE MILITARY OFFICIALLY TAKES REINS OF POWER
description: The Burmese armed forces removed the civilian leadership of the Government Sunday, banned street demonstrations and ordered striking workers back to their jobs.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Transplanted Fans

title: West Germany's Emphasis on Exports Irritates Its Trading Partners
description: West Germany's trading partners have long urged it to become a locomotive for European economic growth, but now some people are joking that it has become the caboose.

title: Caroline Meuly, a Lawyer, Is Married to Marc Leavitt
description: Caroline Lehmann Meuly, an assistant Middlesex County prosecutor in New Brunswick, N.J., and Marc Bruce Leavitt, an editor, were married yesterday at the Onderdonk House in Piscataway, N.J., by Rabbi Irwin Fishbein.

title: Walesa Sees a Legalized Union
description: Lech Walesa told 50,000 pilgrims at a workers' Mass today that the Government is close to recognizing Solidarity, the banned independent union movement that he leads.

title: GERMANS QUESTION THEIR SOVEREIGNTY
description: The plunge of an Italian stunt plane into a crowd of spectators at the Ramstein air base three weeks ago has aggravated a lingering resentment among West Germans at limits on their sovereignty, some 43 years after the end of World War II.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Insurer's Chief Mixes Profit and Social Good
description: LEAD: On the lookout for new insurance business many years ago, Bernard Rapoport found what he saw to be an easily targeted, underserved market: union members with a potential need for coverage beyond what their organizations provided.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Women's Basketball; U.S. Beats Czechs In a Struggle, 87-81
description: It was the type of game that made several of the American players wonder whether they had come to the right venue. Basketball, international style, can often appear as if it is incorporating elements of wrestling, boxing and taekwondo. Teams learn to shoot and play self-defense.

title: Haiti's Ordeal: The Years Of Strife
description: 985 November: Although President Jean-Claude Duvalier had announced a series of political reforms earlier in the year, anti-government rioting breaks out when several teen-agers are killed during a demonstration. December: President Duvalier reshuffles his Government, shifting power to an inner circle of hard-liners.

title: Deferral of Drilling Off California Coast Is at Bush's Request
description: Vice President Bush generally supports off-shore oil drilling but he has urged that the policy be deferred in at least one area off Northern California.

title: Socialists Retain Power in Sweden
description: Sweden's governing Social Democratic Party retained its dominant position in national elections today, enabling Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson to claim a mandate to go on governing the country for the next three years.

title: Group Refuses to Meet With Zenith
description: A partnership led by two New York arbitragers said yesterday that it would not meet with the board of the Zenith Electronics Corporation because the board had not responded to the group's proposal to sell the company.

title: Roundup; Weight Lifting Marks Fall
description: Sevdalin Marinov of Bulgaria set two world records today to win a gold medal in the 114-pound division of weight lifting.

title: Metro Matters; Another Trial For Friedman: What's Behind It
description: Stanley M. Friedman's bribery and conspiracy trial is scheduled to open in State Supreme Court in Manhattan today. Perhaps you're wondering why.

title: Diving; U.S. Women Prove a Point
description: If the United States Olympic diving team matches the eight medals won four years ago or even comes close, Michele Mitchell and Wendy Lian Williams will have contributed more than the silver and bronze medals they won in the 10-meter platform.

title: Requiem for a Victim: A Singing Cabby
description: When they were students at the High School of Music and Art in the early 1960's, Leslie Dorsey and his classmates used to stride through Manhattan, singing arias and cantatas, their voices resonating between buildings and inside subway cars. It was as if the city was theirs.

title: 5 Going on Trial Today Over Rare-Birds Cargo
description: Five Miamians accused of trying to smuggle 243 birds of protected or endangered species into the United States are to go on trial Monday in Federal District Court in Key West.

title: Retiree Health Plans Need Cost Management; Taxed for Being 65
description: To the Editor:

title: Pivotal Figure Emerges In Moet-Vuitton Feud
description: A high-stakes board-room drama with all the intrigue, glamour and bold moves of a Hollywood plot has captivated the French business community this summer.

title: Burma Unrest: A Chronology
description: The coup in Burma yesterday was preceded by months of upheaval that began last spring. These were some of the key events:

title: Short-Term Rate Rise Anticipated
description: Credit market analysts said that short-term interest rates are likely to move higher during the remainder of the month, without the prodding of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Ethnic Pop and Native Corn
description: LEAD: Ethnic Pop was not invented by Gov. Mario Cuomo, but he did carry it to archetypal heights at the 1984 Democratic convention, when he captivated his party with the story of his immigrant father's hardships in the New World.

title: Article 258688 -- No Title
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, starting with today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills, and continuing on Thursday when $9 billion of one-year bills will be auctioned.

title: 18th for Gooden As Mets Close In
description: The Mets kept fitting the final pieces into the puzzle yesterday: They defeated the Montreal Expos, 5-3, moved to within a game or two of clinching the Eastern championship of the National League and named Dwight Gooden to open the playoff for the pennant two weeks from tomorrow.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Cynthia Rich and Glenn Kessler Marry
description: Cynthia J. Rich, a daughter of Mrs. Peter S. Eagleson of Boston and E. Roy Rich of New York, was married yesterday to Glenn A. Kessler, a son of Dr. Else Bolotin of Seattle and Adriaan Kessler of Cincinnati. Thomas Ferrick, a Humanist chaplain, performed the ceremony at the DeCordova Museum in Lincoln, Mass.

title: Rams' Pass Rush Roughs Up Raiders
description: A group of fans among the 84,870 in the Coliseum today howled for Jay Schroeder to replace the beleaguered Steve Beuerlein, and another cluster of fans behind that ''Just Win Baby!'' sign near the end zone booed the Raiders' defense. But it's unlikely that Schroeder or the defense could have prevented what happened in the Raiders' 22-17 loss to the Rams.

title: Canada Prices Up 0.3%
description: The Canadian consumer price index rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August, compared with a six-tenths of 1 percent rise in July and a one-tenth of 1 percent increase in August 1987, the Government agency Statistics Canada said Friday. The August year-to-year rise was 4 percent, compared with a 3.8 percent in the July year-to-year figure.

title: U.S. Boxers Suffer A 2d Startling Blow
description: It took 110 seconds and one punch to end Kelcie Banks's bid for a gold medal in boxing. It took less time and no punches to scotch Anthony Hembrick's. It would be difficult, though, to say who felt worse when it was all over.

title: INSIDE
description: Socialists Win in Sweden Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson retained office as the Social Democratic Party retained its dominant position in Swedish elections. Page 12. Possible Snag for Gulf Talks The furor over accusations that Iraq has used chemical weapons against its Kurdish minority may create new obstacles for the Iran-Iraq peace talks, Western diplomats and Iraqi officials say. Page A8. Burton Benjamin Dies Burton Benjamin, former head of CBS News and executive producer of the ''Evening News,'' died. He was 70 years old. Page B10. Torah Funeral in Brooklyn About 10,000 people yesterday mourned the destruction of five scrolls by arson. Two young boys were charged in the desecration of a synagogue. Page B1.

title: You Can't Tell the Olympians Without a Satellite Network
description: Employees at the worldwide satellite consortium Intelsat here will have their hands full for the next two weeks. More than 170 countries representing three-quarters of the world's population - the largest audience ever - have booked more than 7,500 television hours for the Summer Olympics, up about 35 percent from the number of hours four years ago. And each national customer wants something different.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There are people who are saying that if the price of German-American friendship is so high, do we need the risks? Next they'll ask, do we need the burden? And then, do we need that friendship? I don't want that last question.'' - Rudolf Scharping, a West German politician, about reaction after the Ramstein air show disaster. [ A13:4. ]

title: Olympic Highlights
description: SWIMMINGJanet Evans won the United States' first gold medal of the Games in the 400-meter individual medley. Kristin Otto of East Germany, Adrian Moorhouse of Britain and Duncan Armstrong of Australia also won golds. BASKETBALLYugoslavia scored a surprisingly easy 92-79 victory over the Soviet Union. The U.S. women opened with an 87-81 victory over Czechoslovakia. BOXINGKelcie Banks of the United States, a former world champion, was knocked out in a 125-pound bout. Another American boxer, Anthony Hembrick, was disqualified after showing up late for his bout. Articles, SportsMonday.

title: INSTALL ANOTHER
description: Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril assumed power in Haiti today after noncommissioned officers of Haiti's Presidential Guard seized power from Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy.

title: Kuwait Lifts Ban on Coke
description: Kuwait today lifted a 21-year ban on products of the Coca-Cola Company, despite the decision of an Arab group to keep the company on a blacklist because of its dealings with Israel.

title: A Portable Boat for the Adventurous Angler
description: Part of the wonder of fishing is being able to get away from it all, but transporting a boat to remote places can be troublesome. Porta-Bote International, a company based in Mountain View, Calif., claims it has a solution. The firm markets a collapsible boat, a polypropelene skiff that looks like a banana and folds like an accordian. When flattened, the craft is four inches thick.

title: Park Protest: Weekly Test For the Police
description: Along Washington Square North, 20 protesters held banners and chanted, ''The park belongs to the people.'' Two hundred others who became spectators milled, and dozens of uniformed and plainclothes police officers watched from the curb across the street.

title: McDonald's Awards
description: Phylicia Rashad and Denzel Washington will be the hosts of a celebrity reading Sept. 26 at 8 P.M. at Theater Four of the Negro Ensemble Companyas part of the 1988 McDonald's Literary Achievement Awards. The winners of the competition will be announced at the fund-raising event for the dance company. The competition rewards excellence in writing about the black experience in America, in the categories of fiction, poetry and playwriting. The winners' works will be read, and a reception will be held afterward at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: Bentsen's Dual Campaigns Raise Financial Issues
description: There's a prominent Democrat running for statewide office in Texas this year who is campaigning all over the state but almost never mentions the job he is seeking or asks voters to give it to him instead of his Republican opponent.

title: Reviews/Music; Love, Nature, Images And Sounds of Vowels
description: Near the end of the first of two shows at the Bottom Line on Friday evening, Toni Childs requested that the lights in the house be extinguished while she lit a candle and sang ''Dreamer,'' a beautiful romantic lament from ''Union,'' her debut album. ''I sometimes run and chase the moon, I just can,'' the singer exclaimed in a half-strangulated shout against a crystalline electronic accompaniment suggesting an amplified autoharp.

title: Los Angeles Journal; Olympics Bring Pride to Koreatown
description: The backbone of Koreatown, the largest Korean community outside Korea, is Olympic Boulevard. But at first glance, there are few signs that the inhabitants of the Los Angeles district have any special connection with the energetic celebration of the Olympics in their homeland.

title: 2 Boys Held in Synagogue Fire And 10,000 Mourn 5 Torahs
description: Only hours after two boys, aged 12 and 15, were arrested for vandalizing and setting fire to a Brooklyn synagogue, about 10,000 people gathered on the nearby streets yesterday to attend a funeral service for the five Torah scrolls destroyed in the Sabbath blaze.

title: LITHUANIANS PLAN MEMORIAL TO JEWS
description: Authorities in Vilnius, the capital of the Lithuanian republic, have authorized construction of what would apparently be the first Holocaust memorial in the Soviet Union, according to an American involved in the project.

title: Beijing Leaders Reportedly Split Over Economics
description: China's leadership is locked in a major struggle over the direction of economic policy, a clash of wills that may have reduced some of the authority of Zhao Ziyang, the Communist Party leader, according to diplomats and Chinese familiar with discussions at the highest levels of government.

title: U.P.I. Exceutives Outline a Path to Profitability
description: Paul Steinle, the new president of United Press International, hopes to make the news service profitable by the end of 1989, and he thinks that the unused space in any television signal will help him do it.

title: Tragedy Hits U.S. Lifter
description: Rich Schutz, the American champion in the 100 kilogram weight-lifting class, flew home today for his mother's funeral.

title: Zoos Organize to Help Gorillas Start Families
description: Katie and Jimmy, two 15-year-old gorillas, are the big ''item'' here at the San Diego Zoo. Lovers, the two have been courting for months - climbing together on rock formations in their outdoor enclosure, frolicking in a nearby pool of water, even mating publicly.

title: Guilty Plea in Intelsat Fraud
description: The former No. 2 executive of Intelsat pleaded guilty Friday to conspiracy to defraud the global satellite giant of $4.8 million.

title: John Wald, Journalist, Weds Maria Palazzola
description: The marriage of Maria Domenica Palazzola, a daughter of Louise Palazzola of Ann Arbor, Mich., and the late Guy Palazzola, to John Gregory Wald, took place yesterday in Spencertown, N.Y., at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Calder, stepfather and mother of the bridegroom. Roberta Davis, a justice of the peace in Spencertown, officiated. Mr. Wald is also the son of Stephen L. Wald of New York.

title: TV Notes
description: Channel 2's Close Look

title: Amy Skilbred Married To Eric Paul Jorgensen
description: Amy Katrin Skilbred, a daughter of Mrs. John M. Harrigan of Essex Fells, N.J., and Dr. L. Arne Skilbred of Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Eric Paul Jorgensen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Jorgensen of Northfield, Minn. The Rev. Thomas Omholt, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the Stronghold Mansion at Sugarloaf Mountain in Dickerson, Md.

title: Corrections
description: An article in SportsMonday Sept. 12 about the Phoenix Cardinals incorrectly attributed critical comments about the football team's departure from St. Louis to the editorial page of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. The comments appeared in a column in that newspaper's sports section.

title: First Home Game No Break for Lions
description: There is more woe ahead for Columbia.

title: Notebook; Lewis Finds Himself Subject of Chase Before Race
description: Sometimes it's hard being a famous athlete . Ask Carl Lewis.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many basketball players have been on teams that won a national collegiate championship, an Olympic gold medal and a National Basketball Association title?

title: Review/Television; And in These Corners, 'The McLaughlin Group'
description: ''The McLaughlin Group,'' one of the noisier talk shows, takes on Presidential elections in a special program tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13. The stentorian John McLaughlin and his regular cadre (the columnists Robert Novak and Patrick J. Buchanan on the hard right, and Morton Kondracke of the New Republic and Jack Germond of the Baltimore Sun at center left) move briskly through such matters as the power of the press, political advertising, polls, primaries, conventions and campaign financing.

title: Ida W. Richard, Philanthropist, 86
description: Ida W. Richard, a philanthropist who was active in charities in New York and Cleveland, died Friday at the Margaret Wagner Nursing Home in Cleveland. She had a severe stroke in early 1987. She was 86 years old and lived in Cleveland.

title: Bridge
description: The great days for the Italians were the mid-1950's to the mid-1970's, when their Blue Team dominated world championship play. Recently, they have been in relative eclipse, although they came within a hair of winning the Bermuda Bowl title in Stockholm in 1983.

title: Del Tredici to Compose For New York Philharmonic
description: David Del Tredici, the American composer whose extravagant preoccupation with ''Alice in Wonderland'' has led to best-selling records and a Pulitzer Prize, has been appointed composer in residence with the New York Philharmonic for this season and next.

title: 175 Are Arrested at Cockfight
description: Police raided a social club north of Miami Saturday and arrested 175 people for taking part in gambling at a cockfight, a Metro-Dade police spokeswoman said. Seventy-five of the fighting birds were seized. The charges included gambling and partaking in the baiting or fighting of game cocks, midemeanors, and managing, promoting or directing a cockfight, a felony, said a police spokeswoman, Lucy Fitts.

title: Unseal the Records For Adoptive Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: Largent Sets Record
description: Steve Largent broke the National Football League career record for receiving yardage today but the Seattle Seahawks lost to the San Diego Chargers, 17-6.

title: U.S. Is Planning A Limited Part In Radon Effort
description: With its warning last Monday that tens of millions of people should test their homes for the presence of carcinogenic radon gas and make repairs, the Government in effect proclaimed a national emergency, according to Government officials and spokesmen for consumers' organizations.

title: Diana Loomis and William Leeds Wed
description: Diana Rachel Loomis, the daughter of Gloria C. Loomis and Robert D. Loomis, both of New York, and William Scott Leeds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Leeds of New York and Phoenicia, N.Y., were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Parrish in Sag Harbor, L.I. Edward W. Horne, a Town Justice of East Hampton, L.I., officiated.

title: Reviews/Television; NBC Takes a Chance on Tamer Olympic Games
description: Well, it wasn't George Gershwin. Friday evening's broadcast of the opening ceremonies of the Games of the XXIV Olympiad did not feature several dozen pianists playing ''Rhapsody in Blue.'' Instead of the King Kong-like chest thumping that predominated in Los Angeles four years ago, South Korea offered a gentler spectacle, stressing the themes of space, openness and reconciliation. It remains to be seen if American viewers will remain glued to the quadrennial games as they unfold in a context of sights and sounds very different from those they found in Los Angeles. NBC Sports has spent millions on the optimistic hunch that they will.

title: Japan to Lift Oil Supply
description: Japan will increase its state oil stockpile by 20 million barrels, to 190 million, in the next six months, the chairman of the Japan National Oil Corporation, Hashimoto Toshikazu, said today during a visit to the United Arab Emirates. ''Our policy is to continue plans to increase our crude oil stockpile, which now accounts for 170 million barrels,'' he said. That would accommodate about 48 days of consumption. Mr. Toshikazu said Japan's oil demand of about four million barrels a day would decline by 5 percent in the next five years or so because of greater energy efficiency.

title: Yanks Lose; Trail By 6 1/2
description: The Yankees probably took their last gasp today. It is only a matter of days before the race will be officially over.

title: U.S. Aide Hopeful on Beirut Vote
description: Richard W. Murphy, the United States envoy to the Middle East who has been trying to defuse a political crisis in Lebanon, said today that he was confident the country's bellicose leaders would meet a Friday deadline for the election of a new president.

title: U.S. Officials Say New Haiti Rulers Are About Like the Old Ones
description: American officials said today that the coup in Haiti may have been a response to the breakdown of public order and the re-emergence of the Tontons Macoute, a paramilitary security force suspected of savage attacks on a church in Port-au-Prince earlier this month.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis inadequately described the position of Vice President Bush on offshore oil drilling. A corrective article is on page A16.

title: Old Casts Hark Back To Re-create 'Ballet' For Jerome Robbins
description: Did you hear the one about Jerome Robbins and the comedian Joey Faye?

title: Books of The Times; Shedding Clear Light On Iran-Contra Affair
description: Landslide The Unmaking of the President, 1984-1988 By Jane Mayer and Doyle McManus Illustrated. 468 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $21.95.

title: Newly Released Letters Etch Life in Jonestown
description: Eight boxes of correspondence and memorandums from the People's Temple commune at Jonestown, Guyana, where 913 members of the American cult people died by suicide or murder 10 years ago, have become available for scholarly review.

title: Africans Pushing for Peace in Angola
description: The leaders of Angola, Angola's neighbors and South Africa have agreed to meet in coming weeks to discuss peace in Angola, President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire said in an interview here today.

title: Companies Report Progress Against Counterfeit Goods
description: Counterfeiting and copying of brand-name products appears to be on the decline this year, the makers of these products say, as a result of their tough litigation policies, new laws here and abroad, and the weaker dollar.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Gannett Aims For Coupon Business
description: GANNETT's Four-Color Newspaper Network, a national advertising representative for the company's papers as well as for independents, has increased its total circulation to a point where it is pursuing national manufacturers' couponing money, much of which goes into free-standing inserts.

title: Burton Benjamin, 70, Dies; Former Head of CBS News
description: Burton Benjamin, former vice president and director of CBS News, and a longtime documentary producer who wrote the report about the preparation of the controversial CBS television documentary critical of Gen. William C. Westmoreland, died of a brain tumor last night at his home in Scarborough, N.Y. He was 70 years old.

title: U.S. Swimmers Get Needed Help From Evans
description: The United States, which had started badly in Olympic swimming, received a big boost today from 17-year-old Janet Evans, all 5 feet 6 inches and 105 pounds of her.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * AC&R/DHB & Bess Advertising will change its name to AC&R Advertising on Oct. 1.

title: Juvenile Crime Study Gauges Impact of Drugs and Family
description: Nearly three out of four juveniles in correctional institutions were from broken homes and nearly half were under the influence of drugs or alcohol when they committed their offenses, the Government reported today.

title: Washington Warns Haiti on Indicted Colonel
description: The White House warned today that the new President of Haiti should not give any additional power to a Haitian Army colonel who has been indicted in the United States on charges of drug trafficking.

title: Grain Talks Moving Slowly
description: Officials from Washington and Moscow met secretly this weekend in Vienna to try to negotiate a new American-Soviet grain pact, but no agreement was reached, an Administation official said today.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Close-Up; Cycling on the Track
description: Life in the Fast Lane The trace events are staged on an outdoor velodrome 333.3 meters in circumference. Competitors frequently will ride behind an opponent to gain from reduced air resistance. There are five events for men and one, a match sprint for women. 1,000-meter Match Sprint Three laps on the oval, but riders dawdle while jockeying for position until only about 200 meters remain, when a mad dash results in speeds of up to 40 miles per hour. Cyclists compete in pairs, with the losser eliminated. 1,000-Meter Individual Time Trial One man racing against the clock. 4,000-Meter Individual Pursuit Cyclists start at opposite ends of the track and try to pass each other. If one is passed, he loses; if no one is passed, best time wins. 4,000-meter Team Pursuit Same as individual pursuit, only with four-man teams. 50-Kilometer Points Race Cyclists ride for 150 laps and earn points for sprints every five laps. Sprints halfway through the race and at the end score double. Keep an Eye on ...

title: Rains Offering Hope for Winter Wheat Crop
description: Good rains over the last few days, some of them spawned by Hurricane Gilbert, have supplied the winter wheat areas of the Southern Plains with most of the moisture needed for fall planting, agricultural weather experts say.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: CSX to Buy Back Shares and Sell Assets
description: The CSX Corporation, the giant transportation company, said yesterday that it was initiating a broad restructuring that would include the repurchase of up to 38 percent of its stock and the sale of assets outside the transportation business.

title: Auto Wrecks Yield to Computer Analysis
description: APPLYING new computer programs and long-known laws of physics, scientists have become increasingly adept at recreating and analyzing car crashes, providing a powerful tool for improving automotive safety and resolving legal disputes.

title: Science Accessories Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss Latest quarter and 9-month results reflect litigation expenses of $72,400 and $276,973, respectively. Year-ago quarter and 9-month results reflect litigation expenses of $101,406 and $141,842, respectively.

title: Georgia Bonded Fibers reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Daggers of Debt, Drugs Aiming At the Americas
description: For whoever wins the White House, some of the toughest foreign policy challenges will be close to home.

title: Washuup of Medical Waste Doesn't Affect Offshore Seafood
description: To the Editor:

title: Let Computer Fill the Guidance-Counselor Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Forests Sought to Counter Greenhouse Effect
description: VIRTUALLY all the carbon dioxide emitted by power plants to be built in the next decade could be absorbed by 10 million acres of new forest, according to the Environmental Defense Fund. The organization has proposed that such planting be undertaken by the Federal Conservation Reserve Program, a project of the Department of Agriculture.

title: Market Place; Why Discounters Are Consolidating
