description: INVESTORS who like the discount store concept may have to re-evaluate their favorites in view of a new consolidation trend sweeping that industry. Often this involves the acquisition of a weaker company by a stronger one, with a risk that the combination will not produce a winner.

title: Cascade Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Canadian Pact Voted By Senate
description: The Senate, voting 83 to 9, today approved the free-trade agreement with Canada, completing American approval three and a half years after the idea emerged from a summit meeting of President Reagan and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney.

title: 'Broadway Bound' to Close
description: ''Broadway Bound,'' the semi-autobiographical comedy by Neil Simon, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Broadhurst Theater. Directed by Gene Saks and currently starring Joan Rivers, the play will have run for 756 regular performances and 12 previews.

title: Review/Opera; San Francisco Offers Rossini at Full Tilt
description: It takes only a few moments into the overture to ''Maometto II'' to realize that Rossini was up to something beyond his then-accustomed scope. The harmony is rich with unexpected modulations, but more striking is the brevity. This is not a self-contained synopsis, but the first stirring of momentum for a busy first scene. The curtain comes up long before we expect it to, and the action is already at peak acceleration.

title: Jamaica Reviving After Hurricane But Food Shortages Are Predicted
description: One week after Jamaica was stunned by the century's most powerful hurricane, the island seemed well on its way to recovery today.

title: Eagle Telephonics reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and the 9 months included a tax credit of $1,118,000. Year-ago third quarter share earnings was less than one cent a share.

title: Democrat in Nebraska Drops Senate Debates
description: The race for a United States Senate seat in Nebraska between the Republican incumbent, David K. Karnes, and his Democratic challenger, Bob Kerrey, has been disrupted by a third-party candidate, a maverick legislator who was nominated at a convention held in a fast-food restaurant.

title: Peerless Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $34,794 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $514,577 for the quarter and $635,852 for the year. The company said certain reclassifications were made to prior years amounts to conform with current years presentation, which reflects losses from discontinued operations and disposal of assets.

title: 3 Are Sentenced to 16 Weekends in Jail in Howard Beach Case
description: Three white teen-agers convicted of misdemeanor riot charges in the Howard Beach racial-attack case were sentenced yesterday to serve weekends in jail for four months and perform 200 hours of community service work.

title: Lawyers Gain a Victory At Expense of Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Blacks Gain Again in College Admission Tests
description: The scores of black high school students continued to increase this year on standardized college admission tests, the two major testing agencies reported yesterday.

title: Gunfire Erupts in Tense Soviet Area
description: Azerbaijanis and Armenians with firearms clashed in the disputed Soviet territory of Nagorno-Karabakh on Sunday, leaving 17 people seriously wounded, the official press agency Tass reported tonight.

title: Offshore Logistics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $1,459,000 gain for debt forgiveness. c-Includes a $16,374,000 gain on a restructuring.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Roundup; Canadians Test Americans in Basketball
description: The United States men's basketball team turned to 3-point shooting by Charles Smith IV, Hersey Hawkins and Dan Majerle and turned back an upset-minded Canadian team, 76-70, today.

title: Beulah M. Donald, 67, Klan Foe
description: Beulah Mae Donald, who won a $7 million judgment against the Ku Klux Klan for the death of her son in a beating, died of natural causes Saturday at a hospital in Mobile, according to the Mobile County Coroner, Leroy Riddick. She was 67 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: Pact With Canada Advances The Senate, 83 to 9, completed United States approval of a free-trade accord. But the agreement has run into obstacles in Canada. Page D1. Hirohito Seriously Ill Emperor Hirohito of Japan has become seriously ill, and Japanese are sitting in vigil for the 87-year-old head of state. Page A7. Polish Cabinet Quits Prime Minister Zbigniew Messner and his Cabinet resigned amid criticism of their execution of the Jaruzelski Government's policies. Page A3. Report on Medical Examiner In New York City, an autopsy can take as long as six months because of problems at the Chief Medical Examiner's office. Page B1. Mortgage Policy Toughened A new Federal policy on those who abuse the system in mortgage defaults was announced. Page A14.

title: West Pushed Stalin Into Hitler's Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: Inmac Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Haiti's New Leader Installs A Mostly Civilian Cabinet
description: Haiti's new President, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, today swore in a new Government composed almost exclusively of civilians.

title: Luskin's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Mets' Future Clear; Johnson's Still Isn't
description: With less than two weeks to go, the Mets stood on the brink of winning the Eastern championship of the National League for the second time in three years yesterday. But Dave Johnson conceded that he still had no idea whether he would be back as manager next year.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Secretary's Award
description: Two dozen of the Government's most senior national security and diplomatic personnel gathered today in the office of Secretary of State George P. Shultz to honor Lieut. Gen. Colin L. Powell, the first adviser to the President for national security affairs to receive the Secretary's Award.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Armed Forces; Troubling Ratings on Military Education at Top
description: The top echelons of the nation's military education system, under scrutiny by three separate panels for 18 months, have been given troubling report cards. Military leaders have already initiated changes and say that more are coming.

title: Torotel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $44,000 and $22,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: State by State; In Pennsylvania, Politics Is Still a Far-Off Thing
description: The really big news in Reading this weekend was on the sports pages.

title: Careers; Part-Time Jobs Beckon Retirees
description: SOME retirees aged 60 and over have returned to the job market on a temporary basis, drawn by boredom, fears of rising inflation, a desire for extra money and attractive part-time wages.

title: Donaldson Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $291,000 and $1,384,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $653,000 for the quarter and $1,375,000 for the year. Year-ago share earnings figures have been restated for a 2-for-1 stock split on May 2.

title: Beene's Way: Always an Adventure
description: In the beginning, Geoffrey Beene made clean, commercial dresses -the kind that Seventh Avenue has always done so well. Gradually, as he perfected his skill and as his taste grew more sophisticated, he moved off the main thoroughfares of fashion and on to more adventurous designs. He became a pathfinder in matters of hem length, fabric choice and the cut of clothes.

title: India Allows Pepsi In After 2-Year Debate
description: After two years of debate, the Indian Government has cleared the way for Pepsi-Cola to enter the soft drink market, Minister of Food Processing Jagdish Tytler announced today.

title: Stein Assails City Delays On Autopsies
description: The office of New York City's Chief Medical Examiner has been unusually slow in completing autopsy reports, taking an average of six months, according to a 1986-87 report that came to light yesterday.

title: Mergers Announced In Communications
description: A number of ever-popular mergers and acquisitions in the communications field were reported yesterday.

title: Doctor With AIDS Sues City
description: A former doctor at Kings County Medical Center has sued the hospital, the City of New York and two physicians for $175 million, contending that their actions caused her to acquire the AIDS virus.

title: Zenith Labs Cuts
description: Zenith Laboratories Inc., which is operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, has cut its staff by 130 employees, to 307, to save more than $2 million a year. The company also plans to relocate its headquarters and packaging operations to Northvale, N.J., and sell its Ramsey property.

title: Goodmark Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Jackpot Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings were adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend declared July 1, 1988.

title: Our Towns; Vague Answers, Faceless Blame In Tess's Death
description: For 10 months, Pam Miller had Baby Tess Maye in her foster care. She did everything in her power to prevent the baby from being returned to the natural mother, arguing that the mother was being battered by her husband, that she regularly missed visits, that she was not mentally well. Westchester County officials did not listen. In November 1986, Baby Tess went back to her mother, and on March 20, 1987, the mother, Tracey Maye, beat the baby to death.

title: Books of The Times; Three Early Masters of Insider Trading
description: The Scarlet Woman of Wall Street By John Steele Gordon 421 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $22.95.

title: Dolls and Rattles Recalled
description: Several small dolls and rattles marketed as craft goods are being recalled because they could pose a choking hazard for children, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today. The toys are being recalled by the Fibre Craft Materials Corporation of Niles, Ill., which said the products could be returned to the place of purchase for a refund. They include a noisemaking blue ball atop a pink beaded handle, a pink, blue or yellow spoon with a painted-on face, a blue and pink barbell and a noisemaking blue clothespin with a blue painted-on face.

title: Roadway Motor Plazas Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Spec's Music eiInc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Massachusetts Business Leaders Dispute Bush's Economic Charges
description: The Dukakis campaign, responding to the latest of Vice President Bush's charges about the condition of the Massaschusetts economy, assembled a group of high-powered supporters in the state's business community today to rebut the Republican charges.

title: AIDS Among Prostitutes Not as Prevalent as Believed, Studies Show
description: AIDS testing of female prostitutes and their customers - groups under close scrutiny as potential spreaders of the deadly disease among heterosexuals - indicates that infection among prostitutes is not as widespread as some experts had expected.

title: Exile Ends for Zaire's Top Political Prisoner
description: Zaire's most prominent dissident returned home today from internal exile, and there were signs that the remaining political prisoners are to be released soon.

title: U.S. Issues Drop in Profit Taking
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds slumped in lackluster trading yesterday as market participants chose to take profits rather than hold on to their securities.

title: BURMESE CAPITAL ROCKED BY GUNFIRE IN NEW CRACKDOWN
description: Heavy gunfire was reported throughout the day today Mondaand into the night Monday as Burmese troops moved to enforce a crackdown on six weeks of anti-Government protests.

title: As Hirohito Fights Illness, Japan Keeps Vigil
description: Emperor Hirohito became seriously ill late Monday night, and millions of Japanese stayed up until the early hours of the morning watching television as the Imperial Palace here bustled with activity and speculation.

title: PEN Center Readings To Honor Polish Writer
description: A series of readings in honor of Bruno Schulz, a Polish writer murdered by Nazis in 1942, are planned by this month by the PEN American Center and the American Foundation for Polish-Jewish Studies. Schulz who wrote extensively about Jewish life in Poland in the 1930's.

title: Rio Grande Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Where Is This Prosperity We're in the Midst Of?
description: To the Editor:

title: Barr Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Boxing; Tardy Hembrick Is Banned
description: This is a long way from Los Angeles, where four years ago, boxers from the United States won nine gold medals, a silver and bronze in the Olympics. Early in the competition at the Summer Games here in Seoul, the best known American fighter has been knocked out and another potential medalist was disqualified for arriving late for his match.

title: Citizens Growth Properties (Co) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago figures are restated for a tax change.

title: Pier 1 Imports Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
A Race Still to Be Won
description: George Bush has made striking gains in the popular opinion polls since the Republican Convention. No doubt about that.

title: A Civilian Cast In Haiti Cabinet
description: Saying Haitians ''legitimately want proof'' that the army can ''work in permanent contact'' with civilians, the country's new military leader named a 12-member Cabinet that includes only one military officer. The new leader, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, also announced the ouster of Brig. Gen. Williams Regala, the second in command under Lieut. Gen.

title: Godfather's Pizza Sold By Pillsbury
description: Beset by management defections and disappointing results in its restaurant group, the Pillsbury Company said today that it had sold Godfather's Pizza Inc. to an investor group led by the chain's management.

title: Mounting Junk Piles and the Hazards
description: Along a hilltop in this rustic community of 2,800 people is a 20-yard-long pile of discarded refrigerators, washing machines and other household appliances, a rusting monument to the latest environmental problem facing towns and cities.

title: S-K-I Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Business and Health; A Push to Restrict Profit on Referrals
description: CONGRESS and the Reagan Administration are cracking down on physicians who refer patients to health-care companies in which the doctors have a financial interest.

title: Sports People; Lauer Signs
description: The Islanders have re-signed Brad Lauer to a multiyear contract, details of which were not disclosed. The signing leaves Kelly Hrudey, Pat LaFontaine, Alan Kerr and Bob Bassen as the only unsigned Islanders with contracts going into their option year.

title: To Build on a Good Deed in Turkey
description: Turkey took on the unaccustomed role of championing human rights when it opened its borders to 60,000 desperate Kurds fleeing Iraq's army and poison gas. This courageous action by Prime Minister Turgut Ozal is sure to damage relations with Baghdad and spotlight Ankara's repression of Turkey's own large Kurdish minority. But the rest of the means to be more attentive to other human rights issues, its chances for admission into the European Community will surely be improved.

title: Topics of The Times; The All-Too-Perishable Panda
description: To watch a panda in action - waddling, somersaulting, munching bamboo sprouts and heaving the occasional sigh - is to watch a child's stuffed animal come miraculously to life. That's precisely why children, and their parents, crowd the nation's zoo whenever one is exhibited. Pudgy, plushy, with eyes like teardrops: the panda was designed to delight.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: People
description: * Glenn Kaplan has been promoted to senior vice president at Geer, DuBois Advertising.

title: The MX: A Missile For All Reasons
description: LEAD: The public has been subjected to a bewildering array of opinions about modernizing the nation's intercontinental ballistic missile or ICBM force. This has lent the subject a greatly misleading aura of complexity. But neither the basic strategy of deterrence nor the approaches to provide forces to underwrite that strategy are at all complex.

title: Campaign Trail; For Quayle, a Search For Belgian Endive
description: J. Danforth Quayle was delighted. His advisers grinned. Let's go after Gov. Michael S. Dukakis with a new weapon, guaranteed to get on the evening news. Let's go after Dukakis with . . . A Belgian endive.

title: Cenvill Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said the year-ago 9-month results include revenues of $8,917,000 and earnings of $5,620,000, or 39 cents a share, from the sale of a former 80 percent owned subsidiary, Communications & Cable Inc., and certain management agreements with that unit.

title: Greek Temple in Sicily Waits to Be Found
description: To the Editor:

title: Eagle-Picher Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Review/Theater; Caprice and Melancholy in Marriage
description: In a letter to Arthur Schnitzler, written in 1906, the year after the premiere of ''Intermezzo,'' Sigmund Freud expressed his admiration for the playwright's intuitive discovery of ''that secret knowledge'' about ''psychological and erotic problems.'' Though less familiar than ''Anatol,'' ''La Ronde'' and other of Schnitzler's plays, ''Intermezzo'' is one of the playwright's more provocative examinations of modern marriage - as is clear in Gitta Honegger's production at the Yale Repertory Theater. The atmosphere is turn of the century, but the intricate emotional relationships are also relevant to a far more recent time. Furthermore, Schnitzler treats most seriously a woman's need for emancipation.

title: Precision Aerotech reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Homeless Census Planned
description: Census takers will make a special effort to count the homeless in their next calculation of the population of the United States in 1990.

title: Donald K. Phillips, Investment Broker, 84
description: Donald K. Phillips, an investment broker, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Dothan, Ala. He was 84 years old.

title: Judge Upholds Ban on Surrogate Birth Contracts
description: The nation's first law intended to ban commercial contracts for women to bear children for infertile couples was upheld as constitutional today by a state judge. However, Michigan's attorney general agreed to an interpretation of the law that will evidently permit surrogacy, as long as the woman does not give up her rights as a parent.

title: Toned-Down New York Post To Get Ads of 4 Major Stores
description: Six months after its new owner promised to tone down The New York Post's sensationalism, the newspaper's publisher said yesterday that four of New York's most stylish retailers would begin regular advertising.

title: Dayton Hudson's Notes Are Priced
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation yesterday priced $100 million of notes, due in 1993, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: I.B.M. Sells Part Of Satellite Unit
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it had sold a minority interest in its satellite leasing company to a unit of the Hughes Aircraft Company, and had contracted with Hughes to market its satellite channels to corporate customers. Terms were not disclosed. The fleet of three satellites, all made by Hughes, was valued at more than $250 million by I.B.M., which acquired the satellites in 1986 from the MCI Communications Corporation.

title: Bundesbank On Inflation
description: West Germany's central bank today issued a warning about inflation, citing a weaker mark and the rising cost of imported goods.

title: Safeway Purchase
description: Safeway Stores Inc. said it was planning to raise its stake in the Vons Companies to 35 percent from 30 percent. Last month, Safeway acquired 6.7 million Vons shares as part of a $410 million transaction in which Vons acquired Safeway's operations in Southern California. Vons is a supermarket chain based in El Monte, Calif. Safeway, based in Oakland, Calif., made the disclosure in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. It has agreed not to acquire more than 35 percent of Vons's shares.

title: Campaign Trail; Young Conservatives Swooning for Bush
description: Sign of the conservative times:

title: First, Think of Single Mothers
description: With the sun rapidly setting on this term of Congress, welfare reform remains bogged down in conference committee. The sticking point is a ''workfare'' requirement for two-parent welfare families. It is a foolish provision, likely to waste money and manpower for the states that must administer it. But it threatens now to torpedo a two-year effort for genuine welfare reform.

title: Corrections
description: An article headed ''San Francisco Journal'' on Sept. 9 about a beached whale misstated an affiliation of Dr. Ray Dieter, a veterinarian. He is a research associate with the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco and is not affiliated with the California Marine Mammal Center in Sausalito.

title: Centel Buys Back Edelman Holdings
description: The Centel Corporation has bought back a 5.5 percent stake held by the investors Asher B. Edelman and George L. Lindemann, apparently ending a $2.68 billion takeover bid. The 2.15 million shares were purchased for $43 each, or about $92.5 million. Centel, based in Chicago, said the deal was a market-price repurchase made as part of a program to buy back up to five million shares.

title: Saluting 25 Years of Geoffrey Beene's Wit and Flair
description: ''Don't call it a retrospective,'' said Geoffrey Beene. ''A retrospective is waving goodbye and fading into the sunset. I'm saying hello.''

title: More Flags Are Waving, as Bush Encourages Patriotism and the Pledge
description: When patriotism in America increases, the people at Annin & Company see a lot more red, white and blue.

title: Ex-Fordham Pitcher Edged
description: As Pete Harnisch prepared to pitch to Don Slaught at the start of the Yankees' half of the sixth inning last night, a cheer erupted in the stands at Yankee Stadium. At that moment, eight fans were parading through the stands carrying posters that spelled out the Baltimore pitcher's name, so the cheer was for him, right?

title: Skylink America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Ice Volcanoes Discovered on 2 Uranus Moons
description: ASTRONOMERS at Cornell University say they have discovered ice volcanoes on two moons of Uranus. If their analysis of satellite photographs is confirmed, it would be the first time such features have been found anywhere in the solar system.

title: American Medical Holders in Filing
description: An investor group said it had sought Federal antitrust clearance to buy up to 14.9 percent of American Medical International Inc.'s common stock. Richard Rainwater, a member of the group, said the group held more than 5.3 million American Medical shares, or about 7.3 percent of the total outstanding.

title: Book-of-the-Month Club Restructures Its Jury
description: The Book-of-the-Month Club has asked three of its five judges to resign at the end of the year, but plans to replace only two of them.

title: Nike Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Apple Introduces a Faster Macintosh Computer
description: Apple Computer Inc. today introduced the Macintosh IIx personal computer, which it said performed 10 to 15 percent faster than the current Mac II, the company's most expensive machine.

title: Death of a Spouse
description: While the death of a spouse is one of life's greatest blows, new findings show the survivor to be far more resilient than had been believed. A study of 13,380 men and women found that those whose spouses had died were as physically and emotionally healthy, as active, had as many friends, and were as outgoing and open to new experiences as were those who were still married.

title: 21 Laid Off At Paine Unit
description: Paine Webber has laid off 21 employees from its investment banking division, including 16 who were either managing directors or vice presidents.

title: Time Inc. Stock Surges Again
description: The stock of Time Inc. stock soared again yesterday, rising $9.625 a share, to $116.25, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. It was the second day of heavy buying in the giant media company, after Friday's jump of $9.375. The increases prompted

title: Ahold, Koninklijke NV reports earnings for 12wk to July 17
description: Results are in U.S. dollars and used the June 30, 1988 exchange rate of Dfl. 2.05 equals U.S. $1.00 for both 1988 and 1987.

title: Suits Planned Over Default Of U.S.-Insured Mortgages
description: In a new policy, the Department of Housing and Urban Development plans to sue investors and homeowners who default on Government-insured mortgages in economically troubled regions and then buy new homes at lower prices at Government foreclosure sales, an agency official said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Medical International Inc., an operator of hospitals in the United States and abroad, appointed L. Stanton Tuttle as president and chief executive of AMI Psychiatric Inc., Houston.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., which distributes office supplies and pharmaceuticals, said it had acquired T. Talbott Bond Co., Baltimore, which sells and leases office equipment. The cash amount was not disclosed.

title: Los Angeles Area Will Get Expanded Times Edition
description: The New York Times will introduce the expanded version of its national edition in the Los Angeles area on Oct. 3, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The Times, announced yesterday.

title: Review/Television; News in Two Tempos: Con Brio and Serioso
description: Television news or, if you will, information programming has come to a crossroads. One sign points in the direction of entertainment, complete with ever more breezy hosts and livelier graphics. The other leads to a more traditional brand of journalism, its emphasis on clear, simple, reliable reporting. These alternatives are being vividly illustrated in two new half-hour nightly ''reports'' that made their debuts last week. As it happens, each production is connected to a national newspaper.

title: Service Merchandise Head May Take Company Private
description: It has been 18 years since Raymond Zimmerman helped his parents start the Service Merchandise Company, a catalogue showroom chain. Now the Nashville company has 317 showrooms with sales of $2.7 billion annually, and Mr. Zimmerman, chairman, president and chief executive, is thinking about making an offer to take the company private along with other members of senior management.

title: Chess
description: The first of the quarter-final candidates' matches to pick the next challenger for the world champion, Gary Kasparov, ended on Aug. 25 in London with a victory by Jonathan Speelman of Britain over his countryman Nigel Short.

title: Sliwa and Aide Stabbed in Face in London
description: Curtis Sliwa, the founder of the Guardian Angels, said yesterday that he had been stabbed in the face several times with darts by a youth during his visit to Britain to set up chapters of his civilian anticrime group.

title: Riese Group Agrees To Buy Restaurants
description: Murray and Irving Riese, the Manhattan-based restaurateurs and real estate developers, said yesterday that they had agreed to buy 107 restaurants from the Restaurant Enterprises Group for between $200 million and $250 million.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Rowing; Part of the Sport: Paying the Price
description: The water was choppy and the sky dark and threatening this morning as the rowers locked their feet into their long, narrow boats and moved into position to race.

title: In Honor of Justice Benjamin Cardozo, Et Al.
description: Oyez, oyez. All persons are requested to draw near and give their attention, for the relatives of Associate Justice Benjamin Nathan Cardozo of the United States Supreme Court are now in session for a family reunion.

title: Bridge
description: The most successful married partnership in North America, in terms of combined master-points, is Tom and Carol Sanders of Nashville. Their total is about 25,300, which put them 4,200 ahead of the next best total, that of Vincent and Joan Remey of Southfield, Mich.

title: 'Clone Wars' Erupt Again As 9 Chiefs Lead Attack
description: THE Clone Wars have begun again, and if you're confused about which side to support, you're not alone. The announcement last week by the Clone chieftans that they were banding together against the International Business Machines Corporation is bound to cause consternation among people trying to decide which computer to buy.

title: Baseball; Athletics Clinch West Division Title
description: The Oakland Athletics won their first American League West title since 1981 by unseating the Minnesota Twins tonight with a 5-3 victory.

title: Fuji to Greenstone
description: Greenstone & Rabasca Advertising in Melville, L.I., has picked up the Fuji America bicycle account, which the agency says will bill about $1 million. According to G.&R. the business was formerly served by Imaginc in Hauppauge, L.I., which has gone out of business. Fuji has been selling its Japanese-made bicycles in this country since 1971.

title: Jaco Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $129,000 for the quarter and $571,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $208,000 for the quarter and $402,000 for the year. The share earnings are restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend on April 28.

title: Suspension Effect Astounds Scientists
description: ONE of the eeriest manifestations of superconductivity is levitation, in which a magnet hovers in midair above a piece of superconducting material.

title: Sports People; Browning Is Tops
description: Tom Browning of the Cincinnati Reds, who pitched a perfect game last week, was named the National League Player of the Week yesterday. While achieving the first perfect game in nearly four years, Browning struck out 7 of the 27 Los Angeles Dodgers that he faced in a 1-0 victory. Mike Moore, the Seattle right-hander, who yielded only seven hits in two complete games, was named American League Player of the Week. Moore allowed only one walk and struck out 14 in defeating Minnesota and Milwaukee.(AP)

title: Clabir Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Key T.W.A. Executive To Go to Lifeco Service
description: Morton Ehrlich, a top officer at Trans World Airlines Inc. and a key architect of its recovery after its takeover by Carl C. Icahn, resigned yesterday to become the president of the Lifeco Service Corporation, a travel company.

title: Tokyo Journal; Secrets of Police Cell: Woman's Grim Story
description: Chisako Tezuka was arrested last year on suspicion of fradulently obtaining a loan. She says she was taken to the police station, stripped naked, subjected twice to a genital search, and forced to urinate while male police officers watched.

title: Review/Dance; From the Yard, a Trip In a Bleak, Stony Place
description: One never knows what to expect next from choreographic workshops. At the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace on Sunday afternoon, the Yard, an arts colony on Martha's Vineyard, offered a program of dances created as part of its summer workshop. It was a strong program - far stronger, in fact, than another program the Yard offered here last week.

title: New View on Genetic Harm of Atom Bomb
description: HUMANS appear to be somewhat less susceptible to genetic harm from atomic bomb radiation than had been thought, scientists have concluded after more than four decades of studying children born to survivors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

title: Eaton Vance Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
How to Keep New Talent On the Job
description: SOME agency heads consider training programs a financial drag, especially since the young people are often kidnapped by competitors as soon as they show promise.

title: Tab Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SafeCard Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Campaign Trail; Wanted: Journalists For Sunday's Debate
description: The Presidential campaign of Michael S. Dukakis has proposed that the four network television anchors serve as the panel asking questions in the debate Sunday with Vice President Bush in Winston-Salem, N.C. There has been no formal response from the Bush campaign. The Vice President's advisers have simply made it clear that they do not want any journalist on the panel who travels with Mr. Bush in his Presidential effort - in short, anyone who has been exposed to his potential vulnerabilities and shortcomings.

title: Review/Recital; An Unusual Piano Urgency
description: Fou Ts'ong, a pianist who was born in Shanghai, trained in Warsaw and lives in London, stopped in New York on Saturday evening to play a concert of music composed in Paris. He did so in an interesting and compelling way, mingling a stylish refinement of timbre and touch with a current of urgency unusual in the repertory he chose.

title: Isaac Rabinowitz, 79, Dead Sea Scroll Expert
description: Isaac Rabinowitz, professor emeritus of biblical and Hebrew studies at Cornell University and an authority on the Dead Sea Scrolls, died Sept. 11 at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y., after a brief illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Diving; Louganis Wins Historic Springboard Gold Medal
description: Greg Louganis of the United States today became the first man to win the 3-meter springboard competition in consecutive Olympic Games.

title: Yonkers's Bond Rating Is Restored
description: Moody's Investors Service, the important rating guide for investors, restored Yonkers's bond rating today, further easing the fiscal crisis that had gripped the city before it ended its defiance of a court-ordered housing-desegregation plan.

title: Radyne Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $66,000 and $209,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After a tax credit of $51,000.

title: Todd Shipyards Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
By Design; The New Blouse
description: Giorgio Armani was the first to float the idea. When the Milanese maestro of the tailored suit decided to soften his precise shapes a few seasons ago, he also began paying special attention to the blouses that accompanied them. Adding details like delicate collars or a bit of draping, and making the blouses from semisheer silky fabrics, he started a trend that has bloomed into an American fashion statement.

title: Harold's Stores reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The latest first half's net included a credit of $119,000 representing cumulative adjustment from a required change in the method of accounting for financial income taxes.

title: Europe Output Rises by 3.5%
description: The index of industrial production in the European Community rose by an estimated 3.5 percent in the first half of 1988 from the corresponding period last year, the community said today.

title: American Technical Ceramics reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: David Dodd, 93, Dies; Professor of Business
description: David L. Dodd, who taught finance at Columbia University for four decades and who was the co-author of ''Security Analysis,'' a standard work in the investment field, died of respiratory failure Sunday at Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 93 years old and had homes in Falmouth Foreside and Chebeague Island, Me.

title: Dow Falls 17.07, to 2,081.08; Volume Down
description: Stock prices moved lower yesterday as volume contracted sharply.

title: Bush Assails Rival's Campaign Style; Quayle Joins in the Attack
description: One of the major tasks of a Vice-Presidential nominee is to act as a verbal point man for the top of the ticket, and Senator Dan Quayle, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, took that job to heart here today.

title: Primerica Ending Accord to Sell Unit
description: The Primerica Corporation, which plans to merge with Commercial Credit Group Inc., said it would terminate an agreement to sell its Pennsylvania Life Insurance Company subsidiary. Primerica said in April it would sell Pennsylvania Life and two affiliates to the American National Insurance Company, based in Galveston, Tex., for about $240 million.

title: Dukakis Injects a Dose Of Vigor Into Message
description: Michael S. Dukakis painted a bleak portrait of the economy of the Reagan years today, describing it as a ''two-job prosperity'' that strained the working parents of the middle class and would only be worsened by ''four more years of Reaganomics without Reagan.''

title: Biologists Fear Hurricane May Have Doomed Rare Turtles
description: HURRICANE Gilbert may have destroyed the only known breeding habitat of the most endangered of all sea turtle species, naturalists reported yesterday.

title: Art Museum Is Given $1.5 Million
description: The Phillips Collection announced today a $1.5 million gift by Yasuhiro and Hiroko Goh of Tokyo to expand the museum's 1960 wing, which will be named the Goh Annex.

title: Firecom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Evans Captures First Gold for U.S.
description: Janet Evans stands 5 feet 6 inches and weighs 105 pounds, and if she has muscles she hides them well. But she swims with boundless energy and single-mindedness, and on Monday she turned those assets into the United States' first gold medal in the Games of the XXIV Olympiad.

title: Frequency Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said this year's first quarter results include FEI Microwave Inc., which was acquired on Aug. 12, 1987.

title: Chock Full O'Nuts Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss includes an unrealized gain on marketable equity securities of $895,000, or 12 cents a share; latest year loss includes an unrealized loss on marketable equity securities of $2,079,000. Prior year net includes the results of Greenwich Mills Co. from Dec. 30, 1986, the date of acquisition. The prior year also includes a gain on the sale of a 50 percent interest in real estate of $2,260,000, or 35 cents a share.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Gymnastics; Karolyi Cries Foul as U.S. Slips Into 4th
description: The women's team compulsory round of the Olympic gymnastics tournament ended tonight with angry accusations by Bela Karolyi, one of the American coaches, that politics had cost the United States team half a point in the team score.

title: Banks Talk On Housing
description: A consortium of California banks met in Los Angeles today to discuss forming a nonprofit mortgage banking corporation to finance low-cost housing in the state. The California Community Reinvestment Corporation, the lenders' group, said it would try to pool $100 million from participating banks to provide long-term loans for housing.

title: No, Color Isn't Put Ahead of Art
description: LEAD: American artists, like the American people, are of many colors. But they are all Americans, and their art -whether fine or folk, traditional or avant garde, ethnic or mainstream - helps make America strong. I know of no one who claims that only people of color are authentically American, as Jacob Neusner, in his Op-Ed article, says we are being told.

title: Pluto May Be Rocky, Not Icy, New Study Says
description: UNLIKE the giant outer planets and their huge moons, which are primarily composed of ice, Pluto, the outermost planet, is very rocky, according to a report in the current issue of the British journal Nature.

title: Corrections
description: A Man in the News article yesterday about Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, the new military leader of Haiti, misstated the year in which Leslie F. Manigat became President. It was this year.

title: Whooping Crane Population Is Rebounding
description: The world's whooping crane population, down to 16 in 1941, will probably exceed 200 this winter, perhaps the highest number this century.

title: No-Shows Steal Show At a U.S.-Soviet Parley
description: A Soviet-American conference opened here today with the Soviet hosts publicly smiling their welcomes and privately complaining that the Americans had left their heavy hitters at home.

title: Glaxo Holdings Plc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The results are in U.S. dollars. The exchange rate used for conversion of the 1988 figures was $1.71 to the pound sterling, which was the rate prevailing at June 30, 1988, and the rate used for the year-ago results was $1.61 as of June 30. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR) and each ADR represents one Glaxo ordinary share.

title: Review/Dance; 4 Centuries of Steps in One Night in Lyons
description: Everyone from Nijinsky's grandson to Viola Farber, the American choreographer who was one of Merce Cunningham's early partners, showed up on stage at a gala to celebrate ''Four Centuries of Dance in France,'' the theme of the current International Dance Biennale in Lyons.

title: Brain Cancer Drug Advances
description: Cell Technology Inc., a Boulder, Colo., biotechnology company that went public last year, said yesterday that its experimental brain cancer drug, Imuvert, had been designated an orphan drug by the Food and Drug Administration. The designation provides special incentives for research for therapies that are initially needed by only relatively small numbers of patients. W. Terrance Schreier, Cell

title: Polish Cabinet, Under Fire, Steps Down
description: The Government of Prime Minister Zbigniew Messner resigned today amid sharp criticism of its management of the economy. It was the first time in Poland's postwar history that the entire Government had stepped down.

title: Laurel Entertainment And Spelling to Merge
description: Aaron Spelling Productions Inc. and Laurel Entertainment Inc., two small entertainment companies, said yesterday that they had signed a merger agreement valued at about $9.5 million.

title: Review/Recital; Pavarotti at the Met
description: Luciano Pavarotti's career is undoubtedly the most thoroughly documented in the annals of opera, and it seems his New York appearances are to have a special place in his collection: Besides the many Metropolitan Opera appearances that have been televised on ''Live From the Met'' (some of which are now available on videotape and laser videodisk), Mr. Pavarotti's first recital at the opera house, a decade ago, was telecast, as have been his performances with, in various configurations, Joan Sutherland, Marilyn Horne and the New York Philharmonic. And his visit to Carnegie Hall last November was recorded, and has just been issued on compact disk.

title: Lebanese Said to Reject U.S.-Syria Election Plan
description: In an atmosphere of renewed crisis, hard-line Christian leaders in Lebanon have apparently rejected proposals by the United States and Syria to break a deadlock over the election of a new President.

title: The Games at a Glance
description: Diving Greg Louganis, who required four stitches in his scalp after hitting his head on the board yesterday during a dive in the preliminaries of the 3-meter springboard, got all the comfort he needed when the gold medal was wrapped around his neck today. It was the third gold medal of the American diver's career. Gymnastics The bars were uneven, the ruling unusual. The result was that the United States women's team, caught in a technical violation on the uneven parallel bars, cried foul. The Americans, in the middle of a surprisingly strong showing in the compulsory portion of the team competition Monday night, had half a point deducted when a committee ruled that Rhonda Faehn had remained on the raised stage surrounding the uneven bars as one of her teammates completed a routine. The ruling on the obscure violation, which was unsuccessfully appealed by American officials, dropped the team to fourth place behind East Germany. The Soviet Union was in first place, getting a perfect 10 in the vault from Elena Shushunova. Daniela Silivas of Rumania, which was second in team scoring, turned in the most spectacular individual performances, earning scores of 10 on the uneven bars and the floor exercise. Volleyball China, whose women's team is virtually unchanged from the one that captured the gold medal in 1984, again demonstrated skill virtually unapproached by anyone else. Today, China easily whipped the United States, 15-9, 15-5, 15-7, in a repeat of the match that decided the gold medal four years ago. Basketball The United States borrowed a page from Oscar Schmidt's handbook on how to shoot from long range this morning, hitting a trio of 3-point shots down the stretch to hold off Canada, 76-70. Having emulated Schmidt, the Brazilian scoring machine, the Americans now get to encounter him. The United States will face Brazil on tomorrow (tonight, 7:45 P.M., Eastern time). Schmidt led Brazil to a 130-108 victory over China. Swimming Tamas Darnyi of Hungary and Silke Horner of East Germany left Olympic records in their wakes today as they each set marks in qualifying heats. Darnyi, the men's world record-holder in the 400-meter individual medley, completed the event in 4:16.55. Horner smashed the women's Olympic record in the 200-meter breast-stroke with a time of 2:27.63. Matt Biondi of the United States qualified for the finals in the 100-meter butterfly in continuing his pursuit of seven medals. Boxing Unlike his teammate, Anthony Hembrick, Kenneth Gould arrived three hours before his fight. And unlike his teammate, Kelcie Banks, he was still standing three rounds after it began. Gould, of Rockford, Ill., took a 4-1 decision from Joseph Marwa of Tanzania today in the 147-pound class.

title: Cards, Flyers, Banners
description: PRINT Magic, Epyx's printing program, was released a while back, but when I received a copy it wouldn't work with my five-year-old printer, an indication of how fast things move in the world of personal computing.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Sports of The Times; So Much for Communication
description: IN all the tears and sympathy for Anthony Hembrick's disqualification from the Olympics for not getting to the ring on time, his coaches have taken the rap for misreading yesterday's schedule. That's thoughtful and honest of the coaches. But the 22-year-old middleweight is as much to blame as anybody else.

title: Sports People; 'King' Is Back
description: Arnold Palmer, who had last won a golf tournament in 1985 at the Seniors Tournament Championship, ended his three-year drought last weekend at the PGA Seniors Tour tournament at Richmond. ''The king is back,'' said Larry Mowry, the defender who finished four strokes behind Palmer. ''Long live the king.'' Palmer said: ''When you haven't won in a couple of years, a lot of things go through your mind. You wonder why you haven't won, if you're ever going to win again. I wanted to win very badly and I felt if I didn't make any bad mistakes, I could.''(AP)

title: Bush Assails Rival's Campaign Style
description: Pursuing a new avenue of criticism, Vice President Bush accused Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts today of using a ''divide and conquer'' strategy in an attempt to convince the electorate that ''everything is bad in America.''

title: Sports People; Hello, Mr. Mattingly
description: With both New York teams in town, the Mets' rookie sensation, Gregg Jefferies, took advantage of a rare off day to pay a visit to Yankee Stadium and do something he's wanted to do for a long time. He introduced himself to his idol, the Yankees' first baseman, Don Mattingly. They spoke for the first time last night before the Yankees' game with the Baltimore Orioles. ''He knew who I was,'' a beaming Jefferies said. ''That really surprised me. What a thrill, for a great player like him to know me. He told me he's watched me on TV and he said he likes my swing. That's all I needed to hear. I wasn't in awe of him, or nervous, but when I shook his hand, I was thinking, 'God, I'm shaking hands with maybe the best hitter in baseball.' ''(AP)

title: Drugs, New Surgery May Offer Protection In Marfan's Syndrome
description: OBSERVATIONS made on turkeys 30 years ago have led to a trial of drugs in humans that now seem to hold the best hope of forestalling the deadly effects of Marfan's syndrome.

title: Transnational Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $81,000 and $165,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes losses of $367,000 and $595,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations.

title: Fight to Be First in Infection Drug
description: Two biotechnology companies - the Xoma Corporation and Centocor Inc. - are racing to bring to market a drug for treatment of septic shock, a condition caused by a bacterial infection often acquired in hospitals. Septic shock kills tens of thousands of people each year.

title: Farmhouse Foods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 23
description: b-Net income

title: Japanese to Ask U.S. Aid
description: Japan's powerful Zenchu agricultural union said today that it planned to seek support from American farmers in its fight to protect the Japanese rice market from imports. A spokesman said Zenchu would send representatives to the United States to seek support from American farmers. Last week, the United States Rice Millers Association filed a complaint with the United States Trade Representative's Office seeking retaliation against Japan for failing to give equal access to its rice markets.

title: Herbert Lansdale, 90, A Y.M.C.A. Executive
description: Herbert P. Lansdale Jr., a retired executive of the National Council of Young Men's Christian Associations, died of heart failure a week ago yesterday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 90 years old.

title: Texas Utilities Inc reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL The Senate approved the free-trade agreement with Canada, 83 to 9, completing American approval. The pact has run into opposition in Canada, where it was approved by the House of Commons. The Canadian Senate, which is controlled by the opposition Liberal Party, has refused to approve the agreement and has demanded that Prime Minister Brian Mulroney call an election. He is expected to call a general election, which would serve as a referendum on the pact, for before Jan. 1, when it would take effect. [ Page D1. ] Industrial nations are likely to call for the dollar's continued stability, to salute the world economy's good health and to promise more help for poorer countries at economic meetings beginning in West Berlin this week. [ D2. ] India has cleared the way for Pepsi-Cola to enter the soft drink market. Pepsico will initially invest $17 million and have a minority stake in a company with two Indian partners. [ D5. ] COMPANIES CSX will buy back up to 38 percent of its stock as part of a restructuring. The plan also includes the sale of assets outside the transportation business. One of the units on the block is a gas pipeline company that CSX bought for $1.06 billion four years ago. [ D1. ] Kroger received a takeover proposal for $55 a share, or $4.3 billion in cash and securities, from the Haft family of Washington. Kroger, the nation's second-largest supermarket operator, has said it would undergo a restructuring to fend off the Hafts. [ D1. ] The New York Post has won the advertising of four stylish retailers - Bloomingdale's, Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman and B. Altman. Since it changed hands in March, the paper has been trying to tone down its sensationalism to win back more advertisers who cater to the affluent. [ D1. ] Pillsbury sold Godfather's Pizza to an investor group led by the chain's management. Analysts estimated the price at under $100 million for the nation's fifth-largest pizza maker. [ D5. ] Apple Computer introduced the Macintosh IIx, which it said performed 10 to 15 percent faster than the Mac II, the company's most expensive machine. [ D9. ] Aaron Spelling and Laurel Entertainment will merge. The deal is valued at about $9.5 million and reflects Carl H. Lindner's plan to broaden his broadcast holdings. [ D26. ] Murray and Irving Riese will buy 107 restaurants from Restaurant Enterprises at a price of $200 million to $250 million. [ D5. ] Managers of KDI are negotiating a buyout of the company, which makes electric and electronic components, swimming pools, industrial chemicals and gases and other products. [ D5. ] MARKETS Stock prices moved lower in slower trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 17.07 points, to 2,081.08. Volume dropped to 135.8 million shares, from 211.1 million on Friday. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury issues slumped in lackluster trading. Analyst said the selloff was mostly a technical correction to the credit market's recent rally. [ D21. ] The dollar weakened in light trading. Gold prices continued to erode, dropping $2.50, to $409.20 an ounce, on the Comex. [ D22. ] Soybean futures prices fell sharply, reflecting disappointment in the lack of foreign and domestic demand, analysts said. Grain futures prices also declined. [ D22. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Congress and the Administration are cracking down on physicians who refer patients to health-care companies in which the doctors have a financial interest. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Discount stores may need to be re-evaluated in view of a consolidation trend in the industry. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: 2 Opposing Versions Given as Friedman's State Bribery Trial Starts
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, bribed the deputy commander of the New York National Guard in an effort to sell the Guard a computer from a company in which Mr. Friedman was the largest stockholder, the prosecutor in Mr. Friedman's state bribery trial said during opening arguments yesterday.

title: Name Change at IC
description: The directors of IC Industries have approved a change in the company's name to the Whitman Corporation, effective Dec. 1. ''The new name was selected after a year of study and research that showed the name Whitman to have the required attributes of familiarity, quality and distinction,'' the company said.

title: Riverbend International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Conagra Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Though Unofficial, Change Is in the Air For U.S.-Hanoi Ties
description: It was the Minuteman statue in Concord at the site of the opening battle of the Revolution that most impressed Le Luu, the first writer from Communist Vietnam to visit the United States since the end of the Vietnam War in 1975.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a singer who was killed while driving a cab in New York City misstated the inspiration for the movie ''Fame.'' The movie was modeled on the High School for the Performing Arts, not the High School of Music and Art.

title: On Horse Racing; Change Is Coming So Bettors Beware
description: A new era in the separation of horseplayers from their dollars begins tomorrow at Belmont Park with the advent of parlay betting. Parlays, as anyone who has ever done business with a bookmaker knows, is sort of a do-it-yourself daily-double. Pick two horses and if they both win, you win big. With a parlay, you can pick up to six horses, but all must come through for you to collect.

title: Hyatt Bid Spurned
description: As expected, Ramada Inc. rejected an unsolicited $10-a-share cash offer from the HCC Corporation, a holding company controlled by Chicago's Pritzker family, which owns the Hyatt chain of hotels. Ramada, which owns the Ramada Inn hotel chain, said its board had based its decision on an opinion by Salomon Brothers Inc., its investment banker, that called the offer ''grossly inadequate.'' A spokeswoman for the Pritzker family said HCC would have no response.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Senate's Early Risers
description: Few members of the United States Senate are more masterful than Jesse Helms, the conservative Republican from North Carolina, in using the institution's arcane rules and procedures to political advantage.

title: N.F.L. Notebook; Drug-Test Policy Is Bedeviling Rozelle
description: While trying to further implement the league's drug policy, Commissioner Pete Rozelle has heard more than one knock on his door as well as finding legal snags that have brought the policy under scrutiny.

title: Baseball; Hershiser Stays Stingy
description: Orel Hershiser pitched his fourth consecutive shutout tonight with a four-hitter and extended his scoreless streak to 40 innings as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Houston Astros, 1-0.

title: Notebook; Lewis Gets an Ultimatum to Cooperate
description: If Carl Lewis doesn't get his four gold medals at these Olympics, he may have only himself to blame. Lewis was given an ultimatum today by Russ Rogers, the sprints and relays coach for the United States, to behave or get be removed from the 400-meter relay team.

title: Jeff de Lange, Diamond Importer, 51
description: Jeff de Lange, president of the Diamond Manufacturers and Importers Association of America, died of a heart attack last Thursday at the St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center. He was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Trident Missile Is Destroyed
description: A Trident 2 submarine missile misfired today and was deliberately destroyed by a radio signal from the ground about a minute after it lifted off from a land launching pad on a test flight.

title: Jaclyn Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company said fiscal 1987 results are restated for a 4 percent stock dividend in June.

title: Albert E. Jenner, 81, A Watergate Counsel
description: Albert Ernest Jenner Jr., a prominent Chicago lawyer who participated in the impeachment inquiry of President Nixon and the investigation into the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, died of a neurological disease Sunday at the White Hall North Nursing Home in Deerfield, Ill. He was 81 years old and lived in Kenilworth, Ill.

title: Promotion at I.B.M. Could Be Step to Top
description: In naming Edward E. Lucente to head its Asian and Pacific operations, the International Business Machines Corporation could be giving the executive a second chance to rise to the top, observers of the company said yesterday.

title: Sandinistas and Contras Resume Some Talks
description: Representatives of the Nicaraguan Government met with rebel leaders today for the first time in three months, but both sides remained sharply divided on ways to end seven years of civil war.

title: U.S., Urging Calm in Burma, Weighs Aid Cutoff
description: The Reagan Administration is considering cutting off its aid to Burma to protest the shooting of unarmed demonstrators by Burmese soldiers, White House and State Department officials said today.

title: Circuit City Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Crucial Bloc for Bush; Thus Far He Has Succeeded in Stemming Defections Among President's Supporters
description: The single most important change in the state of the 1988 Presidential contest since early August is George Bush's success in wooing and bringing home Ronald Reagan's supporters.

title: The Gospel From a Tropical Paradise
description: It is 6 A.M. and Carlos Perdomo hits his cue with a chirpy good morning and a welcome to Trans World Radio, the most powerful radio station in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Kafka's Manuscript Of 'The Trial' to Go On the Auction Block
description: The manuscript of Franz Kafka's ''Trial,'' written in 1914 and published in 1925, the year after his death, is to be auctioned by Sotheby's in London on Nov. 17. The auction house, describing the novel as the most important modern literary manuscript ever to be auctioned, estimates it will bring more than $1 million.

title: Diversified Foods reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
At First for Dukakis and Now Favoring Bush, Some Voters Tell Why
description: A New York Times/CBS News Poll taken after the Democratic National Convention showed Gov. Michael S. Dukakis leading Vice President Bush by 50 percent to 34 percent. Another, taken just after Labor Day, showed Mr. Bush leading 47 to 39 percent. In new interviews last week, some Dukakis supporters in the first poll gave these reasons for switching to Mr. Bush. Bob Willmoth, Fort Worth, Tex.

title: Rate of Hysterectomies Puzzles Experts
description: DESPITE repeated warnings against unnecessary hysterectomies and despite medical advances that now enable some patients to avoid the surgical removal of their uteruses, the operation is still being performed at a rate that alarms some women's groups and perplexes some physicians.

title: KDI in Talks On a Buyout
description: A group of senior managers of the KDI Corporation is negotiating a buyout of the Cincinnati-based company. KDI makes electric and electronic components, swimming pools, industrial chemicals and gases and other products.

title: Campaign Trail; Star Performance On Air Force Two
description: Mr. Bush himself may, or may not, be a Michael Jackson fan.

title: Pope Leaves Africa With Appeal for Peace
description: Pope John Paul II, leaving Mozambique at the end of a tour of southern Africa, made a final appeal today for peace in the region.

title: United Nations Chief to Visit Angola on Plan for Namibia
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar announced today that he will visit South Africa and Angola later this week to push for the carrying out of a United Nations plan to establish independence for Namibia, the South African-controlled territory also known as South-West Africa.

title: Browns' Pagel Riddles Colts
description: Mike Pagel, Cleveland's third starting quarterback in three weeks, threw for 255 yards and two touchdowns tonight and the Browns' defense virtually shut down Eric Dickerson in the second half to beat the Indianapolis Colts, 23-17.

title: Police Anti-Bias Decoy Unit Is Scaling Back Operations
description: A police decoy unit assembled eight months ago to help combat bias-related attacks in New York City has drastically scaled back its operations because the results did not justify the expense, according to a high-ranking police official.

title: Chalmette Journal; After 22 Years, the Girls Are Where the Boys Are
description: Ronnie Kornik remembers all too well when the girls, one and all, disappeared from Chalmette High. It was 1966, his senior year. ''I was sprouting wings,'' he said, ''and looking for female companionship,'' and suddenly the girls were gone.

title: Kroger Gets Hafts' Plan On Takeover
description: The Kroger Company, the nation's second-largest supermarket operator, disclosed yesterday that it had received a takeover proposal for $55 a share, or $4.3 billion in cash and securities, from the Haft family of Washington.

Giants Savor End of Texas Stadium Jinx
description: A handful of players trickled in and out of Giants Stadium this morning. Most of them were treating minor bumps and bruises and stretching sore muscles.

Soviet Still Frowns on Liquor, But Opens Up the Spigot a Bit
description: Slowly but surely, the Government is easing up its anti-drinking campaign, the first and most visible domestic initiative of the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Sports People; It Counts Anyway
description: A freshman for the Colorado School of Mines was the first college football player in the country to return an unsuccessful extra point attempt for 2 points under a new rule this season, a National Collegiate Athletic Association historian said. But the score by Rod Beauchamp, a linebacker for the Golden, Colo., school, should not have been permitted to stand, the historian, Steve Boda. said. Beauchamp scored his team's only points in a 36-2 loss to Hastings on Sept. 3. At N.C.A.A. headquarters in Mission, Kan., Boda said Hastings was attempting an extra point kick when the center snapped the ball over the head of the holder. Under college rules, a team may not advance a recovered fumble. But Beauchamp plucked the ball off the ground and ran 87 yards. (AP)

title: Clerical Workers at N.Y.U. Agree to End 3-Week Strike
description: Office workers at New York University, on strike since Aug. 29, began returning to work yesterday after negotiators reached a tentative settlement late Sunday night. The package, endorsed overwhelmingly at a union meeting yesterday morning, will now be presented to the full membership for ratification by mail ballot.

title: KEY RATES
Olympic Highlights
description: Basketball: The United States men's team, highly favored to win the gold, had to rely on long-range shooting to turn back Canada, 76-70. Brazil, which will be the Americans' next oppponent, was paced by 44 points from Oscar Schmidt in a 130-108 victory over China. GYMNASTICS: The Soviet Union and Rumania, as expected, led the women's team competition after the compulsory exercises. There were also charges of politics over a ruling that left the United States team in fourth place. SWIMMING: The medal competition began with golds for Janet Evans of the United States, Adrian Moorhouse of Britain, Kristin Otto of East Germany and Duncan Armstrong of Australia. Matt Biondi qualified for his second final, winning his heat of the 100-meter butterfly. VOLLYBALL: China opened defense of its women's volleyball title by routing the Unites States, 15-9, 15-5, 15-7. The teams met in the 1984 gold-medal game. Articles begin on page A21.

title: Discovery of New Dinosaur Species Reported
description: FOR the second time this year, Robert T. Bakker, a paleontologist at the University of Colorado, has announced that he has discovered a new dinosaur species not by digging out in the field, but by rummaging through a museum collection. Dr. Bakker says he has found a new species of armor-plated dinosaur that was a natural foe of the fierce Tyrannosaurus rex.

title: Memorial to Jews in France Adds Stark Touch of Realism
description: ''When I survived, I felt a great sense of guilt,'' said Shelomo Selinger, who spent four years in Nazi concentration camps as a teen-ager. ''I felt the good people had died, and only the bad survived.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Peek Behind the Curtain
description: The first participant in the Iran-contra affair to pen his own version of the events in that and other foreign policy initiatives is Michael A. Ledeen, a former consultant to the National Security Council.

title: 5 RUN FOR SENATE IN PRIMARY RACES
description: Representative Mike Lowry is expected to beat Representative Don Bonker Tuesday after a hotly contested Democratic Senate primary race, while former Senator Slade Gorton is considered a shoo-in for the Republican nomination to replace retiring Senator Dan Evans.

title: Army Retreats on Utah Test Site Plan
description: The Army today backed away from its plan to build a biological laboratory in Utah with a design that would have allowed research using the most deadly known varieties of microorganisms that can cause disease.

title: Sports People; Umpire Resigns
description: Dave Pallone, a minor league umpire who was hired by the National League in 1979 during a strike of regular umpires, has resigned. Pallone gained publicity this spring when he ejected Manager Pete Rose from a game in Cincinnati after the two bumped during an argument that sparked an angry crowd reaction, causing Pallone to leave the field. He was reportedly told by league officials that he could either leave now or be dismissed at the end of the season. Pallone last umpired a game on Thursday night in Philadelphia and is not scheduled to work again this season. ''He has asked for a leave of absence for personal reasons,'' said Kathy Feeney, a spokeswoman for the league. ''It was granted by Mr. Giamatti.'' Pallone, who lives in Manhattan, could not be reached for comment. Pallone was one of eight umpires who joined the National League in April 1979 during the umpires' seven-week strike. He never joined the umpires' union and, like the other seven replacements, was ostracized by regulars when he returned. (AP)

title: Scientists From Western Countries Pressing for AIDS Studies in Africa
description: Western scientists, concluding that large-scale human trials of the effectiveness of AIDS vaccines will be nearly impossible in the United States and other Western nations, are asking African countries to agree to the studies.

title: Asbestos and Cancer
description: Occupational exposure to asbestos, already known to cause cancers of the long colon and lining of the chest and abdomen, has now been linked to acute myelocytic leukemia, a particularly lethal cancer that arises in the bone marrow.

Every Monday through Friday, at about 10

Plotkin, the candidate's physician, said in a statement that Mr. Dukakis ''underwent a routine checkup and was found to be in excellent health.''

description: An editorial on Saturday misidentified the chief negotiator for the Nicaraguan contras. He is Alfredo Cesar.

description: Dora Collazo-Levy, executive director of a development agency on the Lower East Side, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 52 years old.

description: Seeking to shed the image of a Governor without a ''foreign policy,'' Michael S. Dukakis has undertaken an ambitious effort to broaden the scope and sophistication of his positions and circle of advisers on arms and international relations.

title: The Battle Over Disclosure: A Chronology
description: FROM the beginning, labeling issues have been as important as health concerns in discussions concerning mechanically boned meat. 1976 - Earl Butz, Secretary of Agriculture in the Ford Administration, gave the meat industry permission to use mechanically boned meat in processed meats. The department was sued by several consumer groups arguing that consumers were not given an opportunity to comment on whether they wanted ground bone in food. Objections were made to the department's plan to exempt this mechanically separated meat from labeling requirements. The court agreed with consumers: the regulation was struck down. 1977 - Safety studies on mechanically separated meat were conducted by the Agriculture Department under the Carter Administration's appointee, Bob Bergland. Mechanically separated meat was allowed on the market, limited to 20 percent of the meat portion of processed meats. Labels were to indicate the presence and percentage of such products. The meat industry claimed such labels would deter sales. 1981 - The meat industry repeated its request for less restrictive labeling. John Block, Secretary of Agriculture, agreed to amend the regulations. References to bone would be deleted; the prominently placed phrase ''mechanically processed beef [ or pork ] product'' also would be deleted. Instead, mechanically separated meat was listed only in the ingredient list. Labels now indicated presence of ''calcium.'' 1982 - Consumer groups sued the Agriculture Department, contending that the reference to calcium made processed products seem nutritionally superior to regular meat products; the consumer groups lost. 1986 - Four sausage makers sued the Agriculture Department seeking regulations to label mechanically boned poultry the way mechanically boned meat was labeled. The department promised to consider more lenient regulations for the meat industry. The industry wanted elimination of the mechanically separated meat label requirement if no more than 10 percent of a product was such meat.

title: President of Fotomat Resigns After 3 Years
description: The effort to turn around the fortunes of the Fotomat Corporation has gone slowly, and John R. Chase, the company's president for three years, is leaving.

title: Campaign Trail; Togetherness Not All It's Cracked Up to Be
description: They should be the perfect campaign team. The President and Vice President. The Gipper and Poppy.

title: Britain to Lend to China
description: Britain has agreed to offer China $:300 million ($500 million) in low-interest loans in the next three years, a senior British official said today. Chris Patten, Minister for Overseas Development, said the loans would probably be used for energy and transport development. Terms have not been decided. Britain's last loan package offered funds for 20 years at 5 percent interest.
