title: With Flag as His Backdrop, Bush Urges Help for the Poor
description: Taking a line from a Peggy Lee song, Vice President Bush said today that he looks around at America's pride and prosperity and asks himself, ''Is that all there is?''

title: TRW Sells 2 Units
description: TRW Inc. agreed to sell two divisions to the British company Pearson P.L.C. for more than $300 million. TRW said in a statement that it would sell its Reda Pump division, based in Bartlesville, and its Oil Well Cable division, based in Lawrence, Kan., to Camco Inc., a Pearson subsidiary. The deal is expected to be closed within a few weeks, the company said. Reda Pump has 800 employees nationwide, most of them in Bartlesville, while Oil Well Cable has about 85 employees. TRW is involved in the defense, automotive and informations systems businesses.

title: A Movie by New Yorkers About New Yorkers
description: It was another typical day at 77th Street and West End Avenue.

title: Haiti's Kleptocratic Jackals
description: When I lived in Haiti during the mid-50's, Paul Magloire, a jolly and corrupt President, ran things, partying and stealing and getting fat belly laughs out of the good deal he had made for himself. The people suffered, of course, but now that time is remembered as a golden age of music, art, tourism and foreign aid.

title: Interco Acts to Block Move by Rales Brothers
description: Interco Inc. began defending itself today against a hostile takeover attempt.

title: Robinson Joins Suns
description: Len (Truck) Robinson, a 6-foot-7-inch power forward who played for Phoenix from 1978 to 1982, has been hired by the Suns as a part-time assistant coach to work with the team's forwards and centers. Robinson, 36 years old, who was with the Knicks when he retired in 1985, joins a staff headed by Coach Cotton Fitzsimmons. ''The younger players are bigger and stronger, but I wouldn't say they're better coached,'' Robinson said. ''I've been around. I can help young players.''(AP)

title: Grapefruit Safety Questioned
description: FLORIDA grapefruit will begin showing up in supermarkets sometime next month, but a number of environmental groups say consumers should shun the fruit because it may contain lead arsenate, a lead compound that can cause brain damage, and arsenic, which can cause cancer.

title: Senate Republicans to Seek New Penalties on Drug Use
description: Senate Republicans are expected to match or exceed the House in proposing new civil penalties for casual drug use when the Senate begins debate on its own version of drug legislation.

title: Jersey Exempts Trump From Yacht Sales Tax
description: Donald J. Trump does not owe New Jersey's 6 percent sales tax on his $29 million yacht, the state Division of Taxation has ruled.

title: A Fountain of San Francisco Sweets
description: EVERY Wednesday, for as far back as he can remember, Peter Christakes has mixed up a batch of the family's secret recipe for chocolate syrup, poured it into a potbellied copper kettle and lighted the old gas jets underneath. He stirs the mixture with a wire whisk the size of a baseball bat and gives the old kettle an affectionate kick.

title: Foster-Care Agency to Help Sexually Abused Children
description: A private foster agency plans to place sexually abused children in foster-care homes and to train those parents in the special needs of such children.

title: Lenz Winery on L.I. Changes Hands
description: LENZ VINEYARDS, one of Long Island's first wineries, is changing hands in a transaction that Peter Lenz, a co-founder, said would exceed $1 million.

title: Review/Dance; Art Nouveau's Esthetic in Motion: Invoking the Spirit of Loie Fuller
description: Swathed in yards of swirling silk that sensuously transformed her into a quivering flame or a huge butterfly, Loie Fuller became the toast of Paris at the turn of the century.

title: Carrington Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
After 14 Years, 2d Conviction In Murder Case
description: Fourteen years after the crime, a former Brooklyn resident was convicted yesterday of murdering an off-duty police lieutenant during a robbery attempt on a street in Queens.

title: Montpelier, Vt.
description: THE waitress arrives at the table bearing a lemon wedge that was supposed to accompany the herbal tea that arrived a good half hour ago. ''Funny the way the mind works,'' she says, shrugging.

title: Close-Up: Team Handball
description: Two Sports in One The game is a combination of soccer and basketball, played indoors on a varnished hardwood floor, with six players and a goalie on each side. The object is to throw the ball, which is about the size of a cantelloupe, into the goal, either in the air or on a bounce. Players dribble, pass and shoot with their hands, and cannot shoot from closer than 6 meters from the goal. Do Anything but Kick the Ball Players may run three steps; hold it for three seconds on the floor or in their hands; dribble as long as they want, and stop, catch, hit or throw the ball with open or closed hands, heads, arms, torsos, thighs or knees. They cannot touch the ball more than once unless it hits the floor or touch the ball with their legs below the knee. Only goalies can dive for the ball. A player fouled in the act of shooting gets a free throw from 7 meters out. Minor fouls result in a free throw from the point of the infraction. Serious fouls draw a two-minute penalty.

title: Beirut Car Bomb Kills 3 in Christian Sector
description: A car bomb killed 3 people and wounded 25 others in Christian-controlled East Beirut today as Lebanon struggled with the failure of the country's factions to agree on a new head of state.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Petr Klima and Bob Probert of the Detroit Red Wings have been sent to a farm team, the Adirondack Red Wings of the American Hockey League, ''on a day-to-day basis,'' according to Coach Jacques Demers. Klima, a left wing, had been fined $500 for being late for practice and Probert, a right wing, the same amount for missing a team plane. . . . Bobby Hurley, regarded as the best high school basketball player in New Jersey, has signed a letter of intent with Duke University. Hurley, a senior at St. Anthony's High School in Jersey City, averaged 19.5 points and 8.5 assists a game last season. . . . Solomon Johnson, a heralded sophomore running back for Columbia, will miss the Lions' game with Lafayette Saturday because of a knee injury he suffered last Saturday in the team's 41-7 opening loss to Harvard. . . . John Lucas, saying he thought Seattle had a chance to win the N.B.A. championship next season, signed a one-year contract with the SuperSonics Monday night. The Sonics will be the 34-year-old guard's sixth team in 12 professional seasons. . . . Emphasizing his movement toward younger players on the Dallas Cowboys, Coach Tom Landry yesterday waived Mike Renfro, a 10-year veteran who had been the Cowboys' premier receiver. His place on the roster will be taken by Everett Gay. His place on the field has been taken by Michael Irvin, the Cowboys' No. 1 draft choice, who started the season at Renfro's flanker position. ''Renfro didn't have a good summer,'' Landry said. ''He had a pulled hamstring and didn't have a chance to compete.'' Renfro played for six years for the Houston Oilers and four years for the Cowboys. With the Cowboys, he caught 163 passes for 2,525 yards and 17 touchdowns.

description: Since his co-manager, Jim Jacobs, died in March, Mike Tyson has been the object of boxing's most publicized infighting.

title: Campaign Trail; Kitty Dukakis Plans A Quiet Holy Day
description: Katharine Dickson Dukakis, who has the prospect of being the nation's first Jewish First Lady, plans to spend a quiet Yom Kippur. Yesterday afternoon, the wife of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis returned to Brookline, Mass., from a campaign trip to Rhode Island so she could spend the holiest of Jewish holidays at home.

title: Bonn Aide Unhurt in Shotgun Attack
description: A pair of assailants with shotguns fired on a senior West German Government official today, missing him but raising fears for the security of a congress of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank scheduled for next week in West Berlin.

title: Review/Television; Pitting 'SCTV' Against the Olympics
description: What do you do when the writers' strike has postponed the start of the new season and one of your competitors is monopolizing attention with coverage of the Summer Olympics? ABC has whipped up something called its ''First Decathlon of Comedy,'' an umbrella gimmick that can cover everything from sitcom reruns to tonight's ''Best of SCTV.''

Capt. Don Parker of the Escambia County Sheriff's Department said the four were slain in execution style, which led investigators to suspect they could be related to the drug trade. The police were trying to identify the victims.

Wives were making last-minute purchases for big meals they would cook and serve before sundown, the same as always. And toddlers were struggling to break in stiff new shoes, the same as always.

Kennedy Stadium here on Monday.

title: KEY RATES
O'Neill Centennial Gala Planned for October 16
description: A gala celebrating the 100th anniversary of the birth of Eugene O'Neill is to be held Oct. 16 at 7 P.M. at the Circle in the Square Theater. The tribute, consisting of scenes and songs from O'Neill's plays performed by Colleen Dewhurst, Jason Robards, Geraldine Fitzgerald and a dozen other stars of the stage and movies, is sponsored by the Theater Committee for Eugene O'Neill and will be directed by Stuart Vaughan. Joseph Papp and Paul Libin are the co-producers. Admission is by invitation.

description: Hughes Hubbard & Reed, the venerable Wall Street law firm, suffered a stunning setback yesterday when more than a third of its Washington lawyers announced that they would move to Arnold & Porter.

For the year-ago quarter and 6 months, those gains were $122,000, and $5,361,000, respectively. The year-ago periods also included expense of $7,308,000 from elimination of FSLIC secondary reserves. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95. How unpleasant to meet Mr. Eliot! title: Real Estate; Project Alters Old Building In Hartford
description: FOR several generations the Goodwin, the first luxury apartment house in downtown Hartford, served as a fashionable home to an assortment of business people, artists and rich bohemians. But eventually the five-story red brick and terra cotta landmark lost both its luster and its well-heeled tenants.

description: Donald L. Thomas, the 71-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Anchor Savings Bank, has told the board that he plans to retire after a 50-year banking career.

description: A PROMINENT chateau owner here did something unconscionable a couple of days ago: he gave an opinion on the 1988 vintage. To a journalist.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE question: ''How do you get to Carnegie Hall?'' The anticipated answer: ''Practice.'' There are, however, countless variations on the theme of getting to Carnegie Hall. This is one of them: how the Baton Rouge Symphony Orchestra and its conductor, James Paul, happened to be booked there next month.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Is Seeking Kroger
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company entered the battle for the Kroger Company yesterday with a takeover offer of $58 a share, or $4.6 billion.

title: College Football Notebook; Long Time Coming But Rutgers Is Up
description: It is about time a Rutgers team beat Penn State and this time seems as good as any.

title: L.I. Suspect Pleads Guilty
description: A Medford man has pleaded guilty to killing the companion of another man after agreeing to the slaying as a way of paying off a drug debt. The suspect, Brian France, 24 years old, pleaded guilty in Suffolk County Court before jury selection began Monday. The plea was part of an agreement in which Mr. France is to be sentenced to 18 years to life in prison, instead of the maximum 25 years to life. He was charged with killing Tracy Amrhein, 24, of Selden.

title: Electoral Journalism: Not Yellow, but Yellow-Bellied
description: LEAD: During the Reagan years, journalists have been spooked by absurd right-wing charges that they are a bunch of liberals who are out of step with ''real'' Americans. Thus, they have frequently ended up pulling their punches for fear of appearing biased.

title: Stram Leaves Hospital
description: There was no pain, Hank Stram recalled. Just a shortness of breath and some dizziness. The next thing he knew, he was lying on the sidewalk as paramedics worked on him. ''I told the doctor I must have had some bad potato soup,'' said Stram, 65 years old, who was released from Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis yesterday, a week after undergoing open-heart surgery for a severely blocked aortic valve. Stram's aortic valve was replaced by an artificial one during a four-hour operation. Stram, a CBS football analyst and former National Football League coach, collapsed Sept. 10. ''It's been a congenital thing,'' he said. ''About five years ago, I had to have a physical examination for an insurance policy. I went to a doctor, a friend of mine, who said I had an aortic valve problem and to be sure to check it from time to time.'' He said he would return to his home in Covington, La., and probably go back to work for the Dallas-New Orleans Monday night game on Oct. 3.(AP)

title: Florence Lewis May, Curator Emeritus, 89
description: Florence Lewis May, the curator emeritus of textiles for the Hispanic Society of America's museum in Manhattan and the author of a number of books, died of multiple myeloma, a form of cancer, on Sept. 6 at Arnot-Ogden Memorial Hospital in Elmira, N.Y. She was 89 years old and lived in Elmira.

title: Reparations Office Is Opened
description: The Office of Reparations Administration is handling inquiries about restitution to people of Japanese ancestry interned by the United States in World War II. Its toll-free telephone number, (800) 228-8375, or 835-2094 in the Washington area, takes calls from 8:30 A.M. to 8:30 P.M., Eastern time, Monday through Friday. The address is P.O. Box 66260, Washington, D.C. 20035-6260.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This election will be decided in neighborhoods that didn't exist when Ronald Reagan was first elected President.'' - Tony Podesta, a Dukakis campaign official, on California's suburban voters. [ B6:2. ]

title: Santa Ana Journal; Drunken Drivers Visit the Morgue
description: The nervous joking, what little there was, ended as the four young visitors to the coroner's office passed the body of a teen-age suicide victim on a wheeled table in the hallway. No one wanted to go first into the busy autopsy room.

title: Report Faults Leadership In Jersey Blaze
description: Five firefighters who were killed when the roof of a burning car dealership collapsed here last July died ''needlessly,'' a highly critical report said today.

title: Economic Panel to Get Plan to End U.S. Deficit
description: Robert Strauss, the co-chairman of the bipartisan National Economic Commission, said today that he had developed $68.5 billion in proposed spending cuts for inclusion in a plan to eliminate the Federal budget deficit in the next four years.

title: Head Start Gets Credit For Rise In Scores
description: The news that teen-agers in most minority groups had again raised their scores on standardized college admissions tests is at least partly a result of two decades of the Head Start program and an increasing emphasis on more demanding high school programs, education experts said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of coming events in the Connecticut Weekly last Sunday gave an incorrect admission price for an antiques show this Saturday and Sunday at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, Conn. Admission is $4.

Steinbrenner Is Willing to Trade Clark
description: George Steinbrenner said yesterday that he would be willing to honor a trade request from the team's designated hitter, Jack Clark, in the off season, but would make no other decisions regarding changes on the Yankees until after the season.

title: San Francisco
description: VISITORS to other nations are often enchanted by their bustling markets, so distinct from this country's antiseptic supermarkets. Northern Californians can experience Old World charm at the Old Mill Public Market, 45 minutes south of San Francisco, at 2540 California Street in Mountain View.

description: Workers at a Christian-operated Arizona manufacturing company cannot be required to attend prayer services, a Federal appellate court has ruled.

description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds posted modest gains in very quiet, trendless trading yesterday, recapturing most of the losses sustained during Monday's session.

title: U.S. Scores Upset in Water Polo
description: Jim Bergeson's goal with five seconds left in the game lifted the United States to a 7-6 victory over the favored Yugoslav team today in the opening day of the water polo competition.

title: Armenians Hold Rally Over Disputed Region
description: Thousands of striking Armenians gathered today in Yerevan, the capital of the Soviet republic, to protest violence in the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region of Azerbaijan, a neighboring republic.

title: On Euphemisms - or, Through the Dark, Glassily
description: LEAD: The 80's are winding down and it's probably not too early to begin characterizing them. If the 1960's were a period of conscience and the 70's belonged to the ''me'' generation, the 80's, I believe, is the decade of the euphemism.

title: From the Minors to Montrachet
description: IT was a bar-stool baseball fan's fantasy last week in the wood-paneled tavern at Keens steakhouse in Manhattan. A couple of guys were slouched over their beers watching the Cleveland Indians at bat against the Yankees, top of the third. The batter hammered a double to right center field. At the other end of the bar someone bellowed: ''Look at that outfielder! He's taking too many steps before throwing the ball.''

title: San Francisco Bonds Priced
description: The City and County of San Francisco yesterday priced $145 million of revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.60 percent for a 7 1/4 percent issue due in 2015 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Merrill led the underwriting group that submitted the winning bid on the competitive issue.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: New Subaru Model
description: Subaru of America said it would introduce a new, midsize car in April that is to compete with products like the Honda Accord and the Toyota Camry. The 1990 model, to be called the Legacy, will be imported from Japan and later manufactured at a plant in Lafayette, Ind., that is being developed by a joint venture with Isuzu. The Legacy will be offered as a sedan and as a station wagon. It will have front-wheel drive in the basic version and four-wheel drive in the more elaborate one, the company said.

description: TO everything there is a season, and that includes apples.

title: Yonkers and Stamford: 2 Paths, Similar Results
description: Back in 1966, Mayor Thomas C. Mayers came up with a plan to house Stamford's needier residents, mostly blacks and Puerto Ricans, in garden apartments scattered around the city, from its gritty core to its leafier edges. The plan matched the civil rights ideals of the era with Stamford's disillusionment with high-density high-rise public housing. Mr. Mayers, a self-described optimist, was sure it would fly.

title: HAITI IN TURMOIL IN WAKE OF COUP
description: Civil disorder increased today in Haiti, with strikes by public employees, widespread violence in the streets and reports of major breaches in the military chain of command three days after a coup.

title: Education; Lessons
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology is famous for the Nobel Prizes won by its faculty, computer nerds and a superintense academic environment that its president, in a welcoming address to this year's freshmen, compared to ''taking a drink from a fire hose.''

title: Wage Tied to Move on Judges
description: Republicans in the Senate threatened today to block legislation to raise the minimum wage unless several of President Reagan's judicial nominees are quickly confirmed.

title: Bridge
description: An American team concluded its down-under tour in Auckland, N.Z., Saturday, winning by 41 imps against a group of players in which most had represented New Zealand in world competition. The best playing effort was by Stephen Lester on the diagramed deal. He held the South cards and arrived in five clubs as shown.

title: A Moral Test for Congress
description: Will Congress go home without passing a congressional ethics law? The Senate passed one four months ago, and a weaker version is ready for the House Judiciary Committee. Many a legislator and staff member wouldn't mind if time ran out. If that happens, Congress will have perpetuated a notorious double standard.

title: Carriage Horses Deserve Better Treatment From New York City; Worse in Evening
description: To the Editor:

title: Msgr. Raul del Valle, Archdiocese Aide, 62
description: Msgr. Raul del Valle, the Chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, died of cancer Tuesday at the Archbishop's residence in Manhattan. He was 62 years old and lived at the residence.

title: Lionel I.C. Pearson, 80, Classical Scholar
description: Lionel I.C. Pearson, a classical scholar who won a Guggenheim fellowship and wrote more than a dozen books, died of pancreatic cancer Sunday in a hospital in Menlo Park. He was 80 years old.

title: JAPANESE PEERING INTO NEXT EPOCH
description: Japan tried today to imagine what life would be like without the only Emperor it has known since 1925 and raised questions that until now have just been whispered.

title: New Pact for Jordan
description: He rewrote the books in the National Basketball Association last season as the league's leading scorer, most valuable player and top defensive player, so it was not too surprising yesterday that the Chicago Bulls rewrote Michael Jordan's contract. The revised one will pay him $25 million over the next eight years. Jerry Krause, the general manager, said: ''Michael is among the highest-paid players in the history of professional basketball.'' Krause said the pact restructured portions of Jordan's current contract and extended the agreement. Jordan said he was satisfied. ''It's something you take as a compliment,'' said Jordan, who is entering his fifth pro season. ''I'm happy.'' (AP)

title: Bears' Perry Sidelined
description: William (Refrigrator) Perry, the 300-plus pound defensive lineman who has become something of a national folk hero since joining the Chicago Bears in 1985, is expected to miss eight to 10 weeks of the National Football League season after suffering a broken left arm in the Bears' 31-7 loss to the Minnesota Vikings Sunday. Perry missed most of Chicago's preseason training camp while being treated for an eating disorder, but said he felt good and ready to play when he returned shortly before the final exhibition game. He was hurt in the final minute of play against the Vikings and underwent surgery on Monday when a plate was inserted in his left arm. Al Harris will replace Perry at defensive tackle.(AP)

title: City in Washington Offers Settlement
description: The City of Richland, a defendant in the Washington Public Power Supply System bond default case, agreed to pay Washington Public Power bond holders $6.5 million to settle its share of the alleged liability, Melvin Weiss, an attorney for plaintiff bond holders, said in a statement.

title: Campaign Trail; Taking the Measure Of Debating Stances
description: Bulletin from the Debate Front.

title: Inflation Rate Shows Rise to 5% in Quarter
description: Prices climbed at a faster clip than previously thought during the second quarter, pushing the inflation rate further above the expectations of the Federal Reserve and Administration policymakers, Commerce Department figures showed today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; For the Affluent, Yet Another Magazine
description: Fame is the name of still another magazine aimed at the affluent, and it will make its debut in the middle of next month with a November cover date. Its publisher, Stephen A. Greenberg, is already saying it is ''possibly the most successful new magazine launch for 1988.''

title: Islanders Are Short on Shots
description: The Islanders, a present and perhaps future array of them, slogged through their third preseason game tonight at the Coliseum against a likewise patchy squad of Montreal Canadiens, who prevailed by a 3-1 score. Teams like to call the exhibition season a learning experience; tonight the Islanders learned that games are rarely won by teams that take just 13 shots on net.

title: Gateway Medical Systems reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a $13,905,550 credit for forgiveness of debt. c-Net loss

title: The Brawley Family Moves to Virginia Beach
description: After months of traveling outside New York State, Tawana Brawley and her family have resettled in Virginia Beach, Va., a family member said yesterday.

title: About New York; A Korean Feast Of Kimchi, Mook And Much Pride
description: ''Gun-Bae!'' the Koreans exclaimed, hoisting glasses of ice-cold OB beer in their traditional toast. Among the delicacies arrayed on the table were mook, a jelly made from acorns; hundreds of tiny marinated anchovies, heads still attached, and, most typically Korean, kimchi, a fiery pickled cabbage best marinated for months.

title: Newmont Sells Foreign Unit
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation, one of the largest gold mining companies in the United States, said today that it had agreed to sell the foreign assets of its Newmont Oil Company subsidiary to the Dutch subsidiary of Clyde Petroleum P.L.C., a British oil exploration company, for $234 million. Under the terms of the agreement, the Clyde subsidiary, Clyde Petroleum B.V., will assume $46.7 million in liabilities, including debt and taxes.

title: 2 Queens Men Are Sentenced In Arson Case
description: A Queens teen-ager convicted of twice firebombing the home of a man who had complained about drug dealers was sentenced yesterday to the maximum term of 50 years to life in prison.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the growing volume of submissions, however, we regret that we can no longer return articles unless accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Reagan on Washington
description: President Reagan offered a bit of advice yesterday: ''Go home soon. Because if you stay here, strange things may start happening to you.''

title: Toronto Broker Losses
description: Nearly two-thirds of the Toronto Stock Exchange's 70 member firms lost money in the first half of the year, and matters may be worse in the third quarter because of declining late-summer trading volumes. The exchange said 45 brokerages posted losses during the half, up from 39 in the first three months of the year. Overall profits increased to $9.6 million (Canadian), or $7.9 million (United States), in the second quarter from a loss of $7.9 million (Canadian) in the prior period.

title: Suriname's Nesty Stuns Field
description: This was a bittersweet day for Matt Biondi in Olympic swimming. It was a wonderful day for Anthony Nesty of Suriname, an almost obscure swimmer from an obscure nation that had never won an Olympic medal in any sport.

title: Market Place; Analysts Size Up Fluor's Prospects
description: INVESTORS are again taking notice of the Fluor Corporation, the engineering and construction company. Its stock, which closed unchanged yesterday at $21.875, has about doubled from the Oct. 19 low of $11. Much of that gain has occurred recently: in June, for instance, the month's low was $18.25.

title: Saul Bellow to Read At the Poetry Center
description: A reading by Saul Bellow on Oct. 10 at 8 P.M. will open the 50th season of the Poetry Center at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Mr. Bellow, who won the 1976 Nobel Prize for Literature, is to read from his own works. Remaining tickets for the reading are available to members of the Poetry Center. The annual membership fee of $85 includes admission to all 30 readings at the center.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Latin American Staples

title: Estelle Wolf, Advocate For Central Park, 102
description: Estelle Wolf, a founder of Friends of Central Park, died of pneumonia Sunday at Mt. Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 102 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CML Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Carriage Horses Deserve Better Treatment From New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Cavazos Takes the Oath As Education Secretary
description: The Senate voted 94 to 0 today to confirm Lauro Cavazos as Secretary of Education, and hours later he was sworn in by Vice President Bush.

title: Adobe Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Shoe Client to Rossin
description: Rossin Greenberg Seronick & Hill, known more fondly in the Boston area as R.G.S.&H., is walking tall as the new agency for Sperry Top-Sider shoes, part of the Strid eRite empire. Billings, according to the agency, should be between $2 million and $3 million. The former agency was Emerson Lane Fortuna, also in Boston. R.G.S.&H. won the business after a six-week review involving five New England angencies.

title: HDTV: Will U.S. Be in the Picture?
description: The American electronics industry seemed to be getting a break earlier this month when the Federal Communications Commission set technical guidelines for high-definition television that undercut Japan's head start in the potentially lucrative field.

title: Team Spirit Leaves Players a Bit Giddy
description: The midmorning sounds were familiar, a tennis ball strumming the string of a racquet, players practicing as they would at the National Tennis Center, Roland Garros or Wimbledon. And yet the Olympics are something quite unique for the players taking part in the tennis competition here, giving them a chance to escape from the confines of the single-minded world they live in.

title: Rax Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
description: b-Included tax credits of $195,000 and $673,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and included a pre-tax charge of $4,409,000 for the sale or refranchising of company-owned stores and image enhancement costs.

title: Oren Lee Staley Is Dead at 65; Farmers' Advocate Since 1950's
description: Oren Lee Staley, the first president of the National Farmers Organization, a group that grew out of the turbulence of farm price protests of the 1950's to become a strong advocate for growers, died at a local hospital Monday. He was 65 years old.

title: Soviet Men Set Record for Games
description: ''That may be one of the greatest sports teams of all time out there, and I'm not talking just about gymnastics.''

title: Soviets Face Up to an Alien: The Specter of Bankruptcies
description: Soviet banks today released a list of industrial enterprises that cannot pay their bills, with a pointed warning that the Government plans to begin forcing failing companies into bankruptcy.

title: American Libraries: A World Far Beyond Books
description: With little fanfare, public libraries are being transformed into all-purpose centers for learning, recreation and social needs.

title: A First-Rate Crop
description: Near-record rains in recent months spawned a mold scare among New Mexican chili growers, but a last-minute spell of dry weather rescued this year's harvest. Some processors report that New Mexico's chili fields are producing the highest-quality crops in years, enough chilies to supply the growing market.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Harry S. Oakley Jr. has been appointed chief administrative officer and senior vice president of Hill & Knowlton Inc., an international public relations firm.

title: Werner Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Education; Inner City's Summer Writing Project
description: Joe Mattic did not know much about his inner city neighborhood or its leaders, politics or history. A high school dropout, he did not know much about poetry or grammar, either.

title: Ambulance Chief Plans 60-Vehicle Backup Fleet
description: The new director of New York City's municipal ambulance service said yesterday that he planned to create a 60-vehicle backup fleet of basic ambulances to be used when the primary ambulances were out of service.

title: Clear Sailing as the Regatta Gets Going
description: The powerful current that sometimes stalks the coast off Pusan stayed far out to sea today for most of the races on the opening day of the Olympic yachting regatta.

title: Polish Shift: Any Change?; Cabinet Quit, but It Only Obeyed Party
description: The resignation of Poland's Prime Minister and Cabinet over charges of economic mismanagement appears to be a move to shield the real source of power, the party leadership, from frontal assaults on its policies.

title: Princeton Announces A Deficit of $1.1 Million
description: Princeton University had a $1.1 million deficit for the fiscal year that ended June 30 and a $500,000 deficit is projected for the current year, the univeristy's president, Harold T. Shapiro, announced in a faculty meeting here on Monday.

title: Chicago
description: BARRY BLUESTEIN and Kevin Morrissey have opened what is believed to be the first Chicago bookstore devoted to cookery, Season to Taste Books Ltd., at 911 West School Street. It is a fitting location, because the owners say they want to educate customers as well as to sell them books. This brightly lit North Side bookstore is as cozy as a friend's apartment, with a pot of coffee, table and chairs inviting customers to sit and peruse the growing stock of books on food, wine and beer.

title: Donald K. Phillips, Investment Broker, 84
description: Donald K. Phillips, an investment broker, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Dothan, Ala. He was 84 years old.

title: Review/Music; Concert by Composers, One Minimalist, Two Jazz
description: The Minimalist composer Philip Glass and the jazz composers Max Roach and Henry Threadgill each offered a 20-minute set in a free concert at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Equitable Center on Monday evening. The performance was offered as a prelude to a tour of New York State under auspices of the New Music Network.

title: McCormick & Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included property sale gains of $800,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $900,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a gain of $6.4 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Included a property sale gain of $3.6 million, or 15 cents a share. The share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in April 1988.

title: Rep. Chappell Discloses His Finances
description: Representative Bill Chappell Jr. of Florida, whose activities have been under scrutiny in the Pentagon procurement inquiry, today released documents that provided some new details about his personal finances and commercial ventures.

title: Insider Case Guilty Plea
description: The former chief executive of a Connecticut bank pleaded guilty today in United States District Court to obstruction of justice relating to an insider trading investigation.

title: Cone Raises Record to 18-3
description: The Mets raced for the finish line last night with another unarguable performance that knocked off the Philadelphia Phillies, 6-4, and moved them into position to clinch their second title in three years in the National League's East, perhaps as early as tonight.

title: Washington Talk: The Senate; Choosing a Majority Leader: An Arcane and Curious Process
description: It is a campaign quite unlike any other in American politics. There are no opinion polls or stump speeches, no image consultants or bumper stickers. The votes are solicited face to face in the strictist privacy, and the returns are kept secret except for the name of the winner.

title: Customs Charge On Chip Imports
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation disclosed in its annual report, released this week, that the District Director of United States Customs in San Francisco had charged the company with underpaying duties of about $19.5 million between June 1, 1979, and March 1, 1985, on chips it imported from foreign subsidiaries. National said the claim was without merit.

title: Claude K. Bell, 91, Sculptor of Dinosaurs
description: Claude K. Bell, whose dinosaur creations became a landmark to millions of travelers in the Southern California desert, died of pneumonia Monday at Humana Hospital in Anaheim. He was 91 years old, Mr. Bell and his dinosaur sculptures have been featured in the film ''Pee-Wee's Big Adventure'' and a book titled ''The Well-Built Elephant and Other Roadside Attractions - A Tribute to American Eccentricity.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Waterford/Wedgwood Retail to Wells, Rich, Greene's Image Group.

title: Digitech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Woman, 37, Is Slain; Student, 19, Arrested
description: A 37-year-old Westchester woman who was known to jog regularly around the Somers High School track was found dead in nearby woods on Monday and a 19-year-old student at the school was charged yesterday with her slaying, the police said.

title: C. Rufus Rorem, 93, Economist; His Ideas Led to Blue Cross Plans
description: C. Rufus Rorem, an early proponent of prepaid health care whose studies led to the creation of Blue Cross and Blue Shield, died of heart failure Monday at the Cadbury retirement community in Cherry Hill, N.J., where he lived. He was 93 years old.

title: Game of Political Roulette For California's Key Vote
description: In California, where the television advertisement has dominated politics for decades, both parties believe the Presidential campaign is so close that they are investing heavily in the sort of door-to-door campaigning that is as out of step with this state's image as is the silent movie.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Lafarge Coppee Group, the giant French cement producer, said yesterday that it had received a offer of $1.47 billion from an unidentified group of investors for its 57 percent stake in its Lafarge Corporation, its cement-making subsidiary based in Reston, Va.

title: Martin Marietta
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said it would realize about $140 million in after-tax profits from the sale of its interest in a London-based computer services company. Martin Marietta, which has aerospace, computer, construction and defense operations, recently sold its 68.3 percent interest in Hoskyns Group P.L.C. to the Plessey Company of Britain for $191 million.

title: Kitty Carlisle Hart Reflects
description: IF she had not had a change of heart when she was selecting a stage name a half century or so ago, Kitty Carlisle Hart would be known today as Vere de Vere Hart. The year was 1932 and the young woman born in New Orleans as Catharine Conn had come to New York with her strong-willed mother, Hortense, to embark on a theatrical career. Eventually that career embraced working in theater, films, nightclubs and television and serving as chairwoman of the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: Coppola Picked to Head Film Jury at Cannes
description: The American director Francis Ford Coppola will be the president of the jury for the 1989 International Film Festival to be held in Cannes from May 11 to 23, festival officials said Monday.

title: Koch Assures Chase on Security If It Moves Unit to Brooklyn Site
description: In an effort to persuade the Chase Manhattan Bank to move thousands of workers to downtown Brooklyn, Mayor Koch met yesterday with senior executives of the bank and offered them a list of things that might be done to improve security in the neighborhood.

title: RESULTS PLU
description: TENNIS Curren Rallies to Advance: Second-seeded Kevin Curren rallied for a 5-7, 6-4, 6-4 victory over Todd Nelson yesterday in a first-round match of the $415,000 Volvo-Los Angeles tournament. Curren, ranked No. 22 in the world, needed more than two hours to eliminate Nelson, who is ranked 86th. Curren served the final game at love to end the match. In other first-round action yesterday, fourth-seeded Mikael Pernfors of Sweden outlasted Tim Wilkison, 3-6, 6-3, 7-6; fifth-seeded David Pate overpowered Peter Lundgren of Sweden, 6-3, 6-2; Johan Kriek rallied for a 6-7, 6-0, 6-0 victory over Patrick Kuhnen of West Germany; Christo van Rensburg of South Africa topped Jim Grabb, 6-2, 6-2, and Jorge Lozano of Mexico beat Michael Robertson of South Africa, 7-6, 6-4.

title: Witness in Friedman Trial Tells of Computer Deal
description: The prosecution's main witness in the bribery trial of Stanley M. Friedman testified yesterday that the former deputy commander of the New York National Guard sold the Guard a hand-held computer from a company in which Mr. Friedman had a controlling financial interest.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American General Corp., Houston, a financial services and insurance company, appointed Walter A. Saunders Jr. senior vice president and general auditor.

title: Economic Scene; Earnings Plight Of Baby Boomers
description: COUNT the Reagan Administration's economic successes: Inflation is running a tepid 5 percent, unemployment is at a decade low and after-tax household income has never been higher. How, then, can Michael Dukakis hope to score points with voters on pocketbook issues?

title: Yanks Win to Keep Their Hopes Alive
description: Every night, they get closer to the finish. But the Yankees, officially still in the American League East race, insist on keeping their fading hopes alive.

title: Education; Liberal Arts Scholars Seek to Broaden Their Field
description: Colleges and universities must find an effective way to organize and broaden the teaching of the liberal arts, which has suffered in the push and pull of sweeping technological and social developments.

title: OLYMPIC HIGHLIGHTS
description: SWIMMING: Anthony Nesty scored a stunning upset by winning the 100-meter butterfly in the Olympic-record time of 53 seconds and giving Suriname its first gold medal in the sport. The favorite, Matt Biondi of the

title: Max Loehr, 84, a Leading Scholar in Oriental Art
description: Max Loehr, professor and curator of Oriental art at Harvard University from 1960 to 1974, died of complications resulting from Parkinson's disease at St. Joseph's Hospital in Nashua, N.H., last Friday. He was 84 years old and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: EATING WELL
description: PERHAPS you noticed news reports last week that the United States Department of Agriculture has proposed allowing manufacturers of hot dogs, bologna and other processed meats to put ground bone in these products without identifying it on the labels.

title: Moscow Says Changes in Voting Usher In Many New Local Leaders
description: Soviet Communists taking part in the first wave of local party elections under more democratic procedures have been voting their old leaders out of office at an unusually high rate, according to party officials.

title: Rudolf R. Freeman, Executive, 82
description: Rudolf R. Freeman, who for many years was a prominent figure in the New York produce industry, died of complications after surgery for a blood clot at the Imperial Point Medical Center in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Sept. 14. He was 82 years old and was a resident of Lake Worth, Fla.

title: L.I.R.R. May Add Double-Decker Coaches
description: The Long Island Rail Road would operate a rush-hour train with double-decker cars by the end of 1990 under a pilot program the railroad's parent agency is expected to approve Friday.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

The Nail's Story
description: To the Editor:

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Austin, Tex.
description: LEAD: UNTIL a few years ago, Austin was basically a two-food town: barbecue and Tex-Mex. As it turned out, the citizens were simply waiting for something more interesting to come along, which it did: Austin now has a home-delivery service for paella, the saffron-tinted Spanish dish of seafood, meat and rice.

title: 2 Officers Die in a Car Wreck
description: Two off-duty New York City police officers assigned to the Bronx were killed early yesterday when their car ran off a highway ramp in Westbury, L.I., struck a tree and burst into flames.

title: Diana Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 23
description: b-After a $408,000 loss from the writeoff of deferred debt. c-Net income

title: A High-Tech Wood Beam
description: A Canadian company is building a factory at Colbert, Ga., that will bring to this country an advanced technology that uses glue and small strips of wood to build long wooden structural beams.

title: Candela Laser Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Polaroid Rejects Shamrock
description: The Polaroid Corporation today rejected as inadequate a $42-a-share hostile tender offer from Roy E. Disney's Shamrock Holdings Inc. and said it had begun talks about a selling a minority interest in the company to unspecified third parties.

title: Baseball; Red Sox Beat Jays as Boggs Gets 200th
description: Wade Boggs became the first player this century to get 200 hits in six consecutive seasons as Roger Clemens and the Boston Red Sox trounced the Toronto Blue Jays by 13-2 tonight and maintained their lead in the American League East.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Abitibi-Price Inc., Toronto, a producer of newsprint, pulp and paper products, said it would increase newsprint prices 6.9 percent on Jan. 1.

title: Krelitz Industries() reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Global Information Sets McGraw-Hill Alliance
description: Global Information, which last year began publishing Global Finance, a 50,000-circulation international publication, has formed a joint venture with McGraw-Hill to publish the magazine.

title: Survey Gives Bush the Lead Over Dukakis
description: Vice President Bush is narrowly ahead of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in the Presidential race, according to a poll released tonight.

title: I.B.M. Sets Compatible Software
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would offer software products so that its computers could communicate and share information with machines made by different manufacturers.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, a unit of Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., entered the corporate debt market yesterday with a $150 million offering of first- and refunding-mortgage bonds due 1993.

title: Zymos Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,490,000 from the sale of assets.

title: Art's-Way Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: The company said the year-ago first quarter includes a tax benefit of $123,000.

title: Corrections
description: An Executive Changes listing in Business Day on Monday misidentified the new position of Andrew S. Barrett at Del Monte Foods. He has been appointed an executive vice president of Del Monte, an operating unit of RJR Nabisco Inc.

title: C.I.A. Tied to Nicaragua Provocations
description: Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, said today that the Central Intelligence Agency had deliberately provoked opposition activities in Nicaragua in hopes of prompting an overreaction by Nicaragua's Sandinista Government.

title: JET'S PURSER TELLS OF DIVER'S BEATING
description: The purser of a T.W.A. jetliner hijacked in 1985 testified in court today that the defendant, Mohammed Ali Hamadei, helped to beat a United States Navy diver senseless, then ridiculed the American, saying: ''Look at him. He thinks he's so strong.''

title: Coast Guard Calls Off Mexico Rescue Efforts
description: The United States Coast Guard halted rescue missions into flood-ravaged northern Mexico today, two days after responding to pleas for aid from dozens of isolated towns.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly GENERAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON REVIEW AND APPRAISAL OF AFRICAN RECOVERY PROGRAM - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Blast in Downtown Belfast
description: An explosion tore through a complex in downtown Belfast today, the third blast to hit the downtown in the last month, the police said. Officials said that the site, at Royal Avenue, was cleared after a telephone warning and that no one was hurt. Security officials said the I.R.A. might be returning to the tactic of urban bombings that wrecked Belfast's commercial district in the 1970's.

title: Pillsbury Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a gain of $14 million, or 16 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Sales represent total sales.

title: The Games at a Glance
description: GYMNASTICS The exercises may have been optional, but the rest of the competition had little choice but to watch in admiration as the Soviet Union won the gold medal in the men's team competition. The Soviet athletes, the dominant force in men's gymnastics, put on a stunning display of individual talent and collective strength, garnering at least one perfect score in five of the six events and three from Dmitri Bilozerchev as they easily outpointed East Germany, which took the silver. SWIMMING When Matt Biondi buried his head in the water to glide the final meter of the men's 100-meter butterfly final, he had the lead and every reason to believe the gold medal, as well. When he resurfaced, he had only regret. Anthony Nesty of Suriname used a final surge to edge Biondi and capture his country's first Olympic swimming medal ever. Nesty's time of 53.00 seconds was one-hundredth of a second faster than Biondi and shaved .08 off the Olympic record. Biondi, who won the bronze in the 200-meter freestyle, settled for the silver. He then returned hours later to earn his third medal of the games when he swam a brilliant anchor leg as the U.S.'s 800-meter freestyle relay team won the gold and set a world record of 7 minutes 12.51 seconds. CYCLING If it wasn't tough enough getting air into his lungs, Aleksandr Kiritchenko had the added problem of losing air out of his tire as he came down to the final 100 meters of the men's 1,000-meter time trial. The 21-year-old Soviet cyclist ultimately finished on a flat tire, but he completed the course in 1 minute 4.49 seconds to win. WEIGHT LIFTING Every time Naim Suleymanoglo got the bar over his head, another world record seemed to fall. Suleymanoglo, of Turkey, set three world marks on the way to the gold medal in the 132-pound class. Suleymanoglo, who defected from Bulgaria in 1986, lifted 336 pounds in the snatch, 419 in the clean and jerk and 755 over all. WATER POLO Revenge could not have come a moment too soon for the United States. As it happened, it came with only seconds left. The United States, whose bid for a gold medal was sunk by Yugoslavia four years ago, kept its current hopes afloat when James Bergeson scored with five seconds remaining as the Americans beat top-ranked Yugoslavia, 7-6, in the opening day of the tournament. BOXING Michael Carbajal cleared one of the major stumbing blocks to a gold medal when he won a 3-2 decision over Oh Kwang-soo of South Korea in the 106-pound class. Carbajal, a native of Phoenix, won the brawling fight by a single point on the cards of three judges in knocking off one of the favorites for the gold. WRESTLING When he left Italy, Vincenzo Maenza, promised his 6-year-old son Yuri he'd return from South Korea with a gold medal. Wednesday, he took the gold medal in Greco-Roman wrestling when he defeated Andrzej Glab of Poland in the 105-pound division.

title: Carriage Horses Deserve Better Treatment From New York City; Old and Worn Out
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Stops Brazil To Reach 3-0 Mark
description: A pep talk was not necessary. John Thompson simply brought his United States basketball team into an empty room, dimmed the lights and played the videotape of the Pan American Games final in 1987. Only three Olympians were on the team that made Oscar Schmidt a Brazilian folk hero, but after watching the rerun, all the American players thought they had a personal stake in today's game.

title: Bernard A. Confer, 74, Former Relief Official
description: Bernard A. Confer, a former executive director of Lutheran World Relief, died of leukemia Saturday at his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 74 years old.

title: Murdoch Sets Deal to Sell Stake in Elle
description: Rupert Murdoch has agreed to sell his 50 percent stake in the American version of Elle magazine and British Elle to his partner, Hachette Publications Inc., for $157.5 million.

title: Monopoly on Dirty Air
description: While New York City waits to learn the penalties it faces for failing to meet Federal air quality standards last month, Albany could readily strengthen the case for mercy by monitoring auto tailpipe exhausts more rigorously.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an American warning to Haiti misidentified Walter E. Fauntroy's role in the House of Representatives. He is the Delegate for the District of Columbia, not a Representative.

title: Teachers Tackle Child Abuse
description: GALVANIZED by the beating death of 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg last November, the New York City public-school system has begun training teachers and other staff members to identify and report suspected cases of child abuse.

title: Argentine Elected Chief of 43d General Assembly
description: The Argentine Foreign Minister, Dante Caputo, was elected President of the 43d General Assembly today during the opening session. His election, by secret ballot, came after a hard-fought campaign against Dame Ruth Nita Barrow of Barbados.

title: Book Notes
description: Plum for an Upstart

title: Adding Fuel to Americans' Taste for Fiery Foods
description: LEAD: FIERY foods are the order of the day. Changing American tastes have contributed to the skyrocketing popularity of Sichuan, Thai, Indian, Cajun and Southwestern cooking.

title: U.S. Bombing Inquiry Closed
description: The Justice Department announced today that, without the issuing of any indictments, it was closing its investigation into the 1985 confrontation in Philadelphia in which 11 people died when the police dropped a bomb on a heavily fortified row house occupied by the radical group Move.

title: On Target Beyond the Action
description: IF it's Wednesday, it must be Thursday in Seoul. Or is it Tuesday night?

description: I HAVE been experimenting lately with ground fresh turkey meat, which is widely available in supermarkets. It is an excellent low-fat alternative to ground beef and considerably cheaper. It can be used in casseroles, to thicken sauces and stews, or to make burgers.

description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it planned to lease a closed aircraft plant in Columbus, Ohio, to produce parts for its C-17 transport plane. The plant will eventually employ 2,000 workers.

title: Iraq Used Gas Against Kurds, Senate Staff Report Charges
description: A staff report issued today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee says there is ''overwhelming evidence'' that Iraq used chemical weapons against Kurdish guerrillas and civilians in Iraq.

SCS-Compute reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
J.A.L. Expansion
description: The Japan Air Lines Company will set up a wholly owned subsidiary in New York in October to start a housing rental business aimed at the increasing number of Japanese business executives working in the United States, the company said. J.A.L. has already contracted to buy 24 condominiums in Chicago, 3 in New York and 5 in Anchorage.

title: Review/Dance; Jose Greco and Family
description: The Jose Greco Company, which opened a two-week engagement Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, could just as easily have been called Jose Greco and Family. It is headed by Mr. Greco, the Italian-born, Brooklyn-raised dancer whose name was virtually synonymous with Spanish dance for American audiences of the 1950's and 60's. Featured dancers include three of his children: Lola Greco, Carmela Greco and Jose Greco 2d. Lola and Carmela Greco are also responsible for some of the choreography and the troupe's musical director is Jose Luis Greco, another of Jose Greco's sons.

title: Index for New York Area Shows Costs 0.5% Higher
description: Prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose one-half of 1 percent in August, fueled by higher retail food costs and the yearly introduction of apparel lines, the Labor Department reported yesteray. In July the area's prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Leeco Diagnostics Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
Dukakis Proposes to Cover Costs of Care in Pregnancy
description: In an event laden with family images and political symbols, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis accused Vice President Bush today of turning a ''cold shoulder'' to pregnant women and children and proposed a $100 million program to provide medical and nutritional care for expectant mothers who are not covered by insurance or Medicaid.

title: Campaign Trail; The Nominees Get Advice on Debates
description: The Dukakis camp is swathing their candidate with advice and preparation for the upcoming debate. There are videotapes of past debates available, if Mr. Dukakis wants to watch them. There is a briefing book, if he wants to read it. The staff has even arranged for Mr. Dukakis to campaign in a studio with cameras and lights, if he feels he needs it.

title: The Pepsico Summerfare Says Next Summer Will Be Its Last
description: The Pepsico Summerfare, a music festival admired internationally for its freshness and quality, announced yesterday that it would cease operations at the end of next summer. The festival has operated since 1980 out of the four-theater Performing Arts Center at the State University College at Purchase, N.Y.

title: Court Bars Deportation of Aliens Until Amnesty Cases Are Settled
description: A Federal appeals court has authorized work permits and has temporarily banned deportation of thousands of aliens nationwide whose right to amnesty under the new immigration law is in dispute because they left the United States briefly.

title: Is It a Criminal Offense Not to Lead the Pledge?; Keep It Special
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fault - and Default - in the Stars
description: LEAD: One of the great educational benefits of a Presidential campaign is watching tomorrow's policy makers race down dead-end streets and careen off the walls of reality. The latest wrong turn is Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's promise to give the sun, the moon and the stars to college-bound students. Mr. Dukakis has proposed a novel loan program that would ''open wide the door of opportunity to every youngster in this country who is qualified to do college work.

description: b-Net loss

title: AA Importing Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $711,064 from an accounting change.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Truth About Pacific Salmon
description: Every schoolchild knows that after salmon spawn on Northwestern rivers, they die without returning to the sea. But until a recent trip to Alaska, I never gave the matter much thought. I assumed that having met their connubial responsibilities, the exhausted fish simply departed for salmon heaven somehow, leaving behind only the memory of their sleek muscular forms.

title: Massachusetts to Alter Investor Dispute Process
description: Massachusetts plans to become the first state to ban mandatory arbitration agreements by brokerage firms.

title: Needham's Flourishing Japan Link
description: THE 12-year-old relationship between DDB Needham Worldwide of the United States and Dai-Ichi Kikaku of Japan continues to flourish and grow, with the latest venture being the biggest yet announced.

Reco International reports earnings for Qtr to July 31

title: Bush, Like Reagan in 1980, Seeks Tax Cuts to Stimulate the Economy
description: Although supply-side economic theory has lost some of its luster since it helped Ronald Reagan get elected in 1980, the tenets of that philosophy are at the heart of Vice President Bush's proposals to keep the economy strong through a new round of tax cuts.

title: Metro Matters; Boerum's 'Law': Victim Arrested, Thief Goes Free
description: When Barbara Sparhawk bought her 19th-century carriage house for $29,000 12 years ago, Boerum Hill in Brooklyn was on the frontier of gentrification.

title: Vie de France Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
Federal Policy Against Discrimination Is Sought for AIDS Victims
description: Since a Presidential commission urged a Federal ban against AIDS discrimination as its major recommendation in June, neither the President nor Congress has acted and the states remain divided over how to address the issue. Some states still provide no safeguards against discrimination for its victims.

Syria Summons Lebanese Leaders As Beirut Regime Nears Collapse
description: President Hafez al-Assad summoned virtually all the major leaders of the warring Christian and Moslem factions in the Lebanese Government here today in an 11th hour attempt to end a crisis that threatens to bring renewed warfare to Lebanon.

description: b-Net loss

title: Jackson's Relative Is Charged in Killing Of Former Employee
description: Noah Robinson half brother of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, has been charged with murder, accused of hiring members of a Chicago street gang to kill a man two years ago.

title: Review/Music; Steve Forbert's Folk-Rock
description: When Steve Forbert arrived on the New York folk-music scene more than a decade ago, the singer and songwriter from Meridian, Miss., was greeted by a tide of critical enthusiasm that painted him as a real-life Huckleberry Finn transplanted into the contemporary pop world. Great things were predicted for a young performer who quipped in his musical self-introduction ''What Kinda Guy?'': I might be leavin' but the door ain't shut I'm here for lovin' but I ain't no slut.

title: American Hoist & Derrick Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,570,000 from discontinued operations. c-After income of $332,000 for the quarter and $2,519,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. The latest periods consisted of 13 weeks for the quarter and 39 weeks for the 9 months, compared with 17 weeks ended Sept. 19 for the year-ago quarter and 42 weeks for the 9 months in 1987. The company said the difference in the length of the quarters results from a change in fiscal accounting periods.
