description: b-Net loss

title: Ex-Rep. Glenn Davis, 73, Dies
description: Glenn R. Davis, who was a United States Representative from Wisconsin for 20 years, died today at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 73 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: * BEI Holdings Ltd., Atlanta, a consulting and management service company, announced a definitive agreement to acquire the Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan Association of Nashville for $33 a share in cash, or a total of about $119 million.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Hockey Devils and Whalers Tie: The Devils scored twice 29 seconds apart but finished in a 2-2 tie with the Whalers in an exhibition game last night before a crowd of 11,234 at Civic Center in Hartford. All the goals came in the second period of a game in which the Devils outshot the Whalers, 36-27. Randy Veliscek's power-play goal for the Devils at 12 minutes 3 seconds matched Stewart Gavin's goal, which opened the scoring at 11:47. Troy Crowder gave the Devils the lead at 12:32, but Ron Francis tied it at 15:44. Tennis Agassi Makes Quick Gain: Andre Agassi needed just 57 minutes to defeat Christian Saceanu of Rumania, 6-2, 6-2, Tuesday night to advance to the second round of the Volvo-Los Angeles event. Earlier, second-seeded Kevin Curren rallied for a 5-7, 6-4, 6-4 victory over Todd Nelson, and fourth-seeded Mikael Pernfors of Sweden rallied to beat Tim Wilkison, 3-6, 6-3, 7-6. Curren needed more than two hours to eliminate Nelson, but finished with a flourish, serving the final game at love. (AP) Duncan Advances: Third-seeded Lawson Duncan of Asheville, N.C., rallied to beat unseeded Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 3-6, 7-6, yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the $123,400 Puglia tournament in Bari, Italy. In another second-round match, Christian Miniussi of Argentina routed Eduardo Luis Osta of Spain, 6-3, 6-3.(AP) Horse Racing Kunjar Wins: Kunjar, ridden by Angel Cordero Jr., held off a late challenge by Secret Claim for a three-quarter-length victory yesterday in the $27,000 Guitar Player Purse at Belmont. Secret Claim, with Jean Cruguet aboard, was the runner-up in the field of nine, seven lengths ahead of Split Shot. Secret Claim, the favorite, came away sluggishly but rallied to catch Kunjar entering the stretch. But Cordero knocked the whip from Cruguet's hand nearing the three-sixteenths pole, and Cruguet was unable to urge his mount effectively thereafter.

title: Prime Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Premier Industrial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Review/Theater; A Work by O'Casey Offered by Countrymen
description: The new Irish Repertory Theater has an admirable goal - to present Irish and Irish-American drama ''performed professionally with a native understanding'' - and it has opened its first season with an auspicious choice of play, Sean O'Casey's ''Plough and the Stars.'' Despite the evident sincerity of the undertaking, and the fact that there are many Irish-born actors in the cast, the inaugural production is indecisive.

title: Henley Plan On Splitting
description: Henley Group Inc. yesterday provided details of its plan, announced in March, to split into two separate public companies. The two companies would be Wheelabrator Group Inc., which would hold Henley's refuse-to-energy assets, and the new Henley Group, which would get the remaining assets, mainly in manufacturing and chemicals.

title: The Missing Meaning
description: At a conference here on Soviet participation in the world trading system, a Soviet official who was to be among the panelists failed to show up as scheduled on Tuesday. American and international Kremlinologists present had a field day trying to assess the broader meaning - if any.

title: Campaign Trail; Outspoken Advice From a G.O.P. Hero
description: Campaigning in Arizona yesterday, Senator Dan Quayle sought out the local political hero to stand by his side.

title:
CURRENTS;
For the Weak of Finger
description: LEAD: LAST year, a heavy-duty black plastic and metal cork remover called the Screwpull Lever, produced by the Hallen Company of Houston, made its debut. The lever variation of the original Screwpull model looks as if you could use it to drill oil or to repel intruders.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My two-story pre-1930 house has a flat roof above the second-story apartment. I want to insulate the roof to minimize heat loss in the winter, but am at a loss about how -or whether - this should be done.

title: Edwards, A G & Sons Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
A Telephone Plan That Rings
description: Right Is there a way to keep the lid on telephone profits without discouraging cost-cutting innovation? Regulators in 28 states think so. They have given local phone companies broad discretion to run their own systems, as long as service remains good and average rates keep coming down.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Media Business page on Monday about United Press International included an erroneous account received from a U.P.I. executive about the news agency's relationship with SuperNews, an electronic information service. SuperNews is marketed and sold over the Financial News Network. U.P.I. is using the same technology and software to create similar services of its own.

title:
CURRENTS;
Where Architects Speak Of What They Build
description: LEAD: ARCHITECTS have been known to boast, ''We build, we don't talk.'' They like to make architecture, not discuss it, especially in Chicago, where so many outstanding examples of architecture attest to the fruits of this pragmatic outlook.

title: Computer Communications reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $75,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Includes a tax credit of $700,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said that at June 30, 1987, it recorded $4,126,000 in income, net of applicable legal fees and other costs, from settlement of its litigation with Codex Corp. The company also said the net settlement amount which related to lost sales revenue amounted to $2,806,000 and was recorded in revenue in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1987; the balance of $1,320,000, related to accrued interest, was recorded in interest income, also in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1987.

title: The Healing Power Of a Bit of Solitude
description: WHENEVER Olinda Turturo, an aspiring actress in New York City, has an important audition, she schedules some time to be alone, either reading or watching television.

title: Chefs International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Consumer Prices Rise 0.4% Again
description: The Consumer Price Index, the nation's most widely followed inflation gauge, rose in August by four-tenths of 1 percent, the same as in July, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Africans Weigh Threat of AIDS to Economies
description: The economic consequences of the AIDS epidemic in Africa could be so disastrous that the growth rates of already fragile nations could be reduced to zero, a gathering of scientists has been told.

title: Commuter Nixon Pulling Out of Manhattan
description: Richard M. Nixon won't be kicking around New York anymore.

title: Protest Gets Ugly After Korean Loses
description: South Korean boxing coaches attacked a New Zealand referee after one of their boxers lost a decision to a Bulgarian today in a 119-pound class bout.

title: Mitch Green Arrested
description: Mitch Green, the heavyweight who lost a 10-round decision to Mike Tyson in 1986 and scuffled with the heavyweight champion in an early-morning fight in Harlem last month, was arrested early yesterday on a charge of disorderly conduct. According to the police, Green was acting irrationally at Park Avenue and 125th Street in Manhattan at about 1 o'clock when a woman complained to police officers in a patrol car. According to Sgt. Ed Burns, a Police Department spokesman, an Emergency Service Unit subdued Green with an electronic stun gun and took him to Metropolitan Hospital. He was released at 4:30 A.M. and charged with disorderly conduct. (AP)

title: Diversified Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $108,000 and $99,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, tax credits of $165,000 for the quarter and $394,000 for the 9 months, and the 9 months also included a gain of $1,616,000 on disposition of subsidiaries. c-After income from discontinued operations of $330,000 for the quarter and $466,000 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $152,000 and $253,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Notes and Bonds Rise Modestly
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds posted another modest advance yesterday, even though a string of favorable economic reports suggested the gains might have been larger.

title: Medal Quota for Soviet Squad
description: When Sergei Bubka steps up to the pole-vault runway, he will not only be going for the gold. He, like many a Soviet worker, will also be striving to fulfill the plan.

title: Review/Television; 70's Series On Women In Rock
description: Beginning tonight at 11:30, Channel 13 is bringing back ''Rock Follies.'' Made in the mid-1970's, the British series follows the efforts of three actresses to snare success as a rock group called ''The Three Ladies.'' Written by American-born Howard Schuman, ''Rock Follies'' is based on an idea conceived by a music group called Rock Bottom. The series exudes remarkable authenticity as it pounces satirically and affectionately on the pop-music scene, its dreams and ripoffs.

title: Texas Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $6,599,000.

title: Major Video reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Williams Stricken
description: Doug Williams, the Washington Redskins quarterback, was hopsitalized after practice yesterday for tests after having experienced abdominal pains and later underwent surgery for acute appendicitis. He is expected to be out at least for weeks, the team said. In his place, the starter for Sunday's game against the Cardinals in Phoenix will be Mike Rypien, a second-year player from Washington State who has never taken a snap in a regular-season game. The club also said it was trying to sign David Archer, the former Falcon. . . . Coach Mike Shanahan of the Los Angeles Raiders made official Wednesday what he had implied two days earlier: Jay Schroeder will be his team's starting quarterback against Denver next Monday night. ''He does have experience,'' Shanahan said. ''He's 24-7 as a starter. We would not trade Jim Lachey to get a backup.'' Schroeder, 27 years old, was traded by the Washington Redskins for Lachey and two draft choices Sept. 5. Schroeder replaces Steve Beuerlein, 23, who had gone all the way at quarterback in the Raiders' three games, completing 42 of 91 passes for 675 yards and 5 touchdowns with 2 interceptions and 14 sacks.(AP)

title: Smokers Urged to Quit To Reduce Radon Peril
description: Since smokers are 10 times more likely to die of lung cancer caused by radon than are nonsmokers, the best way for many homeowners to cut the risk of developing radon-related cancer is not to undertake expensive home repairs, but to quit smoking, a former Federal environmental official has said.

title: Price Data Ease Inflation Fears
description: Consumer prices are rising at a moderate annual rate of 5.2 percent, indicating that inflation is unlikely to climb to worrisome levels. In the New York-northeastern New Jersey area, prices are rising slightly more quickly.

title: Engineering Measurements Company reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Michael Francis Powers, Literary Agent, 51
description: Michael Francis Powers, executive vice president of the Betsy Nolan Literary Agency, died Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 51 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Bahamas Leader Calls U.S. Drug Inquiry 'Baseless'
description: The Prime Minister of the Bahamas accused the Justice Department today of conducting a ''baseless investigation'' of charges that he had accepted bribes from narcotics traffickers.

title: Citicorp Backing Paper in Buyout
description: The Capital Markets Assurance Corporation, a subsidiary of Citicorp, is guaranteeing $124 million in commercial paper for the Rhodes Financial Services Corporation, a special-purpose subsidiary of Rhodes Inc. It marks the first time that commercial paper, backed by consumer receivables, has been used in the initial financing of a leveraged buyout.

title: Cockpit in Crash Sold For Flight Simulator
description: The cockpit from the Aloha Airlines Boeing 737 that lost part of its fuselage in flight last April will be turned into a training simulator.

title: Books of The Times; Sojourning in Hawaii, Roots and All
description: Last Notes from Home By Frederick Exley 397 pages. Random House. $18.95.

title: Angry Americans Finish 4th
description: One by one they said it was all right. In their hearts, the six Americans who finished fourth in the women's gymnastics team competition tonight knew they had won the Olympic bronze medal, even if the final standing showed otherwise, even if their worst suspicions were true.

title: Machinists at Eastern Reject Offer
description: The members of the machinists' union at Eastern Airlines voted overwhelmingly to reject a contract offered by the airline that called for deep pay and benefit concessions, the union said yesterday.

title: Rise in Farmland Prices
description: A modest upturn in United States farmland values has been slowed by this summer's drought, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Rural appraisers surveyed in August reported a 1.2 percent increase in nationwide farmland prices for the May-to-July period, lower than the 1.8 percent gain reported for the preceding three months, the agency said in its monthly agricultural report.

title: Key Executive At Y.&R. Quits
description: John Ferrell, until recently the top creative man in the New York office of Young & Rubicam, is leaving the agency because, as a staff memo from Arthur R. Klein, president, New York, says, he ''has decided that he does not want to accept the new assignments we had offered him.''

title: State by State; Pennsylvanians Search For Lesser of Two Evils
description: The young waiter said he would probably vote for Vice President Bush in November because of Mr. Bush's knowledge of the ways of Washington. But he added, ''To tell you the absolute truth, I'm not so much leaning toward anyone as leaning away from someone.''

title: Brazil Sets Oil Targets
description: Brazil plans to double its crude oil production within a decade, nearly eliminating import needs, an official of the state oil company said Tuesday. Brazil, which now produces about 630,000 barrels a day, has set goals of one million barrels a day in 1993 and 1.5 million in 1997, Milton Franke of Petroleo Brasileiro, told an international oil conference.

title: The Costa Ricans Rock, but Some Just Shake
description: Cultures clashed but youth won out as a phalanx of rock stars descended on Costa Rica for a concert the like of which has never been seen here.

title: Review/Theater; A Look at Emma Bovary
description: The Alchemy Theater Company and Paul Edwards can hardly be faulted for lack of courage. It is hard to think of any work of fiction that resists dramatic adaptation more stubbornly than Gustave Flaubert's novel ''Madame Bovary.'' Yet, at the Judith Anderson Theatre this young company is presenting a version of it by Mr. Edwards that is an often provocative exercise in interpretation.

title: Ethic of Protecting Land Fueled Yellowstone Fires
description: Some wildfires were allowed to burn unattended in Yellowstone Park for nearly three weeks after National Park Service officials were ordered to fight all fires, park officials say.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball LOS ANGELES LAKERS (NBA) - Signed Milt Wagner, guard. Football ATLANTA (NFC) - Signed Leander Knight, cornerback. Placed Alex Higdon, tight end, on injured reserve. CHICAGO (NFC) - Signed Brent Novoselsky, tight end. Placed William Perry, defensive lineman, on injured reserve. DENVER (AFC) - Re-signed Marc Munord, linebacker. Waived Kevin Clark, defensive back. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Signed Kevin Williams, cornerback. Placed Eric Coyle, center, on injured reserve. Hockey PITTSBURGH (NHL) - Signed Bruce Racine, goaltender, to a multiyear contract. Colleges CALIFORNIA (PA.) - Named Tina Moynihan assistant women's basketball coach. CORNELL - Named Sam Carpenter assistant lacrosse coach. MOUNT ST. VINCENT - Named Mark Morey assistant athletic director. ST. JOHN'S - Named Marilyn Lowder assistant to the vice president-director of athletics. TUESDAY Baseball BALTIMORE (AL) - Appointed John Barr scouting director. Basketball CHICAGO (NBA) - Restructured and extended the contract of Michael Jordan, guard, through the 1995-96 season. PHOENIX (NBA) - Appointed Len Robinson part-time assistant coach. COLUMBUS (CBA) - Appointed Tom Sise general manager; George Beim director of marketing and public relations, and Daine Van Laarhoven office manager. Announced the team will be called the Horizon. Football DALLAS (NFC) - Waived Mike Renfro, wide receiver, and Charles Wright, cornerback. Activated Ron Francis, cornerback. DETROIT (NFC) - Re-signed Rob Rubick, tight end. Released Mark Lewis, tight end. INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Waived Jess Atkinson, kicker, and Steve Knight, offensive tackle. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Placed John Rienstra, guard, on injured reserve. Re-signed Brian Blankenship, offensive lineman.

title: Reagan Backs Bush In Assailing Dukakis Over Issue of Pledge
description: President Reagan, supporting Vice President Bush's attacks on Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, said today that teachers should be required to lead students in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance because ''that's what they're there for.''

title: El Chico Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 22
Heavy Selloff Pushes Gold Price Below $400
description: Gold prices in New York plunged below the important level of $400 an ounce yesterday for the first time in 19 months, as worries over inflation continued to ease.

title: School-Enrollment Drop Shows Population Shifts
description: The number of schoolchildren in New York City has dropped over the last decade, but the ratio of public to private school students has remained about the same, statistics from the State Education Department show.

title: TREASURY SEEKING TO DETERMINE COST OF SAVINGS RESCUE
description: Concerned about conflicting estimates of the cost of dealing with 500 insolvent savings and loan associations, the Treasury Department said today that it had begun its own investigation of the problem.

title: Chicago Patients Gain Curb on AIDS Carriers
description: The Cook County Board has approved a policy allowing county hospital patients to refuse to be treated by people with the AIDS virus, but the hospital has not developed a way to make the policy work.

title: Hudson General Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After an aggregate of $2,438,000 in losses attributable to Hudson General's minority equity interest in, and provision for uncollectibility of trade receivables due from a Canadian company engaged in the transportation of air freight through the chartering of two DC-8 aircraft. c-Net loss The year-ago results included an aggregate of $2,460,000 in operating losses and provision for anticipated future losses related to a contract to supply certain maintenance services and spare parts to an airline in Canada. The contract expired in April 1988. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Computer Automation Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and the year includes a pre-tax gain on termination of lease of $223,000.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Edge Up on the Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered rose three-tenths of 1 percent in the four-week period ended Sept. 15.

title:
CURRENCTS;
Putting Architects On Film
description: LEAD: FOR two decades, Michael Blackwood has made award-winning documentaries about artists. In the next few weeks, the Architectural League of New York will present three new films that demonstrate Mr. Blackwood's current focus on architecture.

title: A Former Singer Becomes Largest Owner of Donnay
description: Bernard Tapie, who made his fortune in France, has become the majority owner of Donnay S.A., the bankrupt maker of tennis racquets.

title: Yankees Ready For Last Shot
description: Even after their failure last weekend in Boston, the Yankees somehow convinced themselves they were not finished. Apparently, it worked.

title: The Home President Taft Knew as a Boy
description: IN early January 1854 Louise Taft, William Howard Taft's mother, wrote to her sister describing efforts to furnish the parlor of the family's Cincinnati home.

title: Haitian Struggles to Consolidate Power
description: Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril struggled today to consolidate power on his fifth day as President of Haiti, but a garrison north of the capital was reported in rebellion. Elsewhere, enlisted men and junior officers were carrying out a purge against mid-level commanders.

title: French Protest Aims at Gillette
description: Four workers from the local Gillette razor plant left today on an expedition to climb Mount Blanc to protest what they say is the company's intention to close the plant.

title: Jersey Race Is Taking Brutal Turn
description: For months, the United States Senate race in New Jersey has been shaping up as one of the nation's most competitive. As the campaign gets under way in earnest, it is turning into one of the most brutal, as well.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Mammograms are extremely useful tools in the war against breast cancer, a disease that now strikes one woman in 10 in this country. These low-dose X-ray examinations of the soft breast tissue can often reveal cancer even before the woman or her doctor can detect it as a lump or other physical abnormality. And when breast cancer is detected and treated very early, 90 percent of affected women can be cured.

title:
CURRENTS;
Remodernization Restores an Old Building's Harmony
description: LEAD: AS any observant pedestrian knows, the bottoms of old buildings in New York rarely go with the tops: the bases are often visual travesties, their street-level exteriors crudely ''modernized'' in the 1950's or 60's, or given a franchise-store design in the 70's. So it is reassuring that at 141-145 Wooster Street in SoHo, an eight-story cast-iron building put up in the late 19th century, the 1960's brick facade on the ground floor was recently replaced.

title: WASHINGTON STATE PICKS SENATE FOES
description: Representative Mike Lowry, a five-term Democrat, defeated a fellow Congressman, Don Bonker, in the Washington primary Tuesday and will oppose former Senator Slade Gorton for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Daniel J. Evans.

title: Tests Show Shroud of Turin To Be Fraud, Scientist Hints
description: A scientist associated with the Vatican-sponsored analysis of the Shroud of Turin hinted broadly yesterday that the reputed burial cloth of Jesus has been proved to be a medieval forgery.

title: Neiman-Marcus Group reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-After a tax benefit for the quarter from new accounting policies resulted in an after-tax gain of $3,713,000 and the year was after a tax expense of $10,542,000 related to an accounting change. c-Net loss Preferred stock dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest year. The 1987 fourth quarter and year losses reflected $40.8 million of non- operating expenses related to the restructuring which created Neiman- Marcus Group. The primary factors causing the fourth quarter loss were a $6.7 million pre-tax charge resulting from management's decision to adopt the LIFO method of inventory accounting retroactive to the beginning of fiscal 1988 and higher than anticipated markdowns at Neiman-Marcus and Contempo Casuals taken to clear inventories for the fall season.

title: Construction Of Housing Down 3.3%
description: Housing construction fell 3.3 percent last month, to an annual level of 1.44 million units, as a decline in apartment construction outweighed a small gain in the building of single-family homes.

title: Burton Benjamin Service
description: A memorial service for Burton Benjamin, a former vice president and director of CBS News, who died on Sunday, is to be held at the Ethical Culture Society Meeting House, 2 West 64th Street, on Sept. 30 at 11 A.M.

title: The Bomb Maker Becomes a Bomb
description: Decay hangs darkly over the manufacturing complex that makes America's nuclear weapons, an enterprise so vast it ranks with the 20 largest corporations. Extended lack of maintenance and pollution control now endanger both national security and the environment.

title: Bridge
description: Players have a rare chance to win gold points at their own clubs tonight as the second Royal Viking continent-wide game is played at clubs throughout North America, including these in the New York metropolitan area:

title: Sensor Control reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company attributed the decrease in fourth quarter earnings to an aborted tender offer for Boonton Electronics of New Jersey, which resulted in $301,000 of operating costs.

title: Soviet Sweep In All-Around
description: The Soviet Union's three best male gymnasts staged a sensational battle for the Olympic all-around championship tonight, with Vladimir Artemov winning the gold medal despite Dmitri Belozerchev scoring perfect 10.00's on his last three apparatuses.

title: R Train Derails in Midtown, Delaying Thousands in Morning Rush
description: More than 1,000 subway passengers were removed from two trains at the start of the morning rush yesterday after a Brooklyn-bound train derailed 100 yards from the station at 57th Street and Seventh Avenue.

title: Ault Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Savings Bailout Warning
description: The American Bankers Association said Tuesday that $74 billion would be needed to rescue the ailing savings and loan industry and that the use of taxpayers' funds ''now appears unavoidable.'' This estimate from the association, which represents 95 percent of the nation's 13,500 commercial banks, is about 50 percent greater than Federal projections.

title: Studs Terkel's Busy Year
description: In China, 1988 is the Year of the Dragon; in literary America, it's the Year of the Terkel. Studs. ''Everything's happening at once,'' Studs Terkel said the other day. ''And at my age, too. Figure it out, I was born in 1912.''

title: Body of Bound Woman Found
description: The naked body of a women, her hands bound and her throat slashed, was discovered yesterday in a weeded field in Howard Beach, Queens, the police said. The police found the body at 6 P.M. about 250 yards from the street in a the field at on 156th Avenue between 78th and 77th Streets, according to Sgt. Raymond O'Donnell, a police spokesman.

title: Super Valu Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
Home Improvement
description: ROOF gutters protect buildings from serious damage resulting from poor drainage. In late fall and early spring, gutters should be inspected, cleared of debris and repaired if necessary so that they continue to function efficiently. But if you live where there are many trees, postpone cleaning your gutter until after the leaves have fallen.

title: Rise in Yields Slows Down
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose at a slower pace in the week ended yesterday, as a general trend toward lower interest rates began to take hold.

title: Review/Opera; New Violetta And Germont In 'La Traviata'
description: Sunday evening's ''Traviata'' at the New York City Opera brought two singers to their roles for the first time in the house. Frances Ginsberg, the new Violetta, is a singer of temperament and vocal strength, and on her own terms she made an affecting statement in the role. Those terms include a sensitivity to dynamic light and shade, a full tone around the top of the treble staff, and an enthusiasm for verismo-style effects in singing and deportment.

title: Kenya to Oust Wildlife Aides
description: Kenya said today that it was dismissing 33 wildlife officials suspected of collaborating with poachers. Independent wildlife experts in Kenya recently voiced concern that poachers, apparently with help from Government officials, were stepping up the slaughter of elephants. President Daniel arap Moi last week ordered game wardens to shoot poachers on sight.

title: Your Debate Guide
description: Reams of copy offering sage advice on debating technique will be directed at both candidates before they climb into the arena in Winston-Salem this Sunday. Not in this space.

title: Japanese Rate Rise Doubted
description: The governor of the Bank of Japan, Satoshi Sumita, said today that the prospects for higher interest rates had declined, primarily because of developments in the United States.

title: Turkey Senses Boon to Image In Kurd Policy
description: While insisting that it is a secondary consideration, Turkish Government officials see the recent influx of Kurdish refugees from Iraq as a welcome opportunity to improve a human-rights image that could stand some burnishing overseas.

title: Mega Group reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Transnet Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Robert S. Ferguson, 73, Film Company Official
description: Robert S. Ferguson, the former head of marketing for Columbia Pictures, with which he was associated for nearly a half century, died of heart disease last Friday in Westchester Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived in Atlantic Beach, L.I.

title: Aerosonic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Transition Preparation, A Hot Growth Industry
description: The capital's cleverest entrepreneurs know that change means opportunity - for greater profit, influence, status. And the hottest growth industry in town now involves preparation for the sharpest change of the last eight years: the transition to a new President.

title: Stocks Eke Out a Gain On Arbitrage Activity
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 3.02 to close at 2,090.50.

title: Mine Injures 19 at Johannesburg Terminal
description: Nineteen people were wounded today when a mine exploded during the evening rush hour at a busy bus terminal, the police reported.

title: Bentsen Promises Program To Retain Rural Hospitals
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen promised rural Americans today that a Democratic administration would make rural health care ''an urgent national priority,'' keeping small country hospitals open and encouraging doctors and nurses to serve outside the cities and suburbs.

title: People
description: * Barry R. Frankel has been named president and Stephen J. Weinstein chairman of S. J. Weinstein Associates.

title: Review/Operetta; Changes in 'Widow' Cast
description: Even with its stream of frothy, caloric melodies, Franz Lehar's ''Merry Widow'' can make for a tedious three hours, and the New York City Opera's production doesn't make a great or sustained effort to enliven matters. Still, it clearly appeals to enough ticket buyers to have become a perennial. It opened the season in July, and has since popped up intermittently.

title: U.S. Overwhelms Yugoslavia
description: What the United States women's basketball team needed was the equivalent of a second cup of coffee, a pick-me-up to help break the slow, methodical pace opponents have been using against it. So on Wednesday night, Kay Yow, the coach, told Teresa Weatherspoon that she would be starting against Yugoslavia today. After a summer of adjusting to a reserve role, the all-America point guard was back in the role she enjoys best.

title: Robert Gwathmey, 85, an Artist Of Social Passions and Style, Dies
description: Robert Gwathmey, a leading artist of social realism whose works combine a high modernist style with a passionate concern for society's underprivileged, died of Parkinson's disease on Wednesday at the Southampton Nursing Home. He was 85 years old, and until six months ago had lived at his longtime home in Amagansett, L.I.

title: 2 Gold Powers in Takeover Battle
description: A takeover battle between the largest gold-mining powers in the non-Communist world began today when a unit of South Africa's Anglo American group made a $4.9 billion bid for Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C., a London-based concern that has vast gold-mining operations in South Africa.

title: Bermuda Star Line reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Is It a Criminal Offense Not to Lead the Pledge?; A Formal Rite
description: To the Editor:

title: Hundreds Go on Rampage After a Black Man Is Slain in Shreveport
description: Hundreds of black people burned two stores and threw stones at whites early today after a a black man was fatally shot in what one witness described as a drug deal gone sour. A white woman was charged in the killing.

title: Texaco's Plan In Ecuador
description: Texaco Inc. will continue operating in Ecuador until the Ecuadorean Government takes complete control over the pipeline and oilfield operations that the two now run jointly, a company spokesman announced Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 5 about a new national movement in Yerevan, capital of Soviet Armenia, misidentified a member of a group of intellectuals calling themselves the Karabakh Committee. He is Ambartsum Galstyan.

title: Pakistani Opposition Leader Gives Birth to 7-Pound Boy
description: Benazir Bhutto, the Pakistani opposition leader, gave birth today to a seven-pound boy, and 500 well-wishers celebrated by beating drums and dancing outside the hospital here where she is staying.

title: Naked Man Slays Usher In Cathedral and Is Killed
description: A man described as mentally ill stripped off his clothes and ran into St. Patrick's Cathedral last night, where he fatally bludgeoned a 77-year-old usher and seriously injured a police officer before he was shot and killed by another police officer, police officials said.

title: Mets Clinch Tie for Title but Lose Ojeda for Season; Pitchers Finger Severely Cut
description: Bob Ojeda, the ace left-hander of the Mets, suffered a career-threatening injury yesterday when an electric hedge clipper nearly severed the upper part of his left middle finger as he was trimming the honeysuckle bushes at his home in Port Washington, L.I.

title: Families' Share of Households Has Shrunk
description: The percentage of American households in which the people who live together are related - by marriage or otherwise - has declined by a fifth in the last 40 years, the Census Bureau has reported.

title: Moscow Said to Suggest Separate Pact on Warheads
description: Soviet officials have privately suggested that the United States and the Soviet Union complete a side agreement that would limit the number of warheads on nuclear missiles in advance of a new strategic arms treaty, American officials said today.

title: Precision Target Marketing reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Direct Action Marketing reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Health Page on Sept. 1 about possible dangers to elderly users of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs omitted information on the dosages involved. The study indicated that chronic use of high-dose prescription versions of the pain-killing drugs, including ibuprofen, could cause ulcers and other serious disorders. Short-term users of low-dose, over-the-counter versions of ibuprofen were not studied.

title: Fare Study Looks at T.W.A.
description: A Congressional study concluded that Trans World Airlines' fares rose sharply at St. Louis after T.W.A. became the dominant carrier there through a Government-approved merger.

title: Heir to Fulfill Hirohito's Duties
description: The Japanese Cabinet this morning officially conferred the Constitutional duties of Emperor Hirohito, who is still seriously ill, on his son and heir, Crown Prince Akihito.

title: San Juan Racing Association Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Campaign Trail; Bush on the Stump Shuns Ivy-Speak
description: George Bush will never completely shake his Topsider accent. Only recently, after hearing the name of a woman who is a reporter for Time magazine and had interviewed him on foreign affairs, he smiled in recognition and said, ''Ah, yes, the arms control lass.''

title: Bertolli Olive Oils Move To Lowe Marschalk
description: Bertolli USA in Secaucus, N.J., has decided to trust the advertising of its olive oil to Lowe Marschalk in New York. The ad budget is an attractive $5 million.

title: Milan, Home of Modern Design, Loses Its Cool
description: What has happened to Milanese design? At the prestigious Salone del Mobile di Milano, the Milan Furniture Fair, the sentimental, the whimsical and the exotic replaced the rational, the cool and the industrial. Milan, the renowned capital of hard-edged modern design, is embracing an era of furniture with feeling.

title: Japan Vehicle Output
description: Japan's vehicle production fell 2.6 percent in August from a year earlier, the first drop since a 2 percent decline in January, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. An association official said the lower production of 782,895 was caused by fewer operating days in August and the remodeling of major cars.

title: Chicago Journal; Trap and Skeet Shooting: Is It Sport or Pollution?
description: Fred Lappe pressed his cheek to the shotgun stock, barked the ritual command ''Pull!'' and took aim as a clay pigeon whirled over the Lake Michigan shoreline. There was a sharp report and the target exploded over the water.

title: Penn Plaza Removes Nudes
description: For three brief days it was an exhibition of paintings and drawings of nudes by well-known artists, but now the walls themselves are bare.

title: 2 Hunts File for Personal Bankruptcy
description: Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt each filed for personal bankruptcy protection today to avoid having to post a $225 million bond required for appealing a Federal jury verdict against them.

title: Amereco Environmental Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Senator Aids Son of Ex-Wife
description: The Senate has passed a bill introduced by Elizabeth Taylor's sixth husband on behalf of her second husband's son, who was facing possible deportation because of a drug conviction.

title: Urban Guerrilla Group Says It Tried to Kill German Aide
description: An urban guerrilla group, the Red Army Faction, claimed responsibility today for an unsuccessful shotgun attack on a senior West German official.

title: U.S. Agency Urges More Aid for Bangladesh Now
description: The Agency for International Development has urged President Reagan to send additional relief assistance immediately to Bangladesh, where floods that affected three-fourths of the country have claimed at least 1,000 lives, according to a report by the agency.

title: Diodes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $62,196.

title: Critic's Notebook; Seeking a Consensus on Carnegie
description: Last week, Carnegie Hall made a momentous announcement during a press conference called at the last minute. First, critics received phone calls asking them to be free the following afternoon, but sorry, no details. The next morning, hand-delivered letters stamped ''confidential'' arrived with word that Carnegie would be announcing some acoustical experiments that afternoon.

title: Jetborne International reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Bid Made to Drop Yonkers Seminary Site
description: The Federal judge in the Yonkers housing discrimination case has offered to help find an alternative to land owned by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York that is among seven sites proposed for a low-income housing plan.

title: Saul Bellow Tries a New Approach
description: Saul Bellow has written a novella that will be published as a paperback original. The book, ''A Theft,'' will be published by Penguin next March. It is thought to be the first time a major American literary figure has elected to be published first in paperback.

title: Fisher Business Systems reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Duracell Holdings Offering $1.07 Billion in 'Junk Bonds'
description: In one of the largest speculative-grade issues this year, the Duracell Holdings Corporation is offering $1.07 billion in debt securities through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Duracell Holdings, a company organized by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, acquired Duracell Inc. on June 24.

title: Mony Real Estate Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Campaign Trail; On the Soap Box, A Matter of Inches
description: The Bush campaign has been scouting around for some hot new issues with which to deck the Duke. The patriotism theme is running thin and, with hecklers carrying signs reading ''Patriotism Is the Last Refuge of Scoundrels,'' even the Vice President seemed to feel that mentioning the Pledge of Allegiance again might be edging into jingoism.

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Arms Proposal

title: Tailback Ineligible
description: Vince Workman, Ohio State's starting tailback, will lose his eligibility for the rest of his senior season because he signed with an agent, Athletic Director Jim Jones announced yesterday. Workman played in both the 26-9 victory over Syracuse on Sept. 17 and the 42-10 loss to Pitt last Saturday. Workman said he accepted $1,000 from a San Francisco-based agent, David Lueddeke, to help his kid brothers. Workman testified Tuesday before a Federal grand jury in Chicago. ''There was no way to know anything about this because it was a grand-jury matter and was secret,'' Jones said. The grand jury is investigating the dealings of Lueddeke and the New York-based agents Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom. The three are accused of offering athletes cash, cars, clothing and trips for signed agreements allowing the agents to represent them in professional contract negotiations. The grand-jury investigation is part of an inquiry that last year cost the wide receiver Cris Carter his senior year of eligibility at Ohio State. Workman rushed for 1,030 yards in 1986 and led the Buckeyes in rushing last season with 470 yards on 118 carries. (AP)

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Agouron Pharmaceuticals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Incomes Up Only Slightly In August
description: The personal incomes of Americans increased only half as fast as inflation in August, providing analysts with more evidence that economic growth has eased, at least temporarily.

title: Bankruptcy Plan For Triad Cleared
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has approved an agreement under which the Saudi businessmen Adnan and Essam Khashoggi are to pay $32 million to creditors of the Triad America Corporation. Judge John H. Allen approved the agreement Tuesday between the Khashoggi brothers and R. Todd Neilson, the court-appointed trustee for Triad.

title: Sandata Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: Is It a Criminal Offense Not to Lead the Pledge?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-Soviet Publishing Pact
description: A United States-Soviet venture to open 18 print shops and a central printing plant in the Soviet Union was announced today.

title: Pride and Deficit
description: You might think that anybody who had reached the pinnacle of power at an agency like the Office of Management and Budget could take a little ego bruising now and then. But no.

title: Instead of Foster Homes, Revive Orphanages
description: To the Editor:

title: Phone Service Knocked Out By Texas State Workers' Calls
description: After thousands of outgoing phone calls knocked out the State Capitol phone system, officials disconnected the line that allowed state employees to dial a radio station call-in contest.

title: Consumers Financial Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $64,000 and $104,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and tax benefits of $6,000 for the quarter and $84,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes realized investment losses of $13,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $302,000 for the 6 months, and tax benefits of $75,000 and $133,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said share earnings in 1988, particularly in the 6-month period, have been impacted by the effects of the convertible preferred stock issued in July 1987 because of the size of the preferred stock dividend requirement in relation to operating results.

title: Gandhi Goes To Punjabis With a Plea
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi came to the heart of India's most violent region today to tell the people of Punjab State that his Government had not forgotten them. It was Mr. Gandhi's first visit to Punjab in almost four years.

title: KDI Accepts Buyout Offer
description: The KDI Corporation said today that its board had accepted a $19-a-share management-led buyout offer, valuing the diversified manufacturer at about $184 million.

title: 8 Passengers Injured As Pan Am Jetliner Strikes Turbulence
description: Eight passengers on a Pan Am jet from New York to Rio de Janeiro were injured today in turbulence over the Caribbean, and one man died later of a heart attack, an airline official said.

title: Bergen Paper Curbed On Delivery in Passaic
description: A Superior Court judge has ordered a Bergen County-based newspaper to delay plans for morning home delivery in neighboring Passaic County.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There were real laws back in Stalin's time. If we hadn't had those laws, we wouldn't have won the war.'' - Iliyo Palelashvili, 77-year-old veteran from the dictator's hometown. [ A12:3. ]

title: Precision Standard Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Import Petition Rejected
description: The International Trade Commission has rejected a petition for curbs on imports of automotive shock absorbers from Brazil. The Federal agency voted, 5 to 0, Tuesday against the complaint, filed by the Monroe Auto Equipment Company, of injury to American producers.

title: Replacing Furniture Hinges
description: LEAD: To function properly, furniture hinges must be maintained. The pins securing the two plates should never be allowed to corrode and ''seize up'' - a drop of oil helps here - and the plates must be housed squarely in the recesses provided for them. These recesses are vulnerable to damage through constant use, shrinkage and warping, and possibly, poor maintenance.

title: New and Old School Chiefs Differ on Issues and Styles
description: The new Secretary of Education, Lauro F. Cavazos, took office today and did something that perhaps no other member of a Cabinet had ever done before. He held a bilingual news conference, using it as a platform to plead with Hispanic youngsters in the United States: ''Por favor, ninos, no dejen la escuela.''

title: Glamis Gold reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $1,403,000 from a lawsuit. Results are in Candian dollars.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AIQ Systems Inc., Incline Village, Nev., a publisher of artificial-intelligence software for stock market trading, appointed Raymond E. Boyle president. The company was formerly Criterion Software.

Olympic Highlights
description: SWIMMING: One day after Matt Biondi's disappointing silver-medal finish in the 100-meter butterfly, the swimmer from Moraga, Calif., set an Olympic record in a heat of the 100-meter freestyle.

title: FDP Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Washington Opera Fails In a Bid For Funds
description: Amid suggestions that contributions to many cultural organizations may be declining in the months ahead, the Washington Opera has announced that it has been unable to raise the funds it sought for a lavish production of Tchaikovsky's ''Queen of Spades.''

title: Cabot Medical reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
First Financial Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank went public in April 1987.

title: Boardroom Business Prodcts Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Arrest in Killing of Veteran
description: The female companion of Robert T'Souvas, the 39-year-old homeless veteran of the My Lai massacre who was shot to death earlier this month, was charged Tuesday with killing him. Police Detective Robert McCabe said the homeless defendant, Kathlynn T'Souvas, 36, had admitted shooting Mr. T'Souvas in a quarrel over a bottle of vodka.

description: b-After a gain of $250,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Stealth Bomber Built by Computer at Northrop
description: In order to build the ultrasecret Stealth bomber, the Northrop Corporation has apparently turned to the computer on a scale never before seen by American industry, Air Force and company officials said.

title: Manatron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Burma's Army, Despite Foe, Appears to Control Capital
description: The Burmese Army appeared today to be consolidating its control over the capital, Rangoon, but opposition leaders remained defiant and diplomats said militant students might be preparing for guerrilla warfare.

title: Megadata Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: A Developer Foils State Attempt to Buy Adirondack Land
description: A private development company said today that it had purchased 96,000 acres in the Adirondack Park, an announcement that embarrassed state officials because New York State had planned to acquire much of the land as wilderness.

title: Orbit Instruments
description: An investment group led by the investment firm Hopkins-Eaton & Associates Inc., based in Coral Gables, Fla., said it had decided to seek control of the Orbit Instruments Corporation. Orbit, an electronics concern in Hauppauge, L.I., has 9.5 million shares outstanding. Its stock climbed 37.5 cents today, to $6.375, in over-the counter trading, giving the company a present market value of more than $60 million. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Hopkins-Easton said it hopes to negotiate a friendly cash transaction with Orbit in which the present management would participate in the buyout. The investment group holds 11.1 percent of Orbit. Orbit officials were not available for comment because of the observance of Yom Kippur.

title: Rights of the Mother Upheld in Settlement
description: The Michigan court action this week in the first legal challenge to a law making it a crime to arrange a contract with a surrogate mother may mark an emerging consensus on the legal status of such arrangements.

title: Well, if It Isn't the Governor of Massachusetts
description: LEAD: My boyfriend, Ed, has authorized me to tell this personal story about us, because it bears on the Presidential campaign. A few years ago I developed an infatuation with someone else, and then it fizzled out - mainly because of the shrewd way Ed handled the situation. He just began referring to this other guy, whose name he knew perfectly well, as ''the Governor of Massachusetts'' (which he wasn't).

title: U.S. Grants Asylum To a Bolshoi Conductor
description: A conductor of the Bolshoi Opera defected in Bolivia this month and has been granted asylum in the United States, State Department officials said today.

title: Tyson vs. TV Camera
description: A day after Mike Tyson ducked camera crews when he arrived at Kennedy International Airport at the end of his trip to the Soviet Union, a camera crew was said to be doing the ducking yesterday.

title: A President Needs Foreign Policy Professionals
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Inspiration Meets Technique
description: HOW do young craftsmen today see the nature of their art? The answer can be found in ''Young Americans,'' a revealing exhibition at the American Craft Museum through Oct. 28. The artists, ages 18 to 30, whose work is shown are wizards of technique. The demanding process most of them go through on their way to professional maturity has led to a high level of accomplishment. And this achievement frees them to concentrate on ideas.

title: Market Place; Gundle's Growth And Volatility
description: GUNDLE ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS INC. is a growth stock that presents some classic quandaries for investors. The one-product company has enjoyed strong demand for the plastic liners it makes for trash dumps and toxic waste sites. Its stock has about tripled since the Oct. 19 stock market crash, from $8 to $24.125 yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Carl Typermass, Insurance Executive, 82
description: Carl Typermass, a retired insurance executive, died of a blood disorder Tuesday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhassett, L.I.

title: Archdiocese to Hold Synod And Give Laity a Voice in It
description: For the first time in the 180-year history of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, lay people will join bishops, priests and nuns in a meeting this weekend to chart a course for the local church.

title: Police Union in Boston Says It Endorses Bush
description: Leaders of Boston's police union endorsed George Bush for President in a unanimous vote today. They said the Vice President would do a better job than Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts in meeting the needs of law enforcement.

title: Intrigue on Way to Victory
description: It may take time, but the news will eventually reach Bulgaria, Naim Suleymanoglu said. He will call his parents, whom he hasn't seen in almost two years. The Turkish people living in Greece and Yugoslavia will gossip, too, spreading the word, and perhaps the Bulgarian weight lifters here in Seoul will tell their friends about the success a former countryman had at the Olympic Games.

title: Talking Deals; Ford and Nissan Take New Route
description: IN announcing last week that they would jointly produce and sell a new mini-van in this country, the Ford Motor Company and Nissan Motor Company were trying to solve a common problem: how to introduce a new model without all the expense of developing it on their own.

title: U.S. Averts Atom Agency's Ouster of Pretoria
description: The Reagan Administration appears to have succeeded in its drive to stop South Africa from being expelled from the international organization that oversees the nuclear industry and tries to halt the spread of atomic weapons, American officials said today.

title: Financial News Composite Fund reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes net realized and unrealized gains of $3,034,921 for the quarter and $2,017,157 for the year. Year-ago income figures were unavailable because the fund was formed in September 1987.

title: Gold Medal Consoles Biondi
description: In a span of two hours Wednesday, Matt Biondi went from gloom to satisfaction. The gloom came from a silver medal that should have been gold. The satisfaction came from a gold medal that most people thought would be silver or bronze.

title: Is It a Criminal Offense Not to Lead the Pledge?; Patriots All
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Has Mexico Murder Case
description: The case of three men charged with the kidnapping and murder of a United States narcotics agent in Mexico went to a Federal jury Tuesday. The prosecution says the defendants, one of whom is a former Mexican police officer, acted at the behest of a drug baron, Rafael Caro Quintero, because he feared assaults by Drug Enforcement Administration agents, like Enrique Camarena, who was killed, on his drug empire. The defense argued that the three are scapegoats for corrupt Mexican officials.

title: Southern Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Awash in Sailboats, a City Guards Gorges
description: For days this week, more than 60 sailboats have marched up and down Cayuga Lake, the longest of the Finger Lakes and the body of water that borders this bucolic city in upstate New York.

title: Soviets Make Overture to Japan About 4 Islands
description: The Soviet Union has informally suggested that Japan might lease the four Soviet-held islands that have remained a constant source of dispute between the two nations since the end of World War II, a senior official of the Japanese Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Torotel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $44,000 and $22,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Nevada Goldfields reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Strauss's Deficit Remarks Stirring Angry Reactions
description: Suggestions that a Congressional advisory panel on deficit reduction might recommend Social Security benefit cuts and tax increases touched off angry Congressional reactions today and predictions that it will now be more difficult for the panel to achieve a consensus.

title: Nine Years After Births, F.B.I. Investigates Baby Swap Case
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had opened a kidnapping inquiry based on a couple's charge that their healthy baby was swapped for a child with a heart defect in a hospital nursery nearly a decade ago.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The Treasury began an investigation of the savings industry in an attempt to develop an accurate estimate of the cost of resolving the status of the nation's 500 insolvent savings institutions. Senator William Proxmire, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said the next Congress would have to appropriate at least $20 billion to liquidate and merge these institutions. [ Page A1. ] The Consumer Price Index rose in August by 0.4 percent, the same as in July. Sizable increases for gasoline, cereals and other grain products, used cars and auto financing were partly offset by a huge drop for clothing and lesser declines for meats, fish and household fuels. The report reinforced the view that inflation is unlikely to climb to worrisome levels. [ D1. ] Prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose 0.5 percent. [ D6. ] Americans' personal incomes increased only half as fast as inflation in August. [ D6. ] Housing construction fell 3.3 percent last month; a decline in apartment construction outweighed a small gain in single-family homes. [ D6. ] Some lawmakers rejected the idea of cutting Social Security benefits. Robert S. Strauss, co-chairman of a bipartisan commission on deficit reduction, had said Tuesday that a proposed package of $68.5 billion in spending cuts would affect Social Security and other benefit programs. [ D1. ] COMPANIES A takeover battle between the largest gold-mining powers in the non-Communist world began when a unit of South Africa's Anglo American group made a $4.9 billion bid for Consolidated Gold Fields, a London-based company with extensive gold-mining operations in South Africa. If successful, the takeover would bring about a restructuring of the gold-mining industry. [ D1. ] Polaroid filed a lawsuit that seeks to block a $2.4 billion hostile takeover bid from Shamrock Holdings. [ D5. ] McDonnell Douglas will lease a closed aircraft plant in Columbus, Ohio, to produce parts for its C-17 cargo jet. [ D5. ] Lassiter Properties will pay $17 million for 96,000 acres in New York's Adirondack Park. [ B1. ] Digital Equipment and MIPS Computer will share technology for reduced instruction set computing, or RISC. [ D2. ] KDI accepted a $19-a-share management-led buyout offer, valuing the diversified manufacturer at about $184 million. [ D5. ] MARKETS Massachusetts will ban mandatory arbitration agreements by brokerages, the first state to do so. The securities industry said it would sue, calling the plan ''clearly unconstitutional.'' [ D7. ] Stock prices were mixed, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 3.02, to close at 2,090.50. Losers slightly outnumbered gainers on the New York Stock Exchange, 697 to 689. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds again advanced, despite a string of favorable economic reports. [ D16. ] Gold prices dropped below $400 an ounce for the first time in 19 months, as worries over inflation continued to ease. [ D6. ] Copper futures prices posted a sharp decline. [ D17. ] The dollar rose mildly in light trading. Gold fell $6.90 an ounce on the Comex, to $398.40. [ D17. ] Yields rose on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds for the week ended yesterday. [ D21. ] Shares sold short and not yet covered rose 0.3 percent on the Big Board. On the American Exchange, short interest was up less than 0.1 percent. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Ford and Nissan are trying to introduce a model without all the expense of developing one on their own. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Gundle Environmental Systems is a growth stock that presents some classic quandaries for investors. Market Place. [ D8. ]

description: Hundreds of jubilant residents spilled into the streets here Tuesday to celebrate Costa Rica's first Olympic Games medal, the silver won by Silvia Poll in the women's 200-meter freestyle swimming race.

description: Going home after school to an empty house is not by itself necessarily bad for children in grade school, recent studies suggest.

description: LEAD: THE last of 2,700 roses are being moved this week from a propagation range where pots had been tucked into every corner of the greenhouses and temporary shelters. They will join the masses of roses that have already been installed in a new two-acre garden at the New York Botanical Garden. The rose garden is a reconstruction of a plan that lay dormant for 70 years.

description: High and huge on its granite base here stands the last Soviet statue of Josef Stalin. Like the songs Gori children sing about him - ''Little Gori is great: It gave birth to Stalin'' - the statue is a tribute to the visceral loyalty he still commands in his native town.

description: The Reagan Administration rebuked House Speaker Jim Wright of Texas today for discussing information about covert activities in Nicaragua, but it did not deny his statement that the Central Intelligence Agency had deliberately incited opposition activities there.

description: The way the season has gone for the Baltimore Orioles, it would seem that Frank Robinson, the manager, would want to get it over as soon as possible, but here he was trying to extend it.

description: The Federal investigation into a fatal confrontation between the police and a radical group was closed this week without indictments, but bitterness and civil suits linger.

description: Latin American nations, already deeply in debt to private banks, are now also being drained by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. These institutions are siphoning about $2 billion annually from Latin America. At their annual meetings next week in Berlin, the agencies must face the question of how to reverse this destructive trend.

title: Scientists Use Powerful Toxin to Fight Spread of AIDS Virus
description: Using a toxin so potent that a single molecule will kill a cell, researchers have devised a new way to fight the AIDS virus.

Solarz, the Brooklyn Democrat, returned from Burma earlier this month, the House passed his resolution supporting democratic processes in that troubled nation. The United States Information Agency distributed the text of the resolution to all but one of the six Burmese daily newspapers.

title: Sickness in Old Age: Preparing Now Can Help to Ease the Burdens
description: As America's population ages, an array of advisers and advocacy groups have sprung up to help people prepare well in advance for potentially high medical expenses, incapacitating disease and, as death nears, possibly wrenching medical decisions.

description: The hero of the day for the Jets, who have had a lot of heroes lately, was Bobby Humphery, the cornerback designated by the National Football League as the defensive player of the week in the American Conference.

title: African Art And Life Reflected In Fabrics
description: LEAD: FABRICS hold an exalted place in most West African cultures south of the Sahara. Besides clothing the body, they designate a person's social position. Special fabrics are used in rituals of birth, puberty, marriage and death, as well as in the ceremonies of the secret societies. References to fabrics abound in songs, proverbs and myths.

title: Parent & Child
description: LISA HEISER knows that in the next nine months she will see a lot of very anxious college students and, occasionally, hear from upset and frustrated parents. As director of the career development office at the University of Minnesota College of Liberal Arts, Ms. Heiser helps students figure out how they can earn a living once they're through with school.

description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

description: Christine Norden, a British-born film and stage actress, died of a respiratory infection yesterday in West Middlesex Hospital in London. She was 63 years old.

description: The United States volleyball team survived Waldo Kantor and its own erratic play today and rallied to defeat Argentina, 11-15, 11-15, 15-4, 17-15, 15-7.

Two Shot, One Fatally, As They Sit in an Auto
description: A 19-year-old man and an 18-year-old woman were sitting in a car in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn last night when an unidentified man approached the car, pulled out a gun, and shot them both, killing the man, the police said.

title: A Lesson From Suriname
description: MATT BIONDI, the king salmon of this United States Olympic swimming team, never predicted he would splash to seven gold medals, the record total swept by Mark Spitz at Munich in 1972. Seven medals were all Biondi thought about, not seven golds. But when Biondi had to be satisfied with a bronze in the 200-yard freestyle earlier this week behind Duncan Armstrong of Australia and Anders Holmertz of Sweden, he no longer had even the opportunity to match Spitz's sweep.

title: McCaffrey & McCall Gets Real Estate Job
description: McCaffrey & McCall, a subsidiary of Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi, has become the first agency ever retained by the Macklowe Organization, a real estate development, construction and management company.

description: The Detroit office of McCann-Erickson, the agency for General Motors' Chevrolet, has been awarded the Champion Spark Plug Company business, which, trade sources say, could bill up to $15 million.

title: Life in the 30's
description: ONE of the most beautiful and most moving love stories I have read in a long time is contained in a new book titled ''Borrowed Time'' (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich). It is about the devotion that two human beings have to each other, even in the maelstrom of death, and about how that devotion enobles and elevates both of their existences. It is a book I have been recommending a great deal, although not one I recommend to everyone. That is because the two lovers both happen to be men.

title: Citizens' Holders Vote Acquisition
description: Citizens Financial Group Inc.'s shareholders overwhelmingly approved the sale of the company to the Royal Bank of Scotland, the sixth-largest bank in Britain, for $440 million in cash. If the $30.50-a-share deal is approved by regulators, it would be the first foreign takeover of a leading New England bank and would transform Citizens into one of the largest of the regional banking companies in the Northeast.

title: Rate Put at 88% In Court Survey On Camera Use
description: Halfway through New York State's 18-month experiment with the use of cameras and audio equipment in courtrooms, 88 percent of the applications for coverage submitted by newspapers and television and radio stations have been approved by presiding judges, a survey by the State Office of Court Administration shows.

description: The National Rifle Association's costly lobbying effort played a far greater role last week in the House's rejection of a gun control measure than did the group's contributions to lawmakers' re-election campaigns, according to several politicians and strategists on both sides.

description: A futures trading firm with 17 offices in Florida, California, New York and Michigan has agreed to close as part of its settlement of fraud charges leveled by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Botswana Foils Jail Rescue
description: Botswana said today that its police have arrested a black South African commando who planned to rescue two South African soldiers from prison. A black Botswanan lawyer has also been arrested in the plot, which was intended to free a pair of soldiers captured in an abortive South African raid into Botswana in June.

title: Pentagon Says Armed Forces Increased Slightly in August
description: The number of men and women in uniform increased in August but still remained well below the levels of a year earlier, the Pentagon said today.

description: Mike Flanagan and Duane Ward combined on a six-hitter tonight as the Toronto Blue Jays slowed Boston's drive toward the American League East title by beating the Red Sox, 1-0.

description: An old model of the nozzle inlet ring was used in the final test of the redesigned solid-fuel booster rocket for the space shuttle, but the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has not decided if the development will delay the launching scheduled next week, a spokesman said today.

title: Cherne Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day yesterday about Global Information misidentified the previous magazine started by the creators of Global Finance. It was Venture.

title: Chaparral Steel Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a gain from cumulative effect of accounting change of $3,895,000.

title: Suzuki '89 Models
description: The Suzuki Motor Company introduced two automobiles for 1989, including a four-wheel-drive car. The company also introduced its first car made specifically for the United States market. The new models are the Sidekick, a slightly larger four-wheel-drive vehicle, and the subcompact Swift, Suzuki's first car for the United States market. Suzuki will initially import the two vehicles from Japan. Beginning in April, they will be built in Canada.

title: Lebanon's Religions
description: Christians

title: Jeep Output to Rise
description: The Chrysler Motors Corporation said it would expand production at its two plants that make the popular Jeep line of sport utility vehicles. Beginning in January 1989, annual production of Jeeps will increase by 55,000 units. The Toledo Jeep plant, which has current capacity of 220,000 units, will increase its production of Jeep Cherokees, Wagoneers and Comanches by 23,000 units. The Brampton, Ontario, plant will add another 32,000 units to its current production capacity of 50,000 Jeep Wranglers. Chrysler will invest $24.2 million in the two plants as part of the expansion and increase its work force by about 575 people.

title: Biotherapeutics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Yom Kippur Affects Contests
description: It does not seem fair, but because the ultimate responsibility for the rules in the Olympic Games rests with each international sports federation, athletes with identical problems can be treated very differently. Today was Yom Kippur, the most solemn Jewish holy day, and observant Jews could not participate in competition until after sundown.

title: The Games at a Glance
description: Gymnastics The three, all from the same country, were separated by the smallest of differences. Vladimir Artemov edged teammate and his countryman, Valeri Lyukin, by one-tenth of a point yesterday to capture the gold medal and lead a Soviet sweep of the men's all-around gymnastic competition. Dmitri Bilozerchev was third for the bronze. Artemov, who has a history of faltering in major competitions, registered two perfect scores. In women's competition, the Soviet team, which remained well above the fray concerning the bronze medal, finished just above its chief rival for the gold. While East Germany and the United States traded charges in their squabble for third place, the Soviet and Rumanian athletes battled with grace and skill. In the optional portion, Yelena Shushunova posted perfect scores in the vault, uneven bars and the floor exercise to carry the Soviet Union to a satisfying triumph over the country that beat them in the world championships a year ago. The United States which lost the bronze to East Germany by three-tenths of a point, blamed its finish on an East German official who had invoked an obscure rule to penalize the American team five-tenths of a point in the compulsory segment. Basketball Around the track or up and down the court, it has never really mattered. Americans have always run well at the Olympics. The women's basketball team ran early and often and as a result Yugoslavia no doubt spent most of the second half wanting nothing more than to hide. The Americans led by 15 at intermission and by as many as 28 in the second half as they went on to defeat Yugoslavia, 101-74, and gain a spot in the medal round. In men's play, the Soviet Union, which had already lost to Yugoslavia, barely squeaked past Puerto Rico in overtime. Weight Lifting Mitko Grablev of Bulgaria was stripped of his gold medal and banned from the Games after testing positive for drugs. Grablev, who won the 123-pound class, was found to be using furosemide, a diuretic and one of the roughly 100 drugs on the I.O.C.'s banned list. Wrestling His hold on the audience was as good as his grip on his opponent. South Korean Kim Young Nam, a hometown hero, delighted a partisan crowd of his countrymen by outpointing Daoulet Tourlykhanov of the Soviet Union, 2-1, to capture the gold medal in the 162-pound class of Greco-Roman wrestling. Other gold medal winners included Jon Ronningen of Norway and Andrzej Wronski of Poland. Dennis Koslowski of Minneapolis took a bronze in the 220-pound class. Boxing The bout was rough and tumble, but not nearly as ugly as what followed. South Korean boxing coaches attacked a New Zealand referee after one of their boxers lost a decision to a Bulgarian boxer. Water bottles and at least one chair were thrown into the ring as referees, coaches and competitors roamed the canvas in confusion. The judges had awarded Aleksandr Hristov a 4-1 decision over Bun Jong Il in a 119-pound fight.

title: Interface Offering Convertible Debt
description: Interface Inc., a manufacturer of carpet tile, is offering $95 million of 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2013, at a price of par, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: Mellon's Board Clears Settlements
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation's board has approved a $7.5 million settlement of nine class-action and shareholder derivative lawsuits stemming from the company's first-ever quarterly loss. The lawsuits were brought against the bank-holding company and some of its current and former officers and directors after Mellon reported a loss in the first quarter of 1987.

title: U.S. Does a Much-Needed Turnaround
description: Matt Biondi broke an Olympic record today and moved closer to his fourth swimming medal in four events. Chris Jacobs, so disgusted with his cocaine addiction that he almost committed suicide two years ago, held an Olympic record for six minutes until Biondi broke it. And Janet Evans moved toward the second of her projected three gold medals.

title: Lodgistix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $1,000 for the quarter and $89,000 for the year. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $37,000 for the quarter and $77,000 for the year. The company said results for both years have been restated to reflect the sale of its computer forms division in July 1988.

title: Polaroid Files Lawsuit To Block Takeover
description: The Polaroid Corporation said today that it had filed a lawsuit that seeks to block a $2.4 billion hostile takeover bid from Roy E. Disney's Shamrock Holdings Inc.

title: Fish Oil Pill Seen as Artery Aid
description: Taking fish oil capsules dramatically reduces the chances that coronary arteries will become clogged again after angioplasty, a procedure in which doctors use a tiny balloon to open clogged arteries, according to a study.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Buffalo Bills have acquired Leonard Smith, a strong safety, from the Phoenix Cardinals for Roland Mitchell, a reserve cornerback, and an undisclosed draft pick. . . . The Pittsburgh Steelers have placed John Rienstra, a guard, on the injured-reserve list with a broken right leg and re-signed Brian Blankenship, a lineman who was waived Aug. 29 during the final preseason cuts. Rienstra suffered the fracture during the Steelers' 17-12 loss Sunday to the Cincinnati Bengals and will be sidelined from four to eight weeks. . . . Jerome Lane, a first-round draft choice, officially became a Denver Nugget, signing a multiyear contract that will reportedly earn the 6-6 forward from Pitt $200,000 this season.(AP)

title: Revival Spurs New Confidence for Cram
description: A year ago it would have been inconceivable to think of Steve Cram winning a gold medal for Britain in the Olympic Games. His confidence was down, his form off, and it all became painfully clear in the 1,500-meter final of the world championships in Rome.

title: Taking Stand For Europe, Thatcher Says
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher went off this week to explain to Continental skeptics that Britain is, after all, an enthusiastic member of the European Community, eager to do its part to bring about a true common market by the end of 1992. Here's how she has been doing it: ''A centralized European government would be a nightmare.''

title: American Wrestler Takes Bronze
description: Minutes after he won a bronze medal today in Greco-Roman wrestling, Dennis Koslowski of the United States said he had finished his career as a wrestler.

title: Close-Up: Equestrian Dressage
description: Test of Style Dressage is a test of a rider's and a horse's control, pace, seat, regularity and ease of movement. Inseparable Teams Competitors are given from 1 to 10 points in various categories. Horses can be any breed, but must be at least six years old. Horse and rider are an inseparable team; if either is unable to perform, the entry is scratched. Six judges are used to rate the riders and horses; raised tails, tossing and hesitation are costly. The dressage arena is a rectangle 60 meters by 20 meters. Keep an Eye on . . . Anne-Grethe Jensen, Denmark Christine Stuckelberger, Switzerland >Reiner Klimke, West Germany

title: Walsh May Go Pro
