description: Steve Walsh, the Miami junior who passed for a career-high 335 yards and 3 touchdowns to rally the top-ranked Hurricanes to a 31-30 victory over Michigan last Saturday, has led Miami to 14 straight victories as a starting quarterback. But as Bernie Kosar did in 1985, Walsh is considering the possibility of forgoing his final year of eligibility as a fifth-year senior to turn professional. ''It's something I'll discuss with Coach Jimmy Johnson and with my family,'' said Walsh, who expects to receive his degree in finance in June.

title: Review/Television; Barbs and High Praise From Justice Marshall
description: An interview with a Supreme Court Justice is something of an event, which is a reason to watch ''Thurgood Marshall: The Man,'' on Channel 13 tonight at 9 o'clock. Justice Marshall chats in folksy manner with the columnist Carl T. Rowan. Few of Justice Marshall's views will astonish anyone acquainted with his long career as a fighter for civil rights, but they are delivered in pithy one-liners of a sort not often heard on the high bench.

title: Parliament Delays Vote
description: The Lebanese Parliament failed to meet today to elect a successor to President Gemayel and put off the session for 24 hours to allow time to break a deadlock over the succession and resolve its crisis.

title: A Magician Breaks Out of the Mold (and the Pack)
description: Prowling a cabaret stage, wearing a sorcerer's robe embellished with stars and moons, the magician Jeff McBride is definitely not David Copperfield: clean-cut is hardly the description that leaps to mind. It is instantly apparent, too, that this magician is no cheery Doug Henning, as he peers through a forbidding whiteface mask and performs a show dense with drama, mystery and occult symbolism.

title: Chrysler Forecast
description: Chrysler Corporation officials said they did not expect sales to increase in 1989, despite the introduction later of three new car models. Bennett E. Bidwell, president for marketing at Chrysler Motors, said he expected sales of about one million cars and the same number of trucks next year, about even with projected 1988 sales.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Old Is Good At Memories Magazine
description: WHILE Diamandis Communications is preparing to welcome aboard the highly successful Elle magazine, elsewhere in the organization Memories magazine is getting ready for its first advertising effort.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Women's Marathon; A 'Small Country' Takes Distant Strides With Mota
description: Rosa Mota was asked what her financial gain would be from winning the Olympic marathon today and she held up her gold medal and said: ''I will show you.''

title: Baseball; Tigers Gain On Red Sox
description: Tom Brookens hit a two-run double to highlight a four-run fourth inning as the Detroit Tigers pulled within 4 1/2 games of first place in the American League East by beating the Baltimore Orioles, 7-4.

title: Guitar, With Loops
description: Doug Baldwin will play guitar solos, with tape loops, tonight at 9 at Lunch for Your Ears, 25 Prince Street (941-1774). Admission is free.

title: WRIGHT IS DENYING SECRET DATA LEAK
description: Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, today categorically denied that he had revealed classified intelligence information this week when he told reporters that Congress had ''clear testimony'' that the Central Intelligence Agency was inciting opposition activities in Nicaragua.

title: Results PlusB. J. Scoot Triumphs: B. J. Scoot never trailed and won the 43d Little Brown Jug by 1 1/4 lengths over Threefold before a crowd of 47,218 yesterday at the Delaware County Fairgrounds in Delaware, Ohio. B. J. Scoot, driven by Michel LaChance, had times of 26 4/5 seconds for the quarter-mile, a Jug-record 53 4/5 for the half, and 1:23 for three quarters on the way to a winning time of 1:52 3/5 for the mile. The 3-year-old pacer, owned by Sybarite Stable of Islington, Ontario, was the first Ohio-bred horse ever to win the Little Brown Jug. Threefold, driven by Bill Fahy, finished two lengths ahead of Dare You To, driven by John Campbell. B. J. Scoot paid $6 for $2 to win. (AP)  Golf  4-Way Tie in B.C. Open: Ed Dougherty, Jim Simons and Roger Maltbie each shot six-under-par 65 yesterday morning and watched as their scores held up throughout the day for the first-round lead at the $500,000 B.C. Open in Endicott. N.Y. They were joined atop the leader board by Dave Rummells, who converted birdies on four of his last six holes at the par-71 En-Joie Golf Course.(AP)  Tennis  Mezzadri Eliminated: Eduardo Bengoechea of Argentina eliminated the defending champion, Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland, 6-2, 6-2 yesterday in 79 minutes to advance to the quarterfinals of the $220,000 Geneva Open. Bengoechea will meet Jordi Arrese, seeded third, who beat Jesus Colas, 6-1, 6-3, in other second-round play yesterday.(AP)
description: Harness Racing

title: System Integrators Parting From Founder
description: As chairman and founder of System Integrators Inc., a leading maker of electronic publishing systems, James P. Lennane has been one of the computer industry's most feisty and flamboyant executives. He once took the floor for three minutes at a meeting of shareholders of the Eastman Kodak Company to attack the company for throwing away money on its subsidiary Atex Inc., his archrival for big sales to newspapers and magazines.

title: The Debates: Dead on Arrival
description: LEAD: I produced the first Presidential debate between Richard M. Nixon and John F. Kennedy. Unfortunately, it was not a debate. It was a joint appearance and a quasi-news conference, which is what I expect this Sunday's Presidential debate to be. If we really want debates, we should adopt the the Oxford approach, with each candidate bringing along a team.

title: MDS Health Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Revenue represents net revenue.

title: Reagan Courting Texas Democrats
description: President Reagan campaigned vigorously today through Texas, a major battleground in the fall election, and tried to drive a wedge between this state's conservative Democrats and the national party leadership.

title: Savings Unit Acquired
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has announced that the Loves Park Federal Savings Bank of Loves Park, Ill., has been acquired by the Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of Rockford, Ill. Loves Park is the 106th troubled savings institution to be disposed of this year. Home Federal received $4.9 million in assistance from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. Home Federal will also be indemnified against claims or litigation challenging the transaction.

title: Judge Orders Medical Exam For Helmsley
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that he would appoint a doctor to examine Harry B. Helmsley to determine whether the 79-year-old billionaire hotel operator is mentally and physically able to stand trial with his wife on charges of fraud and income tax evasion.

title: Neighbors Flee 5-Alarm Fire
description: A five-alarm fire roared through a drugstore under construction in the Haight-Ashbury District Wednesday with heat so intense that paint on buildings across the street caught fire. The blaze, two blocks from Golden Gate Park, forced residents of several apartments to flee. No injuries were reported.

title: First Interstate Plans To Spin Off 'Bad' Bank
description: As the final leg of a restructuring begun last October, First Interstate Bancorp plans to spin off $400 million in problem loans into a separate entity, the company said today. After this move, $20 billion in poorly performing assets will have been swept from the company's books.

title: Lucien O. Hooper, 92, Ex-Securities Analyst
description: Lucien Obed Hooper, a retired securities analyst who was known as the dean of Wall Street market-letter writer, died of heart failure Monday at the Valley Nursing Home in Westwood, N.J. He was 92 years old and lived in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J.

title: Democrats in the Bronx Nominate 3 for Court
description: Assemblyman George Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader who lost control of a Democratic judicial district convention last year, staved off another challenge last night and succeeded in nominating three of his choices for the State Supreme Court in the Bronx.

title: Fire Report Is Perplexing Main Street, Hackensack
description: After five firefighters died when the roof of a burning car dealership collapsed last July, John R. DeNoy, the owner of John's Coffee Shop near the Bergen County Courthouse, could not understand why the firemen had gone into the building in the first place.

title: On Stage
description: A Dropout Returns

title: Israel Offering $4.8 Billion Of Government Certificates
description: Israel is offering more than $4.8 billion of Government trust certificates in four parts through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. as lead manager and Salomon Brothers Inc. as co-lead manager.

title: Pop/Jazz; Saxophonists With More Than Be-Bob
description: When Bobby Watson, the 35-year-old alto saxophonist appearing at the Village Vanguard this weekend, plays, he might as well be driving a gospel audience to salvation. He's an old-style burner, someone who manages to turn every solo into an uproarious event. Hunched over, he'll send blues phrases reeling into the audience; be-bop trickery shows up, and everything he plays swings. Like James Moody, the great flute, alto and tenor saxophone player appearing down the street at Sweet Basil, Mr. Watson is often labeled a be-bopper; anyone with good ears knows the category is senseless for either of them.

title: Wider Deficit In Soviet Trade
description: The Soviet deficit in trade with the West widened in the first six months of 1988, official figures show.

title: When High Court's Away, Clerks' Work Begins
description: While most of the Supreme Court's nine justices spent a good part of their three-month summer recess out of town, the lights in their chambers burned late as their 33 law clerks plowed through papers in the nearly 100 new cases filed each week.

title: Comprehensive Care Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
As Bush Collects a Political Windfall, Dukakis Counterpunches in Boston
description: Vice President Bush swooped into Michael S. Dukakis's territory today to revel in the endorsement of a Boston police union, but Mr. Dukakis counterpunched by mustering law-enforcement officials from around the nation for a red-white-and-blue rally on the Statehouse lawn.

title: Envirodyne Rejects A Takeover Offer
description: A group led by the San Francisco investment firm Richard C. Blum & Associates Inc. has offered to purchase Envirodyne Industries for $32 a share in stock and debt, but the Chicago-based food-packaging concern rejected the bid. No reason for the rejection was included in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosing the offer. Envirodyne has 18.25 million shares outstanding, giving the proposed transaction a total value of $584 million.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Track and Field; Record Start by Joyner-Kersee
description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee, the overwhelming favorite in the heptathlon, got off to a record-breaking start today in quest of the Olympic gold medal that barely eluded her in 1984.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Notebook; For Seoul's Mayor, A Rule to Regret
description: After asking Seoul's 10 million citizens to reduce traffic congestion during the Olympic Games by alternating the days they drove their cars, Mayor Kim Yong Nae switched the license plates on his car so that he could be on the road every day.

title: Corrections
description: A dividend listing in Business Day on Wednesday misstated the value of the regular quarterly stock dividend declared by the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. Stockholders of record on Oct. 1 will receive 82 cents a share on Oct. 25.

title: Jets Will Try to Ground Lions
description: The Jets and the Detroit Lions, who face each other Sunday in Pontiac, Mich., have played only four times since the realignment of the National Football League in 1970. The last time was on Thanksgiving Day in 1985, and Jet memories are dim.

title: Shevardnadze Meets With Shultz as U.S. Assesses Arms Offer
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz opened two days of talks with the Soviet Foreign Minister today as American officials assessed a Soviet suggestion for an interim agreement to limit the number of warheads on ballistic missiles.

title: Review/Art; Kenny Scharf Grows Up
description: In his current exhibition at the Tony Shafrazi Gallery, Kenny Scharf sets out on a new path as a painter. It's not an entirely untrammeled path - in fact, it's rather trammeled -nor is it certain that these new paintings aren't transitional. Nonetheless, it is always encouraging to see an artist set aside a successful style before it becomes old hat and yet remain true to it at heart, and this is what the 29-year-old Mr. Scharf has done.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Soviet troops were deployed in Armenia. They sealed off official buildings and several central squares in the latest move to contain spreading ethnic unrest in two Soviet republics. Page A1

title: Haiti's Hopes and General Avril
description: Haiti suffered through another coup last weekend only to sink into new turmoil. One general had barely replaced another when soldiers mutinied, workers struck and killing returned to the streets. Yet the soldiers who engineered the coup appear to share with the public a wish to rid Haiti of the brutal, arrogant daily lawlessness. The Haitians, for all their desperate poverty, have not given up.

title: Ford Aerospace Settles In False-Pricing Case
description: The Ford Aerospace Corporation will pay $7 million to the Government to settle accusations that it submitted false pricing information for sophisticated bombing equipment sold to the Air Force, the Justice Department announced today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: 66 of 67 Survive Blast On North Sea Oil Rig
description: An explosion and fire tore through an American-operated oil-drilling rig in the North Sea today, but all but one of the 67 people aboard appear to have been rescued, the Coast Guard said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Annin & Company, a flag manufacturer in Roseland, N.J., misidentified the union that represents its production workers. The union is the United Textile Workers of America, A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: Panel of 3 Questioners Is Selected For Initial Bush-Dukakis Debate
description: The Presidential campaigns of Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis agreed today on whom they would allow to ask questions Sunday night at their first debate.

title: Slim Pickings
description: Yes, you can have a sumptuous buffet without driving everybody's cholesterol level right through the Capitol dome, maintains Public Voice for Food & Health Policy, a consumer research organization here.

title: Seymour R. Kaplan, Professor, 66
description: Dr. Seymour R. Kaplan, a professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his office in the Bronx. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Haiti Getting Back to Normal Amid Army Moves
description: Amid continuing questions over the chain of command in the Haitian military, diplomats and soldiers here agreed today that the situation was gradually returning to normal, five days after a coup led by noncommissioned officers.

title: Clean Harbors Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: The Islanders, who still have 30 players to drop from their training camp, trimmed their roster to 56 by returning two left wings, Yves Gaucher and Wayne Doucet, and a defenseman, Andre Brassared, to their junior hockey clubs. . . . Larry Krystowiak, a forward for the Milwaukee Bucks, underwent minor foot surgery and is not expected to be able to participate fully in training camp, which begins Oct. 7.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Swimming; Evans and Biondi Win Gold Again
description: The Matt and Janet show continued Thursday night in Olympic swimming, giving the United States two gold medals in 30 minutes.

title: Stein Seeks to End Panel's Money
description: The City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, said yesterday that he would try to have the city eliminate the entire budget of the agency that licenses teachers in New York City if the Legislature failed to do so.

title: Review/Film; A Nuclear Cover-Up in Australia
description: What connection can there be between a long-buried radioactive airplane and a smart young cinematographer who films dancing chili dogs for a living? It's the kind of connection that's often found in taut, clever conspiracy-theory thrillers, of which the new Australian film ''Ground Zero'' is a prime example. What's more, the dreadful secret that is revealed in this film by Michael Pattinson and Bruce Myles turns out to be largely true. The closing titles, corroborating information that is unearthed during the course of the story, are sobering indeed.

title: Concord Camera Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company had its initial public share offering in July 1988.

title: Strangers On a Train, In 'Kansas'
description: ''Kansas'' sets itself up as a suspense story entangled with the people and values of America's heartland. Here is what happens in one supposedly sleepy little town. A wheat field-wholesome young man named Wade (Andrew McCarthy) is on his way to New York City. After his car burns up, he jumps on a freight train where he meets a drifter named Doyle (Matt Dillon) and is so unfazed by his sinister looks - the gold tooth and the panther tattooed on his forearm might have made most folks suspicious - that he hops off the train with his new friend. Following Doyle's lead, the impressionable Wade breaks into a house, goes to a parade where he spots the girl of his dreams and robs a bank. But while he is fleeing the bank, a car carrying the Governor's small daughter falls into the river, so Wade saves the child from drowning, runs away and hides the money - all this before lunchtime. Soon he finds work at a farm owned by the father of the girl of his dreams, a convenient place to roll in the hay, literally, while the town searches for the mystery hero.

title: Chameleons Thrive Under Apartheid
description: LEAD: Let me quote from one of our few remaining daily newspapers, The Government Gazette:

title: Knick Tickets Going on Sale
description: Tickets for the Knicks' two home exhibition games and the first 19 home regular-season games will go on sale at Madison Square Garden and all Ticket Master sites next Tuesday at 10 A.M.

title: Review/Film; A Mirror Image of Disintegration
description: The sleek, icy elegance of ''Dead Ringers,'' David Cronenberg's film about twin gynecologists teetering on the brink of madness, is unexpected. Both the director, whose past films include the much gorier ''Scanners'' and ''Videodrome,'' and the highly unusual subject suggest a more lurid approach. But Mr. Cronenberg, who has begun to emerge as a master of body-related horrific fantasy (his last film was ''The Fly''), clearly understands that a small amount of medical mischief can be more unnerving than conventional grisliness. Even the film's opening credits, which present antiquated obstetrical drawings and strange medical instruments, are enough to make audiences queasy.

title: F.A.A. Orders That Airlines Arm Planes to Detect Wind Shift Peril
description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered airlines today to equip all their planes with devices that will help pilots detect and escape from deadly shifts in the wind.

title: Auctions
description: Washington Under Fire

title: Haiti Terrorists Form in New Groups
description: Last week, a band of thugs who are widely being referred to as Tontons Macoute invaded a Roman Catholic mass here with machetes and guns. They killed a dozen parishoners, wounded 77 others and set the church afire.

title: Holly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $207,000 for the quarter and $913,000 for the year. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July.

title: Paris Journal; A Marriage at Figaro: Right Lies Down With Left
description: A powerful but troubled newspaper reaches out for the editorial talents of a brilliant young journalist: a familiar story. The right-wing press baron Robert Hersant steals the 39-year-old editor of France's leading leftist weekly: another story altogether.

title: Gandhi Drops Measure Denounced by the Press
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi bowed to weeks of opposition from Indian journalists today and scrapped a measure to revise the law on defamation.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday misidentified the auto maker for which McCann-Erickson provides advertising. The agency represents Buick.

title: Papers Filed by 2 Hunts Give Glimpse of Wealth
description: Personal bankruptcy documents filed here by William Herbert Hunt and Nelson Bunker Hunt offer glimpses into the assets now held by the two Texans who once controlled enough oil, real estate, silver and sugar to make them among the world's wealthiest men.

title: TROUBLED YEARS BEFORE ST. PATRICK'S: JORGE DELGADO'S ODYSSEY
description: Only records from Bellevue Hospital Center and Rikers Island were available. Mr. Delgado may have spent time in other hospitals. When not in detention, Mr. Delgado was usually in city shelters. June 29, 1983: First admitted to Bellevue Hospital Center. Was brought in for smashing windows of a Broadway movie theater. Was under arrest in prison unit. Discharged July 1. July 2: First incarcerated at Rikers July 2, 1983, charged with third-degree assault. Released Aug. 8. Aug. 19: Bellevue. Was brought in after being found swimming in Hudson River. Discharged Sept. 7. Sept. 10: Rikers. Charged with third-degree criminal trespassing. Released Oct. 11. Feb. 9, 1984: Rikers. Charged with first-degree robbery. Released April 6. April 16: Bellevue. Discharged April 23. April 25: Bellevue. Discharged May 10. Dec. 19: Bellevue. Examined in prison unit and released to police custody. Dec. 20: Rikers. Charged with criminal possession of stolen property. Released Jan. 5, 1985. Jan. 19, 1985: Rikers. Charged with petty larceny. Released Sept. 17. Dec. 10: Bellevue. Discharged Jan. 6, 1986. Feb. 27, 1986: Manhattan House of Detention. Charged with second degree criminal trespassing. Released March 6. Aug. 11, 1986: Rikers. Charged with fourth-degree criminal mischief. Released Sept. 19. Sept. 25, 1986: Rikers. Charged with fourth-degree criminal mischief. Released Oct. 10. March 26, 1987: Rikers. Charged with criminal mischief. Released April 10. April 1: Bellevue. Treated in emergency room and given an appointment. April 27: Bellevue. Seen for appointment. April 28: Rikers. Charged with criminal mischief. Released May 8.

title: JOUSTING KNIGHTS AND ROVING JESTERS IN MEDIEVAL FESTIVAL AT THE CLOISTERS
description: ''THIS is the renaissance of the Middle Ages,'' proclaimed City Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern, whose department is co-sponsoring a fanciful foray into the 15th century on Sunday in Fort Tryon Park in upper Manhattan.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 9:45 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON REVIEW AND APPRAISAL OF U.N. AFRICAN RECOVERY PROGRAM - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Sports of The Times; The Breakfast Club
description: AT an hour when big-time athletes in the States would usually still be shifting their REM cycles, fists were flying and so were chairs and plastic bottles at the sweet science known as boxing yesterday.

title: Women Coaches Are an Endangered Species
description: LEAD: As you sit in the stands at Fenway Park or Shea Stadium and your eye drifts to the third base coaching box, do you ever see a woman? No. At first base? No. Do you ever see a woman manager in the dugout? Of course not.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Basketball; U.S. Teams Mingle Off Court
description: They occupy the same floor in the Athletes Village, separated only by the rules and regulations stipulated by their respective coaches. That still allows enough time for the men and women on the United States basketball teams to share their experiences here, having discussions that range from the games they have played to what awaits them when the Olympic Games are over.

title: Restaurants
description: In recent years, seafood prices have jumped higher than dolphins at a Florida marine park. Almost extinct are the clattering old-fashioned fish houses, where simple, grilled fillets (usually dyed with paprika) were served up with a salad, boiled potatoes and cole slaw. Today's seafood restaurants are more likely to be genteel places with French or Italian accents and princely prices. Six-year-old Claire in Chelsea is a happy exception.

title: Brazil and Its Creditors Sign Debt Agreement
description: Brazil and its foreign creditor banks signed a sweeping debt agreement yesterday that provides $5.2 billion in new loans and restructures $62 billion worth of medium- and long-term bank debt at sharply lower interest rates.

title: Former Florida Official Is Guilty in 3 Slayings
description: A former Franklin County Commissioner was convicted Wednesday of killing a judge, a lawyer and his former sister-in-law at an alimony hearing in a courthouse last year.

title: 6 Asian Nations Move To Block Khmer Rouge
description: Southeast Asian nations, suspecting that the well-armed and brutal Khmer Rouge are preparing to seize control of Cambodia again, are planning new action at this year's United Nations General Assembly aimed at forestalling a Khmer Rouge return to sole power, according to diplomats from these countries.

title: Review/Film; Bad Men Traveling And Killing
description: A suspenseful, brutal and tautly told tale measures up to the title of the film ''Murder One,'' which opens today at the Cine Twinand other theaters. It is a drama based on the cold-blooded killing of seven people in 1973 during a wild journey through the South by three brothers and their friend.

title: National Service Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Ojeda Faces Long Road Back
description: Bobby Ojeda sat in his hospital room yesterday and remembered how it happened: He was shearing the hedges with an electric clipper about 11:15 Wednesday morning, happy and healthy, earning $750,000 at the age of 30 and scheduled to pitch the fourth game of the playoff for the Mets.

title: INSIDE
description: Military Regime in Lebanon

title: U.S. and Allies Show Ability To Influence Currency Levels
description: After winning another battle this summer, the world's industrial democracies are beginning to offer convincing evidence that, more than before, they can influence the course of the volatile foreign-exchange markets.

title: Ottawa Will Pay Compensation To Uprooted Japanese-Canadians
description: The Canadian Government agreed today to pay the equivalent of $17,325 in compensation to each of about 12,000 surviving Japanese-Canadians who were forcibly uprooted from their homes in British Columbia, interned and deprived of their property in World War II.

title: Roy Kinnear Is Dead At 54 After Falling From Horse in Film
description: Roy Kinnear, a British actor best known for his comic roles, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Ruber International Hospital in Madrid after falling from a horse. He was 54 years old and lived in London.

title: NBC's Debate Decision: No Applause Please
description: LEAD: The decision by NBC to wipe out 90 minutes of live television coverage of the Olympics to broadcast, instead, the first Bush-Dukakis Presidential debate has been hailed as a service for democracy. This service, noted so approvingly, lies in making the debate available to Americans who might otherwise not see it.

title: Review/Film; Schrader's 'Patty Hearst'
description: Patty Hearst, a k a Tania, a member of the self-styled Symbionese Liberation Army, and two of her S.L.A. comrades sit on a bed in an anonymous Los Angeles motel room and watch a ''live'' telecast as the police storm their S.L.A. hideout in another part of the city. Everyone in the house is finally killed. It's only by chance that Patty and the other two are not in the house.

title: The Life of a Weight Lifter Can Be Solitary and Painful
description: Before the American weight lifters came to Seoul, they gathered in a Los Angeles hotel room to drink beer and have their hair cut. A barber came to the room, set up shop in the bathroom and gave each of them the same punk coif, long on top, bristly on the sides. The lifters wanted the barber to cut little barbell-shaped patterns in their hair, but he told them he did not have the tools for custom work.

title: Thornburgh Assails A.C.L.U. As Having 'Political Agenda'
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh tonight accused the American Civil Liberties Union of adopting a ''political agenda'' that led him to resign from the organization sometime ago.

title: S.E.C. Assails Brokerages In '83 Default
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today harshly criticized securities firms for their practices in the 1983 default on muncipal bonds issued by the Washington Public Power Supply System.

title: Campaign Trail; Democrats Sport Fearsome New Look
description: A new button appeared Thursday on Capitol Hill: ''President Quayle.''

title: OLYMPIC HIGHLIGHTS
description: GYMNASTICS: Yelena Shoushounova of the Soviet Union, with a perfect 10 in the vault, won the women's all-around gold. She edged Daniela Silivas of Rumania by .025 point. TRACK: Jackie Joyner-Kersee set an Olympic record in the first event of the heptathlon, the 100-meter hurdles. Carl Lewis and Ben Johnson, the world record-holder, reached the 100-meter dash semifinals. TELEVISION: With ratings a disappointment, NBC will give advertisers a break. Articles begin on page D19.

title: Iran Clearing Mines
description: The Iranian Navy began mine-clearing operations in the Persian Gulf today, Iran's official press agency reported. When Iran announced last week that its forces would begin clearing mines, an American official said that was ''tantamount to admitting that they laid the mines'' during the eight-year-old war with Iraq. A United Nations-sponsored cease-fire in the war began Aug. 20.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Gymnastics; All-Around Title To Shoushounova
description: Combining the elegance of a prima ballerina with the stunts of a circus acrobat, Yelena Shoushounova of the Soviet Union commanded perfect 10s from the judges in the floor exercise and vault today to win the women's individual all-around gold medal in gymnastics.

title: Boston U. Relents on Schools
description: Boston University has backed down in its quest for near-total control over Chelsea's schools by agreeing to let the city's School Committee retain some power.

title: K Mart Recalls Scissors Sets
description: The K Mart Corporation is recalling 48,000 desk sets that could be dangerous to children, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today. The School Days Scissors Desk Set includes a cutting knife that could injure children, the agency said.

title: Review/Art; A Sculptural Circus Of Whips and Suspense
description: It does not take long before the initial amusement that overtakes a visitor to an exhibition of quirky kinetic sculptures by Rebecca Horn disappears, and a sense of considerable unease takes over. Entitled ''An Art Circus,'' it is a show not of clowns and prancing horses but of lion tamer's whips and high-wire suspense. With the timing of a master director and the precision of a Swiss watchmaker, Miss Horn orchestrates a grippingly theatrical event.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Chicago Man Kills 4 and Wounds 2 Before Dying in a Shootout
description: A man ''who never said a word'' shot and killed two people in an auto parts store here today, then fatally wounded a police officer and a custodian at a nearby school before the police killed him.

title: Our Towns; Tough Watchdog Is Bogged Down In Political Mire
description: Twenty years ago, leaders from three New York counties joined with three Pennsylvania counties across the border to take advantage of a new Federal grant program. They formed a regional health-planning agency, NY-Penn. Key goals were reducing health-care costs by preventing the overbuilding of hospital beds in the area and making sure that local hospitals planned care for their share of the poor.

title: Yanks vs. Red Sox in Revival
description: Outside, under a setting sun, the faithful at Fenway Park rose together and cheered; the Yankees had been left in a heap. Inside, the Boston Red Sox gathered in the comfort of their clubhouse and smiled. If there had been champagne somewhere, corks surely would have popped.

title: TV Weekend; Townsend and Friends
description: Last December, Robert Townsend got his very own television special. Transmitted live as part of Home Box Office's ''Comedy Hour'' series, it was called ''Robert Townsend and His Partners in Crime.'' Now, using basically the same format, HBO is presenting, taped, ''Take No Prisoners: Robert Townsend and His Partners in Crime II.'' The new show makes its debut on the pay-cable service tomorrow night at 10.

title: Campaign Trail; Brown Considers Producing a Sequel
description: Hollywood loves comebacks.

title: Nine Are Injured as Engine Shard Punctures a Plane Near Albany
description: Nine people were injured when a metal piece from an engine sheared off a Pan Am Express airplane and punctured the skin of the aircraft as it approached the Albany County Airport Wednesday night, officials said yesterday.

title: 22 Held in New Pretoria Crackdown
description: At least 22 black trade unionists and anti-apartheid organizers have been detained and the activities of five others have been restricted in a nationwide security crackdown this week.

title: Canonie Environmental reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BRIEFS
description: * British Petroleum Co., London, postponed the initial public offering of its BP Gold Co. subsidiary because of the recent drop in the price of gold.

title: Inquiry Demanded In Gold-Mining Bid
description: Britain's opposition Labor Party demanded a Government inquiry into a huge takeover bid for the British gold-mining giant Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. as the stock exchange looked into possible insider trading in its shares. Luxembourg-based Minerals and Resources, known as Minorco, which is 60 percent owned by Anglo American and De Beers Consolidated Mines of South Africa, made the biggest takeover bid in British history Wednesday, valuing Consolidated at $:2.9 billion ($4.9 billion). Consolidated rejected the offer as ''ludicrous.''

title: U.S. Administration Claims Some Credit For U.N. Successes
description: As President Reagan prepares to address the United Nations General Assembly, the Administration is trying to share credit for the United Nations' recent successes, arguing that its earlier criticism and the withholding of the United States' dues has brought results.

title: U.S. Pupils Get Low Mark in Science
description: American pupils' understanding of science has improved slightly, but it remains ''distressingly low'' and threatens American economic and social progress, a major new educational study concludes.

title: 'Messing With Their Turnstiles'
description: All the improvements in New York subway service brought by Robert Kiley and David Gunn are imperiled by a new trend: seizure of turnstiles by thieves and thugs. The heads of the Transit Authority need to respond as forcefully as they did to the defacing of cars with graffiti.

title: Victory for McDonnell: Big Order From Delta
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation won a badly needed victory today when it beat out the Boeing Company for most of a huge aircraft order from Delta Air Lines.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 452 money market mutual funds increased $654.2 million, to $267.24 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 126 institutional funds rose $496.9 million, to $69.06 billion. The 223 general purpose funds fell $102.4 million, to $84.82 billion. The 103 broker-dealer funds rose $259.7 million, to $113.36 billion.

title: Sports People; Leyland Seeks Security
description: Manager Jim Leyland, who has guided the Pittsburgh Pirates to second place this year, has let it be known that he is seeking the longterm security of a two-year contract when the third of his one-year agreements runs out at the end of the season. Management seems completely receptive to the idea. ''He's done a marvelous job,'' said Carl Barger, the Pirates' president. ''I would have no problem with that. I couldn't be higher on him.'' Barger also indicated that he would like to rehire Leland's entire coaching staff of Ray Miller, Gene Lamont, Milt May, Tommy Sandt and Rich Donnelly. Leland, who reportedly made $125,000 last year when the average for a National League manager was $287,000, is believed to be seeking $250,000 annually for two years. ''I don't care what anybody else gets,'' he said. ''I just want to be satisfied for myself. I just want what I think is fair. ''I think I've proved something. So it's up to them. They gave me the opportunity and I think I've earned it.''(AP)

title: Grey on Trombone
description: Al Grey, a trombonist, will lead a quartet tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1,432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., with a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7.50 minimum at tables and $0 admission at the bar.

title: Holding in Lonrho Is Frozen by Court
description: Lonrho P.L.C., a British mining and hotel conglomerate, obtained a court order freezing a block of its stock controlled by the New York speculator Asher B. Edelman. The freeze order is effective until a full trial, but Mr. Edelman can ask the court to lift the temporary order. Mr. Edelman said in New York that he would appeal the ruling.

title: Bellwether Exploration Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Comparable prior year figures not applicable; company switched its year-end to June 30 in 1987 from Dec. 31 in 1986.

title: Baptist Agency Won't Give Out Report on AIDS
description: An agency of the nation's largest Protestant denomination has decided to stop distributing the Surgeon General's report on AIDS because it does not reflect the group's conviction that only heterosexual relations within marriage are moral.

title: 70,000 Serbs Vent Anger at Officials
description: About 70,000 Serbians braved a steady rain and fields of mud after the factories closed in this Serbian industrial town this afternoon to cheer speakers and shout slogans.

title: W. R. Higginbotham Ex-News Executive, 74
description: W. R. Higginbotham, a former correspondent and news executive for United Press, died Wednesday at District of Columbia General Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Fort Worth.

title: Campbell Gets New Chairman
description: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that its board had named Robert J. Vlasic to succeed William S. Cashel Jr. as chairman.

title: Films Evoking Global Themes Open the New York Festival
description: ''MOVIES may be in their last flowering,'' the great French director Marcel Ophuls surmised recently, when asked to reflect upon the emergence of a world cinema in which many of the finest films seem to share an international perspective. ''It could be a final flowering like the Austrian Empire when things were about to go under, or France before the French Revolution,'' Mr. Ophuls continued. ''In those instances, there was a sort of neurotic, sensitive feeling among artists to what was happening around them. Right now, this feeling may be centered around movies because both collectively and as a form of individual expression they are particularly threatened.''

title: Sam Woodyard Dies; Jazz Drummer Was 63
description: Sam Woodyard, one of three major drummers who played in Duke Ellington's orchestra, died of cancer Tuesday in a Paris hospital, friends reported. He was 63 years old and had lived in Paris since 1975.

title: About Real Estate; Dispute Over Connecticut Site Ends
description: A fiercely debated redevelopment site in Greenwich, Conn. - the 20-acre Electrolux factory site next to the Old Greenwich Metro North station - is finally entering the construction phase.

title: PARTS OF ARMENIA ARE BLOCKED OFF BY SOVIET TROOPS
description: The authorities deployed troops and armored vehicles today in Yerevan, the Armenian capital, in the latest move to contain spreading ethnic unrest in two Soviet republics.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Boxing; Anger by Koreans Over '84 May Have Spurred Outburst
description: It might have been surprising that two South Korean boxing officials climbed into the ring and attacked a referee Thursday, but it was perhaps inevitable. South Korean officials have been sensitive about closely contested bouts since the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles, when American fighters were beneficiaries of several favorable decisions, a couple at the expense of South Korea.

title: Review/Film Festival; Concentric Eccentricities in Almodovar Tale
description: It hasn't been Pepa's day, or even week. Ivan, her longtime lover and a male-chauvinist rat, walks out on her, leaving only a bland message on her answering machine. Planning suicide, Pepa spikes a blenderful of garden-fresh gazpacho with sleeping pills, but forgets to drink it.

title: 'Plow' and 'Butterfly': New Leads, New Light
description: Though David Mamet's ''Speed-the-Plow'' and David Henry Hwang's ''M. Butterfly'' were among the most highly acclaimed productions of last season, the praise was balanced, at times even drowned out, by dissonant strains of ridicule. Gregory Mosher, the director of ''Speed-the-Plow,'' took his lumps for the seemingly hypocritical casting of Madonna in a play that mocks the kind of cynical Hollywood moguls who wouldn't think twice about casting Madonna as Eleanor Roosevelt. ''M. Butterfly'' was nailed for an ostensible credibility problem. How could its protagonist, a French diplomat named Gallimard, carry out a 20-year affair with a Beijing Opera diva without realizing that ''she'' was a he? Mr. Hwang seemed to be asking an audience not merely to suspend but to extinguish disbelief.

title: Univar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Review/Concert; Brass Sounds, From Medieval To the Modern
description: Solid Brass, an ensemble composed mainly of players in New York's dance and opera orchestras, played a concert at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon and proved itself not only virtuosic but also imaginative. In a suite of medieval pieces that opened the concert and in a Wagner excerpt that began the second half, the 11 players were deployed in several groups -onstage, in the wings and in the hall's corridors - but their coordination was unfailingly precise.

title: Review/Film; Saving Africa's Gorillas
description: When Sigourney Weaver, as the naturalist Dian Fossey, is first seen arriving in Africa, she towers over everyone else in view. A trim, impatient, utterly confident white woman, she is instantly at home giving orders to the impoverished black tribesmen who gather around her. This supreme self-assurance of Miss Weaver's, sometimes less than helpful in other films, is perfect for ''Gorillas in the Mist,'' the story of a smart, determined, well-bred and physically commanding woman who brooks no frailty in others. Like Katharine Hepburn, who might well have played this part if Dian Fossey had lived earlier, Miss Weaver was made for such a role.

title: 25 Grants Go to Arts Projects
description: Twenty-five long-range projects intended to advance the arts nationally have been awarded grants totaling $9 million by the National Endowment for the Arts, it was announced yesterday.

title: Blount Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Beds in the Street
description: Beds are the competition in an offbeat race to be held Sunday at the South Street Seaport, starting at noon. Five-person teams, in costume, will roll decorated beds down Water Street in an effort to reach the finish before an alarm clock rings. Live music will be played along the way. Awards for the fastest team, best costumes, decorations and team spirit will be presented during a cruise aboard the steamboat De Witt Clinton, which will leave the Seaport at 4 P.M. and return at 8. Admission to the Great Bed Race is free; tickets for the cruise are $25 for adults and $10 for children under 16. The event is a benefit for muscular dystrophy. Information: 557-9366.

title: Carl F. Farbach, 87, A New Deal Lawyer
description: Carl Frederick Farbach, a retired lawyer and former Federal counsel, died of cardiopulmonary arrest Sept. 15 at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 87 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Grass Is Greener For Foreign Horses
description: It's that time of year again: horses with mediocre form in Europe are piling onto airplanes to plunder America's richest grass races. This year, even more than in the past, they are likely to come away with most of the booty, beginning with the $596,000 Man o' War Stakes tomorrow at Belmont Park.

title: Burma Crackdown: Army in Charge
description: Brute force appears to be succeeding in Burma, at least for the moment, in cowing a population that had begun prematurely to sense victory over its Government.

title: Columbia to Start 3 More Sophomores
description: To get more life into his Columbia team, Coach Larry McElreavy will start three more sophomores tomorrow against Lafayette at Baker Field, bringing to seven the sophomores in the lineup.

title: House Panel Seeks to Penalize Iraq for Gas Use
description: Over the objections of the Reagan Administration, the House Foreign Affairs Committee approved legislation today that would impose economic sanctions on Iraq as a penalty for the use of chemical weapons against Kurdish guerrillas.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Roundup; Finn Misses Chance For 4th Rowing Gold
description: Pertti Karppinen, the Finnish singles sculler who is a three-time Olympic champion, won his race in the consolation finals of Olympic rowing Friday. It placed him seventh in the competition.

title: Sequencers: Putting Careers on Hold
description: The trapped housewife was replaced by superwoman, who somehow managed to rear her children while catapulting ahead in a career. Now, with legions of superwomen worn out and discontented, a new model has been suggested for married professional women: ''the sequencer.'' Some experts are already warning that the sequencer is just another doomed variation of women trying to do it all.

title: JAPANESE PROTEST SLUR FROM BRITAIN
description: As Emperor Hirohito lay seriously ill, Japan filed a formal diplomatic protest in London today over items in the British press that called the monarch ''a worse butcher than Hitler'' and said that ''he will surely be guaranteed a special place in hell.''

title: Close-Up
description: Fencing Simple yet Complex Game It is a simple game to understand, but a difficult one to master: touch your opponent and avoid being touched. Five touches decide a match in early rounds, 10 in later rounds. Bouts are fought on a piste, a strip of metallic mesh 2 meters wide and 14 meters long for foil and 2 meters by 18 meters for epee and sabre. One director supervises all the action on the piste. All weapons are wired to a scoring machine that registers touches. Keep an Eye on . . . .

title: A Very Rare Collection With a Rarer Mandate
description: ''The humanities may not receive as much attention as politics but they are alive and well in Washington,'' Hermione de Almeida said from her study in the Smithsonian Institution's red sandstone castle on the Mall.

title: Giants' Manuel Catches a Healthy Break
description: Three games into the season, Lionel Manuel has emerged as one of the National Football Conference's most productive receivers.

title: 4 Suspects in Killing Freed
description: Four suspects in the killing of a 19-year-old man and the wounding of an 18-year-old woman in Brooklyn Wednesday were released yesterday. The police recovered a 9-millimeter pistol, which they believe was used to shoot Robert Nepolitano of Brooklyn and Lisa Ciullo, also of Brooklyn, who was hit in the leg. Eight shell casing were also found. The victims were shot as they sat in a parked car at West 10th Street and Avenune at 8 P.M., Wednesday.

title: A Rite of Purification, A Plea for Forgiveness
description: Wearing the purple vestments of a Mass for forgiveness, John Cardinal O'Connor strode rapidly up and down the aisles of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, sprinkling holy water throughout the church in which two men were killed the evening before.

title: McCarthy Will Be on Ballot For President in Four States
description: Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said today that he would appear on the November ballot in Michigan, Minnesota, New Jersey and Pennsylvania as a candidate for President.

title: Lawyer Fighting Hunts Sees Delay Tactics
description: Mark A. Cymrot, the lawyer who won a suit charging the Hunt brothers with conspiring to corner the world's silver market, was a stranger to the commodities markets before the trial and had to verse himself in their intricacies before proceeding.

title: The Panic That Gripped Jaffa in April 1948
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Police Ruse at Kennedy Airport Trips Up High-Charging Cabbies
description: Twenty of 50 medallion cabdrivers who picked up undercover investigators posing as Asian tourists were arrested yesterday for overcharging their passengers by as much as $75 on trips from Kennedy International Airport to the World Trade Center.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; FKB Group to Acquire 2 More U.S. Companies
description: Britain's FKB Group, a holding company for sales promotion and marketing services companies, is adding two more companies to the four it acquired in the United States in March.

title: Nicaraguan Cancels Planned Trip to U.S. Over a Visa Dispute
description: Nicaragua announced tonight that President Daniel Ortega Saavedra would not visit the United States as planned in the coming days because the State Department had refused to grant visas to all members of his 60-member delegation.

title: At the Movies
description: Twins in Toronto

title: Garbage Disposal Needs More Than Tough Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Henry Kaiser on Guitar

title: Sale of Steel Plant to Iraq Is Called Off
description: The Government of Iraq has failed to conclude a contract with the USX Corporation to buy an idle steel works in Texas and ship it back to Iraq, the company said today.

title: NBC to Give Free Air Time
description: NBC's ratings for the Olympic Games have been so disappointing during the first week that the network yesterday began the process of ''make-goods'' for most of its more than 70 sponsors. That is the industry term for free advertising to compensate for lower-than-projected ratings.

title: MINIMUM WAGE BILL STALLED IN SENATE
description: Senate Republicans today blocked an effort by Democrats to limit debate on a proposed increase in the minimum wage.

title: TV Weekend; Superpower Rivalry
description: Are Soviet-American relations taking a new turn, owing to the much- celebrated changes now stirring the Soviet Union? ''Global Rivals,'' a thoughtful four-part series that begins tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13, sets out to address the question with a review of the beginnings of the Cold War and the competition of the superpowers ever since.

title: 'Violence Against Homosexuals Is Also Evil'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Games at a Glance
description: Track and Field After running more than 26 miles, Rosa Mota won it in a walk. Mota, the world champion from Portugal, easily won the women's marathon, jogging the final 100 meters with a raised fist and shining smile. Mota, who finished third at the Los Angeles Games in 1984, completed the course in 2 hours 25 minutes 39 seconds. Lisa Martin of Australia captured the silver and Kathrin Doerre of East Germany the bronze. In other events during the first day of track and field competition, Jackie Joyner-Kersee built a 101-point lead after two events in the women's heptathlon. Carl Lewis and Ben Johnson advanced to the semifinals in the men's 100-meter dash. Swimming It is a reversal of the standard behavior at wishing wells, but it has nonetheless allowed Matt Biondi's dreams to come true. Biondi takes gold and silver out of the water at Olympic Park. The American swimmer won his fourth medal of the Games when he finished first in the men's 100-meter freestyle. Biondi, who has a chance to come home with seven medals, won his second gold in an Olympic record time of 48.63 seconds. In women's competition, Janet Evans, acknowledged as something of an aerobic wonder, had her breath taken away when she got a look at the clock after the 400-meter freestyle final. Evans, the California high school senior, shaved an astonishing 1.6 seconds off her world record, finishing in 4 minutes 3.85 seconds for her second gold of the competition. Volleyball The United States women, already in trouble in their effort for the gold medal, found themselves in danger after four games against Brazil. However, they managed to remain in the race for medals. The Americans won the final game against Brazil to complete a 14-16, 15-5, 15-13, 12-15, 15-7 victory. Gymnastics Yelena Shoushounova stood at one end of the long runway to the vault understanding that anything less than perfection would have meant something less than gold. Shoushounova then promptly nailed her vault and got to hang the top medal from her neck. The Soviet gymnast produced a perfect 10 in her final apparatus to capture first place in the women's individual all-around competition. Rumania's Daniela Silivas was just .025 points back in claiming the silver. Weight Lifting The Bulgarians, who have dominated both the competition and the headlines concerning drugs at these Games, won another gold medal when Borislav Guibikov took first place in the 165-pound class. His combined total of 805 pounds easily topped the silver medalist, Ingo Steinhoefel of East Germany. Boxing The bout was rough, but not nearly as ugly as what followed. South Korean boxing coaches attacked a New Zealand referee after one of their boxers lost a decision to a Bulgarian boxer. Water bottles and at least one chair were thrown into the ring as referees, coaches and competitors roamed the canvas in confusion. The judges had awarded Aleksandr Hristov a 4-1 decision over Bun Jong Il in a 119-pound fight. Five South Korean boxing officials were suspended from the Games for their roles in the incident.

title: Unisys Loan of Computers Is Said to Be Under Scrutiny
description: The Army and a Congressional committee are investigating whether the Unisys Corporation illegally supplied computers to the National Guard in 1986 without having received a valid order for the equipment, committee officials say.

title: An F.T.C. Rule Is Reviewed
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it would consider easing rules covering purchases of 10 percent or less of a company's stock.

title: Isco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The latest fourth quarter results were after a LIFO inventory charge of $229,000. All share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 20 percent stock dividend of June 17, 1988.

title: MILITARY CABINET NAMED IN LEBANON
description: President Amin Gemayel appointed a military government headed by a Christian general to rule Lebanon today after a deeply divided Parliament failed to choose a successor for him on the last day of his six-year term.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amoco Corp., Chicago, a holding company for energy concerns, elected William R. Hutchinson treasurer, replacing James E. Allard, who was named senior vice president for finance at Amoco Canada in Calgary, Alberta.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Women's Marathon; Mota of Portugal Runs to the Gold
description: Rosa Mota of Portugal increased her stature as one of history's best female marathoners by winning her speciality today in 2 hours 25 minutes 39 seconds and earning the first gold medal in the track and field phase of the Summer Olympics.

title: Abe Greene, 89, Dies; Jersey Boxing Official
description: Abe J. Greene, the Paterson, N.J., newspaperman and ring official who was credited with cleaning up boxing in New Jersey and turning the state into a major venue for the sport, died of heart failure yesterday at Barnert Memorial Hospital in Paterson. He was 89 years old.

title: 'Yankee Panky'
description: ''Manifest Destiny: An Evening of Yankee Panky,'' is a musical comedy about United States involvement in the Philippines at the turn of the century, written by someone with definite expertise on the subject. Raul S. Manglapus, the Secretary of Foreign Affairs of the Philippines, wrote the work in 1974 during a self-imposed exile in the United States. Performances are tonight at 8 o'clock and tomorrow at 3:30 and 9 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. Tickets are $35, $25 and $18. Reservations: 662-2133.

title: Israelis Open Fire on Arabs, Wounding 24
description: Israeli troops fired live ammunition and plastic bullets today to put down widespread Palestinian unrest, including an attack by masked, ax-wielding youths. Twenty-four Palestinians were wounded, Arab hospital officials said.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Unisys Corporation yesterday priced $200 million of 9 percent notes, due 1993, through competitive bidding.

title: Lewis and Johnson Are Ready
description: They have been running against each other since 1980, and Carl Lewis holds a 9-6 edge outdoors over Ben Johnson, the 100-meter world-record holder. But on Saturday morning here in the Olympic Stadium, they will burst out of the starting blocks in a 100 that each hopes to burn into track-and-field history.

title: Liberalism Just Isn't the Same as It Used to Be
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Violence Against Homosexuals Is Also Evil'; Patchwork Garment
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Love and Unhappiness in 'Sweet Hearts Dance'
description: Susan Sarandon, Jeff Daniels and Elizabeth Perkins play residents of a small, picturesque, rather too ingrown Vermont village in ''Sweet Hearts Dance,'' and Don Johnson is there, too. So there arise some blunt but inevitable questions: can Mr. Johnson hold his own in this company? Has television stardom made him too much of a commodity to fit comfortably into an ensemble film like this? Will there be large-screen life for him after ''Miami Vice''?

title: E.P.A. Sets Strategy to End 'Staggering' Garbage Crisis
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced a broad strategy today to cope with what it called a ''staggering'' garbage crisis, setting a target of reducing the nation's solid waste by 25 percent within four years through recycling and other methods .

title: EX-OFFICER GUILTY IN DEATH OF AGENT
description: A former Mexican police officer was found guilty by a Federal jury today in the 1985 kidnapping and murder of a United States drug law-enforcement agent.

title: Animed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $9,081 for the quarter and $794,160 for the 9 months. c-After a gain of $42,428 and a loss of $244,231 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations.

title: Campaign Trail; Democratic View From the Outside
description: For weeks, senior Democrats have been saying it privately: Although the Dukakis campaign has finally begun to lift itself out of its August torpor, the effort has failed to reach out to Democratic leaders across the nation. And it's hurting Mr. Dukakis. Now, some Democrats are saying so publicly.

title: Soaring Mets Capture Title With a Flourish
description: For the second time in three years, the Mets marched to the championship of the National League's East last night, and they did it with a fury as they won their 8th straight game, the 13th in their last 14 and the 23d in their last 28.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball

title: Seabrook Plant Faces New Test
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday that the Seabrook nuclear plant could not conduct low-power tests until its principal owner, which has filed for bankruptcy protection, could demonstrate its ability to pay for decommissioning the plant if no operating license was granted.

title: PNC to Acquire Delaware Bank
description: The PNC Financial Corporation, an aggressive super-regional banking company based in Pittsburgh, said today that it would acquire the Bank of Delaware Corporation, the second-largest banking company in the state, for $230 million in stock. ''The merger will expand

title: Tax Act's Corporate Effect
description: The landmark 1986 tax revision increased the total taxes paid by 250 of the nation's largest corporations by $9 billion last year, but 16 of the corporations surveyed legally paid no Federal income tax, a private research group said today.

title: Fighting for Ali
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a sometimes pugnacious Utah Republican, has proposed relief for the always pugilistic Muhammad Ali, but he has pulled his punches for now.

title: House Panel Deals Blow To Bank-Powers Effort
description: The banking industry's quest to win new securities powers suffered a severe setback today when a House committee voted to prohibit banks from underwriting corporate debt, corporate equities and mutual funds.

title: College Football; Georgia Planning to Control South Carolina Passer
description: Coach Vince Dooley and his Georgia team were not too pleased when they escaped with a 42-35 triumph over Mississippi State last week. It should have been easier for the undefeated Bulldogs, who are thinking of a Southeastern Conference championship.

title: A Killer in St. Patrick's: Hospital to Jail to Death
description: The huge man shot down as he raged murderously in St. Patrick's Cathedral Wednesday evening was described yesterday as a severely disoriented street dweller who had been arrested at least 11 times and hospitalized as a mental patient 7 times.

title: Pan Am Matches Deals Offered By American Air
description: The airlines' battle for North Atlantic passengers grew more intense yesterday as Pan American World Airways lowered advance-purchase requirements and cancellation penalties to match moves made by American Airlines.

title: Massachusetts Updates Mental Health System
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday RV Superstores reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Second Rude Surprise at Honeywell
description: For the second time in three months, Honeywell Inc. has surprised investors with news of substantial write-offs. With Tuesday's announcement, the Minneapolis-based manufacturer conceded that its earnings for the year would decline as a result.

title: Setbacks For Drexel In 2 Courts
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. suffered several court setbacks yesterday in its defense against the huge securities fraud case filed earlier this month by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Rent-Law Chief Held on Charges In Bribe Inquiry
description: The state official in charge of enforcing New York City's rent-control and rent-stabilization laws was arrested yesterday in Manhattan on bribery and grand larceny charges stemming from an undercover operation organized by the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: In Absence of Widespread Standards, Local Officials Decide the Programs
description: Pilots and the airline industry are controlled by the Federal Aviation Administration. Nuclear power plants are overseen by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Teachers, barbers, accountants, architects and electricians need licenses or certificates to work in most states.

title: Review/Film; A Family Stays Nervous Once You've Shot Dad
description: Patrick Swayze, lately of ''Dirty Dancing,'' gets a chance in ''Tiger Warsaw'' to be brooding and boyish, soulful and shaky and to show off his chest. He plays a fellow in his early 30's who returns home 15 years after having made a mess of the family household and tries to pick up the pieces. What the young Charles (Tiger) Warsaw did, we gather through quick flashbacks, was shoot his dad after being caught peeping at his sister, who was in her undies at the time. He is eye-wateringly contrite, but the reception is heated rather than warm.

title: American Greetings Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Campaign Trail; Importing Help To Get Last Word
description: As Vice President Bush and Governor Dukakis curtail campaigning and prepare for their nationally televised 90-minute debate Sunday in Winston-Salem, N.C., both sides are looking toward that all-important post-debate spin. That is, sending high-profile surrogates into the press room to feed reporters and tell them that their candidate was, well, nothing short of Lincolnesque. The Democrats are sending a plane Sunday to Winston-Salem loaded with such heavyweight spinners as Governor Cuomo and Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Xerox Unit Offers Notes Set at 9.35%
description: The Xerox Credit Corporation, a unit of the Xerox Corporation, tapped the corporate debt market yesterday with a $100 million issue of notes due 1993.

title: 3Com Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Executive Convicted in Asbestos Bribe Case
description: The president of a Brooklyn demolition company was convicted yesterday of giving payoffs to a Federal inspector to overlook violations of rules for asbestos removal and disposal.

title: Aides to Bush Rebut Report on Noriega
description: Aides to Vice President Bush moved swiftly today to combat a report that prompted a new round of questions about when Mr. Bush first learned of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's alleged involvement in drug trafficking.

title: Amplification Endangers Theater's Live Quality
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Policies For Schools Are Criticized
description: The New York City Board of Education has failed to do enough to teach children about the dangers of drug abuse and to establish standard anti-drug policies in the city's more than 1,000 public schools, Mayor Koch and the chief Federal drug agent in the state have charged.

title: Review/Theater; Writings of Passage
description: The plays presented in the annual Young Playwrights Festival have often dealt with young people going through rites of passage. In this season's festival (at Playwrights Horizons) there are indications that, at age 7, the series itself has reached its artistic maturity. Each of the three new playwrights whose works are produced demonstrates a definite theatrical talent, as well as an ability to treat perceptively such subjects as religion, sex and suicide.

title: Election Panel Seeks Stiffer Rules on Spending for Candidates
description: The Federal Election Commission today proposed new rules for a practice in which political parties channel millions of dollars that cannot be donated directly to candidates into efforts that benefit the candidates' campaigns.

title: Dynamics Research Corp reports earnings for 12wks to Sept 3
description: Year-ago shares outstanding are retroactively adjusted for the November 1987 stock distribution.

title: Atlantic Hurricane Monitored
description: Hurricane Helene's winds intensified to 100 m.p.h. today and forecasters warned Caribbean residents to keep a close watch on its movements even though it was still more than 1,000 miles east of Barbados, about four days' travel at the storm's current rate of speed. Storm trackers said the hurricane was expected to maintain its westward course for at least the next 24 hours and then might veer onto a more northerly path, missing the Caribbean.

title: Bush Leading Dukakis in 2 Polls; Defense Linked to G.O.P. Gains
description: Vice President Bush led Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts in two polls released today, and one of them, by NBC News and The Wall Street Journal, showed that one of Mr. Bush's greatest advantages over the Democratic Presidential nominee was on the issue of the national defense.

title: Bridge
description: There was a time when players would travel to a tournament and be content to play bridge for 7 hours in each 24. Nowadays, however, many enthusiasts choose to add morning or late-night games, or even both, to the normal afternoon and evening sessions. Team events are popular, in part because a group with five or six members is slightly better off in terms of sleep.

title: After the Olympics, Games of Another Kind Begin
description: This is a story about American athletic heroes from the New York metropolitan region and their hopes for victory in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Economic Scene; The Broad Protest On Strauss's Plan
description: ROBERT S. STRAUSS, the veteran Texas lawyer who serves as co-chairman of the bipartisan National Economic Commission, set off a storm this week when, at a Washington monetary conference, he disclosed his thinking about the combination of tax increases and cuts in military outlays and in Social Security and other entitlement programs required to eliminate the Federal budget deficit by 1992.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday OTHER PHILHARMONIC

title: Mark IV Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a gain of $3,172,000, or 29 cents a share, from asset sales. c-Included a gain of $8,624,000, or 79 cents a share, from securities transactions and asset sales. d-Included net income of $1,256,000, or 13 cents a share, from the sale of Baird Corp.'s common stock for the both periods and the quarter also included Conrac's results from May 1, 1987. The latest periods included Cetec Corp.'s results of operations from July 1. Both year-ago periods included Eagle Signal Controls' results of operations from June 1, 1987, and the 6 months also included Conrac's results of operations from May 1, 1987.

title: Mars Graphic Services reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income Mars attributed the loss in the latest quarter to the writeoff of a customer's accounts receivable balance of $467,724 as a result of involuntary bankruptcy.

title: Space Agency Says Proper Nozzle Rings Are in New Rockets
description: The space agency said today that the proper nozzle inlet rings were in the rockets attached to the space shuttle even thought it had been discovered that an outdated ring was used in the final test of the redesigned booster rocket for the shuttle.

title: Rev. Juvenal Lalor, 77, Ex-Chief of University
description: The Rev. Juvenal Lalor, a former president of St. Bonaventure University, died of complications following surgery at St. Anthony's Hospital in Warwick, N.Y., on Sunday. He was 77 years old and had lived in retirement at the Holy Cross Friary in the Bronx.

title: Sheldon Coleman Is Dead at 86; Led Lantern Concern for Decades
description: Sheldon Coleman, chairman of the Coleman Company, the family enterprise that created the Coleman lantern, died of pneumonia Wednesday at the Wesley Medical Center in Wichita, Kan., after complications from lupus, a skin disease. He was 86 years old and lived in Wichita.

title: Wide Use of Yonkers Tactic Unlikely, U.S. Official Says
description: While the Justice Department has firmly insisted that Yonkers comply with a court order to desegregate its neighborhoods, other communities have little reason to fear similar legal pressure, the head of the department's civil-rights division said this week.

title: Tough Penalties For Drug Abuse Voted by House
description: The House today overwhelmingly passed drug legislation embodying a range of civil penalties for people who use relatively small amounts of illegal drugs. The vote was 375 to 30, with 27 members not voting.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Haiti's Tabou Combo

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They break their legs in half, they break everything. These people struggle a hell of a lot more than the able-bodied athletes.'' - David Balsey, track coach, on American amputee athletes headed for Seoul. [ B2:2. ]

title: Number of AIDS Cases In New York Still Varies
description: State officials and nationally recognized authorities on AIDS who met in New York City yesterday failed to resolve the dispute over the number of New Yorkers infected with the deadly virus, but all agreed that services are woefully deficient and must be expanded to meet the growing caseload.

title: Market Place; Wall St.'s Worry About Pepperell
description: HOPING for a takeover battle, some Wall Street traders several months ago loaded up on shares of West Point-Pepperell, the big Georgia textile company. Now they are worried that Pepperell may not be a takeover target after all.

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Williams Is Out, Schroeder Is Gone, So Rypien Starts
description: Before the season opened, Doug Williams, the Washington Redskins' starting quarterback, said: ''The Lord knows I've had my ups and downs, but now I'm up and I want to stay up. Nobody has worked any harder than me to get here. It'll take a heckuva lot for me to lose this job.''

title: Curbside Concert
description: Michael Feinstein, the pianist and Gershwin expert, will give a curbside concert on Sunday at 3 P.M. on Fifth Avenue between 56th and 57th Streets, as part of the ''Love Your Landmarks'' block party. His repertory will consist largely of songs about New York. The festivities are sponsored by several preservationist organizations. An information booth will be available for New Yorkers to find whether they live or work in a landmark building. Information: the New York Landmarks Preservation Foundation, 861-4641.

title: Yonkers Told To Show Need For Church Site
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that Yonkers will have to establish a ''compelling need'' for a church-owned piece of property before condeming it for use as low-income housing in a desegregation plan.

title: How Robert Strauss Sinned
description: Robert Strauss, the prominent Democrat, was speaking simple truth. The way to shrink big budget deficits, he said, is to look for savings in the biggest programs, ''because that's where the money is.'' He hinted that the National Economic Commission, of which he is co-chairman, might cast its eye on Social Security. And that, Social Security being sacred at election time, produced a flaming reaction.

title: Quayle, on Foreign Policy, Cites Monroe Doctrine
description: Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, delivered the most substantive foreign affairs speech of his 1988 campaign today, offering a vision of ''a century of peace'' and warning Communist countries that the Monroe Doctrine was still ''alive and well'' in the Western Hemisphere.

title: I.M.F. Leader Criticizes Dollar's Rise
description: The managing director of the International Monetary Fund today criticized the dollar's recent rise, asserting that it would slow efforts to end the world's trade imbalances.

title: Bonds Fall After an Early Rise
description: Bond prices fell broadly but narrowly yesterday in subdued trading activity.

title: KEY RATES
Bush And the Courts
description: Does it make any difference who's elected President in November? Of course it does, but not perhaps on as broad a range of issues as the candidates and their most fervent supporters would have you believe.

title: Holders Accept LVMH Board
description: After months of a backstage struggle for control of the world's largest luxury-goods conglomerate, LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, shareholders today accepted the nomination of a 12-member supervisory board that will name a new management board on Monday.

title: Books of The Times; Retouched Portrait of a Young Poet
description: The Temple By Stephen Spender 210 pages. Grove Press. $15.95.

title: U.N. Chief, in South Africa, Gives Pledge on Namibia
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, came to South Africa today and offered his assurances that the United Nations would be impartial in assisting with the transition of Namibia to independence.

title: Honor Journal; Success Threatens Salmon Fishing
description: For two decades the economy of this village of 300 has been tied to the three-year life cycle of the coho salmon that begins life in a hatchery here. When nature returns the salmon to their natal stream each fall, so, inevitably, return the fishermen chasing the coho as they swim upstream to spawn and die.

title: William J. McCarthy, Book Dealer, 61
description: William J. McCarthy, president of Kroch's & Brentano, the oldest and largest bookstore chain in Chicago, died Tuesday of complications resulting from a liver transplant at the University of Chicago Medical Center. He was 61 years old and lived in Evanston.

title: Bush Proposes Defense Policy Based on Edge in Technology
description: Vice President Bush proposed tonight that the United States seek to counter the Soviet Union's advantage in conventional forces by not matching Moscow ''bullets for bullets'' but by more effective strategic planning that would take advantage of this country edges in technology and some weapon systems.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Courtyard Cafe and Bar

title: Macmillan Shifts on Bid
description: Macmillan Inc. said yesterday that its board had withdrawn its recommendation that shareholders accept the $85-a-share offer from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the buyout firm. The Kohlberg, Kravis bid is lower than a subsequent bid of $86.80 a share from Robert Maxwell, the British financier.

title: Amplification Endangers Theater's Live Quality; A Boon for the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Pallone Part of Inquiry
description: E. Stewart Jones Jr. of Troy, N.Y., an attorney representing Dave Pallone, has confirmed that the former National League umpire was questioned yesterday in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., as part of an investigation of a sex ring involving teen-age boys. ''There is an investigation under way. The D.A.'s office has not confirmed or denied that, but in fact it is involved,'' Jones said. No charges have been filed against Pallone, Jones said of the umpire, who took a voluntary leave of absence last week. David Wait, the Saratoga County District Attorney, would not confirm that his office had met with Jones and Pallone, maintaining his position of refusing to confirm investigations until ''an accusatory instrument or indictment'' were filed.
