title: Dow Falls 10.49 Points; Program Trading Cited
description: LEAD: Stock prices sagged yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial avergage fell 10.49 points to close at 2,080.01.

title: AM International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontiued operations of $15,644,000 and $28,471,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $5,030,000 for the quarter and $11,482,000 for the year. The company said the latest quarter and year income was reduced by $18,100,000 of non-recurring charges associated with its computer graphics business.

title: Episcopalians Prepare to Select Next Bishop of New York
description: Entering the final days of an exhaustive yearlong campaign, the Episcopal Diocese of New York is preparing to select a successor to its Bishop, the Right Rev. Paul Moore, since 1970 a New York institution with a national reputation.

title: POPE TO KEEP BAN ON WOMEN PRIESTS
description: In a long-awaited document on women's issues, Pope John Paul II will reaffirm his opposition to the ordination of women as priests, Vatican officials said today. The text is to be issued next week. The Pope also offers a vigorous defense of women's dignity as equal to men's, the officials said. The document was described by the officials as a theological and anthropological meditation on the roles that women play in the Roman Catholic Church and in secular society.

title: Savings Industry Losses Fall a Bit, to $3.6 Billion
description: Huge losses in the savings industry continued in the second quarter but at a slightly lower level, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Dining Out Guide: French, Downtown
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Au Troquet ** (April 5, 1985), 328 West 12th Street (924-3413) - Au Troquet, with its lettered awning and patterned lace curtains, captures the style of a neighborhood haunt on the Left Bank.

title: U.S., Studying Lebanon Options, Continues Calls for New Elections
description: Reagan Administration officials today continued to call for presidential elections in Lebanon despite the appointment of a military Government.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the Henley Group's plan to split into two companies, the Henley Group and the Wheelabrator Group, misstated the distribution of shares in the new Henley. For each 100 shares in the existing company, stockholders will receive 22 shares in the new Henley Group, as well as one-half share that will be redeemed in cash.

title: The Ordinaires
description: The Ordinaires, an instrumental rock band, will perform tonight at 9 and midnight at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $8.

title: FUNDS FOR BURMA SUSPENDED BY U.S.
description: The United States decided today to halt $12 million in aid to Burma to underline its displeasure over the shooting of unarmed protesters by the country's armed forces, a State Department official said.

title: Two Wrongs on Nicaragua
description: Jim Wright charges the Reagan Administration with conducting covert operations in Nicaragua that would provoke the Sandinistas into acts of repression. The aim of this policy, he says, is to undermine the Sandinista Government and undercut the peace negotiations with the contras.

title: A SAVINGS RESCUE LOOMS AS BIG ISSUE TO BE FACED IN '89
description: No matter who wins the Presidential election, a cure to the woeful financial shape of the nation's savings industry has moved to the forefront among the issues that Congress and the next President must tackle upon taking office.

title: Insider Case Plea Rejected
description: Fred Lee, the Taiwan-based businessman who is charged in an insider trading scheme in the United States, failed today to persuade a Hong Kong court to release $12.5 million to two of his companies.

title: Verbatim
description: Federal financing for the Legal Services Corporation, which provides lawyers for the poor, has diminished since President Reagan took office. In 1981, Washington appropriated $321 million; in 1988, after seven years of inflation, the figure was $306 million. In its Oct. 1 issue, The A.B.A. Journal asked the Presidential candidates what they view as the proper balance between programs like the Legal Services Corporation and the use of private lawyers who volunteer their time. Here are their answers: Bush

title: At The Bar
description: When Lesley Friedman grew fed up with life in her large Manhattan law firm, she sought out kindred spirits last year to work for her fledgling temporary placement service for lawyers. The young lawyer had no idea how many others were looking for an alternative to conventional careers, but in four days she received more than 1,000 resumes.

title: U.S. Budget Deficit Up 6%
description: The Federal Government posted a $23.08 billion deficit for August, up almost 6 percent from a year earlier, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Dukakis's Economics
description: A Dukakis administration would probably combine a Republican reliance on the private sector with a Democratic reliance on government to promote social and economic change. Page 34.

title: Dukakis Signs Jackson to Record Radio Spots
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, expanding his effort to court black voters, has signed up the Rev. Jesse Jackson for radio advertisements and named a prominent Jackson aide to his staff of advisers, the Governor's Presidential campaign organization said today.

title: Filibuster on $4.55 Wage Survives a New Assault
description: Senate Democrats failed today on a second attempt to stop a Republican filibuster of a bill that would increase the minimum wage by $1.20 over the next three years, to $4.55.

title: Defectors Reportedly Return
description: Theodore and Cheryle Branch, a couple from nearby Summit Township who emigrated to the Soviet Union last fall when he could not find work, have returned to the United States, Mr. Branch's mother said today.

title: Oracle Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
American Medical Tie Cut by Firm
description: Wedge Group Inc., a Houston investment firm controlled by Issam M. Fares, has sold its entire 7.27 percent stake American Medical International Inc., for $105.1 million. The investment firm is one of four shareholder groups that have been putting pressure on the Beverly Hills, Calif., hospital concern because of its lackluster earnings and its restructuring program. The group succeeded in removing Walter L. Weisman from his position as the company's chief executive.

title: Kathleen Collins, a Film Maker, Dies at 46
description: Kathleen Collins Prettyman, a film maker, playwright and professor of film history and production at the City College of New York, died of cancer Sunday at Memorial Hospital. She was 46 years old and lived in Nyack, N.Y.

title: Man Is Arrested in Brooklyn Auto Break-In
description: A Brooklyn man has been arrested and charged with breaking into the automobile of a woman who had been arrested two weeks earlier by a patrolman as she tried to retrieve her belongings from the man.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because the relevant data were lost in transmission, the Tracking the Markets chart does not appear today.

title: Olympics Worth Watching
description: The Olympics haven't captured America's attention this year the way they did in 1984, and not just because NBC's cameras flit around too much. Seoul can't hope to duplicate the excitement, or the hype, of games at home in California. And U.S. athletes can't hope to match the gold they got when the Russians stayed away. Still, the Games of the XXIV Olympiad appear to be the best ever.

title: NBC Faces a Tough Fight As Olympics Ratings Lag
description: Like some American athletes at the Summer Olympic Games, the National Broadcasting Company is finding that the competition is tougher than expected.

title: Invasion of Quayle Territory Proves Heady for Bentsen
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen today swung through the Middle Western territory of his Republican opponent, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, with a strong offensive on the issues of trade, Social Security and education.

title: Patents; New Designs For Sports Equipment: A Softer Baseball
description: Few balls can do as much injury as a baseball. This week, a California company, Incrediball Inc., won patent approval for a softer, safer ball made with a core of densely packed polyu rethane foam. Incrediball says the ball will rebound almost as well as a regulation hard ball but is safe enough to use indoors and has never been known to cause an injury. The company says its balls are being used in amateur games and in batting practice by some major league baseball teams.

title: Recalling Jean-Pierre Ponnelle, Who Brought Opera to Millions
description: To the Editor:

title: Agreement Said to Be Close For P.L.O. to Declare a State
description: After weeks of intense debate, the Palestine Liberation Organization is close to agreement on a formula for declaring a Palestinian state in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip that would seek to be placed under United Nations trusteeship and would not necessarily recognize Israel, according to the leader of the organization's most radical faction.

title: Louis D. Gualandi, 63, An Interior Designer
description: Louis D. Gualandi, an interior designer and a co-founder of Waterloo Village, a restoration in northwestern New Jersey, died of lung cancer yesterday at Morristown Memorial Hospital in New Jersey. He was 63 years old and lived in Waterloo.

title: Lee Ann Burnett Weds Thomas David Berman
description: The marriage of Lee Ann Burnett, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Jerome Burnett of Washington, Pa., to Thomas David Berman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian L. Berman of Glencoe, Ill., took place yesterday at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn. Judge John W. Reynolds of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin in Milwaukee performed the ceremony.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 15.

title: It's Showtime for Baby Whale
description: A Sea World killer whale went into labor minutes before showtime today and delivered her baby to the shouts and cheers of thousands of people who witnessed the birth. Park officials knew that the mother was pregnant but the baby arrived about a month sooner than they had expected.

title: KEY RATES
A New Pitch For Yellowstone
description: Officials at Yellowstone National Park hope that this summer's devastating fires will have the beneficial effect of drawing more tourists to the nation's oldest national park.

title: Electro Scientific Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Kroger Rejects 2 Bids And Backs Revamping
description: The Kroger Company, the huge Cincinnati-based supermarket chain, disclosed last night that it had rejected two hostile multibillion-dollar offers and had approved its own restructuring plan.

title: Patents; New Designs For Sports Equipment:
description: Standard sports can still generate attention from inventors.

title: Kaufman & Broad Home Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
German Cad, as Seen by 4 Women
description: ''Felix'' was conceived, it seems, as a somewhat solemn stunt of a movie but turns out to be a surprisingly jolly entertainment.

title: Truck Accident Spills Tar on Jersey Turnpike
description: Thousands of motorists were trapped for hours today on an elevated southbound section of the New Jersey Turnpike after an asphalt truck overturned and dumped liquid tar on two lanes of the three-lane road.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5, 28 Two groups claim to lead Lebanon now that the Presidency is vacant. A Christian-led Cabinet and a Moslem-led Cabinet each claimed to be the legitimate government, raising new fears of civil war. Page 1 Progress was reported in arms talks between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze toward resolving U.S.-Soviet differences that are holding up new negotiations on reducing conventional weapons. 1 A U.N. team may enter Namibia, South Africa said, to start planning the deployment of United Nations military and civilian personnel there once the territory's transition to independence begins. 2 A major cause of the Haitian coup last week was a terrorist attack against a church six days earlier. The incident appeared to undermine Government authority in the eyes of many citizens. 4 Salvadoran troops killed 10 peasants in a village 30 miles from San Salvador, relatives and neighbors of the victims say. A spokesman for the armed forces first said the villagers were ''subversives'' killed during ''fierce combat.'' 3 A furor has erupted in Nicaragua over a statement by the House Speaker, Jim Wright, that the C.I.A. is manipulating opposition political parties, which the Sandinistas say proves their much-repeated contention. 3 A provisional government in Chile would be established immediately by the oppostion if Gen. Augusto Pinochet does not win the plebiscite on Oct. 5, a Chilean Communist Party leader asserted. 3 A formula for a Palestinian state in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip that would seek to be placed under U.N. trusteeship and would not necessarily recognize Israel is close to being agreed upon within the P.L.O. 4 Thousands waited to wish Hirohito a speedy recovery from his illness, standing in a line that stretched for blocks outside the gates of the Imperial Palace to sign get-well messages. 5 A Mexican priest will be beatified by the Roman Catholic Church, making him the nation's first modern candidate for sainthood. Because the Government shot him 60 years ago, the action could also create political tensions. 4 National 6-8, 34-35 A House vote to limit textiles imported by the United States was 17 votes short of the two-thirds needed to override an almost certain veto by the President. The Senate approved the identical bill last week by 59 to 36. 1 A drug that induces abortions was approved for sale in France. The drug, RU 486, is expected to replace as many as half of all surgical abortions in France. 1 Michael Deaver was sentenced to a suspended three-year prison term, placed on probation, fined $100,000 and ordered to perform 1,500 hours of community service for lying about his lobbying activities. 1 Charred Yellowstone has new charm, official say. As nature restores the trees and meadows that have been destoyed by wildfire, tourists will be asked to visit ''nature's laboratory.'' 6 The House passed an AIDS bill that calls for spending $1.2 billion over three years to combat AIDS through testing, counseling and research. A previously approved Senate bill emphasizes education of the public. 6 The resignation from the A.C.L.U. by the Attorney General in 1969 was prompted, a member of the group at the time said, by a coming government appointment, not because he thought the group had a political agenda. 7 The Food and Drug Administration proposed that standardized absorbency testing and labeling for tampons be established to help women minimize their risk of toxic shock. 8 Sleep loss said not to harm medical residents' work 6 Navy instructor guilty of negligent homicide in death 6 Filibuster on minimum wage withstands second assault 7 U.S. charges executives in health care kickback scheme 8 Politics 34-35 Dan Quayle has not moved opinions toward one Presidential ticket or the other in one Midwestern town in Ohio, which is fortunate for Republicans because many voters do not think much of Mr. Quayle. 1 Michael Dukakis would not use taxes to pay for many of his Government programs, economists say, pointing to his three most important economic-policy proposals, which rely on businesses and the beneficiaries of his programs. 34 Bentsen invades Quayle territory 34 Regional 29-32 An operating license for Shoreham should be issued by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, a Federal licensing board recommended. 1 A sentence in the Howard Beach case was handed down to Robert Riley, a principal assailant, who was given a six-month jail term and ordered to perform 400 hours of community service. 29 Four inspectors were sentenced in New York City after having pleaded guilty to soliciting bribes. The sentences ranged from one to eight months in jail. 31 A State Senator was indicted in New York on five counts of fraud after an investigation into allegations that the senator, Richard Schermerhorn, had taken contributions from organized-crime figures. 30 An overhaul of electronic cab meters in New York City's 11,787 yellow medallion taxis to make it easier for passengers to tell if they are being overcharged is planned by the Taxi and Limousine Commission. 29 New York City revenues declined, creating a $71 million shortfall in July and August, the Koch administration reported, saying fiscal flexibility could be limited. 29 The usher at St. Patrick's Cathedral who was killed in the church by a deranged man Wednesday night, used to regale and worry his wife with stories about ''weirdos'' coming into the cathedral from the streets. 31 Comptroller Edward V. Regan of New York State was questioned on fund-raising records showing that many of his contributions in the last five years were from companies doing business with his office. 30 The Grateful Dead are in town, and their fans, known as Deadheads and recognized by their long hair and tie-dyed shirts, have been hanging out near Penn Station, perplexing afternoon commuters. 29

title: Gaming & Technology Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $565,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Ex-Teamster Chief Is Paroled On Condition of Cooperation
description: Roy L. Williams, a former head of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters who is serving a prison term for conspiracy to commit bribery, will be paroled Tuesday on the condition that he continue to cooperate with the authorities in criminal investigations, the Justice Department announced today.

title: I.R.S. Seeks a Halt To PTL Broadcasts In Bankruptcy Case
description: The Internal Revenue Service is trying to stop PTL's religious broadcasting because of financial problems.

title: Hauser Chemical Research Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Patents; New Designs For Sports Equipment: A 5-Bladed Boomerang That Flies Straight Back
description: J. Turner Hunt, an aeronautical engineer at the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, has invented a five-bladed boomerang that he says is easier to use than the original Australian type.

title: Lee Bouvier Radziwill Weds Herbert Ross, Film Director
description: Lee Bouvier Radziwill and Herbert Ross were married yesterday evening at the bride's home in New York by Justice E. Leo Milonas of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, First Department.

title: FEAR OF CIVIL WAR GROWS IN LEBANON
description: With the Presidency vacant, a Christian-led Cabinet and a Moslem-led Cabinet each claimed to be the legitimate government of Lebanon today.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Notebook; Korean Olympic Chief Quits
description: Kim Chong Ha, the president of the South Korean Olympic Committee, resigned today, saying he did so to take the responsibility for the boxing incident in which South Korean coaches attacked a referee.

title: Teleprobe Systems Inc reports earnings for Year to June 24
Western Waste Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Drug Agency Allowed to Use Bentsen Ranch in Operations
description: The family of Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, has allowed the Drug Enforcement Administration to use its Texas ranches and other properties in anti-drug operations, the agency said today.

title: Tokyo's on Its Toes for City Ballet
description: When the New York City Ballet last came to Tokyo, 30 years ago, Japan was still rebuilding from World War II and its ideas about dance leaned to the stately and slow.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was a very fair sentence, if I had been guilty.'' - Michael K. Deaver. [ 1:4. ]

title: Robb Shuns Personal Queries
description: Former Gov. Charles S. Robb of Virginia says he is tired of questions about his personal life and does not plan to answer any more questions about it as he campaigns for a seat in the United States Senate.

title: Roll-Call Vote in House on Tightening of Import Curbs
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 248 to 150 by which the House of Representatives today approved tightened curbs on textile, apparel and shoe imports. A ''yes'' vote was a vote for the restrictions. Voting ''yes'' were 186 Democrats and 62 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 49 Democrats and 101 Republicans. An ''x'' denotes those not voting. There are three vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA

title: Dow Up 10.67 Amid Listless Activity
description: Stock prices rose in moderate trading yesterday, but overall market activity was listless.

title: ISI Systems Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
Witness Says I.R.A. Suspects Were Killed as They Gave Up
description: A witness to the shooting deaths of three unarmed Irish Republican Army members in March swore before a coroner's inquest today that British soldiers shot two of them as they raised their hands to surrender.

title: Company Cited in Fatal Scaffold Collapse
description: A Bronx scaffolding company was cited yesterday for violations of the New York City building code in connection with the collapse of a portion of a block-long pedestrian shed that killed a 19-year-old student in Manhattan on Thursday.

title: A Portrait of Thatcher's England
description: A traveler from the country who is lost in London wanders into the flat shared by Cyril (Philip Davis) and Shirley (Ruth Sheen), and he has such a hard time going home that they wind up nicknaming him ''E. T.'' It's easy to see why the stranger, only a minor character drifting through Mike Leigh's ''High Hopes,'' is so drawn to these two. Cyril and Shirley, who travel about in matching motorcycle leathers, are an utterly spontaneous and unpretentious duo, which sets them in marked contrast to everyone else in Mr. Leigh's astute socioeconomic satire.

title: Long-Term Care in New York State Faces Many Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Official Sees Rate Stability
description: The chairman of the International Monetary Fund's chief policy-making committee said today that he thought the recent round of interest rate increases was over. H. Onno Ruding, who is also

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Gymnastics; Soviet Men on Another Roll
description: Seoul, South Korea, Saturday Sept. 24 - Soviet gymnasts added to their trove of gold medals today.

title: Pall Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The latest year's earnings included a gain equal to 18 cents a share on the sale of the air dryer business, and charges equal to 9 cents a share on distribution restructuring, that had been reported in the second and third quarters.

title: Olympic Memory
description: Rod Woodson, the left cornerback for the Pittsburgh Steelers, is having a little trouble with his concentration these days. His thoughts keep drifting to Seoul, South Korea, and the upcoming competition in the Olympic hurdle events. Woodson was a four-time Big Ten Conference 55-yard indoor hurdles champion at Purdue, but never competed outdoors until his senior year because of spring practice. He was timed at 13.29 seconds in the 110-meter hurdles, the fourth-best clocking in the world in 1987. After he was picked in the first round of the draft by the Steelers in 1987, he abandoned his Olympic hopes for a four-year contract worth $1.98 million. ''Yeah, I'd like to be there,'' Woodson said. ''I know a lot of guys over there. I've beaten a lot of those guys and a lot of them have beaten me.''(AP)

title: House Approves AIDS Bill By Overwhelming Margin
description: The House today passed a bill to combat AIDS through testing, counseling and research with a budget of $1.2 billion over three years. The vote was 367 to 13.

title: Nigerian Debt Accord
description: Nigeria has accepted terms of a deal to reschedule payment on $5.2 billion of its debt that delays principal repayments for up to 20 years on medium-term loans, Barclays P.L.C. of Britain said today. Barclays, with Citicorp, heads a group of creditor banks that has led negotiations on Nigerian debt. Banking sources said the agreement cuts Nigerian interest charges and closely matches conditions on recent Latin American accords.

title: Patents; New Designs For Sports Equipment: New Golf Ball May Make Putts Easier to Sink
description: The Acushnet Company in New Bedford, Mass., which manufactures 40 percent of the golf balls in the United States, has designed a ball that it hopes will allow golfers to line up a putt more easily.

title: The Candidates And Fun Power
description: As potential party animals, George Bush and Michael S. Dukakis rate about the same, although Mr. Dukakis would be more fun on a long trip and Mr. Bush would make a better dinner host, according to a poll taken for MTV, the music video cable network.

title: Jets to Start Criswell at Tackle
description: It appeared today that Jeff Criswell is going to be the Jets' starter at left tackle against the Detroit Lions on Sunday.

title: COPING: With the Common Cold
description: Cold season is here. Starting in late September, rhinoviruses, which live in the nose, leave millions of Americans coughing, sneezing and blowing their noses. There is no way to cure the common cold, of course, but there are some simple things you can do to help reduce the chance of becoming infected.

title: Sears-Postal Deal
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company and the United States Postal Service said in Chicago that Sears will open post office units in 10 Sears stores throughout the Chicago area and at one store in Madison, Wis., starting Oct. 7. If the one-year test proves successful, more postal units may be opened in other Sears stores. A Postal Service official said it was the first time that the service had established a contract with a national retailer.

title: Olympic Highlights
description: SWIMMING: Matt Biondi of the U.S. picked up his third gold medal and fifth medal of the Games, but he was being overshadowed by Kristin Otto of East Germany, who ran her gold total to four. In the 100-meter backstroke, David Berkoff of the United States bettered his world record in his qualifying heat.

title: On Refugees: Generous but Clumsy
description: Secretary of State George Shultz has promised to open America's doors to more refugees next year. This is welcome news, reaffirming the nation's commitment to help those seeking asylum. But there's a catch. Because Congress has already set a ceiling on financial aid, the new refugees will receive less help getting started than did many of their predecessors.

title: Navy Instructor Found Guilty In Recruit's Drowning Death
description: A court-martial today convicted a Navy instructor of negligent homicide in the drowning of a panic-stricken recruit who was forced under water in a training exercise here last winter. He was also found guilty of conspiracy to commit battery.

title: Philip Glass and David Hwang on a Science Fiction Excursion
description: Philip Glass has been accused, with some justification, of fulfilling his numerous commissions by cannibalizing his earlier material. Indeed, listening to the clusters of scores Mr. Glass unleashes periodically, one is often struck not only by the presence of the composer's trademark moves, but also by the fact that specific chord progressions and effects are frequently grafted from one work onto another and that harmonic turns that were striking in their original context seem lazily derivative the second or third time.

title: F.D.A. Is Seeking to Standardize Ratings on Tampon Absorbency
description: The Food and Drug Administration proposed today that standardized absorbency testing and labeling for tampons be established to help women minimize the risk of toxic shock, a syndrome characterized by high fever, vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness and rash.

title: Battle of Brains
description: A human brain will compete against an electronic one this weekend in a chess match at the New School, 66 West 12th Street. The Hitech computer, which can evaluate 165,000 chess positions a second and which has been ranked among the 100 top chess players in the United States, will accept the challenge of Arnold Denker, a chess grandmaster. Explanations will be provided by the Hitech's inventor, Hans Berliner; by Shelby Lyman, a television chess commentator, and by Edmar Mednis, a grandmaster. Spectators may watch in the same room, or may work out possible game moves on boards set up in an adjoining room. Hours are 1:30 to 6:30 P.M. today and tomorrow. Admission is $12 for each day's session. Reservations: 741-5690. Information: 741-5615.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Shultz and Shevardnadze Report Limited Progress on Cutting Arms
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said today that they had made some progress toward resolving differences that are holding up new talks on reducing conventional weapons.

title: Fax It Your Way
description: What makes fast food faster? A fax machine. There's one spewing out orders at the Burger King at 66 Newtown Road in Danbury, Conn., thanks to Fujitsu Imaging Systems of America. The company, whose headquarters are nearby, allows the restaurant to use a Fujitsu facsimile machine at no charge.

title: For Leaf Avalanches, Try a Power Blower
description: If you decide you have raked your last pile of leaves, you may be in the market for a power blower this fall.

title: 10 People Slain Near Salvador Village
description: Government soldiers rounded up 40 unarmed peasants in a village 30 miles from here, accused them of collaborating with leftist guerrillas and killed 10 of them with grenades and rifle fire on Wednesday, relatives and neighbors of the victims said today.

title: Control Data Earnings Outlook
description: The Control Data Corporation said it expects third-quarter results to be in the range of break-even to a modest loss, joining several computer companies that have recently downgraded their expectations for the quarter. Control Data also said its net earnings for the year will be ''significantly lower than expectations at midyear.'' The Minneapolis-based computer maker's stock slid $1.625 today, to $20.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: France and China Allow Sale Of a Drug for Early Abortion
description: France and China this week approved marketing of a new drug that induces abortion early in pregnancy, and two family planning experts said they believed an American company would soon apply for permission to market the drug in the United States.

title: Lonrho May Act To Defend Itself
description: Lonrho P.L.C., the British mining and hotels conglomerate that is under pressure from the United States corporate raider Asher B. Edelman, said it would not rule out a management buyout or selling of assets to defend itself. Mr. Edelman, a New York-based stock speculator, disclosed a 3.79 percent stake in the group Tuesday. On Thursday, Lonrho obtained a court order freezing Mr. Edelman's stake.

title: Bridge; Missouri team wins Royal Viking Pairs with 76 percent score.
description: The Royal Viking Pairs, the second of an annual series with instant match points, was played Thursday night at clubs throughout North America. Provisional winners, according to the American Contract Bridge League, were Virgil Anderson of Springfield, Mo., and Dale Burns of Rogersville, Mo., with a 76 percent score.

title: The Games at a Glance
description: Track and Field Everything else had been broken -the world record, the Olympic mark, the American standard - so Ben Johnson completed the amazing collection of physical performances by cracking something really surprising: a smile. Johnson, the superb sprinter from Canada, left Carl Lewis in his tailwind and his world record in the past when he won the men's 100-meter dash in a breathtaking 9.79 seconds. Then Johnson, a man who goes about the business of rewriting track history with a grim seriousness, allowed himself the smallest trace of a smile. Lewis's disappointment was considerably more obvious. Lewis, who had the fastest times by far in qualifying for the finals, was left in the blocks at the start and then only to stare at Johnson's back. In taking the silver in 9.92, Lewis had to console himself with a new American record. In all, four runners finished in under 10 seconds - the first time that has been done. Florence Griffith Joyner of the United States set an Olympic record in the women's 100 meters when she ran her quarterfinal heat in 10.62. Swimming This is Kristin Otto's first Olympics. It is also, she promises, her last. Indeed, it would probably be greedy (to say nothing of being unfair) were she to perform in another. Otto, a 22- year-old from East Germany, won her fourth gold medal yesterday when she set an Olympic record in the women's 100-meter butterfly. Otto, whose remarkable efforts have been somewhat lost in the blitz and glitz of attention detailing every stroke and statement of Matt Biondi and Janet Evans, earlier won gold medals in the 100-meter backstroke, the 100-meter freestyle and the 400-meter freestyle relay. She has two remaining events and a reasonable shot in each. Biondi claimed his fifth medal and third gold when he anchored the United States world-record performance in the 400-meter freestyle relay. Volleyball They have blamed early starting times for their sluggish play so far in the tournament. Somehow, though, the American men's team rises when it counts and as a result will awake tomorrow to find themselves assured of a place in the medal round. The defending world and Olympic champions overcame yet another lackluster start to defeat France, 17-15, 15-6, 15-13, and run their record to 4-0. They are likely to face the Soviet Union or Brazil in the semifinals. Boxing American boxers, having absorbed both shock and embarrassment earlier this week, have been hit with very little of anything lately. Kenneth Gould of Rockford, Ill., extended the Americans' recent ring record to 7-0 when he easily outpointed Alfred Addo Ankamah of Ghana for his second victory of the tournament. Weight Lifting Once again, the ink was barely dry in the record book before a test turned up positive. Anguela Guenchev, who set three world records in the 148-pound class, became the second Bulgarian to lose his gold medal and world records when analysis showed he had been using a banned diuretic. In the wake of the latest embarrassment, the entire Bulgarian weight-lifting team was withdrawn from the Games.

title: Jersey Insurance Official Suspended in Fraud Case
description: The general manager of the Joint Underwriting Association was suspended Thursday after being accused of illegally taking control of cars owned by the agency, selling them for profit and driving without insurance.

title: Orders Up By 6% for Durables
description: Orders for durable goods rose 6 percent in August, suggesting to analysts that recent signs of sluggishness in the economy were probably temporary.

title: Corrections
description: Two captions in highlights sections of the Television section last Sunday misidentified Michael Naranjo, who is featured in ''Bodywatching'' tonight at 9 on CBS. He is a sculptor from New Mexico.

title: Fed Voted Neutral Money Policy in August
description: The Federal Reserve's chief policy-making body voted, 10 to 1, in mid-August to forgo further credit-tightening moves until it could study the effects of a series of previous anti-inflation measures, including a half-point increase in the discount rate just seven days earlier.

title: Regan Is Questioned on Fund Raising
description: New York State Comptroller Edward V. Regan was closely questioned for three and a half hours yesterday about fund-raising memorandums and records that showed that more than 90 percent of the contributions to his campaigns in the last five years were from financial, legal and real-estate companies doing business with his office.

title: A.C.L.U. Member Disputes Thornburgh Account of Quitting
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's explanation of his reasons for resigning from the American Civil Liberties Union was disputed yesterday by a member of the group who was host of the 1969 meeting at which Mr. Thornburgh quit.

title: Income Gain Seen By Corning Glass
description: Corning Glass Works said its earnings for the quarter ending Oct. 9 will increase by $1.10 a share because of a one-time $50 million gain.

title: La Quinta Motor Inns Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
RESULTS PLUS;
description: Tennis 2 Italians Gain Semifinals: Laura Lapi and Cathy Caversazio of Italy moved into the semifinals of the $50,000 Clarins Open with victories yesterday over Marie-Christine Damas of France and Laura Garrone of Italy.

title: Commission Plans to Alter Taxi Meters
description: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission plans to overhaul the electronic meters in the city's 11,787 yellow medallion cabs in an effort to cut down on overcharging, the commission's acting chairman said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the Shroud of Turin incompletely described the pope who was told in 1389 that the shroud was a fraud. He was Clement VII, a claimant to the papacy who sat in Avignon in the 14th century, a time of schism in the church. His claim to the papacy was disputed, and he has been widely considered an ''antipope.'' A later Pope Clement VII reigned from 1523 to 1534; his claim to the papacy was undisputed.

title: Coniston May Make Bid for TW Services
description: Solving a 10-day-old Wall Street mystery, Coniston Partners said yesterday that it might seek to acquire TW Services Inc., a food services company based in New York.

title: South Africa clash Kills One
description: A black guerrilla wounded four South African soldiers with gunfire and a grenade before he was shot dead near the border with Mozambique and Swaziland today, the authorities said.

title: Furor in Nicaragua on C.I.A. Charges
description: A furor has erupted in Nicaragua over charges by the Speaker of the House, Jim Wright, that the Central Intelligence Agency is manipulating opposition political parties here.

title: Rales Brothers Urge Interco Shift
description: Pursuing their $70-a-share, $2.5 billion tender offer for Interco Inc., the Rales brothers of Washington said yesterday that they were disappointed with a competing $2.8 billion restructuring program announced Tuesday by Interco, which valued the offer at $76 a share.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 35.

title: Cordero to Serve Ban
description: When Angel Cordero Jr. was handed a 10-day suspension for careless riding in the closing days of the Saratoga meeting, the jockey immediately appealed the ruling and the ban was stayed. He said at the time that he was not merely trying to ride out the Saratoga meeting, where he eventually won his 13th riding title, but that he believed the suspension was unjust. Cordero withdrew his appeal yesterday and will serve the days from Sept. 26 through Oct. 5.

title: Carolina Freight Corp reports earnings for 12wks to Sept 10
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,590,388 from the sale of Intra-Texas operating authority.

title: Health Care Officials Charged in Kickback Case
description: Health care executives in several states and a health care provider have been indicted on Federal charges in connection with kickbacks in return for employee benefit contracts with businesses and labor unions.

title: From Afar, Both Candidates Are Environmentalists . . . But, Up Close, Dukakis Looks Better
description: LEAD: Judging only by the Presidential candidates' statements and made-for-TV stunts of the last few weeks, voters might easily conclude there isn't much to choose between the two on environmental issues. However, a longer look at their records on specific issues, such as acid rain, virgin forests and the oceans, reveals clear differences that weigh heavily in favor of Gov.

title: Secrecy Reigns as Debaters Prepare
description: At Vice President Bush's mock debates at his Victorian home here, Richard Darman mimicked Michael Dukakis with relish. At the end of Wednesday's 90-minute session, Mr. Darman, the former Treasury Department official who is now an investment banker, reached behind a curtain in the dining room that had been converted into a studio.

title: Food Lion Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
'Cannibal Tours' Film To Open Mead Festival
description: The mutual curiosity of a group of American and European tourists and cannibalistic inhabitants of Papua, New Guinea, is the subject of the film ''Cannibal Tours,'' which is to open the 12th Margaret Mead Film Festival on Monday at 6:30 P.M. at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street.

title: Trump-Griffin Pact
description: Donald J. Trump will pay about $29 million more for the unfinished Taj Mahal hotel-casino and Merv Griffin will contribute an additional $25 million in equity when he buys Resorts International Inc., the two men announced late Thursday. The two moves taken together will increase the amount of cash and reduce the amount of debt that Resorts will have after the various transactions are completed. Mr. Trump agreed to pay $18 million more for the 1,250-room Taj Mahal and to waive approximately $11 million of purchase price adjustments, effectively increasing his purchase price to $284 million. Mr. Griffin agreed to invest an additional $25 million in cash in the company.

title: Communist Back From Exile Alarms Chile Regime's Foes
description: When Volodia Teitelboim, the balding, graying ideologue of the Chilean Communist Party, came home this week, he had an emotional reunion with family and friends at the aiport and said how wonderful it was to see the Andes again.

title: Continental Given Tokyo Route
description: The Department of Transportation yesterday complied with a Federal court ruling and awarded a Seattle-Tokyo air route to Continental Airlines.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Roundup; U.S. Boxers Stretch Streak to 7
description: Kenneth Gould, who started the United States Olympic boxing team's winning streak, stretched it to seven bouts today.

title: Janice Shatton Is Wed To Frederick G. Tate
description: Janice O'Brien Shatton and Frederick G. Tate were married yesterday by Justice Richard W. Wallach in his chambers at the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in New York.

title: William Shaw, 79, Ex-Du Pont Economist
description: William H. Shaw, a retired economist for E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company who was an Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs in the Johnson Administration, died of cancer Sept. 10. He was 79 years old and lived in Annapolis, Md..

title: Price of Oil Is Off Sharply On Fears of OPEC Failure
description: The price of oil fell sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with traders doubting the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will make any progress toward cutting production and raising prices.

title: About New York; He Takes Care Of Everything But Home Runs
description: Nothing is more special than New York teams winning the big games. So it was at 10:12 Thursday night. Ron Darling whizzed a strike past the Phillies' Lance Parrish, and in seconds was buried beneath a screaming, squirming, slap-happy pile of Mets. The championship of the National League East was right back here in this Big League town where it belongs, and the night had become magic.

title: State Power vs. God's Glory: Of Saints and the Not So Saintly
description: On Sunday in Rome, Pope John Paul II will beatify a Mexican priest named Miguel Agustin Pro, thereby providing this country with its first modern candidate for sainthood. But an occasion that in most places would be cause for national celebration is being treated gingerly by both church and state here.

title: Letter: On University Investments; No Dollar Signs in Researchers' Eyes
description: To the Editor:

title: Sleep Loss Said Not to Hurt Work of Medical Residents
description: A new study indicates that medical residents' work is not affected by their getting little sleep.

title: GOING FOR THE INGOTS
description: Professional money managers have stepped up their emphasis on gold as part of a diversified investment portfolio. For the small investor, investments in gold can come in the form of mutual funds, gold stocks, coins or ingots. The rate of return can be attractive, but experts say fortunes change quickly and advise a conservative 5 percent investment in precious metals during stable economic periods to about 10 percent if inflation is heating up. Gold funds were among the biggest winners of all investments in 1987, averaging a return of 35.66 percent. However, in the first falf of 1988, as inflation jitters eased, these funds showed a negative return of 17.8 percent. Here are compounded annual rates of return from 1977 to 1987 for gold fund and comparable holdings in a diversified portfolio, compared with inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index. $ INVESTMENT RETURN OVER 10 YEARS (in percent) Golds Funds 9.6 Corporate Bonds 10.3 Stocks 13.3 Treasury Bills 10.1 Consumer Price Index 6.1 Source: Salomon Brothers Inc.'s Investment Policy Report

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Swimming; Otto of East Germany Takes 4th Gold
description: Certainly, Matt Biondi attracted attention in Olympic swimming tonight by winning his fifth medal (third gold) and anchoring the United States to a world record in the men's 400-meter freestyle relay.

title: Comings and Goings
description: David Palmer, whose season with the Phillies ended Aug. 30 because of a torn rotator cuff, has had arthroscopic surgery on his ailing right shoulder and is expected to recuperate by the beginning of spring training. Palmer had a 7-9 record and a 4.47 e.r.a. . . . Bryan Harvey, a rookie right-handed relief pitcher with the Angels, has also undergone successful arthroscopic surgery to remove two bone chips in his right elbow. . . . Keith Bishop, an All-Pro guard, has signed a multiyear contract extension with the Denver Broncos that makes him among the highest-paid linemen in the N.F.L. Contract figures were not available, but the deal, which will run through the 1992 season, is believed to be for more than $2 million. Not counting incentives, Bishop, 31 years old, will earn $355,000 this season, the final year of a four-year contract he signed in 1985. . . . Blair Rasmussen, a Denver Nuggets center-forward, was admitted to Rose Medical Center to rest his injured back and will not be ready for the start of training camp Oct. 7. (AP)

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Close-Up; Weight Lifting
description: Different Strokes In the clean and jerk and the snatch, the bar must be held overhead for two seconds. In the snatch, the lifter cannot turn his wrists over until the bar is overhead, or extend his arms unevenly or incompletely. Top lifters can usually lift 100 pounds more in the clean and jerk than in the snatch. There are three referees of different nationalities in each match.

title: Fun for Young
description: Clowns, mimes, face painters, fortune tellers, musicians and rope jumpers will provide entertainment for children at the 1988 version of the Union Square Park Carnival, starting at noon today at Union Square Plaza, 17th Street between Broadway and Park Avenue South. The event will end at 5 P.M. with a parade. Baked goods and popcorn, gifts and books will be available, as well as coffee and cold drinks. All activities are free for children from neighborhood welfare hotels. Information: 533-2838 or 243-1661.

title: A Scandalous Work, for Russia of '67
description: A note at the beginning of ''Asya's Happiness,'' Andrei Konchalovsky's 1967 Russian film, describes it as ''the story of a woman who loved a man but did not marry him.''

title: Bond Prices End Session Slightly Lower
description: Bond prices showed only a slight decline yesterday after drops in both oil and gold prices spurred a recovery in late trading.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Armor All Products Corp., Irvine, Calif., acquired the car-care division of Borden Inc., New York, for about $27 million.

title: 4 Former Health Inspectors Get Jail Terms for Extortion
description: Four former New York City health inspectors who pleaded guilty to extorting payoffs from restaurants were sentenced yesterday in Federal court to jail terms ranging from one to eight months and other penalties.

title: Standard Microsystems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Deaver Is Sentenced To Suspended Term And $100,000 Fine
description: Michael K. Deaver, a close friend of President Reagan who was once one of the most powerful officials in the White House, today was given a suspended three-year prison sentence, placed on probation and fined $100,000 for lying about his lobbying activities after leaving the White House.

title: This Is Heavy: If 'the Dead' Is the 60's, Can the 60's Be Dead?
description: Commuters come and commuters go, but the Grateful Dead has endured for more than 20 years, pursued by a hardy group of followers called Deadheads. And for the last 10 days, those followers, who wear their hair long and their shirts tie-dyed, have been lounging around Penn Station.

title: Presley an Unoriginal
description: To the Editor:

title: Baxter Stock Falls; '88 Estimate Cited
description: Baxter International Inc.'s shares fell yesterday in very heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange as word spread that the company has lowered its estimate of 1988 earnings. Shares in the Deerfield, Ill. hospital supply company closed at $18.125, down $1.625, as almost eight million shares were traded. It was the Big Board's most-active issue. Baxter's price, which was in the low 20's two weeks ago, began sliding as stock analysts learned that earnings would not jump 30 percent to reach the $1.40 to $1.50 a share that they had predicted. The company said Thursday that earnings this year would still rise at least 20 percent, Analysts said that would mean $1.30 to $1.35 a share, Les Jacobson, a Baxter spokesman, said the company had lowered its estimates because of reduced profits in international and home health-care operations and spending ''to take advantage of higher-than-expected growth'' in the United States hospital supply business.

title: Vehicle Sales Rose 9.9% During Mid-September
description: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks remained at a strong level in mid-September, rising 9.9 percent from the comparable period last year.

title: Chaus, Bernard Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Net income

title: State Legislator Faces 5 Charges In Fraud Inquiry
description: State Senator Richard E. Schermerhorn of Newburgh was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on five counts of mail and bank fraud after officials investigated allegations that the Senator had accepted campaign contributions from organized-crime figures.

title: Red Sox Rally in Ninth to Beat Yankees
description: They thought they needed a small miracle this weekend. A sweep, that was all. After that, the Yankees would take their chances.

title: Cardinal de Furstenberg Dies in Belgium at 83
description: Maximilien Cardinal de Furstenberg, former head of the Vatican's Sacred Congregation for the Eastern Churches, has died in a clinic in his native Belgium, the Vatican reported today. He was 83 years old.

title: Presley an Unoriginal; 'Warhol's Second Law'
description: To the Editor:

title: Somerset Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Yellowstone, and Its Sales Pitch, Undergo Rebirth
description: At sunset, Electric Peak still lives up to its name, all pink in the natural neon of alpenglow. In the valley below, elk chomp on aspen branches, bison slurp from the Yellowstone River and a lone eagle prowls for rabbit.

title: Hunting for Bargain Flights by Alternate Routes
description: To the Editor:

title: Attack on Priest Called Haiti Catalyst
description: Many here trace the decision last week by young noncommissioned officers to oust Haiti's President, Gen. Henri Namphy, to one event that stands out even amid a long string of atrocities against civilians committed here before the eyes of unconcerned generals.

title: Dorothy Stimson, 97, Former Goucher Dean
description: Dorothy Stimson, a retired dean of Goucher College, died of arterial sclerosis on Monday at her home in Owls Head, Me. She was 97 years old.

title: Dukakis's Social Aims Look Beyond Treasury
description: Michael S. Dukakis, as President, would probably use the Government to initiate programs but make businesses and those who benefit from the programs pay.

title: Radon: Making the Public Pay Attention
description: The Government recently told Americans that their homes may be collecting dangerous amounts of odorless, tasteless, invisible radon gas, which causes about 20,000 lung cancer deaths a year in the United States. As disturbing as the warning was, communication specialists say most people will ignore it unless the message is reinforced with credible publicity and extensive education.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Weight Lifting; Team Lifted After 2d Drug Test Is Failed
description: A second Bulgarian weight lifter was stripped of his gold medal today after tests showed he took a banned weight-loss drug, and Bulgaria then pulled its weightlifting team out of the Olympics.

title: Youth Given 6-Month Term In Attack Case
description: A prime assailant in the Howard Beach racial attack was sentenced yesterday to six months in jail as the final step in a plea bargain in which he received leniency for cooperating with prosecutors.

title: Bill on Alternative Fuels Gains
description: Legislation intended to spur development of motor vehicles that can operate on fuels other than gasoline was passed by the House of Representatives today and sent to the White House.

title: New England Electric System reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
description: b-Included an after-tax writedown of $179 million from a rate settlement. c-Net income The results for the prior year have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for property losses.

title: The Busiest Days Begin
description: More championships will be decided here on Saturday than on any other day of the Seoul Olympics.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Economic Scene column in Business Day yesterday misidentified the former Cabinet post of Drew Lewis. He was the Transportation Secretary.

title: David Rollin Du Val, Securities Analyst, 38
description: David Rollin Du Val, a securities analyst with the Citicorp Capital Markets Group in London and formerly a vice president of E. F. Hutton & Company in Manhattan, died Tuesday in a rafting accident on the Dadu River in Sichuan Province, China. He was 38 years old and lived in London.

title: Eric G. James, 78, Professor and Consultant
description: Eric G. James, a professor and consultant, died of a heart attack Thursday at Our Lady of Mercy Hospital in the Bronx. He was 78 years old and lived in the Riverdale section and Dix Hills, L.I.

title: Baseball; 40-40 for Canseco
description: Jose Canseco became the first player in major league history to hit 40 homers and steal 40 bases in one season tonight when he stole two bases during the Oakland Athletics' game against the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Kenya Bars Rights Lawyer From Visiting U.S.
description: In the last four months, Gibson Kamau Kuria, a Kenyan lawyer, has received four invitations to visit the United States and be honored.

title: Debt Problem For Federated
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., a unit of the Campeau Corporation, has cast some doubt on its ability to repay the bank loans and interest payments used to finance its $6.6 billion acquisition earlier this year by the Toronto-based concern.

title: Punk Being Examined As Historical Movement
description: A symposium on the history and legacy of punk music and culture is to be held from 10:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. today in the Katie Murphy Amphitheater of the Fashion Institute of Technology, 227 West 27th Street.

title: Miss Fiorentino Wed
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Anselm in Brooklyn, Maureen Fiorentino, the daughter of Mrs. Dennis J. Fiorentino of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Fiorentino, was married yesterday to William Harrison Givens 3d, the assistant manager of pension underwriting for Mutual of America Life Insurance Company in New York. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Givens Jr. of New York and the late Mr. Givens. The Rev. Joseph P. Keane, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Herbert Anderson, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: INSIDE
description: Killings in El Salvador

title: For Hirohito, a Vigil Without Fanfare
description: The young people, the polls all showed, did not care anymore. A generation brought up on Levis and Haagen-Dazs, that spent more time in Roppongi's discos than Kyoto's shrines, had little interest in an elderly Emperor, symbol of an empire that has long since disappeared.

title: Mother Margarita Maria, Hospital Administrator, 85
description: Mother Margarita Maria, a Roman Catholic nun who founded a religious order of Carmelite nuns and turned a farmhouse sanitarium into Santa Teresita Hospital here, died Wednesday. She was 85 years old. She became administrator of Santa Teresita after founding it as a tuberculosis sanitarium in 1930.

title: From Afar, Both Candidates Are Environmentalists . . .
description: Some say we can have either a clean environment or a thriving economy, but not both. But I see our challenge very differently. We can't have sustainable economic development without careful and sensitive protection of our natural resources.

title: Elia and Rojas Out
description: With 10 days to go in baseball's regular season, the game of managerial changes has begun on both coasts. In Philadelphia, Lee Elia was dropped as manager of the Phillies. In Anaheim, Calif., Cookie Rojas was let go as manager of the California Angels. In both cases, interim managers were named, meaning that there will be another change before next season.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Track and Field; Johnson Sets World Mark and Tops Lewis in the 100
description: Ben Johnson of Canada won the Olympic 100-meter final today in a stunning 9.79 seconds to lower his world record and defeat his greatest rival, Carl Lewis of the United States, the defending Olympic champion.

title: Sports of the Times; Shortstop From the Zoo
description: The implication was that either he had rattled the bars and been let out of his cage, or he had escaped.

title: Hunting for Bargain Flights by Alternate Routes; 'Hidden City' Ploy
description: To the Editor:

title: Piano-Bass-Drums
description: Niels Lan Doky on piano, Niels Henning Orsted-Pedersen on bass and Billy Hart on drums will play trios tonight and tomorrow at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight tonight, at 8 and 10 P.M. tomorrow. There is a $12.50 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: SENDING THE GAMES ROUND THE WORLD
description: The room is dark except for the rows of small television monitors filling the front wall, making it look like a giant flashing checkerboard of bright images, blinking soundlessly: swimmers splashing, runners running, horses jumping, boxers punching. Eight or nine people mill about the room, chatting quietly and sometimes stopping to watch a small, harried-looking woman seated at a console with a telephone at her ear.

title: Cards Topple Gooden in 9th
description: On the day after, the Mets went to the fourth inning tonight against the St. Louis Cardinals and saw the scoreboard flash the message: ''The Cardinals congratulate the Mets, Eastern Division champions, National League.'' The crowd of 33,290 booed.

title: Rape Victim's Cries Unheeded
description: Several people watched as a 36-year-old woman was raped under a commuter-train platform during rush hour, but nobody moved to help her, the police said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Senate Votes Bill for Study Of F.S.L.I.C.
description: In an effort to address the growing crisis in the savings industry, the Senate today passed legislation that would create a national commission to study how to bail out the beleaguered Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

title: Pretoria Will Let U.N. Send Transition Team to Namibia
description: South Africa said today that it would allow a United Nations technical team into Namibia to start planning the deployment of United Nations military and civilian personnel there once the territory's transition to independence begins.

title: City Manager Cites Failure of Government in Fatal Jersey Fire
description: The City Manager today attributed the deaths of five firefighters here last July to a failure of government, agreeing with a report's finding that the five died needlessly when the roof of a burning car dealership collapsed.

title: G.O.P. Group Assails Dukakis on Farm Policies
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, a leader in Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign in the Farm Belt, said today that if Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's farm policies become law, the 1988 drought would ''look like a Sunday picnic.''

title: AutoInfo Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $93,841 from discontinued operations.

title: HOUSE, BY 248-150, BACKS BILL TO CURB IMPORTED TEXTILES
description: The House of Representatives today backed tough limits on imports of textiles, garments and shoes and sent the bill to the White House, where it faces an almost certain veto.

title: Stuart Janney, 81, Top Horse Breeder, Dies in an Accident
description: Stuart Symington Janney Jr., one of the nation's leading horse breeders and the owner of Ruffian and Private Terms, was killed in an automobile accident Thursday while driving home to Locust Hill Farm in Glyndon, Md. He was 81 years old.

title: Patents; New Designs For Sports Equipment: A Lighter Football
description: Rod G. Martin of San Jose, Calif., has invented a polyurethane football that is lighter and softer than a standard pigskin. Designed primarily for young players who have trouble gripping and passing a standard ball, Mr. Martin's ball comes with a set of curved grooves in which players can plant their fingers for passing.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Jack Carl/312 Futures reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss was attributable to a writedown of good will of about $2.4 million and the establishment of a bad debt reserve of about $6 million primarily due to events surrounding the Oct. 19 market crash.

title: In Heathrow Holding Room: Reporter's Ordeal
description: There was some comment in the British press this week when a correspondent of The New York Times was denied admission to Britain and put on an airplane back to New York because she had arrived at Heathrow Airport without a required document. Her editors asked her to write a narrative of her experience, which follows:

title: Rural Ohioans Back Bush Despite the Quayle Factor
description: They ran the Little Brown Jug for the 43d time at the Delaware County Fair Thursday, and more than 47,000 people came from all over the Middle West on the first day of autumn for one of the reassuring rites of rural America, a race that forms part of the Triple Crown for three-year-old pacers.

title: Mr. Gorbachev's Asian Serenade
description: Fresh from a month's vacation, Mikhail Gorbachev has launched his second major initiative toward Asia. His speech last week in Siberia, like his 1986 Vladivostok address, featured some headline-grabbing hokum. But it also had other layers and audiences. Together with other recent gestures, the speech affirms his eagerness to strengthen Soviet ties in Asia much as he has improved his relationships in the West. It also affirms his considerable diplomatic agility, which the West is inclined to underestimate.

title: Vicious and Virtuous Twins in a Fairy Tale
description: The Notebook By Agota Kristof Translated by Alan Sheridan 183 pages. Grove Press. $15.95.

title: Koch Staff Reports Tax-Revenue Shortfall
description: The Koch administration, already urging fiscal restraint on the City Council, said yesterday that New York City was facing a ''substantial decline'' in projected tax revenues. It said the decline may represent a threat to budgetary reserves and city programs.

title: Scenes on 13 Statehood Stamps Are Typical, Not Historical
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Sox Celebrate Comeback
description: The Boston Red Sox weren't celebrating any championship, not just yet. They were, however, whooping and hollering, clapping and whistling, smiling and slapping as they charged into their clubhouse last night, their energy and adrenaline gushing following a remarkable 10-9 comeback victory over the Yankees at the Stadium.

title: South African Denied Refuge
description: United States officials said today that they turned away a black fugitive seeking refuge in the American Consulate, which is sheltering four escaped detainees. The man, Max Mankazana, 22 years old, was later arrested. An American spokesman did not say why the man's case was treated differently.

title: Haitians See Financial Crisis and Plead for Aid
description: As calm settled over Haiti today, a week after a coup d'etat, leading businessmen declared that the country was in a severe economic crisis and appealed to the United States and other nations for emergency financial aid.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 1 about an American warning to the Soviet Union over a disputed radar station described the American complaint incorrectly. The Reagan Administration contends that the radar, near Krasnoyarsk, is not on the periphery of the Soviet Union and oriented outward, as such installations must be under the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

title: Williams Eyes Return
description: Doug Williams, the Redskins' quarterback hospitalized in Arlington, Va., after undergoing an emergency appendectomy, anticipates returning to the lineup by late October. ''Hopefully, in three or four weeks I'll be practicing and in five weeks I'll be playing again,'' Williams said.(AP)

title: Paul Harvey's Soapbox of the Air
description: It is one of broadcasting's more enduring rituals, played out nearly every weekday morning for more than 30 years inside a small windowless radio studio above Michigan Avenue.

title: TII Industries Inc reports earnings for Year to June 24
description: b-Net income The company said the reversal was because of a $12,850,000 writedown of inventory caused by changes in the specifications for certain products used by principal customers.

title: French Deficit Widens
description: French officials said Thursday that France's August trade deficit had more than doubled, to 9 billion francs ($1.4 billion), from July. The deficit with West Germany alone jumped to 5.07 billion francs ($800 million), from 3.97 billion ($630 million). The gap with the European Community almost doubled, to 7.03 billion francs ($1.1 billion), but the shortfall with Japan narrowed slightly, to 2.24 billion francs ($350 million).

title: A VIBRANT BERLIN GREETS THE I.M.F.
description: West Berlin's city fathers are spending $16 million as hosts to the 10,000 delegates attending the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, and they are convinced it is worth every pfennig to trumpet the city's success story.

title: Canseco: 40-40
description: Jose Canseco of the Oakland Athletics became the first major league player to hit 40 home runs and steal 40 bases in the same season. Page 53.

title: Your Money; Using Psychology To Help Finances
description: Psychological insight, along with sound financial planning, is often needed to straighten out many families' entangled finances. As Dr. Bernard E. Poduska, director of the Family Financial Counseling Clinic at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, put it, ''Financial problems are behavioral problems more often than they are numbers problems.''

title: Federal Board Recommends A Full License for Shoreham
description: A Federal licensing board recommended yesterday that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission issue the Shoreham nuclear power plant a full operating license.

title: Jury Is Picked for the Myerson Trial
description: The painstaking process of selecting jurors for the Bess Myerson trial ended yesterday with the seating of seven men and five women.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Track and Field; Joyner-Kersee Long Jump Sets a Mark
description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee broke the world record in the women's long jump of the heptathlon, leaping 23 feet 10 1/4 inches today as she continued to dominate the two-day event.

title: A South African Thief And His Radicalization
description: The insouciant lead character in the South African film ''Mapantsula,'' a thief named Panic, is as talented as he is cool. Panic is such an unflappable pickpocket that he can steal a man's wallet and then stand there, switchblade in hand, rifling through the wallet's contents while silently daring the victim to challenge him. He's such a skilled shoplifter that he can wrap each half of a man's suit tightly around one of his calves, holding the merchandise in place with heavy socks. And Panic is good with the ladies, too. As ''Mapantsula'' begins, Panic's concerns do not extend much beyond these particular spheres.

title: Former Nazi Guard Deported
description: A 78-year-old Chicago man was deported to West Germany for concealing his pre-World War II service as a lieutenant colonel in the Nazi SS at two concentration camps, the Justice Department said today. Conrad Schellong, deported Thursday, had been the target of a 7 1/2-year legal effort by the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations, which said he served in SS guard companies at the Sachsenburg and Dachau camps from 1934 to 1939.

title: Despite the 'Weirdos,' Usher Refused to Quit
description: John Winters, the usher at St. Patrick's Cathedral who was killed in the church by a deranged man Wednesday night, used to regale and worry his wife with stories about ''weirdos'' coming into the cathedral from the streets, mumbling to themselves and trying to steal nickels and dimes from the collection box.

title: In Burma, Losing the Will to Commit National Suicide
description: LEAD: If it were not for the brutality displayed by Ne Win's latest puppet, Gen. Saw Maung, and the tragedy of countless casualties, events in Burma would recall an Evelyn Waugh satire: four governments in two months - and the current one heading toward self-destruction.

title: NL Industries
description: NL Industries, based in Houston, said that a Federal grand jury was investigating the sale and marketing of drilling mud and other products manufactured by the company's Baroid division. Drilling mud is a lubricant used in large quantities on oil drilling equipment, especially in off-shore drilling. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, NL said it intended to defend itself vigorously if any charges were filed. The filing said the grand jury investigation covers the period from 1980 until 1987, but it gave no further details.

title: The Candidates on the Issues
description: ABORTION BUSH: Would allow abortion only in cases of rape, incest or to protect life of mother. Opposes public spending on abortion. DUKAKIS: Supports women's right to choose. Favors Medicaid financing for abortions for low-income women. AGRICULTURE BUSH: Opposed Harkin-Gephardt bill, which sought to increase prices by limiting production through mandatory controls. Supports phasing out farm subsidies if trading partners do. DUKAKIS: Initially opposed Harkin-Gephardt bill, but reversed his position this year. Favors targeting subsidies to small farms. AIDS BUSH: Says U.S. may have to spend more on research and education. Favors mandatory testing for military, prisoners, immigrants and Foreign Service. Backed Presidential commission call for legislation to protect AIDS victims from discrimination. DUKAKIS: Favors $1 billion increase in funding for research and education. Opposes mandatory testing, except for military, prisoners and some immigrants. Endorsed civil rights protections for AIDS victims. CHILD CARE BUSH: Proposed $2.2 billion day care plan with ''toddler tax credit'' of $1,000 to families with children under age 4, as alternative to so-called ABC bill in Senate, which budgets $2.5 billion for states to make child care more affordable. DUKAKIS: Supports ABC bill in Senate; advocates public-private partnerships to help poor families get affordable child care. DEATH PENALTY BUSH: Supports death penalty for crimes involving murder, treason and espionage, and for drug ''kingpins.'' DUKAKIS: Opposes death penalty on moral grounds. DEFENSE BUSH: Supports development of B-1 bomber, Stealth bomber, MX missile and Midgetman missile. Opposes nuclear freeze. Supports research and deployment of Strategic Defense Initiative. Supports Soviet-American treaty banning intermediate-range nuclear weapons. DUKAKIS: Opposes mobile Midgetman and mobile MX, Supports continued research and deployment on Trident missile and Stealth bomber. Favors only limited research on Strategic Defense Initiative, which he once called ''a fantasy and a fraud.'' Emphasizes improved conventional forces. Supports U.S.-U.S.S.R. treaty banning intermediate-range weapons. DRUGS BUSH: Pledges to increase funds for interdiction, prevention and treatment. Says he would place Vice President in charge of anti-drug effort and would create international anti-drug force. DUKAKIS: Pledged to double number of Federal drug enforcement agents and add 800 prosecutors. Favors raising aid to help state and local law-enforcement agencies control narcotics. Would appoint ''drug czar'' to run anti-drug effort. ECONOMIC BUSH: Rules out tax increases. Would deal with budget deficit through ''flexible freeze'' on Federal budget, allowing most programs to keep pace with inflation rate. Advances free market philosophy, with as little Government role as possible. Supports Constitutional balanced budget amendment. DUKAKIS: Favors tax increases only as ''a last resort.'' Would deal with budget deficit through more vigorous collection of unpaid taxes, making ''tough choices'' on spending. Advocates public-private partnerships to energize industry. Opposes Constitutional balanced budget amendment. EDUCATION BUSH: Favors $500 million program to reward schools that succeed with children from poor homes. Favors Federal matching funds to states creating more magnet schools. Proposes tax-free savings bonds as incentive for families to save for college. DUKAKIS: Proposed program through which students get Government loans repaid through withholding a fixed percentage of income once borrower got a job. Favors fund to provide scholarships for students committed to teaching. ENVIRONMENT BUSH: Supported Reagan veto of renewal of Clean Water Act. Vows to end ocean dumping by 1991 and beef up enforcement of pollution regulations. Says within four years would try to exceed Environmental Protection Agency goal of cutting wastes by 25 percent. DUKAKIS: Supported renewal of Clean Water Act and ban on ocean dumping by 1991. Favors laws requiring industrial companies to adopt accident prevention programs, and for national standards to reduce toxic emissions. EQUAL RIGHTS AMENDMENT BUSH: Opposes. DUKAKIS: Supports. FOREIGN RELATIONS BUSH: Supports military and humanitarian aid to Nicaraguan rebels. Favors Reagan policy of ''constructive engagement'' with South Africa. Strongly backed invasion of Grenada and using U.S. forces in Persian Gulf. Opposes a separate Palestinian state. Against negotiations with Palestine Liberation Organization unless it abandons terrorism and its call for Israel's destruction. DUKAKIS: Opposes military and humanitarian aid to Nicaraguan rebels. Favors complete divestment of U.S. companies operating in South Africa, a ''terrorist state.'' Opposed invasion of Grenada and American warships in Persian Gulf.

title: Fingers Crossed, Steel Exporters Count Their Gains
description: THE decline of the American steel industry has exemplified the nation's loss of basic manufacturing muscle. Now, suddenly, American steel exports are on the rise, particularly in specialty products used in aerospace, chemical equipment and nuclear plant construction.

title: 'All's Well': What Does She See in Him?
description: IT'S easy to mistake one of Shakespeare's less accessible plays, ''All's Well That Ends Well,'' for one of his less appealing ones. The memorable Royal Shakespeare Company staging, transposed by the director Trevor Nunn to the Edwardian era and produced on Broadway in 1983, proved, however, that the play's interpretive possibilities are boundless.

title: Kathleen Clarke Weds
description: Kathleen Helen Clarke, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Calvin B. Clarke of Fort Wayne, Ind., and Theodore Cacouris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias M. Cacouris of Abidjan, the Ivory Coast, and Athens, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. The Rev. John A. Lynn of the American Fellowship Service performed the ceremony. Mrs. Cacouris is a graphic artist in New York. Her husband is a doctoral candidate in electrical engineering at Columbia.

title: JAIL POPULATION REACHES A RECORD
description: New York City's jails, already overcrowded, are seeing a wave of new prisoners this fall that made the inmate population jump to a record 17,128 last week.

title: 'The Facts'
description: In the spring of 1987, at the height of a ten-year period of creativity," Philip Roth says in his opening paragraphs, "what was to have been minor surgery turned into a prolonged physical ordeal that led to an extreme depression that carried me right to the edge of emotional and mental dissolution." This is as specific as he gets about "the facts" of what he twice refers to as a "crack-up" (a term that immediately calls up associations with F. Scott Fitzgerald). But among the factors contributing to it, Roth, now 55, mentions his mother's death, the prospect of his father's and his own "exhaustion with making fictional self-legends." This new book, "The Facts," is in part Roth's attempt to retrace his steps; find an originating self, unformed and tentative, that had not yet learned to whack experience into self-legend; and then arrive at a therapeutic, midlife settling of accounts.
