title: Review/Music; A Night of Leonard Bernstein in a Solemn Mood
description: When Leonard Bernstein composed his Symphony No. 3 (''Kaddish'') in 1963, he assigned to a woman the central role of the Job-like Speaker who upbraids God for creating an imperfect world. In his 1977 revision of the score, Mr. Bernstein permits either a male or female to take the part, an ambiguity entirely consistent with the composer's ecumenical view of life and art. In either event, it is clear that the Speaker is always Mr. Bernstein himself, confronting a fallible God with charges of incompetency but finally making his peace with this seemingly indifferent Father, who is forgiven and even offered human sympathy for failing to run the universe properly.

title: Allende's Widow Returns to Chile After 15-Year Exile
description: The widow of Salvador Allende, Hortensia Bussi, came home today after 15 years of exile, through the ''wide open door'' that she had wanted.

title: The Issue That Matters Most: Are Bush and Dukakis Discussing It?
description: Registered voters were asked what they thought should be the single most important issue in this election. Then they were asked whether they thought Bush and Dukakis were talking enough about what they would do about that issue. Based on 802 registered voters nationwide, interviewed by telephone Sept. 21-22, and weighted to reflect a ''probable electorate.'' Those who were not sure about the most important issue, or about whether the candidates were talking enough about it, are not shown.

title: Transplant in Rats Cures Disease Blamed for Blindness
description: In a major advance, two groups of scientists have successfully transplanted cells from the eye of a rat to the retina of another rat and cured a disease that would otherwise cause blindness. The work, the first successful retinal cell transplant, is the first time that researchers have been able to cure a degenerative disease of the central nervous system.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: THE MAN WHO WAS THE WAR
description: A BRIGHT SHINING LIE John Paul Vann and America in Vietnam. By Neil Sheehan. Illustrated. 861 pp. New York: Random House. $24.95.

title: BEING THERE
description: APRIL, 1965. THE NATION'S BALance of payments is deteriorating at an alarming rate. President Johnson has established a voluntary program calling for business to trim the transfer of dollars overseas. As Secretary of Commerce John Connor's point man for the program, I have arranged for the members of the advisory committee - the chief executives of Mobil Oil, General Electric and seven other major multinationals - to meet with Lyndon Johnson at the White House.

title: Robert Kennedy in History
description: To the Editor:

title: A Traditional Japanese Menu
description: If you expect the new Sakura in Stamford to be a clone of its parent restaurant in Westport, you are in for a surprise and a pleasant one. Not only is the new offspring more attractive, spacious and authentically Japanese in decor, but the food is better and more attractively presented, the sushi is fresher and the menu is considerably expanded and more interesting.

title: Headliners; Valuable 'Trial'
description: Franz Kafka might well be as bemused as some of his improbably situated characters to learn that the coming sale of one of his manuscripts is the talk of the rare-book set. Sotheby's, which is handling the gavel on this one, says Kafka's handwritten version of ''The Trial,'' written in 1914 and published in 1925, the year after the author's death, is the most important modern literary manuscript ever to be auctioned. It is expected to bring more than $1 million at the Nov. 17 sale. Kafka gave the manuscript to his friend Max Brod in 1920. Mr. Brod, who was also Kafka's literary executor, turned over the bulk of the author's manuscripts to Oxford in 1961, but kept ''The Trial,'' which he said was a personal gift. Ernst Pawel, a Kafka biographer, said that when Mr. Brod died in 1968, the manuscript was inherited by Mr. Brod's secretary.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Swimming; Familiar Names Are Lighting Up Results Board
description: The rich got richer Saturday night in Olympic swimming.

title: Army Wins Without A Pass
description: Having played Air Force last Saturday and Army today, perhaps Northwestern can be grateful that Navy is not on its schedule this season.

title: Where Menu and Music Are Lively
description: JAZZ is king at Syosset's Cafe Royale. Food is secondary. That as obvious when, at 7:30 on a Saturday night, ours was the only occupied table. After the talented jazz trio (piano, bass and saxophone) began to play, we had lots of company.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Bedside Manner Counts Here

title: Homelessness at a Remove: An Urge to Stare
description: There are certain newsworthy subjects - war, natural disasters, starvation - that the camera can illuminate with relative ease. Their effects are apparent to the eye, and their causes can be readily deduced. Other issues of public concern - the national debt, for example, or radon gas - seem to resist any form of photographic interpretation. Between these two poles lies the issue of homelessness. Homeless people are indisputably visible, but the reality of homelessness is not comprehensible from mere appearances.

title: Dukakis Is Forced to Deal With Sniping at Home
description: With a month and a half left in the campaign, about the last thing Gov. Michael S. Dukakis wanted was Vice President Bush needling him in his backyard, the Massachusetts Legislature defying him and Massachusetts residents grousing about his record. But that is exactly what has happened.

title: Ms. Dentzer, Editor, Weds
description: Susan Grace Dentzer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Dentzer Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y., and Charles Clark Alston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Alston of Greensboro, N.C., were married yesterday. The Rev. John B. Macnab and the Rev. John O. Mellin performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Autumn's Gold in Urban Settings
description: THE annual phenomenon of colorful autumn foliage takes place wherever there are deciduous forests, abundant rainfall and a succession of hot sunny days followed by nights in which the temperature drops well into the 40's. For it is the sugar, formed by the leaves in the heat of the sun and later trapped by the cold night, that turns the leaves to brilliant reds and oranges.

title: YITZHAK SHAMIR'S STUBBORN STRENGTH
description: Yitzhak Shamir differentiates the Israeli struggle against the British mandatory administration from the Palestinian struggle against Israeli rule, saying, ''But we never attacked civilians, women and children. . . .'' One wonders if it was geographic inaccessibility to the British civilians that accounts for this forbearance, since Israeli forces, including the Lehi (of which Mr. Shamir was a member) had no such compunction when, on April 9, 1948, they destroyed the Arab village of Dir Yassin, executing nearly every man, woman and child. MERTON CHERNOFF Jamaica, Queens

title: John J. Smith Dies; Ex-Squash Player And Broker Was 75
description: John J. Smith, a senior partner at the stock brokerage firm of Fahnestock & Company and a former professional squash racquets player, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 75 years old and had been suffering from liver cancer.

title: Hilma Wolitzer, At the Beginning
description: I had the privilege of interviewing Hilma Wolitzer [ ''2 Housewives Sitting Around Writing,'' Aug. 28 ] for the author's page of a Long Island magazine a number of years ago. Her first novel had just been published. I had read it and decided because of the pure quality of its writing that I wanted to interview this author. (The publisher was dubious. She had never heard of Hilma and besides was looking for the ''more popular'' type of writer.) I persisted and eventually persuaded the publisher that this was the type of author who was going to make her mark on fine literature; not that the publisher was interested in fine literature, I might add.) I thoroughly enjoyed and was inspired by speaking with Hilma and have read all the rest of her novels that followed the first. I never felt I was wrong in my first estimation of the quality of her prose.

title: FOCUS: Land Use; Investors Seek More Remote Locations
description: When Dr. Vernon Sylvest, a pathologist in Richmond, Va., lost $60,000 in several oil and energy ventures in the early 1980's, he decided he wanted more to show for his money than worthless pieces of paper. He bought land because, he said, ''I figured land was a sure thing.''

title: Phil Leslie, Writer, 79
description: Phil Leslie, who for more than a decade created the comic antics of ''Fibber McGee and Molly'' on radio, died Friday of cancer. He was 79 years old.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE ORGAN BUILDER. By Robert Cohen. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) Robert Cohen's first novel is an intimate, stunningly written portrait of a man and his reluctant confrontation with the past. Herschel Freeman (Hesh) is a New York lawyer, a bit awkward, a bit lonely after his recent divorce, and a bit underambitious.

title: Nominees Battle Tonight to Emerge Most Presidential
description: As the Presidential contenders prepare for the debate here Sunday night, they know full well that the tone a candidate strikes can be as influential as any specific words he says.

title: A Tough Job, But Rewarding
description: THE mission: Get out there on the street and find out what color stockings are currently in favor with young women who like to wear their skirts short. This was tough, thankless work, but someone had to do it.

title: Spotting the Fun at the Games
description: Halfway through these Summer Games, it's easy to spot the negative parts. Television ratings down in the U.S.? NBC should have known that baseball and football are hot in September and that many American fans don't think it's a good Summer Games unless Mary Lou Retton is winning all the medals.

title: Land Investors Seeking More Remote Locations
description: When Dr. Vernon Sylvest, a pathologist in Richmond, Va., lost $60,000 in several oil and energy ventures in the early 1980's, he decided he wanted more to show for his money than worthless pieces of paper. He bought land because, he said, ''I figured land was a sure thing.''

title: East Hampton May Ban Seaplanes
description: LEAD: FOR a handful of homeowners, taking a seaplane between Manhattan and their waterfront homes in East Hampton has become a convenient, if not costly, way to commute.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Notebook; Coverage of Brawl Comes Under Fire
description: In the controversy surrounding last week's melee in the ring when penalties cost a South Korean boxer a decision against a Bulgarian, South Korea's ruling party has criticized the foreign news media in general and NBC in particular for their coverage of the Games.

title: 7 Industrial Powers Back Dollar's Level
description: Economic officials from the largest industrial democracies today endorsed the dollar's current exchange rate and said the world economy was sound and growing faster than expected.

title: Gas Mileage Tax Placed on More Cars This Year
description: The Environmental Protection Agency's annual survey of automobile gasoline mileage shows that more models than ever are being charged the special tax on fuel-hungry cars, most of them expensive European luxury models.

title:
GARDENING;
Trees Can Mitigate Greenhouse Effect
description: LEAD: MANY environmentalists predict that a buildup of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere from the burning of fossil fuels and others will result in the greenhouse effect and that the buildup will reduce the amount of heat the Earth radiates into the atmosphere, raising global temperatures.

title: Baby Boomers Need a Break
description: Contrary to conventional wisdom, it is not glamorous to be a baby boomer. Often, it has been difficult, sometimes painful and occasionally even frightening.

title: U.S. Tests Soviet Equipment Against Its Own
description: The Pentagon is testing Soviet, Chinese and Warsaw Pact jets and other military equipment at a nearby air base to see how well they operate and what problems might turn up.

title: Elizabeth Couch, Eric Forstmann Exchange Vows
description: At the First Congregational Church in Washington, Conn., Elizabeth Couch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur W. Couch of New Preston, Conn., was married yesterday to Eric Allen Forstmann, a son of Carol Millar Forstmann of Warren, Conn., and Peter Allen Forstmann of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev. Richard C. Sears performed the ceremony.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Plymouth, Mass.;
80 Homes Sold, 743 to Go
description: LEAD: DOWN a winding country road, amid a cluster of seven clear ponds, the Ponds of Plymouth, where 823 single-family homes are planned, is now home to the first 80 families.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Fairfield, Conn. $269,500 133 Orchard Hill Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old ranch; fieldstone fireplace, near university campus, 0.25 acre; taxes $2,147. Lyme, Conn. $725,000 Tantumorantum Road 6-bedroom, 5 1/2-baths, 2-story, 48-year-old converted barn; pond, pool, 10 acres, taxes $2,695. Riverside, Conn. $325,000 35 Amherst Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old split-level; new roof, remodeled kitchen; taxes $2,040. Chappaqua, N.Y. $395,500 327 Millwood Road 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 51-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, den, screened porch, 1.2 acres; taxes $7,084. Katonah, N.Y. $321,500 Orchard Hill 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 19-year-old colonial; living-room fireplace, den, deck, 2 acres; taxes $4,726. Larchmont, N.Y. 500,000 123 Beach Avenue 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 81-year-old colonial; fireplace, study, enclosed porch, terrace; taxes $7,395. Trenton, N.J. $77,900 304 Genesee Street 5-bedroom, 1-bath, 70-year-old rowhouse; formal dining room, full basement; taxes $1,060. Massapequa, L.I. $160,000 154 Commonwealth Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 47-year-old ranch; finished basement, 1-car garage, 80- by 100-foot lot; taxes $2,400.

title: DATA UPDATE: September 25, 1988
Quotation of the Day
description: ''When the big issues matter less, the small issues matter more. So small things, like one-liners and gaffes, can make a big difference.'' - William Schneider, political analyst, on tonight's Presidential debate. [ 26:2. ]

title: Fulfilling Olympic Dreams
description: IF a star should be born in Robert Cottingham Jr. at the Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, it would be ironic, since his father's Olympic dreams died there 36 years ago.

title: Roberta O'Neill Weds Charles Bayard Kieler
description: Roberta Marguerite O'Neill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Francis O'Neill of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and Cooperstown, N.Y., and Charles Bayard Kieler, the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Charles Benedict Kieler of Cooperstown, were married yesterday at the Farmers' Museum Church in Cooperstown. The Rev. Leo O'Brien, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: 39 Injured in Texas Collision Of 3 School Buses on Outing
description: Three buses carrying a high school band and drill team collided Friday night, injuring at least 39 people, nine seriously.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ANOTHER CITY: A Memoir. By Patrice Chaplin. (Atlantic Monthly, Paper, $9.95.) In ''Albany Park,'' published last year, Patrice Chaplin, an English novelist and playwright, recounted her escape at 15 from a dreary existence in a London suburb and her bohemian adventures on the Continent. In the ancient Catalonian city of Gerona she fell in love with a man named Jose - poet, Catalan patriot, dreamer, liar, gigolo, flimflam artist, charismatic charmer.

title: New Grants to Finance Commuter-Bus Studies
description: COMMUTERS trying to squeeze through the increasingly congested White Plains-Stamford highway corridor could get help from a privately operated express bus service, local transportation officials said last week.

title: W. E. Bryson Jr. Weds Miss Smith
description: Jennifer Nell Smith, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger C. Smith of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to William Elwood Bryson Jr., the son of Doris K. Israel of Arnold, Md., and Mr. Bryson of Glen Burnie, Md. The Rev. Brian A. Lathrop performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in New York. He was assisted by the Rev. John Ashley Null, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Margaret S. Mahaney, the bride's aunt, who is a United Church of Christ minister.

title: No Headline
description: ROBBINS W. BARSTOW formed Cetacean Society International in 1974 after a whale-watching cruise, and has been its full-time volunteer director for two years, since he retired as director of professional development for the Connecticut Education Association.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Track and Field; Moses Loses; Griffith Joyner Wins
description: Two past Olympic champions from the United States were defeated in their quest of another gold medal today. But their losses were balanced for the American team by the fact that they each lost to teammates setting Olympic records.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: MADAM COCOLAT
description: LUNCHTIME IN PALO ALTO, CALIF.

title: Headliners; Suspended Sentence
description: Michael K. Deaver, the former White House deputy chief of staff, spoke of his battle with alcohol and of the pain that he caused his family when he asked for leniency last week in Federal District Court in Washington. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson was apparently moved. He gave Mr. Deaver, who was convicted of lying under oath about his work as a lobbyist after leaving the White House, a suspended three-year sentence and a $100,000 fine. The sentence fell far short of what the special prosecutor, Whitney North Seymour Jr., had recommended.

title: About Cars; A Stylish Jaguar Convertible
description: If it seems that you've been seeing more new Jaguars on the road, that's because . . . well, there are more new Jags on the road.

title: Coach Cracks Down
description: When Petr Klima showed up late for a midweek practice and his teammate Bob Probert missed a team flight from Chicago, Jacques Demers, the coach of the Detroit Red Wings, decided he'd had just about enough. So in an effort to teach the players a lesson, the coach ordered them sent down to the club's Adirondack farm club in Glens Falls, N.Y., on a ''day-to-day basis.''

title: Graf's Triumph Is Discredited
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FLAUNTING SUCCESS
description: NOTHING IN HER CREAM-COLORED OFFICE - WITH the exception of the Financial News Network reports flickering on the television screen - hints at her occupation. And Elaine M. Garzarelli likes it that way. Settling back on the plump sofa and fanning out her hair, the Manhattan-based securities analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton (she clinched her reputation by predicting last October's market crash a week in advance, on Cable News Network's ''Moneyline'') says she has always avoided working in a place that looks too obviously ''officey.'' She feels that way about her wardrobe, too. ''I try never to look businesslike - ever,'' she says.

title: WHOSE DEFEAT IS THIS?
description: ''This society,'' writes Dudley Clendinen in HOMELESS IN AMERICA (Acropolis Books, Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $19.95), ''with all its computers and all its enormous wealth of resources and research, cannot count the homeless.'' Do they number 300,000 (one of the Reagan Administration figures), asks Mr. Clendinen, an assistant managing editor at The Atlanta Constitution, or three million (according to advocates for the homeless)? A tattered army, is it they who are defeated, or the America in which they cannot find housing? The purpose of this joint photographic project of the National Mental Health Association and Families for the Homeless is ''to raise the level of public awareness and concern over the plight of America's homeless population.'' Who are the homeless? According to this book, they are us: mothers, fathers, children, veterans, the aging, the sick, laid-off workers and - a rapidly increasing segment - the employed. Families in which both parents work live in tents or cars because they cannot afford basic housing. In black-and-white photographs that document the pervasiveness of homelessness around the country, it is the children - the smaller army within the larger - who appear the most vulnerable: a defiant girl eats from a metal bowl under a California overpass; a toddler, serene in sleep, lies beside his mother on a patch of grass in New York City. For individuals and communities that want to help, the book lists public and private ways to do so. The photographs - by Eugene Richards, Stephen Shames, Mary Ellen Mark, William Pierce and Eli Reed, among others, edited by the photojournalist Michael A. W. Evans - are also part of a traveling exhibit that will be at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, through Oct. 22. It is scheduled to visit a number of American cities over the next two years.

title: Hospitals Asking State To Reverse Rate Cuts
description: HOSPITALS in the state face budget cuts as deep as 48 percent starting this week, at a when time they contend that they need increases of 15 to 40 percent to continue.

title: First Sine of M.I.T.: 29-7
description: A Massachusetts Institute of Technology tailback, Shane LaHousse, rushed for 260 yards and 4 touchdowns to lead the Beavers to victory in their first game as a varsity team, defeating Stonehill College, 29-7, at Steinbrenner Field today.

title: Earning The Name 'University'
description: NEW JERSEY does not want to be at a competive disadvantage with neighboring states when it comes to higher-education opportunities.

title: TRISKAIDEKAPHILIA
description: J. IRA HARRIS OF Chicago, a 50-year-old partner at Lazard Freres, is simply crazy about the number 13. Harris's license plate and his home and office telephones contain 13's. He was born on April 13th, has often bet successfully on the numbers 1, 3 and 13, and once sent a bill to a client for $1,313, 313.l3 for an acquisition deal.

title: MAN IS SENTENCED IN A FRAUD SCHEME
description: A former debt collector who wrote a how-to crime book while in prison has been sentenced to more prison time for credit-card fraud and told to repay American Express $35,000.

title: Economist Is Wed To Dr. Fergusson, Vassar President
description: Dr. Frances Daly Fergusson, the president of Vassar College, and Dr. Michael Moohr, the chairman of the department of economics at Bucknell University, were married yesterday at St. Luke in the Fields Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Ledlie I. Laughlin Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Hitters Could Have Problems In National League Playoff
description: The National League cannot have a pennant winner if neither of the teams in the pennant playoff scores a run. The problem for the hitters of the Mets and the Los Angeles Dodgers, then, will be to figure out how to score runs against the Dodgers' and the Mets' pitchers.

title: TURNAROUND ARTIST: Bennett S. LeBow; Collecting Wall Street's Wallflowers
description: BENNETT S. LEBOW claims that the only thing on earth that infuriates him is getting caught in New York City traffic. But the 50-year-old investor was clearly irritated last week when he was asked about reports that executives at American Brands Inc. - his latest acquisition target - have been calling him a ''pawn'' of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the investment bank that was recently charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with securities violations.

title: Market At Airport May Close
description: LEAD: A FLEA market in operation for more than a decade at Republic Airport in Farmingdale will close next Sunday unless its owners can come to an agreement with the state's Department of Transportation, which runs the airport.

title: U.S.-Style Philanthropy Gains in the Soviet Union
description: American-style philanthropy seems to be taking root here.

title: Troubles in Yonkers Are a Lesson for Us All
description: REGARDLESS of what happens in the Yonkers brouhaha over proposed low-income housing in a predominantly white, middle-income section of that troubled city, I predict that it will have a decided impact upon other towns and villages, with similar housing challenges.

title: THE CASE OF PAUL DE MAN
description: I am identified by James Atlas as the ''prosecution'' who, his ''voice shaking with anger,'' spoke about Paul de Man in Antwerp. I am sorry that the grief I felt on describing a scene evoked in Lanzmann's film ''Shoah,'' in which Nazi guards mock the Jews murdered and disinterred at Chelmno, by calling them ''figures,'' prompted Mr. Atlas to report a cruder emotion.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE MEN AND WOMEN OF YESHIVA: Higher Education, Orthodoxy, and American Judaism. By Jeffrey S. Gurock. (Columbia University, $35.) In the spring of 1970, when college campuses around the nation were exploding in the wake of Kent State and Richard Nixon's bombing of Cambodia, Yeshiva University was faced with a dilemma. Should it close down, like other universities, or should it keep its doors open? Yeshiva's solution was appropriately Solomonic: it decided to close the college but keep its Jewish studies programs going. The incident is just one telling detail in this well-written and lively account of Yeshiva's first 100 years by Jeffrey S. Gurock, a professor of history at the school. For most of its life, Yeshiva has walked the fine line between American culture and Orthodox Judaism and come up with something unique - American Orthodoxy, which says Jews can be true to their traditions while playing full and active roles in the modern world. Mr. Gurock traces Yeshiva's history from a small Jewish school on the Lower East Side to a major university. I graduated from Yeshiva College in 1971, and I maintain strong personal and familial ties with the school. I found ''The Men and Women of Yeshiva'' worthwhile, not only because I am among those invoked in the title, but because the book has something to say to a much broader audience. After all, Yeshiva is only one of hundreds of universities, Harvard and Yale among them, that began with a distinct religious mission. While the religious dimension of many of the other schools is today but a memory, Judaism remains at the core of Yeshiva. That has not always made life easy for Yeshiva, but it has made it - and this book - interesting.

title: Working the Gap Between Art And Politics
description: The walls of the Dia Art Foundation exhibition space at 77 Wooster Street have been painted blackboard gray and smeared with chalk. A grade school regulation clock oversees one wall, the American flag another; and rows of school chairs, replete with carved initials, march across the floor. These props set the stage for ''Education and Democracy,'' an exhibition that juxtaposes, among many other things, the efforts of blue chip art stars and junior high school students from Brooklyn, forming a handsome, cacophonous collage in which many disparate voices are heard.

title: GOLDEN OLDIES
description: IT BEGAN AS A HOBBY.

title: JAPAN BORROWS A CHINESE WALL
description: FOR MOST OF ITS HISTORY, Japan has borrowed liberally from China, adapting the best of its inventions outright and modifying others. So when Japanese securities firms, deeply embarrassed by a torrent of insider-trading cases, rushed to build a ''Chinese Wall'' between their retail sales forces and their corporate finance departments last summer, it seemed reasonable to assume that Japan had done it again.

title: Comforting the Afflicted in an Intolerant World
description: FROM its beginnings just after World War II, United Cerebral Palsy of Nassau has been guiding the helpless toward as normal a life as is possible and teaching them to cope with a largely uncaring, if not intolerant, world.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: CHAMBER SERIES

title: Torah Scrolls: Sacred History and Knowledge
description: THEY are called ''People of the Book,'' and Jews lived up to their name last week at an extraordinary funeral service in Brooklyn for five Torah scrolls destroyed by vandals. As rabbis delivered eulogies over the plain pine coffin holding the charred scrolls, it was almost as if the People of the Book had made a person of the Book.

title: The Fate of Baby Amy
description: IT WAS AN EARLY SPRING. I remember stopping to smell the blossoms on a neighbor's plum tree while out walking with my husband during the early hours of my labor. An earlier pregnancy had ended in miscarriage, but our hopes had grown again when my doctor picked up a strong heart-beat three months into this pregnancy. The promise of new life held only happiness for us that February evening.

title: 'Robeson': Back To Broadway Amid Calm
description: When it first opened on Broadway 10 Years ago, phillip Hayes Dean's play ''Paul Robeson'' capsized under an attack of black intellectuals who issued an open letter charging the play with trivializing its subject, the prodigiously talented singer, actor, athlete and social crusader. This week the play is returning to Broadway without a murmur of dissent.

title:
DINING OUT;
Staying Power in Yorktown
description: LEAD: SITUATED in a sparsely populated area of the county, the Lakeside Restaurant should be congratuated for its staying power. It has been there as long as we can remember, through its several ownerships remaining a humble establishment of limited accomplishment, delivering to a neighborhood clientele hefty, straightforward cuisine in equally hefty portion.

title: 'Punchline' Comes Up With the Last Laugh
description: The world of ''Punchline'' is thick with cigarette smoke and even thicker with anger. It is the world of basement comedy clubs where sloppy drunks dare the people on stage to make them laugh, and the man in the spotlight needs applause as desperately as a drowning man needs air.

title: Student Dies in Plunge From Columbia Dorm
description: A freshman at Columbia University plunged to his death from his 14th-floor dormitory room in an apparent suicide early yesterday, the third student in New York City to die that way in the last week, the police said.

title: Who Caged Ebony Rabbit?
description: I'M worried that I'm a worry wart. I've always had this tendency. One reason I quit as a college English teacher is that it became too worrisome.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: 'Slide-Proofing' a Stretch of the Thruway The rock wall along a 2,000-foot stretch of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway is contining to retreat under an assault by demolition crews. The section of highway, in the town of Greenburgh was the site of a rockslide last January that left one motorist dead.

title: THE WORLD: Two Views; For Chileans, It's Finally Yes or No On Pinochet
description: CHILEANS will vote Oct. 5 on whether to extend Gen. Augusto Pinochet's presidential tenure for eight more years. If he does not win a majority in the one-man plebiscite, he is supposed to call free elections by the end of next year. For outsiders, the decision seems self-evident: The Government is repressive and has been linked to political killings and torture. But Chileans are weighing a desire for democracy against the country's troubled history.

title: Meredith von Brock Weds in Connecticut
description: At the Congregational Church in New Canaan, Conn., Meredith von Brock, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Raymond von Brock of Bohannon, Va., and Charles Geza von Arentschildt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. von Arentschildt of London, were married yesterday by the Rev. Charles C. Smith.

title: Kathryn McDonald Is Engaged to Kurt T. Doctor
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. McDonald of Hackettstown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathryn Frances McDonald to Kurt Timothy Doctor, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ivan S. Doctor of Southfield, Mich.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Soviets to Limit Moscow Tours To 3 Nights

title: New Dorp Wins, 15-14, on a 2-Point Conversion Pass   P.S.A.L.
description: Staten Island football teams were the class of the Public Schools Athletic League in last year's regular season, but after the first round of the 1987 playoffs, none remained. Last week, the losing continued, as Staten Island schools lost four of five games in the first week of P.S.A.L. action.

title: Kathleen Rae Bole Becomes the Wife Of Paul H. Klingenstein 2d, Executive
description: Kathleen Rae Bole, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin P. Bole 3d of Scholls, Ore., and Paul Henry Klingenstein 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Paul Klingenstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., were married yesterday on the grounds at the Mountain Lakes House in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Frank C. Strasburger, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Finding Ways to Turn Trash Into Cash
description: IT will soon be harder to get rid of products made with plastic, that substance that has come to symbolize our throwaway society. Discarded plastic bottles, milk jugs and fast-food containers - not to mention the plastic syringes and vials that have washed up on our beaches - are flooding the nation's already-overflowing landfills. As a result, lawmakers are clamping tight restrictions on the disposal of the 10.5 million tons of plastic waste generated each year.

title: Landscaping
description: To the Editor: At the end of his article on Humphry Repton's architectural gem, Sheringham Hall (Travel, July 3), Paul Lewis referred to the late-18th-century controversy over landscape gardening between Repton, Uvedale Price and Richard Payne Knight.

title: IN THE MARKET: FEAR OF BUYING
description: LEAD: PEOPLE ARE AFRAID OF STOCKS,'' says Valery Craane, a Merrill Lynch & Company broker in New York. ''People want more safety and liquidity in their investments,'' says Bruce J. Rhodes, a first vice president of Raymond James & Associates in its Boca Raton, Fla., brokerage office. ''Several clients who have been equity investors for years, and who have made good money, have decided to liquidate completely,'' says Jerry R.

title: As More Companies Make Compact Disks, Flaws Increase
description: The ascent of compact disks seems a classic case of virtue triumphant. After all, CD's are supposedly faultless: no clicks, pops or any of the other ills the old LP's were heir to. On technical merits, the success of the silver platters seems well deserved.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: AMERICAN EARTHQUAKES. By Constance Urdang. (Coffee House Press/Consortium Book Sales and Distribution, 213 East Fourth Street, St. Paul, Minn. 55101, Paper, $9.95.) The poet Constance Urdang's new novella is a bold experiment in style and structure. Focusing on three generations of a St. Louis family, ''American Earthquakes'' narrates in a highly fragmented, elliptical fashion the lives of three sisters - Helen, Tess and Ethel - and their husbands, lovers, children and grandchildren.

title: The Idea That Democracy Pays Helps Reshape East-West Ties
description: IS the cold war over? Has the West won? The questions may seem impudently provocative in the midst of an American campaign that has Michael S. Dukakis scrambling to demonstrate that he is as tough-minded on defense as George Bush, while the Republican's running mate dismisses Mikhail S. Gorbachev's innovations in the Soviet Union as warmed-over Stalinism.

title: Si Newhouse Tests His Magazine Magic
description: EVERY weekend in July when many of his friends and colleagues are preparing for their long drives to the Hamptons, Si Newhouse boards a jet and heads for his house in Palm Beach to spend the weekend reading.

title: Elizabeth Otto Weds Christopher Paquette
description: Elizabeth Davis Otto, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Otto Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Christopher Jean Paquette, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Paquette of Manchester, N.H., were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Oxford, Mass. The Rev. William J. Winterrowd officiated.

title: IN THE THEATERS, AN AMERICAN HARVEST
description: It almost seems to have been a conspiracy. On the eve of the 26th New York Film Festival, which opened at Avery Fisher Hall Friday night, Manhattan's movie theaters were suddenly offering more films by talented and innovative American film makers than have been seen here at any one time in years: Jonathan Demme's ''Married to the Mob,'' Francis Coppola's ''Tucker,'' Paul Schrader's ''Patty Hearst,'' Martin Scorsese's ''Last Temptation of Christ,'' Errol Morris's ''Thin Blue Line,'' Sidney Lumet's ''Running on Empty'' and John Sayles' ''Eight Men Out.''

title: Flexible Work Hours Grow More Popular
description: WHEN Susan M. Garvey worked for MONY Financial Services' personnel department in Manhattan, she took advantage of the company's ''flex-time'' program to beat the heavy commuter traffic to and from her home in lower Westchester.

title: 174 Laws Taking Frce This Week
description: WHEN Federal Judge Robert H. Bork was nominated to the Supreme Court last year, a Washington publication listed his videotape rentals, and that might have made more than a few people in Connecticut consider that their rentals might become known.

title: Taking Tokens
description: 'We're seeing a very serious trend. A year ago, we were losing $50,000 to $60,000 a month from break-ins. But it's now approaching $170,000 for August and, I expect, $200,000 in September.' - David L. Gunn, president of the Transit Authority on the growing loss of revenue from the vandalism of New York City's subway turnstiles.

title: Vivian Steir Wed to Dr. Douglas Rabin
description: Vivian Esther Steir, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Berton Steir of Brookline, Mass., was married last night to Dr. Douglas Stuart Rabin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Charles Rabin of West Chester, Pa. Rabbi Ephraim Greenberg performed the ceremony at Temple Bnai Moshe in Boston.

title:
GARDENING;
Trees Can Mitigate Greenhouse Effect
description: LEAD: MANY environmentalists predict that a buildup of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere from the burning of fossil fuels and others will result in the greenhouse effect and that the buildup will reduce the amount of heat the Earth radiates into the atmosphere, raising global temperatures.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Gregg Jefferies The Rookie Of the Year?
description: When we examine three recent winners of the Rookie of the Year award, only one statistic needs to be taken into consideration, games played: A.L., 1986, Jose Canseco (157); A.L., 1987, Mark McGwire (151) and N.L., 1987, Benito Santiago (146). By season's end Jefferies will have played in between 30 and 35 games. There appears to be some discrepancy with these figures. Dream on, Met fans. OHN MAITA Paramus, N.J.

title: Talks Urged in Suits Against Judge's Estate
description: Compromise, not litigation, appears to be the best way for embezzlement victims of a Danbury Probate judge to get back their money, a judge said.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Coming: Swedish Prefabs for Connecticut
description: SKANSKA U.S.A., a Swedish builder based in Greenwich since 1982 that has yet to build anything in Connecticut, carries on its business with such quiet efficiency that few have heard of it.

title: After 3 Years, Miners Still Walk Picket Line
description: Harold Durham sat outside the entrance to the No. 4 mine of Zinc Corporation of America, alone in his Dodge pickup with his cigarettes, coffee and pillow.

title: Far-Off Hurricane Affects New York's Apple Crop
description: Even though it was far away, Hurricane Gilbert, which devastated Jamaica, has had an impact in New York, delaying the state's apple harvest.

title: Theater Plans Arouse Protests
description: A PLAN to build a multi-use theater complex on five and a half acres acres along Jericho Turnpike in Syosset has aroused angry protests and serious concerns among local residents.

title: ZONKED AGAIN
description: LEAD: STORY OF MY LIFE By Jay McInerney. 189 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $16.95.

title: The Condo Option for Transient Employees
description: SEVERAL years ago officers of Bankers Trust Company, an international financial institution with a staff of more than 11,000 worldwide, became aware that its corporate expenses for housing transient employees in New York were rising rapidly, and were beginning to exceed $1 million a year.

title: Soviet To Hear His Mass in Hartford
description: THE Soviet composer Vitali Gewicksmann will be traveling to Connecticut from Moscow to attend the world premiere of his ''Duodecim Cantica'' Mass next Sunday at Hartford's Trinity College.

title: Ex-Panama President Challenges U.N.'s Invitation to His Successor
description: Panama's ousted President has challenged plans for his successor to address the General Assembly next week.

title: U.S. and Afghan Guerrillas Debate New Raids
description: There is a growing debate between American officials and Afghan guerrilla leaders over how best to insure the speedy exodus of Soviet troops from Afghanistan.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Windsor,Ont.;
Condo Buys Near Detroit
description: LEAD: A GROWING condominium market in this quiet city of 200,000 on the Canadian side of the Detroit River has hundreds of Americans streaming across the river in search of new housing at a favorable price.

title: Electric Boat Strikers to Face Charge Before Labor Board
description: The National Labor Relations Board will hold a hearing on a charge by the Electric Boat company that its striking unions broke the law by not notifying Federal mediatiors of the potential for a walkout 30 days in advance.

title: Miss Oratz to Wed Carl Siegel Nov. 19
description: Dr. and Mrs. Murray Oratz of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Ann Oratz to Carl Siegel, a son of Mrs. Maurice T. Siegel of Baltimore and the late Mr. Siegel. The couple plan to marry Nov. 19.

title: A 'Talk Shop' to Decrease the Deficit
description: A DEBATE erupted last week in Washington that highlights the fact that the Federal budget deficit won't go away.

title: Conquering Those Killer Queues
description: WHEN he is hard at work, Richard Larson sometimes finds himself watching videotapes, his eyebrows arched in perpetual scrutiny. He doesn't watch ''Top Gun'' or ''Meatballs'' or anything fun like that. He peers at tapes of customers in line at checkout counters at Zayre department stores. People shuffle forward, merchandise gets shoveled on checkout conveyors. Now and then, someone sneezes. After a while, viewing the tapes can be worse than waiting in line. ''They do get boring,'' Mr. Larson admits. ''So you just fast-forward them.''

title: Question Of the Week; Is Gregg Jefferies The Rookie Of the Year?
description: To give Jefferies the Rookie of the Year award would be to make a mockery of that award. Let's wait and evaluate him after a full year in the big leagues. DOUG FRIED New York

title: The Political Epilogue To Jamaica's Disaster
description: THE devastation wreaked by Hurricane Gilbert two weeks ago may become an important factor in Jamaica's first political campaign in eight years. Neither of the island's two principal politicians, Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga and Michael N. Manley, whom Mr. Seaga defeated in 1980, are openly trying to capitalize on the disaster. But calculations about how it will affect the election are already being made behind the scenes.

title: Mexico City and the Loss of Innocence
description: I carried a manual typewriter and a certain Olympian innocence to Mexico City 20 years ago. I didn't fully understand that the Games I was covering were not the only games being played. I thought that Bob Beamon's great leap forward and the black power salutes of Tommie Smith and John Carlos were entirely separate incidents, one a sporting event, the other a political statement, and that the Olympic Movement itself was so swollen with pretension and hypocrisy that it would soon explode in the atmosphere like one of its ceremonial balloons. No gold for foresight there. Today I am wired to $80,000 worth of video equipment and I am almost too hip to be happy. I can see those two Olympic moments not only with the clarity of hindsight - replay, slo-mo, freeze frame - but I can see them as a double exposure: Beamon's incredible leap was an expression of muscular joy that made possible the Smith-Carlos rage. If we didn't feel ennobled by sports achievement we would never be so vulnerable to its exploitation.

title: K. J. Redding Wed To Miss Canavan
description: Patricia Reynolds Canavan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Terence C. Canavan of Chatham, N.J., and Kenneth James Redding, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Redding of Chatham, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J. Msgr. John F. Corr performed the ceremony.

title: Distinction from an Ancient Order
description: BURIED in the historic center of Rome is what may be the world's smallest stamp-issuing authority.

title: SCENARIO FOR A NEW AGE
description: FOR THE EMPLOYEES OF THE Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, it was the worst of times. On Aug. 28, 1986, the company announced a massive restructuring plan to foil a takeover threat mounted by Sanford C. Sigoloff, chairman of the Wickes Companies. In the months that followed, Owens-Corning sold off some of its divisions and reorganized others; the work force was cut from 28,000 to 17,000. Many employees were embittered and exhausted.

title: YITZHAK SHAMIR'S STUBBORN STRENGTH
description: Joel Brinkley described Yitzhak Shamir's background as a Jewish rebel against British rule in Palestine during the 1940's (''The Stubborn Strength of Yitzhak Shamir,'' Aug. 21). He interviewed former British policemen with bitter memories of their comrades slain by Mr. Shamir's forces.

title: Fall Foliage Outlook is Optimistic
description: LEAD: ALONG with the stock market and election outcomes, the brilliance of fall foliage is a perennial favorite for prediction.

title:
ART;
Paintings That Seem Like Puzzles
description: LEAD: THE Peter Stroud retrospective at the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton is an austere show that does not fit the category of crowd pleaser. It is too bare bones for that and will appeal to those who like the squares within squares of Josef Albers or the all-white paintings of Robert Ryman.

title: Sarah Bernhardt Examined In Photographs and Film
description: She could not recall who the father of her son was, Sarah Bernhardt wrote in her memoir, but she placed Victor Hugo on a short list of possibilities. She once announced she was having a leopard's tail grafted into herself. She continued acting well into old age, a star and a scandal because she adored theatricality on stage and off. ''Sarah,'' Edgardo Cozarinsky's half-hour film about her life and career, is as wonderfully profligate as the actress herself. A rich compilation of photographs and films, it captures the wild variety of Bernhardt's histrionics and the feel of an age when melodrama was a descriptive word, not a dirty one. ''Sarah'' will be shown at the New York Film Festival tonight at 9:30 and tomorrow at 6:15.

title: AGENCY WILL TRACK THOSE DISCIPLINED OVER MEDICAL CARE
description: In an effort to identify incompetent health practitioners, the Department of Health and Human Services is creating a nationwide data bank of disciplinary actions taken against physicians, dentists, nurses, therapists and other licensed health professionals.

title: Why Debates Fizzle Instead of Sizzle
description: If the prospect of tonight's encounter between George Bush and Michael Dukakis does not set your blood to racing, that probably means you have seen previous Presidential debates.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: South; Humphrey Out With Fracture To Foot
description: Bobby Humphrey, Alabama's career rushing leader and a Heisman Trophy candidate, suffered a broken bone in his left foot today in his team's 44-10 Southeastern Conference game victory over Vanderbilt and will probably miss the rest of the season.

title: Career Ban Eyed For Drug Users

description: Few things in Canadian politics in recent years have run so much against expectation as the vexed fortunes of John N. Turner, once a champion athlete and Rhodes scholar and now leader of the Liberal Party.

description: To the Editor:
