title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We recently had our kitchen cabinets refinished with a Formica veneer. Several months later, we noticed that the veneer on one five-foot-long cabinet door was starting to come loose in the middle, forming a blister or ''balloon'' about six inches long. The adhesive above and below this is adhering tightly. Is there anything we can do to loosen the panel so that it can be taken off and reglued?

title: Mamaroneck Grapples With Parking Meters
description: LEAD: PARKING METERS in Mamaroneck have some people seeing red. It seems that many of the 536 meters the village installed last year - mostly on Mamaroneck Avenue, its main business district - accept money but often do not provide the paid-for time.

title: Correction
description: An article and a brief report on Sept. 11 about rail travel in the Soviet Union misstated several prices because of currency conversion errors. At the exchange rate of 0.63 rubles to $1, the cost of a first-class rail compartment from Moscow to Irkutsk is $230; the one-way fare to return to Moscow by air is $178; a cupful of berries in Irkutsk costs 48 cents; a bunch of gladiolus is $1.59, and men's suits are $238.50 to $254.40.

title: In London, a Sense of the Ballet World's Intimacy
description: Sometimes it seems as if all ballet is one big artistic family. I certainly felt that in London recently after seeing performances by the Kirov and London Festival Ballets and an exhibition called ''Shadowland'' at the National Portrait Gallery devoted to the works of Gordon Anthony, a British photographer of ballet stars from the 1930's to the 50's.

title: The Quest for Firewood Dwindles
description: LEAD: FALL arrived last week, causing many Westchester residents to eye branches for the first colorful signs of the season. But Geoffrey Thompson of Yorktown has set his sights lower, often stopping his car to gaze at trees that are on the ground.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TEATOWN BIRTHDAY Teatown Lake Reservation will celebrate its 25th birthday and kick off a $2 million fund-raising effort next weekend. The 475-acre nature center serving Westchester and Putnam Counties has begun restoration of the 70-year-old stables, grooms quarters and carriage house of the former Swope estate to create classrooms, administrative offices, a community center and staff housing.

title: A Hard Lesson
description: THE UNITED STATES HOLOCAUST Memorial Museum, a tribute to the victims of the Nazis, is scheduled to open in 1990 in Washington. Its permanent exhibition will document the story of the Holocaust from the rise of Hitler through the implementation of his ''Final Solution,'' but its most resonant feature may well be contributed by citizens too young to have any knowledge at all of the century's darkest historical episode. The ''Wall of Remembrance,'' dedicated to the 1.5 million Jewish children murdered by the Nazis, will consist of ceramic tiles handpainted by American schoolchildren.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L Rangers Top Devils: Tomas Sandstrom and Ulf Dahlen scored first-period power play goals yesterday to lead the Rangers to a 3-2 victory over the Devils in an exhibition game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J. Sandstrom opened the scoring at 9 minutes 43 seconds with a 10-foot shot over the stick of the Devils goaltender, Sean Burke. Dahlen scored at 14:52. The teams traded second-period power-play goals. Bruce Driver scored for the Devils at 11:36 as he beat Mike Richter with a shot from the point. Richter had just replaced Bob Froese in the Ranger net. Kelly Kisio scored the final goal at 16:41 on a Ranger power play. Corey Foster added a goal for the Devils with 41 seconds left in the game.(AP) Golf Hill Ahead by a Shot: Dave Hill birdied his final hole for a second consecutive four-under 68 yesterday, taking a one-stroke lead over Bobby Nichols and Bob Charles after two rounds of the Paine Webber Invitational Seniors tournament in Charlotte, N.C. Hill hit a 7-iron within 3 feet of the 413-yard 18th hole and then made his birdie putt for a 136 total. Nichols also had a 68 after beginning the round trailing Don Massengale, the first-day leader, by two strokes. Charles, who lost a playoff to Gary Player here last year, had three consecutive birdies on the front nine and had the day's low round of 66.(AP) Glasson Leads B.C. Open: Bill Glasson made six birdies on his first 11 holes yesterday and shot a six-under-par 65, giving him a 213 and a three-stroke lead after three rounds of the $500,000 B.C. Open in Endicott, N.Y. Glasson's closest challenger going into today's final round was the defending champion, Joey Sindelar. Wayne Levi, Don Pooley, Brad Bryant and Lanc ten Broeck were four strokes at 217, followed by Ian Baker-Finch at 218. Glasson is seeking his first victory on the tour since the 1985 Kemper Open.(AP) Tennis Agassi Defeats McEnroe: Top-seeded Andre Agassi downed John McEnroe 6-4, 0-6, 6-4, yesterday, to advance to the finals of the $415,000 Volvo Los Angeles men's tennis tournament. McEnroe withstood six match points before the 18-year-old Agassi finally won. McEnroe lost the first set when Agassi got a service break for a 5-4 lead and then served out the set. A barrage of hard, well-placed serves and crisp passing shots allowed McEnroe, seeded No. 3, to tie the match without losing a game in the second set. The players held serve in the third set until Agassi broke McEnroe in the seventh game. With Agassi serving for the match at 5-4, McEnroe battled back to deuce six times before falling. (AP) Soccer Liverpool Beats Southampton: Despite having seven players injured, Liverpool turned on a championship performance to win, 3-1, at Southampton yesterday, spoiling the home team's unbeaten record and moving up to second place in the English First Division standing. Norwich City stayed in first place despite a 2-2 home tie with Millwall. Arsenal lost, 2-1, at Sheffield Wednesday, and Everton was upset, 2-0, at home by Luton Town. (AP) Australian Football Hawthorn Wins Final: The Hawthorn Hawks won the Victorian Football League final yesterday, defeating the Melbourne Demons, 152-56, before a crowd of 93,754 at the Melbourne Cricket Ground. Hawthorn's victory gave the Hawks their third title in six years. Melbourne, which finished the regular season in fifth place, was playing in the final for the first time in 24 years. (AP)

title: POSTINGS: $86 Million Islip Development; 359 Homes Near the Airport
description: When the Town of Islip began to have second thoughts about the industrial zoning of some land near Long Island MacArthur Airport, Racanelli & Associates, one of Long Island's largest industrial builders, had second thoughts about holding on to it. Instead, they sold the 75-acre, factory-sized lot in Holbrook to the Holiday Organization, one of Long Island's largest residential builders. The wooded site is bounded on three sides by single-family homes. But the lot had been zoned for light industrial and retail use since the 60's when Islip officials hoped new jobs would be created for the buyers of new homes being built. Land across Furrows Road has retained industrial zoning, but the homeowners on either side of the Racanelli site opposed such a development and asked the town to rezone.

title: Hats to Go
description: PATRICIA UNDERWOOD, whose hats grace the collections of Calvin Klein and Perry Ellis at $200 to $600, has a new line of moderately priced headgear. The line, called Patricia Underwood Too, features 17 crushable hats made of velvet, wool knit or nylon and polyester taffeta at $25 to $80. The designer, at right, wears a black and white wool houndstooth toque; $35 at Bergdorf Goodman, $40 at Barneys. Matching scarf is $45 at Bergdorf's, $48 at Barneys. The T. S. Eliot Hat, left, is red, black or blue; $45 at Bergdorf's, $56 at Barneys. The velvet trapper hat, right, in black or purple, is $75 at Bergdorf's, $80 at Barneys.

title: Lilly Shiland Weds Stanley Shoemaker
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Louise Shiland, a daughter of Mrs. Ralph S. Gallagher of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the late Andrew Shiland Jr., to Stanley George Shoemaker, a son of Mrs. Marshall L. Shoemaker of Saratoga, Calif., and the late Mr. Shoemaker, took place yesterday at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Mission Impossible
description: MAX HOLLAND, A WASHINGTON writer, began missing letters and magazines when he got a new postman last spring. Two months later, he went to a party at an office building nearby. In the lobby, he found a stack of mail that included his missing letters and magazines. Even after he had notified the post office of the error, his mail continued to go to the office building. In Lancaster, Ky., the Christian

title: Westerner Is Crowned Lama
description: Catharine Burroughs, a 38-year-old mother of three, today became the first adult in the Western world to be crowned as a reincarnate Buddhist lama. The lamas, teachers with an obligation to help rid the world of suffering, are venerated by Tibetan Buddhists because they are believed to return to this world voluntarily to enlighten others. Mrs. Burroughs was crowned by Penor Rinpoche, a designated ''living Buddha'' who heads a monastery in India.

title: A Matter of Technique
description: Setting a Presidential tone will be a preoccupation for the nominees tonight, for voters respond to nonverbal cues and not just to words. Page 24.

title: Mari Nakakuki Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Mari Louise Christiana Nakakuki, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Masafumi Nakakuki of Englewood, Colo., to Michael Patrick McAndrews, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. McAndrews of Kennett Square, Pa., took place yesterday in New York. The Rev. Kenneth Frances-Kelly performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church.

title: Concerns About Coverage
description: I have many problems with the Olympic Games, namely the unnecessary hype of the television coverage and the participation of seasoned professionals such as Chris Evert. But what I viewed last Saturday afternoon took the cake. In order to be comical and to show the poor caliber of athletic abilities of some of the countries, NBC played a portion of the basketball game between Egypt and the People's Republic of China in fast forward with humorous music. What bothers me is that this occurrence may not have been an oversight by NBC, but a serious attempt at humor at the expense of countries that are fulfilling the Olympic ideal by taking part. I would have to believe that the people of these two countries must be angry and dismayed and I am embarrassed at this. BARRY N. NOCKS Marblehead, Mass.

title: INSIDE
description: Gain on Eye Disease

title: Nancy Ameen and Toby Hoden Marry
description: Nancy Adele Ameen, who is to join the New York law firm of White & Case as an associate Oct. 31, and Alan George Hoden, a product manager with the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, were married yesterday at the Congregational Church of the Redeemer in New Haven. The Rev. Thomas Burgett-Lentner performed the ceremony.

title: Sunshine Forever Holds On
description: Last month, John Veitch tried to become the first trainer to win $1 million races at different tracks within 24 hours. He sent out Brian's Time in the $1 million Travers at Saratoga and Sunshine Forever in the Arlington Million at Woodbine, but the two 3-year-olds sons of Roberto both finished third, beaten under two lengths.

title: Oklahoma Feels Crunch of U.S.C.
description: The Oklahoma Sooners came here thinking of taking a forceful and significant step toward a national college football championship. They left this afternoon defeated in every phase of the game after the sixth-worst defeat in Barry Switzer's 16 seasons as coach.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Lane Theater; In a 1930's Movie Palace, the Stars Still Come Out
description: THE Art Moderne Lane Theater in New Dorp has an unusual decorative scheme, but most of it has been painted over. It is also the last single-screen movie house on Staten Island, at a time when the multiplex theater dominates movie-house economics.

title: Kitty Dukakis Stings G.O.P. With Her Attack
description: She corrected a television journalist in Columbus, Ohio, who suggested that Vice President Bush was ahead in the polls. The race is ''dead even,'' Kitty Dukakis insisted with a steely smile.

title: A Neglected British Genius
description: THOUGH van Gogh has become the archetype, the style for neglected genius was set 100 years earlier by the English poet Thomas Chatterton, who achieved immortality by poisoning himself shortly before his 18th birthday. David Bomberg (1890-1957) suffered greatly for lack of recognition, but the fame that eluded him in life seems no closer in death, notwithstanding the presence of his work in numerous English collections, public and private.

title: A Takeover Battle In the Gold Fields
description: Two gold-mining giants began a takeover battle. A division of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa offered $4.9 billion for Consolidated Gold Fields, a London-based company with huge mines in South Africa. Anglo American, the Western world's largest gold producer, is controlled by the Oppenheimer dynasty of South Africa, which runs the De Beers diamond operations. Consolidated, the second-ranked gold producer, can trace its roots to the British Empire days of Cecil Rhodes. Anglo American said it would try to sell Consolidated's South African mines. That was seen as a sign that Harry Oppenheimer, who opposes apartheid, might be wanting to trim his family's stake in South Africa. Consolidated said it was against the takeover, which would be the largest ever of a British company.

title: Folly of Destroying Old School Buildings
description: In her excellent article, ''Old, Old School Buildings'' [ Opinion, Sept. 11 ] , Edie Brown Eisenberg showed the folly of the destruction of the Hewlett-Woodmere school complex. It is now due to be replaced, in part, by ''additions'' to the existing schools if the voters approve a bond issue she cites at ''$20 million to $30 million.''

title: Milton Waltcher, 69, an Executive, Dies
description: Milton Waltcher, director of administrative services for Automated Data Processing Inc., died of skin cancer yesterday at St. Clare's Hospital in Denville, N.J. He was 69 years old and lived in Madison, N.J.

title: When You Need to Send Cash in a Flash
description: THERE are numerous reasons why someone may need to transmit cash in a flash. A son or daughter is stranded with a broken-down car and not enough money to get it fixed. A spouse extends the length of a trip because of unforeseen circumstances. A wallet is lost on a vacation or a business trip. These are just some of the unfortunate situations requiring money to be sent immediately.

title: EMILY'S BRILLIANT CAREER
description: AFTER SHE LEFT By Richard P. Brickner. 290 pp. New York: A Donald Hutter Book/Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

title: Elin Slutsky Is Wed
description: At Temple Beth-El in Cedarhurst, L.I., Elin Beth Slutsky, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Slutsky of Massapequa, L.I., was married last evening to Michael Benjamin Nierenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Nierenberg of Massapequa Park. L.I. Rabbi Sanford H. Jarashow, assisted by Cantor Robert Applestone, performed the ceremony. The bride is an account executive at Racquet magazine in New York. Mr. Nierenberg is a mortgage analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York.

title: Divorce Keeping Taxes Minimal
description: THE bloating of property values in many parts of the country in the last several years is creating a new set of issues for couples to face in separation and divorce.

title: No, Don't Let Yellowstone Burn
description: To the Editor:

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Which Is The Better Team, '86 Mets, Or '88 Mets?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: THE CASE OF PAUL DE MAN
description: Beyond an enigmatic remark to a bewildered colleague and a few ambiguous lines about the mercies of his own forgetfulness, Paul de Man never expressed the slightest remorse for his eager little contribution to the intellectual underpinnings of the Nazi Holocaust.

title:
MUSIC;
Israeli Pianist to Make County Debut
description: LEAD: THE Teatown Lake Reservation in Ossining is one of the county's environmental jewels and next weekend the Nature Center there is preparing a three-day celebration of its 25th anniversary. Its centerpiece is the Westchester debut of the young Israeli pianist Ilan Rechtman.

title: Police 'Point Man' in Davis Shootout Is to Testify
description: The Bronx detective who was the ''point man'' in the group of seven police officers who confronted Larry Davis in a shootout in a cramped Bronx apartment almost two years ago is expected to provide a dramatic climax this week to the prosecution's case in the Davis trial.

title: Liam Thomas Ward Marries Miss Grogan
description: Mary Ellen Grogan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Grogan of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Liam Thomas Ward, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Ward Jr. of Fort Myers, Fla. The Rev. Gerald E. Murray Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Ossining, N.Y.

title: BETTING AGAINST THE ODDS
description: HE CONSIDERED HIMSELF a model family man. Bright, friendly and personable, the bank vice president left his job every afternoon at 5 and headed straight home to Long Island. When he arrived, he kissed his wife and child, hung up his jacket, went into the bathroom to wash up - and broke into a cold sweat.

title: Ethnic Problem for Moscow: Few Likely Options
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's predecessors would have known how to handle the tense standoff that now prevails in the southern Soviet republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: LEAVES OF FORTUNE. By Linda Barlow. (Doubleday, $18.95.) ''Leaves of Fortune,'' a new novel by Linda Barlow, the 1986 winner of Romantic Times magazine's award for best new historical author of the year, should be subtitled, ''Something for Everyone.'' This saga of the Boston-based Templeton Tea dynasty has channeling and crystals for the New Age crowd.

title: THE NATION: Still the Leader; Reagan Lays Out Coattails For the Bush Campaign
description: THRUSTING their arms into the air, clenching their hands into claws, students at Baylor University screamed at top volume, ''Sic 'em, Bears!''

title: Regan Attacks Monitoring of Zoning Waivers in New York
description: The New York City Planning Commission has allowed developers to construct buildings larger than zoning ordinances allow in exchange for amenities like public plazas and subway station improvements, but it has not guaranteed that the amenities are created, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan asserted in an audit last week.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Midwest; Ohio State Stuns L.S.U., 36-33
description: Greg Frey passed 20 yards to Bobby Olive for the game-winning touchdown with 38 seconds remaining as Ohio State upset Louisiana State, 36-33, today.

title: By Rail Among the Peaks of Peru
description: THE train had stopped at the Continental Divide and we were hurrying toward the doors when I noticed the elderly woman beside me gasping for air. Some travelers before her must have felt similar problems, for the porters carry an ample supply of oxygen. ''But I didn't want to take the time,'' she said later. Instead, she stood perfectly still for a moment, took a measured breath, and gamely marched down the aisle to get a closer look.

title: James Brown Arrested Again
description: The soul singer James Brown was arrested today after a two-state auto chase that ended after authorities shot out two tires on his truck, the authorities said.

title: Miles Per Gallon
description: To the Editor:

title: Grants for Commuter-Bus Studies
description: COMMUTERS trying to squeeze through the increasingly congested White Plains-Stamford highway corridor could get help from a privately operated express bus service, local transportation officials said last week.

title: Power Line Project Opposed
description: LEAD: A planned underground transmission line beneath Roslyn Road in East Williston has provoked the ire of residents.

title: Pamela Pobrislo Marries Paul Salvatore in Denver
description: Pamela Fontaine Pobrislo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Stanton Pobrislo of Englewood, Colo., was married yesterday to Paul Alfred Salvatore, the son of Lorraine Salvatore of White Plains and the late Alfred Salvatore. The Rev. Robert Swensen performed the ceremony at the Augustana Lutheran Church in Denver.

title: Episcopal Diocese Chooses First Woman to Be a Bishop
description: For the first time in history, a woman was elected yesterday to be a bishop in the Episcopal Church.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: WHO could like them - the $200-a-night tariffs for hotel rooms in Manhattan, the $1,000 studio rents, the $55 prix-fixe dinners, the $150 boots, the $50 haircuts? But life being what it is these days, the sense of shock and outrage at what were once considered astronomical and ridiculous prices has, in many cases, become muted. Once-startling totals are now accepted, not always gracefully and not necessarily by everyone, but some of them sometimes by some part of the population.

title: Dance, Music and Dining
description: City Center Opening

title: African Nations Barring Foreign Toxic Waste
description: Tourist guidebooks call it Congo's ''Little Colorado,'' a stunning gorge of plunging, pink cliffs draped with green Central African jungle.

title: The 'N' Word
description: To the Editor:

title: Competing With Laser Giants
description: LEAD: IN the early 1970's, after working nearly a decade for two of America's corporate giants, Ed Comperchio was offered an unusual opportunity. A private investor said he would help Mr. Comperchio set up his own company to compete with his former employers.

title: Hartford Symphony Votes to Strike
description: The Hartford Symphony Orchestra today postponed a Saturday concert after its musicians voted to go on strike for higher wages and a shorter work schedule.

title: Gull's Life: Home, Friends, Fan Club
description: To many people who live in this small seacoast community, seagulls are a dirty, noisy nuisance, but to members of the GULL fan club, one bird rises above the rest.

title:
GARDENING;
Trees Can Mitigate Greenhouse Effect
description: LEAD: MANY environmentalists predict that a buildup of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere from the burning of fossil fuels and others will result in the greenhouse effect and that the buildup will reduce the amount of heat the Earth radiates into the atmosphere, raising global temperatures.

title: 23 Consecutive Victories
description: Brockton, Mass., known as the home of a pair of world boxing champions, Marvelous Marvin Hagler and the late Rocky Marciano, now boasts the best high school football team in the country.

title: Carole C. Holmes Is Married
description: Carole Christine Holmes, the daughter of Arlene Dahl Rosen of New York, Sparkhill, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., and Christian R. Holmes 3d of Houston, was married yesterday to Sean Wallace McCarthy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick McCarthy of Boston and Christmas Cove, Me. The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, the senior pastor emeritus of the Marble Collegiate Church in New York, performed the ceremony in Sparkhill at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Marc Rosen. He was assisted by the Rev. Ronald Cadmus of the Fort Washington Collegiate Church in New York.

title: Money for U.N. Peacekeeping
description: President Reagan is asking Congress to divert up to $150 million in defense or foreign aid money to help launch new United Nations peacekeeping operations in the coming months. The funds would be transferred to the State Department to meet ''urgent requests that may arise'' before March for contributions to peacekeeping and truce operations planned in Afghanistan, between Iran and Iraq and possibly in Angola, South-West Africa, Cambodia and the Western Sahara. The House international organizations subcommittee approved the proposal Friday.

title: The Perils of Shunning America's Past
description: We Americans assault our past with the tenacity of ancient Egyptian soldiers chiseling the names of former pharaohs from off the stone walls of tombs and temples.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Jean de Florette Starring Yves Montand, Gerard Depardieu, Daniel Auteuil, Elisabeth Depardieu, Ernestine Mazurowna, Marcel Champel, Armand Meffre. Directed by Claude Berri. 1987. Orion Home Video. 121 minutes. $89.98. Rated PG. Contains two violent scenes that could trouble young children.

title: Ms. McVay Weds Thomas Hughes
description: At the Princeton University Chapel yesterday, Catherine McVay, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Scott McVay of Princeton, was married to Thomas McMaster Hughes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Hughes of New York. The Rev. Ernest Gordon, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: SHE FEARED NO EVIL, INCLUDING HER SONS
description: MAMAW By Susan Dodd. 350 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: THE M.D. WHO WOULD BE A TYCOON
description: LEROY A. PESCH, M.D., HAD A dream. Simply put, he wanted to create an empire that would deliver comprehensive medical care from the cradle to the grave. He had the credentials: a career as professor, medical school dean, Federal official and president of Chicago's Michael Reese Hospital and Medical Center. And he also had the support of his father-in-law, W. Clement Stone, the colorful Chicago insurance magnate who was a major contributor to Richard Nixon's 1968 Presidential campaign.

title: Florence's Artistry in Wood
description: FIORENZO BARTOLOZZI, say his friends, is a mixture of Geppetto, the carpenter who created Pinocchio, and Einstein. When the ancient Benedictine abbey of Monte Cassino was reduced to rubble by Allied bombs during World War II, it was to the workshop of Bartolozzi & Maioli in Florence that the monks came for help in restoring and carving the wooden choir stalls. It took Fiorenzo Bartolozzi and his workshop of 30 artisans 10 years to complete the work, piecing together the fragments from sacks full of bits and pieces of wood from the ruined abbey.

title: Ann Pollis Weds In Massachusetts
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Woods Hole, Mass., Ann Margaret Pollis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Pollis of North Attleboro and West Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Jonathan O'Herron Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Herron of Darien, Conn.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: AN AQUARIUM OF WOMEN. By Bjorg Vik. Translated by Janet Garton. (Norvik/Dufour Editions, Box 449, Chester Springs, Pa. 19425, Paper, $12.95.) Sixteen years is a long time in the women's movement. This volume of stories by Bjorg Vik, a leading Norwegian feminist and one of her country's best-selling authors, was first published in Norway in 1972, and it bears the mark of the early days when radical activist women were first noticing that the men in the socialist and antiwar movements had a certain contempt for their female comrades.

title: WRIGHT DISCLOSURE TERMED ACCURATE
description: American officials say House Speaker Jim Wright gave a generally accurate description of American policy toward Nicaragua when he said that the United States was supporting opposition groups there in hopes of provoking an overreaction by the Sandinistas.

title: A Sleek New Hybrid Enters the Marketplace
description: FOR the last two years I've been writing about two basic types of 35-millimeter cameras. There are single-lens reflexes (SLRs), which let you compose, meter and focus through an interchangeable-mount lens. And there are point-and-shoots, a.k.a. lens/shutter cameras, which have separate viewfinders beside their fixed-mount lenses.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The bailout to come will be the largest ever in the history of the United States. It will be far bigger than the combined cost of the assistance given to Chrysler, Lockheed and New York City.'' -Senator William Proxmire, on the problems of the savings and loan industry.

title: Fatal Mite Imperils the State's Honeybees
description: STATE officials want to renew a ban on importing bees from states infested by a mite deadly to the insects. The officials are seeking to safeguard the production of honey and the cultivation of fruits and vegetables, as well.

title: Opera in Which Solos Are Pre-Eminent
description: Handel's operas have suffered strange vicissitudes. Many of them enjoyed great success in their day, yet they were soon so completely forgotten that between 1754, when Handel was still living, and 1920 not one of them was staged anywhere. Even after the publication of the scores more than a century ago, no attempt was made to revive them, though anyone could see that they were full of superb music. When at last they achieved performances in Germany in the 1920's, they were so grievously distorted on every level by cuts, insertions, transpositions and reorchestration, in a misguided attempt to bring them into conformity with later operatic practice, as to be scarcely recognizable. Many subsequent productions, while less obviously outrageous, have still been marked by awkward compromises.

title: Peggy Bier Becomes Bride Of Dr. Gerald M. Sturman
description: Peggy C. Bier, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Bier of Teaneck, N.J., and Sarasota, Fla., and Dr. Gerald M. Sturman, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Aleck Sturman of New York, were married last evening by Rabbi Allen Mark Darnov at the Pierre in New York.

title: Olympic Highlights
description: SWIMMING: Kristin Otto of East Germany kept her perfect record intact: five golds in five events.

title: For Singer-Musician, Hamptons Call the Tune
description: LEAD: FOR Jim Turner, living in the Hamptons and all its contradictions, from pickup trucks to BMW's, are the stuff that songs are made of.

title: Maine U. Sale of Artifacts Is Protested
description: Faculty members at the University of Maine are protesting a decision to sell a portion of a vast collection of pre-Columbian artifacts to help finance a baseball clubhouse.

title: Cleaning Bronx River: Making Room for Fish
description: Cleaning up the Bronx River is not an easy proposition. In just one sweep of the waterway in the West Farms section of the Bronx several years ago, the catch amounted to 6 cars, 2 horse trailers, 53 refrigerators, 5 sofas and most of an upright piano.

title: Half the Nation's Children: Born Without a Fair Chance
description: To talk about the condition of children is by definition to talk about the families in which they live. That is why we are going to have to learn to talk about two kinds of children, because - of a sudden, in a flash - we have become a society divided into two kinds of families. Call it a dual family system. In this dual family system, roughly half our children, somewhat randomly, but inexorably, are born without a fair chance. We know precious little about what to do about it.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Plymouth, Mass.;
80 Homes Sold, 743 to Go
description: LEAD: DOWN a winding country road, amid a cluster of seven clear ponds, the Ponds of Plymouth, where 823 single-family homes are planned, is now home to the first 80 families.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington;
Building Behind A Cathedral
description: LEAD: A DEVELOPER and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington resolved a dispute early this month with lawyers who opposed a 10-story office building planned adjacent to St. Matthew's Cathedral here.

title: Beetle, Fire's Precursor, Riddles Western Pine
description: Swarms of mountain pine beetles are cutting a swath through the West, creating fuel for forest fires as they kill huge, dense plots of trees from Montana to New Mexico and Colorado to California.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Rental Incentives; Troubled Marketplace Puts Brakes on the Free Ride
description: RELUCTANTLY, landlords in troubled office markets are reducing their dependency on ''free rent,'' a financial gimmick that allows tenants to move into office buildings without paying rent for several years.

title: Emotional Ojeda Vows to Return
description: After 48 ''crucial'' hours that may have decided his future in baseball, Bob Ojeda reported from his hospital room in New York today that he felt the worst was over ''and I know now that I'll pitch again.''

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: West/Southwest; Punter Averages 59.8 Yards
description: The Colorado punter, Keith English. set a Big Eight Conference and school record today, averaging 59.8 yards on 5 punts during the Buffaloes' 28-21 victory over Oregon State.

title: Bentsen Seeks Local Angle Over Big Picture
description: Every campaign stop Senator Lloyd Bentsen makes around the country includes three basic activities: a political speech, a closed meeting with local newspaper reporters and a series of short television interviews with local broadcasters.

title: Correction
description: A chart on Aug. 7 comparing health care spending in eight countries misstated the total spending per capita in the United States for 1986. It was $1,926.

title: Wendy Olsoff Marries
description: The marriage of Wendy G. Olsoff, a co-owner of the P.P.O.W. Gallery in New York, to Gregg L. Deering, an artist, took place last evening at the National Arts Club in New York. Rabbi A. Allen Block officiated. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Olsoff of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Deering of Whidbey Island, Wash. Mr. Olsoff is president of Frederick Atkins Inc., a merchandising and market-research company in New York. The bridegroom's father retired as a senior financial adviser at Exxon in New York.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: PINELANDS TOUR The naturalists at the Center for Environmental Studies in Roseland call the New Jersey pinelands the largest, unspoiled woodlands in the Northeast, and next Sunday they invite you to experience them firsthand during a day-long tour.

title: Rape Victim's Cries Unheeded
description: Several people watched as a 36-year-old woman was raped under a commuter train platform at the rush hour, but nobody moved to help her, the police said Friday.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS CLOSE-UP: Judo; 'The Gentle Way'
description: The Japanese developed judo, ''the gentle way,'' as an alternative to the more violent jujitsu. One competitor, a judoka, is allowed per country in each of eight weight classes. The strategy is to use an agressor's weight and momentum to your advantage (pushing when being pulled, pulling when being pushed) and defeat him through a series of holds and throws. Matches are 5 minutes long for men and 4 minutes in women's judo, which is a demonstration sport. Victories are determined by an ippon (a clean and forceful throw) or by points. Terms Ippon: Throwing a rival on his back or side, pinning him for 30 seconds or choking or arm-locking him into submission. Waza-ari: Given for a less-than-perfect throw or for immobilizing an opponent for between 25 and 30 seconds. Two equal an ippon. Yuko: A throw less than a waza-ari, or a hold lasting between 20 and 25 seconds. Koka: A hold lasting between 10 and 20 seconds or a throw that knocks an opponent to his hips. Han-soku make: Disqualification for repeated infractions. In one of the most humiliating penalties in sports, the offender must kneel for public dishonor by the officials. Infractions Penalties are levied at the end of a match if it is not decided by ippon. Infractions include: throwing an opponent with one leg entwined around the opponent's; using locks on joints other than the elbow; using an arm or hand on an opponent's face; stepping outside the contest area; grabbing the inside of an opponent's judogi; applying any hold that could injure the neck or vertebrae, and kicking or hand-slashing. Repeated infractions result in han-soku make. Keep an Eye on . . . Kim Jae-Yup, South Korea Yosuki Yamamoto, Japan Michael Swain, U.S. Hirotaka Okada, Japan Fabian Canu, France Hitoshi Sugai, Japan Gregori Verichev, U.S.S.R Judogi, a baggy white or off-white jacket and trousers, tied by a an obi. Ukiotoshi, a two-handed grab and throw that flings the opponent through the air and onto his back. Koshiwaza, a hip throw. A throw that is the end result of a sacrificing position. Kouchigari, using a foot and leg to throw an opponent. Safety area Danger area Contest area 8 meters 1 meter 3 meters

title: A Glory Trail for the Underdog
description: CHESS is notorious for neither respecting titles nor achievements, but only what is actually being done over-the-board at the given moment. That's why the probability of upsets is so high - probably much higher than in sports.

title: Miss Selden Has Wedding
description: Virginia Willingham Selden, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Lord Selden of New York, was married yesterday to Taylor Chapin Gray, a son of Mrs. Richard B. McKinley of Paradise Valley, Ariz., and the late Dr. Parke H. Gray of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Alcohol Treatment And Its Cost
description: This is in response to the recent article ''Panel Finds Excesses in Drug and Alcohol Care.'' As the chief executive officer of Sunrise House Foundation, a freestanding alcohol treatment center in Sussex County, New Jersey, I note my objection to the generalizations concerning ''typical inpatient programs'' as extremely costly.

title: APPEARANCE ANXIETY
description: Four years ago, my husband told me he was offended that I was rejecting - and altering - the face that he called beautiful. Beauty is in the eye of the beholder, he argued. But I couldn't hide from the fact that, although love might be blind, I wasn't. I forsook Henry V in favor of Hamlet's Polonius, and to my own self was true: there was nothing ''pretty'' or ''dear'' about the excess cartilage on the tip of my nose or the absence of a discernible chin.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Kansas City, Mo.; A Revival for The West Side
description: WHEN the Department of Housing and Urban Development labeled this city's West Side as ''no longer viable'' in 1972, residents refused to let their historic neighborhood die.

title: The Candidates and Poor Children; An Issue for the No-Issue Campaign
description: It's almost October, the first Presidential debate is upon us, but where are the issues in the campaign? There's plenty of posturing, like Michael Dukakis posing helmeted aboard a tank. There's no end of puffed-up patriotism, like George Bush, dauntless defender of the Pledge of Allegiance, mis-reciting ''and to the liberty for which it stands.'' Yet it remains the Campaign of No Issues.

title: STALKING THE PLAZA
description: DONALD TRUMP CHARGES UP A STAIRCASE, kicks open a fire door and greets the blinding summer sun. Surrounded by heavyset bodyguards wearing gold-plated ''T's'' in their lapels, he stands 18 stories above Fifth Avenue on the roof of the Plaza Hotel.

title: A Rabbi Gets and Gives Warmth in Curacao
description: Rabbi Aaron L. Peller, an American who grew up in Buffalo, N.Y., remembers the winter of 1978 as having been particularly cold and bitter. He had been assisting an older rabbi in Philadelphia for four years and had started thinking of moving on. The snow drifts and the skidding on the expressways had turned his mind to warm places.

title: HOROWITZ AT 85: STILL PLAYING FREE
description: There will be no festivals, tributes or gala concerts to commemorate Vladimir Horowitz's 85th birthday on Saturday. This is the way he wants it. His plans are to spend the day as he spends most days, at home. During the recent heat spell he stayed inside for six weeks reading the letters of Mozart, which have become a near obsession, listening to recordings, receiving friends, anything but practicing the piano. ''I haven't practiced at all for two months,'' he said recently, sitting with his wife of 55 years, Wanda Toscanini Horowitz, in the parlor of his East Side townhouse near Central Park. ''But I have practiced enough in my life. It will come back fast.''

title: Along the W ater's Edge, Menaces and Fears
description: WE were driving past the Mamaroneck harbor on the Boston Post Road when my 5-year-old daughter, Jamie, said, ''Oh, what beautiful water, is it polluted?'' I was struck by her question, and I had to tell my daughter that, yes, the water is often polluted. No one needed to tell my 3-year-old, Jenny, as she glanced into Long Island Sound one day and proclaimed, ''Looks like dirty.'' She was right.

title: Critic's Notebook; In Lyons, an Overview Of 4 Centuries of Dance
description: ''Dance is an international language, an international form of poetry. That is why I wanted to be a choreographer.''

title: No, Don't Let Yellowstone Burn; New Forest Corps
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Those Who Perch Lightly

title: When Light Overcalls Are Worth the Venture
description: BRIDGE organizers have struggled for years to deal with the problem of slow play. There have been players who have thought for 20 minutes over a single bid or play, upsetting their opponents and dislocating time schedules. A variety of regulations have been tried with limited effect.

title: Off Broadway
description: JACKIE MASON: THE WORLD ACCORDING TO ME! Written by Jackie Mason. Produced by Nick Vanoff. HBO Home Video. 58 minutes. $39.99.

title: The Question of Work Leaves Welfare Reform Stuck on Capitol Hill
description: IT is a bold vision: an overhaul of the welfare laws that would break the cycle of dependency by moving poor Americans off the welfare rolls and onto the payrolls. The notion represents a break with the original tenets of the welfare program, established in the Depression to provide relief for millions of impoverished people.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ART & ANGER: Reading Like a Woman. By Jane Marcus. (Miami University/Ohio State University, Cloth, $30; Paper, $11.95.) These feminist critical essays about Wilde, Ibsen, Meredith and above all Virginia Woolf have grown old, but honorably. They bring back the atmosphere of earlier stages in evolving feminist arguments, when plucky polemicists took on critics who considered Oscar Wilde an effete decadent or Virginia Woolf a hopeless esthete, a snob - apolitical, sexless, mad.

title: Speed-Metal: Extreme, Yes; Evil, No
description: Rock is on trial again. A few weeks ago, the Nevada Supreme Court decided that a suit could proceed against the British heavy metal band Judas Priest due to the alleged effect of its music. Last December, after listening to the band's 1978 album, ''Stained Class,'' for six hours straight, Raymond Belnap, 18, and James Vance, 21, shot themselves in a Reno churchyard, Mr. Belnap fatally. The suit, brought by the men's parents and estate for unspecified damages, alleges that Judas Priest mesmerized the pair, and the band's lyrics brought on the suicide attempts.

title: IN YONKERS, A MEASURED INTEGRATION OF SCHOOLS
description: In the last 28 months, even as Yonkers risked bankruptcy in its battle against a court-ordered housing desegregation plan, the public schools here have moved quietly and methodically to abolish deeply rooted segregation in the system.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: A LANDMARK HOME The most advanced techniques have been employed in the $500,000, 4-year restoration of the Stanley-Whitman House at 37 High Street in Farmington, a colonial home with National Landmark status. An open house will be held from 1 to 4 P.M. Saturday. Admission is free.

title: Marshall Field 6th to Marry Clea Olivia Newman in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Newman of Westport, Conn., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Clea Olivia Newman to Marshall Field 6th, the son of Mr. Field 5th of Lake Forest, Ill., and Mrs. Samuel Tatnall of Plymouth Meeting, Pa. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Chris Jacobs And Compassion
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Review/Music; Alla Pugacheva's Moody, Ardent Soviet Pop
description: Alla Pugacheva is a woman of many voices - delicate pop chirps, a clear rock mezzo-soprano, dramatic cabaret growls and sobs. A pop superstar from the Soviet Union who has reportedly sold 150 million records, Mrs. Pugacheva wound up her first American tour with a sold-out concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night that offered a fascinating glimpse of mainstream Soviet pop.

title: Outdoors; Season for Waterfowl Hunting Is Near
description: Most waterfowlers have long known that the drought that has plagued breeding habitat in Canada and this country has resulted in a near-record low in duck production this year. They also knew that seasons and bag limits would be reduced and that there would be no special or bonus seasons for such species as teal and scaup, that the highly prized canvasback would be off limits across the nation, and that shooting hours would be shortened from sunrise, instead of a half-hour before, to sunset.

title: A New Latin Offer
description: Carlos Andres Peres is campaigning for president, too - of Venezuela. He came to the U.S. with some new ideas about dealing with what he calls ''the historic misunderstanding'' between the U.S. and Latin America. He is almost certain to be elected, but the visit here may help.

title: Orchestras Are Finding Pops is Hot
description: INSOFAR as orchestras in the state can see the future, it is at least partly pops, and many are expanding or adding to their programming to reflect the vision.

title: A Manager's Reward
description: His team chased the Mets through most of the season in the National League East, and even though the Pittsburgh Pirates failed to catch up, the effort was enough for Manager Jim Leyland to get the two-year contract he was pursuing. Terms of the contract were not disclosed. He reportedly earned $125,000 this season and was seeking about $250,000 each of the next two seasons.

title: The Good Life in Switzerland, In Pound Ridge Poster Show
description: THE illustration is of a poster for the Odeon Cafe, in Zurich. Done by Hugo Laubi, in 1920, this is one of the 27 Swiss posters now at the Hiram Halle Memorial Library in Pound Ridge, and it is as bold in color - the table is vermilion with everything else either black or white - as it is in design.

title: Binney Brady Weds Thomas Van Allen
description: Lois Smith Brady, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. William J. Brady Jr. of Philadelphia, was married in Southampton, L.I., yesterday to Thomas Halsey Van Allen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James Van Allen of Iowa City and Southampton. The Rev. Malcolm L. Foster performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Dune Episcopal Church.

title: FICTION
description: WALKING PAPERS. By Jay Cronley. (Random House, $16.95.) It is said that W. C. Fields stomped out of the premiere of Charlie Chaplin's ''City Lights,'' growling loudly, ''That man's no comedian, he's a [ expletive deleted ] ballet dancer!'' One recalls that tale after reading the newspaper columnist and novelist (''Fall Guy,'' ''Screwballs'' ''Funny Farm'') Jay Cronley's latest effort because, while a visit to the ballet figures in the story, there is no ballet dancer in the magical sense Mr. Fields intended - and this book needs one badly. The putative hero, John Grape, a novelist in the throes of divorce and divestiture, never dazzles us with fancy footwork, never elicits admiration of any sort, not even for his undeniable doggedness. Taken to the cleaners in the first chapters by his soon-to-be-ex-wife, Delores, Grape broods a bit and then grimly launches himself on a course of total reconstruction, removing or concealing everything she found objectionable about his life, from obesity to drunkenness, compulsive gambling to tobacco addiction. Then it's on to cosmetic surgery, hair transplants and a whole new identity so he can woo her (and, much more to the point, the divorce settlement) back again. The kicker - and also the source of some truly hilarious scenes - is that Grape's agent is out peddling this scheme as a book and a movie even while Grape is trying to pull it off. Will he succeed? We'd care a lot more if Mr. Cronley had given us a single reason why Grape deserves any better than he got in the courtroom opening. But he's such a relentlessly loutish, unlovable loser we find ourselves wishing we could warn Delores of what's afoot -if only she weren't such a hopeless ninny that we're forced to conclude they deserve each other.

title: Cathy Dean Wed To Bret Edwards
description: At the Central Presbyterian Church in New York, Cathy Lee Dean, a daughter of Lieut. Col. Scott E. Dean, U.S.A.F. retired, and Mrs. Dean of Sacramento, Calif., was married yesterday to Bret Edwards, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thornton G. Edwards of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Eric Markman performed the ceremony.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Ivy League; Holy Cross Stuns Tigers on Last Play
description: Tim Donovan took a lateral and ran the last 55 yards to complete a 70-yard kickoff return on the last play of the game to give Holy Cross a 30-26 victory over Princeton today.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
The Last in a Series For the Olympics
description: LEAD: SOUTH Korea has issued its final series of gold and silver coins to commemorate and help finance the XXIV Olympic Summer Games. The final Series IV includes six coins: two made of gold and four of silver. All are dated 1988.

title: Parting Shots in the 7-Year Battle of Nerves on Contra Aid
description: THE final chapter on the Reagan Administration's contra policy will be written in coming weeks not so much in conclusion as in exhaustion. It will commit the United States to supply the rebels with enough food, clothing and medical supplies to sustain them through early spring and leave the new occupant in the White House to decide what happens next.

title: Antoinette Ziluca Becomes a Bride
description: At St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn., Antoinette Ziluca, a daughter of Nancy H. Ziluca of Sante Fe, N.M., and Tony Garibaldi Ziluca of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to James Joseph Cummiskey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Cummiskey of Greenwich. The Rev. Kevin Royal performed the ceremony.

title: Vacancy Report
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Launches Satellite to Study Weather and to Make Spy Photos
description: The United States launched a $54.5 million satellite early today that will study weather conditions and make spy photographs, space agency officials said.

title: LOVERS WERE BESIDE THE POINT
description: MEN By Margaret Diehl. 282 pp. New York: Soho Press. $17.95.

title: Exploring the Role Anger Plays in Community Conflict
description: THE frustrations of modern life ''seem designed to generate quantities of anger,'' Dr. Willard Gaylin writes in ''The Rage Within -Anger in Modern Life'' - an observation anyone made late by a traffic jam might share. But expressing that anger is increasingly unacceptable in a civilized world, according to the author. ''We have trained ourselves to endure frustrations as the inevitable price of a technological society.''

title: The Smell of Greasepaint - And Pickles
description: The old Cafe Royal - the Yiddish Sardi's, Algonquin and Elaine's rolled into one - stood on the southeast corner of Second Avenue and 12th Street for about 30 years, until it went out of business in the early 1950's. It was the most glamorous of the many Lower East Side coffeehouses, within walking distance of at least five Yiddish theaters - a sociable mass promenade after the show - and a quick subway trip from several others.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Drexel as Pioneer; Junk Bonds Still Have a Bad Name
description: DESPITE Drexel Burnham Lambert's ubiquitous television and magazine advertisements, portraying the company as the investment bank of the common man, its most famous product, junk bonds, have not overcome the stigma of their name.

title: A French Port Via England
description: WITH its busy waterfront, outstanding food shops and picturesque 13th-century Old Town, Boulogne is the most attractive of the French Channel ports convenient for day trips from England. The trip takes 35 minutes by Hovercraft from Dover, an hour and 50 minutes by ferry from Folkestone. If you rise early and stay late you can have seven hours ashore.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: The Best in the World; Fastest Runs Even Faster
description: If he had snookered the world, he laid the groundwork more than a year ago. After Ben Johnson of Canada lowered the world 100-meter record to 9.83 seconds in the world track and field championships in Rome in 1987, he said the time would probably stand another 50 years. He was off by 49. So what is the world to make of his miscalculation? As the crown jewel today of a sparkling afternoon of Olympic track and field, Johnson lowered the record yet again, to 9.79 seconds, which seems as astonishing now as the 9.83 was a year ago.

title: The Many Accents of Latino Art
description: When Luis Cancel, director of the Bronx Museum of the Arts, was growing up Puerto Rican in New York, he couldn't learn much about the art of his own people. ''There was no information about 20th-century Puerto Rican or Latin American art in the libraries I went to,'' he said, ''and there were no art history courses that could feed my interest at the schools I attended. I had to educate myself.''

title: Stacey Raider and Richard H. Gowen Are Married
description: Stacey Raider, the daughter of Mrs. Leonard J. Raider of New York and Milford, Pa., and the late Dr. Raider, was married yesterday to Richard Henderson Gowen, a son of R. Harold Gowen of Portland, Me., and the late Marian E. Gowen. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, chaplain of the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Water Club in New York.

title: Foiling the Ladron: A Guide to Street Scams
description: KEEPING your money and belongings safe from thieves when traveling in South America is a matter of common sense. But the common sense that works at home may have to be adapted to respond to new surroundings, according to Linda Rojas of Denver, a former resident of Peru who helped form a nonprofit group called the South American Explorers Club. You may know what to do in your own town, she says, but in an unfamiliar place your guard is down and you may not be alert to danger signs.

title:
MONTVILLE JOURNAL;
Stories Diverge About a Teacher Accused of Slurs
description: LEAD: IT is back to the school routine for most students in New Jersey. But a small group of teen-agers from Montville High School have had more on their minds than reading and arithmetic. Their first few days of classes were spent testifying at a judicial hearing that will decide the fate of one of their teachers, who is accused of telling them that the Holocaust was ''a myth.

title: Patricia Quick Is Married To Paul J. Pollack, Investor
description: St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Patricia Quick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie C. Quick Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Laurel Hollow, L.I., to Paul J. Pollack, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John R. Pollack of Newark, Ohio. Msgr. James Collins performed the ceremony.

title: Space Shuttle Is Poised to Fly With Fragile Cargo of Dreams
description: American astronauts are at last ready to return to orbit on the space shuttle Discovery, seeking to revive the nation's flagging civilian space program and to end the long struggle with self-doubt and paralysis that followed the worst disaster in space flight history 32 months ago.

title: Fight Ends On Plant for Trash
description: LEAD: A SETTLEMENT reached Tuesday in a contract dispute between the Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority and Engineering Inc., a contractor in Stamford, over the Mid-Connecticut trash-to-energy plant in Hartford will cost the contractor up to $7 million.

title: Coaches Bring Excitement and Energy Back Into Jet Defense
description: One sounds like a cheerleader at an after-hours club. The other looks as if he is the bouncer.

title: A CORRECTION
description: The Streetscapes column of Sept. 11 misstated the ownership of the Russian Tea Room and its building at 150 West 57th Street. The sole owner is Faith Stewart-Gordon.

title: Two U.S. Agencies Split On Reservoir Proposal
description: Gov. Edward D. DiPrete and the Federal Environmental Protection Agency are embroiled in a high-stakes dispute over the future of the state's water supplies.

title: Making Garbage 'Disappear Like Magic'
description: THE movement to ban many categories of plastics unless they degrade in the environment is not founded strictly on logic. After all, plastics make up only about 7 percent of the garbage in waste dumps. But to the casual observer, that is a highly visable 7 percent. ''What the public is reacting to is the fact that the first plastic clam shell that was ever thrown out is still lying there,'' said John Angus, a director of the Eco Corporation, a Canadian maker of additives that make plastics degrade. He was referring to the plastic containers fast-food chains use to package hamburgers.

LEAD: HENRY R. LUCE 3D, president of the Henry R. Luce Foundation, is providing $450,000 to Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers for the establishment of a Henry R. Luce Professorship in Parents, Work and the New Economic Imperatives.

title: BEING AND CAPPUCCINO
description: UNSENT LETTERS Irreverent Notes From a Literary Life. By Malcolm Bradbury. 218 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95. MY STRANGE QUEST FOR MENSONGE By Malcolm Bradbury. Foreword/Afterword by Michel Tardieu, translated by David Lodge. 104 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: Robert Kennedy in History
description: To the Editor:

title: It's a House of the Same Representatives
description: THE Founding Fathers intended the House of Representatives to be the part of the Federal Government closest to the electorate and thus most responsive to shifts in political winds. Describing the function of the House under the Constitution, Alexander Hamilton declared: ''Here, sir, the people govern. Here they act by their immediate representatives.''

title: A Brazilian-American Cultural Exchange
description: American and Brazilian pop have enjoyed a cultural exchange for decades, but since the early-1960's bossa nova craze no Brazilian singer has managed to grab the ear of the American pop public directly. Djavan, who performed to a full house Thursday night at the Ritz, is the most likely contender for that long-awaited crossover. Handsome and relaxed on stage, with a soothing but vulnerable voice, he is willing to split the difference between Brazilian pop and the American pop-funk that has lifted some of its best effects from such Brazilian masters as Milton Nascimento, Jorge Ben, Gilberto Gil and Caetano Veloso, all Djavan's elders.

title: The 2 Identities Of David Roberts
description: ON THE one hand, there was Bob Lord, the gentle, compassionate coordinator of shelters and soup kitchens for the homeless. He often worked around the clock, helping people, recalled an official of Project Hospitality, a nonprofit New York corporation that sponsors the shelters on Staten Island.

title: Two Farms, Two Fates
description: LEAD: ''BEGINNING at a hickory tree standing near the east corner of an orchard.'' So goes the deed description to the Francisco Farm, 280 acres owned by the Francisco family for three generations. But the rural boundary markers may be about to give way to a 590-home subdivision that would occupy most of the western half of Andover Borough and almost triple the population of the Sussex County community, which straddles

title: From Italy, 'La Maschera,' A Story of Hidden Identities
description: ''La Maschera'' is the sort of sublimely silly movie that somehow finds its way into every film festival. It is prettily photographed, solemnly acted and so supremely and vacuously irrelevant that it prompts serious thoughts about revolution. Any society that can take it seriously must be in the last stages of decadence. Quick, Angelo, my Faberge snuffbox!

title: Handle With Care
description: HAVE JUST SPENT 12 HOURS IN A DARKENED room with a man who exudes fury and despair. Disagreeable, rude, scathingly critical, he lies wrapped in blankets because he is always cold, an angular bony heap, too weak to hold a newspaper without effort, too dejected even to try, shut down from whatever life he has left. Refusing to complain, he hugs his misery to himself like a cloak of thorns.

title: 'Olympus On My Mind,'' Musical, in Fairfield
description: WITH big-time musical theaters subsisting on super spectacles and secondary theaters relegated to duplicating each other's retreads, along comes ''Olympus on My Mind.''

title: Unjust Tax Laws Corrupt Our Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Islp Pushing Proposal to House Mentally Ill
description: LEAD: RESPONDING to what officials see as a need for supervised housing for people with a history of mental illness, the Town of Islip is coordinating an effort with the state's Office of Mental Health to open three group homes in the township.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We recently had our kitchen cabinets refinished with a Formica veneer. Several months later, we noticed that the veneer on one five-foot-long cabinet door was starting to come loose in the middle, forming a blister or ''balloon'' about six inches long. The adhesive above and below this is adhering tightly. Is there anything we can do to loosen the panel so that it can be taken off and reglued?

title: Emphasis on the Arts Should Join the 3R's in Classrooms
description: IT has been said that you can assess the character of a community by the arts it keeps. All communities in the state must insure that students have ample and varied opportunities to participate in highquality arts activities and programs. A commitment must be made to elevate arts education in our schools, recognizing the importance of aesthetic literacy, the artistic heritage of our culture, the creativity that the arts bring to learning and the beauty and essence of ''arts for arts sake.'' The arts must be recognized as an integral component of the ''basic skills'' program of every school. The arts must not be viewed as the stepchild of the educational continuum or as an orphan of the school curriculum. Rather, there needs to be a realization that through a comprehensive arts education program students' lives are enriched, their mental capacities challenged, their appreciation of the environment increased and their understanding of the profound forms of human achievement intensified. Such is the power and wonder of the arts!

title: Sands Casino Rebuffed in a Move Against Trump
description: A state official is urging that a petition against Donald J. Trump's efforts to buy a prime block here be dismissed. A rival casino owner is also seeking to buy the land.

title: Arboretums; Tranquil Oases for Learning
description: CONNECTICUT'S two arboretums are parts of educational institutions, but they are also oases of peace in busy areas. They attract many who have no course of study in mind, but simply want to stroll and savor nature.

title: RUSSIAN AND RARE
description: The chase is the most compelling part of an antiques dealer's profession - the constant search for that which is unique and undiscovered and appealing. But as fewer great objects come on the market each season, this has become a difficult task, especially for those dealers who specialize in areas little-known even to scholars.

title: J. C. Carlson Wed To Miss Streeter
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., Claire Wood Streeter and John Curtis Carlson were married yesterday by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee. Marianne Spafford, a cousin of the bride, was the maid of honor, and Brian Carlson was the best man for his brother.

title: On the Cape, Cranberries Everywhere
description: OUTLANDERS who think of cranberries as being inextricably wedded to Thanksgiving and turkey may be surprised to find that on Cape Cod cranberries seem to be everywhere all the time.

title: State Curtails Freedom of Speech Against Hunters
description: At first, I thought it was a joke. How could anyone seriously propose a law in the United States making it illegal for one group of people to express an opinion directly to another group of people?

title: Hydraulic Door Closers
description: HYDRAULIC door closers, the metal tubes mounted horizontally on the interior side of most lightweight storm and screen doors, seldom break, but they sometimes malfunction and their mounting brackets often come loose. Repairing them is usually not difficult.

title: THE COSMIC CHESSBOARD
description: THE TOWER STRUCK BY LIGHTNING By Fernando Arrabal. Translated by Anthony Kerrigan. Illustrated. 242 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: HIS BIG IDEA
description: THE AGES OF GAIA A Biography of Our Living Earth. By James Lovelock. Illustrated. 252 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

title: A Mother's Search for a Heart Donor
description: I FEEL bitter and sad. It's hard to feel any other way after your 9-month-old baby has died.

title: State by State; Strategist for G.O.P. Plays Key Role in Ohio Race
description: On paper, Ohio looks like a state that Democratic Presidential candidates ought to be able to carry, but in the last 20 years only one has managed it - Jimmy Carter in 1976, and he did it by only about 11,000 votes.

title: Moroccans Say Attack Won't Derail Peace Effort
description: Moroccan officials say they are determined not to let a major attack by Polisario guerrillas upset plans for a United Nations-sponsored negotiation to end the war in Western Sahara.

title: Departure Taxes
description: To the Editor: In your article on airport departure taxes (Travel Advisory, July 24), you state that there are no departure taxes in West Germany. I believe this is correct. However, last September I was charged a tax of $7, of which I had not been previously informed, when departing from West Berlin. As such a charge may be inconvenient for people traveling on limited budgets, it would seem desirable to make it known. JEFFREY L. SAMMONS New Haven Editor's note: While it is true that no departure taxes are imposed at airports in most of West Germany, West Berlin is an exception. The airport there is still under the jurisdiction of the World War II Allies (United States, Britain and France), and a tax of 11 marks (about $6 at the current exchange rate of 54 cents for 1 mark) is in effect.

title: Asbury Park Pins Its Hopes on Oceanfront Plan
description: Where dilapidated rooming houses and failing oceanfront businesses stand as reminders of this city's past, Asbury Park is paving the way for an ambitious redevelopment plan to bring back the middle class it lost.

title: THE NATION  Three Views: The Troubled Savings and Loan Associations; On the Future, if There Is One, of the Thrifts
description: GRIM news for the savings and loan industry keeps coming. American thrifts lost $3.6 billion in the second quarter of this year, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported last week, bringing losses for the last 12 months to $13.5 billion. Congress is moving toward consideration of a Federal bailout to close down or merge the industry's insolvent institutions: Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said last week that a $20 billion bailout would be in order. Meanwhile, the Home Loan board, which has rescued 105 insolvent thrifts this year, predicts it will settle as many as 50 more by the end of this month. Some experts are beginning to ask whether the thrift industry will survive the crisis. Others say that maybe it should not survive because the business has so changed that the traditional savings and loan association is obsolete. There are predictions, too, that Washington might seek to reorganize the industry, possibly merging the thrifts into the banking industry. Nathaniel C. Nash, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times discussed the thrifts' future with three experts: R. Dan Brumbaugh, a former economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and now a consultant in San Francisco; Gerald J. Levy, chairman of the Guaranty Savings and Loan Association of Milwaukee and former chairman of the United States League of Savings Institutions; and Richard T. Pratt, chairman of Merrill Lynch Mortgage Capital Inc. and former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank. Here are excerpts. R. DAN BRUMBAUGH: We No Longer Need A Specialized Lender

title: Q and A
description: North Carolina

title: Jury Hears Testimony on Klan Attack on Marchers
description: A Federal jury has begun hearing testimony in a lawsuit seeking damages from members of the Ku Klux Klan who were part of a violent confrontation with civil rights marchers on a rural Georgia road last year.

title: 2 Regimes in Lebanon Try to Assert Authority
description: Lebanon's rival Moslem and Christian governments were engaged in a power struggle for control of the country's public affairs today.

title: The Issue That Matters Most: Are the Candidates Discussing It?
description: Registered voters were asked what they thought should be the single most important issue in this election. Then they were asked whether they thought Bush and Dukakis were talking enough about what they would do about that issue. Say neither candidate is talking enough about the most important issue . . . 52% Say one or both candidates are talking enough about it . . . 21% Not sure if candidates are talking enough about the most important issue . . . 7% Not sure which issue is most important . . . 20 % Based on a poll of 802 registered voters nationwide, interviewed by telephone Sept. 21-23, and weighted to reflect a ''probable electorate.'' How the Poll Was Conducted

title: Berlin Monetary Talks Spur Protests
description: When the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank chose to hold their annual meeting in a city divided, they should have expected a meeting divided.

title: That Strange Breed of Singer, Countertenors
description: When this writer was a student accompanying in vocal studios at Northwestern University, there came to the music school a talented undergraduate, not a music major, who sang countertenor and wanted lessons. Nobody knew what to do with him; a tenor on the faculty taught him for a while, but concluded that countertenor singing was beyond the ken of the conventional instructor, and remanded the young man to the liberal arts.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Roundup; Reggi of Italy Rallies to Upset Evert in Third-Round Match
description: Chris Evert's dream of Olympic glory was blown away in the wind today as the 33-year-old American lost, 2-6, 6-4, 6-1, to Raffaella Reggi of Italy in the third round.

title: Iraq's Dark Victory
description: BY THE EMERALD rush of the Habur River, on the Turkish frontier, the Iraqi armies of Saddam Hussein raised their banners in late August to signal their victory over the Kurds. But the message of triumph went much further than that. Throughout the eight years of Baghdad's war with Iran, guerrillas from Iraq's Kurdish minority had stubbornly resisted the Baghdad regime's successive campaigns to crush a revolt that had spanned almost seven decades. Now, with the greater war stilled by a ceasefire that took effect Aug. 20, President Hussein had deployed the full might of his forces - armor, helicopter gunships and, according to an official United States assessment, which Iraq denies, chemical weapons - in the lesser war against the Kurds in their mountain fastnesses.

title: Q and A
description: A Transfer Fee on a Gift

title: There's Still More Fat in the Budget
description: THE next Presidential Administration - Democratic or Republican - must take on a role akin to the cleanup crew the morning after a big party. Over the last several decades, we Americans have been consuming more than we are producing, borrowing more than we are saving, and spending more than we are earning. We have taken the easy route.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 25, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 8 FALLEN HEARTS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The scandals and horrors of her past return to haunt a bride in a backwoods town. 2 4 TEAM YANKEE, by Harold Coyle. (Berkley, $4.95.) The exploits of an American tank company in Europe - during World War III. 3 11 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.)
