The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: With the Future Unclear, Sri Lanka's Leader Plans To Depart in Satisfaction
description: WHEN this small Indian Ocean island became an independent nation in 1948, it was a potentially prosperous land.

title: Academia's Liberals Defend Their Carnival of Canons Against Bloom's 'Killer B's'
description: IN some respects, the scene in North Carolina last weekend recalled the daily ''minute of hatred'' in George Orwell's ''1984,'' when citizens are required to rise and hurl invective at pictures of a man known only as Goldstein, the Great Enemy of the state.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Gregg Jefferies The Rookie Of the Year?
description: Gregg Jefferies should not be the Rookie of the Year because he has not played enough. He has not proven himself yet. This year he was in the minors and hit .286. Then he comes up to the majors, gets some home runs, some doubles, and a game-winning r.b.i. Yes, this is good, but the award should go to either Mark Grace or Chris Sabo. PETER EGBERT Bedford, N.Y.

title: MEDICINE ND ITS DISCONTENTS
description: WORSE THAN THE DISEASE Pitfalls of Medical Progress. By Diana B. Dutton with Thomas A. Preston and Nancy E. Pfund. 528 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press.

title: Correction
description: The Executive Computer column last week gave an incorrect telephone number for ordering the Career Navigator computer-based job-search system. The correct telephone number is 1-800-345-5627.

title: The Andrus Planetarium
description: THE Andrus Planetarium of the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers is the only public planetarium in the county. The planetarium presents five shows a year in addition to six school shows for kindergarten through college students that are based on the state's science syllabus.

title: NOT WORTH DYING FOR
description: OUTRAGEOUS CONDUCT Art, Ego, and the ''Twilight Zone'' Case. By Stephen Farber and Marc Green Illustrated. 394 pp. New York: Arbor House/William Morrow & Company. $18.95

title: THE CASE OF PAUL DE MAN
description: In his article on Paul de Man, James Atlas says, ''As for what he did, how can any of us know what we would have done under those same circumstances?'' This amounts to an excuse for Mr. de Man's collaboration with the Nazis.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Gregg Jefferies The Rookie Of the Year?
description: A year is a year. How about rookie of the month? DAN WALLACK New York

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Local Colleges; Wagner Trounces District of Columbia
description: Tom Pugh scored three touchdowns, all on 1-yard runs, as Wagner routed District of Columbia, 61-14, yesterday at Fisher Field on Staten Island. Pugh's 3 touchdowns raised his career total to 30.

title: Charles H. Levine, 49, Expert on Civil Service
description: Charles H. Levine, a political scientist who was an expert on the civil service, died of a heart attack Friday night at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 49 years old.

title: Pope to Beatify Serra In Vatican Ceremony
description: Father Junipero Serra, honored by Roman Catholics as the founder of California's missions but reviled by some Indians as a tyrant who abused their ancestors, will be elevated by the church Sunday to a point one step away from sainthood.

title: Tracey Ullman: She's a Real Character
description: Ask Tracey Ullman the time of day and the puckish, rubber-faced British comedienne might transform herself into Big Ben. Or perhaps she'll produce the tinny computer voice of a telephone time service or a 3-year-old learning to tell time. A singing response is possible, maybe an Atlantic City lounge singer's rendition of ''Time Is on My Side.''

title: Ban on 2 More Lifters
description: Weight-lifting officials announced two more suspensions for positive drug tests today after Bulgaria, stung by the loss of two gold medals because of drug use, pulled its entire weight-lifting team out of the Olympics.

title: HOWARD'S WAY
description: THE INSPIRATION CAME EARLY, AS Richard Howard, translator of more than 150 books from French into English, once told Charles de Gaulle. Howard was working on de Gaulle's memoires, and the President of the French Republic had invited him to the Elysee Palace on the Rue du Faubourg St.-Honore for lunch.

title: Many in Haiti Wonder Who Is Really in Charge
description: One week after a coup led by noncommissioned officers in Haiti, many Haitians are still not sure about the nature and intent of the new military government or how long it might last.

title: APPEARANCE ANXIETY
description: Susan Jacoby suggests that a woman assuage appearance anxiety by salting her money away in a retirement savings account instead of spending thousands on lifting her face or enlarging her breasts, But why not donate those thousands to smoothing the lives, expanding the opportunities of less fortunate women -in Nicaragua, in Eritrea, in our own crisis centers? Reaching out to others can be many times more fulfilling than a quest for youthful beauty, or even a snug old age. MALVINE COLE Jamaica, Vt.

title: THE LAW WAS THE KILLER
description: LEAD: WE ARE NOT AFRAID The Story of Goodman, Schwerner, and Chaney and the Civil Rights Campaign for Mississippi. By Seth Cagin and Philip Dray. Illustrated. 500 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $22.50.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Mixed-Use Project Proposed on Peconic
description: LEAD: A 500,000-SQUARE-FOOT mixed-use development proposed for a 32-acre parcel along the Peconic River on the Southampton-Riverhead border is one of the most dramatic indicators so far of new growth in this area of Long Island.

title: Labor Rights Of Europeans Are Debated
description: Concerned that its blueprint for a single market of 320 million consumers is unfairly biased in favor of business, the chief executive of the European Community has started a campaign to shore up workers' rights when national frontiers are eliminated at the end of 1992.

title: CLASSIC SCENTS
description: A woman wearing a huge jeweled and feathered headdress and a man in Ben-Hur garb paraded around Macy's in New York last month. There were togas and trumpeters; in short, it was business as usual in the fragrance department.

title:
ART;
At Focus '88, A Range of Images
description: LEAD: THE six photographers whose works are featured in ''Focus '88,'' now at the Smithtown Township Arts Council's Mills Pond House in St. James, are the winners of last January's Juried Photography Exhibition.

title: >New Rules Called a Threat to Small-Scale Funeral Directors
description: FUNERAL directors in the state who handle fewer than 150 funeral calls in a year face financial hardship because of the increasing demands of new state and Federal regulations on the industry, say several of the directors and an official of their trade association.

title: Lafayette Trounces Columbia As Lions Lose 43d Straight
description: The 43d consecutive defeat for Columbia yesterday was as thorough and convincing as any of the others.

title: BellSouth Opens an Electronic Mall
description: BELLSOUTH, one of the seven regional Bell telephone companies, earlier this month became the first Baby Bell to offer an information gateway service - an electronic portal through which the consumer can gain access to local, national and international data bases and information services through a single local phone call.

title: Residential Resales

title:
INVESTING;
Behind the Collapse in the Price of Gold
description: LEAD: IN the last two weeks, prices of precious metals have dropped sharply. On Wednesday, gold fell below $400 an ounce to its lowest level in more than a year and a half. And many experts expect prices to fall even more in coming months. The slide has convinced some portfolio strategists and economists that an increase in the rate of inflation - a threat that has hung over the financial markets since the

title: The Short, Happy Life of the Italian Prune Plum
description: DEPENDING on your point of view the arrival of the small, dark purple to blue Italian prune plums signals either the end of summer or the debut of fall. These seasonal fruits, traditionally in the market for just a few weeks, inspire great baking.

title: Lynne R. Hyman Is Wed To Caird Forbes-Cockell
description: Lynne R. Hyman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Normand Hyman of Stamford, Conn., was married last evening to Caird Forbes-Cockell, a son of Mrs. Seton Forbes-Cockell of Ascot, Berkshire, England, and the late Mr. Forbes-Cockell. Joseph Chuman, an Ethical Culture Society leader in Bergen County, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Park Lane Hotel in New York.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Greenville, Del.; A Question Of Taste
description: THE tastefully aged shopping center in this wealthy community is undergoing a transformation after its sale in a family feud three years ago.

title: Collecting Recyclables For Profits and Grades
description: ON the campus of Rutgers University in New Jersey, students at the business and engineering schools are participating in an unusual experiment: sifting through barrels of discarded plastic garbage.

title: NONFICTION
description: BOXED IN: The Culture of TV. By Mark Crispin Miller. (Northwestern University, Cloth, $36.95; Paper, $14.95.) In this book of previously published essays on the strange and sometimes indigestible fruits of postwar American culture, Mark Crispin Miller, an associate professor in the Writing Seminars at Johns Hopkins, shows a goatlike intellectual appetite uncommon in an academic. Concentrating on television and its influence on culture at large, Mr. Miller is as comfortable discussing the metaphysics of ''The Cosby Show'' as he is meditating on Theodor Adorno. This amphibious quality is rare, although not quite so rare as the author's sometimes self-congratulatory prose tends to imply. Mr. Miller loves to examine the archetypes hidden in the images of mass culture. His hilarious and chilling close readings of commercials, the game show ''Family Feud'' and the Jerry Lewis telethon are, or will be, classics, and his remarks on television's effects on politics are eloquent and damning. His diary of the 1984 Presidential campaign is a field guide to the techniques of network news; sharp, funny and finally horrifying, it is a welcome companion to this year's race. Mr. Miller says that criticism such as his is ''the one action that could still counteract'' the distortions and philistinism of the ''culture of TV,'' a notion that suggests he leaves the ivory tower only through television's magic window. Perhaps as a result, half-baked assumptions and unreliable conclusions accompany brilliant insights. But for readers who can keep their heads while the author occasionally loses his, ''Boxed In'' is an extremely valuable and entertaining guide to our electric landscape.

title: Roadwya Expansion Awaits Bond Issue
description: LEAD: A $3 billion state transportation bond issue that would include $690 million for a fourth lane on portions of the Long Island Expressway, as well as for other Long Island road projects, will go before the state's voters on Nov. 8.

title: Robert Kennedy in History
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: FISHING WITH JOHN. By Edith Iglauer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) When Edith Iglauer, a frequent contributor to The New Yorker, went to British Columbia in 1974, she knew nothing of salmon fishing or the rigors of a fisherman's life. A year later, having met and married an eccentric local fisherman named John Daly, she began what was to become a four-year adventure, until his death, aboard a 41-foot troller. This graceful, well-written book is the record of her experience. In the beginning, fishing with John was anything but easy. An idealistic, feisty, deeply principled man with a near-religious love for nature and an aversion to cities, big government and bureaucracy, he had a system for everything, all of which Ms. Iglauer had to master. His was a difficult but exhilarating routine of 14-hour workdays, with stretches of 10 to 12 days at sea. Despite the cramped living quarters, inclement weather and repetitious domestic chores, life with John had its own special ease: spontaneous poetry readings at sunrise, excursions for berry picking, a soak in a wilderness hot spring. And there were always visits and shared stories with fellow fishermen. It is in the precise telling of these anecdotes that Ms. Iglauer reveals her marvelous eye for detail and her unerring ear for the quirky syntax of colloquial speech. Yet she is also able to make the technical aspects of salmon fishing - including the dangers of pollution and overfishing - an integral part of what is otherwise an elegantly understated love story as well as a quiet account of personal metamorphosis. Ultimately, hers is a plea for the respect of nature through the finding of our own humanity.

title: Space for the Dead Gets Scarce
description: IN the parts of the state where the living are many, final resting places for the dead are becoming increasingly few. Most of the shortage of cemetery space is occurring in the most intensely developed areas of the state: the cities and in Fairfield County.

title: Jersey Offers New Program To Catch Uninsured Drivers
description: A six-point program intended to track down about 600,000 New Jersey motorists who drive without insurance has been announced.

title: GET THEE BEHIND US, FREUD
description: LEAD: NELLY'S VERSION By Eva Figes. 218 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Paper, $8.95. GHOSTS By Eva Figes. 150 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $16.95.

title: Adelaide W. Lapsley Weds Sean F. Mulry
description: The marriage of Adelaide Weld Lapsley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Lapsley of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Northeast Harbor, Me., to Sean Francis Mulry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Carroll Mulry of Locust Valley, L.I., took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Westbury, L.I.

title: APPEARANCE ANXIETY
description: So the man in Susan Jacoby's life calls her face - and, presumably, her wrinkles -dear to him (Hers column, ''Appearance Anxiety,'' Aug. 28).

title: Plan for Cyanide Disposal Runs Into Problem
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has been forced to postpone indefinitely its plans to detonate a hazardous cylinder of hydrogen cyanide at a chemical plant in the nearby town of Nitro.

title: Identifying Fying Objects (And Others)
description: JON ELVERT has had a lot of telephone calls recently about the bright orange object in the southeastern night sky. As director of the Andrus Planetarium at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, Mr. Elvert patiently explained that the blazing object is Mars, and that this month the planet is closer to the Earth than it has been for 17 years or will be again for 25. (The actual opposition, or nearest meeting of the two planets in their orbits around the sun, took place three days ago, but Mars will remain bright through the fall.) Mr. Elvert said it was ''typical'' for people who rarely looked at the sky to call the planetarium to find out what they had seen. Astronomy has been neglected as a science since the early part of the century, he said, and many people don't know the planets from the stars.

title: Horchata
description: To the Editor: Speaking of horchata (Fare of the Country, May 1), mine was an amusing little experience. My husband and I were Prado-weary and sought refreshment in the nearby Palace Hotel. Having been entreated by my guidebook not to leave Spain without having tried an horchata, I ordered one. Drawing himself up and looking down his long Spanish nose, the waiter said, ''Madam, that is a drink of the streets!'' BETTY F. GIRDLER Aiken, S.C.

title: Spies & Thrillers
description: Two of the more respected practitioners of the British espionage novel are Gavin Lyall and Ted Allbeury, and both are represented by new books, Mr. Allbeury by THE STALKING ANGEL (Mysterious Press, $17.95) and Mr. Lyall by UNCLE TARGET (Viking, $16.95).

title: When Down in the Dumps Was Fun
description: Each time Nancy Clark has run for a seat in the Maine Legislature in the last 16 years, she made one place a regular campaign stop: the Freeport town dump.

title: World Economy Judged Healthy
description: Finance ministers of the largest industrial democracies said yesterday that the world economy is growing at a faster pace than had been expected, that employment has increased and that inflation is being contained.

title: UNDONE BY OLIVER NORTH
description: MEN OF ZEAL A Candid Inside Story of the Iran-Contra Hearings. By William S. Cohen and George J. Mitchell. Illustrated. 350 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Jeffrey Boden Is Wed To Caroline B. Garnett
description: At St. David's Episcopal Church in Washington, Caroline Barclay Garnett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Hunter Garnett of Richmond, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Keith Boden, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Nash Boden of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Luther D. Miller performed the ceremony.

title: TOP WOMAN CLIMBS HIGHER
description: She invested four years of hard work, testing her will and physical endurance as well as the patience of the coach who became her husband. Now, on a warm afternoon, thousands of miles from where Jackie Joyner-Kersee first envisioned competing in the Olympic Games, she walked to the starting line on the brick-red track for the 800-meter race, only two minutes and a pocketful of seconds from winning an elusive gold medal in the heptathlon.

title: Newspapers Use Taboo Word on Hirohito: Cancer
description: As concern heightened here today over the condition of Emperor Hirohito, the Japanese press violated one of its unwritten rules, publishing the word that until now no one would say publicly: cancer.

title: Headliners; Unique Conviction
description: Two days after a Texas insurance and brokerage firm dismissed Donald Gene Burleson in 1985, the company found itself with one sick computer. Later Mr. Burleson was charged with planting a destructive ''virus'' program in the company's computer, destroying 168,000 payroll records and holding up checks to company employees for more than a month. Mr. Burleson was subsequently charged with gaining harmful access to a computer, a third-degree felony. Last week, he was convicted, apparently becoming the first person to be found guilty of planting a computer virus. ''We've had people stealing through computers, but not this,'' said a prosecutor, Davis McCown. At his sentencing Oct. 21, Mr. Burleson could get 10 years in prison and be fined $5,000.

title: Vietnam's Changed Since It Fell Into the Hands of the Vietnamese
description: To the Editor:

title: That Urge for the Complete Everything
description: The urge toward completion is one of the primal human impulses, not quite up there with thirst and sex, but a strong one, nonetheless. Gestalt psychologists were not the first to recognize this obsession, but they were the first to describe, in graceful Germanic prose, our strange need to see the whole picture. The human mind may tolerate a vacuum, but it seems to abhor fragments.

title: Schools Responding to Beeper, Tool of Today's Drug Dealer, by Banning It
description: The staccato tweet of the paging beeper, which is the latest in high-technology gear for today's enterprising drug dealer, is being squelched in schools around the country.

title: Holmes Adventure Is Untraditional
description: TO go to the BayWay Arts Center in East Islip expecting ''Sherlock's Last Case'' to be a traditional colorful Sherlock Holmes adventure would be a mistake.

title:
INVESTING;
A Bet on Arabian Receivables
description: LEAD: GIVEN Wall Street's recent history, some investors think playing the stock market is a lot like playing the horses. In the case of the Interfund Corporation, they may be able to do both.

title: A Charity To Revise Practices
description: CHALLENGED by the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York, a small national charity based in Bergen County says it is revising its fund-raising practices.

title: Upon the Greensward, With Jacks, bowls and Wicks
description: FROM a crouch, Bert Schinto rolled a beautiful bowl to within a few inches of the jack on the rink at Bruce Park in Greenwich. Mr. Schinto was ecstatic, but that was shortlived.

title: 11th Grade Skills Test Quietly Advances
description: SIX years have passed since the stormy introduction of the High School Proficiency Test, the state-mandated graduation test. Educators, predicting a possible 50 percent failure rate and heightened dropout problem, criticized the shift from testing minimum basic skills to a more advanced level of basic skills testing.

title: The Games At a Glance
description: Track and Field Maybe age caught up with Edwin Moses. There is no doubt, though, that Andre Phillips plainly outran him. Phillips went out fast, gained confidence while refusing to give ground, and came back with the gold medal in the men's 400-meter hurdles, winning in an Olympic record 47.19. Moses, whose career accomplishments will stand out for years, faded in the sprint to finish just third. Amadou Dia Ba of Senegal was a stunning second. In the women's 100-meter dash, Florence Griffth Joyner, racing in an unusually understated outfit, turned in another flabbergasting time, capturing the gold in an Olympic record time of 10.54 seconds. Diving Gao Min of China made the entire morning's degree of difficulty appear minimal. Gao, with as much bounce around the pool as off the board, easily captured the gold medal in the women's springboard event. Gao, the world champion, totaled 580.23 points to win by nearly 50. Page 3. Swimming A couple of Californians got even more deeply golden as Matt Biondi and Janet Evans both won again. Biondi captured his fourth gold medal when he won the 50-meter men's freestyle. Evans, a high school senior, was again at the head of the class when she claimed her third gold in the 800-meter freestyle. Kristin Otto won her fifth gold, as a member of East Germany's 400-meter medley relay. Page 3. Boxing The American boxers, according to their coach, are finally putting punches together. They certainly are taking opponents apart. Michael Carbajal, a 106-pounder, and Romallis Ellis, fighting at 132, both earned early knockouts to run American triumphs to 10 straight. Page 4. Tennis Chris Evert mystified a lot of people when she chose to play in the Olympics. She shocked even more by falling in three sets to Raffaella Reggi of Italy. Page 7.

title: Angry Farmer Fends Off Developers
description: LEAD: FARMING can be difficult in a developing area. Traffic, roadside litter, vandalism, complaints from homeowners as well as the loss of the farming community and necessary services can all chip away at the feasibility of farming.

title: Shifting Gears With My Son
description: MY SON TEDDY IS 16, and I have been teaching him how to drive. It's the hardest thing we've done together since he was born.

title: Where Dinosaurs Roamed
description: AS a boy I often recited the mysterious, multisyllabic names of the great reptiles: Stegosaurus. Triceratops. Brontosaurus. Since then, my fascination has deepened. No longer the swamp-bound, pea-brained behemoths we once knew, dinosaurs are now viewed as lively, supremely adapted beings that thrived in a variety of habitats. Roughly 65 million years after their demise, they are making a comeback, with a rash of new discoveries in the field inspiring scientists to take a fresh look at the creatures.

title: Pamela Newman Wed To Eric Arthur Pooley
description: Pamela Elizabeth Newman and Eric Arthur Pooley were married yesterday at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Avery Manchester.

title: Yanks Refuse To Quit
description: It was supposed to be the weekend of the great Yankee comeback, but the whole thing was spoiled Friday night. Now, it has become the great Yankee tease.

title:
GARDENING;
Trees Can Mitigate Greenhouse Effect
description: LEAD: MANY environmentalists predict that a buildup of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere from the burning of fossil fuels and others will result in the greenhouse effect and that the buildup will reduce the amount of heat the Earth radiates into the atmosphere, raising global temperatures.

title: PLAN TO STERILIZE WOMAN IS DEBATED
description: Melody Baldwin poisoned her first child. A second baby is on the way. Now the judge who controls her fate has proposed an unorthodox solution to the troubles of her life - sterilization.

title: Radar Detectors And Car Insurance
description: IS IT fair to deny auto insurance to drivers who own radar detectors?

title: Sri Lanka's Human Barometer of Discontent
description: For more than a decade, Ronnie de Mel held Sri Lanka's lifeline to the world.

title: The Time Has Come for Seasonal Chores
description: SINCE fall is officially here, the rush is on to keep up with planting especially conifers, broadleaved evergreens and new selections of containerized perennials. Finish dividing established clumps of perennials and share viable roots with friends. Continue planning bulb displays and select first choices from garden center bins; bulb planting continues until early November, but the sooner the better so new roots can grow. QUESTIONS/ANSWERS CUTTING BACK

title:
DINING OUT;
East-West Fare Mixes in Madison
description: LEAD: A CONCEPT that is gaining popularity is the marriage of Eastern and Western cuisines. Cutting-edge restaurants in California and Manhattan are combining the flavors and artistry of Asia with European techniques and American ingredients. And so word of a brand new restaurant in Madison offering Japanese

title: Murray Cohen, Lawyer, 61
description: Murray Cohen, who retired two years ago as senior partner of the New York law firm of Rosenman Colin Freund Lewis & Cohen, now Rosenman & Colin, died of complications from kidney disease on Friday at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 61 years old.

title: UNDERGROUND RAILROAD, 1980'S STYLE
description: SANCTUARY A Story of American Conscience and the Law in Collision. By Ann Crittenden. Illustrated. 410 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $21.95. CONVICTIONS OF THE HEART Jim Corbett and the Sanctuary Movement. By Miriam Davidson. 187 pp. Tucson: University of Arizona Press. $22.50.

title: Fontainebleau: Grand Palace, Magical Forest
description: FRANCOIS I, who brought the Renaissance to France, began building it; his successors added to it; Louis XIV loved it; Marie Antoinette found it came close to her ideal of a country palace. Throughout the centuries, Fontainebleau remained a favorite residence of the kings of France. It is still a rich and diverse building, full of treasures and memories, set in a park linked to a mysterious forest that once was home to wood nymphs and a ghostly hunter visible only to the kings of France. Here, microclimates change with amazing rapidity; tall rocks appear suddenly at the turn of a path just when you thought you were in a sandy waste; wild animals prosper. So it is no wonder that from the the 12th century there has been a house in those magical woods.

title: LOVE AND HATE FOR THE PERFECT HERO
description: LAST NOTES FROM HOME By Frederick Exley. 397 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: Air Control: Full Skies, Help Wanted
description: IN Westbury, at the half-empty, dimly lighted radar approach center that monitors most aircraft flying through the New York-Long Island area, night shifts can stretch on and on.

title: Alexandra P. Sheerar Weds Paul Dewey Jr.
description: At. St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Portsmouth, R.I., Alexandra Pavlinka Sheerar, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Harmon Sheerar of Sarasota, Fla., was married yesterday to Paul Carpenter Graves Dewey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dewey of Newtown Square, Pa. The Rev. Gordon Stenning performed the ceremony.

title: Nancy Scurlock Wed in Bermuda
description: Nancy Lynne Scurlock, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arch Chilton Scurlock of Arlington, Va., and Tucker's Town, Bermuda, was married yesterday at Holy Trinity Anglican Church in Bailey's Bay, Bermuda, to Michael Weld Collins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Collins of Bethesda, Md.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Gregg Jefferies The Rookie Of the Year?
description: Gregg Jefferies steps up to the plate. Gets a fourth hit in four times at bat. Pandemonium at Shea. McCarver is yelling, Kiner is yelling, and on my radio, Thorn is shouting, and the Murph is ecstatic. Disregard the technicalities that say Mr. Jefferies does not have enough times at bat. Not only do you have the rookie of this year, but the rookie of last year, the year before, and next year as well. PAMELA ROMANO White Plains

title: CHASE MANHATTAN'S MAN IN HONG KONG
description: FROM THE WINDOW OF HIS SKYSCRAPER office, Hughlyn F. Fierce looks out over Hong Kong harbor, jammed with sampans and junks bound for the South China Sea. A senior vice president and Chase Manhattan's man in charge of the Asia-Pacific area, Fierce commands an empire that encompasses 11 nations, 1,500 employees and $5 billion in assets. A husky 52-year-old, he wears an amiable expression that belies the large demands he makes on himself - and his staff.

title: PLAY IT AGAIN, NATHAN
description: LEAD: THE FACTS A Novelist's Autobiography. By Philip Roth. 195 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: Drug Agency Allowed to Use Bentsen Ranch in Operations
description: The family of Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, has allowed the Drug Enforcement Administration to use its Texas ranches and other properties in anti-drug operations, the agency said Friday.

title: WHAT FACTS? A TALK WITH ROTH
description: LEAD: Philip Roth has often been accused of relying too heavily on the facts of his life in his fiction. Almost as though in answer to his critics, he writes in his autobiography that ''every genuine imaginative event begins down there, with the facts.'' In an interview last month in Chicago, we talked about the problems he faced in telling the story of his life, and how that story relates to his fiction.

title:
ART;
A Sculptor's Rhythmic Vision
description: LEAD: AS a tribute to Costantino Nivola, the East Hampton sculptor who died in May, the Dia Art Foundation in Bridgehampton has assembled an exhibition that helps to clarify his special vision.

title: Suspect in U.S. Agent's Death Is Sentenced
description: A man believed to be a leading Mexican drug trafficker accused in the 1985 slaying of an American narcotics agent has been sentenced to 34 years in prison on other charges, a Mexican judge announced Friday.

title: Rutgers Holds Off Penn State
description: Mike Botti, a senior running back for Rutgers, said that the prospect of beating Penn State had been in his thoughts since he first began playing for the Scarlet Knights.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We recently had our kitchen cabinets refinished with a Formica veneer. Several months later, we noticed that the veneer on one five-foot-long cabinet door was starting to come loose in the middle, forming a blister or ''balloon'' about six inches long. The adhesive above and below this is adhering tightly. Is there anything we can do to loosen the panel so that it can be taken off and reglued?

title: U.S SWIMMERS ARRESTED
description: Troy Dalbey and Doug Gjertsen, both double gold-medal swimmers for the United States, were dropped from the squad today following their arrest on charges of stealing a marble lion's head valued at $830 from a hotel.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Say, Did You See the Sign We Saw?
description: LEAD: AS a tour escort, I travel across the American landscape, often traversing the same routes, yet I regularly find new charm and surprises on each trip. A particularly appealing source of interest to me is the ingenuity that seems to be everywhere these days in the names that have been given to stores and business.

title: ARMY TAKES BLAME IN HELICOPTER CASE
description: A senior Army official has acknowledged to Congress that the Army was lax in overseeing contracts with Bell Helicopter, thus allowing the company to charge excessive prices.

title: TIME FOR SNACKS
description: The French call it le gouter de quatre heures, that sacred moment somewhere around 4 o'clock each afternoon when small stomachs begin to rumble. If you pay attention, you will notice sweet aromas wafting through the damp Parisian air. From one quarter comes the buttery scent of freshly baked croissant dough oozing with sticks of melting, bittersweet chocolate. From another comes the trail of warm apple tartlets, embellished with brown sugar. Nearby, the senses detect a faint hint of grilled hazelnuts, as fragrant financiers, tiny buttery rectangular cakes, are shuffled from the oven.

title: Katie Ridder, Editor, Is Wed
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Katherine Lee Ridder, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Anthony Ridder of Miami Beach, was married yesterday to Peter Morgan Pennoyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Pennoyer of New York and Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: Carolyn J. Sedor, Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Carolyn Jean Sedor, a pediatric resident at Boston City Hospital, and Dr. Maturin Delafield Finch, a resident in physical medicine and rehabilitation at the Boston University Hospital, were married yesterday in Sturbridge, Mass. The Rev. John Buehrens, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Old Sturbridge Village Meeting House.

title: POSTINGS: 9 Units in a Walkup; Condo Rehab In Hoboken
description: ''I probably spent too much money,'' said Santo Fulmino of his nine-unit rehabilitation project in Hoboken, N.J. It was, after all, his first development. It was also a learning experience. The costs were $725,000 to buy a five-story, walkup of railroad flats at 1214 Washington Street and $700,000 to turn it into the Patrician condominium.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Diving; Gold and Silver to Chinese Women
description: Gao Min and Li Qing, teen-age symbols of China's rise toward diving supremacy, won Olympic gold and silver medals in women's springboard competition today.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: FOLIAGE DISPLAY

title: Miles Per Gallon
description: To the Editor:

title: APPEARANCE ANXIETY
description: Susan Jacoby fails to discuss the male rush for minoxidil and the modern acceptance of such co-ed beauty aids as perms, exercise, tanning salons, designer clothes and toiletries. Plastic surgery may not be considered macho just now, but this may change. ANA T. TUCKMAN Monsey, N.Y.

title: Correction
description: Because of a computer transmission error, an article in the Long Island Journal on Sept. 11 incorrectly described the engine power of the Smithtown marine bureau's patrol boat. The boat has a 150-horsepower engine cover concealing a 235-horsepower engine.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Working on the Railroad

title: IRAN IS SAID TO CHANGE DIRECTION IN DOMESTIC AND FOREIGN POLICIES
description: Iran is distancing itself from the aggressive policies that characterized its behavior in the last few years, moving instead toward moderation in domestic and foreign policies, according to Iranian officials and experts in Persian Gulf affairs.

title: Susan Jacobs, Lawyer, Marries Richard Lobel
description: Susan Jacobs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Jacobs of White Plains, was married last evening to Richard I. Lobel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Lobel of Savannah, Ga. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony at Bridgewaters at the South Street Seaport in New York.

title: Douglas Huff Jr., Politician, 57
description: Douglas Huff Jr., who resigned his seat in the Illinois House of Representatives two weeks ago after being convicted of Federal tax evasion and admitting a cocaine habit, died Thursday. He was 57 years old.

title: Back for Now
description: Almost a month after he was given a 30-day suspension for violating the National Football League's substance-abuse policy, Terry Taylor, the Seattle Seahawk cornerback, will be making his second game appearance and his first start of the season today.

title: By Wood Burner From Buenos Aires
description: AT dawn, rattling through Paraguay's rural interior on the Ferrocarril Presidente Carlos Antonio Lopez, I was dogged by the pungent aroma of burning wood - not a smell I'd previously associated with trains. Hot grease, steam, coal smoke and diesel exhaust: those, in my experience, were proper train smells.

title: A President's Summer Retreat
description: LEAD: RONALD REAGAN has a Western White House and so did Richard M. Nixon. But Chester A. Arthur, President of the United States from 1881 to 1885, decided to stay East when retreating for the summer, and now the home he occupied, restored and redecorated, is up for sale. The asking price is $925,000 furnished, $775,000 unfurnished.

title: Can a Middle-Aged Writer Fill a Void Onstage?
description: Funny writers are funny. I have never met a writer who wrote funny who wasn't funny in person. And with funny writers, humor permeates everything they write. So it doesn't require a vast leap of imagination to accept that Calvin Trillin, with a long list of credits as a funny person - two comic novels, three books on eating, which he refers to as ''the tummy trilogy,'' chronicles on American life for The New Yorker, sitdown comedy turns on Carson and Letterman, a weekly syndicated column called ''Uncivil Liberties'' and appearances on the lecture circuit - is doing a one-man show on a theater stage. It opens tomorrow at the American Place Theater and will run through Oct. 9.

title: A Runner's Patience Pays Off at the Post
description: A RELATIVELY serious runner, he was near his East End home, cruising the approximate route of the 10-kilometer race and near the end of the first mile of what might have been a warmup for the event, when it occurred to him that a quick stop at the post office was in order. It also occurred to him that in these sweaty sweats his might be an unwelcome, even rude, spring bouquet.

title: A SPOOK WHEN YOUNG
description: THE SECRET WAR AGAINST HITLER By William Casey. Illustrated. 304 pp. Washington: Regnery Gateway. $19.95.

title: Bujones, Last of the Romantics
description: LEAD: There was a time, 15 years ago to be precise, when the ballet world was very glamorous. There seemed to be a limitless supply of exciting international performers, including Anthony Dowell, Natalia Makarova, Erik Bruhn, Marcia Haydee and Rudolf Nureyev. Their artistry dazzled audiences and they all swarmed to American Ballet Theater, where they were pampered and fussed over by the company's founder, Lucia

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Gymnastics; GOLDEN FINALE FOR SOVIET MEN By LAWRIE MIFFLIN
description: When the last man had flung himself through a spinning, twisting dismount from the high bar Saturday afternoon, ending the men's Olympic gymnastics competition, it had never been clearer that the Soviet Union is the dominant country in this sport.

title: Charles B. Persell Jr., Bishop, 79
description: The Rev. Charles B. Persell Jr., Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Albany from 1963 until his retirement in 1977, died Friday at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany after a stroke. He was 79 years old and lived in Loudonville, N.Y.

title: Review/City Opera; 'Tosca,' A Standard, Returns
description: The City Opera has the ingredients for a good solid ''Tosca'' this season, and that is what the company gave at the opera's first outing Friday night. Leading the cast was Linda Roark-Strummer, who sang the title part even more securely than she had last season.

title: Mortadella
description: To the Editor: In ''Mortadella: Bologna's Bologna'' (Travel, Aug. 7), the name mortadella is explained by a bit of etymological guesswork as shortened from mortaio della carne di maiale, much as Americans shorten maitre d'hotel to maitre d'.

title: Open Cage Presents Homage to Sandburg
description: HE was extolled as the American Bard, poet laureate of the people and a prairie philosopher - and likened to one of the Lord's prophets. When an evening of his writings was produced on Broadway, seven years before his death, Carl Sandburg was described as ''the 82-year-old urchin of literature.''

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Katonah
description: LEAD: EARLY in 1983, Janet and David Fletcher, cold and hungry and heading back to Manhattan from a Vermont vacation, pulled off Interstate 684 into the hamlet of Katonah in northeastern Westchester County and found what Mrs. Fletcher called ''just the most perfect place we had ever seen.''

title: 7 CASES OF POLIO REPORTED IN ISRAEL
description: Thousands of Israelis were inoculated against polio today as Health Ministry officials tried to decide whether to vaccinate the entire nation. Seven cases of the paralyzing virus were confirmed in the north of the country this month, causing concern among many Israelis.

title: 'Show Boat' Makes New Waves
description: More than 60 years after Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein 2d's ''Show Boat'' galvanized Broadway by injecting serious dramatic music into a lighthearted popular art form, a major new recording of the show has been churning up the waters of the musical-theater world.

title: Freeze! You're on TV
description: ON MAY 15, MARK GOODMAN was serving the last days of a brief sentence for burglary in the Palm Beach County, Fla., stockade. That night, a Sunday, Goodman and his fellow inmates turned on the cellblock TV set to watch ''America's Most Wanted,'' one of the hottest, and most controversial, shows on television.

title: Pentagon Delays Payments, Upsetting Suppliers
description: The Pentagon, facing an apparent cash shortage as it nears the end of the Federal Government's fiscal year next Friday, is delaying payments to suppliers until October, industry and Government officials say.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Boxing; U.S. Overcoming Early Ring Failures
description: Admittedly, it was not the most auspicious way to start the competition. The best-known boxer on the United States team was knocked out in the first round, while one of the medal favorites missed a bus and was disqualified. But since those embarrassments last week, Team Chaos has been doing quite well, slowly repairing its image, showing that the Americans may have a stronger Olympic team than expected.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Sept. 11 Design Preview article, two picture captions on the bottom of page 78 were inadvertently reversed. The lounge chair by Knoll International was on the right; the stacking armchair by Toussaint on the left.

title: Stalemate Over Shoreham Persists Despite Recommendation for License
description: In recommending that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission grant the Shoreham nuclear power plant a full license, a Federal panel has moved Shoreham much closer to the possibility of commercial operation, officials said yesterday, but done little to resolve the 20-year stalemate over the plant.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about Campbell Norsgaard and Ernestine Jaediker Norsgaard, husband and wife nature writers, misidentified the publisher of their book ''How to Raise Butterflies.'' It is the Putnam Publishing Group.

title: PUTTING A GLOSS ON THE TOMBSTONE
description: IN THE PARK AVENUE OFFICE of Robert K. de Veer Jr., a managing director of the First Boston Corporation, a caricature holds a place of honor. The setting is Vietnam. Bombs are falling. De Veer and three First Boston colleagues hunker down in a foxhole. The painting celebrates their hard-won triumph, a successful public bond offering for Hercules, the chemical company.

title: Michael Fessier, Writer, 82
description: Michael Fessier, a movie and television scriptwriter as well as an author of short stories, died Tuesday. He was 82 years old.

title: Agent Enters Plea
description: A week after Cris Carter admitted that he had received $5,000 from an agent while playing for Ohio State, the agent pleaded not guilty to a charge that he lied in telling a grand jury that he had not made such a payment. He also pleaded not guilty to a charge that he had urged Carter to deny the payment.

title: WHEN THE C.E.O. WON'T GO
description: BRUCE D. HENDERSON created the Boston Consulting Group 25 years ago and turned it into one of the nation's premier management consultants. But in 1979, at the age of 64, he fell victim to a palace revolt and was deposed as chief executive officer.

title: Amnesia
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Findlay Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Kimberly Wrede Findlay, a daughter of Mrs. E. Andrew Deeds of Charlotte, Vt., and David B. Findlay Jr. of New York and New Canaan, Conn., to Jonathan Bostwick Davis, the son of Dr. E. William Davis Jr. of New York and Old Westbury, L.I., and the late Lillian Bostwick Davis, took place yesterday at the Charlotte Congregational Church. The Rev. Robert Gormbley performed the ceremony.

title: For Burmese, the Operative Word Now Is Shortage
description: As Burma settles in for what could be a war of attrition between the military Government and the popular opposition, reports from Rangoon portray a city struggling to survive after six weeks of strikes and shortages.

title: Miles Per Gallon
description: Opposed to the CAFE regulations, we have the president of a corporation that was a leader in helping excavate the pit of perdition in which the domestic auto industry finds itself. Over many years, General Motors failed to pay attention to what its overseas competition was doing and insisted that what the American public needed were inefficient, plush, oversized vehicles.

title: Mary Elizabeth McCaffrey Is Wed to John T. Daniel
description: The marriage of Mary Elizabeth McCaffrey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. McCaffrey of Port Washington, L.I., to John Thomas Daniel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Daniel of Garland, Tex., took place yesterday in New York. The Rev. Christopher Maloney, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We recently had our kitchen cabinets refinished with a Formica veneer. Several months later, we noticed that the veneer on one five-foot-long cabinet door was starting to come loose in the middle, forming a blister or ''balloon'' about six inches long. The adhesive above and below this is adhering tightly. Is there anything we can do to loosen the panel so that it can be taken off and reglued?

title: Miss America, I Love You
description: WHEN television was still a rather new form of entertainment on my block, millions of Americans watched mesmerized in 1954 as the first televised Miss America Pageant came into our homes. I was a very young boy when this event captured my heart and hooked me for life.

title: CONSUMER RATES
They're Battling at The Bastille Again, This Time Over A Brave New Opera House
description: Paris is famous for politics, the arts and polemics, and all three have come together in a battle royal over the futuristic $350-million opera house being built on the Place de la Bastille.

title: Heirs of Sol Goldman Battle Over Estate
description: ON Oct. 20, 1983, Lillian Goldman moved out of the Waldorf-Astoria suite she shared with her husband, Sol, and began a divorce proceeding. She asked for half of Mr. Goldman's $1 billion in assets, New York City's largest private real-estate empire.

title: NEW JERSEY FOLLOW-UP
description: Police Shooting A MOUNTAINSIDE police officer was justified when he opened fire on a fleeing stolen auto that had struck a fellow officer just moments before, a Union County grand jury decided last month. Seriously wounded in the incident, which occurred on July 8 on eastbound Route 22, was a Berkeley Heights man who happened to be driving by in a pickup truck.

title: Rice (.264) Bats in Place of Boggs (.362)
description: When Spike Owen batted for Jim Rice earlier this season, Rice got into a tussle with the Boston manager, Joe Morgan, and was suspended for three days. In an even more unusual move, Rice batted for Wade Boggs yesterday, but no confrontation followed.

title: KING OF THE HIPOISIE
description: THE LIVES OF JOHN LENNON By Albert Goldman. Illustrated. 719 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE MEDIA LAB: Inventing the Future at MIT, by Stewart Brand. (Penguin, $10.) Among the projects being pursued by the zealous denizens of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Media Laboratory is an artificially intelligent electronic newspaper that, anticipating its readers' interests, selects with them in mind. Stewart Brand ''does a good job of translating the arcane language of M.I.T. engineers into English,'' our reviewer, Lawrence Hunter, said last year, though at times he ''seems overwhelmed by imminent utopia.'' THE CHILD IN TIME, by Ian McEwan. (Penguin, $7.95.) One Saturday morning, on a trip to the supermarket with her father, 3-year-old Kate Lewis disappears. Devastated, her father, Stephen, is set mentally adrift, withdrawing from those around him as he embarks on a personal exploration of the meaning of time. Ian McEwan ''is something of a master at representing misery,'' Rebecca Goldstein said here last year. Though she thought the novel's ''powerful empathetic current [ was ] occasionally frozen over by something cold and overly calculated . . . we are carried to an ending as artfully conceived as it is poignantly realized.'' The same publisher has reprinted Mr. McEwan's novel THE CEMENT GARDEN ($6.95), in which four children hide their mother's corpse in the basement to keep from being institutionalized as orphans. In 1978 one reviewer said the book was evidence of ''an original talent that . . . can only advance and grow.'' THE FIREBRAND, by Marion Zimmer Bradley. (Pocket, $8.95.) The author of ''The Mists of Avalon'' retells the ''Iliad'' from a woman's point of view. This popularization, ''a very different vision,'' one reviewer said last year, ''is full of flesh-and-blood characters.'' FIRST CONTACT, by Bob Connolly and Robin Anderson. (Penguin, $10.95.) In 1930, the people of isolated valleys in the interior of New Guinea experienced a strange visitation of ''skymen,'' who turned out to be Australians seeking gold. Through photographs and narratives of the highlanders, the authors ''succeed here in re-creating one of the last great adventures of exploration on our planet,'' Michael Fobes Brown said in The Book Review last year. THE ANTHROPIC COSMOLOGICAL PRINCIPLE, by John D. Barrow and Frank J. Tipler. (Oxford University, $15.95.) Purveyors of the anthropic view - who believe that, by the very act of observation humans create the universe - have an easy answer for those who ask why the universe is so old: if it were any younger, carbon atoms never would have developed and we carboniferous creatures wouldn't be around to ask questions. The authors ''understand their subject very well indeed, and they have written a clear, rigorous and exhaustively researched book that promises - or threatens - to keep the principle kicking for years to come,'' Timothy Ferris said here in 1986. ''I was infuriated by it, disagreed with it and loved reading it.'' THE RIDDLE OF THE THIRD MILE, by Colin Dexter. (Bantam, $3.50.) A dismembered and beheaded body found in a canal is apparently that of an Oxford don. But as more bodies turn up, ''the plot assumes the complexity of a computer chip,'' Newgate Callendar said here in 1984. ''There has been nothing like it since the days of Ellery Queen. Preposterous? Perhaps. But also mischievous, tongue-in-cheek and an utter delight.'' EVERYTHING TO GAIN: Making the Most of the Rest of Your Life, by Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter. (Fawcett, $4.95.) When the Carters' combination memoir and self- help book was published last year, our reviewer, Letty Cottin Pogrebin, called it ''inspiring.'' ''They describe their last seven years with endearing honesty - and with the fervent wish that you, dear reader, apply to your own retirement or middle age the lessons learned by the involuntarily unemployed First Family.'' LITTLE EDEN: A Child at War, by Eva Figes. (Persea, $8.95.) The author of this recollection was 6 years old when she fled Germany with her family in 1939, settling in England, where she began her assimilation into British culture. Last year, our reviewer, Lore Segal, said the memoir of childhood and war was ''nostalgic and lyrical.'' NEW ISLANDS: And Other Stories, by Maria Luisa Bombal. (Cornell University, $6.95.) When this collection, translated from the Spanish by Richard and Lucia Cunningham, was published in English in 1982, our reviewer, Ronald De Feo, said these ''evocative, haunting stories,'' written in the 1940's by a Chilean, anticipated the magic realism of later Latin American writers like Gabriel Garcia Marquez. GRAND OPENING, by Jon Hassler. (Ballantine, $3.95.) During World War II a family of newcomers tries to start a supermarket and a life in a small, xenophobic Minnesota town. ''Despite a few slow moments and stock secondary characters, this well-constructed novel effectively portrays human weakness and triumph,'' Gardner McFall said here last year. ''Without sentimentality, Mr. Hassler illustrates - in the spirit, if not the virtuosity, of Flannery O'Connor - that we often learn more about God from misfits than do-gooders or saints.'' LETTERS FROM THE COUNTRY, by Carol Bly. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) Carol Bly's essays, written when she lived in Madison, Minn., with her former husband, the poet Robert Bly, are not aimed at city folk, Noel Perrin said here in 1981. ''These are letters to small towns [ and ] a very readable mixture of sociology, secular sermons and good stories. All are intended to raise rural consciousnesses.''

title: BARTER IS HIS STOCK IN TRADE
description: IN THE FALL OF 1986, W. DOUGLASS LEE Jr., an American commodities trader based in London, received a call for help from a representative of a major chemical producer. The United States multinational corporation had sold $8 million in chemicals to Zimbabwe and had agreed to take payment in tobacco rather than cash. The company had resold the tobacco to Egypt and, in the process, had negotiated a $12 million chemicals sale as well. In lieu of cash, Egypt was offering in payment for both deals a shopping list of commodities ranging from pig iron to rice and coriander.

title: McBooks, McBucks
description: LEAD: The publishing world is buzzing with news of the latest big buyout.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Tide of Renewal Laps at Newark's Core
description: LEAD: OVER the last decade Newark has undergone a slow but steady commercial revitalization. The signs of this new economic strength are most evident near the Pennsylvania Railroad Station, at the edge of downtown, where the four-building, 2.5 million-square-foot Gateway office and hotel complex now stands.

title: Vacancy Report
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Special Care If Needed; Retirement Village, Plus
description: With their empty-nester condominiums, the communities north and west of Hartford have become magnets for the Connecticut capital's older residents. By 1990, only one in 10 people in Hartford will be 65 or older, but one in four residents of West Hartford will fit that description and, in Bloomfield, one in five. Yet, many of these people want more than their hedges trimmed and need more than a condominium association to look after them.

title: POSTINGS: On the Housatonic; Milford Condos
description: Kevin Bartlett recently completed 24 condominium apartments and 103 condominium boat slips in Milford, Conn. Now, he is starting on 24 more apartments and 120 more slips there. But Mr. Bartlett contends he is more a home than a marina builder. And, despite waiting lists up and down Long Island Sound for slips and the imbalance of his own development, he insists that condominiums measured by the square foot are as much in demand as those measured by the linear foot.

title: Pamela A. Kurtz And C. D. Welch Exchange Vows
description: Pamela Anne Kurtz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert John Kurtz of Northampton, N.H., and Christopher Donnelly Welch, the son of Mrs. Peter Charles Welch of Boston and Osterville, Mass., and the late John Donnelly of Dedham, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Maurice Rochefort performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Exeter, N.H.

title: A THIRD OF VOTERS REMAIN UNCERTAIN ON EVE OF DEBATE
description: Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts meet tonight in a debate that could be pivotal for a Presidential contest in which voters are uncertain and dissatisfied with how the candidates have discussed the issues.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additonal titles of interest:

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: I WON'T say I was bored. But you can only thumb through a copy of ''The Birds of Australia'' for so long. Checking out the Saturday night television lineup wasn't the option it is in most households. The set is busted - has been, in fact, since 1975 - and the pile of unread novels was down to Michener's latest.

title: Group Raising Money For Cleanup of Shore
description: JOHN SCHMIDT and Richard Kinney sat at the Spring Lake Bath and Tennis Club on a recent morning discussing medical waste, beach closings and what some see as the tainted image of the New Jersey Shore. As officials of the New Jersey Shore Foundation, Mr. Schmidt, its president, and Mr. Kinney, a member of its board of trustees, were optimistic about eventually changing that image and supplementing what local and state governments are doing to save the shore.

title: Lowey Turns Her Attention to DioGuardi
description: LEAD: WITH six weeks remaining until Election Day, the two major candidates for Congress in the 20th District are trying to portray themselves as moderates, while describing the opponent as an extremist.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: East; SYRACUSE TROUNCES VIRGINIA TECH, 35-0
description: Todd Philcox threw for three touchdowns to the wide receiver Rob Moore and scored on a flea-flicker play today as Syracuse (2-1) routed Virginia Tech, 35-0. Philcox, a fifth-year senior, completed 9 of 18 passes for 167 yards in three quarters.

title: Data on Youths' Promiscuity Stir Concern on AIDS
description: A new survey indicates that as many as 700,000 young American men may have at least 10 sexual partners a year. The Federal Centers for Disease Control said this put them at ''considerable risk'' of contracting sexually transmitted diseases, including AIDS.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: STATE OF WAR. By Ninotchka Rosca. (Norton, $17.95.) Ninotchka Rosca's ''State of War'' takes place on the eve of revolution during an annual Philippine festival. From the outset, Ms. Rosca uses the Dionysiac abandon associated with the festival's rites to foreshadow the explosive political turbulence that lies at the core of the narrative.

title: THE REGION: Senate Post for Marino; A Suburbanite Ascends In Albany, for a Big Change
description: IN New York State, where county borders often form the lines for political battle zones, regionalism is potent. So when it became clear this month that the next leader of the State Senate would be Ralph J. Marino, a Republican from Nassau County, and not the upstate legislator of tradition, the event was seen more as a change of eras than as just another shift in leadership.

title: THE CASE OF PAUL DE MAN
description: I must correct James Atlas's informative article ''The Case of Paul de Man'' (Aug. 28) on one point. I never stated that members of the comparative literature department at Yale ''knew all about'' Paul de Man's past. On the contrary, most of Mr. de Man's colleagues, including myself, knew nothing about his wartime past. What I said to Mr. Atlas is that following the publication of the Times article of Dec. 1, 1987, that first made public Mr. de Man's wartime journalism, I learned that at least one senior faculty member at Yale (not, in fact, in comparative literature) had known about Mr. de Man's implication in collaborationist activities at the time of his appointment to the Yale faculty. I do not know the extent or the detail of this knowledge, and I am quite certain that it was not widely shared among other Yale faculty members.

title:
MUSIC;
Conducting Without 'Dictating'
description: LEAD: THE Stockton Performing Arts Center, at Stockton State College, will open an extensive season of cultural events with a performance by the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra on Saturday at 7 P.M., followed by a gala reception for the audience.

title: Goal Met in Fighting Children's Tooth Decay
description: As many as two-thirds of the nation's children are free of tooth decay, but other dental health problems remain unsolved, new Federal statistics show.

title: Disabled Learn to Sail for Self-Esteem
description: Timothy Flynn started sailing as a child and did so just for the fun of it until he was 19, when he lost the use of his limbs in an automobile accident.

title:
GARDENING;
Bulbs and Perennials as Teammates
description: LEAD: ONE of the most exasperating experiences of gardening is trying to remember where last spring's bulbs were planted when looking for sites for the new ones. The gardener's memory is short.

title: Where the Street Signs Are The Most Popular Attractions
description: WHEN James Bozzi gives friends from out-of-town directions to his home in Portland, he gives detailed ones and does not rely on street signs to guide his visitors' way.

title: From Bottles to Bathtubs - Sinks and Showers, Too
description: WHAT do bathtubs, boat piers, flower pots and carpets have in common? Answer: they are all products that have been made from recycled plastic bottles.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Gregg Jefferies The Rookie Of the Year?
description: Even though Gregg Jefferies has been a superstar hitter, batting .400-plus, and also a great fielder, I'm sure that he doesn't have enough games to be eligible to win the award. [ To qualify for the award, a rookie must have been on a major league roster for at least 45 days and have at least 130 times at bat. Jefferies will fall short by approximately 12 times at bat. ] SANJAY NAIK Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: In Chess, a Machine Is the Master
description: Man has met machine at the New School for Social Research, and the machine has won.

title: John E. Ray Wed To Miss Consagra
description: Francesca Consagra and John Edward Ray were married yesterday at the home of the bride's mother, Sophie Chandler Consagra, in Montchanin, Del. The Rev. John O'Hear, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Annick Finlan Weds W. P. Tavoulareas Jr.
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York, Annick Finlan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Finlan of Whitegate, Cheshire, England; Majorca, Spain, and London, was married yesterday to William Peter Tavoulareas Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tavoulareas of Sands Point, L.I.; Boca Raton, Fla., and New York. The Rev. Henry A. Boyle performed the ceremony.

title: House Divides New Hampshire Town
description: In this town's 250-year history, few situations have warranted a special town meeting, except for those called to discuss revolt against the British. And so when an unscheduled town meeting was held last month, it was fitting that the impetus was something some townspeople consider revolting in its own way: construction of a modern house in a historic district.

title: When Hunters Are Hunted
description: ''JACKING'' deer - hunting them at night by shining a spotlight into their eyes to make them ''freeze'' -is illegal, but the odds of catching violators are slim. Delaware wildlife officers were reported lowering the odds early this year by using decoys - styrofoam deer covered with deerskins and equipped with antlers and reflective glass eyes.

title: Dr. Kesselman Weds Dr. H. W. Fingerhut Jr.
description: Dr. Amy J. Kesselman, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at George Washington University Hospital in Washington, and Dr. Herbert Wise Fingerhut Jr., an attending anesthesiologist at the Reston (Va.) Hospital Center, were married last evening in Westport, Conn. Rabbi Robert Orkand performed the ceremony at Temple Israel.

title: Correction
description: An article on page 19 in some copies of the Travel section today, about botanical gardens, misstates the admission charge for the Summer Palace gardens in Beijing. It is 3 cents, not $3.

title: Bush Aims at Broad Issues In Debate Tonight With Foe
description: A seemingly relaxed George Bush said today that he was heading into his debate with Michael S. Dukakis on Sunday night hoping to present ''broad principles'' rather than specific proposals to project his differences with the Democratic Presidential nominee.

title: Brand-New Degree?; Consider Nursing
description: For liberal arts majors with no place to go [ ''Brand-New Degree and No Place to Go,'' Opinion, Aug. 28 ] , nursing is a profession that offers ''rewarding work.''

title: THE POET WHO FELL TO EARTH
description: THE SYKAOS PAPERS By E. P. Thompson. 482 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Gregg Jefferies The Rookie Of the Year?
description: Chris Sabo of the Cincinnati Reds is the National League Rookie of the Year. Sabo's performance as a rookie is an enviable paradigm of baseball excellence, a synthesis of performance, professionalism, discipline, and a personal modesty. MITCHEL GERBER East Meadow, L.I.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Bangkok
description: One aspect of Bangkok that strikes almost everybody, visitor and resident alike, is the bewildering speed with which the city is changing. Except for temples and a few royal landmarks, little seems as it was even five years ago - from the skyline, now impressively studded with high-rise office buildings, condominiums and hotels, to the favorite haunts of locals in search of what the Thais call sanuk (fun).

title: Mooris Should Be Taylor's Model
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Aral Sea Vanishes as Cotton Fields Expand
description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy Stevens Marries
description: Wendy Beth Stevens, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay P. Stevens of Great Neck, L.I., and Jupiter, Fla., and Donald Hal Schneidman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Schneidman of Rye Brook, N.Y., were married last night. Rabbi Jerome Davidson officiated at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck. The bride, who will keep her name, is a certified public accountant with Laventhol & Horwath in New York. Her husband is a certified public accountant and the assistant controller of the Imrex Company, an electronics and computer software concern in Great Neck.

title: Supervisor's Contest Unfolds in North Salem
description: LEAD: MANAGEMENT is emerging as a key issue in North Salem, site of the county's lone supervisor's race this year.

title: Bronco Is Fined
description: To the referees who watched the play and to some viewers who have studied the videotapes, there was nothing improper about the tackle that knocked Steve Largent out of the season opener against the Denver Broncos with a concussion and caused the Seattle Seahawk receiver to have two teeth capped. As they saw it, the hit by Mike Harden, the Denver free safety, came just after the ball arrived on a pass to Largent, who did not hold on to the ball. No penalty was called on the play, and, according to Harden, neither Largent nor anybody else in the Seattle organization complained about the hit.

title: ACROSS AFRICA WITH MACHINE GUN AND PRESUMPTION
description: THE LAST HERO By Peter Forbath. 729 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.

title: Undefeated Rams to Show Giants a New Defense
description: In the weeks after Eric Dickerson's trade from Los Angeles to Indianapolis last season, the Rams succumbed to one of their worst slumps in nearly six years.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FIREBRAT By Nancy Willard. Illustrated by David Wiesner. 121 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title: City and State at Odds on Battery Park Hotel Plan
description: A preliminary agreement that would allow a Swiss company to build a luxury hotel in Battery Park City has been approved in a deal in which the company would contribute more than $30 million to the construction of a Jewish heritage museum, city officials said yesterday.

title: Chance Encounters of the Best Kind
description: IT was the first and only time I have ever gambled. I hadn't even known there was a casino when I arrived in Baden-Baden earlier that day, but quickly enough I learned about the tables and dice that attracted 19th-century czars and British princes after their mineral baths and water cures. Dostoevski and Turgenev had tried their luck in its ornate rooms. And so, bolstered by a sufficiency of the local Riesling, I headed to what is called the most beautiful gambling establishment in the world.

title: Carl Lewis Still Doesn't Know
description: It's as if Carl Lewis were an actor instead of an athlete. As if he had just enjoyed taking a curtain call for a supporting role in a Broadway hit instead of having lost the biggest race of his career in the Olympics.

title: Soldiers Draw The Line In Haiti
description: THE unceremonious ouster last week of Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, who had twice ruled Haiti since the collapse of the Duvalier dictatorship, was an event that soldiers on the street appreciated most.

title: Correction
description: A brief obituary by The Associated Press last Sunday about Harold Eugene Davis, a Latin American scholar and professor at American University, misstated the cause of death. His widow, Audrey, says it was pneumonia, not cancer.

title: WHAT NERVOUS BREAKDOWNS ARE MADE OF
description: ''THEY ALWAYS CALL US LADIES'': Stories From Prison. By Jean Harris. 276 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $18.95.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
For Every Child There Is a Hometown
description: LEAD: AS a teacher in a summer writing institute for local teachers, I have recently observed how many people focus in their own writing on their connections to important places in their earlier lives.

title: Rugged Types
description: THE OX-BOW INCIDENT Starring Henry Fonda (in photo), Dana Andrews, Mary Beth Hughes (in photo), Anthony Quinn, William Eythe, Henry Morgan. Directed by William A. Wellman. 1943. Key Video. 75 minutes. $19.98. Closed Captioned.

title: A Jewish Family's Tortuous Course
description: IN a Tel Aviv museum is a caricature of an American Jewish family, portraying it from shtetl generation to golfing suburb to counterculture commune.

title: Security Concerns on the Waterfront
description: DESPITE the security problems of living on a waterfront, people still want houses there and will pay millions of dollars for them, a longtime real-estate agent says.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Can't Stand the Heat? Get a New Kitchen
description: LEAD: TO think, it all began with the wallpaper. The hottest look in kitchen wallpaper today is brightly colored flowers on a black background. That is precisely what I have in my kitchen. Except that my black background is the result of 16 years of dirt.

title: FEELING DUMB? TRY MENTAL SELF-MANAGEMENT
description: THE TRIARCHIC MIND A New Theory of Human Intelligence. By Robert J. Sternberg. Illustrated. 354 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: West Virginia Improves to 4-0
description: West Virginia established itself as the No. 1 team in the East today when the undefeated Mountaineers, the highest-scoring team in the nation, handed Pitt its first loss of the season, 31-10.

title: In a Chic Setting, Remembrances of Washdays Past
description: American Washboards - lathe-turned rods, rippled zinc sheets, ridged ceramic plaques, stapled wood panels and polka-dotted cast iron - became one of Ivan Karp's collecting obsessions about six years ago. Mr. Karp, a SoHo art dealer, put his private holdings of 19th- and 20th-century boards on exhibition and sale last weekend at his O. K. Harris gallery, 385 West Broadway.

title: The New Zoo: At Home in Central Park
description: Kevin Roche is an architect of sprawling corporate headquarters, museums and skyscrapers. His work is inevitably ambitious in conception, often powerful in its imagery, and rarely modest in scope. Nothing in his experience suggests that he would be the logical man to design a zoo, much less a zoo like the one in Central Park - a zoo that had to be small in size and deferential to a natural landscape around it.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Fame in the Footlights
description: LEAD: ''You had your shot against Mario. You didn't do good then, and you're not doing any better now.''

title: Johnson Auditions Two Pitchers
description: ''There are a lot of little things still to be settled,'' Dave Johnson said today. And so he set out to settle a couple of them to fortify the Mets for the playoff and maybe even the World Series.

title: New Jersey Q & A: Richard T. Dewling; Keeping Tally on Environment
description: RICHARD T. DEWLING, for two and a half years the Commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Protection, has left office to start his own engineering company. He holds a doctorate in environmental science from Rutgers and is considered outspoken on environmental issues.

title: Eat Your Peas
description: I HATE MY MOTHER-IN-law,'' muttered the cannibal.

title: When the I.M.F. Meets
description: Tuesday marks the beginning of the combined annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, which are to be held in West Berlin. The I.M.F., which lends money primarily for balance-of-payments shortfalls, and the World Bank, which lends to third world countries for economic development, still must grapple with the continuing debt problems in Latin America and Africa. What will be achieved in Berlin? Shafiqul Islam Senior fellow, Council on Foreign Relations.

title: Morgan Library Plans Show of German Works
description: More than 100 drawings and paintings by noted German artists from the 18th century to the mid-19th century are to be on display beginning Nov. 17 at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street. This is the first time the artworks, drawn from museums in East Berlin and Dresden, have been displayed in the United States.

title: Plan to Dump Harbor Muck Raises Fears for Water Supply
description: LEAD: TO keep shipping lanes open, the Army Corps of Engineers continually dredges muck from the bottom of New York Harbor.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: SOMERS RURAL ROUTE 1;
Vantage on a Community in Change
description: LEAD: SOME of the quaintest buildings on Somers Rural Route 1 are about 18 inches long, 8 inches wide and 6 inches high. There are a red barn with white trim, a shingled farmhouse and a charming old Colonial - all affixed to posts, just the right size to hold the mail that Alberta Morley delivers every day.

title: And Where Is Jim McKay?
description: JIM MCKAY went shopping in a supermarket the other day and someone asked him, ''Why aren't you in Seoul?''

title: Succession Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: PRESIDENTIAL DEBATES: The Challenge of Creating an Informed Electorate. By Kathleen Hall Jamieson and David S. Birdsell. (Oxford University, $19.95.) The ''great'' debates of Presidential politics have been, by and large, neither great nor, in many ways, debates. Kathleen Hall Jamieson, a professor of communications at the University of Texas, and David S. Birdsell, who teaches in the speech department at Baruch College, review the history of debating in American politics and conclude that debates could be a lot more useful in helping voters to select Presidents. They would discard the format George Bush and Michael Dukakis are due to use tonight in their first of two televised debates, with reporters throwing questions. ''Lincoln, not a panel of journalists, posed the questions for Douglas and vice versa,'' they note in reference to the 1858 Senate debates in Illinois. The larger point is that debates are better designed to elucidate issues than to illustrate character. But in the rigid form evolved for Presidential campaigns, issues are rarely explored. The authors recommend debates that are more conversational, where more time is allotted for each answer and where a considerable block of time is devoted to a single topic. If they ruled the political world there would be at least three televised debates, each with a different format, supplemented by televised news conferences and televised speeches. Their proposals are at once reasonable and utterly romantic. Several were considered this year and rejected, largely by Mr. Bush, who saw no advantage to experiment. But debates are relatively new to Presidential politics, and their form and role may yet be susceptible to good ideas whose time has not yet come.

title: Business World/Magazine Part 2
description: * How Robert Bass and Donald Trump matched wits over the Plaza Hotel in New York. * Chase's man in Hong Kong. * Investors' fear of buying puts brokers to the test. * The M.D. who would be a tycoon.

title: 158 Held in Abortion Protest
description: The police arrested 158 anti-abortion demonstrators for blocking entrances to a medical clinic in this Seattle suburb. Those arrested, who refused to identify themselves, were among about 180 protesting at the Cedar River Clinic, where officials said about 2,400 abortions are performed annually.

title: 'ANYTHING I WRITE IS GOOD': LETTERS OF T.S. ELIOT
description: These letters are excerpted from ''The Letters of T. S. Eliot: Volume I, 1898-1922,'' which will be published tomorrow, on the 100th birthday of the poet. In virtually every case, it is possible to give here only short sections of individual letters; for, while the poet said he was often a tardy correspondent, he was seldom a brief one.

title: Picking Up The Pieces In Home Shopping
description: MONEY manager Ken Heebner, vice president of Boston-based Loomis, Sayles & Company, once held more than a million shares of Home Shopping Network in his portfolio. This had an unusual impact on his life: in 1986 and early 1987, when the stock's price was in orbit, he developed an odd ritual.

title: Horse Racing; Sham Say Persists To Capture Ruffian
description: Sham Say, who finished third to the star fillies Personal Ensign and Winning Colors in the Maskette Stakes 16 days ago, proved how good they were and how good she is by coming back to win the $244,000 Ruffian Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Diane Amy Shenker Wed to Todd E. Pearl
description: The marriage of Diane Amy Shenker, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. I. Ronald Shenker of East Hills, L.I., to Todd Evan Pearl, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Pearl of New York and Torrington, Conn., took place yesterday at the Westbury Hotel in New York. Rabbi Joseph Sternstein officiated.

title: Higher Cost of Newsprint Is Part of an Odd Equation
description: NEWSPRINT, the kind of paper on which this article appears, is going up in price again this winter if the people who produce it can make a 6.9 percent increase stick with the newspaper companies that are their customers.
