That will be the third increase since late 1986, after five years of almost no change at all.

title: Books of The Times; When the Child Chess Genius Becomes the Pawn
description: Searching for Bobby Fischer The World of Chess, Observed by the Father of a Child Prodigy By Fred Waitzkin 226 pages. Random House. $17.95.

title: Cone Defeats Cards For 19th
description: David Cone won his seventh straight game today and his 19th of the season against 3 losses when he pitched the Mets to a 9-7 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. With one more start to go in the regular season, he put himself into position to become the Mets' first 20-game winner in three years.

title: Review/Theater; A Christmas Fable Of People Who Learn To Know Themselves
description: ''I'll be home for Christmas,'' sings Bing Crosby, ''if only in my dreams.''

title: Beauties And Beasts Abounding
description: Brigands chased one another on horseback around a darkened park, illuminated hedges revealed children standing frozen as mechanical dolls. And for one totally magic moment, clusters of white balloons trailed silently from a castle roof up into the night sky.

title: Bell or Buzzer? More Boxing Chaos
description: Even in the mad, mad world of amateur boxing, this was unprecedented. Last night, fans were treated to a new concept called a rematch, and less than two hours after the original bout ended in almost total chaos. And as luck would have it, this latest bizarre episode of life inside the Olympic rings involved the United States and South Korea, countries that haven't learned to duck when it comes to controversy.

title: Quayle: The Defense Industry's Champion
description: Senator Dan Quayle has sought to portray himself as a true military reformer, out to clean up the waste and abuse so prevalent at the Pentagon. The facts about the Republican Vice Presidential nominee's role in military procurement reform suggest otherwise.

title: Joseph V. McKee Jr.; Executive, 67
description: Joseph V. McKee Jr., a retired chairman of the National Union Electric Corporation, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 67 years old.

title: Muslims Keep Lid on Drugs in Capital
description: Alone but unafraid, in his blue sweatsuit and matching sneakers, 5-year-old Joshua sauntered up to the white truck with a red star and crescent and the words ''Dopebuster Mobile'' emblazoned on its sides.

title: The U.S. Steps Up Defensive Pressure
description: With two games remaining, it has become apparent that the United States men's basketball team may be better than anyone gave it credit for. Even Puerto Rico, an old nemisis in international play, was unable to slow down John Thompson's Olympians today. If the Summer Games last another month or so, they might improve enough to even please their coach.

title: Japan Proposes Debt Program
description: Japan announced a new plan today to use its large trade surplus to help developing nations deal with their foreign debts. Under the plan, the Export-

title: Susan Lisette Mann Weds Richard Allen Herschlag
description: Susan Lisette Mann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Mann of Allentown, Pa., was married yesterday to Richard Allen Herschlag, a son of Jack Herschlag of Upper Montclair, N.J., and the late Harriet Herschlag. The Rev. Harry Goos, a Lutheran minister, and Rabbi Joseph H. Gelberman officiated at the Historic Hotel Edison in Edison, N.J.

title: L.I. Man Is Accused of Slaying His Parents
description: A Long Island man, apparently upset over his parents' disapproval of his girlfriend, shot them dead at their home, the police charged today after arresting him.

title: Ereng of Kenya Upsets Field To Win 800 Meters
description: A major upset highlighted the fourth day of the Olympic track and field competition. Paul Ereng of Kenya, the National Collegiate Athletic Association champion from the University of Virginia, stunned an outstanding field in the men's 800-meter final today to win the gold medal, the first for his country in the Games.

title: A Low for Crop Acreage
description: American farmers this year are likely to harvest the lowest number of acres in this century, the United States Agriculture Department said Friday. In a monthly report, the department said that record acreage left unplanted under Government programs and high crop failure this year because of the summer drought resulted in the record low acreage. Harvested cropland in the United States was estimated at about 284 million acres, down 9 million from last year and 67 million acres below the 1981 peak.

title: Otto Takes 6th Gold; One More For Biondi
description: The eight days of Olympic swimming ended tonight after enough twists and turns for a television series.

title: Behind a Mask of Modernity, Koreans Reaffirm a More Traditional Identity
description: This was a day of two rituals here: the Olympics, to show the world the new Korea, and the holiday of Chusok, to show Koreans that their identity remains constant in a society that is changing fast.

title: Doubts Remain About Shuttle as Launching Nears
description: As the Thursday launching of the winged spaceship Discovery approaches, tension is rising among engineers and officials who feel they have done all they can to make the flight safe but who also know they can never be absolutely confident that a disaster will not occur.

title: Peres Discounts the 'Biography' of Potential Palestinian Negotiators
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel says he would not worry about ''the biography'' of Palestinians who might negotiate peace with his country as long as they renounced violence and accepted Israel's right to exist.

title: Cleaning Up Boxing
description: Abe J. Greene, the New Jersey newspaperman and ring official who died last week at the age of 89, was known as a friend of boxers, one who pressed for any number of safety innovations from the mandatory standing 8-count to periodic physical examinations for fighters.

title: Changing of Guard in Track
description: If the passing of a generation truly occurs in a neat, orderly fashion, then three of the United States' finest track athletes might have let the world know today that their time is approaching.

title: Mosque Rising Is a First in New York
description: From the corner of Third Avenue and 96th Street the dome of the first mosque ever to be built in New York City is now clearly visible, rising like a half moon above the fence surrounding the construction site.

title: The President's Legacy to the U.N.
description: Speeches before the United Nations General Assembly do not typically make history, or policy. Today, President Reagan has a chance to do both. He makes his last address to a U.N. that's far more alive and hopeful than anyone would have dreamed possible when he took office.

title: Buyout Cost Adding Burden To Troubled Chicago Paper
description: The Chicago Sun-Times, the nation's 12th-largest daily newspaper, has suffered a number of recent setbacks that are raising new questions about what its future will be like. Some think that the paper, which has changed owners twice in the last four years, may be sold again; others say it will be sharply squeezed in an attempt to regain a solid financial footing.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 25, 1988: MONDAY Amer Express Disney (Walt) Ameron Inc United Industrial BellSouth Corp Unocal Corp TUESDAY Centerior Energy Montana Pwr Delmarva Pwr & Lt Pub Service Co Colo Hydraulic Co Signet Banking WEDNESDAY Amer President Cos Hunt Mfg Brooklyn Union Gas Iowa Resources Central Maine Pwr Raytheon Co E G & G Inc USAir Group Holly Farms Washington Gas Lt THURSDAY American Water Works Harsco Corp Ampco-Pittsburgh Corp Knight-Ridder Combustion Engineering FRIDAY Aetna Life & Casualty Potlatch Corp Cascade Nat Gas Rohm & Haas Co Dennison Mfg Southwestern Bell

title: Dr. Carron Meg Grin Weds Eric Jorgensen
description: Dr. Carron Meg Grin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. S. Spencer Grin of New York and Rowayton, Conn., and Eric Martin Jorgensen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Jorgensen of Owls Head, Me., were married yesterday at Temple Shalom in Norwalk, Conn. Rabbi Mark Lipson performed the ceremony.

title: Jousting With Melons: A Frolic for Medievalists
description: The crowd cried ''Huzzah!'' as a pair of horsemen galloped up to a post, trying to spear cantaloupes and cranshaw melons balanced on it. Public officials wore long robes and funny hats. Their constituents strolled about, gnawing on turkey legs and drinking from cattle horns dangling on strings around their necks.

title: Bills Repel Steelers To Stay Unbeaten
description: Robb Riddick scored two touchdowns in the third quarter, including one on Buffalo's second blocked punt of the game, and Scott Norwood connected on all five field-goal attempts today as the Bills beat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 36-28.

title: Out of the League, Ivy Teams Suffer
description: In Ivy League circles it is known as Black Saturday. It is the second Saturday on the schedule, the day when the eight Ivy teams play nonleague opponents who have the advantage of spring football practice and in some cases athletic scholarships.

title: Closeup: Water Polo
description: Staying Afloat

title: Theory Is Unveiled on Breaking Barrier of Electricity Resistance
description: A team of scientists from the California Institute of Technology announced today that they had developed a long-sought comprehensive theory explaining key aspects of superconductivity, the phenomenon in which certain materials are able to conduct electricity without resistance.

title: Big Protest At I.M.F. Site
description: About 20,000 demonstrators from a broad array of leftist causes marched peacefully through West Berlin today in the largest of many protests planned against the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

title: Hurricane Wanders North
description: Hurricane Helene strayed farther from land today, pushing northward over the central Atlantic and heading toward chillier water that will eventually sap its strength, the National Hurricane Center said. The storm, with top sustained winds of 115 miles per hour, turned from north-northwest to north and was moving at 8 m.p.h. At noon today, its center was about 875 miles northeast of Antigua.

title: Countdown for Shuttle Delayed 8 Hours
description: Technicians preparing the space shuttle Discovery for its planned launching on Thursday fell behind in their inspections and troubleshooting today, leading officials to delay the start of the countdown Monday by eight hours. They are still aiming for liftoff Thursday morning.

title: Joe Don Looney, 45, Former Football Star
description: Joe Don Looney, a former football star at the University of Oklahoma who was known for his eccentricities on and off the field, died Saturday in a motorcycle accident. He was 45 years old.

title: Diocese Installs A Black Bishop
description: The Episcopal Diocese of Southern Ohio installed its first black bishop Saturday.

title: Billy Carter Dies of Cancer at 51; Troubled Brother of a President
description: Billy Carter, the irrepressible gas station proprietor and farmer who vaulted to national celebrity in his brother Jimmy's successful campaign for President in 1976, died of cancer of the pancreas yesterday at his home in Plains, Ga. He was 51 years old.

title: Opposites Wind Up With Gold Results
description: They are the queens of Olympic swimming, as different in size, temperament and public image as their native lands.

title: School Bias: Town Looks For Answers
description: About 20 years ago, faced with the first signs of white flight as black families began moving in from neighboring Hartford, this picturesque New England town took a step to welcome integration.

title: Farms, Deadliest Workplace, Taking the Lives of Children
description: The gentle patchwork of cornfields and barnyards in the nation's midsection masks a troubling reality: farming, which has surpassed mining and construction in recent years as the nation's deadliest occupation, is claiming the lives of hundreds of children and leaving thousands disabled.

title: Louganis Is in Second Place After First Platform Session
description: Greg Louganis, who is trying to become the first man to win both diving events in consecutive Olympics, was second after the opening session of platform preliminaries today.

title: Giving a New Twist to the Rat Race
description: WHEN they dreamed up a foot race called the Rat Race, it was no surprise that it would be run in New York where frenetic office workers throng the streets evoking images of rats on a laboratory treadmill.

title: Market Place; Analysts See Growth at Mesa
description: THREE years after T. Boone Pickens's last acquisition in the energy business, the expectation of a fresh maneuver has many analysts talking positively about the units of his Mesa Limited Partnership.

title: How to Obtain Tickets for 'Degas'
description: Admission to ''Degas,'' which opens to the public Oct. 11 after two weeks of previews for members of the Metropolitan Museum, is by ticket only. Tickets may be bought through Ticketron (399-4444) for $6.25 or Teletron (947-5850) for $7. There is a limit of eight tickets per person. Starting Oct. 11, tickets may also be bought at the museum for $5. ''Degas'' remains on view through Jan. 8.

title: Jennifer Crandall Weds
description: Jennifer Willoughby Crandall, a daughter of Dr. John Crandall of Pallisades Park, N.J., and Audrey Crandall of Glen Cove, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard David Story, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Truman Story of Oklahoma City. The Rev. Dr. George Calvert, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the nondenominational service at the New Marlborough (Mass.) Meeting House. The bride is a picture editor at US magazine. Mr. Story is a senior editor at New York magazine.

title: Yeshiva to Display 1478 Trial Record
description: A 510-year-old transcript of a famous trial that destroyed a Jewish community in northern Italy has found its way to Yeshiva University in Washington Heights.

title: Bridge
description: Half a century ago, thanks largely to the promotional abilities of Ely Culbertson, bridge was a normal social occupation. Admitting an inability to play could draw, at the least, a raised eyebrow. As a result, bridge problems were often used as advertising tools.

title: Diane Chernoff, a Lawyer, Married to Matthew Rosen
description: Diane Chernoff, an associate, and Matthew A. Rosen, a partner in the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, were married yesterday. Criminal Court Judge Patricia Anne Williams officiated at the couple's home in New York.

title: Financing Deal For Oil Project
description: A consortium of oil companies said Friday that it had agreed on a financing package with the Canadian Government and the government of Alberta to proceed with an oil sands project in northern Alberta.

title: Congress Should Pass Child Care This Session
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston Mayor Urges School Changes
description: Mayor Raymond L. Flynn wants to lead the most thorough restructuring of the city's schools since a Federal court ordered them desegregated in 1974.

title: Local Effort By Federal Express
description: FALLON McElligott of Minneapolis may be painting the big national advertising picture for the Federal Express Corporation, but starting this month, Muller, Jordan, Weiss has begun sketching in a few local scenes.

title: Dodgers' Clinching Delayed By Defeat
description: Dennis Cook threw a two-hitter as the San Francisco Giants beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2-0, preventing the Dodgers from clinching the National League West title.

title: Victory in Arizona A First for Cards
description: Tony Jordan, a rookie, scored twice on 1-yard runs and Cedric Mack, a cornerback, returned a fumble 45 yards for a touchdown with 41 seconds remaining today as the Phoenix Cardinals defeated the Washington Redskins, 30-21. The Cardinals, who moved here from St. Louis, posted their first National Football League victory in Arizona.

title: Nine Seasons To Hunt Deer
description: The hunting season for deer in New York, which starts tomorrow, is composed of nine different seasons.

title: Congress Should Pass Child Care This Session; Civil Rights Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Partial Pact In Boesky Case Seen
description: A major settlement will be announced this week in a group of lawsuits against the investors in Ivan F. Boesky & Company, the investment vehicle for the fallen Wall Street speculator, people involved in the suits said yesterday.

title: Grey Acquisition
description: Grey Advertising, whose British company bills $412 million, has acquired the eight-year-old Taylor Partnership, with $34 million in billings and offices in London, Leicester and Manchester. Taylor will retain its name.

title: Tighter Reins on Municipal Bonds
description: The shock waves from the 1983 default of the Washington Public Power Supply System are still rippling through the municipal bond market.

title: Rams Coast to 4-0 By Routing Giants
description: The reputation of the Giants' defense took a severe thrashing this afternoon.

title: U.S. Rolls-Royce Losing Chief, Maybe to Porsche
description: Robert Schwartz, who has had success selling Rolls-Royce automobiles to Americans, is leaving the company amid industry rumors that his next job may be as chief executive at Porsche's American operation, to revive sagging sales there.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: >Debt

title: Dusty Titles Add Luster To Publisher' Profits
description: In the late 1930's Vanguard Press published two books by Dr. Seuss, ''And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street'' and ''The 500 Hats of Bartholomew Cubbins.'' While the author later moved to Random House, the books are still earning money for Vanguard and the 84-year-old author a half-century later.

title: Speech by Reagan to U.N. Today Seen as Sign of Change in Attitude
description: President Reagan, who has regarded the United Nations with skepticism for most of his years in public life, is expected to salute the international organization Monday in his address to the General Assembly.

title: Hirohito Watches TV To Catch Sumo Match
description: Emperor Hirohito lay in serious condition today but was alert enough to watch the finals of the autumn sumo tournament on television, the Imperial Household Agency said.

title: Why Kroger Was Ripe for Attack
description: When a takeover fight for the Kroger Company erupted last week, it seemed to confirm what many in the supermarket industry had begun to suspect: that giant publicly traded supermarket chains are an endangered species.

title: Arthur Ross Heads A Lambert/Dale Unit
description: Arthur R. Ross, 55, who is a widely experienced creative man, is heading up the new Ross/Hayden/Principe, a retail-advertising division of Lambert/Dale Advertising.

title: Manhattan Stargazing Calls for Low Shoes and High Hopes
description: The guided tour got off the ground at the back door of a certain apartment in the Turtle Bay section of Manhattan where a photo opportunity occurred - a newspaper whose mailing address glowed with the name Katharine Hepburn, along with a flier for Chinese take-out food.

title: The Early American Roach
description: Housework in 19th-century America was no barrel of laughs. The plumbing was terrible, doing the laundry took two days out of every week and beating egg whites with a spiked stick must have been murder on the arms.

title: New York Catholic Synod Urges Bigger Role for Laity
description: Delegates to an unprecedented meeting called by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York have strongly urged a greater role for the laity in the church's organization and prayer life.

title: 2 Sides in Lebanon Seem Wary of War
description: Despite the existence of two rival governments, the Christian and Moslem political leaders of Lebanon appeared today to be trying to avoid an escalation of their conflict into renewed warfare.

title: Judging System Is Not Quite Perfect
description: Two questions remained after the Olympic gymnastics competition ended today.

title: How the Times Are Changing: Climbing A Wall Is Fun Now
description: NOT since King Kong scaled the Empire State Building has sport climbing captured the attention it has today.

title: Moscow Saturday Night
description: A woman who recently visited the Soviet Union reports on Moscow television in the Gorbachev era:

title: Will Appalachian Spring Go Down a Sewer?
description: LEAD: In a 1986 speech, John Calhoun Wells, then Kentucky's Secretary of Labor, made an ominous prediction at a conference in Lexington. Mr. Wells said that Appalachia would soon become ''the trash heap of postindustrial America.''

title: Tax Watch; Review Advised For Pension Plans
description: MANY employers face sharply higher pension costs as of Jan. 1 because of changes mandated by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, warns Frederic S. Kramer, a lawyer and editor for the Research Institute of America who specializes in pension plans and employee benefits.

title: Taba Journal; In Battle Over Beach, It's Time to Draw the Line
description: First-time visitors to Taba often shake their heads and in a puzzled voice ask, ''What's all the fuss about?''

title: A Fair Chance for the Mother; An Issue for the No-Issue Campaign
description: Sandra, who was 16 when she gave birth to her first baby in a Manhattan hospital last spring, hasn't thought much about the Presidential campaign or the Federal budget. But she, and 470,000 other teen-agers who will bear children this year, figure prominently in both.

title: Susan Bowman Weds Lieut. Frank Taboada
description: The marriage of Susan Clare Bowman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earle Lindell Bowman Jr. of New Rochelle, N.Y., to Lieut. (j.g.) Frank Joseph Taboada U.S.N., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Taboada of Los Angeles, took place yesterday in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. The Rev. Robert Verrigni performed the ceremony.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Friday about campaign appearances by Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis with law-enforcement officials misstated, in one reference, the endorsement of the Boston Police Patrolman's Association. It endorsed Mr. Bush, not Mr. Dukakis.

title: Depleted by Draft
description: Dave Magarity, the basketball coach at Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., winces when cynics remind him that Rik Smits, the second player chosen in the last National Basketball Association draft, was not the first player drafted from the tiny liberal arts school.

title: Red Sox Delighting In Numbers Game
description: At no time this season have the Yankees won eight games in a row. At no time since Joe Morgan became Boston's manager have the Red Sox failed to win at least two games in any seven-game stretch.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in some copies Saturday, provided by Agence France-Presse, misidentified the woman competing against Connie Paraskevin-Young of the United States in an Olympic cycling event. She was Erika Salumiaee of the Soviet Union.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Brazil's President vowed to wage ''a war without quarter'' on the country's triple-digit inflation rate, now that a new agreement has been reached with the nation's commercial bank creditors. The president, Jose Sarney, did not announce any new measures, however, and Finance Minister Mailson Nobrega has repeatedly said he would resist political pressure to begin ''shock measures'' like a wage and price freeze. Brazil's inflation rate may exceed 700 percent this year.

title: Transcript of the First TV Debate Between Bush and Dukakis
description: Following is a transcript of the first Presidential debate between Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis last night in Winston-Salem, N.C., as recorded by The New York Times. Drug Use Q. Our questions this evening will be about equally divided between foreign and domestic policy matters. The first question, by agreement between the two candidates, goes to Vice President Bush. It is a domestic question. You have two minutes for an answer, sir.

title: Israeli Troops Wound 30 in Routing Protests
description: Troops wounded at least 30 Arabs while dispersing weekend protests against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, Israeli officials and Palestinians said today.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Campaign Trail; Presidential Hopeful With Empty Pockets
description: Eugene J. McCarthy is running for President, but somehow his party cannot seem to nominate him formally.

title: 62 Errors for Evert In Upset by Italian
description: Chris Evert sprayed 62 errors across the court as she lost, 2-6, 6-4, 6-1, to Raffaella Reggi of Italy in the third round of the first full-scale Olympic tennis tournament since 1924.

title: An Assailed Missionary To America Is Beatified
description: Pope John Paul II today beatified an 18th-century missionary, the Rev. Junipero Serra, bringing the controversial pioneer of the American West within one step of sainthood.

title: Philip Morris Topples P.&G.
description: After 23 years as the country's biggest national advertising spender, the Procter & Gamble Company, the Cincinnati-based soaper, has been toppled by the Philip Morris Companies, which has acquired the free-spending General Foods Corporation and the Miller Brewing Company.

title: Outdoors: Counting Deer
description: THE white-tailed deer population of New York and the rest of the Northeast is growing by leaps and bounds. Ten years ago there were 450,000 deer in New York State. As the new hunting season begins tomorrow, the big game experts of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation said there are almost twice as many, 800,000, a record number.

title: Bush Backs Act On Homeless
description: Vice President Bush said in tonight's debate that he would favor full financing of legislation already approved by Congress to aid the homeless.

title: Hyde Athletic Shoes To McKinney & Silver
description: Hyde Athletic Industries, a shoemaker in Massachusetts that has been through a number of local agencies in recent years, has discovered McKinney & Silver in Raleigh, N.C. The agency said the billings would be about $5 million.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Leading Indicators Aug. New-Home Sales Aug.

title: America's Best in Table Tennis Goes Home Again
description: The best American table tennis player took a walk in the Myongdong section the other day, through the narrow streets of the artisans' quarter. She was tired from chopping at the tiny white ball and needed a change of pace.

title: Feeney Quits Padres Post
description: Chub Feeney resigned today as president of the San Diego Padres, but said his decision to leave had nothing to do with an obscene gesture he made to two fans Saturday night.

title: Ruling in Case Of Apple Suit
description: A Federal judge on Friday denied the request of Apple Computer Inc. that he disqualify himself from its copyright infringement case against the Hewlett-Packard Company and the Microsoft Corporation because his son works for Hewlett-Packard. Apple sued the companies in

title: W. B. Doner to Handle Ford Dealers' Group
description: W. B. Doner & Company in Detroit has picked up the large New England Ford Dealers Association that Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopulos resigned to take on the Nissan Motor Company's Infiniti.

title: OPEC Studying Demand Outlook
description: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries reviewed prices and production today, searching for ways to restore discipline to the organization and rein in the runaway production that is depressing prices.

title: With Gold Below $400, U.S. Mining Concerns Worry About Profit Margins
description: The decline in gold prices has increased the concerns of American gold producers that their profit margins will be drastically narrowed or eliminated.

title: Jewish Vote Represents Small Percentages
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Thursday about the campaign for United States Senate in New Jersey misstated the timing of a poll conducted for Senator Frank R. Lautenberg. It was Aug. 28 to 31.

title: Rumrill-Hoyt Resigns From a Pfizer Account
description: Nicholas I. Orloff, the president of Rumrill-Hoyt, and Gale A. Johnson, the senior vice president and director of public relations, were in town from Rochester last week to resign Pfizer Inc.'s United States Animal Health Operations account.

title: Quito Assures Investors
description: The new Government of Ecuador said last week that it welcomed foreign investment and was worried that its decision to assume operating control of much of the nation's oil industry would be misinterpreted as a nationalization. Energy Minister Diego

title: INSIDE
description: Billy Carter Dies of Cancer Billy Carter, the former President's irrepressible brother, is dead at 51 years of age. Page B8. Tracking the Mentally Ill The history of the mentally ill man who killed an usher in St. Patrick's Cathedral raised the question, for many professionals, why it doesn't happen more often. Page B1. Distress Signal on Debt The Group of Seven industrial nations' plan to help developing nations reflects the persistence of the debt problem. News analysis, page D1.

title: 1,000 Points Of Light?
description: Michael Dukakis more than held his own with his better-known opponent, and to that extent gained from the debate; George Bush did nothing to blow his lead, and to that extent his supporters can breathe a sigh of relief.

title: 19 Grants Are Awarded For Dance and Its Music
description: Leonard Bernstein will compose for Martha Graham and John Cage will compose for Merce Cunningham, thanks to grants of the Composer-Choreographer Project of Meet the Composer. These grants to the Martha Graham Dance Company and the Merce Cunningham Dance Company are among 19 grants, ranging from $10,000 to $60,000, and totaling $390,000, that Meet the Composer has announced it has made to enable companies to commission new works by American composers and choreographers.

title: Yankees Lose Their Last Hope
description: The day seemed to grow darker and colder and painfully longer as one inning moved into the next. But there was never a comeback, never much of a serious threat all day. The Yankees simply played and lost and then cleaned out their lockers.

title: New Hardships Assail Northern Ethiopia
description: To the Editor:

title: USA Today TV Producers Fight to Save Show
description: In the months before it went on the air, ''USA Today: the Television Show'' was treated to an unprecedented amount of attention and uncommonly high expectations. Now, after two weeks on the air, the flashy, expensive syndicated show is being treated to unprecedented scorn and dire predictions of imminent demise.

title: Exchange Pays C.F.T.C. Fine
description: The Minneapolis Grain Exchange will pay a $30,000 penalty to help settle an administrative complaint filed by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the Federal agency said last week.

title: Review/Theater; 'Blitzstein Project' Gives a Taste of 30's Composer
description: Marc Blitzstein was one of the more contradictory musical personalities of significance that this country has produced. An ardent left-wing populist during the Depression, his music sought to refine a vocabulary that engaged the masses with a rugged tunefulness and hearty language while also acknowledging the sophisticated modernism of Stravinsky and others. Aaron Copland hailed him as a father of the serious American musical. And in his strongest music, one discerns a direct link between Brecht-Weill and Blitzstein's enthusiastic champion, Leonard Bernstein.

title: Coast to Coast
description: There is partisan wrangling, such as the usual fare between Democrats and Republicans, and then there is Partisan Wrangling, such as between Met and Dodger fans.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Tour Drought Ends: Bill Glasson shot a two-under-par 69 yesterday during the final round of the B.C. Open in Endicott, N.Y., and that was good enough to give him his first PGA Tour victory in three years. Glasson finished at 16-under-par 268 for the 72-hole tournament, two strokes ahead of Bruce Lietzke and Wayne Levi, who both made late charges at the leader. Lietzke shot a 64 on the par-71 course after starting seven strokes behind Glasson, who took the lead Saturday with a 65. (AP) Big Birdie for Hill: Dave Hill sank an eight-foot birdie putt on the final hole to hold off Bruce Crampton by one stroke in the Paine Webber Invitational seniors golf tournament yesterday in Charlotte, N.C. After pushing his tee shot on the 413-yard, par-4 18th into a fairway bunker, Hill hit a 4-iron to within eight feet to set the stage for the winning putt.(AP) Jones Wins Santa Barbara: Rosie Jones posted an even-par 72 to capture the $300,000 L.P.G.A. Santa Barbara Open at the La Purisima. Missie McGeorge, of Fort Worth, led by a shot with five holes to play, but consecutive bogeys on the 15th, 16th and 17th holes allowed Jones to take the lead. (AP) AUTO RACING Sullivan Edges Michael Andretti: Danny Sullivan stretched his lead in the Indy-car points race yesterday with a comfortable victory in the Bosch Spark Plug Grand Prix at Pennsylvania International Raceway in Nazareth. Sullivan drove his Penske Chevrolet 12.206 seconds faster over the 200 miles than his nearest challenger, Michael Andretti. Sullivan averaged 148.526 miles per hour in winning $54,460 of the $450,000 purse. Mario Andretti, who, like his son, was racing on his hometown track, finished third. (AP) Prost Wins in Portugal: Alain Prost of France, driving a turbocharged McLaren-Honda, moved back into first place in the drivers championship standing yesterday by winning the Portuguese Grand Prix in Estoril. Prost, winning for the fifth time in 13 Formula One races this season, overtook the previous leader, his teammate Ayrton Senna of Brazil, who finished sixth in the 70-lap race on the 2.7-mile circuit.(AP) Waltrip Is First: Darrell Waltrip, taking the lead when the engine in Ricky Rudd's car blew, pulled away over the final 80 laps yesterday to win the Nascar Goody's 500 race at Martinsville, Va.(AP) ROAD RACING Marathon Tuneup: Carlos Roa of Colombia led from start to finish in winning the New York City Marathon 25-kilometer tuneup yesterday in 1 hour 20 minutes 13 seconds at Central Park. Bonnie McLeod of the Warren Street A.C. won the women's division in 1:40.10. A record field of 3,156 competed in the 15.5-mile race, a prelude to the New York City Marathon on Nov. 6.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, the Saturday News Quiz omitted one question and misnumbered others.

title: Hundreds Protest Jehovah's Witness Tower Plan
description: In a genteel demonstration punctuated by cries of ''Don't rezone!'' several hundred people marched in Brooklyn Heights yesterday against a proposal by the Jehovah's Witnesses to build a 19-story tower in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: College Football; Quarterback on Record Pace
description: Todd Ellis, the junior quarterback at South Carolina, continues to threaten the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I-A career passing record for yardage. He threw for 321 yards and one touchdown Saturday as the Gamecocks improved their record to 4-0 with a 23-10 victory over previously undefeated Georgia (3-1).

title: West Germany Builds Trade Ties With India
description: Steadily and with quiet efficiency, West Germany has edged past the United States, Japan and Britain as the largest net exporter of goods to India, and both countries envision a growing link in high-technology enterprises.

title: Judge to Rule on Challenge of Macmillan
description: A judge in Delaware Chancery Court said Friday that he would rule this week on a challenge to Macmillan Inc.'s ''poison pill'' plan that was filed by the Maxwell Communications Corporation.

title: Wanted in Poland: Less Money, More Goods
description: The resignation of Poland's Government last week was the most candid admission to date that the ambitious economic program announced last fall has not worked. Zbigniew Messner, the outgoing

title: Rare Role For Pernod As Pursuer
description: Even the chairman of the Pernod Ricard Group, the world's leading maker of pastis, admits the European aperitif has a nasty taste when mixed with American tap water. So despite the fact that Pernod Ricard sells so much of the anise-flavored cordial, Patrick Ricard is basing his company's international growth on more universally palatable flavors.

title: Jets Win Again
description: This was the kind of game the coaches who handle the young Jets worried about: how would they react in a tight affair?

title: THE GAMES AT A GLANCE
description: Track and Field Paul Ereng's move down the stretch was so subtly sudden in the men's 800 meters that it caught everyone off guard - among them Said Aouita, Joaquim Cruz and a very embarrassed announcing team from NBC. Ereng, a Kenyan who had hung back through nearly 700 meters, quietly burst from the back of the pack and into the lead to capture the gold medal in 1 minute 43.45 seconds. But throughout his surge, Ereng was misidentified as Nixon Kiprotich, his teammate from Kenya, by Charlie Jones, NBC's veteran track announcer. Ereng beat Aouita, the best middle-distance runner in the world, and Cruz, the gold medalist at the distance in 1984. But it was not until at least a minute after the result was official that Jones correctly announced Ereng as the winner. ''We just entered the world record book of blunders,'' said Jones. Cruz took the silver and Aouita the bronze. In the women's 800, Sigrun Wodars of East Germany claimed the gold with a time of 1:56.10. Her teammate, Christine Wachtel, took the silver and Kim Gallagher of the United States was third for the bronze. Basketball The United States women's team expected it would have to defeat the Soviet Union in order to win the gold. It didn't, though, anticipate having to beat the Russians just to guarantee winning something other than the bronze. Australia, the team from down under, stood the tournament on its head when it upset the Soviet Union, 60-48, to move into the semifinals against Yugoslavia. The loss for the Soviet women - their first ever in Olympic competition - set up a early showdown with the Americans in the other semifinal tomorrow. In the men's quarterfinals, the United States' pressure defense cracked apart another opponent's gameplan and the Americans spent the rest of the game waltzing through the openings. The Americans, sparked by Danny Manning's 18 points in the first half, raced to a 94-57 elimination of Puerto Rico in the quarterfinals. Volleyball The American women's team was ahead by 2 games to 0 against Peru when it was officially eliminated from the Olympics. Odd? Yes, but then the Americans had been faced with an unusual and extraordinary assignment. The United States not only had to beat Peru to gain the last spot in the semifinals. The United States had to beat them badly. And for a brief couple of minutes, the chances looked good. The Americans, who had to both sweep three games from Peru and hold them under 33 combined points, took the first two games while yielding only 21 points. But Peru's 12th point of the third game ended the American bid for a medal. Peru, which went on to beat its disheartened opponents, 3-2, joined China, Japan and the Soviet Union in the medal round.

title: Confederate Kissinger
description: It never hurts an author to have a friend in the Senate.

title: Koreans Protest Film
description: Hundreds of movie stars, directors and others demonstrated Saturday outside two theaters planning to show ''Fatal Attraction,'' the first American film to be distributed directly in South Korea. The direct American distribution of films, which bypasses local distribution companies, is part of trade liberalization measures between the United States and South Korea.

title: The Runner Who Ran Too Fast
description: THOSE feet. Those little bare feet with the tiny heels poking back at her. For four years, Mary Decker Slaney saw those feet.

title: Campaign Trail; Jackson Discovers All the Luxuries
description: ''Stop eating the grapes!''

title: Battle of Ohio Goes to Surging Bengals
description: When Ohio's professional football teams clash, it is always a game of frolicking knocks and tremendously bruised egos between the two American Conference Central Division rivals. Only 300 miles separate the Cincinnati Bengals and the Cleveland Browns, but Ohio fans' loyalties for their favorite are much wider than that.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''A person goes into that voting booth, they're going to say, who has the values I believe in; who has the experience that we trust; who has the integrity and the stability to get the job done. My fellow Americans, I am that man and I ask for your support.'' - Vice President Bush. [ A19:5. ]

title: New York Times Reporter to Receive Award
description: John Kifner, a New York Times reporter and foreign correspondent, has been chosen to receive the Elijah Parish Lovejoy Award for 1988 from Colby College in Waterville, Me.

title: New Device Hopes to Take Guesswork Out of Calling Lines
description: THE age of electronics has worked its way onto the tennis court with a device designed to take the guesswork out of line calling. The system will call a shot within one-thousandth of an inch of where the ball lands, according to the inventor of Accu-Call.

title: Canada Pipeline Plan
description: The Canadian and British Columbian governments said last week that they would provide $230 million ($188.5 million United States) in grants and interest-free loans for a $485 million ($400 million) natural gas pipeline linking the mainland of British Columbia and Vancouver Island. The pipeline, proposed for nearly 40 years, will make natural gas available the island and to British Columbia's western coast. The 330-mile line will be built by the Pacific Coast Energy Corporation, the governments said Thursday.

title: Nancy Hale, Fiction Writer, Is Dead at 80
description: Nancy Hale, a novelist and short-story writer, died Saturday at the Martha Jefferson Hospital in Charlottesville, Va., after suffering a stroke. She was 80 years old and lived in Charlottesville.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Basketball teams at Indiana coached by Bobby Knight won National Collegiate Athletic Association championships in 1976, 1981 and 1987. The United States team coached by Knight won the gold medal at the 1984 Olympic Games. If John Thompson, who coached Georgetown to the N.C.A.A. title in 1984, leads the American team to a gold medal at these Summer Olympics, he would match Knight's feat. Has any other coach achieved it?

title: Among Political Prisoners, Joe Doherty Makes a Better Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Tool Orders Rose 33.2% In August
description: Orders for American-made machine tools rose 33.2 percent in August, to $339.6 million, bolstered by substantial increases in exports, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the industry's trade association.

title: Study on Insider Cases Finds Many Rejections
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission conducted formal investigations on fewer than half of the referrals it received from stock and commodity exchanges about suspicious trading in 1985 and 1986, the General Accounting Office said in a report released Friday.

title: 2 Officers Shot As a Cabby Foils Holdup
description: Two police officers were wounded, one seriously, early yesterday when a man robbing a livery cabdriver opened fire on them after the cab swerved into the path of their radio car, the police said.

title: Bishop Henry Pinger; Ex-Missionary Was 91
description: Bishop Henry Ambrose Pinger, a Roman Catholic priest whose three decades of missionary service in the Orient included nine years of imprisonment, died Saturday. He was 91 years old.

title: Susan Kitzen Weds
description: The marriage of Susan A. Kitzen, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Maurice R. Kitzen of Philadelphia, to James A. Oberman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Oberman of Springfield, Ill., took place yesterday in the garden at the Provence Restaurant in New York. Cantor Deborah Bard performed the ceremony. The bride is a senior editor at Daniel Weiss Associates, a producer of children's books in New York. Mr. Oberman is an information specialist at the ABC News Research Center in New York.

title: Slaying in Cathedral Spurs Scrutiny of Mental Health Care
description: When a deranged homeless man went on a murderous rampage through St. Patrick's Cathedral last Wednesday after years of sporadic jailings and hospital treatment, the public turned to the mental health system and asked how such a thing could happen.

title: Soviet-West Ventures Still Small and Cautious
description: The Soviet Union has invited Western capitalists to help modernize its moribund economy, but the ventures seem to be producing more fast-food sizzle than high-stakes technology, Soviet and American officials said.

title: 'Honneur' of Foreign Legion Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: For First Time, a Chess Computer Outwits Grandmaster in Tournament
description: Hitech, the chess-playing computer from Carnegie-Mellon University, triumphed easily in its four-game match against Grandmaster Arnold Denker yesterday, winning the last game in 23 moves.

title: Who's the Best? Mum's the Word
description: It seemed a simple enough question to those unfamiliar with the subtleties of gymnastic diplomacy. Yelena Shoushounova of the Soviet Union had won the women's individual all-around gold medal Friday. But Daniela Silivas of Rumania, the all-around silver medalist, today won three of the four gold medals in the apparatus finals.

title: Sunnydale Journal; Chips Off Old Block? No, New Car Computer
description: Hot-rodding, an old California sport, has been married to computer decoding, a new California sport, and one result may be a rebirth for the hot-rod.

title: PRIEST HELD LIABLE FOR CIVIL DAMAGES
description: A judge has ruled that a Roman Catholic priest who pleaded guilty in 1986 to molesting three youths is liable for the civil damages claimed in a lawsuit that was filed by one of the youths' families.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in some copies Saturday about Michael S. Dukakis's economic proposals misstated the estimated cost to the Government of a plan to require that employers offer their workers health insurance. The estimate is $110 million.

title: Inquiry to Review Record Of Care for Deranged Man
description: The city and state have agreed to conduct a joint investigation into the psychiatric care provided to the deranged homeless man who was shot by the police after he killed an usher in St. Patrick's Cathedral last week.

title: A Too-Polite Silence About Shoddy Science
description: LEAD: Everybody applauds first-rate science, the stuff of which Nobel prizes are made. Yet, there is such a thing as second-rate science - but who will tell you what it is or where to find it?

title: Throw Out the Old, Haiti Bishops Say
description: The bishops of the Roman Catholic Church in Haiti today urged the new military Government to conduct a sweeping purge of loyalists from the Duvalier dictatorships, and they urgently appealed for an increase in international economic aid.

title: Review/Television; Placing Public Light on Private Lives
description: In January, PBS will begin a 10-part series on ''Ethics in America,'' the latest of the Columbia University Seminars on Media and Society. A preview is available tonight on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock. Titled ''The Politics of Privacy,'' it brings together journalists and politicians in a good-humored, if not especially enlightening, exchange on the question with which Fred Friendly, who originated the series, starts the program: Has the press gone too far in invading the privacy of public figures?

title: Film Festival; Charlie Parker's Tempestuous Life and Music
description: Although the first scene of ''Bird'' shows the young Charlie Parker in a rustic setting, the film seldom ventures outdoors after that. Most of ''Bird,'' Clint Eastwood's film biography of the legendary jazz saxophonist, takes place in the smoky nightclubs where Parker played or in the dimly lighted apartments where his unruly private life unfolded. The film's studied, shadowy look, at times so striking that the actors' features can't clearly be seen, becomes its most concerted effort to capture the spirit of Parker's music.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Advertising column on Wednesday about Endless Vacation magazine described the publication's status incorrectly. It has not suspended publication; it has kept to its bimonthly schedule for the entire year. The report also credited the magazine's design incorrectly. The art director is Patricia M. Prather; Milton Glaser and Walter Bernard were consultants on the redesign.

title: Amelia Armitage Becomes a Bride
description: Amelia Conze Armitage, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lacey Armitage of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday to Gary Mathias, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Mathias of Merrick, L.I. The Rev. Hugh Livengood, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi H. Philip Berkowitz performed the ceremony at the Stronghold Mansion in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: Review/Art; New Metropolitan Galleries Open With Degas
description: He chose his subjects from among the characters of late 19th-century Paris - the musicians at the Opera, the ballet dancers, prostitutes, businessmen, women leisurely shopping for hats, the singers and stragglers and fellow painters who crowded the cafes along Baron Haussmann's sweeping new boulevards. With an unerring, clinically unsentimental eye, Edgar Degas depicted them in paintings and pastels that remain, a century later, startling for the oddness and obliqueness of their compositions, the daring banality of their topics and the breathtaking virtuosity of their rendering.

title: Devils Beat Rangers, 5-3
description: After their physical game at the Meadowlands Saturday afternoon, the Rangers and the Devils moved their wrestling matches to Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Rutgers Turns Back the Clock
description: The last time Rutgers defeated Penn State in football, Woodrow Wilson was the President, World War I was a week away from the armistice and the Boston Red Sox had recently won the World Series.

title: Campaign Trail; Presidential Profile: Please Turn Around!
description: It was one of those typical photo opportunities in which Michael Dukakis -or for that matter, George Bush - do not generally excel. Ronald Reagan is another matter. The time: 8:15 A.M.. The place: Outside the Dukakis home at 85 Perry Street, Brookline.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ALC Communications Corp., Birmingham, Mich., a holding company, named Marvin C. Moses executive vice president and chief financial officer, replacing Robert Peiser, who resigned in January.

title: SOVIET CHIEF SAYS DRIVE FOR CHANGE IS BEING UNDERCUT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has told Soviet editors that his campaign to reshape the country is faltering, undermined by a gap between plans and deeds.

title: Turks Reject Ozal's Referendum
description: Voters defeated a measure to move up the date of local elections, the state television reported today, but Prime Minister Turgut Ozal vowed to remain in office despite having said that the defeat of the measure might lead to his resignation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Mikhail Gorbachev admitted a lag in his campaign to reshape the Soviet Union. He told Soviet editors that a gap exists between the goals and the results of his program to restructure the economy. Page A1

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Head of KDI Reaches Goal of Independence
description: LEAD: After several false starts with other companies. Eugene A. Cafiero, the chairman and chief executive of the KDI Corporation who last week led its management in a $184 million leveraged buyout, has a measure of independence he has never had before.

title: Tiffany Opens in Zurich
description: Tiffany & Company has opened a store this week in Zurich, its fourth outside the United States. The others are in London, Hong Kong and Munich. Tiffany is owned by the Bahrain-based investment bank Investcorp.

title: China's Economy Takes Small Leap Backward
description: China's Communist Party Central Committee meets Monday to deal with economic problems that have grown increasingly serious since the country embarked on an ambitious program of restructuring its economy nearly a decade ago.

title: Billiards Seeks Better Image
description: WHEN Gene Young was a teen-ager growing up in Toronto, he would often skip school to go out and ''shoot some pool.''

title: Penalty for Hockey Program
description: Hazing and drinking by college students, topics that have received national attention in recent years because of student deaths and injuries, have caused the suspension of an athletic program at Kent State University in Ohio.

title: Chile Awaits an Uncertain Plebiscite and an Even More Uncertain Aftermath
description: A campaign poster circulated by opponents of Gen. Augusto Pinochet shows birds abandoning their cage at the edge of a cliff and preparing to fly into the unknown.

title: Dollar Is Strong in Tokyo
description: The dollar edged up against the yen early today, while stock prices recovered earlier losses. The dollar opened at 134.80 yen, up 0.33 yen from Thursday's close. The Nikkei Stock Average gained 39.45 points from last Saturday to finish the morning session at 27,429.57. Dealers said the dollar's strength followed a reaffirmation among monetary authorities from seven major industrialized countries, meeting in West Berlin over the weekend, that they would continue to coordinate economic policies targeting stable exchange rates and control of inflation.

title: Changes at Thompson
description: At the J. Walter Thompson Company, a subsidiary of Britain's WPP Group, Michael Cooper-Evans, 54 years old, has been promoted to chairman and has been replaced with two regional presidents. They are Dominique Simonin, 44, who will be running eastern and southern Europe, and Miles Colebrook, 40, who, while continuing to run the London office, will also have Europe's northern and western regions on his plate.

title: Dining on Arena Floor for AIDS Benefit
description: ''I come to Boston Garden 40 times a year,'' said Harvey Allen, a wine and liquor wholesaler from Summerville, Mass., ''and I've never seen anyone dressed like this before.''

title: TV Notes
description: Prime Time Pays Off

title: Advocate Of Equality: Barbara C. Harris
description: On July 29, 1974, when women were first ordained as priests in the Episcopal Church, a young black public relations executive and civil rights worker literally led the way. Holding the crucifix high, she led the procession into Philadelphia's massive Church of the Advocate in Philadelphia, where three Episcopal bishops, acting without authorization, ordained 11 women as she watched.

title: 2 Rivals in Red Ties Speak Softly, Looking for Jabs and the TV Cameras
description: Both men wore dark suits and red ties. And both talked so softly, as a way of leavening their attacks on the issues, that reporters in the back of Wait Chapel, where Vice President Bush and Michael S. Dukakis faced off in their first debate, often had a hard time making out their words.

title: Anniversary Exhibit
description: The National Museum of African Art, formerly on Capitol Hill, marks its first anniversary on the Mall this week.

title: Gold Merger Could Bring Divestment
description: The hostile $4.9 billion bid by the overseas arm of the South African Oppenheimer dynasty for London-based Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. could lead to the biggest divestment yet in South Africa, brokers and investment analysts here say.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: The Park Service; Surviving Political Fires By Letting Them Burn
description: William Penn Mott Jr., the Director of the National Park Service, has been simmering in the political cauldron more or less continuously since taking over the Park Service in 1985, and he is by nature an optimistic sort.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES A major settlement is expected this week in a group of lawsuits against the investors in Ivan F. Boesky & Company, the investment vehicle for the fallen Wall Street speculator, people involved in those cases said. The partial accord does not include Mr. Boesky or his main underwriter, Drexel Burnham Lambert. [ D1. ] The takeover fight for Kroger seems to confirm that giant publicly traded supermarket chains are an endangered species. [ D1. ] THE ECONOMY Orders for American-made machine tools surged 33.2 percent in August, to $339.6 million, bolstered by substantial increases in exports, according to an industry report scheduled to be released today. The monthly figure on orders was more than double what it was in August of last year but was still well below the record amount of orders for one month. [ D1. ] The S.E.C. conducted formal investigations on fewer than half of the referrals it received from stock and commodity exchanges about suspicious trading in 1985 and 1986, the G.A.O. said. [ D2. ] U.S. gold producers are concerned that the decline in gold prices may drastically narrow or eliminate profit margins. [ D11. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT OPEC oil ministers reviewed prices and production, searching for ways to restore discipline to the organization and rein in the runaway production that is depressing prices. The group held the first of two days of talks in Madrid. [ D1. ] New U.S.-Soviet ventures seem to have more fast-food sizzle than high-stakes technology, Soviet and U.S. officials say. [ D6. ] West Germany is now the largest exporter of goods to India, as it has edged past the U.S., Japan and Britain. West Germany and India envision a growing link in high-technology enterprises. [ D10. ] Pernod is trying to make diversifications more palatable. It is now seeking to bring an Irish whisky or two into the fold. [ D10. ] The biggest South African divestment ever could result from the $4.9 billion bid by Minorco for Consolidated Gold Fields. [ D10. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Setbacks at The Chicago Sun-Times are raising questions about its future. Some think the paper, which has changed owners twice in four years, may be sold again; others say it will be squeezed in an attempt to help pay for its leveraged buyout. [ D1. ] A Delaware Chancery Court judge said he would rule this week on a challenge to Macmillan's ''poison pill'' plan that was filed by Maxwell Communications. [ D2. ] ''USA Today: The Television Show,'' harshly criticized in its first two weeks on the air, is being overhauled by its producers in an attempt to improve bad ratings. [ D14. ] Many publishing houses count on backlist books, the industry term for books that remain in print long after publication. The quest for such books has been a major reason that bigger publishing houses have been buying smaller ones. [ D14. ] The price of newsprint may rise again this winter if the people who produce it can make a 6.9 percent increase stick with the newspaper companies that are their customers. [ D14. ] New ads for Federal Express's Eastern region start next week with a print campaign by Muller, Jordan, Weiss. Advertising. [ D12. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Many employers face sharply higher pension costs as of Jan. 1 because of changes mandated by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, says a lawyer and editor for the Research Institute of America who specializes in pension plans and employee benefits. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] Mesa Limited Partnership is getting better word of mouth from many analysts. Market Place. [ D6. ] The bond market is still feeling the effects of the default of the Washington Public Power Supply System. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]

title: 2-Year and 4-Year Notes to Be Auctioned
description: Teasury financings this week start with today's regular auction of new three-month and six-month bills. Tomorrow the Treasury will auction new 2-year notes, and on Wednesday 4-year notes will sold.

title: Derisive Exchange
description: Vice President Bush and Michael S. Dukakis clashed sharply and at times angrily last night, with Mr. Dukakis relentlessly pressing the Iran-contra affair and drug policy and Mr. Bush criticizing Mr. Dukakis's stands on military issues, the death penalty and taxes.

title: Review/Music; Echoes of a French Style
description: Not many instrumental groups have a built-in composer, but Robert Chumbley is not only a member of the Broyhill Chamber Ensemble but also its founder and artistic director. Not surprisingly his music - in this case a trio called ''An Odyssey of Reminiscence'' - found its way to Friday night's program at Weill Recital Hall.

title: SYRIAN ISOLATION AMONG ARABS SEEN
description: With the halting of the Iran-Iraq war, Syria has been left perilously isolated in the Arab world, estranged from some Persian Gulf nations and exposed to Baghdad's threats of vengeance for supporting Teheran during the eight-year conflict, Western and Arab diplomats say.

title: Distress on World Debt; Signal by Seven Industrial Powers Reflects Persistence of Problem in Poorer Countries
description: A communique released by the Group of Seven industrial democracies Saturday night took a ''don't rock the boat'' approach to currency exchange rates and efforts to reduce the huge American trade deficit.

title: Suburb Runs Ads for Minorities, but Few Respond
description: Parma, Cleveland's largest suburb, is running court-ordered advertisements telling members of minorities that they are welcome in the nearly all-white community, but so far the campaign is getting a lukewarm response.

title: Before It's Built, A Road Suffers Political Gridlock
description: Callers to a new State Transportation Department office on Fifth Avenue are informed that they have reached the ''Route 9A Reconstruction Project.''

title: Dukakis Assailed on War Vote
description: Vice President Bush charged tonight that Michael S. Dukakis had demonstrated ''misguided passion'' by supporting a bill that would have exempted Massachusetts residents from fighting in the Vietnam War.

title: OLYMPIC HIGHLIGHTS
description: SWIMMINGKristen Otto of East Germany, above, got her sixth gold medal, the most ever for a woman, and Matt Biondi of the U.S. picked up his fifth gold and seventh medal. BOXINGIt was another mad, mad day of buzzers and bells and two knockouts in two bouts between the same two fighters. Articles begin on page B7.

title: Shuttle's Giant Payload Aims to Broaden Links to Space
description: The space shuttle Discovery, scheduled to be launched Thursday, will be carrying a giant, enormously complex communications satellite that is virtually identical to one destroyed in the Challenger disaster nearly three years ago.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Horn & Hardart Picks A New Top Executive
description: LEAD: Fans of the automat, take heart. Donald Schupak, the new chairman of the Horn & Hardart Company, just might be willing to experiment some more in the time-honored tradition that made the company famous.

title: Ban Could Cost Plenty to Johnson
description: Canadians were stunned today by reports from Seoul, South Korea, that Ben Johnson had tested positive for steroids and was to be stripped of his gold medal in the 100-meter dash in the 1988 Olympics.

title: Dollar's Rise Is Curbed by Intervention
description: The Federal Reserve and several European central banks quickly stepped into the foreign exchange market yesterday in an effort to cut off a dollar rally and back up a crucial weekend communique reasserting support of stable currencies.

title: Dodgers Clinch Title
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers clinched their fourth National League West title in eight years as Mickey Hatcher's run-scoring single broke an eighth-inning tie in a 3-2 victory over the San Diego Padres tonight.

title: American at Hijacking Trial Describes Beating of Diver
description: Mohammed Ali Hammadi, the Lebanese hijacker of a Trans World Airlines plane, severely beat a United States hostage and shouted ''let the pig suffer'' before hustling him at gunpoint to the spot where he was shot dead, a witness said at his trial today.

title: After the Debate; Dukakis Makes Headway in a Detroit Suburb, but Changes Few Minds
description: Most of the people at Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 6691 Sunday night to watch the Presidential debate came there as avowed partisans of Vice President Bush.

title: Couple Suffer a Double Loss in Daughter's Death
description: Regina and Ernest Twigg were consumed night and day by the worst crisis of their lives -their 9-year-old daughter, Arlena, was near death and about to undergo heart surgery - when the medical specialists called this summer and asked them to come at once.

title: INSIDE
description: New Plea for Ozone Shield The head of the Environmental Protection Agency called for complete elimination of chemicals thought to destroy the ozone layer. Page A20. A Refund From Kodak Kodak gained court approval to disburse nearly $200 million to an estimated 3.4 million people who bought its instant-picture cameras. Page D5. Hard-Liner Gets Polish Post Poland's Communist leadership picked Mieczyslaw Rakowski, the party's propaganda chief, as the new Prime Minister. Page A3. Anti-Drug Lessons All public schools in New York City will be required by the end of December to provide some form of education about drug abuse. Page B1.

title: Trial for Helmsleys Postponed by Judge
description: A Federal judge yesterday postponed until January the tax fraud trial of Harry B. Helmsley, the hotel magnate, and his wife, Leona, leaving unresolved the question of whether Mr. Helmsley's mental state is adequate for him to stand trial.

title: From Boston Police, Endorsement or Indictment?
description: LEAD: George Bush has a fixation about Boston's garbage. Three weeks ago, he went there to gloat about the dirty harbor. Last week, he returned to fawn over the city's most prominent political polluter, its police union.

title: Japan Is Seeking Larger Role in World's Financial System and Debt Crisis
description: Japan is demonstrating an increased willingness to accept more financial responsibilities as officials of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank gather here for their annual meetings.

title: Merger Fever Is Unabated
description: A wave of billion-dollar buyouts in the first half of the year pushed corporate mergers to a record level, the research firm W. T. Grimm & Company said today.

title: Software to Help You Wax Poetic
description: SHALL I compare thee to a perfect word processor?

title: After the Debate; Like Others Before Them, Debaters Stretched the Truth at Times
description: Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis hurled piles of complicated figures, obscure names, tongue-twisting acronyms and seemingly irrefutable facts at each other in their debate Sunday night.

title: Bill Banning Genocide Still Snagged in Senate
description: Forty years after President Harry S. Truman called for an international treaty outlawing genocide, and two years after the Senate finally agreed to American participation in it, a law giving force to the treaty in the United States remains bottled up in the Senate.

title: Basses Cut Stake
description: An investment group led by Sid R. Bass, Lee M. Bass and Perry R. Bass, three members of the wealthy Fort Worth family, have lowered their stake in the Standard Brands Paint Company to 2.7 percent, from 4.5 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the Bass group said it sold 108,082 shares for $14.38 to $15.60 each. It gave no reason for the sales. The group paid an average of $20.17 per share when they bought the stock last November. Standard Brands Paint is a chain of home decorating stores based in Torrance, Calif.

title: Take Your Time
description: Here is an encouraging thought to light the way:

title: Q&A
description: Q. When a cormorant catches a fish, it appears to swallow it alive. What kills the fish? Does the same thing happen to a python's victims? A. The cause of death is, 'in all probability, suffocation,'' according to Dr. Emil Dolensek, chief veterinarian of the New York Zoological Society.

title: Agreement Is Reached On Margins
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Options Clearing Corporation have agreed to lower sharply the amount of money an investor would have to post to cover positions in stock index options and stock index futures.

title: Yugoslav Politburo Member Resigns Over Ethnic Dispute
description: Franc Setinc, a Slovenian member of the Yugoslav Communist Party Politburo, resigned today to protest Serbian agitation over ethnic troubles in Kosovo Province, Tanjug press agency said.

title: In Goshen, Challenge on Power Line's Effect
description: Behind a squeaky door here, in a courtroom that barely seats 20 people, 58 farmers and other large landowners from rural Orange County are taking on the New York Power Authority in an emotionally charged case that could result in a landmark decision for the nation's utilities.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: The Justice Department; A Very Different Kind Of Attorney General
description: The talk of the Justice Department these days is that Attorney General Dick Thornburgh seems to be settling in for a very long stay.

title: Debates, Domesticated
description: Ideally, one purpose of Presidential debates is to give voters a sense of how the candidates handle themselves in an atmosphere approaching spontaneity. Yet few aspects of modern politics are unrehearsed, and the first confrontation between Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael Dukakis was no exception.

title: N.F.L. Notebook; Montana Learns to Share the Limelight
description: Before the San Francisco 49ers tackled the Seahawks in Seattle on Sunday, Joe Montana spoke about the times he had been replaced at quarterback by Steve Young this season.

title: Lebanese Regimes Seek Foreign Recognition
description: The rival Lebanese cabinets, each claiming legitimacy over the country's leadership, worked today to gain international recognition.

title: Patterns; Punk Fashion Revisited
description: Remember Johnny Rotten? When safety pins were fashion points? Students of punk history came together Saturday with a group of fashion icons to remember and reflect on the glory days of torn clothes, circa 1978-84, at a symposium at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan.

title: A Company's Fall Turns Brother Against Brother
description: It is a story that Kansas City has been following for nearly two years - the disintegration of both a long-respected family and a family enterprise. One prominent citizen called it ''a tragedy to the city of major proportions.'' It is the story of the fall of the house of Kroh.

title: MTV Beckons, And, Like Wow, A Star Is Born
description: Like, would you just die if they picked you -you! - to be a dancer on the ''Club MTV'' show or what? ''It would be like really great,'' said Lizette Acosta, who works in a Center Moriches beauty parlor.

title: KEY RATES
Campeau's Operating Net Off 2.3%
description: The Campeau Corporation had a 2.3 percent decline in its first-half operating profit, to $172 million, from $176 million in the comparable period last year, reflecting its takeover in May of Federated Department Stores, the company said yesterday.

title: Republican Platform Puts Fetus Before Mother; Vengeful Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Debate; G.O.P. Says Big Donors Gave Party $10 Million
description: After Watergate, laws were passed to stop millionaires like W. Clement Stone from bankrolling political campaigns. But a list of $10 million in Republican donations, made public today, shows that Mr. Stone and others like him are again making hefty contributions, though not directly to candidates.

title: Dukakis Needs Republicans
description: LEAD: ''Hello. May I please speak to Republicans for Dukakis?''

title: In Schools, a Palpable Silence on Launching
description: Rick Fredrickson, a junior at the high school here where Christa McAuliffe taught, did not know that the space shuttle Discovery was scheduled to lift off on Thursday.

title: Marcus Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 18
SECOND CONVICTION IN DRUG SLAYINGS
description: A second defendant was found guilty today in the kidnapping and slaying of an American drug agent in Mexico in 1985.

title: HOUSE VOTES BILLS TO SAVE WILDLIFE
description: Bills to strengthen the nation's effort to save endangered plants, animals and fish and give special protection to African elephants and Pacific dolphins were passed by voice votes in the House today.

title: Kroger Plans Sale Of Assets
description: The Kroger Company, the giant supermarket operator, said today that it was offering to sell assets worth an estimated $333 million after taxes as part of a restructuring to fend off two hostile takeover bids.

title: Doskocil Sweetens Wilson Foods Bid
description: Seeking to top a competing bid for the Wilson Foods Corporation, the Doskocil Companies said it would raise its offer by $2.25 a share, to $14.50, putting a new value of about $147 million on the meatpacking concern. Doskocil, which makes pizza toppings, wants to buy Wilson to gain entry into grocery stores and delicatessens. Its previous bid valued Wilson, based in Oklahoma City, at $124 million.

title: Bozell, Jacobs Names Chief Creative Officer
description: Ron Anderson, 52 years old and recently arrived at New York headquarters of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt from Minneapolis, has been promoted to chief creative officer from associate chief creative officer.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Alabama Stars
description: Alabamians who make their home in the Capital are contentedly humming ''Stars Fell on Alabama'' in anticipation of the Washington debut of the Alabama Symphony Orchestra Sunday at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, the orchestra's first major appearance outside its home state.

title: A Galway Booster Shot
description: James Galway, wielding his golden flute and a pair of concertos, brought a measure of sprightliness and virtuosity to the opening concert of the Brooklyn Philharmonic's 35th season last Friday evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. And it was while accompanying Mr. Galway that Lukas Foss was able to coax the smoothest and most polished playing from his orchestra.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., and Lucas Industries P.L.C., London, said Lucas would purchase the Utica Power Systems unit of Allied, which makes engine power transmission products, for $40 million.

title: Tokheim Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,390,000 from an accounting change.

title: Campaign Trail; The Second Debate Gets Hollywood Cast
description: Forget Winston-Salem, N.C. It's Hollywood now, and the issues will count, of course, not style or appearance.

title: Zaire Dispute With I.M.F. Centers on Capital Flows
description: Traditionally pro-Western, this Central African country has emerged as an unexpected spokesman for the developing world's hostility to the International Monetary Fund's handling of the debt crisis.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Credit Markets column of Business Day yesterday, about a Securities and Exchange Commission interpretation of the responsibilities of municipal bond underwriters, described the document incorrectly. It was indeed published, on Friday afternoon.

title: The Smearing of the Olympics
description: THE world's fastest human has been convicted of speeding on steroids. And the Olympics has been smeared by drugs as never before.

title: Kay Sugahara Is Dead; Ship Executive Was 79
description: Kay Sugahara, a Japanese-American who was interned on the West Coast after the Pearl Harbor attack and who later built a worldwide ship-owning business and worked for better relations between the United States and East Asian nations, died of liver cancer Sunday at his home in Pelham Manor, N.Y. He was 79 years old.

title: Ruling Upholds The Britannica
description: Encyclopaedia Britannica Inc. said today that it had won a decision in which a Taiwanese company and two of its officers had been found guilty of book piracy in publishing the 15-million-word Concise Encyclopaedia Britannica.

title: O'Koren to Broadcast
description: Michael O'Koren, the Nets' 1980 first-round draft choice, has joined the team's radio broadcast team and speakers' bureau. O'Koren, 30, who starred at North Carolina, played six seasons for the Nets before being traded to the Washington Bullets in October 1986. He was waived by the Bullets several months later. O'Koren signed as a free agent with the Boston Celtics last season and was re-acquired by the Nets toward the end of the season but never played for them. He was plagued by a pulled hamstring. The Nets also announced that Al Menendez, the director of player personnel for the past nine years, has resigned.

title: Review/Television; Snoopy's Brother Loves A Human, Charlie Brown
description: Nearly 40 years have flitted by since Charles M. Schulz created ''Peanuts.'' Keeping the comic-strip characters remarkably fresh, Mr. Schulz has adroitly parlayed Charlie Brown and the gang into a stage musical, animation television specials, greeting cards and hundreds of other tie-in products. It's a remarkable success story. But even at this stage of the game, Mr. Schulz can take an unseemly pratfall. Witness ''It's the Girl in the Red Truck, Charlie Brown,'' the hourlong special tonight at 8 on CBS.

title: By Design; Chemise Alert
description: The chemise is the chic dress shape of the moment. After several seasons of clothes fitted closely to the body, sometimes too much so, the linear silhouette of the chemise seems fresh and elegant.

title: East German Cyclist Sprints To Victory in Last 300 Meters
description: Olaf Ludwig, an East German cyclist, took the lead with 3 kilometers left and outsprinted Brend Groene of West Germany in the final 300 meters today to win the men's 197-kilometer road race.

title: Helene Curtis Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
After the Debate; Bush Pledges Support For Bill on Homeless
description: Vice President Bush said in the debate Sunday that he would favor full financing of legislation already approved by Congress to aid the homeless.

title: A Thief Eludes Extra Security at St. Patrick's
