description: Despite police protection that was stepped up after a deranged man bludgeoned an usher to death last week, a thief at St. Patrick's Cathedral was able to rifle through a collection box and break into the gift shop early yesterday, escaping with about $100 in coins and religious medals.

title: After the Debate; A.C.L.U. Reports Rise in Membership Calls in Wake of Bush's Attacks
description: funny thing happened when Vice President Bush decided to make the American Civil Liberties Union an issue in the Presidential campaign and began attacking the organization's ''far left'' views.

title: Goodbye to Tarzan, Meet Captain Africa
description: Fresh out of an African university, young Abbie Momo bursts into tears upon learning that her parents paid the school fees with a bride price secretly negotiated with ''the notorious Chief Eza.''

title: Tate & Lyle Sets Deal To Buy Amstar Sugar
description: The Amstar Corporation, which makes Domino sugar and is the nation's largest refiner of cane sugar, agreed yesterday to sell its Amstar Sugar unit to Tate & Lyle P.L.C. for $305 million.

title: Federal Paper Board Co reports earnings for 12wks to Sept 10
description: b-After a charge of $8,217,000 representing premium on retirement of debt.

title: Minister Sentenced to Death
description: A minister convicted of shooting and killing a church handyman before beheading him and leaving the man's body in a burning church has been sentenced to death by electrocution.

title: Kodak Pact On Payouts Is Cleared
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it had received final approval from a Cook County court here to begin disbursing nearly $200 million to an estimated 3.4 million people who bought Kodak's instant-picture cameras from 1976 to 1986.

title: Drexel Drive to Oust Judge Is Said to Cite Wife's Deal
description: In an attempt to remove a tough Federal judge presiding over their case, lawyers for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and other defendants in a large securities fraud lawsuit have asserted in sealed court papers that the judge has a conflict of interest involving his wife's family business, several people who have seen the papers said yesterday.

title: Piniella Calmly Prepares for Talks and Yanks Get 5-4 Victory
description: He has been hired twice, dismissed once and heaved into controversy more times than he can count, so Lou Piniella knows the uncertainty of being employed by George Steinbrenner. It is for that reason, perhaps, that Piniella does not intend to spend the winter waiting. Next week, he will meet with the Yankees' principal owner to decide his immediate future.

title: Super Rite Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Talking Business with Furlaud of Squibb; Betting the Farm On Research
description: The Squibb Corporation predicts that Capoten, its blood pressure and heart disease drug that is a member of the ACE inhibitor family of pharmaceutical agents, will have worldwide sales this year in excess of $1 billion, about 40 percent of the company's revenues. Only two other drugs, Glaxo's Zantac and SmithKline Beckman's Tagamet, are in the billion-dollar club. But Merck's new blood pressure drug, Vasotec, is gaining fast and may catch up with Capoten in 1989.

title: Meadowlands: Studies Dispute Link to Cancer
description: Two scientific studies conducted after four members of the Giants football team developed cancer in the last eight years have concluded that there is no link between the cancers and the environment at the Meadowlands sports complex.

title: Controversy Can Upstage the Events
description: WE should have known things would go a bit crazy at the Olympics when an American boxer showed up late for an appointment he had waited his whole career to keep.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Carriers Inc., Overland Park., Kan., a motor carrier holding company, named John Bigger president and chief executive, succeeding Leon Robertson, who is retiring.

title: Rivalry Runs 16 Years Deep
description: They were expected to meet in the final, the ideal scenario for settling a 16-year-old score. It did not matter that the basketball players now representing the United States and Soviet Union were only children in 1972, too young to understand the ramifications of the upset in Munich, when the Soviet Union punctured the air of invincibility surrounding American basketball.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL OPEC acknowledged that it had failed to bolster oil prices and said it would seek ''a new approach.'' OPEC's Secretary General said the move was a ''signal to the oil market'' that OPEC is searching for serious solutions to its lack of discipline. Oil prices have fallen by a third in the last year. [ Page D1. ] Zaire has emerged as an unexpected spokesman for the developing world's hostility to the I.M.F.'s handling of the debt crisis. From 1983 to 1986, Zaire closely followed an I.M.F. program and its debt service rose to half of its budget, from 10 percent. [ D1. ] Japan is demonstrating an increased willingness to accept more financial responsibilities as officials of the I.M.F. and the World Bank gather for annual meetings. The Japanese have indicated that they want to contribute a far larger amount to the I.M.F. and to help reduce the $1.2 trillion third world debt. [ D6. ] COMPANIES Lawyers for Drexel Burnham Lambert say a conflict of interest should disqualify the judge presiding over the securities fraud charges brought against the brokerage. Drexel has been seeking to remove Federal District Judge Milton Pollack, who has a reputation for being tough on defendants. In sealed papers, it says the family business of the judge's wife has a link to Drexel. [ D1. ] Eastman Kodak received final approval from a Cook County court to begin disbursing nearly $200 million to an estimated 3.4 million people who bought Kodak's instant-picture cameras. [ D5. ] Amstar Sugar will be acquired for $305 million by Tate & Lyle P.L.C., which acquired Staley Continental in June. [ D2. ] Arthur Andersen will study how to prevent defections from its huge and successful management consulting practice. [ D2. ] Campeau's operating profits fell 2.3 percent in the first half of its fiscal year, reflecting its takeover of Federated. [ D5. ] Time magazine will make several editorial changes, starting with its Oct. 17 issue. [ D24. ] Irving sued Bank of New York, accusing it of improperly persuading Banca Commerciale Italiana to end its bid for Irving. [ D7. ] Kroger will sell $333 million in assets as part of a restructuring to fend off two hostile takeover bids. [ D13. ] Best Products rejected a $520 million offer from an unidentified suitor and is considering selling the company. [ D5. ] A suburban Chicago electronics company is under investigation by Federal officials for its export activities. [ D15. ] Auto makers will sharply cut employment in the next few years, the head of Renault predicts. [ D8. ] MARKETS The Federal Reserve and several European central banks intervened in the foreign exchange market in an effort to cut off a dollar rally and back up a crucial weekend communique reasserting support of stable currencies. [ D1. ] The Chicago Merc and the Options Clearing Corporation agreed to lower sharply the amount of money an investor would have to post to cover positions in stock index options and stock index futures. [ D1. ] Stock prices fell moderately in lethargic trading. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 5.51 points, to 2,085.17. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury bonds and notes dipped in light trading. [ D21. ] Soybean futures prices plunged to their lowest close in nearly four months on the Chicago Board of Trade. [ D22. ] Shares sold short and not yet covered fell 0.8 percent on Nasdaq in the month ended Sept. 15. [ D24. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Concentrating on its prescription drug business, Squibb has had ''the best earnings record in terms of growth in our industry during the last four or five years,'' said Richard M. Furlaud, its chairman and chief executive. Talking Business. [ D2. ] Wall Street is skeptical about a possible takeover of K Mart because more than $10 billion would be needed. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: Trail of Hot Dog Leads Back to 1880's
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stellar Career Abruptly Clouded
description: The story goes that when Ben Johnson was 12 years old, he and a friend were walking down a street in Jamaica. From the dark recess of a doorway, an old man who was a fortune teller stepped out. After examining Johnson's hand, the fortune teller said, ''One day you will be famous and travel the world.''

title: Illegal Computer Exports Are Suspected
description: Federal authorities are investigating whether a suburban Chicago company illegally exported hundreds of thousands of dollars' worth of computer equipment that may have been resold in the Soviet Union.

title: Blaming G.O.P., Democrats Drop Effort to Raise the Minimum Wage
description: Senate Democrats gave up on their bill to raise the minimum wage today, then tried to stake out a campaign issue by blaming the Republicans.

title: A Foe of Solidarity to Be Polish Premier
description: A veteran politician and seasoned foe of the outlawed trade union Solidarity, Mieczyslaw Rakowski, was chosen as Prime Minister today by the Communist Party Central Committee.

title: Note and Bond Prices in Decline
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes dipped in very light trading yesterday, as market participants reacted negatively to firmer oil and gold prices and to a successful effort by major central banks to stem a rally in the dollar.

title: Shuttle's Countdown Resumes
description: The countdown began this morning, the astronauts arrived this afternoon and as night fell on the space shuttle Discovery at its launching pad, work was proceeding toward liftoff Thursday of the first flight by American astronauts in 32 months.

title: Henry Koster, 83, Director of 'Harvey' And 'Bishop's Wife'
description: Henry Koster, the director of such films as ''Harvey'' and ''The Bishop's Wife'' died of complications after liver surgery Wednesday in Camarillo, Calif. He was 83 years old.

title: Filibuster Stops Wage Measure
description: Senate Democrats gave up on their bill to raise the minimum wage, blaming the Republicans whose filibuster has blocked the bill for a week.

title: Protesters Assail Anti-Gay Violence
description: Chanting slogans, blowing whistles and carrying banners, more than 200 demonstrators marched onto the West Side Highway, from Christopher to Clarkson Streets, at the height of yesterday's evening rush hour, to protest violence against homosexuals. Organizers called the event a ''Gays of Rage'' rally.

title: Train Kills 2 Tots on Tracks
description: A freight train struck and killed two 2-year-old children Sunday as they played on railroad tracks that ran behind their homes, the authorities said. Amanda S. Harmon and Brian S. Johnson were pronounced dead at the scene.

title: New Kuwait Tanker
description: The Kuwait Oil Tanker Company said today that it had put into service a 35,000-metric-ton refined products tanker, the first of six ordered from a South Korean shipyard.

title: 3 Palestinians Slain By Israelis in Gaza And East Jerusalem
description: Israeli soldiers and police officers killed two Palestinians in the Gaza Strip and another in East Jerusalem today during the bloodiest clashes between troops and demonstrators in several months, Arab hospital officials said.

title: August Home Resales Up
description: Sales of existing single-family homes rose a modest 1.1 percent in August, pulled up by strong demand in the South, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: Gunman in S. Carolina School Kills 1 and Wounds 10 Others
description: A gunman walked into an elementary school today and opened fire, killing an 8-year-old girl and injuring 10 other people, the authorities said.

title: Curb on Bear Watching Leaves Uneasy Truce
description: Across 20 feet of ankle-deep water, Charlie Land stared at a brown bear sow.

title: Careers; Intelligence Experts for Corporations
description: THE intelligence activities of corporations are on the rise. Howard Sutton, senior research associate of the Conference Board, a business research organization, discovered this by doing a study, ''Competitive Intelligence,'' that the board issued this week.

title: Subway Safety Unit Faulted Over Delays on Violations
description: Correcting some subway safety violations takes at least 14 months, and the Transit Authority's safety unit has not done an effective job of finding hazardous situations, the Inspector General of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

title: A Lot Riding for Thiokol on Shuttle
description: When the space shuttle Discovery is launched, executives of Morton Thiokol Inc. will be holding their breaths during the first 120 seconds of the flight - now scheduled for Thursday - waiting to see how their rocket boosters perform.

title: REAGAN HAS TALKS ON MIDEAST PEACE
description: President Reagan met today with the Foreign Ministers of Egypt and Israel and lavished praise on the 10-year-old Camp David accords negotiated by the Carter Administration.

title: World Leaders Urge U.N. to Build on Peacemaking Successes
description: World leaders and diplomats today hailed the United Nations' recent political successes, but urged the organization to push ahead with peacemaking efforts and press for new breakthroughs in areas like arms reduction and third-world debt.

title: New York Selects A Medical Examiner
description: Charles S. Hirsch, a 51-year-old professor and forensic pathologist, was named yesterday as New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, filling a post that has been vacant for almost a year.

title: Who's on the 'Right' Track for America?
description: George Bush is staking his hopes for the Presidency on the belief that the country will choose a conservative over a ''strong liberal Democrat,'' as he portrays Michael Dukakis.

title: TURK SEES VICTORY IN JAWS OF DEFEAT
description: Although he suffered a clear defeat in a national referendum on Sunday, Prime Minister Turgut Ozal said today that he was sufficiently satisfied with the results to withdraw an earlier threat to resign.

title: Reagan's Visit to the U.N. Disrupts Traffic
description: President Reagan's visit to the United Nations yesterday seriously disrupted traffic along a 30-block stretch of the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Compromise Collapses In a Ford Family Feud
description: A last-minute settlement in a family feud over the $350 million trust left by auto magnate Henry Ford 2dbroke down in court today.

title: U.S. Fighters' Bets Called Off
description: Just when Olympic boxing buffs were beginning to wonder why the United States gladiators were trying for quick knockouts, Riddick Bowe spilled the secret: Each of the 12 members of the American team put $100 into a pool that would go to the boxer who produced the quickest knockout in the tournament.

title: Mets Are Counting Down to the Playoffs
description: When you mention ''countdown to the playoffs'' to Dave Johnson, he laughs and says: ''I haven't announced any countdown, especially for my pitching rotation. But people have gleaned some ideas on who'll pitch when.''

title: Let Amputee Cadet At Least Graduate
description: To the Editor:

title: Louganis Wins In Final Round
description: Greg Louganis became the first man to earn two diving gold medals in consecutive Olympics when he won a dramatic battle with Xiong Ni today by overtaking the Chinese teen-ager on the final dive of the 10-meter platform competition.

title: Product Introductions Fell a Bit in August
description: Even though the drop was slight, August was the fourth month this year that had a decrease in product introductions, compared with comparable months in 1987, according to Gorman's New Product News.

title:
Miami Beach Journal;
Finally, Lincoln Road Is Turning a Corner
description: LEAD: In the 1940's and 1950's, when this resort town was the country's foremost vacation spot, Lincoln Road was the commercial and social center of Miami Beach. The 10-block street running west from the ocean was a place to see and to be seen.

title: 2 Drug Companies End Name Dispute
description: Two pharmaceutical companies -Schering A.G. of West Germany and the Schering-Plough Corporation of the United States - have settled a dispute over the use of ''Schering'' in North America. The West German company said it would pay Schering-Plough $8 million under the pact.

title: Review/Opera; Luciano Pavarotti and Eva Marton In 'Il Trovatore' as the Met Opens
description: Opening night at the Metropolitan Opera is traditionally first of all a social ritual and second, if at all, a musical performance. That is why, for many years, it has been the company's custom to begin with a heavyweight production calculated to persuade even the novice that he is attending an important cultural event. This year, for instance, we have ''Il Trovatore,'' in the arid and gloomy staging that sent Verdi lovers away in a funk when it was new last season. The production's return on Monday evening did little to banish memory of that gloom.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A stronger chemical weapons ban should be enforced by a new international effort, President Reagan said in a farewell speech to the United Nations that was his most laudatory toward the organization. Page A1

title: A Fair Chance for the Baby; An Issue for the No-Issue Campaign
description: Picture a hospital nursery: rows of healthy infants, some of them sleeping, some of them crying and most of them plump as pigeons. Now picture the neonatal intensive care unit in the same hospital: rows of skinny, stiff-legged little creatures trembling nervously, squalling fitfully. Were these children born equal? Not on your life.

title: Time Magazine to Begin New Editorial Features
description: Time magazine, the largest United States news magazine, will make several editorial changes, starting with its Oct. 17 issue.

title: Mr. Reagan, the Multilateralist
description: ''The United Nations is a better place than it was eight years ago and so too is the world. . . . We see not only progress, but also the potential for an increasingly vital role for multilateral efforts and institutions like this United Nations.''

title: Books of The Times; From Young George to Mephistophelean G.B.S.
description: Bernard Shaw Volume I 1856-1898: The Search for Love By Michael Holroyd 486 pages. Illustrated. Random House.

title: An Undercurrent of Perplexity on U.S. Performance
description: If the 1986 world championships were a disaster for American swimming, how do you describe the disappointments of the Americans in the Olympics?

title: Maimed Protester and Others Win Right to Sue Train Crew
description: A court has ruled that five protesters may sue three railroad crew members and civilian officials over the Navy train that ran into a group of demonstrators last September, maiming one of them.

title: Best Products Spurns Offer of $520 Million
description: The Best Products Company, the large catalogue-showroom company, said yesterday that it had rejected a $520 million offer from an unidentified suitor but was considering selling the company or taking other steps to increase shareholder value.

title: Authority to Expand Its Electricity Pact
description: The New York Power Authority is expected to announce today that it will supply all the electricity required by government agencies in New York City and Westchester County for the indefinite future, at a reduced cost, a change in policy that would save the agencies about $200 million in the next 10 years.

title: Presidio Oil Accord
description: The Presidio Oil Company has reached an agreement to acquire a major portion of the properties and operations of the General Atlantic Energy Corporation, an oil and gas company based in Denver, for $100 million in cash and 1.6 million of Presidio's class A common stock. The shares of Presidio, based in Englewood, Colo., closed yesterday at $5.125, down 37.5 cents each, on the American Stock Exchange. The properties are generally in the Powder River Basin of Wyoming and along the Gulf Coast of Louisiana and Texas.

title: Excerpts From the President's Speech to the U.N.
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's address to the 43d General Assembly of the United Nations yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Washburn Suspended
description: The Atlanta Hawks' center-forward Chris Washburn has been suspended from the National Basketball Association and returned to the N.B.A.'s rehabilitation center in Van Nuys, Calif., after suffering a relapse with substance abuse. The Hawks' general manager, Stan Kasten, confirmed yesterday that Washburn was suspended without pay until doctors clear him to return to basketball. Kasten said no decision has been made about replacing Washburn on the roster. The team could replace Washburn with a minimum salary player but Washburn's $777,000 contract will continue to count against the club's salary cap total. Washburn confessed to cocaine abuse during the 1986-87 season, while he was with the Golden State Warriors. Thus, he is one step away from being banned by the N.B.A. for at least two years in the event of a third offense. Washburn was acquired by the Hawks last Dec. 15. He worked 174 minutes while playing in 29 games for the Hawks. He averaged 2.0 points and was benched in the playoffs.(AP)

title: Evidence Points to Deceit by Brawley
description: A seven-month New York State grand jury inquiry has compiled overwhelming evidence that Tawana Brawley fabricated her story of abduction and sexual abuse by a gang of racist white men last year, according to investigators, witnesses and official summaries of evidence presented to the panel.

title: Economic Growth Forecast
description: A panel of 60 economists from the National Association of Business Economists is bullish about growth this year, predicting an expansion of 3.9 percent as measured by the gross national product. But the median forecast for next year is an anemic 2.3 percent.

title: After The Debate; A Smiling Dukakis Renews His Offensive Against Bush
description: Michael S. Dukakis, reveling in his aggressive performance in the debate with Vice President Bush on Sunday night, renewed the attack today in New Jersey and Ohio by saying Mr. Bush would ''lead America nowhere'' as President.

title: Husband Loses Appeal To Bar Wife's Abortion
description: The Supreme Court refused today to stop a Michigan woman from having an abortion her estranged husband sought to prevent.

title: OLYMPIC HIGHLIGHTS
description: DIVING: Greg Louganis became the first man to win both diving events in consecutive Olympics. He overtook a 14-year-old Chinese on his final dive of the 10-meter platform competition and won by 1.14 points. BASKETBALL: The United States women's team routed the Soviet Union, 102-88, and advanced to a gold-medal game against Yugoslavia, a team it has already defeated. TRACK AND FIELD: Carl Lewis and Roger Kingdom successfully defended the gold medals they won in 1984 in the long jump and the 110-meter hurdles. In a major upset, Paul Ereng of Kenya won the men's 800 meters over Joachim Cruz, the defending champion, and Said Aouita, the favorite. Articles, page D29.<

title: International Multifoods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Belfast Journal; A Priest Brings Jobs (and Hope) Into a Living Hell
description: The problems of Northern Ireland are inordinately clustered in West Belfast, a Roman Catholic ghetto of poverty, broken homes and crime, where the Irish Republican Army finds plenty of sympathy for its credo of violent revolution and where a priest named Matthew Wallace is trying to change all that.

title: Progress Reported on Military Spending Bill
description: Leaders of the Congressional Armed Services committees and Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci today neared agreement on a modified version of the $299.5 billion military program bill that President Reagan vetoed last month.

title: Open Positions on Nasdaq Short Sales Down 0.8%
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a monthly decline of eight-tenths of 1 percent in the ''short interest'' for the most active over-the-counter securities in its national market system.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about a Columbia University student who died in a fall from a dormitory window misidentified the college attended by a student who died in a fall earlier in the week. The victim, a 27-year-old medical student, attended the Rockefeller University-Cornell University Medical College.

title: Campaign Trail; Shakespearean Cast To Sunday's Debate
description: Joseph Papp dozed off watching the Big Debate, dreaming of Shakespeare. ''Imagine doing King Lear with Bush, or Macbeth with Dukakis,'' said the producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival. ''With those two there was no passion, no real coming to grips with issues, neither of them threw themselves into the role with any recklessness or abandon. I'd recast the roles. And if these two were reading for me, I'd have to be pretty desperate to cast them. We're talking off-off Broadway with these two.''

title: Paul Cowan, Village Voice Writer And Author of 5 Books, Dies at 48
description: Paul Cowan, a journalist of strong social passions whose book ''An Orphan in History'' influenced thousands of assimilated Jews like himself to recover their Jewish heritage, died of complications from leukemia yesterday at New York University Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: G.A.O. Warns on Jobless Insurance Reserves
description: The unemployment insurance system has enough reserves to last only five months in a severe recession and would have to borrow billions of dollars from the Federal Government to keep paying benefits, the Congressional overseeing agency said today.

title: Graf Pondered Taking Shot at Running
description: The best tennis player in the world is also a big track fan. After finishing first in the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles - when tennis was a demonstration sport -Steffi Graf of West Germany briefly contemplated training for the 800-meter run. She told her brother Michael this one day, when they were jogging on a beach in southern California.

title: Japanese Banker Given New California Mission
description: Like most Japanese companies, the Bank of Tokyo routinely gives its top officers new jobs every three years, in locations that can range from Argentina to France.

title: Vote 'Yes' on the Voter-Assistance Proposal
description: To the Editor:

title: 59th and Lex Goes to Michigan Avenue
description: ''It's a six-ring circus, a six-floor-ring circus,'' said Lyn Gastevich of Chicago, summing up opening day of the new Bloomingdale's store at 900 North Michigan Avenue. It was 10:30 Saturday morning and she was buying a handbag while hordes of customers inched their way through tap dancers, clowns and mimes.

title: Close-Up: Archery
description: Pointing the Way Three men and three women from each country can be entered in individual events. In the preliminary round, men shoot 36 arrows, from 90, 70, 50 and 30 meters; women shoot from from 70, 60, 50 and 30 meters. After that, all but the top 24 scorers are eliminated. Six more are eliminated after each of two 36-arrow rounds, and four more after another round of 36. The eight remaining archers shoot a final 36-arrow round; the top three win medals. Archers have 2 1/2 minutes to shoot three arrows, called an end. If an archer fires before or after the proper time, he loses the highest score in that end. An arrow landing on the line between two rings on the target gets the higher score. Keep an Eye on . . . MenDarrell Pace, U.S., the defending Olympic champion, and Jay Barrs, U.S., Vladimir Esheyev, Soviet Union. WomenYelena Marfel, Soviet Union; Kim Su Nyung, South Korea, and Denise Parker, U.S.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 12 about the annual Afro-American Day Parade in Harlem misidentified marchers. They were the Westchester Invaders from Yonkers.

title: Odds Increase for Sharp Speedup in Testing of U.S. Pesticides
description: The sluggish pace of retesting potentially dangerous pesticides that are now used by the American public would be substantially speeded if legislation approved by the House of Representatives last week is enacted.

title: Stocks Drift Lower as Volume Languishes
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in lethargic, directionless trading.

title: The Tobacco Industry's Last Gasp
description: LEAD: Hold your breath. The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company has announced that, beginning Oct. 1, consumers can purchase Premiers, a new ''smokeless'' cigarette, in test markets in St. Louis, Phoenix and Tucson. Neither smokeless nor safe, the cigarette may be the industry's final gasp before all cigarettes face further Congressional control or an outright ban.

title: William H. Brown, 72, Building Manager
description: William Harmon Brown, a former manager of the New York State office building in Harlem, died of cardiopulmonary arrest on Friday at University Hospital in Washington. He was 72 years old and lived in Washington.

title: After The Debate; Round One Undecisive
description: Many politicians looked to Sunday night's televised debate between Michael S. Dukakis and Vice President Bush as an opportunity for one of the candidates to gain a clear advantage in the 1988 Presidential race. That didn't happen. Instead, the contest was left more muddled than before and as open as it has been at any point since last spring.

title: Fedders Sees Sales Surge
description: The Fedders Corporation, which makes air-conditioners, said today that it expected sales for 1988 to approach $200 million, up about 50 percent from 1987 sales of $129 million. Fedders also said it expected an additional 50 percent gain next year, bringing 1989 sales to about $300 million, assuming normal summer weather and a stable United States dollar.

title: HAITIANS PRESSING FOR NEW ELECTIONS
description: With a brittle calm prevailing in Haiti, political leaders have begun presenting proposals to the new military Government for reinstatement of the Constitution and the scheduling of elections.

title: Rest of the Jets Following O'Brien's Lead
description: ''Mistakes are killing us!'' Coach Weeb Ewbank used to groan about a young Jet team of an earlier era.

title: Chicago Pacific Tells of Suitor
description: The Chicago Pacific Corporation said today that it had recently been approached by a group interested in buying the company at a ''substantial premium'' to current market values.

title: 2 Koreas Are 2 Pieces In a Developing Puzzle
description: It's a shrewd director who knows the effect of his work as well as Lee Chang Ho. At a press conference after ''The Man With Three Coffins,'' the first South Korean film to be shown at the New York Film Festival, he said through an interpreter, ''Thank you for your patience'' - a bluntly honest remark. ''The Man With Three Coffins'' is the kind of film that must be seen twice before it makes sense. But only the most committed and curious students of world cinema may feel that Mr. Lee's artistic rigor is reward enough for struggling through the film's taxing narrative strategy and its obscurity to most Western viewers.

title: Battered Giants Await Taylor
description: In the wake of the Giants' 45-31 rout by Los Angeles, a clarion call has gone out for Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' all-Pro linebacker.

title: Withdrawal of Soviet Troops From Armenia Is Reported
description: Most of the Soviet soldiers sent to the capital of Armenia to quell ethnic tension were withdrawn over the weekend, a local official said today. The official Tass press agency said strikes and demonstrations continued in the republic.

title: Officer Quits United Artists
description: Anthony D. Thomopoulos resigned today as chairman and chief executive of United Artists Pictures, the third high-level executive to depart from the MGM/UA Communications Company in recent weeks.

title: Vatican Acts To Discipline Cleric in Brazil
description: The Vatican has initiated moves to discipline a Spanish-born bishop working in an impoverished region of central Brazil who is closely identified with a doctrine known as liberation theology.

title: A Bolshoi Star Will Join Ballet Theater for a Season
description: Andris Liepa, one of the most acclaimed young stars of the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow, will join American Ballet Theater for the 1988-89 season. With special permission from the director of the Bolshoi Theater and the Soviet Ministry of Culture, he will dance with the company both on tour and during its season at the Metropolitan Opera House, May 8 to July 1, 1989.

title: Tranzonic Companies reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Basil de Ferranti; Parliamentarian, 58
description: Basil de Ferranti, chairman of the British electronics corporation Ferranti and a member of the European Parliament, died Saturday of cancer. He was 58 years old.

title: Is Sentenced In Theft of Jury's Minutes
description: A 49-year-old Manhattan resident who once worked as a printer in the office of the State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, was sentenced yesterday to three years' probation for stealing the minutes of a Dutchess County grand jury that initially investigated the case of Tawana Brawley.

title: Higher Macmillan Bid Seen
description: Several Wall Street professionals predicted yesterday that Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company would raise its buyout bid for Macmillan Inc. today.

title: From Calm to Champagne at the Met
description: Amid the festivities at the Metropolitan Opera last night there sounded a glum note, or more precisely the glum absence of a note. At every other opening night within recent memory, the beloved soprano Licia Albanese, a star from the 30's through the 60's, has been in a center box and has flung a ringing, age-defying high B-flat into the climax of the National Anthem.

title: Republican Platform Puts Fetus Before Mother
description: To the Editor:

title: Population Is Surging In U.S. Pacific Islands
description: Populations of the Pacific islands under United States jurisdiction are skyrocketing, but departures from Puerto Rico are holding down growth there, , the Census Bureau reported Sunday.

title: U.S. Overwhelms Soviets in Semifinal 871
description: The Soviet Union had its first taste of defeat in 1986, and it came as a rude awakening then. Twice within a month, a women's basketball team from the United States beat the Soviets on their home court in Moscow, which prompted a changing of the guards, as well as forwards and even the coach, in an effort to keep up with the rapidly improving Americans.

title: Micron Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: b-Net loss Micron, during the latest fourth quarter, recognized a pre-tax cost of $9.8 million related to product and process rights.

title: Market Place; K Mart Rumors: Some Skepticism
description: AFTER a week of rumors about a possible takeover of the K Mart Corporation, investors became more skeptical yesterday. The stock fell by $1.25, to $38.25, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange, after having run up by $3.125 last week.

title: Iraq Agrees to More Peace Talks With Iran Special to The New York Times
description: The Iraqi Foreign Minister has agreed to resume peace talks on the Persian Gulf war with his Iranian counterpart next Saturday in New York, but only for a single formal meeting, according to diplomats and United Nations officials.

title: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $1,750,000 on the early retirement of debt for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes a $10,100,000 gain from a change in accounting. c-Net loss d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $73,777,000 for the quarter and $34,115,000 for the year, and the year also includes a loss of $29,253,000 on the early retirement of debt. The company said the latest fourth quarter and year results include a $30 million pretax gain on the sale of a shopping center and a $28.5 million pretax charge for operational and facility realignment programs. Year-ago fourth quarter and year results includes a pretax charge of $15.7 million for operational and facility realignment programs. Also included is a pretax loss of $4 million on the sale of John Wanamaker and pretax charges of $23.2 million in direct and other restructuring costs. Fiscal 1987 includes a $6.2 million pretax loss on the sale of John Wanamaker and pretax charges of $48.2 million in direct and other restructuring costs.

title: Friedman Bribery Trial Ends; Judge's Verdict Due Oct. 11
description: Both sides completed summations yesterday in the bribery trial of Stanley M. Friedman, and the state judge hearing the case without a jury said she would hand down her verdict on Oct. 11.

title: Layoff Rumors At First Boston
description: The merger of the First Boston Corporation and its London affiliate, Credit Suisse First Boston, could result in 1,000 or 1,500 layoffs, according to rumors circulating yesterday.

title: Schools Plan New Assault On Drug Use
description: Before the end of December, the Board of Education will require every public school in the city to provide some form of education about drug abuse to students from kindergarten through the 12th grade, the Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green, said yesterday.

title: Dermott F. McCarthy;Advertising Executive, 68
description: Dermott F. McCarthy, a retired advertising executive at Young & Rubicam, died of a stroke Wednesday at his home in Albuquerque, N.M. He was 68 years old.

title: Inquiry Begins Into Police Cadets' Hospitalization
description: Investigations began today at a police academy into whether strenuous exercise contributed to the exhaustion and dehydration that hospitalized 16 cadets, including one who was undergoing a liver transplant.

title: An Anti-Mafia Judge is Shot Dead in Sicily
description: A senior judge who handed down tough sentences against leaders of the Sicilian Mafia was assassinated Sunday night in what the authorities called the first Mafia killing of a sitting judge in recent years. The judge's son was also killed.

title: Salvador TV Dares to Tell the News
description: Barreling past sleepy sentries at the crack of dawn, a caravan of foreign journalists and Salvadoran television reporters sped into the mountains a few months ago to rendezvous with senior commanders of the guerrilla movement fighting the Government.

title: LVMH Names Board Officials
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton announced today that Alain Chevalier would continue to head the world's largest luxury goods conglomerate as president of a six-member board.

title: Rite Aid Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-After income of $47,059,000 from discontinued operations and a $3,712,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Food Stamp Program To Test Plastic Cards
description: Food stamp recipients in three states will soon be able to buy groceries with plastic magnetic cards instead of paper coupons, the Department of Agriculture said today.

title: Burger King to Offer $1 Million Game Prize
description: Pillsbury's Burger King division announced yesterday that it was starting a scratch-a-card game called Triple Jump Checkers on Friday that will have a $1 million first prize among its $140 million in cash and prizes. See how far companies have to go to compete with state lotteries?

title: A Comet in the Making?
description: Chiron, whose diamter of 150 miles makes it one of the largest asteroids, has increased its brightness 2 1/2 times, leading some specialists believe it is shedding gas in the manner of a huge comet. Some day, in the distant future, it may be thrown into the inner solar system, they believe, producing a spectacular display.

title: Campaign Trail; Republicans Target Votes of the Military
description: From the theatrics of the debate to the grittier world of day-to-day politics.

title: Farewell Comments
description: The San Diego Padres' clubhouse was subdued after the club's president, Chub Feeney, announced his resignation less than 24 hours after an obscene gesture to two unappreciative fans. Club officials were silent after Sunday's announcement. Players didn't seem too surprised or concerned, and some were relieved. ''I think it's the best way for the organization to go,'' the pitcher Andy Hawkins said of Saturday's incident. ''Last night couldn't be overlooked.'' The obscene gesture was prompted by two fans who paraded along a stadium walkway during the seventh-inning stretch of the San Diego-Houston game with a banner urging the Padres' owner, Joan Kroc, to ''Scrub Chub.'' Feeney, 67 years old, who was in the owner's box, then waved and retreated to the rear of the box as a chorus of boos erupted from many spectators who witnessed the gesture. Feeney initially denied making the gesture, which was captured by television cameras. He issued an apology Sunday along with his resignation but said the two were unrelated. ''I was going to announce this Wednesday, but I figured I might as well do it now. I will not be coming back next year, not at all,'' Feeney said. ''This was a decision I made about 10 days ago.'' Kroc, owner of the Padres, was unavailable for comment Sunday. Vice President Dick Freeman declined to talk with reporters.(AP)

title: Patterns; Hue and Cry
description: Color, like fashion, runs in cycles. After recent seasons that emphasized ruffles, poufs and a psychedelic clash of colors, designers have reacted with strong, simple silhouettes and bright solid tones. Taking the designers' lead, fashion magazines emblazon the new season's message in their headlines: ''Fall Flash,'' ''Full-Throttle Fuchsia,'' ''Shocking Shearlings,'' ''Color for a Change.'' Elle magazine headlined its September issue ''Knockout Color,'' and featured an essay on color by the French novelist Madeleine Chapsal, who wrote: ''I believe color is life. Color is also love.'' In keeping with such journalistic effusions, retailers seeking to revive sales have stocked displays that fairly scream with chromatic urgency. They hope that after years of neutral colors for daytime clothes, women will be ready to add some color to their closets. But there are risks in electrifying the ready-to-wear palette.

title: Bridge
description: Be wary if someone approaches you, shows you a pair of bridge hands and asks, ''What contract would you like to play?'' There may indeed be a straightforward answer, but frequently your response should be one or more questions: ''Will the defense be perfect, on a double-dummy basis? If not, will the bidding help the opposition find the best opening lead? And what scoring method is in use?''

title: Cincinnati Reconsiders
description: City officials in Cincinnati plan to investigate whether to use nets to catch extra-point kicks at Riverfront Stadium after a fan fell from the stands during Sunday's Cleveland-Cincinnati football game and was seriously injured. Witnesses said the fan, identified as John Knapke, 25, of Dayton, Ohio, was stretching to catch the final extra point booted by the Cleveland Browns' kicker, Matt Bahr, in Sunday's 24-17 loss to Cincinnati when he fell 25 feet from behind a railing to a concrete runway. He was flown by helicopter to the University of Cincinnati Hospital, where he was reported in serious condition yesterday. Mayor Charles Luken has asked City Manager Scott Johnson to investigate improvements that can be made to prevent other such accidents. Those improvements could include using nets behind the Riverfront goalposts to keep kicked footballs from going into the stands, or raising the height of railings at the stadium, Luken said. . . . Bernie Kosar, the injured Cleveland Browns' quarterback, has begun throwing a football lightly as he continues his rehabilitation from a badly sprained elbow. ''He threw a football 20 times for 10 yards Friday,'' Coach Marty Schottenheimer said yesterday. ''They're going to continue with the rehabilitation.'' Kosar was hurt in the Browns' opening game at Kansas City when he was hit on the throwing arm. He has missed three games already and does not appear likely to be reactivated soon.(AP)

title: PRESSURE BUILDING ON NAMIBIAN TALKS
description: Under the pressure of a symbolic anniversary this week, negotiators from Angola, Cuba and South Africa resumed talks today to set a timetable for the withdrawal of 50,000 Cuban troops from Angola.

title: CABINET MINISTER SLAIN IN SRI LANKA
description: A Cabinet minister who had been helping to rebuild two Sri Lankan provinces torn by five years of ethnic violence was assassinated today.

title: The Games at a Glance
description: Track and Field Ben Johnson, the world's fastest man, has been caught - not on the track, but in the laboratory. Johnson, the Canadian sprinter who holds the world record in the 100-meter dash, now also holds the ignominious distinction as the most prominent athlete to have tested positive for use of a banned substance. The urine sample Johnson submitted Saturday after he captured the gold medal in the men's 100 meters, which he won in the astounding time of 9.79 seconds, was found to contain traces of an anabolic steroid. As a result, the International Olympic Committee voted unanimously to strip Johnson of his gold medal. Carl Lewis, who finished second to Johnson in an American record time of 9.92, was awarded the gold medal by the International Amateur Athletic Federation. That decision suddenly gave new life to Lewis's bid to repeat winning four gold medals as he did in 1984. Diving The dive was a reverse 3 1/2-somersault tuck. It was a lot more than that, too. Among other things, it was vintage Greg Louganis and the difference between upset and history. Louganis, requiring a spectacular dive to catch China's 14-year-old Xiong Ni, executed a perfect dive and thus barely edged his upstart rival for the gold medal in the men's platform competition. Louganis also became the only diver ever to win both the springboard and platform events in consecutive Olympics. He won both golds four years ago in Los Angeles. Boxing In a display of common sense rare for this implausible and unpredictable competition, Ken Adams, the coach of the American boxing team, warned his fighters to get their minds off the pot and on the gold. Common sense and Michael Carbajal quickly prevailed. Carbajal, the 106-pound boxer from Phoenix who had done his best to win the team's betting pool for the fastest knockout of the competition, earned a 5-0 decision over Scott Olson of Canada that was as convincing as it was sensible. The quarterfinal victory assures Carbajal of at least a bronze medal. Romallis Ellis, at 132 pounds, also advanced to the semifinals for the United States, beating Emil Tchuprenski of Bulgaria. Basketball It took a dozen years for the Soviet Union's women's team to suffer its first loss in the Olympics. It took only another roughly 48 hours for them to experience their first rout. The United States, getting a combined 53 points from Cynthia Cooper and Katrina McClain, easily handed the Soviet Union its second defeat in Olympic competition, 102-88, as the Americans advanced to the finals on Thursday. The undefeated Americans bolted to a 36-17 lead in the first half and comfortably withstood a pair of late challenges before putting the Soviet Union away for good. The Americans will face Yugoslavia, who they beat by 27 points earlier in the tournament, for the gold medal.

title: Kevlin Microwave Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Priest in Bronx Is Found Slain At His House
description: A priest, who neighbors said had been trying to build a church for Albanian Roman Catholics in the Bronx, was found strangled and shot to death yesterday in his house after concerned parishioners had called the police.

title: James Boatwright 3d, Editor, Is Dead at 54
description: James Boatwright 3d, editor of the literary review Shenandoah, died of AIDS on Sunday at his home in Key West, Fla. He was 54 years old and also lived in Lexington, Va.

title: U.S. and Soviets Discuss Curbing Missile Exports
description: American and Soviet officials today held their first in-depth discussions of ways to curb the spread of ballistic missiles to the third world.

title: Games of Chance
description: ACTUALLY wagering your own money while you are learning how to play a game can be painfully expensive.

title: Nissan Weighs U.S. Step
description: The Nissan Motor Company is considering setting up a headquarters in the United States to oversee production, sales and new car development there, a Nissan spokesman said today. Nissan now owns the Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation U.S.A., a production unit in Smyrna, Tenn.; Nissan Research and Development Inc. in Ann Arbor, Mich., and the Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A., a sales unit in Carson, Calif.

title: After the Debate; The Man With No Money To Buy Health Insurance
description: Charles Strickland's name was not used, but his story was told twice in the debate Sunday night between the Presidential candidates.

title: Arthur Andersen to Study How to Prevent Defections
description: Arthur Andersen & Company will undertake a study to try to determine how to prevent defections from its huge and successful management consulting practice, the firm said yesterday.

title: United Illuminating reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
description: b-Net loss The latest 12 months' earnings included a gain equal to 19 cents a share from an accounting change.

title: Researcher Is Criticized For Test of Journal Bias
description: A SOCIAL worker who sent a fictitious article to scientific journals in a test for bias is now facing charges of unethical conduct because he conducted his study without the consent of the journal editors.

title: CONGRESS LEADERS AND WHITE HOUSE AGREE ON WELFARE
description: After three months of fitful negotiations, leaders of a House-Senate conference and White House officials today agreed on the first major revision of the welfare system in 53 years, including the first federally mandated work program for welfare recipients.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Preferred Stock

title: Review/Theater; Calvin Trillin Punctures Those Who Go Too Far
description: If humorists thrive in adversity, Calvin Trillin is an anomaly. As he describes himself in his one-man show, ''Calvin Trillin's Uncle Sam'' (at the American Place Theater), he is a happy husband, father and author. But he is not complacent, and it is from that fact that he draws his telling comic arsenal.

title: Auto Executive Predicts Payroll Cutbacks
description: The head of Renault, the large European auto maker, predicts that stiffening competition and a trend toward relying more on outside suppliers will lead automobile companies to make sharp reductions in employment in the next few years.

title: 26 Demonstrators Arrested After Blocking Capitol Road
description: Twenty-six demonstrators, protesting the lack of affordable housing, were arrested today when they blocked a road on the grounds of the United States Capitol, the police said.

title: E.P.A. Chief Asks Total Ban on Ozone-Harming Chemicals
description: The head of the Environmental Protection Agency called today for the complete elimination of chemicals believed to be destroying the earth's ozone shield, rather than the 50 percent reduction that a recently negotiated international treaty would require.

title: Reviews/Music; Giving Voice to Poetry, In Lee Hoiby's Settings
description: Lee Hoiby's vocal music holds a special place in the contemporary American art song literature, and on Sunday the National Association of Teachers of Singing celebrated his contribution in a concert at the Mannes College of Music. With the composer at the piano, four young singers offered some fine examples of Mr. Hoiby's work.

title: Johnson's Testing Leaves Questions
description: The drug test that resulted in a drastic punishment of Ben Johnson today - he was stripped of a gold medal, a world record, his Canadian Government funding of $650 a month and his potentially vast endorsement income -raised a tangle of questions.

title: Fuller, H B reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Bottle-Law Violations Penalize the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Polls at the Pubs
description: What would you call a cocktail made of light rum, ''nectar of the bogs'' (Massachusetts cranberry juice), orange juice and raspberry liqueur? The Duke, of course. And how about a blend of tequila, ''Texas crude'' (Alamo ruby red grapefruit juice), orange juice and peach schnapps? The Veep, naturally. For the past week, the powers that be at two Capital watering holes, Clyde's and the Old Ebbitt Grill, have been conducting their own brand of Presidential preference poll by tallying sales of the drinks.

title: Review/Dance; Passion and Rage in 2 Parts
description: ''Heat'' evoked city streets on sweltering nights, and its emotional temperature was that of passion fueled by rage. Conceived and choreographed by Jawole Willa Jo Zollar and directed by Ms. Zollar and Laurie Carlos, the ambitious multimedia production was offered Saturday night at the Kitchen by Urban Bush Women, Ms. Zollar's dance company; members of a group of writers and performers called Thought Music, and Craig Harris and his band, the Dirty Tones.

title: Nathan H. Gates; Lawyer, 78
description: Nathan Henry Gates, a lawyer, died after a stroke Sunday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan and Bridgehampton, L.I.

title: Trial Opens for Rowan in Shooting of Trespasser
description: Carl T. Rowan, the columnist and outspoken advocate of gun control, went on trial here today for possessing the unregistered pistol with which he shot a teen-age intruder at his home June 14.

title: William F. Bramstedt; Oil Executive, 83
description: William Frederick Bramstedt, a retired executive with the Standard Oil Company of California, died Thursday after a long illness at his home in San Francisco. He was 83 years old.

title: Research Studies Tobacco-Breast Cancer Link
description: AN analysis of cancer rates throughout the world has suggested that exposure to tobacco smoke might induce breast cancer in women decades later. The analysis, by Dr. A. Wesley Horton, a public health specialist at the Oregon Health Sciences University in Portland, found that a a rise in tobacco consumption was followed by a rise in lung cancer rates and the incidence of breast cancer.

title: Nobel Winner to Head Gene Project
description: DR. JAMES D. WATSON, who won the Nobel Prize for work in deciphering the structure of DNA, has been appointed an associate director of the National Institutes of Health to coordinate efforts to map, identify and define all of the human genes.

title: Sears-I.B.M. Venture Starts Drive
description: ALVIN TOFFLER, the futurist; Linda Ellerbee, the journalist, and Dave Johnson, the manager of the New York Mets, all took to the television airwaves yesterday in three widely scattered spot markets in behalf of the Prodigy Services Company, which provides a myriad of electronic informational, educational, functional and entertainment services to owners of personal computers.

title: Sociology Is Open to New Approaches
description: To the Editor:

title: Judges' Views on Eastern
description: Two Federal appeals judges suggested today that business considerations and not union-busting tactics motivated Eastern Airlines' decision to lay off 4,000 workers.

title: 3 U.S. Trainers in Salvador Exchanged Fire With Rebels
description: Three American military trainers stationed in El Salvador fired on guerrillas when the Americans were caught in a crossfire two weeks ago between the rebels and Salvadoran Army troops, a Pentagon spokeswoman said tonight.

title: 'Pass, American!'
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Debate; Bush and Running Mate Join at Tennessee Rally
description: A buoyant Vice President Bush appeared today for the first time in weeks with Senator Dan Quayle in a carefully orchestrated expression of confidence in his running mate.

title: Chess
description: The 55th Soviet championship ended last month in Moscow in a tie for first place between the world champion, Gary Kasparov, and his perpetual challenger, Anatoly Karpov. The two giants of the chess world topped an impressive field with identical 11 1/2-5 1/2 scores.

title: After the Debate; BUSH CAMP OFFERS A CLARIFIED STAND ABOUT ABORTIONS
description: Vice President Bush concluded after Sunday night's debate that women who have abortions should not suffer any criminal penalties, but doctors who perform them should, his campaign chairman said today.

title: Sweep Of Long Jump For U.S.
description: The United States had its best performance so far in Olympic track and field Monday, winning six medals, with Carl Lewis leading a sweep in the men's long jump and Roger Kingdom winning the men's 110-meter hurdles.

title: Irving Says Suitor Made Rival Flee
description: The Irving Bank Corporation yesterday sued the Bank of New York Company, asserting that it improperly persuaded Banca Commerciale Italiana to withdraw its friendly bid for Irving last August.

title: In Ashes of Burned Forests, a Rare Chance to Study Nature's Recovery
description: IT is among nature's most dramatic scenes: fire that sounds like a jumbo jetliner, yellow, red and blue flames soaring hundreds of feet into the air, lighting the night sky for miles, throwing leg-sized embers hundreds of yards ahead and consuming all the cabins, cars and towering trees in its path.

title: Interco Gives Data To Rales Brothers
description: Interco Inc. has given confidential financial information to the Rales brothers of Washington about the proposed sale of its Ethan Allen furniture division. Selling the unit is an essential component of the St. Louis-based company's restructuring, with a stated value of $76 a share. The effort is intended to thwart a hostile offer from the brothers, Steven M. and Mitchell P. Rales. Analysts have estimated that the subsidiary could be sold for $1 billion.

title: Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
Lautenberg's Style: Easygoing but Biting
description: Out on the campaign trail, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg likes to tell the story of his father's stint as a saloonkeeper. The elder Lautenberg opened an establishment in Paramus in the 1930's but, being rather a straight arrow, he set a strict two-drink limit and prohibited profanity.

title: Failure Admitted By OPEC
description: After five years of trying to reverse the drop in oil prices, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that the effort had failed and that it had to search for ''a new approach'' or face the possibility of another collapse of prices next year.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is incumbent upon all civilized nations to ban, once and for all, and on a verifiable and global basis, the use of chemical and gas warfare.'' - President Reagan, addressing the United Nations. [ A1:5. ]

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Corrections
description: A transcript of the debate between Vice President Bush and Michael S. Dukakis rendered a word incorrectly yesterday in Mr. Dukakis's answer about his running mate, Senator Lloyd Bentsen. Mr. Dukakis said, ''But I didn't pick Lloyd Bentsen because he was a clone of Mike Dukakis'' (not ''client'' of Mr. Dukakis).

title: When East and West First Met, 14,000 Years Ago
description: Fourteen thousand years before the Cold War, the peoples of Siberia and Alaska had considerably more contact than they do today. It is perhaps appropriate that this prehistoric precursor of detente should be the subject of ''Crossroads of Continents: Cultures of Siberia and Alaska,'' the first museum exhibition organized jointly by Soviet and American curators.

title: Researchers Detect Chemical Differences In Muscle Fatigue
description: THE sense of fatigue felt after strenuous physical exercise may differ biochemically from the tiredness felt after a hard day at the office, researchers using a new device have found.

title: Borman's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 6 months included inventory charges of $465,000 and $1,085,000, respectively, and the year-earlier quarter and 6 months included inventory charges of $285,000 and $665,000, respectively. The company said year-ago figures are restated to reflect change to equity accounting for S E G Stores.

title: Biederman Gets Job For Alcoholic Beverage
description: Euro-Trade, a New Orleans importer, has come to New York to hire Biederman & Company to make ads for Tarkhuna, a vodka-like alcoholic beverage named for the Georgian herb it is flavored with.

title: Study of New Jobs Since '79 Says Half Pay Poverty Wage
description: Half the new jobs created in the United States in the last eight years were at wages below the poverty level for a family of four, a Senate report said today.

title: Johnson Loses Gold to Lewis After Drug Test
description: Ben Johnson of Canada, who won the Olympic 100-meter final Saturday in the world-record time of 9.79 seconds, was stripped of his gold medal and today was disqualified from the Games after drug tests showed he had used an anabolic steroid.

title: Researchers Pit Alien Wasp Against a Beetle
description: SCIENTISTS have begun releasing imported wasps into a grove of eucalyptus trees in an effort to save the trees from beetles that have infested the grove and others like it across Southern California. The wasps, like the trees and the beetles, originated in Australia.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Two Tied in Metropolitan: Rick Meskell of the Century Country Club and Scott Dietrich of the Brayburn Country Club were tied for the lead yesterday in the opening round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship at the Inwood (L.I.) Country Club. They both were at two-under par 70.

title: Police Informer Is Slain in Idaho Prison Uprising
description: An inmate who was identified in court papers as a police informer was killed in his cell Sunday while other prisoners went on a rampage, the authorities said.

title: Dow Joins Venture To Recycle Plastics
description: The Dow Chemical Company and Domtar Inc. of Montreal will form a company to recycle plastic bottles. The 50-50 venture will retrieve from the trash of the two countries polyethylene terephthalate and high-density polyethylene plastics, which make up about 90 percent of the plastics used in bottles for milk, soft drinks and other products.

title: U.S. ASKS STIFF BAN ON CHEMICAL ARMS
description: In a farewell speech that was his most laudatory toward the United Nations, President Reagan called today for a new international effort to stiffen the ban on using chemical weapons.

title: On Horse Racing; Handicapping the Confusion
description: Alysheba beat Forty Niner by a neck in the Woodward Handicap. Forty Niner beat Seeking the Gold by a nose in the Travers Stakes. Seeking the Gold beat Happyasalark Tomas by a neck in the Super Derby. Does this mean that Alysheba, a champion who has won nearly $5 million, is only two necks and a nose a better horse than the obscure and unaccomplished Happyasalark Tomas?

title: Soviet Press Hears Unwanted News
description: A backlash against the increasingly unbridled Soviet press appears to have gained a new and unexpected convert: Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Zenith Strikes 2 Key Defenses
description: In response to pressure from an investor group led by the arbitragers Herbert B. Abelow and Nicholas L. Ihasz, the Zenith Electronics Corporation's board today voted to dismantle two of the company's key takeover defenses.

title: Study Finds Ways to Fight Career Malaise
description: A new study of professionals who were intensely dissatisfied with their careers, feeling bored or trapped in roles that did not meet their expectations, has identified traits that seem to help some people emerge from these periods of malaise with renewed happiness and satisfaction in their lives.

title: Thornburgh Criticizes F.B.I. for Lobbying Against Gun Legislation
description: The Justice Department issued a rare public criticism today of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, ordering the F.B.I. and all other law-enforcement agencies in the department to speak with one voice before Congress.

title: Ohio Mattress Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The latest year operating results included 9 months of the operations of the Sealy acquisitions that were acquired in December 1986, versus 8 months in the prior year. The share earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on July 22, 1988.

title: Difficulties Speed Up Succession at Centerior
description: The Centerior Energy Corporation, a holding company for two large Ohio utilities, moved its succession timetable ahead yesterday and named Richard A. Miller as its chairman and chief executive.

title: Dawkins on the Road in Quest for Voters
description: At the White House Sub Shop - ''World Famous Since 1946,'' according to the sign out front - Pete Dawkins moved from booth to booth, televison cameras in tow, introducing himself to the diners.

title: Republican and Liberal And Proud to Be Both
description: To the Editor:

title: Burma Opposition Names Leader
description: U Aung Gyi, a retired army officer who broke with the country's longtime ruler, U Ne Win, and became the country's leading dissident, today was named chairman of a newly formed opposition alliance.

title: Campaign Trail; Baseball Steps Aside For Omaha Debate
description: Because of the debate between the Vice-Presidential candidates, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana and Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, baseball fans will now have to reshuffle their schedules.

title: Houston Counts on Success by Space Shuttle to Lift Its Sluggish Economy
description: As Gerry Griffin and his brother, Larry, watch the liftoff of the space shuttle Discovery on monitors at Mission Control at the Johnson Space Center near here Thursday morning, they will probably see more than just a hefty white machine flying into orbit.

title: Computer Components Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $217,598 and $393,227 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $4,964 for the quarter and $40,078 for the year.

title: SmithKline's Revamping to Cut 1,600 Jobs
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation announced a restructuring yesterday that includes spinning off its Beckman Instruments division and dismissing 1,600 employees. The company also said that its earnings would drop as much as 17 percent this year.

title: 2 Czechoslovak Delegations Will Soon Be Sent to Israel
description: Czechoslovakia, which has had no diplomatic relations with Israel since 1967, will soon send two delegations to that country to deal with consular and economic matters, an Israeli spokesman said today.

title: Agency's Loan Role In Danger
description: In the closing days of the 100th Congress, an initiative supported by organized labor could block renewal of an operating charter for the 19-year-old Government agency that insures American investment overseas.

title: Richardson Electronics Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Casablanca Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $715,000 from discontinued operations for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes an extraordinary credit of $2,220,000.

title: Education; Government Delays Tougher Loan Default Rules
description: The Department of Education's proposal to cut off Federal aid to colleges and trade schools whose former students have high rates of defaulting on loans has drawn such concerted opposition that the department has essentially agreed to let the next Administration decide how best to reduce the total of $1.6 billion in defaults.

title: Rowe Furniture Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Jam or Jelly? What's What
description: THE Federal Government lumps jams and preserves into one category for regulatory purposes, mandating a fruit content of at least 45 percent. There are, however, distinct differences.

title: WSMP Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 12
description: b-Included a $1,412,000 pre-tax gain on the disposition of restaurant properties.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: The Senate; For Lugar of Indiana, the Torch Passes to a New Generation
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar sat in a rocking chair in his Capitol Hill office, sipping coffee and recalling the times he was not chosen as a Vice-Presidential nominee.

title: Taylor Reinstated, N.F.L. Tells Giants
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' All-Pro linebacker, completed his 30-day suspension for substance abuse today and was expected to rejoin the team in time for practice.

title: Northeast Utilities reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
description: The prior 12 months' results are restated to reflect the writeoff of Connecticut Light and Power Co.'s disallowed portion of its Millstone 3 investment.

title: Athletes Doubt Drug Use Will Diminish
description: Igor Ter-Ovanesyan of the Soviet Union and Don Quarrie of Jamaica were once Olympic track and field champions, and Roger Kingdom of Monroeville, Pa., is an Olympic champion now. Patrick Sang of Kenya and Domingos Castro of Portugal rank among the world's leading distance runners. John Smith of Los Angeles was once a world record-holder and now coaches an Olympic champion.

title: Review/Television; Behind the Munich Pact
description: The 1938 Munich Agreement, by which Britain and France gave Hitler the go-ahead to take over the Sudetenland, stands as one of the more shameful episodes leading to World War II. Nothing in ''The Peace of Paper'' is designed to change that estimate, but it helps us to understand the play of forces behind what is called here ''a symbol of diplomatic naivete and military weakness.''

title: Panamanian Accuses U.S. of a 'War'
description: A Panamanian leader today accused the United States of waging ''economic war'' against his country and declared that his Government had ''grave reasons'' to fear military aggression.

title:
Education;
Alternative Certificates: New Paths to Teaching
description: LEAD: For six years after he got his undergraduate degree in philosophy, Robert Pollock remodeled homes for a living. Now, after three weeks of training, he is a teacher in the Houston Independent School District.

title: Publisher Has Birthday Party for T.S. Eliot at 100
description: In the room the people came and went Talking of T. S. Eliot.

title: I.B.M. Sets $2 Billion Stock Buyback
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its board had authorized the repurchase of up to $2 billion worth of its capital stock.

title: Qume Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company, formerly Data Technology Corp., said its latest quarter and 6 months' figures included the results of Compac Microelectronics Inc., acquired in December 1987 in a transaction accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Economic Scene; Back-Door Attack On Tax 'Reform'
description: WILL the Tax Reform Act of 1986, the sweeping tax law that only fully came into effect this year, survive the next Presidential administration?

title: I.L.O. Chemical Report
description: The world's chemical industry faces tougher competition and possible job losses despite a probable rise in demand, the International Labor Organization said today. A report by the trade union umbrella group saw prospects of higher demand for chemicals in the food, clothing and health sectors, but added, ''In this brave new world, competition will be tougher.''

title: Fewer Businesses Affected by Parental Leave Bill
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, today won Senate approval to modify his bill that would require employers to offer unpaid leaves to workers so they could care for newborn, newly adopted or seriously ill children.

title: Colleges Must Learn Some Fiscal Responsibility; Bush's Aid for the Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: Apartment Building Collapse Kills 2 and Traps 4 in Mexico
description: A six-story apartment building collapsed today, killing two people and trapping about four others in the rubble, officials said.

title: Bank Board's Admission: Rescues Rushed Needlessly
description: After weeks of rushing to complete rescues of savings institutions before Oct. 1, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had misunderstood the budgetary process and had not been under deadline pressure to complete deals.

title: Campaign Trail; Losing a Diamond To Campaign Chic
description: Mr. Bentsen may not seem as nervous about the debate as his rival, but the Texas Senator and his wife, B.A., are plainly uneasy about appearing, well, too Republican.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a deal involving the Amstar Corporation described the transaction incorrectly in some editions.

title: Toys 'R' Us Insider Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged a former official of Toys ''R'' Us Inc. with illegal insider trading of options on the toy retailer's stock while he possessed a confidential forecast of better-than-expected sales in the 1986 Christmas season.

title: For Reservations, Dial NBC
description: ON Oct. 26 New York will have another new restaurant.

title: Chaus, Bernard Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Net income Corrected from Saturday, Sept. 24, editions.

title: Correction on Debate Text
description: A transcript of the debate between Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in Winston-Salem, N.C., printed on Monday, omitted part of an answer by Mr. Bush. Following is the question, with his complete answer: Q. Well, Mr. Vice President, you said you met Secretary General Gorbachev, you have met with Mr. Shevardnadze, but for the last 40 years, Americans have been taught to regard the Soviet Union as the enemy. Yet President Reagan has signed two arms control treaties and he has promised to share ''Star Wars'' technology with the very country he once called the evil empire, so perhaps you could tell us this evening, should we be doing a lot to help the economics and the social development of a country that we have so long considered as an adversary? BUSH: What I think we ought to do is take a look at perestroika and glasnost, welcome them, but keep our eyes open, be cautious, because the Soviet change is not fully established yet. Yes, I think it's fine to do business with them, but I don't want to see us exporting our highly sensitive national security oriented technology to the Soviet Union. I don't want to see us making unilateral cuts in our strategic system, while we are negotiating with them, and so I'm encouraged by what I hear when I talk to Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Shevardnadze. But can they pull it off?

title: Determining The Winner, And the Time
description: One of the enduring images of the 1988 Olympics is likely to be Ben Johnson, the Canadian sprinter, left, winning the 100- meter dash, his arm triumphantly aloft. Two days later, he lost the medal to Carl Lewis of the United States after tests showed he had used an anabolic steroid.

title: Sports People; Coach's Pact Extended
description: The Portland Trail Blazers have extended the contract of Mike Schuler, one of only eight coaches in National Basketball Association history to win 100 games in his first two seasons, for three years through the 1990-91 season. No financial terms were disclosed. Schuler's Trail Blazers had a 49-33 record in his first season and were 53-29 last season. Schuler was an assistant to Don Nelson in Milwaukee for three years before succeeding Jack Ramsay as coach at Portland in May 1986. (AP)

title: Senator Adams Disputes Sex Assault Charge
description: Senator Brock Adams, a Washington Democrat, today called a news conference to deny allegations by the daughter of family friends that he sexually assaulted her when she spent the night at his home a year and a half ago.

title: Mubarak, in Europe, Stresses Role as Peace Broker
description: With a European tour that took him today to Paris, President Hosni Mubarak has cast himself more forcefully than in recent months as a broker and central figure in the stalled quest for a Middle East peace.

title: Meskell Leading Met by 2 Strokes
description: Rick Meskell, assistant pro at the Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., held the lead yesterday after two days of play in the Izod Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship at the Inwood Country Club. Meskell, a 36-year-old resident of Wayne, N.J., shot his second straight 70 for a four-under-par total of 140 as the reduced field prepared for the final day of play.

title: Shahid Tammtk Journal; The Bounty of the Desert: Tomatoes and Rebellion
description: On a patch of oasis here, a seemingly endless sea of sand is broken by a clump of lush greenery that provides subsistence, if barely, for thousands of people.

title: Sanford Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Give Regan Credit for Investment Record and Campaign Views
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Nets Player Arrested
description: Under the terms of the league's drug policy, Duane Eddy Washington, who joined the Nets in the final weeks of last season and played in 15 games, faces expulsion from the National Basketball Association if he is convicted of possession of cocaine. According to Capt. George Dickscheid of the Newark Police Department, the 24-year-old Washington, a guard, was arrested by two policemen in Newark last Sunday after they investigated a car that was parked on the wrong side of the street with Washington in the driver's seat. Washington tried driving away but was blocked by a double-parked car, the police said. While questioning Washington, the police reported, they spotted several clear glass vials believed to be cocaine in a pouch on the inside of the driver's door. Washington was charged with possession of cocaine and possession of a controlled substance in a vehicle. He was released on a $10,000 personal recognizance bond. Aside from a conviction, if there was evidence of cocaine or heroin use, the N.B.A could request permission from an arbitator to test Washington for drug consumption. If he tested positive, he would be banned from the league for failure to come forward. Brian McIntyre, an N.B.A. spokesman, said yesterday that the league was investigating.

title: CutCo Industries reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding in 1987 reflected adjustment for a 10 percent stock dividend distributed on Aug. 17, 1987 to stockholders of record on Aug. 3, 1987.

title: Thousands of Western Books Placed on Exhibit in Moscow
description: Dozens of Soviet citizens got a chance to browse through stacks of American books today at a trade exhibit in Moscow.
