title: Review/Film; Hands Across the Channel
description: Can a young woman from the British middle class find happiness in France with a working-class youth of radical disposition? That is the question posed and answered in ''Nanou,'' which opens today at Film Forum 1. Produced in French and English, it introduces the work of Conny Templeman, a young British director and writer. Rather like her heroine, Ms. Templeton displays a feeling for French working-class ways as well as an agreeably light approach to her actors and to individual scenes. Unfortunately, the writer has shortchanged the director; once we catch onto the theme, the story saunters along a touch predictably.

title: Dukakis Assails Bush on Social Security
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts took his attacks against Vice President Bush to the Midwestern city that has symbolized mainstream America for generations of vaudevillians and politicians, and portrayed his opponent as a threat to the Social Security system.

title: Hurricane Helene's Winds Fall
description: The once-mighty winds of Hurricane Helene have fallen from 140 miles per hour to 85 m.p.h. as the storm continues to push north over colder mid-Atlantic waters. Forecasters are predicting that the storm will be downgraded to tropical storm status within the next two days. ''It's just barely a hurricane right now,'' Jim Gross, a forecaster at the National Hurricane Center, said today. The hurricane was spawned last week near the Cape Verde Islands off west Africa.

title: Questions Push Regina Stock Down
description: The chairman of the Regina Company, the vacuum cleaner maker, resigned yesterday, and the company reported that its financial statements for the fiscal year ended June 30 were ''materially incorrect.''

title: Book Notes
description: New Post for Seaver

title: Concern Grows Over Steroids
description: Anabolic steroids are compounds that cause the body to build up muscle and other tissue. As growing numbers of athletes have begun using them in recent years, medical experts have expressed deep concern about their dangers.

title: Soccer Stars in Jersey
description: A game involving a number of the world's legendary soccer players will be staged at Giants Stadium Oct. 29.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Sports of The Times; Johnson's Ban A Lifesaver
description: THE banishment of Ben Johnson - say it ain't so, Ben - is a gloomy affair, the world's fastest human slinking out of town on a jet plane, still insisting he had been framed.

title: Anti-Nausea Drug Gains Against Lawsuits
description: LEAD: For the second time in four weeks, a Federal appeals court has absolved the prescription drug Bendectin of any role in causing deformities in the children of women who took it to alleviate nausea in pregnancy.

title: Note Offering Set By Austrian Bank
description: The Austrian Bank (Oesterreichische Kontrollbank A.G.) has established a $300 million medium-term note program guaranteed by Austria. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets arranged the program.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Datapoint Corp., San Antonio, said a leveraged buyout group that had previously offered to buy the company for $6 a share had withdrawn its offer after Datapoint's financial adviser, Prudential-Bache, deemed the offer inadequate.

title: U.S. Backs Trainers in Salvador Who Fired
description: Commenting on a firefight involving guerrillas and United States military advisers in El Salvador, President Reagan said today that he would never deny the advisers ''the right to defend themselves.''

title: Teddy Bears' Work Is Never Done
description: LEAD: EIGHTY-SIX years after teddy bears were first stuffed, sewn and sold, the tubby, fuzzy creatures are busier than ever.

title: Belgian Inflation Rises
description: Belgium's annual inflation rate stood at 1.21 percent in September, the highest this year, the Government reported today. The Belgian Ministry of Economy said the rate compared with 0.91 percent in August and 1.01 in July.

title: Yanks Watch in Anticipation
description: Call it the curious case of the American League East. The Boston Red Sox cannot close out a division race that seemed theirs for the taking last Sunday afternoon. The Yankees keep winning and keep wondering.

title: KEY RATES
EATING WELL
description: IT is getting difficult to find the standard garden variety of ice cream in the supermarket today. Light, low-calorie, low-fat, no-cholesterol, lactose-free alternatives are crowding out the familiar products.

title: Britain-Iran Talks May Yield Diplomatic Thaw
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, said today that he would meet with Iran's Foreign Minister here on Friday as a possible prelude to restoring normal diplomatic relations.

title: Juno Lighting Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in the form of a stock dividend in May 1987.

title: Review/Film; Of Lobsters and Love
description: As a Hollywood movie extra named Abe Polin, Alan King dresses in a lobster costume. There is a joke about melted butter. Abe's son, Abbie (Billy Crystal), is visiting from New York, so they go to a bar where the heart-surgeon son quietly drinks Perrier while crass old Dad sits at the piano and belts out ''Too Pooped to Pop.'' He ends by announcing: ''No applause. Just throw money.''

title: Nobility Homes reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about clashes between Palestinians and Israeli forces misstated the location of the Jabal Mukabeh neighborhood in some copies. It is in East Jerusalem.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Diving; Louganis At Best In Test Of Will
description: These Olympics tested his courage and, ultimately, his will to succeed. At the age of 28, 12 years after he made his first splash in diving - winning a silver medal in Montreal - Greg Louganis today gave what was probably the finest performance of his career in Seoul, overcoming adversity and his heir apparent, to earn a place among the great champions of the Summer Games.

title: Genentech Sees Lower Drug Sales
description: Genentech Inc. said today that sales of its flagship product, tissue plasminogen activator, or TPA, would be lower than expected in the third quarter and that as a result, its earnings would be flat, compared with the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Stride Rite Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
Corrections
description: An article on May 20 about Stefan Olszowski, a former Polish politician who immigrated to the United States in 1986, described some of Mr. Olszowski's continuing Polish ties incorrectly. He says he did not meet in May 1987 with Jozef Czyrek, who is now Foreign Minister of Poland.

title: Trade Gap With Japan
description: The United States trade deficit with Japan will probably shrink but never be eliminated entirely, a Congressional expert told the House Committee on Foreign Affairs today. ''Under any scenario, we're going to have a trade deficit with Japan,'' said Allan Mendelowitz, a senior associate director with the General Accounting Office, the research branch of Congress.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Opto Mechanik Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Both Macmillan Suitors Raise the Ante
description: In quick succession yesterday, the two rival bidders for Macmillan Inc. announced higher takeover offers for the publishing and information services company.

title: Corrections
description: A transcript of the debate between Vice President Bush and Michael S. Dukakis, printed on Monday, omitted part of an answer by Mr. Bush. The passage is printed today on page A25.

title: Scientist Says Low Radon Levels May Be Harmless
description: Although exposure to high levels of the radioactive gas radon causes lung cancer, exposure to low concentrations of the gas may present no hazard at all, an environmental physicist asserted today at the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society.

title: New Haiti Chiefs Charm 3 Backers of Democracy
description: Three former presidential candidates came out of a meeting with Haiti's new military leaders today charmed and optimistic that the country would soon be heading toward democracy.

title: About New York; Doctor's Dream: Healthy Profits From Sore Feet
description: Canadians like Ben Johnson and Wayne Gretzky have no trouble getting their names in the paper. Were it so simple for Dr. Glenn Copeland, a Toronto podiatrist with a dream.

title: Astronauts to Have Many New Ways to Escape
description: If serious problems should arise in the space shuttle mission scheduled Thursday, changes in the spacecraft and support gear will give the Discovery astronauts many new ways to escape.

title: Campaign Trail; Playing Peoria, Dukakis Is Pleased
description: The Presidential rivals are now focusing on Illinois, a crucial state where polls show a close race.

title: Steeped in Tradition, Stepping Toward the Future
description: IT happens now and then when one turns onto the noble, tree-lined avenue leading up to the great portico of Chateau Margaux. For a fleeting moment, the perception and the reality of Bordeaux become one: a harmonious blend of nature, tradition and refinement, a singular way of life.

title: WINE TALK
description: ONE reports on exclusive wine tastings with misgivings.

title: OLYMPIC HIGHLIGHTS
description: TRACK AND FIELDCarl Lewis's bid to repeat his sweep of four gold medals, revived after the disqualification of Ben Johnson, was ended in the final strides of the 200-meter dash as a teammate, Joe DeLoach, sprinted past him to win the gold medal. In the 400-meter run, the United States swept the first three places, with the winner, Steve Lewis, timed in 43.87 seconds. Butch Reynolds, the world record-holder, won the silver and Danny Everett the bronze. Florence Griffith Joyner set an

title: Stocks Retreat Broadly as Dow Drops 2.84
description: Stock prices ended broadly lower yesterday as investors continued to shun a directionless market.

title: Koch Is Losing The Support Of Politicians
description: Mayor Koch is apparently as unpopular among his fellow politicians as polls indicate he is with the public.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Bilzerian Seeking Fortune Financial
description: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida financier, said he had sent a letter to Fortune Financial Group Inc. seeking talks on a possible $157.8 million buyout of the savings and loan company. Mr. Bilzerian already owns 9.9 percent of the company, based in Clearwater, Fla., and his offer would be $35 a share for the rest of Fortune Financial's shares. Shares of Fortune Financial rose $2.75, closing at $30.50 in over-the-counter trading. Separately, Fortune Financial said its board would consider the offer as well as other alternatives to maximize value for its shareholders. Fortune owns the Fortune Savings Bank and has mortgage, appraisal services and leasing units.

title: Citicorp Rates Rise at Auction
description: For the first time in four weeks, interest rates rose yesterday at Citicorp's auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE first dish I ever made for a customer as a cook's teen-age apprentice in France was an omelet. Making the perfect omelet - smooth and lightly browned outside, moist and well seasoned within - is a technique about which I have written often over the years. Italians have their own version of an omelet, called frittata, and it can be equally delicious.

title: Readicare Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GENERAL QUITTING AS PROJECT CHIEF FOR MISSILE SHIELD
description: In a surprise announcement, the Pentagon said today that Lieut. Gen. James A. Abrahamson of the Air Force had resigned as director of the research program to develop a space-based anti-missile defense.

title: Commerce Savings Buyout Talks Held
description: The American Century Corporation, the parent of Commerce Savings Association, has discussed a buyout of the Texas savings institution with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. The disclosure of the talks was contained in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing by a Dallas investor, G. H. Stool, who is a director of American Century. Commerce Savings operates 18 branches from its headquarters in San Antonio.

title: National Medical Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Irwin Novograd, 81, Longtime Stable Owner
description: Irwin Novograd, who with his family has operated the Claremont Riding Academy on West 89th Street in Manhattan for 45 years, died of a stroke Monday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: To Our Readers
description: Philip H. Dougherty, writer of the Advertising column for 22 years, died yesterday. The column does not appear today; other writers will resume it tomorrow. An obituary of Mr. Dougherty is on page D35.

title: A Cafe of Poets Is Turning 100
description: LEAD: AS Jose Lopez de Brito remembers from his teen-age years, when Ernest Hemingway was a frequent patron of Gran Cafe de Gijon, the American writer insisted on one rule: Tourists were not to take pictures of him.

title: A.C.L.U. Goes Hollywood in Countering Bush's Campaign of Derision
description: Next week Burt Lancaster will look out from television screens in Southern California and confess, ''I am a card-carrying member of the A.C.L.U.''

title: Thatcher Sees Benefits for West If Gorbachev Reshapes U.S.S.R.
description: Comparing her own experience in Britain to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's attempt to reshape the Soviet Union, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that it was ''in the Western interest'' for Mr. Gorbachev to succeed in his effort.

title: Education; About Education
description: The phone rings. ''Hello, it's me,'' a boy says, ''I need help with my homework.'' Maalfrid Grude Flekkoy says she is sorry, but that's something to take up with his teacher or parents.

title: The Victims of the Brawley Case
description: After seven months of investigation, a grand jury seems ready to offer persuasive evidence that Tawana Brawley's claim of racial and sexual victimization was a lie. Welcome as it is, that report will only begin to vindicate the real victims in this case - the people and institutions abused by Miss Brawley's ''advisers.''

title: At Edge of Furor, Lewis Describes Dream Come True
description: As Ben Johnson of Canada was flying home to Toronto today, disgraced after failing a drug test and losing his gold medal, Carl Lewis turned the Youido Full Gospel Church into an Olympic venue.

title: Man Held in School Shooting Is Depicted as Jobless Recluse
description: A young man accused killing an 8-year-old girl and wounding 10 people in a shooting attack Monday was in and out of a hospital psychiatric ward several times over the past eight months, relatives say.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Roundup; 5 U.S. Boxers in Semifinals, But an Australian Beats Foster
description: Kenneth Gould, scoring with flurries in close and countering well from the outside, advanced today to the 147-pound semifinals at the boxing tournament.

title: Clarcor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Philip H. Dougherty, 64, Is Dead; Advertising Columnist for Times
description: Philip H. Dougherty, advertising columnist of The New York Times, died in his sleep yesterday at his home in Queens. He was 64 years old. His wife, Dorothy Patt Dougherty, said his death was apparently due to heart failure.

title: SCRIPT FOR QUAYLE: LOCAL AND LOW KEY
description: When Senator Dan Quayle, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, awoke here this morning, he found his picture top-center on the front page of The Times-Picayune, three columns wide, in full color, hands gesturing authoritatively as he spoke to workers at a nearby plant that produces space shuttle parts. ''Quayle: Record Speaks to Ability,'' the accompanying headline read.

title: Dotronix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Colleges Must Learn Some Fiscal Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: National Heritage Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lightning Underscores NASA Weather Rules
description: Bolts of lightning struck within five miles of the space shuttle launching pad at the Kennedy Space Center today, slowing preparations for launching the shuttle Discovery and threatening to delay the countdown. The problem underscored the importance of new weather rules that could postpone the liftoff.

title: Raise Another Flag
description: Margaret Thatcher, now in her third triumphal term as Prime Minister, is the senior European leader. Her complete dominance of the British political scene, her prestige, the force of her personality make her the one who could carry the Community's gold-starred blue flag to consolidate great new European power.

title: Corrections
description: The Press column of the Media Business page on Monday reported the price of newsprint incorrectly.

title: Sports People; Indians Rehire Edwards
description: They finished the 1987 season with the worst record in baseball, and they stand solidly in sixth place this year, but the Cleveland Indians obviously think that Manager Doc Edwards has turned things around enough to justify being rehired. So yesterday they extended Edwards's contract a year, through next year. Terms were not disclosed but Edwards said it was ''a heck of a lot more than he ever made as a player,'' which never execeeded $17,500. Edwards who replaced Pat Corrales on July 16, 1987.(AP)

title: Botha and Mobuto to Meet Saturday on Angolan Peace
description: President P. W. Botha of South Africa is expected to travel to Zaire on Saturday to meet with President Mobutu Sese Seko, in the latest move to bring peace to Angola, diplomats said today.

title: Sports People; Name Game
description: The Jackson County Legislature in Kansas City, Mo., has unanimously voted to rename Royals Stadium for Ewing Kauffman, the co-owner of the Kansas City Royals, and his wife, Muriel. But Kauffman, the millionaire founder of Marion Laboratories, a Kansas City-based pharmaceutical company, says no change will be made at least until next year. Kauffman, who brought major league baseball back to Kansas City as a expansion franchise in 1969 after Charlie Finley moved his Athletics to Oakland, said he was deeply honored by the vote, but said: ''I believe that if the name of the stadium is to be changed, it should represent the feelings of the vast majority of the citizens of our community. Therefore, until further review next year, we will continue with the name Royals Stadium.''(AP)

title: Rape Victim Gives Up On Collecting Award
description: A rape victim whose attacker cut off her arms with an ax has reluctantly given up efforts to collect a $2.56 million judgment from the man after he disclosed he was nearly broke, her lawyer says.

title: Bentsen Seeks More Technology Aid for Business
description: In a bid for support for the Democratic ticket from business, Senator Lloyd Bentsen called today for an aggressive partnership between the Federal Government and American industry to restore the nation to world leadership in technology.

title: Review/Theater; Life and Love at the Laundromat
description: ''Leader of the Pack,'' ''The Taffetas'' and now ''Suds'': nostalgia for the songs and sentiments of the 1950's and 60's is apparently insatiable. ''Suds: The Rocking 60's Musical Soap Opera,'' at the new Criterion Center theater, is a musical for those who cannot get enough of their favorite period. The show aspires to be the ''Pump Boys and Dinettes'' or ''Oil City Symphony'' of this season, but those two had points of view, homespun wit and brevity - all of which are lacking in the case of ''Suds.''

title: Providence Chefs, Husband and Wife, Share an Ideal
description: THE seductive fragrance of wood smoke mingles with the aroma of roasting garlic and drifts across the waterfront in Providence, R.I., these crisp autumn evenings. Hungry diners trace the scent down South Main Street toward the banks of the Providence River. There, in a former commercial stable that has been converted into a restaurant optimistically called Lucky's, the owners and chefs, George Germon and Johanne Killeen, are confirming a reputation for hearty portions of good food with gutsy, assertive flavors.

title: Film Festival; Glimpses of a Depressing Future
description: Surely Derek Jarman's ''Last of England'' is the longest and gloomiest rock video ever made. Its manifold images of annihilation and misery are assembled in free-associating fashion, without any concern for narrative but with the quick, vigorous, flashy pacing that video audiences understand. The energy level of ''The Last of England'' is much too high for monotony, but the film's expressionistic leaps are determinedly obscure. Whatever the reason, there were many walkouts during the film's New York Film Festival press screening.

title: Tandy's Earnings Estimate Lowered
description: Shares of the Tandy Corporation were traded furiously and closed at $39.625, down 87.5 cents, after analysts at Salomon Brothers Inc. and Paine Webber Inc. issued lower earnings estimates for the computer maker. The analysts said they had lowered their first-quarter projections because the Fort Worth-based company is experiencing a softness in sales volume and has yet to ship its new models, which had been expected in stores by mid-September. Tandy is expected to recoup the majority of the lost sales in the second quarter and to produce earnings in the range of $3.95 to $4.10 for the year, the analysts said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error in some copies, an article yesterday about talks in Brazzaville, Congo, about southern Africa misstated a timetable. At the Moscow summit meeting last spring, Sept. 29 was set as a goal for a settlement of differences on Angola and Namibia, including establishment of a timetable for a Cuban withdrawal from Angola.

title: First Family Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a credit of $130,000, or 4 cents a share, for the cumulative effect to July 1, 1987, of an accounting change reported in the first quarter to include in inventory certain purchasing, warehousing and transportation costs. c-Net income d-Net loss The company said a one-time $2.7 million after-tax charge against earnings, resulting from the company's decision to close 13 California stores in fiscal 1987, was cited as the cause of the prior year's net loss.

title: CR-PL Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Close-Up
description: Canoeing and Kayaking One Blade or Two Canoeists use a single-bladed paddle in an open boat, which is usually made of wood. Kayakers paddle in a closed boat with a double-bladed paddle. Races are either 500 or 1,000 meters, in singles, doubles and fours. Women only race kayaks in singles and pairs. The boats are weighed before each race so that all conform to rigid standards. Keep an Eye on . . .

title: Camping Out With Hot Dogs, But No Nouvelle Restraint
description: Glenn Bernbaum pitched a tent last night beside Mortimer's, his exclusive beanery on Manhattan's Upper East Side, and the social set descended with bells on. They love camping out for a good cause.

title: Africa's Cassava, a Fruit of Colonialism
description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln Center Groups Receive Hearst Grants
description: Grants totaling more than $1.2 million were given to organizations at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts by the William Randolph Hearst Foundation, a spokesman for Lincoln Center announced Tuesday.

title: Episcopalians Elect Kansan as Coadjutor
description: Early this morning, a special convention of the Episcopal Church in New York elected a new bishop who will eventually head the New York Diocese.

title: Hillenbrand Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
General Host Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 14
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $1,650,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income d-After gains from discontinued operations of $67,722,000 and $64,722,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the extraordinary loss in the 1988 periods reflects the anticipated settlement of class action litigation which resulted from a problem in the accounts payable system at General Host's Frank's Nursery & Crafts unit. Income from discontinued operations in the 1987 periods included an after-tax gain of $87,000,000 from selling the company's 75 percent interest in all American Gourmet Co. and an after-tax loss provision of $15,000,000 to settle claims for retiree medical insurance coverage.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 The I.M.F. was criticized by Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady for not doing more to collect debts. He also balked at its efforts to bolster its finances and made what was seen as an attack on a Japanese proposal to help debtors. Page A1

title: Rashad al-Shawa, 79, Ex-Palestinian Mayor
description: Rashad al-Shawa, a Palestinian Mayor of Gaza for 11 years until he was deposed by Israel in 1982, died today at home of a heart attack, his family said. He was 79 years old.

title: Colleges Must Learn Some Fiscal Responsibility; Michigan Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Dodgers Get One Job Done
description: The big scoreboard in right-center field listed final scores for each of the other games in the major leagues late Monday evening. The Cincinnati Reds, the closest thing to a competitor that the Los Angeles Dodgers have had for the National League West championship, had won in San Francisco.

title: Review/Opera; Luciano Pavarotti and Eva Marton In 'Il Trovatore' as the Met Opens
description: Opening night at the Metropolitan Opera is traditionally first of all a social ritual and second, if at all, a musical performance. That is why, for many years, it has been the company's custom to begin with a heavyweight production calculated to persuade even the novice that he is attending an important cultural event. This year, for instance, we have ''Il Trovatore,'' in the arid and gloomy staging that sent Verdi lovers away in a funk when it was new last season. The production's return on Monday evening did little to banish memory of that gloom.

title: Summagraphics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Rita Develin, Teacher, 74
description: Rita Develin, a retired New York City teacher, died of cancer Wednesday at her home in Sedona, Ariz. She was 74 years old.

title: Centel Capital Sets Offering Of $400 Million in Securities
description: The Centel Capital Corporation, a unit of the Centel Corporation, a telephone, electronics and communications system company, is offering $400 million of debt securities in two parts through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Saying 'I Had to Shoot Him,' Writer Testifies on Intruder
description: First, Carl T. Rowan said in testimony today, came the long string of callers threatening to kill him for his writings against the Ku Klux Klan. Then a series of nighttime intrusions at his home. Then the sound at his bedroom window that awakened him at 2 A.M. last June 14. And finally, the stranger who just kept coming at him in the dark.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Women's Basketball; Yow Tries to Restrain Her Joy
description: She began thinking about this game two years ago when she was named the Olympic women's basketball coach. Reaching the final, though, has only heightened her expectations, Kay Yow said today. It would be of little consolation to come this far and not leave with the gold.

title: Obscenity Prosecutor Is Under U.S. Inquiry
description: The Justice Department's top pornography prosecutor has been placed on leave amid an investigation into a charge that he asked a colleague to destroy evidence in a pending case, department officials said today.

title: Bipartisan Group Agrees on Drug Bill to Be Offered in Senate
description: A bipartisan team of Senators reached agreement today on key provisions of a drug bill, but the Senate as a whole was divided on whether to permit amendments that some members consider a threat to civil liberties.

title: Kaufman & Broad Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,336,000 for the quarter and $1,794,000 for the 9 months.

title: Drexel Widens Court Move
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has expanded its request that a Federal district judge disqualify himself from all civil securities fraud cases filed against the firm, people involved in the complex legal proceedings said yesterday.

title: Diva Not Ill, Just Disgruntled
description: Licia Albanese, the retired star soprano whose traditional attendance and traditional high note in ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' were missed at the Metropolitan Opera opening on Monday night, wants all her friends and admirers to know that she was not ill, but just disgruntled.

title: Suit Filed to Recover Money Stolen From Parking Meters
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney, who with Mayor Koch unsuccessfully sought jail sentences for 26 former parking-meter collectors as well as restitution of the money they stole from meters, filed suit yesterday to recover $50,000 from them.

title: 2,000 Missing in India Floods
description: About 2,000 people are missing in devastating floods in four states in northern India, flood control officials said today. They said five days of nonstop monsoon rains caused floods over huge areas of Punjab, Himachal Pradesh and Haryana states and flashfloods in mountainous Jammu and Kashmir. The official death toll in the four states stood at 330 today, but the figure is expected to rise.

title: VWR Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a credit of $570,000 representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The latest second quarter's net is after a reserve of $1.4 million to cover the costs associated with restructuring of the company's graphics operations and relocating staff and line activities from the San Francisco Bay area to new subsidiary headquarters in Media, Pa., and Oakbrook, Ill., or to corporate headquarters in Bellevue, Wash.

title: U.S. Panel Lays Denver Air Crash To Failure to De-ice Second Time
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that the crash of a Continental Airlines jetliner in Denver nearly a year ago resulted from the captain's failure to have the plane de-iced a second time after it stood in a steady snowfall for 27 minutes.

title: A Fair Chance, Even Before School; An Issue for the No-Issue Campaign
description: In 1970, Dr. Arnold Hutschnecker, once Richard Nixon's personal physician in New York, sent a memo to the President that quickly became notorious. He urged that all 7- and 8-year-olds be psychologically tested for ''violent and homicidal tendencies.'' Those found in need of corrective treatment would get it in day care centers, after-school programs and special counseling.

title: Education; Coaching Courses for S.A.T.'s Show Sharp Rise
description: Almost half the high schools whose students take the Scholastic Aptitude Test now offer special preparation courses, according to the College Board.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - Working Group on International Convention on Migrant Workers' Rights - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Officials Deny Abuse In Academy's Training
description: Training at a state-run police academy that left 16 cadets hospitalized last week was strenuous but not abusive, officials said today.

title: At National Beef Cookoff, Less Is More
description: The days of the big slab of beef are over, replaced by bite-size pieces common in some ethnic cuisines and more palatable to health-conscious Americans, said cooks at the National Beef Cookoff here.

title: Grocery Merger Delayed Further
description: A Federal judge extended his temporary order blocking the purchase of the Lucky Stores Inc. supermarket chain by the American Stores Company, which owns the Alpha Beta grocery chain. Federal District Judge David Kenyon said he needed more time to consider the merits of a challenge to the merger by California's Attorney General, John Van de Kamp.

title: McDowell's Slump Extended by Phils
description: Roger McDowell came gliding past the Mets' dugout on a pair of purple roller skates before tonight's game and whizzed to a stop in front of an unappreciative audience of one: his manager.

title: Edward White, 79, Retired Civil Engineer
description: Edward E. White, a civil engineer who retired in 1975 as president of Spencer, White & Prentis, a contracting concern, died of complications of Parkinson's disease Monday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: A Time-Warner Merger Was Reportedly Studied
description: In an attempt to make their companies so big that they would be almost invulnerable to a takeover, executives of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. came close to a $10 billion merger last month but then broke off the deal, an industry expert familiar with the talks disclosed yesterday.

title: Texaco Goes Outside To Pick a Top Officer
description: Texaco Inc. reached outside its ranks yesterday and named Allan J. Krowe, a top executive at the International Business Machines Corporation, as its chief financial officer.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Long and Short of It
description: The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, had a ready answer yesterday when he was asked to comment on the Administration's position on a bill: ''floccinaucinihilipilification.''

title: The Games At a Glance
description: Basketball This game was taken from the Americans, too. Only it was taken from them both early and legally. No, the Soviet Union didn't need chaos to defeat the Americans. Its court order and strategic discipline were more than enough. As a result, the Soviet Union, which moved to a 10-point lead by intermission, had little trouble fending off a belated and erratic American comeback to beat the United States, 82-76, and move into the final of the men's competition. Sixteen years after the Soviet Union dealt the Americans their first defeat in Olympic play in a controversial and bitter 1972 game in Munich, it dealt them just their second loss fairly and emphatically. The Soviet Union was scheduled to face the winner of Yugoslavia-Brazil for the gold medal. On the women's side, Coach Kay Yow of the American team insisted the gold medal was not now going to be handed to her squad ''on a silver platter.'' The general consensus, though, is that it will no doubt eventually be handed to the team at the end of the standard ribbon. The Americans, who took apart the Soviet Union, 102-88, in the semifinals, only have to beat Yugoslavia - a team they trounced by 27 points earlier in the tournament - to claim their second consecutive gold. Track and Field Steve Lewis and his coach from U.C.L.A. stood in Olympic Stadium waiting to watch the photo finish of the men's 400 meters. Finally, the image was flashed on the screen and instantly the two became the picture of joy. Lewis, thought to be the weak link, turned out to be the golden boy. Lewis, the youngest, most inexperienced of the three American runners entered in the 400-meter final, also happened to be the best as he finished first in 43.87 seconds. Butch Reynolds, the world record-holder and prohibitive favorite from Ohio State, was second by a milisecond for the silver. Danny Everett was third for the bronze. In the men's decathlon, Jurgen Hingsen, the chief rival to the defending gold medalist, Daley Thompson, was disqualified from the 100 meters after his third false start. The West German protested, lost and withdrew from the rest of the competition. Volleyball The Soviet Union's women's volleyball team entered these Olympics almost entirely rebuilt, and now, its international stature has been largely regained, a process that took a shockingly brief hour to accomplish. The Soviet Union overwhelmed China, the defending champion, by taking three straight games, including a rare shutout, in the semifinal. The rout, in which the Soviet Union lost just 11 total points, moved the Soviet Union into tomorrow's final against Peru, a 3-2 victor over Japan.

title: Police Detain 3d American
description: Johnny Gray, a member of the United States track team, became the third American athlete to be detained by South Korean police when he was arrested and charged with kicking a taxi.

title: 1990 Census May Face A Shortage of Workers
description: The 1990 census, which could cost as much as $3 billion, may have problems hiring enough workers to do the massive national head count, the director of the census, John G. Keane, said today.

title: A Communist Of Many Hats: Mieczyslaw Rakowski
description: The selection of Mieczyslaw Rakowski as Prime Minister of Poland appears to reflect a calculation that the Communist Party badly needs an aggressive new brand of leadership.

title: Justice Blinked for Michael Deaver
description: Michael Deaver brought special shame even to a Reagan Administration abloom with scandal. Convicted of perjury after offering almost no defense, he deserved a taste of prison, not the slap on the wrist he has received from a Federal judge.

title: Review/Theater; Romantic Fantasy Revue
description: Beneath their hardened urban facades, adult New Yorkers still harbor irrational romantic dreams instilled by the movies when they were growing up. That concept informs a breezy 16-song cabaret revue, ''Life Is Not Like the Movies,'' created by Francesca Blumenthal, an advertising copywriter, that plays on weekends at Don't Tell Mama (343 West 46th Street) through Oct. 14.

title: Muskegon Journal; A Centennial in Honor Of All Things Jewish
description: These days the Star of David is appearing all over this western Michigan town, first settled in the mid-1800's by Dutch lumberjacks who wore crosses and sang carols at Christmas.

title: Preserves: Jewels Of the Fall Kitchen
description: LEAD: ABUNDANCE month is almost gone. Summer has segued into fall, the blaze of tomatoes, peppers and eggplants giving over to the glow of autumn's fruit.

title: O'Neill, Avowed Liberal, Contrasts Dukakis
description: Former House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., an unabashed liberal, today rebutted Republican charges that Michael S. Dukakis is so liberal he is ''out of the mainstream'' of American politics.

title: DeLoach Dashes Lewis's Bid in 200
description: Carl Lewis lost his chance to win four Olympic gold medals today when Joe DeLoach, a training partner, edged him at the finish line in the 200-meter final.

title: Books of The Times
description: Anything for Billy By Larry McMurtry 382 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Ex-Detective Denies Firing A Shotgun in the Davis Raid
description: A retired Bronx detective testified yesterday that he never carried a shotgun or fired a shotgun at Larry Davis during a shootout with him in a Bronx apartment in 1986 in which the detective was wounded.

title: RB Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss of $720,000 from the sale of about 960,000 shares of Cousins Home Furnishings Inc. stock that RB reacquired when the purchaser defaulted on a note receivable. c-Included $3,063,000 in unusual charges related to its former interests in Cousins Home. d-Net income and after tax credits of $167,000 for the quarter and $1,816,000 for the year.

title: Hyster Seeks Japanese Curb
description: The Hyster Company is contending that its Japanese competitors are ''dumping'' forklift parts in the United States in an effort to evade new customs duties imposed on them for selling complete forklifts below cost.

title: Hana Biologics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New School Is Reviving Course on 'Great Books'
description: The New School for Social Research in Manhattan plans to offer a modified version of the Western civilization course that the faculty of Stanford University scuttled recently.

title: Sports People; Eagles Get Kicker
description: The Philadelphia Eagles have signed a free-agent kicker, Luis Zendejas, to a two-year contract. Terms were not announced. ''Luis has experience in the N.F.L. and has a very strong leg,'' said Bill Davis, the Eagles' vice president for player personnel. Zendejas, a second-year pro, started the season with the Dallas Cowboys, where he was 5 for 5 on extra points and 1 for 3 on field goals. He was released when Roger Ruzek, the Cowboys' kicker last year, settled a contract dispute. (AP)

title: Costar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Includes a gain of $89,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $50,000 and $419,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and gains from the disposal of discontinued operations of $75,000 for the quarter and $605,000 for the 9 months, and the 9 months also includes a $307,000 tax credit. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid this month.

title: A.&P. Renews Delchamps Bid
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company yesterday renewed its offer to buy the Delchamps Inc. supermarket chain of Mobile, Ala., with a offer of $30 a share, $3 higher than an offer made last year.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Washington Law Firm Suffers New Defections
description: More than a dozen lawyers from a commercial Washington firm, Lane & Edson, will soon be leaving to join the Washington and New York offices of a major Manhattan firm, lawyers involved in the move said yesterday.

title: United Nations of Athletes Protected by Tight Security
description: The tall buildings reminded her of a nice housing project, Pam Shriver said, each one taking on the identity of the athletes who are staying there. The Dutch, for instance, have placed the orange umbrellas they carried in the opening ceremony on their balconies. Others hang their colorful warm-ups or perhaps laundry there to dry. That is what makes the Olympic Village unique, a combination small city and college quadrangle, occupied by a United Nations of athletes.

title: Bush and Noriega: Examination of Their Ties
description: Throughout the 1988 Presidential campaign and again in the televised debate Sunday, opponents of Vice President Bush have invoked the name of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian ruler, as shorthand for questioning Mr. Bush's judgment.

title: Axelrod Says 220 Love Canal Families Can Return
description: New York State's top health official said today that about half the neighborhoods abandoned around the Love Canal toxic-waste dump nearly a decade ago could be reinhabited.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Union Station Revisited
description: About 20 years ago the Federal Government began tinkering with restoration of Washington's Union Station, the monumental Beaux Arts terminal that first opened in 1907.

title: Eldorado Motor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: The company said the fourth quarter and fiscal year losses were due to an $800,000 increase in bad-debt provisions, over $1,000,000 in inventory writedowns and reserves, a $635,000 loss related to company-owned retail outlets and about $1,500,000 in reductions of product sales prices.

title: Review/Television; Marriage According to Martin Mull
description: Martin Mull has found modest fame and some fortune dipping into the tribal patterns of white America. Beginning in 1985, his periodic ''History of White People in America'' comedy specials have been so popular on Cinemax that the pay-cable service is giving Mr. Mull an opportunity to flex his satire further in a feature-length film, ''Portrait of a White Marriage,'' which can be seen on Cinemax today at 10:30 A.M. and 11:45 P.M.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: At the Olympics, Soviet Mind Games
description: LEAD: It looks like the Soviet Union is going to do it again: The flow of Olympic gold in Seoul confirms the overall supremacy of Russian and Soviet-bloc athletes. And if all goes according to form, it won't be long before prominent Americans begin calling for a committee to study the matter.

title: Power Authority Nominees Stalled by Shoreham Fight
description: As part of the battle over the deal to close the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, the State Senate refused today to confirm two members of the New York Power Authority. Several senators acknowledged, however, that the move would have no material impact on the deal.

title: Greentree Software reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
A Shift at USA Today
description: USA Today today outlined its plan of succession for the retirement of its editor, John C. Quinn, in 1990. Peter Prichard, 43 years old, a senior editor, will become editor on Oct. 1, as Mr. Quinn, 63, moves up to editor in chief. The changes were announced by John J. Curley, president of the Gannett Company, which publishes USA Today.

title: Moody's Raises Ratings for Delta
description: The rating on more than $1.1 billion of debt issued by Delta Air Lines Inc. has been raised by Moody's. Moody's said the action reflects the likelihood of further improvement in the airline's earnings, cash flow and debt-protection measurements despite growing capital spending requirements. Delta has quickly absorbed the operations of Western Airlines Inc., which it acquired in December 1986, and is beginning to realize the benefits of a larger, more cost-effective airline with expanded routes, Moody's said.

title: Medical Examiner Says He's Up to the Task
description: New York City's newly appointed Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Charles S. Hirsch, describes himself as a lucky man, who, always thirsty for new challenges, has steadily climbed the rungs of his profession.

title: House Approves Sanctions Against Iraq
description: The imposition of economic sanctions against Iraq became virtually certain today as the House of Representatives followed the Senate in voting to punish Iraq for use of chemical weapons against Kurdish guerrillas and civilians.

title: 2 Pay Dearly For Affront To Hirohito
description: One of Japan's largest newspaper groups demoted its editor in chief today and dismissed another senior editor after an English-language edition of the newspaper mistakenly published an editorial lamenting the death of Emperor Hirohito.

title: William V. Shannon, 61, Envoy Under Carter and a Times Writer
description: William V. Shannon, a journalist and college professor who served as United States Ambassador to Ireland under President Carter, died today of cancer. He was 61 years old.

title: U.S. Issues Fall in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds slipped again in light trading yesterday as dealers pared positions to place bids on an auction of $8.75 billion of new two-year Treasury notes.

title: Colorado Utility Expects a Loss
description: The Public Service Company of Colorado said that it expects a third-quarter loss because of an additional $63.8 million charge related to the eventual shutdown of a nuclear plant.

title: G.M. Sues Perot Over E.D.S. Deal
description: The General Motors Corporation filed suit today against H. Ross Perot, accusing him of violating an agreement not to compete in the same markets as the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, which Mr. Perot founded and sold to G.M.

title: Johnson's Fall Leaves Canada Shaken
description: Canada, a country that has long considered itself a model of fair play, struggled today to cope with the shock of finding itself at the center of what a columnist in The Toronto Star, John Robertson, called ''the most publicized fraud in the history of sport.''

title: Mrs. Friedman Given Privileges In Rikers Visits
description: Stanley M. Friedman's wife received special privileges to visit him at a city prison on Rikers Island after he had been transferred from a Federal prison in Missouri, the Department of Correction acknowledged yesterday.

title: Review/Music; Philadelphians Open Carnegie Season
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra opened its New York series and Carnegie Hall's season last night with a strongly played program of Soviet music: Shostakovich's First Violin Concerto with Viktoria Mullova as soloist and Prokofiev's dramatic cantata ''Alexander Nevsky.'' Riccardo Muti, the orchestra's music director, is in his element in almost every way with these scores, and there was no mistaking the audience's vociferous reaction to the combined impact.

title: Elders Has Stake In Anheuser-Busch
description: Elders Investments Ltd., an affiliate of the Australian brewer Elders IXL Ltd. disclosed today that it holds almost 1 percent of the Anheuser-Busch Companies, the St. Louis-based maker of Budweiser beer. John D. Elliott, the chairman of Elders, confirmed that the company still held the stake - about 0.84 percent - but would not comment on its intentions toward the company.

title: A Retirement At Northrop
description: Welko E. Gasich, one of several officials of the Northrop Corporation subpoenaed in a Federal investigation of the company's business dealings in South Korea, retired today.

title: Market Place; Merrill's Timing For Its Buy Signal
description: WHEN Donald T. Regan, the former Treasury Secretary and the former chief of staff for President Reagan, was head of Merrill Lynch & Company, he was especially proud of the television ad showing a bull safely maneuvering its way through a china shop. Mr. Regan and Merrill Lynch liked to do the unexpected.

title: 23 Charged in Drug Sales
description: Twenty-three employees of the United States Postal Service have been arrested on charges of selling small amounts of cocaine and heroin in or near post offices in Manhattan and the Bronx, the Federal authorities said yesterday. Also arrested were three suspects not working for the Postal Service. Nine other suspects, including seven postal employees, were being sought.

title: Wine (for Humans), Liver (for Dogs)
description: THERE was a Toto, of course, plus a Krystle, a Miranda, a Mookie, a Mopti-Malone, a Snaps, and a Barkley Baker Peacock the First, along with 50 or so other well-behaved tail-wagging partygoers.

title: Soviets Press Offer on Disputed Radar
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, today enlarged on an offer by Moscow to turn a disputed Soviet radar into an international space research center by inviting the United States to do likewise with two American military radar stations.

title: When Effort Matters
description: To The Living Section:

title: ISRAEL REAFFIRMS A STERN RESPONSE AS VIOLENCE GROWS
description: Three Palestinians died of gunshot wounds inflicted by Israeli troops today, bringing to six the number of deaths in a little more than 24 hours, and Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said demonstrators in Israel's occupied territories could expect more of the same.

title: Park Electrochemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Sports People; Demotion Time
description: The first-year Pittsburgh Penguins coach, Gene Ubriaco, said yesterday that the left wing, Wayne Van Dorp, was demoted to Muskegon because he failed to aid the All-Star defenseman, Paul Coffey, during a fight in an exhibition game last Saturday. The 6-4, 225-pound Van Dorp, obtained from Edmonton last season as an enforcer in the same deal that brought Coffey to Pittsburgh, stood by as Steve Martinson of Montreal threw several punches at Coffey.(AP)

title: Scouts Plan a National Food Drive
description: The Boy Scouts of America plans a food drive that the organization says will be the largest in United States history.

title: Morgan Dix Wheelock, Realty Executive, 79
description: Morgan Dix Wheelock, a real-estate agent and former chairman of the Children's Aid Society of New York, died of respiratory arrest Monday at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 79 years old.

title: Reagan's Plan for Chemical Arms Parley Is Called a Stopgap
description: President Reagan's call for an international meeting to discourage the use of chemical weapons is a stopgap response to delays in eliminating the weapons altogether, Administration and Congressional experts and arms control analysts say.

title: Bush Proposes Savings Plan In Bid for Middle-Class Vote
description: Vice President Bush attempted to bolster his appeal among middle-class voters today by proposing a tax-deferred saving plan that aides said would encourage young families to save.

title: Britain Chips Away at Socialized Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: New Look at Scaasi Is Slim
description: THERE are, of course, a few big, rounded ball gowns in the fall collection of custom-made clothes by Arnold Scaasi; his clients insist on them for extravagant parties, he said. His strongest design direction, however, is to slender evening dresses that show off the body. Yet the reduced sweep does not mean the clothes are quiet and unassuming.

title: Conferees Approve Welfare Revisions; Moynihan Lauded
description: House and Senate conferees tonight approved a compromise that would overhaul the nation's welfare laws and provide the first federally mandated work requirement for welfare recipients.

title: INSIDE
description: Shevardnadze at U.N. Moscow's Foreign Minister enlarged on an offer on a disputed radar, inviting Washington to turn over radars for international research. Page A3. New Episcopal Bishop Bishop Richard F. Grein of Kansas was elected coadjutor of the New York Diocese, to succeed Bishop Paul Moore Jr. when he retires. Page B1. Moscow by the Mountains A Soviet verification team at a missile plant in Utah is a little overwhelmed by American amenities and local residents' warmth. Page A18.

title: Article 855688 -- No Title
description: A manufacturer of electronic equipment has told the Air Force that the defensive systems on the much-disputed B-1 bomber can be repaired for $520 million, and the Air Force is deciding whether to approve the plan, spokesmen for the company and the service said today.

title: Nader Criticizes Cadillacs
description: The consumer advocate Ralph Nader contended today that workmanship on the Cadillac sedan has steadily slipped since the early 1970's.

title: PC Powerhouse (Made in Taiwan)
description: To many people, the idea of personal computers made in Taiwan conjures up an image of cheap machines slapped together in one of Taipei's back alleys.

title: Sharpton Dismisses Report on Brawley Case
description: An adviser to Tawana Brawley dismissed an article in The New York Times yesterday that said a special state grand jury had compiled overwhelming evidence that the black teen-ager had fabricated a tale of abduction and sexual assault by six white men.

title: MGM/UA Plans a Sweeping Restructuring
description: The MGM/UA Communications Company, beset by a slew of top-level resignations and questions about its future, said today that it planned a sweeping restructuring that is likely to include a major financial infusion from Kirk Kerkorian, the majority owner of the motion picture and television studio.

title: Club Med Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Editors' Note
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about The Chicago Sun-Times reported concerns about the future of the newspaper and described several of its setbacks. Through an editing lapse, the article omitted reference to some positive developments at the newspaper since it was taken over by an investor group. The Sun-Times has acquired Star

title: The Long History of a Toxic-Waste Nightmare
description: 1894 - William T. Love begins building a ''model industrial city'' along a canal linking the Niagara River with Lake Ontario. The invention of the alternating-current motor makes it unnecessary for industry to be near water power, and the project is dropped.

title: Legal-Service Group Files Suit Against Segregating Inmates With AIDS
description: Lawyers for New York State prisoners are battling the state's corrections department over what they contend is the department's unconstitutional policy of segregating some prisoners who tests show are infected with the AIDS virus but are not yet ill.

title: Reagan Signs Law on Film
description: Legislation establishing a national film commission was signed by President Reagan yesterday. The National Film Preservation Act, part of a Department of the Interior appropriations bill, creates a 13-member panel that could name up to 25 movies a year to be included in a national registry of classic films.

title: Austen Manuscript Is Sold
description: An important Jane Austen manuscript containing two early novels was purchased at auction today by the British Library, ending weeks of speculation that it would leave Britain.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Blend of Two Worlds

title: Campaign Trail; Dukakis Unleashes A Point of Light
description: Michael S. Dukakis sought to inspire viewers in Sunday night's Presidential debate with the story of Charles Strickland, an unemployed Houstonian who, because he had no health insurance, would not let his children play school sports.

title: Thermal Industries Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
Education; Lessons
description: Arthur Wise remembers vividly how his Great Idea came to him, because he was in bed at the time. It was the spring of 1964, and Mr. Wise was a 22-year-old graduate student at the University of Chicago trying to come up with a quick and dirty topic for a term paper.

title: Comtech Telecommunications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes gains from the exchange of notes of $37,000 and $1,719,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,798,000 for the quarter and $3,531,000 for the year.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Data General Corporation said it would take a $45 million fourth-quarter charge to consolidate manufacturing, repair, distribution and other functions - a move that would save the company about $50 million annually. The computer concern will move manufacturing of its high-end minicomputers from Portsmouth, N.H., to underused sites in Durham, N.H., and Apex, N.C., it said. Product repair and parts distribution will move from Fountain, Colo., to Southboro, Mass., and the company will sell its Portsmouth and Fountain plants.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Burger King Corp., the fast-food chain that is a subsidiary of the Pillsbury Co., named Kevin Moriarty executive vice president and manager of the North Central division. The division includes Chicago, Detroit and Minneapolis.

title: Debate Forces Playoff Switch
description: The starting times for baseball's League Championship Series games Oct. 5 have been changed to accommodate the telecast of the Vice Presidential debate that night, the Commissioner's Office announced yesterday.

title: A New Way to Get Rid of Old Tires
description: For several decades America has been struggling with the disposal of old tires. They number about two billion and are growing by 240 million a year. Most methods for dealing with the problem have either been too expensive or have run into environmental barriers.

title: Campaign Trail; Comparisons Aside, Quayle Is Studying
description: Senator Quayle has compared himself to John F. Kennedy (''Jack Kennedy was about my age when he ran for President''), Winston Churchill (''Churchill was not a great student'') and Franklin D. Roosevelt (''F.D.R. failed the bar examination a number of times.'') Nonetheless, Mr. Quayle's mentor, Mr. Bush, plainly feels that his running mate needs all the help he can get in preparing for his debate against Mr. Bentsen.

title: More Journalists Converge on Cape Canaveral
description: By last night the press office at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida had processed more than 5,000 requests from journalists for credentials to cover scheduled liftoff of the Discovery tomorrow morning, more by far than any launching since the first space shuttle took off in 1981.

title: New American Shoe reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The latest year reflected an extraordinary gain of $4,043,000 resulting from debt restructuring.

title: The Candidates Deserve Each Other
description: LEAD: Twenty years from now, how many of you will remember where you were on the night of the attack of the midget Presidential candidates? At home, right? Seated or sprawled in front of the TV set. Restless, dazed, already half-stupefied by hours - nay, days, or possibly weeks - of fabulously live coverage from Seoul, South Korea, of Olympic volleyball and water polo.

title: 37-Year-Old Lafleur Signed by Rangers
description: It may be premature to term this a successful comeback, but Guy Lafleur's survival at the Rangers' training camp was made official yesterday when he was signed to a one-year contract by Phil Esposito, the team's general manager.

title: One Day in Seoul
description: They wept for sadness in Seoul when Ben Johnson, ''the world's fastest human,'' tested positive for steroids and was stripped of his gold medal. Hours later, Greg Louganis wept for joy as the narrow victor over a spectacular Chinese teen-ager in diving from the high platform. These two episodes showed the best and the worst of Olympic competition.

title: Mayflower Cooperative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The year-ago per share earnings not applicable; bank went public in December 1987.

title: Chrysler Is Testing Car-Return Programs
description: The Chrysler Corporation has begun test-marketing two programs that give customers the right to return vehicles they do not like within 30 days or 1,000 miles, whichever comes first.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Men's Basketball; After 16-Year Wait, Soviets Stun U.S. Again, 82-76
description: It was 16 years later and a new generation of players, but defeat wasn't any easier to accept. Their voices were subdued, eyes glazed and egos crushed. There were no excuses this time, either, no claims of being cheated as the United States felt it was in Munich, West Germany, in the 1972 Games. This was the first time the Americans had played the Soviet Union in the Olympics since then and the result was the same.

title: Roadway Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
description: The results for the latest quarter reflected the company's investment in Viking Freight Inc. and included Viking's net income for the final three weeks of the quarter. Roadway completed a tender offer for Viking in August.

title: U.S. Olympic Reporting Hits a Raw Korean Nerve
description: Charges that American television coverage is unfairly focusing on this nation's dark side during the Olympics are prompting a spasm of anti-Americanism here.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is extremely both bold and prophetic at this time for the Soviet Union to have a leader who comes right to the top and says, look, for 70 years Communism hasn't produced the hopes and dreams that we had for it. Those hopes and dreams crumbled. And we've got to go in the direction of freeing up speech, the discussion, freeing up responsibility.'' - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. [ A1:1. ]

title: U.S. BALKS AT PLAN BY MONETARY FUND FOR MORE REVENUE
description: In a surprisingly hard-hitting speech, the United States' new Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, today balked at efforts by the International Monetary Fund to bolster its finances and criticized it for not doing more to collect its debts.

title: 60 Days of Missiles and Middle-Class Life for Soviet Inspectors
description: Anatoly Samarin loves pickup basketball, Fanta Orange and weekend cookouts around the pool with his neighbors. Like 4,000 other workers who punch in each day at Magna's sprawling Hercules missile factory, he enjoys knowing that his job has vital military importance. But he also chafes a little under all the rules that go with working in a top-secret plant built to thwart spying by Soviet agents like, well, himself.

title: NASA Hopeful On Launching Despite 2 Flaws
description: Space agency officials, emerging from a thorough, five-hour review of mission preparations, expressed confidence today that the shuttle Discovery would be ready for launching Thursday morning.

title: Maxwell's Plum Auction
description: The eccentric furnishings of the Maxwell's Plum restaurant are to be auctioned Jan. 21, 1989, everything from the Tiffany glass ceiling to ceramic tigers and monkeys, said Warner LeRoy, the owner.

title: Bridge
description: Once your partnership has located a good fit, it is seldom right to do anything but show support. This is particularly true in a competitive auction, but there is an interesting exception: it is sometimes possible to slip in a bid that will suggest an opening lead.

title: Real Estate; Fifth Avenue Rejuvenation Is Expanding
description: THE commercial rebirth of Fifth Avenue from the Empire State Building at 34th Street north to the New York Public Library at 42d Street is well under way, with a total of 1.5 million square feet of office space under construction or in the planning stages.

title: Pencretec Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: THE POP LIFE
description: Material Matters

title: Defiance Precision Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $45,000 and $1,233,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $306,000 for both the quarter and year. The latest fourth quarter loss from continuing operations of $270,000 included $864,000 in losses related to divisions which were sold in the quarter.

title: Political Sparring Erupts at Economists' Meeting
description: It was no surprise that the National Association of Business Economists heard a lot of talk about politics, with its annual meeting coming amid the Presidential campaign.

title: Numerous Faults Found In U.S. Trade Promotion
description: Activities by the Commerce Department to promote exports - a focal point of Reagan Administration efforts to redress the trade deficit - are ''in a state of disorder'' that has spurred more confusion than foreign sales, the General Accounting Office said.

title: Pact to Widen L.I. Expressway Is Announced
description: A fourth lane would be added to the Long Island Expressway in both directions under an agreement announced today on the distribution of the state's proposed $3 billion transportation bond issue.

title: Let's Not Discourage the Pursuit of Beauty
description: To the Editor:

title: DeBerg a Challenge for Jets
description: In their stunning march to a 3-1 record, the Jets have yet to face the quarterbacks whose talents, in a twist, have helped mold the New Yorkers' defense.

title: Phillips Petroleum Cutback in Denver
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company will relocate part of its operations from its Denver office to Texas in a consolidation that will affect about 125 employees, a spokesman, Dan Harrison, said. The regional oil exploration and production office and the partnership operations now based in Denver will be merged with offices in Houston and Borger, Tex., Mr. Marrison said. He described the action as ''part of the ongoing effort to improve profitability during this period of low prices'' for crude oil.

title: Policing the Pentagon
description: Speaking earlier this month about America's defense purchasing mess, the Secretary of Defense, Frank C. Carlucci, sent a concise message to Congress: ''Reformer, reform thyself!''

title: Heekin Can Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
Challenger International Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S.-Indicted, Colonel Holds A Key in Haiti
description: A wealthy army colonel, under indictment in the United States on drug smuggling charges, has become a critical force in Haiti's balance of power.

title: An Outlandish Gift: A Star Named Just for You
description: People hoping for immortality, or seeking a gift for someone who has everything, are providing a market for businesses that promise to name stars after them. For a price, of course.

title: Record for Griffith Joyner; 2d Gold for Joyner-Kersee
description: Florence Griffith Joyner broke the world record for the women's 200-meter dash today, 65 minutes after her sister-in-law, Jackie Joyner-Kersee, won the gold medal in the Olympic long jump.

title: Space Shuttle, After 32 Months, Makes Comeback Attempt Today
description: With the future of the nation's civilian space program hanging in the balance, the space shuttle Discovery was being readied today to carry American astronauts into orbit for the first time since the Challenger disaster 32 months ago.

title: Review/Pop; Guy's Soul-Heated Beat
description: Teddy Riley, Guy's 20-year-old producer and mastermind, had come out and opened the sold-out show at the Apollo Theater Friday night with a few instrumentals. Carrying a portable keyboard, he stalked the stage, showering the audience with gospel ideas that were deep and bluesy against the huge drum beat and slamming funk of the group's three keyboardists.

title: Hospital Links Care Problems To Fiscal Strain
description: In a report outlining planned corrective actions, a troubled Brooklyn hospital has issued a detailed response to criticisms of severe deficiencies in care that the State Health Department made last month.

title: Taylor Practices With Giants
description: One month after being suspended for violating the National Football League's drug policy a second time, Lawrence Taylor returned to the Giants and the spotlight today.

title: Renewable Notes By Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch & Company is offering $200 million of floating-rate renewable notes at a price of 100 through its Merrill Lynch Capital Markets unit.

title: Four Bond Issues By Farm Banks
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday offered four bond issues totaling $2.68 billion. All the issues are offered at a price of 100 through various securities dealers.

title: Death to Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect Shot by the Police in a Theater Dies
description: A 20-year-old man who was shot in the head Tuesday afternoon in a brief gunfight with the police in a Bronx movie theater died yesterday in Jacobi Hospital.

title: Arthur McCashin, 79, Equestrian Designer
description: Arthur J. McCashin, a rider and jumping-course designer who served as captain of the United States Equestrian Team that won a bronze medal in show jumping at the 1952 Summer Olympics in Helsinki, Finland, died last Saturday at Fairfax Hospital in Falls Church, Va. Mr. McCashin, a resident of Ocala, Fla., was 79 years old and had undergone heart surgery.

title: A Tale of Bloopers Ending in Success
description: Like a football game that is won on the opposing team's fumbles, Union Station in Washington was saved in part because those who wanted to demolish or alter it made such a mess of their plans.

title: Pros May Play in 1992
description: On April 8, a special session of FIBA, the international basketball federation, will meet to vote on a proposal that may allow stars from the National Basketball Association to compete in international competition.

title: William V. Shannon Dies at 61; Author and Former Ambassador
description: William V. Shannon, a journalist and author who was Ambassador to Ireland in the Carter Administration, died of lymphoma Tuesday at University Hospital in Boston. He was 61 years old and lived in Brookline, Mass.

title: Baseball Notebook; Yanks Are Right on Schedule
description: George Steinbrenner and Lou Piniella are scheduled to meet in Tampa, Fla., next week, marking the start of the Yankees' annual post-season ritual.

title: Center-Left Coalition Takes Office in Iceland
description: A new center-left Government headed by former Prime Minister Steingrimur Hermannsson took office today, decreeing a price-wage freeze and devaluing the currency.

title: Macmillan Accord Is Challenged
description: The Robert M. Bass Group Inc., which opened the bidding battle for Macmillan Inc. four months ago, yesterday protested the ''crown jewel'' provision of the company's $2.5 billion leveraged buyout agreement with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: Colts Sign Solt
description: The Pro Bowl guard Ron Solt ended a 10-week contract dispute yesterday by signing a five-year contract with the Indianapolis Colts yesterday. He then bitterly criticized Robert Irsay, the team owner.

title: Eastern Plans to Add Flights
description: After sharply reducing the number of flights it offers and laying off more than 3,000 employees in recent weeks, Eastern Airlines today announced a 10 percent increase in some service.

title: Changes Urged in Payments to Doctors
description: A major overhaul of Medicare payments to doctors in which some specialists would lose up to 50 percent of their Medicare revenue was recommended today in a study ordered by Congress and commissioned by the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Review/Music; The Choir of Westminster Abbey
description: One would be hard pressed to find a choir with firmer historical connections than those the choir of London's Westminster Abbey can claim. The Abbey itself has been the site of England's coronations and other state rites of passage since 1066, and although its records do not say when the choir was established, it is known that three-part polyphony was sung there by the mid-13th century. The first reference to a choirmaster appeared in 1479, and a charter of 1540 set forth the details of the all-male choir's constitution.

title: Holly Farms Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Electro-Nucleonics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: LA Gear Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid last month.

title: Corken International reports earnings for Year to June 30
Bridge
description: The biggest score ever in a North American event, and one of the biggest at any time anywhere, brought victory to an Arizona pair in the American Contract Bridge League's Royal Viking continent-wide game on Sept. 22. Mark Jones of Mesa, Ariz., and Howard Segel of Phoenix, whose score was not available when a probable victory for a Missouri pair was reported in this column, recorded 80.5 percent.

title: Heavy Trading In Bouygues
description: Amid speculation that the world's largest construction company, Groupe Bouygues, may be the target of takeover action, almost 6 percent of the company's shares outstanding changed hands on the Paris stock exchange today. The stock closed today at 596

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some copies yesterday on an article about Vice President Bush and Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian ruler, misstated the beginning and extent of their contacts. Their paths first crossed in 1976; they did not have a 20-year relationship.

title: Brokerage Lays Off 40
description: Paine Webber Inc. has laid off 40 employees in its equities division, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Making Old Carvings Look Whole Again
description: FROM Gothic gargoyles to 19th-century French consoles, there is very little that Robert Neal Carpenter, a 42-year-old sculptor, cannot reproduce. When Tarrytown House, a conference center in Tarrytown, N.Y., was to be renovated and restored, Mr. Carpenter was one of the artisans called.

title: Gun Case Against Carl Rowan Is Put in the Hands of a Jury
description: A District of Columbia jury today began deliberating the case against the syndiated columnist Carl T. Rowan, an outspoken proponent of gun controls who used an unregistered pistol to shoot a teen-ager trespassing in his yard last spring.

title: Washington Savings Bank FSB (Maryland) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Transactions
description: BASKETBALL MIAMI (NBA) - Signed Nate Johnston, guard-forward. FOOTBALL NATIONAL FOOTBALL LEAGUE -Suspended Al (Bubba) Baker, Minnesota Vikings defensive end, for one game for poking Ron Heller of the Philadelphia Eagles in the eye last Sunday. DALLAS (NFC) - Signed Roger Ruzek, place-kicker, to a series of one-year contracts. DENVER (AFC) - Placed Dennis Smith, safety, on injured reserve. Re-signed Steve Wilson, cornerback. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Placed Darrell Colbert, wide receiver, and Byron Ingram, guard, on injured reserve. Waived David Hollis, defensive back, and Rod Jones, tight end. Signed Mike Jones, wide receiver, and James Harvey, guard. INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Signed Ron Solt, guard, to a five-year contract. Waived Bob Brotzki, offensive tackle. JETS (AFC) - Waived Steve Bullitt, linebacker. MIAMI (AFC) - Signed Joe Cribbs, running back, and Ilia Jarostchuk, linebacker. Placed Tom Toth, guard, on injured reserve. Waived Chris Gaines, linebacker. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Waived Art Plunkett, offensive tackle. HOCKEY DEVILS (NHL) - Assigned Paul Ysebaert, center, and Chris Terreri, goaltender, to Utica of the American Hockey League. RANGERS (NHL) - Signed Kelly Kisio, center. Traded Chris Jensen, right wing, to the Philadelphia Flyers for Michael Boyce, defenseman. COLLEGE ALLEGHENY - Named Gary Aldrich men's and women's track coach and Paula Acree assistant athletic trainer. CAL-POLY POMONA - Named Kevin Patterson full-time assistant men's basketball coach. COTTON BOWL - Named Rick Baker director of operations and marketing. MIAMI (OHIO) - Announced that Bud Haidet, assistant athletic director in charge of tickets and promotions, has resigned to become director of athletics at Wisconsin-Milwaukee, effective Nov. 1. NEW ORLEANS - Named Mike Lopriore head trainer.

title: Rail Station Ends Trip From Ruin to Renewal
description: In an age in which factories are being converted into condominiums and schools into shopping malls, Washington is about to inaugurate what may be the most daring transformation of a historic structure yet - the conversion of its spectacular, 81-year-old train station back into a train station.

title: Infinite Graphics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Bell Atlantic Agency
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation has named J. Walter Thompson/New York its agency of record for media buying and planning for its Yellow Pages, Mobile Systems units and all Bell Atlantic's companies. The budget is $35 million, bringing the total of all Bell Atlantic business handled by the agency to $95 million. Meanwhile, the creative side will continue to be handled by Lewis, Gilman & Kynett, Philadelphia, and W. B. Doner, Baltimore.

title: TW Rebuff To Coniston
description: After a meeting of its board yesterday, TW Services Inc. said it had no interest in being acquired by Coniston Partners, the New York investment firm that recently disclosed it had accumulated 19 percent of TW's stock as the possible prelude to an acquisition of the company.

title: Manufacturers Hanover's Bridge Fund
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced yesterday that it had set up a $1 billion fund to finance corporate restructurings, particularly for companies defending themselves against takeover attacks.

title: Yields Post Another Rise
