description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose again for the week ended yesterday.

title: Chicago Conservatives Spread the Doctrine
description: To the Editor:

title: Growth in Aquaculture
description: Aquaculture production in the United States, which includes fish farming, has grown by 20 percent a year since 1980, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Production includes food and non-food fish, shellfish and aquatic plants, the department's economic research unit said. The report by the agency was the first in six years.

title: International Dairy Queen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
Mother Jailed in Baby's Death
description: A teen-age mother has been sentenced to six months in jail for the death of her 6-month-old son despite pleas from her lawyer that she had suffered enough. The mother, Rhonda Cassan, 18, pleaded guilty last month to negligent homicide. Her son, Michael, died in May, five months after the mother admitted that she had shaken him to stop him from crying. Ms. Cassan was also sentenced to five years' probation and weekly counseling.

title: Film Festival; A Children's Folk Fable For Romantic Adults
description: The Soviet director Sergei Paradzhanov brings affection, humor and high style to his retelling of ''Ashik Kerib,'' Mikhail Lermontov's fable of a wandering minstrel. Set in the misty past, presumably in the Ukraine or in Armenia, whose folklore has served Mr. Paradzhanov before, ''Ashik Kerib'' portrays the buffetings that the artist takes at the hands of philistines and despots before being rescued by the magic of his art.

title: Books of The Times; Melting Pot on a High Flame
description: Broken Alliance The Turbulent Times Between Blacks and Jews in America By Jonathan Kaufman 311 pages. Charles Scribners Sons. $19.95.

title: Fine Them When They Harass Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday on an article about a suit by New York state prison inmates against the state corrections department incorrectly characterized the inmates who say they are being segregated. The inmates have tested positive for the AIDS virus but are not ill with AIDS.

title: Senate Backs Bill to Speed Testing of Pesticides for Health Dangers
description: The Senate today adopted legislation that would speed the testing of pesticides already on the market to determine if they pose a danger to public health or the environment.

title: Town Elects a Mayor After Three Tie Votes
description: A school bus driver has been elected mayor of this tiny town after the opponent who tied him in three elections this year moved away.

title: Casting a Backward Glance at Design
description: THE rooms in ''The History of the Interior:

title: U.S. Says Panama Is Harassing G.I.'s
description: American military documents describe nearly 300 reports of harassment of American servicemen in Panama in the six months after the United States indicted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega on drug charges. The documents indicate that repeated American protests havehad no effect.

title: NDL Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $58,321, or 2 cents a share, from Grid Inc., acquired in 1988. The latest quarter sales included $786,999 from Grid. The results reflect the company's acquisition of Grid.

title: Wilton Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a gain of $514,000 from a tax loss carryforward. c-After a charge of $665,000 from settlement of a class action lawsuit for the quarter and year, and a charge of $722,000 from a tax loss carryforward for the quarter and a tax credit of $526,000 for the year.

title: Prague Calls 2 Britons Spies And Directs Them to Leave
description: Czechoslovakia has ordered two British military attaches out of the country for activities ''incompatible with their diplomatic status,'' the official Czechoslovak press agency reported today.

title: U.S. Defense Not Enough
description: In defeat, John Thompson tried to be philosophical, saying that there was life after the Olympic Games and that hard work and a good effort should be its own reward. It may have been the right thing to say, but those were not his sentiments during the summer when he was apprehensive about falling short of the gold. And it wasn't the attitude echoed in Seoul these last two weeks, when he said that the first priority was to win, not have a good time.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Plymouth Rubber Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Net loss c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $861,000.

title: Graf Defeats Garrison, 6-2, 6-0, To Advance to Singles Final
description: Steffi Graf advanced to within one victory of the first ''Golden Slam'' in tennis today, beating Zina Garrison of the United States, 6-2, 6-0, to reach the women's final.

title: Inc. Magazine Goes To McCaffrey & McCall
description: McCaffrey & McCall, a Saatchi & Saatchi agency, has been assigned Inc. magazine, a publication of the Goldhirsch Publishing Group. The other agency in competition for the $1 million account was Albert Frank-Guenther Law.

title: Behind the Boom in Takeovers
description: Even though Wall Street has been the catalyst for the takeover wave sweeping corporate America in recent years, financial experts never quite believed the future could be as frenzied. An inevitable slowdown was always around the corner, investment bankers and analysts figured.

title: Cambridge Medical Techology reports earnings for Year to June 30
Felice Jarecky Louria, Labor Advocate, 88
description: Felice Jarecky Louria, long active in social issues in New York and California, died of congestive heart failure Monday at the Orange Park (Calif.) Nursing Home. She was 88 years old and lived in Santa Ana, Calif.

title: Santa Fe Journal; Of Indian Roots, and Profits as Well
description: When two well known artists whacked each other in a bar here several months ago, they were exchanging the first physical punches in a verbal brawl that had already bruised New Mexico's artistic community.

title: This Time, Bicentennial Is France's
description: President Francois Mitterrand opened a yearlong celebration at New York University yesterday to mark the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution, noting that ''the message of 1789 has not faded.''

title: Adding a Bit of Whimsy to Mother Nature
description: GARDENERS love tinkering with Mother Nature. Not far from downtown Portland, two large wholesale nurseries specialize in clipping, bending and bonding plants together. For the past few years, they have been taking advantage of Oregon's temperate climate, which accelerates the growth of such complex trained plants.

title: Color System Technology reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company said the loss for fiscal 1988 includes non-recurring charges totaling $11,394,000. The charges in fiscal 1988 include a writedown of $7,282,000, primarily for color-conversion equipment which the company believes has limited production capability and must be enhanced with the company's new graphic system before profitability can be achieved, and a $4,112,000 lowering of the value of the company's film library due to an overall decline in the domestic syndication marketplace.

title: Campaign Trail; Country Singers Stand By Their Man
description: ''He will make a good President,'' exclaimed Loretta Lynn on Wednesday, moments after singing, ''I Saw the Light.''

title: Medals Piling Up For the U.S. Team
description: After five days of track and field competition at the Olympics, American athletes have surpassed the number of medals the American team won at the world championships in Rome last summer.

title: Film Festival; Prizes for Working-Class Nostalgia
description: ''I wouldn't say no to a bust like that,'' a chatty suburban hairdresser says of (I think) Diana Dors.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The space shuttle is ready to fly.'' - Rear Adm. Richard H. Truly,associate administratorfor space flight. [ A1:5. ]

title: Voices of the Homeless
description: In a way, it was a typical performance for the cast of ''Les Miserables'' -a fashionably late start and two standing ovations - except that in this case the cast members were part of the audience.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We recently had a licensed contractor remove all the asbestos insulation from the steam pipes in our basement. Now we feel we should insulate these pipes again to conserve heat in the winter. We would like to do this job ourselves (we are fairly handy). What do you think would be the best insulation to use?

title: Legacy of Kennedy
description: Peace Corps volunteers plan to gather in the Capitol Rotunda for an upbeat memorial to the group's founder, John F. Kennedy, on the 25th anniversary of his death, Nov. 22.

title: U.S. Women Beat Yugoslavia for Gold
description: As she spoke, Kay Yow, the Olympic coach, wiped her eyes with a tissue, overcome with joy. In the corridors of the Chamshil Gymnasium, Anne Donovan stood above the reporters interviewing her, wearing the blue T-shirt all the players received, the one reading, ''The Sole Goal Is the Seoul Gold.'' Around her neck was the gold medal the United States women had come here to win.

title: Pontiac Projects Sales of '89 Models
description: The Pontiac division of the General Motors Corporation, said it expects to sell 800,000 cars in the new model year, up from 738,000 cars in the 1988 model year. At a preview of 1989 models, Michael Losh, general manager for Pontiac, also said in a statement that the division expects to increase its market share in 1989 to 8 percent from its 7.1 percent share in the 1988 model year.

title: Break-Free Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company said the loss for fiscal 1988 is directly related to reduced sales and certain one-time expenses associated with becoming an independent company. The company was spun off from San-Bar Corp. on Sept. 16, 1987.

title: Review/Music; City Opera Recasts 'Die Zauberflote'
description: ''Die Zauberflote,'' with a different conductor and a substantially new cast for the fall segment of the season, returned to the New York City Opera Sunday evening, and the performance fell victim to some of the difficulties that beset repertory opera. Mozart's final masterpiece for the stage is not one of the operas that will play itself, given competent participants.

title: Largest New York Pension Fund To Invest $300 Million in Housing
description: The board of the largest New York municipal pension fund voted yesterday to invest as much as $300 million to help finance housing for low- and middle-income New Yorkers.

title: Pornography Measure Passes
description: The Senate today passed a measure aimed at combating the use of children in pornography. The vote was 97 to 0.

title: Notes and Bonds Edge Upward
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday, as securities dealers absorbed a new $7 billion issue of four-year notes.

title: Mobutu's Village Basks in His Glory
description: Lost in the Central African rain forest, this languid village of mud huts and dugout canoes changed radically after Mobutu Sese Seko, a native son, became President.

title: Medical Economics To Buy 3 Publications
description: The Medical Economics Company in Oradell, N.J., said it would buy three publications from Health Learning Systems that serve business executives who buy and manage employee-health services.

title: Where Is NASA Headed?
description: A successful flight today by the space shuttle Discovery will help restore NASA's pride and America's access to space. But Discovery's success will solve only half of NASA's dilemma. The other, deciding national means and goals in space, is as far from solution as ever.

title: Study Reports Flaws in Federal Workplace
description: The Federal Government is becoming a frustrating place to work, with salaries low, prestige falling, offices seedy, and workers subjected to humiliating experiences and sapped of initiative, says a study ordered by Congress.

title: Dynatrend Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 26
The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Now Children, Too, Hear From the I.R.S.
description: Children and teen-agers who filed their first tax returns in April may get a message from the Internal Revenue Service: Pay your overdue taxes or your bank account may be seized. But the I.R.S. is going out of its way to avoid carrying out the threat.

title: 3d Body in Mexican Collapse
description: Rescue workers today recovered a third body from a six-story apartment building that collapsed here and continued to search for three other people believed trapped in tons of rubble. The rescuers, aided by dogs, found the body of a woman. Soon after the building collapsed on Tuesday, the body of a man and an infant were found.

title: 9.4% Deposit Notes By Mitsubishi Unit
description: The New York branch of Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. is offering $100 million of 9.4 percent deposit notes due in 1993 at an initial price of 99.60, to yield 9.515 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: West German Team In Sweep
description: West Germany's equestrians achieved an unusually difficult triple crown of Olympic horse sports today when the nation's jumping squad edged the United States for the gold medal. Team jumping was the last of the three team events in the Games, and the West Germans won all three gold medals.

title: At 90, a Dowager of a Hotel Turns Into a Witty Sylph
description: THE reopening of the Royalton Hotel on Oct. 10 is one of the most-awaited design events of the year in Manhattan. Philippe Starck, the current superstar of French design, has completely restructured the 90-year-old neo-Georgian limestone building on 44th Street, aiming to turn it into a home away from home for well-traveled sophisticates. Mr. Starck has put his imprint on everything, from the horn-shaped door handles to the spectacular block-long lobby punctuated with his startling new furniture.

title: NEW GENES MAKE CELLS RESIST VIRUS
description: Genes transplanted into animal cells can make them resistant to a virus infection, scientists have reported, describing a research advance that they believe might eventually be applied to the treatment of AIDS patients.

title: Soviets Buy More Corn
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 550,000 metric tons of United States corn, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. The sale brought total corn sold to the Soviets in the last four weeks to more than 3.5 million tons. The corn is for delivery in the 1988-89 year, which began Sept. 1.

title: Market Place; Zenith Dissident Meets Skepticism
description: BROOKHURST PARTNERS' announcement last week that it would begin a consent solicitation against the Zenith Electronics Corporation produced both skepticism and confusion among investors.

title: Loud Pledge Reciting Leads to Noise Charges
description: City officials said they hope to prosecute two supporters of Vice President Bush who hosted a party where college students allegedly recited the Pledge of Allegiance too loudly.

title: Congress Backs Pentagon Budget After Making Cosmetic Changes
description: Congress today approved and sent to the White House a $300 billion military budget measure that gives President Reagan less than he sought for a defensive shield against nuclear missiles but removes restrictions on how money for the shield could be spent.

title: Ex-Aide to Ohio Senator Indicted in Bribery Case
description: A former aide to Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio was indicted today on charges that he received or agreed to receive illegal gratuities in exchange for official acts in behalf of two Polish immigrants.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Campeau Corp., Cincinnati, a holding company primarily involved in retailing, elected Jack Brown senior vice president, control and tax, of its department store group, Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. It also named Glen Griffith a corporate senior vice president.

title: Events: Armory Antiques and Art Deco
description: Armory Antiques Show, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street; 212-861-3358.

description: b-After tax credits of $198,000 for the quarter and $410,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $255,000 and $475,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

description: To the Editor:

title: Voice of America Is Granted Permanent Moscow Bureau
description: The Soviet Union gave permission today for the Voice of America to open a permanent bureau in Moscow, welcoming a broadcast organization it used to jam.

title: Chile Opposition Exhorts the Military
description: Increasingly confident that they are going to defeat Gen. Augusto Pinochet in the presidential plebiscite next week, opposition leaders today called on the armed forces to respect the results and urged the public to remain calm.

title: Louganis May Go To 1992 Games
description: Greg Louganis, a two-time double gold medalist, returned to the United States today and said he had not ruled out diving in the 1992 Summer Games in Barcelona, Spain.

title: Diocese Calls On a Kansan: Richard Frank Grein
description: On Tuesday, the eve of his election as the future Episcopal Bishop of New York, Richard F. Grein's staff in Topeka, Kan., ceremoniously presented him with a Yankees cap, a ''Let's Go Mets'' bumper sticker, a Giants' pennant and a one-way airplane ticket to New York.

title: Now, Korea Must Face Its Success
description: During these weeks of Olympic panoply, South Korea is parading its extraordinary economic accomplishments to the world - a 12 percent increase in its gross national product last year, exports of everything from cars to semiconductors and a work force that puts in 57-hour weeks.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: Indiana Financial Investors Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $16,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $765,000 for the year. c-Net income after an extraordinary loss of $17,000.

title: China Assails Graft in Party
description: The Communist Party harshly criticized undisciplined members today and said they were helping to increase inflation and corruption that threaten economic change.

title: Barry Blau & Partners reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue represent fees and production revenue.

title: Survey Finds Urban Schools Lacking Equipment and Staff
description: A large majority of educators questioned in a study of urban schools that was released today said teachers were suffering from a serious lack of classroom supplies, equipment and staff.

title: BUSH, ON BUS TOUR, HITS LIBERAL ISSUE
description: Vice President Bush traveled by bus through central Illinois today, trying to convince crowds in one town after another that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis is a liberal.

title: Science Panel Defends Research on Animals
description: The use of animals in research is appropriate despite the pain suffered by the animals, the National Academy of Sciences has concluded.

title: Mr. Bush Thinks About Abortion
description: Vice President Bush's handlers have once again showed their skill at quick damage control by clarifying what the candidate thinks about penalties for illegal abortions. They rate an ''A'' for agility. But Mr. Bush has still showed himself careless and superficial on what may be the most perilous subject in politics.

title: Compumat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Reviews/Rock; Rod Stewart, Without the Nonsense
description: Rod Stewart had a simple plan for his Madison Square Garden show on Monday night: bash out the hits, sing with feeling and show the crowd a good time. While most current arena shows have escalated to become song-and-dance spectaculars, for his current tour Mr. Stewart has chosen a clear well-lighted stage that allows him room to romp freely.

title: Rates Reduced at Public Campgrounds
description: Twenty-five of the public campgrounds run by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation are offering reduced rates this fall and winter.

title: Dukakis Sharply Attacks Bush on Ethics
description: In a sharp attack on Vice President Bush's ethical standards, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said yesterday that if elected President he would sign an order tightening restrictions on lobbying by former Government officials.

title: Safety-Kleen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
Rise in Steroid Use Seen as Side Effect
description: Interest in the Ben Johnson case spread yesterday far beyond sports circles to raise issues of medical and social ethics touching on the question of what constitutes healthy competition and whether there are enforcable limits to winnning at any cost.

title: Kabul Rocket Attack Kills 35, Tass Reports
description: A rocket fired into the Afghan capital by guerrillas killed 35 people and wounded more than 150 at a downtown bus stop, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: Restoring Glory to a Gothic Revival House
description: LEAD: ''I FIGURED I had one more house left in me,'' said Carol Prisant, an antiques appraiser. Sitting on the porch of Clifton, her 1862 Gothic Revival house overlooking the water in Roslyn Harbor, L.I., she added: ''The last house we renovated was our undergraduate work. This is our doctorate.''

title: Turnaround Specialist Settles In at Franklin
description: The Franklin Computer Corporation is the third company that Morton E. David has turned around. It may be his last, because Mr. David appears to have found a home at Franklin, and he intends to stay put as chairman and chief executive.

title: Lafleur Impressing Rangers
description: Marcel Dionne came close to waxing poetic as he described the pass he received from Guy Lafleur last night. He said it landed on the blade of his stick like a feather. LaFleur simply called the pass perfect, and said he couldn't help but smile when he knew it was Dionne who would be its recipient.

title: Chrysler and Renault Discuss Jeep Venture
description: The Chrysler Corporation and Renault are discussing the possibility of building Jeeps in Europe. The talks were made known today by Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, Lee A. Iaccoca, at a news conference at the Mondiale de l'Automobile, the annual car show in Paris.

title: Price Cuts Backed For Pacific Bell
description: Pacific Bell, the telephone operating subsidiary of the Pacific Telesis Group, said that the California Public Utilities Commission had approved an agreement allowing lower prices for certain telephone services.

title: Air Canada Stock Issue
description: The public stock offering of a 45 percent stake in the Government-owned Air Canada has been oversubscribed, a spokesman for an underwriter of the issue said today.

title: KEY RATES
On-Line Software International reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,310,000. c-Net income

title: Oxford Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
Burma Opposition Parties Formed
description: The main opposition group accused the military Government today of killing nearly 1,000 people since it began a crackdown Sept. 18, and it registered as a political party to challenge 26 years of authoritarian rule.

title: Vallone vs. Mayor; Council Leader Again Takes on Koch In Dispute Over Financing Drug Fight
description: Once again, Peter F. Vallone, the New York City Council majority leader, has chosen to challenge Mayor Koch in a fiscal tug of wills he seems destined to lose. Ostensibly the fight is over how to pay for the Mayor's $110 million anti-drug program, of which the police Tactical Narcotics Team is the centerpiece. But at the core of Mr. Vallone's refusal to support the Mayor's plan to either raise real-estate taxes or make across-the-board budget cuts is the majority leader's wish to reshape the 35-member Council into a more powerful and independent body.

title: Home Improvement
description: BROKEN window glass requires immediate attention.

title: U.S. Approves New Subsidies for 'Clean' Coal Projects
description: The Energy Department said yesterday that it would give $537 million in subsidies to 16 projects to demonstrate clean ways to burn coal.

title: The Final Minutes of Countdown: One Man's Decision
description: The decision to launch the shuttle Discovery will be made under a tightly disciplined process designed to correct weaknesses that led to the Challenger disaster. Explicit recommendations will be made by key officials in recorded votes, with final authority to launch given to Navy Capt. Robert L. Crippen, right, an experienced shuttle astronaut. A MANAGEMENT COUNCIL: led by Rear Adm. Richard H. Truly, left, a former astronaut who is NASA's associate administrator for space flight, will feed the judgment of top agency administrators into the decision. The council was moribund at the time of the Challenger accident but has been revived. It includes the directors of the Kennedy, Johnson, and Marshall space centers and of several NASA space technology laboratories. A MISSION MANAGEMENT TEAM, composed of 21 key shuttle program managers and related experts, will take a last-minute poll on whether to launch. The group is headed by Captain Crippen, right. A LAUNCHING TEAM, headed by Robert B. Sieck, the launching director, left, will monitor every element of the complex shuttle, including the orbiter that will carry the astronauts, the external fuel tank, the main engines, and the booster rockets. The 230-member team will check hundreds of newly installed sensors for abnormal pressures, temperatures or electrical voltages that might signal a problem as the shuttle sits on the pad. It will feed its findings to Mr. Sieck, who will make a final recommendation on launching to Captain Crippen. CAPTAIN CRIPPEN, will make the final decision on whether to launch based on all the recommendations and reports that have funneled into him from the launching team, the management council, and the experts on his own management team. The 21-member team, created after the Challenger accident, includes a safety officer, a weather expert, and key managers of the major shuttle components, such as the booster rockets, many with deep and long experience of the shuttle's development. Shuttle experts from industry will assist.

title: Ashton Chief Is Positive Despite a Product Delay
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation has confirmed that shipments of the latest update of its flagship product, dBase IV, will be further delayed. Originally scheduled for release on July 31 and delayed until Sept. 30, the new version of dBase is now expected to ship within two to three weeks, the company said.

title: Old College Try Not Enough?
description: In 1972, Tom McMillen, then a University of Maryland sophomore, was a member of the United States basketball team that suffered the controversial 51-50 loss to the Soviet Union for the Olympic gold medal in Munich.

title: CONGRESS PASSES MILITARY BUDGET
description: Both houses of Congress approved a $300 billion military budget measure, a revision of legislation that President Reagan vetoed Aug. 3.

title: The Tax All Candidates Can Favor
description: Washington is about to set a new fuel economy standard for cars; it will rise to 27.5 miles per gallon next month if the Department of Transportation doesn't rule otherwise. But Detroit says consumers want bigger, less efficient cars. Industry resistance to stiffer standards makes clearer than ever the need for a hefty gasoline tax.

title: Murdock M. Rand, Executive, 63
description: Murdock M. Rand, a retired vice president of the Union Carbide Corporation, died of cancer Tuesday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: An Old Friend, Swedish Design
description: WHAT is happening in Swedish design today?

title: Dolphins Sign Cribbs
description: The Miami Dolphins improved their depth at halfback yesterday by signing Joe Cribbs, who was released earlier this season by San Francisco and Indianapolis. Two Miami halfbacks, Troy Stradford and Lorenzo Hampton, are nursing injuries: Stradford has a sore ankle and Hampton has a hamstring problem. Cribbs, 30 years old, was the American Conference rookie of the year in 1980 with Buffalo and had more than 1,000 yards rushing in three of his first four seasons. Last season, he gained 300 yards in 70 carries as a reserve for the 49ers. (AP)

title: Q. Where's Maxwell Anderson? A. Lost in the Shadow of O'Neill
description: Once upon a time there was a playwright named Maxwell Anderson.

title: A Rich Reward
description: He joined the Kansas City Chiefs as a free agent from Rutgers in 1981, won a job in the secondary and was released before rejoining the team in the third game of the season. He has been such a mainstay since then that Deron Cherry, the free safety who has made five straight Pro Bowl appearances, signed a contract extension yesterday through 1991 that makes him the Chiefs' highest-paid player and the National Football League's highest-paid defensive back.

title: 3 Killed in Bombing in Lebanon
description: A car bomb exploded at a Syrian checkpoint on the southern outskirts of Beirut today, killing 3 people and wounding at least 15, the police and witnesses said. They said the casualties included Syrian soldiers.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the departure of lawyers from the firm Lane & Edson misstated William E. Simon's current position at the Wesray Capital Corporation. He is chairman emeritus.

title: Brajdas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago earnings are restated to reflect accounting change.

title: Corrections
description: A brief Reuters article in Business Day Monday about the opening of a new store in Zurich by Tiffany & Company incorrectly described the concern's ownership. Tiffany is a public company of which Investcorp owns only about 10 percent.

title: Finally, the U.S. Gets the Gold
description: After three galling losses in major international tournaments in the last four years, the United States finally has a gold medal in what is often called ''the national pastime.''

title: Later Drexel Charges Seen
description: Lawyers involved in the criminal investigation of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and the head of its ''junk bond'' department, Michael R. Milken, said yesterday that the Government might not seek indictments before some time in November.

title: For Couples, Retirement Brings Joy And Stress
description: LEAD: KATHRYN KOSSIS retired from a job she loved in 1981 at the age of 68 because of failing health. Her husband, Ralston, retired a year later. Since that time the couple moved to an apartment in Santa Monica, Calif., and they no longer own a car. Mrs. Kossis said her husband of 45 years was content to read and watch television.

title: Yonkers Council Balks at Shift in Housing Plan
description: The City Council, faced with its first major action on a housing-desegregation plan since agreeing to move nearly three weeks ago under the pressure of contempt-of-court fines, defied a Federal judge again Tuesday night and continued to block the plan.

title: Four Are Convicted Of Smuggling Birds From Cuba to U.S.
description: A Federal jury today convicted four of the five Miamians accused of smuggling into the United States 243 birds classified as either endangered or protected.

title: The Abortion Issue
description: To many Bush supporters, the most worrisome moment of the debate came when the Vice President appeared unprepared on an abortion question: if, as he wishes, abortions were to become illegal again, what penalties would the offending woman face?

title: Change Due At Air France
description: The conservative head of France's state-owned airline, Air France, will be terminated and replaced by a supporter of President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, the Government announced Tuesday.

title: For Hershiser, 59 Innings Without a Run
description: Orel Hershiser of the Los Angeles Dodgers pitched 10 shutout innings against the San Diego Padres tonight to complete a total of 59 consecutive scoreless innings and surpass a baseball record he had considered unattainable.

title: Man Who Killed 2 at Random Is Sentenced to Life in Prison
description: A young man who shot two people to death and wounded a third at a government building here last winter was sentenced Tuesday to the maximum of two consecutive life terms plus 35 1/4 years in prison.

title: Hartmarx Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Healthcare Services of Amerca Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $664,942 and $1,506,022 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and after tax credits of $14,866 for the quarter and $94,725 for the 6 months. The company changed to a June 30 year from a calendar year.

title: Mysterious Errors
description: Officiating errors were made during the Clemson-Florida State football game Sept. 17, according to Bradley Faircloth, the supervisor of officials for the Atlantic Coast Conference. But Faircloth declined to specify the errors or which officials made them. Clemson lost to Florida State, 24-21, at its home field. The game was officiated by a split crew. The referee, umpire, linesman and field judge were from the A.C.C.; the line judge, side judge and back judge were assigned by the Southern Independents Collegiate Officials Association.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES BILL THAT LIMITS IMPORTED TEXTILES
description: Plunging into the middle of a touchy political issue, President Reagan vetoed a bill today that would strictly limit imports of textiles and footwear.

title: Political Memo; Rivals on Different Paths To Win Middle-Class Vote
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and Vice President Bush have very different approaches to the American middle class. Mr. Dukakis is trying to appeal to their pocketbooks. Mr. Bush is trying to appeal to their values.

title: Wedding Information Network Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Pec Journal; A Poor Marxist Makes Good; Now He's a Magnate
description: Bogoljub Karic was decorated with the Order of Labor with Silver Wreath today, an honor customarily reserved for shock workers of Communism. But that is not the way Mr. Karic sees it.

title: Tamil Groups Are Choosing Election Role
description: Prospects for the rebuilding of northeastern Sri Lanka after years of violence depend in part on whether ethnic Tamil groups decide to take part in regional elections.

title: Let's Not discourage the Pursuit of Beauty; Illusion and Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; 'Tempore,' Overview Of Dances
description: After an afternoon spent amid the Renaissance courtyards of the district known as Old Lyons, any visitor to the International Dance Biennale here was more than primed for a performance of dances that ranged from the 15th to the 18th centuries.

title: N.B.A in 1992 Olympics?
description: NOW that the Soviet Union has turned the United States basketball team into a bronze bust at best, the whine fermented by American sour grapes might demand that National Basketball Association players be allowed to compete in the Olympics. And for the good of the game, even the wily white-haired Soviet coach, Aleksandr Gomelsky, the real Red on Roundball, hoped that happens.

title: Scimed Life Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Close-Up: Field Hockey
description: Soccer With a Stick

title: Nissan to Introduce British-Made Car
description: The Nissan Motor Company of Japan plans to introduce a British-made car in Continental Europe next week but says it does not yet know which countries will accept it. The destination of the Nissan Bluebird sedan, built in Sunderland in northeast England, is still unclear because of French opposition to importing Japanese-labeled cars that are less than 80 percent European made.

title: Researchers Single Out Virus That May Cause Fast-Growing Cancers
description: Among the more than 50 known varieties of papilloma virus that infect humans, one particular type often appears in the cancers that develop and spread most rapidly, scientists have found.

title: U.S. and Spain Negotiate a Pact on Military Bases
description: The United States and Spain reached a new agreement today on the three remaining United States military bases in Spain, the State Department announced.

title: Europe Limits Steel Aid
description: Despite producers' fears that a boom in steel may not last, the European Community said today that it planned to extend curbs on state aid to the industry for three years beyond the end of 1988. The community's executive commission said it would propose extending rules that allow producers to draw state aid only to promote research and development, support environmental protection or ease the social impact of factory closings.

title: Review/Theater; Gothic 'Dark Shadows'
description: With the addition to the cast of Barnabas Collins, a troubled 175-year-old vampire, ''Dark Shadows'' began its long journey from late 1960's soap opera to Gothic cult phenomenon. As with ''Star Trek,'' ''Dark Shadows'' spawned spinoffs as well as collectibles. Now the experimental Via Theater has brought the serial to the stage. As adapted and directed by Brian Jucha, the show is running at Dance Theater Workshop. To make the transition from daytime television complete, performances begin at 11 P.M. and run well past the witching hour of midnight.

title: Laser May One Day Avert Need for Eyeglasses
description: Doctors are testing dramatic new laser surgery that they hope will correct vision problems and eliminate the need for eyeglasses in many people.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a chess grandmaster's defeat by a computer listed the moves incompletely. Those in the second column of the table were Black's and those in the third column were White's. In addition, Black's second move was given incorrectly; the correct move was d5.

title: Investment Plan For General Tire
description: Continental A.G., the German-based parent of General Tire Inc., plans capital investments totaling $470 million to improve General's plants in the next four years, Continental's chairman, Horst W. Urban, said. The investments will be in addition to $220 million in previously announced capital expenditures. Most of the money will be spent in North America, Mr. Urban said. Mr. Urban said financing for the improvements would come largely from the company's cash flow, with debts of $220 million to $280 million being incurred.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Meskell Wins Met: Rick Meskell, the assistant pro at Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., shot his weakest round of the tournament, but his 74 yesterday on the par-72, 6,600-yard Inwood (L.I.) Country Club course was good enough for a three-day total of 214 and first place in the Izod Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship.

title: MILLER RESIGNING FROM BUDGET JOB
description: James C. Miller 3d, director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, will resign Oct. 15. He will work as a scholar at George Mason University in Virginia and at a Washington research organization.

title: Political Buttons and Car Stickers Seem a Vanishing Sign of the Times
description: It may have more to do with politics than fashion, but a lot of voters this fall seem to be favoring the uncommitted look. They are wearing their lapels bare and their automobile bumpers uncovered.

title: 27-Year Term For Fraud
description: A tax-shelter promoter, John Peter Galanis, was sentenced to 27 years in prison today for leading a multimillion-dollar fraud and racketeering operation.

title: McGraw-Hill Is Buying 2 Random House Units
description: McGraw-Hill Inc. has signed a letter of intent to acquire the assets of the college and schools divisions of Random House Inc. for an undisclosed sum, spokesmen for both publishing companies said yesterday. The agreement reaffirms the intention of both houses to concentrate on the kinds of publishing they do best.

title: Gooden Sputters In Playoff Tuneup
description: As dress rehearsals go, this one was reasonably important: Dwight Gooden pitching for the final time in the regular season before opening the playoff for the National League pennant Tuesday in Los Angeles against Orel Hershiser of the Dodgers. And Gooden was 0 and 3 in the playoff and World Series two years ago.

title: Campaign Trail; A.C.L.U. 'Cards' Turn into Hot Items
description: Suddenly, it's all over Capitol Hill.

title: Utility Tie Is Reviewed
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission today sent the proposed merger between Pacificorp and the Utah Power and Light Company back to its staff for further information.

title: House Unit Bars Data For Inquiry on Wright
description: The House Intelligence Committee today rejected turning over classified material for an investigation of House Speaker Jim Wright's assertions about the Central Intelligence Agency's activities in Nicaragua, people familiar with the panel's private meeting said.

title: The Wisdom of Judicial Lockjaw
description: LEAD: Justice Harry A. Blackmun has done what both Presidential candidates fear to do: make the Supreme Court an election issue. While denying ''taking sides in this business,'' he has nonetheless done just that. His statements, in two speeches, are extraordinary - and could prove costly for the Court and the country.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: As the swelter of summer yields to the cool, crisp days of fall, millions of Americans forget about the most important substance they put in their bodies: water.

title: U.S. Protesting Israelis' Use of Plastic Bullets
description: The Reagan Administration objected today to Israel's practice of using plastic bullets to subdue demonstrators in the occupied territories, and it called on the Israeli authorities to show more restraint.

title: Review/Opera; Kathleen Battle Sings Cleopatra In Handel's 'Giulio Cesare' at Met
description: If anyone with an ear attached to either side of his head still questioned Kathleen Battle's place among the singing elite of this century, her portrayal of Cleopatra in Handel's ''Giulio Cesare'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday evening should have swept away all doubt. Miss Battle proved herself a mistress of Handelian bel canto worthy of mention in the same breath as Joan Sutherland and Beverly Sills, if not earlier divas of hazy legend. In a strenuous series of arias whose technical and interpretive demands often verge on the inhuman, Miss Battle was a vocal seductress, always flirting with perfection and frequently attaining it. No wonder Julius Caesar fell so hard. He was obviously not tone deaf or, for that matter, blind.

title: College to Pick Art Foundation Trustee
description: A new trustee for the board of the Barnes Foundation in Merion, Pa., one of the world's greatest collections of 19th- and 20th-century European art, will be appointed by Lincoln University, a small but distinguished liberal-arts college with a predominantly black student body near Oxford, Pa. ''We will set up a search committee to find the most sensitive and intelligent candidate we possibly can,'' said Franklin Williams, a lawyer and former United States ambassador to Ghana, and chairman of the university board.

title: Review/Television; A Look at 'The Romantic Brahms'
description: Classical music and television were not made for each other. Apart from the poor sound reproduction still delivered by most television sets, the purely visual aspects of recitals and concerts are decidedly limited. Pop music can revert to frenetic editing and hyperkinetic choreography, but these sorts of gimmicks just won't do for the classical repertory.

title: Talks on Angola Fight Are to Continue Today
description: Citing progress ''in overcoming a number of obstacles,'' American diplomats said today that talks here over the withdrawal of 50,000 Cuban troops from Angola would continue on Thursday, a day beyond schedule.

title: Hi-Shear Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Campaign Trail; Food for Thought, Or for Indigestion
description: Scene at a Washington restaurant on Wednesday.

title: 20th Century-Fox Advances in Box-Office War
description: The stars of last summer's movie box-office battle were Paramount and Disney, but the drama was supplied by 20th Century-Fox.

title: New Sony Camera
description: The Sony Corporation of Japan has introduced a compact still-image video camera to be sold in the United States sometime next spring and in Europe by next summer. The camera uses a two-inch floppy disk instead of conventional film. The disk takes 50 frames that can be viewed individually on a television set through a player. The camera, called the MVC-C1, will cost 69,800 yen ($519.90), while the player will go for 30,000 yen ($223.50). It will be available in Japan starting in mid-December.

title: Topics of The Times; Sting City
description: The New York City police have put a new spin on an old parental dictum: Be nice to those you meet because you never know who they might turn out to be.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Advanced Micro Devices, Sunnyvale, Calif., said it would close its Sunnyvale manufacturing facility at the end of the year.

title: 3 Americans Reach Finals
description: Knockouts by Kennedy McKinney and Ray Mercer and a decision for Michael Carbajal today put three Americans into the gold-medal round of the Olympic boxing tournament.

title: Olympic Highlights
description: TRACK AND FIELD: Florence Griffith Joyner broke the world record in a semifinal heat of the 200-meter dash with a time of 21.56 seconds, 15-hundredths of a second under the record held by Marita Koch of East Germany. Jackie Joyner-Kersee, winner of the heptathlon gold medal, captured first place in the women's long jump with a mark of 24 feet 3 1/2 inches, an Olympic record. BASKETBALL: The fast-breaking United States women's team defended the title it won in 1984 by beating Yugoslavia, 77-70, for the gold medal. BOXING: Three Americans reached the finals: Kennedy McKinney and Ray Mercer advanced with knockouts, and Michael Carbajal won a decision.

title: Talking Deals; New Lease on Life For New World
description: WHEN a company is drowning in debt, it is tough to find a way out, particularly in an era when bondholders have become increasingly assertive about their rights. But after months of scrambling, New World Entertainment Ltd., the troubled Hollywood movie and television company, managed to find a method for reducing payments on its $285 million in high-yield, high-interest ''junk bonds'' that were virtually crippling the company.

title: McCann Gets Weintraub
description: McCann-Erickson/Los Angeles, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has been tapped to handle the Weintraub Entertainment Group account. The budget is $25 million. The agency, which was up against one other agency, whose name was not disclosed, will look after all media placement and buying, as well as marketing for all of the group's motion pictures.

title: Fastcomm Communications reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Hoffman-LaRoche In Amgen Deal
description: Amgen Inc., a biotechnology company based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., said that F. Hoffman-LaRoche & Company of Basel, Switzerland, had agreed to market Amgen's Neupogen recombinant granulocyte colony stimulating factor, G-CSF, in the European Community. Neupogen, which would be sold under Amgen's trademark by both companies, is a hormone that stimulates the production of white blood cells as a defense against infection.

title: Parent & Child
description: EVERY morning during the first two weeks of seventh grade, he would try to hide under his bed and fight off his parents' attempts to get him ready for school. ''I was so scared of school that I didn't want to live anymore,'' said the boy, who is now 16 years old and in the 10th grade. He asked that his family's name not be used.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY President Reagan vetoed a bill that would limit textile and footwear imports. Congressional Democrats said it would be hard to override the veto and indicated that they would try to make the measure a campaign issue. White House aides said the veto reflected Mr. Reagan's intention to play a leading role in the final legislative and political battles of his Administration. [ Page A1. ] The Commerce Department was sharply criticized in a draft of a G.A.O. report for bungling its attempts to promote exports. [ D6. ] Unsurprisingly, Beryl W. Sprinkel offered a cheery appraisal of the Reagan era. He is the President's chief economist. [ D6. ] James C. Miller 3d will resign as director of the White House Office of Management and Budget on Oct. 15. [ A24. ] The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has begun discussions on how to tap new funds to clean up the savings industry. [ D13. ] The Energy Department will provide $537 million in subsidies to 16 projects to demonstrate clean ways to burn coal. [ D2. ] A former Navy consultant settled civil charges that he illegally traded in the stock of Airship Industries. [ D5. ] COMPANIES Banca Commerciale Italiana did not hold secret talks with Bank of New York about Irving Bank, its lawyer said in Federal court. The statement ended the Italian company's silence on the increasingly bizarre legal charges. [ D1. ] A law firm must step down from representing a Dalkon Shield trust fund because of a conflict of interest, a Federal judge ruled. He said Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, could not represent the fund's trustees. [ D1. ] Manufacturers Hanover has set up a $1 billion fund to finance corporate restructurings. [ D6. ] A Federal district judge dismissed Carl C. Icahn's objections to the plan that brought Texaco out of bankruptcy. [ D2. ] McGraw-Hill will buy Random House's college and schools divisions for an undisclosed sum. [ D22. ] Warner's acquisition of Lorimar Telepictures was blocked by A New York State court. [ D22. ] The Bass Group protested the ''crown jewel'' provision Macmillan's buyout agreement with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts. [ D22. ] Shamrock Holdings said it would restore employee benefits and pay cut by Polaroid if it succeeds in taking over the company. [ D5. ] Chrysler and Renault may build Jeeps in Europe. Lee A. Iaccoca said Spain was a possible site for the venture. [ D5. ] Montedison proposed buying all remaining shares of Ausimont for more than $266.1 million. [ D5. ] INTERNATIONAL Third world officials painted a stark picture of how debt burdens, trade barriers and slow growth have combined to worsen living standards for the world's poor. Growth is hampered and poverty increasing, they said. [ D1. ] MARKETS Stocks meandered again in very quiet trading and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.20 points, to 2,085.53. [ D10. ] Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly, as securities dealers absorbed a new $7 billion issue of four-year notes. [ D19. ] The dollar was mixed in lackluster trading as the pound continued to draw most investor interest. Gold rose 90 cents an ounce on the Comex, to $398.20. [ D17. ] Platinum futures prices surged after forecasts of a supply shortfall in the coming year. [ D17. ] Yields rose again on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS New World Entertainment has gained breathing room by doing a bond swap with a twist. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Brookhurst Partners's consent solicitation against Zenith has produced skepticism and confusion. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: Sprinkel Is Optimistic On Growth and Inflation
description: As part of a cheery, partisan appraisal of the Reagan era, Beryl W. Sprinkel, the President's chief economist, said today that the economy could keep growing at about its current pace without risking higher interest rates and inflation.

title: Quaker Fabric Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Net income and after tax credits of $700 for the quarter and $171,700 for the 6 months.

title: DUKAKIS ADS AIM AT WOOING BLACKS
description: The Dukakis campaign and the Democratic Party, concerned about indifference among black voters, plan to spend $3 million to $5 million on advertising to stir their enthusiasm, the director of the advertising drive said today.

title: Anger Lives in Canal's 'Uninhabitable' Zone
description: The 71 families who stayed in the abandoned neighborhoods around Love Canal here waited almost a decade for state health officials to decide their fate. Today Love Canal is a neighborhood of winners and losers.

title: HIGH CHINESE AIDE WILL VISIT MOSCOW, SOVIETS ANNOUNCE
description: China's Foreign Minister will visit Moscow this year and meet with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman announced today. It will be the highest level at which the two nations have met since the 1960's.

title: Soviets Reportedly Relaxing Steps in Emigration Process
description: Soviet officials have informed the United States that they have drafted new regulations that would significantly reduce the obstacles to emigration by Soviet citizens, Administration officials said today.

title: Los Angeles Is Curbing Trucks in Rush Hours to Ease Traffic and Pollution
description: Faced with the worst traffic congestion and air pollution in the country, Los Angeles today moved to impose the most drastic curbs on trucks of any major American city.

title: Workers Ousted for Drug Use
description: Six workers were dismissed after an investigation into accusations of drug use at the Point Beach nuclear power plant, officials said today. The Wisconsin Electric Power Company said its investigation began after a tip that employees had used marijuana or cocaine in off-duty hours. All six workers were described as working in maintenance and other support jobs at the plant.

title: U.S. Company Denies Plans for Abortion Drug
description: An American company said this week that it does not currently plan to seek Federal permission to market a new drug that induces abortion early in pregnancy.

title: Corrections
description: A film review of ''Bird'' on Monday, about the jazz saxophonist Charlie Parker, omitted the name of the actor who played Parker as a young man.

title: Bentsen, in Truman's Town, Turns Up the Heat on Quayle
description: Evoking memories of Harry S. Truman, Senator Lloyd Bentsen today opened up on his Republican opponent, Senator Dan Quayle, stopping just short of calling him unqualified for the Vice Presidency.

title: Addendum
description: * Princeton Public Relations Group, specializing in corporate and financial public relations and investor relations, has been set up by three principals: Robert Marquis, James M. DiClerico and Seth D. Petok.

title: Koch Picks 11 New Members For Panel on Human Rights
description: As part of his promise to revitalize the New York City Human Rights Commission, Mayor Koch yesterday appointed 13 people to it, 11 of them new.

title: More and Tighter Requirements Govern Launching
description: The launching of the space shuttle Discovery will be governed by criteria that are more numerous and more stringent than those applied to the Challenger.

title: Cousins Home Furnishings reports earnings for Year to June 30
Bank Board Looks for New Funds
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has begun internal discussions on how to tap new funds if its resources fall short of resolving the savings industry's problems, the agency's chairman, M. Danny Wall, said today.

title: Heilig-Meyers Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Soviet Party Calls a Hasty Meeting, Setting Off Speculation on Chief's Aims
description: The Soviet Communist Party has scheduled a meeting of its ruling Central Committee on Friday to overhaul the party's political structure. There was no explanation for why the meeting was so hurriedly arranged.

title: Banner Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $2,042,000 for the quarter and a gain of $5,353,000 for the year both from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $314,000 and $1,308,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a tax credit of $1,510,000. Share earnings figures are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split to paid in October.

title: Reviews/Rock; Skewed Blues and Chunky Counterpoint
description: Henry Kaiser, the Berkeley-based guitarist who's collaborated with all sorts of rock and jazz avant-gardists, devoted his first New York performance since 1982 to neo-psychedelic jamming. On Sunday at the Knitting Factory, opening a two-night stand, Mr. Kaiser played two hourlong sets for his early show. The first, he said, would be ''a bunch of weird junk'' and the second, he announced mysteriously, would be ''a wide variety of G. D. material.'' The concert amply demonstrated Mr. Kaiser's eclecticism, but it played down his own music in favor of tributes.

title: Dow Rises 3.20 as Trading Remains Quiet
description: Stocks meandered again in very quiet trading yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.20 points to 2,085.53.

title: Subtleties Of Dutch Poster Art
description: AFTER years of obscurity, Dutch poster art is finally having its day. ''The Modern Dutch Poster: The First 50 Years,'' the first such exhibition in the United States, will open at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum in Manhattan on Oct. 4.

title: Consul Restaurant reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $250,000 for both the latest quarter and the year-earlier period.

title: Third World Tells I.M.F. That Poverty Has Increased
description: Third world officials painted a stark picture today of how debt burdens, trade barriers and slow growth have combined to worsen living standards for the world's poor.

title: Report to Koch Faults Official in Tax Assessment Cuts
description: A deputy New York City finance commissioner reduced property tax assessments for several of the city's largest commercial landlords without maintaining proper records, according to a report released yesterday by the Koch administration. The official also did not explain the reasons for his decisions or tell his superiors of his actions, the report said.

title: Law Firm Told to Quit Dalkon Case
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a law firm retained to represent a Dalkon Shield trust fund must step down because of a conflict of interest.

title: U.S. Aims to Buoy Khmer Rouge Rivals
description: In an effort to curb the influence of the Communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas, the Reagan Administration intends to triple its aid to the non-Communist Cambodian opposition, senior State Department officials said yesterday.

title: Xicor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
description: The prior year results reflected the adoption of a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Deaver Prosecutor Seeks Paid Appearances to Discuss Ethics
description: Whitney North Seymour Jr., the independent prosecutor in the case of Michael K. Deaver, has sent a promotional letter to several colleges and universities advising them of his availability as a ''paid speaker'' to discuss the Deaver case and ethics in Washington.

title: Saztec International reports earnings for Year to June 30
Shamrock Makes Vow On Benefits
description: If Shamrock Holdings Inc. succeeds in its $2.4 billion takeover bid for the Polaroid Corporation, it would immediately restore employee pay and benefits that were cut as part of Polaroid's restructuring plan, a Shamrock executive said today.

title: Negotiating New Directions for American Trade
description: In July 1985, when Clayton K. Yeutter took over one of the prickliest posts in government as the Reagan Administration's trade representative, he was considered not only an outsider but also a bit of a rube even though he had served in the Nixon and Ford Administrations.

title: Children's Museum: New Ways to Play
description: THE Brooklyn Children's Museum has begun a $4.5 million renovation that is to be completed in five years. The museum, designed in 1976 by Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates of Manhattan, was built as a large open space, which museum staff members have found inefficient. In the renovation, rooms are being built so visitors can focus on single activities. On Saturday, a neon-lit entrance, an early-childhood playroom, and a music room are to be unveiled.

title: Florida Girl to Be Tested To Determine Parentage
description: A Sarasota man said today that he would have his 9-year-old daughter tested to determine if she is actually the biological child of another couple.

title: Judge Dismisses Claim By Icahn on Texaco Plan
description: In an apparent end to four and a half years of monumental legal turmoil, a Federal district judge yesterday dismissed Carl C. Icahn's objections to the plan that brought Texaco Inc. out of bankruptcy in April.

title: Why Bush Wants to Limit the Debates
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; The Age of Equality
description: Poor Kitty Dukakis. If only she'd been born in 1949 instead of 1937 she'd have known what Marilyn Quayle knows: ''Women are totally equal with men.'' Mrs. Quayle, who was born in 1949, told The New York Post recently that such knowledge is restricted to her generation.

title: Cocaine Seized in California
description: Four Mexicans were arrested and more than 1,500 pounds of cocaine was seized when the authorities raided a warehouse Tuesday, Federal officials say. The arrests were made a day after the cocaine was first discovered by United States Customs Service inspectors in a routine check, said Ralph Lochridge, a spokesman for the Drug Enforcement Administration. The drugs were believed to have been shipped from Colombia to Mexico and then to California, Mr. Lochridge said.

title: Panel Votes for Waste Curbs
description: Legislation to force the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate the disposal of infectious medical waste was approved today by the House Energy and Commerce Committee.

title: Bush's Edge: He's Likable
description: LEAD: With all the hype leading up to Sunday night's joint appearance by Michael S. Dukakis and George Bush, one could be forgiven for expecting a wrestling match - the Iceman vs. the Kennebunk Kid. The resulting performance, however, was less a debate, joint news conference or wrestling match than an epic quiz show, a strange combination of ''College Bowl,'' ''Jeopardy'' and ''What's My Line.

title: Kerkhoff Industries reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Violence Reported in Lithuania
description: Riot policemen with truncheons broke up a demonstration today by tens of thousands of Lithuanians protesting Soviet administration of the Baltic republic, a witness said.

title: Larry Gallagher, 41, Creator of a Musical
description: Larry Gallagher, the creator and director of the Off Broadway musical ''Beehive,'' died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 41 years old. He died of encephalitis, according to his brother Steven Gallagher. ''Beehive,'' a revue of 1960's pop music, began at the cabaret Sweetwaters and moved to the Top of the Gate, where it played more than 600 performances. Mr. Gallagher also directed the revue's national touring company, as well as productions in Washington, Chicago, Toronto and Japan. He also wrote the musical revue ''Ain't No Mountain High Enough,'' and was a booking agent for nightclubs and cabarets in New York.

title: Mafia Couple Slain in Sicily
description: Gunmen burst into a villa near here today and killed a Mafia boss and his wife, the authorities said. The killing of Giovanni Bontade and his wife, Francesca, both 42 years old, were the latest in a rash of gangland murders.

title: A Piano You Can Walk On
description: REMO SARACENI, a sculptor and inventor, believes in interactive technology. In 1976, he designed the Light-O-Matic wall switch, a device that turns on the light in a room when a person enters and turns it off after the person leaves. The Walking Piano on which Tom Hanks dances in the movie ''Big'' is Mr. Saraceni's latest design.

title: Astronaut on the Ground Making Final Decision
description: When the countdown clock in the firing control room here halts automatically for the last time Thursday morning, one man will be faced with the one big question. He will have 10 minutes to decide whether or not to restart the clock and ''go'' for liftoff in 9 minutes.

title: Brawley Rejects Evidence Cited To Grand Jury
description: Tawana Brawley today rejected the evidence before a special state grand jury that has discredited her account of abduction and sexual assault by a group of white men last November.

title: BOTHA URGES UNITY AMONG AFRIKANERS
description: Marking his 10th year as head of the South African Government, President P. W. Botha said today that his greatest regret was the growing division within the ranks of Afrikaners, the minority of Dutch descent that dominates the country's politics.

title: Canadian Government Will Lead Investigation of Olympic Scandal
description: The Canadian Government announced today that it would summon Ben Johnson to testify at an inquiry into the circumstances that led to his disqualification as the Olympic 100-meter race champion.

title: TV Notes
description: TV Musical Chairs

title: Donna Karan Unveils Styles for Everywoman
description: HER newest fashion collection, called DKNY for Donna Karan New York, is not about fashion at all, Donna Karan insists. The operative word is ''clothes.''

title: Victoria Creations reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: State by State; In Michigan, After Lagging, Dukakis Seems to Be Winning Black Support
description: Michigan is the state where, in the Democratic caucuses on March 26, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts suffered the worst defeat in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, losing to the Rev. Jesse Jackson by the sobering margin of better than 2 to 1.

title: Argentine Rebel Sentenced
description: A retired air force commodore was sentenced to 12 years' imprisonment Tuesday night for leading a rebellion against the Government in January. The commodore, Luis Estrella, led a group of officers who occupied Buenos Aires' domestic airport for several hours before surrendering to loyal troops.

title: People
description: * Bernard Kramberg has been promoted to senior vice president, director of marketing research, at Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson.

title: Mexican Convicted of Aiding In Slaying of U.S. Drug Agent
description: A Mexican drug trafficker was found guilty today of aiding and abetting the 1985 torture murder of a United States drug agent and his pilot. He was the third man convicted in the case, which strained relations between the United States and Mexico.

title: Bank Says It Made No Secret Pact
description: In a Federal court hearing, a lawyer for Banca Commerciale Italiana said yesterday that the banking company had entered into no secret talks with the Bank of New York to divide up Irving Bank.

title: Apogee Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
California Fight on Car Insurance
description: THE most intensive political advertising campaign of the year may not be the one between Michael S. Dukakis and George Bush. Rather, it is likely to be the heated battle in California between special-interest groups offering voters competing proposals to overhaul the state's automobile-insurance industry.

title: Datalease Is Sold
description: Atlantic Computer Systems Inc., the United States subsidiary of Atlantic Computers P.L.C., said that it had bought for an undisclosed amount of cash the Datalease Corporation of Westport, Conn., a computer-leasing company that had $25 million sales in 1987. London-based Atlantic Computers, owned by British and Commonwealth Holdings P.L.C., said the deal had been approved by the Federal Trade Commission and Britain's Bureau of Competition and was made final today. Philip Hold, president of Atlantic Computers Systems, said the move should bolster its mid-range computer system leasing operations.

title: Citicorp Unit Breaks Ground With a Tax-Exempt Bond
description: Citicorp Securities Markets Inc. yesterday claimed the honor of being the first commercial bank affiliate to take full advantage of its new ability to underwrite all kinds of tax-exempt revenue bonds.

title: Kuwait Offers Plan to Ease Debts of Poor Nations
description: The Emir of Kuwait proposed a plan of action today to relieve the ''ever-widening gap'' between rich industrial countries and poor countries.

title: Weight Lifter Used Drug
description: An Olympic weight lifter from Hungary who won a silver medal has been caught using the same drug that led to Ben Johnson's disqualification.

title: Post-Debate Poll Sees No Change
description: Vice President Bush leads Michael S. Dukakis by 50 percent to 46 percent, according to the the latest ABC News Poll.

title: New York Will Try House Arrest for Some Prisoners
description: The rise in New York City's jail population has led to a new program that will allow a select group of 200 prisoners to await trial under house arrest rather than in a city jail.

title: Inland Steel Sees Strong Year Ahead
description: Inland Steel Industries expects the United States steel industry to stay strong through 1989, but any profit gains are likely to come through cost cuts instead of higher prices, Inland's president, Robert Darnall, said. Interviewed after he addressed a national meeting on corporate ethics Tuesday, Mr. Darnall said he expects industrywide steel shipments to total about 82 million tons in 1988 and remain at about that level next year.

title: INSIDE
description: No Move on Abortion Drug

title: Cognos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Christiana Cos reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $917,000 for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes a credit of $743,000 from an accounting change. c-Includes a loss of $3,781,000 from discontinued operations for both the quarter and year. Revenue represent rental income.

title: 'Shirley' Drink Dispute
description: Shirley Temple Black, the 1930's child actress, has gone to court to prevent a soft-drink company from marketing a soda with her name. Mrs. Black, 60 years old, filed suit in San Mateo County Superior Court in an attempt to prevent the Soda Pop Kids Company from selling a drink named ''Shirley T.'' Judge John Schwartz declined to block sale of the drink pending an Oct. 13 hearing, but he granted a restraining order preventing the company's owner, Bradley Weidman, from starting a nationwide advertising campaign.

title: Campaign Trail; Now Quayle Fails A History Exam
description: Although he has been comparing himself to John F. Kennedy, Winston Churchill and Franklin D. Roosevelt, Senator Dan Quayle will have to drop Roosevelt from his list.

title: Accounts
description: * Conde Nast's HG magazine to Cliff Freeman & Partners, a unit of Saatchi & Saatchi's DFS Compton.

title: M.D.C. Holdings Sells Imperial Stake
description: M.D.C. Holdings Inc., the Denver-based home building and mortgage banking company, has sold its 9.6 percent stake in the Imperial Corporation of America. Imperial, based in San Diego, owns savings and loan associations with branches in California, Kansas and Colorado. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, M.D.C. said that it sold 1.4 million Imperial shares on the open market for $10.34 to $10.45 a share, or a total of $14.7 million.

title: Former Consultant to Navy Settles S.E.C. Charges
description: Charles A. Mills, a former independent consultant to the Navy, today settled civil charges that he illegally traded in the stock of Airship Industries Ltd., while in the possession of nonpublic information that the company would most likely win the contract on which he was working.

title: When You Go Away But Rover Stays Home
description: ''WHEN people go away and leave animals that are elderly or have medical problems, it's a lot less traumatic for the pets to stay at home than go into a kennel,'' said Pam Sprosty, whose firm, Pampered Paws, provides at-home pet care. She says it is better for healthy animals too. ''If you bring an animal into the hospital for care, even though it may be healthy, it may pick up something in the hospital.'' Even if pets are boarded with an excellent veterinarian, she said, dogs can catch kennel cough and cats can develop upper respiratory illnesses.

title: Rookie Stymies Yankees
description: The Yankees lost a game and a day in their fading chase for the American League East title. But they apparently have still not lost hope.

title: Figure in Brink's Case
description: Adolph Maffie, the last survivor of those convicted in the $2.7 million Brink's robbery of 1950, died Sunday after a long illness. He was 77 years old. In the robbery, seven men took $2.7 million in cash and securities from the Brink's counting room in Boston's North End. Less than $1 million was recovered. The authorities said the robbery was planned in Mr. Maffie's home. Mr. Maffie was sentenced to life in prison but his sentence was commuted by Gov. John Volpe and he was released in 1969.

title: N.F.L Suspends Baker
description: Al (Bubba) Baker, a Minnesota Vikings defensive end, suspended for one game yesterday for poking Ron Heller of the Philadelphia Eagles in the eye last Sunday. The incident occurred after the first play of the second period as players were walking on and off the field for a Philadlephia punt. Joe Browne, a National Football League spokesman, said Baker was suspended without pay for Sunday's game in Miami for flagrant unsportsmanlike conduct.(AP)

title: The Games At a Glance
description: Track and Field For those who watch Florence Griffith Joyner run, the Olympics have been a blur. Already the gold-medalist in the 100-meter dash, Griffith Joyner ran to a world record on the 200-meter semifinals with a time of 21.56 seconds. Her sister-in-law, Jackie Joyner-Kersee fouled in her final jump and her last attempt to set a world record in the long jump. After all, her leap before had already taken her where no American woman had ever gone. Joyner-Kersee's jump of 24 feet 3 1/2 inches, an Olympic record, made her the first woman from the United States to win the Olympic long jump. It also completed a spectacular double for Joyner-Kersee, who last weekend won the heptathlon by some 400 points. Her victory in the long jump marked the first time an American women had won a field event in 32 years. Joe DeLoach, who as a teen-ager considered it a great thrill to get Carl Lewis's autograph, reacted with mixed feelings after he had outrun Lewis in the men's 200 meters. DeLoach, a friend and protege, upset Lewis by finishing in an Olympic-record time of 19.75 seconds. Afterward, DeLoach was torn, grateful for his success and saddened that it came at Lewis's expense. DeLoach's victory ended Lewis's bid to repeat his four-gold-medal performance of four years ago. Weight Lifting He may not have the irrepressible charm of Olga Korbut, but Aleksandr Kurlovich will return to their shared hometown in the Soviet Union with something Korbut never did: a gold medal. Kurlovich, a 292-pound sports instructor, earned the unofficial title of world's strongest man when he took first place in the superheavyweight class. He lifted a total of 1,017.5 pounds. Boxing The competition is there, said Kennedy McKinney. It just isn't there for long. McKinney stopped Pahjol Moolsan of Thailand at 2:32 of the first round. McKinney thus became the second of three American fighters to advance to the finals. ''The competition is there,'' said McKinney, who fights at 119 pounds. ''But I'm not giving them a chance.'' Michael Carbajal, too, will have a chance at gold thanks to his artful and aggressive 4-1 decision over Robert Isaszegi of Hungary. The 106-pound Carbajal, up against it after two rounds, backed his opponent in the third to advance to the final. Ray Mercer, fighting at 201 pounds, halted Arnold Vanderlijde of the Netherlands, the European champion, in the second round to earn a shot at a gold medal. A pair of American boxers, though, had to settle for bronze medals. Kenneth Gould lost a 4-1 decision to Lauraent Boudouani of France. And at 132 pounds, Andreas Zuelow of East Germany won a 5-0 decision from Romallis Ellis of Ellenwood, Ga. Basketball Kay Yow, who had been emphatic about not assuming success or celebrating early after her team beat the Soviet Union in the semifinals, could have begun relaxing anytime after the second half began against Yugoslavia. The United States women built a lead as large as 17 points in the second half on the way to a comfortable 77-70 victory over Yugoslavia and an untainted second gold medal. With no boycott this year, there was nothing less than full satisfaction for the Americans.

title: Life In The 30's
description: WE made guilt cookies the other night.

title: Now, About Ethics
description: Aides to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh say he may give a speech next week that will almost certainly be seen as a slight to his predecessor, Edwin Meese 3d.

title: Review/Dance; A Reunion of Gregory and Bujones
description: Cynthia Gregory and Fernando Bujones, two ballet stars who had not performed together since 1985, were reunited Tuesday night at the City Center in ''Together,'' a program of fine dancing that showed signs of serious thinking.

title: Metro Matters; Could 'Throw The Bums Out' Work for Koch?
description: When Luis Herrera Campins was running for president of Venezuela against the ruling party 10 years ago, his political consultant devised a two-word campaign slogan that struck a responsive chord.

title: Allegation Against Northrop
description: The chairman of the House Oversight and Investigations subcommittee said today that there was circumstantial evidence that the Northrop Corporation had paid bribes to South Korean officials in an attempt to sell its F-20 jet fighters to the Seoul Government.

title: Mitterrand Urges Sanctions Against Users of Poison Gas
description: President Francois Mitterrand told the United Nations General Assembly today that a wide range of international trade sanctions should be imposed on any nation using poison gas or other chemical weapons against its own citizens or another country.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Acoustic Parker

title: Customedix Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $156,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $29,260; a $683,959 gain on a debenture exchange offer, and a $711,000 tax credit. Year-ago results are restated for an accounting change. Prior year includes a $1,213,000 benefit reflecting change in accounting of inventory at Teneric Industries.

title: Police Lift Ban on Gun Ward Carries, a Glock
