description: A day after it was disclosed that Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward had been licensed to carry an Austrian-made handgun that is banned in New York City, the Police Department announced that it had dropped its prohibition and would allow officers and private citizens to purchase and carry the pistol.

title: INSIDE
description: Feminists and the Law Scholars are redefining legal theory to reflect women's real-life perspectives. The Law, page B9. Drugs Among the Police New York City has established a squad to look for drug-related crime at the precinct level. Page B1.

title: Danish Cigarette Import
description: The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation will apparently become the first major American tobacco company to import a brand for distribution when it test-markets a Danish cigarette in Arkansas starting on Monday. The cigarette, named Prince, is made by Scandinavian Tobacco International and is sold in 30 countries.

title: On Stage
description: A Stage Manager for 'Our Town'

title: Sound Warehouse reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
New Drug Unit Checks Police On Corruption
description: The New York City Police Department, trying to keep narcotics corruption from increasing among officers, has established a special undercover squad to look for drug-related crime at the precinct level.

title: China Sees Better Soviet Ties Ahead
description: Prospects for a summit meeting between Chinese and Soviet leaders will be strengthened by the visit by China's Foreign Minister to Moscow later this year, a Chinese official said today.

title: Former Jersey State Senator Pleads Guilty
description: A former state senator who was the subject of a worldwide manhunt pleaded guilty today in Federal Court to racketeering, four days after testimony began in his trial for pension fund fraud.

title: George C. Henny, Medical Educator, 89
description: Dr. George Christian Henny, an educator and medical physicist, died of a stroke Sept. 14 at his home in Clinton, Wash. He was 89 years old.

title: Review/Music; American Jazz Orchestra
description: The opening concert of the American Jazz Orchestra's third season illustrated the place a permanent jazz orchestra should fill in the city's cultural life. Not only did it bring out rare pieces, but it also recast - simply by playing them well and swinging hard - pieces that had at one time been big-band hits.

title: Israel Is Expelled By Boxing Group
description: Israel was expelled from the International Amateur Boxing Federation for five years today because some of its fighters participated in a South African tournament earlier this year.

title: Feminist Scholars Spurring a Rethinking of Law
description: As more women have become law school professors, they have begun to redefine legal theory to reflect what they see as the distinctive perspectives of women.

title: Crossing The Magic Line
description: THERE will barely be time for Cynthia Cooper to unpack her bags in Los Angeles before she has to leave for Italy. This is the bitter reality for the best female basketball players in the United States, where there is no place to play after college ball.

title: Restoration Echoes
description: While the restoration of Union Station has been pronounced a great visual success, its limitations as an auditorium became evident at an opening ball Wednesday night.

title: Elma Stuckey, 81; Poet Wrote About Blacks
description: Elma Stuckey, a former schoolteacher who won acclaim late in life with her poetry about black Americans from the time of slavery to the present and who published her second volume of poems last year at age 80, died of a heart attack at Washington Hospital Center on Friday. She was 81 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Howell Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Auctions
description: Lincoln Material

title: Long Hiatus Ends
description: The space shuttle Discovery, picking up the baton from the fallen Challenger, raced into orbit Thursday carrying five experienced astronauts and the nation's hopes for revival of its civilian space program.

title: Review/Art; Calling The Roll Of Latinos
description: There have been ''los tres grandes'' - Diego Rivera, David Alfaro Siqueiros, Jose Clemente Orozco - and a small handful of other artists from Latin America whose names sound, or whose paintings look, familiar to much of the art public in this country. It is the admirable goal of ''The Latin American Spirit: Art and Artists in the United States, 1920-1970'' that the list of names grow longer.

title: Alpha Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Boston Globe Is Cleared in King Libel Charge
description: A jury in State Superior Court here ruled today that The Boston Globe did not libel former Gov. Edward J. King of Massachusetts by reporting that he had tried to influence a judge.

title: Board Blocks Tower for Religious Group
description: After a heated daylong hearing attended by hundreds of people, the New York City Board of Estimate last night voted down a plan by the Jehovah's Witnesses to build a 19-story dormitory for the religious group's workers near the waterfront in Brooklyn Heights.

title: 20 Years of Nobel Peace Laureates
description: 1969 International Labor Organization, a United Nations agency involved in efforts to improve worldwide working and social conditions. 1970: Norman E. Borlaug, an American agricultural scientist and developer of high-yield grains credited with helping to alleviate world hunger. 1971: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany, a champion of East-West detente. 1972: No prize. 1973: Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger of the United States and Le Duc Tho, Foreign Minister of North Vietnam, who negotiated the Vietnam cease-fire agreement. Mr. Tho declined the prize. 1974: Eisaku Sato, a former Prime Minister of Japan and campaigner against nuclear weapons, and Sean MacBride of Ireland, United Nations commissioner for Namibia. 1975: Andrei D. Sakharov, a Soviet physicist and human rights campaigner. 1976: Mairead Corrigan and Betty Williams, founders of the Peace People organization in Northern Ireland, awarded in 1977. 1977: Amnesty International, a human rights organization. 1978: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, who negotiated the Israeli-Egyptian peace accord. 1979: Mother Teresa, a worker for the poor in Calcutta. 1980: Adolfo Perez Esquivel of Argentina, an architect, sculptor and human-rights campaigner. 1981: Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. 1982: Alva Myrdal of Sweden and Alfonso Garcia Robles of Mexico, campaigners for disarmament. 1983: Lech Walesa of Poland, leader of the Solidarity trade union federation. 1984: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu of South Africa, a leader of the anti-apartheid movement. 1985: International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, an organization jointly headed by a Soviet and an American doctor. 1986: Elie Wiesel, an American writer on the Holocaust and Nazi death camp survivor. 1987: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, author of a peace plan for Central America. 1988: United Nations peacekeeping forces. Source: Associated Press

title: Clinton Art Show
description: In an effort to correct what it considers an undeserved reputation for crime, the Clinton section of Manhattan is having an outdoor art show on Sunday, from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. The area is between Eighth Avenue and the Hudson River, from 57th to 23d Street. There will be artworks on display and for sale, food, entertainment, community service information tables and visiting politicians. The rain date is Oct. 9. Information: 245-2909.

title: Small Lead For Bush
description: A Gallup Poll made public yesterday showed Vice President Bush leading Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, although more Americans thought Mr. Dukakis had won Sunday's debate.

title: Wespercorp reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $665,000 on the settlement of litigation.

title: Gretzky Helps Kings Win, 8-6
description: Wayne Gretzky skated as a member of the Los Angeles Kings on their home ice Wednesday night for the first time in the exhibition season in an 8-6 victory over the Winnipeg Jets. Gretzky collected an assist as the Kings got goals by Bob Carpenter and Ron Duguay in the final 52 seconds for the victory.

title: Concepcion Journal; Pinochet's Graffiti Warriors Fight Against Odds
description: The graffiti here mostly say ''Si'' -a call to vote for Gen. Augusto Pinochet in the presidential plebiscite.

title: Armada Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Most Subway Riders Want More Music, Even in the Morning; Music-Lovers' Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a news conference given by Tawana Brawley incorrectly characterized an earlier account in The Times about a grand jury's investigation in the case. The earlier article was based on summaries of evidence presented to the grand jury; the grand jury has not released any conclusions.

title: Mastercard Fee Increase
description: Mastercard International, the credit card company, this week announced a rate increase affecting the banks that handle the transactions for a merchant after a consumer makes a Mastercard purchase.

title: Review/Dance; Of Slurps And Burps, Cruelty And Power
description: A king sits on stage. His back is to the audience as he faces a low-lying banquet table with 12 roast turkeys. To the sound of slurps and burps, he throws a bone to his not-so-loyal subjects who growl on all fours at a distance.

title: School Pictures Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax loss carryforward of $87,000.

title: Salomon Says U.S. Seeks $311 Million in Oil Penalties
description: Salomon Inc. said yesterday that the Department of Energy was seeking $311 million in payments for suspected oil pricing violations by its Phibro Energy subsidiary from 1978 to 1980.

title: Fonar Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits resulting from the tax benefit of net operating loss carryfowards of $1,026,000, or 5 cents a share, and $1,154,000, or 5 cents a share, for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Grand Met Hotel Sale Indicated
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the owner of the Inter-Continental Hotels Corporation, may be close to a deal to sell the luxury chain to the Seibu Saison Group of Japan for substantially more than $2 billion in cash, Japanese and American investment bankers said yesterday.

title: Nicaragua Asserts Honduras Encroached With 2 Aircraft
description: Government troops fired artillery and rockets at Honduran military aircraft that it said violated Nicaraguan airspace near the border, an official Nicaraguan newspaper reported today. Honduras denied the report.

title: Candidate Cuomo
description: Twice in the last few days, Governor Cuomo has come close indeed to announcing he'll run for a third term in 1990. But his press secretary, Gary Fryer, downplays the Governor's utterances. Back in February 1987 Mr. Cuomo said he could not run for President and govern the state from a phone booth in Iowa at the same time. Hardly any political reporters believed him, and many New Yorkers bet that he would run for President. But the Governor turned out to be true to his word.

title: Most Subway Riders Want More Music, Even in the Morning
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Faults Loopholes in Campaign-Fund Law
description: There are so many loopholes in New York City's new campaign finance law that they ''undercut the promise of reform held out to New York voters,'' a state commission has concluded.

title: OLYMPIC HIGHLIGHTS
description: TRACK AND FIELD: Two sisters-in-law, Jackie Joyner-Kersee and Florence Griffith Joyner, each won a second gold medal. Kersee became the first American woman to win the Olympic long jump. Joyner set a world record in the 200-meter sprint. BASKETBALL: The Soviet Union captured the gold medal with a 76-63 victory over Yugoslavia. The U.S. won the bronze. TENNIS: Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia won the gold medal in men's singles by beating Tim Mayotte of the United States in four sets. Articles begin on page A15.

title: Review/Film; Winning Elvis's Heart (And the Rest of Him)
description: Who's the mythic figure in the multicolored suit, the one who descends from on high to grant our wishes and make our troubles easier to bear? Is it Santa Claus? Superman? Or, as opined by the slick and sometimes amusing new comedy ''Heartbreak Hotel,'' is it Elvis Presley?

title: Review/Art; Kosuth Takes a Turn For the Psychological
description: Joseph Kosuth is becoming the eminence grise of Conceptual art while remaining its enfant terrible -still capable of confounding his audience with new twists and turns in his work. Mr. Kosuth's art has always been analytical, but in recent years he has moved away from the analysis of language and images toward the psychological, specifically Freudian, kind. For some time now, he has recycled the texts of Sigmund Freud into wall pieces and installation works that often boggle the mind and eye.

title: Panel Faults 'Inadequate' History Curriculums
description: A commission of historians and history teachers said today that the history curriculums in American schools were ''seriously inadequate'' and that more than half of today's students do not take a basic history course in high school.

title: Review/Film; 'Big Time,' a Look at the Rock Star Tom Waits
description: ''Big Time'' squanders a rare opportunity: The chance (and budget) to film Tom Waits, one of rock's most aberrant and meticulous character actors, in a theatrical concert tailored to his eccentricities.

title: Insurance Company Is Fined $100,000
description: Continental Insurance Company of New Jersey has been fined nearly $100,000 for violations of insurance laws governing rates, complaint handling and other areas of business, the state's Insurance Department announced yesterday.

title: At the Movies
description: Seltzer's Next Project

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday ANTARCTIC ADVENTURE

title: A Munich Refrain: Peals Of Music in Hitler's Hall
description: Though the cold atrium is empty, the muffled cacophony of pianos, trumpets and voices and the echo of heels clacking somewhere on a marble floor seem today to be almost a theatrical prelude to a fateful scene - like the one staged here a half-century ago.

title: Hurricane Benefit
description: The singers Melba Moore, Jocelyn Brown and Sylvester, the rap performer Doug E. Fresh and the calypso artists Swallow and Blue Boy will be among the performers taking part in a benefit concert tonight at 7:30 at New York City Technical College, Klitgard Auditorium, 300 Jay Street, in downtown Brooklyn. Proceeds from the concert, sponsored by the college and The Daily Challenge, a newspaper, will be used toward a fund to rebuild a hospital in Kingston, Jamaica, that was damaged during Hurricane Gilbert. There is a $20 donation. Information: (718) 643-5511.

title: U.S. Honda Prices Rise
description: The American Honda Motor Company said today that it had raised the prices of its 1989 car models by 1.7 percent, or $211 a vehicle, in the case of the Honda division, and by 2.6 percent, or $485 a vehicle, in the case of Acura, its luxury division. Honda prices now range from $6,385 for the Civic hatchback to $17,690 for the Prelude Si, which has four-wheel steering. Acura prices range from $11,260 for the Integra RS to $30,840 for the Legend Coupe LS.

title: Dean Foods Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Reagan Links Nuclear Arms Cuts to Testing Need
description: President Reagan has told Congress that the United States might have a greater need to carry out an extensive nuclear testing program if Moscow and Washington agree to cut their strategic arsenals.

title: Macmillan Gets Higher Bid From Maxwell
description: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, yesterday again raised its bid for Macmillan Inc., to $90.25 a share in cash, or more than $2.5 billion.

title: At The Bar
description: Not long ago a law student making the rounds of New York firms spent a day at Anderson, Russell, Kill & Olick. After meeting with several partners, some scarcely older than she, the law student appeared thoroughly perplexed. ''I don't know what to make of this place,'' she lamented. ''Everyone I spoke to seems happy. Is someone trying to pull something over on me?''

title: Hershiser a Reluctant Hero
description: For one more night, he had somehow managed to defy the dozens of situations, conditions and misfortunes that can suddenly and subtly lead to the scoring of a run in a baseball game. His night of work not yet over, Orel Hershiser's streak of consecutive scoreless innings had reached 58, the historic number that Don Drysdale, a Dodger of another generation, had established 20 years before.

title: Slower Chip Growth Seen
description: Growth in the semiconductor industry will slow in the next two years, a trade group predicted today. Total shipments by United States and foreign chip makers, which amounted to $32.5 billion in 1987, will grow 38.2 percent, to $45 billion, in 1988, followed by a 10.2 percent increase, to $49.5 billion, in 1989, the Semiconductor Industry Association predicted at its annual forecast dinner.

title: Stage Designers Are Stars at Gallery
description: ''Broadway: A Survey of Works by Scenic and Costume Designers,'' an exhibition featuring the work of more than two dozen designers in many media, is on view through Oct. 15 at Gimpel Weitzenhoffer Ltd. & Harold Reed, 724 Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street. The exhibits include set-design models by Tony Walton (''The Front Page,'' ''I'm Not Rappaport''), John Napier (''Les Miserables''), Robin Wagner (''Dreamgirls'') and David Jenkins (''The Elephant Man''). Theoni V. Aldridge, Ann Curtis, Patricia Zipprodt, Willa Kim, Peter Larkins, David Mitchell and John Lee Beatty are some of the others whose work is on display. Gallery hours are Tuesday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; admission is free.

title: G.O.P. Assembly Edge Shrinks
description: The Republican advantage in the Assembly narrowed to two today, when John Villapiano was sworn in to succeed Anthony Villane, who joined the Kean administration. Mr. Villapiano, 36 years old, won a special election Sept. 15 to represent the 11th District in Monmouth County. There are now 39 Democrats and 41 Republicans in the Assembly.

title: Prosecutors Move to Give DNA Evidence in Rape
description: LEAD: Queens prosecutors are seeking to become the first in New York State to present a trial jury with evidence intended to link a defendant with a crime through an analysis of his own DNA.

title: What's Cooking on Duane Street; A Mix of French, Thai and Italian
description: As recently as five or six years ago, TriBeCa was a gastronomic no man's land, block after block of lugubrious industrial buildings featuring an occasional threadbare bar or luncheonette. A measure of how far this blossoming residential and commercial area has come can be seen in a walk along Duane Street between Church and Greenwich Streets, where nearly a dozen restaurants have opened (although two recently closed: Tapis Rouge, a French bistro, and an American spot called Country Fare).

title: Democrat Gets Last Word on Quayle
description: Harsh words over the Presidential campaign erupted in the House of Representatives today as a Democrat accused Senator Dan Quayle of ''hypocrisy,'' repeating the word four times as he went through the motions of withdrawing the accusation.

title: Lennar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
U.S. ARMS SHIPMENT SEIZED BY PANAMA
description: Panama seized a shipment of American military equipment, both nations said today. The Pentagon said it would protest what it deemed ''a clear-cut treaty violation.''

title: Peacekeepers' Challenge in Lebanon
description: In awarding its Peace Prize to United Nations peacekeeping forces, the Nobel committee honors a brave and under-recognized multinational corps that has contributed strongly to containing violence in world trouble spots.

title: A Look At the U.N.'s Peacekeeping Forces
description: U.N. Iran-Iraq Military Observer Group Created Aug. 9, 1988 Location: Iran-Iraq war front, with headquarters in Teheran and Baghdad Mission: Observe cease-fire that took effect Aug. 20, monitor troop withdrawals, and assist in the exchange of war prisoners. Participants: About 350 observers from Argentina, Australia, Austria, Bangladesh, Canada, Denmark, Finland, Ghana, Hungary, Indonesia, India, Ireland, Italy, Kenya, Malaysia, New Zealand, Nigeria, Norway, Poland, Senegal, Sweden, Turkey, Yugoslavia and Zambia. U.N. Good Offices Mission in Afghanistan and Pakistan Created April 14, 1988 Location: Afghanistan, with headquarters in Kabul and Islamabad Mission: onitor Soviet troop withdrawal from Afghanistan, which is to be completed by Feb. 15, 1989. Participants: About 50 observers dispatched from existing peacekeeping and military observation groups. U.N. Disengagement Observer Force Created June 3, 1974 Location: Golan Heights in Syria, with headquarters in Damascus. Mission: Supervise cease-fire between Israel and Syria after the 1974 war. Participants: About 1,330 observers from Austria, Canada, Finland, Poland. U.N. Interim Force in Lebanon Created March 19, 1978 Location: Southern Lebanon, with headquarters in Naqura. Mission: Confirm Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon after the Israeli invasion, and insure peace and security. Participants: About 5,800 troops from Fiji, Finland, France, Ghana, Ireland, Italy, Nepal, Norway, Sweden, United States. U.N. Truce Supervision Organization Created June 11, 1948 Location: Beirut and Sinai, with headquarters in Jerusalem. Mission: Assist Arab-Israeli truce missions. Participants: About 295 from Argentina, Australia, Austria, Canada, Chile, Denmark, Finland, France, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Soviet Union, Sweden, United States. U.N. Military Observer Group in India and Pakistan Created Jan. 24, 1949 Location: India-Pakistan border, with headquarters in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, and Srinagar, India. Mission: upervise India-Pakistan cease-fire in Jammu-Kashmir area. Participants: About 36 observers from Australia, Chile, Denmark, Finland, Italy, New Zealand, Norway, Sweden, Uruguay, United States. U.N. Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus Created March 27, 1964 Location: yprus, with headquarters in Nicosia. Mission: Maintain buffer between Greek and Turkish regions of Cyprus. Participants: About 2,100 troops from Australia, Austria, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Finland, Ireland, Sweden. Source: Associated Press

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Sheila Cohen and Harry Baron, respectively, have been promoted to executive vice president and senior vice president at Reichenstein Advertising, Mountainside, N.J.

title: United Merchants & Manufacurers Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,806,000, a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $23,751,000, and a pre-tax gain on the sale of divisions and joint ventures of $41,771,000. c-Net loss and includes net from discontinued operations of $5,375,000 and a pre-tax gain on the sale of divisions and joint ventures of $11,012,000. Latest results are pro forma and are adjusted to reflect the sale of the company's Etienne Aigner and Valchem divisions as if they had been completed on June 30, 1988. Prior-year results are restated to reflect the disposition of the company's industrial segment as a discontinued operation and the adoption of an accounting principal.

title: Gacy Death Sentence Upheld
description: The Illinois Supreme Court today upheld the convictions and death sentence of John Wayne Gacy in the sex-related killings of 33 boys and young men. The execution was scheduled for next Jan. 11, but that is almost certain to be delayed by further appeals.

title: Once Just Chemicals, and Now Bombs
description: The discovery of an explosive cylinder of deadly hydrogen cyanide at an abandoned plant here has thrown into sharp focus a potentially serious threat, posed by deteriorating chemicals, to communities across the country.

title: Film Festival; Von Sydow as a Father In 'Pelle the Conqueror'
description: Bille August's ''Pelle the Conqueror'' is not for people who prefer to take showers. It's for the person who likes to get into a movie as if it were a long hot bath. To hurry it would be to miss its method and its point.

title: Commonwealth Mortgage Co. of America LP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
All American Television Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: NCNB Raises Funds For Rescue in Texas
description: Exceeding a pledge made last July, the NCNB Corporation said today that it had raised $250 million through the private sale of preferred stock. The bank holding company said it would commit $210 million of the total to buy 20 percent of the newly formed Texas bank, NCNB Texas.

title: Review/Opera; Wagner's 'Rheingold,' Harbinger of Met 'Ring'
description: It seems as if New York's Wagnerites have been waiting since primeval times for it to happen, and the countdown is still under way. But, yes, next month, when its new ''Gotterdammerung'' appears, the Metropolitan Opera will have the final work of the ''Ring'' ready for inspection. And in April and May of next year, Wagner's cycle finally will be presented three times intact. By now, however, the interpretative intentions of Otto Schenk, the director, and Gunther Schneider-Siemssen, the designer, have become quite clear. They hope to provide the Metropolitan with a handsomely traditional ''Ring'' that will outlive fads and fashions.

title: Graf Hits Stride, Trounces Garrison
description: The quest appeared to be taking its toll on Steffi Graf. She arrived in Seoul almost two weeks ago looking beleaguered, then was engulfed by a wave of reporters and photographers at the airport. The Grand Slam champion sounded tense in her first post-match interview and the weariness showed on the court, where Graf struggled in her early matches as she hasn't all year on the professional tour.

title: Baltimore Mayor Supports Legalization of Illicit Drugs
description: Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke of Baltimore told Congress today that legalizing the possession of illicit drugs would help, not hurt, the United States.

title: Judge Declares Mistrial in Case Against Rowan
description: A mistrial was declared today in the gun-possession case of Carl T. Rowan, the syndicated columnist and television commentator, after the jury reported that it could not reach agreement.

title: Yankees Stay Alive, Barely
description: The race in the American League East has likely come down to its final day. The Yankees, who should have lost it all twice already, are down to their last glimmer of hope.

title: Avery International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Israeli Parties Clash on Ruling Over Enclave
description: Israel accepted today's decision on the Taba border dispute with resigned sorrow, but the ruling set off bitter recriminations between political parties.

title: Soviets Roll Past Yugoslavs for the Gold
description: The Soviet Union won the men's Olympic basketball gold medal today with a 76-63 victory over Yugoslavia.

title: Ramada Is Quoted On Restructuring
description: The Pritzker family of Chicago disclosed in a Federal filing that the top official of Ramada Inc. had said the hotel chain was considering a restructuring in light of the unsolicited $10-a-share , or $368 million, unsolicited Pritzker bid. Richard Snell, Ramada's chairman, told Jay Pritzker, whose family controls the Hyatt chain of hotels, on Monday that Ramada was reviewing alternatives. Ramada confirmed that it might restructure.

title: S.&P. Shift On Seabrook
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday lowered its opinion of $1.47 billion in bonds issued by the Massachusetts Municipal Wholesale Electric Company, one of the major owners of the Seabrook nuclear power plant. S.&P.'s action came after the

title: U.S. Issues Post a Modest Gain
description: The price of Treasury securities rose modestly yesterday after dealers learned of a $1 billion note sale by Italy, which was accompanied by an interest-rate swap agreement and large-scale purchases of Treasury securities.

title: Back in Space; Soviets Unveil Shuttle As Discovery Goes Up
description: The Soviet Union released the first photographs of its secret space shuttle today.

title: Dining Out Guide: Steakhouses
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Brandywine
