title: Oh Quits as Manager
description: Japan's legendary home-run hitter, Sadaharu Oh, admitted yesterday what many ballplayers discovered before him: Great hitters do not necessarily make great managers. At a news conference in Tokyo, Oh said that he would resign as manager of the Yomiuri Giants next week after another disappointing season by the team that once dominated Japanese baseball. The front office, which used the expiration of Oh's five-year contract as a graceful moment to ease him out, appointed Motoji Fujita as manager. Oh, 48 years old, took full responsibility for the team's third-place finish in the Central League. ''I had expected this to come,'' said Oh. ''Over the past five years I have not been able to meet expectations, and I accept that. In this world of professional sports, you have to win. That's the bottom line.'' Oh's entire career was spent with the Giants, starting in 1959. During his 21-year playing career, the team won 13 pennants and 12 Japan Series titles, and Oh hit 868 home runs, exceeding the 755 by Henry Aaron and the 714 by Babe Ruth. But managing in a six-team league, his Giants were third three times, second once and won the pennant last year but lost the series to the Seibu Lions.

title: Griffith Joyner Wins 200; 2d Gold for Joyner-Kersee
description: After six days of Olympic track and field, the leaders in women's gold medals were three of the sport's great powers: the Joyner family with four, East Germany with three and the Soviet Union with two.

title: Back in Space; Bush Applauds Shuttle Liftoff
description: Vice President Bush hailed the successful launching of the space shuttle Discovery today and said that he hoped to travel to Edwards Air Force Base in California for the landing.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think I had my fingers crossed like everybody else.'' - President Reagan, after the launching of the space shuttle Discovery. [ A1:4. ]

title: Who Wins If Gorbachev Wins?
description: Mikhail Gorbachev now concedes that his economic reforms have yet to make a dent, and in an apparent bid to consolidate support he has suddenly called meetings of the Communist Party's powerful Central Committee and the Supreme Soviet. All this raises fundamental questions: Can Mr. Gorbachev survive the arduous path to economic reform? Can and should the West try to help him survive?

title: Review/Recital; A Debut for a Young Cellist
description: Daniel Gaisford, a 23-year-old cellist who grew up in Salt Lake City and completed his studies at the University of Southern California and the Juilliard School, made an impressive New York recital debut on Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. Mr. Gaisford's technical and interpretive gifts are considerable, as are those of his pianist, William Gugala Hirtz.

title: U.N. Peacekeeping Forces Named Winner of the Nobel Peace Prize
description: The United Nations peacekeeping forces, which for 40 years have been deployed to reduce tensions in the world's trouble spots, were named here today as the 1988 winner of the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: The Ethics Market
description: Whitney North Seymour Jr. served justice well as independent prosecutor in the Michael Deaver case. Having persuaded a jury that the former top White House aide committed perjury, he tried without success to persuade a Federal judge that lying to Congress and a grand jury called for some prison time. He quite properly continues to argue publicly for a stronger Ethics in Government Act and a better moral climate in Washington.

title: Taiwan Share Prices Fall
description: Panic selling sent Taiwan share prices plummeting today after the Government announced a tax on stock market profits. Investors streamed into brokerages to dump shares, pushing the weighted index down 175.96 points, to 8,613.82. Taiwan's Finance Minister, Shirley Kuo, said on Saturday that, to cool Asia's fastest-growing stock exchange, profits on sales exceeding $3 million (Taiwan), or $105,000 (United States), would be taxed starting Jan. 1. Although the shares bought this year are exempt, the news was seen as an attempt to stabilize the market, which has climbed by almost 280 percent since the start of the year. The market was saved by a rule that prices can move by just 3 percent a day.

title: Nahama & Weagant Energy Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Kurdish Refugees in Turkey May Have Fled the Lion for the Fox
description: To the Editor:

title: E.D.S. Purchases Software Concern
description: Electronic Data Systems, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, acquired a smaller company, General Data Systems of Philadelphia, that specializes in computer services for the property-and-casualty insurance industry. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Warner-Chilcott, a generic pharmaceutical division of Warner Lambert, to Daniel Glassman Advertising, Fairfield, N.J.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE, Working Group on International Convention on Migrant Workers' Rights - 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: Frederic M. Roberts, Investor, 59
description: Frederic M. Roberts, an investor, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Tuesday in New York Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Lawrence, L.I.

title: Quick & Reilly Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
Cost Accounting?
description: A puzzling question has arisen at the Pentagon on how to count personnel costs.

title: Trail Blazers Blamed
description: Coach Mike Schuler said efforts by the Portland Trail Blazers to help rehabilitate injured the Soviet basketball star, Arvidas Sabonis, had nothing to do with the Soviet Union's semifinal victory over the Americans in the Olympics. Sabonis, a Trail Blazer draft pick in 1986, had 13 points and 13 rebounds in the 82-76 victory. The 7-foot-3-inch Sabonis spent three and a half months in Portland before the Olympics working on his injured Achilles' tendon. Wednesday morning, 20 callers to the Trail Blazer office said the team bore responsibility for the American loss. ''Beyond being involved in sports medicine, even as a physician, if someone comes to you with a problem, you have to address it,'' said the team physician, Dr. Robert Cook. ''If you put politics and national pride ahead of that, well, that's sad. If we're not prepared to beat the Soviet athletes in their best health, we don't deserve to win. Withholding athletic care is no avenue to a gold medal.'' (AP)

title: Advance Circuits Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary gain of $1,737,000. The latest quarter and year results include a $10 million charge for the termination of operations at the company's west coast facilities.

title: Surprising Move
description: It is common for members of the House to reserve an hour at the close of the day for a Special Order in honor of a colleague who is retiring or marking some important change in life.

title: Campaign Trail; Dukakis Encounters Hazards of the Road
description: It began as such a perfect morning in New York for Michael S. Dukakis.

title: Canadian Wins In Sychronized
description: Carolyn Waldo of Canada scored a perfect 10, five 9.9s and a 9.8 in the final round to win the gold in solo synchronized swimming today over Tracie Ruiz-Conforto.

title: Shouts, Tears and Applause Amid a Vast Wave of Relief
description: Gathered anxiously in front of their television screens, millions of Americans watched the space shuttle Discovery thunder spectacularly into orbit yesterday morning amid applause and cheers but, most of all, amid an overwhelming sense of relief.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Yomo Toro With Cuatro

title: Review/Art; 'Andy Warhol, Cars': Last Works of the Artist
description: ''Andy Warhol, Cars,'' an exhibition that opens today at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, is an unusually seamless instance of corporate sponsorship. The 47 paintings and drawings in this show constitute a series commissioned by Daimler-Benz, the West German car manufacturer, to celebrate 100 years of automotive design using images of Daimler-Benz cars. What's more, the Guggenheim stop of this exhibition, which originated at the Kunsthalle Tubingen in West Germany, has been sponsored by Daimler-Benz.

title: Prizes in Sight for Three Mets
description: Far from running out the clock, the Mets will open their final weekend of the season tonight with three main individual prizes to be reached in three games. They will start with David Cone's attempt this evening to win his 8th straight game and achieve his 20th victory of the season against only three losses.

title: Few Johnson Tests In '88, Doctor Says
description: Dr. Robert Dugal, the chief medical officer of the International Olympic Committee, said yesterday that Ben Johnson had apparently not been tested for anabolic steroids and other performance-enhancing drugs since the beginning of the year.

title: Johnson Will Tell His Side of Story
description: Ben Johnson has resolved to make a personal statement over his Olympic debacle at a news conference as early as Monday, according to an attorney representing the athlete. The decision today came after Johnson apparently broke with two key members of his entourage who had urged him to sell the story of his Olympic debacle to a West German magazine.

title: Shelly Associates reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Microenergy Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Drug Makers Try Biotech Partners
description: In the belief that the biotechnology industry is about to become a major source of important new drugs, the big pharmaceutical companies are racing to strengthen their ties to the industry's most promising members.

title: Second Victim Dies After School Shooting Incident
description: A second victim of a gunman's shooting spree at an elementary school died today, a few hours after students and teachers returned to class for the first time since Monday.

title: Pact Is Reached On Bill to Slow Sea-Sludge Ban
description: House members from New York and New Jersey have agreed on a new compromise bill that will postpone a ban on the dumping of sludge at sea until 1993.

title: Dukakis Turns Attack on Bush To Environment
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today shifted his attack on Vice President Bush from Social Security, ethics and taxes to the environment, charging that his opponent's role has been ''hazardous to our health.''

title: Bronx Inquiry Into Tampering With Jury in Donovan's Trial
description: District Attorney Paul T. Gentile of the Bronx yesterday ordered an investigation into an allegation of jury tampering at a 1987 state trial in which former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and seven construction executives were acquitted of fraud charges.

title: Senate Votes to Extend An AIDS Drug Effort
description: The Senate today approved a six-month extension of a Federal program that provides the drug AZT to victims of AIDS who cannot afford the costly treatment.

title: Regina Suits May Focus on Stock Trades
description: The Regina Company's shares fell sharply this summer while some shareholders were selling large amounts of stock in the weeks before the company announced that its earnings projection for the current quarter was overstated.

title: Craft Festival
description: The American Arts and Crafts Alliance will hold its autumn festival tomorrow and Sunday from 10 A.M. to 6:30 P.M., on Columbus Avenue between 77th and 81st Streets. Jewelry, blown glass, gold and silver sculptures, painted silks, leather, ceramics, masks, quilts, toys and fantasy clothing will be on display. Strolling musicians will provide accompaniment. Prices range from $5 to $1,000. The fair will be repeated on Oct. 8, 9 and 10 during the same hours. Information: 866-2239.

title: Chemical Offering Backed By Credit Card Receivables
description: Chemical Bank Credit Card Trust 1988-B is offering $500 million of securities backed by credit card receivables. Chemical Bank is the underwriter for the offering.

title: 840 New Jail Cells Planned in Nassau
description: Nassau County plans to build 840 new cells at the county jail in East Meadow to relieve overcrowding, a spokesman for the County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, said yesterday.

title: Food Store Tie Blocked In California
description: A Federal district judge today blocked completion of the $2.6 billion merger of Lucky Stores Inc. and the American Stores Company, saying the deal violated antitrust laws because the deal would ''substantially lessen competition.''

title: Burma Reports 18 Looters Slain
description: Government troops fired on hundreds of looters in three separate incidents today, killing 18 people and wounding 8, the state-run Rangoon radio announced.

title: Dokes Arrested
description: Michael Dokes, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, was jailed Wednesday after he was arrested on a charge of assaulting his live-in friend during a quarrel, a Sheriff's Department spokesman in Los Angeles said. The woman, Michelle Woods, 30 years old, suffered bruises and other injuries in the incident, but refused treatment, according to Sgt. Chris Gutierrez. Woods told deputies she had six broken ribs and a possibly fractured jaw, Deputy Chris Wahla said. Dokes, 30, posted $5,000 bail after being held at a county jail facility in Lennox, about 10 miles south of Los Angeles. Dokes won the World Boxing Association heavyweight title Dec. 10, 1982, beating Mike Weaver in a first-round knockout. He lost the title Sept. 23, 1983 when Gerrie Coetzee knocked him out in the 10th round. His last fight was March 15, 1985. (AP)

title: Zenith Sues Group Special to The New York Times
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation sued Brookhurst Partners L.P., accusing the investment group of illegally manipulating the market. The suit, in Federal District Court in Chicago, said Brookhurst falsely indicated that it planned to acquire or broker the acquisition of Zenith, in Government fillings. Brookhurst, which has a 6.1 percent stake in Zenith, said last week that it would try to oust Zenith's board. The partnership said it knew of no basis for the accusation.

title: Olivetti To Divide Into 3 Units
description: Two days after reporting lower quarterly profits, Olivetti, the Italian computer giant, today announced a broad corporate reorganization to bolster its competitiveness.

title: Mecir Beats Mayotte for Gold
description: It was 64 years between gold medal points, a period that spanned the careers of Bill Tilden, Don Budge, Rod Laver and Bjorn Borg, several of the legendary names in tennis. None had the opportunity to accomplish what Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia did today, when he won the Olympic gold medal, defeating Tim Mayotte, 3-6, 6-2, 6-4, 6-2.

title: Radio Executive Chosen
description: Lewis D'Vorkin, a former front-page editor of The Wall Street Journal, will become managing editor of a new radio network that will begin Jan. 12 with business news broadcasts 24 hours a day. The network is owned by Business News Broadcasting Inc. Mr. D'Vorkin, 36 years old, resigned from The Journal in June. Joseph J. Knowles Jr., a vice president of the company, said that 12 stations in major markets had agreed to replace their current formats with the business programming.

title: Knoll Bids for All C3 Shares
description: An investment group led by Knoll Capital Management has offered to purchase all the shares that it does not own of C3 Inc. for $13 each, or $128.8 million.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Gilberto Roman of Mexico, the World Boxing Council superflyweight champion, will defend his title against a former champion, Jose Rojas of Miami, on the undercard of the Sugar Ray Leonard-Donny Lalonde W.B.C. championship fight in Las Vegas, Nev., Nov. 7. Roman won a 12-round decision from Rojas last April 8 to capture the title. . . . The Los Angeles Kings have acquired a defenseman, Doug Crossman, from the Philadelphia Flyers in exchange for another defenseman, Jay Wells. Crossman, 28, is a seven-year veteran who had 9 goals and 29 assists in 76 games last season. Wells was in the option year of his contract.

title: John L. Davenport, 82; Directed Cancer Labs
description: John L. Davenport, who directed the cancer research laboratories of Pfizer Inc. before his retirement in 1967, died of cancer Wednesday at Boca Raton (Fla.) Community Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Boca Raton. He had formerly lived in Westwood, N.J.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ex-Foote, Cone Chief To Head the Four A's
description: John O'Toole, former chairman of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., has been elected president and chief executive of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, effective Jan. 1. He succeeds Leonard S. Matthews.

title: College to Select Art-Collection Trustee
description: A new trustee for the board of the Barnes Foundation in Merion, Pa., one of the world's greatest collections of 19th- and 20th-century European art, will be appointed by Lincoln University, a small but distinguished liberal-arts college with a predominantly black student body near Oxford, Pa.

title: Team Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $283,000 tax credit. c-Net loss

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Sluman Leads Southern Open: Jeff Sluman, on a hot streak since capturing the PGA Championship six weeks ago, shot a seven-under-par 63 yesterday to take a three-shot lead over Gary Koch after the first round of the $400,000 Southern Open in Columbus, Ga. Sluman had nine birdies and two bogeys over the par-70, 6,791-yard Green Island Country Club course, including birdies on six of his first eight holes, none longer than six feet. The 31-year-old Sluman also lipped out two putts.(AP) TENNIS Wilander Advances: Mats Wilander, the top seed in the Sicilian championships, qualified for the quarterfinals of the Grand Prix tournament yesterday by downing unseeded Franco Davin of Argentina, 6-1, 7-6, in Palermo. Second-seeded Kent Carlsson of Sweden, third-seeded Guillermo Perez Roldan of Argentina and fourth-seeded Thomas Muster of Austria also gained quarterfinal berths. Fifth-seeded Jorge Arrese of Spain was upset by Horacio de La Pena of Argentina, 6-3, 6-4.(AP) SOCCER France Wins World Cup Qualifier: Jean-Pierre Papin scored on a penalty shot with five minutes remaining in Paris Wednesday night, giving France a 1-0 victory over Norway in its opening qualifying match for the 1990 World Cup. Papin smashed a right-footed shot just to the right of the Norwegian goalkeeper, Eric Thorstvedt, who deflected the ball with his hand but not enough to keep it out of the net.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Acquired Jody Davis, catcher, from the Chicago Cubs for Kevin Coffman and Kevin Blankenship, pitchers. CINCINNATI (NL) - Named Stephen Schott executive vice president. FOOTBALL GIANTS (NFC) - Placed Andy Headan, linebacker, on injured reserve. Signed Paul McFadden, kicker. HOCKEY LOS ANGELES (NHL) - Acquired Doug Crossman, defenseman, from the Philadelphia Flyers for Jay Wells, defenseman. RANGERS (NHL) - Assigned Larry Bernard, Paul Broten, Barry Chyzowski, Todd Elik, Simon Gagne, Mike Golden, Robb Graham, Mark Janssens, Paul Jerrard, Kevin Miller, Barry Nelson, Steve Nemech, Brad Stepan, Bret Walter, Simon Wheeldon, forwards; Jeff Bloemberg, Michael Boyce, Stephane Brochu, Jeff Crossman, Don Herczeg, Peter Laviolette, Jayson More, Mark Tinordi, Andre Villeneuve, defensemen; and Scott Brower, Toby O'Brien, Ron Scott, goaltenders, to Denver of the International Hockey League. Released Joe Flaherty, defenseman. COLLEGES CORNELL - Named Jack Spates wrestling coach. NEWBERRY (S.C.) - Named Dip Metress assistant basketball coach.

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Coach of Puzzling Chargers Is Putting Pieces Together
description: Let's stop trying to figure out the San Diego Chargers.

title: CUNY Trustees Seek Dismissal Of 2 Teachers
description: Less than a month into the academic year, the trustees of the City University of New York have voted to dismiss two law school faculty members, thrusting the five-year-old institution into further disarray.

title: Skipper's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 4
description: b-Net income

title: Crabs and Beer
description: Crabs and beer, with unlimited repeat servings, will be available for $20 at Our Lady of Pompeii Church Hall, Bleecker and Carmine Streets, tonight from 6 to 9 o'clock. Proceeds will go to the Village Visiting Neighbors, an organization that helps the elderly through home visits. Information: 260-6200.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bess, Bayer to Handle Account for Ameritech
description: After a 14-way race, Ameritech, Chicago, has selected Bayer, Bess, Vanderwarker, also of the Windy City, to handle its corporate advertising account. The budget is $10 million.

title: The Fall Photography Season: Sly Portraits and Radical Still Lifes
description: MORE than any other season in recent memory, this fall has begun with a rich and varied spectrum of photography shows. Those that can be seen this weekend run from surveys of individual artists' careers to a group exhibition of work reclaimed from obscurity - with a number of high-quality shows of new images added for good measure.

title: Restaurants
description: It is easier to snag trout with your bare hands than to get a table at the new Docks in midtown on short notice. You don't need to be a restaurant critic to see why. This gleaming brasserie serves just what people want: uncompromisingly fresh fish that is minimally fussed over, in a congenial atmosphere and for a reasonable price.

title: About Real Estate; Low-Cost Housing Need: Early Cash
description: The shortage of low-cost housing in New York is acute, everyone agrees, and there is a fair amount of money available from city and state agencies and from private groups to help rebuild decaying houses for the homeless and for those unable to pay market rents.

title: Bring Minimum Wage Into the World of 1988; Subsidizing Employers
description: To the Editor:

title: 27-Year Term For Fraud
description: A tax-shelter promoter, John Peter Galanis, was sentenced Wednesday to 27 years in prison for leading a multimillion-dollar fraud and racketeering operation.

title: Power Panel in Making: The Hispanic Caucus
description: The Congressional Hispanic Caucus is but a shadow of its role model and ally, the Black Caucus, but that is changing as Hispanic residents grow toward becoming the nation's largest minority.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Egypt's border dispute with Israel was resolved in Egypt's favor by an international arbitraion panel, but it is still up to the two sides to work out a final section of the boundary which has been their major unresolved issue since 1979. Page A1

title: Rypien Ready To Face Taylor
description: For three seasons, the quarterback situation for the Washington Redskins has been unsettled.

title: Coaches Alert Devils About Job Security
description: Jim Schoenfeld, the Devils' coach, is worried that last season's success may make his players think that they will have jobs this season. That judgment, he said, would be up to the coaching staff.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''THE TALES OF THE BARDS: STORIES IN MUSIC AND ART,'' a one-hour gallery program focusing on storytelling in medieval music and art,with music by the Ensemble for Early Music, 1 P.M. tomorrow, at the Cloisters, Fort Tryon Park. The program is free with museum admission; donation: $4.50 for adults; children under 12, free. Information: 923-3700. APPLE CIDERING, a demonstration of the old-fashioned way to make cider with hand-turned presses, and a display of various kinds of apples, 1 to 4 P.M. Sunday, at the Stamford (Conn.) Museum and Nature Center, 39 Scofieldtown Road. Admission: children and the elderly, $2; others, $3. Information: (203) 322-1646. ''A MAGICAL TOUR THROUGH ELFIN REALMS,'' a program about elves, trolls and leprechauns, presented by Jonathan Kruk, 2 P.M. tomorrow, at the Trailside Nature Museum, Ward Pound Ridge Reservation, Route 121 South, Cross River, N.Y. Free. Information: (914) 763-3993. FAMILY FLICKS AT THE BROOKLYN MUSEUM, featuring ''Dracula,'' with Bela Lugosi, 3 P.M. tomorrow, at the museum, 200 Eastern Parkway. Tickets: children, $1; students and the elderly, $2; others, $3. Information: (718) 638-5000. YUNG YUNG TSUAI DANCE COMPANY, a program blending East and West, presented by the Byrdcliffe Performing Art Organization, for older children and adults, 8:30 tonight, at the Emelin Theater, Library Lane, Mamaroneck, N.Y. Tickets: children and the elderly, $6; others, $10. Information: (914) 698-0098. STORY HOUR, a 45-minute program for ages 3 to 6, with refreshments, 12:30 P.M. Sunday, at Eeyore's Books for Children, 25 East 83d Street (988-3404) and 11 A.M. at 2212 Broadway, at 79th Street (362-0634). Free. ''THE WIZARD OF OZ,'' presented by the Puppetworks Theater, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays at 287 Third Avenue, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Tickets: $3.75. Information: (718) 834-1828.

title: Campaign Trail; Reading the Signs Of Quayle Campaign
description: To see how Dan Quayle performs on the campaign trail, reporters and aides can almost avoid watching the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate. Instead, they pay strict attention to his wife, Marilyn.

title: Bangladesh Thwarted On Area Flood Control
description: The Indian Government today deflected pleas from Bangladesh for an international approach to flood control in South Asia and announced instead that there would be another joint Indian-Bangladeshi study of river waters.

title: A Freedom Update
description: By the end of this year, 53 more political prisoners who have been locked up in Soviet jails or psychiatric wards may be free men. Moscow has just promised that to the United States and delivered the names.

title: Soviet Parley Called 'No Threat to Gorbachev'
description: Soviet officials said today that a meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee hastily scheduled for Friday did not signal that Mikhail S. Gorbachev was in political trouble.

title: Back in Space; Boosters Are Monitored And There Isn't a Flaw
description: Shuttle booster rockets, whose disastrous failure 32 months ago caused the explosion that destroyed the Challenger and killed its crew of seven people, apparently functioned flawlessly this morning aboard the shuttle Discovery.

title: Back in Spasce; NASA Turns to Seasoned Crew of 5 Shuttle Veterans for Crucial
description: For the flight of the Discovery, the first space shuttle mission since the Challenger disaster 32 months ago, the space agency chose a seasoned crew. Four of the crew members have backgrounds in the military as fighter or test pilots, while the fifth is a civilian scientist. For the first time in the history of the shuttle program, every member of the crew has flown on previous shuttle flights. Here are the backgrounds of the crew members: Frederick H. Hauck Mission Commander

title: Griffith Joyner Wins More Than Gold
description: Sometimes she races in the Olympics with her braided hair in a speed-skating hood, and sometimes, the hood discarded, her uncovered hair flows through the air at high speed.

title: Maxwell Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Bring Minimum Wage Into the World of 1988; Scrap It Altogether
description: To the Editor:

title: Fiscal Experts Give Dukakis More Credit Than Bush Does
description: Vice President Bush takes glee in terming ''the Massachusetts miracle,'' a slogan adopted by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis for the state's economic upturn, ''the Massachusetts mirage.'' He calls his Democratic opponent the nation's leading taxer, spender and borrower, saying that Mr. Dukakis is presiding over the erosion of his state's manufacturing base.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Diner's Journal
description: Le Laurier

title: Article 613888 -- No Title
description: The family of three brothers who were once barred from school because they had been exposed to the AIDS virus settled a civil rights suit today against the school district for more than $1.1 million.

title: Graphic Scanning Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARBITRATORS RULE IN FAVOR OF EGYPT ON SINAI ENCLAVE
description: An international arbitration panel ruled in Egypt's favor today in a dispute with Israel over a border enclave, but left it to the two sides to work out a final section of the boundary.

title: TV Weekend; New Talk Show in Competition for Celebrity Guests
description: At the rate talk shows are proliferating on television these days, the competition for guests is likely to ensure that we will all get the 15 minutes of fame that Andy Warhol once threatened. From Bob Costas being ever so friendly on late-night NBC to Bill Moyers doing intellectual pushups on late-night public television, talk formats don't show the slightest sign of shutting up. This week's new entry in the blabber sweepstakes is a syndicated show called ''Public People, Private Lives.'' The host, and one of the producers, is Sarah Purcell, described in press handouts as ''one of television's most popular personalities.'' The series is having its debut on Channel 4 Sunday afternoon at 1 o'clock.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Co., Seattle, said that Condor, the charter subsidiary of Germany's Lufthansa German Airlines, has ordered five 757-200 twin-jets and has secured options on two more 757's, for a total of $330 million.

title: What It Meant to Be Called 'Carpetbagger'
description: To the Editor:

title: Braves Obtain Davis
description: With four days left in the season, the last-place Atlanta Braves began remodeling the team for next season by acquiring the catcher Jody Davis from the Chicago Cubs yesterday in exchange for the rookie pitchers Kevin Coffman and Kevin Blankenship. ''We've been working on this deal for two months,'' General Manager Bobby Cox said. ''We are thrilled with obtaining a player with Davis's capabilities. He's had an off year, but he was bothered by a foot injury early in the season and, with coming home and at his age, he should have several good years left.'' Davis, who is 31 and would have been eligible for free agency at the end of the season, agreed to a two-year contract. He lives in Gainesville, Ga., 55 miles northeast of Atlanta. (AP)

title: Du Pont Plans New Coolant
description: The Du Pont Company said today that it would begin commercial production in 1990 at Corpus Christi, Tex., of a substitute refrigeration chemical for one of the significant chlorofluorocarbon compounds that destroy ozone.

title: Glen E. Covington, Singer, 61
description: Glen E. Covington, a singer and pianist who performed with his trio in supper clubs around the country, died on Sept. 18 after suffering a heart attack in Cleveland. He was 61 years old and lived in Indianapolis.

title: Back in Space; Networks Plan Updates on the Flight
description: ABC, CBS, NBC and the Cable News Network, will provide updates on the flight of the space shuttle Discovery throughout the day today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Cosmopolitan magazine will raise its cover price to $2.50, from $1.95, effective with the November issue.

title: Bring Minimum Wage Into the World of 1988
description: To the Editor:

title: Marriott Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding for the 9-month periods are fully diluted.

title: Dukakis Faults G.O.P. for Savings Crisis
description: Trying to bring into the Presidential campaign what many think will be a pressing economic issue next year, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today placed the blame for the savings and loan industry crisis on Vice President Bush and the Reagan Administration.

title: Cuomo Presses Inquiry Of Brawley Disclosure
description: Governor Cuomo said today that the investigation into the possible unauthorized disclosure of grand jury evidence about Tawana Brawley should be pursued vigorously and quickly.

title: Measurement Specialties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Jets' Guard Eager To Sustain 'Streak'
description: Dan Alexander said his consecutive game streak is at 167: ''Not the N.F.L. count, but the D.L.A. count: Daniel Lamarr Alexander.''

title: House Backs Rise in World Bank Funds
description: The House today voted, 303 to 90, to authorize American support for a huge increase in resources for the World Bank, ending a year of wrangling over a lender that commits nearly $20 billion a year in the developing world.

title: Acupuncture Seems to Ease Crack Addiction, Study Says
description: Acupuncture appears to be a surprisingly effective way to treat crack addicts and help them stay away from crime and out of jail, the New York City Probation Commissioner and drug-treatment experts said yesterday.

title: U.S. Boxers Go for Knockouts
description: Of the six United States boxers in the Olympic finals, two must defeat South Koreans if they are to win a gold medal. But to some, that translates to Ray Mercer and Roy Jones needing knockouts to avert a possible home-nation decision.

title: Nestor Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
Decor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Sharpton Arrested in Protests
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton and C. Vernon Mason, advisers to Tawana Brawley, and nine other demonstrators were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday evening after street protests that briefly blocked the Manhattan and Brooklyn Bridges and the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.

title: KEY RATES
Market Out of Doldrums As Dow Surges 33.78
description: Stocks snapped out of their lethargy yesterday, propelling the Dow Jones industrial average to a hefty 33.78-point gain, the biggest since a jump of 52.28 points on Sept. 2.

title: Bush Takes New Tack on the A.C.L.U.
description: Taking a new approach to his persistent criticism of Michael S. Dukakis's membership in the American Civil Liberties Union, Vice President Bush suggested today that the organization might influence the selection of Supreme Court justices if the Democratic nominee was elected President.

title: Review/Film; Anything for a Laugh
description: David Seltzer's ''Punchline'' is a tepid romantic comedy about two aspiring stand-up comics, Steven Gold (Tom Hanks), a failed medical student who can only express himself in one-liners, and Lilah Krytsick (Sally Field), an otherwise happily married New Jersey housewife who dreams of stardom on television and the nightclub circuit.

title: Avantek Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $2,605,000 and a pre-tax charge of $7,484,000. c-Net income and after a loss of $290,000 for the quarter and net of $417,000 for the 9 months both from discontinued operations.

title: Economic Scene; A Strident U.S. At I.M.F. Talks
description: THE new Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, went to the West Berlin meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank with a brief inherited from his predecessor, James A. Baker 3d, who is now running Vice President Bush's campaign. Nobody expected Mr. Brady to abandon Mr. Baker's approach to solving the world debt problem in the midst of the election campaign. But neither did anyone expect so rigid and strident a response from Mr. Brady to the proposals of others for dealing with the problem.

title: Court Rejects Bar by G.S.A. To Perot Pact
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Board of Contract Appeals of the General Services Administration did not have the authority to void a contract that the United States Postal Service awarded without bidding to the Perot Systems Corporation.

title: Senate Clears Welfare Revision
description: The Senate gave its nearly overwhelming approval today to the first major revision of the welfare system in 53 years, including the first federally mandated work program for welfare recipients.

title: Frank Caplan, 77, Toy Developer
description: Frank Caplan, an educator and a pioneer in the development of educational toys for children, died of pneumonia Wednesday at the Medical Center at Princeton. He was 77 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Sterling, a New Agency, Gets Computer Sciences
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation, El Segundo, Calif., has called on Sterling Advertising, a two-month old agency in Los Angeles, to handle its corporate image campaign. The budget is about $1 million.

title: California Savings Unit Gets $281 Million Rescue
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it had reached an agreement to merge the insolvent Butterfield Savings and Loan Association of Santa Ana, Calif., with a healthy California institution. The bank board will provide $281.1 million in assistance.

title: Lionel Hampton
description: Lionel Hampton and the Bethune Big Band will perform at the Lincoln Center Performing Arts Library from 6:30 to 9:30 P.M. today, in a benefit for the Good Shepherd Services. The associated provides help to troubled young people and their families. Hors d'oeuvres and a buffet supper are included in the $125 individual contribution or $200 corporate donation. Requested dress is ''jazzy.'' There will be dancing and an open bar. Information: 475-4245.

title: Fires Force Evacuations
description: Two brush fires in the foothills about 60 miles east of Los Angeles forced the evacuation of about 250 houses and four elementary schools today. A Forestry Department spokeswoman, Holly Kress, said the fires, which began on Wednesday, covered 6,000 acres and may have been deliberately set. She said they were being fueled by hot, dry desert winds that made it difficult to predict when firefighters would have the fires under control.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Easy Goer Faces Biggest Test in Cowdin
description: How far can Easy Goer go? That may become racing's dominant question for the next six months after the Cowdin Stakes tomorrow at Belmont.

title: No Charges in Theft of Statue
description: No charges will be filed against two American gold medal swimmers for taking a marble carving from a hotel, a South Korean Government prosecutor said today.

title: Most Subway Riders Want More Music, Even in the Morning; Just More Noise
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop/Jazz; The Rhythms And Ragas Of Ancient India
description: Alla Rakha, the tabla drummer who has helped carry Indian music around the world since his duets with Ravi Shankar in the 1960's, said he is ''very happy'' that Indian music has reached the Western audience during this century. ''But I have one gripe,'' he said. ''Everybody seems to think that Indian music is ethnic music, and it is not. It is classical music.''

title: Accord on a 24-Month Angola Pullout Reported
description: Negotiators from Angola, Cuba and South Africa agreed in principle here today on a 24-month timetable for the withdrawal of all Cuban troops from Angola, diplomats said.

title: Rootless in Americanized Taiwan
description: ''Daughter of the Nile,'' directed by the Chinese-born, Taiwanese-bred Hou Hsiao-hsien, is of primary interest as contemporary sociology interpreted as fiction by an earnest film student.

title: 3 on Plane Safe In Hudson Landing
description: A pilot and his two passengers escaped serious injury last night when their single-engine plane was forced to land in the Hudson River, the New York City police said.

title: 'Junk Bond' Fund Draws Japanese
description: An offering of a fund that invests in American ''junk bonds'' attracted $277 million in subscriptions from Japanese investors, considerably more than the $100 million that had been expected, a spokesman for Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd said today.

title: Ameron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said 1987 net income per share includes 25 cents in the third quarter and $1.44 for the 9 months from non-recurring income, primarily from land sales.

title: Bingo King Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Bridge
description: The age at which a person becomes a ''senior'' varies with the context. In bridge it is 55, and there are some tournaments designed for that group. The Seniors Regional of the Greater New York Bridge Association begins today at the Penta Hotel, at 33d Street and Seventh Avenue.

title: Cast-Iron Buildings and a Patch of Green
description: Duane Street, a five-block hyphen between Lafayette and Greenwich Streets in lower Manhattan, begins amid the jungle of municipal buildings north of City Hall and proceeds westward into the heart of TriBeCa, a neighborhood whose early-1980's avant-garde edge is giving way to gentrification. All the while, this little street - named for James Duane, New York's first mayor after the Revolution - never strays far from the amorphously defined financial district and its glitzy new adjunct, the World Financial Center of Battery Park City.

title: Back in Space; Challenger Kin at Launching
description: Relatives of two of the astronauts killed in the Challenger disaster watched from a guarded location at the Kennedy Space Center as the Discovery lifted off today, a space official said. Scott Smith, son of the Challenger pilot, Michael J. Smith, and Claude Onizuka, brother of Ellison S. Onizuka, a mission specialist, gathered with the families of the five Discovery astronauts to view the launching, said Arnold Richman, a spokesman for the space agency. Both were kept away from reporters and the space agency had no comment on their reaction.

title: Close-Up: Synchronized Swimmming
description: Underwater Choreography Synchronized swimming, which made its debut as a medal sport in 1984, is a series of choreographed maneuvers, some with aquatic names such as swordfish, heron, albatross and flamingo. Competition is in singles and duet and is comprised of compulsory figures, done without music (55 per cent of the score), and routines, with music (45 per cent). Swimmers compose their own routines, which have time limits of 3 1/2 minutes for singles and 4 for duet. Underwater speakers allow the swimmers to hear the music. Look Good but Don't Touch Swimmers used an ''egg-beater'' kick, adapted from water-polo players, to tread water, and propel themselves by sculling with their hands. They cannot touch the bottom or sides of the pool. A panel of seven judges award from 1 to 10 points, with the highest and lowest discarded. Keep an Eye on . . . SinglesTracie Ruiz-Conforto, U.S.; Carolyn Waldo, Canada, and Muriel Hermine, France. DuetMichelle Cameron and Waldo, Canada; Sarah and Karen Josephson, U.S., and Mikako Kotani and Miyako Tanaka, Japan.

title: Chrysler Agrees to Pay On Lemon-Law Resales
description: The Chrysler Motors Corporation, which repurchased 400 defective automobiles under the New York ''lemon law,'' allowed dealers to resell them without warning purchasers about the past problems, Attorney General Robert Abrams said yesterday.

title: Campaign Trail; Mining New York For Veins of Support
description: A Bush aide pointed to a map of New York State and grinned.

title: Real Estate Company to Buy Lyle Stuart
description: The Carol Management Corporation, a privately held real estate company that owns the Doral hotel chain, said yesterday that it would acquire Lyle Stuart Inc., the book publisher, for a price it said exceeded $10 million.

title: Royal Palm Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Officer Seeks to Broaden SmithKline's Drug Line
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation stumbled when it staked its fortune on a few products. Now John F. Chappell has been given the crucial task of reversing that strategy.

title: Cowboys Eye Johnson
description: At least one National Football League team would be willing to sign Ben Johnson to a contract after a tryout.

title: New Portrait of the Playwright as a Young Man
description: Young Shakespeare By Russell Fraser 247 pages. Illustrated. Columbia University Press. $29.

title: Comstock Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Prices Paid to Farmers Rise 0.7% in Month
description: The prices that farmers got for raw products in September rose seven-tenths of 1 percent from August, including the highest wheat prices in almost seven years, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Soviets Say U.N. Group Ignores Pakistani Acts
description: The Soviet Union sharply criticized the United Nations peacekeeping operation in Afghanistan today for failing to investigate what it called Pakistan's flagrant violations of the Geneva peace accords.

title: Back in Space; Spectators Follow the Shuttle With Their Hearts
description: The voice of Mission Control blared from car radios: T minus 30 seconds and counting. T minus 20 seconds.

title: Congress Aims to Complete Action on All Spending Bills
description: Lawmakers, one eye on the voting booth and the other on the budget deficit, are aiming to close out the 100th Congress by Oct. 8, performing a minor legislative miracle before they leave town.

title: Citing Drug Use, Olympic Official Proposes a Ban on Weight Lifting
description: An Olympic official said Thursday that he would recommend that weight lifting be dropped from future Olympic Games because of drug use by some athletes.

title: Barney Josephson, Owner of Cafe Society Jazz Club, Is Dead at 86
description: Barney Josephson, who brought down racial barriers as the owner of the legendary Cafe Society and who brought recognition to Billie Holiday, Teddy Wilson, Alberta Hunter and other jazz singers and musicians during nearly half a century of showmanship, died of gastrointestinal bleeding yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 86 years old.

title: Ol' Man Mainstream
description: George Herbert Walker Bush of Phillips Andover Academy and Yale University proclaimed in the first Presidential candidates' debate that he was ''in touch with the mainstream of America.'' But Michael Dukakis, he insisted, is ''out of the mainstream'' because Mr. Dukakis has confessed to being ''a card-carrying member of the A.C.L.U.''

title: J.C. Heard Dies at 71; Long a Jazz Drummer
description: James Charles (J. C.) Heard, one of jazz's most recorded and widely traveled drummers, died of a heart attack on Tuesday. He became ill at a friend's home in Southfield, Mich., and was taken to William Beaumont Hospital in Royal Oak, Mich., where he died. He was 71 years old and lived in Troy, Mich.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Brooklyn Union Gas Co. elected as a director Kenneth I. Chenault, executive vice president and general manager of the personal card division of American Express Co.

title: Our Towns; How Mt. Vernon Avoided Racism: It Voted Yes
description: Whites on Yonkers's East Side say their opposition to low-income housing is not black or white, it's green. (They're not racist; they're protecting property values.) A bit farther north, whites in the Mayfair section of Greenburgh aren't being racist either. But when the Town Council approved a homeless facility in their area, they filed petitions to secede and form their own village. They intend to keep out the homeless; they say it's a matter of property values, really.

title: SENATORS OPPOSE VISA FOR ARAFAT
description: Fifty-one senators, including the two Vice Presidential nominees, Lloyd Bentsen and Dan Quayle, today urged the Reagan Administration to deny an expected request for a visa for Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Not My Problem
description: LEAD: Several weeks ago, my wife and I were showing an out of town couple around New York. We had dinner in Chinatown. Leaving the restaurant, we came across a well-dressed, clean-cut young man lying flat on his back on the busy corner of Canal Street and the Bowery. He was unconscious. There was nothing in his appearance to suggest the drunken dropout often associated with that part of the city.

title: Haitian Vows 'Irreversible Democracy'
description: The head of the new military Government, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, said today that his goal was to establish ''an irreversible democracy'' in Haiti.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the election of the Rev. Barbara C. Harris as a bishop in the Episcopal Church misstated the position taken by Anglican leaders this summer on consecrating women as bishops. The conference proposed ways for the 27 autonomous churches of the Anglican Communion to minimize conflict over different policies on the issue, but it did not formally approve or disapprove the consecration of women.

title: Americans Top Brazil, 3-0, to Gain Final
description: One look at the faces on the United States basketball players back at the Olympic Village after their semifinal loss to the Soviet Union on Wednesday, was enough of a reminder for the American men's volleyball team, the defending gold medalists.

title: Review/Film; 'Cane Toads,' Irreverent Documentary
description: ''Cane Toads'' was shown as part of the 1988 New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 21. The film opens today at the Collective for Living Cinema, 41 White Street, and will be shown there through Oct. 6.

title: Reeds Spring Journal; An Iron Eagle Is Back, and So Is a Town's Pride
description: Joe Dan Dwyer did not take it lightly when somebody stole his eagle.

title: Corrections
description: An Executive Changes listing in Business Day yesterday about the Sherwood Group incorrectly reported the status of Fredric W. Rittereiser, the firm's chief executive. He remains chief executive, but will be leaving if negotiations for sale of a large part of Sherwood succeed. The company announced on Wednesday that it had authorized the sale of a block of stock to Arthur Kontos, a managing director of Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, another securities concern.

title: Anchors Away
description: All was well at Cape Canaveral yesterday. The shuttle, looking like a huge Taj Mahal, soared off satisfyingly into space. On television, Peter Jennings narrated for ABC, Dan Rather narrated for CBS and Tom Brokaw narrated for NBC. Tom Brokaw? Isn't he in Korea?

title: The Day the General Blinked
description: LEAD: In September 1945, the occupation of Japan was less than a month old. Gen. Douglas MacArthur had made no advance toward meeting Emperor Hirohito and there was silence from the Imperial Palace. I was an aide-interpreter for MacArthur and my immediate superior was a one star general, Bonner Fellers, his military secretary.

title: Total Assets Protection Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Film; 'Elvira,' a Friendly Witch
description: Elvira's jet-black wig shoots up in a giant beehive shape, then falls like a veil to her waist. Her eyes are so heavy with makeup it's a wonder she can blink. And her slinky black dress might make Cher jealous or Frederick of Hollywood blush. Cut up to her thighs and down to her navel, it is designed to expose Elvira's proudest comic prop, a gravity-defying bosom more believable on Jessica Rabbit than on any real-life woman. Elvira the spoofy-sexy witch (the persona of an actress named Cassandra Peterson) is not what you'd call a class act, but she is a successul one. She began by introducing old horror films on television in Los Angeles, and soon spread her trashy-comic image nationwide in syndication and on video. Like Pee-wee Herman, Elvira is a walking visual joke, a cult figure trying to break through to the mainstream. And if you had to ask about any of this, you don't want to see her movie.

title: Campaign Trail; Insurance Dispute Flares Up Once More
description: The final chapter (perhaps) in the saga of Charles Strickland.

title: 2 Added To Fed List Of Dealers
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday named another Japanese securities firm and another British one as primary dealers, a status that allows the firms to deal directly with the central bank.

title:
Market Place;
Analysts Favor Masco Strategy
description: LEAD: FEARFUL of an economic downturn, investors have been shunning companies that make big-ticket consumer items. While that may be a prudent investment strategy, analysts say it should not be applied to the Masco Corporation, which makes products for the home ranging from expensive faucets to furniture.

title: TV Weekend; Mark Russell on Politics
description: ''I worry about a man whose teeth look like Chiclets,'' Mark Russell frets, considering the 1976 Presidential candidate Jimmy Carter. ''He wants to please everybody. He's the only candidate who would order a hot pastrami sandwich on raisin bread with ketchup.''

title: Knicks Pursuing Vandeweghe Deal
description: Ever since 1980, when Kiki Vandeweghe was a senior at U.C.L.A. and a likely first-round draft choice, Dr. Ernie Vandeweghe, his father, dreamed that one day his son would follow in his footsteps and play for the Knicks.

title: THE GAMES AT A GLANCE
description: Track and Field The Games are nearing completion, but for Florence Griffth Joyner, it's all been a blur: a glorious, glamorous blur. Griffith Joyner, who sets world records with all the evident effort of someone going to the corner for milk, won her second gold medal when she took the women's 200 in a world-record time of 21.34 seconds. Indeed, Griffith Joyner, who has the world mark and the gold medal in the 100, can't even run qualifying races without lowering world bests. The world record she broke in the 200 final was the one she had set in the semifinals. In the men's decathlon, Daley Thompson of Britain, whose pole snapped in the middle of his vault, was left in midair and, for all intents and purposes, out of the race for the gold. Thompson, attempting to become the only man to earn medals in three Olympic decathlons, injured his hand and thigh in the mishap and was never the same competitor, finishing 22 points shy of the bronze medal. Christian Schenk of East Germany won the gold. Volleyball Three times, the women's team from Peru was one kill from the gold medal. Each time, though, the Soviet Union somehow came away with new life. Ultimately, it also came away with the gold medal. The Soviet Union, after having lost the first two games of the match to Peru, staved off three match points in the fifth and final game to gain the singular prize of the tournament, 10-15, 12-15, 15-13, 15-7, 17-15. In men's play, the American team needed just 70 minutes to eliminate Brazil and move into the gold-medal game against either the Soviet Union or Argentina. The United States, defending its Olympic title, won 15-3, 15-5, 15-11. Boxing Riddick Bowe took a shot to the body and, as he said, ''saw Brownsville all over again.'' As a result, he slowly began to see reason, as well. Bowe, the New York City boxer who is hoping to cash his gold medal in for a ticket out of the inner city, was knocked down in the first round of his superheavyweight semifinal fight with Aleksandr Miroshnichenko of the Soviet Union. But he survived the round, gathered his wits and started unleashing punches. Two rounds later, he was awarded a 5-0 decision. His move into the finals meant the United States would have six boxers poised for a gold medal. The others are Michael Carbajal, Ray Mercer, Kennedy McKinney, Andrew Maynard and Roy Jones. Wrestling Dan Gable, who in his day liked to mix it up in the wrestling ring, tries to keep it pretty simple when it comes to metaphors. Here then is Gable, the assistant coach of the American team, talking about John Smith and trying to pin down just the right image. Smith is, Gable said of the world champion, like air. ''And it's kind of hard to take air down,'' he said. Smith took the gold in the 136 1/2-pound class of freestyle wrestling when he shut out Stephan Sarkissian of the Soviet Unions, 4-0. Team Handball It was a small revolution in a largely minor sport. But it produced a major upset. The Korean women's team, whose young, small, but very fast squad befuddled opponents throughout the competition, surprised the powerful and heavily favored team from the Soviet Union, 21-19, to win the gold medal.

title: Back in Space; U.S. Signs Pact to Build Space Station
description: On the day the United States returned to space, it and 11 other countries signed agreements to build the next major space project, a permanently manned station to orbit the Earth by the late 1990's.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 8 about the aftermath of floods in Bangladesh misidentified the language in which ''pani'' means water. The word exists in Hindi and Urdu.

title: Foe Slowed by Weicker's 2-Party Appeal
description: At a Free South Africa conference here last weekend, a crowd of liberals applauded the arrival of the senior Senator from Connecticut, Lowell P. Weicker Jr. They nodded when the rambunctious Republican from Greenwich reminded them that he was the first, and so far the only, Senator to be arrested at an anti-apartheid demonstration.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Magazine With a Profit At Its Debut
description: HOW did Special Report, the new oversize service magazine that comes in six parts, manage to sell $80 million worth of advertising over the next two years? The magazine will make its debut Monday in the offices of 16,500 doctors.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah, which conclude the harvest festival of Succoth, alternate-side parking will be suspended in New York City on Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: At Group Foster Home, The Hunger Is for Love
description: Waking from her afternoon nap, the toddler pulled on her shoes before calling out to be lifted from her crib.

title: Charles Addams Dead at 76; Found Humor in the Macabre
description: Charles Addams, the cartoonist whose macabre humor brought a touch of ghoulishness to The New Yorker's glossy pages for five decades, died yesterday at St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center, 415 West 51st Street. Virginia Stuart, director of community relations at the hospital, said Mr. Addams died in the emergency room after being brought to the hospital by ambulance. He was 76 years old and had an apartment in midtown Manhattan and a house in Sagaponack, L.I.

title: SENATOR PRESSED ON SEXUAL CHARGE
description: The parents of Kari Tupper, a former legislative secretary who says she was sexually assaulted by Senator Brock Adams of Washington have defended their daughter, saying Mr. Adams betrayed their trust.

title: Postal Instant Press reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company sold its one-half interest in its headquarters building on April 19, 1988, resulting in a $1,663,000 gain. As an offset to the capital gain from the building sale, the company disposed of certain marketable securities at a loss of $456,000. The effect of these transactions was to increase net income for the quarter by 17 cents a share. Costs related to the proposed acquisition of the company for the quarter were about 8 cents a share.

title: Top Winnebago Ranks Are Shaken Up Again
description: John K. Hanson has a reputation for being tough on top management: he once demoted his oldest son.
